column2: BERLIN, June 29. -- The Rev. Dr. Ludwig Mueller, army chaplain, today assumed control of the German Evangelical Church Union as Chancellor Hitler's plenipotentiary.
NEWARK, N.J., June 29 (AP). -- The Newark Bears won their fourth in a row today, taking the series opener from Albany, 10 to 4.
The New York Stock Exchange has received an application for the listing of certificates of deposit for $14,861,100 of 6 per cent gold notes of the Studebaker Corporation, due Dec. 1, 1942.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 29. -- Aknusti and the Aiken Knights gained the semi-final round of the Meadow Brook Club Cup tournament today.

Professor Albert Einstein, mathematical explorer of the cosmos, was criticized here yesterday by Professor Chaim Weizmann, president of the Hebrew "University in Palestine, for declining a professional post there.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Professor Irving Fisher of Yale University told the American Association for the Advancement of Science today that the best and quickest way for the country to regain economic equilibrium was through the government's monetary reflation program.
WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The Bureau of navigation issued the following orders today, dated June 27:

After assisting at a post-operative treatment of a 7-year-old boy, Dr. Michael Mislig, former treasurer of the Russian Socialist Federation in America, fell dead of a heart attack yesterday in the Park East Hospital, 112 East Eighty-third Street.

Three beer garden and restaurant leases in Jackson Heights are reported by Frank O'Hara, Inc. The former site of the Public National Bank branch at the northwest corner of Northern Bivd and 85th St. was rented to William Barnhill and William Sheeny. The building at 81-16 Roosevelt Av. was leased by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to William Noel, realty operator, who is to open a tavern.

PARIS, June 29. -- The French Government issued today a large batch of new import quotas for the third quarter of 1933. They are all much smaller than the quotas for the second quarter, which means greatly curtailed imports.

The Commercial Solvents Corporation has entered into an agreement to acquire the industrial alcohol business of the Rossville Alcohol and Chemical Corporation, it was announced yesterday. The property to be transferred also includes the New Orleans plant, the plant of the California subsidiary and certain of the current and working assets of the Rossville company and its subsidiaries, including inventories.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 29. -- Wilmer Hines, member of the undefeated University of North Carolina team, scored the only upset in the quarter-finals of the National Intercollegate Lawn Tennis championships today when he eliminated Martyn Buxby of Texas in a bristling match, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

Murray Marks, 32 years old, alias Murray Miller and Martin Marks, of the Palace Hotel, 132 West Forty-fifth Street, was shot and killed yesterday afternoon and an elderly bystander was slightly wounded in front of the Bank of the Manhattan Company's branch at Pelham Parkway South and White Plains Road, the Bronx.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 29. An angry, confused and hotly arguing handful of delegates wound up late today the four-day convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers by adopting a "code of fair competition" for submission to the government.
PARIS, June 29 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:
Prices on the Cotton Exchange changed frequently yesterday over a range of a dollar a bale and ended at losses of 4 to 9 points.
BERLIN, June 29. -- Chancellor Hitler flew to Neudeck, President von Hindenburg's East Prussian estate, this afternoon for another eye-to-eye conference with the Field Marshal.
Jack Sharkey weighed 201 pounds and Primo Carnera tipped the beam at 260 1/2 when they entered the ring for their championship fight at the Long Island City Bowl last night.

Forty-five students of the Talmudical Academy received diplomas before an audience of 1,000 last night at the fifteenth commencement. The exercises were held in the auditorium of the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary and Yeshiva College, 186th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Jack Sharkey's first defense of the world's heavyweight championship was his last. The Boston exsailor was knocked out in the sixth round of what was to have been a fifteen-round struggle last night in the Long Island City Bowl, by Primo Carnera, Italian giant.

Fenner, Beane Ungerleider, members of the New York Stock Exchange, yesterday leased the entire thirteenth and fourteenth floors in the International Telephone, and Telegraph Building at Broad and Beaver Streets. The lease involves about 30,000 square feet of space and was arranged by the Ames Cuneham Company.

LONDON, June 29. -- All day today there has been fought what the French consider the "Verdun of the gold standard." In secret meetings five gold countries pressed Prime Minister MacDonald and Neville Chamberlain. British Chancellor of the Exchequer, to join them in a declaration to the effect that the gold standard in no event would be allowed to be wiped out.

The New York Stock Exchange announced new rules yesterday which bar speculation by customers' men, and which require that a firm's market letters must be approved by a member of the firm issuing them.

William A. Prendergast, who two weeks ago resigned three public utility posts that paid him $50,000 yearly, calls for continued private ownership of utilities, denies the existence of a "power trust" and denies that public utility regulation has broken down, in his "Public Utilities and the People," published today by Appleton-Century.

A concerted drive against the American merchant marine is under way in Europe, according to Basil Harris, vice president of the Roosevelt Steamship Company. Mr. Harris returned yesterday on the United States liner Washington after seven weeks in Europe.

Creditors of the International Match Company will have a long wait for their first dividend, according to Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey. He granted a $75,000 fee "on account," yesterday to Rosenberg, Goldmark Colin, 165 Broadway, attorneys for the receiver, The Irving Trust Company.
Many changes in Stock Exchange firms, effective today or tomorrow, were announced yesterday. Twenty-seven individuals are either retiring or are becoming partners in firms.

The Treasury Department's complete monthly report of the stock of all kinds of money in the United States as of June 1 shows the following principal changes in May. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted; gold released from earmark, is added:

Surrogate James A. Delehanty ordered the removal yesterday of Frank B. York, an attorney, as temporary administrator and executor of the estate of Mrs. Mary S. Morris, formerly Mrs. Mary S. Shepard, who died Sept. 5, 1920, and surcharged him with a total of $99,488.

ALBANY, June 29. -- Formal charges against George U. Harvey., Borough President of Queens, were filed today with Governor Lehman, asking for his removal from office. The complainant is Fritz Brieger, former Street Cleaning Superintendent of Queens.

Eugenie Hats Managed. What happens if the salt loses its savor? ALFRED E. SMITH not long ago made it his chief point against the Technocrats that their picture of a world surfeited with goods overlooked the factor of style obsolescence.

LONDON, June 29 (By Wireless) -- Senator Couzens, Republican member of the United States delegation to the World Monetary and Economic Conference, says he cannot consistently support the delegation in any new action at the conference while the financial "situation remains so uncertain.

WILLIAMSVILLE, N.Y., June 29. -- Three of the top-heavy pretournament favorites and one invader from the West today gained the semi-final round of the national intercollegiate golf championship by registering decisive victories in the thirty-six-hole quarter final round.

BOSTON, June 29 -- A warning against "cut price bootlegging" and secret rebates by sweatshops and unethical manufacturers who will seek to evade the established codes under the Industrial Recovery Act was given today to about 100 manufacturers from all parts of the country who are here in connection with the Rotary International Convention.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The Cabinet advisory board working with Secretary Ickes and Colonel Donald Sawyer, Public Works Administrator, will act Saturday upon applications submitted by more than sixty Federal agencies involving between $300,000,000 and $400,OOO,OOO.

LONDON, June 29. --The financial editor of The London Times declares that, today's fluctuations of the dollar "serve to show how completely the exchange market is dominated for the time being by speculators."

On July 9 a tax of 30 cents a bushel will be imposed on the milling of wheat. It is estimated that this will add $1.38 a barrel to the price paid by bakers for their flour and about a half a cent a loaf to the cost of bread. The purpose is to raise a fund out of which to pay bounties already promised to the farmers.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- Because of misunderstandings by dealers in malt liquor, wines and fermented fruit juices over their liability for special tax in connection with sale of their product, the Internal Revenue Bureau issued a statement today outlining the conditions.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Presaging even more sensational performances in the senior tests tomorrow night, the junior athletes sent the forty-sixth annual American track and field championships off to a flying start in the rain at Soldier Field today.

R. Hoe Co., printing press manufacturers, which went into equity receivership in April, 1932, did so as the result of fraud, Federal Judge Frank J. Coleman ruled yesterday. The ruling was made after Judge Coleman had personally examined a score of witnesses.

Charles R. Dunn, fiscal agent for the Federal Intermediate Credit Bank System, made public yesterday the consolidated statement of the twelve banks of the system as of May 31, 1933, showing total assets of $124,771,246, of which $119,327,319 are quick assets.

WASHINGTON, June 29. -- The Federal Trade Commission adopted a rule late today that under the new law issuers of securities may file tentative registration statements in such form as may be reasonably considered to comply with the act, if they have been unable to obtain copies of the official registration form.

All six favorites lost at Aqueduct yesterday. This continued the long sequence of losing choices, bringing the score this week to twenty in twenty-four races run. One choice that fell with a particularly dull thud was George H. Bostwick's Sonrisa, which receded in the betting steadily and then finished out of the money far back of the Glen Riddle Farms' Gold and Black.

All six favorites lost at Aqueduct yesterday. This continued the long sequence of losing choices, bringing the score this week to twenty in twenty-four races run. One choice that fell with a particularly dull thud was George H. Bostwick's Sonrisa, which receded in the betting steadily and then finished out of the money far back of the Glen Riddle Farms' Gold and Black.

MARION, Mass., June 29. -- Winning two of the three final races, the St. Mark's School crew today retained its Interscholastic Yacht Racing Association championship, won here a year ago, scoring 20 1/2 points.
GIBSON ISLAND, Md., June 29. -- Under the lift of a westerly breeze a number of the yachts in the 475-mile ocean race from New London, Conn., arrived today.
Mayor O'Brien announced yesterday that he would be a candidate for re-election.

The Dodgers have yet to win a game from the Cubs in the current campaign. Having lost the only three games played in Chicago, they kept their record intact at Ebbets Field yesterday when Charley Grimm's boys captured the first of a five-game series, 7 to 2.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 29. -- The two American favorites and defending singles titleholders, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and H. Ellsworth Vines Jr., moved steadily and effectively toward their major objectives today in the British tennis championships, but another stalwart of the invading contingent, Keith Gledhill, paased out of the men's tournament picture.

Prosperity was all around the ringside corners, but otherwise little in evidence in the Long Island City Bowl last night as Jack Sharkey and Primo Carnera did battle for the world's heavyweight boxing championship.

Justice Franklin Chase Hoyt, who was instrumental in bringing about the establishment of Children's Court as a separate tribunal, announced yesterday that he intended to retire to private life before Oct. 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The first highly important result of the National Industrial Recovery Act -- namely, the pledge of the cotton mill owners to abolish child labor in their industry, is one to celebrate and to felicitate. If other industries will follow suit, our President and his "brain trust" will indeed be blessed by every decent citizen of our country.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Numerous exhibits were introduced by Ferdinand Pecora, counsel for the Senate committee, which Otto H. Kahn identified as having been furnished by Kuhn, Loeb Co., at the conclusion of his examination this afternoon.

BOSTON, June 30 -- If the present London conference fails, "the economic war now being waged will become fiercer and the depression may be prolonged indefinitely," Rotary International was told today by Senator Robinson, the Democratic leader.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Sharply higher levels for grains were established today after overnight selling orders had caused an early break. The demonstration on the bull side of corn and oats was regarded as remarkable, as good rains fell over a large part of the belt.

June Retail Volume Off 5 Per Cent. Retail trade in the metropolitan area continued to decline again this week, the recession being sharper than in the previous week, according to store executives yesterday. In view of the drop in consumer buying, stores feel that June business trill fall from 4 to 5 per cent behind the volume for the corresponding month last year.

The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore reports a net income of $2,463,614 for the first five months of 1933 after taxes, charges and depreciation, equal after preferred dividends to $1.70 a share on 1,167,397 common shares, comparing with $3,057,028, or $2.21 a share, in the 1932 period.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP). -- A definite agreement to stabilize sugar prices at higher levels through a quota system was reached today by leaders of the industry.

Four justices of the Appellate Division, with Presiding Justice Finch dissenting, voted yesterday to reverse a decision of Supreme Court Justice McCook removing the members of the independent bond holders committee for seventy-eight defaulted S.W. Straus Co. properties throughout the country on which $65,000 000 of bonds were sold.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Government property estimated to be worth $150,000,000 will pass into the control of the Tennessee Valley Authority when that body takes over Muscle Shoals tomorrow. This organization, under the chairmanship of Arthur E. Morgan, will carry out the development projects voted at the special session of Congress.

LONDON, June 30. -- A First Folio of Shakespeare, one of the treasures of the late Earl of Rosebery's library, brought u14,500 [about $62,000] at the auction at Sotheby's today after a bidding duel between leading American dealers.

GIBSON ISLAND, Md., June 30. -- Continuance of the westerly wind today brought in trailers in the yacht race here from New London, Conn. Several had been becalmed so long those aboard them had forgotten time.

BOSTON, June 30 (AP). -- The Braves ran their string of consecutive victories to five today as they walloped the offerings of Red Lucas and Allyn Stout of the Reds for thirteen hits to win a series opener, 9 to 2.

Elaborate preparations covering a period of more than a year have laid the groundwork for the Italian mass flight to the United States and return. Problems of harborage, fuel and servicing had to be solved.

Motion picture versions of "Alice in Wonderland," Noel Coward's "Design for Living," G. Martinez-Sierra's "Cradle Song" and of "Lives of a Bengal Lancer" will be included among the sixty-five pictures Paramount will produce during the new 1933-34 season.
CAMPOBELLO ISLAND, N.B., June 30 -- Consideration of the stabilization problem made hardly a dent in the President's holiday today, for he is holding strictly to a course already defined.
CLEVELAND, June 30 -- The Indians staged an uprising against the Yankees in the ninth inning today and chased Mr. McCarthy and his young men out of first place.

OBERTELLO, Italy, Saturday, July 1. -- The roar of fifty powerful engines announced to the world today the departure of Air Minister Italo Balbo's air armade of twenty-five seaplanes on the first leg, to 'Amsterdam, of their great flight to Chicago.

HARRISON, N.J., June 30. -- This town was wondering tonight what the United States Government was going to do about the Harrison Beverage Company's refusal to close its brewery. The 3.2 beer permit of the brewery has been revoked by Dr. Ambrose Hunsberger, Supervisor of Permits.

LONDON, June 30. -- Again throughout the whole day the World Economic Conference marked time while discussions inside and outside of it on immediate peril to Continental currencies from speculative attacks and on means for meeting these absorbed all attention.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Representatives of the fifty-one western Class I railroads at a meeting here today elected the following as the western coordinating committee, provided in the emergency transportation act of 1933:

The controversy between the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation and the New York Stock Exchange concerning the adequacy of Allied's financial reports to its stockholders has been settled, it was announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP). -- Running over a muddy track, Charles T. Fisher's Esseff breezed to victory today in the Shadybrook Purse, the feature event at Arlington Park, by six lengths.

ORBETELLO, Italy, Saturday, July 1. -- Twenty-five powerful seaplanes roared away from Orbetello today, with General Balbo and more than 100 of his crack Fascist fliers on the first leg of a 6,100 mile cruise to Chicago.

The Presbyterian Theological Seminary of Chicago reports in a copyrighted article today that its excavations at Beth-zur, in Palestine, have produced "the prototype of the saloon," and that "the only divine image that we found, except those stamped on coins, was the head of a very crude Astarte (the Phoenician goddess of love) figurine."

DAYTON, Ohio, June 30. -- The murder of a government official and a plot to kill a member of Congress was attributed by police today to a disgruntled Spanish-American War veteran, who was cut off the pension and disability rolls of the Veterans Bureau three week ago.

The Western Union Telegraph Company agreed yesterday to restore, effective today, the 10 per cent reduction in wages that went into effect on Aug. 1, 1932. The decision was made at a meeting here of representatives of the Association of Western Union Employes and officers of the company.

More than two years ago Dr. HENRY HOWARD, then 72 years of age, wrote to the Session of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church saying that he would be happy "if they would graciously retire him in 1933." Death has stepped in to give him the release which his congregation were reluctant to grant.

HAVERFORD, Pa., June 30. -- Richard T. Murphy of Utica, representing Hamilton College, and Jack Tidball, University of California, at Los Angeles, today fought their way to the final of the national intercollegiate tennis tournament on the grass, courts of the Merion Cricket Club.

Without ceremony, the $40,000,000 Bronx Concourse line of the new city subway system was opened at 12:50 o'clock this morning. Trains had begun operating last night on the schedule that was in effect, and the opening tools little more than the removal of chains that barred the public from turnstiles.

The payment of $6,448,044 to meet the July 1 interest and sinking fund charges on the 5 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds of the Interborough was ordered yesterday by Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, sitting as a District Court judge.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The United States will not participate in any North Atlantic passenger or freight shipping pool, such as the French delegation suggested to the World Economic Conference in London, if its administration listens to government shipping experts, according to comment here today.
Plans for the immediate construction, of two new buildings to complete the international group fronting on Fifth Avenue were announced yesterday by Rockefeller Center.
CHICAGO, June 30. -- Formation of "super trade association" for the machine manufacturing industry was announced tonight.

Owing to the holiday on Tuesday and also to the fact that new State and municipal financing this week was heavy, only $4,356,645 of new municipal issues will come up for award next week. This compares with this week's revised total of $33,680,893 and with the weekly average for the year to date of $13,424,787.
II Ponderoso. Over in Italy they will now probably change the Vergilian text to read:

American shipping men were Skeptical yesterday of the proposal of the French delegation to the World Economic Conference for a world-wide pooling of merchant Shipping. The plan advanced by the French on Thursday advocated a limitation of ship construction, regulation of rates and the joint operation of ship lines competing on designated routes, the lines to operate under their own flags.

Samuel S. Koenig, Republican County leader, stole a inarch yesterday on the group seeking to oust him. In a letter to Clarence H. Fay, one of his supporters, and leader in the Tenth Assembly District, he asked Mr. Fay to renominate the present Assemblyman, Herbert H. Brownell Jr.
LONDON, Saturday, July 1 -- Under the heading "Towards a Compromise," The London Times today says:

Despite the prospects of spotty weather part of the way, five of the seven entrants in the Bendix transcontinental air derby were prepared last night to take off before daybreak today for Los Angeles.

The City of Detroit Bondholders Refunding Committee announced yesterday that, pursuant to the ratification this week by the Detroit Common Council of a contract for refunding the city's obligations, the official plan of refunding would be made public next week and a call made for the deposit of bonds.

MILWAUKEE. June 30. -- A declaration of unyielding opposition to repeal of prohibition and a militant demand for a third party which could "be trusted to work for clean government" brought 2,000 W.C. T.U. delegates to their feet cheering today at the organization's opening convention session.
Over the protest of the Charity Organization Society Mayor O'Brien filled two vacancies on the magistrates' court bench yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 604,668 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 16,737 cars, or 2.8 per cent, more than in the preceding week, 105,675 cars, or 21.2 per cent, more than in the corresponding week last year, but 154,695 cars, or 20.4 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

BUCHAREST, June 30 -- The State Secretary of the Rumanian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, M. Radulescu, returned tonight from Paris. M. Radulescu, whose visit was made in behalf of Foreign Minister Titulescu, is believed to have received from the French Foreign Minister, Joseph Paul-Boncour, assurances that France would not tolerate under any circumstances either the restoration of the Hapsburgs or the reunion of Austria and Hungary.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Otto H. Kahn, senior partner of Kuhn, Loeb Co., was again a witness before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee when it resumed it hearings today and was questioned further concerning details of the creation of the Pennroad Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The untried trail into industrial control was blazed further today by the cotton textile operators, who proposed voluntarily to establish a higher minimum wage than at first proposed, and presented simultaneously a proposal for economic planning on behalf of the entire industry.
Rear Admiral Yates Stirling took over the command of the Third Naval District from Rear Admiral William Woodward Phelps yesterday morning at ceremonies at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn.

President ROOSEVELT expressed the feelings of both Canadians and his own countrymen when, at Campobello Island, he spoke of the international boundary without a fortification or a garrison. For more than a hundred years the United States and Canada have lived side by side at peace, free of the slightest suspicion that any act of the one could be aimed at the security or sovereignty of the other.

Activity in the marketing of new securities improved considerably last month, the offerings making the largest monthly volume since July, 1932. Two of the largest issues of the year were placed on the market in the closing week, swelling the month's total well above that of a year ago.

ALBANY, June 30. -- A determination that a water company furnishing service to Uticans was entitled to a return of only 6 per cent on the value of its property used in giving service was reached by the Public Service Commission today, as new arguments for general utility rate reductions were pressed before the body.

BERLIN, June 30 -- Final provisions for Germany's partial transfer moratorium on her foreign debt, effective July 1, were announced today by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of the Reichsbank, following a conference with the Cabinet.
Featuring Joe Stripp, with five clean hits in as many times at bat, the Carey troupe yesterday staged a first-rate show for 2,500 fans at Ebbets Field and defeated the Cubs, 6 to 3.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- A revolutionary system of heating houses and buildings, totally unlike the central heating-plant system now in vogue, was described here today before the American Institute of Electrical Engineers by L.W. Schad research engineer of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Scoring in ten of the eleven events, accounting for two of the three meet records and winning five championships, the Illinois "Women's Athletic Club marched off with the team title in the women's national track and field championships at Soldier Field today.

Nineteen members of the Oxford-Cambridge track and field team arrived here yesterday aboard the Cunarder Aquitania to compete against Yale and Harvard in Harvard Stadium on July 8 and the combined Cornell-Princeton forces at Princeton on July 15.

CINCINNATI, June 30. -- The convention, of the Disabled American Veterans today rescinded its demand for the removal of General Frank T. Hinea as administrator of the Veterans' Bureau. It voted to remove from, the records a resolution passed yesterday regarding General Hines and his associates.

LONG BEACH, L.I., June 30. -- Miss Grace Surber of Jackson Heights, defending singles champion, today gained the finals in both the singles and doubles of the women's metropolitan clay court tennis championships at the Lido Country Club.
WASHINGTON,. June 30. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated June 28:

Holiday travel of record proportions was handled yesterday by railroad, steamship, bus, air and other transportation lines. Various systems reported that they were prepared to handle record travel again today.

The Railroad Credit Corporation authorized yesterday its first refunding of sums contributed to its treasury from the proceeds of the freight surcharges that took effect on Jan. 2, 1932. This was the initial step in returning to the railroads the moneys they earned from the surcharges and pooled with the corporation for loans to needy roads.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Leaving the record-breaking activities to others but helping themselves to a generous allotment of points right down the line, the New York Athletic Club stalwarts made a runaway of the team championship in the fifty-eighth annual national A.A.U. track and field title games under the floodlights and starlight at Soldier Field tonight.

Religion in Russia is experiencing a revival such as it has not had in 200 years, Archbishop Benjamin of the Russian Orthodox Church said last night at a meeting in the Labor Temple, Fourteenth Street and,Second Avenue.

SOUTHAMPTON. L.I., June 30. -- Many guests arrived today to pass the holiday at various estates. Several entertainments were given for them. Mr. and Mrs. Duncan S. Ellsworth gave a dinner at O-GoYa-Go, their place on the ocean, for Mr. and Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt of Oyster Bay and Mr. and Mrs. John Magee of Mount Kisco, who are with them for the holiday.

The four-story and basement dwelling at 57 W. 76th St. was leased by the Porovita Realty Corp. to Bessie Boltax and Harry Sherman for five years from Feb. 1, 1933, as a furnished-room house, 'at yearly rentals of $2.880 for the first year, $3.000 for the following two years and $3,120 for the last two years.

The critic of the New York Amateur Journalists Club last night, at his own request, became editorial director. His original poem, "Broadway Isn't Broadway Any More," will be read tomorrow night at the Hotel New Yorker when the annual convention of the National Amateur Press Association begins its three-day convention.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Seton Porter will give a dinner dance on Tuesday at their home in Wheatley Hills, L.I., for Mrs. Porter's debutante daughter. Miss Ann R. Foster.

The volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the largest for the month of June on record. Sales as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, totaled 125,627,124 shares, compared with 104,229,094 shares last month, and with the record of 141,668,410 shares in October, 1929.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 30. -- Robert H. Gore, who tomorrow will become Governor of Puerto Rico, succeeding James R. Beverley, arrived with his family this afternoon by plane from Florida. They went immediately to La Fortaleza, the Governor's residence, where they spent the night.

As Judge Otto A. Rosalsky was about to adjourn Part III of General Sessions for the June term yesterday, he dictated a statement for the record commending District Attorney Thomas C.T. Grain and his staff of prosecutors "for their indefatigable labor on behalf of the administration of criminal Justice in this county."
The prohibition division of the United States Attorney's office, which for the last fifteen years has been one of the strongest units of that office numerically, was virtually wiped out last night.

Retail buyers in all lines are being confronted by arbitrary price rises and changes in established discount terms, Lew Hahn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared yesterday. He called on all retailers to resist unwarranted price advances.

BERLIN, June 30. -- For the first time after a long lapse President von Hindenburg today once more raised his voice as supreme head of the Reich. It was on behalf of embattled Protestantism, which is fighting for the maintenance of dogmatic self-determination and independence from political domination, that he spoke, both as a Protestant and as Germany's chief executive.

Alice Kenny Diamond, 33 years old, widow of Jack (Legs) Diamond, was found dead last night on the living room rug of her $45-a-month apartment at 1,641 Ocean Avenue, in the East Midwood district of Brooklyn, with a bullet in her right temple.

The direct effect of the drop of the dollar in foreign exhange markets on the general price advance in this country has been very limited, according to the monthly economic review by the National City Bank. The survey states that the recovery in business since March 1 is the most impressive ever made in this country.

Edith Ward, 60 years old, known as "Major" "Ward, went on trial yesterday before Magistrate Goldstein in Yorkville Court charged with soliciting funds without a license. Miss "Ward is the "head" of the Actors Memorial Foundation, Inc., of 489 Fifth Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (AP). -- Four hits, resulting in three runs in a ninth-inning batting spree, today gave the Phillies a 5-to-4 verdict over the Pirates for their second straight victory in the series.

Late rallies in the local commodity markets allowed many of the staples traded to close with small gains on the day. In other cases, josses were reduced. In nearly all cases, trading volumes were sharply curtailed. Cash prices were irregular, with several new high levels reached.

ROME, June 30 -- Holy Year pilgrims numbering many thousands renewed their homage today to the most illustrious of their number, Pope Pius XT, as the Pontiff emerged from the Vatican and attended a brilliant high mass at the basilica of St. Paul-Outside-the-Walls.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 30. -- With the exception of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, who easily advanced to the last eight of women's singles, American entrants in the Wimbledon tennis championships had heavy going today, with Cliff Sutter eliminated and Lester Stoefen barely winning in fourth-round matches.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- A civilzation in which two gigantic "worldbrains," each composed of millions of individual brains, are engaged in a titanic life-and-death struggle for survival was pictured here to night.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 30. -- The Nassau County Cancer Committee need not worry about losing its supply of radium because its funds are tied up in the closed First National Bank of Hempstead. Mrs. George W. Loft, wife of the president of the South Shore Trust Company, offered to lend the committee $7,000 without interest until such time as the bank is reopened.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 30. -- Thomas C. Eastman of 59 East Fifty-fourth Street, IJew York, and the Piping Rock Club gave a supper dance tonight at the club for about 200 members of the Summer colonies on the north shore. Dancing was in the large living room and supper tables were arranged on the terrace overlooking the golf course.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Business in the United States is rapidly improving because confidence has returned, Grover A. Whalen, president of the Advertising Club of New York and general manager of John Wanamaker's in New York, told 1,000 advertising men at a meeting of A Century of Progress Exposition today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Roosevelt has delegated to Secretary Wallace of the Department of Agriculture all authority, except that relating to wages and conditions of employment, contained in the Industrial Recovery Act pertaining to the handling of milk, tobacco and all foods and foodstuffs.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- As the new fiscal year approached tonight the Federal Government was engaged in seemingly contradictory activities. On the one hand, to meet the order for drastic reduction in "ordinary" expenditures, preparations were being made to dismiss thousands of employes.

Indications that concerted steps were about to be taken to prevent further wild fluctuations in the foreign exchanges may have been disconcerting to the more reckless speculators in the various markets, but the news was welcomed by responsible elements of the financial community.

Although keeping a suspicious eye upon the foreign exchange market, traders and investors in Wall Street found time yesterday to weigh more carefully the latest reports touching the industrial recovery in the United States. The lively runup on the Stock Exchange in the last hour was generally ascribed to the expectation of a favorable statistical account of the railway freight business.

BERLIN, June 30 -- Pastors of the so-called Young Reformatory Movement, many of them war veterans and wearers of the Iron Cross, distributed a circular letter today urging pastors to disregard the Nazi Protestant Church commissioners' orders to fly the Nazi swastika emblem and the revived flag of monarchist Germany Sunday and conduct services of thanksgiving.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Congressional investigation of the charges that banks are dictating to Boards of Education in various parts of the country as to what shall be taught in schools and what teachers shall be paid, was suggested today as a strong possibility by leaders of the National Education Association, assembling for its annual convention which opens here tomorrow.

Plans for a temporary "steadying" of the dollar in foreign, exchange markets to save the World Economic Conference have been definitely adopted. They will be put in operation by the Federal Reserve Bank and foreign central banks in such a manner as to leave the Federal Government's domestic recovery program free from restrictions.

Today marks the opening of the bass fishing season in New York State and Connecticut, two Commonwealths which boast of a multitude of streams, lakes and ponds which long have been noted for harboring both large and small mouth black bass.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- May exports from the United States surpassed the value of those for April in the case of twenty-three of' the forty principal foreign markets, the Commerce Department announced today. The total value was $114,243,398 or about $9,000,000 larger than the preceding month.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- An improved and extended mathematical theory for the design of suspension bridges, which is expected to effect large economies in the construction of various types of these bridges was presented here this afternoon before the American Society of Civil Engineers by Dr. D.B. Steinman, New York consulting engineer.
The Public Service Commission laid the foundation yesterday for temporary emergency reductions in the rates charged by ten gas companies in the city.

CAMPOBELLO ISLAND, N.B., June 30. -- President Roosevelt will not obligate the United States at this time to any form of stabilization of the dollar, it was learned on high authority today as reports poured into his holiday home concerning attempts to bring the United States into the stabilization fold.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 30. -- Owen Madden, lately called Sing Sing's "quietest and best-behaved prisoner," returns tomorrow to the life of freedom he relinquished on July 6 last year when he surrendered as a parole violator at the prison gates.

The net result of the few transactions, reported by the Federal Reserve, of changes in gold holdings in June was a small gain for the United States. It amounted to $277,000 and followed a gain of $710,200 in May. Imports of the metal from Latin America accounted for the addition.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Profits from stock and bond issues floated through Kuhn, Loeb Co., and through pool operations in which that firm or its agencies participated, amounted to more than $20,000,000 from 1927-1931, according to evidence submitted to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today.

ALBANY, June 30. -- The Rev. Dr. James De Wolf Perry, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, was censured today by Judge Frank Cooper of the Federal District Court. In a letter to Bishop Perry'the jurist criticized the prelate's announced intention of attending the "pontifical mass" of the "Catholic" Congress in Philadelphia, which service he declared would be a violation of the "fundamental laws" of his communion.

New bond financing this week in the aggregate of $94,594,000 represented the largest amount of new flotations in about a year and a half. The last high mark was for the week ended Jan. 22, 1932, when the issue of $100,000,000 New York City 6s was offered by a city-wide banking group, together with $7,401,000 of other issues.

The Board of City Magistrates is a purely political body. The necessary qualifications were summarized to Judge SEABURY by a member: "I was "active in the party. I was active in "politics." The full board consists of fifty members. Business is rather slack at present.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- Admiral William V. Pratt, Chief of Naval Operations, was detached from duty today and tomorrow in a ceremony in his former office he will turn over command of the naval establishment to Admiral William Harrison Standley.
Several business parcels, In addition to gficnerous housing properties, were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.
ROME, June 30 -- Primo Carnera's victory over Jack Sharkey was the first piece of news communicated to Premier Mussolini when he arose today.

Mayors have come and gone, but Justice HOYT has for nearly a quarter of a century remained undisturbed in his office. It was unique when he was first appointed to it. And now his name is so closely associated with it that to speak of him is to think also of the Children's Court which he was influential in establishing and whose first justice he was.

RICHMOND, Va., June 30. -- A special session of the Legislature to consider setting a date for a State referendum on repeal was assured tonight when three Senators, whose signatures were needed for a two-thirds majority in both houses, gave assurance that they had wired the Governor petitioning for the session.

MOUNT EVEREST, June 30 (via Mount Everest Wireless Station). -- Orders have been received from the chairman of the Mount Everest committee to bring the expedition home. Only Frank Smythe, E.E. Shipton, Colin Crawford, Tom Brocklebank and myself are now fit enough to make a further attempt on the mountain if the monsoon abated, but the heavy snow on Everest is unlikely to clear before October.

VIENNA, June 30 -- While several thousand supporters of the National Socialist cause demonstrated outside the Vienna City Hall today, the Nazi Deputies were deprived of their mandates by a unanimous vote of the other parties.

An appraisal yesterday of the estate of Mrs. Electa Matildo Ziegler, widow of William Ziegler, baking powder manufacturer, fixed the value at $1,077,099 gross and $950,486 net, of which $1,004,031 was in securities. The appraisal showed that the E. Matilda Ziegler Foundation for the Blind, Inc., established by her because of the blindness of her son, Charles G. Gamble, will receive thirty parts of the estate, amounting to $240,342.

GLASGOW, Scotland, June 30. -- As an appetizer for the British open, starting Monday, Captain Walter Hagen and his Ryder Cup men today made an excursion from St. Andrews to Western Scotland and before a golfwise gallery of 4,000 Scottish fans smashed record after record on the White Craigs links.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter headed "Straw Hot Weather," which you reprinted on Saturday from The London Times, illustrates perfectly how the men's clothing industry and the retailers have been passing by a golden opportunity to help themselves and the millions of poor males who still believe that these worthies know what they are doing.

GLEN COVE, N.Y., June 30. -- While there were several hardfought matches in the opening round of the Nassau Country Club invitation turf court tennis tourney today, the erstwhile Spanish Davis Cup player, Manuel Alonso, won decisively from the world's amateur 18.1 billiard/champion, Edgar T. Appleby.

The threat of a general strike of garment workers appeared yesterday. The International Ladies Garment Workers Union announced that its members had defeated in a referendum a proposal to negotiate a collective agreement in the cloak and suit industry on the basis of piece work instead of the prevailing week-work system.

HAVANA, June 30. -- The plan of Ambassador Sunnier Welles for mediation of the conflict between the regime of President Machado and rebellious factions will enter its second stage tomorrow, when delegates of the opposing sides meet separately, with the United States envoy linking the two gatherings.

With the promotion of the heavyweight championship bout between Primo Carnera and Jack Sharkey safely out of the way, and showing a neat profit, William F. Carey officially tendered his resignation as president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation yesterday.
Curtis B. Dall, son-in-law of President Roosevelt, will become today a partner in the Stock Exchange firm of Fenner, Beane Ungerleider, the firm announced.

LONDON, June 30 -- The World Economic Conference delegates of the leading countries continued from early morning to late tonight efforts to make sure that the money situation would not get out of hand on either side of the Atlantic.

With a view to identfying customers' securities which have been segregated as fully paid, the New York Stock Exchange has suggested that brokerage firms use a new card index which will establish the ownership of such stock.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP). -- Uncle Sam sets out on a new fiscal year tomorrow with a payroll shortened by the elimination of thousands of men and women.

Representative Loring M. Black of Brooklyn formally announced yesterday that he would enter the Democratic Mayoralty primary. Mr. Black had previously said he would be a candidate only if an attempt were made to renominate Mayor O'Brien.

Representative Loring M. Black of Brooklyn formally announced yesterday that he would enter the Democratic Mayoralty primary. Mr. Black had previously said he would be a candidate only if an attempt were made to renominate Mayor O'Brien.

Wendel Case Settled. Half a dozen distant relatives in the Wendel case receive approximately $2,000,000 in settlement of their claims on an estate now appraised at $40,000,000. In the contested will the whole fortune was left for philanthropic purposes.
SHANGHAI. June 30. -- Efforts to end the revolt In Chahar Province were disrupted today by the mysterious death by shooting of General Shang Wu, Nanking's mediator.

ST. LOUIS, June 30 (AP). -- The Athletics and the Browns divided two slugging contests today, three home runs featuring the afternoon play, which resulted in a 12-to-11 victory in the opener and a 11-to-7 defeat for St. Louis in the nightcap.

Berkeley Beil's hope of adding the Eastern clay court challenge trophy to his private collection came to naught yesterday when the former intercollegiate titleholder from Texas went down in defeat at the hands of Prank Bowden in the quarter-finals of the tournament at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society, plaintiff In the foreclosure of a $1,238,727 lien on the twenty-two-story Flatiron Building, at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-second Street bought in the property on a bid of $100,000 yesterday. This was the only bid.
Indications of a cessation of the long-existing tendency by corporations to curtail payments was noted in the dividends declared in June.

Only a few days ago Professor COMPTON was predicting that very soon engineers will rule the world. Their conceptions and creations, their applications of science, their skill and accuracy will so capture the imagination of all people that they cannot fail to be employed to take charge of public affairs.

WASHINGTON, June 30. -- The Treasury at midnight tonight closed one of the most dramatic years in, its history with a deficit of about $1,775,000,000, a decrease of more than a billion dollars from 1932, when the year-end deficit was $2,880,184,000.
WASHINGTON. June 30. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 29, unless otherwise specified:

LONDON, June 30 -- The technical subcommittee of the World Economic Conference considering the gold clauses of the Pittman resolution today rejected the proposal of Finance Minister Madgearu of Rumania that the central banks in agricultural countries should adapt themselves to agrarian needs.

Under the auspices of the Metropolitan Federation of Daily Vacation Bible Schools, 280 Protestant churches will open the doors of their parish houses Wednesday to children's classes,for a month. The schools will be in session everyday except Saturday and Sunday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the ranking minority member of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, I am constrained to reply to the statement of Representative Sam D. McReynolds, chairman of the committee and now a delegate to the Economic Conference at London, in which he blamed the Republicans for the Hawley-Smoot Tariff Act.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP). -- The population of the United States has increased 2,917,954 since April 1, 1930, to a new high of 125,693,000.

BERLIN, June 30. -- The Ministry of Popular Enlightment and Propaganda announced a new film law today, the most important provision of which is the exclusion of Jews from any part in the production of German films. This prohibition also applies, to American moving picture concerns producing in Germany.

LONDON, June 30 -- Representatives of the British Dominions threw their weight solidly against linking the pound with European gold currencies in an interview with Prime Minister MacDonald and Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, this morning.

BERLIN, June 30 -- The stock market commanded special attention today because of the changes in the Cabinet by which Richard Darre and Gottfried Feder, two of the foremost exponents of the National Socialist doctrine, were put in leading government positions.

An Increase in liquidity and a gain in assets are shown for the first half of the year by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, the first major institution to give a full statement of condition since the effects of the banking crisis in March have had time to wear off somewhat.

With Mr. Khayyam, best of the 3-year-olds, scheduled to start in the Shevhn. and with the $2.500 added Great American Stakes for 2-year-olds as the feature, the Queens County Jockey Club offers at Aqueduct today one of its most interesting programs.

WHITE PLAINS, N.T., June 30. -- The two-year reign, of the Old Country Club combination of Mrs. Joseph A. Millang and Miss Dorothy Millang in the mother and daughter tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association came to an end today.

DETROIT, June 30 (AP). -- In a game replete with sensational fielding, particularly by Schulte, Goslin, Rogell, White and Stone, the Senators evened the series with the Tigers today by winning, 2 to 1.

LONDON, June 30 -- Although several subcommittees met listlessly and discussed such now remote and academic questions as tariff reduction and the abolition of subsidies, there was an air of unreality about the economic conference today.

Increased employment in lines allied to the beer industry was computed yesterday by the research division of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board. In some instances the numbers employed had risen as 600 per cent.

LONDON, June 30 -- Representatives of the British Dominions threw their weight solidly against linking the pound with European gold currencies in an interview with Prime Minister MacDonald and Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, this morning.

BERLIN, June 30 -- The stock market commanded special attention today because of the changes in the Cabinet by which Richard Darre and Gottfried Feder, two of the foremost exponents of the National Socialist doctrine, were put in leading government positions.

An Increase in liquidity and a gain in assets are shown for the first half of the year by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, the first major institution to give a full statement of condition since the effects of the banking crisis in March have had time to wear off somewhat.

With Mr. Khayyam, best of the 3-year-olds, scheduled to start in the Shevhn. and with the $2.500 added Great American Stakes for 2-year-olds as the feature, the Queens County Jockey Club offers at Aqueduct today one of its most interesting programs.

CHICAGO. July 1. -- With a message of "cordial greetings and best wishes" from President Roosevelt and a declaration that "the calamity that has overtaken the 600.000 Jews In Germany has cast a shadow over everything else in Jewish life," the Zionist Organization of America opened its convention here today.

MOSCOW, June 30. -- "Fifteen years of Soviet Art" is the pretentious title of an exhibition of about 2,500 paintings, which was opened in the Historical Museum at Moscow this week. It is the first real big exhibition of painting in Russia since the revolution.

The Pendleton Canoe Club of New York City will defend its metropolitan canoeing title and the Sir Thomas Lipton Cup, which it has held for the past five years, on the Seventy-second Street Lake in Central Park on Tuesday. The entire Atlantic Division of the American Canoe Association will participate and more than one hundred paddlers will compete in the sixteen events listed.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Attorney General Cummings is considering recommending legislation, to Congress next Winter to arm the Federal government with weapons for the fight on racketeers that he has inaugurated.

MR. GWYNN has written the romance of an irreconcilable. We see the impossible man who proved to be inevitable -- the man denounced and derided who survived to dictate. This political porcupine, bristling all over with points of controversy, had been the despair of friend and foe.

WHEN curfew tolls the knell of parting day and the purple shadows of Summer twilight creep through the side streets of Broadway's theatrical sector, the stage doors of all those theatres which stand dark and empty through the hot months are thrown open, elderly men in shirt-sleeves place chairs outside on the pavement and then come forth, with their pipes and their evening papers, to take up a vigil through the night.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 1. -- There were many dinner parties here tonight as a prelude to the Independence Day festivities. The principal one was given by Mr. and Mrs. George D. Widener, who have a house party at Miramar, the home of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Hamilton Rice for the holidays.
BRUSSELS, June 22. -- The trial of forty nudists, accused of "exposing" themselves, was terminated in Brussels today, and judgment is to be pronounced in July.
PITTSBURGH, July 1. -- Pay increases affecting more than 35,000 workers and ranging as high as 10 per cent were announced by six leading industrial concerns in the Pittsburgh area today.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Frank B. Noyes will spend the week of his seventieth birthday at his Maine estate, Ingleside, at Winter Harbor on Mount Desert Island. He and Mrs. Noyes have spent the larger part of every Summer there for the last ten years.

FOR the solace and encouragement of all who suffer from the depression -- which, of course, means everybody -- comes this little book with its careful study of similar financial phenomena in the past and hopeful comparison of the courses run by them with that taken by our own particular economic collapse.

ALBANY, July 1. -- The State's new fiscal year opened today with prospects much brighter than a year ago. Instead of a deficit there is likely to be a surplus next July of about $9,000,000. Largely responsible for the upturn in revenues is the stock market, whose rising tendencies have aided the State's income.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- President Roosevelt will meet his entire Cabinet Monday on the cruiser Indianapolis off Annapolis, the White House announced today. No indication of the nature of the meeting was given, but it was generally assumed that currency stabilization, the prime topic of international concern at present, would be discussed.

Operation of the Bronx Concourse line of the new city subway system proceeded smoothly and on schedule yesterday, according to officials of the Board of Transportation. Although no figures were made public regarding passenger volume and revenue, it is understood that they were regarded as satisfactory, in view of the normally light Saturday travel on subway and elevated lines throughout the city.
LONDON, July 1. -- W.L. Stephenson's likely America's Cup challenger, Velsheda, today gained her fifth victory in the Royal Clyde Yacht Club regatta fortnight.

Shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange showed a theoretical increase in market value of approximately $3,000,000,000 in June. It was the fourth consecutive monthly upturn and made the rise in the computed value of listed stocks approximately $15,700,000,000 since March 1.

MOSCOW, July 1. -- The Soviet-British trade conflict ended today with the release of the two British prisoners, William MacDonald and Leslie C. Thornton. It might be called a victory for Britain, but it is asserted here that the British embargo was lifted twelve hours before the prisoners were released, and that it is therefore a victory for the Soviet Union.

FROM time immemorial those who have known the Mississippi River best have thought of it as a personality -- a male personality. To the Indians it was the Father of Waters. To the Negroes it has always been Old Man Mississippi.

With the general exodus from the city to country and seashore resorts for the prolonged "Fourth of July week-end," which began officially yesterday, several of the noted beach clubs patronized by members of society have received hundreds of reservations for special entertainments and sporting events that were planned long in advance.

Rockefeller Center was the loser yesterday in the first construction by a higher court of the terms of the lien-law amendment passed in 1929 permitting builders' liens to be removed from a property by the filing of a bond to cover them. The Appellate Division, by a vote of three to two, ruled that the law does not affect liens filed before a bond is given.

CHICAGO, June 30. -- Thousands of teachers from all parts of the country, here for the annual convention of the National Education Association, may glimpse during the next few days two novel school classes in action. Their members are fifty-four boys and girls who have won the coveted privilege of giving up their Summer vacations and going back to school.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 1. -- The "conscience of the court is shocked," Supreme Court Justice Joseph Morschauser declared today in reluctantly confirming a referee's report in a mortgage foreclosure proceeding. Under his decision, the holder of the mortgage, who bought in the property at a forced sale for $300, may now obtain a deficiency judgment for the remainder of the amount of the mortgage, which totaled $5,200.

CHICAGO, June 29. -- Excess of zeal last Fall in the cutting of tax levies has precipitated a situation in Indiana that occasions grave anxiety to many public officials and to those private citizens familiar with the facts. The insistent clamor for economy and reduction of the tax burden has resulted in many instances in inadequate provision for costs of government which already were closely trimmed.

The heavy buying which marked the first week of the Fall furniture opening in Chicago last week will not affect either the attendance or the orders placed at the local wholesale trade opening scheduled for two weeks beginning July 17, manufacturers and store representatives agreed yesterday.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 30. -- In its latest report the Central Bank points to a marked improvement in Chilean conditions attributable both to external and domestic causes, despite the fact that the depression continues.

PARIS, Sunday, July 2. -- President Roosevelt's rejection of the proposed international declaration on currency stabilization evokes expressions of disappointment and renewed demands for adjournment of the London Economic Conference in the Sunday morning newspapers here.

FOR a nation hoping that recovery has at last begun in earnest, there remains the problem of debts contracted on a vanished scale of prices. Values of every kind of property, whether common stocks or city real estate, farm land or surplus cotton, are far below their pre-depression levels, despite the gains of recent months.

The police in Brooklyn inclined to the belief yesterday that Mrs. Alice Schiffer Diamond, widow of the late Jack (Legs) Diamond, had committed suicide. They have been unable, however, to explain satisfactorily the disappearance of the pistol with which she was shot.
The Wheatley Stable's Slapdash yesterday captured the featured Great American Stakes at Aqueduct before a cheering crowd of 10,000 persons.

A "vast toll" of sea-birds' eggs annually is being taken by the natives of Northern South America for commercial purposes, according to a report from the National Association of Audubon Societies, which states:
MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 1. -- Next Tuesday, nearly 154 years after George Washington made Morristown virtually the military capital of the Colonies, the nation will dedicate a new national park here.

The proposal, as indicated by a bill before the New Jersey Legislature, to abolish the New Jersey Real Estate Commission is strongly opposed by the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards. That organization comprises fortyfive local realty bodies in different parts of the State, and President John J. Berry of Newark reports that the sentiment is unanimous against abolishing the commission.
LONDON, June 23. -- The conference in London is moribund. The best proof of this is in the fact that on all sides responsible people are asking the question: What after?

DESPITE her story's title, Jenny is not a bad girl but a perfectly virtuous one, the unwarranted assumption that she is a fast character arising from the slander of bigoted old meanies and their interpretation of circumstances that seem to reflect Jenny in a shady light.

CAMPOBELLO ISLAND. N.B., July 1. -- His carefree, informal vacation virtually over, President Roosevelt sailed homeward today aboard the new cruiser Indianapolis as she began a speed-test run down the Atlantic Coast.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1. -- The Wimbledon tennis championship today moved into the quarterfinal stage of men's and women's singles. Ellsworth Vines Jr. and Mrs. Helen Wills Moody -- both defending their titles -- remain among the survivors.
PARIS, July 1. -- Rex Ingram, American film producer, announced in an interview today his intention of abandoning the motion picture field and of embracing the Mohammedan faith.

There was none of the pre-holiday atmosphere in the markets yesterday. Although brokers said there was considerable profit-taking on the Stock Exchange, the general list bad an almost vertical advance with the result that all groups of j averages went to new high ground for the year and movement.

Reflecting accurately for the first time the extent to which they have participated in the rise in values of securities, four investment trusts whose shares are listed on the New York Stock Exchange made statements yesterday of condition as of June 30.

Following widespread criticism of the code of ethics published during the week by the National Retail Dry Goods Association, retail interests declared here yesterday that the program was only tentative, that it provided a basis for future compromise and that the work of welding together the hundreds of thousands of retail stores throughout the country was a tremendous job which could not be accomplished overnight.

BUDAPEST, June 30. -- After months of labor Central European politics has again given birth to a mouse. It is now apparent that of all the weighty schemes considered, urged and opposed in the last two months by the various powers for a solution of the Austrian problem nothing more important will be forthcoming than the unimportant German-Hungarian commercial agreement.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 1. -- Three champions retained their titles as the metropolitan senior and national junior swimming meet got under way in Zach's Bay today under the direction of the Women's Swimming Association of New York.

Ship design and construction have been brought to the level of art and science by the demands of international trade for speed and safety, according to J. Howland Gardner, president of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers.

It may have taken the Giants quite a long time to gain their first victory of the year over the Cardinals. But when they finally did get around to it none could say they failed to make a thorough job of it.

THE July list of Little, Brown Co. includes "Heavy Weather," by P.G. Wodehouse; "Five Days," by Eric Hatch; "The Lord of Life." by Neil Bell; "Jeremiah and the Princess," by E. Phillips Oppenheim, and "Richard of Bordeaux," by Gordon Daviot.

To the Music Editor: Through the controversy begun by Mr. Downes after Mr. Kerr's contention for contemporary composers in Trend, immediate cause was given for organization of the Composers Protective Society, and we of this country were again led to believe that there might yet be a great music of the United States.

THE broadcasters swing into July with the New York-Philharmonic, the Goldman Band and the Century of Progress using considerable time, watts and wave lengths. The month begins with more music on the ethereal calendar, less politics and economic discussions.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 1. -- With a dinner dance this evening and a reception for 300 persons this afternoon, the Maidstone Club's formal opening was the first of several Important affairs to be held this week-end. The reception was given in honor of new members and followed a beach luncheon.

ASBURY PARK -- Golf tournaments at the Rumson Country Club and the Monmouth County Country Club, long the centres of golf and polo activities, lead the list of July Fourth coast activities on the Northern New Jersey shore. The first round for the golf championship of the Rumson Country Club at Rumson will be played this morning and the second round in the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- A need for more stringent laws covering sales of securities has been shown by the investigation into the affairs of J.P. Morgan Co. and Kuhn, Loeb Co., according to Senator Fletcher, chairman of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

WILLIAMSVILLE, N.Y., July 1. -- A 20-year-old University of Oklahoma sophomore, Walter Emery, who came out of the West to play in the tournament for the first time, today won the national intercollegiate golf championship.
WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The government wound up its 1933 fiscal year today with a deficit of $1,786,000,000 as compared with $2,880,000,000 for the fiscal year 1932.

IT is the commendable custom of the Carnegie Institution of Washington to supply the press of the country with popularly written accounts of the scientific work carried out by its large staff and thus to spread abroad information on the results of recent research.

Dr. Elmer Ellsworth Brown, retired as chancellor of New York University yesterday after twenty-two years of service as its head. He had devoted fifty-four of his seventy-two years to education as teacher, author, scholar and administrator.

LONDON, June 30. -- The Industrial Recovery Act and related price-raising measures in the United States are playing a vital role in the economic conference. The two broad aims of the conference are monetary stabilization and the reduction of the multifarious trade barriers.

With the advance sale assuring a crowd of at least 55,000, and more if the overflow gathering is permitted on the playing field, Chicago promises to provide a genuine world's series touch to the all-star interleague game which will be staged in the Windy City on Thursday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Pirates and the Phillies played eighteen innings to a standstill today, dividing a double header. The Phils captured the opener, 13-8, and then dropped the nightcap, 4 to 3.

HOLLYWOOD. THE extent to which Hollywood imaginations can be stretched was tested this week, when, on one of the hottest days of the Summer. Will Rogers and his "Life's Worth While" company donned overcoats, ear muffs and overshoes for an interlude in snow-mantled New England.

WESTPORT - ON - LAKK - CHAMFLAIN, N.Y. -- While the Adirondacks colonies are looking forward to the Fourth, they are looking even more intently to the 14th, when the third annual seaplane cruise will bring fifteen seaplanes and amphibians for the first visit of cruise to this centre.
SEASIDE PARK, N.J., July 1. -- The sailing season opened on Barnegat Bay today with eighty-five yachts competing in eight races under the auspices of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association.

The Standard Oil Company of Indiana advanced yesterday service station and tank wagon prices of its premium and regular grades of gasoline 1/2 cent a gallon, it was reported from Chicago. No change was made in the price of its third-grade gasoline.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 1. -- In a quartering breeze on Long Island Sound today Horace Havemeyer's Mouette defeated the other twelve-meter sloops handily. After reaching practically all the way around a 15 1/2-mile triangle, she came in 1 minute 28 seconds ahead of Van S. Merle-Smith's Cantitoe, and 2 minutes 49 seconds before the Iris, sailed by Drake H. Sparkman.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 1. -- Making his debut in the tourney, Sidney Wood, fourth ranking player of the country, met stern opposition before he gained the quarter-final round in the nineteenth annual Nassau Country Club invitation tennis tournament today.

DODGE CITY, Kan., June 28. -- Deflation program legislation based on the sharpest economies consistent with emergency efficiency has failed to meet the inflation plan of the Federal Government and three Southwestern States, Colorado, Kansas and New Mexico, contemplate special legislative assemblies.

In continuing its study of the alloys of iron, which was begun in 1929 by a committee of which Professor George B. Waterhouse of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is the head, the Engineering Foundation has assembled what is probably the largest collection of classified data on the whole field of alloy steels and cast irons in existence, according to a report made public yesterday at the headquarters of the organization, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 28. -- An advance copy of the inaugural speech of Governor-designate Gore, who will become the eleventh Governor of Puerto Rico since the establishment of civil government in 1900, says the hour has come for recasting the island's governmental and political life.

IN Summer the vast structure of steel and masonry which is called New York absorbs heat during the day and gives it off during the cooler hours of the night. Thousands of chimneys pour hot gases into the atmosphere, and through gratings the superheated air of the subways pours out into the streets.
THE first half of 1933 crowded much into the microphones at home and abroad. Seldom if ever have six months been so vibrant with important events and historic words spoken by distinguished voices.

TORONTO, July 1. -- The twenty-first annual meeting of the McIntyre-Porcupine Mines, Ltd., was held this week and J.P. Bickell, president, who has been associated with the company since its inception, spoke of the early difficulties and the uniformly satisfactory achievements of the mine since.

RYE, N.Y., July 1. -- Richard Hebard of Hill School became the first Eastern interscholastic tennis champion today when he defeated Richard Clements of Choate in straight sets at the Manursing Island Club. The scores were 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1.

ONCE upon a time Sir William Herschel, perhaps the greatest astronomer of the day when the eye and not the photographic plate did the work of observing, turned his telescope on the Milky Way and saw nothing but blackness in the very midst of a region thickly powdered with stars.

OTTAWA, Ont., June 28. -- Canadian newspapers today offer ample foundation for the confidence in the immediate future which is spreading from one end of the Dominion to the other. Canadians never have been pessimistic concerning the eventual outcome of the depression, but for the past two years they have not been putting a date to their confidence.

LIVERPOOL, July 1 (Canadian Press) -- The touring "West Indians scored 305 runs in the first innings of their cricket match against Lancashire today and Lancashire had seven for loss of no wickets when play closed for the day.

CAIRO, June 30. -- All Moslems in Egypt incited by the entire Arabic press here, are now engaged in a bitter anti-missionary campaign. The trouble arose over a reported attempt to convert a Moslem girl to Christianity.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- Converting the national relay championships into even more of a runaway than it made of the senior games last night, the New York Athletic Club swept four of the five events today, placed second in the fifth, and easily annexed the relay crown with 26 points.

Thousands of car owners seeking the half-rate automobile plates issued for the second semester of each year thronged the main office of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles, 80 Centre Street, yesterday. It was estimated that more than 7,000 pairs of tags were issued during the day.

Another sharp rise has taken place in THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity and the number has advanced to 93.8 for the week ended June 24 from 91.4 in the previous week. For the corresponding week last year the index was 65.0.

HAVANA, July 1. -- The political peace negotiations got off to a flying start this morning when Ambassador Sumner Welles of the United States read a special message of good-will from President Roosevelt to the delegates appointed to represent the Cuban Government and the opposition factions.

When the President gets back to Washington this week he will find practically every activity of the American people -- except sports -- centralized at the capital. Congress adjourned shortly before he departed to take the helm of Amberjack II, and the Supreme Court had already recessed for the Summer. In sole command, as never before, is the Executive branch of the tripartite Federal Government, and as that it has already begun to function.

BERLIN, July 1.-The Boerse was closed today and will continue to close every Saturday during July and August. Only the Frankfort and Munich Boerses did business today. Prices there fluctuated within narrow margins. Bonds continued weak.

The 210 varieties of birds in Yellowstone National Park will have an interpreter this year. Visitors to the museum at Fishing Bridge and at campfire gatherings there will hear Charles Bowman Hutchins, nationally known bird-man," discuss, illustrate and imitate the birds of Yellowstone, says a bulletin from the National Park Service.
All lines of transportation were taxed yesterday to handle travel of record proportions occasioned by the annual fourth of July exodus and other factors.

AT soon as Prime the Magnificent had been installed with pomp and ceremony on the heavy-weight throne, he sent forth royal greetings to his people. The words of great men should be treasured and Primo is now a great man. His royal proclamation started:

Although the field In the medal play tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association, which starts on Wednesday at the Sands Point Club, is small, it contains the strongest players in the district.

PARIS, June 17. As the season approaches its social climax, there is nearly always a drop in the artistic interest of its theatrical productions. Dancing would, however, appear to be an exception, for the ballet is still a fashionable fad, and it naturally breaks out at the most fashionable moments, when there is a fair chance of covering its heavy costs of production.

Seneca Lake, at Geneva, N.Y., will be the scene of intense activity during next week-end, when about a hundred outboard drivers will compete for the New York State championship on Saturday and Sunday.

With more sections of the country falling into line, particularly the Pacific Coast, the recovery of business in the United States since the banking holiday has assumed sweeping proportions. The nation is entering the second half of the year with a comfortable lead over last year and with confidence in the future.

JOHN GHESEL was an amusing old quack who lived in the seventeenth century. We do not really know whether he was old, or even if he was amusing, but in the absence of evidence to the contrary it seems reasonably safe to assume these attributes.

The college professor, notably in Washington and at the economic conference, is taking a greater share in public and political life. In the following article Dr. William Lyon Phelps of Yale, who recently retired after forty-two years of college teaching, contrasts the professor he knew in his youth with the professor of today.

DOES history repeat itself? There are times when it appears to. At least in fashion there is one chapter that comes up with persistent regularity and yet seems to be perennially new. It records that black has taken its place in midsummer's multicolored glory.

Frank B. Noyes, president of The Associated Press and president of the Evening Star Newspaper Company, publisher of The Washington Star, will celebrate his seventieth birthday next Friday at his Summer home at Winter Harbor, Maine.

Conservation of game is a subject discussed from one corner of the United States to another. The work of saving and restoring game is a matter which has taken on a national aspect in recent years, and numerous programs have been designed to restore wild life in almost all forms.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As was doubtless the case with other students of Bible history, I was interested in the recent article in THE TIMES summarizing the researches of Professor Otto Eissfeldt of the University of Halle-Wittenberg on the identification of the locality where Pharaoh's army was drowned while pursuing the Israelites out of Egypt.

The financial community in general and banking circles in particular hailed with considerable satisfaction yesterday the overnight disclosure that the Federal Reserve and European central banks would undertake temporary "steadying" of the dollar in the foreign exchange markets without reference to an arbitrary stabilization or pegging.
WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Anticipating approval by President Roosevelt of their fair competition code, cotton textile manufacturers began laying plans today for putting it into operation on July 17.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- A 90-to-1 shot in the wagering, owned by Mrs Dodge Sloan of New York, galloped to a surprising victory in the $16,000 Hyde Park Stakes before a stunned crowd of 20,000 at Arlington Park today.

Retail and wholesale activity here slackened somewhat during the week, although the total volume continued to be sizable. Completion of buying in the wholesale apparel markets for Summer brought a lull, and in other trades it appeared that distributers had covered requirements sufficiently for the time being.

IF the Eighteenth Amendment is repealed, the rum-runners and allied racketeers, deprived of rich sources of revenue, are expected to turn their talents to other fields. The National Association of Credit Men believes that the "best minds" now engaged in the liquor trade will turn to merchandise rackets as offering the next most-profitable "take," and is preparing to resist them.
CLEVELAND, July 1. -- Tony Lazzeri's bat sang a ninth-inning song of victory for the Yankees in the game with the Indians at Municipal Stadium today. About 6,000 fans saw the champions win, 4 to 2.
