With the structural work practically completed on the huge Parcel Post Office covering the block bounded by Ninth and Tenth Avenues, Twenty-ninth and Thirtieth Streets, another of the many sharp contrasts between the old and the new city conditions is presented.

LONDON. IT is not surprising, remarks Humbert Wolfe in The Observer, that as a protest against the poetry of dismemberment, now so prevalent in the United States, there should have arisen a brisk and affirmative school that stands for growth rather than putrefaction .

Two stories or prose sketches written by the poet WHITTIER are printed in all unkindness, by The New England Quarterly. It is fortunate for his reputation that moat of his early prose work has disappeared, doubtless on account of his own critical disapproval One of these tales is taken from The New York Visitor and Lady's Parlor Magazine for 1840.

It is fortunate for his reputation that moat of his early prose work has disappeared, doubtless on account of his own critical disapproval One of these tales is taken from The New York Visitor and Lady's Parlor Magazine for 1840.

Four of America's colleges and universities have just named new presidents, and in all cases have named young men. Dr. Harold Willis Dodds, at 44, will be the youngest man in 175 years to occupy the presidency of Frinceton, and Dr. James Bryant Conant will be the third youngest man ever to be president of Harvard.

The sales tax is on trial in the State of New York. While the tax imposed upon retail sales of tangible personal property is only an emergency measure, at present limited in its duration to a period of fourteen montns from May 1, 1933, it may, depending upon its constitutionality, workability and productiveness, be the forerunner of some form of general sales tax and result in the permanent retention of this system of taxation.

AN American once "reigned" as king over part of New Zealand. His name was William Webster and his "kingdom," which he bought from the Maoris about the year 1830, was a district near the site of the present city of Auckland.

The June burst of rose glory was all that could be expected. Nature did her best. Seldom have roses been more beautiful than this year. The tide of color is receding; only the everblooming varieties continue to gladden our hearts with colorful beauty.

More than 100 oil organizations, whose representatives in Chicago on June 15-17 and June 22-24 drafted a code of fair competition for the petroleum industry for recommendation to the National Industrial Recovery Board, acted last week on the code, according to the American Petroleum Institute.

THE ship of State has a real salt-water skipper at the helm in the person of President Roosevelt. The water is to him more than a place to go fishing. The open sea calls out his mastery of sailing, and a complete mastery that is.

Owing to increased receipts of peaches toward the latter part of the week the price trend was downward, it was said yesterday by George G. Royce, bead of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets. Mr. Royce said that a few small shipments of peaches had begun to arrive from Delaware, as well as from New Jersey.

Frank Shields of New York, fifth ranking player of the country, and J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N. J., reached the final of the Eastern clay court championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

BALTIMORE, July 1. -- Baltimore won a double-header from Jersey City today, taking the first game 4 to 1 and the nightcap 6 to 4. Beryl Richmond allowed only six hits in the first contest, struck out eight men and issued only one pass.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the good old days when Benjamin Harrison was President the American dollar was not 30 cents in Europe, John Wanamaker, member of the Cabinet, was active in Sunday school work and Vice President Levi P. Morton owned the Shoreham Hotel with its alluring bar, the presence of Baby McKee in the White House was always good copy for the newspaper men on dull days.

CLEVELAND, July 1.-- Spencer McElwyn, owned by Henry H. Knight of Chicago and ably driven by Marvin Childs, Indianapolis reinsman, won the annual renewal of the Classic Matron Stake for 3-year-old trotters at the opening of the Grand Circuit season today at North Randall.

CAMPOBELLO ISLAND, N.B., July 1. -- President Roosevelt started back from his vacation cruise today aboard the trim fighting ship, the cruiser Indianapolis, with his thoughts again turning to work and more particularly to the London Economic Conference.
PARIS. MORAND'S "Londres" is infinitely better than his "New-York" -- not for any literary reason but simply because he is more deeply and more intimately familiar with London.

ROME, June 30. -- The Italian newspapers find in the returns on international trade for May from both the United States and France confirmation of the inability of currency depreciation to bolster up exports.

Additional ways in which college athletic associations are keeping the flag of sport flying continue to be supplied. Reduced funds in many places have curtailed programs, but in almost every instance of threatened extinction the students individually or the college organizations have rallied to provide funds for sports and games.

Next to go was Russell Thaw, the son of Evelyn Nesbit and Harry K. Thaw, flying a Gee Bee racer powered with the same motor with which Major James H. Doolittle established the world's land plane record last year at Cleveland. The sun had come up when Thaw took off at 5:52 and its rays glistened from his chunky red and white racer as it left the runway and roared into the West.

Great baskets of flowers, greetings from other banking institutions of the city and personal visits of felicitation from their executives were the only outward signs yesterday that the Greenwich Savings Bank was marking its 100th birthday.

PARIS, July 1. -- Georges Bonnet, Minister of Finance, who returned from London today, presented to the Cabinet and to the Finance Commission of the Chamber of Deputies a full account of his actions at the World Economic Conference and he obtained the fullest approval.

For those who measure the scope of our recovery by the appreciation in quoted values, the market records at the beginning of the second half of the year lend themselves to fascinating calculations. Taking only the stocks and bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the three major agricultural commodities, some staggering figures can be shown.

LINCOLN and Lee, Cyrus McCormick and Charles Augustus Lindbergh, father of the flier, are among the 665 citizens of this country who appear in the eleventh volume of the Dictionary of American Biography. The book begins with a sketch of the life of Joseph G.E. Larned, who introduced the roaring steam fire engines to New York in the middle of the nineteenth century.

HARTFORD, June 28. -- Connecticut's political phenomenon, Governor Wilbur L. Cross, the retired dean of the Yale Graduate School, continues to be a great puzzle, and a worry, for, with the Legislature ended and active politics in a Summer coma, politicians try to picture the situation in 1934.

In the experiment on which a large number of High schools and colleges are to embark this Fall, as recently announced, "progressive" education is making a great attempt to shoto that its methods are superior to the old. Under the influence of these methods many old familiar educational words are dying out.

DURING the onrushing season of 1933-34, Universal will release thirty-six feature productions, an increase of ten over the present dying season. Two of the films will be road-show, or two-a-day, enterprises. The first of these is "Only Yesterday," from the book by Frederick Lewis Allen; the second is "Blossom Time," based on the successful stage musical of some seasons ago.
LONDON, July 1. -- The Anglo-Russian trade relations were renewed today following the release by the Soviet Union of Leslie C. Thornton and William MacDonald.

ON Jewish Day, to be observed tomorrow at the World's Fair in Chicago, the guest of honor will be the distinguished scientist and leader in Zionism, Dr. Chaim Weizmann, who is visiting the United States for the occasion.

BOSTON, June 28. -- The Summer season for religious, educational and ethical conferences is well under way in New England. As always, visitors from every part of the land are coming to New England shores and mountains for rest and recreation, but not by any means do all of them come for pleasure and physical rejuvenation alone.

Several reassurances were given last week to those who had feared, for any one of several reasons, that the advance in prices as it pertains to commodities and securities might have been unwarranted by the actual economic situation.

WHEN Al Jolson came back to the New Amsterdam Roof for a return engagement on the WEAF wave length last Monday night he had things pretty much his own way. A capacity audience was there to greet him, and the presence of such familiar faces as Ed Wynn, Jack Pearl, Bert Lahr, Burns and Allen and Jack Benny in the front rows visibly cheered the comedian.

Blame for the failure of many modern buildings to "express the spirit of our age" cannot be laid entirely on schools of architecture and at least a part of the responsibility must be placed on engineers contractors, speculators and real estate operators, according to Dean G.H. Edgell of the School of Architecture, Harvard University.

THERE was a day not so long ago that a 1,000-watt broadcasting station was rated as a powerful voice. Today the highpower transmitters in the United States are 50,000 watts. Station WLW at Cincinnati, however, is building a 500,000-watt installation and at the same time Russia is considering a 1,000,000-watt outfit, according to Dr. Louis Cohen, radio engineer, who recently returned from Russia after a visit upon invitation of the Russian Government.
NEWARK, N.J., July 1. -- Newark divided a double header with Albany today. The Bears won the first game, 4 to 3, and lost the second, 5 to 2, in twelve innings.

AN incredible black mare, Miss Midnight (affectionately called Middle for short), is the real heroine of this weird tale of the adventures of a young Connecticut Yankee in the Big Horn country in Montana Territory in the early Seventies before the Custer Massacre.

UP in Albany a new postoffice building, now under construction, invites a word of comment on the still vexed problem of modern architecture and submits proof that in the matter of embellishment modern American motifs can effectively replace hybrid or ever so pure "classical" gimcracks, long, as we alas know, considered indispensable in this country.

With the bulk of Fall business on staple goods placed, and with, buyers hesitating to make further commitments at the high levels reached on some manufactured goods, a decline in wholesale activity can be expected, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

The rain again interfered last night with the concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium. Shortly after 8 o'clock an announcement was made that owing to the threat of stormy weather the concert would be held in the Great Hall of New York City College, where it subsequently took place before an audience of about 1,000.

Stating that repairs and modernization should provide the keynote for the building industry until business recovery is definitely assured, the Long Island Real Estate Board points out that the Home Owners' Loan Corporation should grant generous appraisals in its efforts to aid distressed home owners so as to put every home upon which a loan is made in the best possible condition.

THERE is Gargantuan laughter, however tinged with alarm, in the dance world at the theory recently advanced by one of the City Fathers that income is to be acquired through taxing the dancing schools. This is all that was needed to bring the dancers' situation to the state of calamitous farce.

ALONG and busy life of varied and picturesque activities, pleasurable and useful, has been the rarely fortunate lot of Colonel A.A. Anderson, artist, rancher, big-game hunter, traveler, public-spirited citizen. Looking back over it he has selected and described scenes and events of special interest, keeping them in approximate chronological order within a sort of general framework of his life story.

A GEOMETRICAL plot structure, suspense, surprise and most of the other characteristics of a dramatic tale are either minimized or lacking in this latest Benson novel, for the author has placed his emphasis on portraiture, evolution of character and the delineation of background.

THAT Mr. Collins's promising title is no more than a catch-penny title need not further disturb the reader. He will hear very few of the facts of fiction in this amusing book. He will not be told how, when and where fiction began, when Richardson was born and Fielding died.

BABYLON, L.I., July 1. -- The yachting season on Great South Bay opened today with an invitation regatta of the Babylon Yacht Club. The regatta will continue tomorrow, Monday and Tuesday. The committee in charge is E.V. Ketcham, chairman; John Vanderveer and James A. Swan.

MESSRS. ABBOTT AND DUNNING, who attempted last season to break up the N.Y.C.R.R. monopoly on "Twentieth Century," are at it again. In various flag stations of the East they are making grim plans for the Fall.

Recent events have again emphasized the basic issue at the London conference: economic internationalism versus economic nationalism. In last week's issue of The New York Times Magazine the case for nationalism was stated by Wallace B. Donham, Dean of the Graduate School of Business Administration at Harvard.

AL COPELAND, whose home is Hollywood, specializes in carnivals. With but twenty-four hours' notice he can convert a vacant lot into a tent-bordered midway with barkers, freaks, Ferris wheels and concessions running full blast.

PITTSBURGH, June 29. -- Democrats here and in many other parts of the State feel that a fundamental party change has begun in Pennsylvania; for many of the Republicans who voted for Roosevelt last Fall are now registering Democratic.

Two Ends Meet. Of the first ten States in the order of population, four have not yet voted on repeal. These are, 2, Pennsylvania; 4, Ohio; 5, Texas, and 10, Missouri. All the other six have voted for repeal: 1, New York; 3, Illinois; 6, California; 7, Michigan; 8, Massachusetts; 9, New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, July 1. -- James B. Stewart of Santa Fe director of the Foreign Service Officers' Training School of the State Department, has been assigned as American Consul General at Budapest.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 1. -- By breaking fifty straight targets, G. E. Mole annexed the regular shoot of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. Four gunners, each with a full card, tied for the handicap cup, H. Frankling scoring in the shoot-off.
The last few days of racing on Long Island until the coming Fall will be this week's competition at Aqueduct, which will end its meeting on Friday.
Maurice Perlow and Eugene Berger led the field Into the quarter-final round in the Bronx public parks men's doubles championship at Crotona Park yesterday.

OMAHA, Neb., June 28. -- For many years the valley of the Missouri River has dreamed of barges, of the busy traffic of steamboats snorting up and down the stream and above all of the low freight rates that go with water-borne transportation.

THERE are sixteen stories in Walpole's collection, and they all reach a high degree of merit; all are marked by the distinguished literary quality one is sure to find in his work, touching acutely the human sphere, pleasantly satisfying to the reader's expectancy and demand.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1. -- When Arthur Williamson was coming out of ether three years ago following the amputation of eight fingers and his right thumb, he heard his mother told by the doctor at the Greensburg (Pa.) hospital:

CHICAGO, July 1. -- With head bloody but unbowed, American public education withstood the bludgeonings of a half-dozen critics speaking today before the National Council on Education. This is a policy-forming subsidiary of the National Education Association, whose annual convention began here today.

DOROTHY BURGESS, who appears in "Hold Your Man," at the Capitol, is the daughter of a theatrical family. On her father's side there was Dave Montgomery of Montgomery and Stone. Her mother is a sister of Fay Bainter.

LONDON, July 1. -- With the end of its third week the Economic Conference has reached its most critical stage. The anxiety which marked the second week after the encouragement given during the opening week by the war debts arrangement has deepened.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 28. -- A general feeling of buoyancy pervades the State of Missouri as more moderate temperatures and increased prices of farm crops combine with a definite program, with Federal aid, to decrease unemployment thus creating an economic situation that is more cheering in prospect than the State has experienced in several years.

CHICAGO. CAN the success of a marriage be foretold? Dr. Leonard S. Cottrell Jr. of the University of Chicago thinks it can. He believes that matrimonial prediction will some day be developed into an exact science -- he has in fact, made a start in that direction.

SOME day we may be fertilizing the soil with coal and even taking coal pills to keep ourselves young. If we interpret correctly some remarkable discoveries made by Professor Lieske of the Kaiser Wilhelm Institut fur Kohlenforschung in Mulheim, Germany.

Claims aggregating $13,490,000 were submitted to Dillon, Read Co., fiscal agents of the Brazilian Government, by exporters up to midnight Friday, it was announced yesterday. Filing of the claims is the first step in clearing the large balances, which have been tied up by Brazilian exchange restrictions for periods of one to two years.

PARIS, June 30. -- It seems to be the fate of the French people that after the war they should never be able to agree about anything with their former allies. They did not agree about reparations and they did not agree about the Rhineland occupation.

THERE may be a great deal of conversation for a screen work in the pictorial translation of Rachel Crothers's play "When Ladies Meet," but as the lines are cleverly written and spoken by a group of efficient players the interest in this subject never wanes.

A violent electrical storm, sweeping over New York at dusk yesterday, brought much-needed relief after a day of oppressive heat; but it left in its wake fires, floods and widespread destruction. The temperature, which had risen 20 degrees during the day to a peak of 90, fell 16 degrees during the storm.

JUST as the tormented tenderfoot lost in the forest primeval (see the early works of Owen Wister) crashes frantically through the brambles and the bush for hours only to sink down at last on the mossy ground where first he was nudged by panic, so has Fannie Brice in her professional wanderings completed a wide and exciting circle to arrive at the identical point where she made her fear-stained start some twenty-five years ago.

In keeping with the generally buoyant spirit that pervaded the security and commodity markets yesterday, the listed bond market swung higher in active dealings, with railroad issues leading. Trading was active for a Saturday, topping $9,000,000, whereas a week ago the turnover in bonds on the Stock Exchange amounted to approximately $6,500,000.

Discussing and explaining some of the features of the Home Owner's Loan Act, recently signed by President Roosevelt as a means of aiding distressed home owners, A.N. Gitterman of this city and a member of the American Institute of Appraisers said yesterday that he believed this measure would prove to be a large contributing factor in steadying real estate values and thereby strengthening business conditions.
WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 30, unless otherwise specified:

WASHINGTON. July 1 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace today warned Iowa bakers who propose to increase the price of bread from five to eight cents a pound loaf, effective July 5. that "the anti-trust laws are still in effect."

The first of the monthly index numbers of commodity prices, compiled by Dun's Review, shows increase of 6 5/8 per cent in the average during June, following an average increase of 4 3/8 per cent in May and of 4 1/4 per cent in April. Dun's index number now stands at 19 per cent above the July 1 average of 1932 and 1 3/4 per cent above the average for the same date in 1931.

THE chemical journals have been insisting in the last two years that research has suffered less in this depression than in past ones. Figures compiled by Dr. C.J. West and Miss Callie Hud for the National Research Council lend a certain color to the claims.

TOKTO. All the arts of Hollywood which the Japanese producers copy assiduously cannot kill the strong native strain in their film drama. Hollywood has affected them profoundly and, as was inevitable, indiscriminately.

AMID the vicissitudes of depression and recovery, a bewildered mankind is watching the mysterious abracadabra of two great international conferences in Europe and is wondering what, if anything, will come out of them.

AN airplane alights on a lonely farm in the mountains of Norway and a young woman carrying a black bag steps out from the passenger's seat. She is the district midwife, trained by the State in scientific obstetrics, and she has come to deliver the farmer's wife.

THE Fourth of July program scheduled for the Stadium concert Tuesday night includes Wagner's "Festival March," which Theodore Thomas commissioned for the Centennial Exhibition at Philadelphia in 1876 and which was given its first performance there May 10.

WITH the passing of June, those who seek licenses to fly planes for pleasure in this country find themselves confronted with the new regulations Instituted by the Department of Commerce in the interest of safety.

AN orange-yellow glow lights the way for motorists over a half mile of Balltown Road near Schenectady, where the newly developed sodium vapor lamp was recently given its American premiere for highway illumination. After a few days of experimentation the lights are now permanently in use.
WASHINGTON. THE National Recovery Act bestows upon the President of the United States a measure of control over industry unprecedented in peace time and inaugurates a vast program of public works.
WOODS HOLE, Mass., July 1. -- Two schooners were saved by Coast Guard vessels today from possible destruction.

ST. ANDREWS. Scotland. July 1. -- Gene Sarazen, defending titleholder, and Henry Cotton, England's leading professional, were joint favorites tonight in the British open golf championship starting Monday.
ST. LOUIS, July 1 (AP). -- After trailing 13 to 4, the Browns came from behind today to win a slugging match from the Athletics, 15 to 14.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Among the letters in THE TIMES I read one with keen interest entitled "Financing Columbus." The author of the letter reaches the conclusion that it was Catholic money which was responsible for the expedition that discovered America.
MADRID, June 30. -- The possibility of regular transatlantic air service within one to three years was widely discussed in Madrid this week.

LONDON. THE party which now dominates not only the government but even the private activities and the intellectual life of Germany, steadily enforcing its claim to identify itself with the State, has as one of its basic principles a vehement and sweeping repudiation of what its leaders call "Marxism."

SOUTH BEND, July 1. -- In May, 1932, Mr. Erskine was involved in litigation concerning his income tax. He was ordered by the Board of Tax Appeals to pay a deficiency of $732,008. It was brought out at the time that an agreement had been made between Mr. Erskine and the Studebaker Corporation whereby he was permitted to purchase large blocks of stock each year that the company's net profits amounted to $15,000,000.

DETROIT. LOOKING toward uniform traffic regulation the country over, the motor vehicle law administrators of approximately forty States met here on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. The group deliberated on the general principles of driver licensing financial responsibility laws and other phases of the highway safety problem.

Because Tuesday is Independence Hay the clergymen who occupy New York pulpits today will preach sermons on the price of America's liberty and will treat the subject in the light of recent movements for international peace and permanent disarmament.

LATONIA, Ky., July 1. -- Gold Basis of the stable of M.L. Schwartz of New York came up with a rush today to win the $10,000 added Latonia Derby from Mrs. S.B. Mason's Head Play, prime favorite of the crowd of 10,000.

BERLIN, July 1. -- Although the Catholic Centrist party has not yet pronounced its self-dissolution, the decision having been deferred until Monday, the suppression today by order of Premier Goering of Prussia of all but the strictly ecclesiastical Catholic organizations and the attachment of all their property leaves little doubt of the outcome, whatever Dr. Heinrich Bruening and the other Centrist leaders may say or do.

Announcement that the administration reserved freedom of action as regards dollar fluctuations in order to carry out the domestic price-raising program caused a further recovery of about a quarter a cent in cotton yesterday. After selling at 10.03 cents on Friday, October advanced to 10.50 cents and closed at 10.40 cents, compared with 9.75 cents on the previous Saturday.
NEW YORK. Mrs. James W. Gerard of 1,014 Fifth Avenue will leave for Hamilton, Mont., on July 11 to visit her mother, Mrs. Marcus Daly.

William L. Ward, veteran Republican leader of Westchester County, is recovering from an operation performed about ten days ago at Mount Sinai Hospital here, it was learned yesterday. Mr. Ward's condition was described by the hospital authorities as "fair."

One explanation of the bewilderment of our authorities, when subjected to pressure at London to "stabilize the dollar" and be done with it, has been the lack of visible reason for stabilizing at any one point of depreciation rather than, another. Congress, in its Inflation Act, authorized no greater reduction than 50 per cent in the dollar's gold content, but that left margin enough for executive uncertainty.
CHICAGO, July 1. -- Confirmation of the most sensational reports of crop damage from the record heat and dry weather in June was given to the trade today.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 1. -- Governor Robert H. Gore in his inaugural address today made his contribution to a new deal for Puerto Rico by suggesting that it might be both practical and legal to require large landholders to share their holdings with their employes to end homelessness, hunger and unemployment.
FLOWER GARDENS are luxuries which apartment dwellers, Jacking either front or back yards, seldom may indulge in, and most tenants need to be content with a window box or a few potted plants.
Track -- The New York A.C. captured four of the five relay events to win the national relay title with 26 points as the A.A.U. track and field championship meet came to a close at Chicago.

LONG BEACH. L.I., July 1. -- Triumphing in decisive fashion, Baroness Maud Levi today defeated Miss Grace Surber, the defending titleholder, in the final of the women's metropolitan clay court tennis championship at the Lido Country Club.

THE word "slummy" is not to be found in the smaller Oxford Dictionary, although perhaps it is included in the unabridged edition. Evidently, however, the word, while sometimes an adjective, is chiefly used as a noun, and means a person born and reared in the slums.

LONDON, July 1. -- In an estimate of the services of Sir Eric Drummond, The London Times declares editorially that as the first Secretary General of the League of Nations, nominated to the post in the Treaty of Versailles, he had to build an international civil service, the first that the world had known.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 1. -- With Stewart Iglehart turning in his finest performance this season, the Aiken Knights gained the final round of the Meadowbrook Club cups tournament today by downing Winston Guest's Templeton quartet, 7 to 6, on Cochran Field. Iglehart counted five times.

True to her traditions of religious and political liberty, Great Britain is the first to organize an agency to aid the university scientists, scholars and teachers who have been swept out of their posts by the wave of "non-Aryan" hysteria that now passes for patriotism in Germany.

THE radio audience is divided into two general classes, the receptive listener and the passive listener, according to Willem van Hoogstraten, now conducting the Philharmonic concerts at Lewisohn Stadium. He believes that by devoting complete attention to the music the listener, whether musically educated or not, gets the most from symphonic broadcasts.

LAST week an expedition sent out by Pan American Airways left for Greenland Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, technical committee chairman for the company, will join the expedition this month to do the flying.

Evidences of increased interest in home buying are apparent in many of the choice residential centres of Westchester County, according to several of the leading brokers there. This buying movement is also being reflected in a number of the suburban localities in New Jersey and Long Island.

During recent months while tax-payers and public officials have been searching for ways of cutting school budgets, considerable discussion has arisen in regard to essentials and non-essentials or "frills" in education. Taxpayers associations, bankers, parents and educators have attempted to settle this question.

Officers of the Newark Kennel Club have under consideration a proposition to change the date of their annual exhibition which, in recent years, has been held on the day following the final sessions of the Westminster Kennel Club in New York City.

To the Editor of The New York Times: During the commencement season it is the custom of brand new B.A.'s to hijack the "Letters to the Editor" column, reserved by custom and usage to Constant Reader and Pro Bono Publico.

HAVANA, June 27. -- Although no rebellious flareups have occurred in the island during the past three weeks, Colonel Juan Blas Hernandez, now popularly being referred to as "The Sandino of Cuba," and who disastrously inflicted severe federal reverses during May, still remains an enigma.

THE recent celebrations in Ireland of the anniversary of the birth of Wolfe Tone, Irish Republican patriot, recall a colorful chapter in the earlier struggles of Ireland to free herself from England. Tone, born on June 20, 1763, injected a new spirit into that fight and led many a desperate enterprise to free his native country from English domination.

LONDON, June 22, 1933. THE scenery and "properties" of the Covent Garden season had been barely returned to their owners most of the scenery and "props" have to be borrowed) when the announcement was made that Covent Garden Theatre is to be pulled down.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Ways of stirring industry into speedier action on minimum wage-making hour codes to be presented under the National Recovery Act were being sought tonight by Administrator Johnson.

Announcement by the Railroad Credit Corporation last week of its revised total of loans to railroads served to show the unexpected breadth of aid extended. Designed to distribute in loans to needy railroads the proceeds of the freight surcharges that took effect at the beginning of 1932.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 1 (AP). -- A 15-year-old boy, honor student in his class at Gilbertsville High School, was held in Otsego County Jail here today charged with hacking his mother to death with an axe.
LONDON, July 1. -- The Daily Express announced today that during the past month it had broken the world's record for net sales, averaging more than 2,000,000 copies dally.

As the second half of 1933 begins, executives of public utility companies are engaged in reviewing the results for the first haff of the year and in planning for the future. Although their feelings and hopes vary, all of them express determination to bring their properties through the depression still in a sound condition.
RYE, N.Y., July 1. -- A gala round of diversions for the Fourth of July holiday period has been planned by the yacht, beach and country clubs of Westchester County.
WESTHAMPTON, L.I., July 1. -- Twenty-eight small yachts sailed in the opening regatta of the yacht racing squadron of the Westhamption Country Club on Moriches Bay today.

SUMMER shows out of town continue to get under way. The Gloucester Society of Artists opened its first exhibition of the season yesterday. This will continue through the month. The eleventh annual exhibition of the North Shore Arts Association also opened at Gloucester yesterday and will be on until the second week of September.

NEWPORT -- Not in a long time has there been a week more devoted to things horticultural than this week is to be. It is to open on Tuesday, the Fourth, which is the regular weekly garden day for the benefit of the Civic League of the city.

Irving Trust Company. The Irving Trust Company in its statement of condition, as of June 30, reports total resources of $566,022,460 against $553,810,674 six months ago. Deposits show little change, declining $365,160. Surplus and undivided profits show a net gain of $150,936.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 29. -- Today is the first anniversary of what Bolivia regards as the beginning of the war with Paraguay in the Chaco Boreal, which was precipitated, the Bolivians hold, by an attack on the Bolivian fort Laguna Chuquisaca, also called Pitianturen, which failed, the fort remaining in Bolivian hands.

VIENNA. THE Prater, Vienna's historic park near the Danube, has suffered a rude awakening from its dream of empire days. Vienna, despite tradition and memories of vanished elegance, has thrust its way into the city's imperial inheritance, felled some scores of trees and erected, in classic-modern style, a great stadium covering 36,000 square yards.

Employers who reject fair offers for conciliation of their differences with their employes should expect little aid or sympathy at present from a court of equity. Supreme Court Justice Hammer ruled yesterday in refusing a picketing injunction.

In the four weeks ended June 28, the return flow of currency to the Federal Reserve Banks amounted to $137,000,000 of which about $40,000,000 came to the New York district, according to the monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON. THIS old globe has whirled around many times since a celebrated politician spoke of the rule that "to the victors belong the spoils." Democratic members of Congress, believing the rule axiomatic, are desperately striving to make it operative.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Extension of industrial productive activity in the week ended on June 24 makes certain that major indexes for June will record considerable improvement over May, according to the weekly survey of domestic business activity made public today by the Department of Commerce.

The Eastern State or Taconic Parkway, now under construction from the northern end of the Bronx River Parkway near Shrub Oak, in Westchester County, through Putnam County to the Carmel-Cold Spring Road, is due to be extended shortly into Dutchess County up to Route 52 (the Pawling-Fishkill Road to Beacon), and will serve to spur realty activity in that part of Dutchess County, in the opinion of Homer W. Guernsey, broker, of Poughkeepsie.
WHEN the young republic of Finland paid the full instalment of $148,592 or her debt to the United States the other day, she was singled out for special mention by the Washington State Department.

Several thousand Girl Scouts in five boroughs will pack their camping equipment and move into the open, this week to put their Winter training into practice, it was Bald yesterday by Miss Leslie Osgood Colby, executive secretary of the Girl Scout Federation of Greater New York.

The man who asks you in the street for the price of a cup of coffee may seem a poor sort of creature, but he has a brain in which, according to Professor HERRICK of Chicago, there is a system of intercellular communication that transcends any mechanism of man's devising.

AS you will recall, the College Art Association's 1933 international exhibition of contemporary paintings made its debut last January at the new Worcester Art Museum, whence it was brought to Rockefeller Center for a New York showing in February.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., June 28. -- Amid the surprises of the special election held in California yesterday probably the most unexpected is that experienced by Governor Rolph when the returns admonished him for betting on the wrong horse.

HANOVER, Germany, June 30. -- The rythm of Germany's national revolution is perceptibly slower in the provinces than in Berlin. The country is apparently half stunned and half fascinated by the magicians in the capital who with a stroke of the pen are wiping out the institutional creations of centuries and who have so centralized the command and move at such a breathtaking pace that the country is scarcely able to follow their day-to-day readjustments.

Is our economic plight partly due to the fact that the average citizen -- housewife or business man alike -- has never been taught how to buy or how to invest? Even if he has been through high school and college the chances are slim that he has ever had any instruction in the art he must practice all his life, that of being a consumer.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 1. -- Bunching five of their ten hits to score seven runs in the last three innings, the New York A.C. nine scored a 10-to-5 victory over the Montclair A.C. in the first game of their annual series today.
Security and commodity markets advanced sharply yesterday, and in some cases to the highest levels of the year, as the dollar depreciated hi terms of all the important foreign currencies.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 28. -- The busy bee in the tar-bucket was in a state of inanimation when compared to the recent activities of Georgia's Governor and the laurels of Louis XIV have withered in the face of Governor Eugene Talmadge's exercise of power.

A 20 per cent increase in the dollar volume of retail stores for the second half of this year was regarded as a distinct possibility in retail circles yesterday. With the total for the first six months estimated as 12 1/6 per cent below that of last year, a 20 per cent gain would enable stores to finish the year with an increase of 5 per cent over 1932, it was said.

MUSIC is often airily described as a "universal language." But I, for my part, can only see that music, as practiced in our concert halls, music schools and homes, is the most parochial, the least universal, of all the arts.

TRENTON, N.J., July 1. -- Attorney General William A. Stevens, in a letter of protest to Henry H. Woodring. Acting Secretary of War, charges that New York City has not only failed to restrict dumping of garbage at sea but has increased the volume.

DRESDEN, Germany, July 1. -- Almost five years to the day after his last previous opera, "Egyptian Helen," Richard Strauss brought forward at the Dresden Opera tonight his new three-act lyric comedy, "Arabella," composed to a much revised, but still rather inept and long-winded, libretto by the late Hugo von Hofmansthal.

MR. KIMBLE combines philatelic and historical instruction very agreeably in his volume descriptive of the commemorative postage stamps of the United States. It may surprise those who have never caught the habit of stamp collecting to know that forty-four distinct issues of commemorative and memorial stamps have been brought out in this country since the famous Columbian set appeared In 1893.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 1. -- During the college year just closed Tale athletic teams participated in 384 dual engagements, with a record of 273 won, 99 lost and 12 tied.

Trade Parley Developments. President Roosevelt notified the gold bloc at the London Trade Conference yesterday that he had rejected "in its present form" the proposal submitted to him upholding the gold standard and providing for curtailment of speculation in exchange.

Semi-annual dividends aggregating $160,000,000 have recently been distributed by the building and loan associations throughout the country, reports Morton Bodfish, executive manager of the United States Building and Loan League.
A national women's yachting association, the first of its kind in this country, will be formed next September at Cohasset, Mass., if plans now under consideration materialize.

Plans for an extensive housing development in the downtown section of Jersey City, covering approximately eleven acres, are being worKed out by a committee consisting of former Judge Richard Dogherty, chairman; former Judge George G. Tennant, Aaron Siegelman, Joseph Cooney, Colonel Hugh A. Kelly, Edwin Lord, the Rev. Father L.C. Stanley of St. Peter's Catholio Church, Matthias Last, Percy Gaddis, J.I. Haas and B. Sumner Gruzen.

WASHINGTON. July 1. -- In connection with steps to improve the price of corn and hogs by controlling their production. Secretary Wallace announced today that a national conference of corn and hog producers would probably be held in the Corn Belt by mid July.

FLORENCE, June 9, 1933. A WAVE of indignation swept over the house when the curtain rose on "I Puritani" at the Teatro Comunale here some days ago. More protests accompanied later scenes; the vision of the armory brought a prolonged uproar, despite the presence of the Crown Princess, while Tullio Serafin went forward resolutely with the music.

OMAHA, July 1. -- Advancing farm prices and a decline in foreclosures have routed the farmers' holiday movement. Just as suddenly as the association jumped into the limelight last Fall and soon became almost a national menace, it has suddenly dropped out of existence.

On Friday the Federal Treasury closed its books at the end of a disappointing year. In round numbers the deficit amounted to $1,750,000,000. This was about $1,100,000,000 less than last year's figure, but the more favorable showing is partly a matter of book-keeping, since expenditures of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation have been carried for the past twelve months entirely outside the ordinary budget.

CHICAGO, June 29. OF plays and the Fair I sing! During the last two or three months the theatrical air has been clouded with rumors and reports of legitimate theatrical productions for Chicago during the period of a Century of Progress.

ACERTAIN amount of ingratitude is due to the master and fellows of Trinity College. Mr. Blunden was pursuing his investigations with a view to writing "a large account" of Lamb. The dons invited him to lecture. So only this smaller book on the subject can be expected from an author who has so many qualities of intellectual and moral sympathy and connection with it.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- A colorful Fourth of July program has been arranged by members of the Summer colony here. The finals of the Independence Day tennis tournament -- which starts today -- will hold the interest on the Casino en-tout-cas courts in the afternoon.

Methods to be followed by Federal athorities in extending aid to diseased property holders under the home owners' loan were described yesterday by Morton Bobdfish, executive manager of the United States Building and Loan League. The plan is due to be in operation within a few days.

DUBLIN, June 30. -- The de Valera Government is dissatisfied with the results of its intensive policy of protection, particularly in the rural parts of the Irish Free State, where greater industrial development was expected.

PARIS, June 29. -- Fashions at the polo garden party, the season's outstanding daylight fete, foreshadow a strong Fall revival of the velvet vogue, particularly in coats, hats and trimmings. All-velvet picture hats matching velvet coats, but with a contrasting dress, are favorites of many style leaders.

wheat figures largely in the news these days. Simultaneously with discussions at London looking to reduction of the world crop, and a broad wheat market in the United States, comes announcement that, beginning next week, a thirty-cent processing tax on wheat is to be applied as a step in giving effectiveness to the administration's farm program.

INTRODUCTION of the new electric eye, or iconoscope, invented by Dr. Vladimir K. Zworykin has focused interest in radio circles on the prospects for television in the home. Pertinent questions have been asked since Dr. Zworykin described the magic optic a few days ago; what will happen to the present broadcasting stations?

WHEN the French praise they praise. The interesting French quarterly with the descriptive title, Le Manuscrit autographe, devotes its forty-first number largely to distinguished Americans, with reproductions of letters by Washington and Franklin, and articles on the work of various artists and writers.

COMPETITIONS to determine the best chaffinch singers have recently been held in various towns in the Harz Mountains, in Germany. The owners take their birds in wooden cages covered by white cloths. At a given signal the cloths are taken off simultaneously and the bird which outsings the others is the champion.

HENLEY, England, July 1. -- The three United States crews in the Henley regatta opening next Wednesday fared well in the draw today, being pitted against only ordinary opposition in their first races.

FAME was kind to Edward FitzGerald. It passed him by in his long lifetime, leaving him undisturbed; a country gentleman content to putter around his garden, to sail his boat, to lie musing in the sun. It waited until after his death, fifty yean ago, to send the praise of his "Rubaiyat of Omai Khayyam" ringing through the earth.

Bonds called for payment in June before their dates of maturity made the smallest monthly aggregate in more than five years. The total of $6,887,000 compared with $17,520,000 in May and $9,102,000 in June, 1932.
New Yorkers left behind in a city deserted by hundreds of thousands will listen Tuesday to patriotic speeches and to the usual cacophony of firecrackers in empty streets.

THE motor bus gained ground as a transport facility in New York with the inauguration last week of a new system operating in the city's east side. The opening ceremonies included a historical pageant depicting the development of surface transportation in Manhattan -- from the stage-coach of Colonial days to the horse car and trolley cars now supplanted by the new bus lines.

ALTHOUGH Kathleen Norrls has hitherto shown little disposition to grapple with major social problems, her heroine in "Wife for Sale" discovers a novel method for dealing with the business depression. Norah Oliver, to put it succinctly, was in a jam.
WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The text of the code of fair competition for the cotton textile industry, as revised and presented to the Recovery Act Administrator, is as follows:

THE opening yesterday of air service between New York and Chicago on a frequency of schedule which well-nigh puts it in the commuting class, establishes this airway as one of the most intensively traveled in the world. United Airlines' eleven flights in each direction each twenty-four hours mean a seating capacity of 220 passengers daily.
WASHINGTON, July 1. -- The text of the code of fair competition for the cotton textile industry, as revised and presented to the Recovery Act Administrator, is as follows:

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 28. -- Puerto Rico is looking forward to the beginning of its second Democratic administration in thirty-five years of American rule with something more of curiosity than excitement.

BASING this book on recent courses of his lectures at the Royal Technical College. Glasgow, Mr. Macpherson has aimed to make it a popular introduction to the life-work of the chief modern astronomers and also a reference work wherein the general reader can find information on the history of astronomy and the men who have made it readily accessible.

Steps taken by the administration to develop a national planned economy through the medium of the Industrial Recovery Act are in line with the procedure which engineers would follow in tackling a similar task, according to views expressed by leaders in that profession here yesterday.

BAR HARBOR -- The season is already on and old favorite events are beginning to find their places in the program. The visit of President and Mrs. Roosevelt to Mount Desert Island last week made an unusually auspicious curtain-raiser.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The public has been much confused as to the effect of labor-saving machinery on our civilization. Engineers have contended with force that the greater ease of production should give us more comforts, with greater leisure to enjoy them.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- John (Jake the Barber) Factor was kidnapped from his car early today while he was returning from a party given by him at the Dells, a roadhouse gambling resort on Dempster Road, four miles west of Evanston, a suburb of Chicago.
Piling up their biggest score of the season the Cubs yesterday routed the Dodgers, 13 to 3, at Ebbets Field.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 1. -- Several dinners were given tonight at various estates for holiday guests. Mr. and Mrs. C. Eric W. McDonald gave one at Penryn for Mr. and Mrs. Charles Garrison Meyer of Bayside, John P. Grier of New York and Daniel E. Pomeroy of Englewood, N.J., who are Visiting them.

PARIS. ALARMED by the decline of the Paris season, style leaders, both professional and amateur, have banded together with the "City-of-Light" elders in an effort to restore the patient to robust health.

CHICAGO, July 1. -- The seven man American track and field team that will invade Europe in a competitive tour through six countries was named today. Headed by three New York A.C. athletes, the American combination is one of the strongest that the United States has ever sent abroad.

AMSTERDAM, Sunday, July 2. -- The Italian fliers arrived here at 12:56 yesterday afternoon after a flight of six hours and twenty-one minutes from Orbetello, Italy. As they landed at the seaplane port, the machine commanded by Captain Baldini capsized and Sergeant Ugo Quintavalle was smothered in the mud.
Closer cooperation between public authorities and private owners and builders is needed to eradicate blighted or slum districts in New York City, in the opinion of the Regional Plan Association.

The opening yesterday of the Concourse subway extension of the city's independent subway system is due to have a marked effect on the residential and business growth of the Bronx, in the opinion of realty and civic interests of that borough.

IN the rush of events tumbing headlong into the pages of history. Edouard Daladler, Premier of France, occupies a place of the utmost importance. Without the cooperation of the head of the French Government what could the world accomplish at the London Economic Conference?

A code of fair practices under the National Industrial Recovery Act has been drafted for the entire printing industry, it was announced yesterday. More than 2,000 employing printers have been invited by John Clyde Oswald, managing director of the New York Employing Printers Association, acting as secretary to the organization committee, to attend a meeting next Thursday evening to consider the code for adoption.

TRAVEL this Summer is livelier than the boldest of ticket-office optimists dared to expect. In a season of stringency steamship deck-rails are double-lined with globe-trotters, train reservations are often sold out weeks ahead, the tourist buses busily ply along the roads laden to capacity, while the air companies fly extra planes and wish they had more to send up.

Low-cost housing should be encouraged under the Federal Government's recovery program with a rate of interest on money advanced for this purpose equivalent to the rate paid by the government, the Regional Planning Association of America suggested yesterday.

Articles ranging from telephone poles to clothespins are among the millions of objects made of wood which the present "metal civilization" finds indispensable. Even before the institution of President Roosevelt's forestry camps, lumbering, measured by the number of persons engaged in it, was one of the largest industries in the United States, a bulletin from the National Geographic Society points out.

Henri Morin de Linclays, general secretary of the French Line, sailed yesterday on the liner Paris to report to the directors of the line after a four months' survey of trade conditions in the United States. M. de Linclays plans to return to New York next Fall to complete his task.

Fordham University will open its sixteenth Summer session July 6 with, courses in its Graduate School, Teachers College, and several courses of instruction. The courses are designed for graduate students, teachers, and candidates for baccalaureate degrees who desire to shorten the period of residence or to make up semester deficiencies.

METRO - GOLDWYN - MAYER has acquired motion-picture rights to "Evelyn Prentice," he new novel by W.E. Woodward which Alfred A. Knopf recently published. This company has also purchased two short stories, "Too Much Air," by Thomas Burtis, and "Paid to Laugh," by Frances Marion.

The New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, has acquired a rare American flag of the type that was adopted by resolution of the Continental Congress on June 14, 1777, It is one of the few flags of its type now in existence.

Each of the ten chapters in this book recounts a separate episode in the careers of two of the trio who call themselves the "Three Just Men." The third member of the trio remains in the background. The mission that the Three Just Men have undertaken is to mete out punishment to evil-doers whom the law has failed to reach.

SOUTHAMPTON. -- Independence Day, which marks the formal beginning of social activities in Southampton, promises to be unusually gay this season. Already elaborate plans are being made for the entertainment of house guests at various estates as well as for several community undertakings that will celebrate the holiday.

Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh tested a new engine and propeller yesterday in the plane in which he will soon make a survey flight to the North with Mrs. Lindbergh. He landed at Glenn Curtiss Airport, North Beach, Queens, after flights at Curtiss Essex Airport, Caldwell, N.J., and a landing at Newark.

PRIZE day for the American short story cornea around punctually once each year. There are rolls of honor, badges of distinction in the form of graded stars, and there is, always, a commencement address by Mr. Edward J. O'Brien.

HAILING the National Industry Recovery Act as the greatest opportunity offered automobile retailers to "eliminate cut-throat competition" and rid themselves of "the shackles of used-car losses," the national Automobile Dealers Association has submitted to its members a suggested code for the regulation of that branch of the automotive industry.

LOS ANGELES, July 1. -- The national air races for 1933 got off to a hurricane start here today. As the inaugural parade was being formed on the field here, Colonel Roscoe Turner, a home-town flier, roared across the finish line fresh from New York to win the annual running of the Bendix Trophy.

OBERAMMERGAU. IN this tiny village, hidden away in the heart of the Bavarian Alps yet world-famous for its Passion Plays, the dictatorship of the Nazis has become of some moment. A ruling party which has waged a campaign against the Jews of Germany could hardly fail, one might Imagine, to concern itself with a town where, every tenth year, the death of Christ is reenacted.

DENVER, Col., June 28. -- The question of what is to be done for silver overshadows all other national and international topics here. It is the only point of contact between Denver and the London conference. Bimetalism is of more concern than the National Recovery Act, the Glass Bill or a kidnapping.

Led by a woman, six racing pilots left Floyd Bennett Field yesterday morning for Los Angeles. They were all entrants in the Bendix transcontinental derby, the first event on the program, for the country at large of the 1933 National Air Races.
WASHINGTON, July 1. -- More than $500,000,000 in farm, mortgages locked in closed banks will be refinanced under plans being drawn by the Farm Credit Administration.

BERLIN, July 1. -- Wolff's (German) News Agency published an official statement tonight denying that Chancellor Adolf Hitler would join the new National Protestant Church after abandoning the Roman Catholic faith.

A new chapter in the history of the Flatiron Building, one of Manhattan's best-known landmarks, was written last week when the property was bid in by the Equitable Life Assurance Society in a foreclosure action.
BOSTON, July 1 (AP). -- The Cincinnati Reds put on a 2-run rally in the tenth inning today to defeat the Boston Braves, 6 -- 5. The upset snapped the Braves' winning streak at five straight.

With a crowd of pursuers at his heels, a hold-up man who had robbed a brokerage office employe of $1,690 dropped his loot at the entrance to the Trinity Building yesterday morning and escaped in the Broadway crowds.

RHYS DAVIES, the young Welsh writer whose austerity of style in some of his short stories contrasts so conspicuously with the sensuousness that marks much of his longer works, is the subject of noticeably diverse criticism in English literary circles.

DETROIT, July 1 (AP). -- The Senators held fast to first place today by quickly defeating the Tigers, 11 to 3. The game was over in one hour and 26 minutes, a new low mark for Navin Field in recent years.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 1. -- Henry Seaman's bay gelding Calumet Author, driven by Alley Cornwell, won the free-for-all trot today at the matinee of the Nassau Driving Club.

PATRIOTIC symbols -- the eagle, the star and the laurel wreath -- so popular as decorative motifs in the days following the Revolution, are today once more in high favor. They are as distinctly American as the banjo clock and the block-front desk.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The business of advertising is going to be greatly benefited by President Roosevelt's National Industrial Recovery plan just as soon as manufacturers and associations of manufacturers realize their part in its success.

At the Albany convention for the repeal Of the Eighteenth. Amendment former Governor SMITH made a pungent address. He warned, after the sad experiment of prohibition, against mistakes of legislation hurried through in the name of the people. He expressed the hope that this country had seen the last endeavor by Federal law to dictate in matters which ought to be left to the control of cities and States.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 1. -- Before a big gallery Jack Tidball of the University of California at Los Angeles won the national intercollegiate tennis championship today by beating Richard T. Murphy of Hamilton College in the final round on the grass courts at the Merion Cricket Club.

READING, Pa., July 2. -- The national executive committee of the Socialist party, meeting here today, discussed placing the full resources of the party at the disposal of organized labor in its effort to organize trade unions under the Industrial Recovery Act.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Whatever else may be expected of the "new deal" in progress at Washington, America witnessed last week a spectacle few even hoped to see this side of a social and economic millennium.
A Jersey City hotel conveyance by Theodore M. Brandle, former "labor czar," featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported over the week-end.

The "new deal" must end wasteful competition in religion, the Rev. Dr. Albert W. Beaven, president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

Buying activity in the wholesale apparel markets declined slightly last week. With consumer interest in seasonal merchandise waning, retailers were awaiting the formal showings of new Fall dress styles here this week. The call for Tall coats increased, but uncertainty over deliveries, because of threats of labor trouble, has affected the volume of purchasing.

CHICAGO, July 2.-Good supplies, although lighter than in the previous week, made an unsettled market for hogs last week, with sharp declines in prices and a rally at the close. Top prices on the best lights were $4.75 at midweek, with Friday's figures 10 cents lower.

Detectives investigating the murder of Murray Marks, racketeer and reputed aide of Waxey Gordon, raided yesterday a ground-floor apartment in the 120-family dwelling at 750 Pelham Parkway, the Bronx, across the courtyard from Marks's second-floor apartment.

The statement of the Chase National Bank for June 30 shows an increase of more than $100,000,000 in deposits since March 31, the date of the last previous statement. Deposits amounted to $1,408,337,000, comparing with $1,306,745,000 on March 31.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- In watching the unusual activity in the wheat market, the stock and cotton markets and the unfavorable crop reports from the American and Canadian North-west, business men, manufacturers and bankers are kept busier than usual.

Frank Shields, America's fifth ranking player, suffered a surprising setback at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday when J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange routed him in straight sets, 6-2, 7-5, 6-4. With this triumph went the Eastern clay court championship and the MacDougall Trophy.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 2. -- A well-balanced Sands Point polo team defeated Roslyn, 15 -- 5, at the Sands Point Club today.

The need for a wholesome type of recreation is greater today than ever before, especially for the unemployed, who have so much enforced leisure on their hands, it is declared in a statement just made public by the board members of the National Recreation Association at 315 Fourth Avenue.
The rural church has lost the cultural leadership which it once had and has given place to the modern, efficient, consolidated rural school, according to Owen D. Young.

LONDON, July 2. -- While the World Economic Conference may be regarded as running a sterile course so far as actual results are concerned, it is having political side issues that are extremely important.

Dr. Robbins W. Barstow, president of the Hartford Theological Seminary, spoke yesterday morning on "Sequences and Consequences of Leadership," at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 2. -- One man was killed and twenty-one persons injured tonight when a bus turned over into a ditch near Sand Hill, on the Brunswick Pike, about four miles south of here.

ALBANY, July 2. -- Governer Lehman ordered all police officers in the State tonight to enforce the new State law governing the manufacture and sale of 3.2 beer and wine. The order was sent to all chiefs and commissioners of police, sheriffs, district attorneys and to Major John A. Warner, superintendent of State Police.

Heat and Recovery. Crowds leaving town for the holidays by rail, boat and bus were bigger than in recent preceding years. There is actually talk of record crowds. The transportation officials see therein one of the surest signs of business recovery.

RYE, N.Y., July 2. -- Horace Havemeyer's 12-meter sloop Moutte, sailed by Harry L. Maxwell, cored a real breeze triumph over the wind-eating Cantitoe today in the special regatta of the American Yacht Club.

When the new fiscal year began on Saturday it was necessarily attended by a set of conflicting economic circumstances. The Central Government's economy program was starting and at the same time Federal recovery was being initiated. To effect the former, employes were dropped from the roll and pensions were reduced by nearly one-half, striking at hundreds of thousands of citizens.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Corn is receiving support from local and country traders who believe that a shortage of feed stuffs, due to hot and dry weather, will bring a largely increased consumptive demand from nearly all over the country for corn and with wheat prices working irregularly higher, that corn is to follow in a moderate way.

BERLIN, July 2. -- The science of racial biology as postulated by Nazi dogma received a practical endorsement today in the mass marriage of forty-seven Nazi couples in the Lazarus Church in the East End of Berlin.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 2. -- Sixteen teams were in play in a mixed doubles tennis tournament today at the Wyantenuck Club.

LONDON, July 1. -- The attention of financial London was diverted from the Chicago pit. Although the world's troubles are mainly financial, the maladjustment of costs and prices has caused advances in commodities to be regarded here with some misgiving.

NEW HAVEN, July 2. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 65.1, which compares with 64 a week ago, 63.5 two weeks ago, 62.7 three weeks ago and 62.1 four weeks ago. The present average is the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

MOSCOW, July 2. -- The Soviet Union enters the second half of the year in a much better position than at the beginning of the year. This is true not only from economic and political standpoints, both at home and abroad, but in the way the Russians themselves feel about it.

An oratorio by an American musician, Evangelie Lehman of Detroit, is scheduled to take place tomorrow in Paris at the Church of St. Nicholas of the Fields, according to dispatches received here. Marcel Dupre will play the organ and Maurice Dumesnil will direct. The oratorio is dedicated to Ste. Therese.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Lard stocks surprised many in the provision trade by increasing 46,485,000 pounds during June, reaching an aggregate of 90,520,261 pounds, and exceeding last year's by 21,589,000 pounds. It is taken by the trade as indicating a rather disappointing demand and a liberal production.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July, 2. -- James H. Price, Lieutenant Governor of Virginia, will welcome the members and friends of the Institute of Public Affairs at its first public meeting tomorrow night at the University of Virginia. A group of Washington correspondents will discuss President Roosevelt's program for economic reconstruction.

PASADENA, Cal., July 2. -- While fliers at the National Air Races are trying to push past the 300-mile-an-hour mark to new records, the earth is speeding through space at a clip to make this seem a snail's pace.
With the return of President Roosevelt to Washington conferences will be held in the coming week, it was learned yesterday, to launch large-scale awards of Federal jobs by July 15.

A code of business ethics that will make American financiers "play the game" is the greatest need of this country today, the Right Rev. Dr. William P. Remington, Missionary Bishop of Eastern Oregon, said in a sermon yesterday morning in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

Senator James Couzens of Michigan, a member of the United States delegation to the World Economic Conference, today told of his experiences as "a United States Senator abroad," in an interview by William Hard, the National Broadcasting Company's commentator at the conference.

BERLIN, July 1. -- Financial circles here characterize the settlement on payment of German bonds negotiated at London as relatively favorable to the foreign bondholders. It is believed that on the basis of the trade balance and services of recent months, a 50 per cent transfer of interest certainly can be maintained, leaving a moderate surplus of exchange for the replenishment of the Reichsbank's reserves.
All commodities traded on local exchanges advanced last week, with some new high levels for the year to date established. Trading was in fair volume. All cash prices were also higher.
Charles H. Sabin, chairman of the board of the Guaranty Trust Company, and Mrs. Sabin will sail tonight for Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- With a new confidence in the stability of the American school system, thousands of teachers from all parts of the country are still pouring into Chicago today by bus and family automobile for the seventy-first annual convention of the National Education Association, whose working sessions begin tomorrow.

WICHITA, Kan., July 2 (AP). -- Miss Ruth Nichols, who hopped off from Floyd Bennett Field, New York, at 3:59 A.M., Eastern Standard Time, today as the last contestant in a transcontinental air race, landed here at 1:40 P.M., Central Standard Time, and announced she would remain for the night.

It was due to God's guidance that Columbus's course veered to the South, leaving North America to be civilized by Anglo-Saxons rather than by "slaves of any King or vassals to a Pope," the Right Rev. William Moreland Hall, Episcopal Bishop of Sacramento, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Reviewing conditions in the steel industry, the magazine Steel says that in June twenty-eight additional blast furnaces were lighted, the greatest gain for any month since October, 1922. The increase in lighted furnaces, bringing the total to eighty-nine, lifted the daily rate of pig iron production in June to 42,500 gross tons, the magazine states.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP). -- Secretary Wallace, in an effort to prevent consumer resentment against the Farm Relief Act, has indicated a decision to employ "to the limit" the powers provided him to ward off "unreasonable" increases of retail prices in the wake of new processing taxes.

New clues to the strange world of insects that see some colors that man cannot see and are blind to others that he does see were disclosed yesterday by the American Museum of Natural History in announcing recent discoveries in insect vision by Dr. Frank E. Lutz, curator of the department of insect life.

NEWARK, N.J., July 2 (AP). -- Newark lost a double bill to Albany today, 4 to 0 and 3 to 2. Lefty Fussell, who pitched a no-hit, no-run game at Jersey City last week, scored a shut-out in the opener to run his string of scoreless innings to twenty-two.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 2. -- This morning found East Hampton's Summer colonists and their house guests on the Maidstone golf links or enjoying a luncheon at the club's outdoor restaurant, or a swim at the Devon Yacht Club overlooking Gardiner's Bay.

NEW YORK. Mrs. William Marston Seabury has returned from Kittery Point, Me., and will sail today to pass the remainder of the Summer with her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Savage Crocker 2d, in Stockholm, where Mr. Crocker is Charge d' Affaires of the American Legation.

BERLIN, July 2. -- Germany's industrial position is bettering, but anxiety prevails among manufacturers over the disappearance from the cabinet of Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, Minister of Agriculture and Economics, who acted as a brake on Nazi radicalism.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Price-fixing in marketing agreements with the Agricultural Adjustment Administration will be permitted only in the case of certain highly perishable commodities, such as dairy and meat products.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- The cruiser Indianapolis, with President Roosevelt as commander-in-chief, rode through a tumbling sea on a generally southwesterly course down the Atlantic coast tonight, its speed set to return him to his Presidential duties by tomorrow afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Asserting that the $3,300,000,000 public works program is intended primarily to increase employment, Secretary Ickes, chairman of the Special Board for Public Works tonight warned prospective contractors that the administration would do everything possible to hold them down to "a legitimate profit."
BERLIN, July 2. -- A new law definitely barring all Jews or persons with Jewish family affiliations from holding any kind of office in Germany has just been promulgated in the official gazette.

BERLIN, July 1. -- Bankers and other financial authorities refuse to harbor the notion that Holland, France and other gold currency countries will abandon the gold standard. It is considered that abandonment would be disastrous to world trade.

BOSTON, July 2 (AP). -- The Braves and Reds took turns shutting out each other today to divide a double-header marked by brilliant pitching. The Tribe took the opener, 1 to 0, while Boston won, 3 to 0, in the second game.

By the side of every writer, or maliciously contemplating him from the ceiling, is that mischievous devil, first cousin of the Imp of the Perverse, the Spirit of Heterophemy. RICHARD GRANT WHITE paid his respects to him years ago; invented the word "heterophemy," that "speaking otherwise," a sort of possession or obsession which makes you say one thing when you mean another.
WASHINGTON, July 2. -- A total of $313,410,370 was spent for relief in 120 American, cities during 1932, the Labor Department announced today.

ALBANY, July 2 (AP). -- Regulations to clarify the sales tax problems of newspaper and magazine publishers and distributers, advertising agencies and printers and engravers were issued tonight by Mark Graves, president of the Tax Commission.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 2. -- Count Alfonso P. Villa, who is among the Fourth of July guests of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Duncan, entertained fifty friends with a luncheon at the Clambake Club today.

BALTIMORE, July 2 (AP). -- Out-hit by almost two to one, Baltimore took the long end of a slugfest with Jersey City today by a score of 15 to 12. Rain prevented the playing of the second half of a scheduled double bill.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2. -- England's traditional observance of the Sabbath kept competitors in the all-England tennis championships on the sidelines today, but hostilities will be resumed tomorrow, with principal attention fixed on men's singles.

The six-story Catholic Club at 120 W. 59th St. was sold by the Catholic Club, Carroll Hayea, president, to the Benguetay Realty Co., Inc., George J. Gillespie, president, the buyer giving a mortgage for $80,000 thereon to the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank. This mortgage has been consolidated with a prior mortgage to form a joint first lien of $480,000 on the premises.

Irreverence and "lack of respect toward everything God has laid His hand upon" are the besetting sins of this generation, the Rev. Henry F. Hammer declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Though the lexicons will allow any one to be "emerited," young or old, who has honorably served out the years of his enlistment, the title "emeritus," as we have come to apply it, suggests something more than mere completion of a term of worthy service. It is an enhaloing word, carrying an added glory.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 2. -- Hard-fought matches marked the tennis in the quarter-final round of the Nassau Country Club invitation tourney today as each of the four victors in the singles advanced by winning a three-set encounter.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Denunciation of Chancellor Hitler and other leaders of the anti-Semitic campaign in Germany as "a group of intellectual perverts and paranoiacs" was delivered this afternoon at the thirty-sixth annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America by Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of New York City.

In a letter to stockholders of the Pennroad Corporation, F.S. Kaufman, temporary chairman of the stockholders' protective committee, says that the testimony adduced before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee last week "indicates the establishment of some very important pieces of evidence" that should prove valuable to them in current litigation.

LOS ANGELES, July 2 (AP). -- Despite the apparent attractiveness of his little kingdom, Douglas Fairbanks often has said to friends he is happiest when traveling. Travel is his idea of play, he has said.
After completing nearly forty-four years with the American Bible Society in Astor Place, Frank T. Brooks, who has supervised the printing of millions of Bibles, retired last Friday.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Higgins gave a reception this afternoon at Ashton Moor, their residence, for Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Tanner, who have taken the D.A.R. cottage for the season. Among their other guests were:

ST. LOUIS, July 2 (AP) -- The Athletics and Browns split a doubleheader today in which Jimmy Foxx, Athletic first baseman, spanked out four home runs, two in the first game, which the Athletics won in the tenth, 6 to 5, and a pair in the nightcap, which went to the Browns, 11 to 6.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- A subcommittee of experts was nearing completion tonight of a tentative draft of an agreement for stabilizing the sugar industry and prices by prorating the potential market demand to the various sources of supply.

The Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, editor of The Christian Herald and president of the International Society of Christian Endeavor, attempts in "John Barleycorn: His Life and Letters," to use the "weapon of laughter with which prohibition has been attacked to show the ludicrousness of the appeals of John Barleycorn and his friends." The book is published by Winston.

VATICAN CITY, July 2 (AP). -- A solution of problems of American agriculture by the application of Catholic principles was proposed in a statement presented to the Pops today by Archbishop McNicholas of Cincinnati, Ohio.

It is scientifically impossible, said a recent writer of remote Gallic ancestry, "that we in our very own forefathers "were not building some of the eighty "cathedrals and three hundred great "minsters with which France was [in "the thirteenth century] clothing her"self as with a white mantle of "churches."

LONDON, Monday, July 3. -- That President Roosevelt's negative action in regard to stabilization, if persisted in, will shake the economic conference badly, if it does not cause its complete collapse, is the opinion expressed today by The Financial Times.

JACKSON, Miss., July 2. -- Speeding reorganization of the New Orleans Great Northern Railroad under a plan whereby it will be taken over by the Gulf, Mobile Northern, the former road was auctioned off at foreclosure sale here yesterday for $989,760.

LONDON, July 2. -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull in London has been studying plans for handling the problem of the depression as a whole, while Assistant Secretary Raymond Moley is engaged with the immediate emergency with which gamblers in currencies and commodities have conference.

LOS ANGELES, July 2. -- At nearly four miles a minute, James R. Wedell, aircraft designer and racing pilot of Patterson, La., lapped the entire field here today and won the feature race of the second day of the national air races.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 2. -- Less than forty-eight hours after arriving from abroad, the combined Oxford-Cambridge tennis team launched its invasion of American courts today with a 5-4 victory in doubles over former Yale and Harvard internationalists on the turf of the Rockaway Hunting Club.
