The F.W. Woolworth Co. leased to Wil-Low Cafeterias, Inc., G.A. Lowenstein, president, the store and basement in 1.41517 St. Nicholas Av., from May 1, 1933, to Aug. 31, 1948, on terms contained in a separate unrecorded lease agreement.
Pitching of a superman variety that dazzled a crowd of 50,000 and bewildered the Cardinals gave the Giants two throbbing victories at the Polo Grounds yesterday over a stretch of six hours.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 2. -- The second day of play in the forty-first annual New Jersey men's championship tennis tournament today at the Montclair Athletic Club was featured by the advance of two seeded players, Lemoine Heuser, former Brown University football star, and John Nogrady of Astoria, into the fourth round.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July 2. -- The decline in the dollar continues in the foreign exchange market here, to the profit of grain exporters, though not necessarily of the farmers, most of whom were forced to sell their holdings long ago to obtain cash.

BERLIN, July 2. -- In a three-hour speech at Bad Reichenhall, Bavaria, within earshot of the Austrian border, Chancellor Hitler yesterday againn outlined the aims and significance of the National Socialist revolution in Germany. The occasion was the convention of the leaders or commanders of Herr Hitler's storm troops and picked guards, who had gathered there from the entire country.

A large increase in the number of "relief gardens" cultivated by the unemployed in New York State this year has made this activity an important part of the program to relieve distress among destitute families, the State Temporary Relief Administration announced yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 2. -- Play in the Hempstead Cups polo tournament, the Meadow Brook Club's annual twelve-goal handicap event, will get under way on Tuesday, with William Ziegler's Great Island quartet facing the Rockaway Whips.

AMSTERDAM, June 30. -- Heavy speculation against the guilder caused a renewal of rumors concerning a possible departure of Holland from the gold standard, but the government and the management of the Netherlands Bank declared most decidedly that they had no intention of abandoning gold.
The Fox Film Corporation will produce fifty-four feature pictures and 156 shorts besides the regular semi-weekly issues of Fox Movie-tone News during the new 1933-34 season.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 2. -- Revolt was in the air over ancient St. Andrews tonight on the eve of the British open golf championship because the historic links have been fenced in and an admission charge of a half-crown will be levied on every person watching play this week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whether the Indian head-hunters of South America are savage or tame and whether their unexplored wilderness is dangerous or safe seem to be the subjects of some talk -- talk in the newspapers. As one who spent several years among these little-known people, I can perhaps clarify the current rumors of tame Indians and safe jungles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At this time, when many lack the actual necessities of life, it is natural to feel that purely artistic and intelectual endeavors -- colleges and universities, books and scholarly journal orchestra and opera, museums of science and museums of art -- should be pushed aside in favor of unemployment relief hospitals and all those activities which minister to urgent physical needs.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- Sensationally bullish crop reports on all grains for a good part of the leading surplus-producing countries of the world, combined with continued buying by the public which has been most successful in its operations in the last month or more, are expected to carry prices higher.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- President Roosevelt will get a picture of the progress of the domestic recovery program and its realtion to stabilization of the currency at a conference with Cabinet and other officials aboard the cruiser Indianapolis when she arrives at Annapolis tomorrow.
The American Foundation announced yesterday the formation of a committee to determine what recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States would mean to the American business man.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- President Roosevelt's order that 250,000 men be placed in forest conservation camps by July 1 and additional recruits enrolled to make the total available 274,375 has been carried out to the letter, Robert Fechner, director of the emergency conservation work, said today in a report to the President.

LONDON, July 2. -- This has been far from a day of rest for the statesmen of the principal powers participating in the World Economic Conference. It has been a day devoted to the exchange of views, to the discussion of possible steps to be taken, to explanations and, it must be confessed, to more or less guarded recriminations.

The season's greatest thrill came to 17,000 fane at Ebbets Field in the dusk of a long afternoon yesterday when Sefior Alfonso Lopez stole home in the ninth inning of the second game with the winning run for the joyous completion of a double victory over the Cubs.

Mayor O'Brien and his associates on the Board of Estimate will try this week to complete the public works program for which Federal aid is to be sought under the National Recovery Act. The executive sessions at which the program has been discussed and analyzed will probably be resumed on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- High temperatures and lack of moisture at critical growing periods have damaged all feed crops in virtually every important section of the country, particularly through the Middle West, Northwest and Southwest.

DAIREN, Manchuria, July 2. -- Walter Miller, a German, and Arthur Gautschi, a Swiss, were jailed tonight by the Dairen police as missing members of a quintet of pirates who raided the steamer Chengan, killing the captain and his wife, the Russian mate and seven Chinese members of the crew.

The Summer theatre season gets under way in earnest this week. In several score rural and urban communities the holiday players will be giving new plays and old. By tomorrow night most of the companies will have started their schedules, for only a few begin after Independence Day.

SYDNEY, Australia, July 2 (AP). -- Approval in principle with reservations of the restriction of wheat exports has been given by a meeting of Australian States with the Federal Government, it was announced today in a statement issued by J.G. Latham, Minister of Industry.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 2. -- That Miss Joan McSheehy will be an important factor in the nationals later this month was proved to the satisfaction of 7,000 spectators today as the Women's Swimming Association star captured her second title in as many days.

The third British expedition to climb Mount Everest, led by HUGH RUTTLEDGE, was better organized than the enterprises of 1922 and 1924, but it was unable to carry the assault on the last one thousand feet, which cost MALLORY and IRVINE their lives nine years ago.

BERLIN, July 2. -- Details of the first annual budget decreed by the Hitler government of "national revolution" without consultation with the Reichstag have now been published in the Official Gazette. Income and expenditures are balanced at 5,900,000,000 marks [about $1,796,550,000 at current exchange].

If any strong nation refuses to join with genuine sincerity in these concerted efforts for political and economic peace, progress can be obstructed and ultimately blocked. In such event the civilized world, seeking both forms of peace, will know where the responsibility for failure lies.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES and its representative, Mr. Laurence, well deserve praise for the splendid reporting of the addresses of scientists at the Chicago meeting. On that score I agree with Professor Bartlett of Hobart College. But his comment on "epoch-making" contributions seems a little preliminary.
Charles B. Cochran of London and Arch Selwyn, theatrical producers, have become associate producers for the Fox Film Corporation, Sidney R. Kent, president of the corporation, announced yesterday.

This is the season of the year when the angler has his greatest choice. He can get fresh water fishing and take any species and still be within the law. He can turn to the salt water and find almost any species.

LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, July 2. -- Planes of General Italo Balbo's Italian air fleet gave spectators a thrill when they grazed the treetops in landing here today. Some had narrow escapes from crashing, but all were finally moored without mishap.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Representative Snell's attack a week ago on the Roosevelt administration and on the record of the special session of Congress was denounced today by Postmaster General Farley as a "ruthless and reckless exhibition of petty partisan politics."

The philosophy of the late John W. Burgess must underlie all efforts to solve the world's problems, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declares in a foreword to a revised edition of Professor Burgess's work on "Political Science and Comparative Constitutional Law," just published by the Columbia University Press.

PRESTONBURG, Ky., July 2 (AP). -- An election gun fight at the head of Prater Creek was ranked as Kentucky's worst shooting in recent years today when the death toll mounted to five, with three wounded, one critically.

The fantastic but true story of some years in the life of Robert Clairmont, who enlivened Greenwich Village and others parts of the city with some record openhanded spending in the big years of the bull market, is told by his friend Tom Boggs in "Millionaire Playboy," a rather impressionistic biography just published by Vanguard.

PITTSBURGH, July 2. -- As the end of the second quarter of the year approached, there was a last-moment naming of prices for various steel products to apply to the new period. Producers had delayed their decisions, awaiting more definite information from Washington, but realized the position in which they would be on July 1 if they had no prices to quote, as all contracts and understandings terminated on June 30.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The longevity of annuitants as a reason for increasing the cost of life insurance annuities is plausible but not substantial, for, although it is traditionally true that "annuitants live long," the expectation of life by those of an age most benefited by buying annuities has not latterly increased, according to life insurance statistics.

CLEVELAND, July 2. - The Yankees brought their road trip to a successful close at the Municipal Stadium today, triumphing over the Indians in the final encounter of the series, 7 to 3, thus cutting the idle Senators' lead to half a game.

Creation of a city housing agency to handle the construction of low-priced model tenements was urged on Mayor O'Brien in a letter sent to him by the Public Housing Conference, 112 East Nineteenth Street. The letter, made public yesterday, was signed by Miss Helen Alfred, secretary, and suggested Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch, Edward T. Devine, William Hodson and Herbert Bayard Swope as suitable members of such an agency.

A new issue of $700,000 Town of Stamford, Conn., 4.70 per cent funding bonds, due serially from July 1, 1935 to 1948, will be placed on the market today by a syndicate comprising Roosevelt Son, Blyth Co. Inc., Dewey, Bacon Co., and G.L. Austin Co., of Hartford.

LONDON, July 1. -- The real drift of purpose of the international economic conference is still as obscure as ever. Without sound money assured, the financial district here feels that little progress is to be expected. Hence the anxiety of France and other European gold countries that their currencies be supported.

"Let's not talk politics," said jovial Mayor O'BRIEN to the City Hall reporters, after announcing that he would seek another term. He implied that he must give all his thought, and so must everybody else, to getting the city out of its immense and baffling difficulties, financial and other.

CHICAGO, July 2. -- A private estimate of the oats crop for the United States this year is 750,000,000 bushels, and some other returns said to be lower. This estimate places the crop at the lowest since 1898 when the production was 731,000,000 bushels.

PARIS, July 1. -- This week's bank return shows an increase of 64,000,000 francs in its gold reserve, representing the difference between gold sent to London and gold arriving from Holland and Switzerland. Since March 31, the reserve has increased 836,000,000 francs and now totals 81,244,000,000 whereas note circulation totals 82,590,000,000.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The statement made by Municipal Court Justice Pette to the effect that the game of golf originated in Scotland is quite correct. It did.

PARIS, July 2. -- President Albert Lebrun said today in a speech at Besancon that stability of money was "imperiously necessary" and that talk of tariff adjustments without this stability was "pure Utopia." He added that it was not certain that price rises would result from "those artificial measures which some recommend."

ROGERS HORNSBY, a recent visitor at the Polo Grounds, came to Harlem with something of a record as a pinch-hitter for Gabby Street's clattering Cardinals. In seven consecutive trips to the plate when he was nominated to awing for somebody else he knocked out a homer, two doubles and three singles and drew one base on balls.
CHICAGO, July 2. -- Damage estimated at $1,000,000 was done by a freak hail and windstorm which struck the Chicago area early today.
CHICAGO, July 2. -- A demand for $75,000 ransom for the release of John (Jake the Barber) Factor was telephoned late today to the kidnapped broker's 19-year-old son, Jerome.

LOS ANGELES, July 2. -- The "house of happiness" of Douglas Fairbanks and Mary Pickford has fallen and separation of the two famous motion picture stars is contemplated. Tearfully Miss Pickford confirmed today rumors of the separation, with the announcement the Pickfair Beverley Hills mansion that has been a show place of the film world for many years, is for sale.

LONDON, July 2. -- Charles Rist, honorary vice governor of the Bank of France and acting head of the French delegation at the World Economic Conference here in the absence of Georges Bonnet, was interviewed by William Hard in a radio broadcast to the United States tonight over the National Broadcasting Company network.

An extensive Summer program in many Eastern resorts favored by members of society has been arranged in the interests of the National Charity Air Pageant, which is to be held on Oct. 7 and 8 for the benefit of the Judson Health Centre and the Emergency Exchange Association.

WASHINGTON, July 2. -- Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, announced tonight that the directors of the corporation with the approval of President Roosevelt and Secretary of the Treasury Woodin had authorized loans to American exporters to finance the sale of from 60,000 to 80,000 bales of cotton for shipment to Russia.
Fifty detectives were working yesterday in Brooklyn, Manhattan and up-State trying to solve the mystery surrounding tie death of, Mrs. Alice Kenny Diamond, widow of Jack (Legs) Diamond.

The appointment of Captain Fritz Kruse as commodore of the Hamburg American Line fleet was announced yesterday. He is master of the flagship New York, and succeeds Captain Paul Wiehr who retired from active duty in June, under the line's regulation which fixes 60 as the active age limit of its masters.

As judged by the speculators (who are at present distinctly in the saddle) last week's succession of rapid up-and-down movements in stocks and commodities was inspired by the plunging-about of the dollar's international valuation. London cables, commenting earnestly on the "set and masked faces" of delegates at the conference, were broadcast on the Stock Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade.

NEW ORLEANS, July 2. -- There was more activity in the cotton market last week than in any like period in a long time. Not only was there a heavy volume of business, mostly buying orders and profittaking sales, but the price fluctuation was as much as 115 points.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 2. -- Weetamoe defeated Vanitie in a 31-mile race over a triangular course in Massachusetts Bay today for a cup offered by the Corinthian Yacht Club. Weetamoe won by 8 minutes and 11 seconds actual and 11 minutes and 50 seconds corrected time.

EASTVIEW, N.Y., July 2. -- Following elaborate plans developed over a two-week period, Arthur Palumbo, 27-year-old veteran of the "Vincent Coll gang, escaped today from an "escape-proof" solitary-confinement cell in the Westchester County penitentiary.

A review of legislation in the United States on old-age pensions, showing that twenty-five States now have such laws, was issued yesterday by the American Association for Social Security, Inc., of 22 East Seventeenth Street.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 2. -- A well-rounded Aknusti combination, riding with W. Averell Harriman, Jimmy Mills, and Elbridge and Bob Serry in that order, went into the final round of the Meadow Brook Club Cups Tournament today. Aknusti downed Earle W. Hopping"s Eastcott quartet by 9 to 5 on Cochran Field of the Meadow Brook Club in a semi-final match of the club's annual twenty-goal handicap tourney.

MEXICO, D.F., July 2. -- Francisco Ruiz and Alejo Garcia, convicted of killing Mrs. Rosalie Evans on Aug. 2, 1926, will be shot by a firing squad Thursday morning. They were to have been executed at dawn tomorrow, but an injunction was granted postponing the sentence for seventy-two hours.

Although lacking details of changes to be made in building trade practices in connection with the National Recovery Act, leaders in the building industry in this city and vicinity are confident that any proposed innovations in trade policy will be for the better.

LONGMIRE SPRINGS, RainIer National Park, July 3 (AP). -- Tranas-planted from the steaming pavements and crowded tenements to this vast, snow-choked stillness of the Pacific Northwest, hundreds of boys from the east side of New York City in the Civilian Conservation Corps camps here still are wondering what it is all about.

LONDON, July 3 -- "France has her currency; she will keep it and she has the means to defend it. Get that clear!" said Finance Minister Georges Bonnet of France on arriving in London late tonight for the meeting of the steering committee of the conference tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, July 3. -- Hoot Gibson, who rode to fame in pictures on a horse, took to an air-plane today in a special match race at the National Air Races and wound up in a hospital with concussion of the brain or a possible skull fracture received in a crash witnessed by 25,000 spectators.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Seeded stars mowed down members of the dark-horse brigade without even removing their wraps today as the big battle for the national clay courts singles tennis championship opened at the Chicago Town and Tennis Club.

MUNICH, July 3 -- The Nazi rulers of Bavaria are torn between two desires these days, the desire to complete the "totalism" of the National Socialist State and thus earn the commendation of Adolf Hitler and the desire to preserve Bavaria as the greatest tourist attraction in Germany, bringing relief to the suffering tourist industry.

LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Tuesday, July 4 (AP). -- Prospects for the Italian seapplane squadron starting the next leg ot its journey to Chicago today were remote with reports at midnight telling of continued unfavorable weather in the region of Iceland.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- How the Federal Government bore a large part of relief expenditures in the country in the first three months of 1933 is shown in reports made public today by the Federal Emergency Relief Administration.

CLEVELAND, July 8 (AP) -- A rumble in the ninth inning by Bad News Hale was bad news for Oral Hildebrand today, as the bobble ruined the Cleveland ace's chance of pitching his seventh shutout of the season. It did not stop the Indians from climbing into fourth place, however, with a 5-to-2 victory over the White Sox.

Sam Hellman, writer and humorist, came back from Paris on the Holland-America liner Volendam yesterday after living abroad for two years. He is hurrying anxiously back to Hollywood to steep his mind in the "American lingo," because it is his bread and meat, and two years in France has left him behind the times.
Blenheim today will have a chance to be the first horse in history to win twice in succession the historic Brooklyn Handicap, scheduled for its forty-fourth renewal at Aqueduct.
All live of the theatrical productions current along Broadway will hold special matinee performances this afternoon.

The ninety-third anniversary of Cunard Line will be observed today aboard all ships of the Cunard and Anchor Lines at sea. The program calls for patriotic music and group singing and the explosion of rockets at night. Cunarders at sea will include the Aquitanla, Berengarla, Mauretania, Franconia, Carinthia, Laconia, Transylvania and Caledonia.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- Recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States, an open question since the beginning of the present administration, came unmistakably to the fore today following establishment by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of credits up to $4,000,000 for financing cotton exports to Russia.

CLEVELAND, July 3. -- Delegates to the triennial convention of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers heard charges today that Alvanley Johnston, Grand Chief of their organization, negotiated the 10 per cent wage cut for railroad men throughout the country early in 1932 to aid banks by bolstering railroad securities.

Tha Kentucky Joint Stock Land Bank invited yesterday holders of its bonds to submit tenders for the sale to it of such bonds. The bank has authorized the Harris Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago to act as its agent to open sealed tenders at 10 A.M. July 15.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- A single code for the entire bituminous coal industry was said today by General Johnson to be the administration's standard.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 3 (AP) -- A square-jawed lawyer, Joseph B. Keenan, who believes some of his own profession have been drawn into racketeering, was preparing today to assume charge of the nation'a drive against organized crime.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 3. -- Many members of the Summer colony attended the first in a series of dinner dances which was held tonight at the Meadow Club. Long lines of colored lights silhouetted the clubhouse and the ground, and gardens were also illuminated.
BOSTON, July 3. -- Not even a 30 degree drop in the temperature had a cooling effect upon the Giants, who seem to be getting hotter with each succeeding hour.

The annual convention of the National Amateur Press Association got under way yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker, attended by more than sixty delegates representing the boys and girls throughout the country who write and publish newspapers and magazines for the pleasure of it. Their association was organized July 4, 1876.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Running a perfectly timed race over a heavy track at Arlington Park today. Red Roamer moved into the lead in the stretch in the Glenview Purse to win drawing away by a length and a half.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP). -- The tropical disturbance moving slowly across the Caribbean in the last few days is not expected by Weather Bureau officials to get within reaching distance of the Florida coast in the next twenty-four hours and, measured by its present size, is expected to affect only a small area if it should come inland later.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Optimism over the situation of the nation's schools dominated the gatherings here of teachers from all parts of the country today for the annual convention of the National Education Association.
Two young men whose canoe was overturned at midnight Sunday came ashore in the Bronx yesterday after a nine-hour battle against water, wind and darkness in Long Island Sound.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on June 28 shows decreases for the week of $140,000,000 in loans and investments, $82,000,000 in net dep and deposits and $24,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks, and increases of $70,000,000 in time deposits and $70,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Developments today in the "kidnapping" of Jake Factor caused questions as to whether the former Halsted Street barber was being held for ransom or was on his way to Central America to avoid extradition by Great Britain on a fraud charge.

A plan for readjustment of the capital of the Public Utility Holding Corporation of America and the change in name to General Investment Corporation will be submitted to stockholders at a special meeting in the Newark (N.J.) office on July 19, immediately after the annual meeting.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 3. -- Winner of two metropolitan championships in successive days, Miss Joan McSheehy sought her third triumph tonight in an A.A.U. handicap swimming meet. However, her efforts were frustrated by the Kompa sisters, the Misses Erna and Elizabeth, in a 100-yard back-stroke event.

Police Commissioner Bolan refused to comment yesterday on Governor Lehman's order directing all local authorities to enforce strictly the State Beer and Wine Law other than to say that New York City police have been enforcing the measure.

To encourage travel the New York Central Railroad announced yesterday that it would try to change tariffs to permit the checking of empty trunks. Removal of the regulation, which is in effect throughout the country, would aid commercial travelers and business men, the railroad contends.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- There appeared today to be no stopping the bull markets that have developed in grains, and despite the private crop estimates, which usually cause profit-taking, setbacks were only temporary.

MOSCOW, July 3 -- The news that the United States Reconstruction Finance Corporation will finance cotton exports to the Soviet Union will come as a surprise to the Soviet public. There had been no mention in the newspapers here that negotiations were even in progress and the news arrived too late for official comment today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A strict reading of the National Industrial Recovery Act and a perusal of the codes of fair competition published so far lead me to the conclusion that the act contains precious little, if any, of that phenomenon called social planning.
"How does it feel to be 100 years old? Well, it's not very nice," said William Henry Eves yesterday, with a wry smile.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Perry Belmont will sail on the Ile de France on Thursday. After a short stay in London they will proceed to Paris.

BERLIN, July 3 -- Negotiations for a concordat between the Vatican and the German Nazi government have progressed so far that the agreement has been virtually completed and there is hope here that it may be initialed at noon tomorrow.

OWEN YOUNG omitted one important factor in his description of the ideal rural school, which has become a reality in his own district school, No. 1 of Stark Township, New York. He did not mention his own part in making it possible. It was he who provided the new buildings in all or in large part, and perhaps took more than his taxpayer's share in meeting the expense of the better school.
Patriotic New Yorkers completed plans last night for this year's celebration of Independence Day.

ST. LOUIS, July 3 (AP). -- The Tigers went on a batting rampage today, garnering seventeen hits and defeating the Browns, 8 to 5, in the first game of the series. All three Brown pitchers -- Coffman. McDonald and Stiles -- were hit hard.
To the Editor of The New York Times; With extreme regret I have seen in this morning's TIMES that Justice Hoyt has determined to retire at the close of his present term.

Heavy buying yesterday on the Stock Exchange advanced bonds of domestic corporations 1 to 5 points, of many leading foreign issues 1 to 3 points, and of most United States Government issues 1/32 to 8/32 point. Scores of domestic corporation bonds touched their best prices for the year and in many instances closing levels represented the highest for the day.

Last night's concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in the Lewisohn Stadium finally broke the hoodoo of bad weather that had kept the orchestra indoors for three successive nights, and Willem Van Hoogstraten conducted in the Stadium instead of in the Great Hall of City College.
The following is the text of the audit made by Price, Waterhouse Co. of New York City's accounts for 1932:
NEWPORT, R.I., July 3. -- A dinner was given this evening by Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Huntington at their home for about fifty guests.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 3 (AP). -- Russell Boardman, Boston sports-man and aviator injured during the transcontinental air race, died early this morning at City Hospital.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 3. -- Tonight's main event in East Hampton was the opening dinner dance at the Devon Yacht Club, which was attended by most of the Summer residents and their house guests.

BERLIN, Tuesday, July 4 -- Germans who have been most skeptical of the success of the London conference view what are now called its "death agonies" with mixed feelings. On the one hand, they regard the conflict between the gold-standard and paper-currency countries with sarcastic satisfaction, because they see the end of any united front againat Germany; on the other hand they are apprehensive of the results of a failure.
Nationalism was described as an "obstacle to progress," yesterday by the Prince of Wales in an address rebroadcast from London in the United States and Canada by the National Broadcasting Company.

Mayor John P. O'Brien will make his first address before a political gathering since he announced his candidacy for re-alection when he addresses the braves of Tammany Hall at the annual July Fourth exercises this morning.

President Roosevelt's emphatic rejection of all suggestions that a temporary stabilization of the currencies now be undertaken interested the markets greatly yesterday, whether or not this was the influence behind the broad advance in securities and commodities.

Sugar, coffee and cocoa futures moved higher in yesterday's trading, and wool tops were unchanged. These were the only commodities traded in local markets. Trading on the Commodity Exchange was suspended as the constituents moved to their new floor.

The United States Flag Association, which previously had stated that it intended to conduct an offensive against crime and racketeering, announced yesterday in formal statements distributed from its headquarters in Washington that Independence Day would open one phase of the campaign.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 3 -- Having enunciated a policy of not entering into an international currency stabilization pact, President Roosevelt, aboard the cruiser Indianapolis at anchor off Annapolis, today turned his attention to pushing ahead his domestic program to rebuild American prosperity.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 3 -- President Roosevelt's suspension of gold payments and the inflation features of his industrial recovery program were denounced today by Edmund Platt, vice president of the Marine Midland Corporation of New York, and Dr. H. Parker Willis, financial expert, of Columbia University, at the opening session of the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

A temporary stoppage of about 50,000 men's clothing workers will take place on Thursday in New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore and New Jersey, it was announced yesterday by Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.

Six men and a woman aboard a disabled sloop off the Delaware Capes were picked up at 1 P.M. yesterday by the oil tanker Yorba Linda. Three hours later the sloop filled with water and sank, according to a message last night to the tanker's owners, the Standard Vacuum Transportation Company, 26 Broadway.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 3 -- The qualifying rounds of the British open championship began at St. Andrews today in most unusual weather. The course lies sweltering under a heat wave which ought to suit American golfers.

President Roosevelt's message to the economic conference construed by the markets as a strongly inflationary declaration, brought about a further fall in the dollar yesterday to a new low point since the suspension of the gold standard here.

CLEVELAND, July 3 (AP). -- Shaking off stiff opposition, Pronto Worthy, bay son of Allworthy, owned by W.R. Hayes of Duquoin, Ill., and driven by Harry Fitzpatrick, won the H.K. Devereaux Memorial Trot, the feature of the Grand Circuit card at North Randall today.

With the dedication today of a national historical park, to include Jockey Hollow, the encampment of 12,000 Revolutionary soldiers in the Winter of 1779-80, the Fort Nonsense earthworks and the Ford mansion where WASHINGTON made his headquarters, Morristown, then a village of 300 inhabitants, will receive recognition as a region of great strartegical importance in the War for Independence.
BERLIN, July 3 -- The Reichsbank's statement as of June 30 shows the following changes, in reichsmarks:

HAVANA, July 3. -- The hurricane that has been ravaging shipping on the Carlbbean Sea for the past three days struck Cuba around 1 o'clock this morning and is known to have taken at least seven lives, in addition to thirteen last week in Trinidad.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 4 -- President Roosevelt, in the opinion of The London Times, "believes in plain speaking." In an editorial this morning headed "Two Views on Stability" it says the Continental view is that the first object should be to keep exchanges steady, preferably by an immediate return to gold.

NEWARK, N.J., July 3. -- Ewing Y. Mitchell, new Assistant Secretary of Commerce, was a passenger today at Newark Airport aboard a department plane when Pilot E.A. Cuttrell brought it in to a landing without once glancing at the ground. The plans was flown along the "bent" radio beam developed by engineers during the last two years under Colonel Clarence M. Young, the former Assistant Secretary.

With four of its witnesses already murdered, the Federal Government declined yesterday to furnish Irving Wexler, former big-time beer runner known as Waxey Gordon, with a bill of particulars, amplifying charges made against him for income tax evasion.
Sea bass along the New Jersey shore seem to be attracting chief attention from the salt water anglers. There is good reason for this. The fish are abundant and they provide excellent sport.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Every reasonable dry must know by this time that the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment is inevitable. What possible advantage can come from attempting to delay repeal?

WARSAW, July 3. -- The new Nazi President of the Danzig Free City Senate, Dr. Rauschning, and Minister of the Interior Kreiser received a cordial welcome in War-saw today when they paid a State visit to the Polish Government.

Observance of the Independence Day holiday will bring a complete cessation of activity in all financial centres today. The banks, as well as the various commodity and security exchanges, will be closed. Business will be resumed as usual tomorrow.

Three police lieutenants, seeking to dislodge four others from places, which, because of World War disabilities, the four occupy at the head of the captains' list, won an alternative mandamus yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Phoenix Ingraham.

LONDON, July 3 -- No international gathering has ever met a harder blow than that dealt by President Roosevelt to the World Economic Conference today. His firm "no" to the currency proposals made to him has staggered the conference.

LONDON, July 3 -- President Roosevelt's message to the World Economic Conference was scanned by the delegations of eight Central European countries today with the apprehension of neutrals reading a mobilization notice.

With automobile production reaching the highest levels in more than two years, the adjusted index has advanced to 60.7 for the week ended July 1, as compared with 57.2 for the previous week and 38.1 for the corresponding week of last year.

To the Editor af The New York Times: "To teach Individuals to act together and to think for themselves" -- the aim of education according to a prominent educator of today -- was the bit at philosophy that came to my mind as I read the statement of the altered conception of the Y.W.C.A. purpose as related In THE TIMES recently.

Pending a hearing by the Interstate Commerce Commission on the reorganization plan of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway the company has extended the time for deposits under the plan to Aug. 31. By that time it is expected that corporate and commission action necessary to the carrying out of the proposal will have been taken.

LOS ANGELES, July 3 (AP) -- Separated by thousands of miles, Mary Pickford, "somewhere in Southern California," and Douglas Fairbanks in London, were equally silent tonight after the actress' announcement that they contemplated living apart and possibly being divorced.
A fire that followed an explosion of an ammonia tank damaged the plant of the Michel Brewing Corporation, Third and Bond Streets, Brooklyn, yesterday and caused injuries to three persons.

LONDON, July 3. -- A pact between Russia and her neighbors, defining aggression, was signed at the Soviet Embassy here today by the plenipotentiaries of Afghanistan, Estonia, Latvia, Persia, Poland, Rumania and Turkey.
Editorial comment from some representative American newspapers on President Roosevelt's message on currency stabilization to the World Economic Conference follows:
ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 3 -- In an unusual Cabinet session aboard the cruiser Indianapolis in Chesapeake Bay today the sailor President ordered the opening of a national back-to-work movement.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- New laws have piled such a heap of work upon President Roosevelt's desk as could hardly have accumulated in a similar period during any other administration in this generation.

LONDON, July 3 -- No one here seemed quite so surprised, not to say dumfounded, by President Roosevelt's message rejecting the gold bloc's declaration as those in his own delegation who thought they were among the men closest to him.

A little man who carried his stick with a swagger and spoke his words as if they bored him, emerged yesterday from the Federal House of Detention, where he had just completed a sentence of ninety days for immigration fraud.

BERLIN, July 3. -- Gottfried Feder, economic expert of the National Socialist party, who, as newly appointed State Secretary of the Reich Ministry of Economy, supposedly dominates the Hitler government's business policies following the fall of Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, outlined his program in a speech at the Mining Academy of Claustal-Zellerfeld in the Province of Hanover today.

PARIS, July 3 -- President Roosevelt's statement to the London Conference was read in Paris this afternoon with a kind of gasping wonder. In the Chamber of Deputies, representatives of all parties seized on the afternoon editions of the newspapers and, after reading the text once, read it twice and then said they would have to study it before they could venture any opinions.

The rejection by President Roosevelt, in his message to the Economic Conference, of plans for a temporary stabilizing of currencies provided the background yesterday for a sharp pre-holiday advance in stocks and commodities to the highest levels at the year.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 3 -- Brilliant 71s by young George T. Dunlap Jr. and Horton Smith and a 72 by Billy Burke today featured the first day of qualifying play in the British open golf championship. American players swept across the parched surfaces of historic St. Andrews to place six low scorers among the first eleven.

The recent course of our trade with Russia explains the loans to be made by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for the purpose of financing a large sale of American cotton. From 1929 to 1931 Russia stood sixth in importance among European markets for our goods.

The National Safety Council, by its report for last year, has completed twenty years of service. During that time 1,720,857 deaths from accidents occurred in the United States. Of the total, 361,741 were caused by the operation of motor vehicles; otherwise classified, 1,359,116.

New York City at the end of 1932 had made authorizations and commitments amounting to $187,184,213 which it had no money to meet, according to the audit made by Price, Waterhouse Co., released yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 3. -- Nassau County acted today upon a plan to hold in escrow rents paid by the Home Reliel Bureau to landlords who have not paid their taxes. It is planned to apply the rents to tax arrears. The proposal was made in a resolution submitted to Supervisor J. Russell Sprague at a meeting of the County Board here.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) - Joseph B. Keenan, a Cleveland lawyer, was chosen today as an Assistant Attorney General to direct the government's efforts to quell the activities of organized crime. He said he intended to go after "gangland leadership" first.

New Yorkers, who were sweltering last Saturday with the temperature at 90 degrees, appeared yesterday in topcoats as the erratic mercury went to the other extreme. The day's minimum, 55, at 10 A.M., set a new low mark for July 3 and was only one degree above the coolest July day in the Weather Bureau's history.

DENNIS, Mass., July 3 -- With a first performance which would have aroused any mid-season Broadway audience to unwonted enthusiasm, John Golden opened the Summer season tonight in Raymond Moore's Cape Playhouse with his production of "The Divine Drudge," adaptation by him and by Vicki Baum of the latter's successful novel, "And Life Goes On."

LONDON, July 3 -- A huge steel merger, planned with the idea of consolidating and reconstituting the iron and steel industry throughout the rich coal area on the northeast coast of England, was announced tonight. The companies concerned are Dorman, Long Co., the South Durham Steel and Iron Company and the Cargo Fleet Iron Company.

LONDON, July 3 -- The "official text" of the proposed Joint declaration which President Roosevelt rejected was issued tonight after a meeting between Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and representatives of the gold bloc.

LONDON, July 3 -- Several subcommittees of the Economic Conference held scheduled meetings today and debated the subjects assigned to them; but nothing developed at these sessions to arouse new hopes in any field of the conference.
TOKIO, July 3. -- The Soviet-Manchukuo conference for the sale by Russia of the Chinese Eastern Railway revealed widely divergent standpoints today in a seven-hour session.

ROSLYN, L.I., July 3. -- Miss Audrey Phipps, daughter of Mr and Mrs. Henry Carnegie Phippa of 1 Sutton Place, New York, and Spring Hill, Roslyn, was introduced to society tonight at a supper dance given by her parents at their country home for about 1,000 members of the debutante set of the North Shore colonies, their house guests from out of town and the younger married couples.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Automatic control of commodity prices through a system of public quotations patterned after the stock market is being seriously considered for solution of the price-fixing problem under President Roosevelt's recovery program.

Monday, July 3, 1933. Money market was quiet at the opening of business in the new week and quotations for all classes remained unchanged. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent and Street trades 3/4.
GLEN COVE, L.I., July 3 -- Two of the first ten ranking players of the country met with defeat today In the semi-finals of the invitation grass court tennis tournament of the Nassau Country Club.

Shocking Dollar Variation. A peculiarly flagrant example of the injustice, hardship and confusion produced by a dollar whose purchasing power fluctuates from generation to generation is cited by Professor MANASSEH K. YARDSTICK in his "History of Money and Other Trifles."

LONDON, July 3 -- There it no doubt that President Roosevelt's statement today came as a bitter disappointment to the British delegation at the World Economic Conferance and the whole British Government. No attempt was made to disguise that fact at a conference at 10 Downing Street tonight at which a spokesman explained the British position to the British press.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 3. -- The annual encampment of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States here today called upon President Roosevelt and Congress to plug the loopholes "by which Morgan, Kahn and others slipped through the income tax law."

LONDON, Tuesday, July 4 -- Adjournment of the World Economic Conference, Swiss and Dutch quarters said early today, will be moved this forenoon at the steering committee meeting by Hendryk Colijn, Premier of Holland.

Holiday Cuts Buyers' Total. Due to the holiday, the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended Tuesday showed a drop in comparison with the figures for the preceding week but remained slightly above the total reached in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

PARIS, July 3. -- With the dollar oscillating between 19.37 and 19.20 francs and the pound sterling between 86.20 and 85.96, and the future beyond the possibility of calculation, there was a rush on the Paris Bourse today by professional speculators, followed in small degree by the public, to buy industrial and bank stocks.

WASHINGTON, July 3. -- As a result of the economy program, Army Reserve flying this Summer will be limited to 8,500 hours for all reservists, instead of the 21,000 flying hours allocated to this service last Summer.

"To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been reading daily in THE TIMES the articles recording the latest theories and discoveries of various members of sociological research and scientific societies and associations in Chicago. Having a somewhat limited intelligence, I should be glad to be corrected if the following impressions I have received from some of the articles, and my subsequent comments on them, are wrong:
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- One American industry not sharing in the business upturn but finding itself worse off with every price advance is gold mining.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced sharply about $2 a bale and made new high marks for the season in the early trading yesterday. With all speculative markets continuing to advance, cotton also moved higher in discounting dollar depreciation.

RYE, N.Y., July 3. -- While wave after wave raced foaming at hull and deck, the yachts of the Long Island Sound fleet today sailed through the championship regatta of the American Yacht Club, which was lts golden anniversary event.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, July 3 (AP). -- Ten men, marooned on a Jetty at Cedar Point for more than twenty-four hours, were rescued late today by Coast Guardsmen after a tense battle with wind-lashed Lake Erie.
LONDON, July 3 -- The news of the World Economic Conference from day to day has been not the chronicle of events but the picture of moods. Just now the mood is predominantly gloomy.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Movements of vessels follow, alt dates are July 1, unless otherwise specified:
PRINCETON, N.J., July 3. -- Princeton sports teams won 83 of the 139 events on their Spring schedules to attain a percentage of 601, statistics made public today reveal.

ROME, July 3 -- A concordat between the Vatican and the German Government has baen virtually concluded and it may be initialed tomorrow. It is understood that of the thirty-two articles in the pact, agreement has been reached on twenty-seven of them and that no great difficulties are presented in the other five.
LOS ANGELES, July 3. -- The honors of the third day here at the 1933 National Air Races were awarded the visiting military forces of the army, navy and Marines.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 -- In the quarter-final match against Henri Cochet, Lester Stoefen lost because he was not as accurate as his opponent and because he was out of position needlessly so many times.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Final approval of the first trade marketing agreements submitted under the Agricultural Adjustment Act will be withheld pending decision by Secretary Wallace and the administrators on wages and hours of work to be prescribed.

After two of its founders had been questioned yesterday by Joseph P. Martin, Assistant District Attorney, The Brewers Outlook, a monthly publication, started last May at 129 Lafayette Street, went out of business.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP). -- Frank A Chase of Miami, Fla., was appointed today director of the field service of the Home Loan Bank board with instructions to organize Federal savings and loan associations throughout the country and to "encourage thrift and home financing."

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 3. -- Deeds to property valued at more than $1,000,000 will be presented here tomorrow to Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes at the dedication of Morristown National Historical Park. A parade will pass in review before the home of Mayor Clyde Potts, who was active in bringing about the establishment of the park.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Jewish Day at the Century of Progress Exposition reached its climax tonight when 125,000 men, women and children crowded Soldier Field to witness a Biblical pageant, "The Romance of a People."

American shipping men viewed yesterday the action of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in granting a loan of $4,000,000 for the purchase of American cotton by Russia as the opening of a new source of traffic for American vessels. Reports from Washington and London, which indicated that trade with Russia may be extended even further, also helped create hopes for cargoes.

Twenty-three New York business men, including cotton and rubber exchange brokers, telegraphed congratulations yesterday to President Roosevelt for his stand on currency stabilization. The telegram said:
RENO, Nev., July 3 -- A decree of divorce was granted today to Joseph J. Seltzer of Woodmere, L.I., in his suit against Theresa F. Seltzer, whom he married in Brooklyn in 1920.
LONDON, July 3 -- The text of President Roosevelt's, message to the World Economic Conference today follows:

WITH flags flying -- and weather permitting -- the ball clubs will parade past a notable "given point" today. The jolly Fourth of July is generally accepted as the day that sees the nomination of the world's series contenders for the following Autumn. The teams in the lead when firecrackers are being tossed around are the teams that are supposed to rumble ahead into the big series.

LONDON, July 3 -- Fresh rejection by the United States of any plan for limiting the depreciation of the dollar was followed today by, a new outburst of speculative selling of United States currency in the money market here. The closing rate of $4.43 3/4 to the pound showed a rise of 12 1/4 cents from the closs on Saturday.

BERLIN, July 3. -- The Boerse opened the week with a continuation of the downward tendency which assumed increasing momentum. Business was dull owing to scarcity of buyers. Sales originating in Hamburg supposedly for Dutch account caused losses up to 4 per cent, with Niederlausitz Coal dropping 7 per cent.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 3. -- Dr. Reginald S. Woods, co-manager of the Oxford-Cambridge track team which will close its practice at Yale University tomorrow, said today that the squad is the strongest ever sent to the United States by the two English universities.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July3. -- The sixth Summer season at the Berkshire Playhouse in Stockbrldge opened tonight with the presentation of St. John Ervine's three-act comedy, "The First Mrs. Fraser." Katherine Grey had the leading role.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES quotes Herr Goebbels, speaking at the "mass wedding" of forty-seven Nazi couples, to the effect that "there never in all the world was a mass wedding to equal today's."

AMONG the good hitters of other years who are far down in the batting averages this season are Vosmik of Cleveland, Reynolds of the St. Louis Browns, Combs of the Yankees, Smead Jolley of the Red Sox. Mickey Cochrane of the Athletics, Hack Wilson of the Dodgers, Woody English of the Cubs, Lefty O'Doul of the Giants and Waner, Waner and Lindstrom of the Pirates.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Preparing to wind up its inquiry into the affairs of Kuhn, Loeb Co. on Thursday and adjourn until October the Senate Banking and Currency Committee has been asked to investigate a phase of the Detroit banking situation regarding Henry Ford.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 4. -- Branding international conferences as "barren," Bainbridge Colby, who was for a time Secretary of State in the Wilson Cabinet, urged rehabilitation along national lines as the solution of the world's ills, when he addressed a Fourth of July audience at the Chautauqua conference tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4. -- Politicians who serve two masters, gangsters on one hand and their constituents on the other, were assailed today at a municipal Fourth of July service in Old Pine Street Presbyterian Church.

Addressing the annual Fourth of July gathering at Tammany Hall yesterday, United States Senator Royal S. Copeland hailed President Roosevelt's message to the London conference as one that "should give heart to every American."

Shops and exhibits representing the major business activities of Italy will be established in the Italian Building in Rockefeller Center as the result of reservations just made for nearly one-third of the entire space of the nine floors in the building, soon to be erected at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

BUENOS AIRES, July 4. -- Because the Argentine Government refused to permit an exhibition of the body of the deposed President Hipolito Irigoyen in a public place, his family declined tonight to accept proffered official funeral honors.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 4. -- Anton F. von Bernuth, Edward G. Tarangioli, John Nogrady, Lorenzo Nodarse, a member of the Cuban Davis Cup team, and R.J. Sommer, were in the quarter-finals of the forty-first annual New Jersey State men's singles tennis championship as play closed today at the Montclair Athletic Club.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 4. -- Mr. and Mrs, John Thomas Smith gave a large reception this afternoon at their estate for Mr. and Mrs. Robert Sargent Shriver, who are passing the holiday with them.
LONDON, July 4. -- The British dominions today unanimously voted in favor of continuing the Economic Conference.

LONDON, Wednesday, July 5. -- After one of the most turbulent days in their experience, Assistant Secretary of State Moley and other members of the United States delegation to the World Economic Conference sat up most of the night waiting and hoping for some fresh instructions that would soften the effect of President Roosevelt's statement on Monday.

BERLIN, July 4. -- Contempt for "personal, political and business espionage" and a determination to relieve business and industry of the fear engendered by such practices are expressed by Chancellor Hitler in a communication to Herr Loeper, Federal Governor for the State of Brunswick.

The Gelsenkirchen Mining Corporation of Germany announced yesterday an offer to holders of its six-year 6 per cent secured notes, due on March 1, 1934, in connection with the proposed merger of the corporation with the United Steel Works Corporation, Phoenix Corporation and Van der Zypen Wissener Corporation.

LOS ANGELES, July 4. -- Before a holiday crowd of more than 50,000 Colonel Roscoe Turner piloted his Wedell-Williams ship through the 100-mile race for the Thompson Trophy here today to win handily with an average speed of 241.05 miles an hour.

Freight traffic in the third quarter of 1933 will be about 10 per cent above the total for the same period last year, according to estimates by the Shippers' Regional Advisory Boards. The estimates, which are the first to forecast an increase since the last quarter of 1929, were based on reports from about 20,000 shippers.
After having been closed yesterday for Independence Day, the financial and commodity markets as well as banks and business organizations generally will resume business as usual this morning.

New public financing in the United States in the first six months of 1933, excluding domestic and Canadian municipal flotations, aggregated only $125,560,000, according to a compilation announced yesterday by Otto P. Schwarzschild, president of the National Statistical Service, Inc.
Newark made a clean sweep of the two-game series with Jersey City at West Side Park, Jersey City yesterday, 6 to 4 and 4 to 2. It marked the seventh and eighth straight defeats for the home team.
NEW YORK. The Earl of Chichester, attache of the British Embassy at Washington, is at the Ambassador.

RUTLAND, Vt., July 4. -- One hundred members of the Windham-Windsor Boy Scout Councils paid a tribute to their former chief, Calvin Coolidge, today by making a pilgrimage to his birthplace in Plymouth Notch and decorating his grave in the village cemetery.

LATONTA, Ky., July 4 (AP). -- Cousin Jo, long shot from the stable of Charles Nuckels, passed the tiring favorite and second choice today and won the $2,500 added Independence Handicap, feature of the Latonia card.

Far-flung but comparatively quiet celebrations marked the observance yesterday of the 157th anniversary of Independence Day. The unusually low temperature threw a chilly atmosphere over the festivities here and in many other parts of the country.
WINDSOR, Conn., July 4. -- Close finishes and a large attendance featured the opening of the Bay State Circuit light harness races at Sage Park today. Favorites won all three events.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- An indication that the States intend to cooperate in the national recovery program by harmonizing their laws to the Industrial Act was hailed today by General Johnson, its administrator, as a bright spot in the economic outlook.

President ROOSEVELT has frequently said, and once RAMSAY MACDONALD said it jointly with him, that efforts for domestic recovery should be made at the same time by all the nations. Mr. ROOSEVELT used to speak of this concerted program as a "supplement" to currency and tariff agreements on van International basis, but lately has reversed the order of procedure.

LONDON, July 4 (Canadian Press). -- Lively exchanges in the Congress of the Empire Chambers of Commerce took place today in discussion of increasing empire preferential trade when a British delegate asserted Canada had not reduced her tariff barriers to the same extent the United Kingdom had.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- An attack on the Veterans' Administration was made here tonight by Louis Johnson, National Commander of the American Legion, in a talk carried by the National Broadcasting Company.

VIENNA, July 4. -- Chancellor Dollfuss, in an address tonight at a dinner of the Union of Foreign Correspondents, said he hoped they had received, the impression during recent months that a new Austrian patriotism had been born.

The eleventh annual Independence Day celebration on the site of the Old Stone House of Gowanus, Third Street and Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday, took on added significance because of the re-discovery of this historic landmark in excavations last May.
FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., July 4 (AP). -- In the same packet with a prosaic request for more beans and coffee, scientists announced today the discovery of an Indian cliff house hidden for centuries.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP). -- An 18-year-old Texan, George Ball of El Paso, dropped a giant firecracker into the national clay courts tennis championship today that blew one of the seeded stars, Jay Cohn, Chicago city champion, out of the tournament picture.

STRABO, who, writing in the first century of the Christian era, has just come to the end of his "Geography" in the Loeb series, makes a brief summary of the Roman, Empire, "since the Romans occupy the best and best-known "portions of our inhabited world." Its continents, STRABO states, were "three in number," the "fourth land," as the New World was first called, being still a thousand years beyond his ken.

Holders of Public Utility Holding Corporation of America 7 per cent notes due on April 15, 1935, have been invited to submit tenders to the Chemical Bank and Trust Company not later than noon on July 15 for the sale to it of sufficient notes to exhaust the sum of $100,000.
CHICAGO, July 4 (AP). -- Guy Bush pitched the Cubs to a 4-to-0 victory over Cincinnati in the first game today, but the Reds came back in the second number to pound out an 8-to-1 decision.

LONDON, July 4. -- The impression has become strong in the Russian delegation to the Economic Conference that recognition of the Soviet Government by the United States is definitely near. In fact, after years of waiting there is apparently a firm belief in the highest Russian quarters that the establishment of diplomatic relations with their government by the United States is only a question of a few months, and perhaps less than that.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The remarks of the Bight Rev. William Moreland Hall, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Sacramento, as delivered from the pulpit of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday and reported in THE TIMES, must be of profound interest to readers in the Spanish-founded countries south of the Rio Grande and in the Province of Quebec.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 4. -- The annual Highland games of the Hound Hill Scottish Games Association, held today on the estate of Charles Arthur Moore at Round Hill, attracted more than 7,000 persons from Eastern States.

A block of 63,506 additional common shares of the International Mining Corporation with stock purchase warrants is being offered today at $11 a share by Lehman Brothers in this country and by Greenshields Co. in Canada. The warrants entitle the holder to buy one additional share at $10 on or before Sept. 1, 1939.

LYNCHBURG, Va., July 4. -- State regulation and control of liquor in event of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was one of the major planks in the platform of the Virginia Republican party, adopted at the State convention here this afternoon.

BERLIN, July 4. -- With the fate of the London conference still in the balance, today's Boerse session opened weak and remained so throughout the session. Domestic political factors also continued to have a depressing effect on the bond market despite reports that Boerse officials have appealed to the government for supporting action in behalf of the market for fixed interest securities.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- Farm administrators have drafted tentative plans for a processing tax on hogs by Oct. 1, to provide up to $150,000,000 to finance application of the Farm Relief Act to corn and swine.

The contributions made by Jews to the establishment and defense of the United States were reviewed yesterday by Samuel Untermyer in a radio address over a nation-wide hook-up of the National Broadcasting Company.

NEWARK, N.J., July 4. -- Cynara, 2-year-old filly from the Newbrook Stables, driven by Ed Mansfield of Hoboken, won the feature event of the holiday meeting sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

LONDON, July 4. -- There came this morning a scene the most charged with human emotion this conference has yet known. It is known to only a few here. If it can be told now it is only because it was that rare kind of deep emotional experience that few men can keep entirely to themselves and that even diplomats, accustomed to keeping secrets, can not help narrating to some of their intimate friends.

To the Editor of The New York Time: About two years ago the government informed war veterans that they may have one-half of their bonus due in 1945. Nearly 4,000,000 men took the money, and so did I. My share was $700.

The June statistical bulletin of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company cautions against accepting at face value provisional figures, recently announced by the Census Bureau, which seem to indicate that the decline in the rural birth rate is much less marked than that in the urban one.

Before the week is ended the Department of Agriculture hopes to persuade a large majority of cotton planters in the South to accept the acreage reduction plan. It calls for the destruction of part of the growing crop. In return the department offers compensation.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 4. -- Raynham Hall, a historic home-stead built 193 years ago by Samuel Townsend and occupied until recently by members of the Town-send family, was formally opened to the public this afternoon by Oyster Bay Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution.

As a naval expert, President ROOSEVELT knows how difficult it is to save a ship after she has been torpedoed. But this is precisely what he is now asked to do for the sinking Economic Conference. The American delegates aboard the apparently doomed vessel have begged him for new "instructions" so as to avert a complete wreck.
ST. ANDREW, Scotland, July 4. -- Another blazing hot day, with greens no faster and a fluctuating breeze dropping away to almost nothing.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 4. -- Finishing in the fringe of a squall after a calm of three hours, 115 racing craft in the Larchmont Yacht Club's Independence Day championship, which was its fifty-second annual regatta, had a hectic time today.

SPARTANBURG, S.C., July 4 (AP). -- Disabled war veterans may expect a "square deal as well as a new deal" from President Roosevelt, Harry W. Woodring, Assistant Secretary of War, told the South Carolina Department of the American Legion today.

A committee of five representatives of the apparel Industries will confer today at the Hotel New Yorker with Professor Earl Dean Howard, deputy administrator under the National Recovery Act, in an effort to frame a code for the women's wear group.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 4. -- The name of Manuel Alonso, veteran Spanish Davis Cup player, war added today to the roll call of wireness of the Nassau Bowl, one of the oldest challenge trophies in tennis, and which bears the inscriptions of almost every outstanding American player of the past generation.

VIENNA, July 4. -- Twenty-nine American college boys and girls, with, several professors, have arrived in Vienna in order to stage three typical American plays next week before Viennese audiences on the boards on which Marie Antoinette once danced and Maria Theresa played in shepherd and shepherdess masquerades.
Governor Albert C. Ritchie of Maryland told a nation-wide radio audience yesterday how his State had managed to maintain a balanced budget and reduce its tax rate in spite of the depression.

PITTSBURGH, July 4 (AP). -- Playing at Forbes Field for the first time in weeks, the Pittsburgh Pirates sent the local fans home happy by downing the Cardinals, 4 to 2, in the afternoon encounter of today's holiday bill, after bowing to St. Louis, 5 to 1, in the morning game.
Following the unfortunate example set by the other two metropolitan clubs, the Dodgers yesterday succumbed to the Phillies in both ends of a double-header, 6 to 3 and 4 to 2.
Chill winds and overcast skies put a damper yesterday on New York City's Fourth of July celebration.

Kathleen Norris, one of the most popular and prolific of novelists, sketches some of the things she likes about the State in which she lives in "My California," published by Doubleday, Doran. She tells one story of how she saw her first snow when she was grown up and married.

Guaranty Trust Company. The Guaranty Trust Company in its statement for June 30, shows an increase of $35,078,104 in deposits in the second quarter. Deposits were $1,087,621,195, against $952,543,091 in March and $928,343,300 a year ago.

LONDON, July 4. -- Germany's determination to achieve that equality of armament with her neighbors which the preliminary agreement of other nations at the disarmament conference has yielded her is already being translated into fact, despite the Versailles Treaty and all other considerations, according to information obtained here from sources distinctly reliable.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 4. -- An All-America final in the women's singles, featuring two rivals of many years from Berkeley, Cal., Miss Helen Jacobs and Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, loomed tonight after a day in which the feminine contingent held the centre of the stage in the annual Wimbledon tennis championships.

The Wheatley Stable's Dark Secret, a son of the Kentucky Derby winner Flying Ebony, added his name to the roll of winners of the historic Brooklyn Handicap when he led all the way at Aqueduct yesterday to win by a neck in a thrilling finish.

Last night's concert in the Lewisohn Stadium was interrupted by rain after the second number on the program and the sparse audience scattered hurriedly to exits to claim rain-checks for tonight's performance.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4. -- Elisha Lee, vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, said his wife had seemed in perfect health when she and their younger son, Elisha Lee Jr., sailed from New York on June 24 for two months in Europe. Her death followed an intestinal operation.

TORONTO, July 4 (Canadian Press). -- Construction and banking issues, steel and allied stocks scored important gains today as the Toronto Stock Exchange, Under its own power because of the holiday in New York, passed through its duietest day in about two weeks.

LONDON, July 4. -- Francis W. Hirst, former editor of The Economist, told the League of Nations Union at its luncheon today what he thought the conference ought to do about money and gold debts "but what it probably won't," he added.

CHICAGO, July 4. -- Lively scenes, in which presiding officers and delegates dragged at one another's coat-tails and sleeves, pinioned one another's arms to avoid threatened fisticuffs and shouted, marked the closing sessions of the annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America.

The Knickerbocker Canoe Club of New York City dethroned the Pendleton Canoe Club, metropolitan canoeing champions, for the past five years, in the races on Conservatory Lake in Central Park yesterday.

With all domestic exchanges closed for the holiday, the foreign markets furnished the only index to the course of prices yesterday. Where active trading took place in the securities and commodities in which we are chiefly interested, the movement was generally upward.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 4. -- A plan for the elimination of unemployment, suggested as a permanent remedy instead of the means adopted in the industrial recovery bill, was presented here tonight by Henry K. Norton of New York in an address before the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

Expressing concern over the anti-Jewish campaign in Germany, 142 presidents of American colleges and universities and 77 of this country's outstanding social scientists have formulated a "statement of belief." It is addressed to the heads of every institution of higher learning in Germany, and pleads for recognition and respect of the rights of Jews and all minorities as essential to culture and civilization.

LONDON, July 4. -- Strong arguments in favor of continuing the economic conference are presented In a London Times editorial tonight. While several delegations contend nothing effective can be accomplished without stabilization of exchange, The London Times supports those who are equally convinced much useful work can be done despite the divergence of views on the currency question, especially on the economic as opposed to the financial side.

To The Editor of The New York Times: The National Industrial Recovery Act offers an excellent opportunity to eliminate certain aspects of child labor as an emergency measure, but this does not alter pie need for ratification of the Federal, child labor amendment. Previous experience indicates that when a period of unemployment begins to abate and industry picks up, the number of children, entering industry tends to increase.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 4. -- Ellsworth Vines worked out at the Queens Club this morning with Keith Gledhill. Vines's footwork is improving and the same old speed is there. He has gained in accuracy and we hope to see his game right up to that of last year.

The newly formed firm of Mallory. Eisemann Co., located at 120 Broadway, has opened a new branch Office at 33 East Fifty-first Street under the management of Holbrook Smith, another at 163 West Seventy-second Street under the management of Herbert A. Cone and 176 Montague Street, Brooklyn, with Charles A. Boylhart as manager.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4. -- Frank Silvia of the New York Athletic Club won the junior single shells event in the annual People's Day regatta on the Schuylkill River today before a crowd of 15,000 persons, including Mayor J. Hampton Moore, who followed the races in the officials' launch.

ST ANDREWS, Scotland, July 4 -- Thirteen Americans, including the defending champion, stocky Gene Sarazen, and one amateur, George T. Dunlap Jr. of New York, celebrated a sizzling Fourth of July in Scotland today by qualifying for the British open golf championship.

CLEVELAND, July 4 (AP). -- Calumet Crusader, brown son of the mighty grand circuit trotter, Truax, won the Tavern "Steak" for 2:14 class trotters, feature of the holiday program at North Randall today after a stirring four-heat battle.

The United States cannot pursue a policy of economic self-sufficiency and isolation. Professor William E. Dodd, the new Ambassador to Germany, said last night. It must strive to cooperate with other nations if the present world-wide depression is to be overcome and the nations are to enter upon another era of prosperity, he added.

The New York Board of Trade, Inc., made public yesterday the results of a country-wide survey of business; showing a marked improvement In employment, working hours, wages, payrolls, volume of sales and public confidence in all sections.

CLEVELAND, July 4 (AP). -- The Indians divided a doubleheader with Chicago today before 8,000 fans and thereby maintained their half-game lead over the White Sox for fourth place. The Indians won the opener, 5 to 2, and Chicago took the nightcap, 6 to 3.
In the general flurry attending the opening of the black bass season there probably were many who forgot that July 1 also marked the opening of the musky season in this State.

DUBLIN, July 4. -- The United States flag was flown extensively in Dublin today in celebration of the Fourth of July. At the United States Legation the Minister and his wife entertained Legation and consular officials at tea. A party for the children of American officials also was given at the Legation.
MILWAUKEE, July 4 (AP). -- Mrs. Ida B. Wise Smith of Des Moines was elected today to be president of the National Women's Christian Temperance Union, succeeding Mrs. Ella A. Boole of Brooklyn.

The New York University's Washington Square Centre will open today for registration for the annual session of the Summer School, which includes five schools and colleges of the university. The program consists of about 400 courses presented by 370 members of the regular faculty and twenty special teachers.
PARIS, July 4. -- Commemorating America's Independence Day, Ambassador Jesse I. Straus and General John J. Pershing today laid wreaths on the graves of Lafayette and of France's Unknown Soldier.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 4. -- Beneath the windows of the room in which General Washington penned letters of appeal for his ragged and starving Revolutionary army, Morristown National Historical Park was dedicated this afternoon and the scenes of struggle and sacrifice in the Winter of 1779-80 became the common heritage of the nation.

Operating on a greatly reduced appropriation and at practically last minute notice, the annual safe and sane celebration of Independence Day again was held yesterday throughout the city in more than 100 parks and playgrounds.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 4. -- A swimming record that had stood for fifteen years was smashed by George Fissler today in an A.A.U. exhibition meet at the Sands Point Bath Club pool. Fissler shattered the old national mark for the 250-yard free style in a sixty-foot pool by almost four seconds, thrashing the distance in 2:37 2-5.

The Socialist party held its Fourth of July celebration in Union Square yesterday at noon. Speakers hailed their party as the true inheritor of the traditions of "this revolutionary holiday," and several pointed with derision to Tammany Hall across the square, where another celebration had ended before the outdoor gathering had begun.

The Rev. Oscar Ellstein of 233 East Twelfth Street, a retired Orthodox rabbi, was killed yesterday when struck by a taxicab at First Avenue and First Street, according to the police. Charles Spinelli, 36 years old, of 1,431 Second Avenue, the cab driver, was charged with homicide.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 4. -- President Roosevelt ended his vacation at sea today on the cool, quiet waters of Chesapeake Bay, observing the anniversary of American independence at a family luncheon aboard the cruiser Indianapolis.

Jean Tillier, general manager of the French Line in the United States and Canada, returned yesterday from Paris on the He de France with Mme. Tillier. He announced he had resigned his position with the company to take effect after Dec. 31.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Being anxious to visit the Chicago fair as economically as possible and in the most pleasant manner, I planned for a round trip excursion ticket, with coupon good for boat transportation from Buffalo to Detroit.

Geologists from all over the world are beginning to arrive here to attend the sixteenth International Geological Congress which opens in Washington, July 22, it was announced here yesterday by Professor Charles P. Berkey, head of the Department of Geology, Columbia University, and secretary of the Geological Society of America.

Before baseball's record crowd of the year and the second largest in the history of the game here, the Yankees suffered two disastrous setbacks yesterday at the hands of the Senators in the holiday double-header at the Stadium.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP). -- Beer since its legalization April 7 has produced more than $7,000,000 in revenue for thirty-two States and the District of Columbia, on the basis of incomplete returns compiled today.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP). -- The Administration's economy program already has removed nearly 8,000 government employes from the payrolls, and hundreds more face imminent dismissal.

Use of out-patient clinics and dispensaries has increased in the last six years by nearly one-third in voluntary and municipal hospitals of the city and has more than doubled in the city hospitals, the United Hospital Fund reported yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 4. -- A new political department for transport on the lines of the tractor political department in the collective farm movement was inaugurated today by a decree of the Council of Commissars signed by V.F. Molotoff and Joseph Stalin.
