ALBANY, July 4. -- In the two weeks ended June 28 a total of 346 certificates of registration and licenses to drive were revoked or suspended for infractions of the Motor Vehicle Law, Charles A. Harnett, commissioner, announced today.

Aroldo Palanca, the new general manager of the Italian Line for the United States and Canada, arrived yesterday on the liner Conte di Savoia. He will supersede the directorial triumvirate that has guided the line since it was formed two years ago by a merger of the Lloyd Sabaudo, Cosulich and N. G.I. Lines.

PARIS, July 4. -- With the single exception of the radical newspaper La Republique, the whole French press of all parties has united today in attacks on the tone, form and substance of President Roosevelt's message to the London conference.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of F.F. Greeley to THE NEW YORK TIMES gives a welcome bit of historical knowledge. For many years there has been a question in my mind as to the beginnings of the electoral franchise. What history has come into my hands makes only the vaguest references to it.

An idea born in the last days of 1929 prosperity and theoretically realized in the blackest days of early 1932 will become a reality this morning when for the first time traders in six commodities will watch, the formal opening of their new quarters in the Commodity Exchange, Inc.

BOSTON, July 4. -- A couple of Giant firecrackers went off at the wrong end today, with the result that the holiday excursion of Memphis Bill Terry and his array of National League leaders suffered no little damage.

Tammany always takes occasion on the Fourth, of July to renew its devotion to liberty and pure government. Others may misuse the great national holiday by merry-making or idling, but the Sachems of the Hall meet to refresh their patriotic memories and resolves and to "dedicate" themselves anew to public service.

MIAMI Fla., July 4 (AP). -- A tropical storm in the Gulf of Mexico, breasted now by a strong high-pressure area from out of the north, apparently was moving west-north-westward toward the Texas and Louisiana coast regions tonight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So China has adopted the 4-H Club idea! Reading of the enthusiasm with which the 150 boys and girls from the country districts acted upon Harry S. Martin's suggestion, I could not but hope for a most successful transplanting of one of our most successful institutions for the development of the youth in our rural communities.

WASHINGTON, July 4. -- President Roosevelt tonight sent an urgent cable to Secretary Hull at London instructing the American delegates to the World Economic Conference to do everything in their power to prevent adjournment until important items on the agenda had been dealt with.

Robert Maynard Hutchins, who became president of the University of Chicago in 1929 when he was 30 years old, writes in the Summer issue of The Yale Review of the changes wrought by hard times on higher education. He also suggests more changes which, he believes, would do some good.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Of the five hundred people who met death by falling from windows in one year in this country, an alarmingly high number did not commit suicide but lost their balance due to a too-low parapet and plunged to a terrible death.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 4. -- About a hundred persons attended the Independence Day luncheon at the Lenox Club. Those who entertained included Mrs. Anson Phelps Stokes, Mrs. Ross W. Whistler, Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. de Gersdorff, Miss M. Symphorosa Bristed, Mr. and Mrs. Clement M. Burnhome, Mrs. Henry Hollister Pease and Giraud Foster.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP). -- The Red Sox exploded plenty of Fourth of July fireworks at Shibe Park today, trimming the Athletics handily in both ends of the holiday bill.

To the Editor at The New York Times: Your editorial "The Incorrigible Whistler" seems to treat in a very light vein the part that Dr. McBride is now playing in attempting to prevent the repeal of prohibition. You are quick to forget the immense amount of damage, which includes a consider able loss of life, property, taxes and the encouragement of crime, that admittedly was caused by prohibition.

CHICAGO, July 3. -- Laying aside pedagogic reserve, 10,000 school teachers of the United States assembled here for the annual convention of the National Education Association, celebrated Independence Day with protestations of their right to enter politics and with noisy demonstrations for rival nominees for the presidency of their association.

The former Barrett estate, situated east of the Village of Katonah, has been sold by George Howe, Inc., as broker, to a client of Root, Clark, Buckner Ballantine, attorneys. The property consists of forty acres of land, a large stone residence and numerous outbuildings overlooking Croton Lake.

BUENOS AIRES, July 4. -- The government decreed that Presidential honors be accorded to Hipolito Irigoyen, who died yesterday, but refused permission for the body to lie in state in the cathedral or a plaza or other public place. His family, however, rejected the honors unless they could be complete.

READING, Pa., July 4. -- The National Executive Committee of the Socialist party, closing a three-day session here today, declared that the National Industrial Recovery Act "constitutes an admission that capitalism can make no recovery without governmental supervision."

Controller BERRY'S accounts have been examined by an auditing company end found correct. Certain changes in method are suggested; but the safeguards surrounding the collection and disbursement of the city's funds are thought to be not merely ample but redundant.

LONDON, July 4. -- The World Economic Conference's subcommittee on commercial policy today discussed tariffs and debts, but the date of its next meeting was left to the decision of the bureau of the conference when it meets Thursday to determine whether the conference is to continue.

LIVERPOOL, England, July 4 (Canadian Press). -- The cricket match between the touring British West Indies eleven and Lancashire ended in a draw today after three days of play when it was found impossible to complete the second innings.
Despite official precautions and "safe and sane" propaganda, about 1,100 persons, mostly children, were burned and otherwise injured in all parts of the city yesterday by Fourth of July fireworks.

ROME, July 4. -- President Roosevelt's message refusing immediate stabilization of the dollar caused disappointment because of its threat to the London conference and caused surprise because of its tone, which is held to be unnecessarily harsh.

A man fleeing from the scene of a petty theft was shot dead by a patrolman in front of 21 West Forty-third Street last night. Two others, accused by the police of being his companions in the looting of a showcase at Fifth Avenua and Forty-second Street, were caught.

Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large, will sail for London today with Mrs. Davis on the Washington of the United States Lines. Others on the ship will be William E. Dodd, newly appointed United States Ambassador to Germany, and Mrs. Dodd; Robert P. Skinner, United States Ambassador to Turkey, and Mrs. Skinner, and Dr. and Mrs. Fred H. Albee.

An additional saving of at least $50,000,000 this year in the city budget is one of the goals to be sought by the Merchants Association of New York as part of its general program for civic and business improvement, according to a statement issued yesterday by Louis K. Comstock, its new president.

LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Wednesday, July 5. -- The Italian air armada of twenty-four seaplanes commanded by Air Minister Italo Balbo was unable to resume its Journey to Chicago yesterday, as weather reports from Iceland were unfavorable.

BERLIN, July 4. -- The end of recognized political opposition in Germany came suddenly tonight with the announcement that the Catholic Centrist and Bavarian People's parties would disband. Their adherents have been invited to join the Nazis as "guest members."

A half gale out of the northeast, which raged across the coastal shipping lanes for the last three days and piled up white-capped combers along the North Atlantic seaboard, caused widespread damage and delay to shipping, reports received here last night showed.
LONDON, July 4. -- Typical of the more bitter of British, newspaper comments on the situation created by President Roosevelt's message is the following from The London Daily Express:

The National Amateur Press Association, composed of boys and girls who write and publish amateur newspapers and magazines throughout the country, ended its fifty-eighth annual convention at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday with the election of officers for the coming year.
About 3,000 persons attended yesterday the annual Independence Day celebration of the Long Island Chapter, Knights of Columbus, at the Music Grove, Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 4. -- The annual Henley Royal Regatta, which will open tomorrow, will have its most extensive international representation since the World War. Oarsmen from eight countries will compete over the historic upper Thames course -- England, Ireland, the United States, France, Italy, Germany, Denmark and Czechoslovakia.

Turners Condemn Hitler. Hitlerism has been challenged and condemned by a representative body of German-American opinion. The annual convention of the League of Turner Societies at Elkhart Lake, Wis., adopted two resolutions.

BOSTON, July 5 -- Justice Brandeis of the Federal Supreme Court signed an order today which amounted to a stay of execution for Herman (Red) Snyder, condemned murderer. The action was believed to have established a legal precedent.
The Theatre Guild is still buying plays. It has now acquired "As We Forgive Our Debtors," by Tillman Breiseth. This play, the author's first, has been put on next season's schedule.

In the last two years the old art of pamphleteering has been nourished back to life and something approaching profit by the John Day Company. In that time 2,000 ideas and manuscripts intended for publication as pamphlets have been submitted to the publishers.

BUENOS. AIRES, July 5. -- Argentina has never before witnessed anything comparable to the demonstration of public mourning lor former President Hipolito Jrlgoyen. Fifty thousand persons arrived today from the interior, on seven special trains running from the larger cities.

PARIS, July 5 -- Two measures of reprisal against the United States -- an embargo on Hollywood films and a surtax on all American imports to compensate for the dollar's decline -- might be an immediate result if the World Economic Conference adjourned because of President Roosevelt's unwillingness to stabilize the dollar.
LONDONDERRY, July 5 -- A bit of excitement today marked the departure of the twenty-four Italian seaplanes for Reykjavik.

Asserting that the "great weight of the industry, both in numbers and volume, is making a serious effort to cooperate," C.B. Ames, chairman of the Texas Corporation, says there must be cooperation between the national administration and the State enforcement agencies if the objective of the National Industrial Recovery Act is to be achieved so far as the petroleum industry is concerned.

An appreciation in the net value of its assets of more than 75 per cent was shown by the Lehman corporation in the fiscal year ended on June 30. The report, issued yesterday, also showed that an unrealized loss of nearly $25,000,000 was wiped out and a small unrealized profit created.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 5 -- Virtually every resident of Purchase was represented at a hearing before the town board tonight to protest a proposed change in the zoning laws to permit the operation of a hotel in a highly restricted residential area.

A decline of 50,000 to 75,000 in Christian, church membership in China in recent years is noted in the third instalment of the report of the Layman's Foreign Missions Inquiry made public yesterday by Albert L. Scott, chairman. The total number of members of Christian churches in China is assumed to be 400,000.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- The balloon which is to carry the seven-foot-in-diameter dowmetal sphere and its crew of two into the high altitudes of the stratosphere from Soldiers Field some time this month is 104.5 feet in diameter, with a capacity of 600,000 cubic feet.

ALBANY, July 5 -- The Public Service Commission's refusal to permit the Staten Island Edison Corporation to issue $8,500,000 first mortgage gold bonds to meet obligations previously incurred has been upheld by the Appellate Division, Third Department.

State of Illinois. A new issue of $1,000,000 State of Illinois 4 per cent waterway bonds, dated Jan. 1, 1920, and due on Jan. 1, 1940, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate composed of Lehman Brothers, Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc.; Estabrook Co., Kelley, Richardson Co., Chicago; R.W. Pressprich Co. and the First of Michigan Corporation.

Shipping men expressed the belief yesterday that developments of the last few days at the World Economic Conference would mean the abandonment of any attempt to limit the development of the American merchant marine by standards advanced by foreign nations.

The present liquid financial status of the Paramount Pictures Corporation, the subsidiary which manufactures and distributes the output of the bankrupt Paramount Publix Corporation, was revealed yesterday at the hearing for creditors. The meeting was held before Federal Referee Henry K. Davis at 140 Nassau Street.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 5 -- The new and the old kings of the tennis courts, Ellsworth Vines and Henri Cochet, met today for the third time, and for the third time Vines won. Smashing through the once invincible French ace. Vines scored a 6 -- 2, 8 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 1 triumph in the semi-finals of the Wimbledon tennis championships.

THE all-star ball game is scheduled for today at Comiskey Park in Chicago, and even the ball players are stirred up over it. Vines is resting on his racquet at Wimbledon, waiting for the final clash with Jack Crawford of Australia. The Kent School and Hun School crews are in pursuit of the Thames Challenge Cup in the Henley regatta. The British open-golf championship goes into the second round at St. Andrews.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., son of the President, sailed yesterday on the United States liner Washington with a group of other graduates of Groton School. They will make a two-month tour of France, Spain, Switzerland and England.
LONDON, July 5 (AP) -- Cheers, flowers and kisses greeted L.C. Thornton and William MacDonald, the British engineers whom Russia freed from prison, as they arrived at Liverpool Street Station today.

The peoples of the ancient world kept antiques with as much reverence as such things are kept today. Professor Elihu Grant of Haverford College, who has been excavating for several years in Palestine and who has just returned-with twelve cases of ancient objects of art and household use, says that some of his finds were 1,000, years old when the house in which they were found was built 2,700 years ago.

Nine years after the flight around the world by United States Army officers which took them across the North Atlantic westward by way of Scotland and Iceland, General BALBO, the Italian Air Minister, is attempting with twenty-four service planes to make the same crossing in military formation on his way to the World Fair at Chicago.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Movements of vessels follow:

MUNICIPAL AIRPORT, Chicago, July 5 (AP) -- Two of America's speed pilots, "Johnny" Livingston of Aurora, Ill., and "Jack" Wright of Utica, N.Y., set new unofficial records today as the American air races ended.
HENLEY ON THAMES, England, July 5 -- A brilliant gathering at the opening of the Henley Royal Regatta today saw Americans figure in two victories and three defeats.

A decent respect to the opinions of mankind was mentioned in the forefront of the Declaration of Independence. In the "statement of belief," signed by more than two hundred American college presidents and social scientists, there is a like significant clause: "The growing interdependence of the world makes it appropriate" -- appropriate that individuals should express their concern touching a matter of human welfare.

Two recently appointed diplomats sailed for their foreign posts yesterday on the United States liner Washington. Ambassador William E. Dodd left with his wife, son and daughter for Berlin, and Robert P. Skinner, new Ambassador to Turkey, departed with Mrs. Skinner.

MOSCOW, July 5. -- Jubilant headlines greet the signing in London of the Soviet pacts defining non-aggression, with her neighbors. The eight-column front, page of the newspaper Izvestia carries a three column editorial with the caption, ''U.S.S.R. at Head of Struggle for Peace," and a five-column banner caption reading, "Great Victory for Pacifist Policy of U.S.S.R," which are the same words as appear in a four-column headline of the Pravda.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 5 -- Gregory S. Mangin of Newark, holder of the national indoor championship, required only forty-five minutes to advance through four rounds of play and join the field in the quarter-finals of the annual New Jersey men's championship tennis tournament today on the courts of the Montclair Athletic Club.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Francis G. Stuart of 30 East Sixtieth Street will leave tomorrow for North Hatley, P.Q. Miss Katherine O'Brien, who makes her home with Mrs. Stuart, sailed last week for a tour of Europe.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. Richard Travis Atkins was modest as to his attainments. Fame came unbidden and unsought from grizzled veterans among his fellow-surgeons who acclaimed him, and from grateful patients to whom he had brought relief and restoration.

The dollar sank again yesterday to a new low level in the foreign exchange market. Transactions were fairly heavy and trading was excited as quotations here sank to meet the losses scored by the dollar abroad over the holiday and then continued on down to extend the losses.

WINDSOR, Conn., July 5.-- It was a great day for the Brusies at Sage Park today, where Harry took a first, a second and a third money and his son Lyman won two firsts and divided second and third moneys in another race.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP) -- Dick Oliver, a young right-hand pitcher taken off the sand lots of Philadelphia, made his starting debut in the major leagues today and pitched the Athletics to a 4-to-2 victory ovep the Red Sox.

Sixteen sailing craft and seven motor boats bad been named last night for the New York Athletic Club's annual races to Block Island, which will be started off Execution Lighthouse on Saturday morning. The motor craft will be sent away at 10 A.M. and the sailing division an hou later.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- A growing anxiety was discerned today among friends of John (Jake the Barber) Factor that some fate worse than kidnapping had befallen the stock speculator who was supposedly seized for ransom Saturday morning.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- A big first inning, during which they scored four runs, three of them when Manager Charlie Grimm doubled with the bases loaded, gave Lyle (Bud) Tinning and the Cubs a 5-to-3 victory over the Reds today.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 5 -- Thirty-two men, women and children, who had been trapped in a smokefilled apartment house at 128 Palisade Avenue, were saved from suffocation early this morning in a series of thrilling rescues by firemen.

NEWARK, N.J., July 5. -- More than 500 laymen of the Newark Diocese of the Roman Catholic Church attended a dinner here tonight in honor of the Most Rev. John A. Duffy, newly consecrated Bishop of Syracuse. The dinner had been arranged by the laymen's organization In cooperation with the Newark Diocesan Federation of the Holy Name Society and the Knights of Columbus.

Wednesday, July 5, 1933. Quotably, the money market was unchanged, and small in turnover, but minor-size lots of short-date money shaded the rate and were done at one-half of 1 per cent. The bulk of the offerings from 60 days up to and including four months is 3/4.

The nine-story apartment house at 59-65 West Seventy-first Street has been sold by the Union Dime Savings Bank to a group of investors represented by the Gresham Realty Company, Inc., it was announced yesterday. Alexander S. Bing is president of the buying company.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 5 -- President Roosevelt's "new deal" was characterized as a revival of "antique and discarded theories," and vacillations of American policy were denounced in addresses made today before the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Eleven selections of Latin-American music were played or sung for the first time in the United States tonight at a concert of the Pan American Union on the national holiday of Venezuela. High officials of Ihe United States Government and members of the diplomatic corps were in attendance.

MILWAUKEE, July 5 (AP) -- Dissatisfied with the stand taken by both major political parties, the annual convention of the National Woman's Christian Temperance Union adopted a resolution today proposing a third party which would attract dry voters.

Isolationists have been gleefully declaring that President ROOSEVELT is with them. They assert that his nationalistic policy is a reversal of the doctrine and efforts of his former chief, his last Democratic predecessor, President WILSON. But the Administration and its advisers number so many Wilson men that the most rigid discipline and the most conscientious loyalty cannot prevent them from utterances that do not go well with their leader's momentary view.

There was an increase in June of $251,876,682 in loans on securities by members of the New York Stock Exchange, the Exchange reported yesterday. This was the third consecutive monthly advance. The total increase since March 31 was $459,424,539, the April gain having been only $11,530,607, while the May increase was $206,017,250.

Early unification of rapid transit lines on the basis of a self-sustaining fare was urged upon Mayor O'Brien and the Board of Estimate last night. Two committees of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York sent a joint report to the Mayor and board.

The City Affairs Committee sent a letter yesterday to the Department of Plant and Structures asking for the privilege of radio time on the city's station, WNYC, for the broadcasting of three talks on city problems by John Haynes Holmes, chairman of the committee; Professor Joseph B. McGoldrick of Columbia University and Paul Blanshard.

LONDON, July 5 -- The theory on which most of the monetary manoeuvring of this conference has been based received a disconcerting blow today. The refusal of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister MacDonald to join in the stabilization declaration resulted in a run from the dollar, and especially the pound, to the franc, the guilder and other gold currencies, which rose sharply.

Nervous uncertainty surrounded the financial and commodity markets yesterday. There was a slow and orderly decline in the afternoon and prices were generally lower at the close. Business was active on all the important exchanges, but traders proceeded more cautiously.
Conditions for both fresh and salt water fishing have not been the best recently, but indications are that the weather soon will give fishermen a break.

While steel executives have been drafting a code for the operation of their industry, under the National Industry Recovery Bill, the American Federation of Labor has seized the opportunity presented by the new law to carry on a campaign to unionize the industry, according to reports from steel centres.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The year 1932, because of the depression, resulted in an all-time lowwater mark for the number of marriages performed in this country. The ratio was 7.9 per thousand of population, as compared with 8.5 for 1931.

Two leading companies announced yesterday an advance of 33 cents a barrel in the price of crude oil in the Mid-continent area. The new prices, which, range from 61 cents on oil below 29 gravity to 85 cents on 40 gravity and above, were inaugurated by the Continental Oil Company and immediately met by the Sinclair-Prairie Oil Marketing Company, a subsidiary of the Consolidated Oil Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- After laboring a full week, Sunday and the Fourth of July included, leaders of all elements supplying the United States sugar market, meeting as a conference sub-committee, today completed a draft agreement which will be submitted tomorrow to the general committee.

PITTSBURGH, July 5 (AP) -- Overcoming a five-run lead, the Pirates broke loose with savage attacks in the fifth and seventh innings today to defeat the Cardinals, 7 to 6, and advance within one game of their second place opponents. The St. Louis club now trails the league-leading Giants by five and a half games.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- Headed by Lanky John McDiarmid of Fort Worth, Texas, who upset Bryant Grant of Atlanta, Ga., in straight sets, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, five players gained the quarter-final round of the national clay court singles championship at the Town and Tennis Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- President Roosevelt, back at his desk today after his vacation, plunged into conferences on speeding the public works phase of the national back to work movement. Meanwhile, his aides were prepared to lay before him tomorrow suggestions for immediate positive action to quicken the process of bringing industry into coordination under the Industrial Recovery Act.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 5. -- The first of the series of chamber music concerts arranged, for the Summer will take place at the home of the Missea Edith and Maud Wetmore on July 20. For the first concert Mrs. Gustave J.S. White has volunteered to be vocal soloist.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- Youth in the role of potential savior of the public schools appeared today before the teachers of the country assembled here in the convention of the National Education Association.

The Board of Estimate, meeting yesterday in committee of the whole, approved the model housing project planned by Sloan Robertson, architects, for the seven blocks of city-owned land in the Chrystie-Forsyth Street area at a total cost of $12,789,708.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP). -- Silvio Concci gave Mrs. Payne Whitney's Dabchick, 15-to-l shot, a good ride in the stretch today to account for the featured Ravinia Purse, a five furlong preparation for the Lassie Stakes, Saturday's feature at Arlington Park.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 5 -- It was the backhand stroke of Henri Cochet that failed him in the match, with Ellsworth, Vines today.

After an arraignment of domestic cement manufacturers yesterday by Samuel Untermyer, the Board of Estimate, sitting in Committee of the Whole, voted to rescind its resolution specifying American-made cement in all the city's public works.

The daily average gross crude oil production of the country last week was 2,602,050 barrels, as compared with 2,513,600 barrels in the preceding week, an increase of 88,450 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A gain of 82,600 barrels in the daily output of Oklahoma and a decline of 23,050 barrels in the average daily production of East Texas were the most important changes for the week.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 5 -- The Italian air armada of twentyfour seaplanes arrived here from Londonderry, Northern Ireland, this afternoon, completing the third stage of their flight from Italy to the Century of Progress Exposition in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Judge Genevieve Cline will head a delegation, of New York women coming here Saturday to participate in memorial services for women leaders. The services were organized by the National Woman's party as a tribute to the late Mrs. Oliver H.P. Belmont, former president of the party, who died in France last January.

LONDON, July 5 -- The text of the statement handed to the Secretary-General of the World Economic Conference in London today concerning the stand of the United States in connection with the conference follows:

LONG BEACH, Cal., July 5 -- Yale's varsity crew established itself as favorite today to win the national intercollegiate sprint championship Saturday by sweeping over the 2,000-meter course in 6 minutes 20 seconds in a time trial.

PARIS, Thursday, July 6 -- Raising his voice almost alone among his countrymen, Edouard Herriot, former Premier, in this morning's L'Ere Nouvelle pleads for a better understanding of President Roosevelt's stand regarding monetary stabilization and the London conference.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Drastic modification of restrictions on distribution of sacramental wine was authorized today by Attorney General Cummings and Acting Secretary Gibbons of the Treasury amending regulations.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 5 -- Bolivia, essentially a mining country, has turned its skill in this line against Paraguay in the Chaco war, with a resultant victory for Bolivian arms, according to a government bulletin this morning.

BERLIN, July 5 -- A National Socialist one-party State under the autocratic command of Adolf Hitler was established tonight when the Catholic Centre party formally announced its dissolution. Thus the last non-Nazi party disappeared.

Miss Helen Kane came back last evening to what is shyly called the speaking stage. She arrived under the auspices of Harry Meyer, in a little piece named "Shady Lady." Set forth grumblingly upon the stage of the Shubert Theatre, this was in the nature of a bow to New York in Summer.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- The government put a double budget system into effect today under which the regular, general expenses of Federal departments will be segregated from expenditures listed as extraordinary.

RYE, N.Y., July 5 -- Leo Kaufmann of Gedney Farms shot a brilliant 69, two strokes under par, to carry away low gross honors as the Westchester Golf Association held a one-day tourney over the Rye Coutry Club's course today.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Regulations designed to protect the investing public against the sale of worthless securities were completed tonight and will be promulgated by the Federal Trade Commission tomorrow.

The necessity for a drastic salary reduction for all employes of Jersey City in an effort to strengthen the financial condition of the city was announced yesterday by Commissioner William B. Quinn, Director of Revenue and Finance. He said that reductions ranging from 20 to 35 per cent had been considered for the city employes, totaling about 4,000 and including policemen, firemen and school teachers.

When the Tenement Renovation Contracting Co., Inc., bought 4 and 6 Monroe St. from Domenica Gatto at a price of about $25,500 above the first mortgage of $25,000 and the second for $11,550, the seller took back a purchase money third mortgage for $10,000, due on demand at 6 per cent.

Myron Bennett, 33 years old, and his wife, Mabel, 32, arrested yesterday at 325 East Fifty-seventh Street on charges of violating the Sullivan Law and possessing "a liquid believed to be opium" were held in $5,000 bail each in Yorkville Court for hearing tomorrow.

With nearly all of Its members and many guests on the floor, the new Commodity Exchange began operation yesterday in its first headquarters. Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, came as the guest of honor to welcome the new exchange to Broad Street and to New York City's financial community.

LOS ANGELES, July 5 -- The contest committee of the National Air Races, after deliberation since last night, today disqualified Colonel Roscoe Turner as the victor in the classic Thompson Trophy race and named Jimmie Wedell, Louisiana pilot and designer, as the winner.

A dominating interest in the United Founders Corporation has been acquired by the Equity Corporation and its associates under the direction of David M. Milton. Mr. Milton is a son-in-law of John D. Rockefeller Jr., and the United Founders Corporation was at one time the largest investment trust in the world, with assets of nearly $500,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: According to the present plans of the Federal Government the Civilian Conservation Corps camps will have some 300,000 recruits. The majority of these men will be between the ages of 18 and 25. They are being recruited from that vast army of unemployed whose physique and morale have been seriously affected, by months, if not years, of want and idleness.
LONDON, July 5. -- The marriage of the Hon. Phyllis Astor to Lord Willoughby de Eresby will take place at the church in Taplow July 27.
The Public Service Commission's hearing on Mayor O'Brien's complaint against rates of the Bronx Gas and Electric Company opened yesterday with 300 Bronx women on hand to support the city's attack.

LONDON, July 5 -- The British Dominions, at another meeting today with the United Kingdom delegation, pressed even more strongly their view that the economic conference should continue. Although they put their case before tonight's American declaration was issued, the reasons they advanced in favor of going on strikingly bear out those mentioned in the American statement.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- Appointment of Arno B. Cammerer of Virginia as director of the National Park Service was announced today by Secretary Ickes as he accepted the resignation of Horace M. Albright.

The broad-shouldered silhouette with slim, straight skirt, together with marked favor for satins, novelty woolens and crepes, featured intian openings of Fall dress lines here yesterday by leading style houses. Among the firms showing yesterday were members of the Fashion Originators' Guild of America and the Dress Creators' League of America, Inc.

DETROIT, July 5 -- Testifying today at the resumption of the bank, investigation before Judge Keidan, Thomas G. Long, attorney for the closed First National Bank, stated that Arthur P. Leyburn, former chief examiner for the Seventh Federal Reserve District, had informed the directors on March 10, nearly a month after the banking holiday was declared by Governor Comstock, that the institution was solvent.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The withdrawal of the United States from the International Convention for the Abolition of Import and Export Prohibitions and Restrictions was announced here today with the publication of formal notification to this effect sent to the Secretary General of the League of Nations by Acting Secretary of State Phillips.

LONDON, Thursday, July 6 -- A midnight meeting of the gold-bloc nations at the World Economic Conference decided that the American stand, as reiterated by the United States delegation last evening after cable and telephone communication with President Roosevelt, only emphasized the differences which, temporarily at least, were irreconcilable.

Two of the five men from the barge S.G. Wilder, who were missing on Tuesday night after drifting off the Jersey coast in a dory, were picked up yesterday as the threeday coastal storm receded and taken safely into Norfolk, Va. The three others were believed lost.

CHICAGO, July 5 -- The chinch bug has become a big factor in the corn market. Reports indicating that the infestation in Illinois was the worst ever, known, and had caused losses of 20,000,000 to 25,000,000 bushels in Southwest Iowa, sent prices skyrocketing to new high marks for the season and nearly 5 cents above the inside figures of the morning before heavy profit taking checked the advance.

BERLIN, July 5. -- The Third Reich of Adolf Hitler will have three classes of inhabitants if authoritative interpretations of the speech of Dr. Pfundtner, State Secretary in the Reich Ministry of the Interior, before the Academy for Administrative Science yesterday are a guide to the structure of the future Nazi State.

President ROOSEVELT is apparently making strenuous and sincere efforts to prevent the Economic Conference from dying in its tracks. One report is that he would favor some kind of stable "international dollar" as a yardstick to be used in measuring values in foreign exchange.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Expansion of business activity continued in June, offsetting usual seasonal adverse influences, the Department of Commerce reported today. Production in that month reached the highest point since the middle of 1931.

BERLIN, July 5 -- Accepting failure of the London Economic Conference as an established, fact, the German Government and German financial circles are already making preparations to meet the resulting situation. There is no doubt here that failure of the conference will further complicate Germany's economic position which in turn will have repercussions on the political situation at home.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- President Roosevelt issued an executive order today continuing the 15 per cent cut in pay of Federal employes.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 5 -- Walter Hagen, grand old warrior of American golf, jumped into the lead today with a brilliant 68, five under par, in the first round of the British open golf championship.
The garment centre in the vicinity of Seventh Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street was in turmoil at noon yesterday when 500 Communist demonstrators clashed with the police.

PARIS, July 5. -- Mrs. Dorothy Caruso Ingram and Dr. Charles Holder were married here today In the Mairie of the Sixteenth Arrondissement in the presence of two witnesses and their respective daughters, Gloria Caruso and Peggy Holder.

Seven men alleged to be connected with the Communist fur workers' unions, and charged with assaulting other workers, were taken to Police Headquarters yesterday by Lieutenant James Tyke and other policemen attached to the Criminal Alien and Radical Investigation Bureau.

Bank reports for the end or the half-year are uniformly showing large increase in deposits, as compared with their statements at the end of March. Not all the reports of June 30 have yet been published, but the general trend had been foreshadowed by the fact that the New York City member banks, reporting to the Federal Reserve as of June 28, made the increase in demand and time deposits $613,000,000 compared with March 29.
LONDON, July 5 -- The quarters of the United States delegation to the World Economic Conference have never been as active as they were all day today.

CLEVELAND, July 5.-- Reynolda, fleet 2-year-old son of The Laurel Hall, owned by Henry H, Knight of Chicago and driven by Marvin Childs of Indianapolis, won the annual renewal of the $2,400 Rainy Day Sweepstakes at the North Randall Grand Circuit track today in straight heats.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 5 -- The Prince of Wales came to St. Andrews today to sea a fine day's play in the British open championship proper. He certainly saw some exciting golf, with Walter Hagen as its leading figure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial this morning you attack Dr. Frick, the new German Minister of the Interior, for advocating a healthy race of heroes. You charge him with taking a step back to the practices of ancient savages.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Nature hid gold in crannies and crevices about the earth. It was mined by men who spent it for things made by men. It was spent and respent, passing from hand to hand until it found itself eventually hidden by man in the subcellars of the central banks, coining to rest again beneath the surface of the very earth from which it was taken.

Favorites continued to lose with Monotonous regularity at Aqueduct yesterday. The shortest priced choice was Character, at 13-20, which met defeat in the third race. Jamison, the St. James gelding which races for Charles H. Miller, won, his score being considered an upset by many.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Complaints against unwarranted increases of from two to three cents a loaf in bread prices in various parts of the country were turned over to the Department of Justice for investigation today by Secretary Wallace, following warnings by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, repeated today by George N. Peek, chief administrator, that "this is no time to increase the profit on bread."

H.O. Caster of the executive committee of Henry L. Doherty Co., New York, has been nominated for president of the American Gas Association. The election will be held at the association's fifteenth annual convention, in Chicago on Sept. 26, which date has been designated as International Gas Industry Day at the Century of Progress Exposition.

Sales of copper were made in the domestic market yesterday at 8 1/2 cents a pound, as compared with 8 to 8 1/4 cents on Monday. The volume of business done at the high level was said to be small. However, all producers are quoting 8 1/2 cents a pound delivered in the domestic market.
MILAN, Italy. June 25 (by Mail). -- Hats with handles, bumpers, square trims and adjustable shades are on display in the men's futuristic headwear exhibition recently inaugurated here.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Evidence that Kuhn, Loeb Co. lent more than $88,000,000 to 175 stock brokerage firms in the five-year period that saw the stock market boom and crash was made public today by the Senate banking investigating committee.

LONDON, July 5 -- The immediate fate of the World Economic Conference will be decided tomorrow morning at a meeting of the steering committee consisting of the chief delegates of sixteen of the sixty-six nations represented in the conference.

MIAMI, Fla., July 5 -- Predicting failure of the present efforts of Ambassador Sumner Welles to settle Cuban troubles by mediation and charging the envoy from the United States with two basic errors. General Mario G. Menocal, former President of Cuba, today said he favored elimination of the Platt Amendment to the Cuban Constitution, authorizing United States Intervention.

LONDON, July 5 -- The heads of the World Economic Conference delegations of the gold bloc countries, who met hurriedly tonight, studied the new United States note to the conference and considered that it left only one course for the conference -- adjournment until the Americans had finished devaluing the dollar and raising prices and were ready to discuss the question of stabilization.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Secretary Swanson has decided to ask President Roosevelt to allocate $77,000,000 to modernize the battleships and all other units of the United States fleet.

PARIS, July 5 -- The members of the United States Davis Cup team, practicing here for the coming interzone play, today joyously greeted news from Wimbledon of Ellsworth Vines's defeat of Henri Cochet.
CHICAGO, July 5 -- Baseball's contribution to the World's Fair, "the game of the century," found Chicago sweltering tonight in a world's series atmosphere.
CLEVELAND, July 5 (AP) -- The White Sox battered their way back into fourth place at the expense of the Indians today, winning 10 to 6, by making one big inning count. Cleveland fell to fifth.

PARIS, July 5 -- Out of what is described as "the catastrophe of the London conference," many morals are being drawn today in France. And of these one which merits attention is the suggestion made by La Volonte, a Left newspaper, which often reflects the views of the Foreign Office and has been a consistent supporter of the late Aristide Briand's policy.

Earl Dean Howard, deputy administrator of the National Industrial Recovery Act, sent a message to the conferences in the apparel trades yesterday thanking the leaders for their cooperation and urging them to complete their codes of hours and wages as speedily as possible.

JOHN QUINCY ADAMS was a college professor. General GARFIELD was a college president -- which is worse. In his latest piece in The Herald Tribune Professor MOLEY, perhaps not without thought of vindicating his order from gibes, takes his text from another professor, WOODROW WILSON: "Administration is government in action."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 5 -- Award of 149 fellowships and scholarships to students in the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences was announced today by Dean George H. Chase. The awards amount to $74,215.

MADRID, July 5 -- Judge and spectators burst into tears during a highly emotional court session today when General, Sanjurjo, Spain's convict General, who is doing time in Duero Penitentiary as leader of the military revolt of August, 1932, attempted to exonerate thirty-odd companions who are just now undergoing trial.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/2 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- Legal Holiday.
TOKYO, July 6. -- Soviet recognition of Manchukuo is implied in the first sentence of the Russian offer to sell the Chinese Eastern Railway, which reads:

After reopening with something of a flourish yesterday, the stock market ran into occasional difficulties. Aside from the fact that the foreign news was disconcerting, the eagerness to take profits was everywhere indicated. Selling was aggressive at times, but at no time produced acute weakness.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP). -- A last effort to save for George Washington's home town of Alexandria, Va., the quaint time-tinctured apothecary shop at which he traded was started tonight at Gadsby's tavern.
Sales of small dwellings formed the bulk of realty trading in New Jersey yesterday.

Weakness in the dollar in international exchange during the holiday caused an upturn of 15 points at the opening of the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Best quotations, however, were made on the call, and the market came under pressure, which caused a break, with the loss 17 to 23 points at the close.

LONDON, July 5 -- On this day, when doubt as to future prospects of the World Economic Conference was at its greatest, there came out the first concrete result it has produced. This concerned wheat -- the first of the world economic problems taken up.

The deposits of the Bankers Trust Company amounted on June 30 to $693,872,807, against $621,867.431 on Dec. 31; resources were $822,106,504, against $762,609,324 at the year's end. The company reports surplus and undivided profits of $62,519,452, compared with $77,136,109.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated July 1:
LONDON, July 5. -- Attacks on the Hitler government and a declaration by Captain Anthony Eden, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, were features of the debate in the House of Commons tonight.

VIENNA, July 5. -- The Nazi leaders, who have fled or been expelled from Austria have just, received a severe rebuke from Chancellor Hitler of Germany close to the Austrian frontier, Says tonight's Heimwehr organ, the Abendblatt.

Reforms in methods of handling unlisted securities on the Curb Exchange, which have been tacitly approved by Attorney General Bennett, are expected to be incorporated in the Exchange's rules and regulations by the board of governors today.
MONTREAL, July 5 (AP) -- Doubles by Oscar Roettger and John Winsett gave Montreal a 3-to-2 decision in ten innings over Jersey City today.

Geologists Understand Seismics. Geologists from all over the world are arriving here for their sixteenth international conference at Washington. It is not stated in what hall the scientists will meet, but it would be a happy thought if one of the government buildings were placed at their disposal!

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., July 5 -- Ray Maxwell of Wykagyl and his son, Lloyd, a junior at Dartmouth, won the Westchester father-and-son golf championship after a play-off at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The release of 1,891 employes of the Commerce Department, effective July 15, was announced today by Secretary Roper, in line with the $7,000,000 reduction in the department's appropriation for the new fiscal year.

BUFFALO, N.J., July 5 (AP) -- The Newark Bears defeated Buffalo tonight, 12 to 5, in a comedy of errors. The Bisons were guilty of eight miscues while the game was marked by 16 bases on balls and 25 men were left on the sacks. Ollie Carnegie hit his eighteenth home run of the season for Buffalo.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 5 -- Judging by her scoring triumphs on the links this season, Miss Rosalie Knapp will bear close watching when it comes time to play the national women's championship.
ST. LOUIS, July 5 (AP) -- Tommy Bridges held the St. Louis Browns to six hits and struck out nine men as the Detroit Tigers took the final game of the series today, 9 to 4.

Administrative salaries of the seven electric companies of the Consolidated Gas group will total more in 1933 than in 1932, although the officers of the companies received a general salary cut on May 1. The total increase in the New York Edison Company this year will be $31,985.85.

The outstanding feature of the reports of condition now being issued by local banks and trust companies is the substantial gain in deposits indicated for the last three months. The next most striking aspect of the statements is the evidence they provide that bankers are pursuing a highly conservative course and are jealously preserving their liquidity, despite the return-flow of deposits and the general recovery in business and in public confidence.

Formation of the general committee for the Eastern railroads was announced yesterday. This body, which will assume the functions of the committee on preventable wastes of the Eastern lines, will act to further economies by the elimination of unnecessary duplications of service and equipment.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- President Roosevelt turned to a plan for a managed domestic currency based on the 1924-1925, commodity price levels, and to a vigorous prosecution of his domestic recovery program following indications of a recess of the World Economic Conference at London.

The National Industrial Recovery Act is "truly a noble experiment" of great promise to the economic life of the nation, Samuel Untermyer said yesterday as he was preparing to leave for London to attend an international Jewish conference on the situation in Germany.
Seven American track and field athletes sailed on the Deutschland of the Hamburg-American line last night for a tour of Europe, which will take them to ten meets in six countries.

Professor Earl Dean Howard, deputy administrator of the National Industrial Recovery Act, collapsed from an attack of indigestion yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker after conferring with industrial leaders in the apparel trades. He was put to bed after receiving medical attention and it was announced that he expected to resume his conferences in a day or two.

A majority of the commodities traded on local exchanges closed higher yesterday. In this group were silver, coffee, rubber, silk, hides, wool tops and copper, while sugar and cocoa were lower. Trading was fairly active. Cash prices were irregular, with many new high prices established.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Forty-five States, the District of Columbia and Hawaii shared in the distribution of $51,531,731 of emergency relief funds through June 30.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Chief Executive and his advisers on industrial control were represented today as determined that obstacles which have prevented other industries from following the lead of cotton textiles in drawing up codes for minimum wages and maximum hours should be removed Immediately.

HARROGATE, England, July 5 (Canadian Press). -- The Yorkshire Cricketers, champion county eleven, were dismissed for a first innings total of 240 runs by the British West Indies team today. Before close of play the West Indies had scored 29 runs for no wickets.

In spite of the holiday interruption steel operations increased this week to 56 per cent of ingot capacity as compared with 53 per cent last week, according to the review of The Iron Age, which appears this week a day later than usual.

Bank clearings for twenty-one major cities in the week of four business days ended on Wednesday showed a gain of 8.6 per cent compared with the corresponding week of last year. Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. In the week ended on June 28 the gain over the corresponding week of last year was 26.9 per cent.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 6. -- Tribute to the way in which President Roosevelt is dealing with the farm mortgage situation was paid today by A. Wellington Taylor, dean of the Graduate School of Business Administration of New York University.

The aggregate market value of all listed shares on the New York Stock Exchange increased from $32,473,061,395 on June 1, to $36,348,747,926 on July 1, a gain of $3,875,686,531, or 11.9 per cent. In May, the gain was $5,658,000,000, or 21.1 per cent. Since March 1, the total theoretical increase in the value of listed shares has been $16,648,000,000.
PARIS, July 6 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

In the heaviest trading of any day this year but one, the listed bond market advanced briskly yesterday in all departments. Railroad liens scored the most spectacular gains in the domestic list with utility and industrial issues by no means laggard.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 6 (AP). -- A united veteran movement to give veterans power in politics was advocated by a number of speakers at today's session of the annual State encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, at which more than 800 delegates are registered.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest of the year to date, while total bills discounted reached a new low figure for the year. No other important item in the system went to a new high or low point.
WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The text of the regulations governing issuance of securities, made public today by the Federal Trade Commission, follows in full:

COPPER GULCH, Col., July 6. -- Because a gray-haired Negro became lost on a copper-colored mountainside at the edge of dazzling Royal Gorge, there is a new stream of glittering gold and silver wealth flowing out of Southwestern Colorado.

The great official and patriotic duty of the hour is to raise prices. Word to that effect has gone forth from Washington. It is strange, then, that upon certain efforts to raise prices the Government comes down with a heavy hand. It looks with a tolerant and hopeful eye upon the large rise in the price of wheat.
LONDON, July 6 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Iron production in June, according to The Iron Age, was 1,265,007 tons, or 41,166 tons a day, compared with 887,252 tons, or 28,621 tons daily, in May, an increase on a daily basis of 47.3 per cent. The daily average in June was the highest since July, 1931.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 6. -- Fifty-seven polo players, representing fourten combinations, took part in seven matches at the Meadow Brook Club today. It was the most active day in the club's history since its organization in 1881.

Copyright, 1933, by The NANA, Inc., and THE NEW IDES TIMES Company. Had President Roosevelt's critics any real understanding of what constitutes monetary stability, his statement last Monday would not have proved the bombshell it did. On the contrary, even the gold standard countries would have acclaimed the President as their deliverer.

Chaco Imitates Messines. Another triumph for civilization is registered in the Chaco jungle, where Bolivia and Paraguay have been engaged in mutual slaughter for close to two years. The two nations are small, Bolivia having a population of less than three millions, the other less than a million.
HENLEY ON THAMES, England, July 6. -- Two American crews came through successfully in heats of the Royal Henley Regatta today.

LONDON, July 6. -- Second only in force of effect to the speech of Secretary Hull in the meeting of the bureau or steering committee this morning were the arguments presented by Prime Minister Bennett of Canada in favor of continuance of the economic conference.

With the traditional market leader, United States Steel, advancing into new high ground, the trading on the Stock Exchange took on yesterday the appearance of the older bull movements. Steel common rose to 64% and closed at 64. Other steel stocks advanced sharply, many of them to "new highs."

LONDON, July 6 (Canadian Press). -- A near triple century by Leslie G. Ames, famous test player who tallied 295 runs, and centuries by Todd and Valentine, aided Kent in scoring a smashing victory over Gloucestershire in a county cricket championship match ending today at Folkestone.

BERLIN, July 6. -- Boerse Interest was still concentrated today on the bond market, which began to show considerable firmness after the Boerse authorities appealed to the government several times yesterday in an effort to stop the slump. For whose account the purchases are made "is virtually unknown," according to Berlin financial writters, but today's purchases were sufficient to lift bond quotations 3 per cent.

DETROIT, July 6 (AP). -- The Detroit Free Press says tonight in a dispatch from Washington that President Roosevelt has instructed the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to solve the banking situation in Detroit. It adds that the way will be paved at a meeting tomorrow afternoon in Washington for the re-establishment of credit facilities throughout the State.

LONDON, July 6. -- The Very Rev. Arthur S. Duncan-Jones, Dean of Chichester, who flew back from Germany yesterday, has written a letter to The London Times describing an interview with Chancellor Hitler on his attitude to the church.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 6. -- Herbert L. Bowman, New York veteran, five-time winner of the crown, scored a brilliant quarterfinal round victory over John No-grady, St. John's College star, to gain the semi-finals of the annual New Jersey men's tennis championship today at the Montclair Athletic Club.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 6 (AP). -- Johnny "Wilson outpitched Big Jim Weaver to score his seventh, victory today as Buffalo squared the series with the Newark league leaders through a 5-to-2 triumph.

The longest trial of a criminal case in the history of the Federal Court in this district neared an end yesterday when a weary jury which had heard evidence for 109 days listened to a three-hour charge by Judge John M. Woolsey and began deliberating at 4:45 P. M.
After holding in a narrow range for several hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced sharply more than 30 points and ended at gains of 22 to 26 points, or about 1/4 cent a pound.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 6. -- "The better the day the better the deed," was the motto that Miss Helen Hicks adopted today when she started her second round of the women's Long Island 54-hole medal play competition trailing the leader, Miss Rosalie Knapp, by five strokes.
ENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 6 (AP). -- Two different methods of rowing the mile and five-sixteenths of the Henley distance brought the same result for two victorious American eights today.

In London the order to the Economic Conference is "Carry on." But this does not mean "As you were." The biggest subjects hitherto under discussion are to be dropped, at least temporarily. There will be no more public debate about stabilization, whether of exchange or currencies, no further proposals to cut down high tariffs, no revival of the Pittman resolution respecting return to the gold standard with the use of silver as an added reserve.

The Carter Oil Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, advanced yesterday Kansas and Oklahoma crude oil prices 10 cents a barrel. As a result a dual-price structure prevails in these States. On Wednesday the Continental Oil Company initiated a rise of 33 cents a barrel, which was subsequently met by several other oil companies operating in that area.

San Francisco, Cal. A new issue of $980,000 city and county of San Francisco (Cal.) relief bonds will be placed on the market today by a syndicate comprising the Bankers Trust Company, R.H. Moulton Co., Inc., Dean Witter Co. and the Security First Company of Los Angeles.

Free Summer classes designed for jobless and partly employed adults will open today under State auspices in nine New York City public schools and other meeting places donated by civic, charitable and private organizations.

Strange tales come from New York's Aquarium -- recalling the healing springs of medieval days. People afflicted with skin diseases beg for permission to dip their hands into tanks teeming with tropical fish. It is because of a casual announcement made by Drs. COATES and BREDER.

LONG BEACH, Cal., July 6. -- Yale and Washington were rated almost on even terms as the favorites, as six slender shells swept through workouts on the Olympic 2,000-meter rowing course today in final preparation for the intercollegiate sprint championship which opens tomorrow with preliminary races.

A firmer tone in Federal funds which rose to 1 per cent at the close from an earlier 1/2 and a charge of 1/8, which had been prevailing regularly up to this session featured. Tightening in rate was ascribed to combination of disbursements at the half-year and withdrawals for holiday account which left the lending banks with reduced reserves.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- A picture or America as a kind of prodigal who has selfishly wasted his birthright in gaining material power and must now be educated to a new mode of life, was painted by Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, before the teachers of the country at the National Education Association convention here this evening.

The combination last night of Beethoven's Ninth symphony and a fine moonlight evening drew the first big audience that has appeared at the Stadium concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra since the Summer season opened a week ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Eight thousand men and women in Federal employment, a majority of them of the lower salary bracket, have been dismissed. More are to follow, according to department chiefs at Washington. The Federal budget must be balanced.
CHICAGO, July 6 -- The National League is still trying to catch up with Babe Ruth, but apparently with no more success than in recent world's series conflicts.
Small frame dwellings continue to feature the market in New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 5, unless otherwise specified:

The combination last night of Beethoven's Ninth symphony and a fine moonlight evening drew the first big audience that has appeared at the Stadium concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra since the Summer season opened a week ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Eight thousand men and women in Federal employment, a majority of them of the lower salary bracket, have been dismissed. More are to follow, according to department chiefs at Washington. The Federal budget must be balanced.
CHICAGO, July 6 -- The National League is still trying to catch up with Babe Ruth, but apparently with no more success than in recent world's series conflicts.

NEWARK AIRPORT, N.J., July 6. -- Lincoln Ellsworth, accompanied by Mrs. Ellsworth, left here today for San Francisco in a United Air Lines plane, starting the explorer's journey to New Zealand, where he will make preparations for his flight between the Ross and Weddell Seas in the South Polar region.

Fifty days out of Bathurst, capital of Gambia, a British colony on West Africa's Kerry Coast, the twenty-six-foot Estonian sloop Ahto sailed into New York Harbor yesterday to win a 4,000-mile transatlantic race, from the British cutter Enterprise.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., July 6. -- Governor Lehman, Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner; Harry E. Smith, Warren County Sanitary Inspector, and W.B. Woodbury of New York and Lake George, president of the association, are to speak at the anniversary luncheon meeting of the Lake George Association at the Lake George Club Aug. 12.

The annual report of the Public Utility Holding Corporation of America shows total assets of $26,936,082 on May 31, reflecting a write-down of investments from $39,000,000 the year before to $30,000,000 on May 31, before reserves. A part of this reduction was effected in the reduction of the special reserve from 57,474,000 to $4,119,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the editorial "A Confusing Statement," is it fair to criticize our President at this time, especially when he is separated from his "Brain Trust" by the Atlantic Ocean? You should take into consideration the wonderful things the present administration has accomplished, such as the general increase of wages, commodity prices,

The Eastern railroad coordinating committee elected yesterday as executive secretary, M.C. Kennedy, now chief railroad examiner for the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. He is a consulting engineer and was formerly with Coverdale Colpitts.
SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., July 6. -- A 14-year-old youngster, Charles Petttijohn, playing from the Westchester Country Club, gained the semi-final round of the Westchester junior golf championship today.

Important provisions for stabilizing the printing and pulp and paper industries were adopted yesterday in tentative codes that will be submitted soon for consideration by the nation's printing and paper employers.

George Eilperin, Republican leader of the Fourteenth Assembly District in Brooklyn, was appointed yesterday by Mayor O'Brien to fill the $10,840 position in the Board of Taxes and Assessments left vacant by the resignation of Jobn R. Crews.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 5, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,225,000,000, an increase of $29,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $152,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- After having won a technical victory at the World Economic Conference in influencing it to continue Its sessions with currency stabilization eiliminated, President Roosevelt today concentrated his attention on domeatic fiscal and currency policies and the development of the national recovery program.

While the developments at the World Economic Conference in London were watched carefully yesterday, the markets appeared to be more interested in the progress that is being made in general domestic business. News that the President is pressing for aggressive action under his industrial recovery program gave fresh impetus to the speculative movement.

PARIS, July 6. -- Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, who, in the opinion of many persona here, alone among the delegates to the world conference made good use of his time in London, was received here today by Premier Daladier and Foreign Minister Paul-Boncour.

With crude rubber futures setting the pace, nearly all commodities traded on local exchanges were higher for the day yesterday. Raw silk futures were lower and wool tops were unchanged, but others gained. Many new high levels were reached again in the cash markets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Did not the President say that he digapproved of a diversion of attention from the fundamental questions presented at the conference to "artificial and temporary" stabilization of a few currencies? Somehow these vital words "artificial and temporary" escaped your attention, judging by your Fourth of July editorial.

The railroads as a group reported for May their first increase in gross revenues over a year before since 1929. By continued reductions in expenses, they converted the improvement in gross, which amounted to 1.3 per cent, into an increase of 248.8 per cent in net operating income.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 6. -- In her winning effort today Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, exhibited her usual game in playing to her opponent's backhand, using very few strokes. She mainly topped the ball that was sent either deep or short.

Laurence A. Steinhardt, the new United States Minister to Sweden, sailed yesterday on the French liner Ile de France expressing surprise at "assumptions" that because he was going via London he would carry "last-minute" messages to the American delegation at the World Economic Conference.

The Grace Line announced yesterday that three ships which ware withdrawn temporarily last year from its "B" service between New York and the west coast of South America would be returned to service immediately to accommodate the increased volume of trade which has developed in the last few months.

The Giants and the Senators have become the favorites in the betting on the major league pennant races, according to the mid-season prices now quoted. The Giants, from fifth place 21-1 shots in April are now held at 6 to 5 to take the National League flag.
CHICAGO, July 6. -- Aggressive buying of corn developed again today and sent that grain to new ground for the season. The close was virtually at the top, with net gains 2 3/8 to 2 3/8 cents.

VIENNA, July 6. -- The Austro-Gennan conflict has now extended to the air. The Austrian Broadcasting Company has addressed a protest to Admiral Carpendale, president of the International Broadcasting Union, and to Herr Gieseke, Germany's representative in the union, protesting that anti-Austrian broadcasts from Munich are in violation of the international agreement not to broadcast international political propaganda that might cause bitterness.

Formal approval was given yesterday by the Board of Estimate to the housing plan of Sloan Robertson, architects, for the Chrystie-Forsyth Street area. This project contemplates the building of twelve-story model apartment houses on five blocks of the city-owned tract, with 6,381 rooms, renting at an average of $10.75 a month.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP). -- The administration today abandoned all plans for informal arms reduction negotiations until Autumn, convinced that nothing could be done in the meantime to reconcile the prevailing and persisting disagreements on this vexing question.
WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated July 3:

Two stowaways, one of whom lived in Brooklyn, were found asphyxiated yesterday afternoon in their hiding place in a cargo hold of the Dollar liner President Garfield at a Jersey City pier after Federal agents from Ellis Island had fumigated the hold.

CHICAGO, July 6. -- Two reasons were advanced before the National Education Association today by Robert M. Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, for the present atmosphere of hostility and indifference toward public schools. One he found, much as did Secretary Ickes, in "that laissez-faire economics which the nineteenth century left us and which could tolerate nothing unless it paid."

Osbert, a British, immigrant who had had his troubles, is dead in France " at a ripe age." In 1924 and West Kent he was minding his own business and browsing, when the staghounds got after him. He took to the water, as was natural in so capable a swimmer, and was making his way without asking any favors.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The story of the struggle of the Pennsylvania and other Eastern railroad systems to gain control of the Pittsburgh West Virginia Railway, a small but strategic line in the Pittsburgh district, was told today before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Strict weeding out of non-essential, construction projects from the government's public works program was advocated today by Director Lewis W. Douglas of the budget as he assisted President Roosevelt in scanning the long list of undertakings proposed by the special public works board.

There is one story in "Pink Parade," J.B. Booth's reminiscences of writers and race horses, music halls and tap rooms in London before the World War, about Sarah Bernhardt and her little book, "Noel."

BUENOS AIRES, July 6. -- Bolivia is driving the fiercest offensive of the war against the Paraguayan positions defending Forts Ayala [Nanawa], Gondra and Alihuata, according to official Paraguayan reports reaching Buenos Aires tonight.
BERLIN, July 6. -- Chancellor Hitler held a council of state today with recently appointed Governors to coordinate the various former Federal States into one Third Reich.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 6. -- Reports from Italy that Premier Mussolini and King Victor Emmanuel had been made honorary members of the American Legion were denied at national headquarters of the organization here today.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 6. -- Nassau County detectives had another gem theft case on their hands this morning. It was reported from the home of Clarence, E. Tuttle of Old Westbury Road that burglars had entered some time between 2 o'clock this morning and 7:30 and had stolen $5,500 worth of jewelry and $500 in gold coins.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey decided yesterday to let a jury pass on Joseph W. Harriman's mental fitness to stand trial for a crime. The taking of testimony on his mental condition will begin today.

Surrogate James A. Foley has ordered the case of six Wendel claimants turned over to the Bar Association's grievance committee "because of the persistent and unwarranted efforts" to offer evidence from interested witnesses, he disclosed yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, July 6 (AP). -- After repeated attempts to compete against time in two straightaway dashes had failed, contestants and officials of the National Air Races today decided to end the post-race schedule, drawn up after completion of the regular events July 4, and make awards on previous performances.

Two east side and two west side tenement houses, some of which had been held by the same interests for more than a quarter of a century, figured in the Manhattan realty sales reported by brokers yesterday. With deals also reported in the Bronx and suburban areas, the market generally continued to reflect the improvement which has been evident for several weeks.

ALBANY, July 6. -- Evidence to show that the New York Power and Light Corporation had declared a dividend of 42.61 per cent on its common stock last year was put before the Public Service Commission today by Colonel Charles G. Blakeslee, counsel for the commission.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- A reduction of about 10 per cent in demands on the Federal funds for direct relief of unemployment has been occasioned by the combined effects of seasonal conditions and general improvement in business.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 6. -- Every citizen must join in the government's effort to create jobs and buying power if there is to be national recovery, Governor Lehman said in an address here tonight. He warned that the public must not depend upon government help and agencies alone.

Watching Demand for Staples. Owing to the extremely heavy advance business placed during the last two months on a wide variety of staple and semi-staple merchandise, manufacturers here are watching closely to determine the extent of the reaction, if any, which may occur in the call for these goods during the period directly ahead.
R.S. Reynolds Take East End Av. Apartment -- Other Leases.

The extermination of the whale is threatened, according to Dr. Lewis Radcliffe of the Federal Bureau of Fisheries. In a report submitted to the American Chemical Society, made public yesterday, Dr. Radcliffe pointed out that the League of Nations treaty designed to preserve the 1,000-year-old industry has not yet been adopted by a sufficient number of countries to make it effective.

Mayor O'Brien, with Police Commissioner Bolan and other officials of the Police Department, attended yesterday the sailing of the Clermont with 3,000 children and mothers on the first of the department's outings this season for the poor children of the city.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Rules and regulations to carry out the new Federal Securities Act for the protection of American investors against worthless stock issues were made public by the Federal Trade Commission this afternoon and will apply to all stock offerings sold after July 27.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The plight of the home-owner in the metropolitan district burdened with a heavy mortgage has not been solved by the Home-Owners' Loan Act of 1933 just passed by Congress. The act, admirable though it may be in many respects, does not adequately meet the situation for the following reasons:
Twenty-two properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were put up at foreclosure auctions yesterday. All were bought in by the plaintiffs, half of the properties going to banks. The results follow:

LONDON, July 6. -- The French delegates to the economic conference, whose attitude is shared by those of other countries on the gold standard, were disposed tonight to emphasize the negative aspect of today's decision of the bureau or steering committee to continue work.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 6. -- There was one of the greatest hunts in golfing history at St. Andrews today when Gene Sarazen, drawn two couples behind Walter Hagen, chased him and nearly caught him; then, after one tragical fall, finished a little further behind than when he had started.
WINDSOR, Conn., Duly 6. -- The 1933 Bay State circuit meeting came to an end today with Van Sandt, chestnut son of San Francisco and Mabel Trask, unbeaten in the 2:13 class trot.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Charges that prices are being rixed on aluminum and steel rails on an international basis have been under investigation by the Department of Justice and the inquiry will be pressed, Attorney General Cummings said today.

CHICAGO, July 6 (AP). -- Frankie Parker of Milwaukee and Wilbur (Junior) Coen of Kansas City, battled their way into the semi-finals of the national clay courts singles championship today and battled was the word for it.

Following a conference yesterday with Rear Admiral Yates Stirling, commandant and Captain Paul B. Dungan, manager of the navy yard at Brooklyn, Representative William F. Brunner of Queens and Representative John J. Delaney of Brooklyn announced they would go to Washington next week in an effort to obtain more work for the yard.
WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The War Department Issued the following orders today:

Two alleged counterfeiters, who bad been the objects of an eight-months search by the Federal Secret Service and the police, were arrested early yesterday under circumstances indicating a new turn in counterfeiting.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith assumed the leadership yesterday in a non-partisan movement to insure the renomination and re-election of Surrogate James A. Foley, whose term will expire this year.

ATLANTA, July 6. -- John King Ottley, 65-year-old financier and sportsman, was Kidnapped on the main street of Atlanta today, but talked his way to freedom a few hours later near Suwanee, thirty miles north of here. One of the abductors was known to him as a peddler he had befriended.

A plea addressed to the women of the United States to support the disarmament policies of President Roosevelt regardless of Senatorial opinion was made yesterday by Miss Mary A. Dingman. Miss Dingman is chairman of the Women's Disarmament Committee in Geneva, Switzerland.
The text of the address by Donald R. Richberg, general counsel of the National Recovery Administration, at a luncheon of the Merchants Association yesterday at the Hotel Astor follows:
MONTREAL, July 6 (AP). -- Jersey City evened its four-game series with the Montreal Royals today, winning by the score of 11 to 3.
The Board of Estimate authorized an appropriation of $100,000 yesterday to combat pollution and offensive odors in Coney Island and Jamaica Bay.
