CHICAGO, July 6. -- After the last ball sank into Rick Ferrell's glove today, ending the baseball classic with the American Leaguers victorious, John McGraw, leader of the National Leaguers, bounded out of the dugout and shouldered his way through the crowd to the dressing rooms of his conquerors to extend congratulations.
Ina Claire will leave the cast of "Biography" on Friday night of next week. For the final two performances of the engagement on July 15, Ruth Weston will assume Miss Claire's role.

HE may go slipping into the Swilcan Burn today, but Hagen has made it quite a party so far in the British open over the historic St. Andrews links. He has been there with the old swagger, the cool air of confidence, the tread of a champion walking his own ground.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Thomas J. Lloyd, In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, expresses pleasing amazement in regard to the statement printed in my Sunday letter, "Repeai Delegates." He raises the question as to what plans are being made to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the coming of the franchise (1834) to the "common white man" in New York City, which later spread throughout the United States.

A merger of the County Trust Company and the Lawyers Trust Company is being negotiated. Announcement of the merger plan is expected to be made next week, according to officials of the institutions. Pending the announcement neither bank would divulge any details of the plan yesetrday.

MANILA, July 6. -- General Emilio Aguinaldo in an interview today said that unity on the question of independence was desirable and that since the entire dispute among Filipinos was over the Hawes Law the logical course was to reject the law and then achieve unity to undertake new proposals.
LONDON, July 6. -- The governors of the central banks of six gold standard countries will meet in Paris Saturday morning to endeavor to work out a plan for cooperation in remaining on gold.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 6. -- The Italian armada of twenty-four seaplanes, on the way to the Century of Progress Exposition in Chicago, will be delayed probably for several days until improved weather is reported between here and Cartwright, Labrador, 1,500 miles away.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 6. -- Mrs. Helen Wills Moody moved serenely along toward her sixth Wimbledon singles crown by gaining the final today. The prospect of an all-American title round in the famous tennis championships, however, was removed, as Miss Helen Jacobs, her fellow townswoman from Berkeley, Cal., lost to Miss Dorothy Round in the semi-finals.

Seventeen etchings and engravings by Rembrandt, Durer, Zorn and van Leyden were bequeathed to the Metropolitan Museum of Art by Mrs. Ida Kammerer, it was disclosed yesterday when her will was filed in the Surrogate's Court. No estimate of the value of the bequest was obtainable.

In their preoccupation with, domestic events, many Americans are unaware that improvement of prices and of business is being made not only in the United States hut in other countries where there is less disposition to attribute every gain to fluctuations in exchange.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- The allocation of $400,000,000 for immediate action on Federal public works projects was deferred again today by the Cabinet public works advisory committee until the departments could work out better groupings.
A cheerfully improbable tale of a stolen yacht and a never-ending party is told by Eric Hatch in "Five Days," published today by Little, Brown.

CLEVELAND, July 6. -- Dick Reynolds, driven by Ben White, veteran East Aurora (N.Y.) reinsman, stepped two of the greatest miles of his career today to win the historic Edwards Facing Stake, with a $1,000 value, in straight heats at the North Randall Grand Circuit meeting.

LONDON, July 6. -- One of the most important victories in today's decision to continue the World Economic Conference was for President Roosevelt's tariff truce, which would have expired had the conference adjourned.

Coining on swiftly from almost last place in a field of nine, the 5-year-old Bunting mare, Sweet Scent, owned by John Riches gained her second triumph in succession when she captured the Meadows Purse at Aqueduct yesterday.
With the exception of only one company, all of the following chanstore organizations in their reports for June showed continued improvement in sales.

Normal mid-year influences are reflected in this week's report of the Federal Reserve System, which covers the week ended on Wednesday. In connection with the flrst-of-the-month demands and the Fourth of July holiday requirements, money in circulation rose $77,000,000 and member-bank reserves were drawn down $67,000,000.

LONDON, July 6. -- The British view of today's Economic Conference development, as outlined by the delegation's spokesman, is that continuation is assured and there is no reason why monetary questions should not be considered by those countries that wish to do so.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A subcommittee of the House of Representatives is trying to determine who actually prevented Joseph Zangara from killing Franklin D. Roosevelt. Was It Mrs. W.F. Cross, or \vas it Tom Armour?

To the Editor of The New York Times: After an oppressively hot Summer day in New York a night ferryboat ride across the Hudson was welcome, both for the mitigating river breath and unusual interest of the views from the deck.

The salaries of officers of five electric utilities in the city increased from 17 to 77 per cent in the period from 1927 to 1932, according to a computation read into the Public Service Commission's record yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Frank E. Taplin of Cleveland, president of the Pittsburgh West Virginia Railway Company today revealed before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee the following list of owners of the 222,930 shares of Pittsburgh West Virginia stock which he sold to the Pennroad Corporation in September, 1929, at $170 a share:

The dollar continued its downward plunge in the foreign exchange market yesterday. It fell to a new low in terms of all other moneys. Measured by its discount against the French franc, it dropped to a gold valuation of 72.3 cents.

Bass fishermen are having some very good luck in spots, according to reports received yesterday. For instance, out at Owassa Lake, N.J., a party of three from West Englewood landed six small mouths, one of which ran two and a half pounds and fought for fifteen minutes before he was landed.

One hundred per cent response to the strike call of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers in New York City was the announcement yesterday of Sidney Hillman, president of the union. The purpose of the stoppage, it was announced, is to compel wage increases of 10 to 20 per cent and to eliminate sweatshops in this city and in the suburbs and neighboring States.

The New York Stock Exchange and the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation announced yesterday the terms of the agreement under which the Exchange will retain the Allied Chemical issues on its stock list.

The reopening of the Actors Dinner Club at the Hotel Woodstock, 137 West Forty-third Street, last night, attracted many stage notables. Miss Ethel Barrymore was greeted enthusiastically as a new member of the board of directors, and Daniel Froham spoke in a reminiscent vein of the days when theatrical booking offices were located in Union Square, and dinner with wine cost only 40 cents.
The city administration called yesterday on Samuel Untermyer, one of its severest critics, to help it toward a solution of its transit and financial problems.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP). -- Before leaving on her second will-o'-the-wisp vacation trip from the White House, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt took issue today with National Woman's party feminists, who will hold a rally here Saturday in behalf of the equal rights amendment.
NEW YORK. Vicomtesse de Salignac Fenelon, after a visit with Mr. and Mrs. William D. Guthrie in Locust Valley, is at the Ritz-Carlton. She will sail for France on July 14.
Commodities Gain 1.7 Points in Week, but Lose 1.9 on Gold Basis.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 6. -- Despite a succession of blistering attacks on par and his lead, Walter Hagen of Detroit, 40-year-old American veteran of the golfing wars, kept in front of the field today at the halfway mark of the British open championship.

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Foreseeing legal attacks on the Industrial Recovery and Farm Adjustment Administrations, President Roosevelt today sought to work out a relation between the two organizations which would make both impregnable in the courts.
CHICAGO, July 6 -- The play-by-play description of the American League-National League game follows:

WASHINGTON, July 6. -- Important changes are contained in the Treasury's daily statement for July 1, the first day of the new fiscal year, issued today, in order that the government's financial situation under the new double budget system may be grasped at a glance.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that hereafter no bond or other obligation incurred subsequent to June 5, 1933, would be listed if the title contained the word "gold" or if the bond was payable in gold.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., July 7 -- Max Feinberg of Elmsford, who is a Junior at Dartmouth, became the Westchester junior golf chanmpion today after having carried off the medal honors in the tourney yesterday.

DETROIT, July 7 -- Charles S. Mott, vice president of the General Motors Company, former director of the Guardian group of banks and a director of the Guardian National Bank of Commerce of Detroit, proved to be a spectacular witness today in the bank inquiry before Judge Harry B. Keidan, who is sitting as a one-man grand jury.

CLEVELAND, July 7 -- In a startling upset Mary Reynolds today defeated Spencer McElwyn in the annual renewal of the $11,500 Championship Stallion Stake for 3-year-old trotters at the North Randall Grand Circuit meet.
PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP) -- With former Athletics leading the way, the White Sox defeated the Athletics 9 to 1 today in the first of a five-game series.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- With land values tending constantly upward, in line with the gradual increase in commodity prices, the Farm Credit Administration is finding little use for the $2,000,000,000 with which it was to refinance farm mortgages.

To the Editor of The New York Times: President Roosevelt in his two notes addressed to the economic conference in London stated that: "Revaluation of the dollar in terms of American commodities is an end from which the government and people of the United States cannot be diverted."

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- General Hugh S. Johnson, Industrial Administrator, issued a warning today to all industry that the administration could take no responsibility for continuing the perceptible increase in production unless industry itself used the facilities of the National Recovery Act to increase mass purchasing power.

French Government and municipal "bonds soared 6 1/2 to 10 points yesterday on the Stock Exchange, with bids plentiful and offerings scarce. The rise followed a jump of 7 3/4 to 9 points on the 6s of the cities of Bordeaux, Lyons and Marseilles on the previous day "when the French Government bonds showed only fractional advances.

PARIS, July 7 -- Governors of the central banks of the European gold standard group will meet at the Bank of France tomorrow to consider a concerted policy in view of the London Economic Conference's failure to reach a monetary accord. In financial circles the greatest importance is attached to these discussions because of the effects on exchange speculation and on stock market prosperity.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The TriState Gas and Electric Company today filed suit in the District Supreme Court for an injunction, recovery and accounting against Representative Gale H. Stalker of Elmira, N.Y., and his wife, Helen B. Stalker, charging that he abused his authority as former president of the concern and failed to pay for stock he acquired.

LONG BEACH, Cal., July 7 -- The East rose in all its might today to place three crews to one for the West in the final of the national intercollegiate sprint championship regatta. The deciding race will be rowed tomorrow over the 2,000meter Olympic course.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Fatalities from automobile accidents last year numbered 26,168 in the "death registration area," a decrease of 3,717 under 1931, the Census Bureau said today. Collisions with railroad trains and street cars were not covered in the survey.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Roosevelt has been told by Secretary Wallace that less than 2,000,000 acres of cotton had been contracted for at the close of business Thursday under the program of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration for taking at least 10,000,000 acres out of cultivation.

DENVER, July 7 (AP) -- One body was recovered tonight and Jefferson County authorities said at least twelve persons were missing in a flood which swept Bear Creek Canyon, a few miles west of Denver, demolishing one resort town and damaging another.

LONDON, July 7 -- Two of the four subcommittees of the economic division of the World Economic Conference seemed likely tonight to go on with virtually unanimous consent, while the third was doubtful and the fourth appeared certain to be abandoned.

Exchange of checks at the leading clearing houses of the country in June amounted to $23,277,361.469, an increase of 16.4 per rent from the preceding month and of 6.2 per cent from June of last year. It was likewise the largest for any month since March, 1932.

The twenty-two-day meeting of the Empire City Racing Association will begin today at the Yonkers course with the $2,000 added Empire City Handicap as the feature. Only three have been named, but one is Dark Secret from the Wheatley Stable, which, won the Brooklyn Handicap on Independence Day.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 7 -- The Hun School crew from United States provided the greatest thrills today in the Royal Henley regatta by rowing a dead heat with the London Rowing Club's B crew and then losing its second encounter in another great race by the narrow margin of one foot.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 7 -- 1 Playing on the beautiful championship turf where once the Doherty brothers of England and the giants of American tennis of another generation competed, James W. Nuthall defeated Harry S. Parker to lead the Oxford-Cambridge team to a clean sweep over the Rockaway Hunting Club in the first five matches for the Prince of Wales Cup today.

Subject to one important proviso, four of the principal wheat countries have agreed at London to attempt to control its production and export. The nations are the United States, Canada, Argentina and Australia. Their agreement has been long in the making. It was on May 3 that an American delegation sailed from New York to take part in preliminary discussions at Geneva.

Details in connection with arrests of left wing fur union members, including the seizure on 'Wednesday of several of its leaders, were cited yesterday by Jacques Buitenkant, attorney for the Needle Trades Workers Industrial Union, as indicating that the police were "cooperating with the opposing right wing, A.F. of L., union and the manufacturers."

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Stocks of refinable crude petroleum increased more than 7,000,000 barrels in May to a total of 343,588,000 barrels at the end of the month, according to figures issued today by the Bureau of Mines.

LONDON, July 7 -- Secretary of State Cordell Hull has begun to discuss with the heads of some of the other leading delegations at the World Economic Conference some of the concrete proposals he has heen studying with a view to keeping the conference doing not merely formal but real business.
In five weeks ended July 1, 1933, tonnage increased 11.7 per cent over 1932 period and for twenty-two weeks there was an increase of 4.6 per cent over corresponding period of preceding year.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, will return to the city to preach on Sunday mornings for the next six Sundays, beginning tomorrow. He will commute from his Summer home near Booth Bay Harbor, Me.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 7 (AP) -- General Italo Balbo announced today that he plans to order a take-off at dawn Saturday of the squadron of twenty-four seaplanes he is leading on a flight by stages to the Century of Progress Exposition in Chicago.
CHICAGO, July 7 -- The Giants tried to win with a one-round knockout today, but the idea failed to produce the desired effect.

Two brokers have been proposed for membership on the New York Stock Exchange through the transfer of membership. Daniel T. Pierce Jr., who paid $230,000 for his seat to Max L. Young of Adler, Coleman Co., will become a partner in Redmond Go., if elected.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange rose sharply again yesterday as a result of weakness in dollar exchange only to sag 35 points and close 19 to 23 points, or from 1-5 to nearly 1/2 cent a pound, lower than on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Roosevelt tonight ordered the preparation of a memorandum for the American delegation at the World Economic Conference in London, outlining the position of this government on the questions before the conference in their relation to this country's domestic recovery program.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Industrial Recovery Act and its administration are designed to benefit all labor, organized or unorganized, General Hugh S. Johnson declared in a statement issued tonight.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- New high levels for the season were established early today in wheat and corn, inflation talk as the result of the upturn in sterling exchange being the main influence. After an advance that carried wheat about 13 cents and corn as much as 14 cents above the inside figures of last week the markets turned easier, and the bulge was more than lost at the last.
Denny Shute and Craig Wood, who tied yesterday at St. Andrews for the British open championship, are members of the "new school" of golfers developing in this country.
Listlessly, almost impatiently, Joseph. W. Harriman sat in Federal court yesterday and heard an expert describe him as "mentally incompetent."

At the end of the longest criminal trial ever held in Federal Court in this district, Federal Judge John M. Woolsey imposed yesterday prison sentences and fines upon Otto E. Goebel and eight co-defendants, who had been convicted of mail fraud.

LONDON, July 7 -- The dollar's fall and the speculative wave in major financial centres exerted a powerful influence over the economic conference today. The effect was especially noteworthy behind the scenes in uniting even some of the leading champions of President Roosevelt's price-raising policy with the gold group in the belief that the time has come where it would be more dangerous not to put on the brakes than to put them on.
CHICAGO, July 7 (AP). -- Dominat nating the mile event from the rise of the barrier, S.W. Labrot's Monel won the top event of an ordinary program at Arlington Park today.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 6, unless otherwise specified:

The pound sterling rose to within about 12 cents of parity yesterday as the dollar, continuing its headlong plunge in the foreign exchange market, fell to 70 per cent of its former gold value. There were no new developments to account for the further fall of exchange.

PARIS, July 7 -- With the passage today a second time by both the Senate and Chamber of Deputies of the wheat bill, there are only a few minor points left to be ironed out and it is expected that the measure will become law within a few days.

WASHINGTON, July 7( AP) -- The American Federation of Labor today saw a threat to increasing prosperity in certain aspects of the rise in industrial productivity. In its monthly survey of business, the federation said:

A total of $38,577.000 of new short and long term bonds was placed on the market this week, the greater part accounted for by a single issue, that of $35,000.000 2 1/2 per cent debentures, of the Federal Intermediate Credit Bank system. This offering, representing the first public financing for the system since early in January, was quickly sold, most of it to institutional buyers.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Snow Nicholas, who were married last week in Blue Hill, Me., sailed on the Santa Rosa yesterday for the West Coast. Mrs. Nicholas is the former Miss Martha Milliken.
Back from his history-making home-run exhibition in Chicago, Babe Ruth celebrated his return to the Tankee Stadium yesterday by bouncing his nineteenth league homer of the season against the Tigers.
Ed Belinsky braced his legs on the quarterdeck in West Side Court yesterday and watched his mother-in-law, Mrs. Mildred Polinkoff, for storm signals. They broke out in a torrent of words.
The Italian liner Conte di Savoia sails today for Gibraltar, Villefranche and Genoa with 1,716 passengers, the record number for any one ship this year.

The Magnolia Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of the SoconyVacuutn Corporation, advanced yesterday crude oil prices in Oklahoma, North and North Central Texas 23 cents a barrel. In addition, the company raised prices in other parts of Texas, including the East Texas area, where a price of 75 cents was posted, an advance of 25 cents.
CINCINNATI, July 7 (AP) -- The Reds' batters came to life today and drove out fourteen hits for an 8 to 5 victory over the Braves.

PARIS, July 7 -- The dollar fell sharply again today, losing more than 70 centimes and closing at 18.18 francs. At this level the depreciation reached 29 per cent. The lowest figure during the Bourse hours was 18.05 and after the Bourse session trading took place at 18 even.

There are always silver linings to the clouds for fishermen. While the northeaster was raging off the coast of Long Island and New Jersey recently the anglers and boat captains did not fare so well, but the more experienced veterans were not alarmed unduly.

NOME, Alaska, July 7 (AP) -- The reported finding of Jimmy Mattern in Anadyrsk, a little Siberian trading village southeast of Nome on the other side of the Bering Sea, conforms to the tradition of Alaskan flying that that is where lost Arctic aviators usually turn up some time.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 7 -- The annual flower show of the Newport Garden Association and the Newport Horticultural Society opened at the Casino today. Mrs. Moses Taylor and Mr. and Mrs. M.M. Van Beuren tied for honors in the winning of the most first prizes.

The unemployment relief machinery of the city is stalled and 210,000 families, representing approximately 1,000,000 persons, are unable to get relief because the Board of Estimate has failed to authorize any expenditures for July.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 7 For the tenth successive year the golfing shotmakers from the United States dominated the final rounds of the British Open championship today over the classic St. Andrews terrain.

HENLEY, England, July 7 (AP) -- Seldom, if ever, have two more spectacular races been rowed on the historic Thames than the Hun School-London Rowing Club battles today. Both were ding-dong contests, but in the rerow the London eight managed to slip the prow of its shell across the finish, line a foot in front of the American boat.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., July 7 -- More than 500 persons attended a moonlight organ concert tonight on the terrace of Shallow Brook, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Clark Baldwin Jr. Archer Gibson was the guest artist. The proceeds will go toward the Westchester County Children's Association and the Westchester County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Chil- dren.

On Thursday further discussion of monetary questions was absolutely ruled out by the Economic Conference. Yet on Friday the subcommittee charged with the duty of recommending some measure or measures of financial reconstruction voted to go on wrestling with the problems of exchange and stabilization.
Several houses in Jersey City and Teaneck changed bands in New Jersey trading reported yesterday.

Maud Morgan, the harpist, who retired several years ago after an eminent career as artist and teacher, sailed yesterday on the Cunard liner Laconia to have a "spree" in England and Scotland at the age of 72.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Preparations are being made by the Recovery Administration for a nationwide publicity campaign as soon as the industrial code-making activities are better under way.

James J. Mattern, who was found yesterday in far-off Chukotka, on the Gulf of Anadyr, after the failure of his second attempt to set a record for a world flight, is the only man who has tried twice to circle the earth by plane and the first to try it alone.

A warning that if textbook sales, long an economic backbone of the book trade, do not soon pick up it will be impossible to publish scholarly works of importance in special fields but with little sales possibilities, was sent out yesterday by a committee representing ten textbook publishers.

Officials of the New York Guaranteed Mortgage Protection Corporation, of which George W. Naumburg is president, are reponted to have held several conferences recently with executives of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and other Federal officials in Washington with a view to obtaining a large loan to aid the holders of guaranteed mortgage certificates.

BERLIN, July 7 -- The Boerse displayed the same tendencies today that had characterized it for several preceding days. Stocks again were listless and generally weaker, while the bond market was lively and firm. A sensation on the Boerse was a new precipitate stump in the dollar to 3.02 marks.

The Drug Institute of America, Inc., announced yesterday that it would submit no fair-practice code to the authorities in Washington until it was confident that trade terms would be applied to wholesalers and retailers on a basis of equality with the manufacturers.

WALTER HAGEN blew out a tire and skidded, off the course at St. Andrews. Gene Sarazen lost his British golf crown. Ellsworth Vines stubbed his toe at Wimbledon. But there was a ball game held in Chicago recently and one hero stood up. The Babe hit one. New Deal or Old Deal, G.H. Ruth still dominates the diamond in the great combats and on the great days.

The manuscripts of some 600 letters written by the late Arnold Bennett to his nephew, Richard Bennett, are coming up for sale shortly in England and will be published in book form. Three large volumes of Bennett's diary already have been published here by Viking.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 7 -- Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston gave a dinner tonight at Old Trees for Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe of Planting Fields, Oyster Bay; Miss Alive Van Rensselaer and Francis Henry Balfour Byrne, who are visiting them.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 7 -- America once again has won the British open championship, but I hardly know, after what has gone before, who has won it. In fact, no one has won it yet, but the two golfers who will play off tomorrow on the old St. Andrews course are Craig Wood and Densmore Shute.

NEWARK, N.J., July 7 -- Three employes of the Franklin Leather Company, 585 North Third Street, were kidnapped by seven alleged union organizer, as they were about to enter their place of employment here early today. Police rescued them and arrested the seven alleged abductors.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 7 -- Jack Crawford, brilliant young Australian, battered his way to the top of the men's tennis world today with a smashing five-set victory over Ellsworth Vines, defending champion from the United States, in a Wimbledon final that produced some of the greatest tennis in the history of the famous tournament.

Copper in the domestic market sold yesterday at 9 cents a pound, compared with 8 1/2 cents on Thursday. It is reported that, only a small amount of the metal changed hands at that level because some copper is still available from custom smelters at 8 3/4 cents a pound.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The new security issues registered with the Trade Commission today were estimated to aggregate $75,000,000.

LONDON, July 7 -- Despite the victory won yesterday by the sheer impressiveness of Secretary of State Hull's personality, backed by Prime Minister Bennett's vehemence and the sympathy of delegates from distant countries, it is evident that the fight over continuance as against adjournment of the Economic Conference is far from finished.

New bond issues amounting to $9,386,091, representing the requirements of twenty-nine communities throughout the country, will come up for award next week. This week, according to revised figures, new issues in the amount of $9,242,645 cane up for bids.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 7 -- Governor Lehman is understood to have asked Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. for an opinion as to whether the Donnelly Act must be changed before projected trade combinations can operate in New York, without being considered combinations in restraint of trade.

Raw fur prices are soaring, and women's fur coats will have advanced in the Fall from 25 to as much as 100 per cent over a year ago, trade authorities here said yesterday. Fur-trimmed cloth coats also are expected to show substantial increases in price, owing to the risea in trimming peltries.

PARIS, July 7 (AP) -- Premier Edouard Daladier will go to Rome to sign the four-power pact July 24 and to have a private talk with Premier Mussolini to lay the basis for a settlement of differences which have marred relations between France and Italy since the World War.

Mystery surrounds the award by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment in the matter of the Chrystie-Forsyth development. Title to the property was acquired by the city four years ago. One wonders why there could not have been delay of a few days more so that the merits of the competing plans might have been given more serious and open consideration.
TARRYTOWN, N.T., July 7 -- John D. Rockefeller will be 94 years old tomorrow.

Henry Mandel, formerly a wealthy builder, won a release from jail yesterday as well as a large reduction in alimony payments. He had been in the Manhattan civil prison for failure to pay $37,500 in alimony arrears.
CHICAGO, July 7 -- The need for better rural educational opportunities was stressed before the National Education Association today.

Two Trade Codes: Silk and rayon weavers have their new code of procedure ready for submission to Washington. It will be interesting to see whether the new ethics continues to frown on the practice of making silk purses out of sows' ears.

Retail Clearances Bring Response. Fair headway was made by retailers in clearances of Summer merchandise during the week, according to reports here yesterday. The week, of course, was shortened by the holiday, but some pick-up in consumer demand was noted toward the end of the period as the result of rising temperatures.

County Trust Company. The County Trust Company, in its June 30 statement of condition, reports a special reserve account of $572,882, representing the appreciation in the market value of the bank's securities since they were marked down to actual market prices last April upon the entrance of the institution into the Federal Reserve System.

ST. LOUIS, July 7 -- Opening their second campaign in the West with flash and determination, Max Carey's Dodgers today trounced the Cardinals, 10 to 4. and gave Owen Carroll his ninth seasonal victory.

LONDON, July 7 -- With the dollar rapidly falling and a stiff contest in the bureau or steering committee of the World Economic Conference over the scope of the discussions impending in the monetary committee, the French and their gold-standard allies were preparing tonight to defend their currencies in the money markets of the world and their policies in the conference.

Steel production in the United States in June amounted to 2,597.517 tons, the largest monthly output since April, 1931, when 2,766,959 tons was produced, according to figures issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

Development of merchant marines by the nations of the world, on a broader nationalistic basis was predicted as the aftermath of the London Economic Conference, in an address yesterday by Harvey Klemmer of the American Steamship Owners Association.
The appointment of the new architect members of the advisory board of the Park Association of New York City was announced yesterday at the association's offices at 122 East Twenty-second Street.
"The Ghost Writer," starring Hal Skelly, will close its engagement at the Masque Theatre this evening after a run of three weeks.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 7 -- A future social order which will be increasingly planned in reference to the world as a unit was predicted by Mrs. Laura W. McMullen of New York, chairman of the international relations department of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, in an address delivered tonight before the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

PARIS, July 7 -- For several weeks dispatches have been reaching Paris from the Protectorate of Tunis describing serious economic difficulties and unrest of such wide extent that newspapers here are already asking, "Is France going to lose Tunis?"

Four men who, the police charge, were members of a counterfeiting ring which has flooded cities of the Eastern seaboard with hundreds of thousands of dollars in spurious currency were arrested last night. The plant which they are alleged to have operated was also seized, with elaborate equipment for manufacturing bills in $1, $5 and $10 denominations.

BERLIN, July 7 -- Chancellor Hitler has called a halt to the National Socialist revolution and has decreed instead an evolution, the principal aim of which must be protection of business and solution of the unemployment problem.

An increase in the current sales of the products of the Frigidaire Corporation was announced yesterday at a meeting of the sales division of that organization in the Hotel Astor. More than 1,000 dealers and salesmen from various parts of the New York and New Jersey districts attended the opening of the campaign, which will be conducted in fifty-two leading cities during the Summer months.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 7 -- A great uphill fight waged by Miss Rosalie Knapp to overcome a five-stroke lead that Miss Helen Hicks had starting the last round of the women's Long Island fifty-four-hole medal play tournament went for naught on one hole today.

No one traverses the wilderness for long without being lost," writes FAY WELCH in the July number of Nature Magazine. His statement implies that he has had to learn from experience how to take care of himself in the maze of the forest. Such advice as he gives will be helpful to vacationists who, knowing nothing of woodcraft, attempt to make a holiday of exploring without a guide.

QUEBEC, July 7 -- Only two syndicates are now interested in acquiring control of Price Brothers Co., developments here indicate, these being the McConnell-Sweezey group, representing Canadian capital, and the Duke-Mellon aggregation, representing United States Interests.

LONDON, July 7 (AP) -- A bloc of British sterling and American dollars to raise prices was predicted today by some experts as Great Britain forsook the gold bloc and stood by the American program in the World Economic Conference. This, even high gold-bloc authorities admitted, may be the consequence of the latest battle over continuation of the full conference agenda.

BERLIN, July 7 -- That Chancellor Hitler's order to his lieutenants to transform the National Socialist revolution into a more orderly evolution does not by any means denote abandonment of Nazi aims but is merely an attempt to change the pace and method of attaining them is shown by the following developments today:

Creation of a trust company and a mortgage company, to be owned cooperatively by the savings banks of the State, was announced yesterday by Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, as the first step in a program to lift restrictions on savings banks.

The five blocks of new housing that the city has authorized the firm of Sloan Robertson to build on the vacant $5,000,000 Chrystie-Forsyth Street tract are not intended for the poor of the vicinity, John Sloan explained yesterday. He declared that the project had been misjudged as one of slum relief when it should be recognized as a "slum clearance."

LONDON, July 7 -- The flight from the dollar continued with vigor today. The sterling rate which on Thursday finished at $4.50 rose to $4.75 and the final quotation at $4.71 1/2 showed a loss in the sterling value, of the dollar of 21 1/2 cents.
RYE, N.Y., July 7 -- Recent allegations concerning Evangeline the alligator proved correct here today. She laid twelve eggs at Playland, the county amusement centre.

MEXICO, D.F., July 7. -- A rousing ovation was given tonight to Jose Iturbi, Spanish pianist, when he completed the conducting from memory of Beethoven's Ninth symphony. More than 6,000 persons crowded the largest theatre of the capital, the Politeama, to the final inch of standing room to hear Iturbi conduct the orchestra he has organized here, consisting of more than 100 musicians and a chorus for tonight's concert of 100 voices.

Special sales in drug stores would be banned as an unfair trade practice unless the prices were first approved by the State Board of Pharmacy, under a tentative code for retail pharmacists drafted yesterday by the Eastern States Pharmaceutical Conference.

Friday, July 7, 1933. Firmer money ruled in most sections of the money market. While the Stock Exchange call loan rate continued at 1 per cent, outside funds went at the same figure, compared with a recent 1/2, and Federal funds were 3/4 bid, likewise a fractional advance over the early week.

Mr. RUDYARD KIPLING is no glutton for honors, but he must appreciate, and for more than one reason, the rare distinction which the French Academy of Moral and Political Sciences has conferred upon him by making him an associate member. This is a laurel greener from the brows of Cardinal MERCIER and worn by King ALBERT of Belgium.
The selection of Captain H.H. Railey as director of the League of Nations Association has been announced by the board of directors of the association. He will succeed Philip C. Nash.

After uniformly strong openings, commodities traded on local exchanges slumped yesterday and in some cases closed with, small losses on the day. Silver, coffee, rubber, copper, hides, silk and wool tops were higher, while cocoa was irregular and sugar was off. Trading was again heavy.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Provisional recognition of Soviet Russia, at least to the extent necessary to permit unhampered trade with the United States, is a distinct probability within the very near future, it was indicated today in well-informed quarters.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- With a considerable change in the complexion of the government securities market apparent in the last few weeks, experts are speculating on the possibility of an issue of $500,000,000 to $800,000,000 in ten-year bonds by the Treasury on Aug. 15.

LONDON, July 7 -- The satisfaction expressed on the political side of the United States economic conference delegation with the monetary commission's 25 to 15 vote in favor of continuing discussion of all items on its agenda is not shared by some of its expert members.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- An increase in the price of tread of one and one-third cents, with a possibility that the increase might go to one and one-half cents, was viewed as necessary tonight by Henry Stude, president of the American Bakers Association.

John B. Crews, Republican leader of the Sixth Assembly District in Brooklyn, who gave up his $10,840 position as Commissioner of Taxes and Assessments at the request of Mayor O'Brien, made public his letter of resignation yesterday. In the letter Mr. Crews wrote that the Mayor had told him "a political situation required a change."

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Bureau of Statistics of the United States Department of Labor announces that its index number of wholesale prices for the week ended July 1 stands at 66.3, as compared with 65.1 for the week ended June 24, showing an increase of approximately 18-10 per cent.

MOSCOW, July 7 -- "Safe at Anadyr, Chukotka, Siberia, Jimmy Mattern," read a wireless message received today by THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent here for transmission to the backers of James J. Mattern, round-the-world flier. It was dated 11 P.M., July 5.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Approval by the Federal Trade Commission for some fifty new security issues was sought under the new Securities Law today when dealers in stocks and bonds began filing their required registration statements.

Business progression was reflected yesterday in Manhattan commercial leasing activity. Reports from brokers showed several firms taking additional space to care for their expanding needs. Among these were two clothing concerns, one on Broadway and another near Fifth Avenue, and a motion-picture production company.

Mayor O'Brien refused yesterday to make public a letter from Samuel Untermyer accepting appointment as the city's special counsel in the matter of rapid transit unification, the Interborough receivership and related phases of the city's financial policy.

Although total orders were smaller this wreck, because of the interruption of the holiday, general wholesale trade was more buoyant than it has been in two years, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet. Inc. The number of visitors to the principal markets is keeping well ahead of last season's record, with orders for Fall merchandise ranging from 2 to 5 per cent in excess of the 1932 figures.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 7 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bisons made it two out of three in their series with the Newark Bears tonight, toppling the league leaders, 9 to 3.

Negotiations between the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union and the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers for a new agreement terminated abruptly yesterday. The probability of a strike, involving 30,000 workers in the New York cloak and suit industry, became imminent when the negotiations were definitely broken off.

The foreclosure sale of the twenty-four-story Manhattan Towers, at Broadway and Seventy-sixth Street, scheduled for yesterday, has been adjourned to Aug. 7, it was announced by Joseph P. Day, the auctioneer. The building contains apartments and also houses the Manhattan Congregational Church.

The adjusted index of lumber production, used in the weekly index of business activity of THE NEW YORK TIMES, advanced to 63.1 for the week ended July 1 from 60.7 in the preceding week. The figure was 38.3 for the corresponding week of last year.

CHICAGO, July 7 -- A militant attempt by classroom teachers to wrest the control of the National Education Association from the superintendents and other higher school authorities who have heretofore largely dominated its policies was defeated at the last session of the annual convention here today.

General T. Coleman du Pont, financier and former United States Senator from Delaware, left an estate appraised here yesterday at $17,799,766 gross and $17,520,642 net. The only part of the estate taxable in New York was $457,174, which was his country place, Nevis, at Tarrytown, formerly the home of Alexander Hamilton, appraised at $454,585, and personal effects.

HAVANA, July 7 -- Oppositionist factions today won a signal victory in the mediation negotiations now under way with Ambassador Sumner Welles as mediator when representatives of President Machado guaranteed full protection to all oppositionist factions who have accepted mediation.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated July 5:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the general scrapping of established formulas and economic reasoning, all so-called laws or scientific study translated into rules are waived aside to suit immediate popular demands.

The uprush of prices in domestic corporation bonds and foreign loans on the Stock Exchange yesterday occurred in the heaviest trading of any day since March 20, 1930. Yesterday's turnover reached $26,549,000, with the 1930 record at $28,276,000.

Frederick F. Proctor, vaudeville pioneer and chain theatre organizer, who died on Sept. 4. 1929, at the age of 78, at his home in Larchmont, left an estate appraised yesterday at $6,200,880 gross and $5,836,697 net, or which $5,568,544 was in securities.
Bronx detectives investigating the murder of Murray Marks, aide of Irving (Waxey Gordon) Wexler, bad three of Marks's friends in the lineup at Police Headquarters yesterday.
MASTIC, L.I., July 7 -- Aunt Martha Mayne, honored as the last full-blooded Poosepatuck Indian, died last night in her humble cottage on the tribe's reservation along the shore of Great South Bay.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Progress toward writing a code for a large section of the bituminous coal industry was reported today, following a conference of coal operators and officers of the United Mine Workers of America. At this conference John L. Lewis, president of the mine workers, proposed that the code contain provision for a basic minimum wage scale of $5 a day for a six-hour day and a thirty-hour week.

ROCKFORD, Ill., July 7 -- Convicted six years ago of a murder which he did not commit, Henry T. Olson today obtained an award of $29,250 in damages granted by a jury, against the attorney, Harry B. North, who failed to save him at his trial.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 7 -- Subscriptions for stock in the new First National Bank in Yonkers were being received today, from depositors of the restricted First National Bank and Trust Company of Yonkers, which the new bank is to succeed.

The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company has sold in the open market the block of 585,000 shares of its common B stock which it held at the end of 1932, It was announced yesterday by S. Clay Williams, president.

Reflecting the flow of funds from New York, which has resulted from the suspension of interest rates on demand deposits under, the new banking act, the money market tightened yesterday. The sequence of events began with a shortage of reserves by member banks of the Federal Reserve here, leading to some calling of loans and a firming of the cost of money to dealers and brokers.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Transfer of the largest amount of money and securities ever made by a government official was completed today when Walter O. Woods, former Treasurer of the United States, turned over to his successor, W.A. Julian, a total of $19,347,366,089.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 7 -- Two breaks in service lost for Ellsworth Vines in his match today with Jack Crawford, Australian champion. Crawford got the ball on his forehand, took it on the rise and placed it on Vines's backhand, deep.

PARIS, July 7 -- There is something of an admission of having been outmanoeuvred in today's French comment on the London conference, but the flag of the gold standard, around which France rallied her gold allies, has not yet been pulled down.

LONDON, July 7 -- The main battlefield of the World Economic Conference today was in the monetary subcommission on temporary measures, where Continental Europe almost solidly spoke and voted against the contention of the rest of the world that the conference might continue to discuss all monetary and financial subjects, despite the failure to reach a stabilization agreement.

With the dollar falling to a discount of 30 cents in the foreign exchange market, speculators turned their attention yesterday to the possibility of an active and official devaluation campaign by the administration.

DAIREN, Manchuria, July 7 -- "The conference just ended may be the beginning of a new phase of improved relations among China, Manchukuo and Japan," Major Gen. Okamura stated exclusively to the correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES today after the Chinese, Japanese and Manchukuo representatives had signed an agreement concerning the demilitarized area northeast of Tientsin.

Aided by an accomplice who wore a policeman's uniform, armed robbers held up the staff of the Corn Exchange Bank's branch on 110th Street, near Broadway, yesterday and escaped with loot of $23,835. Borough-wide efforts of police radio cars to intercept them failed.

If the Pacific Coast section be disregarded, power output in the United States in the week ended July 1 set a new high record for that week. Including the Pacific Coast, the power output in the nation was only 3.9 per cent below the 1,723,428,000 kilowatt-hours produced by public utility companies in the week ended June 29, 1929, the highest corresponding week on record.

PILGRIMAGE," the Fox Film Corporation's version of I.A. R. Wylie's story, will have its premiere at the Gaiety Theatre on Wednesday evening and will linger there indefinitely on a two-show-a-day basis. Beyond the fact that the producers herald it as the "Cavalcade" of rural America, the film marks the talking screen debut of Henrietta Crosman of the stage.

RICHMOND, Va., July 5. -- Described by Jouett Shouse, executive director of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, as the "straw that broke the dry camel's back," Virginia's special legislative session, which will convene Aug. 17 to legalize beer and to fix a date for a repeal referendum, is expected to be an important factor in leading the South, the last hope of supporters of the Eighteenth Amendment, into the anti-prohibition camp.

RAUL ROULIEN, a bulwark in the cast of "It's Great to Be Alive," at the Seventh Avenue Roxy, is a well-known South American entertainer. He was born in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, Oct. 8, 1905, and made his first theatrical appearance in Sao Paulo at the age of 5.

WHEN a comedian remains on the air for sixty-three weeks in a row he is likely to be missed, especially if as popular as Ed Wynn, who completed his first series of broadcasts last Tuesday night, and with a program maintaining the standard he set in the beginning.

BETWEEN the prints by anonymous or known European masters of the fifteenth century and prints of our own time there stretches, naturally, a breach that is both deep and wide. Yet there are many points of living contact.

Most commodities traded on local exchanges showed losses yesterday, as speculators and investors took week-end profits. Silver and wool tops were the exception. Trading was in fair volume. Cash prices were irregular.

BAR HARBOR. -- Early July on Mount Desert Island is a tuning-up period preliminary to the familiar Summer symphony of whose gray themes even the most seasoned Summer resident never tires. The Garden Club of Mount Desert has just been making ready and on next Thursday will have its garden visiting day for the eastern half of the island.
AUTOMOBILE-RADIO is called the Summer stabilizer for the radio industry. When the market for home sets begins to decline in March, the auto-radio sales curve climbs until late in August.

BUCHAREST, July 8. -- Expressions of disappointment over the lack of success at the London Economic Conference have been drowned in Rumania by general jubilation at the conclusion of what is being called the "London Eastern Pact" between the Little Entente nations and the Soviets.

Editor, The New York Times Book Review: In his notice of my book, "The Golf House Mystery,'' your reviewer says the device described in connection with John Brand's will had been used previously by Mary Roberts Rinehart in her story, "The Door."

THE owner of the big Lane ranch had been killed, apparently accidentally, leaving no will. His 17-year-old daughter had been packed off to a school in St. Louis by a rascally guardian who was keeping her slightly older brother intoxicated and inducing him to gamble away his share of the estate.

RUGS, robust in coloring and boldly geometrical In design, are once more arriving from tie Caucasian and Western Turkestan districts. These floor coverings, which nave not been imported to any extent since the World War, were at one time much valued because they are distinctly different from other Near and Far Eastern types.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Licensing of the entire baking industry, if necessary, to prevent unwarranted increases in bread prices, was threatened today by George N. Peek, administrator for the Agricultural Adjustment Act, on the eve of the application of a processing tax on flour milling.

SOUTHAMPTON. -- One of the most important artistic events ever undertaken at Four Fountains, the Ethel Hunt Tyng Memorial, will be inaugurated this afternoon when the Loan Exhibition of American Landscapes opens there.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., July 7. -- Just a little more than a year ago Alfalfa Bill Murray, Governor of Oklahoma, crashed into the Democratic National Convention at Chicago as a candidate for President. Of course he had no votes except the hog-tied delegation from his own State, but with his magnavox larynx and his flair for the spectacular, he cut quite a swath.

IN a heavily timbered section known as Beechmont Woods, off Forest Avenue, in New Rochelle, Westchester, a two-story English manor cottage modeled after the simple but distinctive old stone farmhouses in the Cotswold section of Worcestershire, England, is being erected by Gerald Campbell.

DURING her eldest son's minority Lady Cadmium governed Crashams -- a huge rambling stone manor house with majestic pillared portico flanked by terraced gardens and set in a great park. Even in this age of disillusion and proletarian assertiveness Crasham's tenantry regard the Sexton family and its noble chief as creatures molded from a finer clay.

FOR the very reason that this book will rapidly recommend itself on the basis of its own merits to students of history. It should be all the more emphatically brought to the notice of the general reader, who may otherwise overlook it.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Fears of another wave of intense heat over the week-end in the Canadian and American Northwest increased the bullish sentiment on the Board of Trade here today and advanced prices of wheat rapidly after an early dip, making the close around the best figures of the day and the season.

Because of the opening tomorrow of the Summer school of Columbia University, Union Theological Seminary and other institutions, special preachers, including a number of bishops, have been engaged to preach today in the leading churches of Manhattan, particularly those on Morningside Heights.
PARIS, July 8. -- Concluding its work by voting a number of measures, the French Parliament adjourned today, assuring the life of the present Cabinet at least until it reconvenes in October.
"Every day in every way" the real estate market grows better and better.

ONE of the interesting alterations among the many which are now in progress on old tenement properties in Manhattan is that at 342-48 Third Avenue, four out-moded four-story structures near Twenty-fifth Street, which have been taken over by the Union Dime Savings Bank.
ROME, July 7. -- The Vatican shows the keenest satisfaction in the conclusion of a concordat with Germany which will give the Holy See several notable advantages.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Proposal for a code in the bituminous coal industry which it is hoped will put an additional 150,000 men to work was made to the joint conference of operators and miners today by William Taylor, vice president of the Valley Camp Coal Company.

TNTRIGUINGLY Mr. Mond, who is Assistant Professor of Economics in the University of Washington, quotes in the opening sentence of his preface the remark of an English writer who 300 years ago justified his study of monopoly on the ground that "the name and nature of monopoly is more talk't of than well understood."
Bishop Manning has sent a latter "to the friends and builders of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine" asking for subscriptions to put idle men to work on the completion of the nave.
COUTANCES, July 6. -- Celebration of the thousandth anniversary of Normandy opened here this month and will be observed in other towns throughout the district during the Summer.

John Sloan, the architect, said last night that an application probably would be filed tomorrow with the State Housing Board, asking approval of the plans for building model tenements in the Chrystie-Forsyth Street area.

DETROIT. JULY has found the automobile plants hard pressed to supply national demand for new cars. May usually registers the peak of the seasonal rush for the year, but under the unusual conditions now prevailing, the sales and production curves have maintained a steady climb through June and into the midsummer period.

Most vegetables were in plentiful supply here last week, with a moderate demand and little price fluctuation. This was announced yesterday by George G. Royce, director of the local office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, in his consumers' weekly review of wholesale markets.

LONDON, July 8. -- The successful experiment of Drs. Wilson Smith, C.H. Andrews and P.P. Laidlaw in inoculating ferrets with influenza germs obtained from humans has aroused the greatest interest among medical men and scientists here, as it is held to be a further step toward actually isolating the germ and finding an antidote.

For the bewilderment caused by President ROOSEVELT'S message of July 3 to the Economic Conference there was a twofold reason. His message of May 16 to all the nations had declared first of all that "the conference must "establish order in place of the present chaos by a stabilization of the "currencies."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. Dublin, Metropolitan Life Insurance Company statistician, estimates that on the basis of the rapidly declining birth rate the population of the United States will have declined to 75,000,000 by the year 2100.

Perhaps hard times automatically force hard thinking, social, civic and economic; upon people generally. But nowhere is that effect more striking than upon the teachers of the country. In every one of the hundreds of speeches made at the National Education Association convention just closed in Chicago the new tone was heard.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 6. -- For the first time in the history of Delaware a woman has become the leader of a major political party, with power and influence that no Democrat has wielded since the Civil War. She is Mrs. Marguerite Dugan Bodziak, manager of the recent Mayoralty campaign of Dr. William H. Speer, Democrat, who on June 3 was elected by the largest majority ever won by the Democrats in this city.

"I CHOSE children's work because I believed it offered the greatest opportunities for service." said Justice Hoyt, and there was that in his voice which dared one to question his right to the use of that much-mistreated word in its ancient and most honorable sense.

Mortgage conditions and future possibilities, real estate taxes, property investments, office space occupancy and building construction were among the topics discussed by Joseph P. Day and Charles F. Noyes in their broadcast talks over Station WOR last Thursday evening.

PARIS, July 6. -- Nobody will deny that President Roosevelt's declaration of July 3 is disagreeable reading to a Frenchman. It shows a departure from the program of international solidarity which he had adopted. It reads a lesson to Europe and especially to France.

ROBERT HERRICK has here invaded a field familiar to the philosopher and the philosophical novelist. Plato seems to have discovered it. Sir Thomas More unwittingly gave it a name. Plutarch, Bacon and William Morris achieved distinction therein.

Industrial and educational leaders, including two college presidents, will compose the faculty of a boys' camp offering vocational guidance to be conducted next month by the Stevens Institute of Technology at Johnsonburg, N.J.

Examination of the records in the Tenement House Department for 1932 indicates that the demolition of the old-law tenements is progressing rather slowly, points out Joseph H. Fink, secretary of the housing committee of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities.

PARIS, July 6 -- Bouffant bridal fashions have been approved by Mlle. Lesseps, Empress Eugenia's grandniece, for her marriage on July 25. She is ordering from Chanel a near crinoline and white tulle gown to accompany an heirloom lace veil, which was a gift to Eugenie.
THE idea of blending alcohol with gasoline as a motor fuel, vigorously promoted and as vigorously attacked in the last session of Congress, is not by any means dead.

NEWPORT. -- The present week will close with a brilliant event in the big training ring building at Oakland Farm, the home of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt in Portsmouth. It will be the Red and White Ball, sponsored by Mr. and Mrs. Vanderbilt for the benefit of the Boy Scouts of Newport County.
WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Lack of recognition of Russia by the United States will not interfere with the rescue of James J. Mattern from the remote Siberian seacoast town to which he made his way.
CHICAGO, July 8. -- Reversing their tactics of the previous afternoon, the Giants got off rather badly against the Cubs but remained satisfied to rate off the pace.

BARCELONA, July 7. -- The miniature mountain State of Andorra, lying unnoticed for centuries, suddenly has become a pawn in Europe's international game of political chess. Its 5,000 inhabitants are in a state of turmoil in consequence of the action of representatives of its coprinces a few days ago in dismissing its Council General or Parliament and depriving its President and Vice President of holding office during'a term of one year.
WASHINGTON, July 8. -- In naming Secretary Ickes aa administrator of the public-works program today President Roosevelt ended a dispute between factions as to the method of carrying out the program.

IT would sometimes seem as if the motto of the modern novelist had become: Dare everything -- you may get away with it. Marching with heavy feet where Shelley, John Ford and Sophocles trod with poetic delicacy, Mr. Cuthbert essays the notoriously difficult theme of Incest.

THE Food and Drugs Act of June 30, 1906, was an innovation in Federal legislation. It has none the less been notably effective in the control of adulterated and misbranded foods and drugs and has been the means of correcting many of the serious conditions which led to its enactment.

FORMER Mayor Walker once remarked that it is a pity the cheers of yesterday have such a short echo. While the rise of stars in the ethereal firmament is often meteoric, after twinkling for a while, they frequently pass into eclipse.

IT has been a week of notable activity in aviation. Roscoe Turner earned real speed laurels by his record-breaking flight from Floyd Bennett Field to Mines Field, Los Angeles, in 11 hours 30 minutes, to win the Bendix Trophy, and by taking the Thompson Trophy race in the same plane at an average speed of 241 miles an hour.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Virtual completion of the machinery for studying veterans' benefits under the revised economy orders was reported to President Roosevelt today by Lewis W. Douglas, Director of the Budget, and Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans Affairs, who called together at the White House.

After conferring with representatives of west side business organizations that have taken a stand for drastic treatment of street peddlers, Magistrate Greenspan In Night Court, suspended sentences upon about 150 peddlers brought before him last night.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 8 (AP). -- For the second time in the long history of the classic Henley regatta an American crew today won the Thames Challenge Cup when the Kent (Conn.) schoolboys triumphed. Browne and Nichols of Boston won the trophy in 1929.

CARLSBAD, June 27. -- Germany has become a powder keg since the assumption of the Chancellorship by Hitler. Hitler holds in his hand much greater political power than any Chancellor or Kaiser ever disposed of. On the basis of the so-called Enabling Act of March 23, 1933, even decision over war and peace rests entirely in the hands of the dictator, Hitler.

ARECENT report to the effect that road builders near Norfolk, Va., had unearthed the remains of twelve skeletons near land which, according to tradition, was once occupied by a fort of the pirate Blackbeard, recalls the bloody record of that freebooter of the early eighteenth century.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. James T. Terry gave a large reception this afternoon at Top Hole for Mr. and Mrs. George D. Terry, who are at Bon Acre for the season.

CALGARY, Alberta. -- More than 200 bronco riders, calf ropers, steer riders, steer "decorators" and chuck-wagon drivers are gathered in this foothills city, where ranching days will live again, and people from many parts of the world will join the home folk in paying tribute to the champions of the plains.

RECENT activities and future plans of the New Deal have led to a closer scrutiny of our industries. General Hugh S. Johnson, recovery administrator, estimates their number at about 7,000, of which five major lines -- cotton, coal, steel, oil and motors -- are making rapid progress in preparing their new operating codes.

CARMEL, N.Y., July 8. -- Dickerson, bay gelding by Siliko, owned and driven by Frank B. Maynard of Carmel, won the Class A trot and pace at the Putnam County Driving Park today, repeating his victory of July 4.

TO line up the aviation industry as a unit under the provisions of the Industrial Recovery Act, the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America has taken steps for a thoroughgoing reorganization. At a recent meeting of its board of governors, which was unusually large and representative, the lull plan outlined by Thomas A. Morgan, president, was unanimously approved.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 8. -- With a change in encampments in three State military training grounds due tomorrow, the first units of a total of 6,900 New York National Guardsmen started to move today. The troops affected include the Fourteenth Infantry of Brooklyn and the 165th Infantry of Manhattan.

BERLIN, July 7. -- The complete obliteration of "political Catholicism" in the new Nazi state through the dissolution of the Centrist and Bavarian. People's Parties represents a distinct moral victory for Adolf Hitler. They were the last of the old-established parties to succumb to the clamor for a one-party state.

A new low in insurance rates has been established in the schedule fixed for the Port Authority Commerce Building, 111 Eighth Avenue, between Fifteenth and Sixteenth Streets, reports the Port of New York Authority. It applies both to the rates on the building and on the contents.

SEVENTY-FIVE YEARS after setting her flag upon it in the name of Napoleon III, France regains possession of an island, the Isla de la Pasion, also known as Clipperton Island. Mexico claimed it as a discovery of the Spanish conquistadors.

GENEVA, July 7. -- The current volume of the League of Nations' statistical year book, which has juat appeared, shows that infant mortality increased by 75 per cent in Germany in 1932, suddenly attaining a figure exceeding even that of the immediate post-war period.

A collection of 150 books which are considered exceptionally well made are on public exhibition at Avery Library, Columbia University. The printers and designers of three countries are represented, there being fifty books each from the United States, from England and from Germany.

LATONIA. Ky., July 8 (AP). -- Leading almost all the way, Marooned of the Le Mar Stock Farm faltered as Jockey Montgomery looked back at the finish today and lost the Quickstep Handicap to No More, from the stable of C.E. Davison.
MADRID, July 8. -- During the last few days the difficult reconstruction work at which Spain is laboring was interrupted by numerous attacks by anarchists and other opponents of the government.
THE HAGUE, July 6. -- The new wing of the Peace Palace to be occupied by the Academy of International Law was dedicated on Tuesday on the tenth anniversary of the opening of the palace.

Due in part to the shorter week occasioned by the holiday, both wholesale and retail trade registered moderate declines last week. Retailers launched their seasonal clearances of Summer apparel and are expected to appear in this market in large numbers this week to begin major purchasing for Fall.

LAKELAND, Fla., July 6. -- The Tampa Bay Hotel, built by Henry Plant, railroad magnate and developer, and opened with elaborate ceremonies in 1889, will be used henceforth as the main building of a university, leaving behind a romantic past and a reputation for lavish hospitality known to thousands of wealthy Winter visitors from all over America and many foreign countries.

THE Brahms anniversary is not needed as an excuse for the American release of the three-record set of the sonata for viola and piano in F minor (Op. 120, No. 1) by Lionel Tertis and Harriet Cohen which comes this month In Master-works Album No. 183.
IF you wanted a job in a motion picture studio, how many questions would you have to answer? How many trades, professions and vocations are needed steadily or intermittently in a modern cinema plant?

In the year since the stock market touched its lowest levels for the depression, on July 8, 1932, the increase in the market value of shares listed on the Stock Exchange has been about $23,500,000,000. Of this gain approximately $19,500,000,000 has been scored in the last four months.

MAKING allowance for the usual post-holiday reaction and the short week, retail trade here was fairly well maintained. Most stores concentrated attention on the clearance of stocks of Summer goods. Preparations for showings of new between-season merchandise and for August sales events are now being completed.

WASHINGTON. UNDER the glare of focused spotlights our national capital has entered what promises to be one of the most dynamic Summers in its history. Unavallingly nature does her best to make the city dreamy and langourous.

With prices already starting to rise faster than the increase in consumer purchasing power, it is paramount that the preparation of codes under the National Industrial Recovery Act be speeded up so as actually to put more men to work, Louia E. Kirstein of William Filene's Sons Company and member of the board representing industry under the act, said here yesterday.

The Chicago convention of the National Education Association, which closed last Friday, was the first gathering of this great organization, for three years which has not been under the shadow of impending disaster.

WASHINGTON. July 8. -- The names of thirty-six of the concerns which have registered proposed issues of stocks and bonds under the Securities Act were made public by the Federal Trade Commission today.

The Knickerbocker Canoe Club of New York will defend its New Jersey State team title in the second annual regatta to be staged on Weequahic Park lake in Newark, N.J., today. All nine clubs of the Atlantic Division of the American Canoe Association will compete in thirteen races over the 550-meter course over which the national championships were staged in 1931.

Dean Palmer H. Graham, chairman of the New York University Washington Square College Scholarship Committee, announced yesterday the names of 108 students and graduate students who earned commendation for excellence in scholarship during the second semester of the 1932-33 school year.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 8. -- Nassau County authorities, investigating the death of 7-month-old Richard Hope, questioned five of his relatives here today. Meanwhile, they refused to permit the body to be buried, and ordered it to be placed in a sealed vault in Greenfield Cemetery.

Encouraged by supercharged motor experiments in his Gold Cup boat Delphine V, Horace E. Dodge is considering challenging for the Harmsworth Trophy race this Fall. The way was paved when Hubert Scott-Paine challenged with his new boat Miss Britain III.

LONDON, July 8. -- A recess after earlier discussions during which ministers from reasonably near countries can return to them, while experts elaborate detailed proposals for later acceptance, is sometimes a convenient procedure in an assemblage such as the World Economic Conference.

LUSTY infants of science growing like a fakir's tree are no rarity in these twentieth century days. So many of these young sciences have sprouted and shot up like Jonah's gourds during recent decades that they crowd the scientific foreground.

So far, this has been an upsetting year in sports. Champions have been bowled over In rows. Gene Sarazen, who held the United States open golf crown and the British open golf crown live weeks ago, now holds neither. Ellsworth Vines, Wimbledon champion last year, was defeated on the courts by Jack Crawford of Australia.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Increased trade volume, further gains in employment and a general return of confidence throughout Canada in the latter part of June have been reported to the Commerce Department by Lynn W. Meekins, Commercial Attache at Ottawa.
BOSTON. July 8 (AP). -- The Red Sox were in a charitable mood today and handed the Browns a 4-to-1 victory through the medium of three errors.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Into the South, where the fate of prohibition eventually will be decided, President Roosevelt today threw the force of his influence on the side of repeal. His appeal in reply to a letter of inquiry, was simply a telegram addressed to Leon McCord, National Democratic Committeeman for Alabama, citing the repeal plank in the Democratic platform.

Much Federal patronage will come to the State when the New York Home Loan Bank is organized. Postmaster General James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman and chief dispenser of patronage under the Roosevelt administration, said yesterday that the appointment of the director of the hank would he announced In Washington tomorrow and that the job would be awarded to a prominent Democrat.

LONDON, July 8. -- The Economist still argues for suspension of the Economic Conference while leaving a certain number of its component committees to carry on during the Summer such exploratory work as may be feasible. It says that, although such a decision would represent a regrettable suspension of the main efforts at international cooperation, it is scarcely avoidable in the circumstances in which the conference finds itself.

LONDON, July 8. -- Secretary of State Hull's communications with Washington and almost continuous conferences with the heads of other delegations resulted today in a public statement by him emphasizing the need for continuing the economic Conference in full vigor and listing the subjects with which it could deal without damage to the susceptibilities of the gold bloc.

LONDON, July 8. -- Leopold Amery, Colonial Minister in the last Baldwin Cabinet, says in a letter to The London Times that the world should be grateful to President Roosevelt for saving the economic conference from attempting to set the gold standard Humpty Dumpty on his wall again and reminding the nations that in the nationally planned world of the future the internal stability of currencies will be of greater importance than their exchange stability.

BERLIN. THE demonic spirit of the tropics. . . . We are surfeited with portrayals and descriptions of the tropical world. Yet few travelers succeed in stirring our imagination with the powerful magic of those countries.

A plan of international pooling of merchant skips such as the French delegation proposed to the World Economic Conference in London last week is inevitable, according to Robert C. Lee, vice president of Moore McCormack, ship operators.

Probability of an America's Cup challenge this Fall for an international match next year is considered by American yachtsmen stronger than ever as a result of the performance of the Velsheda, W.L. Stephenson's new sloop, on the Clyde.

MAX BRAND is particularly adept in the spinning of Western yarns that bristle with hazardous ventures and throb with excitement. He writes 'em rough. While this one is rough enough (though hardly rivaling its immediate predecessor, "Slow Joe," in all-round toughness), it is perhaps the queerest, most curiously involved story among the half-score by this writer now in print.
Several proposed amendments to the State Housing law, particularly with respect to provisions for tax exemptions, are being mapped out by a special committee of the First Avenue Association.

MAX BRAND is particularly adept in the spinning of Western yarns that bristle with hazardous ventures and throb with excitement. He writes 'em rough. While this one is rough enough (though hardly rivaling its immediate predecessor, "Slow Joe," in all-round toughness), it is perhaps the queerest, most curiously involved story among the half-score by this writer now in print.
Several proposed amendments to the State Housing law, particularly with respect to provisions for tax exemptions, are being mapped out by a special committee of the First Avenue Association.

EXTRACTING the melodrama from the life of Edmund Kean is at first sight, a peculiarly ungrateful task. For in the career of this waif who became England's most passion-compelling tragic actor, overhanging the first half of the nineteenth century with the murky thunder-clouds and lightning flashes of his genius, is so embedded and embodied the fierce frenzy of inordinate theatricality that Kean out of a melodramatic setting is unthinkable -- off the stage as on.

NO historical event can yield all the Information or all the human Interest that is in it without first-hand examination of the sources. Particularly is this true of that glamourous period, extending roughly through the first half of the nineteenth century, which saw the exploration and partial settlement of the trans-Mississippi West.

WEST HAMPTON BEACH, L.I., July 8. -- Lady Mary, 5-year-old chestnut mare owned by Carleton Tobey of Southold, L.I., was the outstanding saddle horse in the third annual West Hampton Beach Horse Show today.

THE conception of history as dramatized economics has gained wide enough ground to make us more and more tolerant of having our history written for us by economists. And when these new historians turn out to be economists of the type of Mr. Keynes one is almost tempted to forgive history the bad lines assigned to some.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 8. -- Repeating its clean sweep of yesterday in the opening session of five singles, the Oxford-Cambridge tennis team carried off all six doubles matches with the Rockaway Hunting Club today to win the prince of Wales Cup for the third successive time in these quadrennial contests.

LONDON, July 8. -- The French sprang a surprise today by formally proposing that the World Economic Conference create a special subcommittee of its economic commission for the study of public works. Their resolution reads:

PART II. A FEW works written before 1750 (such as Bach's, Handel's and Palestrina's) are widely presented, but almost invariably with distortions and with an indifference to the obvious intentions of the composers that are positively hair-raising; obviously, our conductors do not take the traditions of these older composers seriously.
