CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 8. -- The Oxford-Cambridge track and field forces have yet to score their first victory over the combined Yale-Harvard team on American soil. But they came perilously close to doing it before a crowd of 8,000 in the sun-drenched Harvard Stadium today.

THE original callisthenes was the public relations counselor of Alexander the Great. Great Britain knows the name today as the author of a daily column of brief essays placed in paid space in the advertising columns of the London newspapers by a great department store.

ALTHOUGH it is plotted in the same swift and highly intricate fashion, this novel lacks a good deal of the crispness and vigor of its predecessor, "Four Wives." Neither story, to be sure, was notable for its depth or conviction; and each, from time to time, lays its author open to a charge of meaningless and deliberate sensationalism.

DALLAS, Texas, July 5. -- In the fires of the present campaign for repeal and beer are being forged the weapons for next year's campaign for Governor. It is fully a year before the Democratic primaries take place, but already the lines are being drawn and the candidacies mapped out.

AKRON, Ohio, July 8 (AP). -- An air-tight metal ball and a huge balloon were put to drastic tests yesterday to determine their fitness to carry and keep alive two human beings on a journey of twelve miles into the stratosphere -- higher than man has ever before ascended.

Establishing a women's record for a west-to-east flight across the continent, Miss Amelia Earhart landed at the Newark Airport at 8:19:30 o'clock last night, exactly 17 hours 7 minutes 30 seconds after leaving Los Angeles. Miss Earhart beat her own women's transcontinental record of 19 hours 4 minutes, established in 1932, by 1 hour 56 minutes 30 seconds.

Golf -- Densmore Shute of Philadelphia defeated Craig Wood of Deal, N.J., by five strokes in the thirty-six-hole playoff for the British open championship. Shute led from the first hole to the last as he scored 75 -- 74 -- 149, only three strokes over par for the thirty-six holes. Wood carded 78 -- 76 -- 154. They finished the regulation seventy-two holes of the tournament on Friday tied at 292.

International conferences cannot be permitted to break up without action of some sort. The great nations that sponsor them will do anything to prevent that. Their reasons are twofold: One part is politics, the other statesmanship

HENRY R. EAST has a way with dogs. His business Is the training of dogs for performance in moving pictures, and testimonials he presents from Marie Dressler, Mack Sennett and Al Christie indicate remarkable success.

A receiver for the property of A. C. BIumenthal, theatrical producer and promoter, and friend of former Mayor Walker, has been appointed in the Supreme Court, it was revealed yesterday. The receivership is based on an unpaid judgment for $28,029.

THE horrifying crimes whose narrative is told in this book were made public in Germany three years ago when the man who committed them Peter Kurten, was brought to trial and executed. The author, Mrs. Wagner, is an English newspaper correspondent in Berlin who reported the trial and has since made a thorough study of the medical and criminal records of his life.

Ahto Walter and Thomas Olsen, 21-year-old sea dogs who crossed the Atlantic from Africa in a 26-foot sloop, to win a 4,000-mile race with the British cutter Enterprise, are marveling at the interest created by their adventure. The Enterprise is believed to be nearing port, but has not been sighted for several days.

BROADCASTERS have climbed high, and dipped low to pick up novel programs, but never to such lofty altitudes as the stratosphere, which they now plan to tap for entertainment labeled both as "scientific" and "stunt." Broadcasts have been flashed from submarines and from William Beebe's undersea tank.
The stadium of the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, L.I., has been a quiet place these many months. Where so many tennis battles have been fought the grass remains unmarked.

LONDON, July 8. -- Secretary of State Hull today engaged in quiet conversations with spokesmen for various countries friendly to the American policy with a view to drawing up a program in which many delegations will have a hand and which will not bear the American label.

The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange maintained its upward movement in the brief trading period yesterday in contrast to the irregularly lower market for stocks. THE NEW YORK TIMES averages of foreign loans and of all domestic bond groups moved to further new highs for the year to date in trading which reached $10,529,000.

FREDERIC ALLEN WHITING Jr. informs this department that during the season just concluded the American Federation of Art's traveling exhibitions were more in demand than ever before. There were 450 bookings for the 100 shows sent on tour.

PITTSBURGH, July 8 (AP). -- Young Hal Smith today pitched the Pirates to a 3 to 0 victory in the second game of a double header after the Phillies had staged a last-inning four-run rally to capture the first fray, 8 to 7.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- A new plan for recasting the financial structure of Armour Co. will be presented to stockholders within a week, it was indicated today. Details of the plan are not available but it is understood it will differ in several important features from the tentative reorganization scheme advanced a few weeks ago.

Unemployed heads of families working on jobs provided by the city's emergency work bureau have had their pay cut and their working tune reduced, it was learned last night. The pay has been cut from the present $45 a month to $40.50 by reducing the working time from ten days a month to nine.

TORONTO, July 8. -- Dome Mines reports bullion production in June valued at $400,312, a decline of $15,620 from May. The decline was almost entirely due to the loss of a day in the shorter month. It is understood that tonnage treated and average grade held close to the record of May.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 8. -- An unusual exchange of valuable, art treasures by the Fogg Art Museum of Harvard University and the Spanish Government is announced by the museum's directors.

ROME, July 8. -- A concordat between the Holy See and Germany "destined to render impossible any future conflicts between the Church and State in Germany," to quote Vice Chancellor von Papen, was initialed today by Cardinal Pacelli, the Papal Secretary of State, and Colonel von Papen.

Professor PAUL MORT, director of the School of Education, Teachers College, urges the United States to engage 1,000,000 educators to grow "the greatest economic product, education." The persons so employed in the public schools approached that number in 1930 -- as given in the census, 854,263 -- with a total for salaries of $1,250,427, -- 194 and a global school expenditure of $2,316,790,384.

The new cabin liner Washington is the only merchant ship on the Atlantic equipped with a pitometer, for accurate measurement of speed and distance, according to an announcement of the United States Line yesterday. The device has been tried and found successful on the two round trips completed a week ago.

LONDON. ONE of Queen Mary's hobbies is flowers. Recently she visited Kew Gardens to see the display of bluebells and rhododendrons, and, as usual, she supervised the arrangement of flowers used as decorations at Buckingham Palace on the nights when the courts were held.

RYE, N.Y., July 8. -- A beach fete will be held on Friday at the Beach Club of the Westchester Country Club to aid the Leake and Watts Orphan House of Yonkers. The features will include a beauty contest, a fashion show, aquatic exhibitions by Olympic swimmers, a specialty dance by Gomez and Winona of the Riviera Club, a tea dance, bridge and backgammon.

This Summer an unusually large number of children will remain in the city, missing their natural heritage of green fields to run in, brooks to wade in and woods to explore. But correspondingly more ingenuity is being exercised to provide good care for those left behind.
WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Secretary Ickes of the Department of the Interior today became Emergency Administrator of Public Works through an Executive order issued by President Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, July 8. -- To the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company and subsidiaries of New York have been awarded an income tax credit and refund of $799,262.

IN the Cleveland laboratory of the General Electric Company Dr. W.E. Forsythe is using the largest spectroscope in the world to study the color of light emitted by different sources and to measure its energy. If we are to improve the quality of artificial light it will be largely through work of the kind he is doing.

THE Lindbergrhs are about to fly an ocean again, to explore the northern route to Europe by way of Greenland and the Ice-clad seas. They have flown so much together that the tact la itself means little. But it brings them back into the air again, sets them against their natural scene, the clouds and blue sky, storm and fog and sleet, the most romantic adventurous couple in American life.

Haitians, who have taken over the responsibilities formerly held by Americans under the occupation, which now is being withdrawn, are performing their duties with marked efficiency, according to H.P. Davis, former secretary of the American Chamber of Commerce in Haiti.

An armored car driver was killed and a woman, pedestrian was seriously injured yesterday afternoon in a collision between the armored car and a private automobile at 150th Street and Walton Avenue, the Bronx.
The current home stand of the Yankees is rapidly assuming the proportions of a rout.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 8. -- The hole-by-hole description of the play-off between Densmore Shuts and Craig Wood for the British open golf championship follows:

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 8. -- The Tammany Tiger, owing to the financial collapse in New York City, needs new feeding grounds and is seeking to extend its political sway beyond the city, W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee and of the Suffolk County Republican Committee, declared at a meeting of the organization here today.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 8. -- Mr. and Mrs. Justin O'Brien Haynes gave a dinner tonight at their Lee Avenue Summer home for Mr. and Mrs. John Vernour Bouvier 3d. They have as their house guests Mr. and Mrs. Earl E.T. Smith and Mr. and Mrs. J. Alien Grover.

A WIT has noted recently that a spectator who is moved to tears at the performance of a drama will probably express his resentment at such an invasion, of his lachrymal privacy by setting the exhibit down as unabashed hokum.

HAMBURG, July 8. -- The pool of the Hamburg-American Line and the North German Lloyd reported a net loss of 13,000,022 marks for each line in 1932. This loss was registered despite the fact that no depreciation was charged against the fleet and total liabilities were increased.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 8. -- The Kent School crew from the United States won the coveted Thames Challenge Cup by rowing two fine races in the Royal Henley Regatta today.

THE Empire State Building in New York City is the tallest, most elaborate and most successful lightning rod ever erected by man. Time and time again it has been struck. In fact, hardly a thunderstorm sweeps over lower Manhattan Island that does not single it out to hurl a bolt at its towering mooring mast.

Sales of General Motors cars to consumers in the United States in June amounted to 101,827 units, compared with 85,969 in May and 56,987 in June, 1932, the company reported yesterday. The total last month was larger than in any month since April, 1931.

MEMPHIS, Tenn, July 7. -- Memphis, from 1900 until the crash of 1930 the capital of a hard-wood lumber empire, is about to regain its position as the leading hardwood centre in the world. It is not that any competitor has, during the last three years, disputed the claim with Memphis.

THE Beethoven Ninth symphony drew its immense audience when it was performed last Thursday night at the Stadium concerts. This symphony always draws. It contains pages of the greatest music Beethoven ever wrote.
ST. LOUIS, July 8. -- Dizzy Dean today achieved his tenth seasonal triumph, his four-hit shut-out of the Dodgers delighting a ladies' day gathering of 7,800, of which 5,800 were feminine fans.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 8. -- Starting in a light air and a thin fog and finishing in a good breeze and a clearing, ninety-one craft participated on Long Island Sound today in the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's forty-fifth annual regatta.

BERLIN, July 8. -- Nazidom's sons abroad and other absent German sympathizers with the movement who may be marooned in foreign lands will soon receive opportunity to engage in active missionary work for the cause.

Dr. Menas S. Gregory, head of the psychopathic ward at Bellevue Hospital, examined Joseph W. Harriman yesterday on behalf of George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney. Dr. Gregory made a confidential report on the banker's mental condition for Mr. Medalie.

WE have thought so much about roof gardens and beer gardens and cocktail hours and beaches, and what to wear for each and all, that we may have forgotten what the clothes look like that one stays at horns in.

A very clear and comprehensive statement of the purposes for which the Mortgage Conference was organized last January was presented to the members of that body at a recent meeting by Philip A. Benson, president of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn and president of the Mortgage Conference.

The thirty-fourth Summer session of Columbia University will begin tomorrow with an enrolment indicated at approximately 10,000. The students come from all sections of the country. Last year's attendance was 11,559.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- The British Embassy in Washington has requested the State Department to keep a watchful eye on the John (Jake the Barber) Factor kidnapping case and to keep it advised of all developments, it was learned today.

THE reported conversion to Mohammedanism of Rex Ingram, American film producer, directs attention to other Christians of the Western World who have embraced that faith. A number of prominent Britons, especially those who have come Into contact with peoples of the East, have turned to the religion of the prophet.

The National Electrical Wholesalers Association, 165 Broadway, announced yesterday that its national code committee of twelve members would meet here on Tuesday and Wednesday to draft a code of practices for that branch of the electrical industry.

After questioning here, Theodore a. Holmes, 20-year-old sophomore at Antioch College, Yellow Springs, Ohio, was taken back to Ohio yesterday for further examination on the death of Mrs. Nora Coffey, 24-year-old resident of Springfield, Ohio.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 8. -- Declaring that the welfare of all countries is interdependent, Dr. Otto Nathan of New York, former adviser to the German Ministry of Economics, speaking today at the University of Virginia, took issue with those who advocate a policy of economic nationalism as a way out of the present world-wide depression.

A distinct upturn in suburban residential sales during the past six weeks has accompanied the revival in general business, and brokers handling small home properties are expressing optimistic opinions on the outlook for the remaining Summer months and the Fall season in the metropolitan district.

The recent emphasis placed on manufacturing gains was more apparent than ever in the business reports for last week from leading Federal Reserve centres. Retail trade, however, appears to have slackened to a more normal seasonal trend in most sections, despite increasing employment, rising wages and improvement in all major business indices.

Billy Petrolle, the Fargo Express, who has quit the lightweight division in an attempt to grain the world's welterweight crown, will clash with Bep Van Klaveren of Holland, 135 and 145 pound champion of Europe, in the feature ten-round bout at the Polo Grounds on Wednesday.

Judging from the vigorous exhortations of the recovery administration, the response from industry in the movement to create a new prosperity has not been entirely satisfactory. The Industrial Administrator, General Johnson, complains that the various groups are too slow in submitting their codes.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- Postmaster James A. Farley, in his capacity as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, today handed down the dictum that contributions to the Democratic party funds will not affect patronage rolls or save the positions of employes dismissed under economy measures.

Existing foreign markets for American raw cotton and for all types of finished and semi-finished cotton piece goods can readily absorb the entire domestic surplus of these materials, Samuel C. Lamport, head of the Liamport Manufacturing Company, said here yesterday.

LIKE the English sparrow, the European starling is rolling up enemies by the score. Michigan farmers recently reported that thousands of starlings had settled in every county of the State. The huge flocks not only ravage the orchards, eating tons of fruit, but they commit a more serious offense, driving other birds out of their homes and sanctuaries.

Elimination of competitive wastes among railroads, long advocated, now permitted under the law, will be furthered In the East in a manner distinct from the procedure to be followed in other regions. This will result because when the new railway law was passed greater progress toward elimination of these wastes had been made by carriers in the East than by lines in the remainder of the country.

LONDON, June 23. PRODUCTIONISM," in the sense in which I understand the word, has for several years been the curse of the theatre, and I have always been steadfastly opposed to those who, regarding a producer as the artistin-chief of a stage performance, wish dramatists to act as subordinate suppliers of rough material which he is free to transform at will.

IT is now four years since the publication of the first half of the Regional Plan and two years since the appearance of the final volume. The first dealt with land uses and communication systems in the region as a whole, and the second with the principles and methods guiding the building of the cities, towns and villages within it.
To the Editor of The New York Times: William Spies, in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, raises once more the question of our unsatisfactory national anthem.
WASHINGTON, July 8. -- President Roosevelt appealed tonight to cotton growers of the country to join, as a "patriotic duty," in the administration's acreage reduction program.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Mata Hari, the fleet 2-year-old filly from the Dixiana establishment of Charles T. Fisher, showed her superiority over a band of nine other well-regarded juveniles, scoring easily by two and a half lengths in the 510,000 added Arlington Lassie Stakes at Arlington Park today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The findings of the so-called "new theories" by the scientists in Chicago have no doubt created a maze of disillusion and doubt in the minds of many thinking people. The theories are, apparently, irrefutably logical.

AMONG the recent accessions in the Metropolitan Museum is one gift that should be warmly welcomed. It comes from the sons and daughter of Thomas Nast and consists of a collection of proofs, three books and a number of photographs.

Formulation of a unified code for the entire retail field is expected to result at the meeting Wednesday of the Retailers National Council in the offices here of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. Following the meeting, which will be presided over by H.J. Tily of Strawbridge Clothier, Philadelphia, president of the council, the indications yesterday were said to be that the coordinated code will be submitted to Washington.

MOSCOW, July 7. -- "The wheel of revolution rolls on and breaks hearts as well as bodies," Mme. Alexandra Kollontay, Soviet Ambassador to Sweden, once said bitterly about some of her "opposition" friends here who fell suddenly from the heights of power.

Not only the capitals of the world but the vast stretches of agricultural hinterlands have looked recently toward London, where the theories of economic nationalism and economic internationalism were brought into conflict. In the following article is pictured the changing attitude of this nation's largest State, whose prosperity, its people have come increasingly to recognize, is linked closely with volume of foreign trade.

With all series moving upward, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity again surged higher for the week ended July 1, the advance of nearly 4 points bringing the figure to the highest level in more than three years. The index now stands at 97.3, as compared with 93.8 in the previous week and 65.2 for the corresponding week of last year.

MADRID, July 7. -- It is a difficult task that faces Dr. Goma, installed as Primate of the Spanish Church in impressive ceremonies in the ancient narrow-streeted Toledo. The church has gone through two of the worst years in its centuries of existence in Spain.

THE plot structure of "Arizona to Broadway" called for a racketeer, forced to take over a musical show, to send out his henchmen, in search of talent to make his show a success. The gun-toters ran-sack the radio and theatre stages along Broadway, returning with a group of celebrities who, quavering with fear, put on a sample performance for the gunman leader.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 8. -- The first step by the Republican administration toward drastic reorganization of Westchester government was taken today. William B. Folger, County Budget Commissioner, addressed a letter to the Board of Supervisors recommending the appointment of a citizens committee to study governmental reorganization, both county and municipal.

Late this month, according to the dispatches, Senator REED will visit the titular leader of his party, Mr. HOOVER, to discuss the present state and future policies of the Republicans. It should be an interesting meeting. Certainly there is much to talk about. By the custom of American politics, Mr. HOOVER will remain chief of the Republicans until another than himself is nominated for the Presidency.

IN "The Canyon Trail" George B. Rodney achieves something of an advance in technique, in narrative skill and in characterization over the last preceding tale from his hand -- "The Mormon Trail." And this new yarn is not only livelier, more exciting, but also is more cleverly and more convincingly written.

QUEBEC, July 6. -- Beggars in this old city are sharply divided by caste, there, being the "regulars" who occupy fixed pitches and who only accept money, street car tickets or tobacco, and the "occasionals," mostly women, who go from house to house, taking anything that is offered.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 8 (AP). -- Unleashing a terrific attack on three Bison pitchers, the Newark Bears rode over the Schalk outfit today by 11 to 3, gaining an even break on the series.

PARIS, June 30. -- Beginning with declarations for the current year, the French Revenue Office will check all income-tax statements by an investigation of what have been designated as the "external signs of wealth."

THE year 1791, which marked the publication in two large quarto volumes of Boswell's immortal "Life of Johnson." witnessed also the first appearance of a work that has rivaled it in popularity. It too was printed in London in two volumes, but its publisher was William Lane instead of Charles Dilly, its size duodecimo and its form that of a novel, although its contents were biographical.

BUFFALO, July 6. -- The effect on welfare work of the recent improvement in business and industrial conditions in this city has not been to decrease the demands for help as compared with last year. On the contrary, they still show an increase.

AFTER months of silence President von Hindenburg has once more raised his voice. His letter to Chancellor Hitler urging an understanding between the warring factions in the Protestant churches halted, at least temporarily, the "coordination" of Protestant worship under the Third Reich.

WHAT does an atom look like? Thirty years ago it was supposed to be a minfature solar system -- a nucleus of mixed electrons and protons (hydrogen hearts) around which other electrons revolved. Such a structure could be drawn on paper and imagined.

SHANGHAI. SOOCHOW CREEK, one of the strangest and most crowded harbors in the world, is only three blocks from Shanghai's busiest modern thoroughfare, but maintains unchanged customs that were already centuries old in China before Columbus sailed to America.

The United States lags in the volume of fast merchant tonnage which should be available as naval auxiliaries in time of war, according to a survey made by the Middle West Foreign Trade Committee. Only fourteen merchant ships capable of twenty knots are available, and of these one-half are more than fifteen years old and five are more than twenty years old.

BERLIN, July 8. -- The initialing of the concordat between the Vatican and the National Socialist Government of Germany is regarded here as marking one of the biggest triumphs of Chancellor Hitler both in foreign and domestic politics and one that is bound to go far in consolidating his hold on Germany.

PARIS, July 8. -- Means to assure "integral" maintenance of the gold standard" were discussed and agreed on at a meeting of the governors of the central banks of France, Italy, Holland, Switzerland, Belgium, Luxemburg, Poland and Czechoslovakia, held today at the office of Governor Moret at the Bank of France.
CLEVELAND, July 8. -- Cold Cash, fleet pacer owned and driven by Walter J. Britenfield of Kansas City won the handicap pace, feature event of the get-away day North Randall grand circuit card today.

JEREMIAH AND THE PRINCESS" Is a typical Oppenheim romance, which is to say that it is an adventurous and highly colored and essentially implausible tale. For its setting Mr. Oppenheim has devised another of those tiny and turbulent kingdoms in Central Europe, somewhere in the general neighborhood, no doubt, of Ruritsnia and Graustark.
LONDON, July 8 (AP). -- Swooping over the line only 200 feet above the ground the veteran pilot Captain Geoffrey de Haviland today won the King's Cup, classic air race around England.

SHIPS have been launched with champagne and tables are christened with water, but for the latest in baptisms one must seek out Ward Wing, who directed the filming of "Samarang" in the Malay Archipelago.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 8. -- Miss Dorothy Round, Great Britain's tennis hope, started something against Mrs. Helen Wills Moody. She undertook to bring Mrs. Moody up from her favorite base line position to the volley position near the net.

NOTTINGHAM, July 8 (Canadian Press). -- The British West Indies collared the bowling and ran up a first-innings score of 314 runs opening the cricket match with Notting-- hamshire today. At the close of play Notts had scored 35 runs for one wicket.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP). -- Banners once used to picket the White House for suffrage were part of a pageant which tonight dramatized a national woman's party campaign for women's economic rights.
PARIS, July 7. -- This Summer's tourist invasion of Paris proceeds apparently uncurtailed by the dollar's depreciation. But no one of the big hotels is more than half full, if any Is doing that well.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In this time of discussion of monetary standards and foreign exchange the following story, which I ran across in The Southern Enterprise, a newspaper printed by the late Lucius Coffe Bryan at Thomasville, Ga., on Jan. 24, 1866, is of interest:

WITH the disagreement over stabilization at London, the world currency situation enters upon a new phase. The uncertainty with respect to exchange began when England abandoned the gold standard nearly two years ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In accurately reporting the recent annual convention of the American Association for the Advancement of Science THE NEW YORK TIMES is to be congratulated for a journalistic feat in handling difficult subject matter and an editorial policy which treats as news the elemental but complex realities of contemporary scientific research and conclusions.

As a result of the prolonged rally in security prices, unusually large percentages of advances have been made in asset values of common | stocks in some investment trusts having leverage. The trusts kept fairly well abreast of the market during the rally, their semiannual reports show.

Although this book begins by telling how Jim Reckett set his Heart on becoming a member of the Canadian Mounted Police, and how he finally prevailed upon his parents to allow him to enlist, and although the book follows at first Jim's personal fortunes, it is not a story but a history of Canada's Mounted Police from 1873 to 1931.

NORWICH, N.T., July 8 (AP). -- With six comrades in jail and thirty-four others sent back to Harlem, Negro recruits, comprising the major strength of the Civilian Conservation Corps Camp at Preston, worked under rigid military discipline today, following a rebellion against camp authorities yesterday.

Oriental studies are not receiving nearly the amount of attention in American education due them in view of the importance of our relationships with the Far East, in the opinion of Edward C. Carter, secretary of the American Council of the Institute of Pacific Relations, which has its headquarters here.

EAST NORTHFIELD. Mass., July 8. -- The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Brown of New York, who are spending the Summer here, will be "at home" next Monday afternoon to their friends who live in and near this town and to those from elsewhere who are here for a vacation.

PHYLIS BENTLEY'S already large circle of readers need not fear that "Carr," first published a few years before "Inheritance," is in any way immature. It is written with the same care, though since it touches only slightly on historical or commercially historical events, the research involved must have been less.

HOUSES of a strange new sort begin to be seen in America. There have always been queer-looking houses in this realm of rugged individualism but usually they have been recognizable as dwellings. These latest constructions, appearing at the Chicago Exposition, at architects' shows and in city suburbs, bear as little resemblance to the house of the present as the smartest motor car bears to the oldest family carriage.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 8. -- Over the same golf course on which his father learned his trade -- historic St. Andrews in Scotland -- dapper Densmore Shute today blazed his way to the world's most coveted golf prize -- the British open championship.

SALLY EILERS has three major ambitions. She would like to top "Bad Girl," her greatest success to date; appear in a play on Broadway, and travel extensively. A lesser goal is to trim her golf score, bringing it way below her present average of 124.

LONDON. OLD-FASHIONED liberalism, with its belief in human personality, la dead and gone. The idea that it was the duty of the State to protect the individual in his right to develop himself freely was steam-rollered out of existence during the war; and the acute international tensions of these post-war years have swept State after State into a new era of Caesarism which, in some parts of the Continent, has wiped out even democracy itself.

MILWAUKEE, July 8 (AP). -- Young men and women from all parts of the nation, as well as Canada and Mexico, gathered here today for the biennial convention of the International Society of Christian Endeavor, which its president, the Rev. Dr. Daniel A.

CHICAGO, July 8. -- Two 17-year-old schoolboys, Frankie Parker of Milwaukee and Gene Mako of Los Angeles, sailed into the final of the national clay courts singles tennis championship today at the Chicago Town and Tennis Club.
Flood control work, which is being taken up energetically by the Federal Government through its Recovery Act, promises to do more for the future of fishing than anything undertaken in recent years.
CHICAGO, July 8. -- To the booming of artillery and the clatter of cavalry, Japan Day at the Century of Progress Exposition was celebrated today.
WHILE it is perhaps too early to characterize Hitler as an involuntary peacemaker, signs are certainly increasing that the German Chancellor is bringing about a new alignment of European politics.

THE little red schoolhouse on the Warner studio lot was taxed to capacity during the filming of "The Mayor of Hell," which continues at the Strand. It was, in fact, unable to accommoddate more than thirty of the 350 boys who formed the major production problem on the picture.

PIERRE, S.D., July 3. -- It's the beer that South Dakota legislators neglected to legalize in their last session of the Legislature that is troubling the Berry administration these days and bringing a wave of unpopularity seldom forced on any State officials so soon after election.

DENVER, July 8 (AP). -- Seven persons were listed as dead, with three bodies recovered, and property loss estimated at around $1,000,000 as a check-up progressed today after cloudbursts in five sections of Colorado.

THE Fourth Atlantic Novel Contest, just announced by the Atlantic Monthly Press and Little, Brown Co., offers $5,000 as an outright prize and $5,000 as advance on royalties for the best manuscript novel submitted on or before March 1, 1934.

A large swimming pool, occupying the entire width of the central court, 70 by 100 feet in dimensions, has just been finished for the benefit of the tenants in the Flagg Court apartment house erected by Ernest Flagg, the architect, on Ridge Boulevard between Seventy-second and Seventy-third Streets in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated nervously yesterday in a range of a dollar a bale as operators evened up market interests before the acreage estimate appeared. Trading ceased at 11:50 A.M., with quotations 1 to 5 points lower than on Friday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES Charles A. Weil states the general misconceptions of the term "compensated dollar" in such clear and concise form that it would seem what is needed is but a similarly concise answer to set the matter straight.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 8. -- Slender Densmore Shute, 28-year-old American golfing artist with steely wrists and cool temperament, today defeated his long-driving countryman, Craig Wood, by five strokes in their thirty-six-hole play-off for the British open golf championship.

NEW YORK. Captain Richard F. Hennessy of London, his brother, Francis Hennessy, and their sisters, the Misses Sheila and Aileen Hennessy, have left the Plaza for a visit to Mr. and Mrs. Warren Leslie in Centre Moriches, L.I.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP). -- Cotton in cultivation in the United States on July 1 was reported by the Department of Agriculture today as totaling 40,798,000 acres, as compared with 36,452,000 acres in cultivation a year ago and 35,939,000 acres picked last year.

A year ago, when the powers of the R.F.C. were broadened by Congress to include Mousing loans for slum-clearance, there was much rejoicing by public-spirited men and women who felt that a new day was dawning for hundreds of thousands of families who have become acclimated to slum conditions.

LONG BEACH, Cal., July 8. -- In a thrilling sprint climax to a bow-and-bow race with Yale, Washington's long-sweeping oarsmen won the national intercollegiate sprint championship before 15,000 persons today over the Olympic 2,000-meter course at Marine Stadium.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 8. -- Hammering three Montclair A.C. twirlers for a total of fifteen hits, including homers by Don Kellett, George Beyer and Hap Hanlon, the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club scored an 11 to 7 victory today to clinch second place in the Eastern Athletic Club League.

THAT was an auspicious day -- "a climax," Mrs. Irwin calls it, in the history of feminism, when Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Lucretia Mott, American women delegates to the World's Anti-Slavery Conference held at London in 1840.

LONDON, July 8. -- Proposals for the international regulation of the markets for bread cereals and butter were made today to the economic conference by the Polish delegation. They will come before the committee on the coordination of production, which is most likely to continue work whatever the extent to which other activities of the conference may be curtailed.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- The Lenox Horse Show will be held on the Dan R. Hanna Farm on July 28 and 29, two months earlier than in other years. The judges will be Herbert L. Camp of Middletown, Conn., for the saddle horses; Samuel J. Shaw of Brookline, Mass., for the harness classes; James Butler of Katonah, N.T., and Frank A. Bonsal Jr. of Lyndon, Md., for hunters and jumpers.
Belief that the first objective in the price-raising campaign of the administration may shortly be realized had a restraining influence on the share market yesterday.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 8. -- Harry Whitney, driving Calumet Calculation, won the free-for-all pace at the Fair Grounds today after three heats from Hollyrood Knight, star of the New England Circuit.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Unless William Galloway can cite some good authorities for the origin of golf in Scotland, it seems to me he cannot beat the Dutch. Webster's Dictionary is the only reputable authority I have found that even hints that the Scots played the game first.

IN his "Shiva, or the Future of India." published in 1929. Mr. Minney's strongly Tory and pro-British views on the subject of Indian nationalism were much less pronounced than in this later volume, in the whole of which he only once admits to a major mistake on the part of those who now rule the continent-peninsula.

AE. HOUSMAN gave a final laurel to the year's apotheosis of beer when he told a Cambridge audience that a pint at luncheon had a great deal to do with the inspiration of his poems. In Mr. Benet's anthology the poets singularly overlook beer and all allied potations as a cause of poetry.

A provision of the new banking act that has received little notice, but that is likely to produce some interesting developments in the banking world, is the one that gives bank stockholders the right to cumulate their votes for directors.

MONTREAL, July 8. -- The position of the newsprint industry in Canada is regarded here as being slightly improved by an increase in exports to the United States and the prospect of a general business recovery which would further increase demand.

THIS is a book invaluable as a record to naval men, designers and engineers of all countries. The subject bad been neglected In Great Britain and the United States, although there seems to have been no dearth of material In Admiralty and Navy Department archives.

BERLIN, July 8 (AP). -- A new constitution for the Prussian State Council in which storm troop members were officially recognized as among the chief advisers of the State Premier was promulgated today by Captain Wilhelm Goering, chief aide of Chancellor Hitler in the National Cabinet.

EDGAR ALLAN POE said that the exiled Englishman who in mid-nineteenth century America wrote under the name of Frank Forester had an obvious poetic gift with a bright fancy. Sir Hubert himself could praise no more.

PRESIDENTIAL airs blow about the new issue of The Colophon. The palpable manifestation appears in the final paper, "The Hoover Translation of Agricola's 'De Re Metallica,' " by William R. Castle Jr. Mr. Castle was Mr. Hoover's Under-Secretary of State.

SOURABAYA, JAVA. IF the authors of profound books about art knew what they were talking about you might expect to find the drama an integral part of native life all over the world. But intellectuals are notoriously wrong about everything that matters, and the fact remains that drama on even the simplest terms is as scarce as a modest tourist.

PASIS. THE depression as felt in France has been responsible among other things for teaching Parisians the meaning of the word "home" -- you know, of course, that it has not existed in the French language in our meaning of the word.

THIS is Walter Wilkinson's fourth book on traveling through rustic byways with a one-man Punch and Judy show; the first being "The Peep-Show," the second "Vagabonds and Puppets" and the third "Puppets in Yorkshire."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 8. -- The University Extension Division of Rutgers University will offer required college courses of the freshman year in evening classes at Newark and New Brunswick, it was announced by Professor Norman C. Miller, director of the division.

HARRY MOSES has both a plan and an intimate revue (the two being pretty much the same thing) for November. According to his description of it, the affair will be not unlike the Chauve-Souris. There will be ten sketches, in the mode of satire, and fifteen principals therein.

DUBLIN, July 7. -- Despite the fact that most newspaper dispatches printed here give the British and French viewpoint of the monetary crisis in the World Economic Conference, majority opinion in the Irish Free State is strong in admiration for and understanding of the position taken by President Roosevelt.

GRAND CENTRAL PARKWAY in Queens and its extension. Northern State Parkway, in Nassau County, which are scheduled to be opened officially next Saturday, are expected to go a long way toward solving one of the city's major traffic problems -- the bottleneck in western Long Island.

The investment banking fraternity has received the official rules and regulations from the Federal Trade Commission governing the issuance of new securities under the Federal Securities Act and is prepared to make the best of a situation regarded with some misgivings by those bankers.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 6. -- A State-wide campaign is under way in Kentucky, not only to bring about repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, but also to put Kentucky's State laws in harmony with the changing sentiment of the United States on this issue.

MUNICH, July 8. -- Bavaria, always proud of being somewhat "different," has the distinction of having raised the first public clash between members of the new and the old regimes, which because of the importance of the personages involved, cannot be Kept out of the newspapers.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 8. -- Two teams rode into the semi-final round of the Hempstead Cups polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.

AN interesting piece of research is presented here by Mr. Sessler, who has very fully reconstructed the story of the Moravian Church and the pioneer Moravians in this country, especially as connected with the settlements in and around Bethlehem, Pa.

MISS RICHARDSON'S scholarly monograph enriches our knowledge of Greek life by its wide investigation of all available sources of information upon its subjects and its masterly assemblage and presentation of the material thus collected.
NEWARK, N.J., July 8. -- An orphan boy from Omaha stepped off a train from the West this morning, clutching a small valise and a copy of "The Hand of Fu Manchu."
STOCKHOLM, July 8. -- Professor Gustav Cassel, in the quarterly review of the Swedish Bank, Skandinaviska Kreditaktiebolag, today gives an expose of the Swedish stabilization program.

Bonds called last week for redemption before their dates for maturities were principally small lots of municipal bonds for payment in July, numerous amounts of foreign bonds and several domestic industrial issues called in their entirety for payment in future months.

TODAY. VENETIAN Little Symphony Orchestra of twelve musicians under the baton of Antonio d'Annunzio, brother of Italy's warrior-poet, brings a musical novelty to American listeners. The plectrum orchestra, comprising three first mandolins, two second mandolins, three guitars, one mando-' cello, a mandobasse and two mandolinas, will be heard in a series of Sunday broadcasts.

NARROWSBURG, N.Y., July 8. -- Hundreds of lights glimmered like fireflies and scores of campfires burned over the wide Ten Mile River Camp of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York tonight as more than 1,300 Boy Scouts from New York City started their first five encampments for 1933.

NEWARK, N.J., July 8. -- Trotting the first heat in 2:12 1-4. Peter Parole, bay gelding owned and driven by Elias Bodenweiser of Newark, won the feature event of the fifth matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

CHICAGO, July 7. -- In that region that skirts the western shore of Lake Michigan, and bends around its southern end, there are signs of returning prosperity. That is to say, although the almost forgotten features of the goddess who carries an overflowing cornucopia beneath her arm are not as yet clearly discernible, a form resembling her once familiar figure can be seen approaching.

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- President Roosevelt is understood to have set aside this week-end for a study of the legal steps that may be necessary to require conformity to his plan for industrial recovery.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., July 5. -- Southern California is wondering what kind of an outmoded map and what vintage census returns guided the War Department when it allocated $5,418,371 for improvement of defenses in the vicinity of San Francisco, and only $423,443 for all of Southern California.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- The demand for more sophisticated entertainment in the White Mountains Summer colonies is being answered with a vim. Following the opening of the eight weeks' season in Summer stock of the Forty-niners of the Yale Dramatic School at Notchland, another group of players, the Footlighters, has just commenced a series of performances which they will give at Conway, Intervale and other East Side resorts.

WHEN the republican Cabinet recently resigned in Spain, the temporary crisis and ensuing reshuffle of republican politicians served as a reminder that ex-King Alfonso, who has renounced none of his rights, is watching and waiting in his exile at Fontainebleau.

IT was not so many years ago -- about five -- that Clarence D. Chamberlin stood before the members of the largest club of prominent railroad men in the country and said impressive things about air transport.

DARIEN, Conn., July 8. -- A cleancut victory was scored today by the Warfield Farms of Frederick P. Warfield, Port Chester, N.Y., sportsman, when his thoroughbred hunter, Prince Charming II, captured the hunter championship of the seventh annual Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show.
THE Museum of Modern Art launches its Summer exhibition this week, on Tuesday to members and on Wednesday to the public. Meanwhile, several new shows have become current in New York.

MEXICO, D.F., July 8. -- Fifteen persons are dead and property damage is considerable as a result of a hurricane which swept the Gulf coast of Mexico last night after striking Cuba, where extensive damage and some loss of life were reported.

IT has been pointed out more than once in these columns that the filament incandescent lamp seems to have reached its highest development. Both in Europe and America the electrical research laboratories have been experimenting with tenuous vapors.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 8. -- A flagdecked city and gaily decorated Boardwalk welcomed the vanguard of 25,000 Shriners, who arrived here today for the opening of the annual frolic and session of the Imperial Council of the Ancient Arabic Order, Nobles of uhe Mystic Shrine.

Charles Bancroft Dillingham, who helped found the old New York Hippodrome and during the three decades he has served with the theatre produced more than 200 shows, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday. He listed liabilities of $7,337,703 and assets of $108,063.

During the month of June 4,500 dogs were registered with the American Kennel Club, an advance of 50 over the previous month. This compares favorably with the figures for the corresponding month a year ago, during which 4,312 dogs were registered.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 8. -- Playing true to form, Gregory S. Mangin of Newark, national indoor champion, and Herbert L. Bowman, veteran New Yorker, scored semifinal victories at the Montclair Athletic Club today in the forty-first annual men's New Jersey State singles championship.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 8. -- John D. Rockefeller celebrated his ninety-fourth birthday today at his Pocantico Hills estate with his son John D. Rockefeller Jr., his grandchildren and his two great-grandchildren.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 8. -- Wah-ne-ta III, owned by George E. Rice, repeated her victory of last year by winning in Class A of the Power Boat Division in the New York A.C.'s annual race to Block Island tonight.

Administrators of the National Industrial Recovery Act should profit by the mistakes which led to a partial breakdown of the British system of joint industrial councils, started in England after the war and similar to the movement now under way here, William H. Ingersoll, formerly of the Ingersoll Watch Company and now a marketing consultant, told THE TIMES yesterday.

Work on the new 52-acre public park on Fort Washington Hill, which includes historic Port Tyron, is now well advanced. Since early last Spring a large force of workmen have been razing old buildings. Masons have erected walls and archways, driveways have been built and landscape gardeners and architects have laid out trees, shrubbery and flower beds.

WASHINGTON. AT a time of life when most men are thinking of armchair comfort and slippered ease. Claude Augustus Swanson -- with forty years in public office behind him -- has chosen the strenuous job of supervising the navy's "new deal."

WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The tension caused here by recent events at the London Economic Conference was relieved today by growing confidence that the conference has been "saved" without the United States sacrificing one iota of its stand or its prestige.

WELLESLEY, Mass., July 8 (AP). -- An appeal for ratification of the Child Labor Amendment and continuance of efforts for State minimum wage laws was made tonight by Secretary Perkins in an address at the Wellesley College Institute for Social Progress.

The alumni association of the New England Conservatory of Music has celebrated an event that is unlikely to have a counterpart in the history of the conservatorythe fiftieth anniversary of Charles Dennee's connection with the institution as a member of its faculty in the piano department.

THERE is a genuine quality about this book that makes it seem more like a bit of autobiography than a story. In the opening paragraph the author describes himself as "half-past being a lad and on the stroke of young manhood."

WARSAW, July 7. -- An international agreement guaranteeing the existing frontiers of Eastern Europe for many years has at last been realized in the eight-power convention at London defining aggression, it is held here. Soviet Russia and all her neighbors possess now an instrument of protection against invasion or unofficial wars of the Manchuria type.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 8. -- Wimbledon closed its annual tennis fortnight in a final blaze of British glory today as a little English girl, Miss Dorothy Round, forced Mrs. Helen Wills Moody to battle as she hasn't had to in years to win the women's singles championship for the sixth time.

Remodeling of studio apartments in the Carnegie Hall Building at Seventh Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street has led to an increased demand for quarters and a high occupancy record has been made in the forty-two-year-old structure, according to Louis G. Kibbe, manager.
BOSTON, July 5. -- For weeks the Question uppermost in the minds of the people of Vermont has been: When will our banks be allowed to reopen?
To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of F.F. Greeley, published, in THE NEW YORK TIMES, needs correction.

WITH the dollar low and European affairs too disturbed to allow for much dance activity, it is a good Summer for American dancers to stay at home and take advantage of some of their own educational facilities.

While activity in the local market has been somewhat slow last week, a substantial increase in the arrival of buyers to do major Fall purchasing is expected this week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 8. -- With half of the four racing events completed, Ken Mackenzie, New Haven, Conn., took the lead today in the New York State outboard championships on Seneca Lake. He holds an edge over Roy Straley of Buffalo, 2,065 points to 1,482.

DOVER, Del., July 8. -- While there was an increase in the number of charters filed with the State Corporation Department in the first six months of this year, compared with the last six months of 1932, the revenue from the increased number of charters was less hy $18,000.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 8. -- Densmore Shute is our new open champion, and a worthier one could not wear the laurel nor follow in the line of American golfers who have come over to show us how to do it for ten long years.

THE recent adjournment of our national legislature after handing over unprecedented peacetime powers to the President, and the resulting speculation as to how much it will venture to reassert its authority when it meets again in January, make it pertinent to ask, What is an American legislature?

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP). -- Early extension to one State in each of the twelve Federal Land Bank districts of the Wisconsin plan for refinancing farm mortgages held by closed banks and banks operating under restrictions is planned by the Farm Credit Administration.
MEXICO, D.F., July 2. -- Dispatches from Tampico today said Soto La Marina, a seacoast village in Tamaulipas, was destroyed by a hurricane.

Four contributions sufficient for the establishment of as many complete individual playgrounds were announced yesterday by the Citizens Summer Playground Committee. It hopes to raise funds sufficient to open 136 playgrounds.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 8. -- The campaign against Christian missionaries which the Moslems of Egypt have been carrying on for the past few weeks, although still as serious as ever, has now taken on an entirely different aspect.
PHILADELPHIA, July 8 (AP). -- The Athletics and White Sox divided a double-header today, the Mackmen winning the first game, 10-4, but dropping the second, 11-6.

HOLLYWOOD. IN anticipation of more joyous financial times which the industry feels are imminent, the town this week took a new lease of life and announced a substantial increase in the number of films local studios will produce during the season just starting.
WASHINGTON, July 8. -- The Treasury Department has declined to require its officials to testify about the Detroit banking situation in the Federal court inquiry in that city or to turn over records.

Corner House, home for orphanage "alumni" and homeless Jewish youths, is to move next Saturday from its present location at 311 West Fourteenth Street to new quarters at 331 East Twelfth Street.

OMAHA, Neb., July 5. -- Legally Kansas and Nebraska are Just as dry as they ever were. The Kansas Legislature last Winter refused to Join the Federal Government in giving sanction to 3:2 beer. The Nebraska Legislature gave its sanction but failed to attach the emergency clause to the bill, which automatically delays legitimacy until Aug. 10.

Whitlock of Springfield, Ill., president of the league.

Ames Co., Ltd., in their July review of the bond market point out that no currency or credit inflation has actually taken place.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 9 -- John D. LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 9 -- Sixty-three sailing craft, including small local boats, competed today in the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club's special regatta.

LONDON, Monday, July 10 -- Summing up the prospects before the economic conference in advance of today's meeting of the steering committee to discuss the future program, The London Times says the main obstacle is still undisposed of, although it was voted down.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 9 -- A large mosaic floor has been discovered in the ruins of a building bordering the south side of the ancient marketplace of Corinth, Greece. This was announced here today by Professor Richard Stillwell, director of the American School of Classical Studies at Athens and a member of the faculty of the department of art and archaeology of Princeton University, who has returned to Princeton for the Summer.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Arrangements were being completed tonight by the Chicago backers of Jimmie Mattern to enable him to resume his solo round-the-world flight from Anadyr, Siberia, where he has been stranded for the last twenty-five days.

LONDON, July 9 -- Diligent investigation of reports that industrial plants in Northern England were receiving cancellations because of American competition resulting from the cheaper dollar reveals there have been no withdrawals of orders thus far, although some might be expected later.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- Lighter supply of hogs, with an improved Eastern demand, absorbed the offerings on the weak spots and brought several upturns that did not fully hold at the top. The extreme top was $4.75 and the average $4.50 with a week's average of $4.45 at Chicago, which was 10 cents higher than the previous week and compared with $4.90 last year.

It is nearly forty years since Ruritania was added to the kingdoms of romance. The fortune of Mr. HAWKINS of the Middle Temple was made. His vogue was earlier and greater here than in his native country. In the Nineties, that now seem almost as far away as an early Egyptian dynasty, ANTHONY HOPE'S photograph was throned on many a mantel in the women's colleges beside that of RICHARD HARDING DAVIS.

Speculative activity on the secirrilies exchanges of the country reached the highest levels for any bull market on record last week. The average daily volume of sales during the week was exceeded only during the panic of October, 1929, and in the March reaction of the same year.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 9 -- Howard McMichaei, sailing Grey Fox, won the Star Class race held by the New Rochelle Yacht Club off Execution Light today. However, the boat that finished second a minute behind Grey Fox, Adrian Iselin's Ace, will be the Western Long Island Sound Star Class fleet's representative at the Star Class international regatta at Long Beach, Cal., late next month.

Stephen Vincent Benet, poet, will be this year's recipient of the Roosevelt Medal for a distinguished contribution to American literature, it was announced yesterday by James R. Garfield, president of the Roosevelt Memorial Association.

Registration in the senior high schools of New York City is expected to reach 233,000 students this October and 245,000 in October, 1934, Dr. Harold C. Campbell, Deputy and Associate Superintendent of Schools, announced yesterday. The figures for this year represent an estimated increase of 18,655 over the registration in October, 1932.

PARIS, July 8. -- President Roosevelt undoubtedly was the most talked-about man on the world's markets this week. Mr. Hoover's" suprise declarations" remain among the market's legends, but Mr. Roosevelt has gone him one better, as financial Paris sees it.

In his "Frontiers of Medicine," a kind of history in highlights of medicine intended for the general reader, Dr. Morris Fishbein, editor of The Journal of the American Medical Association and Hygeia, ranges in 207 small pages from the days before Hippocrates, father of modern medicine, to the present.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- Grain and commodity prices have been on the upturn most of the last four months. Traders as a rule are looking for a continuation of the advance. The public is said to have the market and its buying has been largely responsible for an advance of about 37 to 58 cents a bushel on wheat from the low point of the season.
Harry Kenny stood in the doorway of the monkey house in Central Park yesterday and watched the crowds running for shelter from the rain.

The present week is an ambitious one in the schedule of the Summer theatres that dot the countryside. Many new plays are being tried out on behalf of Broadway producers, or in the interests of potential ones. Most of the playhouses are now open for their seasons, and those that are not actively engaged in "try-out" matters are giving versions of past local successes.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.L., July 9 -- Coasting along in light airs for most of the way, W.H. Wheeler Jr.'s Class Q sloop Cotton Blossom II was victorious today in the sailing division of the annual race conducted by the New York A.C. from Execution Light to this port.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 9. -- The second of the series of test matches to decide the team which will represent the East in the polo matches against the West at the world's fair in Chicago next month was held at the Sands Point Club today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 (AP) -- While thousands of Californians gathered today at key points of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay bridge project, President Roosevelt in Washington pressed a button which officially launched work on the $75,000,000 undertaking.

The Bible should be attractively printed and bound In a fifty-six volume edition to meet modern needs, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie, rector of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

VIENNA, July 9. -- Premier Goemboes of Hungary, who arrived suddenly in Vienna at 6 o'clock this evening, had a long conference with the Austrian Chancellor, Dr. Engelbert Dollfuss. At 11 o'clock he received the Austrian and foreign press.

The Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, made public yesterday the results of a study of newspaper, magazine and broadcast expenditures for advertising in 1932. The survey showed that newspapers received about 59 per cent of the aggregate appropriations of 432 national advertisers, and were the preferred medium in nineteen out of thirty leading trade groups.

VIENNA, July 9. -- Premier Julius Goemboes of Hungary, after a conference today with Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss of Austria, said economic restoration of the Danubian countries could be had at the price of revision of the post-war treaties.

Specifications against contracts entered into before the recent price advances virtually assure a July output of steel at approximately the current rate, which was 55 per cent last week and will be at least 56 per cent this week, according to the magazine Steel.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, July | 9. -- The steady export demand throughout last week enabled Argentine grains to avoid the sharp price fluctuations that characterized some markets in the northern part of the hemisphere. Wheat rose 5 per cent, or from 6.30 to 6.35 pesos a quintal.
CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- Interrupting the second round of the Intercollegiate chess tournament, an outdoor match on a giant chessboard was played today with living pieces at the World's Fair.

The Crown Willamette Paper Company reports a net loss of $37,613 for the fiscal year ended on April 30, contrasted with a net profit of $2,233,926 for the previous fiscal year, after full deductions for depreciation, depletion and adjustments for Pacifies Mills, Ltd., minority stockholders.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The doubting Thomases may shake their heads at the mention of the National Industrial Recovery Act; the cynics may scoff at Roosevelt idealism; the Hoover die-hards may fume over the President's socialistic trend, but the fact is apparent that Franklin. D. Roosevelt has performed a miracle -- he has made our people think, and think seriously and hopefully as they have never thought before.
WASHINGTON, July 9. -- The text of President Roosevelt's order approving the Cotton Textile Code follows:
GENEVA, N.Y., July 9 -- Cab Walier, 30-year-old Syracuse (N.Y.) boat builder, today was crowned New York State's outboard champion, in the sixth annual speedboat regatta on Seneca Lake.
LONDON, July 9 -- The steering committee, or bureau, of the World Economic Conference meets tomorrow to decide how and within what scope the conference shall continue during the next few weeks.
The 100th anniversary of the founding of the Oxford Movement was celebrated yesterday in many Protestant Episcopal churches.

LONDON, July 8. -- Never exuberant concerning the outcome of the International Economic Conference since President Roosevelt refused to allow a discussion of war debts, the financial district here is now taking the course of events calmly, pointing out that the world already is slowly emerging from the depression without the aid of politicians.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 9 -- Only the subscription of $200,000 tonight stood between Chattanoogans and the release of more than $4,000,000 now tied up in the closed Chattanooga National Bank. A subscription committee headed by Carter Lupton of Chattanooga is ready to begin canvassing tomorrow, and little trouble is expected in reaching the required quota.
Babe Ruth hit three home runs Yesterday at the Stadium before 25,000 fans and lifted the Yankees out of the doldrums.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 9 (AP) -- Rochester erred at critical times in today's games with Newark, which increased its International League lead to three full games by winning twice. The Bears enjoy this margin over Toronto, which, although idle, gained second place as the double defeat dropped the Red Wings into third position.

TOKYO, July 9 -- A Rengo News Agency dispatch from Hakodate today reported the seizure of the Japanese fishing boat Kotohira Maru, carrying a crew of twenty, by a Soviet trawler yesterday, adding a fresh incident to the Russo-Japanese fishing fleet quarrels in the northern seas.

George S. Van Schaick, state Superintendent of Insurance, made public yesterday a letter sent to the forty title and guaranty mortgage companies under his jurisdiction, asking them to extend time to trustworthy debtors who are temporarily embarrassed and not bring unreasonable foreclosure actions.

CHICAGO, July 9. -- Frankie Parker is the new master of America's clay tennis courts. The 17-year-old youth from Milwaukee won the crown in convincing fashion at the Chicago Town and Tennis Club today by conquering Gene Mako, University of Southern California star, in straight sets, 6-3, 6-3, 6-3.
LONG BEACH, Cal., July 9 -- National intercollegiate crew racing has come to Southern California to stay.

WASHINGTON, July 9. - Boris E. Skvirsky, unofficial Soviet representative here, today communicated to the backers of James J. Mattern, American round-the-world flyer stranded in Siberia, an offer to send a Russian plane to Nome, Alaska, for a motor and spare parts for Mattern's ship.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Labor and relief officials of twentysix States, gathered here at Federal behest, today pledged the cooperation of their agencies with the new United States Employment Service toward spreading new jobs at top speed.

LONDON, July 9 -- Commemoration of the ceptenary of the Oxford Movement, which, taking its rise in the work of Newman and Pusey, has revived in the Church of England and some of her daughter churches overseas much ritualism of pre-Reformation times, began today and will last a week.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- President Roosevelt late today tapped a gold-plated telegraph key in the White House, starting construction on the mammoth San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge, which he described as "symbolizing the upturn that has come in our industrial life."

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh took off yesterday on the first leg of a survey flight that will take them across Labrador, Greenland and Iceland. It was 3:40 P.M., Daylight Time, before they finally got away from Glenn Curtiss Airport, North Beach, Queens, following a day of intense activity on the part of the Colonel and a corps of mechanics and engineers who were working on the plane.

DANBURY, Conn., July 9 -- Henry P. Brumell, 36, of Bridgeport, Conn., was drowned early this morning in Lake Candlewood near here, while taking a moonlight swim. Volunteer divers, working with State Police recovered his body this afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, July 9 -- The Dodgers battled the Cardinals to a standstill today before 10,500 fans. Carey's athletes took the first contest in eleven innings, 8 to 6, but were shut out, 2 to 0, in the afterpiece by Tex Carleton.
THE visitor started talking about Rotterdam, but before he had finished he had touched on Paris, Berlin, New York, Melbourne and a few cities between.
NEW YORK. Princess Aymon de Faucigny Lucinge will return tomorrow on the Bremen and will be at the Madison.

The end of the first week or the new fiscal year finds the Government seeking to reduce one set of costs and to expand another. About 8,000 Federal employes have been dismissed at a time when the Government is preparing to spend upward of $3,000,000,000, if necessary, in order to create employment.

BERLIN, July 9. -- While German opinion is not inclined to impute to President Roosevelt responsibility for the threatened failure of the Economic Conference, his currency policy is not favored in banking circles here, and is condemned as inadvisable and impracticable by financial journals.

BRISTOL, Pa., July 9 (AP). -- Answering criticism of his factory in the legislative sweatshop investigation, former United States Senator Joseph R. Grundy tonight denounced what lie termed "an obvious conspiracy" of State officials "to create a sinister and false picture of industrial conditions."

MOSCOW, July 9 -- Great prominence is given by the Soviet press to Foreign Commissar Litvinoff's visit to Paris and to the recent London pacts between the Soviet Union and her western neighbor States.
A revival of St. John Ervine's "John Ferguson" will open this evening at the Belmont Theatre. Augustin Duncan is its star and director.

MOSCOW, July 9 -- Anadyr is a tiny settlement in the Arctic waste with a small radio station and highly capricious meteorological conditions," G.A. Ushakov, vice chief of the Soviet Arctic Service, told your correspondent today. "That explains not only why James Mattern's first message still has not been followed up and why we have no other information to date.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 9. -- Twenty-nine executives of food handling, processing and distributing companies, representing the largest food industries of the nation, with a total business turnover of $8,000,000,000 annually, completed today a program for the conduct of their industry under the "new deal."

Heat and high humidity drove huge throngs to the New Jersey and Long Island shore resorts yesterday. Transportation lines were taxed to capacity as 800,000 flocked to Coney Island, 400,000 to the Rockaways and proportionately large crowds to almost every other resort between Montauk Point and Cape May.

In the Westinghouse Laboratories in Pittsburgh revolutionary experiments in domestic heating are being conducted. The thermometer records only 55 degrees F. Yet men work the year round in the lightest of Summer clothing in an atmosphere that would ordinarily demand woolens.
CHICAGO, July 9 -- Disaster continued to beset the Giants on all sides today as they dropped both ends of a double header to the Cubs, while 35,000 Chicagoans chortled with glee.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 9 -- Four hundred music lovers from Berkshire resorts were present this afternoon when the tenth season of Mrs. Frederick S. Coolidge's chamber-music concerts opened at her temple of music on South Mountain here.
Flats and small dwelling's were sold in larg-e number in New Jersey over the week-end.

ALBANY, July 9 -- Governor Lehman, in issuing a financial statement tonight, declared he was confident that the State would be able, barring unforeseen demands, to balance its budget by the end of the fiscal year. He showed that the estimates of revenue receipts for the fiscal year which ended June 30 were fully realized.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- President Roosevelt's message a week ago finally barring stabilization work by the London Economic Conference was described as being in line with the recommendations of experts who laid the groundwork for the conference in a radio talk tonight by Louis McHenry Howe, the President's secretary.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- New York State provided $375,242,445 of the $1,616,223,408 in internal revenue receipts collected by the government in the 1933 fiscal year, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

While officers of some of the larger baking corporations disclosed that no rise in bread prices had been scheduled for today to absorb the new wheat processing tax and increased cost of wheat, smaller bakers announced that they would raise their prices.

PARIS, July 9 -- Speaking at a banquet given, in his honor by the Radical Socialist party of Apt in Vaucluse, Premier Daladier tonight defined his policy as "a considered and unshakable determination to spare France from the dangers of violence and experiments."

Funds being raised by the American Joint Distribution Committee of Jews in Germany have reached a total of $708,000, Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national chairman of the campaign, announced yesterday. The goal sought is $2,000,000, of which $1,000,000 has been set as the New York quota.

NEW HAVEN, July 9. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 66.6, which compares with 65.1 a week ago, 64 two weeks ago, 68.5 three weeks ago and 62.7 four weeks ago. The present average is the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- A downward revision of crop estimates on Spring wheat in the American and Canadian Northwest is necessitated by the absence of timely rains covering a large area. Where moisture was sufficient conditions have held well, but prospects for a bumper yield are regarded as past.

MANILA, July 9 -- While talk of compromise, national unity, forebearance and a peaceful settlement heard on every side, the speeches of campaigners for and against the Hawes Law are making unity or compromise daily more remote.

PITTSBURGH, July 9. -- Because insufficient time has elapsed since the limit expired for placing-orders against second-quarter contracts for steel, producers are unable to gauge the rate of buying. Prices have been specifically advanced in some lines and firmed in others by withdrawals of concessions.

Insurance policies sold or given away in connection with the sale of securities, commodities, services and subscriptions to newspapers and periodicals is disapproved by a ruling of State Superintendent of Insurance George S. Van Schaick, made public this morning.

Governor Lehman will be the principal speaker at the laying of the cornerstone on Wednesday of the new Hall of Springs at Saratoga Springs, N.Y., it was announced yesterday. The $900,000 building is being financed by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

GENEVA, Tuly 9. -- For the first time since the beginning of the depression, statistics published by the International Labor Office indicate decreased unemployment compared with last year in some important countries.

LONDON, July 9 -- Unless there are some concrete developments tending toward wide acceptance of the American price-raising program, statesmen gathered here probably will begin to east about soon for a few general resolutions on which nations might agree and which might leave a respectable tombstone over the World Economic Conference.
Viscount Granard and Lady Granard are arriving today from London on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, which is making her seventy-fifth round trip across the Atlantic.

BERLIN, July 9 -- There, is at least one official voice in Europe that expresses understanding of the methods and motives of President Roosevelt. This voice is that of Germany, as represented by Chancellor Adolf Hitler. When asked in an interview what he thought of the messages of the President to the London Economic Conference, Herr Hitler replied:

Francis J. Sinnott, secretary of the Board of Transportation, will be the next Postmaster of Brooklyn. Mr. Sinnott, whose name was the only one presented by John H. McCooey, Kings County leader, has been deemed acceptable and will be appointed, according to reliable information yesterday.

Representative James W. Wadsworth, according to information from well-informed sources, has definitely turned his back on proposals that he seek nomination and election next year to his old seat in the United States Senate. He lost his seat in the 1926 election, owing to dry opposition.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 9 -- The industrial pick up now going on has had little if any effect on the relief problem. The decline in relief expenditures during April and May has been seasonal and less rather than more in amount than is usual at this time of year, according to Langdon W. Post, associate director of the Federal Emergency Relief Administration.
BOSTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Red Sox shut out the Browns, 4 to 0, in the first game of a double-header today and then were humbled, 9 to 2, in the nightcap.

Rapid transit unification on terms fair to the city cannot be achieved until its credit is restored sufficiently to permit the sale of 4 per cent long-term bonds at par, Samuel Untermyer warned the Board of Estimate in his letter accepting appointment as special counsel on unification and related matters.
Forty-nine prominent New York physicians signed a statement yesterday protesting against discriminations to which Jewish doctors and men of science are being subjected in Germany.

With thousands of men on the city's emergency employment rolls unpaid because of lack of relief funds and 210,000 families receiving home relief facing a cut or suspension of disbursements, steps will be taken today by the city in an effort to assure the continuance of relief work for this month.

The historic residence at 21 Fifth Avenue will be sold today at auction in foreclosure proceedings in the Vesey Street salesroom. It was in this house that Albert Bigelow Paine compiled much of the material for his biography of Mark Twain.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- President Roosevelt tonight signed the cotton textile code, abolishing child labor in the industry, establishing a forty-hour work week and fixing minimum wages at $12 weekly in the South and $13 in the North. This is the first code for fair competition accepted under the Industrial Recovery Act.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 9 -- Dr. A. Kingsley Porter, William Dorr Boardman Professor of Fine Arts at Harvard, went to Ireland in May with his wife to spend his Summer vacation as usual at Glenveagh Castle, County Donegal, which he purchased several years ago.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 9 -- Many beach and dinner parties marked the week-end at the Atlantic Beach Club. Guests included ex-Governor Alfred E. Smith and his family, members of the Oxford and Cambridge tennis teams and Grand Duchess Marie of Russia.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 9. -- Attacking from the first minute of play with a force and determination that made their handicap of two goals unnecessary, the Aiken Knights captured the Meadow Brook Cups on International Field of the Meadow Brook Club today, turning back Aknusti in the final by a score of 14 to 8.
