WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- With a processing tax of 30 cents a bushel resting since last midnight squarely upon all wheat going into the making of food for American consumers, administrators of the Farm Act today were expectant of an early legal test of this first application of one of their principal powers.

Scholarships for 1933-34 have been awarded to fourteen blind students from eleven States and Cuba by the American Foundation for the Blind, it was announced yesterday by Robert B. Irwin, executive director. They are granted annually on the basis of the success of students, general recommendations, choice of a definite occupation and their probable chance of success.

Building construction trades in the metropolitan, area are looking forward more hopefully to a steadily increasing trend in structural activity than has been the case for three years, points out the Dow Service Daily Building Reports. The increase in building is expected to be more noticeable in the residential field than in commercial construction.

There must be live food if one is to have bass, or any species of fish for that matter. Many sportsmen fail to remember this vital truth. They set forth on a fishing expedition to some place they have known as a great spot and when they get there they are greatly disappointed over their lack of success.
CHICAGO, July 9 -- An unusual situation exists in the corn market. The crop is one to three weeks late, but has made fair growth the last few weeks because of high temperatures.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 9 -- President Roosevelt's plea for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, coming as it did ten days before the voters of Alabama cast their ballots on this issue, was acclaimed by repeal leaders in Birmingham, Montgomery and other points in the State.

Poor Mark Twain. MARK TWAIN'S reputation has just been subjected to serious damage in the eyes of at least one school of literary appreciation. ALBERT BIGELOW PAINE explicitly denies the story that a large mass of Twain manuscripts has remained unpublished because subject and manner are too broad even for the emancipated taste of the day.

PARIS, July 9 -- A large part of French opinion and the French press continues to regret continuation of the London Economic Conference. Budget Minister Lamoureux, speaking today at Moulins, referred to the conference as if it had been adjourned.

Prices for all commodities traded on local exchanges moved higher last week, in sympathy with the outside markets and encouraged by weakness in the dollar in foreign exchange. Trading was heavy in most cases.

NEWARK, N.J., July 9 -- Amassing a total of 30 points, the Yonkers Canoe Club upset all predictions by defeating the Knickerbocker Canoe Club of New York, defending champion, for team honors in the second annual New Jersey State canoeing championships on Weequahic Park Lake today.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $3,307,056,600. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 9. -- Gregory S. Mangin of Newark, holder of the national indoor tennis crown, captured his first major outdoor tennis championship of the 1933 campaign by defeating Herbert L. Bowman, veteran New Yorker, in the final round of the forty-first annual New Jersey State men's singles tennis championship today at the Montclair Athletic Club.

The nine-ton British cutter Enterprise, owned and navigated by Peter Barber with a one-man crew, Waldemar Brackel, an Estonian, which started on May 18 from Gambia, West Africa, arrived last night at Sandy Hook and anchored off Atlantic Highlands Light.

Transatlantic travel in the last four weeks has shown its first important advance in two years, according to executives of the principal ship lines. After an unusually light Winter, early Spring bookings lagged, but during the latter part of June and so far this month hundreds of persons have visited the offices of the ship lines asking for immediate passage.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 9. -- With two doubles matches finished and a third standing at 5 -- all in the third set, a deluge of rain drove the players from the court today in the final session of the quadrennial match for the Prince of Wales Cup between the Oxford-Cambridge teams and the Rockaway Hunting Club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is clearly evident to those who follow the unraveling of the National Industrial Recovery Administration's plan, that a troublesome snag will be struck in its attempts to establish a uniform code for minimum wages in the various industries.

Prices for all commodities traded on local exchanges moved higher last week, in sympathy with the outside markets and encouraged by weakness in the dollar in foreign exchange. Trading was heavy in most cases.

To the visitor in London the university that bears the name of the city consists of colleges and schools scattered about the metropolis and in a sense fugitive. The University of London was founded in 1836, and admitted women to all degrees in 1878. About 8,000 students are on the rolls, but more than 20,000 "external students" present themselves for examination only.

MANCHESTER, England, July 9 (AP) -- Lancashire, one of the greatest cotton-spinning districts in the world, is viewing the rise in price of the great American staple with its traditional conservatism. Lancashire is not stocking up with cotton at these prices, but not necessarily because of a belief that the rise in prices will fail to hold, according to experts.

Secretary HULL has received high praise for his resolute and tenacious efforts to keep the Economic Conference alive. But for his fervid speech and private appeals it would apparently have hurried on to adjournment. On Saturday Mr. HULL made a public answer to the question which doubtless had been pressed upon him personally.

Openings of Fall dress lines featured activity in the wholesale markets here during the week. Buyers showed marked interest in the new offerings, in which the one-piece style with peaked shoulders is expected to be a volume-seller. Falls for Summer merchandise declined, with some orders placed, however, for fill-ins and close-outs to be included in the clearances of retailers.

NEW ORLEANS, July 9 -- Despite the interruption of the Independence Day holiday early last week, trading in cotton was rather active. Price fluctuations were moderately wide, but traders were more or less nervous and the course of values as a result was erratic.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems amazing that in this day and age the platform recently adopted by the Virginia Republican party at its convention at Lynchburg should provide for State regulation and control of liquor.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Washington Senators pushed over three runs in the first inning and staved off the advances of the Indians for nine innings today to win their third straight game from Cleveland by a 3-to-2 score.

According to the Viking Press it now appears that the publishing refuge of the German literary exiles is to be not Switzerland, but Amsterdam. Querido, Dutch publishing house, is to have a German language department and has already signed up Lion Feuchtwanger, Arnold Zweig, Joseph Roth and others.

WASHINGTON, July 9. -- Presidential intervention to speed formulation of a code on the bituminous coal industry may come by the end of the week, according to reports in coal circles, unless groups of operators now in session present copies in a few days to General Hugh S. Johnson, recovery administrator.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- Expansion in business activity in the Chicago area is continuing on a broad scale in practically all leading lines. Prices of raw and manufactured products are advancing, with wheat above the dollar level and corn above 70 cents.

CINCINNATI, July 9 (AP) -- Only four percentage points kept the Reds from sharing the National League cellar with the idle Phillies after losing a double-header to the Braves today, 3 to 2 in ten innings and 3 to 1.

MOSCOW, July 9 -- The entire front pages of the newspapers Pravda and Izvestia are devoted to decrees of the Soviet Council of Commissars and the Central Committee of the Communist party concerning railroad reorganization.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A rise in prices to the 1924-25 level need not necessarily be followed, it would seem, by a reduction in the gold content of the dollar. The monetary gold stock of the country is approximately what it was in 1924-25. At that time it was sufficient to sustain the prevailing industrial and agricultural activity at the then current prices.

All markets were in some confusion yesterday. The dollar had another setback, falling to about 69 cents in terms of the gold franc. But stocks and commodities failed to adjust themselves as they ordinarily have done to acute weakness in our currency.

Strength in foreign loans was a feature yesterday of the market in bonds on the Stock Exchange, with Dutch East Indies, French Government and municipal and British Government bonds kiting to new record highs. Domestic railroad bonds moved irregularly lower, while industrial and utility issues averaged slightly higher on the day.

The report of the receivers of the Studebaker Corporation for the first quarter of 1933, filed with the New York Stock Exchange, shows a net loss of $3,156,000 for the period, including the company's proportionate share of the first-quarter losses of the White Motor Company and the Pierce-Arrow Motor Car Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of July 9 there appears an article by Edwin L. James, in which American recognition of the U.S.S.R. is discussed. Mr. James is usually very accurate, but has been so badly misinformed in one particular as to call for a reply from me.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10. -- The man who has thrice conquered the Arctic and who is now on his way to explore parts of the Antarctic never yet beheld by man is visiting San Francisco for the first time in his life.

VATICAN CITY, July 10. -- The Pope left the city of Rome today for the first time since attaining the Papacy, driving to the pontificial villa at Castel Gandolfo, fifteen miles south of Rome, to inspect the great works performed there in the last two years to renovate it for use as a Summer residence for the Pontiffs.

There is something almost startling in the news that today at Chicago "Republican strategists," directed by their national chairman, will hold their fourth regional meeting to formulate plans to win control of Congress in the elections of 1934. The party's crushing defeat last Fall seems so near, the next balloting so distant.
VANCOUVER, July 10 (AP). -- Bobby Reith, slender 18-year-old son of a Winnipeg professional, paced a field of 107 in the 36-hole qualifying round of the Canadian amateur golf championship today.
PITTSBURGH, July 10 (AP) -- Freddy Lindstrom's bat, silent for weeks, boomed into action today to give the Pirates a ninth-inning 3 to 2 triumph over the Phillies.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- The bullish crop reports that the grain trade has had the last two weeks were confirmed today by the monthly report of the United States Department of Agriculture announcing its estimate of about 496,000,000 bushels as of July 1.

Childhood's pleasantest dream, wishing for a toy and getting it, will come true tomorrow afternoon for hundreds of New York City's under-privileged boys and girls with the opening of the first "Toyery," which will lend constructive play-things, at the New York University Community Centre, 244 Spring Street.

Plans have been announced by the United States Polo Association for the first of the season's national championships, the junior, which is to be played on Long Island this year and opens Sunday at the Sands Point Club in Port Washington.
Leases of several penthouses and large suites were included in the list of apartment rentals reported yesterdey. A large number of contracts for suites on Park Avenue was signed. The list follows:

Dr. Katharine Wanda Arends, who gave up medicine last year after practicing for twenty-five years, is convinced that one is never too old to learn. So, at the age of 72, she has enrolled in Mrs. Helen Johnson's class in short-story writing at Hunter College.

DETROIT, July 10. -- Donald N. Sweeney, former president of the First National Bank, testifying before Judge Keidan in the bank inquiry today maintained that there is no justification for the failure of the Federal Government to permit the First National Bank to reopen in view of what it has done for other banks.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Startling reductions in the 1933 production of field crops, with the smallest supply of wheat in forty years and the smallest crop of oats ever recorded in the United States, were predicted by the Department of Agriculture today in its first crop report this year.
NORTH HAVEN, Me., July 10 (AP). -- Fogs and minor damage to their powerful monoplane delayed Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh today on their flight northward to Greenland.

During the last few months an editorial committee, appointed by the League for industrial Democracy, has been at work culling recently published books on social reconstruction. It seeks a representative list of approximately a hundred which might be recommended to public libraries, colleges and individuals as conducive to thought on current problems.

LONDON, July 10. -- Six members of the British Wightman Cup team, among them Miss Dorothy Round, who gave Mrs. Helen Wills Moody a sensational battle before bowing in the final round at Wimbledon Saturday, were named today to compete in the annual competition with the American team at Forest Hills, L.I., Aug. 4 and 5.
Several dwellings in Hudson and Bergen Counties of New Jersey were sold yesterday.

Prices of commodities moved irregularly in yesterday's trading on local stock markets. Sugar, coffee, copper, silk and wool tops closed with gains on the day, while the others were somewhat lower. Trading was moderately active. Several new high levels were reached in the cash markets.

MEXICO, D.F., July 10. -- The first North and Central American Regional Radio Conference opened here today for the discussion of the allocation of radio frequencies and broadcasting channels and other problems. It is believed the sessions may continue as long as two months.

Laura Adams Armer, whose first book, "Waterless' Mountains," received the Newbery Medal as "the most distinguished contribution to American literature for children 1931," is on her way to Arizona and the Navaho country again, now that her new book, "Dark Circle of Branches," is off the press.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- States ignoring the President's dictum that State and local units must bear a reasonable share of the unemployment relief burden are due to receive a "rude shock," Harry L. Hopkins, emergency relief administrator, said today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It makes one feel mighty futile to realize how impossible it is for an individual to complain or defend, criticize or praise any one or anything in this City of New York and its parent State of New York.

All Police Chiefs in the State were asked yesterday by Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the New York State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, to report promptly to the board all arrests for violations of the Beer Control Law and the disposition of such cases.

ALBANY, July 10. -- Peter G. Ten Eyck, president of the New York State Waterways Association and chairman of the Albany District Port Commission, declared today that Senators Norris and Bone were being used as catspaws by "the St. Lawrence advocates to promote a scheme which the interests are delicate about supporting openly."

Those who expected the Chancellor of the Exchequer to make a clear statement of British policy in the House of Commons yesterday forgot two things. One of them is the demonstrated ability of Mr. NEVILLE CHAM-BERLAIN to utter fair-sounding words which conceal thought.

The Mile of the Week. The Cantabs and the Oxonians, with certain familiar figures (and feet) among them, gave the Harvard-Yale combination something of a drubbing on the track last week and will try to do even better against the Princeton-Cornell combination in Tiger-town this coming Saturday.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 10. -- International cooperation through the League of Nations was urged in addresses delivered today before the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

ALTON, Ill., July 10. -- August Luer, 78 years old, wealthy banker and retired head of the Luer Packing Company, was kidnapped tonight at his home and carried out of Alton in an automobile in which rode three men and a woman.

Condition and indicated yield or corn, as estimated yesterday by the government in its report on that crop for the season of 1933, compare as follows with the estimates of July 1, 1932, and July 1. 1931:

A Police Department investigation was ordered yesterday afternoon into the circumstances surrounding the shooting earlier in the day of Miss Fannie Privulick, 19 years old, of 699 Lexington Avenue, Broooklyn. The young woman was sitting in a parked automobile with Patrolman John H. Roop of the Vanderveer Park station, Brooklyn, when she received a bullet wound in the abdomen.

PARIS, July 10. -- Playing plafond bridge for the first time, an American team captained by Ely Culbertson closed the play this evening with a small lead of thirty-six points over France's best four players.

Mayor O'Brien telephoned from Lake George to City Hall yesterday afternoon and authorized the statement that he was conferring with Governor Lehman. Controller Charles W. Berry and Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial were with him.

While the larger bakeries corporations announced yesterday that an immediate increase in the price of bread was inevitable, none had raised their prices by the close of the day. Meanwhile smaller bakeries started the bread price rise with an increase of 1 cent a loaf.

A content between the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway's management and large holders of its securities in respect to the company's reorganization was disclosed yesterday in the announcement that insurance companies, savings banks, security dealers and other interests had formed five committees to protect bondholders in the litigation.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 10. -- Dr. Martin Burke of 147 Lexington Avenue, New York City, for fifty-seven years a practicing physician, died suddenly of heart disease at his Summer home, Oswegatchie, in Waterford, near here, early this morning. He was 77 years old.

Supreme Court Justice Lydon, who heard the suit of Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, against large stockholders of the Bank of United States for a $25 assessment on each share of stock, handed down a final decision yesterday.

LONDON, July 10. -- Raising of the wholesale prices of commodities is a "primary objective of British policy," Neville Chamberlain, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today, in explaining the government's views concerning the World Economic Conference.

First Round. After pounding the body in a clinch, Jeby drove a right uppercut to the face, and Terry hooked a left to the face. Jeby drove a right to the face. Terry hooked to the body in a clinch twice. Terry missed a right uppercut, but hooked a left to the jaw and then drove a right and a left to the body.
WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Bread-price profiteering will be prosecuted with vigor by the Department of Justice, Attorney General Cummings said today.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Rezin Davis of 277 Park Avenue will sail on Thursday to pass the remainder of the Summer in Europe.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday..1 1/2 per cent for the best names Friday.....1 1/2 per cent for the best names The quotations are for three-four months paper.

The Chesapeake Corporation, a unit in the Van Sweringen railroad holding company chain, was reported yesterday to have sold slightly more than 200,000 shares of Chesapeake Ohio Railway common stock and applied the proceeds either to the repayment of bank loans or to the purchase of Alleghany Corporation preferred stock.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., July 10. -- By clipping two strokes off par on the last nine holes, Frank Frampton, amateur, from the Hillcrest Club, and Matty Nardozza of St. Albans won the honors in the amateur-pro one-day best ball event held today at the Valley Stream Country Club under the auspices of the Long Island Golf Association.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Promising swift action on the administration plan to put millions of unemployed to work, and assuring the country that "its funds will not be dissipated on a first-come, first-served basis," Secretary Ickes today assumed control over the expenditure of $3,300,000,000 voted by Congress for a public works program.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., July 10. Additional golfing honors went to the Hicks family today. Making their debut in the sister-and-brother championship, sponsored by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, Miss Helen Hicks, Long Island and women's metropolitan champion, and her brother, Jarvis, captured the tourney after a play-off.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The Federal Home Loan Bank Board is making every effort to expedite the setting up of State organizations so that home owners may have immediate benefit of the new law providing more than $2,000,000,000 for the relief of mortgaged dwellings.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 10. -- Bill Bonthron of Princeton, the middle-distance ace whose foot racing possibilities have never been tried to the full, will start in the half-mile and the mile for the Princeton-Cornell team against the Oxford-Cambridge combination in Palmer Stadium on Saturday.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- Federal inspected slaughtering of hogs in June was the largest on record for that month, aggregating 4,626,285 hogs, against 3,319,863 a year before. For the first six months of this year slaughtering aggregated 24,708,177 hogs, compared with 24,255,075 a year ago.
BERLIN, July 10 (AP). -- The Reichsbank statement as of July 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

After being removed from fourteen large packing cases the continent of Africa was laid out for reassembling yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History. The museum's preparation department was excited about the shipment; it was all that was needed to make the stuffed rhinos and hippopotami feel at home in the new Akeley African Hall.

LATONIA Ky., July 10 (AP). -- Young Brothers' consistent 2-year-old filly Penncote scored her second victory of the meeting in the Green Castle Purse, an allowance affair for juveniles, which featured today's program at Latonia.

Visitors to the Montauk Yacht Club yesterday viewed one of the finest specimens of swordfish ever taken in local waters, a 393-pounder. The fish was landed on Sunday between fifteen and twenty miles off Montauk Point by Charles Lehmann of this city, a veteran big-game angler.

LONDON, July 10. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, tried to assure the House of Commons in the first important debate on the World Economic Conference today that the present violent depreciation of the dollar probably would reverse itself by Autumn.

LONDON, July 10. -- The French delegation expects the economic conference will continue another ten days or two weeks and then adjourn to the end of October in the hope that by that time the United States will have decided what it is going to do with the dollar and be ready to discuss stabilization.

LONDON, July 10. -- Continuing its fall amid active speculative trading here, the dollar dropped today to 4.84 1/2 to the pound -- within 2 cents of the old parity of the pound. Later, The London Times reports, there was a commercial demand for dollar's, and New York also sent in buying orders for them, so the rate fell back, closing at 4.79 1/4.
U.S. Dept. of Agriculture. Meal trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:

LONDON, July 10. -- The outcome of today's highly technical and somewhat involved proceedings in the World Economic Conference is that the conference is slowly forging ahead toward resuming the discussions for which it assembled here.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 10. -- The discharge of Frank W. Darling, director of Playland, the $10,000,000 amusement park of the Westchester County Park Commission at Rye, was recommended today in a report filed with the Board of Supervisors.

ALBANY, July 10. -- Governor Lehman conferred today with Mayor John P. O'Brien, Controller Charles W. Berry and Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial on the financial situation of New York City and the immediate need of action to enable the city to continue unemployment relief on an adequate scale.

International conferences are supposed to be on a far higher plane than American political conventions. But the more they are observed, the closer is their similarity. Most of the delegates to both types of assemblage mill about without any knowledge of what is really going on.

BERLIN, July 10. -- The first internal negotiations between the Reichsbank and the committee of Germany's creditors regarding utilization of the blocked marks retained by the Reichsbank under Germany's partial transfer moratorium have ended without authority to conclude agreements.

Miss Margaret Bondfield, former Minister of Labor in the Ramsay MacDonald Ministry, and now Chief Woman Officer of the National Union of General and Municipal Workers, arrived yesterday on the White Star liner Georgic. She has come to attend the International Conference of the National Council of Women next week in Chicago.
The O'Connell brothers have been prominent figures in Democratic State politics for nearly a decade through their control of the Albany machine.

Nearly 10,000 workers on the emergency payrolls of the city remained unpaid yesterday after waiting for a week for the money due them. At the same time the offices of the respective borough presidents received official notification from the Emergency Work Commission of the pay cuts ordered for the 75,000 emergency workers by the Board of Estimate.

LONDON, July 10. -- While the Economic Conference as a whole was wrangling today over the question of whether it should continue and, if so, on what basis, definite progress was being made or recorded on two important subjects, wheat and silver.
WASHINGTON, July 10. -- President Roosevelt ordered a study today of means of putting the public debt on a long-time basis at a reduced cost.

Norman H. Davis, United States Ambassador at Large and Mrs. Davis are sailing tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Others leaving on the ship for the Channel ports are J.H. Van Royen, Minister of the Netherlands to the United States, accompanied by Mrs. Van Royen, and Baron Hans Joachim von Wackerbarth, accompanied by the Baroness and their son Harry.

Robert P. Braddicks, a Negro, who has held almost every job from Pullman porter to John Barrymore's valet, became the manager yesterday of the first branch established by a national bank in New York City since the bank holiday last March.

The fall of the dollar brought it yesterday to another low record at 31.2 per cent discount in terms of gold. At this level the depreciation of the dollar almost equaled the previous decline of sterling, and the pound advanced to $4.84 1/2, or barely more than 2 cents from its dollar parity of $4.8665.

The buying movement which had been under way on the Cotton Exchange for several months and was temporarily interrupted last week by the approaching government acreage report was resumed aggressively yesterday. Prices rose violently 1/2 cent to new high records for the year and the highest since April, 1931.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The business of the Chrystie-Forsyth Street development must be kept in the limelight. A peculiar situation has arisen because of the recent approval of a plan for the development that offers no solution of the slum problem. It is an occasion for immediate action.

A group of small retail ice cream dealers began suit yesterday to test the constitutionality of a State law whereby they can be prosecuted for illegal use of refrigerators furnished them by the large chain wholesalers. The charge that employes of large dairy chains are being deputized as inspectors for State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

LONDON, July 10. -- The treatment of twenty-five persons suffering from inoperable forms of cancer by a new serum process under the direction of Dr. Thomas Lumsden of the cancer research laboratory at the London Hospital has produced results justifying further intensive investigation, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- An offer to American industry to accept a blanket minimum wage and maximum hours-of-work schedule so as to return several million persons to normal employment immediately was virtually agreed upon by the Industrial Recovery Administration tonight.

Mr. UNTERMYER is willing to try again to bring about subway unification, but his letter to the Board of Estimate plainly states that the city must first pay its debts and balance its budget. There will be no possibility of finding the money to bring about subway unification, whether by recapture or purchase, until the municipality gets its head above the financial deep waters.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP). -- An attempt to recover $37,308,646 from the personal fortunes of the men who piloted the Corporation Securities Company into high finance was begun today.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Decreases in department store sales of v 4 per cent in June and of 15 per cent for the first six months of 1933, as compared with the corresponding periods of 1932, were reported by the Federal Reserve Board today. The computation is based on dollar values.

The charge that the Tammany administration had quickly filled exempt positions with political appointees at the expense of civil service workers meriting salary increases was made yesterday by H. Elliott Kaplan. Mr. Kaplan is secretary of the Civil Service Reform Association.

The Realty Associates Securities Corporation of 162 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, filed a petition in bankruptcy in Federal court there yesterday. The petition said the assets of the company were approximately $10,000,000 and the liabilities $12,500,000.
ALBANY, July 10. -- The kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr. is the sixth that has taken place in Albany and vicinity in thirty-seven years.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The plight of five American citizens, one of them a woman, who have been held without bail since June 4 for trial by court-martial on charges of assaulting a member of the civil guard at Palma, on the Island of Majorca, came to light here today.

CHICAGO, July 10. -- Uniform marriage laws caused a lively discussion before the legal sorority section of the biennial convention of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women, which opened here today. There was no approval of the argument of Judge Camille Kelley of Memphis, Tenn.
Federal Judge John M. Woolsey barred the Concord Casualty and Surety Company yesterday from writing bonds in United States District Court for three years.

Despite a skeletonized force, the local prohibition administrator's office is still raiding small and medium-sized speakeasies. A general feeling of immunity, following drastic curtailment of Federal forces recently, was dissipated yesterday after a raid upon the Biarritz, an exclusive restaurant, at 38 East Fifty-second Street.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 10. -- Marco Hecht of New York, metropolitan junior champion, and Henry R. Guild, president of the Longwood Cricket Club, accounted for the elimination of two seeded players as the forty-first annual competition for the Longwood Bowl opened today at the Longwood Cricket Club.
Improved asset values and reduced or completely eliminated unrealized loss accounts are shown in the semi-annual reports of the Tri-Continental Corporation and its associate investment trusts.
PHILADELPHIA, July 10 (AP). -- Two well-pitched games -- one by Bob Grove and the other by Milton Gaston -- gave the Athletics and the White Sox an even break in today's double-header.

Nikola Tesla, dean of American inventors, with a hundred triumphs in electrical engineering behind him, was 77 years old yesterday. In an interview at the Hotel Governor Clinton, where he lives, he said he was in better health and more alert mentally than ever before in his life.
LONDON, July 10. -- Senator Pittman announced this morning that he expected his committee on silver to report favorably this week on the American resolution for rehabilitation of the white metal.

NEWARK, N.J., July 10. -- Plodding Ben Jeby of New York's east side held his world's middleweight championship as recognized by New York State against the savage bid of Young Terry of Trenton before 12,000 fans at Dreamland Park tonight.

BERLIN, July 10. -- The Boerse opened today with an effort to mark up prices, but lack of public support, together with Swiss sales, soon reversed the trend and the close was somewhat below Friday's levels.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 10. -- Thirty-five persons were made homeless here today by the destruction of eleven homes in flames that spread in a stiff breeze from a lumber-yard fire. Three women, one an invalid, were rescued from their burning dwellings.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 10 (AP). -- Sheriff Blake limited the league-leading Bears to one hit today and Newark was vanquished, 6 to 1. Only four of the visitors reached first base, Hargreaves on a single in the sixth, the same player on an error by Toporcer in the ninth and Selkirk and Neun on walks in the same frame.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 10. -- Headed by Frank Shields of New York, fifth in the national ranking, and Frankie Parker of Milwaukee, recent winner of the national clay court crown, sixty players were drawn today for the annual North Jersey Coast Tennis championship starting tomorrow at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 10. -- Theodore Salisbury Woolsey Jr., forestry expert, died in his home here today from a self-inflicted pistol wound. Worry over family illness was the only apparent motive, said the medical examiner, Marvin M. Scarbrough.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP). -- Secretary Dern of the War Department today modified regulations governing opening of draw bridges across Newark Bay and the Passaic and Hackensack Rivers, and their navigable tributaries, with a view to reducing the number of openings.

The fall of the dollar has taken from the United States the distinction of having the largest bank in the world and restored that financial honor to Great Britain. The report of Barclays Bank, Ltd., of London, Britain's third largest bank, as of June 30, which has just been cabled here, shows deposits converted into dollars at the current rate of exchange of $1,821,098,750 and total resources of $1,971,951,686.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is scarcely surprising that in the editorial "A Confusing Statement" you charge president Roosevelt with inconsistency, obscureness and opportunism in his message to the World Economic Conference. Do you not think that it might be possible that your charges may arise from fixed and preconceived notions, rather than from the President's message?

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Recovery by the railroads of traffic lost to motor trucks and other competing transportation agencies will be one of the principal aims of the government under the organization built up by Joseph B. Eastman, coordinator of transportation.

Four persons whose names appeared on affidavits submitted in Federal court by Assemblyman David Paris in support of a motion for a new trial for his brother, Sidney Paris, convicted of mail fraud, testified yesterday that the signatures were forgeries.

The process of untangling the affairs of Ivar Kreuger, who shot himself in March, 1932, reached a stage here yesterday where the claims of his foreign companies against the American assets of his bankrupt International Match Corporation were reduced by a total of $559,000,000.

BOSTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Browns put on an eight-run rally in the second inning today to beat the Red Sox, 9 to 5, in the final game of their four-game series. The visitors took three of the four games.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Discovery of a series of caves under that part of the Tennessee Valley which would be flooded by the government's proposed Cove Creek dam project is causing concern to the Tennessee Valley Authority officials.

TOKYO, Tuesday, July 11. -- Plans for a naval building program designed to bring Japan up to the maximum permitted under the London treaty have been completed by the naval general staff and are expected to be approved finally substantially in their present form.

A cut of 40 per cent in the salaries of about 3,500 employes of Jersey City was ordered yesterday at a special meeting of the City Commissioners. A similar reduction affecting about 2,200 employes of Hudson County was voted at a meeting of the County Board of Freeholders.

ABOARD THE ILE DE FRANCE, July 10. -- Drastic budget retrenchment, the re-establishment of city credit and the unification of rapid transit lines are likely to be the chief issues of the coming mayoralty election in New York, Samuel Untermyer declared in an interview today.

ALBANY, July 10. -- John J. O'Connell Jr., 24 years old, son of John J. (Solly) O'Connell and nephew of Edward J. and Daniel P. O'Connell, bosses of the Albany County Democratic machine, has been kidnapped and held since early Friday morning for $250,000 ransom under threat of death.

Wall Street assumed that the lazy response of the stock market yesterday to the further depreciation of the dollar was due to a belief that the administration was less interested in the movement of share prices than in the status of commodities.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y, July 10. -- Statements that Jews are not being cruelly treated in Germany were termed "an insult to the intelligence" by James G. McDonald, chairman of the Foreign Policy Association, New York, in an address here today.

Joseph Toblinsky, who perfected the art of horse poisoning in an east side and Brownsville extortion racket thirty years ago, was arrested yesterday with his son Henry on a charge of grand larceny. It was his twenty-second arrest.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 10. -- With an 82 for the eighteen holes, Miss Jane Broadwell of Longmeadow, Mass., won the qualifying medal in the fifteenth annual women's invitation golf tournament for the Griswold Trophy at the Shenecossett County Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- A triple from the bat of Earl Averill sent Willie Kamm across the plate in the twelfth inning of a pitchers' battle today between the first-place Washington Senators and the Cleveland Indians, and the visitors scored a 3-to-2 victory.

Instead of closing its engagement at the Avon Theatre on Saturday night, as previously announced, "Biography" will continue at that house for at least another week. Ruth Weston will have the Ina Claire role and another player will succeed Jay Fassett.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 10. -- Illinois formally ratified repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment today, becoming the tenth State to do so when its convention acted a few hours ahead of Iowa, which followed as the eleventh State by a vote of its repeal convention at Des Moines.

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation increased 176,956 tons in June, the largest upturn for any month since January, 1931, it was announced yesterday. It was the third consecutive monthly gain in the corporation's backlog.

Both the State Housing Board and the Federal authorities will check closely on the plans of Sloan Robertson, architects, for building model housing in the Chrystie-Forsyth Street area, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Society of Certified Public Accountants and Auditors, Inc., has adopted a code of fair practice. It provides for a 35-hour week, with exceptions for emergency or for Federal or State work, and minimum weekly compensation of $200 for principals arid $100 for supervising seniors.

VIENNA, July 10. -- The Allgemeine Zeitung tonight prints a letter alleged to have been sent by the Nazi leader, Count Reventlow, to Adolf Hitler, demanding the latter's intervention to halt the "brutalities" of Nazi storm detachments. Count Reventlow is quoted as saying:
PRAGUE, July 10. -- Floods have laid waste a large area in Ruthenia, in the eastern part of Czechoslovakia, and in Slovakia. About 3,000 persons have been rendered homeless.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 10. -- Mrs. Garrow T. Geer gave a tea this afternoon at Red Brook, her place in Noyack Road, for Miss Elizabeth S. Suydam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Lispenard Suydam of Manowtasquott, Bay Port, who is visiting with her.

O.E. Wee and J.J. Leventhal, whom Summer deters not nor life dismays, last evening entered another revival upon their season's roster. It was "John Ferguson," and it was, of course, the work of none other than St. John Ervine of London.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP). -- Pomponius and his stablemate, Pomposity, racing for W.R. Coe of New York, ran one-two in the Rio Grande Purse at one mile, the feature at Arlington today.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on July 5 shows increases for the week of $21,000,000 in loans and investments and $86,000,000 in time deposits and decreases of $99,000,000 in net demand deposits and $96,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.

BERLIN, July 10. -- Following the conclusion of the Reich condordat with the Vatican, Chancellor Hitler seems determined to unify the Protestant Church in Germany through a new constitution imposed upon the church.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., July 10. -- Local governments must bear their share of the burden of unemployment relief and not continue to rely so heavily on Federal and State aid, Governor Lehman declared in an address at the annual encampment of the State Department of the United Spanish War Veterans in the armory today.

Mike Crisuola, 16 years old, of 370 Madison Street, plunged overboard at the foot of Jackson Street and East River at 10 o'clock yesterday morning and paddled idly toward midstream. Joe, his 10-year-old brother, watched him from the dock and envied him.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 10. -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors considered today a public works program with Federal aid which would cost about $43,900,000. The board also appropriated $64,000 with which to draw plans for the immediate expenditure of $2,217,000 granted to the county by the State as its share of Federal funds already available.

LONDON, July 10. -- As matters stand tonight at the World Economic Conference two economic subcommittees have reported in favor of continuing, two others reported a difference of opinion, one monetary subcommittee reported a majority vote for continuing to discuss every subject on the agenda and another has "taken note of" but not finally agreed on a motion to proceed with discussion of the gold standard and the stabilization of silvar.

The Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company applied in the Supreme Court yesterday for an order to permit it to regain possession of its property, now held by the State Superintendent of Insurance in rehabilitation proceedings, and to resume business, on the ground that it is solvent to the extent of $10,000,000.

Firmness in money rates, which set in at the close of last week, was carried into the current period. Outside money on call loans continued at 1 per cent, matching the official quotation, but Federal funds eased to 1/2 from 3/4@1 per cent. Time money was steady, turnover being negligible, however.
LONDON, July 10. -- The United States delegation decided today to submit to the economic conference a resolution advocating an international policy of a shorter work week and higher wages.

WASHINGTON, July 10. -- President Roosevelt today assured Senator Copeland, chairman of a subcommittee of the Senate Investigating racketeering, that the entire facilities of the Federal Government would be placed at his disposal. These assurances were conveyed to the New York Senator by Louis M. Howe, secretary to the President, with whom he conferred at the request of the President.
Immigration inspectors reported yesterday that examination of passengers had touched a low mark of efficiency, because of the depletion of the staff here.

PATERSON, N.J., July 10. -- Every evening just before he is put to bed in his crib, Charles Normand Jr., who will be two years old on July 28, smokes one of his father's cigars. Occasionally he smokes a cigar after dinner and on special occasions he is allowed an extra one during the day.
The city's reasons for not stopping the dumping of garbage at sea, as ordered by the Supreme Court of the United States, were outlined yesterday at a hearing before Special Master Edward K. Campbell.

Hitler on Cromwell. HITLER'S views on the subject of OLIVER CROMWELL need clarification. Mrs. McCORMICK asked HITLER who was his favorite character in history, CAESAR, NAPOLEON or FREDERICK the Great, and he said he admired CROMWELL most.

Under the handling of the capable apprentice, Howard Cruz, who only recently came off a Virginia farm to thrill metropolitan racegoers, the B.B. Stable's The Heathen yesterday won the featured Prospect Purse at Empire City. The triumph was the fourth in two days for the establishment.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP). -- The National Manufacturers Association marshaled an emergency executive meeting today at which General Johnson, administrator of the act, gave the industrialists a direct talk on the administration's insistence that industries must come under the National Industrial Recovery Act and must do so quickly.

Leases in the garment and clothing centres of the midtown west side featured the commercial space contracts announced by brokers yesterday. Many of the leases were for large space, several of them amounting to 10,000 square feet or more, and a number of others calling for entire floors.
WASHINGTON, July 10. -- Prosecution of gold hoarders appeared more imminent today as Attorney General Cummings announced that 213 persons holding $1,208,526 in gold had refused to surrender it.
TORONTO, July 10 (AP). -- Toronto put on a drive for five runs in the eighth inning and defeated Jersey City, 6 to 5, for its seventh consecutive victory today.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 11. -- The story of how James J. Mattern, American round-the-world flier, was lost for fifteen days in the wilds of Northern Siberia before being rescued was related today in a special dispatch to the newspaper Izvestia from its correspondent at Khabarovsk.

WASHINGTON, July 11. -- Carrying out the promise of Secretary Ickes for quick Federal aid to put men to work, the Cabinet Advisory Board of the Public Works Administration approved and sent to the White House today a list of strictly Federal projects involving about $200,000,000.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 11 -- The Most Rev. Jonn Aloysius Duffy of Newark became fourth Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Syracuse this morning. The impressive induction services, attended by dignitaries of church and State, were held at the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception.

HELSINGFORS, July 11 -- Hundreds of persons are homeless as a result of forest fires raging in many parts of Finland, which have in some places destroyed whole villages. The country is suffering from the worst heat wave and drought in more than a century.

BARCELONA, July 11 -- United States Consul General Claude I. Dawson reported to his office here tonight that he was still unable to effect the release of five Americans from the military prison at Palma on the Island of Majorca. Mr. Dawson was ordered to Palma Saturday by Ambassador Claude G. Bowers, whose repeated appeals in behalf of the American prisoners to the Ministerial authorities in Madrid have met with no greater success so far.

For saving a child from the distress of inoculation against rabies, it will cost Miss Eleanor Witt, 20 years old, of 785 Madison Avenue, a trip to Yorkville court this morning and probably a fine of $2.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 11 -- Members of the Oxford-Cambridge track team and of the Nassau contingent of the Princeton-Cornell team held an intensive practice in Palmer Stadium this afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In my recent letter, calling attention to the hundredth anniversary of the granting of the franchise to "the common white man" in New York City in 1834, I made the statement: "In 1790 only 1,303 males were allowed to vote for Governor."

ATLANTA, July 11 (AP) -- Rain today forced a postponement of third-round matches in the Southern tennis singles championships, but not until Bryan Grant, seeded No. 1, and Jack Simpson of Atlanta had entered the fourth round.

Verdi Against Depression. Grand opera at popular prices packing the big Hippodrome is one of the sensations of the Summer. An outdoor performance of "Aida" in Fairmount Park, Philadelphia, draws an audience of nearly 10,000 for a "gross" of $5,000.

No increase in bread prices was announced yesterday by any of the larger bakeries in New York City. These concerns are prepared to increase their prices soon to absorb the $1.38 a barrel processing tax and rise in cost of materials.

ALBANY, July 11 -- Judicial recognition of the Soviet Russian Government was taken by the Court of Appeals today in upholding title to $30,000,000 of oil land grants, obtained from the Soviet by the Vacuum Oil Company and the Standard Oil Companies.

The National Association of Blouse Manufacturers, Inc., filed its code under the National Industrial Recovery Act yesterday at the headquarters of Professor Earl Dean Howard, deputy administrator, at the Hotel New Yorker.

Captain Gus Rau of Sheepshead Bay, one of the old-time boat captains in this sector, reports that the water again is beginning to warm up along the Atlantic Coast, especially from the Rockaways to Atlantic City. This means, he says, that salt-water fishing is going to improve rapidly.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 11 -- An almost windless calm, which made it impossible to lift the heavy seaplanes from the surface of the water, prevented General Italo Balbo and his Italian fliers taking off this morning for Cartwright, Labrador, on their flight to Chicago.

A man and his wife repeatedly contradicted their grand jury testimony yesterday when they were called upon to testify in Bronx Special Sessions against two men whom they had accused of racketeering in Fulton Fish Market. The two defendants were acquitted.

The prediction by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, that the dollar would rise again in the Autumn was discounted by the foreign exchange market yesterday. The dollar bounded up as rapidly as it had fallen previously.

The University of Virginia receives a bequest of $60,000, and the Baylor School of Chattanooga, Tenn., $3,000 in the will of Edward Dean Richmond, New York investment banker, who died in Chattanooga on July 4, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogates' Court.

American shipyards are building only 3,083 tons of merchant ships, or less than one-half of 1 per cent of the total merchant tonnage under construction throughout the world, according to the quarterly report of Lloyd's Registry of Shipping.

Violent advances in grain prices occurred yesterday following the overnight publication of the government's crop estimate as of July 1. Otherwise, the markets were somewhat hesitant. Stocks showed a slight loss in their average prices, bonds were irregular and cotton declined several points.

Cass Canfield, president of the National Association of Book Publishers and of Harper Brothers, who went abroad to represent American publishers at the Congress International des Editeurs in Brussels, is not expected to return to New York until the middle of August.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 11 -- Victories by the Meadow Larks and Aknusti at the Meadow Brook Club today rounded out the semi-final brackets of the Hempstead Cups tournament. And in a third game Great Neck won the first match In the Wheatley Cups tourney from the Second Corps Area, 10 to 9.

Although prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced a few points further yesterday into new high ground, the slight improvement in dollar exchange and the predictions of possible relief in Western drought areas slackened the upward movement.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Total fees paid to the Federal Trade Commission by registrants of stocks and bonds under the Federal Securities Law have reached $7,422, representing about $74,223,000 in securities registered, the commission announced this afternoon.
BUENOS AIRES, July 11 -- Dispatches from La Paz report the death of Walter Guyhn, an American pilot in the Paraguayan Air Force, in a combat near Isla Poi in the Chaco on June 12.

LONDON, July 11 -- Drafting committees were appointed today in the economic conference to reconcile the differing viewpoints in the economic subcommissions on commercial policy, subsidies and merchant shipping, indirect protectionism and veterinary measures.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., July 11 -- The National Economy League was attacked by William Armstrong of Racine, Wis., senior Vice Commander-in-Chief of the United Spanish War Veterans at their State encampment today. Protesting against cuts in veterans' pensions, he warned police, firemen, teachers and other civil employes that their pensions also are in danger.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Tentative sugar production quotas were drawn up today by the Sugar Conference Central Committee but it was said that President Roosevelt probably will be called upon to set the allocations among the foreign and territorial sources of this country's supply.

LONDON, July 11 (AP) -- The Maharajah of Alwar, exiled for two years from his own realm, on instructions of the Viceroy of India, arrived in London today. On his last visit here he headed a delegation of Indian princes to the roundtable conference.

In a letter sent to stockholders of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation. Orlando F. Weber, president, has disclosed that the company held 187.189 shares of its own common stock and 47,309 shares of the preferred, as of June 30.

ANADYR, Siberia, July 11 -- I froze until I was brittle. I starved until I couldn't tell my stomach from my backbone. I broke my left ankle and my body shows assorted burns. But I am alive, and mighty thankful to be that way. And grateful, too, to those who have helped me, and determined to fly back to New York and complete the first solo flight around the world.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 11 (AP) -- Dick Reynolds, speedy son of the famous Single G, paced the fastest heat of the year in winning the 2:14 Class pace, tonight's feature of the Grand Circuit meet at Fort Miami Park.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- The bullish crop report issued by the government on Monday brought a wave of buying today that carried prices on all grains to new high levels for the season on the Board of Trade, with the finish at a moderate reaction from the top.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The timely editorial "International Conferences" was quite to the point and demonstrated most clearly the weakness of unorganized cooperation.
Sir Josiah Stamp, British financier and economist, approved President Roosevelt's recovery program last evening in a radio talk from London which was heard here and in Great Britain.

The Eastern railroad coordinating committee discussed legal aspects of the new railroad law yesterday at its first meeting in the board room of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, Further details of organization were completed.

BERLIN, July 11 -- The stock market developed better resistance today. Some weakness at the opening was followed by a recovery which wiped out part of the early losses. Gains of 4 per cent on the day were made by certain specialties.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Federal Land Bank System will suffer a loss of $11,000,000 a year for the next five years on outstanding loans of about $1,100,000,000 on farm mortgages as a result of the reduction of 1 per cent in the average rate of interest on new loans.
Dixie Walker and Tony Lazzeri came through with, home runs at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, and the McCarthymen defeated the Crowns, 5 to 4, in the first game of their series.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, July 12. -- The flood menace along China's two greatest river valleys, the Yellow and the Yangtse, have suddenly assumed catastrophic proportions, the government officially announced today.

YARMOUTH, N.S., July 11 (Canadian Press) -- Seamanship of two Yarmouth girls stood out tonight as Canada's lone challenge to United States supremacy in junior yacht racing. Canadian hopes of victory at the close of the first day's racing for the Prince of Wales Cup were pinned on Miss Hazel Critcher and Miss Edythe Chipman of the Acadian Yacht Club.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 11 -- Mrs. A.U. Rodney of Quaker Ridge won the low gross prize in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tourney at the Bonnie Briar Country Club today. A field of 84 started, and 56 returned cards.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 11 -- Oklahoma, bone dry since it was admitted to Statehood twenty-six years ago, voted today to have its beer, but Governor Murray called out the National Guard tonight to prevent premature celebrating in Oklahoma City.

ALBANY, July 11 -- Dr. William H. Walker, brother of former Mayor James J. Walker, will not be able to continue as medical consultant to the New York City Board of Education, the Court of Appeals determined today in affirming, without opinion, the findings of the Appellate Division.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,596,250 barrels, compared with 2,602,050 In the previous week, a decline of 5,800 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A drop of 39,650 barrels daily in Oklohoma's output and gains of 15,250 barrels in Kansas and 11,600 barrels in California were the important changes.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- On all conditions of employment except hours and wages, the conference of coal miners and operators today was in substantial agreement, and a proposed code for the industry may be completed within forty-eight hours, it was announced this evening.

The Merchants Association of New York announced yesterday that it had granted a leave of absence to William H. Chandler, manager of its traffic bureau, whose appointment as assistant to Joseph B. Eastman, Railroad Coordinator, was announced Monday in Washington.

Don Fedro, a gelded son of Spanish Prince II won the featured Amaranth Purse at Empire City yesterday, making the fourth consecutive favorite to win. The winner had little to spare at the end, as Pencader, only a head behind, closed so fast that he was in front a stride or two past the finish.
The Board of Estimate may make a formal request at its special meeting today for a session of the Legislature to provide increased revenue for the city's relief needs and other requirements.

PARIS, July 11 -- With an umbrella in place of a pilgrim's staff Arthur Henderson began today in Paris his pilgrimage through Europe on behalf of the disarmament conference over which he has been presiding for eighteen months.

Charles Hayden, chairman of the board of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway, said yesterday that the reorganization committee which the management recently appointed was working in harmony with five protective committees formed by bondholders affected by the railway's bankruptcy action.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A fair competition code for the lumber and timber manufactures industry, which had a pre-depression level of 750,000 workers, was submitted to the Industrial Recovery Administration today by a committee claiming to represent 85 per cent of the industry.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The success or failure of the government's campaign to finance the destruction of 3,000,000 bales of the cotton crop by removing 10,000,000 acres from cultivation will be decided by midnight tomorrow.
PITTSBURGH, July 11 (AP) -- Behind Tom Zachary's tight hurling the Braves today won their fourth straight game, defeating the Pirates, 5 to 3.

HALIFAX, July 11 (Canadian Press) -- Bound north over the air trails, the flying Lindberghs halted in this port tonight. Bright sunlight sparkled on the harbor and a brisk southeast wind was blowing as the black-barrelled, red-winged monoplane settled on its white pontoons and taxied to a mooring at the Royal Canadian Air Force Base at Eastern Passage.

Billy Petrolle, the "Fargo Express," and Bep Van Klaveren, the unbeaten welterweight from Holland, will clash in the feature tenrounder at the Polo Grounds tonight under the promotion of Tim Mara and the Aram A.C. A crowd of 25,000 is expected to watch a bout that may bring the winner a match with Champion Jimmy McLarnm.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 11 -- Charles M. Miller, treasurer of Westchester County, took steps today before Surrogate George A. Slater to defend himself against any possibility of civil liability in the theft of about $250,000 from the county funds.
THE World Economic Conference should have taken up the subject of finances in the realm of sport. The situation is badly muddled at the moment.

The need for legislative action to relieve the city's financial stress was brought into the hearing yesterday on the delay in building incinerators to end the dumping of garbage at sea off the New Jersey Coast. It was indicated that the incinerator construction could be expedited by an improvement in municipal finances.

Hairdressers, hat check concessionaires, soda dispensers, motion picture machine operators and candy makers are expected to provide the city with new revenue under a set of tax proposals introduced yesterday in the Board of Aldermen.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- To speed progress by the administration's recovery machinery, President Roosevelt today created a supreme council to coordinate the activities and direct the policies of national rehabilitation.

Ole W. Nielsen Kolborg, a civil engineer, bade his wife and children good-bye one bright morning last March and drove away in his automobile for a day's jaunt to Boston and Fall River. He returned yesterday four months late, arriving on the Red D liner Caracas, and Mrs. Kolborg, who met him at the pier, did not even question his alibi that he had been shanghaied.

PEARY LODGE, Greenland, July 11 -- Traveling with light sledges on the downgrade, Max Demorest and I made a rapid march on our trip back from Camp Watking and arrived at Peary Lodge last Saturday at 3:20 A.M.
LONDON, July 11 -- The bureau, or steering committee, of the World Economic Conference adopted the report of the drafting committee of the Monetary and Financial Commission today.

LONDON, July 11 -- Secretary of State Hull was highly pleased with the spirit and substance of today's economic conference compromise, by which there will be limited discussions of indebtedness and monetary measures.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 11 -- Dinner parties this evening preceded the opening of the seventh Casino Theatre season and the hoats and hostesses took their guests to the theatre later. Aa a result the members of the Summer colony were out in force for the season's theatre premiere at which "Criminal at Large" was presented by the Casino players.

CAMP WATKINS, Greenland, July 11 -- Our expedition has just established this station and named it Camp Watkins in honor of the late leader of the Pan American Airways expedition to Eastern Greenland, who was drowned last Summer.

The legend of the "utter innocuousness" of John Greenleaf Whittier, "based upon undue prominence given to some of his later poems and elaborated in academic circles and in the schoolroom, has prevented his acceptance as an important writer by our sophisticated age," Albert Mordell asserts in a new biography of the poet.

For the first time in forty years an American wheat crop short of 500,000,000 bushels is in prospect. The Government forecast published yesterday places the average condition on July 1 at 55.8 per cent of normal and the estimated yield at 496,000,000. This is far short even of domestic requirements, which have approximated 600,000,000 bushels during recent years.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 11 -- Mrs. Dorothy Campbell Hurd of Philadelphia and Miss Edith Quier of Reading, Pa., were among the sixteen survivors of the first day of match pay in the fifteenth annual women's invitation golf tournament for the Griswold Trophy at the Shenecossett Country Club today.

CHICAGO, July 11 -- Every part of the United States and several foreign countries had delegates present as the fall of the gavel marked the formal opening tonight of the biennial convention of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women.

PARIS, July 11 -- It was revealed in today's Official Journal that before the Parliament adjourned last Saturday night for the Summer holidays a bill had been rushed through which increased the existing tariff rates from 30 to 150 per cent in sixty-four categories of imports.

Divergent views on the progress of women in business and the professions were expressed yesterday by guests of the Soroptlmist Glub of New York, an organization of business and professional women, at a luncheon in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
To the Editor of The New York Times: With apologies to Mark Twain, every one talks about the wealth of the United States, but no one does anything about it.

The Manhattan and Bronx auction marts experienced one of the busiest days in their history yesterday, when auctioneers offered for bidding forty-one properties in the two boroughs. These included the Lincoln Building in East Forty-second Street, which was bought in by bondholders for $4,750,000.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 12 -- As the result of a series of raids on super-patriotic societies yesterday and today the police are holding in custody forty-nine leaders and members of these bodies. The raids were made in the belief that a plot was in progress for assassination of some of the government leaders and others, and for a Fascist coup.

LONDON, July 11 -- Another spirited discussion of the relative merits of wine-drinking and prohibition enlivened today's meetings of the economic conference's subcommission on the coordination of production and marketing.

Dictionaries usually lack the best words. The gamins of speech are homeless. Dogberrys of propriety pursue them from parish to parish. They can get no license, show no papers. They are tramps, if you like, but their health is all the better for it. Out of the editorial page of The Morning Oregonian pops a term that drips with poetry and magic.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 -- The century-old Delaware and Raritan Canal, extending forty-four miles from Bordentown on the Delaware River to tidewater on the Raritan River at New Brunswick, was offered today as a free gift to New Jersey.

Recent discussions of world currency problems have frequently featured a vague and sinister figure who, for his own selfish profit, plays with the solvency of governments and jeopardizes the safety of the savings of millions. He is the foreign exchange speculator.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

Sentiment was mixed in the listed bond market yesterday. Domestic railroad bonds moved irregularly lower and industrial and utility issues irregularly higher. French Government and municipal loans and British bonds sold off, while other leading foreign loans pushed higher.

ALBANY, July 11 -- The kidnappers of Lieutenant John J. O'Connell Jr., nephew of Daniel P. and Edward J. O'Connell, most powerful of the Democratic up-State political bosses, were provided at their own request today with a new list of proposed intermediaries.

ALBANY, July 11 -- Governor Lehman made public today the names of fifteen men and one woman whom he has asked to act as a Home and Farm Mortgage Advisory Committee, preparatory to the functioning of the Federal Home Owners Loan Corporation in New York State.
SUFFOLK, Va., July 11 (AP) -- Four men are under arrest here charged with plotting to kidnap C. C. Vaughn 3d, a wealthy young banker.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Aghast at the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr. of Albany, Attorney General Cummings, already engaged in a nation-wide war against the underworld, today ordered the use of all the facilities of the Department of Justice in the search for the abductors and their victim.

BERLIN, July 11 -- Major Paul Schmitthenner, professor at the University of Heidelberg, delivered a lecture before the division of military science of the history seminar of the University of Berlin today, in which he declared:

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Steps to enforce the packers' consent decree were taken today when the Department of Justice announced that the District of Columbia Supreme Court had named J. Bruce Kremer of Butte, Mont., to act as trustee over the stock in Libby, McNeil Libby owned by Swift Co. Mr. Kremer will begin at once to seek purchasers of the stock.

For the third successive month factories in this State showed an increase in employment and payrolls, according to the report for June made public yesterday by Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner. A survey based on data supplied by 1,585 representative factories throughout the State revealed an increase of 4 per cent in the number of jobs and a rise of 5.7 per cent in total wage payments.
Most commodities traded on local exchanges were strong yesterday in fairly active trading, with sugar and silver the features. New high levels were reached again in several of the cash staples.

BERLIN, July 11 -- By way of reinforcing his recent warning to the Governors of the Federated States Chancellor Hitler today sent an emphatic ultimatum down the line notifying his following that any attempt to sabotage the national revolution through unauthorized interference with private business or industry or clamor for a second revolution would be summarily dealt with.

Traders in stocks found it hard to compete yesterday with their fellows in the commodity markets. They did, however, manage to whip up enthusiasm at times, even if they did have to fall back upon a handful of highly volatile issues. The net result was unimportant so far as the general list was concerned.

Continuing its campaign for further and more frequent publicity with respect to investment trusts, the New York Stock Exchange has sent letters to certain of the trusts listed on its board requesting co-operation in this direction.

The fifty - three - story Lincoln Building, said to have represented an investment of about $27,000,000 when it was opened three years ago, was sold yesterday in a foreclosure auction to the first mortgage bondholders' committee on a bid of $4,750,000.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 -- Not even the presence of their employer, Charles A. Stoneham, in St. Louis sufficed to bring the Giants out of their amazing tailspin today as they opened a four-game series with the Cardinals.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 11 -- Half of the quarter-final brackets in the forty-first annual Longwood Bowl tennis tournament were filled by non-seeded players at the conclusion of the second day's play at the Longwood Cricket Club today.

ALTON, Ill., July 11 -- Sheriffs of five counties and a squad of twenty-five State police were searching the Illinois River bottoms for fifty miles between Grafton and Beardstown tonight for the kidnappers of August Luer, Alton banker and retired packer.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 11 -- Golfers from the eastern tip of Long Island who have been forced to travel miles in order to take part in events sponsored by the Metropolitan and Long Island Golf Associations finally came into their own today when the Long Island association gave them a tournament in their own backyard.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 11 -- Many of the younger members of the colony attended the third in the series of junior assemblies tonight at the clubhouse of the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club. The patronesses included Mrs. La Motte T. Cohu, Mrs. Charles Eugene Crawley and Mrs. Basil Harris.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Bertram S. Bosman have gone to New Canaan, Conn., for the remainder of the Summer.

The executive boards of the eleven local unions of the cloak and suit industry, at a meeting last night at the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street, voted to empower the officers of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union to create machinery for calling a strike in the industry which will involve from 25,00 to 30,000 workers in the metropolitan area.

Mrs. Edith S. Mayer, a government witness at the trial of Sidney Paris, who was convicted of mail fraud several months ago, testified yesterday before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey that her name had been forged upon an affidavit submitted by Assemblyman David Paris, the convict's brother, in support of a motion for a new trial.
PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (AP) -- Scoring three runs in the first inning, the Athletics went on to win 6 to 4, today in the opening contest of a four-game series with the Indians.
CHICAGO, July 11 -- The Dodgers, still in a generous mood, today furnished the sixth straight victory for the pennant-hungry Cubs by losing the opening game of their current series, 6 to 2.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 11 -- Although the seeded list remained intact, there were several surprise victories as the starting field in the annual women's invitation tennis tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club today was reduced from forty-six to sixteen players.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- Failing to find their batting punch for the second time in as many days, the Senators suffered a 9-to-3 defeat today from the White Sox, a loss which reduced their lead over the Yankees to only two games.

MILWAUKEE, July 11 -- City Controller Louis M. Kotecki this afternoon shot and wounded Deputy Controller William H. Wendt, his close associate for twenty years, In Mr. Wendt's office in the City Hall. He then turned the pistol and fired into his own head, inflicting a wound which may be fatal.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- President ROOSEVELT proclaimed today the Convention for Limiting the Manufacture and Regulating the Distribution of Narcotic Drugs.
LONDON, July 11 (Canadian Press) -- Closing scores in first-class cricket matches concluded today follow:

Mary Anderson, once noted American actress, receives a life estate Jn the American will of her husband, Antonio Fernando do Navarro, retired New York lawyer, who died at their home, Court Farm, Broadway, Worcestershire, England, on Oct. 11.

In the last year of the Hoover Administration no legislative or executive remedy for the depression could break at any point what Mr. HOOVER used to call the " vicious spiral." Many economists explained this by saying that depressions, like fevers, must run their course, and then they get well by themselves.

Evidence that the stockholders of the Bank of Europe and Trust Company approved the sale of the bank to the Manufacturers Trust Company was offered yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler. The evidence was presented in the suit by Joseph A. Broderick, Superintendent of Banks, to collect an assessment of $1,000,000 from 325 stockholders.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Continuing his warfare against increases in bread prices, Secretary Wallace today telegraphed Mayors of forty-nine cities, warning that complaints agains profiteering were being turned over to Attorney General Cummings for investigation.

ALBANY, July 11 -- New York State's milk control law is sound, the Court of Appeals ruled in effect today in affirming the conviction of Leo Nebbia, a Rochester grocer. He was accused of violating minimum price orders, issued by the Milk Control Board under the law, by giving away a loaf of bread with two quarts of milk sold.
"Biography" reaches Us 250th performance tonight at the Avon Theatre. On Monday night next Norman Stuart will replace Earle Larimore in the cast.

BERLIN, July 11 -- Chancellor Hitler scored a new victory tonight when the new constitution of the German Evangelical Church, completed last night, was unanimously adopted by the representatives of the various Protestant churches in Germany at a meeting in the Ministry of the Interior and officially proclaimed by Bishop Marahrens of Hanover, who was one of the church leaders previously ousted by Herr Hitler's church commissar.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The text of the code of fair competition for the lumber and timber products industries, as submitted to the Recovery Act Administrator, is as follows:

John D. Rockefeller Jr. has offered 265 acres of land worth about $5,000,000 atop the Palisades, running for thirteen miles from the George Washington Bridge to the New York-New Jersey State line, to the Palisades Interstate Park Commissioners for a parkway, it was announced yesterday.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 11 -- Balance of power in the Mediterranean is a problem that is beginning to disturb disarmament conferences, and one that will become acute in 1936, according to Dr. Herbert Adams Gibbons of New York.
Eight witnesses appeared before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey yesterday and related instances of Joseph W. Harriman's erratic behavior before and after the crash of the Harriman National Bank.

Robert Moses, chairman of the State Council of Parks, president of the Long Island State Park Commission and former Secretary of State, definitely withdrew yesterday as a possible candidate for the anti-Tammany nomination for Mayor. He made the announcement in the following statement:

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 11 -- Spurred on by his victory in the Rhode Island State tennis championship and bent on heading into the season's major fixtures at full steam, Frank Shields of New York started out in quest of the Spring Lake Challenge Trophy today with a decisive victory over Haines Stockton of Spring Lake.

In an opinion handed down in the Court of Appeals at Albany yesterday, Chief Justice POUND remarked that of all the powers of government, the police power is "the least limitable." That truth has often been dinned into the ears of lawmakers. Once assure them that they can bring any bit of proposed legislation under the police power of the State, and they can,do almost anything.
Sales reported in New Jersey yesterday indicated a good demand for small dwellings.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I note that THE TIMES is the patron of all adventurous travelers, so I send this strange adventure to it:

Police, clerks and idlers participated yesterday in a two-hour pursuit of Jocko, a year-old monkey, who had begun an unchaperoned tour of the city. Jocko and his mother, Mary, had arrived from Calcutta., India, on Monday, with 107 other Rhesus monkeys.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- H.H. Broach, storm centre of the electrical industry, resigned today as president of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. Ill health was given as the cause. The executive council announced the selection of Dan W. Tracy of Houston as his successor.

The International Committee of Bankers on Mexico, headed by Thomas W. Lamont of J. P. Morgan Co., said in a statement yesterday that the Mexican Government had not deposited the $5,000,000 that was to have been paid by July 1 under the agreement of Dec. 22, 1931, between the bankers and the bondholders.
