WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Acting with a suddenness startling to persons hopeful of patronage, President Roosevelt moved today to place all postmasterships in the United States under civil service rules, thus removing in large part these places from political control.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Fair competition codes were submitted here today by the electrical manufacturing and ship-building industries, and the Recovery Administration was confident that many more industries would quickly follow suit.

LONDON, July 12 -- Australia's drive back toward Davis Cup tennis heights opens tomorrow as Jack Crawford, new singles king from "down under," faces Henry W. (Bunny) Austin, and young Vivian McGrath tackles Fred Perry in the European zone final with Great Britain.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- To the "old maid in the family" was assigned today a place among American heroines. Addressing a luncheon at the convention of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women, Judge Florence E. Allen of the Ohio Supreme Court eulogized the unmarried woman worker who carried on through the depression.

NEW YORK. Miss Elise Plankington gave a luncheon yesterday at the Central Park Casino for Mr. and Mrs. William Wright Harts Jr., Miss Rosalind Kress and Carl Schuster. Miss Plankington later left for Chicago.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP). -- Doing his best running in the stretch, Abraham Bartelstein's Polydorus won the Garfield Purse at Arlington Park today, turning in a 1:36 4-5 performance for the mile.

CARTWRIGHT, Labrador, July 12 -- The first of the seaplanes of the Italian air armada appeared, tiny specks in the sky above a wooded hill beyond Cartwright late this afternoon. At 4:40 P.M. (4:10 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time), General Italo Balbo set his flagship down on the waters of the harbor.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The league-leading Senators kept their two-game advantage over the Yankees today through a return to winning ways with a 4-to-1 victory over the White Sox.

ST. JOHN'S, July 12 -- After spending the night here the Lindberghs planned to proceed to Cartwright, Labrador, where the Italian squadron of twenty-four seaplanes en route to Chicago landed late today after a l,500-mile hop from Reykjavik, Iceland.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Hugh L. Cooper has written to THE TIMES. Ipse dixit. Yet, as a member of the recently nominated Bok committee in search of truth about what was Russia, his letter is decidedly objectionable as indicating preformed conclusions. Published this morning, it prompts the thought that while an engineer may be pardoned for lack of logic, he can scarcely afford to dispense with facts.
Billy Petrolle, North Dakota's famed "Fargo Express," scored a technical knockout over Bep Van Klaveren, heretofore unbeaten Holland welterweight, in the main bout last night at the Polo Grounds.

On his arrival at Cartwright General Italo Balbo immediately sent a wireless report of his flight to the Italian State Aeronautical Department in Rome, which was received by THE NEW YORK TIMES wireless station. It told, among other things, of how General Balbo ordered his men to fly in close formation so that the combined heat from the engines would help prevent the formation of ice on the wings.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Ray Benge outpitched Guy Bush today, but the Dodgers outfumbled the Cubs by a wide margin and gave Charley Grimm's fast-moving club its seventh straight victory and second place in the league race.

LONDON, July 12 -- The German Reichsbank has agreed to make further concessions to foreign medium-term and long-term creditors, according to an official statement issued on behalf of the latter here today after a meeting of both sides.

Herbert I. Foster of Cedarhurst, L.I., a former member of the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange, died last night in the Hotel Sulgrave, 60 East Sixty-seventh Street, after an illness of seven months. He was 57 years old.

QUEBEC, July 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was viewing today the sights of the ancient capital of Canada, having arrived last night in her own automobile. She was the guest of Lieut. Gov. H.G. Carroll of Quebec and Mrs. Carroll at luncheon at Spencer Wood.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Yielding to the urge for exploration, I folded my tent in the Columbia University neighborhood, turned my back on the Hudson and transferred my domicile as near as possible to the East River without falling into this alluring stream.
ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., July 12 -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh arrived here in their plane late this afternoon after a flight of five and one-half hours from Halifax, N.S.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 12 -- The track coaches of Princeton, and Cornell compared notes today and then announced some of their decisions concerning ,the way the combined track and field team would oppose Oxford, and Cambridge here on Saturday.

BALTIMORE, July 12 -- The City of Baltimore, flagship of the Baltimore Mail Line, ran aground in the Chesapeake Bay tonight after she was in collision with the Standard Shipping Company's tanker Beacon, less than a mile off Gibson Island.

YARMOUTH, N.S., July 12 (Canadian Press) -- Junior yachtsmen, of the Eastern United States matched tacks for international : honors on Lake Milo today as Canadian competition for the Prince of Wales Trophy faded with, the defeat of Yarmouth's girl crew.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 12 -- The Mellon interests, controlled by Andrew W. Mellon of Pittsburgh, former Secretary of the Treasury and former Ambassador to Great Britain, are offering to settle for 50 cents on the dollar in payment of delinquent taxes on land in which they have an interest in this vicinity.

BERLIN, July 12 (AP) -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler tonight telegraphed President von Hindenburg at his Summer home at Neudeck that "negotiations for settlement of the church conflict ended satisfactorily today."
Fourteen Manhattan and Bronx properties were bid in by plaintiffs at auction sales yesterday. One parcel went to the defendants. The results follow:
In one of his best pitching performances of the season, Johnny Allen, Yankee right-hander, downed the St. Louis Browns, 4 to 2, at the Stadium yesterday for his seventh hurling triumph of the year.

Yesterday was July 12 to 7,000,000 New Yorkers. But to more than a score of boys and girls of the lower west side it was more like Christmas. New York University's Community Centre had opened the "Toyery," a free lending agency of constructive playthings, at 244 Spring Street.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 12 -- The seeded list held its own in the quarter-final round of the forty-first annual Longwood Bowl tennis tournament today, three of the first four seeded, players surviving.

CLEVELAND, July 12 (AP) -- Alvanley Johnston, who has made a habit of winning ever since he emerged from a locomotive cab to labor leadership, achieved a new victory today when he was re-elected Grand Chief of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 12 -- Twenty-five scholarships, amounting to $8,000, have been awarded by the Faculty of Architecture at Harvard University, students in the School of Architecture receiving twenty awards, totaling $6,000, and students in the School of Landscape Architecture five, amounting to S2,000.

The Men's League In Aid of Crippled Children will begin today a drive for $50,000. This is its first public appeal since the organization was founded in 1925. The campaign has been necessitated, it was announced, because of the growing demand for the league's aid.

American European Securities Company -- Six months ended June 30: Net asset value of shares increased from $93.09 a share on preferred to $4.56 a share on common as of June 30; a year earlier asset value on preferred was $39.70 a share.

Secretary WALLACE has telegraphed forty-nine Mayors, stating that from their cities the Department of Agriculture is receiving "complaints of unreasonable increases in bread prices." The Department disapproves of any advance" in excess of the amount in"volved in market commodity price in"creases plus processing tax," and Mr. WALLACE urges that mark-ups be held within these limits.

VANCOUVER, July 12 (AP) --The defending champion, Gordon Baxter Taylor of Montreal, was dethroned today in the second round of the Canadian amateur golf championship at the Shaughnessy Heights Club. It remained, however, for some of the invaders from the United States to provide the real thrills.

REGINA, Sask., July 12 -- Canadian prairie wheat pools and the governments of the prairie Provinces have rejected the idea of wheat acreage restriction, regardless of what goes on at the international wheat conference in London, and in its place have adopted the quota plan for exports.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- With a Broc...n brewer acting as an agent of communication between the United States and the unrecognized Soviet Government of Russia, arrangements were completed today for a Russian rescue plane to carry James Mattern to Nome, Alaska, if Mattern acquiesces.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- John (Jake the Barber) Factor, who wag kidnapped by gunmen near a roadhouse in Morton Grove July 1, was released just before midnight tonight at La Grange, a suburb. He was found by a traffic policeman there a minute after he had been ejected from the kidnappers' automobile.

The New York County American Legion went on record last night against further exemption of any securities from taxation. At its annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania the county group adopted unanimously a resolution urging that all outstanding tax-exempt government securities be called in or funded, and that legislation be passed to prevent issuance of such securities in the future.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- President Roosevelt has under consideration a blanket order under the National Industrial Recovery Act to establish minimum wages and hours of work pending agreements upon fair competition codes by the nation's industries.

THE leaders of the various great industries, at the request of President Roosevelt, have been submitting their "codes" under the National Recovery Act. The baseball "code" has not yet been formulated in full, but it is understood that the following paragraphs have been submitted for debate or adoption by various leaders of the diamond industry:

The National Electrical Manufacturers Association made public yesterday a code filed with General Hugh S. Johnson, National Industrial Recovery Administrator. A hearing on the code is to be held in Washington July 19.

The suspension of trading in shares of the Continental Motors Corporation, made effective on June 14, will be terminated tomorrow morning at the opening, it was announced yesterday by the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange.

BUENOS AIRES, July 12 -- Paraguayan communiques continue to describe the Bolivian offensive as the fiercest since the Chaco war started thirteen months ago. They say the Bolivians in the last few days have lost 1,600 dead and 3,000 wounded.
Three more witnesses testified yesterday before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey that Joseph W. Harriman showed little comprehension of the details of his business affairs in recent years.

In a radio talk from London on Tuesday, the British economist, Sir JOSIAH STAMP, had some instructive comments upon President ROOSEVELT'S financial policy. On the whole, Sir JOSIAH warmly approved of it. So far as it contemplates bringing about a rise of commodity prices, it is in line with the professed plans and hopes of the British Government and, indeed, of all Governments.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 12 -- Stepping on an Eastern court for the first time this season, Frankie Parker, 17-year-old national clay court champion, entranced an enthusiastic gallery at the Bathing and Tennis Club today with as striking a straight backhand as has been seen here in many a year.

MADRID, July 12 -- Premier Azana has been placed in an awkward position in the Cortes by the debate opened by the Socialist who proposed a "broad and generous amnesty for the monarchists, syndicalists, Communists and Anarchists equally."
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The shipbuilding, industry's proposed fair competition code, submitted today to the National Industrial Recovery Administration, read:

All departments of the bond market on the Stock Exchange pointed higher yesterday in active dealings. Many domestic railroad issues recovered part of their recent losses. THE NEW YORK TIMES averages of domestic industrial and utility issues reached new high marks for the year, as did the average of leading foreign loans.

Activity in the Scaredale section featured the reports of realty transactions from Westchester yesterday. Four homes in that community were sold. Property in White Plains and a home site in the Elmsmere section of Bronxville also changed hands. The trading reflected the general upturn which has been noticeable recently in suburban districts.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The text of President Roosevelt's Executive order relating to first, second and third class postmasterships reads:

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- A Pan-American trade alliance, loosely drawn through individual agreements between the United States and Latin-American countries, but nevertheless an effective one, was forecast definitely today.

Samuel J. Bloommgdale, as president of the Lyman G. Realty Corporation, has added to his holdings in the Fifty-ninth Street retail shopping area by purchasing the property at 738 Lexington Avenue, opposite Bloomingdale's store in the block bounded by Lexington and Third Avenues, Fifty-ninth to Sixtieth Streets.

Stockholders of the former Liberty National Bank and Trust Company, who did not exchange their shares for stock in the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, have applied in the Federal Court to protect their alleged rights to a fund of $247,000 deposited in the Harriman Bank, it was learned yesterday.

Protestant, Catholic and Jewish congregations throughout the nation have been asked by leaders of the three faiths to take definite action in swinging public opinion behind President Roosevelt's National Industrial Recovery Act so "substantial progress may be made toward a better social order."

July gross revenues of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad are running 1 per cent ahead of those of a year ago, according to J.J. Pelley, president. He said that freight traffic was running 26.4 per cent ahead of 1932 levels and that passenger traffic was down 25 per cent, the decline resulting because much of the July 4 travel was begun this year in June.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Henry Stude, president of the American Bakers Association, told Secretary Wallace today that his recent attacks against "bread profiteering" were without foundation in fact, and they were "highly unfair" to the industry, and asked "if you cannot stop this baseless innuendo."

William Suppa of Bethpage, James Costello of Forest Park and Peter Vario of Oceanside scored 72s to tie for medal honors in the qualifying round of the second annual New York State public links championship tournament over the Forest Park links in Queens yesterday.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 12 -- Establishment by a group of industrial States of an insurance authority along the lines of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey was suggested here today by Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, as a step toward the solution of the unemployment insurance problem.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 12 (AP) -- Oklahoma today joined the parade of States which have legalized the sale of 3.2 per cent beer.

BOSTON, July 12 (AP) -- Absorption of idle cotton textile workers in New England and the recall to the industry of many skilled workers were results expected by manufacturers and labor leaders today as they awaited operation of the cotton textile code of the National Recovery Act.
LONDON, July 12 -- The London Times says today of yesterday's decision by the bureau of the economic conference that it is certainly not heroic.

After the excited advance in grains on Tuesday, cotton had its hour yesterday. The confident assertion by the Secretary of Agriculture that the campaign to remove some 10,000,000 acres of cotton from current production is meeting with success must have influenced this market powerfully.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 12 -- The first break in the seeded list of the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club occurred today. Miss Katharine Winthrop of Hamilton, Mass., upset Mrs. John A. Van Ryn, the former Marjorie Gladman, last year's winner, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3.

VIENNA, July 12 -- Frequent intimations and reports that Chancellor Hitler of Germany was connected with a Jewish family of the same name culminated in a three-page story tonight in the Heimwehr organ, Oesterreichische Abendblatt, claiming proof that Herr Hitler was directly descended on his mother's side from a Jewish family of that name in Czechoslovakia.

ALBANY, July 12 -- A flurry of rumors predicting the release by his kidnappers of Lieutenant John J. O'Connell Jr., nephew of the State's most powerful Democratic chieftains, kept the city excited today, but all were discredited by sundown.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The opportunity for cotton growers to accept the government's acreage reduction plan ended at midnight tonight and the Agricultural Adjustment Administration was confident that when the final figures were counted, pledges for the destruction of 10,000,000 acres would be found.

LONDON, July 12 -- Continued shrinkage in Great Britain's foreign trade was revealed today with the issuance of the Board of Trade figures for June, giving the first picture of British imports and exports during the first half of 1933.

Upward tendencies continued throughout the day in most of the local commodity markets, although some opened slightly lower. Coffee, silk and copper lost ground on the day. Trading was in good volume. Additional new high levels were reached in the spot markets.

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 12 -- Its compass broken and its bearings lost, the racing sloop Highland Belle drifted helplessly in the fog ten miles off Cape May today, High seas endangered the small vessel as two Coast Guard boats hurried to her aid.
The controversy over whether postmasterships should be included under civil service or should continue as part of the spoils system and of the political machines dates back many years.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is registrar for 63.500 no-par preferred shares and 375.000 no-par common shares of Bonwit, Teller Co.

TRENTON, N.J., July 12. -- The State Board of Bar Examiners announced today that 130 attorneys had passed the recent test for admission to practice of law as counselors. The examination was taken by 269 candidates.

Breaking a self-imposed rule followed since radio came into being, Rudyard Kipling, the British author, permitted the broadcast of an address he made yesterday at a luncheon at which the Canadian Authors Association was entertained by the Royal Society of Literature in London.

TRENTON, N.J., July 12 --A special committee created by the Legislature this year to study the feasibility of the State acquiring the Delaware and Raritan Canal is expected to meet within the next few weeks to consider the offer of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to transfer to New Jersey its right as lessee.

A special session of the State Legislature was urged on Governor Lehman in a letter dispatched yesterday by the National Public Housing Conference. The conference urged him to include in the program of such a session the creation of a municipal housing authority for New York City.

Retail Group May Include Buyers Plans for the inclusion of buying organizations within the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association are being developed, it was learned here yesterday. A meeting to discuss the formation of such a group, which will include resident offices and group-buying organizations, will be held in the near future.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 12 -- At the close of the flower show at Guild Hall last night, Mrs. Ellery James and Mrs. Shepard Krech, as designers of a shadow box with white iris posed on mirrors to simulate water, and a silver crane in the foreground, won by popular vote the first prize already given them by the judges' decision.

PARIS, July 12 -- Since regional independent economic systems seem inevitable, France should lead the European nations toward a united economic group, Joseph Caillaux writes in today's Agence Economique et Financiere.

Even during the depression American writers have fared better than some of their colleagues in foreign countries, it appears from a description of life in Bulgaria, "Where East Is West," by Henrietta Leslie. The work has just been published by Houghton Mifflin Company.
PARIS, July 12 -- Everybody here seems satisfied with the prospects of a soft-pedal closing of the London Economic Conference.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- President Roosevelt today gave his approval to the recommendations of the Cabinet Advisory Board of the Public Works Administration for Federal projects involving about $200,000,000. Secretary Ickes, head of the board, planned to announce the list of approved projects tomorrow.

Raymond Moley, Assistant Secretary of State; H. Bayard Swope, Oliver M.W. Sprague, economic adviser, and Edmond Day, technical adviser, are returning today on the Manhattan of the United States Lines from the economic conference in London.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Rye has advanced 25 cents for futures in the Chicago market in the last three days. Prices on deferred deliveries are above the dollar level, the top on September today being $1.03 and December $1.07 1/4. The close was 3 to 3 1/2 cents higher for the day on the deferred futures at $1.00 3/4 for September and $1.05 1/4 for December.

Thomas H. Beck, chairman of the Conservation Commission of Connecticut, is one of the few persons in this country who has been entrusted with the vast work of conservation, wild-life saving and wildlife propagation.
ALTON, Ill., July 12 -- A path was laid open today to the kidnappers of August Luer to collect ransom and return the 78-year-old packer and banker, if he is still alive.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- A group of pilots, whose names are known on every air lane, today was called by the National Aeronautic Association to face a disciplinary committee for taking part in the unsanctioned American air races in Chicago last week, with a three-year revocation of their contest licenses a possibility.

MOSCOW, July 12 -- Death sentences were pronounced last night on five cooks of the Moscow Restaurant Trust and five others received heavy terms of imprisonment for deliberately spoiling food in Moscow factory restaurants.

TORONTO, July 12 (AP) -- Jersey City and Toronto today completed their four-game series with an even break in a double-header. The visitors won the opening contest, 6 to 2, and the Leafs, aided by loose fielding captured the seven-inning second game, 5 to 4.
TRENTON, N.J., July 12 -- Governor A. Harry Moors made the following statement today about the proposed new parkway along the Palisades:

To "beat" the Civil Service Laws must seem, a duty to Tammany statesmen. The Board of Education, which ought to have been in better business, has been trying for some nine years to circumvent those statutes. In 1924 it established three posts for medical examiners and sought to make them exempt from competitive examination.

Wednesday, July 12, 1933. A cut of 1/8 in the yield on bills maturing up to 45 days was the only development of interest in the money market. It has been several years since a variation in yield affected any other than an even-month classification.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 12 -- More than 1,000 Paraguayans were killed or wounded in a stubborn Paraguayan offensive in the Gondra sector, but the attack was repulsed by the Bolivians, says a communique issued today by General Kundt at Port Munoz.

H. Eliot Kaplan of the Civil Service Reform Association said yesterday that Mayor O'Brien had sanctioned the city's appeal to the Court of Appeals to retain Dr. "William Walker, brother of the former Mayor, as a medical consultant to the Board of Education.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 12 -- Members of the Garden Club of Southampton met this morning at the Orchard, the home of Mrs. Charles Edward Merrill, Mrs. Robert Waller, president, presided.

ST. LOUIS, July 12 -- Harold Schumacher's sixth shut-out victory of the season, which, had eluded the Giants' young right-hander three times within the past few weeks, finally graced his efforts today and simultaneously ended New York's losing streak of seven straight games.

HENRY JAMES, writing from his memory of the Hudson in its lower reaches, expatriated it by giving it a place in the geography of the ideal, in the realm of poetry and pure literature, where there are no degrees of latitude or longitude. Fortunately, it is still an actuality and is permanently held in its predestined course by the cliffs which are known the world over as "The Palisades."

The First Security Company, affiliate of the First National Bank, issued yesterday a statement of its condition as of June 30, in conformity with the requirements of the new banking law. The statement showed that the corporation's assets had increased in market value about $14,250,000 in the last six months, so that Instead of being $11,750,000 "under water," as it was last December, the company now has a net worth of nearly $2,500,000.

The action of the Board of Estimate in changing Lexington Avenue between Thirty-eighth and Forty-first Streets from a restricted residential district to a retail district in 1931 was declared unlawful by the Court of Appeals on Tuesday. Notice to that effect was received yesterday by Carter, Ledyard Milburn, counsel for the Murray Hill Association, composed of property, owners in the restricted Murray Hill district.
Following is the code filed yesterday by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association:

Golden Gate District Bridge, Cal. A new issue of $3,000,000 Golden Gate Bridge and Highway District (Cal.) series B, 4 3/4 per cent bonds, dated July 1, 1933, and due serially from 1942 to 1970, will be placed on the market today by a syndicate composed of Blyth Co., Inc.; Bankamerica Company of San Francisco, Dean Witter Co. and Weeden Co., Inc.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated July 10:

J.P. Morgan sailed early this morning on the White Star liner Olympic for a vacation in England and Scotland. He will go to the latter country for his usual grouse and partridge shooting. He plans to return some time in the Fall.

A small gain of three-tenths of a point was registered by the adjusted index of electric power production for the week ended July 8, the figure moving up to 98.1 from 97.8 in the previous week. In the corresponding week of last year, the index stood at 85.0.

CINCINNATI, July 12 (AP) -- The Reds and the Phillies swapped positions at the bottom of the National League gladder today, the Phillies losing, 4 to 1, and going back to last place as Cincinnati advanced to seventh.

BERLIN, July 12 -- Premier Goering of Prussia issued a decree today placing German business and German labor under the supervision of the Prussian police and charging the police with the suppression of strikes, lockouts and other labor disputes.

The ceremonies attending the breaking of ground for the Palazzo d'Italia, Italian Building in the Rockefeller Center, took place yesterday morning. An international gathering of several hundred men and women, representing diplomatic, artistic, financial and political circles was present.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 12 (AP) -- Newark took the series from Rochester, three games to two, by Seating the Red Wings today, 2 to 0, behind the effective hurling of Jimmy Deshong and John Murphy.

PARIS, July 12 -- The plafond match between an American team captained by Ely Culbertson and a French team directed by Pierre Bellanger wound up six hands short of the scheduled finish today in a dispute caused by an error in dealing in the 101st hand.

Penitentiary sentences of not more than three years each were j imposed by Judge Nott in General Sessions yesterday on Ernest Suffern, Bonowitz X. Dawson and David Dyche, officers of the defunct General Industrial Foundation Corporation, for conspiring to defraud a woman of $588,000 in stock.

POONA, India, July 12 -- Complete abandonment of the civil disobedience campaign was clearly indicated tonight after the first day of the Congress party's conference, attended by Mahatma Gandhi and all the Nationalist leaders who are not in jail.

ST. PAUL, July 12 (AP) -- An amazing story of a gang which kidnapped a prominent physician, tried to torture him into operating criminally on a chiropractor and finally left him drugged in an automobile in the path of an approaching train, supplied police with a bizarre mystery tonight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The right of individual interpretation of the Bible is, I believe, an essential doctrine of the Protestant churches -- as opposed to the Catholic belief, which, while encouraging individual reading of the Bible, reserves the right of infallible interpretation for a divinely inspired Holy See at Rome.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 12 -- Two old rivals, each holding two legs on the prize at stake -- the Griswold Trophy -- will meet tomorrow for the first time in two years in the semi-finals of the fifteenth annual women's invitation golf tournament at the Shenecossett Country Club.
BOSTON, July 12 (AP) -- A single by Roy Johnson in the eleventh inning broke up a pitchers' battle between Vic Sorrell and Lloyd Brown and gave the Red Sox a 1-to-0 victory today over the Tigers.
The board of directors of the New York Life Insurance Company elected former Governor Alfred E. Smith a member of the board and a member of the company's agency committee yesterday.

Secretary ICKES warns those desiring to do business with, the Government on the new public works contracts not to waste money in hiring agents in Washington to find an "inside track" for their bids. The work will be given, he asserted, to those "able to do the best "jobs for the least money in an honest "way."

Fred Astaire, the musical-comedy actor, and Mrs. Phyllis Livingston Potter, who made her debut in New York society seven years ago, were married late yesterday afternoon by Supreme Court Justice Selah B. Strong in the judge's chambers in the Brooklyn Supreme Court Building.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

Whether it is popularly ascribed to the sudden ending of panicky depression or to supposed "inflation," the rapid recovery in stocks appears to have caused no great surprise. But the simultaneous and almost equally striking advance of prices for investment bonds has been puzzling, even to Wall Street.

NEWARK, N.J., July 12 -- The Industrial code drawn up by the newly formed New Jersey Dyers and Cleaners Association at its convention here early this week was forwarded today to Washington, where a code for the entire dyeing and cleaning industry In the United States is being written under the terms of the National Industrial Recovery Act.

PITTSBURGH, July 12 (AP) -- The Braves, scoreless for eight innings, suddenly came to life in the ninth frame today with an eight-run rally that tied the score. The Pirates, however, bounced back with a tally in the tenth to win, 9 to 8.

Irving Wallenberg, butler for John Ringling, the circus owner, and a stranger to the ways of New York, particularly to the ways of the lower east side, set out last night in quest of some toys for his young son. His innocent search gave an east side neighborhood a false but exciting kidnap scare.

American educators went yesterday to the assistance of German scholars ousted by the Hitler regime with the announcement of the formation of the Emergency Committee in Aid of Displaced German Scholars.

The Palisades Interstate Park Commission, at its regular monthly meeting today, will discuss the offer of John D. Rockefeller Jr. to give a tract of 265 acres atop the Palisades for a new parkway running nineteen miles north from the George Washington Bridge.

The dispute between nearly 300 "permit" motion-picture operators and Local 306 of the Motion. Picture Operators Union as to the membership status of the permit men was settled yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Edward Riegelmann in Brooklyn ruled that they were not members of the union.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Confident that a code for the bituminous industry would be written by tomorrow night, operators and miners adjourned this evening to meet again at 11 A.M. tomorrow.

The United Licensed Officers Association asked the owners of American merchant ships yesterday to meet its representatives and discuss terms of a working agreement for ships' officers in accordance with the suggestion of the Federal Government for the coordination of industry.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 12 -- Gloucester folk, inured to the ways of navy men, especially cruising midshipmen, have been paying scant attention to the group of sixty youths who, clad in shorts and cleated boots, have been kicking and throwing footballs on the beach for the past few days.

MONTREAL, July 12 -- Directors of the Beauharnois Power Corporation, Ltd., have elected J.S. Norris as president of the corporation and chairman of the board of directors, and the directors of Beauharnois Light, Heat and Power Company, a subsidiary of Beauharnois Power, have elected Mr. Norris as president and chairman of that company.
Mayor O'Brien will disclose today the total amount the city will ask in Federal loans to finance its program of public works.

BERLIN, July 12 -- Continuing its recovery of yesterday, trading on the Boerse was in a more optimistic mood today, but complete absence of public interest left prices to the play of the professionals. Nevertheless, heavy industrials, Dye Trust, Rubber and Reichsbank showed rises of 1 to 2 per cent, while some of the specialties made gains of as much as 3 per cent.

Speculators for the advance tested the stock market cautiously yesterday. Various groups were bid up alternately on the Stock Exchange. The widest advance occurred in the so-called "wet stocks," with respect to which there has been much grave head-nodding of late.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 12 (AP) -- Joseph J. Dicarlo, No. 1 on the Buffalo Police Commissioner's list of public enemies, left the city early today with the intention of attempting to get in touch with the kidnappers of John J. O'Connell Jr. He did not say where he was going.

They Built Too Much. The fifty-three-story Lincoln Building across the way from Grand Central Terminal has been sold at auction in mortgage foreclosure. It is said to be the largest structure that ever came under the hammer -- and a mighty hammer it must be to knock down so bulky an item.

LONDON, July 12 -- The World Economic Conference received another shock today just as it was beginning to get under way toward the present limited objectives, and the shock again came from United States sources.

Operations in the steel Industry have risen this week to a national average of 59 per cent, compared with 56 per cent a week ago, acording to the weekly review of The Iron Age. This publication notes that "new business in iron and steel has shown an expected recession, following the heavy specifying marked by the close of the second quarter," but observers at the same time that "pressure for shipments is unrelaxed."
The Board of Estimate will adopt a formal resolution this morning requesting Governor Lehman to call a special session of the State Legislature to aid in financing the city's relief program.

BOSTON, July 12 -- Willard T. Carleton, president of the Boston Safe Deposit and Trust Company, dropped dead at noon today on board the United Fruit Company steamship Petan while the ship was entering the harbor at Kingston, Jamaica, according to wireless advices to officials of the line here.

Samuel Walter, an ex-convict, against whom an indictment charging larceny is pending in State court, testified yesterday before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey that Senator A. Spencer Feld, Assemblyman David Paris and former Assemblyman Weinfeld were as deeply involved in the case as he.

Early nervous trading was followed yesterday on the Cotton Exchange by sharp advances in prices on aggressive buying by wire houses. Then came a violent rise of more than a half cent based on reports that the campaign for acreage reduction was proving successful.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, July 12 -- Addressing a throng of several thousand persons assembled for the laying of the cornerstone of the new "Hall of Springs" here today, Governor Lehman hailed the State spa development as a "boon to humanity," particularly for its treatment of heart ailments.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- Ths government tool: a decisive step toward curbing overproduction of oil today through an order by President Roosevelt prohibiting the shipment in interstate commerce of petroleum produced or withdrawn from storage in violation of State conservation laws.

Holders of German long-term bonds of all descriptions, except the Dawes Plan 7s and the Young Plan 5 1/2s, will receive their interest thereon for the next six months, at least 50 per cent in cash and 50 per cent in checks calling for blocked German marks.

A group of foreign women writers en route to the international conference of business and professional women in Chicago were the guests yesterday of members of the Pen and Brush Club at a tea in the Hotel Grosvenor. Dr. Meta Anderson, vice president of the club, acted as hostess for the gathering, at which Miss Ida M. Tarbell, president, was present.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., July 12 -- A warning that Republicans must avoid "toryism" it they would win back the State was sounded by W. Kingsland Macy in an address at a picnic held here today under the auspices of the Ogdensburg Republican Women's Club.
Formal approval by the Board of Estimate of the $45,500,000 Rutgers-town housing development along the East River front was indicated by Mayor O'Brien yesterday during a board hearing on the subject.

The B.B. Stable grained its fifth success in the four days that the Empire City meeting has been under way when Ayston, a gelded son of Black Servant, triumphed toy five lengths yesterday. The winner was one of the most heavily backed choices of the session, being driven down from 8 -- 5 to 9 -- 10.
Will Irwin is composing the music for "Carrots and Peas," the intimate revue scheduled for a local showing about the middle of September.

PLYMOUTH, England, July 12 (AP) -- Laurence A. Steinhardt, United States Minister to Sweden, arrived on the liner lie de France today and said he thought it "grossly unfair and inaccurate to say President Roosevelt wrecked the conference."

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that It had approved applications of four chemical companies for the listing of additional shares which are being issued in connection with the acquisition of new properties.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12 (AP) -- A three-run rally In the sixth inning, touched off by Jimmy Foxx's twenty-fifth home run of the season, grave the Athletics a 6-to-4 victory over Cleveland today, their second straight over the Indians.

TOKYO, July 12 -- Dispatches to the War Office from Mukden revealed today that Manchukuo forces had made a raid on July 5 on the base of the bandits who captured three British ship's officer's at Newchwang about six months ago.

Declaring that "the recent improvement in the motor industry has exceeded expectations," the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce tentatively put its members'' production for June yesterday at 195,178 cars and trucks. This represented a gain of 104 per cent over the output of these companies for June, 1932, and an increase of 13.2 per cent over May of this year.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Seeking to expedite activities of the recently organized Business Advisory and Planning Council for the Department of Commerce, Gerard Swope, chairman, has called a meeting of the executive committee for July 21.

Philip G. Johnson, former president of the Boeing Airplane Company, was elected president of United Aircraft and Transport Corporation at a meeting at 230 Park Avenue. He succeeds Fred erick B. Rentscher, who becomes vice chairman of the board, a new office created by the directors.

To the Editor of The New York Times: BEVERLY HILLS, Cal., July 12 -- I see by the papers where my old Governor friend, Bill Murray of Oklahoma, called out the National Guard when the folks voted on beer. Now he will have to call out the United States Army to keep the folks from celebrating the voting of beer.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 12 -- The members of the Yale-Harvard and Oxford-Cambridge tennis teams, who tomorrow will begin a three-day tournament at the courts of the Newport Casino, put in a full day of practice today. From the appearance of the teams there will be some spirited matches for the Prentice Cup.

Shares of common stock of the United States Steel Corporation in the names of brokers increased 159.717 shares in the third quarter. The total stands now at 1,558,573 shares, or 17.91 per cent of the total issue. A year ago the floating supply was 1,096,057 shares, or 12.60 per cent of the issue.
Sales of dwellings in Jersey City featured the New Jersey market yesterday.

ANADYR, Siberia, July 12 (By Wireless) -- I am still waiting and hoping and planning to find some way to resume my journey in the air and to be the first person to make a round-the-world flight all alone. I am in shape to do it, despite the broken left ankle I mentioned in my dispatch yesterday.

LATONIA, July 12 (AP). -- The Buena Vista Purse for sprinters served as the feature at Latinia today. It resulted in a popular victory for the silks of Colonel E.R. Bradley as Broad Meadows romped home first in a field of eight.

COLUMBUS, July 12 -- Opportunity to express their wishes Nov. 7 on repeal was made more certain for Ohioans today when the State Supreme Court, by a six-to-one decision, denied the right of referendum on the Mosier-Lawrence Act.
The American-Russian Chamber of Commerce came out yesterday in favor of recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States, a course which it condemned seven years ago.

The Democratic County Committee in the Twenty-second Assembly District, with a membership of 425, will meet tomorrow evening at the clubhouse of the Tammany district organization, 423 West 156th Street, to elect a leader of the district to succeed J.J. McCormick, former Deputy City Clerk.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 12 -- About seventy members of the Newport Garden Association had a luncheon meeting at the home of Mrs. Moses Taylor at the Glen in Portsmouth. The guest of honor was Miss Grace Boynton of New York, who gave an illustrated lecture on "Old Chinese Gardens."

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- A new dirigible to replace the Akron has been recommended by Rear Admiral Ernest J. King, who succeeded the late Rear Admiral William A. Moffett as Chief of the Bureau of Naval Aeronautics.

Seven of the fifty-two Brooklyn dry agents who were dismissed July 1 were the ones who took part in the investigation that led to the indictment of Major Chester P. Mills and eight others, it was disclosed yesterday. Mills and the eight other men were charged with a conspiracy to divert industrial alcohol into other channels.

LONDON, July 13. -- The departure for Britain of J.P. Morgan is taken by The London Times as an opportunity for delivering one of the most remarkable encomiums that newspaper has ever given to a living financier.
LONDON, July 13 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:
WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

CHICAGO, July 13. -- A militant spirit on the part of women was urged today at the international luncheon of the National Business and Professional Women's Clubs by Miss Lena Madesin Phillips of New York, president of the international federation of such clubs.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 13. -- Pince Charming II, the veteran thoroughbred hunter from the Warfield Farms of Frederick P. Warfield, Port Chester, N.Y., continued his long string of victories today by winning two blue ribbons at the opening sessions of the tenth annual Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show.

An advance of 3.9 points carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices up to 103.9 on Tuesday, July 11, from 100.0 (revised) on Monday, July 3, the index now standing at the highest level since May 5, 1931.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- Plans for the reception of General Italo Balbo and the members of his armada of twenty-four seaplanes have been completed, Major Reed G. Landis, chairman of the reception committee, announced today. The armada is expected to land in Chicago harbor either Saturday or Sunday at the end of the flight from Ortebello, Italy.

CHICAGO, July 13 (AP). -- Jack Medica of Seattle, Wash., and Ralph Flanagan of Miami, Fla., showed the way to their older rivals today in the trials of the one-mile free-style, opening event of the National A.A.U. swimming championship meet.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 13. -- Miss Sarah Paltrey of Brookline, Mass., took a forward step toward a berth on the United States Wightman Cup tennis team when she eliminated Miss Josephine Cruickshank of Santa Ana, Cal., 7 -- a, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 3, today in a quarter-final match of the women's invitation tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club.

The Advertising Review Committee, representing advertisers, agencies and representatives of advertising media, announced yesterday that it was ready to put to use its recently revised plan of operation. The plan is offered as an opportunity for advertising to regulate itself.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: The recent hot weather has demonstrated fully the need for additional play facilities in all parts of the city. Since school closed, such areas as are available have been taxed to capacity by the crowds of children who use them.

ALBANY, July 13. -- Worried and haggard but still hopeful, relatives of Lieutenant John J. O'Connell Jr. waited patiently tonight for word from the band that kidnapped the young National Guard officer a week ago. They have not heard from them since Monday.

Sloan Robertson, architects, made public yesterday the names of five directors-to-be of a Reconstruction Housing Corporation, to be organized in this city under the State Housing Law, to build on the vacant city-owned Chrystie-Forsyth Street area.

CHICAGO, July 13. -- Chicago's rye market, looked upon by traders all over the world as relatively the highest, is being used as a target for disposal of holdings. About 600,000 bushels of Canadian rye have been bought to come to Chicago a a good profit to the seller.

What the market sophisticates speak of as "turning on the heat" occurred on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The speculative pace was quickened rapidly, and business went on at a merry pace. The brokers were happy. Pools "lost" a great deal of stock.

LONDON, July 13. -- The world wheat-restriction plan encountered more difficulties today. Representatives of the Danubian grain countries had already agreed to stabilize their production, but when the actual figures of limitation were disclosed differences immediately developed.

After making new high records, during which October sold at 11.85 cents, compared with a low of 5.93 cents last December, or only a point short of a 100 per cent advance, prices on the Cotton Exchange churned around feverishly yesterday in a range of $2 a bale and ended at losses of 15 to 17 points.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- Silk manufacturers neared an agreement today on a code of fair practices to govern their industry under the National Recovery Administration.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13. -- Statistics to show that of 900,000 girls born in the United States not one was born to a woman of 55 or over were brought into Federal court here today, but failed to block payment of an $11,560 inheritance tax in an unusual case.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, will return today from a vacation of two months in Europe. Dr. Butler is on the Cunard liner Berengaria. Winnie Melville, London singer; Billie Burke, widow of the late Flo Ziegfetd; Horton Smith and Johnnie Farrell, golfers, are other prominent passengers.
BERLIN, July 13. -- General church elections were ordered today for July 23 to place German Protestantism's fate directly in the hands of the individual church members.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The Cabinet Advisory Board on public works today divided the country into ten regional zones for their administration. Secretary Ickes, administrator, said that he had been empowered to select the cities from which the work will be directed and expected to announce the locations soon.

Support of the administration at Washington is expressed by Edmond B. Butler, president of the National Catholic Alumni Federation, in a letter to heads of alumni groups of Catholic educational institutions throughout the United States.

To the Editor of New York Times: At last, after attempting to impose local taxes on taxicabs, rents and other thing's, Samuel Untermyer and the members of the city administration have turned to sounder and more practical methods of securing additional revenue, for the city.

BERLIN, July 13. -- The Boerse opened weak today on an early slump in the dollar, but recovered when the dollar became steady at 2.93 marks. Business, however, was entirely in the hands of professionals, and their efforts to advance prices did not go far because of lack of public support.

Spinsters on Guard. The pioneer mother on guard with rifle at the cabin door against prowling danger from man or beast now has a companion-piece. Judge FLORENCE ALLEN of the Ohio Supreme Court has just pronounced the eulogy of the "old maid" in the family, the unmarried woman worker, and her role in the depression.

Patrolman Frank Trapani of the West 100th Street station, after testifying in General Sessions yesterday in the trial of a man on a burglary indictment, was himself arrested on a perjury charge at Judge Corrigan's order. Stripped of his pistol, but wearing his shield on his uniform coat, he later was lodged in a Tombs cell in default of $5,000 bail.

SHEDIAC, N.B., July 13. -- General Italo Balbo and his armada of twenty-four Italian seaplanes glided down onto Shediac's harbor this afternoon after a flight from Labrador in about 5 hours 47 minutes. The 800-mile trip today was impeded only by headwinds, without the fog, clouds and stiffer headwinds encountered yesterday on the 1,500-mile dash over the North Atlantic from Reykjavik, Iceland, to Cartwright, Labrador.
Federal Judge Manton reserved decision yesterday on two motions bearing on the receivership of the Manhattan Railway Company, owner of the elevated railway operated by the I. R. T.

CHICAG'O, Juty 13. -- John (Jake the Barber) Factor, shaved and refreshed by alcohol rubdowns and a night's rest, repudiated today his earlier statements that no ransom was paid for his release. His new story was that $50,000 in $10 and $20 bills was thrown from an automobile by a friend as he passed a car sent by the kidnappers.

Samuel Levy, Borough President of Manhattan, and other city officials and representatives of Rockefeller Center took what was described as "the fastest passenger elevator ride on record" yesterday in the RCA Building in the Rockefeller development.

The New York Telephone Company has been authorized by the Public Service Commission to issue not to exceed $50,000,000 of capital stock within a period not later than Sept. 1, 1933, and to apply the proceeds to the payment and discharge of a like amount of indebtedness owing to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Record trading volumes with rising prices featured the local commodity exchanges yesterday, with the most spectacular price movements appearing in the silver market. Although the major commodities were off in the cash markets, many others reached new high levels.

Milton Aborn announced yesterday that he would inaugurate a series of revivals of light operas at the Majestic Theatre on July 27. The company will be called the Aborn Opera Company, and the first bill will be "The Bohemian Girl." After that, there will be operas by Franz Lehar, victor Herbert and Oscar Strauss.
CINCINNATI, July 13 (AP). -- The Reds and Phillies swapped places again today, Cincinnati dropping back into the National League cellar as Philadelphia won, 4 to 3.

In one of the largest transactions in many months in the residential section of the upper east side of Manhattan, interests controlled by the J.H. Taylor Construction Company have purchased from the Bowery Savings Bank the fifteen old tenements comprising the westerly block front on York Avenue between Seventy-ninth and Eightieth Streets, with adjoining properties on the two streets.

Several proposals for the development of the government piers at Hoboken into an active centre of shipping and commercial activities are being considered by Max Thaten, whose bid for their rental was accepted by the Shipping Board on Tuesday.

The Dry Dock Savings Institution has extended to July 1, 1936, at 5 per cent, the mortgage for $40,000 it holds from Dora Bierman on 130-132 E. 2d St., and this has been consolidated with a prior mortgage to form a joint first lien of $47,500 on the property.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Charges of widespread intimidation to prevent workers in basic industries from unionizing in accordance with the spirit of the Industrial Recovery Act were made today by Frank Morrison, secretary of the American Federation of Labor.

A dark horse is being groomed for the fusion nomination for Mayor. His name was first mentioned to the fusion groups at their weekly conference yesterday. Formal announcement of the fusionist choice for Mayor probably "would not be made until the first week of August, it was said.

Count Folke Bernadotte, nephew of King Gustav of Sweden, has been placed in charge of the distribution in this country of "Gustav V -- King of Sweden," a celebration album printed in honor of King Gustav's seventy-fifth anniversary and the twenty-fifth year of his reign.

Justin C. O'Brien of 60 East Eightieth Street, youngest son of former Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Morgan J. O'Brien, was critically injured in an automobile crash on the George Washington Bridge at 3:25 o'clock yesterday morning.

DETROIT, July 13. -- A statement today by five prominent Detroiters indicated a new Detroit bank with a capital structure of $5,250,000 to replace the closed Guardian National Bank of Commerce is being organized and has its capital assured.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -- The Interstate Commerce Commission struck from its docket today a score of cases which had been brought against railroads in an effort to recapture half of the earnings above 6 per cent the roads had piled up in prosperous years.

Swindled out of their life savings of $16,840, Harry Rosen and his wife, Anna, of 1,015 East 156th Street, the Bronx, appealed to the police yesterday to help them find the three men responsible for their loss.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Backed by approval of President Roosevelt and the Attorney General, Secretary Wallace announced today that the Agricultural Adjustment Administration would use its drastic licensing powers to compel recalcitrant minorities to abide by marketing agreements proposed by the majority of an industry.
WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The "avalanche" of fair competition codes which the Recovery Administration had tried by every means for ten days to loosen started with a rush today.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Federal relief must be extended to all needy unemployed persons whose resources are inadequate to provide necessities of life for themselves and dependents, Harry L. Hopkins, emergency relief administrator, stipulated today in rules governing the allocation of funds to States.

Joseph W. Harriman, indicted founder of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, believes he could have saved that institution "if he had been let alone," Fred Scholz, an accountant, testified yesterday before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey.

The city of Detroit (Mich.), Bondholders Refunding Committee, headed by B. A. Tompkins, vice president of the Bankers Trust Company, New York, issued a call yesterday for deposits of bonds of notes of the city with the committee in order to consummate the previously announced refunding plan.

Dr. Louis I. Dublin, a vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, returned on the United States liner Manhattan yesterday from London. There he conferred with representatives of other countries preparatory to the International Populations Congress next year.

An indictment charging ten men with conspiracy to conceal assets in a bankruptcy proceeding was handed up yesterday by the Federal grand jury in Brookiyn to Judge Clarence G, Galston in the United States District Court.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 13. -- More than 100 persons competed tonight at the Maidstone Club in the first of the duplicate contract series arranged by Mrs. Geraldine Furlow and Mrs. Leila Hattersley. Mrs. Julian S. Myrick and Mrs. Adelaide Leonard were hostesses.
LONDON, July 13. -- Considerable effort and good-will all around today allowed the economic conference committee which is dealing with central banks to proceed with its work.

Intent upon the problem Of obtaining funds to complete the Palisades parkway project made possible by the grift of John D. Rockefeller Jr., the Palisades Interstate Park Commission met yesterday and accepted Mr, Rockefeller's offer of the 265-acre tract.

LONDON, July 13. -- The World Economic Conference much resembles an extremely ill person in the hands of skillful doctors. It is sick almost unto death from the lack of coordination between its component parts and unable to digest food that is offered to strengthen it because of this malady.

The Carnegie Foundation and the Guggenheim Foundation have awarded to the American Woman's Association $5,000 and $2,000, respectively, for further research into the present economic status and outlook for women, it was announced yesterday by Anne Morgan, president of the association.

Preparations for a general strike in the garment industry were made last night at meetings of shop chairmen of the International Ladies Garment Workers' Union. Involved in the threatened strike are 30,000 cloak and suit workers and 55,000 workers in the dress industry in New York and vicinity.

Three men were killed and four others injured in two accidents in Jersey City yesterday, one crash occurring on the Broadway ramp of the elevated highway and the other at the Summit Avenue crossing of the Holland Tunnel approach.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new bigh or low figure.

BABYLON, L.I., July 13. -- Fire aboard his yacht, forced Colonel M. Robert Guggenheim, his wife and son and three guests to leap into the waters of Block Island Sound yesterday. They were saved from drowning by radio and the prompt action of New York National Guard air pilots, Captain William G. Rector and Lieutenant Charles L. Youmans, both attached to Miller Field.
TOKYO, July 13. -- The force behind Japan's political and industrial expansion is again revealed in the Cabinet statistical bureau's report on births.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 13. -- Jack Rogers of Plainfield, a junior at Princeton, became the New Jersey State junior golf champion at the Ridgewood Country Club today by defeating Harold V. Whelan of Suburban, 2 and 1 in the eighteen-hole final.

The Fifth Avenue Association began a campaign yesterday to eject garment manufacturers from Forty-sixth and Forty-seventh Streets between Fifth and Sixth Avenues. Captain William J. Pedrick asserted that the presence of the factory workers would drive shoppers from Fifth Avenue, cause lower property values, and mar the beauty of the district.

TROY, N.Y., July 13 (AP). -- Playing a consistent game, George R. Rayner of Niagara Falls turned in a par 71 to lead a field of New York State's leading youthful shot-makers in the qualifying round of the State junior golf championship tournament over the Troy Club links today.
MOSCOW, July 13. -- The success of Soviet diplomacy has nowhere been more marked than in Turkey, Persia and other Near Eastern lands.
PRAGUE, July 13. -- For twenty-four hours the bridge uniting Poland and Czechoslovakia near Teschen bore a monument to the stupidity of bureaucracy and of the nationality laws of post-war Europe.

Raymond Moley, Assistant Secretary of State, and Dr. O. M. W. Sprague, financial adviser to the American delegation to the economic conference in London, returned yesterday on the Manhattan of the United States Lines. Both were relatively noncommital as to the conference and its possibilities of ultimate success, but Dr. Sprague was a fountain of information compared to Professor Moley.

Inspired by a shattering bombardment from Yankee bats, Vernon (Lefty) Gomez tamed the St. Louis Browns yesterday at the Stadium before about 6,000 fans, and gave the Ruppert forces their sixth straight victory. The score was 12 to 0.

While wholesale foreclosures are impending up-State, Federal mortgage relief legislation is not likely to function effectively for a year, the Consolidated Home Owners Mortgage Committee was told yesterday by a group which conducted an up-State survey.
WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The proposed code of fair competition submitted to the National Recovery Administration today by the Associated General Contractors of America follows in full:

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- In an effort to speed apprehension of kidnappers and the return of their victims, Attorney General Cummings offered several suggestions to the public today, and made known that new legislation to deal with kidnapping and racketeering was being drafted.

Professor Gerald E. SeBoyar, chairman of the committee on scholastic standing of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, announced yesterday that 129 students of that division had been placed on the honor roll for the second semester of the 1932-1933 academic year.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 13. -- Miss Helen Silleck of the Greenwich Country Club won low gross prize with an 87 in a golf tournament sponsored by the Westchester-Fairfield Women's Golf Association at the Greenwich Country Club today.
WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The proposed code of fair competition submitted toddy for the soft coal industry to the National Recovery Administration follows:
WESTBURY, L.I., July 13. -- In close and well-played games, the Great Island and Meadow Lark polo teams came through to the final of the Hempstead Cups tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 13. -- The latest song composed by Mrs. Bradford Norman Jr. of New York and Portsmouth, entitled "Rainy Day," will be one of the entertainment features at the Red and White Ball at Oakland Farm, the home of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt in Portsmouth, on Saturday night for the benefit of the Boy Scouts of Newport County.

In the heaviest trading in more than three years, stocks and many commodities reached the highest levels of 1933 yesterday. The gains were partly canceled, however, in a wave of profit-taking in the last half hour.
WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The cost of living in the United States decined 2.9 per cent during the first six months of 1933, according to a report issued today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

LONDON, July 13. -- A flat statement that Great Britain would make no more expensive experiments with public works schemes to relieve unemployment -- a cardinal point in President Roosevelt's recovery plans -- was flung into a plenary meeting of the economic commission of the World Economic Conference today by Walter Runciman, Britain's President of the Board of Trade.

BALBOA, C. Z., July 13. -- Hope that the project of an inter-American highway connecting the United States with the Panama Canal would not be abandoned was expressed by George Curtis Peck when he arrived here today, bound for Washington, because his office as Commercial Attache in Guatemala has been closed.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Action by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and the Controller of the Currency, coupled with the organization of a new national bank by the Ford interests, opened the way today for solution of the bank troubles at Detroit.

On instructions from President ROOSEVELT, several South American governments have been notified that our State Department would like to "begin exploratory studies of the possibility of negotiating a trade agreement" with each, of them. Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Colombia are specifically mentioned.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 13. -- American membership in the World Court and League of Nations was urged tonight in an address at the University of Virginia by Representative David J. Lewis of Maryland.

Play in the second annual New York State public links golf championship tournament was narrowed to the quarter-final round at the Forest Park links in Queens yesterday. The tourney saw two of the favorites eliminated at the end ner-up for the Metropolitan Golf Association junior championship at Sleepy Hollow two weeks ago, and Edward Kringle of Sound View, finalist in last year's New York State of the day's matches.

Large inflation, of surplus funds of seven gas companies in the city in the last ten years, while little, if any, dividends were being paid by the majority of these utilities, was shown yesterday to the Public Service Commission.

Speculation on the Stock Exchange was carried on at a furious rate yesterday. Transactions ran well above 7,000,000 shares, which represented the greatest volume in more than three years. Trading was also extremely, active in bonds and commodities.

SHEDIAC, N. B., July 13, -- General Italo Balbo and his squadron of twenty-four Italian, seaplanes arrived here today. The city was decorated with British and Italian flags and bunting and thousands of visitors were on the streets to welcome the fliers.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Lyon Boston left yesterday for Keene, N. H., where Mr. Boston will be best man at the marriage of Miss Ruth Faulkner to Richard Folsom Hayward tomorrow at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Faulkner.

ALBANY, July 13. -- That portion of the new Federal Banking Act which prohibits Reserve banks from paying interest on demand deposits does not apply, as a general rule, to deposits of public money by the State or its municipalities, Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, said today.

WASHINOTON, July 13. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 12, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,230,080,000, an increase of $5,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $187,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

A minimum wage of $14 a week and the forty-hour week are established in a code for the cloak and suit industry submitted yesterday to the National Industrial Recovery Administration by the three employers' associations in the trade.

PITTSBURGH, July 13 (AP) -- Five Pirate hits combined with two Boston errors in an eighth-inning out-break today produced five runs, breaking a 3-3 tie and giving Pittsburgh an 8-to-3 victory over the Braves.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP). -- Their league lead shrinking almost as fast as it swelled, the Senators today were beaten, 9 to 6, by the White Sox to cut their advantage over the Yankees to a single game.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/2 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 1 1/2 per cent for the best names.
A new slogan appeared in New York yesterday.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 13. -- Mrs. Dorothy Campbell Hurd of Philadelphia today defeated Miss Edith Quier of Reading, 1 up, in the Shenecossett Country Club's fifteenth annual invitation tournament, to gain the final round.
WASHINGTON, July 13. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated July 11:

Bank clearings jumped upward again in the week ended on Wednesday, carrying the aggregate for twenty-one leading cities 29.7 per cent above the total of a year before anr the daily average amount for the month to date 20.5 per cent above that in the same time in 1932, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 13. -- The invading British collegians from Oxford and Cambridge gained a 4-to-2 lead in today's opening team matches against the Harvard-Yale tennis team in competition for the Prentice Cup.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., July 13. -- A northeast gale, with almost torrential rain and bad visibility which did not begin to clear until 4 o'clock this afternoon kept Colonel and Mrs. Lindbergh indoors all day, delaying the resumption of their exploratory flight.

LONDON, July 13. -- The disappointment of the British Dominions delegates to the World Economic Conference over the British Government's conservative attitude toward schemes for raising world price levels was increased to dissatisfaction today.

The adjusted index of lumber production continued its steady upward climb for the week ended July 8, advancing to 72.9 from 68.6, a revised figure, for the previous week. The index now stands at the highest point in more than two years.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 13. -- The first skirmish in the English-Australian tennis battle for the right to go to Paris to meet the United States in the interzone Davis Cup final ended all square today when the two teams divided the opening singles matches.

BALTIMORE, July 13. -- The fifty passengers of the Baltimore Mail Line's flagship City of Baltimore, which was badly damaged in collision, with the tanker Beacon off Gibson Island in Chesapeake Bay last evening, sailed tonight on the City of Newport News of the same line for Hamburg.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company, which in June, 1871, acquired the Delaware and Raritan Canal by a lease for 999 years of the properties of the United Canal and Railroad Companies of New Jersey, has offered to relinquish to the State, for a "nominal sum," its rights in the waterway.
BUFFALO, N. Y., July 13 (AP). -- After spotting Jersey City four runs in the opening inning, the Bisons came back to rout the visitors at the stadium tonight, 17 to 6.

The appointment of Henri Morin de Linclays as general manager of the French Line in the United States and Canada was announced yesterday after a meeting of the directors in Paris. M. de Linclays will assume his new duties in September as successor to Jean Tillier, who announced his resignation to head a new commercial enterprise on his return from France a week ago.
PARIS, July 13. -- To glory in conceit over one's bridge game is good publicity for an expert player and frequently nettles his opponent sufficiently to make him play badly.

In the eighth week of its open-market campaign of purchases of government securities to increase member bank reserves, the Federal Reserve System, finding its immediate goal in sight, has cut the rate of its buying in half.

TOKYO, July 13. -- The president of the Ibaraki Prefecture Farmers Patriotic Society and several of his associates have been arrested on suspicion of complicity in the Seisanto plot for a coup d'etat.

ST. LOUIS, July 13. -- A gorgeous spectacle was put on at Sportsman's Park today as part of the St. Louis Tuberculosis and Health Society's drive. Society women sold programs among the 15,000 gayly attired spectators, a varicolored pageant was on display and sixteen bands paraded around the arena, all blaring forth at once.
PARIS, July 13 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

WASHINOTON, July 13. -- The verbal warfare of the past two weeks between the Agricultural Adjustment Administration and the American Bakers Association over complaints against "profiteering" in bread prices was understood to have been concluded today following conferences by Henry Stude, president of the association, with adjustment officials.
LONDON, July 13. -- Four great British railway companies are pushing ahead with pooling arrangements in the belief that they will cut operating costs and help offset the competition of motor traffic.

To the Editor of The New York Times: These lovely Summer days are inducive to eating out-of-doors, as the food seems to taste better, and it also creates originality in entertaining, while, most of all, it brings folks closer to nature.

LONDON, July 13. -- The United States is now making a real recovery, and there is no danger of a setback, Dr Lionel Danforth Edie, formerly Professor of Finance at the University of Chicago, said at an American Chamber of Commerce luncheon today.

The city now has on record the first of the season's shark reports. The report was made last night to the police and they regarded it seriously enough to send a teletype alarm, as a protection to bathers in the Hudson River. The alarm went to all police precincts in the city from the Battery northward and to all Hudson River communities as far up as Poughkeepsie.

Mark Stuart, the metropolitan amateur golf champion, put together another of his effective rounds at the Fox Hills Golf Club, Clifton, S.I., yesterday, to win the William Henry Beers Memorial tourney.

HERE'S a proper go! The fight between Jack Peterson and Jack Doyle for the British heavy-weight championship at the White City Stadium in the London h'area ended in a foul in the jolly second round. So the 60,000 sturdy Britons who paid their two bob or whatever it was to see a furious fifteen-round encounter were treated to a proper sell. Pip! Pip!

Litigation over the bonuses and stock allotments to officers and employes of the American Tobacco Company ended yesterday, when decrees embodying a compromise settlement were announced in three courts in the New York area.

Money market was quiet all day. Business was light, and quotations unchanged in all classifications. Stock Exchange day loans commanded 1 per cent, and street funds traded at the same figure, with Federals 1/3@1/4. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances remained steady.
Controller Charles W. Berry, who is on his way to London and the Continent in his search for new sources of taxation, is traveling at the city's expense, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Improvement in the government's fiscal position in the first eleven days of July over the corresponding period of 1932 was shown by the Treasury's financial statement today.

Well, bass fishermen, there are bass to be caught, according to all advices. All one needs is patience, the right equipment and the right spot, the last being especially important. It is a good deal like salt water fishing. The ocean is full of fish, but it requires some effort to find just where the various species are.

The early years of President Roosevelt's life are stressed in 'Young America's Story of Franklin D. Roosevelt -- Man of Action," by Sadyebeth and Anson Lowitz, published today by Doubleday, Doran Co. From his childhood to his school and college days, and through his political career to the White House, Mr. Roosevelt's life is traced in this biography for youths.

Magistrate Benjamin Greenspan in Traffic Court used the laboratory system, yesterday to demonstrate to thirty-five traffic offenders just what are the more common forms of traffic violation. His demonstration, at the corner of Lafayette and Bleecker Streets, attracted a crowd that assumed delightful proportions in the eyes of Patrolman John Shanley of Traffic B, Who aided the magistrate in his elucidations by providing concrete examples.

VIENNA, July 13. -- The latest Nazi provocation from Germany is an announcement that there will be a big "frontier town festival" in the Bavarian town of Kiefelsfeld, half an hour from the Austrian frontier town of Kufstein, during the coming week-end.

It is a humiliating confession and cry almost of despair which the authorities of this city send on to the Governor of the State. The municipal government admits that it has no money to pay its obligations -- not even its supreme obligation to keep its promise of relief for the unemployed
PEIPING, July 13. -- The Japanese are preparing for the final stage of their "military evacuation of Hopei Province, China.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Sufficient offers to curtail acreage planted to cotton have not yet been received by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration to justify an announcement that the cotton plan will be put in effect," Secretary Wallace said today.

Don Meade, rider of the last Kentucky Derby winner, scored a triple at Empire City yesterday. His second winner was W. H. Lipscomb's True Sweep, first in the feature. True Sweep was an indifferently backed 4-to-1 second choice in a test which saw the veteran Sun Mission, a hot favorite at 7 to 5.

In a kind of dignified coma the World Economic and Monetary Conference is fading from the scene, and no one seems to care much. Dispatches from London indicate that some of the American, delegates would enjoy a few extra hours on the world stage, but they are the only ones who want to prolong the actionless sessions.
Joseph H. Choate Jr., attorney, resigned yesterday as a member of the New York City Beer Board. He was one of the two members appointed by, the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

The Board of Estimate adopted a formal resolution yesterday asking a special session of the Legislature to permit the city to raise $41,000,000 a year in new revenue specifically to meet its unemployment relief needs.

The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange was strong and active yesterday in dealings which approximated $21,000,000. A long list of domestic corporation issues were pushed to new highs for the year on gains of 1 to 8 points and a number of foreign loans recorded their best prices for 1933 yesterday.

Following is the text of the code for the garment industry presented yesterday by the American Cloak and Suit Manufacturers Association, Inc., the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., and the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, Inc.:

Following the example set by Great Britain in organizing an Academic Assistance Council, an Emergency Committee in Aid of Displaced German Scholars has been created here to do what it can to cope with the wrong done to the university professors and Privatdozenten who are the victims of Nazi hatred.
PHILADELPHIA, July 13 (AP). -- O'Dell Hale broke up a see-saw ball game by hitting a home run with one on base in the eighth inning today, giving the Indians a 6-to-5 triumph over the Athletics.

TRENTON, N. J., July 13. -- Major William G. Sloan, State Highway Engineer, defended, today the program adopted by the road commission for disbursement of Federal funds allotted to New Jersey under the Industrial Recovery Act.

WASHINGTON, July 13. -- Determined opposition to President Roosevelt's plan to take all post-offices out of politics by bringing postmasterships under the protection of the civil service was manifest today in dozens of protests received by the Democratic National Committee.
