LONDON, July 13. -- The texts of two resolutions introduced, today at the World Economic Conference, the first on hours of work and wages and the second a substitute resolution on the rehabilitation of silver, are as follows:

Bequests of more than $150,000 were left to fourteen charitable institutions here and in Poland by Adolph Arber, retired silk merchant, the appraisal of his estate disclosed yesterday. He left $229,182 gross and $209,688 net, of which $178,530 was in securities.

Peter J. McGuinness of Greenpoint, Brooklyn's Public Works Commissioner, candidate of the "world's garden spot" for the All-America nine and erstwhile menace of the City Hall Reporters Association's annual baseball team, was batted out of the pitcher's box yesterday.

The Schenlcy Distillers Corporation, through Lehman Brothers as agent, is offering 230,000 shares of its capital stock at $15 a share. The proceeds of the offering, which are expected to be $2,890,000, will be used to provide for expansion and for other corporate purposes, including the repayment of bank loans.

Mr. ROOSEVELT has long been a friend of the merit system. In circumstances that make his act something of a disappointment and a challenge to the already angry spoilsmen, he directs by Executive Order the inclusion of Presidential postmasters, something over 15,000 in number, in the competitive classified service.

Peter Grimm, chairman of the Citizens' Budget Commission, attacked free colleges yesterday as being harmful and wasted upon many of our youths. He spoke at the New York University School of Education in the conference courses on economies in school administration, sponsored by the university's Summer school.

Peter the Great is the son of the late Mrs. Murphy, by Caliph I (also deceased). He was born thirty years ago in the environs of Fifth Avenue and, as newspapers of the period reported, was a bouncing, fifty-pound boy. Not many attended his birthday party yesterday, because it was a "pay-day" at the Bronx Zoological Gardens.
In the dim corridors and unlighted holds of the liner Leviathan at her West Seventeenth Street dock, two baboons and a monkey have made their home since last Monday.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 13. -- Herbert L. Bowman, veteran collector of tennis trophies from the New York A. C., can look back upon many a narrow reprieve during the course of a career of almost twenty years. Seldom, if ever, however, has lie salvaged a match under such dire circumstances as he did today.

Peter the Great is the son of the late Mrs. Murphy, by Caliph I (also deceased). He was born thirty years ago in the environs of Fifth Avenue and, as newspapers of the period reported, was a bouncing, fifty-pound boy. Not many attended his birthday party yesterday, because it was a "pay-day" at the Bronx Zoological Gardens.
In the dim corridors and unlighted holds of the liner Leviathan at her West Seventeenth Street dock, two baboons and a monkey have made their home since last Monday.

ST. PAUL, July 13 (AP). -- Dr. Walter Hedberg told police tonight of an incident involving a mysterious woman and marked money as a possible solution to an attack upon him by four men, who attempted to force another doctor to perform a mutilating operation upon him.

An improvement in American Shipbuilding is scheduled during the next few weeks, according to men in contact with the leaders of file industry. Several incidents are cited to show that shipbuilding has touched bottom and that the upswing is under way.

While business on the Stock Exchange was of abnormal size yesterday, Wall Street took a more conservative view of the market. Speculators were much more careful than, on the day before. The entire market community seemed to be under restraint after its excesses of Thursday.

An offer has been made to holders of General Gas and Electric Corporation 5 per cent serial gold notes providing for an exchange of present notes for the same principal amount of 5 per cent notes maturing one year later than the notes they now hold, plus $10 in cash for each $1,000 of notes deposited.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 14 (AP) -- The Jersey City club finally gained the upper hand in a free hitting game tonight, defeating the Bisons, 11 to 9, and squaring the series.

ATLANTA, July 14 (AP) -- John K. Ottley, president of the First National Bank, and two others today identified a police photograph of William, Delinski as the leader of the band that kidnapped the banker on July 6.

CHICAGO, July'14 -- Ralph Flanagan, a 15-year-old star from Miami, Fla., stole the show at the National A.A.U. outdoor swimming' championships today as the Detroit Athletic Club stars took the lead in the race for team honors.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Organized labor will marshal all its forces in a supreme attempt to gain the six-hour day and five-day week for the bituminous coal industry, according to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

GREYSTONE, N.Y., July 14 -- George McLean of Grassy Sprain, former Westchester open champion, and his amateur partner, J.F. Quirk, accounted for the principal honors in the one-day tourney of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association over the Hudson River Country Club course.
LONDON, July 14 -- The Monetary Subcommission on Permanent Measures adopted this afternoon the following resolution which had already been approved unanimously by a subcommittee:

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 14 -- Nine amphibians and seaplanes, piloted by their amateur owners and with guests aboard, took off into a brisk breeze from Manhasset Bay this morning in the third annual invitation cruise of the Aviation Country Club of Long Island.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 14 -- The Oxford-Cambridge tennis team added to 'its lead over the Yale-Harvard squad in the biennial competition for the Prentice Cup today. The invaders took three of the five matches to make the series score 7-4.

John F.A. Cecil, diplomat; Dr. Chaim Weizmann, Senator W.W. Logan of Kentucky and Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow, widow of the late United States Senator Morrow, and Judge Irving Lehman are among the passengers sailing today for Europe on the Cunarder Berengaria.

MONTREAL, July 14 -- The twenty-four silver-winged planes of General Italo Balbo's air fleet rested tonight on the swiftly flowing St. Lawrence, outside this city, after a flight across land from Shediac, the sixth leg of their daring mass flight from Italy.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 14 -- More confusion than achievement has resulted from post-war endeavors to promote world peace by the "new diplomacy" of international conferences, pacts and programs, Bainbridge Colby said tonight at the last evening meeting of the Univergity of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs.

A $6,000,000 claim against the bankrupt International Match Corporation was withdrawn yesterday by the Finanz Gesellscbaft fuer die Industrie, which will proceed instead with an action to reclaim 60,000 shares of Ohio Match Company stock.

Although wholesale commodity prices have been advancing at a rapid rate, the Department of Labor reports in its semi-annual survey a decline of 2.9 per cent in the cost of living during the first six months of 1933. The apparent contradiction is partly explained by the fact that retail prices traditionally lag behind wholesale, both on the way up and the way down.

Suffolk County, N.Y. Suffolk County, N.Y., has scheduled a new issue of $82,200 of various improvement bonds for award on July 19 at 5 P.M. The issue will comprise $5553,000 parkway bonds, due on July 1, 1934 to 1953; $134,000 highway bonds, due on July 1, 1934 to 1953; $63,000 dredging bonds, due on July 1, 1934 to 1946, 'and $72,000 veterans' relief certificates, due on July 1, 1936.
Two more units in Long Island's parkway system -- Grand Central Parkway in Queens and Northern State Parkway in Nassau County -- will be opened this afternoon.

ALBANY, July 14 -- Randall J. Leboeuf Jr., presented to the Public Service Commission today the following table of salaries of officers of the New York Power and Light Corporation, in which the first figure represents salaries for 1932 and the second salaries estimatfl for 1933 on the basis of April payments:

The three employers' associations in the cloak and suit industry, which have filed a code with the National Industrial Recovery Administration, and the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union were informed by Administrator Hugh S. Johnson yesterday that a hearing on the code would be held in Washington July 20.

JERUSALEM, July 14 -- In his report on agricultural and land development in Palestine, just revealed although it was completed more than a year ago, Lewis French, investigator for the British Government, offers a solution of the problem of doing justice to both the Arabs and the Jews.
ST. JOHN'S, July 14 -- The Lindberghs narrowly escaped a ducking this morning as their boat, carrying six persons, attempted to reach their plane for the take-off for Botwood.

BERKSHIRE HELLS, Mass., July 14 -- Mrs. John Henry Hammond was hostess today for her old sewing class at Cozy Cot, a glade in the woods at Elm Court, the Lenox estate of her mother, Mrs. Henry White. There were fifty in the party.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Allocaions made within governmental departments today in the public works program were as follows:

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 14 -- Harvard and Yale baseball players of recent years donned their Crimson and Blue lettered uniforms once more today for the eighth annual Harvard Club-Yale Club diamond battle.

LONDON, July 14 -- It has been decided to postpone until October the assembling of the Jewish conference originally planned to be held in London concurrently with the World Economic Conference. It was to have met a few days hence.
ALTON, Ill., July 14 -- The committee named to negotiate the release of the kidnapped August Luer has established contact with a band claiming to be his captors.
The dollar, pound and franc cannot be stabilized until the dollar has found its own new level in terms of present-day needs, according to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler.

Trading operations were conducted more cautiously on the Stock Exchange yesterday, but elsewhere the speculative movement was active and vigorous. All markets were strong at one time or another, although, the spectacular demonstrations of the previous few days were lacking.

Only a slight increase in the supply of North American ducks can be expected for the coming hunting season, according to a report filed yesterday with the More Game Birds Foundation, following a long and widespread survey. The supply, seriously depleted in recent years because of drought and the effects of drainage, has shown some improvement, but not enough over a wide area to change the rather drab outlook.

A two-acre plot with fifteen-room house and four-car garage at 68 Roosevelt Avenue. Deal, has been sold by Kirsch-Bryan, brokers, to Otto S. Fuerst of the brokerage firm of Anderson, Block Co. The same brokers sold a plot 205 by 275 feet on Lenox Avenue, West End, to T. Dubois for improvement with a Summer home.

Current agreements throughout the country with various theatrical unions, including stagehands, musicians, scenic designers and wardrobe women, will expire simultaneously on Sept. 1. The only exception is the New York local of the musicians' union, the contract of which has another year to run.

The Clothing Manufacturers Association of the United States of America made public yesterday the code of fair competition it had forwarded to Washington. The code establishes a forty-hour week and a minimum wage at the rate of 35 cents an hour in the North and 32 1/2 cents in South.

An important contribution to the study of Coptic architecture is the publication by the Metropolitan Museum of Art of Part 3 of "The Monasteries of the Wadi in Natrun: The Architecture and Archaeology," the third and final volume of the late Hugh G. Evelyn White's series on these Egyptian monasteries.

Reports showing decreased income and increased expenses of the Bronx Gas and Electric Company in the first four months of the year, as compared with the corresponding period of 1932, were submitted yesterday by the company at the rate hearing before the Public Service Commission.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 30 (by Mail). -- Plans to detour the Upper Nile 400 miles, possibly the biggest engineering feat since the Pyramids, have been, announced here. On the map the detour appears only as the dodging of vast swamps in the southern Sudan, but in reality it is a detour to escape the sun.
PARIS, July 14 -- Six groups of airplanes, numbering 100 machines in all, manoeuvred in formation over Paris today during the Bastile Day review of troops.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 14 -- Miss Priscilla St. George of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., riding her own clever little chestnut gelding Nehi, carried off the championship honors in the division for saddle ponies today at the tenth annual Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show.
LONDON, July 14 -- Industrials showed great activity on the Stock Exchange today, dealings starting an hour before the official opening.

Bondholders took over the thirtyeight-story Barbizon Plaza Hotel, at Sixth Avenue, Fifty-eighth Street and Central Park South, at a foreclosure sale held in the Vesey Street Exchange yesterday. The property was struck down to Ida Levine, a plaintiff representing the mortgage bondholders, on a bid of $25,000 over the prier encumbrances.
BOSTON. July 14 (AP) -- Detroit slugged its way to victory in the final game of its series with the Red Sox today, piling up an 8-to-3 score while Tommy Bridges was holding Boston to seven hits.

Prices of bonds on the New York Stock Exchange surged upward yesterday In active trading, with the best gains generally in issues which had lagged behind in the previous few days. In the domestic corporation group, utility bonds showed a better average gain than did the Industrials or rails.
RYE, N.Y., July 14 -- A beach fete was held this afternoon at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, for the benefit of the Leake and Watts Orphan Home in Yonkers.

Members of the Society of the Third Division gathered in the city from all over the United States yesterday to commemorate the fifteenth anniversary of the Second Battle of the Marne. More than 250 veterans of the division that played a conspicuous part in this and other battles are holding their annual convention at the Hotel Victoria.
Larchmont Yacht Club's annual race week, the big midsummer event for yachtsmen, will start today and continue daily, with six championship regattas and other contests, through next week.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Vincent Dailey of New York City has been named State manager for the Home Owners Loan Corporation.
Results of the Industrial Rayon Corporation and its subsidiaries for the first half of this year were decidely better than those for the corresponding period of 1932.

Lewis Prince, 40 years old, was fatally wounded late yesterday afternoon, in a pistol fight with three armed robbers in his haberdashery store at 30 Amsterdam Avenue. The thugs fled, but a man who applied soon afterward for treatment for a bullet wound at Polyclinic Hospital was arrested and identified as one of them, the police said.

Profit-taking came into many of the minor commodity markets yesterday after the unusual advances of the preceding day, but for the most part the selling was well absorbed. Rubber continued its steady advance and cocoa also was higher.
ANNAPOLIS, July 14 -- Admiral William S. Sims, retired, said today that the Naval Academy was "an amateur institution, and the average naval officer an uneducated man."

CINCINNATI, July 14 (AP) -- Holding the Reds hitless until Adams scratched a single in the sixth, Austin Moore of the Phillies won today's game, 6 to 0, and with it the seventh-place prize of the National League "cellar series."

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Congress's full authorization of $3,300,000,000 for job-making relief works will be expended, President Roosevelt announced today. Earlier an allotment of $115,513,610 from the fund was made by the Cabinet Advisory Board.

The charge that the Consolidated Gas Company system had defrauded the city and State of more than $10,000,000 in franchise taxes from 1918 to 1929 was renewed yesterday before Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- A forty-hour week and a minimum wage of forty cents per hour for men and thirty cents per hour for women were adopted at a national meeting of shop printing employers today as part of the industrial code to be presented to the national administration under the National Recovery Act.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Twenty-one of the ranking railroad presidents and executives of the country stood personally by to hear from the lips of Joseph B. Eastman, the transportation coordinator, what the administration thinks are the steps that should be taken to improve the industry.
CHICAGO, July 14 -- Forty wealthy Chicago men are being guarded as the latest step in the Federal Government's war against the reign of terror invoked by kidnappers, it was learned tonight.

Bequests totaling $70,000 were left to charitable and religious institutions by Mrs. Mary Mildred Hammond Sullivan, philanthropist and widow of Algernon Sydney Sullivan, a founder of the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell, who died at her home, 16 West Eleventh Street.

One man was shot to death, at Least four others were seriously injured and about twenty more were cut or bruised when Communists broke up a meeting of the Khaki Shirts of America, Inc., in Columbus Hall, 31-06 Astoria Avenue, Astoria, last night.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 14 -- Richard Murphy of Utica, N.Y., and Martyn Buxby of Miami, Fla., the first two seeded players, swept into the final round of the forty-first annual Longwood Bowl tennis tournament with decisive victories at the Longwood Cricket Club today.
The Polymelian colt Ha Ha, which lost only one race as a 3-year-old, dashed to his first 1933 triumph at Empire City yesterday when he captured the Round Tree Purse by three lengths.

A girl will occupy the pitcher's mound when the bearded and longlocked House of David nine goes out on a field in Middletown, N.Y., on Monday to open the season. Virne Beatrice (Jackie) Mitchell, 19-year-old southpaw who fanned Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig in an exhibition game, was signed up yesterday as the cult's twirler.

John F. Curry, leader of Tammany Hall, swelled the ranks of his active backers in the local Democratic organization last night with the election of Henry A. Thellusson as leader of the Twenty-second Assembly District. Mr. Thellusson's choice was dictated by the head of the Wigwam.

LONDON, July 14 (Canadian Press) -- Hedley Verity demolished seventeen wickets at a cost of little more than 5 runs apiece as Yorkshire increased its long lead in the county cricket championship, defeating Essex by an innings and 172 runs today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

CHICAGO, July 14 -- A broad program which touches economics in various fields, states their position in politics and their measure with men in the business world was approved in resolutions adopted by the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs today at the biennial convention's closing session.
Following is the text of the code for the men's and boys' clothing industry as presented to the National Recovery Administration:
BEAVER, Pa., July 14 -- A father, who, the police say, admits killing his 14-year-old son because he "loved him so," smiled wanly in his Beaver County jail. cell tonight and said he had no remorse.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Edward Main Post gave a dinner last night at the Central Park Casino for Mr. and Mrs. Charles U. Caesar and Mrs. Loew Burrill. Mr. and Mrs. Post will go today to Newport, R.I., to join her parents, Mr. and Mrs. W. Goadby Loew.

POONA, India, July 14 -- The conference of the Indian Congress party tonight adopted a resolution in favor of calling off the civil disobedience campaign provided an "honorable settlement" was reached between the Viceroy and Mahatma Gandhi.

LONDON, July 14 -- Demands of Danubian countries for a larger wheat export quota than overseas producing countries wished to allow were advanced so persistently at a long, lively joint meeting today that Henry Morgenthau Sr. of the "big four" wheat committee cabled Secretary of Agriculture Wallace tonight for fresh instructions.

The use of airplanes for organized law breaking is discussed by Birger Johnsen, veteran pilot, in the story of his life, "The Far Horizon," newly published by Alfred A. Knopf. Although the story is told in the first person, the writing was done by Henry Wysbam Lanier, who got the facts from Mr. Johnsen.

THE story they tell here is that tennis attendance fell off at championships because the Davis Cup has been absent so long from this country. But Great Britain hasn't won the Davis Cup since 1912 and the English tennis fans keeps filling the Wimbledon Stadium just the same.

Howard W. Charles, chairman of Charles Co., established by his father in 1848, left an estate appraised yesterday at $3,524,588 gross and $3,105,908 net, of which $2,470,622 was in securities. The bulk of his estate went to his wife and other relatives, with a remainder bequest of $40,000 to thirteen charities.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 14 -- Mrs. Dorothy Campbell Hurd, veteran Philadelphia golfer, won permanent possession of the Griswold Trophy today by defeating Miss Jane Brooks of Sparkill, N. Y., 4 and 3, in the final of the fifteenth annual women's invitation tournament of the Shenecossett Country Club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his comments yesterday on the upturn of trade and of Stock Exchange prices the financial editor of THE TIMES made some remarks which have a most important bearing on the crucial issues of the time.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP) -- Bing Miller's home run with two on base in the eighth inning gave the Athletics a 3 to 2 victory over the Indians today. The wallop also gave the Mackmen the series. 3 games to 1.

MINDEN, Nev., July 14 (AP) -- After less than a year and a half of married life, 22-year-old Elliott Roosevelt, second son of the President, filed suit here today to divorce the former Miss Elizabeth Donner of Philadelphia.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 14 -- Leonard Martin of Apawamis, former metropolitan amateur champion, led a field of fifty golfers over the first eighteen holes of the eighth annual Sweetser Victory Cup tournament at the Sunningdale Country Club today.

DETROIT, July 14 -- With application for a charter for the Manufacturers National Bank sent today to J.E.T. O'Connor, Controller of the Currency, at Washington, another new bank for Detroit is considered certain. Capital of $3,000,000, surplus of $1,500,000 and undivided profits of $750,000 are proposed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A comparative business chart has been issued by the Cleveland Trust Company covering conditions since 1927 in the United States, Canada, Germany, England, France, Belgium, Italy and Japan. It shows how these nations have been marching in step economically.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Roosevelt will decide, probably before Monday, whether to promulgrate a decree fixing minimum wages and maximum hours of labor in all industries in advance of action on detailed codes under the Industrial Recovery Act.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- A $45,000 race with not an outstanding favorite will be decided at Arlington Park tomorrow. It is the fifth running of the Arlington Classic Stakes at a mile and a quarter and may decide the 3-year-old championship of the American turf for 1933.

Wiley Post notified officials of Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, late last night that he intended taking off on his solo flight around the world at 4 o'clock this morning. The flier started at once for the field from the Hotel Roosevelt, where he had been staying.

In preparation for an Intensive drive to gain control of the Assembly and increase Democratic representation on the hoards of supervisors in up-State counties, Democratic leaders in all parts of the State have been surqmoned to attend a council of war at Elmira on Aug. 19.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 14 -- Many members of the younger set attended the first of a series of supper dances tonight at the Muenchinger King. The series is sponsored by Mrs. Lorillard Spencer, Mrs. George Henry Warren Jr., Mrs. William F. Whitehouse, Mrs. Philip Rhinelander 2d, Mrs. Lewis G. Morris, Mrs. Livingston French and Mrs. Scoville Treadwell.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Acceptances by Argentina and Colombia of invitations extended on Wednesday by the United States to undertake new trade conferences were received today by the State Department.
LONDON, July 14 -- Belief that the United States would reap a whirlwind from the present inflationary movement is expressed in the current issue of Sir Walter Layton's weekly, The Economist.

BUENOS AIRES, July 14 -- A Paraguayan communique tonight reports the capture yesterday of all Bolivian trenches fronting Fort Gondra and says the Bolivian troops in that Chaco sector are in full retreat. The Paraguayans said they were still pursuing the fleeing Bolivians tonight, capturing large quantities of arms and munitions.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (AP) -- Wealthy young Isaac D. Hetzell 2d lay near death in a hospital tonight of bullet wounds in the back. Police said they were inflicted by his constant companion, Harry Maupay, who then committed suicide.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 14 -- Two Californians, Miss Carolin Babcock of Los Angeles and Miss Alice Marble of San Francisco, reached the final round of the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club today by scoring straight-set victories over unseeded opponents.

That the June contributions by teachers and other employes in the public schools to the relief fund show an increase over the earlier months of 1933 is evidence that the pupils are not forgotten as the vacation period comes on. Though the teachers have suffered a cut in their salaries, they have not let it excuse them from giving generally and generously for the relief of the children of the unemployed.

The mutual savings banks of New York State came through the depression with $669,561,000 more deposits than, at its beginning and with 678,000 more depositors, according to the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

Two men in an automobile fired two shots at Anthony Celentano, 65 years old, a retired importer, as he was walking within a half block of his home at 976 East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. One bullet struck him in the right eye and the other scratched the right leg of Miss Marie Wilson of Avenue K and East Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, who was passing.

Throughout the Methodist Episcopal Church the one-hundredth anniversary of the death of Melville B. Cox in Monrovia, Liberia, Africa, will be observed next Friday with a day of prayer. He was the first foreign missionary of his denomination.

Discontinuance of the popularpriced concerts at the Westchester County Centre in White Plains, which have been, furnishing Jobs for three weeks to more than sixty otherwise unemployed musicians, was threatened yesterday by an action of their union.

MONTREAL, July 14 (AP) -- Newark' took its second straight game from Montreal today, 11-9, in a poorly pitched contest. The visitors shelled four home pitchers for seventeen hits. Rolfe got three of the blows.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Winnipeg furnished the sensation in the wheat markets of North America today by a break of about 3 cents early on stop-loss orders and profit-taking sales, only to react as rapidly as it had advanced and reach a new top, with the price up 2 1/2 to 2 3/4 cents from the previous day's finish.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 14 -- Mr. and Mrs. William E. Farnell gave a dinner tonight at their home for Mr. and Mrs. Leavelle McCampbell, who have joined them for the week-end. Among their other guests were Mr. and Mrs. Robert Malcolm Littlejohn and Mrs. Harris R. Childs and Valentine Andrews, who are visiting Mr. and Mrs. Littlejohn, and Mrs. Henry Graff Trevor.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 14 -- Following a day without practice, the trackmen of the Oxford-Cambridge and Frinceton-Cornell teams were on edge tonight for tomorrow's international meet which will start in Palmer Stadium at 4:30 P.M.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- The Italian air cruise from Rome to Chicago, consisting of twenty-four seaplanes flying in mass formation, is expected to reach its goal on the waters in front of the Century of Progress Exposition about noon tomorrow.
An old-fashioned Yankee hitting splurge at the Stadium yesterday propelled the Ruppert forces into a virtual tie with Washington for the league lead.
The second presentation or "Another Language" at the Waldorf Theatre will close this evening. It has been running since May 8.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Wholesalers' and retailers' shelves are about filled with merchandise bought at fairly high prices. I repeat an often-heard question, "How will people purchase commodities at higher prices when they are unable to do so at lower prices?"

Dr. William J.G. Greeff, Commissioner of Hospitals, ordered an investigation yesterday into the case of a 15-year-old boy who died, according to his parents, of an illness which an interne held to be too trivial for hospital treatment.

LONDON, July 14 -- The officers of the World Economic Conference and leading delegations, including hat from the United States, agreed today to hold a plenary session July 27 and then adjourn for a definite period.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 14 -- Fred Perry, playing brilliant tennis for England, with George Patrick Hughes ably supporting him, beat the Australian Davis Cup doubles team of Adrian Quist and Don Turnbull, 7-5, 6-4, 3-6, 6-3, today.

BERLIN, July 14 -- Although Dr. William H. Dodd will not be able to present his credentials to President von Hindenburg for some time because of the President's absence from Berlin, the new United States Ambassador lost no time in starting his work today.

BERLIN, July 14 -- The last Boerse session of the week was firm. The market's strength was based on ths declaration by the Minister of Economy that legal action would be taken against "saboteurs of business." The government's promise of tax easement also aided. Heavy industrials, Dye Trust and motor shares were among the strongest issues.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A copy of The London Chronicle of June 29 has just been received from an English friend who expresses warranted disgust with our feeble attempts to handle the gangster and kidnapper problems. On the front page is the heading "Cat for Gangsters," the following being an excerpt from the text:
U.S. Dept. of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York:

The oil tanker Cities Service Petrol sank in flames late last night 260 miles east-southeast of Cape Hatteras after thirty-four of her crew had been picked up by rescue ships in a heavy sea. Her captain, F.L. Sears, refused to he saved and sank with her.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad bought 1,400 first preferred, 6,500 second preferred and 3,200 common shares of Reading Company stock in 1932 for $273,000, or at an average of $24.65 a share for all classes, according to the B. O.'s report for last year.

CARTWRIGHT, Labrador, July 14 -- Colonel and Mrs. Lindbergh flew into Cartwright tonight and were welcomed by other members of the expedition which will explore Arctic air trails during the next few weeks.

ST. LOUIS, July 14 -- Deviating sharply from the airtight battles that have featured their meetings of recent weeks, the Giants and Cardinals went in for some toe-to-toe slugging today and to the consternation of the St. Louisans Memphis Bill Terry's band of inspired performers excelled again.

Federal Judge Robert A. Inch appointed receivers yesterday to conserve the assets of the New York Investors, Inc., of 162 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, on the application of the corporation and of John A. Selby of Chevy Chase, Md.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 14 -- Frank Shields, fifth ranking player of the United States, and Frankie Parker, gifted young national clay court champion from Milwaukee, today gained the final round of the annual Spring Lake invitation tournament.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Cotton consumption during June was the largest for any month since the Census Bureau began keeping monthly records in September, 1912.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 14 (AP) -- Robert Nolan, aged 40, who had boasted about downtown Buffalo for several days that he "knew something" about the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr., was arrested this afternoon. Several days ago he told the following story to a Buffalo newspaper:

Both Stand to Lose. It is hard to see why anybody should be anxious to prove that HITLER has Jewish blood. If this should turn out to be the case, there will be just as little satisfaction in it for the Jews as for HITLER.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The White Sox defeated the slipping Senators, 4 to 0, today, although the home team called in its pitching ace, Alvin Crowder, to stop the slump.

It has always been observed that advocates of the "commodity dollar" use not only a reasoning but a language peculiar to themselves. Thus Professor IRVING FISHER, in a speech at St. Louis on Thursday, asserted gravely that "to "stabilize this dollar so that it shall "always be 100 cents would be the "greatest of all economic reforms."
Friday, July 14, 1933. Money market was at a standstill in the matter of business and rate changes. Volume was light, and all classifications remained unchanged in quotation.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reports a net income of $66,114,510 for the first half of 1933, with June figures partly estimated, equal to $3.54 earned on each share outstanding, and comparing with $75,290,881, or $4.03 a share, earned in the first half of 1932.

PANAMA CITY, July 14 -- Discovery that there are no electrons in the cosmic rays In this region, but instead a rush of vastly charged positive particles, was announced here today by Dr. Thomas W. Johnson.

Eight consecutive weeks of increasing car loadings have resulted in substantial grains in railroad employment, according to a survey by Railway Age. Railroads in all parts of the country reported augmentation of repair forces to put equipment into condition to meet the increased demands.

Twenty-eight issues of State and municipal bonds, aggregating $15,274,847, will come up for award next week, of which $10,000,000 will be accounted for by a, single issue, that of State of Washington general obligation bonds to be sold as not exceeding 5s. This week's revised total amounted to $12,339,291, and the weekly average for the year to data to $13,246,514.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Roosevelt today signed an order authorizing a processing tax of 4.2 cents a pound on cotton, effective Aug. 1, giving the signal for the start of one of the most ambitious plans of farm relief ever undertaken in this country.
Pending a definite decision on the plan for acreage reduction, prices changed nervously yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and ended at gains of 15 to 21 points, or about 1-5 cent a pound.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Information by which investors will be expected to determine the value behind the securities offered to them has been filed with the Federal Trade Commission on more than $100,000,000 of issues in the first week's operation of the new Security Law.
COMMERCIAL PAPER Yesterday .. 1 1/2 per cent for the best names. Thursday .. 1 1/2 per cent for the best names.

John William Henry Crim, New York lawyer and former Special Assistant Attorney General of the United States, who died on July 3, last, at his estate Oakdale, in Bridgewater Township, Somerset County, N.J., criticized the "petty officials" of that county for "protecting poachers and extortionists," it was disclosed yesterday when his will was offered for probate here.

Production of new life insurance in June exceeded that of any preceding month this year and was only 10.5 per cent behind that in June of last year, the Association of Life Insurance Presidents reports.
Dwellings, apartment houses, a garage and other business buildings, as well as a theatre, figured in leasing deals yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Agriculture Adjustment Administration did some figuring today as to whether the consumer would pay more for cotton goods as a result of the 4.2 cents per pound processing tax on cotton announced as effective Aug. 1.
MONTREAL, July 14 -- The Italian air armada will take off for Chicago at 10 A.M., Eastern Daylight Time, tomorrow, General Italo Balbo, the commanding officer, announced tonight.

With the force of an extensive public opinion unquestionably behind him, Mr. EASTMAN, the Federal Coordinator of Transportation, has advised certain railway executives to cut their salaries. It is true in good times that no price is too high to pay for honest and highly skilled management.

The directors of Armour Co. of Illinois approved yesterday a plan for readjusting and simplifying the capital structure of the company. An initial issuance of 4,792,368 shares of new stock of $10 par in exchange for the preferred and two classes of common stocks now outstanding is contemplated.

Controller BERRY'S appeal to Governor LEHMAN, in the name of this city, can hardly be called a model of tact. The city is going to the State, cap in hand, asking for help, but first of all rebukes the State for bad financial management itself and for gross financial unfairness in its relations with the metropolis.

ALBANY, July 14 -- Ten officers of the New York Power and Light Corporation, large up-State utilities company, drew a total of $107,491 in salaries in 1932, it was brought out today at the Public Service Commission's hearing on rates of the corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Improved business in a number of countries was reported by the Department of Commerce today in its weekly survey of world economic conditions based on reports from its representatives abroad.

ALBANY, July 14 -- A demand by the kidnappers of John J. O'Connell Jr., nephew of Albany's political bosses, for a new list of men who might act as intermediaries in ransom negotiations stirred the family hopes anew today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 14 (AP) -- Professor Raymond P. Dougherty, Yale Orientalist and curator of the Sterling Memorial Museum, was found hanging from a tree in a wooded section of Hamden tonight after he had been missing thirty hours.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Large salaries of railroad executives are not justified under prevailing economic conditions and must be reduced, Joseph B. Eastman, Transportation Coordinator, told the heads of the principal railroads today.

Evidences of broader trade improvement were revealed in the reports received this week from all sections of the country, with the exception of a few isolated districts in the South, and were augmented by summaries of June activities which confirmed a more rapid rise and wider gains over last year's record than the weekly reports had indicated, according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet.

CHICAGO, July 14 -- Despite wind, rain and the banishment of Al Lopez the Dodgers today contrived to score their first triumph, at Wrigley Field since July 16 of last year by downing the Cubs, 5 to 3.
The inheritance of susceptibility to cancer depends on a single gene only in the original germ-cell, according to a report published in the current issue of the American Journal of Cancer, out today.

PARSONS, Kan., July 14 (AP) -- Coolly and with deadly marksmanship, Isaac McCarty, 35-year-old bank cashier, shot down two robbers in the Labette County State Bank at Altamont today and saved his wife from being kidnapped or slain.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The municipal projects approved today in the public works program were as follows:

Governor Herbert H. Lehman demanded last night that Mayor O'Brien furnish him with a "statement of facts" in connection with the city's request for an extraordinary session of the Legislature to authorize new taxes.

MOSCOW, July 14 -- The organ of Soviet heavy Industry devotes an interesting but somewhat disingenuous editorial to Soviet-American relations in connection with the cotton credit extended by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and other signs of a "political change in American public opinion regarding the Soviet Union."
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The proposed code of fair competition of the petroleum industry, submitted yesterday to the National Recovery Administration reads:

BERLIN, July 14 -- The Hitler Cabinet adopted decrees today providing for the confiscation of all property of Individuals or organizations adjudged hostile to the State and the seizure of property and withdrawal of citizenship of all critics of the government living abroad who refuse to return to Germany.

The charge that $1,500,000 of the $5,000,000 spent monthly by the city for home and work relief for the unemployed has been diverted for purposes that were eliminated from the city budget was contained in a taxpayer's suit filed yesterday in the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- When virtually the entire rayon industry and most silk producers asked to come in under the terms of the cotton textile agreement which becomes effective next week, there appeared a possibility, also, that wool textiles might make a similar request, thus putting practically the entire spinning and weaving trade on a forty-hour work week without further delay.

American exporters, fearing price competition in world markets, are prepared to ask the National Industrial Recovery Administration to exclude export sales from all price regulation, exempt the trade from Federal profit taxes and grant special rail freight rate concessions on shipments connected directly or indirectly with foreign sales, it was learned here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- General Hugh S. Johnson received today from underwear manufacturers a conditional agreement to abide by the competitive plan of cotton textile mills until a separate underwear agreement could tie drawn up.

THE word extraordinary has been prepensely chosen as the mot juste to characterize this truly extraordinary yarn. Other adjectives considered were entertaining, anomalous, amusing, Robinson Crusoesque (remember it was dismissed), absurd, incredible, lively, satirical, and the ubiquitous, inevitable and somewhat weary delightful.

NEWPORT -- While entertaining has not been very brisk thus far this Summer, some of those who have entertained and been entertained have evolved an innovation which is having much success. The plan, it appears, is to turn one party into a series of parties on the same evening.

Projects for the improvement of transportation channels in the New York port district which would involve an expenditure of about $20,000,000 are suggested as prospective investments for Federal funds under the terms of the National Industrial Recovery Act in the monthly bulletin of the Port of New York Authority.

ST. LOUIS, July 13 -- Two important decisions made by State officials this week are expected to produce material revenue for Missouri needs which are greater this year than ever before, and for which funds are scant, due to the disinclination of the last Legislature to make appropriations except for the most pressing needs.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- Confronted with labor strikes and industrial difficulties throughout the State, Governor Pinchot today disregarded the resignation, effective on Aug. 1, of Dr. A.M. Northrup, his Secretary of Labor and Industry, and dismissed him forthwith.

PITTSFIELD, Mass -- Various Berkshire activities including dances, golf and tennis at the clubs, chamber music concerts at Pittsfield and Cummington and drama at the Berkshire Playhouse in Stockbridge, are now being carried out.

The watch-tower which the United States Government maintains over the educational activities of this country has acquired a new occupant. And if present portents are correct he bids fair to have at once a clearer and a wider scope than has been granted to any previous head of the Office of Education in the nation's history.

NEWARK, N.J., July 15 -- Stepping tile second heat of the free-for-all trot In 2:10 1/2, Kedgwick, gelding trotter owned by Sam Schwartz of Plainfleld, today turned in the fastest mile trotted here this season.
All signs indicate that bluefish, the gamest of all the salt water fish which come into the waters in and near the Metropolitan area, will be running within a few days.

Sixty per cent of the midtown west side of Manhattan ia given over to industry, manufacturing, distribution and commercial uses, according to data in a survey just completed by the West Side Association of Commerce covering the area bounded by Chambers and Seventy-second Streets, Seventh Avenue and the Hudson River.

STOCKHOLM, July 13 -- The Swedish Government's current policy, sometimes described as a "milk and water" variant of President Roosevelt's policies, has been reflected in a slow rise in security prices, but to date has had little effect on food prices.

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 15 -- With victory in his grasp, Bill Feldhusen, winner of the Albany-to-New York classic, encountered motor trouble 100 yards from the finish of the Class C outboard feature of the annual South Jersey speed boat championship today.

DESPITE his millions Beadleston Preece had never had any fun. Other men considered him a dullard, while the girls all thought him prissy. Carlotta Townsend, whom he'd known since infancy when their nurses wheeled them about Central Park, took a sadistic delight in tormenting him with practical jokes; at parties she embarrassed him horribly with her outrageous remarks.
INTO a thousand new uses in everyday life in office buildings, in factories, in restaurants, in homes, in theatres, in traffic control -- comes a unique instrumentality, the electric eye.

ALTHOUGH authors have been turning a more friendly eye on the California gold hills since 1929, they occasionally make public moan concerning the very horrible things the studios do to something called their Art. The studios, in turn, are wont to keep these artists deep in the background, rarely consult them once their brain-children have been bought and even then do not take suggestions too literally.

HENRIETTA CROSMAN, the veteran stage actress who appears prominently in "Pilgrimage." at the Gaiety, is a native of Wheeling, West Va., where she was born on a certain 2d of September in the last century. Her father, George H. Crosman, an army officer, commanded the military post there.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 15 -- Automobile accidents in Nassau County decreased in the first six months of 1933, according to figures compiled by the Traffic Accident Survey of the Emergency Work Bureau.
NEW YORK. Curtis B. Dall is passing the week-end with Mr. and Mrs. C. Shelby Carter and W. Vinton King at Villa Raggio, Convent, N.J.

THE four States to vote this week will decide whether or not repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment will be accomplished before the end of the calendar year 1933. If all four should vote against ratification of the proposed Twenty-first Amendment to the Constitution, which repeals the Eighteenth Amendment, it is practically certain that repeal will not be completed by Jan. 1 next, though in any event ultimately the necessary thirty-six States will oe assured.

Dr. J.G. William Greeff, Hospitals Commissioner -- said yesterday that he would act tomorrow on a complaint of negligence in the city's ambulance service in connection with the death of a 15-year-old boy in Queens.

Alleged to have obtained $10,000 in the past two years by passing forged checks in Europe and South America, John Seda, 32, of 323 West 100th Street, was in the line-up at Police Headquarters yesterday morning. His wife, Redina, 31, arrested with him, was also in the line-up.

In an effort to save the popular-priced concerts at the Westchester County Centre in White Plains, given by unemployed musicians, Mrs. Marion Downes, sponsor of the programs, conferred here yesterday with officials of Local 802 of the Musicians Union.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 15 -- To a mounting list of notable conquests, Frankie Parker today added another victory over a member of the American first ten to crown with success his first week of the season on Eastern courts.

THE French almost always do admirably whatever they set pen to paper to write, but for this kind of book they seem to have a special gift of color, distinction and charm that lends to a story of the humblest life a quality that makes it memorable.

CHICAGO, July 13 -- If the list of projects conceived by Chicago Aldermen as lure for Federal loans falls under the eye of Secretary of the Interior Ickes, supreme custodian of the $3,300,000,000 public works fund, that commuting citizen of corporate Chicago is likely to be Shocked.

IT is natural that there should be differences of opinion between regulatory bodies, like the Aeronautics Branch of the Department of Commerce, and those whom they regulate; for example, the airplane and aircraft engine manufacturers.

TEETH are more or less off the gold standard because of President Roosevelt's monetary policy. Now industry is beginning to wonder what will happen if silver is to be remonetized. Not that remonetization means any departure from established industrial practices, but that there may be a difference in the cost of some processes.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Steel, the key industry of the nation, submitted its code of fair competition today, as did the wool manufacturers, making the day one of the most important thus far in the progress of the administration's recovery drive.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The largest organizing machine in the history of the American labor movement is working night and day in a race against time to enroll a maximum number of the nation's employes in trade unions under protection of the collective bargaining clause of the National Industrial Recovery Act.
HAMILTON, N.Y., July 15 -- Blood tests on four Colgate University boys suggest that "men of iron" may actually be "men of calcium," this white metal accounting for their emotional steadiness.

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N.J., July 15 -- Charles N. Hart of East Orange, N.J., today won the medal in the metropolitan public links championship with rounds of 76 and 74 for 150, over the Teterboro Golf Club course.

CANBERRA, Australia, July 15 -- A plan to populate the desert wilds of North Australia, her most vulnerable area, at an estimated cost of L200,000,000, is envisioned in negotiations nearly concluded between the Australian Commonwealth Government and groups of British financiers.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- Not the least important by-product of the American Legion's unsuccessful fight for prepayment of the bonus is a lawsuit which had a preliminary hearing in Federal District Court here this week and which is likely eventually to reach the United States Supreme Court.

Wiley Post's air career began fourteen years ago In a barnstormers' "Jenny." Post had joined the barnstormers as a parachute jumper. He did not stay long, but returned to his original job as an oil-well driller's helper.
LONDON, July 14 -- Each new hammer blow of President Roosevelt's domestic policy is driving the wedge of doubt deeper into British minds.

When the President appointed the delegates and experts to the World Economic and Monetary Conference, it was expected that some of them would return and others go to London in their room. At that time it was understood that Secretary HULL would come back to the United States within a few weeks and that Assistant Secretary MOLEY would then go over, Mr. COX succeeding Mr. HULL as chairman.

Detectives posing as grocers' clerks, apartment house janitors and chauffeurs assisted yesterday in the arrest of three men accused of trying to extort $10,000 from a wealthy Brooklyn physician under threat of kidnapping.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- Unfavorable Canadian crop news was the big factor today in the wheat market, whose lead was followed by all other grains. Activity was extensive, advances were made to new highs on most grains, and the volume of business was heavy.

OF that gentle type of book which, making no stir, is nevertheless most agreeable to the "gentle" reader, is Knockmaroon," by W.M. Letts. Knockmaroon, the name of a house, of an estate, somewhere in Ireland, means the hill of the rune.

OMAHA, July 13 -- Out of the Federal funds available for the relief of unemployment Nebraska has been allotted what is regarded as a generous share: $70,000,000 for miscellaneous self-liquidating public construction, approximately $8,000,000 for highway construction and $750,000 for direct relief.
Code for Science. The physics and astronomy business, in the opinion of many people, needs a code almost as badly as any of the industries now submitting their rules of etiquette to General JOHNSON.

RADIO manufacturers and broadcasters are peering ahead, estimating trends and wondering how far the industrial curve will climb between now and November when the production peak is generally reached for the year.

The great private bankers have made definite contributions to economic progress by their part in the coordination of business and industry, Professor N.S.B. Gras, Harvard economic historian, declares in an article "Do We Need Private Bankers?" in August Current History.

WILD BILL HICKOK, scout, Indian city and frontier marshal, is one hero whose exploits do not seem to shrink under the cool light of historical research. The present biography, written by the late William Elsey Connelley, secretary of the Kansas State Historical Society, after forty-two years of painstaking investigation of all possible sources, leaves him still with all the dimensions of a legendary figure.

NEW PLATS IN THE SUMMER THEATRES -- This week along the Atlantic seaboard. For those who have automobiles or ambition (and there is nothing against having both), the tryouts hold the most interest these days.

LONDON, July 14 -- An offensive against the depression will be launched at the Advertising and Marketing Exhibition to be opened Monday by the Earl of Derby beneath the great roof of the Olympia. The Prince of Wales will be a visitor Tuesday.

One woman was killed and four persons were injured, two of them seriously, late last night when a small sedan carrying seven members of a bridal party was struck by an Eighth Avenue trolley car at Central Park West and Ninety-sixth Street.

THE recent announcement of the opening of the three new links of the city's Independent Subway System -- the Bronx Concourse line, which was put into operation on July 1; the line to Queens, and the extension of the Brooklyn line, to start on Aug. 1 -- directs attention to the many miles of trackage of the three underground railways systems.

BERLIN, July 15 -- Chancellor Hitler today appointed a General Economic Council, including some of the prominent business men of the country who have participated in the process of "coordination." They are to advise the Cabinet on all economic problems on request.

WIND tunnel tests have just been completed at the Daniel Guggsnheim Aeronautical Laboratory at New York University on a new low-winged plane of flying wing type which indicate unusual performance figures. The method followed at this laboratory to calculate performance figures from wind tunnel models has consistently shown agreement with full scale flight results.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 15 -- Shoulder to shoulder they wheeled into the home stretch together at Palmer Stadium today, two titans of the track in the greatest mile race ever run. And then Jack Lovelock of Oxford outraced Bill Bonthron of Princeton in the last 100 yards to shatter the world's one-mile record with the almost incredible time of 4:07.6.
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- The American oil industry's day before the Federal recovery administration will see rival groups dumping volatile problems into the government's lap.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to me that, in all this welter of talk about higher wages and higher costs, it would be quite appropriate for those who have any sense of humor left to read the chapter entitled "Sixth Century Political Economy" in Mark Twain's "A Connecticut Yankee in KingArthur's Court."
DUBLIN, July 15 -- The Dail Eireann rose at 2 o'clock this afternoon after a continuous session lasting twenty-seven hours and forty minutes, the longest on record.

Many details for the fifty-eighth annual Westminster Kennel Club dog show to be held in Madison Square Garden, Feb. 12, 13 and 14 of next year, have already been arranged. The list of judges for the fixture was issued yesterday at the club's offices, 450 Fourth Avenue.

PARIS, July 6 -- Paris has become the leading port of France and one of the world's chief seaports -- so far as shipping tonnage handled is concerned. The greatest proportion of this shipping is, of course, that of the barges which come down the Seine or through the inland canal system of France, but many of the small ocean-going steamers now have their terminal docks in Paris.

CINCINNATI, July 15 -- Hailing a victory In the Supreme Court insuring an election of delegates to a convention to act on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, sponsors of prohibition change in Ohio are making preparations to launch an intensive drive to put the State in the repeal column.

AT this season of the year handicraft exhibitions appear in such picturesque country settings as a reconditioned barn, an artist's Summer home or studio among the trees. These informal displays, often held in artist colonies and accompanied by paintings and sculpture, generally include more of the craftsman's work than is possible in city galleries.
James C. Nunneley of Detroit has been granted official recognition of his Class F amateur outboard competition record of 50.308 miles an hour, made at the Seneca Lake regatta at Geneva, N.Y.

DESPITE the heavy toll taken by the depression in the use of many commodities, the operation of automobiles last year declined only about 6 per cent, "evidence of the unwillingness of American families and business concerns to dispense with their use."

Large institutional holders of St. Louis-San Francisco Railway bonds which heretofore have refrained from assenting to the company's reorganization plan will for the first time make public their objections at a hearing to begin before the Interstate Commerce Commission on Tuesday.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 15 -- To England goes the Bernon S. Prentice Cup for another two years. This afternoon on the Newport Casino courts the combined Oxford and Cambridge tennis teams ended their biennial team match against Harvard and Yale with a victory in the series, 12 to 8.

With the Paris market closed for the extended week-end holiday and other markets handicapped as a result, the dollar had little opportunity yesterday to adjust itself in relation to the French franc or sterling.

STATISTICS gathered by the Aeronautics Branch, Department of Commerce, continue to show a slight drop in the number of airplanes licensed in the United States. For the current period as of July 1 the department figures show a drop also in licensed pilots for the first time in more than two years.

LONDON. WHEN A.E. Housman delivered his Cambridge lecture on poetry The Times predicted, as I mentioned in a previous letter, that there would be some "pretty outcries'' when its full text came to be published.

MIAMI, Fla., July 15 (AP) -- Members of the student directorate of the University of Havana said in a statement here today they preferred "to continue our struggle against the Machado tyranny and to sacrifice our lives" rather than accept American mediation in Cuba's political affairs.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 15 (AP) -- Application will be filed for an American native mile record on behalf of Bill Bonthron of Princeton, who trailed the world record-smashing Jack Lovelock of Oxford today, but was timed off in 4:08.7 for the distance.

CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs trimmed the idle New York Giants' lead in the National League race to three and one-half games today as Charley Root shut out the Boston Braves, 4 to 0, with six hits in the opening game of the series.
LONDON, July 15 -- All agreements having been-swept-aside, the circulation war between The Herald, The Daily Express, The News Chronicle and The Daily Mail is proceeding unabated.

More than fifty girl swimmers and divers from all parts of the United States and a few from Canada have contributed 126 entries for the women's national A.A.U. outdoor aquatic championships, sponsored by The Daily News. They will be decided in four days of competition at Jones Beach State Park, L.I., starting Thursday.

Although complete European costumes of the seventeenth century are exceedingly rare and are seldom seen in museum galleries, here or abroad, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has been able to acquire an English Winter dress of about 1690, which is called "perhaps the finest example of its period in existence."
MINEOLA, L.I., July 15 -- Sundance, a bay gelding owned by Joe Andrews of Mineola, made his debut at the Nassau thriving Club matinee today and won the 2:20 mixed race.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 15 -- Unmoved by bitter complaint of public officials against their "utter lack of cooperation" in the investigation into the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr., the captive's uncles grimly insisted that they would continue their negotiations for ransoming their nephew and ignore the police.

TROY, N.Y., July 15 -- Two long-driving youngsters from opposite ends of New York State, Tommy Goodwin of Monroe and Dick Stewart of Buffalo, will meet tomorrow on the Troy Country Club links in a thirty-six-hole match for the State junior golf championship.

FOR the past six weeks the ominous throb of the tomtom has been heard on the plains of Astoria, and the Queens trappers, fearing an uprising of the Arapahoes or a pillaging expedition of the crafty Sioux along the banks of the Interborough, have been feverishly engaged in reinforcing their stockades and burnishing their flintlocks.
CAIRO, July 14 -- Instead of subsiding, the Moslem anti-missionary campaign seems to be gaining momentum daily.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 15 (AP) -- J. Allison Buck, 36, who quit his Wilmington grocery store about ten years ago to become Delaware's best-known pilot, and John Moran of Hempstead, L.I., N.Y., an inspector of the Aeronautics Division of the Department of Commerce, were killed late today while testing a new-type airplane.

PETER FREUCHEN, the Danish Arctic explorer, wants the world to know that at least one coming picture is authentic. He refers to "Eskimo," the cinematic version of his book, which is now about completed after seventeen months of preparation and production in and out of the Arctic Circle.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Active speculation on the date of recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States -- considered a certainty before Fall -- was renewed here today with the discovery that voluminous "records stored in the old Russian Embassy on Sixteenth Street were being sorted.

DUBLIN, July 13 -- The government's policy on Communist activity in the Free State was outlined in the Dail Eireann this week by President de Valera when he was questioned by the Opposition Deputy Daniel Morrissey as to whether public bodies had made representations to the government to have all Red organizations outlawed.

MOTORISTS concerned about the advisability of driving to the World's Fair in Chicago need not fear that conditions in the city will be unsatisfactory, according to The Oil and Gas Journal, whose Chicago correspondent has been surveying the field.
CHICAGO, July 15 -- A rousing victory in the 880-yard relay sent the Los Angeles Athletic Club out in front in the race for team honors in the National A.A.U. outdoor swimming championships today.

PARIS, June 26, 1933 TWELVE years ago musicians and critics met at Salzburg to hear the first International Festival of Modern Music. The society so well satisfied the curiosity as to what had been written during the war that its success was immense.

To The Editor of The New York Times: The depression has been a supreme test of our mercifulness, our loving kindness. Most of us have made sacrifices of one sort or another, willingly or unwillingly, With good or bad grace.

Joe Feldman of Clearview became the New York State public links titleholder yesterday. He triumphed over Charles W. Kehrer of the home course, 2 and 1, in the thirty-six-hole final match of the second annual championship tournament on the Forest Park links in Queens.

LATONIA, Ky., July 15 (AP) -- Assuming command when ready the F.L.B. Stable's consistent 2-year-old, Ding Bin, scored a handy victory over the best juveniles in training here to account for the thirty-second running of the $2,500 added Cincinnati Trophy today.
THIS gossipy personal biography of the last of the Elder Statesmen of Japan is a valuable addition to the small number of works by competent Japanese scholars which are available in English.

The defending champion, Frank Bowden, blazed the trail into the quarter-final round as play began yesterday in the sixth annual Richmond County clay court men's singles tennis championship at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, S.I.

THE esteemed J.J. Dykes of the White Sox was in good voice yesterday. He had come from Washington and was headed for the Bronx. He paused at noon to flick the ashes from a stout cigar and deliver a little discourse on the American League campaign.

The performance of the market for United States Government bonds is running true to form in its relation to the speculative interest that is being displayed in domestic corporation issues and foreign loans. The government's longterm issues have been virtually neglected.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- More than 100,000 Chicagoans and World's Fair visitors, massed on and near the Navy pier, roared a tremendous welcome late this afternoon to 100 gallant Italian airmen under command of General Italo Balbo as they brought the first of their twenty-four huge seaplanes safely to rest on the waters of Lake Michigan at 6 P.M., Central Daylight Time [7 P.M. in New York.]

SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 -- With the return of Senator Hiram W Johnson from Washington political sages and seers have been spurred to renewed crystal gazing with the 1934 Senatorial campaign well within the field of vision. Some of the prophets see the Senator running as an independent as the surest way of resolving a situation he created when he bolted the Republican Presidential ticket last November.

To The Editor of The New York Times: The depression has been a supreme test of our mercifulness, our loving kindness. Most of us have made sacrifices of one sort or another, willingly or unwillingly, With good or bad grace.

Joe Feldman of Clearview became the New York State public links titleholder yesterday. He triumphed over Charles W. Kehrer of the home course, 2 and 1, in the thirty-six-hole final match of the second annual championship tournament on the Forest Park links in Queens.

LATONIA, Ky., July 15 (AP) -- Assuming command when ready the F.L.B. Stable's consistent 2-year-old, Ding Bin, scored a handy victory over the best juveniles in training here to account for the thirty-second running of the $2,500 added Cincinnati Trophy today.
THIS gossipy personal biography of the last of the Elder Statesmen of Japan is a valuable addition to the small number of works by competent Japanese scholars which are available in English.

The defending champion, Frank Bowden, blazed the trail into the quarter-final round as play began yesterday in the sixth annual Richmond County clay court men's singles tennis championship at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, S.I.

THE esteemed J.J. Dykes of the White Sox was in good voice yesterday. He had come from Washington and was headed for the Bronx. He paused at noon to flick the ashes from a stout cigar and deliver a little discourse on the American League campaign.

The performance of the market for United States Government bonds is running true to form in its relation to the speculative interest that is being displayed in domestic corporation issues and foreign loans. The government's longterm issues have been virtually neglected.

SINGAPORE. SUPPOSING after the heat of the day you are looking for a bit of diversion in the damp cool of the evening. There is the New World carnival park at the sign of the electric-lighted pagoda. No stranger in town is likely to find it, although the pagoda holds its pleasure beacon high above the native tenements.

Captain Stephen Darius and Stanley Girenas, the Lithuanian-Americans, now citizens of Chicago, who are flying to their homeland, turned many corners before they qualified as candidates for transatlantic honors.

THE state of the sentimental cinema has not been notably affected by the entrance of "Pilgrimage" on the Broadway scene. Pictures in other years have been as skillful in eliciting the maidenly tear, the manly clearing of throats.

The boosting of prices of commodities and manufactures, one of the avowed objects sought to be achiaved in the enforcement of the National Industrial Recovery Act, is no doubt a timely and helpful influence in bringing about a successful administration of the New York State retail sales tax.

I am off to better my own record for flying around the world -- 8 days 15 hours and 51 minutes -- made in 1931 with Harold Gatty as navigator. I'm sure I can do it, probably by two days, although this time I am going alone.
LONDON, July 5 -- It is Interesting to try to outline the situation in Europe as it appears to responsible observers in London. For big things are happening or are about to happen on the Continent.

With five of the six series moving ahead, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has again scored a gain of slightly more than one point to the highest levels since May 27, 1930. For the week ended July 8, the number was 98.7, as compared with a revised figure of 97.6 for the previous week and 65.4 for the corresponding week of last year.

DETROIT, July 15 (AP) -- Observing that Hugh S. Johnson, Administrator of the Industrial Recovery Act, was "in a pretty tough spot," but would be "a hard man to fool," Henry Ford said in an interview today that everything thus far indicated that the government was acting with good intention in carrying out its program.
HOLLYWOOD'S busy little problem-solvers, the men who first discovered it was possible to bring the mountain to Mohammed, are still taking them in full stride.

DR. LEE DE FOREST, inventor of the three-element vacuum tube, was in New York last week with enthusiastic words for California, where he now lives. He is optimistic about television and it will be recalled that Dr. De Forest's aim for some time has been to enlarge the images so that they may be projected on theatre screens.

GENOA. TO write properly about Dante," in the opinion of Papini, "one should be a Catholic, a Florentine and an artist." In short, one should be Signor Papini himself. As this opportunity is not open to every one, he has concluded that it is up to him to write this book, and so he has written it.

SOME six months ago a shabbily dressed man entered the office of the State Education Department in Buffalo. In the days of prosperity he had been an automotive engineer; two large companies had vied for his services as a designer of new cars.

The New York Curb Exchange admitted yesterday to unlisted trading the new capital stock of Armour Co., which has a par value of $10 a share. The initial transaction in the stock was 2,000 shares at 12 3/s, and the closing price was 11 3/4.

No plane has taken off heretofore on a distance quest equipped with so many devices for the safety and convenience of the pilot as the Winnie Mae, carrying Wiley Post on an attempt to break his own round-the-world record.
From beneath Piers 28 and 29, East River, yesterday at noon came the sound of thrashing waters. A crowd gathered and sent in an alarm, for a police emergency squad.

A NINE-YEAR-OLD boy, Larry Butler, sang "You're in the Money" and in the language of the theatre he "stole the show" on the new program Ed Wynn abandoned to act in a talking picture. Wynn eavesdropped in California as the youthful personality starred on the air across the countryside, and he wired that he hoped the sponsor missed him but not professionally.
A meeting of employes of the North German Lloyd Line, 57 Broadway, has been called for tomorrow at 5:30 P.M. to form a national Socialist industrial organization.

The annual Brookville horse show for the benefit of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children in Nassau County will be held on July 30 on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Davis. As in former years Mrs. James H. Van Alen is treasurer of the show.

Both retail trade and wholesale market activity here registered gains last week. The improvement in retail trade since July 4 has been such as to indicate that dollar volume of local department stores for the first half of this month will run only about 2 per cent under the corresponding period a year ago.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 15 -- Making the round of the outside course without the semblance of a fault, and rated along at a smart hunting pace by Miss Caral Gimbel, Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel's upstanding hunter. His Elegance, came home today to win the Bedford challenge trophy presented by F.T. Bedford in the colorful Corinthian class.

The new supply of crude oil in May was 86,953,000 barrels, the largest for that month since 1829, and an increase of 18.1 per cent over the 73,613,000 barrels in May, 1932, according to a compilation by William J. Kemnitzer, oil technologist, based on figures issued by the United States Bureau of Mines.

BOGOTA, July 13 -- The regular annual four-month session of Congress which opens here July 20 offers President Olaya a final opportunity to complete the administration's legislative program, as his term of office will expire early in the 1934 session.

A NOVEL of this quality, supported by R.H. Mottram's fine prose, brings to mind the power that lies in simple, perfected character creation, the significance in literary art of mere people, unique and compelling, drawn with poetic insight and breathed upon with the ether of life.

A movement is under way to purchase the country home of the late Elisabeth Marbury, leader in the atrical, literary and political life in this city, in Mount Vernon, Me., and maintain it in perpetuity as a memorial to her life and ideals.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 15 -- Three gunners broke 50 straight targets in the regular shoot of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. They were R.H. Helsel, P.E. Gardner, who shot for targets only, and N. Apgar, a professional. The last named two were not eligible, so the scratch trophy was taken by Helsel.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Walter Stewart and Bob Burke, Washington left banders, pitched shut-out ball today in a double header with the St. Louis Browns. The l-to-0 and 2-to-0 victories pushed the firstplace Senators a half game ahead of the Yankees.

Crude rubber futures, scoring one of the widest gains of this year in the heaviest Saturday trading on record, were the feature in local commodity markets yesterday. The general movement was irregular. Cash prices were higher.
LONDON. THERE is much talk in Great Britain of reviving some of the old English spas, of which Epsom, scene of the Derby, was one of the most popular.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 15 -- Sounding the national administration's call for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, Postmaster General Farley called upon the voters of three Southern States next week to follow the example of the sixteen other States which have already endorsed repeal.
BERLIN, July 15 -- After languishing forty-two years, the German Society for Combating Anti-Semitism has voted to disband.
UNCLE SAM might very reasonably advertise "bootleggers for sale." He has a great many of the breed of which he soon must make some disposition.

WINNIPEG, Man., July 12 -- Western Canada, which lives by wheat export, has watched closely the discussion of wheat policy at the World Economic Conference and has noted with surprise, and in some quarters even consternation. Prime Minister R.B. Bennett's pledge that this country will coaperate in wheat-acreage reduction.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In looking over Mr. Bullard's article in THE TIMES, entitled "Religious Groups Begin Meetings," I note no mention of the Green Acre Conferences, held each Summer at Eliot, Me.
CHICAGO, July 15 -- Signs of the normal July slackening in retail trade were routed, temporarily at least, by a heavily advertised State Street dollar day. Stores in the Loop were jammed by shoppers.

THE brief stories on these pages tell of the progress made by the Hundred Neediest Cases of 1932 during the six months since the publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Christmas of the Twenty-first Annual Appeal.

ALBANY, July 15 -- The invitation to an official reception, at Albany extended to General Italo Balbo, commander of the Italian air armada now at Chicago, by Governor Lehman, through a letter personally handed to the Italian Air Mlniater by Senator J. Griswold Webb in Chicago, was made public today.

The sales at auction of the collateral pledged by Continental Shares, Inc., one-time $187,350,000 investment holding company managed by Cyrus S. Eaton, the Cleveland financier, yielded an aggregate amount of $34,972,000 to the banking institutions which had advanced funds to the company on and after Oct. 28, 1930.
Does college, as if often charged, make its students critical of home conditions? Apparently it does, at least out among the girls at Iowa State College.

TOKYO, July 15 -- The Japanese ress, which while the United States was holding a private voluntary naval holiday refrained from ceriticising the Japanese Navy's plans, displays unhappiness now that the United States is to resume building.

TOKYO, June 23 -- While the sixty-six nations in London are discussing currency depreciation, Japan and India are experiencing its effect in the form of an economic war in which the stages to date have been first a boom in Japanese exports, directly due to the fall of Japanese exchange, then a prohibitory tariff imposed by the Indian Government on Japanese textiles, and now a boycott of Indian raw cotton by Japanese spinners.

The momentum of the business recovery was unabated last week, with major industries, wholesale trade and indices of activity all showing further lift and retail trade gaining somewhat more than had been anticipated at the end of the half year.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, C., which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

A decision by Supreme Court Justice Schmuck yesterday disclosed a proceeding by Mrs. Muriel McCormick Hubbard of Middletown, Conn., granddaughter of John D. Rockefeller, for the payment to her at once of four-sevenths of the principal of a trust fund of $8,000,000 created by Mr. Rockefeller for her mother, the late Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick.
