IN JULY the well-kept flower garden offers a consolation and an assurance to the human world. The consolation consists of lovely sights and sweet odors. palliatives that take immediate effect against almost any mental pain.

CALLING this collection of photographic reproductions "a photographic song without words," Alfred F. Loomis explains that his book is an attempt to show pictorially "the dramatic action and the intrinsic beauty at the yacht under sail."
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 15 -- A blue and white dance was held tonight at the Larchmont Yacht Club in celebration of the opening of the annual race week.

PARIS, July 6 -- A movement recently started in legal and Parliamentary circles for the suppression of the French penal colony in Guiana has found popular support and in all probability will be brought to an issue at the next meeting of Parliament.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 15 -- A far from peaceful world, wavering between nationalism and internationalism while war clouds gather over it, was pictured in the closing discussion's today of the round-table sessions of the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

Several presidents and professors of educational Institutions will preach in New York churches today. In at least two instances clergymen will return to the city from their Summer homes to deliver sermons especially addressed to students in the Summer schools of the several universities and colleges.

The present-day trend toward centralization of economic control in the United States will result in an "economic tyranny" more powerful than any political dictatorship, Dr. Florian Znaniecki, Professor of Sociology at the University of Posen, Poland, declared yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 15 -- Van S. Merle-Smith sailed the 12-meter sloop Cantitoe to a winning margin of 3 minutes and 22 seconds over Horace Havemeyer's Mouette, runner-up boat, over a nineteen-mile course on Long Island Sound today.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 13 -- Throughout the South the various cotton manufacturers have been foregathering to approve the textile code and discuss the beneficent result of government control in business. And while the manufacturers were agreeing on their procedure, the farmers were accepting Federal proposals for drastic reduction of cotton acreage.

Among the medievalists of our day the late KINGSLEY PORTER, drowned off the Irish coast, occupied a knightly position. Endowed with all the gifts of person and fortune, he used them for the furtherance of disinterested studies. He was of a delicate scrupulousness, sensitive and idealistic to a fault.

ON a cold dry day we hear sounds for greater distances than on a hot humid day. Over blistering desert sands hearing in the open is at its worst. Why there should be these differences is something that Dr. Vern O. Knudsen has been studying at the University of California, with Dr. H. O. Kneser of the University of Marburg, Germany, who is now in this country, thanks to a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine today Professor and Assistant Secretary of Agriculture TUGWELL outlines the philosophy of the New Deal. His article will attract attention, if for no other reason, by its literary charm. One feels the cultivation, the poetry, the elegance of style, not unaccompanied, perhaps, by some vagueness of thought and expression that stamps the true academic.

WITHIN the month a twenty and twenty-one hour air service between San Francisco and New York has been established. It Is actually feasible to put newspapers on the streets of Los Angeles on their date of publication in New York.

IN recent years there has been a remarkable increase in the wild life of Jasper National Park, in Alberta, a park set aside by Canada as a sanctuary. It is estimated that the number of bighorn sheep in the Athabaska Valley has doubled within a few years.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 15 -- By the deft process of guille overcoming brawn, Great Britain conquered Australia's tennis forces today and now will head for France and a battle with the United States in the interzone final next weekend for the right to challenge France for the historic Davis Cup.

THIS quaint and very delightful little volume is introduced with such humility by its author in his preface as being merely "the work of scissors and paste" that the reader has no intimation of its unusual and charming quality until he delves into its pages.

The establishment soon of a uniform price structure for crude oil in the Mid-Continent and Texas areas is considered probable in the industry. Since the posting, about two weeks ago, of an advance of 33 cents a barrel by the Continental Oil Company in the Mid-Continent and an increase of 25 cents by the Consolidated Oil Corporation, two or more price structures have been in effect in those areas.

HOLLYWOOD. THE humor of Will Rogers brought the comedian a victory this week when Fox acceded to his request that the name of his newest picture be called "Dr. Bull." Behind the change is an amusing inside story which indicates how Mr. Rogers has won his points in the innumerable controversies he has had with the studio.

TODAY, perhaps as never before, industry is faced with a series of complex problems centring around the adjustment of personnel to rapidly changing conditions of work. Shortening the hours of work, for example, raises the question of how hours should be distributed through the week so as to make most effective use of the productive capacity of the worker and to reduce to the minimum the fatigue produced by work.

"Slums are an economic blight and cause colossal financial loss to both their owners and the city," declared Clarence S. Stein of the New York" Chapter of the American Institute of Architects yesterday in a statement urging a new technique of city building in which individualistic haphazard methods are discarded.

Competition for the increasingly profitable speculative patronage was intensified last week, with grain and cotton frequently stealing the spotlight from the stock market. Trading in commodities was heavier than in many years, possibly heavier than ever before in the history of organized markets.

The take-off of the LithuanianAmerican fliers, Captain Stephen Darius and Stanley T. Girenas, from Kloyd Bennett Field yesterday morning was one of the most hair-raising ever made from a New York field.

SOME of the lagging tendencies which featured local retail trade earlier in last month were lacking last week and sales showed improvement. Estimates indicate that dollar volume of department stores in the metropolitan area for the first half of this month win run around 2 per cent under the corresponding period a year ago.

ARDSLEY, N.Y., July 15 -- Miss Dorothy Duggan of Greenwich, Conn., established a new world's record while competing in the Westchester County Archery Association's annual tourney at Woodlands Park today.

BAR HARBOR -- With the opening of Bar Harbor's own Summer theatre this week, the tempo of its social life is moving into a lively allegro. The Surry Players, who, under the direction of Leighton Rollins, have added much both socially and artistically to the gayety of the past four Summers, are still the "Surry Players," although they have deserted their Forest of Arden hillside in Surry for the sidewalks of Bar Harbor.

Housewreckers began last week tearing down the old-fashioned residence at the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street. The house for more than twenty years was the home of D. Willis James, father of Arthur Curtisa James, former commodore of the New York Yacht Club and owner of the steam yacht. Aloha.

James Loeb, New York banker and philanthropist, left his residuary estate of more than $1,000,000 to a German institution. Mr. Loeb, whose father, Solomon Loeb, was one of the founders of Kuhn, Loeb Co., also bequeathed nearly $2,000,000 to charities and institutions of learning here and abroad.

NEWPORT, N.Y., July 15 -- Speaking here today under the auspices of the Herkimer County Republican organization, W. Kingseland Macy, chairman of the Republican State Committee, called upon Republicans of the State to support President Roosevelt's efforts to hasten the return of prosperity.

Consumption of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States in June established a new high record, with a total of 51,326 long tons, it was announced yesterday by the Rubber Manufacturers Association. This compares with 44,580 tons for May, and represents an increase of 23.8 per cent over the total of 41,475 tons for June, 1932.

THE threatened diversion of the Yellow River from its present outlet in the Gulf of Po to its old mouth, 250 miles south in the Yellow Sea, recalls previous similar behavior on its part and that of other rivers. The Yellow River, which has altered its outlet five times within 4,300 years, last emptied into the Yellow Sea in 1852.
ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Finals in the men's tennis doubles to determine the championship in this net class on the North Jersey coast, will be played at the Bathing and Tennis Club at Spring Lake today.

BUFFALO, July 15 -- Jim McCloskey Day was celebrated here today in honor of Jersey City's southpaw pitcher, but he was defeated by Buffalo in the ninth inning to mar a celebration by his friends and neighbors from nearby Lancaster.

SEATTLE, July 13 -- Although this is the year for a plentiful run of sockeye salmon through the waters of Washington, there is little likelihood that the pack will be anywhere near as large as it was twenty years ago. Due to overfishing and the refusal of Washington fisherman to agree to the treaty now pigeonholed in the United States Senate, the richest sockeye salmon fishery in the world is all but exhausted.
BUDAPEST, July 14 -- The appearance of any Central European Premier in a foreign capital usually has the effect on statesmen and the press of a hawk among pigeons.
Two airplanes roared away from Floyd Bennett Field yesterday morning and were heading out over the Atlantic last night on adventures that revived the thrills of the earliest transoceanic flights.

DBS MOINES, Iowa. GONE are the agonized uncertainty and the gnawing fear of dispossession which precipitated the farmer's mutinous mood of last Winter. His gnarled hands enjoy once more the half-forgotten caress of paper money in lieu of the nickels and dimes of recent years.

American dog shows of the better class have reached a high degree of efficiency. Nowhere in the world are canine exhibitions staged with such minute attention to details of organization. In such matters as benching, arrangement of judging sings, catalogs and other accessories of an all-breed show conditions have improved immeasurably within the last decade.

Trading in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday was active with price fluctuations generally confined to narrow ranges in the domestic list. In the foreign group, however, many issues were lifted 1 to more than 7 points to new high levels for the year to date.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va -- The annual West Virginia State open tennis tournament will open on the courts of the Greenbrier Lawn Tennis Club tomorrow with a large field of players from this State, Maryland, Washington, D.C., Pennsylvania, Ohio and Virginia.

Wholesale market activity was at its best for the season last week, due to the earlier-than-usual arrival of many out-of-town buyers, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. Most of the actual purchasing was concentrated on style merchandise, such as ready-to-wear, furs, knitwear millinery, shoes and back-to-school apparel.

I AM a theatrical manager. Even so I have recently been thinking. My thoughts have been considerably concerned with the realistic theories of Moran and Mack, those two economists. Students of economics who attend the cosmic classrooms will recall that Moran once confided a doleful discovery to the microphones when he revealed that he had sold for $5 a hog which had cost him $6 to raise.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) -- Jimmy Foxx's single with the bases filled in the eleventh inning gave the Athletics a hard-fought victory over the Tigers today, 3 to 2. Foxx's blow sent home two runs after Gerald Walker had broken a 1-1 tie by hitting a home run in the first half of the eleventh.
The major sports events for women this week are the New York State golf championship and the national outdoor swimming and diving competitions.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 15 -- More than 100,000 men employed In the steel industry today received word their wages are going up.

CRISFIELD, Md., July 15 (AP) -- President Roosevelt interrupted his cruise of the Chesapeake Bay today to land at Crisfield early this afternoon for a motor trip on Maryland's picturesque eastern shore.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 15 -- With their riding lights bobbing eerily in the pitch black night, twenty auxiliary cruising yachts sailed away at 10:30 P.M. tonight on the third annual Riverside Yacht Club 50-mile race to Stratford Shoal and return.

AUTOMOTIVE authorities are looking for a Fall rise in business such as they anticipated in pre-depression years. During the last three years both motor car and tire sales have slumped in the Fall. This year, with produce prices rising, farmers are seen as heavy buyers of motor equipment, providing enough stimulus to reverse the depression trend.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated July 13:
CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 15 (AP) -- An era of higher pay and a shorter working week dawns Monday for half a million textile workera in the United States.

Ten thousand refugee women and children crowded the American Mission Compound and Jefferson Academy campus in Tunghsien, near Peiping, North China, during the recent Japanese hostilities, reports Rev. Harry W. Martin of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions and native of Spring Valley, Wis., in the first detailed account which has reached the Boston headquarters.

A Summer Demonstration School, in which teachers from all parts of the country attend the same classes as the pupils, has been established by Teachers College, Columbia University, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Rollo Reynolds, principal of the Horace Mann School and director of the demonstration school.

BERLIN, July 15 -- A total of thirty laws, some of the most farreaching effect on German life as well as Germany's standing in the world, were passed by the Cabinet in its session yesterday, which lasted from 11 A.M. until midnight.
Two tankers were pounding heavy seas toward Charleston, S.C., last night with the survivors of the lost tanker Cities Service Petrol which blew up and sank on the North Carolina Coast Friday night.

THE manner in which rare books passed their crucial test at the Rosebery auction last month has brought rejoicing to the camp of the book trade's well-wishers. In the first major engagement since the economic chaos had laid its heavy hand upon book prices there was demonstrated the old.

THOUGH Internationalism is a tenet upon which much hope rests for the future of the dance, as well as for other branches of human activity, it Is time that a word be said for the American dance even at the risk of chauvinism.

THE records of cosmic-ray intensity that Professor Auguste Piccard brought back from his two ascents into the stratosphere left much to be desired scientifically. In a book which he brought out last year he says himself that the observations made on the first ascent were virtually worthless, and that those made on the second were not as complete as physicists wished.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Professor Pieron's speculations on life, thinking and perception have a deeper significance than would appear on the surface, although his position is not tenable from a scientific standpoint because it does not lend itself to proof.

HARTFORD, July 13 -- Connecticut, which has never been a State to complain about hard times nor boast about prosperity, is welcoming with a quiet, but deep-seated satisfaction the general signs of better business. In all parts of the State, according to the observations of the factory inspectors of the State Department of Labor, industrial conditions are better.
IMPROVEMENTS designed to handle automobile traffic more expeditiously and provide adequate parking facilities have marked recent activities at shore resorts and beaches in the metropolitan area.
DURING a month of uncertainty and anticlimax, at least one outstanding development has taken place. That is the improvement in the relations between Soviet Russia an the United States.

IT now appears that Walter Slezak will be In "The Pursuit of Happiness" when Connecticut gets a look at the work next week. If that does nothing else, it will end a saga which reads like the moves of a major Versailles. For the Westport pursuit of Walter Slezak has been a lengthy one and complicated.

THE permanent preservation of one of the most distinctive natural features in the United States east of the Mississippi River is made possible by the offer of John D. Rockefeller Jr. to contribute 265 acres of land, valued at $5,000,000, for a new parkway to run from the George Washington Bridge to the New Jersey-New York State line along the crest of the Palisades.

LONDON, July 15 -- The World Economic Conference is now in the first phases of that sleep which has been decreed as its safest course until some time in the Autumn. Nothing happened today save a little golf between showers and nothing is expected to happen before Monday.

THE season of outdoor orchestral concerts at the Hollywood Bowl, California, began last Wednesday after difficulties and delays which threatened, a cancellation of the entire enterprise. Alfred Hertz, conducting the Philharmonic Orchestra of Los Angeles for his tenth consecutive season, gave a program beginning with the "Lohengrin" prelude, followed by Tchaikovsky's Fifth symphony, Korngold's "Much Ado About Nothing" suite and Johann Strauss's ''Wine, Women and Song."

THE title of this novel is somewhat misleading. "Kept Man" proves to be less the story of Val Sellers than of Frankie Hart, the unsophisticated and warm-hearted young girl who loves him too well for her own good. The narrative opens in the little provincial English village of Opham, where Frankie's father is a school-master.

LAWYERS undoubtedly will be quick to appreciate the value of the analysis of the National Industrial Recovery Act by Mr. Kirsh and his collaborator. It will prove particularly welcome to those specializing in providing legal advice to trade associations.

THE recent controversy regarding the use of the lower reservoir site in Central Park has directed attention to Manhattan's parks and playgrounds. Although many in number, they are not considered adequate for the borough's population.

MORE and more articles on air-conditioning appear in the engineering press -- a sign that the day is not far distant when, however sultry the weather may be in the street, a man may do his work indoors in comfort. That the apparatus for conditioning is in existence is evident enough when we enter a motion-picture house or one of the newest trains.

ST. LOUIS, July 15 (AP) -- Don Hurst doubled and Wes Schulmerich singled in the tenth inning today to score a run and give the Phillies a 3-to-2 decision over the Cardinals and the Red Birds sank deeper into fourth place.
More than 3,000 delegates from many parts of the country are expected to attend the national convention of the United States Building and Loan League in Chicago, Sept. 13, 14 and 15.
MONTREAL, July 15 -- Montreal collected sixteen hits against Vito Tamulis and Al Mamaux today to defeat Newark, 7-5, in the third of a five-game series.

THERE is increasing evidence of a broad recovery of business and employment not only in the United States but in many foreign countries. This recovery is not limited to the industrial nations, to the nations with depreciated currencies or to those Which have avoided such depreciation.

Further details of the plan by which the Equity Corporation group is acquiring a dominating interest in the United Founders Corporation were revealed in the June 30 statement of Equity. A syndicate of the companies composing the Equity group has subscribed 51,150,000 to buy two-thirds of United's Class A management stock and a block of several hundred thousand shares of the common.

When people familiar with economic history made the prediction, a year or two ago, regarding the "turn in the cycle" which all of them. Relieved would come, they were apt to foreshadow much the kind of recovery that has occurred this year. They recalled, at the turn from pre-war depressions, the sudden and extremely violent rise in stocks, the unexpectedly rapid increase in production and trade activity, the swift advance in prices of commodities.

NEXT month about 100,000 men will be at work on highways and related projects under the $400,000,000 Federal road fund authorized by the National Industrial Recovery Act, Thomas P. Henry, president of the American Automobile Association, estimates.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the most curious results of the arrival of Adolph Hitler at supreme power in Germany has been the general improvement in international relations in more than one quarter, but noably as concerns the relations of France and Italy and Italy and Yugoslavia.

LAKE PLACID, -- Arrangements for the fourth, annual Lake Placid Horse Show and the second annual Mid-Summer Ice Carnival will be advanced at meetings to be held this week. Both events are to take place on Aug. 18 and 19.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In his recent letter THE TIMES John D. Connaughton asked the following questions:

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 15 -- Robert A. Lester, 24-year-old New Jersey golfer, who celebrated his return to the game this season by going to the final round in the Jersey State and the semi-final round in the metropolitan amateur, achieved a signal victory on the links today.

THE news published last week to the effect that two coal-tar derivatives have heen discovered which invariably produce cancer is not news at all to specialists. One of these derivatives is known as 1:2:5:6 dibenanthracene. It was discovered by Drs. Cook and Kennaway of London.

PARIS, July 13 -- Worth's aigrette fan headdress, worn on the back or the side of the head, delightfully echoes a useless matching fan which is slung from the wrist. Shoe buckles are infected by the latest symptoms of the ornithological fashion fever.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

Frederic Kernochan, Chief Justice of the Court of Special Sessions, is receiving consideration from the representatives of the several fusion groups who are drafting the anti-Tammany slate, as candidate for District Attorney of New York County to succeed Thomas C. T. Crain.

THE recent report that five Americans are facing courtmartial on charges of assaulting a member of the civil guard at Palma, principal city of Majorca, has directed attention to this garden spot in the Mediferranean.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 6 (AP) -- The Graf Zeppelin arrived here late today on its third trip of the season from Germany and, after a stop of only 1 hour 20 minutes, started its homeward journey.

PARIS, July 6 -- An express train in three parts, each proceeding to a different destination, each capable of being severed from other parts with absolute safety and without stopping the train, is an innovation which will be put into effect on the Paris-Le Havre line of the French State Railways soon.

The story of how the Italian air armada crossed the American border at Detroit and sped onward to its goal in the Western Hemisphere on the waters of Lake Michigan was carried yesterday from radioequipped airplanes to broadcasting networks spanning the continent.

BOSTON, July 13 -- The Boston Police Department has been investigated. In the opinion of the investigator, rendered this afternoon, the result has been the "rehabilitation" of the Bureau of Criminal Investigation. Nobody else takes the outcome so seriously.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 15 -- Police, it was learned today, have been guarding the home of Miss Marguerite Keasbey at 151 Madison Avenue here night and day, since the receipt of a telephone call by her last Thursday demanding payment of $100,000.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A plan for complete motorization of the cavalry, mechanization of machinegun units of the infantry and general replacement of motorized vehicles that have grown obsolete will be put before President Roosevelt early next week by the War Department.

George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday that a public hearing would be held in Room 500, State Office Building, 80 Centre Street, on July 27, to discuss plans for reorganizing the mortgage security business of the National Surety Company.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Green of the American Federation of Labor said today that his organization would oppose strenuously the employes' representation plan proposed by the steel industry's code.

While the opening about the middle of August of the Fifty-third Street extension of the Eighth Avenue subway to Long Island City and Jackson Heights will materially reduce the running time under the existing traffic systems to those points, the Long Island Real Estate Board points out that the benefits of the new line will ultimately extend beyond the Queens County line.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on July 8 amounted to 539,223, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 94,851 cars, or 15 per cent, less than for the preceding week, because of the observance of the Fourth of July holiday.

"The standard of what we call first-class polo is lower in this country than it had ever been," was the startling admission recently made by Lord Kimberley at the luncheon given at the Savoy, London, by the British Sportsman's Association to the Maharajah of Judhpur and his Indian polo team.

THC middle-aged reader of this book will certainly find himself saying again and again, as he turns its pages: "Yes; so it was. At last I see the explanation of certain events and tendencies in American life which I have always recognized as matters of fact but have never completely understood."

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A voluntary downward adjustment of salaries of the more highly paid railroad executives was in prospect tonight following the assertion yesterday by Joseph B. Eastman, transportation coordinator, that salaries "at or near the top" were not justified by prevailing economic conditions.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 15 -- Richard T. Murphy of Utica, N.Y., gained a leg on the historic Longwood Bowl when he triumphed over Martyn Buxby of Miami, Fla., 8-6, 6-4, 6-2, in the final at the Longwood Cricket Club today.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 15 -- Showers today prevented tournament polo play, but the Aurora junior champion team, led by Seymour Knox, won in impressive fashion from a Long Island combination.
MOSCOW, July 15 -- The Soviet agrarian "revolution" of the ast five years is one of the most prodigious changes that ever occurred anywhere in time of peace.

WHO is this comes here? What resplendent young crusader is this, tall and straight and handsome aglow with martial ardor, fire flashing from his eyes and flamecalls from his horn beneath which the walls of Jericho shrivel and collapse?

THE Summer exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art opens pleasantly, with a conspicuous regard for the comfort of the museum public. The pictures are well bung, not too many on a wall, and with sufficient attention to convenient classification, but also blessedly concerned with offering variety -- that delectable spice in which museum fare too often is wanting.

SYDNEY W. CARROLL, a regular contributor on theatrical matters to London's Daily Telegraph, wrote a recent "plea for free trade in art." As it is based on a ruling of the local Actors' Equity, excerpts of it may be of interest here.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- General Italo Balbo's Italian air fleet, already having conquered the dangers of the Alps, of the stormy and foggy coasts of the British Isles and the watery stretches to Iceland and the American Continent, took off this afternoon from Montreal on the is lap of the 6,100 mile journey.

PARIS. ONCE Will Dyson did a brilliant piece about art critics. It was inspired by Peter Arno's exhibition at the Leicester Galleries in London and was written, months ago, for The New English Weekly. I was in London at the time. Though it is a sign of inexcusable short-sightedness, I confess never to have seen the work of Will Dyson.
COPENHAGEN, Sunday, July 16 -- The Politiken published today a dispatch from its Prague correspondent as follows:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 15 -- Many members of the Summer colony attended the second in the series of dinner dances which was held tonight at the Meadow Club. Colored lights outlined the clubhouse and the gardens beyond the ballroom were illuminated by brightly colored lanterns and floodlights.

SOFIA, June 30 -- The growth of an "intellectual proletariat," composed of young men who, having received a secondary education, do not wish, to work upon the land like theor fathers, yet cannot find "black coat" jobs, has been receiving the attention of the government.

Five boys will get traps to the Century of Progress Exposition in Chicago as a reward for winning model airplane contests yesterday in Central Park. The contest was backed by the Department of Parks as part of its recreation program.

SINCE novelists have begun to discover how much fresh and entertaining adventure material may be found in Soviet Russia, we may expect a flood of such tales as "Bright Angel," all of them presenting as this one does more or less thrilling and improbable pictures of that strangest and least explored of contemporary civilization.
NEW YORKERS a few days ago watched a big disk, its rim dotted with tiny lenses, whirl and cast television images on a large screen. U.A. Sanabria, Chicago television experimenter, conducted the show.

ALTON, Ill., July 15 (AP) -- Notes in the handwriting of August Luer, 77-year-old kidnapped banker, have been received from the abductors, but instructions concerning payment of ranson "have been confusing and complicated," his family announced tonight.
A petition in bankruptcy for the Harriman Securities Corporation was filed yesterday in United States District Court by William A. Burke, its secretary and treasurer.

NO practice, it would seem, has grown more rapidly or become more general and more firmly established than that of the granting of subsidies by the State for local betterments, especially in such matters as education, welfare and good roads.
The list of clubhouse boxholders for this year's Summer race meeting of the Saratoga Association to be held at Saratoga Springs Aug. 3 to Sept. 2 was announced yesterday.

PARIS. THE Grande Semaine is full of thrills. From its jumping-off point in the Grand Steeple at Auteuil, to its culmination in the Grand Prix at Longchamps, it affords a fairly inclusive pageant of Parisian life, so ciety, customs, manners and fashions.

TORONTO, July 14 -- Gold mines of Ontario in the first six months of this year produced bullion, exclusive of premium, to the value of $22,164,735, a decline of $1,079,185 from the $23,243,920 reported for the same period of 1932. If figures for exchange compensation were included, however, it would be found that production value in Canadian funds would be far in excess of last year's high record.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Two new banks to provide funds for agriculture, a production credit bank and a cooperative credit bank, soon will be established at St. Louis.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The proposed code of fair competition of the steel industry, submitted today to the National Recovery Administration, follows in full:

A NEW conductor and two evenings of ballet performances will distinguish the forthcoming week of concerts by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium. Leon Barzin, director of the National Orchestral Association training orchestra, will lead the Philharmonic for five concerts, beginning Thursday night, and Edwin Strawbridge, Pauline Koner and their company will dance with the orchestra under the direction of Hans Lange Tuesday and Wednesday nights.

WITH the opening of "The Song of Songs" at the Criterion on Wednesday night there will be two "road shows" running concurrently on Broadway for the first time this Summer. "Pilgrimage," at the Gaiety, is the other.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Japan mistakes our idealism for weakness. The situation requires a concerted campaign to remove sources of misunderstanding and to emphasize our common interests. Japan is our best customer in Asia. We are Japan's best customer in the world.

CHICAGO, July 15 -- To complete a cycle spanning the two generations that lie between the world's fairs of 1893 and 1933, the International Congress of Women of a Century of Progress will open, here tomorrow night.

THE interest that has been aroused by President Roosevelt's reforestation policy and the controversy it has created give to Mr. Pack's book a special timeliness, although it seems to have been projected and mostly written before the attention of the public had been thus drawn to the subject.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 15 -- More than two hundred colonists attended the first contest in the season's riding and jumping series for young riders at the East Hampton Riding Club this afternoon. Mrs. Robert Schey, Mrs. B. Shults Dougherty, Mrs. John Howie Wright and Mrs. William C. Morgan were hostesses at the reception and tea, held in the seventeenth-century farmhouse, headquarters of the riding club, after the event.

IT is gradually dawning upon the average man that the most Important public question is the control of money and credits The men wise in finance have known this fact all the time but Instead of letting the public in on the secret, they have sought apparently to conceal and obscure the issue and divert the public mind to other questions, of minor importance.

IGNORING the gyrations of dollar, pound and franc, art goes on about its serene midsummer way. If points North, trips abroad, week-end cruises and the out-of-doors generally lure away some devotees, many of the New York galleries are nevertheless faithful to those who remain within the city, inside the brazen gates of July, and shows of interest are not lacking.

PARIS, July 14 -- All classes of Frenchmen are as uncertain whether France really can remain on the gold standard much longer as the rest of the world. This is evident from the trend of comment in the daily press and the conversations of men In the street on the foremost topic of discussion everywhere in Paris during the past week.

A forty-hour week and a minimum wage of 35 cents an hour for men and 32% cents for women are among the provisions written into the fair competition code of the National Association of Comfortable Manufacturers.
PARIS, July 15 -- The signing of the four-power pact in Rome today is regarded in France as especially significant of a definite improvement in Franco-Italian relations.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 15 -- Nearly 2,000 persons danced, had supper and were entertained tonight in the show ring building at Oakland Farm, the home of Mr and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt in Portsmouth. The occasion was the red and white ball, given for the benefit of the Boy Scouts of Newport County.

PROFESSOR C.F. REMER'S long-awaited "Foreign Investments in China," an important work of original research in the field of politico-economics, has at last been published. Initiated by the Institute of Pacific Relations, financed by the Social Science Research Council under the trusteeship of the Brookings Institute, it represents not merely an author's desire to express himself on China.

LONDON, July 15 (AP) -- Reports that the expense account of Dr. Raymond Moley, Assistant Secretary of State, for his recent mission to London had been disapproved by Secretary of State Hull, chief of the delegation to the World Economic Conference, provoked smiles in the American delegation today.

With, one of the emptiest records ever made by an international gathering, the London Economic Conference will recess on July 27. It is announced that the delegates will say "au revoir but not good-bye" and that the conference will be resumed again. The date may be set in October or November or the meeting may break up subject to the call of the British Prime Minister.

ATLANTA, July 13 -- With thirteen States officially in the repeal column, Alabama, Tennessee and Arkansas will vote next week on the abrogation of the Eighteenth Amendment. Alabama and Tennessee seem certain to return wet majorities and the odds favor similar action in Arkansas.

Rear Admiral Frederic R. Harris, retired, praised the Italian aerial expedition yesterday as "an achievement worthy of ancient Rome," adding that the success of the flight clearly demonstrated the effectiveness of aviation in the event of war.

Focusing attention on the economic problems facing retailers as they begin shaping their Fall plans, a three-day recovery forum will be held by the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania, beginning Tuesday evening and continuing through Thursday.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The proposed code of fair competition of the wool textile industry, submitted today to the National, Recovery Administration, is as follows:

The Prince of Wales has changed his character; until his speech the other day before the Association of Municipal Corporations at Guildhall, London, he was regarded as "the Empire's best salesman," henceforth he may be called "the nation's hest buyer," for at Guildhall he promoted a great national effort for the purchase of slums, and thereby the recreation of a new civilization for the lowly.

While Wall Street hopefully resumed what are known as "constructive operations" yesterday, the movement did not get far. Stocks were marked up slightly and trading ran above 2,240,000 shares, compared with 3,007,000 on the previous Saturday.

In the Special Features Section of THE TIMES today two pages are devoted to a "follow-up" of the Hundred Neediest Cases helped by the Christmas fund of 1932. When banks and corporations are publishing their midyear statements of condition, it is fitting that the stockholders-meaning the contributors-of the Hundred Neediest Cases should be informed of what has been done with their gifts.
At 1 to 4, the shortest price of the meeting thus far, H.C. Phipps's Balios yesterday won the Empire City Derby in anything but a contest.

In times of sickness and misfortune, charlatans flourish, asserts The Journal of the American Medical Association. The desperate man grasps at any straw and is ready to try any scheme that offers something for nothing, or more for less than it costs, the publication adds.

If education is, as I conceive it to be, largely the process of adjusting individual men and women to their environment, then it should not ignore those conditions which young people must face in the social organism in which, whether they like it or not, their lot is to be cast.

"The beginning of the end at the isolation of Long Island" -- in the words of Governor Herbert H. Lehman -- was celebrated yesterday afternoon when Grand Central Parkway in Queens and its extension, the Northern State Parkway in Nassau County, were formally opened.

THE volume of the program books of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, season of 1932-33, with the engrossing annotations of Philip Hale, is at hand and has been with us in many places. Some books make excellent reading on a rainy day, when the weather may put one in the mood to ruminate and digest at leisure their more palatable portions.

Three underworld forts on wheels were seized by the Bronx police yesterday. They were 1933 model automobiles with secret compartments for machine guns and armored so that they were virtually invulnerable in a pistol or machine gun fight.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H -- The White Mountains colonies are theatre-conscious this season, what with the presence of the Forty Niners of the Yale Dramatic School. Their offering at their little theatre at Notchland, Crawford Notch, for this week will he "The Cricket on the Hearth."

BERLIN. THAT great standard work, the "Propylaen-Weltgeschichte" of the Ullstein Verlag, is nearing completion. The last volume to be discussed -- the eighth of this universal history -- told of the rise of liberalism, the age of Bismarck and the establishment of the new German Empire, complemented and elucidated by the story of events in antithetical France.

MAPS are being consulted at this hour and last-minute plans made for end-of-July and August holidays. Penciled marks trace the course of motor high-ways leading to woodland and mountain resorts, circles mark a favorite fishing village or beach, and many a route is planned to include Chicago and its Century of Progress Fair.
MELBOURNE, July 14 -- Australia has had many sharp reminders in recent weeks that even so remote a country as it is cannot order its affairs as though it were detached from the rest of the world.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Production schedules were generally maintained in the week ended July 8, but the total output in some lines was reduced as a result of the Fourth of July holiday, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Annoyed and somewhat worried by the delay of business groups in formulating codes, and determined at the same time to keep retail price-rises from getting too far ahead of re-employment and increased wages, the President and his aides took a number of important steps. The results were immediate and cheering.

THE bill for "the total abolition of slavery in all its forms within the British Empire" passed through its final stages in England's House of Commons during the last week of July and the first week of August, 1833. This year England is celebrating the centenary of that momentous occasion.
DETROIT. THE first half of 1933 will be remembered in automobile manufacturing as a period which ran the scale from low to high as never before in trade history.

ROME, July 15 -- The four-power pact, which its sponsors and signatories hope will guarantee ten years of peace for Europe, was signed by representatives of Italy, Great Britain, France and Germany in the Palazzo Venezia at noon today.

LONDON, July 15 -- It was reliably reported In Latin-American circles that Ralph W. Morrison of the United States delegation to the Economic Conference had participated in discussions exploring the prospect of a joint agreement of several American nations to grant mutual trade concessions, possibly along the lines of the Ottawa agreement between Great Britain and the dominions.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 15 -- Miss Alice Marble of San Francisco showed no respect for the seeded list or the national rankings when she defeated Miss Carolin Babcock of Los Angeles, 6-3, 6-4, in the final round of the women's invitation tennis tournament at the Longwood Cricket Club today.

OXFORD, England, July 15 -- The "house party" of the Oxford Group Movement, now proceeding at Oxford, presents a striking contrast to the stormy beginning of the movement at the university twelve years ago.
The Yankees continued along the victory trail yesterday, defeating the Chicago White Sax, 11 to 2, for their eighth straight triumph.

There are 1,885 different species of "wild"flowers in Bucks County, the 590-square-mile rectangle of Pennsylvania soil that forms the northeast boundary of Philadelphia, according to the Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences. These range from the smallest blossom known to botanists -- the microscopic Wolffia columbiana, which blooms on a water plant the size of a pinhead -- to the showy rose-mallow, which sometimes attains a diameter of nearly 10 inches.

AMID the traffic that surges along the Strand in London there rises, like an island, a famous church, From the spire rings forth the nursery rhyme "Oranges and lemons, said the bells of St. Clement's," and the pew is shown where Dr. Johnson worshiped.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- James G. Strong, former Republican Representative from Kansas, who was appointed June 19 as treasurer of the Some Owners Loan Corporation, has been supplanted in the post by Patrick J. Maloney of Columbia City, Ind., a Democrat, William F. Stevenson, chairman of the Home Loan Board, announced today.

PARIS, Sunday, July 16 -- The second day of the Socialist Congress ended early this morning with a schism between the parliamentary majority and the orthodox group, which is trying to keep the French party true to the Socialist dogmas.

EVIDENCE accumulates that the theatre, which has the air in New York of being precariously kept alive by injection of explosive stimulants -- the nitroglycerine of sex-shocks, principally -- is not really nearly so dead as it looks, from Broadway and Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A new cotton production, control program to cover next year's crop and possibly that of 1935 took form today as farm administrators, heartened by the response of cotton growers to this year's plan, moved ahead along the whole farm front.

NO longer does the constable of the Tower of London look through a slit to see how many prisoners the barge is bringing along the Thames to the historic fortress. Today the old prison, begun 850 years ago, is more of a sightseers' paradise than a jail.

LONDON, July 15 (AP) -- The House of Commons retained its domination over royalty on the golf links today when 67-year-old George Lambert defeated the Prince of Wales 5 and 4 in the 36-hole finals of the Parliamentary Handicap tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The failure of all efforts by the United States to obtain even the provisional release of five American citizens imprisoned on the Spanish island of Majorca since June 4 was reported today by the State Department.

CUT off the petroleum supply of the United States and automobiles would stop, airplanes would cease to fly, thousands of motor boats would lie idle, half the world's shipping would rot away, whole industries dependent on fuel oil would collapse.
ANNAPOLIS, July 15 -- Twentyfive New Yorkers, forming the largest group from any State, are included in the new Fourth Class at the Naval Academy this Summer.

Generally improved conditions in credits and collections are reported by exporters shipping merchandise to Latin-American countries, the foreign Credit Interchange Bureau of the National Association of Credit Men reported yesterday. Completing their nineteenth quarterly survey of the twenty-one South and Central American markets, the credit bureau reported that the upward trend in credits and collections which started early this year has continued.

IN days like these, while statesmen and economists are frantically seeking a remedy for the "morning after" headache following a cosmic spree, it may be a comfort to remember that the world has survived similar experiences in the past.
A marked decrease in foreclosure actions in Brooklyn indicates to a considerable extent, points out Stephen F. Barrera of that borough, that real estate conditions are improving.

Citing the fact that the city real estate assessors must, under the tax law, make oath that "they have estimated the value of said real estate at the sums which a majority of the assessors have decided to be the full value thereof," Henry M. Powell, an attorney of this city and a member of the Mayor's special committee on taxation states that "full value" as well as "ordinary value" are synonymous with "market value."

THE World Economic Conference in London has perhaps not been a pleasant experience for most of the delegates, but one of them. Maxim Litvinoff, the Soviet Foreign Minister, has apparently enjoyed it. He has had the sarcastic pleasure of offering to the representatives of capitalistic nations a means, through sales to Soviet Russia, whereby they might pull themselves out of the swamp of overproduction.
BOSTON, July 15 (AP) -- Dusty Rhodes, Red Sox hurling ace, limited Cleveland to six hits and struck out ten men today as Boston defeated the Indians, 7 to 2, in the first game of the series.
LONDON, July 16. -- Great Britain marks tomorrow the twenty-first anniversary of her national health insurance scheme, which is probably the most ambitious and the most successful in the world.

While dissatisfaction with the government and antagonism toward employers as a class is widespread among unemployed professional engineers, "genuine political or economic radicalism" is not much greater among idle engineers than among those who are employed.

PARIS, July 15. -- Attention here this week was centred principally upon foreign exchange fluctuations. Hope expressed by Mr. Chamberlain, the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, for a rise in the dollar by Autumn seems to have been the reason for the recovery that took place.

Many have arranged parties for the Aviation Dinner Dance to be held on Friday at the Lido Country Club, Lido Beach, L.I., in the interest of the National Amateur Charity Air Pageant scheduled for early October at Roosevelt Field.

ALBANY, July 16. -- There were no developments here today in the O'Connell kidnapping case, so far as could be learned from the family or from the authorities, although the District Attorney's investigators seemed unusually active.

NASSAU, N.Y., July 16. -- A heavy motor truck loaded with tons of brass pipe burned out its brakes on a Berkshire mountain highway today, roared down into the village of Nassau and killed a father who was driving his family home from church.

Three reasons why Christianity is waging a successful fight against secularism, communism and nationalism throughout the world were advanced yesterday morning in a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Robert M. Hopkins, general secretary of the World's Sunday School Association.

More than 100 occupations are represented by the candidates for the twenty-five scholarships to be awarded by the Art Students League of New York in the competition which ends Aug. 1, it was said yesterday by the committee in charge.

Out of every $100 spent In 1932 by the New York City Department of Education $96.90 went for the cost of instruction, providing recreation and operating and maintaining the school plant. The remainder, $3.10, was the cost of administration and miscellaneous expense.

LONDON, July 15. -- The Economist's index of wholesale commodity prices, based on tie average of 1927 as 100, works out at 65.9 as of July 12, against 65 a fortnight before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Jack Lovelock of Oxford ran a 4:07.6 mile at Princeton on Saturday and, unbelievable as it seems, he left the impression that ha has yet to race his fastest mile. And Bill Bonthron of Princeton, a gallant loser also in world's record time, gave observers the same idea.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 16. -- The award of fourteen scholarships and fellowships to students in the Harvard Law School for the coming academic year was announced tonight at University Hall. The awards total $8,675, or an average of about $600.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 16. -- The South Mountain String Quartet, Willem Willeke conductor, at Mrs. Frederick S. Coolidge's Temple of Music, Pittsfield, this afternoon played a Brahms string quartet, the Bach sonata for viola and piano and the Schubert string quartet, "Death and the Maiden," by request.
Everything is ready at Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn for the arrival tomorrow or Wednesday of General Italo Balho and his Italian air armada from Chicago.

Only vision, without which the people perish, will impart to the pendulum of progress the forward impulse that will overcome the reaction of the last few years, the Rev. Dr. Charles Clifford Peale, pastor of the First Methodist Church of Columbus.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., July 16. -- The Rhode Island Textile Council, representing 25,000 workers in the worsted and woolen goods industry, today rejected the employers' proposal for a national forty-hour week and a minimum wage of $14 a week and demanded instead a thirty-hour week and $18 minimum.
No word had been received here up to an early hour this morning of the Lithuanian-American fliers, Captain Stephen Darious and Stanley Girenas.
LONDON, July 16. -- The signature of the four-power pact has been greeted in England with deeper satisfaction than seemed possible when it was first proposed a few months ago.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 16. -- With both wet and dry leaders claiming victory, a careful survey of the prospects in Alabama's repeal vote Tuesday indicates that the State will go wet two to one.

With the number of buyers here showing a, marked increase, additional showings of Fall lines of better and popular price dresses featured wholesale market activity last week. The volume of purchases was reported as indicating a stronger feeling on the part of retailers throughout the country.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- All wheat futures are selling well above the dollar level and more than double the prices four months ago, with the trade as bullish and confident of higher prices as it was bearish around 50 cents and under. The whole picture has been changed by governmental expansion plans and crop deterioration.

A drop of 19 per cent in the aggregate philanthropic gifts and bequests in the six largest cities of the United States is reported for the first six months of 1933. The decline is based on a comparison of figures for the corresponding period last year.

Flowers that vanished from American gardens and returned to the wild state 150 years ago and more; plants that have never had a place in the formal garden but blush unseen in mountain fastnesses, will be sought by an expedition of the New York Botanical Garden, it was announced there yesterday.

The doom of the pushcart peddlers as purveyors of candy was sounded yesterday by the Wholesale Confectioners Board of Trade, Inc., when it adopted its code of fair competition, under the National Industrial Recovery Act.

Charles A. Boston, president of the New York County Lawyers Association, made public yesterday through Terence J. McManus, secretary, the committees named for 1933-34. For the second successive year Samuel Seabury, former Supreme Court justice and counsel for the Hofstadter legislative committee, heads the committee on cooperation with bar associations, which includes Charles E. Hughes Jr. and I. Maurice Wormser.

Continuance of the popular-price concerts at White Plains despite the action of Local 802 of the Musicians Union, which withdrew its members from the orchestra on Saturday night, seemed assured yesterday.

Russia today is a land of "slavery, barbarism and desolation," despite a thousand minor virtues, Will Durant, author of "The Story of Philosophy," asserts in his new book, "The Tragedy of Russia," published today by Simon Schuster.

NEW ORLEANS, July 16. -- The cotton market here was characterized last week not only by the greatest activity known in years, but also by an advance in prices which carried all months beyond October above the 12-cent line. Prices in reaching the highest levels of the present upward movement and of the season, advanced to figures not reached since March, 1931.

BUNNY AUSTIN settled it. The line-up will be Great Britain vs. the United States for the privilege of moving into the challenge round for the Davis Cup, which is not a cup at all but a jolly big silver bowl. Jack Crawford stood up for Australia, but even in the days of Tilden it took more than one man to make a tennis team, and it still takes a team to capture the Davis Cup.

BUENOS AIRES, July 16. -- Argentina seems destined to reap greater benefits from the improvement in commodity prices in the United States than from any of her new trade treaties or the efforts of her own government to improve the country's economic situation.

LONDON, July 16. -- The United States delegation to the World Economic Conference does not take seriously the suggestion advanced from British quarters that the conference, if and when it is resumed, shall take up its labors in Washington.

A three-day fete will be held at the Brightwaters Casino, Islip, L.I., for the benefit of the Southside Hospital. It will open on the night of Thursday, July 27, and continue on Friday and Saturday afternoons and evenings. On those days the Casino will be open to the general public for a small admission fee.

RYE, N.Y., July 16. -- Wet weather sailors in oilskins took part in the special regatta of the American Yacht Club today. A wet southeaster kept many beats of the midsummer Western Long Island Sound fleet in snug harbor, but forty-four craft were out, their owners defying the weather and wet sails.
William L. Ward, political overlord of Westchester and one of the few remaining members of the Republican "Old Guard," died last night in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was In his seventy-seventh year.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 16. -- Mrs. Thomas H. Barber gave a luncheon today at Claverack House for the Rev. Dr. Theodore Sedgwick, rector of St. Paul's American Church in Rome, who is passing several days with Mr. and Mrs. Harry Pelham Robbins at Pelham Farm.

More than a dozen new plays will be tried out at various Summer theatres this week. Pelham Manor, N.Y., will see -- under the auspices of the Manor Players -- "Broomsticks, Amen," by Elmer Greensfelder, with Lew Fields in the cast. At Red Bank, N.J., the Red Bank Players will offer "Ride a Cock Horse," by Kate Horton.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP). -- The second-place Cubs and the Boston Braves divided their double-header before 28,000 fans today. The Cubs took the second game, 3 to 1, behind Guy Bush's pitching. Wally Berger won the opener for the Braves, 2 to 1, with his seventeenth home run of the season.

Dr. Hereward Carrington, director of the American Psychical Institute, revealed here yesterday that he had succeeded in applying laboratory tests for the identification of personality to the supposed spirits of the dead summoned by a trance medium.

On Aug. 1 a Federal tax of 4.2 cents a pound will be placed on the processing of cotton. Its purpose will be to raise a fund, estimated at $120,000,000, which the Government can use for bounties to Southern planters who will plow under or otherwise effectively destroy part of the crop now growing.

The new headmaster of Phillips Andover Academy, CLAUDE M. FUESS, in his article in yesterday's TIMES makes out a good case for the changed course of study. He admits that it does not go far enough for the "progressives," though it does keep "abreast of genuine progress," without lowering standards of scholastic excellence.
PITTSBURGH, July 16 (AP). -- Preparing for an era of all-metal homes, the Mellon Institute announces a new marble-surfaced steel.

The National Alliance of the Theatre, which is composed of various theatrical groups, will meet today at the offices of the League of New York Theatres. It will discuss codes for submission to the National Industrial Recovery Administration and will learn who is to be the administrator appointed by General Hugh S. Johnson.

Two realty announcements yesterday, one involving an apartment house sale in the west Harlem section and the other the sale of a large cooperative apartment on upper Fifth Avenue, furnished additional evidences of a continued improvement in the real estate market.
Gerald Weed, a crony of the late Francis Crowley, made an unsuccessful attempt to escape from the prison ward at Fordham Hospital yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The text of the oil regulations issued by the Interior Department today follows:

MONTREAL, July 16 (AP). -- Montreal and Newark divided a double-header today. The Bears won the opener, 5 to 3, and the Royals took the second, 1 to 0, when Lou Finney's single with the bases loaded in the eighth and last inning broke up a pitching duel between Johnny Michaels and Jim Weaver.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Out of 3,410,507 individual income tax returns filed in the United States for the calendar year 1931, 682,603 came from New York State, including 476,301 from the five counties of New York City, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

ARDSLEY, N.Y., July 16. -- Three world's records in two days were established by Miss Dorothy Duggan of Greenwich, Conn., in the Westchester County Archery Association's annual tournament that ended today at Woodlands Park. Miss Duggan tallied 612 points with 90 hits in the American round to eclipse the former universal mark of 584 points.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 16. -- Mrs. Hall McNeil, who is occupying Mrs. Harry L. Hamlin's home, Rowdy Hall, on Egypt Lane, this season, is entertaining a weekend house party for her daughter, Miss Jean McNeil, and her fiance, John Wheeler Peck of Bridgeport, Conn., whose engagement was announced a few days ago.

When the blockfront on the west side of York Av., between 79th and 80th Sts., was sold by the Bowery Savings Bank to Chal Associates, Inc., Albert Mayer, president, the consideration was approximately $571,500. The bank took back a purchase money mortgage for $571,322, payable according to the bond, this being a lien on all fixtures and personal property now or hereafter used in connection with the premises.

What is said to be the first reorganization plan worked out through the agency of the State courts has just been approved by Justice Bernard L. Shientag of the Supreme Court following the report of Jeremiah T. Mahoney, referee in the rehabilitation plans for the forty-four-story building at 10 East Fortieth Street.

Wiley Post's flight from New York to Berlin was hailed here yesterday by fliers as a record that is not likely to equaled for some time. The aviator not only set a record for point to point navigation, matched only by Colonel Lindbergh's flight to Paris six years ago, but he also established a new distance record for solo flying.

CHICAGO, July 16 -- More than thirty representatives from abroad were grouped on or about the speakers' platform in the grand ballroom of the Palmer House tonight as the congress of the National Council of Women opened.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 16 -- Richard C. du Pont of Wilmington, Del., taking his father, A. Felix du Pont, for his first ride in a soaring plane, was caught by a tail wind late this afternoon and crashed. Neither father nor son was hurt, but the motorless ship was wrecked.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the consolidation of the Danubian States as an economic unit lies the key to the peace of Europe and the prosperity of the world. This simple truth is known to every statesman of any importance on the Continent, but how many are there that will dare admit it?

Professor MOLEY refused to be interviewed when he returned from London last week, but in his article in yesterday's Herald Tribune he lets a little of the mortifying truth escape him. The chief cause of the failure of the Economic Conference was, according to him, that the question of stabilization got itself tangled up in the conference."

MANILA, Monday, July 17. -- In the midst of the acrimonious discussion of the Hawes-Cutting Independence Law, Governor General Frank Murphy today boldly urged prompt action on this issue in his first message to the Insular Legislature.

A suit brought in 1931 by George L. O'Hare to establish the validity of twenty-nine $1,000 bonds of the Dayton Union Railroad Company, which he bought for $25 in 1929, was dismissed yesterday by Federal Judge Fatterson for lack of jurisdiction.

BERLIN, July 16. -- The real conflict going on in Germany today is between antagonistic elements in National Socialism itself, between the extremists and moderates in the party, now freed of all outside interference -- and particularly between warring ideas and ambitions in the inner circles of the government.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some time ago I went into the catalogue room at the New York Public Library to find some material for a debate in our high school. After properly filling out the request blanks I showed them to the clerk at the desk. After studying the titles for a full minute he looked up at me and asked, in a very patronizing tone, "What's your name?"

Steel operations increased two more points last week to 57 per cent of capacity, according to the magazine Steel. The national average, reaching for the first time the 1530 trend line, compares with 80 per cent as the average for July in tha five years, 1926-1930, the publication says.
The Board of Estimate was called upon yesterday by the Citizens Union to defer granting further bus franchises in Manhattan until a comprehensive bus system has been devised.

PITTSBURGH, July 16. -- Buying of steel is fairly heavy, although not at the rate in June. The mills entered July with enough shipping orders to run them through July at the recent rate, but with the additional business being booked they have been able to increase operations.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 16 (AP). -- A story of rescue after a daylong battle against flames on a blazing oil tanker in a heavy sea, whipped by a strong wind, was brought to this port today by thirty-six survivors of the Cities Service Petrol.

An amendment to the State Alsoholic Beverage Control Law to permit the sale of 3.2 beer and wine in candy stores is sought by the Independent Retail Cigar, Stationery and Newsdealers Protective Association.

The economy axe has been wielded with so much zeal, not always according to knowledge, among Government bureaus that science has fared badly. Even in prosperous years less than 1 per cent of the Federal budget was appropriated for research. Now there is a reduction of 60 per cent over 1932.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Executive orders bringing the rayon, cotton thread, silk, and throwing, or thread-twisting industries under the Cotton Textile code, effective at midnight tonight, were signed by President Roosevelt immediately after he returned this evening from a week-end cruise and motor trip along the Maryland coast.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 16. -- Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt, sponsors of the Red and White Ball last night, grave a buffet luncheon for more than 100 guests at the Clambake Club today.

Viscount Kikujiro Ishii, chief Japanese delegate to the World Economic Conference in London, yesterday expressed confidence in the ultimate success of the conference. He spoke from London over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Regulations of the most drastic nature which are expected to go a long way toward the elimination of "bootlegging" in petroleum and its products, and at the same time hold the oil industry to the strict letter of the law, were promulgated today by the Department of the Interior.

Doubt as to the faith in God of persons who "throw salt over their shoulder, knock on wood and observe all the other ridiculous rituals of superstition" was voiced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Adam Burnet, pastor of the Westbourne Church, Glasgow, Scotland, in his morning sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

Most taxpayers are unreasonable in their demands for decreased school expenditure, In the opinion of 832 Summer School students of the New York University School of Education, 90 per cent of whom represent communities whose school budgets have been sharply reduced during the last four years.

The Right Rev. William Hall Moreland, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Sacramento, preached yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. His sermon was addressed particularly to the students of the Columbia University Summer School.
A Sheepshead Bay fisherman braved the rocks off the Rockaway Point jetty last night to rescue two small children, four women and two men whose cabin cruiser, the Marge, fast on the reef, was sinking.

CINCINNATI, July 16. -- The top and tail-end teams of the National League battled each other for more than five and a half hours today, with honors so evenly divided that for the most part a crowd of about 8,000 seemed unable to tell one club from the other.

BERLIN, July 16. -- Wiley Post, who started from New York yesterday on a solo flight around the world, dropped out of the clouds to Tempelhof Field today at 11:55 A.M. [6:55 A.M. Eastern Daylight Time.]

The five-cent fare was projected anew into the Mayoralty campaign yesterday when former Mayor John F. Hylan, aspirant for the fusion nomination, charged once more a "plot" to increase the subway rate.

An order for electrical equipment to be used on a new high-speed, light-weight train on the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Company's lines has been placed with the Westing-house Electric and Manufacturing Company subject to the approval of the Transit Commission.

BERLIN, July 16 (By Wireless). -- With good weather and perfect refueling arrangements en route to help you along, a solo flight around the world would be a cinch. So far, both on this and my previous flight, I have not been favored with either, and while I had hoped to do the stretch between Bennett Field and Tempelhof in twenty-two hours, yet really I should not grumble.

In weighing the President's announcement that he intends to make full use of the authorization by Congress of $3,300,000,000 for public construction, it need not be assumed that this means jwasteful expenditure. Nor can it be intended to spend the whole sum at once.

While no official order has been received as yet at Ellis Island from Washington, it is understood by the officials here that the new executive order for the combination of the immigration and naturalization offices all over the United States will go into effect on Aug. 10.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, in a letter to the Long Island Division of the Home Mortgage Advisory Board made public yesterday expressed the belief that conversion of "troubled mortgages" by their owners into bonds provided for that purpose by the government, would remove from the market the frantic offerings of hundreds of thousands of homes at a little above their mortgages.

Strongly advising holders of State of Arkansas bonds not to part with their holdings at present depreciated prices, and predicting that they would eventually receive better terms than those now offered under the State's Refunding Act of 1933, Judge Richard M. Mann of the Sixth Judicial Circuit, Little Rock, Ark., in an interview here yesterday said the great majority of the citizens of the State did not approve the arbitrary provisions of the Refunding Act.

MOSCOW, July 16. -- There is a perceptible hardening in the tone of the Soviet press toward Japan. Whether it is the result of Russia's improved position in the west or of irritation over the Japanese attitude in the negotiations for the sale of the Chinese Eastern Railway it is impossible to say.

As a cheering sign of the times the Viking Press announces an expansion of its book list for the Fall. While retaining its policy of publishing only a small list of books, the press has added a junior book department which increases the list from twenty to thirty-two titles, the largest number that has been issued by Viking in one season.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- The corn market is a two-sided one. There has been an unusually large movement, with heavy stocks at leading points of accumulation, as well as in the country, which traders consider bearish. On the other hand, there is a less favorable crop outlook than a year ago, and a larger volume of speculative trade with several important leaders on the buying side.

Acting on an underworld tip that John J. O'Connell Jr. and his kidnappers would be found in one of two buildings on the west side of Manhattan, detectives and uniformed police searched both structures last night without finding any trace of the missing Albany youth or his captors.

NOVOSIBIRSK, Siberia, July 16 (AP) -- Waiting here to help Wiley Post when he arrives on his globe-circling solo flight is a 24-year-old American girl flier, Fay Gillis. She not only has made all refueling and rest arrangements, but will act as the aviator's interpreter during his brief halt at this Far Eastern outpost.
ALBANY, July 16. -- Following is the text of the letter Governor Lehman transmitted to the Board of Estimate and Apportionment:

LONDON, July 16. -- The National Sporting Club, with its traditions going back to the earliest days of boxing in England, will soon move from its historic home in Covent Garden to a new modern building in St. James's Square.

"The Mounties," by which name the Royal Canadian Mounted Police is familiarly known, now have a quarterly magazine. In the first number Prime Minister BENNETT pays a merited tribute when he says of the officers and men that "they are as intent on "conciliation as on accusation: their "efforts have been almost as much "devoted to the prevention of disputes "and crimes as to the apprehension of "those who have broken the law."

Sensational performances in crude rubber and silver futures were the features of trading on local commodity exchanges last week. Sugar, coffee, cocoa, wool tops, hides and copper also were higher. Many new high cash prices for the year to date were established.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- General Italo Balbo climaxed his crowded day at the Century of Progress Exposition today with an address to thousands of Italian-Americans who assembled in and about the Italian pavilion at the fair grounds.
BUFFALO. July 38 (AP). -- The Buffalo Bisons gained two one-run verdicts over Jersey City today, taking the first game, 11 to 10, and the second, 7 to 6.

BUENOS AIRES, July 16. -- The Paraguayans completely wiped up the troublesome Fort Gondra salient, reached the Saavedra-Alihuata Road and began an attack against Fort Alihuata today, according to Asuncion dispatches reaching here shortly before midnight.
More than 500 members and guests are planning to attend the annual circus dinner dance of the Sands Point Bath Club, Sands Point, L.I., which will be held in the casino on Friday evening.

ST. LOUIS, July 36 (AP). -- The Cardinals divided a double bill with the Phillies today and, in winning the first game, broke a four-game losing streak and gave Hallahan his eleventh victory of the season.

Walter Slezak will continue his appearances in "Music in the Air," the longest-run show on Broadway, instead of withdrawing next Saturday night, as he had intended, to act in the tryout of a new play for Lawrence Langner. Accordingly the management has arranged to have the Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein 2d operetta continue through Sept. 2, at least.

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- If President Roosevelt's disarmament suggestions are adopted they will mean an estimated saving to the world of more than $1,000,000,000 a year, according to Louis McHenry Howe, the President's secretary, in his talk tonight over the National Broadcasting Company network.
A report on a two-year study of the status of psychiatry in medical education is made public today by the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, Inc.

More Than Roads. The roads that led to Rome were presumably the roads that led away from Rome. In one respect New York has it over the ancient imperial city. Mere roads will not do for approaching and leaving the queen city of the Western world.

Two hundred White Russians gathered yesterday to pay their respects to the memory of Czar Nicholas II. They stood, raptly attentive, in the Russian Orthodox Church of Christ the Savior, Madison Avenue and 121st Street, and heard their rector, the Rev. Vasily Kurdiumoff, recite the story of the dynasty's last moments.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP). -- Treasuries of unemployment relief funds are benefiting from shortening bread lines and newly created jobs in nearly every section of the land.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Anent this discussion of "bomber-shoot," may I add these remarks, as I believe that I have the answer as to the charming word's derivation.

CHICAGO, July 16. -- Expansion in all lines of business is not only maintaining recent gains, but there are many industries and merchandisers who report enlargement. Leaders are predicting a continuation of the present high level and pay they would not he surprised to Bee greater activity as the year advances.

Governor Lehman announced yesterday his intention to call a special session of the Legislature to enact measures authorizing New York City to levy additional taxes so as to extricate itself from its financial morass. This money is to go specifically for unemployment relief.

ALTON, Ill., July 16. -- Released by his kidnappers on a lonely country road, August Luer, 77-year-old invalid banker, was returned to the home of a son here today. Mr. Luer was abducted from his home last Monday night.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 16. -- A.O. Jennings's yawl, Contest, representing the Pequot Yacht Club of Southport, Conn., was the winner of the third annual overnight sailing race of the Riverside Yacht Club from Riverside to Stratford Shoal east of Bridgeport and return, which ended today.

The picture of rising prices and reviving trade took on last week some still more striking colors. Steel trade activities rose 5 1/4 per cent; production was more than four times the low March figure. Actual takings of cotton by our spinners were shown to have exceeded in June all monthly records of the trade.
COLLINSVILLE, Ill., July 16 (AP). -- Details of his 124-hour imprisonment in a musty dungeon were recounted today by August Luer, released near here last midnight by kidnappers.

MEMPHIS, July 16 (AP) -- Postmaster General James A. Farley wound up a busy Southern visit today, addressing a gathering of young Democrats in the morning and attending a baseball game in the afternoon.

Rutherford, Fullerton of Columbus, Ohio, is one of five Americans now in prison at Palma, Island of Majorca. The other Americans detained, with him are Mr. and Mrs. Clinton B. Lockwood, Roderick F. Mead and Edmund W. Blodgett.
BERLIN, July 15. -- The week's certificated dollar bond market declined further, these securities showing losses of 10 to 15 points since the beginning of the month.
NEW YORK. Lady Elizabeth Cheylesmore will return to the Madison tomorrow from Alberta, Canada, where she has been visiting her son and daughter-in-law, Lord and Lady Cheylesmore.
NASHVILLE, July 16. -- Prohibition forces are climaxing their campaign in Tennessee by putting a thousand speakers in the field in preparation for the State vote Thursday on repeal.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP). -- The St. Louis Browns scored a 7-to-0 Shutout over the Senators today, forcing Washington into a tie for the American League lead with, the New York Yankees, who were held idle by rain.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 16. -- Frank A. Tibbetts, who retired as the principal of Dickenson High School here on July 1, had been in ill health for nearly two years.

BERLIN, July 15. -- Bankers attribute the advance in stocks in Wall Street partly to justified expectation of a recovery in industry and partly to distrust of the dollar's future course. They consider that the price rise is due mainly to the latter factor.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The kidnapping situation in the United States is fast assuming a menacing aspect.
