Grain shipments through New York have been greatly increased in the last two months, shipping men and observers in the grain trade report, but abnormal transportation conditions at Vancouver, British Columbia, have retarded the recovery of the traffic of Canadian wheat to parts of the United Kingdom which had long been an important source of income to Atlantic ship lines.

Man's know-it-all attitude during the boom years was criticized yesterday as not only a detriment to the individual but to the nation by the Rev. Paul C. White, secretary for religious education of the United Lutheran Synod of New York. He preached the sermon at the Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninety-third Street.

LONDON, July 16. -- Forty-five thousand Anglo-Catholics, by far the largest congregation ever assembled for public worship in England, knelt for the Holy Eucharist today in the culminating service of the centenary of the Oxford movement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: SANTA MONICA, Cal., July 16. -- It's a good thing those Italians landed in seaplanes. If they had landed on the ground they wouldn't have had room to land for Italians.
A man and his wife were killed yesterday in an automobile collision at the intersection of East Tremont and Crotona Avenues, the Bronx, during a downpour of rain at about 9 A.M.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 16. -- Arkansas will certainly, vote to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment in the special election Tuesday, according to most of the State's political prognosticators, who, regardless of their personal views on the issue, are agreed that the wets will win by a vote of 2 to 1.
LONDON, July 16. -- The controversy over whether Great Britain should follow the price raising policy of the United States received two distinguished contributions tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 16. -- The text of the Executive Orders relating to industrial codes issued tonight by President Roosevelt follows:

WASHINGTON, July 16. -- Now that some of the country's basic industries have submitted codes of fair competition, thus starting an avalanche of codes on their way, the National Recovery Administration faces the problem of expeditious handling of the public hearings which begin late this week.

ANADYR, Siberia, July 16 (By wireless) -- When I left Khabarovsk at five in the morning [June 14] on my 2,500-mile flight homeward, I was feeling very good and rested. There was a good weather report, and it was good for the first 1,400 miles.

Sir Arthur S. Woodward and Lady Woodward, Professor John M. Wells and Professor Victor Van Straelen are among the passengers arriving today from Antwerp via Havre and Southampton on the Red Star liner Minnetonka. Others on board are:

Unless West Virginia is counted as a Southern State -- always a moot point -- the first States in the South to vote on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment will go to the polls this week. Arkansas and Alabama are to vote on Tuesday, and Tennessee on Thursday. The scene will shift to the Pacific Coast on Friday, when Oregon holds a referendum.

Rain and cool weather cut down attendance at all the neighboring shore resorts yesterday. With thermometer readings ten degrees below normal and leaden skies unloosing an almost constant down-pour throughout the morning and early afternoon, most of the resorts were practically empty.
The crash and death of the Lithuanian-American fliers, Captain Stephen Darius and Stanley Girenas, after so gallant a flight, was received here yesterday with many expressions of sympathy and regret.
The following is the code of fair competition under the National Industrial Recovery Act adopted by the Association of American NewsPrint Manufacturers:
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Secretary Dern today approved the allotment of $2,679,800 for maintenance of river and harbor projects in the North Atlantic division.

Mayor O'Brien conferred yesterday with Assemblyman Irwin Steingut and State Senator John J. Dunnigan on the special session of the Legislature through which the city hopes to raise $41,000,000 a year in new revenue.

Stocks and commodities continued to rise yesterday in extraordinarily heavy trading. Many new highs for the year were established. The markets were apparently stimulated by the approval of codes by the steel and woolen industries, reports of rapid improvement in general business and corporate earnings, the expectation of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, and by a further moderate weakness in the dollar.

NARROWSBURG, N.Y., July 17 -- Showers and a cold rain ushered in the third week of the five encampments of the Boy Scouts from New York City accross the river here as more than 2,000 boys and their leaders sought the shelter of the tents and log houses.

LONDON, July 17 (AP). -- The British team, led by 1,170 points tonight at the end of the second session of an Anglo-American contract bridge tournament with a team captained by Ely Culbertson of New York. With fifty boards played, the scores were: England 20,050 and United States 18,880.

In the six months ended on May 31, the net asset value of the common stock of the United Founders Corporation increased from 75 cents to $1.06 a share, according to the semi-annual report, issued yesterday. A year earlier, the asset value was 52 cents a share.
Forty-five golfers have filed their entries for the Metropolitan P.G.A. championship which gets under way Thursday at the Rockwood Hall Country Club, North Tarrytown.

Off-shore fishing is improving greatly, judging from all reports received from Long Island and New Jersey points. The off-shore fisherman has an advantage over the angler who prefers to fish closer to land. The fish run in bigger schools, generally are larger and usually give a better account of themselves when some distance out.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Buying of all grains by the public on the Board of Trade here was on from the start to the finish of the market today. Prices of all cereals advanced to the highest levels in recent years, cutting little figure with the average speculator, who was anxious chiefly to get possession of grain.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Public building, river and harbor and flood-control estimates were sent back to President Roosevelt's Cabinet Board today for strenuous reducing exercises to work off any fat that might be called "pork."

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., July 17 -- His motor boat capsized by the waves from the steamer Sagamore about 1,000 feet from Sabbath. Bay Point on Lake George, Henry Gillette, 18 years old, of New York City, narrowly escaped drowning today.

Anton L. Trunk, president of the New York Real Estate Board, wrote to Mayor O'Brien yesterday protesting tax exemption for the proposed Rutgerstown housing development on the East River. The project is before the Board of Estimate today for consideration.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. P.A.S. Franklin of 11 East Sixty-sixth Street will sail for Europe on Aug. 1.

David Lloyd George, wartime Prime Minister of Great Britain, was heard in the United States yesterday in a radio address from London, picked up by the networks of the National Broadcasting Company, commemorating the twenty-first anniversary of the British National Health Insurance Act, which Mr, Lloyd George was instrumental in enacting into law.

Furniture prices quoted yesterday at the opening of the Fall market in the New York Furniture Exchange, Inc., were 10 to 15 per cent above the levels prevailing two weeks ago at the Chicago opening, buyers said here yesterday. The sharpest rise was in case goods, which advanced in some instances as much as 60 per cent above the Chicago quotations.

With a second extraordinary session of the Legislature about to be called by Governor Lehman to give New York City financial relief, legislative leaders are looking for a highly controversial stay at the Capitol unless some formula can be worked out to avert partisan strife.

Not Capek's Robot. WILET POST'S robot-steered airplane would be receiving a lot of attention in the Soviet press if the newspapers there were interested in anything so frivolous as a flight around the world without a proletarian purpose.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- President Roosevelt tonight called the Civilian Conservation Corps the "vanguard of the new spirit of the American future," in a speech broadcast over two national radio chains.

HASBROUCK HEIGHTS, N.J., July 17 --Joseph A. Merola of North Side, defending his twice-won metropolitan public links title at the Teterboro Golf Club, lost in a semifinal match today to Louis Porreca, a former Teterboro Club champion, by 1 up.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on July 12 shows increases for the week of $38,000,000 in loans and investments, $67,000,000 in net demand deposits, $29,000,000 in time deposits and $36,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and decreases of $23,000,000 in government deposits and $10,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

BERLIN, July 17 -- The transatlantic flight of the Lithuanian pilots Captain Stephen Darius and Stanley Girenas came to a tragic end when, after conquering the Atlantic Ocean, both died as their plane crashed in a forest outside Soldin, Pomerania.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- In the first general order issued under the Emergency Railroad Transportation Act, Joseph B. Eastman, coordinator of transportation, today directed all railroads to report to him on the number, names and compensation of workers employed by them during May, 1933.

The estate of John McEntee Bowman, sportsman and president of the Bowman -- Biltmore Hotel Corporation, who died Oct. 28, 1931, was appraised yesterday as insolvent. While Mr. Bowman owned property valued at $750,331, there were deductions of $2,249,979, of which $2,112,527 was for debts.

TRENTON, N.J., July 17 -- In the third of a series of statements, made public today, the Legislature's Joint Committee on Taxation said consolidation of local governments, changes in structure and a redistribution of functions were imperative steps toward a sound and more equitable taxing policy.

Memberships on the Commodity Exchange jumped 50 per cent in value yesterday as a result of transactions, rising from $5,000 to $7,500. When the Exchange was formed in May, the issuing price for seats was $900. Yesterday's transactions were:

J.B. Priestley's sardonic history of life in polite society -- "Dangerous Corner" -- came back last night for another tussle with the local muses. It was revived up at the Waldorf Theatre, by the tireless Messrs. Wee and Leventhal, whose collective name seems to be Local Drama, during the Summer of 1933.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Prosecution of gold "hoarders" today appeared no more imminent than for some time past. Attorney General Cummings declared that the hoarders had been located and that action would be taken at the proper time.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES printed recently an interview with. Peter G. Ten Eyck, president of the New York State Waterways Association, in reference to the St. Lawrence waterways project, or "scheme," as he calls it, in which he accuses Senators Norris and Bone of being catspaws for the St. Lawrence advocates to promote a scheme which the "interests" are delicate about supporting openly.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated July 14:

ONDON, July 17 -- Producers of gasoline made from coal mined within the British Isles are to receive government help in the form of a tax preference of 4d per gallon. The gasoline tax is now 8d per gallon.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- An admonition to the Philippine Islands to consider the question of independence only "in accordance with the best and highest interests and aspirations of the Fillpino people," marked the first message of Frank Murphy, newly appointed Governor General, to the island Legislature.

FRIEDRICHSHAFEN, Germany, July 17 -- The giant airship under construction at the Zeppelin Works -- the LZ-129, which will be double the size of the Graf Zeppelin -- is taking shape, with 121 feet of the framework finished.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 17 -- The Essex County Club's women's invitation tennis tournament swept through the first two rounds today with play running true to form, to the anguish ot three young Pasadena (Cal.) players and as many members of the famous Palfrey family of Brookline.

ST. JOHN'S, Nfld., July 17 (AP) -- Colonel and Mrs. Lindbergh were prevented from leaving Cartwright, Labrador, today, on their aerial survey expedition, by dense fog along the Labrador coast. They are making their headquarters on the steamer Jelling, chartered by Pan-American Airways for the attempt to find practicable transatlantic routes by way of Labrador and Greenland.

Fall Purchasing Continues Gain. Buyers continued to arrive in this market yesterday from all sections of the country, and indications are that buying totals of style merchandise for the week will show a gain over last week. Preparations for August sales events are being rapidly completed, and response to these promotions will afford retailers the first definite test of improving conditions under the Industrial Recovery Act.

MOSCOW, July 17 -- Wiley Post took Moscow by surprise today when he made a short stop-over here on his journey in quest of the round-the-world flight record. He alighted at the Moscow airport at 2:20 P.M. [17:20 A.M. Eastern Daylight Time] and was off again for Novosibirsk at 5:12 P.M. [10:12 A.M. Eastern Daylight Time].
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- First departmental construction projects approved for New York and New Jersey under the $3,300,000,000 public building program include the following:

Chicago, Ill. The Chicago Board of Education has authorized $40,000,000 of new bonds, bankers here were advised yesterday. Robert B. Upham, who has just been named City Controller, has set no date for the marketing of the initial block of this authorization.

"The world must be made safe for prosperity," Dr. 'Wallace McClure, formerly acting economic adviser of the United States Department of State and co-founder of the Academy of World Economics, declares in his volume, "World Prosperity," published today by the Macmillan Company.

WASHINGTON, July 17.-With acceptances received from all of the countries invited to enter into individual trade-agreement negotiations with the United States, an informal official fact-finding committee began today a study of topics to be discussed.

Well educated, rich by inheritance as well as by his own efforts, a singularly able business man, WILLIAM L. WARD found in politics the satisfaction of his love of power. He loved, too, the struggles, excitements, lively fights of the game. Except for one term in the House of Representatives, he never held office, though heaven knows how many offices were filled upon his recommendation equivalent to a demand.

Last night's concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium took place before an audience of about 6,000. Willem Van Hoogstraten, who conducted, will not direct the orchestra again until Aug. 3. His program last night included Beethoven's fifth symphony, Tchaikovsky's "Romeo and Juliet," Strauss's waltz, "Voices of Spring," and the overture to "Tannhauser," as well as Sibelius's "Valse Triste" as an encore.
WEIMER, Germany, July 17 -- A memorial tablet to the assassins of Walther Rathenau was unveiled today in Saalek Castle in Thuringia by Captain Ehrhardt of Kapp revolt fame.

Prices of bonds rocketed yesterday on the Stock Exchange, many foreign and domestic issues gaining 1 to 9 points on the day and establishing new high quotations for the year to date. THE NEW YORK TIMES averages for foreign loans and domestic railroad, industrial and utility bonds touched new peaks for 1933.

BERLIN, July 17 -- Arthur Henderson, president of the Geneva Disarmament Conference, who is making a round of European capitals to discuss disarmament, arrived here today after having visited Paris and Rome.
The text of the Citizens Budget Commission's letter to Governor Lehman suggesting retrenchment measures for the city follows:

LONDON, July 17.-- The necessity of keeping the "World Economic Conference alive, whether in session or in recess, and of its steadily persisting till real progress is made was reaffirmed by Secretary of State Hull to American newspaper correspondents today.

LONDON, July 17 -- A Brazilian request for a reduction of tariff charges on coffee as part of a stabilization plan received scant sympathy from European consuming countries at today's meeting of the production and marketing subcommission of the World Economic Conference.
MINDEN, Nov., July 17 (AP). -- The brief marriage of Elliott Roosevelt, second son of the President, and the former Elizabeth Donner, Philadelphia society girl, ended in a swift divorce today.

Mrs. Dela Delapenha, 48 years old, ended her life by gas yesterday morning in the kitchen of her sixroom apartment on the sixth floor of the Century Apartments, 25 Central Park West. Mrs. Delapenha shared the apartment with her husband, Cecil E. Delapenha, a director of the importing house of R.U. Delapenha Co., 57 Laight Street.

MADRID, July 17 -- Ambassador Claude G. Bowers of the United States called on Foreign Minister Fernando de Los Rios today and demanded immediate action in the case of the five Americans arrested after a fight with the Guardia Civil in Palma, Island of Majorca, more than a month ago.

American steamship owners and operators have discussed in recent weeks the advisability of formulating a code of ethics under the National Industrial Reconstruction Act and have appointed a committee headed by J. Caldwell Jenkins, vice president of the Black Diamond Steamship Company, to study the matter further.

Ralph McElvenney, seeded No. 3, who was almost eliminated on Saturday, was close to defeat again yesterday before he vanquished William Thompson, Brooklyn southpaw, in the second round of the men's Richmond County clay court singles championship at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, S.I. The scores were: 6-2, 3-6, 6-4.

Unless present plans fail, New York's residents will be treated to the spectacle of General Italo Balbo's twenty-four Italian Army planes wheeling around three sides of Manhattan Island before they come to rest in Jamaica Bay on their way homeward from Chicago.

CHICAGO, July 17 -- Weather permitting, New York City will get its first glimpse of General Italo Balbo and his twenty-four silver-lined flying boats late Wednesday after noon on their homeward journey.

CAIRO, July 17 -- The violent antimissionary campaign, which has been gaining strength in Egypt in the past month, has now developed into a political issue. Since the government last week banned all public anti-missionary gatherings, the Opposition press is criticizing the government for trying to suppress what it terms "a peaceful movement to avert the danger of missionaries."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter from George Swinnerton Parker published in THE NEW YORK TIMES advocating physical punishment as a deterrent for the activities of gangsters will not, I believe, strike a responsive chord in the minds of those who have given considerable thought to the problem.

The Board of Estimate made its plaintive appeal to Albany, and now has its answer. Governor LEHMAN is willing to have a special session of the Legislature in order to grant the city government additional power to levy taxes, but the particular taxes proposed by the City Hall he bluntly rejects.

LONDON, July 17 -- David Lloyd George listened to plaudits from the whole nation today on the twenty-first anniversary of Britain's National Health Insurance Act which he sponsored in the teeth of the bitterest opposition in 1912.

Evidence of widespread improvement of business in Canada is noted by several official agencies. The wholesale price index of the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reached 67.6 in June, compared with 63.6 in February. This is a grain of 6.3 per cent in three months, or progress at the rate of about 20 per cent for a full year.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- In giving his final approval last night to the cotton textile code under the National Recovery Act, President Roosevelt accepted certain modifications which the applicants offered In consideration for making other changes on their own account.

LONDON, July 17 -- Discussing empire currency problems at Oxford University today, Sir J. S. Wardlaw-Milne, a former member of the Imperial Economic Committee and Conservative member of Parliament, said unless 'an empire currency standard were created it would be useless to discuss tariff policy.

The city's inability to sell corporate notes caused delay in incinerator construction to end the dumping of garbage at sea. This explanation was offered yesterday before Special Master Edward K. Campbell at a hearing in the Municipal Building.

Opposition by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, to the plan of the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company for resuming business was set forth in the Supreme Court yesterday in a petition by the Superintendent for permission to sell enough securities of the company to realize about $10,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Determined to approve only the most worthwhile projects in the Federal public works program, the Cabinet Advisory Board today submit to Lewis W. Douglas, Director of the Budget, a mass of proposed public building plans, and requested that he indicate early those he thought necessary.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 17 -- Westchester mourned today the loss of William L. Ward, "benevolent despot" of the Republican party, who ruled the county with a lima hand, but never missed an opportunity to help those in need. He died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital, New York, of pneumonia, which attacked him after an operation two weeks ago.

Although the dollar was comparatively steady yesterday in the foreign, exchange market, stocks and agricultural staples, as if to show their independence, engaged in another broad advance. Trading on the Stock Exchange and on most of the commodity exchanges was extremely active.

TORONTO, July 17 -- Bobby Pearce, star Australian sculler now living in Hamilton, Ont., today signed a contract to meet Ted Phelps of England, world's professional sculling champion, in a three-mile match race here Sept. 1.

FRANKFURT-AM-MAIN, July 17 --The body of Dr. Wilhelm Schaefer, who in November, 1931, advised the police of the notorious Bokheimer document, was discovered today in a ditch near a railway bridge on the outskirts of this city.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The proposed fair competition cods of the rayon weaving industry, submitted today to the National Recovery Administration, follows:
LONDON, July 17 -- The World Economic Conference is all ready to wind up its present business and subside until conditions are more favorable to its renewal.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 17 (AP). -- Rochester scored two in the ninth and one in the eleventh to beat Jersey City today, 6 to 5, in the first game of the series. Behind, 5 to 3, going into the final frame, the Wings bunched hits by Ostermueller and Carey with a walk to Toporcer to tie the score.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP). -- Thrilling finishes marked the running of the two top events at Arlington Park today.

The De Witt Clinton High School tennis ace, Joseph, Abrams, who won the Greater New York junior championship on Saturday, marched through two matches in the opening rounds of the Eastern junior clay court tourney yesterday with the loss of only one game.

MELBOURNE, July 17 -- The Australian Government's proposals for peopling the barren wastes of Northern Australia by granting concessions to two chartered companies financed by private capital has aroused world-wide interest.

A large and important school of European and American biologists has for years been collecting evidence from family histories and life insurance statistics to support the hypothesis that cancer is an inheritable disease. Much to be preferred are deductions from laboratory experiments under strict control.

The New York Stock Exchange has been notified by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, trustee for the guaranteed 6 1/2 per cent mortgage sinking fund gold bonds due in 1946 and guaranteed 6 1/2 per cent mortgage sinking fund gold bonds Series B due in 1946 of the Schulco Company, Inc., that the following mortgages constitute the present underlying collateral for the bonds:

The Eastern coordinating committee will confer tomorrow with Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Railroads, or his representative in the board room of the Central Railroad of New Jersey. H.J. German, on leave as president of the Montour Railroad and now Eastern regional director in Mr. Eastman's organization, is to attend the meeting and, in the absence of Mr. Eastman, to represent him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The violent swing from the enthusiastic and romantic internationalism of President Roosevelt's earlier utterances to the narrow and reactionary nationalism he now proclaims is no less astonishing than are the contradictions in our foreign policy -- if, indeed, the term "foreign policy" may be applied to an inchoate mass of conflicting tendencies and purposes.

With the speculative movement gathering momentum, the markets moved into new high ground again yesterday. Stocks took their cue largely from the action of commodities, although the week-end news touching the domestic business position must have encouraged the buying of securities.

Hearing on a motion to punish. Assemblyman David Paris for contempt of court on the charge made by Thomas E. Dewey, Chief Assistant United States Attorney, was adjourned yesterday until next Monday. The Assemblyman is accused of knowingly submitting forged affidavits to support a motion for a new trial for his brother, Sidney Paris, convicted of mail fraud.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Wholesale commodity prices rose 3% per cent from May to June, showing an increase for the fourth consecutive month, and, for the first time since 1929. an increase for the current month over the corresponding month of the previous year, the Department of Labor announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Entrenched racketeering was linked to corrupt politicians and the bootleggin traffic by Attorney General Cummings today in an appeal to the public to support the law enforcement agencies.

Postponed for the second time by a wet field yesterday, the national junior polo championships will get under way today at 5 o'clock, weather permitting, with Roslyn and the Aiken Knights meeting in a first-round match at Bostwick Field, Old Westbury, L.I.

It would require the talents of Mr. Chadband adequately to lament the unfortunate situation in which the London Conference now finds itself. Soon it is to take a recess which is generally expected to be an adjournment. Fathered by RAMSAY MACDONALD, and certainly for a month or so mothered and nursed by President ROOSEVELT, the Conference has apparently lost both parents.

Five persons were burned, two of them critically, when two large trucks in which they were riding collided at West and Leroy Streets last night. Both vehicles burst into flames. The injured, one of whom was a 17-year-old girl, were rushed to St. Vincent's Hospital in police cars and private machines.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- More than 10,000,000 acres of cotton have been offered for destruction in the sixteen cotton States, taking 3,500,000 bales or more out of production, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today on the basis of latest estimates.

For a time JIM WATSON has vanished from Washington. That fine, robust figure and voice are seen and heard only in memory and his Indiana. Fortunately, his influence as a great constructive statesman is still powerful. Next to him and literature, Bedford limestone is the most famous of Hoosier products.

BOSTON, July 17 (AP). -- The hum of cotton textile machinery in New England mills today spelled a message of greater employment as thousands of operatives went to work at increased wages and shorter hours under the National Recovery Act.

Colonel Jacob Ruppert, whose investments in New York City real estate have been a feature of the current market, enlarged his holdings yesterday by the purchase of a tall building in the Grand Central zone. The brewer and owner of the New York Yankees has just bought the twenty-three-story Hoagland Building at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Fortieth Street.

A forty-eight-hour week and a minimum wage of 35 cents an hour for men and 27 cents for women will be established by the code of fair competition adopted by the newsprint industry under the National Industrial Recovery Act.

A 1-to-3 shot and three other favorites met defeat at Empire City yesterday in one of the greatest setbacks form has sustained at this session. Ayston, owned by the B. B. Stable, was the outstanding choice, and he lost by four lengths before the stretch rush of Mrs. T. R. Queen's Grannys Trade, a 10-to-1 shot, in the featured Old Hickory Purse.

SOLDIN, Germany, July 17 -- Although, the log of the airplane Lithuanica had been badly damaged in the plane's crash and was blotted by oil, it showed that Captain Stephen Darius and Stanley Girenas had left the North American Continent at Ragged Harbor, Nfld., and flown straight for Ireland, proceeding south of Galway.

The development by the Federal Government of the Tennessee Valley is not primarily a power and fertilizer project, and care will be taken to avoid competition with existing power interests. Earle S. Draper, Director of Land Planning and Housing of the Tennessee Valley Authority, said here yesterday.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Tuesday, July 18 -- General Feng's occupation of Dolonnor is regarded as a violation of the spirit of the Tangku truce and represents an intolerable threat to the peace and safety of Jehol, said a spokesman of the Japanese Army headquarters today.

Signs of a firming up in time money were evident in the day's session. Demand was keen for all maturities, but offerings were not particularly heavy. The only funds around were 90 days', and this was done at 1 1/4, all offerings being used up.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 17 -- Rear Admiral and Mrs. William S. Sims will open their home tomorrow for an exhibition and sale of industrial products for the benefit of the Grenfell mission in Labrador. The patrons and patronesses for the sale include:

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The entire staff of the National Recovery Administration was pressed into action today by General Hugh. S. Johnson to frame a blanket code for all business without waiting for approval of the various fair-competition agreements.

Officers of the Musical Mutual Corporation, a union, protested yesterday that the bands of the Police, Fire and Sanitation Departments and the letter carriers' band encroached upon the field of professional musicians. The statement, signed by Richard McCann, president, and Sigmund Pollatschek, secretary, said that 15,000 of the city's approximately 17,000 musicians were jobless and should not have to face municipal "competition."

With Wiley Post speeding eastward into the Siberian wastes many hours ahead of his 1931 time, when he set the record, with Harold Gatty, for a flight around the world of 8 days 15 hours 51 minutes, his wife and friends here were in a cheerful frame of mind yesterday.

The imposition of an excise tax of at least 2 cents on rapid transit fares is receiving serious consideration from Tammany leaders, looking to the special legislative session to be called by Governor Lehman at the request of the Board of Estimate.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Two codes of fair competition in men's wear manufacturing now are before the Industrial Recovery Administration.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 17 -- Mrs. Henry Lorillard Cammann gave a luncheon today at Lougret Lodge, her place in North Sea Road, for Mrs. Patrick A. Valentine Jr. of Chicago, who is passing the Summer at Valmay cottage. Others In the party were Miss Louise Willard and Mrs. Cammann's daughter, Mrs. William C. Browning, who, with her young sons, William H. Browning 2d and Kirk Browning, is here for a visit.

BUENOS AIRES, July 17 -- A governmental crisis involving the pending trade treaty with Great Britain and continued payments on foreign debts resulted tonight in an offer of the resignation of Finance Minister Alberto Hueyo. President Justo is trying to get him to withdraw the resignation.

PARIS, July 17 -- The whole future of French political development has been rendered uncertain by the action of the Socialist Congress, which by a very large majority today censured, though in the mildest possible manner, the support that the Socialist party in the Chamber of Deputies has given during the past seven months to the Daladier government.
Sales announced in New Jersey yesterday indicate a preference for housing properties there.

When Congress enacted in 1897 the law under which the Library of Congress has since been administered, it rejected political patronage by putting upon the Librarian full responsibility for the selection of his staff. So concerned was Congress for the institution which was to bear its name that it wished it to be above reproach.

Two more arrests were made last evening in the investigation of charges of racketeering in workmen's compensation claims, started last April by Morris H. Panger, Assistant District Attorney, at the request of Governor Lehman. The prisoners are Dr. Louis H. hadin, who is connected with three workmen's clinics operated by Dr. Max Lowenthal on the lower west side, and Louis Simon, an attendant in the clinic at 72 Bleecker Street.

HARRISBURG, July 17 -- Miss Charlotte E. Carr, Director of the Bureau of Inspection of the State Department of Labor and Industry and former Acting Director of the Women's Bureau of the Department of Labor in New York under Miss Frances Perkins, was appointed today by Governor Pinchot as Secretary of Labor and Industry.

CARLISLE, Pa., July 17 -- Company A, consisting of New York, college students, won the annual R.O.T.C. track and field meet today with a total of 50 points. The other scores were: Company D, 47; Company B, 29 1/2; Company C, 25 1/2.

The Guardian Life Insurance Company, as plaintiff, yesterday bought in the Port Morris Industrial Terminal at Locust Avenue and the East River on a bid of $100,000 at a foreclosure sale held by Reid Kyle, auctioneers. The insurance company was foreclosing a lien of $234,973 against the Port Morris Industrial Terminal Company.

LONDON, July 17 -- Prime Minister MacDonald astonished the House of Commons today by partly repudiating "Walter Runciman's rejection of public works schemes at the World Economic Conference last week.
ALBANY, July 17 -- The eleventh day of the O'Connell kidnapping case dragged slowly by today with no outward sign of progress in the ransom negotiations or the official investigation.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 17 -- The popular concerts at the County Centre continued tonight in defiance of the ruling of Local 802 of the New York Musicians Union that they should stop.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 17 (AP). -- Starting cautiously because it never before has been regulated by Federal law, the Carolina textile industry today joined cotton mills of the nation in putting into effect the new code of fair competition.

PITTSBURGH, July 17 -- More than 125,000 steel mill employes in the Pittsburgh district rejoiced today with wage advances which will add $1,250,000 to their monthly payroll in the future. Their last month's payroll was $8,500,000 and this is their first rise in ten years.

The Home and Farm Mortgage Advisory Committee recently appointed by Governor Lehman met yesterday afternoon at the Merchants Association offices in the Woolworth Building. It was appointed to study and report on how the State could cooperate in the functioning of the Federal Home Owners Loan Corporation.

NOVOSIBIRSK, Siberia, Tuesday, July 18 -- Wiley Post, the American round-the-world flier, took off toward Irkutsk, Siberia, at 9:02 A.M. today, Moscow time [2:02 A.M. Eastern Daylight Time] just two hours and thirty-five minutes after completing an 1,800-mile jump from Moscow.
Madison Toy Mart, Kurt Schoenfeld, proprietor, large shop on the ground floor of the RCA Building in Rockefeller Center for ten years, through Cushman Wakefield, brokers.

MANILA, July 17 -- Widespread approval was accorded here today to Governor General Frank Murphy's message to the Legislature in which he urged speedy action on independence, a sound financial policy, suffrage for women and governmental guidance for business and agriculture.

"Strictly Dynamite," a satirical comedy by Robert T. Colwell and Robert A. Simon, will be offered by Morris Green and Frank McCoy at the Boulevard Theatre in Jackson Heights on July 31. It is to be directed by Leo Bulgakov.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 17 -- There were 228 competing sailing craft today in the second regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week. It was the largest number gathered since 1931. Last year the top was 211, also at Larchmont.

Urbain Ledoux, who recently announced his candidacy for Mayor as "Mr. Zero" from the ranks of the unemployed, attempted yesterday to outline a part of his campaign program. He visited the office of Mayor O'Brien at noon and left a letter containing several tax recommendations.

In the following comparisons the Labor Bureau's index numbers of wholesale prices are based on 784 commodities since the end of 1931 and on 550 for earlier dates. Comparisons with months prior to 1932 are presumably affected by this change. The index number for all commodities in June. 1933, com- pares with the average in previous months and years as follows:

Representatives of nearly all the organized groups associated with the legitimate stage were present yesterday afternoon at the first meeting presided over by Sol A. Rosenblatt, acting for General Hugh S. Johnson, administrator of the Recovery Act, in an attempt to adopt a unified fair practice code.

PATERSON, N.J., July 17 -- Several strikes in some of the smaller silk mills of this city marked the establishment today of the industry's code as prescribed by the National Industrial Recovery Act, and under which the cotton industry also began to operate today.
BOSTON, July 17 -- Attorney General Joseph E. Warner told a legislative committee today that what the State needed was a fearless, capable and relentless leader to cope with crime conditions.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- A swift gathering of Federal strength to help the oil industry back to sound footing was in progress today as the Interior Department put investigators to work in East Texas to carry out its program for halting the flow of illegal petroleum.
Inexperience with Hudson tides almost caused the drowning of three youths last night under the George Washington Bridge.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 17 -- One hundred and five employes of cotton mills in the immediate Chattanooga area lost their jobs today as the new cotton mill code went into effect. The Richmond Hosiery Mill, Chattanooga's largest hosiery manufacturer, telegraphed President Roosevelt that the new hosiery code, if adopted, would force the release of 300 to 400 employes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In this day of codes and legislated ethics one cannot but ponder the death of Captain F.L. Sears, who chose to go down with his burning tanker the other night southeast of Hatteras. In taking this grim course he fulfilled to the letter an unwritten code which has come down, unaltered, through centuries, that the captain shall be the last to leave his ship.

For an hour and forty-seven minutes yesterday the baseball teams of the Police and Fire Departments played before 20,000 partisan fans at the Polo Grounds. The curving shadow of the upper stand was just beginning to eat across the diamond when Johnny Buthman, lanky first baseman, scooped up Fireman Harry McCrystal's grounder and made the put-out that clinched a police victory.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 17 -- Jack Mackie Jr., former New York State amateur champion, and his partner, Pete Cassella, made a runaway out of the amateur-professional one-day tournament sponsored by the Long Island Golf Association and played over the Old Westbury Golf Club course today.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Events today moved toward a clash of organized labor and open shop industrialists on the company union provisions of the steel code submitted last week.

As the textile code went into effect and many steel mills anticipated the 15 per cent wage increase promised by that industry's code, nearly a million Americans benefited yesterday by pay rises or increased employment through shorter working hours.

Record trading in crude rubber and cocoa futures was the feature of the local commodity exchanges yesterday. Prices in all markets pushed higher, although some openings were irregular. New high prices for 1933 were made in many of the cash markets.
Joseph W. Harriman disappeared yesterday from the Regent Nursing Home for the second time since he was indicted for falsifying the books of the Harriman National Bank.

ALBANY, July 17 -- Governor Lehman today met with Vincent Dailey, State manager for the Federal Home Owners Loan Corporation, but would not reveal the subject of the conversation. Later the Governor attended the opening of the new Troy-Menands Bridge across the Hudson River, where he spoke informally for a few minutes.

BERLIN, July 17 -- The Boerse opened firm and active today, the majority of stocks gaining 2 to 3 per cent, bonds followed with gains up to 2 per cent. The upward swing was attributed largely to the formation of the General Economic Council announced Saturday, which is accepted as a further indication that the government wishes to avoid daring experiments and drastic interference in business.

LOS ANGELES, July 17 (AP). -- Aimee Semple McPherson-Hutton, evangelist, was sued for divorce today by David Hutton, her third husband, who listed as a cardinal complaint the baby hoax which he alleged she perpetrated in Paris a few weeks ago.

LEICESTER, England, July 17 (Canadian Press) -- Leicestershire today tallied 231 runs for the loss of eight wickets in the first innings of its cricket match against the touring West Indians, who compiled a total of 156 in their first time at bat.

PARIS, July 17 -- The American Davis Cup squad faced two foes today as Ellsworth Vines, Wilmer Allison, George Lott and Johnny Van Ryn swung into the closing practices for the interzone matches with Great Britain starting Friday.

An enormous audience assembled in the Lewisohn Stadium last night to see the first of two dance performances by Edwin Strawbridge, Pauline Koner and a ballet of forty. Though both the principals are good dancers and many of their assistants also have honorable records, the program was a singularly unrewarding one.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- Threats of injunction suits against Federal oil regulation drew the announcement today from Secretary Ickes that two Interior Department attorneys were in the East Texas field looking over the situation.

The installation of new systems of uniform accounts proposed by the Public Service Commission would cost the electric light and gas companies in the city millions of dollars for installation and maintenance, with resultant rises in costs to consumers, it was testified yesterday at a public hearing in the commission's offices.

The receivers of the American Commonwealths Power Corporation are proceeding with a settlement and adjustment of all the claims existing between the receivership estate and the American Gas and Power Company, American Commonwealth Power Associates, International Utilities Corporation and Dominion Gas and Electric Company.

The era of mechanization is indicted as "the murderer of music" in a pamphlet issued yesterday by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers. What has happened to "the lovely art of music" is revealed by charts, which with figures serve as evidence that the talking pictures, radio and the phonograph have "murdered" music, at the same time failing to compensate musical genius adequately for talent and melody that have been killed.

The machinery set in motion by Sol A. Rosenblatt, representing General Hugh S. Johnson, to work out a unified fair practice code for the legitimate theatre gained impetus yesterday in an effort to have the complete code ready by next week.

The General Electric Company received orders of $35,539,858 in the second quarter of 1933, compared to $35,304,070 in the same period of 1932, a gain of nearly 1 per cent, Gerard Swope, president, announced yesterday. This is the first time since early 1930 that there has been an increase in any quarter over the same period of the year before.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was somewhat surprised to note the complaint registered in THE TIMES in regard to service in the catalogue room of the reference department of the New York Public Library. I have been using that department for years as a student and only on rare occasions has the question whether I was a student come up.

Virtually every radical organization in the city sent a delegation yesterday to the funeral of Antonio Fierro, 22 years old, a City College student, who was shot and killed last Friday in a fight between Communists and members of the Khaki Shirts of America.
CHICAGO, July 18. -- General Italo Balbo and his twenty-four giant seaplanes will leave Chicago's lake front tomorrow morning sometime between 8 and 10 o'clock, Eastern Daylight Time.

The proposed charge for automobile parking at Floyd Bennett Field during the Balbo air manoeuvres in Jamaica Bay was canceled yesterday. The city had seen an additional source of revenue in the concession let to an agency, but later decided to permit free parking to serve "the broader needs of the public."

MADRID, July 18. -- In a pastoral letter to the Spanish Bishops and people, the Archbishop of Goma, the new primate and head of the Spanish Church, emphasizes that the Catholic Church in Spain is fighting against annihilation through being gradually cut to pieces by "fiendishly clever revolutionaries."

Prince Desta Demtu, husband of the Princess Tanagnawork, eldest daughter of the Emperor Haile Selassie I, who is Lord King of Kings of Ethiopia, Conquering Lion of the Tribe of Judah, the Elect of God and the Light of the World, arrived in New York yesterday.

The upward sweep of bond prices continued yesterday on the Stock Exchange, with foreign loans and domestic railroad and industrial bonds leading. Utility issues and United States Government bonds were irregularly lower on the day.

The special committee of shipping men which was appointed to consider the status of the shipping industry under the National Industrial Recovery Act reported yesterday that steamship owners were unanimous in their willingness to adopt a code of industrial ethics if the government desires one.
NEWARK, N.J., July 18. -- Major Gen. Morton was in command of the war-time Twenty-ninth Division, which included the National Guards of New Jersey, Maryland and Virginia.

MOSCOW, July 18. -- Joseph Stalin himself took a most active part in working out the recent measures of railroad reform, the most important of which is the establishment of a new political department like that of the Red Army and tractor stations.

Four seeded singles players were eliminated yesterday during the second day's play in the Eastern junior clay court championship tournament at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills. They were Donald M. Lay Jr., Jack Mahoney, Ray Antigant and Robert Kerdasha, who were ranked Nos. 5, 6, 7 and 8, respectively, in the seeded list.
ST. LOUIS, July 18 (AP). -- Dizzy Dean was effective today, and the Cardinals won from the Phillies, 9 to 4, to get an even break in the series. It was Dean's twelfth victory of the season.
BOMBAY, July 18. -- Events moved rapidly at Poona today, following the receipt by Mahatma Gandhi last night of the Viceroy's second telegram refusing his request for an interview.

NOVOSIBIRSK, July 18 (AP). -- Wiley Post refused to take a nap after he had arrived here today, but he rested a short while on a couch at the airport and chatted with Miss Fay Gillis, American flier, his representative here for the flight.

Should the Massachusetts Legislature grant the power to combat crime which Attorney General WARNER seeks, the probability is that the Supreme Court of the State would hold much of it invalid. In the indignation that mounts against the spread of such crimes as kidnapping it is natural that the authorities should call for more weapons of their own.
BERLIN, July 18 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of July 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

The New Deal was to give us controlled inflation, but who is to control speculation? Thus far inflation has been, more by way of prophecy than fact. Actual increase of the currency has not taken place. On the contrary, money in circulation in the United States is less by a billion or more than it was a few months ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is incredible that in 1933 we should still be in the process of discussing eight-hour duty for nurses, when for years it has been unlawful to employ strong men longer than eight hours, and in this period of depression there is fervent advocacy of the thirty-hour week for every one.

The death of William L. Ward, veteran Republican leader of Westchester County, has placed the Westchester Republicans face to face with a crisis in the election this Fall. A contest over the election of his successor is expected also.

LONDON, July 18 (AP). -- Samuel Untermyer, in a statement today, approved Governor Herbert H. Lehman's agreement to call a special legislative session to aid New York City problems, but criticized the restriction to relief of any taxes levied.

Marked activity in apartment renting in Manhattan was reflected in the long list of contracts for new living quarters reported by brokers yesterday. The brisk market was taken as a favorable augury for the Fall season. Leases were about evenly divided between the east and west sides.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP). -- A 4-to-3 defeat administered by the lowly Browns today removed the Senators from a tie for first place in the American League race and dropped them to the second position, a full game behind the Yankees.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- There is no reason why the Industrial Recovery Act should prove a boomerang for some workers and result in their discharge, said William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today upon receiving word from the South that some textile mills had no places for some operatives under the new dispensation of the forty-hour -week.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Five more registration statements under the Securities Act, including a description of an issue of common stock by the Stutz Motor Car Company, were made public today by the Federal Trade Commission.

SANDWICH, England, July 18. -- The "old gentlemen" of Britain defeated the seniors of the United States and Canada in their tripartite golf matches contested over the Royal St. Georges course yesterday and today. The victory gave the British the Lord Derby Cup.

Except for rubber, which experienced a technical reaction, prices of commodities traded on local exchanges continued to push higher yesterday. Cocoa broke all previous records by a wide margin. There was no interruption in the march of cash prices to higher levels.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 18. -- The contest between Musicians Local 802 of New York City and Mrs. Marion Downes of White Plains, who is trying to give musicians partial employment in her series of "Garden Pop" concerts, was unsettled tonight and Mrs. Downes seemed confident of the concerts' permanency.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Action which is expected by officials to take thousands of unemployed heads of families off the relief rolls of the Federal, State and local governments by putting them on the payrolls of public-works projects was announced today by Harry L. Hopkins, Emergency Relief Administrator.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 18. -- Chattanooga business men were awaiting with considerable trepidation today the final disposition of the Hosiery Manufacturers code which, according to Richmond Spinning Mills, one of the largest local plants, will result in the laying off of several hundred workers there and possibly hundreds more in other full-fashioned plants in this immediate area.
PARIS, July 18. -- The news that French three-month Treasury bills were being offered in the London market arousad considerable comment here today.

When General Italo Balbo's twenty-four flying boats are sighted this afternoon approaching New York it will be the signal for two coast-to-coast networks to begin broadcasting word-pictures of the armada's visit. Long before the air fleet can be seen, two airplanes, equipped with microphones and short-wave telephone apparatus, will soar over Manhattan to look for the fliers.

Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, who has been serving as acting president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation since the resignation of William F. Carey on June 30, was formally elected president of the organization at the regular meeting of the board of directors yesterday.
PLANDOME, L.I., July 18. -- Miss Helen Hicks, former national champion, played an epochal round of golf over the Plandome Club course today.

The code of fair competition under the National Industrial Recovery Act adopted by the hat industry and made public yesterday by the Hat Institute, Inc., provides for a forty-hour week. It establishes a minimum wage at the rate of 35 cents an hour.
Barred windows and guards sur- rounded Joseph W. Harriman last night for the first time since he was indicted for misapplying funds of the Harriman National Bank.

The observatory atop the seventy-story RCA Building, central unit in the Rockefeller Center midtown development, was opened yesterday and a steady stream of visitors was carried up to the roof to view the new panorama of the metropolitan area unfolded below them.

The sixty-five companies writing workmen's compensation insurance in this State paid out more than $27,000,000 during 1932, sustaining a loss of about $1,800,000. These figures were submitted yesterday at a meeting of the special subcommittee on workmen's compensation insurance of the National Convention of Insurance Commissioners.

A 22-year-old sexton who wanted to ring a church bell at 1 A.M. yesterday, but hesitated to ring that of his own church for fear of losing his job, was held in $10,000 bail in police court, Stapleton, S.I., after another church bell had been tolled.

Good-sized tuna are being caught along the New Jersey coast, but few have been reported in Long Island waters. None has been caught around Block Island, but Captain Harry Smith says he has sighted several small schools.

The Yankees vaulted back into first place undisputed yesterday on a barrage of hits that gave them their second straight victory over the Chicago White Sox. The score was 9 to 4. Incidentally, it was the ninth consecutive triumph for the world's champions.

LONDON, July 18 (AP). -- The British team, after having its lead whittled down below the 1,000 mark, came back to lead the United States team by 1,400 points when the second day of the British-American contract bridge match was concluded tonight on the ninety-sixth hand.

DES MOINES, July 18. -- The Federal Government today urged farm organization leaders of ten corn-belt States to take immediate steps to raise the price of hogs by utilizing the powers given the Department of Agriculture under the Farm Adjustment Act to curtail production of corn and live stock.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The index numbers of employment and payroll totals in manufacturing industries in June, as compared with May, June of last year and the twelve-month average of 100 in 1926, were made public this afternoon by Secretary Perkins, as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 18. --The hopes of officials here for a new Pan-American trade alliance were increased today by unofficial reports from Buenos Aires indicating that strong opposition to the intended Anglo-Argentine trade pact had arisen in Argentina.

MOSCOW, July 18. -- Wiley Post, who is racing around the world against time, set his plane down at Irkutsk at 9:35 P.M. Irkutsk time [8:35 A.M. Eastern Daylight Time], having completed the 890-mile hop from Novosibirsk in 6 hours 33 minutes.

PARIS, July 18. -- America's Davis Cup forces, growing steadily in favor in the eyes of the French as the interzone Davis Cup final series with England approaches, practiced lightly today on the Roland Garros Stadium centre court, where play starts Friday.
BUENOS AIRES, July 18. -- President Justo accepted today the resignation of Finance Minister Alberto Hueyo, who has opposed ratification of the new commercial treaty with Britain.

QUEBEC, July 18. -- The outlook for the newsprint industry is encouraging, but the menace of lower prices remains, and unless this is warded off by the Recovery Act program in the United States there is every danger of lower prices prevailing, Colonel J.H. Price, head of Price Brothers Co., Ltd., Canada's oldest newsprint firm, and former president of the Newsprint Institute of Canada, said yesterday in an interview.

A midsummer clearance sale will be held at the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop Association, 705 Second Avenue, next Tuesday and Wednesday for the benefit of four organizations that care for needy cancer patients. They are the Stuyvesant Square Hospital Social Service Department, the Brooklyn Cancer Welfare Service, the Memorial Hospital Social Service Department and the New York City Cancer Institute Social Service Department.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The action of the French Line and the Red Star Line in granting 30 per cent reductions from established tariff fares to members of religious orders holding French and Belgian passports is to be investigated by the Shipping Board.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 18. -- Eighty-four golfers, comprising members of the New York Athletic Club and their guests, turned out for the organization's third monthly one-day tournament today at the Ardsley Club links.

The three-cornered fight for control of comprehensive bus operation in Manhattan was continued yesterday before the Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate. The rival applicants for long-term grants covering important crosstown and longitudinal routes were the Green Bus Lines, Inc., the East Side Omnibus Corporation and the New York City Omnibus Corporation, the latter a subsidiary of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and the New York Railways Corporation.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 18. -- Efforts to sell $400,000 in stock necessary to found the new Commercial National Bank and release $4,000,000 in deposits now tied up in the old Chattanooga National, were near success today, according to the stock sale committee.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- President Roosevelt plans to give a full exposition of his industrial recovery hopes and policies in an address next Tuesday night directed to the Governors' conference in San Francisco.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,633,150 barrels compared to 2,596,250 barrels in the preceding week, a gain of 36,900 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gains of 14,150 barrels daily in Oklahoma and of 12,000 barrels daily in the Conroe field of Texas were among the most important changes for the week.

PALMA, Majorca, July 18. -- The four American men imprisoned here today directed an urgent appeal to their government's representatives in Spain to press for the immediate release from custody of their woman companion, Mrs. Caroline Lockwood.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 18. -- With the vote of three-fifths of the State counted on today's election on prohibition repeal, dry leaders conceded that repeal had carried.

FLUSHING, L.I., July 18. -- By virtue of two consistent rounds today, the Oakland Golf Club entrants, George J. (Bud) Gillespie and Ray Kilthau, carried off the Long Island amateur team championship with a thirty-six-hole bestball net score of 134 at the Fresh Meadow Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The popular vote for and against repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment as represented by the States which have already ratified in conventions or elected wet delegates is shown in the following table, with Alabama and Arkansas, in both of which repeat has apparently won, omitted:

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 18. -- By a ratio of more than three to two on the basis of tabulations of three-fourths of the estimated total vote cast, Arkansas went on record today in favor of repealing the Eighteenth Amendment.
Rathenau's Slayers Honored. A memorial tablet to the murderers of WALTHER RATHENAU has been unveiled by Captain EHRHARDT of Kapp "Putsch" fame in the presence of Nazi storm troops and leaders.
CHICAGO, July 18. -- Elliott Roosevelt, 22-year-old son of the President, arrived today by plane from Nevada, where he was divorced yesterday from Mrs. Elizabeth Donner Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Acting on reports from thirty-nine cities and towns in twenty-one States and the District of Columbia, Attorney General Cummings has begun an investigation into complaints that bread prices have increased more than warranted.

The Madison Square Garden Festival concerts, which were inaugurated last Winter for the benefit of unemployed musicians, will be continued next season, Walter Damrosch announced yesterday. The veteran conductor, who organized last Winter's series, will direct all five concerts projected.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The army, navy and marine corps have completed elaborate arrangements for the welcome and entertainment of General Italo Balbo and his subordinate flying officers when they visit Washington Thursday.

The expansion of universities is necessary in great industrial centres to take care of the young men and women who are not wanted in industry at the present time, according to Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, new chancellor of New York University.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 18. -- Rallying from apparent defeat, Miss Bonnie Miller of Los Angeles today overcame Miss Dorrance Chase of Boston to give the strong California delegation a clean sweep in the third-round matches of the Essex County Club's invitation tennis tournament.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 (AP). -- A home-run attack by John Stone and Erv Fox in the eighth, inning sent three runs across and broke up a pitchers' duel to give the Tigers a 5-to-2 victory over the Athletics today.

William M. Martin Jr. of the Yale Club triumphed in the first upset of the tourney when he conquered Alfred J. Cawse Sr., former national veterans' champion, who was seeded eighth, to gain the quarterfinal round in tie Richmond County clay court men's singles tennis championship at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, S.I., yesterday.

Glenn Hunter and Erin O'BrienMoore will play the leading roles in "Strictly Dynamite," the comedy by Robert T. Colwell and Robert A. Simon, to be put forward at the Boulevard Theatre in Jackson Heights on July 31.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Contradictory views of the outcome of the World Economic and Monetary Conference in London were expressed today by speakers at round tables of the congress being held by the National Council of Women.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The Recovery Administration moved forward on two fronts today, seeking on the one hand to induce the submission of fair competition agreements for hearing and approval, and on the other to work out the final details of a temporary blanket code to bring about immediately a shorter work week with a compensatory higher wage.

SAN JOSE, Cal., July 18. -- Roscoe Arbuckle left an estate of between $100,000 and $150,000, according to the contention here today of his brothers, Clyde Arbuckle of San Jose and Harry Arbuckle of Fresno.
ELKO, Nev., July 18 (AP). -- Jack Dempsey, former heavyweight boxing champion, and Hannah Williams, "cheerful little earful" of the Broadway stage, were married at a surprise ceremony here today.

The Carib Syndicate, Ltd., has given to stockholders rights to subscribe to 220,020 additional shares of stock at $6 a share in the ratio of thirty-eight new shares for each 100 shares held. Warrants will be available on July 24 and may be exercised prior to Aug. 11.

Aside from the "shake-out" in the stocks of companies which are identified in the popular imagination with the possible ending of prohibition, the share market, although it was extremely heavy, furnished little excitement yesterday. Even the brokers found it difficult to account for the enormous volume of trading -- 6,586,000 shares, as compared with 6,386,000 on the day before -- but they asserted that public interest in the market was increasing.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Northern and Southern non-union bituminous coal operators in session here today agreed on a forty-hour work week and separated into two groups to consider the program they are to submit to the Recovery Administration.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius of 960 Fifth Avenue and Locust Valley, L.I., will sail Saturday on the Rex for a stay of several weeks in Italy. She will return late in September and will be at The Shelter, her home in Locust Valley, L.I., for the Autumn.

BERLIN, July 18. -- The Boerse was quiet but fairly steady today. Yesterday's upward swing failed to draw a public following, with the result that traders began to take profits. Nevertheless some of the heavy industrials, machineries, Reichsbank, Dye Trust, Rayons and some of the lignite shares were able to improve from mere fractions to as much as 3 per cent.

BOSTON, July 18 (AP). -- Monte Pearson held the Red Sox to four hits today and pitched the Indians to a 2-to-1 victory. The only run made off the former Toledo hurler was Jolley's homer into the right-field bleachers. Harder relieved him in the ninth with two on bases and two out and retired the last man.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES prints a letter from John Fritz, who advocates a Danubian Economic Union as a means of rectifying the present serious conditions not alone in Central Europe but also in the world as well.
PITTSBURGH, July 18. -- The Dodgers allowed the Pirates to make a clean sweep of the three-game series by kicking away a six-run lead today and winding up on the short end of an 11-to-8 count.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 18. -- Many younger members of the Summer colony attended the fourth in the series of assemblies tonight at the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club. Mrs. John F. Murray gave a dinner at the Meadow Club in advance of the dance, for the patronesses, including Mrs. Louis C. Haggerty, Mrs. Joseph Bradley Murray, Mrs. Wilfred J. Funk and Mrs. Wesley C. Bowers.

CINCINNATI, July 18. -- Launching a violent Offensive, the Giants fairly overwhelmed the Reds today to bring the series to a satisfactory conclusion and maintain a three and a half game margin over the second-place Cubs.

The business code of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, with some modifications from the draft as published, is expected to be filed at Washington soon, possibly this week. Lew Hahn, president of the association, announced last night.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- In the absence of President Roosevelt, who was still confined to his rooms with a slight cold, the first official session of the Executive Council was held today with Attorney General Cummings presiding.
WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The War Department issued the following orders today, dated July 15:

Relief for substitute employes of the Postoffice Department was sought yesterday by several hundred of their number, who marched from Madison Square to the City Hall to protest wages and working conditions.

A group of muncipal bankers and experts in municipal finance will leave here tomorrow for Chicago to attend the Municipal Finance Conference beginning Friday and lasting till Sunday, under the auspices of the Public Administration Clearing House and a score of civic organizations.

Sarah Cooper Hewitt, daughter of Abram S. Hewitt, Mayor of New York in the Eighties, and granddaughter of Peter Cooper, founder of Cooper Union, left an estate valued at $5,999,693 gross and $5,843,122 net when she died on Oct. 16, 1930, the appraisal showed yesterday.

Buyers Here Show Small Decline. The number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a small drop in comparison with the figures for the preceding week. However, the total remained well above the number listed in the same period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Continuing cautiously in distribution of Federal funds for public works and highway projects, the Cabinet Advisory Board allocated an additional $40,363,948 today to nine States for road work.
PEIPING, Wednesday, July 19. -- The Japanese army is today preparing for 3 new adventure in North China.
With fair weather predicted, thousands of New Yorkers are expected to turn out this afternoon to welcome the Italian air fleet of twentyfour seaplanes and ninety-six men, led by General Italo Balbo.

When Dr. MCCLEARY, once principal medical officer of the National Health Insurance Commission for England, was here a few weeks ago he discussed certain phases of the Health Insurance Act. The twenty-first anniversary of its adoption is being celebrated in England this week.

The Stimulus colt Malimou ran in front from start to finish of the featured Geneseo Purse to win by a nose yesterday at Empire City. The short-priced favorite, Ward-InChancery, 7 to 10, was second, driven out to the utmost but unable to overhaul the winner.

Ramsey County, Minn. A new issue of $600,000 Ramsey County (Minn.) public welfare bonds, dated Aug. 1, 1933, and due from 1934 to 1943, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate comprising the City Company of New York, Inc., Kalman Co. of St. Paul and the Mercantile-Commerce Company, Inc., of St. Louis.
The following is the text of the code adopted under the National Recovery Act by the hat manufacturing industry:

The Board of Estimate deferred action yesterday until Friday on the proposal to exempt the $45,000,000 Rutgerstown model housing project from city taxation, as recommended by Herman H. Smith, chief engineer of the board.

Dr. Arnold Nathan of Jamaica Hospital was suspended yesterday pending a decision in the case of Harold Feingold, fifteen years old, of 112-12 Rockaway Boulevard, Queens, who died last Thursday. Dr. Nathan had refused to remove him in a hospital ambulance on Tuesday.

Two physicians were among four men who pleaded not guilty in Special Sessions yesterday to charges growing out of the investigation by Morris H. Panger, Assistant District Attorney, into racketeering in workmen's compensation claims. The inquiry was started three months ago at the request of Governor Lehman, following disclosures before a special State commission appointed by Franklin D. Roosevelt, then Governor.

PARIS, July 18. -- The committee recently created by the League of Nations Council in connection with technical cooperation between the League and China held its first meeting today at the League's Paris office under the chairmanship of Castillo Najera, acting president of the Council.

LONDON, July 18. -- Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of New York discussed the German Jewish problem before the order of B'nal B'rith at Woburn House this evening, beginning, as his "first word on English soil," with a tribute of gratitude for "the understanding and sympathetic utterances" on the subject in the last three months by Sir John Simon, Neville Chamberlain, the Archbishop of Canterbury and David Lloyd George.

Money rates were firm, but the market only moderately active. The official rate for call loans continued at 1 per cent, which figure also ruled in the counter market, and Federal funds came up to that level. Three months' money rose fractionally to 1 1/4@1 1/2, and all that was offered for sixty days at 1 1/4 was taken.

Merchandise buyers have a function under the Recovery Act to see that excessive or unfair prices are not charged by producing groups, David L. Podell, one of the advisers to the National Recovery Administration, said yesterday at the Fall fashion forecast conference of the Mutual Buying Syndicate, in the organization's office, 11 West Forty-second Street.
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP). -- Nudists found support today in a ruling by Superior Judge Joseph B. David, who settled the question so far as his court was concerned with the observation:

Between the cotton code, first to be formulated under the National Industrial Recovery Act, and the agreement recently drawn up by the steel industry, there are significant differences. The former is primarily a compact between employers and employes regarding conditions of labor.

Employment for about 29,500 men and women under special work relief projects of State departments, many of them white-collar workers, will be provided this month by an expenditure of $927,261 in combined State and Federal unemployment relief funds, the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration announced yesterday through Alfred H. Schoellkopf, chairman.

With steel operations showing no signs of abatement, the adjusted index of steel production moved up three full points for the week ended July 15. The index now stands at 85.2, as compared with 82.2 in the previous week and 24.1 for the corresponding week of last year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Public attention is directed to the lower east side due to the fact that the contemplated Chrystie-Forsyth Street development is nearing approval and that the scheme for the improvement of the section between the Manhattan and Williamsburg Bridges comprising eighteen blocks has received the approval of the city authorities.

Pressure against stocks which have figured sensationally in recent speculation because of the possibility that they might conceivably be influenced favorably by repeal of the prohibition amendment had an unsettling effect yesterday upon the general share market.

After long, austere, quiet labor as a scholar and thinker, the late IRVING BABBITT was blown upon by a queer, unexpected blast of notoriety. The coast guards of Bohemia rose against him. Subjectivists, individualists, expressionists, exhibitionists, liberals and Heaven knows how many other little sects raved and roared.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 18. -- Stockbridge won an interclub tennis tournament today with Lakeville, Conn., by 4 to 2. In doubles Stockbridge won both matches and in singles the teams were paired two and two.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18. -- Mrs. Mildred Santry Fell, second wife of John R. Fell, Philadelphia and New York sportsman, has taken steps in the Orphans Court here to enforce a provision in a separation agreement which she alleges entitles her to a life income from a trust fund established by Mr. Fell.

The Chesapeake Ohio and the Union Pacific have reported substantially increased returns for June. The C. O.'s net income for the first six months of the year was $10,365,717, or $1.35 a share on the $25 par common stock, against $8,766,967, or $1.14 a share, in the same period last year.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Despite the campaign of teachers and parents' organizations, supported by President Hutchins of the University of Chicago and other educators, members of the School Board decided today to stand firm on their $5,000,000 economy program, a statement signed by James B. McCahey, President of the board, being made public.
Republican leaders have rejected flatly a proposal from Mayor O'Brien that they help formulate a program for the special session of the Legislature to raise $41,000,000 relief funds for the city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One cent saved each day by every person in the United States amounts to more than $1,125,000 each day -- more than $450,000,000 every year. It is a fair estimate that fully one-half of our people are of necessity obliged to purchase their needs in small quantities and for half unit prices, such as 15 or 25 cents, are charged the odd half cent.

LONDON, July 18. -- Secretary of State Hull will address the World Economic Conference again before leaving. He is one of the representatives of eight principal countries who, it was arranged tentatively today, will speak in the plenary session on adjournment day.

Smiling confidence again pervaded Wiley Post's New York headquarters at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday. With the Oklahoma flier safe at Irkutsk, 16 hours and 34 minutes ahead of his previous time, made with Harold Gatty when they set the globe-circling record of 8 days, 15 hours, 51 minutes, both Mrs. Post and Lee Trenholm, the flight manager, breathed easier.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- More than 500,000 persons obtained employment in June in factories and non-manufacturing industries, Secretary Perkins estimated today. The basis of her estimate was the monthly report of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Reports that 10,000,000 acres had been offered by growers for Federal leasing, instead of the 9,000,000 previously announced, together with virtually no precipitation in dry areas in the cotton belt, caused yes- terday another sharp advance in prices on the Cotton Exchange.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation and bank and insurance company investors joined today in opposing the plan for the reorganization of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company suggested by the road's reorganization committee.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- Wheat exports of not more than 40,000,000 bushels during the current crop year and a carry-over of at least 200,000,000 bushels on July 1, 1934, were predicted by Secretary Wallace today as demonstrating the need for a production control program, despite present high prices.

LONDON, July 18. -- The Jewish World Economic Conference arranged to be held here in October is being preceded by a gathering of Continental leaders of the faith in Amsterdam Thursday at which both Britain and the United States will also be represented.

The root of the present trouble in the Orient lies in the economic poverty of both China and Japan, according to George E. Sokolsky, writer on Far Eastern subjects. Mr. Sokolsky's book "The Tinder Box of Asia" will be issued today in a revised edition by Doubleday, Doran Co.

Anthony Lemba, 44 years old, of 56 East 124th Street, qualified yesterday at police headquarters for what probably will be his last prison term, by admitting in the line-up that he had committed fifty or more burglaries in the last few months.
LONDON, July 18. -- Still higher commodity prices were predicted today by the Westminster Bank in its monthly review, after a careful analysis of the present upturn.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., July 18. -- To the well-balanced team of Aiken Knights went the opening victory in the first of the season's national polo championships, the junior, when they turned back Roslyn, 8 to 4, today at Bostwick Field.

CHICAGO, July 18. -- Wheat prices in the United States are so high that they are said to be on an import level with Argentine wheat, and reports from New York today indicated that a cargo had been bought at $1.22 a bushel, c.i.f.
