New York, plus the duty of 42 cents, and on this basis would be $1.64.

BERLIN, July 18. -- A heart-to-heart talk between Chancellor Hitler of Germany and Premier Daladier of France "to remove French fears" was proposed today by Arthur Henderson, president of the World Disarmament Conference, who is making a tour of European capitals in an effort to save the conference.

An exhibition illustrating "The Making of a Book" is on view in the exhibition room of the Pynson Printers in The New York Times Annex. The material has been assembled by Elmer Adler, president of the Pynson Printers and editor of The Colophon for the College Art Association, which will circulate it to various institutions in the country after the showing here.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP). -- The Cubs maintained their half-game margin over Pittsburgh for second place today, defeating the Braves, 4 to 1, in the series final as Lonnie Warneke turned in his twelfth pitching victory of the season.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, July 19. -- General Feng Yu-hsiang's position under the pressure of both Japan and Chinese troops ordered to Kalgan from Peiping is creating a widespread split in various political and military factions and bitterness is growing over Nanking's insistence on the evacuation of Chahar by Feng, who is the only General who has retaken a city of importance from the Japanese army.

ALBANY, July 18. -- This city fairly hummed today with persistent rumors that the release of John J. O'Connell Jr., who was kidnapped twelve days ago, was imminent and that his family had closed a ransom deal with the band that holds him.
Mrs. Frances W. King was brought to trial yesterday in General Sessions on charges of blackmail and an attempt to extort $50,000 from Bruce Barton, publicist and advertising executive.

Breaking the steadiness of the previous few business days the dollar fell yesterday to a new low level. Its fall sent the pound sterling up to $4.85, or 12-3 cents from the old parity of exchange. It lifted the franc to 5.71 cents, at which level the United States monetary unit had an indicated gold value of 68.7 cents.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 18. -- Miss Julia A. Berwind and Mrs. Bever-Ley Bogert were luncheon hostesses today.

The General Foods Corporation increased the quarterly dividend on its common stock yesterday from 40 to 45 cents, placing the issue on an annual dividend basis of $1.80 a share. Three months ago the dividend was reduced from a $2 annual basis to $1.60.

KAUNAS, Lithuania, July 18. -- The bodies of Captain Stephen Darius and Stanley Girenas, whom all Lithuania is mourning, will be brought here tomorrow by plane from Germany, where they were killed in a crash at Soldin, Pomerania.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 18. -- Under the best breeze they have had the Larchmont Yacht Club race week sailing creations cut the water of Long Island Sound today with rails down part of the time. There were 215 starters, thirteen less than yesterday, but still four more than the high mark of last year.

LEICESTER, England, July 18 (Canadian Press). -- The three-day cricket match between the touring British West Indies eleven and Leicester tail-end county team, was drawn tonight when the time limit prevented completion of the second innings.

Twenty properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were taken over by the plaintiffs at foreclosure sales conducted by auctioneers yesterday. The sales were held as the result of defaults on mortgage payments, the mortgagees acting to protect their investments.

Mayor O'BRIEN is finding out that the post of honor is the post of danger. He is getting no help from his Tammany backers in devising new taxes that will be popular. That impossible task is left to the Mayor himself. Tammany points out that it was thrown back upon him by Governor LEHMAN.

The State regulation prohibiting mortgage companies from redeeming mortgage certificates during the emergency relief period was held by Supreme Court Justice Strong in Brooklyn yesterday to be illegal in so far as it affected certificates issued prior to the ruling.

FOR a neat defensive outfield, almost any baseball manager would be glad to have Sam West of the Browns, Evar Swanson of the White Sox and Ben Chapman of the Yankees. Fast men, fine fielders and rather good hitters on the latest returns.
Several housing properties in Jersey City and West New York changed hands yesterday.

State of Iowa. Plans of the State of Iowa to issue $20,000,000 of bonds to distribute funds to political subdivisions of the State which have money tied up in closed banks, have been declared unconstitutional by the Iowa Supreme Court, bankers here were advised yesterday.

For the first time in many days all commodities traded on local Exchanges broke sharply in price and closed substantially lower on the day. The declines came in sympathy with the general outside trend, as traders rushed to realize on their accumulated paper profits.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- If America succeeds with efforts, in her industrial recovery program, to end child labor, she will have accomplished in a few months what England has been working at for a hundred years, a round-table group at the International Congress of Women was told today.

Twenty-five thousand persons who had waited at Floyd Bernnett Field in a broiling sun to witness one of the most thrilling spectacles in aviation history roared a welcome yesterday to the Italian air fleet upon its arrival.

LONDON, July 19 -- The government issued particulars late tonight of its conversion offer in respect to the twenty-year 5 1/2 per cent gold bonds, due in 1937, under the terms of the war loan of $250,000,000 raised in the United States in January, 1917.
The Court of Special Sessions will have to determine soon whether keeping bees in Brooklyn is equivalent to maintaining a public nuisance.

Music and Machines. Music is being "murdered" by the machines, say the organized song composers, librettists and publishers. But apparently they have not quite worked out in their minds the precise definition of a music machine.
THIS IS AMERICA, produced by Frederic Ullman Jr.: edited by Gilbert Seldes; narrated by Alois Havrilla; musical arrangement by Dr. Hugo Riesenfeld. At the Rivoli.

Joseph Abrams and Jack Behr, seeded first and second, respectively, survived the quarter-final round of the Eastern clay-court junior championship at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday. Alfred Jarvis, ranked fourth, was upset by Marvin Freudenheim of Mount Vernon, 6 -- 2, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4.

The Home and Farm Mortgage Advisory Committee, appointed last week by Governor Lehman to study and report how this State may cooperate with the Federal Home Owners Corporation, is to hold its second meeting at 2 o'clock tomorrow afternoon in the rooms of the Merchants Association, Woolworth Building.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 19 -- The Wartnaby team of three British brothers and one American struck a steady pace today that brought to the national junior polo championship its first upset with the elimination of Thomas Hitchcock Jr.'s Sands Point team in a first-round match.
One of the most spectacular aerial shows that New York has seen in years was put on for the thousands who gathered at the Municipal Airport to greet the Italian air armada.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 19 -- Not one earned point was scored today against Miss Alice Marble of San Francisco, probably the most improved woman tennis player of the year, as she routed Miss Bonnie Miller of Los Angeles, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0, in sixteen minutes to gain the semi-final round of the Essex County Club's women's invitation tournament.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, urged yesterday that the shipping industry formulate a code of ethics as a means of establishing it on a sound economic basis and protecting labor. Mr. Ryan said he had written the chairmen of the steamship committees in the ports in which the association has contractual relationships requesting a conference on wages and working hours, and warned that the longshoremen would take Independent action if necessary.

Price advances already made by retail stores during the last few weeks because of higher wholesale quotations have been accepted by customers, it was reported yesterday at the group sessions of the "recovery forum" being conducted by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.
Following is the amended or substitute code to be submitted today to the National Industrial Recovery Administration by the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union:
Commercial Paper. Yesterday -- 1 1/2 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 1 1/2 per cent for the best names.

The unbelievable happened yesterday at the Stadium. In full view of some 12,000 fans, including about 4,000 youngsters present as guests of the management. Babe Ruth muffed an easy fly, paving the way for the rout of the Yankees by the White Sox, 8 to 4, and ending the Yankee winning streak of nine straight.

General Italo Balbo and his Italian fleet of twenty-four transatlantic seaplanes and ninety-six men gave New York and its environs a thrilling aerial spectacle and an impressive demonstration of the safety of flying yesterday afternoon.

LARCHMONT N.Y., July 19 -- While many of the leading skipper on Long Island Sound were engaging in dinghy racing, 225 youthful sailors under 18 years of age manned ninety-five yachts in various classes in the Junior Day contests of Larchmont Race Week today.
Mayor O'Brien announced last night that the city's public works program aggregating more than $168,000,000 had been placed before Harold H. Ickes, Administrator of Public Works in Washington.

Preparations for receiving the Italian air squadron and for looking after the personnel during their stay at Floyd Bennett Field included, arrangements both at sea and on land. Before daylight yesterday a fleet of ten Coast Guard vessels, augmented later by six more, commanded by Lieut. Commander Frank Kenner, took up strategic positions in Jamaica Bay, extending from Rockaway Point east and north to Canarsie and the Cross Bay Boulevard.

Robert Goelet gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mr. and Mrs. Harry Payne Bingham and Mrs. J. Philip Benkard. Another luncheon there was that given by Mrs. Will H. Hays for Mrs. Henry E. Stehli, who returned recently from Europe.

PITTSBURGH, July 19 -- The Pirates' chances of Injecting themselves a little deeper in the seething National League pennant race loomed bright for a few hours today as the Corsairs, behind the skillful hurling of tarry French and to the delight of a crowd of 22,000, upset the Giants In the first game of the afternoon's doubleheader, 4 to 1.

New York, which has welcomed so many aviators, from LINDBERGH to COSTE, for daring passage of the Atlantic, accounts the Balbo mass flight from Italy to Chicago as a performance of superlative merit. The ease and precision with which the squadron of twenty-four planes proceeded yesterday to New York has marked every transit of the Italians on their itinerary.

BOMBAY, July 19 -- The fact that the promised statement on the Nationalist Congress policy by M.S. Aney, acting president of the party, was not forthcoming today gave rise to reports that there was considerable disagreement between the Congress and Mahatma Gandhi.
BUENOS AIRES, July 19 -- To follow President Roosevelt or not to follow him has become the question of the day in Argentina.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- With half the required thirty-six States now having voted for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, Postmaster General Farley, in his capacity as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, continued from Chicago today his effort to aid in ending national prohibition this year.

The creation by the railroads of a body to centralize their lighterage operations in New York Harbor, a step urged by the Interstate Commerce Commission, the Port of New York Authority and civic organizations, was disclosed yesterday. The agency will be a corporation controlled by the interested roads.

Barring a softening in the rate for Federal funds, which dropped to 1/4 @ 1/2, from 1 per cent on Tuesday, firm lines were shown in the call and time money sections. On the board, and in the counter trading, 1 per cent ruled for day's loans. Time money was quiet so far as business was concerned, but rates were firm.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 19 -- In a day of vicissitudes for most of the elect, Frank Shields and Sidney B. Wood Jr., finalists at Wimbledon and Davis Cup singles players in 1931, led the field into the round before the quarter-finals of the annual invitation tennis tournament of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club today.

In several English comments on the failure of the Economic Conference a comparison is drawn between President WILSON'S role in European affairs and President ROOSEVELT'S. One remark is that the latter's "No" from Washington was more effective than the former's negatives when he was at Paris in person.

LONDON, July 19 -- The National Joint Council of the labor movement, representing the Trades Union Congress, the Labor party and the Parliamentary Labor party, issued a manifesto today demanding a boycott of German goods and services.

ALBANY, July 19 -- Samuel I. Rosenman, counsel to President Roosevelt during his terms as Governor, was named to the Supreme Court bench today by Governor Lehman to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Judge Henry L. Sherman.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union will present an amended or substitute code for the garment industry when its representatives and those of the employers appear in Washington to attend the hearing scheduled to be held today.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Taken up in public hearings for the first time this morning, the code of fair competition for the electrical manufacturing industry had been entirely reviewed tonight and was apparently well on its way to acceptance by all parties concerned.
A sharp break in alcohol issues, followed by the largest decline in wheat prices in several years, caused general weakness in the security and commodity markets yesterday.
The legal hearing to determine Joseph W. Harriman's mental condition waited yesterday on the outcome of an alienist's examination.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The prospects were exceedingly bright tonight for the completion within twenty-four hours of a single code of fair competition for nearly all the non-union coal tonnage of the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Not in any one's memory here, perhaps never in American history, has the government been so centred in one activity as at the present time. That activity, of course is the administration of the National Recovery Act by General Hugh S. Johnson and the President.

The membership of the League of New York Theatres will meet this afternoon to ratify the fair practice code as formulated by the league's code committee. At 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon the National Alliance of the Theatre will convene to approve the unified code, covering all the organized branches of the legitimate stage.

The largest and most important real estate transaction of the year in Manhattan was closed yesterday when the seventeen-story Holland Plaza Building, facing the entrance to the Holland Tunnel on the lower west side, was sold to the Lortay Corporation, of which W.V. Taylor is president.
BOSTON, July 19 (AP) -- Eight pitchers, four on each side, figured in the Indians' 8-to-7 victory over the Red Sox in thirteen innings today.

LONDON, July 19 (By Wireless) -- John Grierson, British aviator, is shortly leaving England in an attempt to fly by the Greenland route to New York in an airplane fitted with a device that allows it to behave very much like a homing pigeon.

Returns for June reported by Railroads yesterday continued to re ect the increased traffic with which these companies have been avored in recent months. The increase was most marked in the case f the Illinois Central, which Slowed a net operating income of 2,211,786 in June, against $260,495 in June, 1932.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Building permits reported to the Bureau of Labor Statistics from 762 identical cities of more than 10,000 population decreased 36.5 per cent from May to June in indicated expenditures for all building operations. The number of building operations decreased 6.3 per cent.

A parade up lower Broadway from the Battery to City Hall will mark the official reception to General Italo Balbo and his fliers tomorrow, according to plans announced yesterday by Thomas F. McAndrews, secretary to Mayor O'Brien.

General Italo Balbo, his squadron of twenty-four seaplanes and his crew of ninety-six pilots, navigators and mechanics have flown close to 7,000 miles to reach New York. They propose to fly 4,000 more before they ride the waters of their own Italy again.

PLANDOME, L.I., July 19 -- Miss Helen Hicks, former national champion, who equaled par for the Plandome course in her qualifying round yesterday, continued her brilliant play in the first two rounds of the women's New York State golf championship today.

Except for limited telephone service, more than a score of men and women were marooned for fortyone minutes yesterday in various parts of the Chrysler Building, Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street. Transformer trouble halted every one of the skyscraper's thirty passenger elevators from 9:34 to 10:15 A. M.

Holders of State Mortgage Bank of Yugoslavia secured 7 per cent sinking fund bonds, due April 1, 1957, have been notified by Radoye Yankovitch, Consul General of Yugoslavia in New York, that on and after today they will receive payment of six semi-annual coupons due from Oct. 1, 1932, to April 1, 1935, both inclusive.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Prices of wheat, grain and stocks dropped yesterday. The market had shown signs of being overstrained for several days. Weakness prevailed virtually from the start with stop-order selling the main feature, especially in the last hour when an avalanche of selling in all markets of the country prevailed, particularly those in the Northwest, where prices dropped so fast that it was impossible to tell where the market really was.
The following is the code of fair competition under the National Industrial Recovery Act adopted yesterday by the National Millinery Council:

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Consolidation of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway with the Rock Island was proposed by the Reconstructtion Finance Corporation today as the basis for reorganization of both roads. Both are now in receivership and were allocated to the same system in the consolidation plan put forth by the Interstate Commerce Commission in 1929.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 -- The Borough of Lansdale in suburban Montgomery County became the centre of Pennsylvania's widespread labor troubles today when Sheriff's, deputies turned tear gas on hosiery strikers and brought from Governor Pinchot a demand for an investigation by the State Police.

The Blind Women's Club of the New York Association for the Blind decided yesterday to hold its annual outing at Roton Point, Conn., again this year. What the members specially liked about the outing last year was that it took three hours to get to Roton Point by steamboat, in Long Island Sound, and three hours to get back again.

One of the largest estate deals closed in New Jersey in recent weeks was announced yesterday when a large Bergen County residential property changed hands. The property, known as "Mira Robles," consists of a main house and other buildings on ten acres of land in the hill section of Englewood.

Neustadtl Brewing. A block of 29,000 shares of the Neustadtl Brewing Corporation of Stroudsburg, Pa., $1 par common stock will be placed on the market today by Sayre Co., Inc., priced at $12.50 a share. The corporation manufactures Gesundheit beer and malt syrups.

What Wall Street accepted resignedly as a long overdue reaction swept all markets sharply lower yesterday. Stocks, bonds and commodities ran into the most aggressive selling movement of the entire recovery dating back to last March.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- A warning that action must be taken in the Stock and Commodity Exchanges to prevent such a recession as occurred today if government supervision or even suspension of trading was to be avoided was issued today by Senator Thomas of Oklahoma.

The depositors of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company are being notified by mail that the bank's conservator, Henry E. Cooper, is now prepared to distribute a payment of 50 cents on the dollar. The letters are being sent out in alphabetical order at the rate of 1,000 a day.

LONDON, July 19 -- Discontent over the manner in which the British Dominions are interpreting the spirit of the Ottawa agreements Broke out in both houses of Parliament today, and from the Laborite benches came rumblings of trouble for the government when the Commons renews its debate on the World Economic Conference Tuesday.

ALBANY, July 19 -- "Rumortism" still afflicted this city tonight. Every street-corner loafer, every cab driver, every one, including friends of the O'Connell clan, had the "inside" tip that Lieutenant John J. O'Connell Jr. would be home in a few hours, delivered from the kidnappers who snatched him July 7.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 19 -- Players in the Maidstone Club's annual invitation doubles tennis tournament, to take place on Saturday and Sunday, will be entertained by Summer colonists with a dinner at the Maidstone Club on Saturday, which will be preceded by a tea at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Beardsley.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The preference given to veterans of the World War, Spanish War and Philippine insurrection in civil service examinations for postmasterships of the first, second and third class, as ordered by President Roosevelt, has led officers of the American Legion to stress the executive order in the hope that more veterans will compete in the examinations and receiver appointments without resort to political Influence.
ALBANY, July 19 -- Hundreds of thousands of eyes searched the clear blue sky here this afternoon in a vain attempt to locate the Italian air fleet as it winged toward New York City.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 19 -- Tennessee, where a State dry law was enacted in 1909 over a Governor's veto and has remained in effect since, will vote tomorrow on the question of discarding national prohibition.

Fifty charitable and educational institutions receive bequests totaling 52,160,000 under the will of John Markle coal operator and philanthropist, who died on July 10. This was disclosed yesterday when the will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.

BERLIN, July 19 -- The Boerse was firm and active today. Overcoming yesterday's hesitation, traders concentrated on stocks while the public mainly was interested in bonds. Heavy industrials led the upward movement and were followed by electric, lignite and potash shares.

PARIS, July 19 -- Of what value is the Four-Power pact signed three days ago at Rome? That question is being discussed in the Paris press, and the answer was given today by Ambassador Henry de Jouvenel on his return from Rome after a six-month tenancy of the Palazzo Farnese.

LONDON, July 19 (AP) -- The American team, led by Ely Culbertson, staged a spectacular comeback to advance within 320 points of the English team as an international bridge match of 300 duplicate boards for a trophy posted by Charles M. Schwab reached the half-way mark tonight.

President Roosevelt has been urged by the National Civil Service Reform League not to approve a proposed repeal of executive orders of Presidents Coolidge and Hoover which extended civil service to about 4,600 Federal posts, the league announced yesterday.
HAMILTON, Ont., July 19 (Canadian Press). -- The summaries of the track meet today between the Hamilton Olympic Club and the Oxford-Cambridge team follow:

The fickle New York police first saluted then arrested Mohammed Al Raschid, the "Emir of Kurddistan," who was born in Detroit, after he shook hands last night with General Italo Balbo in the latter's suite on the ninth floor of the Hotel Ambassador.

MOSCOW, July 19 -- "The most dangerous flight in the history of Soviet aviation," was the phrase used by a veteran flier of the North Siberian coast to describe Pilot Levanovsky's four-day battle to reach Anadyr from Nikolaevsk on the Amur River.

ST. LOUIS, July 19 -- Bill Killefer, manager of the St. Louis Browns since 1930, today resigned, apparently as the result of the owner's dissatisfaction with the showing of the team, which is in last place in the American League.

The American people have always solved their problems and will solve their present ones, "but not without earnest consultation and reasoning together," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt writes in the August "Woman's Home Companion, out today. In this article Mrs. Roosevelt makes her debut as editor of a "Questions and Answers" department in the magazine.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- To the cheers of thousands of early risers massed along the shoreline. General Italo Balbo's fleet of twenty-four Italian flying boats skimmed off the waves of Lake Michigan today and vanished toward the East.

FENNVILLE, Mich., July 19 (AP) -- A 45-year-old farmer and his wife, who told Sheriff's deputies they were "nearly starved all the time," were in jail today after wounding three men in a daring daylight hold-up of the old State Bank here. The $2,000 cash they obtained was recovered.

One has just died in France who should be remembered here for what she did in carrying forward a work for the blinded in battle, begun by Americans under the leadership of Mrs. WINIFRED HOLT MATHER, the founder of "Lighthouses for the Blind" in many countries as well as our own.

Trapped in the blazing wreckage of his automobile, Frank Ciarlo, 30 years old, a fireman of 850. Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, was burned fatally early last night after the machine had been in a 'collision on South Street between Fulton and Beekman Streets.

General Italo Balbo, the 37-year-old leader of one of the most ambitious flights in the history of aviation, took a bath, donned a suit of white pajamas and sat comfortably in the dining room of his suite at the Hotel Ambassador yesterday evening to talk to the press.

Signs multiply that Tammany is in for political difficulties. Governor LEHMAN is proving himself singularly intractable. Although he has agreed to call the Legislature in special session next week, he continues to reject the tax program for it which the Tammany authorities had kindly laid out.

General Italo Balbo and several of his aides of the Italian air armada put the strain and care of their history-making expedition behind them last night. They celebrated their arrival in jolly style with American army and navy officers, high civil officials and prominent citizens at a dinner given by Rear Admiral Yates Stirling Jr., commandant of the Third Naval District, at the Columbia Yacht Club at Eighty-sixth Street and the Hudson River.
"Going Gay," the farce by William Miles and Donald Blackwell, will open at the Morosco Theatre on July 31. The cast will include Edith King, Thais Lawton and Walter Kingsford.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 19 -- Oxford-Cambridge and Merlon Cricket Club tennis stars broke even in six tennis matches today.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Following the decisive success of repeal in Alabama and Arkansas yesterday, wet leaders predicted today that the Eighteenth Amendment would be repealed before the end of the year.
LONDON, July 19 -- J.P. Morgan arrived in England on the liner Olympic today and failed to observe his custom of refusing an interview. Discussing his present plans, he said:

A force of 900,000 trained salesmen maintaining contact with every branch of American industry stands ready to help "sell" the national recovery program to business men throughout the country, Joseph H. Dryer, president of the National Council of Traveling Salesmen's Associations of America, said in a telegram sent last night to General Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator.

With three title events on the opening day's program, the women's National A.A.U. senior swimming championship meet is scheduled to start this morning in the Olympic course in Zachs Bay at Jones Beach State Park, L.I. The events are slated to start at 10:30 o'clock.

BERLIN, July 19 -- The vacancies in the Reich postal, telegraph and telephone services created through the dismissal of employes "inimically disposed toward the State" must be filled exclusively with members of the National Socialist party, it has been decreed.

Unsettled markets generally, in conjunction with partial relief in drought sections of the belt, caused a sharp break of more than 1/2 cent in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Action of outside markets the previous day exerted a disturbing influence on sentiment, and selling pressure started with the opening, catching stoploss limits in the afternoon and ending with a loss of 40 to 43 points, or $2 to $2.15 a bale.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 19 (AP). -- Rochester swept the series with Jersey City by capturing both ends of a double-header today, 1 to 0 and 9 to 2.

An unseasonable increase of $17,863,122 in the volume of bankers acceptances outstanding was reported yesterday for June in the monthly survey of the bill market by the American Acceptance Council. The increase brought the total of bills outstanding to $686,674,450 as of the end of last month, which was only $60,573,912 less than the amount outstanding a year previously.

TORONTO, July 19 (AP) -- With Ervin Brame, veteran right-handed hurler, pitching shut-out ball in the second game, Toronto today broke even with Newark in a doubleheader. The Maple Leafs won the nightcap, 1 to 0, after the league leaders had accounted for the opening contest, 9 to 4.

Stocks passed yesterday through the long-awaited reaction. There was a wide-open break in many of the most prominent issues. Final prices were sharply lower after the market had stubbornly resisted the pressure against special groups in the early part of tha day.

GEORGE DUNLAP threw a scare into the camp of the home guard during the playing of the British amateur golf championship, and Denny Shute captured the British open title. But the Hon. Michael Scott, 55 years old, captured the British amateur title, and the British seniors just recently handed the United States seniors a terrific drubbing at Sandwich.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Acquiescing in the desire of President Roosevelt to have a man of his own selection as chairman of the Federal Power Commission, George Otis Smith vacated that post today to make way for the appointment of Frank R. McNinch, a Democrat, who has been vice chairman for several months since the Democratic victory.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 19 -- Several young women of the Summer colony who will be introduced to society next season in New York and debutantes of recent years played in the fourth annual women's round-robin tennis tournament, which opened today at the Meadow Club with play in the singles.

The dollar cheapened yesterday to a new low level in foreign exchange, then rallied moderately. In London its fall carried the pound sterling up to $4.86 3/4, above the old parity of exchange for the first time in two years. Here the pound reached $4.86 1/2, about one-eighth cent below parity.

Fascism has become a little milder throughout Italy, in the opinion of John Gibbons, whose "Old Italy and New Mussoliniland" will be published today by E.P. Dutton Co. Mr. Gibbons is the author of an earlier travel book, "Afoot in Italy," as well as "Twenty-four Vagabond Tales" and "Tramping Through Ireland."

The fastest short six furlongs of the current Empire City meeting were run yesterday when Irene's Bob, owned and trained by George Odom, raced in front from start to finish of the featured Brevoort Claiming Handicap to win by four lengths in 1:08 2-5.
PHILADELPHIA, July 19 -- Frank A. McClatchy, a well-known real estate broker of Cynwyd, was shot and seriously wounded late today in a struggle with two men who attempted to kidnap him.

LONDON, July 19 -- The stock markets continued animated and cheerful today on yesterday's strength in Wall Street, the rise there in the sterling and dollar rates and favorable revenue returns, all of which were contributory to a better feeling.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- A program for regulating the sugar industry, calling for the establishment of a stabilization committee, fixing quotas and licensing domestic refiners was submitted to Secretary Wallace today by Dr. John Lee Coulter, member of the Tariff Commission.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial of July 15, entitled "The Dream Dollar,' you say that advocates of the commodity dollar "use a language peculiar to themselves," and I, "in a speech at St. Louis, asserted gravely that 'to stabilize this dollar so that it shall always be 100 cents would be the greatest of all economic reforms.' "

Child labor provisions in codes of the steel and other hazardous industries are termed unsatisfactory by the National Child Labor Committee in a statement made public yesterday. The organization has requested General Hugh S. Johnson to incorporate a provision barring employment of children under 16 years in any blanket code that may be adopted.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 19 -- His heart overtaxed by efforts to save the crew of the burning Cities Service Petrol, Captain Anton Nillsson, master of the tanker Gulf Gem, died last night in a hospital here.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- A list of 100 best books of the century written by American women was announced today at the International Woman Writers Conclave, held in connection with the International Congress of Women.

Bus companies seeking long-term franchises from the city must be prepared to better their present offers, Mayor O'Brien indicated yesterday at an adjourned public hearing of the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate. He declared that applicants whose proposals include motorization of surface car lines must also be prepared to substitute buses for street cars promptly upon the receipts of a franchise grant.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- A work basis of not less than forty hours was declared essential to the shipbuilding industry by heads of several great plants at a hearing today on their code. Speakers, said to present 90 per cent of the industry, apparently fearing that the agitation for a thirty-hour week in place of the forty-hour week provided in the code might prevail in the end, offered a series of arguments against a change.

The Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company opposed yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler the application of George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, for permission to sell enough of its securities to realize $10,000,000 in order that the creditors might be paid in full.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP) -- The Tigers and the Athletics divided a double-header today to make an even break of the fourgame series. The Athletics won the first game, 7 to 3, and Detroit took the second, 10 to 5.

Senator Ellison D. Smith of South Carolina, father of the plan for reduction of the cotton acreage, told members of the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday of the outlook for the economic recovery of the country. It was one of the few times in the history of the Exchange when trading was interrupted so that an address might be made to members.

HAMILTON, Ont., July 19 -- Jack Lovelock, Oxford track ace from New Zealand who made the amazing world's record time of 4:07 6-10 for the mile at Princeton last week, failed in his attack on the Canadian mark of 4:14 this evening in a dual meet between the Oxford-Cambridge team and the Hamilton Olympic Club.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 19 -- Harold Flack, secretary of the Cornellian Council, fund-raising organization of Cornell University, hanged himself in the bathroom of his home this morning, a victim of recurring depressions which had affected his health for a year. He was 44 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- An 8-to-7 victory over the Browns today placed the Senators again in a tie with the Yankees for top place in the American League.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- "Ten commandments of the New Deal" in stabilizing industry were outlined today by Harry F. Payer, Assistant Secretary of State, before the University Club, as follows:
Democratic leaders are preparing for an unprecedentedly bold drive in the campaign this Autumn to capture control of the Boards of Supervisors in up-State counties, now controlled by the Republicans.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 19 -- Farrell Kaufmann of Gedney Farm followed the example set earlier in the season by his brother and captured the low gross honors in the one-day tourney of the Westchester County Golf Association today.

AUTEUIL, France, July 19 -- French Interest wavered tonight between discussions of the probable winner in the inter-zone tennis final between the United States and Great Britain starting Friday, and the possibility that Jean Borotra, the Bounding Basque, may again help France defend the Davis Cup in the challenge round.
The National Millinery Council made public yesterday the text of its code of fair competition under the National Industrial Recovery Act. The code has been forwarded to Washington.
A "Scotland Yard" in the United States to fight kidnapping was urged yesterday by Senator Copeland, chairman of the Senate subcommittee investigating racketeering.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- In furtherance of efforts to insure more employment the Cabinet advisory board today awarded $1,526,000 for Federal projects in twelve States and the Panama Canal Zone.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- For the sake of economy, important activities of the Bureau of Standards will be abandoned at once to private initiative, Secretary Roper announced today.

"What, lions in the Bronx?" Magistrate William Farrell sternly asked the question yesterday in Bronx Municipal Term Court. Fred Marks, 43 years old, of 851 East 221st Street, stepped up to the bar and with apprehension confessed that such was the fact.
Bernard M. Baruch is sailing today for London on the White Star liner Majestic. Others leaving on the ship are:

NEWPORT, R.I., July 19 -- A "Gay Nineties" dance has been arranged to take place during tennis week in August. It is being sponsored by a group of the young colonists and will be preceded by a large dinner party. The dance will probably be held in one of the large Bellevue Avenue homes.

Arkansas and Alabama have settled the last doubt, if there was any doubt, about the fate of Federal prohibition. Clearly the passion for repeal is nationwide. Tennessee will join the procession today, Oregon tomorrow. No hope remains of assembling thirteen intransigent Dry States.

The Legislature will meet in extraordinary session at Albany at 2 o'clock next Wednesday afternoon under a call issued at the Capitol yesterday by Governor Lehman. It will consider and act upon measures to afford financial relief to New York City and possibly some other municipalities in need of State assistance.

BERLIN, July 19 -- Chancellor Hitler and Arthur Henderson, president of the World Disarmament Conference, will meet in Munich tomorrow for informal conversations on the disarmament question. The immediate purpose of their meeting is to pave the way for the proposed meeting of the German Chancellor and the French Premier, which Mr. Henderson is trying to bring about in the hope of ending the Geneva deadlock.

Although the national average for the steel industry's operations has fallen this week from 59 to 58 per cent of ingot capacity, the "pressure for deliveries is still severe," according to the weekly review of The Iron Age. The publication remarks that "finished steel releases continued to run behind those of last month, but mill backlogs have not been materially reduced."
The Board of Estimate denied tax exemption yesterday for the proposed model housing development in the east Bronx backed by the Hillside Homes Corporation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With characteristic laconism, George Bernard Shaw informs me in a recent letter that THE NEW YORK TIMES report of his speech before the American Academy of Political Science "is quite useless as it stands," inferring that he had been quoted inaccurately by a paper proud of its high journalistic standards.

STOCKHOLM, July 19 -- Led by Glenn Cunningham, the brilliant American miler from Kansas, the touring all-star track and field team from the United States took the lead in its first international track meet today by winning four of the first day's five events.
WASHINGTON, July l9 -- The text of the Code of Fair Competition for the rayon and synthetic yarn producing industry, as submitted today to the Recovery Act Administrator, is as follows:

NEW YORK. W. Vinton King and his daughter, Mrs. C. Shelby Carter, will leave tonight for Chicago, whence they will go later to Colorado Springs. Mr. Carter will join them in the latter part of August.

LONDON, July 19 -- Secretary of State Hull denied emphatically today reports that efforts for an arbitration treaty between Japan and the United States were being blocked by a Japanese Asiatic Monroe Doctrine.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 19 -- With Alabama today in the list of States that have voted to scrap the Eighteenth Amendment, prohibitionist leaders have turned their efforts to keeping the State's own dry statutes intact.

LONDON, July 19 -- The prolonged efforts that Senator Key Pittman has been making on silver ended today when the subcommittee over which he presided unanimously adopted a resolution which is now deemed certain of ratification by the World Economic Conference.

Extensive changes in the personnel of the Correction Department were forecast yesterday by William J. Cahill, Correction Commissioner, in announcing the transfer of Warden Harry C. Honeck from the Brooklyn city prison to Hiker's Island prison.

ANADYR, Siberia, July 19 (by Wireless) -- Soviet Pilot Levanovsky has arrived with a powerful seaplane of the Soviet Arctic Service to fly me to Nome -- and am I happy! I had almost given him up. It took him about as long to get here as it took to get permission from the United States to let him enter Alaska with the relief plane.

PRAGUE, July 19 -- Philipp Scheidemann, German Socialist leader who is a. refugee here, has addressed a letter to President von Hindenburg asking him to obtain the release of five persons arrested and placed in German concentration camps for no other reason than that they are supposed to be related to him.

A plan of reorganization affecting East Coast Utilities Company first mortgage collateral 5 1/2 per cent bonds, Series A, due 1937; first mortgage collateral 5 per cent bonds, Series C, due 1937, and two-year 6 per cent convertible secured notes, due 1932, has been adopted by a committee composed of Edward C. Delafield, chairman, James Bruce and Robert W. Rea, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, July 19 (Canadian Press). -- According to The Daily Express today, private efforts of dominions leaders behind the scenes of the World Economic Conference may soon produce Important developments in the economic warfare between the United Kingdom and the Irish Free State.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange closed irregular yesterday after an active day's business In which transactions totaled $21,398,500, compared with $18,808,500 on the previous day. Domestic railroad bonds held their ground on the average, but industrial and utilities were weaker.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Efforts to evolve procedure and forms for a blanket "spread-the-work" code for all business and industry were redoubled today by Recovery Administration officials.

Figures of American foreign trade have written a sad record so long that the improvement shown in May, the latest month reported, is of special interest. The current number of The Annalist points out that Exports increased by 8.7 per cent, in the face of a normal seasonal decline of 4.2 per cent.

The appointment of representatives of the short lines and of the electric railways to the Eastern railroad coordinating committee was announced yesterday following a meeting between members of the committee and H.J. German, Eastern regional director in the coordinating system headed by Joseph B. Eastman.

A group of leading figures in the Catholic Church returned from a Holy Year pilgrimge to Rome yesterday, arriving on the Italian liner Rex. They were Archbishop John T. McNicholas of Cincinnati, Bishop Urban J. Vehr of Denver, Bishop John J. Dunn, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, and Bishop James A. Walsh of Maryknoll, N.Y.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 19 -- Coming from behind with three goals in the final period, a well-balanced Aurora polo team downed the Meadow Brook Ramblers, 8 to 7, to advance into the semi-final round of the national junior championship today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 19 -- Henry R. Barrett, secretary of the Westchester County Republican committee and political aide of the late William L. Ward for the last thirty-nine years, announced today that he would be a candidate for the county chairmanship, succeeding Mr. Ward.

Off Montauk Point today -- the exact location depending upon the whims of the swordfish which may become the victims of the experiment -- two well-known sportsmen will make an effort to inaugurate a new method of fishing. Whether it will prove practical remains to be seen.

One may expect moralizing, not unmixed with perplexity, over the fact that the pound sterling went on yesterday's foreign exchange market to the "old parity" of $4.86 5/8. Even while the New York price for the pound was rising from $4.16 a month ago to $4.80 a week ago, the question was repeatedly hurled at visitors to Wall Street why the British pound should be going up while the dollar was going down.

The Tide Water Associated Oil Company reports for the quarter ended on June 30 a net income of $1,413,082 after all charges and reserves, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to 7 cents a share on the 5.611,040 common shares outstanding.

An alleged automobile thief was wounded fatally last night by a traffic policeman on the fire escape of an office building at 7-11 West Forty-fifth Street, after having been chased through the theatre district at the height of the rush hour by a taxicab driver.

State of Washington. The State of Washington Finance Committee has authorized the sale of $2,039,000 of the $10,000,000 unemployment relief bond issue to the group of banks in that State that submitted the only bid for the issue on Tuesday.
Following is the code for the dress industry submitted yesterday to the National Recovery Administration by the Association of Dress Manufacturers, Inc.:

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP). -- Sentenced to the bench last Saturday for light hitting and back in the line-up today only because Riggs Stephenson had a cold, Babe Herman, Cub outfielder, clouted three home runs and a single as Chicago defeated the Phillies, 10 to 1, in the opening game of the series.

BERLIN, July 20. -- Sherwood Eddy, American sociologist, dumbfounded a representative gathering of German officials and leaders of business and the professions here today by declaring that American opinion was becoming increasingly apprehensive over some of the things happening in the Nazi Germany.

Aryans on Jobs? Nazi veterans are to have the jobs in the German postal and telegraph service made available by the ousting of employes "inimical to the State." It is a sordid business, and yet it puts the German situation in a more tolerable, more human light.

A foreclosure holiday until the Federal Home Loan Act will have brought relief to the home owner and farmer was sought yesterday by the Consolidated Home Owners' Mortgage Committee, New York State Division, in a resolution addressed to Governor Lehman, his advisers and legislative leaders.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20. -- With sheets just started and Long Island Sound stirred by a lively, increasing breeze, Horace Have-meyer's twelve-meter Mouette today scored her first victory during the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual race week.
LAMBERTVILLE, N.J., Jul 20. -- Police Recorder James D. MacKay was shot and killed tonight by a prisoner during a private hearing in his chambers adjoining the court in the municipal building here.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Further progress was made today by Northern and Southern non-union coal operators toward writing a code for the bulk of the soft coal tonnage, when a differential was agreed upon for inside labor. The differential, it was reported, was 5 cents an hour, or 40 cents for an eight-hour day, as between the North and South.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20. -- While Frank A. McClatchy, 56-year-old real estat broker, was fighting for his life in Misericordia Hospital today, the police of three counties joined with government agencies in trailing two men who shot him yesterday when he resisted their efforts to kidnap him.

LONDON, July 20. -- The world must choose either a stable or a managed currency, Senator Pittman of the United States delegation told the commission on permanent monetary recovery measures, which adopted today in a public meeting its report for this stage of the World Economic Conference.

The battle of codes between capital and labor, pointing to a new form of struggle between the two forces, with the government acting as referee under the National Industrial Recovery Act, assumed larger proportions yesterday. Printing unions, fur workers and neckwear workers announced that they would present codes of their own as amendments or substitutes for codes presented by employers.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- Steps to form a national transportation policy to embrace carriers by rails, high-ways, air and water were taken by groups representing railroads, lake shipping, inland waterways, highways freighters, security owners, shippers and bankers which finished a three-day session in Chicago today.
WASHINGTON, July 20. -- "The country is safe; we will have repeal by Christmas," Postmaster General Farley said today after calling upon President Roosevelt.

A sudden visit to Washington yesterday by Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, Inc., may be for the purpose of seeking Federal funds under the National Recovery Act for improving New York City's parks, M. Lawrence Craner, executive secretary of the Park Association, announced.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 20. -- A bizarre tale of being kidnapped by two armed gunmen and transported to a point twenty-five miles south of Portland, where he made his escape by means of a daring coup, was told to city and State police today by R.E. Close, superintendent of the Anti-Liquor League of Oregon.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The substitute code for the Shipbuilding Industry, submitted by American Federation of Labor representatives today at a hearing conducted by the National Recovery Administration, follows:

ST. LOUIS, July 20. -- The hideout in which August Luer, wealthy Alton (Ill.) banker, was held captive by his kidnappers was found today and police and Department of Justice agents announced they had under arrest two women and four of the six men said to have participated in the abducting.
ANADYR, Siberia, July 20. -- After the Eskimos found me and started down the Anadyr River with me I thought we were on the way to the settlement of Anadyr.

The selfishness of employers who have failed to raise wages along with prices is threatening the success of the government's efforts to lift the nation out of the depression, Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Recovery Administrator, declared last night in an address before the Central Trades and Labor Council at Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Senator Thomas of Oklahoma, who sent talegrams of reprimand to the Stock and Grain Exchanges yesterday because prices had fallen, does not come under the heading of administration adviser. His importance in the present economic situation lies in the fact that the resolution of Congress that conferred permissive powers of currency inflation on the President bears his name and contains one or two of his inflationary ideas.

About 200 distributers of milk in the metropolitan area, meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania last night, voted to form an organization to be known as the Greater New York-New Jersey Milk Institute, Inc. The institute, which will be incorporated as soon as legally possible, will supplant the New York Milk Conference Board and other distributers' organizations.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Great Britain's plan to convert its 5 1/2 per cent war loan bonds floated in this country in 1917 into 2 1/2 per cent sterling bonds was received with interest in official circles today but without surprise.

Denial that the seventy United States commercial attaches and trade commissioners, ordered to return home from Europe last month and resign in compliance with the Federal economy program, had been ousted almost without warning, is contained in a letter from Secretary of Commerce Roper to Mrs. Emmeline duThoit Neubert of 89-01 120th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens.
The Yankee guns were spiKed yesterday by the superlative pitching of Mel Harder and the Cleveland Indians romped off with the first clash of a five-game series at the Stadium, 3 to 1.

MADRID, June 20. -- Mrs. Clinton B. Lockwood, her husband and the three other Americans who had been held prisoners at Palma, Island of Majorca, following an attack on a member of the Guardia Civil, were released on bail this afternoon.

All except four of the twenty-one leading cities of the country reported larger bank clearings last week than for the corresponding period last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The best relative showing in many years was made for the aggregate of all clearings.

Copyright, 1933, by NANA, Inc. WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Stock market developments of the past two days demonstrate clearly the need for some new method of regulating the exchanges for the protection of the public.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Early repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, indicated by recent decisive votes in the South, is expected by prohibition officials to bring a flood of foreign liquors and wines into the United States.

Two outstanding figures in the real estate field figured in important transactions yesterday, when Elias A. Cohen, owner of several large buildings in lower Manhattan, enlarged his holdings by the purchase of a lower Broadway structure and Frederick Brown continued his activity by acquiring a midtown Fifth Avenue building and a flat in the Bronx.

Some might think that Senator THOMAS cuts a ludicrous figure in his attitude toward the fall in the stock market. To the president of the Stock Exchange he telegraphed yesterday that the day's transactions demonstrated the "absolute necessity for immediate adoption of a rule limiting "amount of loss on any stock during "any one session."

PARIS, July 20. -- United resistance against persecution of Jews by the Nazis in Germany was urged on the Jews of the world by Rabbi Stephen S. Wise of New York in an address to an international audience at the New School of Peace in Paris tonight.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 20. -- Mrs. Dorothy Cheston Bennett, widow of the British novelist Arnold Bennett, scored a triumph tonight before a Summer colony audience in her late husband's London comedy hit, "Mr. Prohack." The play was presented in the John Drew Memorial Theatre by the South Shore players, of which Miss Ann Grosvenor Ayres is the manager.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Three employers' associations in the women's cloak and suit industry joined today at a hearing on their proposed code before Deputy Administrator Earl Dean Howard in urging that the piecework system of payment should be sanctioned if the industry was to be stabilized.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure.
WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The "blanket code" for employers of labor, signed tonight by President Roosevelt, reads:
Between ten and fifteen New York Central trains were delayed last night after the tracks were flooded at a point between Mount St. Vincent and Yonkers by a violent hail and rain storm.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP). -- Questions relating to operation of the Glass-Steagall Banking Act were taken up today at the first meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee at the Treasury Department.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York announced yesterday that it had accepted the invitation of the representatives of several groups in the shipping industry to serve as the clearing house for codes of ethics. These codes will be drafted by the various branches of the industry and brought together in a single code under the terms of the National Industrial Recovery Act.

No church has a right to deprive a man of membership for drinking, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, declared yesterday. He spoke at the thirteenth annual conference for ministers and other Christian workers at the seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.

Richard M. Lederer, president of the Standard National Corporation, building construction and mortgage bankers, has purchased a large estate in Westchester County, it was learned yesterday. He has bought, through 'William J. Yates and the Dodds Associates, as brokers, the place at Pleasantville known as "Hardscrabble Farm."

Mrs. Adam K. Luke Jr. gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Miss Dorothy Rosalie Buckley and John A. Finneran, who will be married next Wednesday. Also in the party were Mrs, William H. Buckley, mother of the bride-to-be, and Miss Kathryn Buckley.

Two things stand out as especially significant in the Government report on employment and payrolls in manufacturing industries last month. One is the striking reversal of a usual seasonal trend. Only twice during the decade from 1923 to 1932 inclusive did employment improve in June as compared with May, and in both cases the gain was merely nominal.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Control of production in the lumber industry was proposed today in an amendment to that industry's code of fair competition when hearings on the code opened. The amendment would give the Lumber Code Authority, the governing body of the Lumber and Timber Industry under the code of fair practices submitted to the National Recovery, Administration, power to restrict the installation of new sawmills when necessary.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- The National Underwriters Association announced today the completion of a plan to strike at the auto stripping racket by abolishing the market for stolen parts, now the chief source of revenue for the racketeers. Recent statistics show that the racket now costs Chicago motorists about $10,000,000 annually.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 20. -- Charles Bulkley Hubbell, retired lawyer, of the Hotel Gotham, New York, had an eightieth birthday luncheon party today at the Brookside, Williamstown, the house in which he was born, now his Summer home.

BERLIN, July 20. -- The Boerse reacted today from yesterday's buoyancy. Stocks sagged under realizing sales, but with the exception of a few issues, notably Siemens Halske, which declined four points, and some foreign stocks, including Chade, which suffered an initial drop of 9 marks, declines ranged from a fraction to two points.
The following code for the dress industry has been submitted by the National Dress manufacturers Association:
WASHINGTON, July 20. -- An aggressive campaign against high-pressure selling of questionable stocks by radio will be undertaken by the Federal Trade Commission, Chairman March announced today.
Stocks and commodities experienced the sharpest break in more than a year yesterday, as the selling movement, which began Wednesday, continued violently in the speculative markets.

Ogden L. Mills, former secretary of the Treasury, will sail tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Europa accompanied by his family. Other prominent passengers will include Katharine Cornell, actress; Senator Bronson Cutting of New Mexico, H.H. Bachke, Norwegian Minister to the United States; Colonel E. Alexander Powell, author; Joseph E. Ridder, vice president of the Staats-Herold Corporation, and Heinz Schuengel, resident director of the North German Lloyd here.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- Two days of frenzied trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, during which wheat dropped 22 to 28 cents a bushel, resulted today in the Board of Governors taking drastic steps to bring the market within bounds.

Two infant grandchildren of Henry W. Taft, law partner of George W. Wickersham, were secretly sent away last night on the White Star liner Majestic because the parents and Mr. Taft feared kidnappers, according to officials of the line.

The "International World Police," to be formed by the leading police officials of many nations at the Chicago Fair at the end of this month, was hailed by Police Commissioner Bolan last night as the greatest forward step in police cooperation yet undertaken.

BERLIN, July 20. -- After signing the concordat with the Vatican on behalf of the German Government today Vice Chancellor Franz von Papen, in an interview with a German newspaper man who had accompanied him to Rome, said that the agreement "guarantees for the first time beneficial cooperation between church and State."
NEW YORK. Miss Violet Gratz-Brown of 29 East Seventy-sixth Street is visiting Miss Natalie H. Hammond in Gloucester, Mass.

PITTSBURGH, July 20. -- The Giants missed several chances to win today and as one slip is usually enough to sink them, the result, one might say, was almost inevitable. The Pirates won, 6 to 5, to take a 2-to-1 lead in the current six-game series and put themselves within three games of the league leaders.

Bruce Barton took the witness stand yesterday before Judge Joseph. E. Corrigan and a jury in General Sessions at the trial of Mrs. Frances W. King, who is accused of blackmail and attempted extortion.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 20. -- At the conclusion of play today in the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club's second annual invitation tennis tournament all of the eight seeded stars found themselves in the quarter-final round.

LONDON, July 20 (AP). -- The American team spurted to a lead of 5,640 points over the British team in today's round of a 300-board duplicate tournament for an international contract bridge trophy offered by Charles M. Schwab. The score at the end of the night session, with 200 boards completed, was: United States, 66,020; England, 60,380.
More than usually interesting, the changes made by the handicap committee of the United States Polo Association at its annual midsummer meeting were announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Declaring the Federal appropriation of $500,000,000 for unemployment relief would be insufficient unless the States assumed their fair share of the burden, Harry I. Hopkins. Federal Emergency Relief Administrator, today refused the request of Governor White of Ohio for $4,000,000, pending further efforts by the State to care for the destitute.

Professor Gerald. E. SeBoyar, chairman of the committee on scholastic standing at the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, announced yesterday that 192 students of evening sessions of that division had been named on the honor roll for the second semester of the 1932-1933 academic year.

The announcement of Great Britain's plan for converting her 5 1/2 pep cent dollar loan of 1937 into sterling obligations at the rate of u260 of new bonds for each $1,000 bond outstanding fell yesterday upon the foreign exchange market like a thunderbolt.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Governmental costs in 1,135 political units of New Jersey for the fiscal year ended June 30, 1932, were $537,023,776, according to figures released today by the Department of Commerce. In this sum, the payments for operation and maintenace of the public schools, placed at $115,516,807, was the largest single item.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 20. -- Wiley Post, round-the-world flier, damaged his plane in landing at the town of Flat this afternoon, but was unhurt, according to word received here at 5:10 P.M. (11:10 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time).

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- An opinion as to whether the Treasury can legally permit or prohibit the export of gold ore or partially refined ore has been submitted to the Treasury Department by Attorney General Cummings, it was stated at the Department of Justice today.

The Vocafilm Corporation, which until 1929 had been engaged In the manufacture of recording apparatus for motion pictures, filed a suit yesterday in Federal Court for $65,953,125 against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the Western Electric Company, Inc., and the Electrical Research Products Company, Inc.

The reorganization plan of the Republic Gas Corporation has been amended to take into account the reduction in earnings during the first half of 1933, due to low prices for crude oil and natural gas. The bondholders' protective committee headed by James R. Buck is recommending acceptance of the modified plan in a letter to holders of first-lien collateral 6 per cent convertible bonds.
WASHINGTON, July 20. -- President Roosevelt and official Washington paid tribute today to General Italo Balbo and his flying companions for their flight across the Atlantic Ocean from Italy.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 20. -- Into the place vacated by Miss Helens Madison a new free-style queen advanced today as Miss Lenore Kight of the Carnegie Library Club of Homestead, Pa., won two of the three titles decided in the opening session of the Women's National A.A.U. swimming championships.

The Victorian silhouette, with emphasis on wide shoulders and fitted hiplines, will continue of major style importance this Fall. Miss Katherine Casey, style authority, made this prediction yesterday afternoon at the Fall fashion conference of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Gertrude Stein's autobiography, in which she refers to herself as Alice B. Toklas, calling the book "The Autobiography of Alice B. Toklas," will be published on Sept. 1 by Harcourt. Brace Co. and will be the September selection of the Literary Guild.

Members of the League of New York Theatres ratified their code yesterday at a special meeting and also considered the master code covering all branches of the legitimate stage. The unified code will be submitted today to the National Alliance of the Theatre.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 20. -- The extent to which New Jersey may expect Federal aid in the financing of many projects for which Governor Moore hoped to get funds from the public works appropriation was outlined today. A report was sent to the Governor from "Washington by Dr. Jacob Lipman of the New Brunswick Agricultural Experiment Station.
WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The war Department issued the following orders today Loving, Lt. Col. J.J., Engrs., to Fort Sam Houston, Texas.

MOSCOW, July 20. -- The harvest is now in full swing throughout the southern half of the Soviet Union -- the territory including the chief grain-producing regions -- and reports everywhere tell of a huge crop.

Thursday, July 20, 1933. An increase in the supply of bills coupled with a strong demand from local and out-of-town banks accounted for one of the most active days in the bill market in weeks. However, rates were maintained for all dates without change.

LONDON, July 20. -- With the British Government's offer to holders of 5 1/2 per cent United Kingdom bonds issued in New York in 1917 was hailed here as a gesture indicative of Great Britain's determination to maintain the spirit of its obligations at whatever cost, some alarm was shown tonight when it became known that the cost in this instance means an additional burden of u5,469,216 on the British taxpayer.
WASHINGTON, July 20. -- Internal revenue collections for June increased $44,606,607 over June, 1932, to a total of $251,600,997, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.
LONDON, July 20. -- Twenty thousand London Jews marched to Hyde Park in the broiling heat this afternoon in a mass protest against Nazi persecution of their brethren in Germany.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- Through the medium of a manifesto which a committee began to draft today, the International Congress of Women, in session here, prepared to speak its sentiments to the governments of the world. The document, terse and pointed, will be presented to the general session tomorrow for debate and for action.

DETROIT, July 20 (AP). -- The one-man grand jury, now in adjournment, which for five weeks delved into the affairs of Detroit's two closed national banks, would like to have the testimony of former President Herbert Hoover.

Copyright, 1933, by NANA, Inc. Few would have expected, after the costly lessons of 1929, that we should have had already a repetition, of the wild days preceding the crash. Yet it was inevitable that there should be a bull market and speculation, as a consequence of the announced purpose of the administration to reduce the swollen dollar -- that is, to raise the commodity price level.

A 40-hour week of five days and a minimum wage at the rate of 35 cents an hour for unskilled workers are specified in the fair competition code under the Recovery Act submitted yesterday by the Association of Dress Manufacturers, Inc.
The address of Percy S. Straus, president of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., to members of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, was as follows:

A reorganization plan of the Memphis Street Railway Company has been mailed to security holders by the bondholders' protective committee, headed by Frederic J. Fuller, which has become the reorganization committee. It provides for the organization of a new company, to be called the Memphis Street Railway Corporation, or other appropriate name, under the laws of Tennessee.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 20 (AP). -- Tommy Thompson's single which scored Harry Taylor from second base in the ninth inning gave Albany a 7-to-6 victory over Newark in an International League game tonight.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 20. -- The Edwin Gould Foundation for Children in New York shares equally with Mrs. Sarah Gould, the widow, in the residuary estate under the will of Edwin Gould, son of the late Jay Gould, filed with Surrogate Howell here today.

In keeping with other markets yesterday, the bond market on the Stock Exchange was weak. The losses in the domestic corporation list ranged from fractions to more than 8 points, although the major declines in the more active issues were limited to two or three points.

Mr. MARKLE'S will shows with what continuing interest he prolongs his stay on the earth which gave him so generously of its treasure. He did not withhold more than was meet during his life, for he began dispensing his fortune while still in the midst of his days. The fact that he became blind explains his bequests for the prevention of blindness and for bringing light to those upon whom the darkness came.

The world-wide study of the cosmic ray, under the direction of Professor Arthur H. Compton, Nobel Prize winner, of the University of Chicago, will be extended next Fall as far as the vicinity of the South Pole, if not the Pole itself, it was announced yesterday afternoon by Dr. Compton.

The Federal Reserve System's open-market purchases of United States Government securities dwindled to $10,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the report of the system published yesterday showed. The previous week the system bought only $12,000,000 of government securities, contrasted with weekly purchases of $25,000,000 when the open-market campaign began in May.

STOCKHOLM, July 20 (AP). -- Continuing their international test against the picked athletes of eleven nations, America's touring track and field stars won four of six events today as Glenn Cunningham of Kansas and Ralph Metcalfe of Marquette University set new Swedish records.

Leon Barzin, director of the National Orchestral Association and a former member of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, made his debut as its conductor last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. The weather was not kind to him. Lowering skies and heavy showers in the early evening reduced the recent big audiences.

LONDON, July 20. -- Yesterday's break in Wall Street caused general lowering of industrials on the Stock Exchange here today. British funds were still favored and South African mines were firm on continued Cape support.

The colors of C.V. Whitney, leading money winning owner in this country, were carried to victory in the featured Lochinvar Purse at Empire City yesterday when Jabot scored by two lengths. It was almost a one, two finish for Whitney. Jabot's stablemate, Piety, was beaten by only a head for second in the last few strides as H.C. Phipps's Changeling, 11-10 favorite, made a determined bid.

A schedule of the earnings of the constituent companies of Drug, Inc., in 1932, and the equivalent earnings for each share of each independent company which will result from the proposed segregation of the properties, was issued yesterday on behalf of the company.

With only a month left in which to make a choice, the fusion candidate for Mayor remained undetermined yesterday with former Representative F.H. La Guardia the most probable selection because of an apparent failure to find a strong enough candidate to put against him.

The Aviation Dinner Dance to be held tonight at the Lido Country Club, Lido Beach, L.I., in the Interest of the National Amateur Charity Air Pageant, promises to be a success judging by the number of reservations made by wellknown persons.

ALBANY, July 20. -- The Milk Control Board today raised the minimum price of retail milk one cent a quart and of cream two cents a half-pint in the New York City area as well as in a number of other places. The new prices become effectives, at 1 A.M. tomorrow.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 20. -- Coming with a rush through the last half today, William Ziegler's Great Island polo team broke a 4-all tie with Burnt Mills and galloped to a 9-to-5 victory in a Wheatley Cups first-round match at the Meadow Brook Club.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 20. -- The season's first Governor's Day celebration brought today hundreds of visitors to the reception held at the executive mansion by Governor and Mrs. A. Harry Moore. The Governor's guests came from nine counties, all of which have representative companies in the 114th Infantry, commanded by Colonel Edward B. Stone, which is encamped here.

Statistically, yesterday's share market was unusually interesting. The volume, 8,118,210 shares, was the seventh largest in the history of the Stock Exchange. It compared with 7,445,000 shares on the day before, when the market was having its first great break.

ALBANY, July 20. -- "No news" was the grim summary of the situation in the kidnapping of John O'Connell Jr. as voiced today by the captive's uncles, Daniel and Edward O'Connell, Albany's political bosses.

LONDON, July 20. -- All currents of London's social, official and diplomatic life converged today at Buckingham Palace, where King George and Queen Mary gave a garden party for more than 6,000 guests.

A deluge of selling orders which in several instances broke trading records and in one case caused a temporary halt in trading, swept all commodity prices down almost without interruption yesterday. Stop-loss orders and short selling were reported to have played a part in the trend.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 20. -- Tennessee became today the nineteenth State to vote for repeal of the prohibition amendment.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 20. -- The first of a series of three chamber music concerts to be given at different Summer residences was held this evening at Chateau-Sur-Mer, the home of the Misses Edith and Maud Wetmore, and was attended by many members of the Summer colony.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The wholesale price index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics made a record leap of 2.5 per cent during the week ending July 15. The index stood at 68.9 July 15, compared with 67.2 tor the week ending July 8, with 66.1 on July 1, with 65.1 June 24 and 64.5 on June 17.

Postmaster General and Double-Chairman FARLEY makes public through The American Magazine the qualifications required for appointment to Federal offices not subject to civil service rules. He follows in the main the lofty principles which he has enunciated several times before.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 20 (AP). -- Milwaukee backers of the national professional golfers' tournament here Aug. 8 threatened today to cancel their $9,000 prize fund unless every member of the Ryder Cup team competes.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 20. -- Henry R. Barrett, secretary of the Westchester County Republican Committee, announced today that an effort would be made to delay the selection of a new county chairman, succeeding the late "William L. Ward, until after the Fall elections.

PLANDOME, L.I., July 20. -- The defending champion, Miss Peggy Wattles of Buffalo, was shorn of her title today in the quarter-final round of the women's New York State championship on the Plandome Golf Club course.
WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The administration moved today to check the wild speculation in the grain markets, which has been a source of acute concern to government officials for some time.

The need for a "civic sense in architecture" is emphasized by Darcy Braddell, secretary to the Royal Institute of British Architects Board of Architectural Education, London, in his book on architecture, "How to Look at Buildings," published recently by E.P Dutton Co.
MANILA, July 20. -- Senator Manual Quezon's anti-Hawes Law faction has won overwhelming victories on all political fronts in the last twenty-four hours.

General Italo Balbo hopes to leave New York Monday morning on his return flight to Italy. While the commander of the Italian squadron and thirty-nine of his officers flew to Washington yesterday to be greeted by President Roosevelt, the rest spent a great part of the day at Floyd Bennett Field going over planes and motors.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Out of Control," which intimates that prices on the Stock Exchange have advanced too rapidly and out of proportion to the improvement of general business conditions, is very wholesome as a warning against the madness and folly of the new era idea which prevailed in 1928-29.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 20. -- Fighting an uphill battle most of the way, Miss Carolin Babcock of Los Angeles today gained her third successive Eastern tennis final by overcoming Miss Sarah Palfrey of Brookline, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3, in the only intersectional semi-final in the Essex County Club's invitation tourney.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- In making public the Federal re-employment agreement tonight, Hugh S. Johnson, the Recovery Administrator, said the blanket code would not be permitted to slow up in any way the submission and approval of detailed codes for individual industries.
New York City will meet its next relief payrolls of about $1,500,000 from 52,000,000 accepted by the city yesterday from the State Emergency Relief Administration.
