SHANGHAI, Friday, July 21. -- While Nanking's punitive expedition against Marshal Feng Yuhsiang in Chahar Province paused today within less than ten miles of the Marshal's entrenched positions at Hsuanhwa, another large force was ordered to join it, bringing the total to about 60,000.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/2 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 1 1/2 Per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.
All markets passed yesterday through a secondary reaction which, with respect to the best-rated stocks and the more important agricultural staples, was even more severe than that of the day before.

FLAT, Alaska, July 20. -- Wiley Post's world-circling plane Winnie Mae was damaged slightly in landing in an east wind here at 3:30 P.M. (9:30 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time) today, but the Oklahoma flier escaped injury and mechanics believed the plane might be ready for a take-off tomorrow morning.
DUBLIN, July 20. -- Former Police Chief Eoin O'Duffy of Dublin was elected president of the Irish, Pascists at their first national convention in the Hibernian Hotel, Dublin, this evening.

RYE, N.Y., July 20. -- The Noyes brothers, Sidney Jr. and Frank, won the new Westchester Challenge Cup for the Ardsley Club today while Ellis Knowles, Apawamis veteran, captured the medal with a 74 in the qualifying round of the Westchester County Club's annual invitation golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The code of fair competition submitted to the National Recovery Administration by the shipbuilding industry is hard and fast aground tonight as a result of a demand by American Federation of Labor unions for an iron-clad 30-hour week, a minimum wage of $25 a week for common labor, and the widest possible latitud for the unions.

With her sixth Wimbledon crown to her string and two silky white Sealyham terriers of championship pedigree on the leash, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody arrived on board the Lafayette of the French Line yesterday, her confidence in no whit shaken by the fact that she lost her first set of singles in six years in the recent British tournament.

BERLIN, June 20. -- In an endeavor to find funds of the Marxist parties and to ascertain which of their members have foreign bank accounts, police officials advertised today that a reward would be given to persons divulging such information.

BUENOS AIRES, July 20. -- The recent cold weather, accompanied by heavy frosts, has caused widespread damage to young flaxseed crops but has greatly benefited wheat and corn, according to a report made by the Bureau of Rural Statistics to the Ministry of Finance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The City of New York seems to be lagging behind, so far as the New Deal is concerned -- I am referring particularly to the subway situation and its effect upon the finances of the city.

Rising prices in the absence of corresponding wage increases and delays by "slacker" industries in formulating their codes may lead to consumer strikes and the defeat of the national recovery plan, Percy S. Straus declared yesterday at the "recovery forum" of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended July 19, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,196,000,000, a decrease of $34,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $242,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

BAIREUTH, Germany, July 20. -- Everything is in readiness for the new and costly production of "Die Meistersinger" which tomorrow afternoon will inaugurate the Bayreuth Festival of 1933. Though this year's festival is officially designated as the celebration of the semicentenary of Richard Wagner's death, the influences which will most vividly color it are those of high-powered Nazi ceremonial and propaganda.
Jersey City broke a seven-game losing streak yesterday by defeating Baltimore, 5 to 4, in the seventeenth inning at Jersey City. Joe Benes's single, scoring Loris Baker, ended the thrilling contest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with much interest Professor Tugwell's article in THE TIMES Magazine, entitled "The Ideas Behind the New Deal," also your editorial comment on the article. May I say that I do not think your editorial comment compares at all favorably in tone with the article itself?

WHEN Rogers Hornsby was traded from the Braves to the Chicago Cubs he made a remark about the club he was leaving and of which he had been manager. He said, with his usual bluntness, that the Braves might miss him as a player but he would be no loss to them as a manager.
The two favorities in the draw, Joseph Abrams and Jackie Behr, entered the final of the Eastern junior clay court championship yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

Fluke fishermen are having a holiday this season in almost all the waters near New York City. The fluke are running heavy, too, as a catch of one weighing sixteen and three-quarter pounds will attest.

The one-story building at 428 W. 25th St. was sold by Ancel J. Brower to Blanchard Press, Inc., and the latter gave to the Metropolitan Title Guaranty Co. a mortgage for $7,500, payable July 1, 1936, at 4 per cent, on the property.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 20 (AP). -- The Chancery Court refused today to prevent the stock of Fox Film Corporation owned by General Theatres Equipment, Inc., now in receivership, from, being voted tomorrow and Saturday in favor of the reorganization and refinancing plan of the film corporation.

BERLIN, July 20. -- Fritz Kreisler, the violinist, said today that he would continue to refuse to appear in Germany despite the announcement by Hans Hinkel, Prussian State Commissioner for Culture, that in Hitlerite Germany "the free artistic activities of foreigners and non-Aryans [Jews] shall in nowise be hindered."

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 20. -- Over the picturesque Rockwood Hall Club links today Jimmy Hines of Timber Point and Mike Turnesa of Fairview waged a golfing battle that ended in a tie for the medal in the Metropolitan P.G.A. championship.
"Tommy," a comedy, by Howard Lindsay and Bertrand Robinson, will be seen in a Wee and Leventhal revival the first week of August at the Forrest Theatre.

Harlem's snake reappeared yesterday and the cosmopolitan population around Madison Avenue and 115th Street is wondering when a certain affable stranger will bring the mongoose he promised three weeks ago.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 20. -- Many members of the Smmer colony entered the fifth in the series of bridge tournaments, held tonight at the clubhouse of the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club. Mrs. Henry W. Sage Jr. gave a dinner at Wyllys House, her home in First Neck Lane, in advance of the tournament.

With the assurance that her husband had made the dangerous crossing from Siberia to Alaska in safety, Mrs. Wiley Post, who had been under great strain, began to relax yesterday. She retired last night before word had arrived of the world flier's landing at Flat, Alaska, when his plane was damaged.

WASHINGTON, July 20. -- President Roosevelt promulgated late tonight a voluntary blanket recovery code for business and industry of the entire country, by which he hopes to re-employ the nation's jobless millions and increase purchasing power to sustain a new prosperity.

AMSTERDAM, July 20. -- In this city upon free Dutch soil where, almost 400 years ago Jews driven from Spain and Portugal found a safe refuge, establishing a colony which in the next generation produced the great philosopher, Spinoza, some thirty representatives of world Jewry met today to deal with Germany's modern revival of Jewish persecution.

PARIS, July 20. -- The United States Davis Cup team enters the interzone finals at Auteuil tomorrow with excellent chances of not only defeating the English tennis team but of turning back France next week to recapture the famous trophy after its seven-year sojourn in this country.

Bernard M. Baruch, friend of President Roosevelt and adviser to the government, sailed yesterday on the White Star liner Majestic to take the cure at Vichy, France. His family is already abroad and will join him there.

Coincident with the breaks in other speculative markets, prices of cotton lost a cent a pound yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. After displaying nervousness rather than weakness for two hours, they gave way under the heaviest selling pressure of the year, dropping $8 a bale from high levels of the week.

Governor Lehman's home and farm mortgage advisory committee held a conference yesterday in the rooms of the Merchants Association to discuss with bankers and State officials the most practical means for State cooperation with the Federal Home Owners Corporation in relieving the distress of owners of mortgaged property.
BUENOS AIRES, July 21 -- The government will encourage farmers to hold back corn under the financing scheme of the Bank of the Nation, which was announced yesterday.

RED BANK, N.J., July 21 -- Three gunmen drove last night into the shore warehouse of R.H. Macy Co. and L. Bamberger Co., held up the manager and escaped with $1,172 in cash. An employe was knocked unconscious with a pistol butt when he tried to flee and spread the alarm.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 21 (AP). -- Wiley Post, Oklahoma pilot, hopped off from Fairbanks at 5:45 P.M. (11:45 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time) today for Edmonton, Canada, in continuation of his solo flight around the world.

LONDON, July 21 (AP) -- The American team under the leadership of Ely Gulbertson stretched its lead in the international contract bridge tournament, for a trophy posted by Charles M. Schwab, to 9,150 points tonight, leaving the English team an almost hopeless task in the remaining fifty boards.

The selling movement in the listed bond market yesterday was more severe than on the previous day, carrying domestic corporation bonds down 1 to 10 points and foreigns 1 to 7 1/2 points. A small group showed only fractional declines and a very small number managed to gain slightly on the day.
LONDON, July 21 -- The text of the resolution submitted by Secretary of State Hull in the economic commission of the World Economic Conference today follows:

Vincent Dailey, newly appointed head of the Home Owners Loan Corporation of the State of New York, returned yesterday from Washington, where he was sworn in on Thursday. He also received approval from the Federal authorities for a plan of organization for this State which he had submitted.

AMSTERDAM, July 21 -- An ap- peal by the Jews of the world to the League of Nations for action in the matter of the persecution of Jews in Germany was framed today by representatives of Jewish organizations in thirty countries who are meeting here.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Railroad freight rates appeared certain to be reduced on Sept. 30.

The report of the Midland Bank, Ltd., London, as of June 30, which reached here yesterday, confirms the expectation that as a result of the fall of the dollar that institution has regained its position as the largest bank in the world.

Socialists Go It Alone. New York Socialists will not enter a fusion movement. They will name a candidate of their own for Mayor, and the bold guess is made that it will be NORMAL THOMAS. Apparently, after some hesitation, the Socialists have discovered that the fusion movement in this city is composed of discordant elements having no social program.

A 40-hour week and a $14 minimum wage for non-manufacturing employes are provided in the code of fair competition under the National Industrial Recovery Act submitted yesterday by the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., and the United Fur Manufacturers Association, Inc.

At a foreclosure sale which as referee I conducted a few days ago a very choice private home was bid in by the plaintiff-mortgagee with a bid of $2,000 on a foreclosure judgment in excess of $18,000. For the very large difference between these two amounts a deficiency judgment is entered against the mortgagor.

AUTEUIL, France, July 21 (AP) -- "This is a big blow to us but we are not out of it yet," Bernon S. Prentice, captain of the United States Davis Cup team said tonight. "We were simply outplayed today and have no excuses."

ALBANY, July 21 -- With four ships already in the harbor and two more expected tomorrow, business was booming in the Port of Albany today. More than 400 men, many of them recruited from relief rolls, are working as stevedores.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 21 -- The "small committee" which will run the Westchester Republican organization until after the selection of a successor to the late William L. Ward will consist of three members, it was learned today.

A decline in the volume of new municipal financing will occur next week, when twenty-five communities will be in the market with issues amounting to only $7,169,168. The revised total for this week was $25,624,847, and the weekly average for the year to date $13,663,698.

The committee on refinery statistics and economics of the American Petroleum Institute estimates that the demand for motor fuel in the last half of this year will be 2.9 per cent more than it was in the same part of 1932. It states that inventories have been consistently below those of last year and that the trend is toward economic levels.

Wall Street had expected a sharp rally yesterday, but was disappointed. While almost every market influence was on the side of the advance, the movement was generally lower. Speculative interests in Wall Street and in Chicago ascribed the decline to frightened liquidation.

The prairie land between the Mississippi River and the Rocky Mountains is now the vital and social centre of the United States, according to Harvey Fergusson, whose book, "Rio Grande," has just been published by Alfred A. Knopf.
DETROIT, July 21 -- Ken Strong, former baseball and football star, received an award of $75,000 in Federal court today in a damage suit against Dr. Alfred D. Laferte of Detroit.
VIENNA, July 21 -- Five "raids" by German airplanes on Austria took place this evening.

PLANDOME, L.I., July 21 -- A golfing feud that started on the sand hills at Pinehurst five years ago flared at Plandome today when Miss Helen Hicks met Mrs. Marion Turpie Lake in one of the semifinal-round matches of the Women's New York State championship.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 21 -- Two world's records were left in the white-flecked wake of two of America's premier mermaids today as Miss Eleanor Holm from the cinema lots of Hollywood and Miss Lenore Kight of Homestead, Pa., thrashed their way to new marks during the women's national A.A.U. swimming championships.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 21 -- Trailing by two sets and with the score 4 -- 2 against him in the third chapter, Gregory Mangin of Newark, national indoor tennis champion, rallied to turn back Berkeley Bell today. By the victory he kept the ranks of the elect intact as play entered the semi-finals in the invitation tournament of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 21 -- Mrs. Goodhue Livingston gave a large luncheon today at Old Trees for Mrs. Preston Davie of Jericho, L.I., who is passing several days with her. The guests were seated at small tables placed on the veranda.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Coincident with proposals in this country for regulation of the stock and commodity markets, the Commerce Department was advised today that the German Government has tightened its control over the Berlin Stock Exchange.

RYE, N.Y., July 21 -- Sir Gilbert, chestnut stallion, owned by Stephen E. Budd of Newtown, Conn., contributed one of the outstanding performances of the two-day Westchester Country Club horse show, which opened today.

Almost completely exhausted, Peter Walsh, 15 years old, was rescued at midnight last night from the Long Island Railroad trestle over Goose Creek in Jamaica Bay, to which he had been clinging desperately for ten hours. Joseph Ackerman, 33, a partly paralyzed companion, was missing and a party of volunteers was still searching the bay for him early this morning.

Renewed efforts to get George V. McLaughlin, former Police Commissioner, to be the fusion nominee for Mayor are being made by the fusion leaders as the result of a conference yesterday at the office of former Governor Charles S. Whitman, chairman of the Republican Mayoralty committee.

STOCKHOLM, July 21 -- Capped by another pair of brilliant victories for Glenn Cunningham and Ralph Metcalfe, America's touring track stars ended a protracted meet with the athletes of eleven nations tonight with a record of fifteen conquests in eighteen events on the three-day program.

Copyright. 1933, by NANA. Inc., and The New York Times Company. World Rights Reserved. NOME, Alaska, July 21. -- I thought the flight from New York to the Norwegian island of Jomfruland was full of thrills, but this flight has them all stopped.
Representatives of tailors, cleaners and dyers told a committee of the Board of Aldermen yesterday that their trades were unable to pay the proposed city taxes now under discussion.

Renewal of the frightened selling of stocks and commodities yesterday was accepted as further evidence of the inability of speculators and investors to readjust their sense of values to the recovery program of the Federal Administration.

LONDON, July 21 -- Secretary of State Hull submitted to the Economic Commission of the World Economic Conference this afternoon, at a meeting closing the commission's work for this stage of the conference, the first concrete tariff plan any one has proposed here.
LONDON, July 21 -- Arthur Henderson, as secretary of the Labor party, in a new memorandum issued tonight on the objectives of the next Labor government in the field of foreign policy.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Industrial groups meeting here to draft fair competition codes under the National Industrial Recovery Act found their labors complicated today by President Roosevelt's call for a voluntary blanket code of all business.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- An appeal by Secretary Hull for international action to raise prices was scheduled today as the final action on behalf of the United States before the recess of the World Economic Conference in London on July 27.

The arrest this week of two women and four men, one of whom confessed participating in the kidnaping of August Luer, wealthy Illinois banker, emphasizes the fact that a high percentage of kidnapers have been brought to justice.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Behind the strong pitching of Earl Whitehill, the Senators today turned back the Tigers, 7 to 1, and maintained their league tie with the Yankees.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 21 (AP) -- Albany made it two straight over Newark tonight by winning, 6 to 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It has been called to our attention that two readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES have asked for information on the financing of the Bear Mountain camp for unemployed women.

The dollar fluctuated yesterday more erratically than at any previous time it was cut loose from gold. In trading of unusually large proportions it first showed weakness, then sudden strength and finally swept downward to close in a burst of liquidation induced by rumors that President Roosevelt was con- templating early reduction of the gold content of the dollar as a measure of defense against the breaks of stock and commodity prices.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I point out that Donald Pendleton, in replying to my letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES on the treatment of criminals, is rather begging the question in dwelling upon the Middle Ages and what might have happened had our earlier immigration laws been more restricted.

Despite the upturn in employment and business generally reported in recent weeks, there has been no diminution in the demand for Kelp from destitute unemployed, according to a report made public yesterday by the Welfare Council on the basis of study made by its research bureau.

Humidity of 100 per cent ushered into the metropolitan area yesterday a day of extreme discomfort during which the mercury rose to 82 degrees. Local thunder showers were expected today, but not much relief was in sight, the Weather Bureau said.

LONDON, Saturday, July 22 -- "L800,000,000 Wall Street Crash" and "Fortunes Wiped Out in Wall Street Landslide" are typical of the streamer headlines in London's leading morning newspapers. There is the greatest speculation on what steps President Roosevelt will take should the slump in grain and other prices proceed further.

Among those most frequently mentioned at one time as British Ambassador to the United States was Viscount BURNHAM. Though he never came in that capacity, he was one of America's best English friends, and was better able as a journalist than as an official diplomat to make his influence felt in the promotion of Anglo-American understanding, amity and cooperation.
FLAT, Alaska, July 21 (AP) -- Wiley Post, Oklahoman flier, resumed his race around the world today at 7:28 A.M. (1:28 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time).
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- United States cotton spinning operations reached a new high record of activity during June.

After closing a long public hearing yesterday on the proposed $45,500,000 Rutgerstown housing development Mayor O'Brien said the Board of Estimate would decide in executive session whether or not to grant tax exemption.

Wiley Post has until 9 P.M. tomorrow to establish a new record for flying around the world. He has only a little more than 3,000 miles to go, so friends here figure he may cut almost a full day from the mark he set two years ago with Harold Gatty.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The hearing on the shipbuilding code was concluded today with shipyard owners and labor organizations still far apart on every provision affecting hours of labor, wages and union privileges. A.D. Whiteside, deputy administrator, who conducted the hearings, declared that the failure to reach an agreement meant a new and regrettable burden put on the shoulders of President Roosevelt and of General Johnson, Industrial Recovery Administrator.

CINCINNATI, July 21 -- Continuing their campaign in reverse, Max Carey's Dodgers today achieved the unwanted objective of the National League cellar by losing their third straight to the Reds and their sixth in a row. The score was 2 to 1, and it moved Cincinnati into sixth place.

LONDON, July 21 -- London was calm today in the face of yesterday's Wall Street slump. Prices on the Stock Exchange opened generally lower, but in the absence of any selling pressure there was a tendency toward recovery after initial dealings.

BERLIN, July 21 -- The political police today closed the Berlin office of the Jewish Telegraphic Agency, which has been serving Central European subscribers from Berlin for the last ten years. The closing order specified that the action was taken to prevent possible future activities by the agency that might endanger law and order.

In New York State the Democrats now control the Executive, the Senate and many of the cities, including the metropolis. Both United States Senators are of their party, and of the forty-five Representatives in Congress twenty-nine are theirs. But the rule of politics is not only to keep what you have but to add to it.

Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck, who refused nearly four months ago to sign an order for the sale of property in foreclosure without reasonable assurance of competitive bidding, set another precedent yesterday when he vacated a deficiency judgment in a foreclosure action.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, July 21 (AP) -- Elliott Roosevelt, son of the President, arrived here tonight at 11:22 o'clock by automobile from Chicago and went to the home of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Swiler, uncle and aunt of Miss Ruth Googins of Fort Worth, Texas, the girl whom he will marry tomorrow.

NASHVILLE, July 21 (AP) -- Charges of "fraud" and threats of court action were the reply of prohibitionists today to Tennessee's vote for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, which left the wets with a narrow lead of 8,840 votes.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Industrial Recovery Administration, through Deputy Administrator Earl Dean Howard, is expected to make an attempt tomorrow to avert the pending strike of 30,000 New York cloakmakers, set for next week.

More than 500 persons attended the annual costume dinner dance and circus last night at the Sands Point Bath Club, Sands Point, L.I. Dinner was served in the Casino, which had been transformed into a circus tent for the occasion, and on the open-air terraces.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 21 -- The "Dymaxion," a new type motor car with three wheels and a streamlined body, attained a speed of seventy miles an hour in its first test run here today.
NEWPORT, July 21 -- Arthur Curtiss James arrived on the Aloha from New York this morning with a party of guests and was a dinner host at Beacon Hill House tonight.

PORTLAND, Ore., July 21 -- A great wave of wet votes in Multnomah County (Portland) and a substantial vote along the same line in the rest of the State indicated tonight that Oregon had voted for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

Friday, July 21, 1933. The money market was quiet and steady all day. Inquiry for accommodation in all sections was virtually at a minimum. Rates, however, were maintained without change. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent. which also ruled in counter trading.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 21 -- Mrs. Edward Menocal entertained at a luncheon bridge today at the Maidstone Club. Her guests included Mmes. George R. McClellan, Theodorus Bailey, Carl Wolff, Frank Carr, Louis Faugeres Bishop, James T. Lee, Henry Dater, Oliver De Gray Vanderbilt, J. Hill Whiting, John W. Howell, William Cox, Frederick Kellogg Hollister, William Methuen Leslie, Charles Carscallen, E. Rodney Burnett and Francis D. Hyde.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 21 -- There were 210 starting craft today in the fifth regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club's race week. Friday is supposed to be a day in which the total drops, but again Long Island Sound was white with sails.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Nils R. Johaneson, who have been in New York for a few days, returned last night by airplane to Hopewell Hall, Alexandria Bay, Thousand Islands, where they are passing the Summer.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- An approximate 15 per cent wage increase for 40,000 soft coal miners in Central Pennsylvania was the first fruit of the conference of nonunion operators, which has been in session here ail the week, adjourning today over the week-end.

Several local churches will hold special services tomorrow in celebration of the golden jubilee of the National Women's Relief Corps of the Grand Army of the Republic, which will be observed throughout the country next week.

Stores Selling Fall Dresses. Initial offerings of Fall merchandise met with good response in local stores during the week, executives reported yesterday. Interest centred on satin dresses and many of these garments were sold, particularly in black and the popular eel gray shade.
PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP) -- The Browns, going into extra innings with the Athletics for the second consecutive day, took a 6-to-3 victory by scoring three runs in the twelfth today.

BERLIN, July 21 -- The Boerse was weak today. With almost complete absence of buying orders even small lots of offerings of stock produced declines of 1 to 3 points. Those most affected were steel and coal issues. Electricals showed more resistance.

BERLIN. July 21 -- George S. Messersmith, United States Consul General, lodged a strong protest with the German authorities today against the maltreatment of Philip Zuckerman, an American citizen of the Jewish faith, by Nazi storm troopers in Leipzig.

New bond financing this week dwindled to $2,902,000, consisting of five State and municipal issues. Last week the total was $8,334,000, and the week previous the aggregate was $38,577,000. Inasmuch as the unsettled condition of the general bond market this week served to delay the time when new corporation financing can be done, the field was left entirely to the municipal bond market.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Future government financing, which will mean issuance of probably more than $5,000,000,000 in securities for the recovery program, in addition to covering maturities in the next two years, was discussed today by the open-market committee of the Federal Reserve System.
Another step was taken yesterday in the litigation involving Wolfe's Pond Park at Prince's Bay, S.I.

Bruce Barton was cross-examined yesterday on his testimony the previous day against Mrs. Frances W. King. Mrs. King is charged with attempting to extort $50,000 blackmail from him. Her counsel, Solomon Hirschhorn, insisted on knowing what Mr. Barton meant when he said he did not believe he could be disgraced "by a woman of your reputation."
The Police Department made public yesterday 185 citations in which more than 300 members of the force receive official recognition "for meritorious conduct performed in the line of duty."
An interval of a month between home runs ended yesterday for Lou Gehrig with a blast that started the Yankees on their way to a 10to-2 victory over the Indians at the Stadium.

BERLIN, July 21 -- Hurried orders were issued this afternoon by Colonel Ernst Roehm, chief of staff of the Hitler army, summoning to Berlin all the higher storm troop and elite guard commanders from all over the Reich.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 21 -- A $41,000,000 bond issue to refinance the Delaware River Bridge and construct a high-speed traction line over the bridge linking Camden with Philadelphia was authorized this afternoon by the Delaware River Joint Commission.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor announces that its index number of wholesale prices for the week ended July 15 stands at 68.9, compared with 67.2 for the week ended July 8, showing an increase of approximately 2 and 5-10ths per cent.

New York, which had craned its neck in admiring wonder when General Italo Balbo's fleet winged in from Chicago on Wednesday, gave the commander and his flying officers a rousing official welcome yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- A new list of public works projects was approved today by President Roosevelt, as his aides estimated that funds already allotted would provide enough direct employment to give every jobless man in the nation a week's work.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 -- Following a blind dash to lower levels in the wake of the break on the New York Stock Exchange, traders on the San Francisco Stock Exchange and Curb took courage in the last minutes of today's session and a wave of cautious buying lifted many issues from 25 cents to $2 a share higher than the New York close.

Mrs. William S. Culbertson, wife of the American Ambassador to Chile, gave a luncheon yesterday at the Chatham. Her guests were Julius Lay, American Minister to Honduras, and Mrs. Lay; Ralph Wooten, American Military Attache in Chile, and Mrs. Wooten; Mr. and Mrs. John Chadwick, and Miss Junia Culbertson.

Jobless household workers and chauffeurs, white-haired men, workworn women and wistful youths, filed before Deputy Commissioner of Licenses Mary F. Kennedy yesterday at a hearing into the conduct of two closed employment agencies.

LONDON, July 21 -- The House of Commons quietly approved today, 131 to 22, the war bond conversion under which Great Britain will pay interest on gold securities either in paper dollars or in sterling at a lower rate.

For the first time since the fiscal year ended on June 30 the Treasury has published detailed figures of its revenues for 1932-33. The various excise taxes adopted a year ago by Congress as a substitute for a general sales tax make a disappointing showing. Compared with an estimated yield of $602,000,000, they actually brought in only $325,000,000.

A special plea for a reduction in the rates charged to wholesale users of electricity in the city was entered yesterday by the Merchants Association of New York at the hearing before the Public Service Commission.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- While preparations were reported under way in Burlington for the wedding of Elliott Roosevelt and Miss Googins, he checked out of a hotel this afternoon, continuing to be uncommunicative about his matrimonial plans.

Continued advances of wholesale commodity prices and of business activity were shown yesterday in tables issued by The Annalist. The table of prices, however, brought them up only to Tuesday, the day before the general break in commodities and securities.

ALBANY, July 21 -- Speaking today for the family of John J. O'Connell Jr., who was kidnapped a fortnight ago, Edward J. O'Connell, one of his uncles, flatly denied that contact had been established with the captors or that any ransom had been paid.

The Stock Exchange announced yesterday the names of brokers who participated in the sales of two seats early this week. George L. Maxwell bought for $230,000 the membership of Charles E. Lewis and Alexander Brown Griswold bought that of Elliot M. Anderson for $240,000. Mr. Griswold will form his own firm.

PITTSBURGH, July 21 -- Exhibiting considerably more power than the opposition seemed to suspect they had at their command, the Giants upset the Pirates today in a stirring finish in which Melvin Ott supplied the concluding stroke.

WASHINGTON, D.C., July 21 -- President Roosevelt contemplates no immediate action to restrain the gyrations of the New York stock market but has a definite plan in view in case action becomes necessary.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- While General Johnson was going through today a flood of telegrams relating to the blanket code for wages and hours in industry, George A. Sloan, president of the Cotton Textile Institute, reported personally that for the first week's operation of the cotton textile code not a single violation had been reported.

The general code by which the legitimate theatre is to operate under the National Industrial Recovery Act was unanimously adopted yesterday at a meeting of the National Alliance of the Theatre. It specifies a minimum wage for actors, prohibits the lowering of wage scales for the theatre's organized labor, and promises more satisfaction to the public in the matter of tickets.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Roosevelt changed his plans today for his Hyde Park vacation during August, to provide for considerable work here in the middle of the month. He had originally planned to spend a whole month in Hyde Park.

For the first time in several days an odds-on choice won at Empire City when the Belair Stud's Fleam, a daughter of General Lee, scored easily by three lengths at 1-to-2 yesterday. The rush of the form players to this haven of refuge was extreme after earlier favorites had fared none too well.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated July 19:

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Pledges of support for President Roosevelt's blanket re-employment agreement were carried in hundreds of telegrams and telephone calls pouring in today on the Recovery Administration. There was not a "sour" message in the whole lot, according to Hugh S. Johnson, the Recovery Administrator.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Offering to raise the pay of all classes of workers materially above the original proposals, electrical manufacturers tonight presented to the government a code designed to come within the terms of the blanket program made public by Mr. Roosevelt last night.

THIS is the report of a baseball tragedy and the solution of a Far East mystery. A tourist gallivanting around the world received instruction from this observer to drop in at Bombay, India, and see how the Bombay Baseball League was coming on. The bad news is that the Bombay Baseball League is not coming on at all. It has gone off completely.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 21 -- It sure was good to see old Joe Crosson last night when he arrived with a new propeller and other parts for the damaged Winnie Mae at Flat. And Joe was a great help again today when he guided me into Fairbanks.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Secretary Wallace today ordered a hearing here on July 31 to determine whether processing taxes should be levied on produces competing with cotton, including rayon, silk, wool and linen. Representatives of the cotton industry and manufacturers and distributers of materials sold in competition with it will be heard.

The substantial increase in gross earnings reported by the railways for June, with the month's surplus of operating revenue over expenses running in some of the first reporting carriers 12 to 30 per cent beyond 1932, is a natural result of the season's trade recovery.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A request for permission to regulate under the National Industrial Recovery Act not only production but minimum prices was argued today at the second session of the nearing on the lumber and timber code.

The Board of Estimate granted a twenty-five-year franchise yesterday to Jamaica Buses. Inc., covering four routes in Queens on which the Jamaica Central Railways Company now operates street cars. The bus company is a wholly owned subsidiary of the surface-car company.
CHICAGO, July 21 -- Mrs. Emily Newell Blair of Washington urged the International Congress of Women here today to lead a revolution against the present type of women's organization.

Conservationists are always faced with troubles in endeavoring to protect and propagate wild life, but it is not often of recent years that a given species of game becomes so abundant as to constitute a menace. Yet that has occurred in the past, especially in the Western States years ago, and more recently in New Zealand.

In the heaviest trading since Oct. 30, 1929, stocks declined from 2 to 22 points yesterday. During the last half hour the market rallied from 1 to 6 points, but not before thousands of speculators' accounts had been wiped out and the trading machinery of the Exchange had been tested to the limit.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 21 -- A golfing champion of other days, Mike Brady of Winged Foot, moved right into the thick of the tussle for the Metropolitan P.G.A. championship by two victories today.

After holding within a range of $1 a bale for two hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange dropped $6.75 and then recovered more than $3.50. The close was at losses of $2.10 to $2.50 a bale on the day. Old traders said that not in many years had so large a quantity of contracts changed hands in a single session and with such violent price changes.

RYE. N.Y., July 21 -- Winning five straight holes after being 3 down with six to play, Sidney Noyes Jr. of Ardsley defeated Jack Graham of Sleepy Hollow, 2 and 1, today. Thus he gained the semifinals along with three others in the Westchester Country Club's fifth annual invitation golf tournanient.

Continuing their precipitous declines, prices for commodities traded on local exchanges met yesterday with losses that were unparalleled in some cases and extremely large in all. Trading was again heavy as the stampede to sell continued.

In 1932 The Literary Digest poll showed that the three Dryest States in the Union were Kansas, North Carolina and Tennessee. Whether or not Tennessee deserves a place in that triad of virtue, her Dry vote on Thursday was much larger than had been expected by outsiders warmed by the example of Alabama and Arkansas.

Another flood of reports testifying to continued betterment in general business and extension of productive operations into the usual holiday season appeared this week according to the weekly review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Substantial additions still are being made to employment and payrolls and thus far nothing has developed to indicate a lull in activity during the remainder of the Summer, the survey said.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- A thoroughbred conceded to be the greatest on the American turf since Man o' War -- Equipoise, owned by Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney of New York -- will go to the post top heavy favorite in the $10,000 added Arlington Handicap at a mile and a quarter tomorrow.

More than 1,000 workers in the printing trades, most of them unorganized, met in Stuyvesant High School, Fifteenth Street and First Avenue, last night, under the auspices of the committee of associated printing trades, and heard appeals from union leaders that they authorize the printing trades unions to represent them in presenting a code under the National Industrial Recovery Act.

About 200 of the leading geologists of the United States and about twenty foreign countries were guests yesterday at a luncheon in their honor at the American Museum of Natural History, where they were officially welcomed by Professor Henry Fairfield Osborn, honorary president of the museum and senior geologist of the United States Geological Survey.

PARIS, July 21 -- England's Davis Cup team today sprang a stunning surprise by beating the favored United States team, in the opening two singles matches of the inter- zone finals played in scorching heat at the Roland Garros Stadium at Auteuil.

PARIS, July 22. -- Confidence in the United States is still firmly held in France, but it is qualified by doubt as to whether the Roosevelt administration is on the right road. There have been too many quick decisions to please the French.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 22. -- The first of about 1,000 sign posts on thoroughfares in Nassau County have just been installed. The work is being done under the direction of the traffic division of the Emergency Work Bureau, and is one of the permanent improvements undertaken by the bureau.
PARIS, July 12. -- The fair weather has encouraged the late season garden parties, some of them large-scale affairs, and in one instance the receipts are for charity.
Wiley Post landed safely in his fleet monoplane, the Winnie Mae, on Floyd Bennett Field, Brooklyn, at 11:59 1/2 o'clock last night, completing a record flight around the world.
A field of 135 professionals and amateurs will seek the Long Island open golf championship in the tourney starting Tuesday over the Lido Country Club links, Long Beach.

THE provincial Manhattanite who makes yearly pilgrimage to the Metropolitan Museum and the American Museum of Natural History may well -- as has been pointed out in these columns before -- add a third objective to his itinerary and visit the Brooklyn Museum.

WASHINGTON. IN its drive for national recovery the administration will use the facilities of a new Federal employment service organized under the Wagner-Peyser Law enacted by the special session of Congress. Headed by W. Frank Persons, the service is proceeding along two main lines.

SINCE Marconi applied for his first wireless patents hundreds of others have followed in his footsteps, and as the experimenter of 1933 surveys the field he may wonder whether the cream is off invention in radio. The basic principles seem to have been covered, but as one considers what a radio set does and what it might do.

The hearing on the code for the oil industry, scheduled to be held tomorrow before General Hugh S. Johnson, administrator of the National Industrial Recovery Act, is expected to be rather acrimonious, in view of the differences of opinion existing in the industry as to its operations under the act.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- A readjustment is under way on the part of leading Exchanges to put the grain market in a healthy condition as the result of the recent break, which carried prices down 30 cents a bushel in less than a week, placing all futures below the dollar level.

WITH the stock market in recent weeks spurred to unusual activity the ticker tape has occasionally lagged behind in its task of reporting transactions to brokerage offices in New York and other cities throughout the country.

ROME, July 22. -- What is considered by many to be the first step toward creation of a unified ministry of all the armed forces of Italy was taken today when King Victor Emmanuel accepted the resignation of General Pietro Gazzera, who has been Minister of War for five years, and entrusted the post to Premier Mussolini.

A total "working" population of 34,500 and a daily transient business population of 180,700 will be provided for in the twelve, buildings of Rockefeller Center when the midtown commercial and amusement development is completed, according to estimates compiled yesterday by officials of Rockefeller Center.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 22. -- For the fourth time in five years Walter Kozak, the 24-year-old Long Island open golf champion, gained the final of the metropolitan P.G.A. championship today.

An aerial photograph of Lardarello, not far from Florence, Italy, suggests a terrain under shell fire. Everywhere there are white clouds. To a resident they ceased to be alarming after 1818, the year in which FRANCOIS DE LARDEREL made them the basis of a prosperous borax industry.

NEWPORT. -- This week members of the Summer colony will do their bit toward furthering the national amateur air pageant to be held at Roosevelt Field early in October. A dinner dance for this purpose will be held at the Clambake Club on Saturday night and an air meet at Newport Airport a week from today.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- To expand its effectiveness in the agricultural relief program, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation today liberalized its lending policy sufficiently to make it embrace a large new class of operations upon which the farmer depends for his income.

THE courageous flight -- to death -- of the Lithuanian-Americans, Captain Stephen Darius and Stanley T. Girenas, once more proves the futility of transatlantic flights per se and the wisdom of the Department of Commerce in throwing restrictive bars around them.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, July 22. -- In a brief ceremony attended only by relatives, Elliott Roosevelt, 22-year-old son of President Roosevelt, aand Miss Ruth Googins of Fort Worth were married here at 6 o'clock this evening. The couple left by automobile a few hours later to board a Santa Fe train at Fort Madison, Iowa, for Fort Worth before proceeding to California.

During our entire history we are a nation have been expanding thoughtlessly the agricultural and urban areas of land. Our policy in regard to land use has been so elementary and so unscientific as to preclude the thought that we have had any.

Contributions to the German Relief Campaign of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee have mounted to $924,000, nearly half of the quota of $2,000,000, it was announced yesterday by Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, chairman of the campaign.

CINCINNATI, July 22. -- Finding the National League cellar atmosphere too damp and depressing, the aroused Dodgers today blasted themselves out with a barrage of extra-base hits and a helpful assortment of Cincinnati errors. The score was 8 to 0.

LOS ANGELES, July 22. -- When a private citizen becomes President of the United States he has traversed certain familiar and well-traveled paths of destiny. An entire nation has kept an attentive eye upon him and everything that has concerned him.

NO doubt it would be impossible and ridiculous to expect sound sense and balanced reasoning of a revolution. In such a moment an impulse more violent and explosive than sound reasoning is required, and at the necessary moment nature supplies it.

THE most impressive items for what should prove a hot July Sunday appear to concern the Shuberts. For those two haven't been idle this Summer, by any means. Last week a scout went off to Locust Valley, and as a result the firm is now the owner of "A Villa at Cannes."

NEWPORT, R.I., July 22. -- Allison V. Armour of New York cleared today aboard his yacht Utowana for a scientific cruise to Labrador. The boat will make a stop at Manchester, Mass., to pick up several guests. At Halifax a number of scientists will board the yacht, which will proceed to the coast of Labrador.

BERLIN, July 22. -- The death penalty for any attempt on the life of any member of the Nazi army, in which the Stahlhelm is now included or of the police or any government official is threatened in a draft law put through today by Premier Goering at a special session of the Prussian cabinet that he convened yesterday from his vacation retreat, the island of Sylt in the North Sea.

AUTEUIL, France, July 22. -- The United States doubles team won today in the Davis Cup tennis play because of George Lott of Chicago. He was a team by himself, and after three sets had been played he had done about everything that can be done in any tennis match.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 22. -- A new machine to boss another machine has been developed in the electrical engineering research laboratory of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP). -- President Roosevelt set up the organization today for using $25,000,000 of public works funds to finance a "back-to-the-land" movement by which it is proposed to put urban unemployed on small farms where they can grow their own food.

But a recent address of his shows that, after all, his dominant interest is in human affairs. He does not pose as an authority in government, but even a physicist "should be able to see general principles," and the general principle which he thinks he sees is this:

LONDON, July 22 (AP). -- Ely Culbertson and his three associates of the United States team won the Charles M. Schwab Trophy tonight by defeating the British combination in the international contract bridge match with a lead of 10,900 points in 300 boards.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- A compromise proposal for a thirty-two-hour week in the shipbuilding industry, proposed tonight by Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, in an effort to break a deadlock between representatives of labor and the industry, was rejected by the shipbuilders after a stormy session lasting two hours.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- North Jersey Shore activities during the coming week focus at Rumson, where the forty-sixth annual invitation tennis tournament of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club will open tomorrow. Ranking players of this country and Great Britain, the latter represented by the Oxford-Cambridge team, will compete during the entire week for possession of the historic Seabright bowls.

A "well-distributed increase in general realty activity is reported by the National Association of Real Estate Boards in its semi-annual survey of market conditions based on reports from 245 large cities. It is the first time since June, 1929, that the survey has shown a predominant upward, trend in the market.
NOME, Alaska, July 22. -- My flight from Anadyr to Nome with the Russian rescue ship was by far the most thrilling hop I have had on the entire flight around the world.

PARIS, July 22. -- Progress in some respects and deadlock in others was noted in disarmament negotiations when Arthur Henderson, president of the Geneva Conference, returned from his European "swing" and conferred today with Joseph Paul-Boncour, the Foreign Minister.

ONE of the most controversial topics in automobile legislation is to be discussed by representatives of twelve States and the District of Columbia in Harrisburg, Pa., next October. The meeting will consider the practicability of reciprocal and uniform legislation and regulation of size, weight, height and length of motor vehicles carrying passengers and freight.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Adoption by the Federal Government of a "fixed-fee contract" system for public works under the $3,300,000,000 program has been urged upon President Roosevelt and Secretary Ickes, chairman of the Emergency Public Works Board, by R.E.J. Summers, construction engineer.

An application by Joseph A. Broderick, Superintendent of Banks, for permission to pay a first dividend of 25 per cent to the creditors of the Mercantile Bank and Trust Company will be submitted to the Supreme Court for approval on July 31. under an order signed yesterday by Justice Schmuck.

MENTION of Schnabel and the significant contributions he has made to the gramophone repertoire in the last year quite naturally brings us back to report on the latest news from the Gramophone Company (H.M.V.) about its various societies organized under the direction of Mr. Walter Legge.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 22. -- Newark defeated Albany, 8 to 3, in the first game of their double-header today. The second contest was called with the teams in a 2-to 2 tie in the third inning on account of rain.
At least two flying fields in the metropolitan area and two hotels were preparing last night to greet the flying Mollisons after they complete their 3,250-mile transatlantic flight this evening.

SALEM, N.H., July 22 (AP). -- The last-day crowd of 30,000 pushed $453,871 through the betting windows of Rockingham Park today. This boosted the New Hampshire Breeders' Association's pari-mutuel handle to $5,244,472 for the 28-day race meeting, the first ever held in New England with legalized betting.

Semi-annual statements by large insurance companies in all fields indicate that, despite the interruption of the banking holiday and the nervousness that preceded that period, insurance has continued its progress.

The principal thing holding real estate activity in check today is not any question about real estate values but the uncertainty in people's minds about real estate financing. This uncertainty is in the minds of both prospective borrowers and lenders on mortgage security.

BERLIN, July 21. -- The reception by the Carl Schurz Society to a select group of American scholars a few days ago in this city could not fail, in the present setting, to recall the days when the South German liberals led by Carl Schurz and the poets Freilingrath and Herwegh sought and found asylum abroad.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 22. -- Exceptionally close competition marked the week-end shoot at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. In the regular event, R.H. Helsel and L. G. Moffatt each broke 50 straight targets to tie for the high scratch cup.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 22. -- Thomas Hitchcock Jr. shifted back to his old international post of No. 2 today and the result was an old-fashioned scoring spree by the American polo captain as his side turned back a 27-goal team in a test match at Meadow Brook, 12 to 6.

THE Summer solstice is long since past, but Summer exhibitions still accumulate. Most conspicuous upon the Avenue at present is that just opened at the Reinhardt Gallery, to run at least until the 1st of August and possibly longer.
AMITYVILLE, L.I., July 22. -- The sanctioned match show of the Bull Terrier Club of New York was held at the Nassau Shores Country Club today. Thirty bull terriers were benched.

PARIS. THE Anglo-Saxon traveler on his return from abroad usually writes a thick and substantial volume crammed with statistics and discussing every problem: the French traveler -- even when he is as serious as M. Taine -- almost always prefers a book of notes and impressions.

The acclaim of General BALBO and the officers and men of his air squadron was a recognition of courage and sportsmanship of the highest order. They were worthy countrymen of the great Duke of the ABRUZZI, whose adventures as an explorer and mountain climber were an inspiration not only to his own people but to men of all nationalities who answer the call of the unknown.

WHEN one does not know what to say about an English essayist it is usual to take the short-cut of convenience and liken him to Charles Lamb. But this has been done so often in the case of E.V. Lucas as to render the compliment threadbare.
A 30 to 1 shot, Sgt. Byrne, surprised 6,000 spectators at Empire City yesterday when he led from start to finish of the featured $2,000 added Eastview Stakes.

John Stella, Eastern horseshoe pitching champion, won the Bronx title yesterday in the round-robin tourney staged at the Starlight Amusement Park under the auspices of the Metropolitan Horseshoe League.
DUBLIN, July 21. -- The threat of civil strife is gain hovering over the Free State and events are fast shaping themselves toward a crisis.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP). -- A large part of the messages received today by President Roosevelt and the Industrial Recovery Administration pledging cooperation for higher wages and millions of new jobs came from Chambers of Commerce in every State.

The railroads serving New York have evolved a plan for consolidating pier and marine operations in the harbor which are expected to result in substantial savings, according to a report issued yesterday by D.T. Lawrence, general secretary of the general committee of the Eastern railroads.

IT seems to be as true of aviators as of poets that they are born and not made, and it is quite evident that Birger Johnsen was marked by destiny to be a rider of the air. He had his first airplane experience as a lad in a technical school in his native Norway when aviation was in its infancy.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Among the hundreds of telegrams received today by the President and the Industrial Recovery Administration by far the great majority pledged acceptance of Mr. Roosevelt's blanket proposal for shorter hours and higher pay, to become effective at once.

Fear that American export trade will either be smothered under the burden of excessive production costs or cut down by anti-dumping regulations in foreign markets if costs are held below domestic price levels grew out of discussions of the National Industrial Recovery Act in export circles last week.
BUDAPEST, July 21. -- A big slump in the Budapest wheat market yesterday followed the throwing of huge quantities of wheat on the market by German buyers.

ANNOUNCEMENT that the hitherto unfruitful wilds of North Australia are to be open to settlers renews interest in that arid stretch whose boundaries shores are washed by the Indian Ocean and the Pacific. It also emphasizes the fact that other large tracts of the earth's surface still await the alchemy of irrigation and the revivifying efforts of hardy pioneers.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP). -- Exercising for the first time the powers granted under the recently enacted Intercoastal Act, the Shipping Board today ordered all lines engaged in the Atlantic-to-Pacific trade to "voluntarily place their rates in line with rates recognized as fair and reasonable."

WASHINGTON. THE prospect that prohibition will be repealed within the next six months, which was made more certain by the results of last week's repeal elections in four States, is causing authorities to speculate on the effect which liquor revenue will have upon the Federal tax situation.

IN 1931 this same association, then called the International Kindergarten Union, published a selection of well-known make-believe tales in a form suitable for use with young children, with the title "Told Under the Green Umbrella."

SEASIDE HEIGHTS, N.J., July 22. -- Two girls and three young men were instantly killed early this morning when their car, traveling at 75 miles an hour, crashed into the jack-knife span of the Bay Bridge drawbridge, which links Seaside Heights with the mainland.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- Under the decision of the Board of Trade directors the minimum price on wheat on any one day until further notice will range from 90 cents to $1, the former on July and the latter on May. On corn it is 46 to 53 cents, oats 34 to 41 cents and on rye 65 to 80 cents, the July on all grains being the lowest and May the highest.

A WRITER in The London Mercury of February, 1931, said that Mary Webb had "no originality of plot" and ber characters were "more or less types rather than flesh-and-blood creations." She would be remembered, the article went on, "not as a great novelist but as a woman with the soul of a poet and the observation of an artist."

VIENNA, July 21. -- An article in the leading organ of the Lower Austrian Bauerbund, the powerful peasant organization within the Clerical Christian Social party, which has supplied several members of the Dollfuss Cabinet, demands the introduction of racial quotas and anti-Semitic measures generally in Austria.

With business activity speeding up its rate of improvement during June and the first half of July, about 40 per cent of the ground lost between June, 1929, and March of this year has been regained, according to the monthly report of the conference of statisticians of the National Industrial Conference Board issued yesterday.

Landlords and property owners in New York should develop a code of ethics and standard practices in accordance with the provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Act, as a means of stabilizing rentals and putting real estate on a sounder basis, in the opinion of Isidor Berger, general manager of the Greater New York Taxpayers Association.

JERUSALEM, July 21. -- Many valuable archaeological discoveries, some confirming Biblical narratives hitherto regarded as legendary, have just been made in Moab, the Biblical land east of the Jordan, which for centuries was the hereditary foe of the People of Israel.

COLUMBUS, Ga. THE city of Columbus. Ga., and Muscogee County, of which it is a part, are cooperating in a back-to-the-farm movement which has helped considerably in their relief and unemployment problem.

LONDON. LONDON'S famous Bow Bells, silent for the past six years, are now ringing again. They were mute so long because two of them were cracked and the rest were out of order and no funds were available for repairs.

A number of clergymen will refer in their sermons today to the flight of General Italo Balbo and his armada and draw moral lessons from this achievement. Several churches will hold special patriotic services in celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the National Women's Relief Corps of the G.A.R.

RYE, N.Y., July 22. -- Always ahead after the third hole, Sidney Noyes Jr. of Ardsley defeated Dr. Robert R. Lauckner of Canoe Brook, 4 and 3, today, to win the fifth annual Westchester Country Club's invitation golf tournament.
HEIDELBERG. HIGH up on the side of the hill, with millions of leaves clustering round the terraces and towers, the old, dull red castle looks out over the sea of tiled roofs scattered at its feet.

COLUMBUS, Miss., July 22 (AP). -- The lynching of a Negro by a mob at Caledonia, small town 15 miles north of here, was reported to authorities here this morning, but officers said late today that they were without details of the affair.

CHICAGO, July 20. -- What may prove to be a political storm of large dimensions for the local Democratic administration, with repercussions disturbing to Governor Horner and his State regime, is developing in Chicago over drastic action taken by the Board of Education, nominally in the interests of economy, but, by many, suspected of marking the initiation of a permanently restrictive program for the city's public schools.

BERLIN, July 22. -- Not only will offenders against the new laws adopted by the Prussian Cabinet today be punished but their families will also suffer, the sentence automatically cancelling pensions, social welfare support and unemployment insurance for each member of the family.

Steamship lines competing in the various trade routes which link the United States with the rest of the world have acted in recent weeks to reduce competition in the minimum. This has been done in an effort to eliminate rate wars and to assure each line a fair share of the income from available traffic.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of July as making the followig interesting statement:

Socialist nominations for a city ticket were postponed until next Wednesday night when delegates to the Socialist city convention yesterday took up so much time wrangling over a platform that the delay was made necessary.

THE perennial decorative appeal of the India shawl makes the current exhibition of antique examples at the Brooklyn Museum a popular Summer show. This is the first time that the museum has had an opportunity to display to advantage so much of its valuable collection.

BERLIN, July 22. -- Some 20,000,000 German men and women will go to the polls tomorrow in the first nation-wide election since Adolf Hitler unloosed the national revolution after his 52 per cent victory in the Reichstag elections of March 5.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Nothing in the Emergency Railroad Transportation Act provided for absolute protection to railroad workers against furloughs or dismissals by individual railroad companies, Joseph B. Eastman, Transportation Coordinator, said today.

BEIREUTH, Germany, July 22. -- Conducting tonight's "Parsifal," Richard Strauss returned to Baireuth in an official capacity for the first time in several decades, after an estrangement with the Wagner family lasting for more than thirty years and occasioned by slighting remarks which Sigfried Wagner was alleged to have made about "Salone" and "Elektra."

LONDON, July 21. -- The issuance at Buckingham Palace today of a statement reminding persons who may possess or control "any letters or papers addressed to his Majesty or prepared for his Majesty's information" that permission must be obtained for publication of any material falling within the terms of the British copyright act has aroused interest and great speculation in literary circles.

STOCKHOLM, July 22. -- Four other Americans who were traveling on the same boat with Marc Connelly also failed to get permission to enter Soviet territory, but they continued aboard the Kings-holm toward Leningrad in the belief that the ban might possibly be raised.

THE Stadium Concerts have adopted an admirable policy toward dancing in that they engage a number of different dance organizations each season instead of re-engaging the same people year after year. The audiences which pour into these special attractions are among the largest of the season, and consist for the greater part of persons who rarely, if ever, attend dance performances at any other place.
MADRID, July 22. -- Protection of her people abroad is a thing upon which Britain has insisted while the United States has been notoriously lax.

RETAIL trade developed a slower Summer pace during the week, with clearances of seasonal apparel and offerlings of main-floor specials receiving the bulk of consumer attention. Good response was also noted on initial lines of Fall dresses, particularly satin styles in the new colors.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- In an effort to stop lumber overproduction at present low wages and long hours of labor, leaders of the industry requested the National Recovery Administration today to grant immediate tentative approval, "without prejudice," to the wage and working scales contained in its code.

TORONTO, Ont., July 22. -- Although commenting that "at the present time all indications point to increased mining activity and production in 1933 as compared to the previous year," the statement of the British Columbia Department of Mines, announcing the issuance of the annual report of the Minister of Mines for 1932, warns against the "gold boom" being carried too far.

PENDINE, Wales, July 22. -- After weeks of waiting, Captain James A. Mollison and his wife, Amy Johnson, started their flight for New York at noon today (7 A.M. Eastern Daylight Time) in their big black bi-plane, Seafarer.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Minimum prices for trading in wheat, corn and other grains until further notice were announced tonight by Secretary Wallace, who approved a program suggested by the Chicago Board of Trade to avert further collapse of commodities.

There is nothing the matter with Arkansas that 10-cent cotton will not cure, according to Paul E. Peltason of Peltason, Tenenbaum Harris of St. Louis, investment bankers. Mr. Peltason, who is in New York, has just concluded a survey of conditions in Arkansas as they affect holders of the State's securities.

As the followers of this interesting author will anticipate -- we trust they are not few -- "Try the Sky" exhibits the same mystical exaltation, but the story itself is quite differently localized.

THE eyes of the shipping world will be focused on a little room on the second floor of the Navy Department in Washington next Wednesday, when bids are opened for the construction of sixteen men-of-war -- part of the naval building program authorized under the public works provisions of the National Industry Recovery Act.

Caterina Jarboro, Negro soprano, made her New York debut as Aida last night in the Chicago Opera Company's presentation of Verdi's opera at the New York Hippodrome. She scored an immediate popular success. After her "Ritornar vincitor" in the first act. she was three times recalled by enthusiastic applause.
