Cooperation among nations to facilitate international reconstruction has been recommended by thirty prominent American economists, in response to a detailed inquiry sent out recently by the National Industrial Conference Board.

The annual Monmouth County horse show, for many years one of the outstanding events for sportsmen and sportswomen, will be held on the grounds of the Rumson Club at Rumson, N.J., on Friday and Saturday, Aug. 4 and 5. Entries closed last Thursday.

HOLLYWOOD. THE infant industry is dedicating one of its new products to the old-timers who knew New York back in the days when the Bowery was more than a street of flop-houses, panhandlers and pawn-brokerage establishments.
BOSTON, July 22 (AP). -- The Red Sox took their third straight game from the White Sox today, 5 to 3, behind the six-hit pitching of Bob Kline.

Dr. Paul Kerby, conductor of the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra and official music representative of the Austrian Government at the Chicago World's Fair, will arrive today from Surope in the motorship Britannic of the White Star Line.

PARIS, July 20. -- Tiny shepherdess hats or embroidered felt Scotch caps, showing many frivolous curls, give a youthful air by reducing the height prevalent in the present millinery mode. Eye veils that float to the shoulders in back are the latest aids to mystery.

An alternative code for the motion-picture industry, opposed to that prepared by the Motion Picture Producers and Distributers of America, will be considered at a two-day conference of independents at the Hotel Astor, beginning July 31, it was announced yesterday.

Although New York City's sewage plan "will go far" to remedy pollution in the metropolitan area, the required improvement will not be attained unless sewage from other sources is also treated. This is the assertion of Nicholas S. Hill Jr., president of the Hackensack Water Company of Weenawken, N.J., in a paper prepared for the Connecticut Society of Civil Engineers.

BOSTON, July 20. -- The Massachusetts General Court is within easy striking distance of an all-time duration record. In the past century prorogation has taken place only eight times in July and only four times later than the present date.

SHANGHAI, July 1.-- Although General Chiang Kai-shek is moving an immense number of his troops into Hunan and Kiangsi Provinces ostensibly to fight the Communists, it is noticeable that the government's forces are not actually conducting a vigorous campaign against the Reds, and even many highly placed officials admit that Nanking's redisposition of its forces is being made with a view to checkings the Canton armies if or when Canton declares war against Nanking.

PITTSBURGH, July 20. -- The substantial character of the business improvement is brought home to the Pittsburgh district or Tri-State territory, Western Pennsylvania, Eastern Ohio and Northern West Virginia, by the 15 per cent increase in wages in the great steel industry.

SHE who looks to her laurels the Summer speeds on way will freshen up her wardrobe and, incidentally, her spirits, with some of the exotic accessories that bloom in the midsummer market. Livening up her appearance is to the woman what second wind is to the athlete running toward his goal.

MR. DUNNING was standing in the cool shade of a beech tree shaking a silver carafe with something more than ardor as the reporter debouched from Red Coat Road, tossed his rucksack to a character out of Somerset Maugham and threw himself, parched and spent, on a willow bench.

THE Press of the Pioneers, 1,107 Broadway. New York City, announces a new book entitled "Servers of the Common Good: The Story of an Experiment in Communism as Practical Christianity," by Robert J. Hendricks of Salem, Ore.
What is going to become of the small-home owners of America during the next few years?

MINEOLA, L.I., July 22. -- Doc Robbing, Bay Shore sportsman, driving the chestnut filly Lucy Follin, came from behind in the first heat of the free-for-all trot to win by a nose. Tipton Volo, driven by Ally Cornwell, was second, and Worthy Heir, handled by Harry Whitney, third.

DELVING through the pages of a Frenchman's profuse journal of the years immediately before the Revolution, one would expect to find countless foreshadowings of the impending upheaval. Yet even the well-seasoned hindsight of a 1933 reader fails to find in Mercier's picture of Paris many hints of the cyclone brewing.

THE quality of the nation's mounting junk pile is bringing joy to the automobile industry. For years the pickings in the automotive ossuaries have been distressingly slim. Motors at the zenith of dubiety were coaxed into more discordant mumblings.

Starting times for the fourth annual women's open golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester Counties, which will be held at the Woodway Country Club, Springdale, Conn., tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday, were announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 21. -- If there are any who think Moscow is full of bread-lines and sad-faced people worrying about shortages they should have seen the city last Tuesday -- the day of the weekly holiday -- with the "Derby," now called the Grand All-Union Prize, and the football match between Moscow and a visiting team from Turkey.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP). -- In accord with, the administration's idea to put as many people back to work as possible, the emergency national committee of the petroleum industry voted today to apply the forty-hour week to all retail outlets, including agencies which handle oil products as a side line.

LONDON. THE great Joseph Chamberlain may have died in 1914, but that need not prevent us from recognizing him as the head of the British delegation to the economic conference in this year 1933 and one of the outstanding personalities whom the London Economic Conference has encountered.

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP). -- Trading in grain futures will be resumed fully on Monday on the Board of Trade here but beginning one hour later daily than has been the rule, the directors announced tonight. Prices must be no lower than the closing figures of Thursday.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 22. -- The determination that carried Gregory Mangin to victory over Berkeley Bell in the face of a two-set deficit was again in evidence today as he came from behind to defeat Sidney B. Wood Jr. and join Frank Shields in the final of the invitation turf court tournament of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club.

PHOENIX, Ariz., July 20. -- The burning Summer sands of that part of the great American desert lying within the confines of Arizona are fairly alive with Arabs. No camel tourists they. Poised on rubber cushions of air thousands of Pacific Coast States pilgrims are darting eastward to the Century of Progress Exposition, while refinanced Easterners trek busily westward to test for themselves the vaunted climate of the sunset coast.

PARIS. PARIS millinery, as represented by the first Fall fashions, has definitely cast off the shackles of standardization. Of course, women are all likely to pounce upon the same hat -- witness the fedora furore and the fez folly.

BERLIN. THE amorphous German soul is in turmoil again, as so often in the past, and the agony of its struggle for a final form is disturbing the world. In a period of revaluation of all values, the classic land of isms, which produced Protestantism but also socialism, is giving birth to a new idea, or refurbishing an old one, or mixing many ideas into a synthetic formula -- depending on the point of view.
Prosperity is peering around her corner on the academic as well as on the industrial front. From three great State universities have just come prognoses of increased enrolments next Fall.

LISTENERS often wonder why the broadcasters do not cooperate, compete less with each other and make the ethereal show move of a planned affair than an overlapping calendar. For example, it is pointed out that on one recent Saturday night between 8:15 and 9 o'clock the Philadelphia Symphony was on WABC; New York Philharmonic on WJZ; a Little Symphony on WOR; Mischa Levitzki, pianist, and WEAF and WMCA had a symphonic concert.

The transatlantic steamship lines report the most profitable Summer cruise season in several years, both in trips operating from New York and from European ports. Ships are carrying close to capacity crowds on trips ranging from three to sixteen, days and some shipping executives admit they underestimated the demand when they planned their schedules.

While last week's decline in securities and commodities may properly be compared, in point of violence, for the time it has lasted, with the collapse of 1929, the conditions which brought on the crash then are not present today. The preponderance of Wall Street opinion is that there need be no repetition of the painful events of that mad panic season.

What Is Art? The Wagner Festival at Baireuth opened on Friday with a performance of "Die Meistersinger." This was followed the next day by "Parsifal" and a Nazi aviation meet attended by Chancellor HITLER, Captain GOERING, who is Premier of Prussia as well as Minister of Aviation, and Dr. GOEBBELS, who does propaganda and enlightenment for the Nazi regime.

LONDON, July 21. -- The British Government's decision to repay United Kingdom gold bonds of 1917 in paper dollars or depreciated sterling shows what queer things are happening to British financial morality after two years of terrific strain.

A distinct firmness came into the local commodity markets yesterday after several days of declines. Silver and copper were higher, while rubber and silk were irregular and only hides and wool tops showed clear losses. Most cash prices were lower.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The twentieth annual renewal of the Virginia State tennis championships will be held this week starting tomorrow under the auspices of the Virginia Hot Springs Golf and Tennis Club at the Casino here.

A THOROUGH and painstaking report on the work of the Bank for International Settlements, Eleanor Lansing Dulles's study will prove valuable as a source book to the specialist in international finance. To the lay reader it will commend itself as a careful compendium of acts and policies to which the governments of a non-cooperative world have been driven in an effort to find a way out of a critical situation.

ON a Spring afternoon in 1919 word was flashed along the New England coast to be on watch for wireless and radiophone from the NC-flying boats of the United States Navy en route to Europe. The flight was not only significant in the annals of aviation but also in the history of radio, because these seaplanes carried radio compasses and it was planned to test them thoroughly.

What Wall Street refers to as "supporting orders" came into the market yesterday in considerable volume. But the buying, as well as could be judged, came from those timid traders who got out or were sold out in the convulsive reaction of the previous three days.

THESE letters from a California mining camp, written in 1851-52 to a sister in New England by Mrs. Louise Amelia Knapp Smith Clappe, whose pen-name was "Dame Shirley." are published by the Grabhorn Press as one of their Rare Americana Series.

WASHINGTON. AS the visitor walks into the new administration building of the Department of Agriculture he sees a large open lobby topped with an expansive skylight. Placards and enlarged photographs concern themselves with cotton, corn and wheat raising.

THE motion picture camera, which is notoriously uncivil to the distortions and asymmetries of the human face, can be enormously friendly in contemplating the face of a beautiful woman. And it is one of the definite virtues of the screen as an art form that on it beauty can be reflected, enriched and idealized as in marble and on canvas; less permanently, perhaps, but producing the added pleasure of mobility.

EUREKA, Nev., July 20. -- Nevada never dreamed, until lately, of becoming a manufacturing Commonwealth. It liked best to be known as a mining State. When metal prices slumped, the Extension Service experts of the University of Nevada buoyed up our courage by proving statistically that farming and stock-raising had surpassed mining in total productive values.

The Home Mortgage Advisory Committee of the Long Island Real Estate Board purposes to introduce for consideration at the special session of the State Legislature called by Governor Lehman to consider the financial needs of New York City equally important suggestions to relieve home owners threatened with foreclosure.

By the purchase of the twenty-three-story Hoagland Building last week on the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and Fortieth Street, Colonel Jacob Ruppert stands out as the largest individual buyer of Manhattan real estate since the financial depression.

IT is possible that the name of Moses Coit Tyler will convey very little to the general reader today, although students of American literature will recognize in it the name of our first important historian of the way the American mind expressed itself in letters.

It was said of RICARDO that he had of all the men of his time the keenest eye for the "imperceptibles" of trade and finance. Some of them were last week brought forcibly to the attention of the American people. Too many of us had been absorbed in contemplating the gross material facts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am glad to know that another voice -- alas, there are altogether too few of them -- is raised to cry out against the approaching economic tyranny. I refer to Dr. I. Zuaniecki of Columbia University.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 22. -- The Larchmont Yacht Club's race week wound up today with 223 more starting craft, making a total of 1,292 for the six days. The record number was 1,452 in 1929.

WHEN the A.B.C. secret society and the Machado government accepted the Cuban mediation proposal offered by Sumner Welles, the new United States Ambassador, the probable success of the plan was assured.

More attention will be paid in the future to the community type of planning and architecture rather than that of individual or groups of houses, is the opinion of Clarence S. Stein of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects. The era of antiquated mass production, loose planning, unsound financing and disregard for social consequences has gone by, he points out.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 22. -- A "Basque" party will be given at the Westchester Embassy Club, Armonk, on Friday night for the benefit of the New York Cancer Institute.

THE position of the Jews in Nazi Germany brings to the fore the whole problem of minority rights. Some disposition must be made of a group of 600,000 people who cannot, by any circumstances, become citizens of the Reich.
Every one of the fifty-nine district superintendents of the Sanitation Department was transferred last midnight in the largest shake-up in the department's history.

The premium list for the Lenox Kennel Club, which will stage its annual dog show on the Hanna estate at Lenox on Aug. 12, has just been distributed. A record entry is expected. Frank H. Addyman of Ardsley, N.Y., will name best in show and also will preside over a long and varied list of breeds.

Mayor O'Brien appointed yesterday Philip D. Hoyt, First Deputy Police Commissioner, as chairman of the Mayor's reception committee to welcome Wiley Post. His associates on the committee will be announced tomorrow.

NOME, Alaska, July 22 (AP). -- The Soviet plane which brought James Mattern, stranded round-the-world flier, from Anadyr, Siberia, to Nome, took off at 1 P.M. (8 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time) on its return flight with Emma Harbor, near East Cape, Siberia, as its destination.

DURING the last fifty years the scientific study of religion has gone on apace. Before the days of Max Mueller of Germany and Herbert Spencer and E.B. Tylor of England, and since, Christian scholars had studied comparative religion and taught it in some fashion in colleges and seminaries; but always to the disparagement of "paganism" and the glorification of Christianity.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 22. -- Bowling home under a big ballooner, the Class J sloop Weetamoe, sailed by Harold S. Vanderbilt, America's Cup skipper, defeated her veteran rival, Vanitie, today by 7 minutes 39 seconds, boat for boat. The yachts sailed a twenty-four and one-half-mile course around Boston Lightship in a match race under the colors of the Eastern Yacht Club.

SUSAN HALE could best be characterized as a Boston gentlewoman of America's Victorian era. Sister of Edward Everett Hale, whose renown as a preacher is one of Boston's most precious heritages. Susan possessed the same vigor of mind, the same determination of character; but just because she was a gentlewoman of America's Victorian era it would not have been meet for her to assert herself in full measure.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (AP). -- The Athletics won both ends of today's double-header from the Browns and took the series, three games to one. The Mackmen captured the first game, 8 to 7, and the second, 6 to 5.
CLEVELAND, July 22 (AP). -- The Great Lakes, mirror of the steel industry, are once more dotted with the black smoke of freighters.

General Italo Balbo. Italy's flying Air Mlnister, and the ninety-five men who came with him by air from Orbetello to New York via the northern islands and Chicago, spent a day of comparative quiet yesterday.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S recent reference to the Canadian-United States border as a boundary without fortifications emphasizes the unusual condition which exists along this 3,000-mile strip of land. Aside from patrols at strategic points of Royal Mounties, customs and immigration officials and boats of the Department of Fisheries on the waterways, it is unguarded.

An organization of swindlers whose 500 members pay dues for a "protection fund," was said yesterday by Postoffice Inspector Herbert Graham to have collected heavy toll during the last several years from gullible Americans and Canadians.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- Equipoise in a gallop. The old champion with the back-breaking impost of 135 pounds came home that way in the renewal of the Arlington Handicap before a crowd of 20,000 sweltering spectators today.

An increase in activities during the six months ended June 30 is recorded in the semi-annual report of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society. The report was issued yesterday by Isaac L. Asofsky, the society's general manager, from its headquarters, 425 Lafayette Street.

LONDON. THE editor of John o' London's Weekly has had the happy thought of inviting several well-known authors to tell him, for publication in his Summer number, what biography they would most like to write.

Twenty-six communities in the State have now joined New York in asking that special taxes to provide new municipal revenues be imposed by the Legislature in its extraordinary session to open Wednesday.

Bonds declined moderately yesterday under the leadership of the domestic railway group. The market did not, however, follow the movement of stocks. Transactions in bonds amounted to $10,450,000 as compared with $8,132,000 on the previous Saturday.

At the recent meeting of the stockholders of the Suez Canal Company, the Marquis de Vogue, president of the company, refuted certain British critics who had alleged that the relatively high tolls of the canal had affected the prices of the commodities on which they were levied, that the volume of commerce had been reduced, and that British trade had severely suffered by the way the canal was being administered.

LATONIA, Ky., July 22 (AP). -- Taking the lead at the first quarter pole. Late Date of the Audley Farms set a sizzling pace to finish first in the Enquirer Handicap today, six lengths in front of Bright Bubble. Marmion, the favorite, barely lasted to take third money.

HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., July 22. -- After being denied world's outboard competitive records because the two-and-one-half-mile course was too long for official recognition, Tommy Tyson of Chestnut Hills, Pa., and Clifton Thompson, Suffolk, Va., hung up new world's one-mile speed marks on the Susquehanna today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 22 (AP). -- With only about 100 small, widely scattered precincts missing, returns today from Thursday's prohibition referendum in Tennessee gave repeal a margin of 8,697. In 2,112 of the State's 2,232 precincts the vote was, for repeal, 125,225; against, 116,528.

EDMONTON, Alta., July 22. -- Wiley Post dropped from the skies into Edmonton today 10 hours and 45 minutes ahead of the time he and Harold Gatty made to here on their round-the-world flight two years ago. Without sleeping, he took to the air again, headed for New York, with his lead increased to 20 hours and 12 minutes.
LONDON, July 22. -- The World Economic Conference entered its final week-end with attention uneasily centred on the situation in the United States.

The economic situation last week was overshadowed by the breaks in security and commodity prices, attributed in large degree to excessive speculative enthusiasm and a business recovery that had carried productive activity at a faster pace than consumption.

More attention to the architectural design of a building must be given in the future in connection with making a mortgage loan upon the property to prevent a recurrence of some of the difficulties under which lending institutions have recently been suffering, points out William W. Schwartz of Thiesen Schwartz, architects and engineers, of Yonkers.

The undergraduate of 1933 is more serious and possesses more mature standards of value than the undergraduate of 1929. The difference can be almost wholly attributed to the influence of the depression. Such are the findings of a small but intensive investigation made on the University of Michigan campus by a group of my students.

A group of realty men in Manhattan, headed by August Heckscher, vice president of the Forty-second Street Property Owners' and Merchants' Association, Inc., and including Borough President Samuel Levy, has sent a petition to Governor Lehman requesting that the forthcoming special session of the Legislature decree a moratorium on real estate mortgages on commercial properties, particularly in Manhattan, for a period of two years when requested by the mortgagor.

The recent trip to the Coast of the three Eastern crews, Harvard, Yale and Cornell, was one of the most carefully planned of sports journeys, according to a recent analysis from railroad authorities. The total cost was roughly $10,000, of which more than four-fifths was spent on the trains.

LONDON, July 12. -- In and around the conference things have happened which are intensely interesting. So, for example, the detached observer has been able to study the relationship between the government and the Bank of England.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP). -- Acting under instructions by President Roosevelt, Henry Morgenthau Jr., governor of the Farm Credit Administration, urged patience today by farm mortgage holders contemplating foreclosures.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Prospects of a strike of 30,000 cloak-makers in New York City next week were perceptibly diminished today as the results of efforts by the National Recovery Administration to harmonize the differences between the employing groups and the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

DRESDEN, July 4, 1933. RICHARD STRAUSS will be 70 next June, but there is no indication that, with "Arabella" off his mind, he intends to close up his desk and call it a day. Wagner, who in his cheerful moments expected to reach 94, announced after "Parsifal" that he had "victoriously completed his mission" and would not write another note.

UNITED ARTISTS has announced a minimum program of thirty pictures for the new season, tripling its usual yearly output. Mary Pickford, Charles Chaplin and Douglas Fairbanks will have one production each.

ST. LOUIS, July 22. -- Mrs. Vivian Chase, wanted by the police on suspicion of being implicated in a bank robbery and a former resident of East St. Louis, has been identified as one of the kidnappers of August Luer.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity continued to rise for the week ended July 15, but the advance was the smallest since the recovery started late in March. Gains in four of the six series brought the combined figure to 99.0, as compared with 98.7 in the previous week and 64.8 for the corresponding week of last year.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- A code of fair competition for silk and rayon dyeing and printing submitted by the Institute of Dyers and Printers, said to represent 80 per cent of the industry, will go into effect Monday as to its wage and hour provisions, as the result of an Executive order signed by President Roosevelt today.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 22. -- More than 200 persons are expected to attend the reception to be given tomorrow afternoon in the art galleries of Guild Hall to present the South Shore Players, who are appearing in Arnold Bennett's "Mr. Prohack" at Guild Hall this week, and "East River Romance," a new play by Edwin Gilbert, beginning next Thursday.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., July 22 (AP). -- A university professor's attempt to sleuthing has solved Bloomington's first bank robbery, and resulted in return of the money and surrender of the holdup man.

WESTFIELD, N.J., July 22. -- Play in the annual Northern New Jersey men's singles tennis tournament got under way today at the Westfield Tennis Club with an entry list of ninety-six players. Entrants from the metropolitan area predominated.

The break of prices in the speculative markets last week demonstrated the imperative need of stabilizing the currency, in the opinion of the majority of Wall Street bankers. Most bankers believe that, painful and dangerous as it was, it was a good thing.

PARIS. BOTH at the disarmament conference in Geneva and at the World Economic Conference in London, France has, during recent weeks, opposed her desires and wishes to American and to British doctrine and policy in a manner which has left many people in these other countries, who are normally disposed toward friendship with France, with a vague feeling of irritation and bafflement.

A request has been sent to Governor Lehman by the Bronx Landlords Protective Association, through its secretary, Henry Winters, asking that, during the special session of the Legislature, consideration be given to the introduction and passing of an act to relieve the present distressed condition of property owners.

RICHMOND, Va., July 20. -- An average increase of 30 per cent in the purchasing power of the 125,000 cotton textile operatives of North Carolina has been brought about by the new textile code, which became effective nationally on Monday, and the fact has sent a thrill through the business life of the Tarheel State.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- A war-time organization was being whipped into shape today by President Roosevelt and his Recovery Administration for the greatest peace-time assault on a national enemy this country has ever seen.
Although constantly reminded of the disagreeable 1929 sequel to the speculative extravagances of that period, the share market gave some indication yesterday of having weathered the present storm.

PITTSBURGH, July 22. -- Manager Bill Terry had only one Carl Hubbell to fire at the enemy today and as a consequence the Giants got nothing more than an even break in the double-header which wound up their six-game series with the Pirates.

THIS little opus, which might have been called "Through St. Peter's Keyhole," belongs strictly to the tut-tut school of journalism. It would never do as a substitute for a standard work on the saints, and it is scarcely an essay which young readers could peruse with any profit.

In spite of the recent trend toward restricted immigration, the United States still faces extensive problems created by the presence of various ethnic groups in its population, Dr. Thomas Jackson Woofter Jr. declares in a monograph to be published tomorrow.

A group of leading police and crime experts of European cities will arrive tomorrow on the Cunard liner Franconia to attend the International Police Conference in Chicago. A series of entertainments and inspections has been arranged for the delegates in New York, Washington, Chicago and other cities which they will visit.

IN the National Gallery of Art, Smithsonian Institution, has been placed on exhibition the Gellatly collection of paintings and art objects. This collection, comprising more than 1,600 pieces, is one of the most valuable in the United States and was left as a gift to the American people by the late John Gellatly of New York City.

Prompt drafting of a code for the electric power and light industry is being urged by students of public-utility affairs. By quick action, they say, the industry may escape the blanket code, which carries no compensating intra-industry agreement and may adopt rules which will provide for all contingencies likely to arise from limitation of hours and rates of pay.
ASUNCION, July 20. -- A medical officer brought from the front the following vivid eye-witness account of Bolivia's two offensives against Fort Ayala:

Conditions were announced yesterday for the Stamford Yacht Club's annual race to the Vineyard, which this year will be held on Sept. 1. It is to be a contest for sailing yachts not more than sixty-five feet long nor less than thirty feet, in cruising trim, from the Cows bell buoy off Stamford around the lightship off Vineyard Sound, and back.

THE smallest grain crop since 1901 is indicated this year. Total production of the five principal grains -- corn, oats, wheat, barley and rye -- is estimated at 3,774,000,000 bushels. In all of the intervening thirty-two years annual production exceeded 4,000,000,000; in seventeen of these years it was more than 4,500,000,000 and in nine years more than 5,000,000,000.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 22. -- The record harvest continued apace on the sunlit waters of Zach's Bay today as a crowd of 25,000 watched the third session of the women's national A.A.U. swimming championships.

Wiley Post, who twice encircled the globe by plane, began life as a farmer boy who preferred tinkering around with the farm machinery to hoeing the crops his father raised. He was born Nov. 22, 1898, on an isolated farm in Van Vandt County, where his great-grandfather was a Baptist preacher.

Following his re-election as president of the Columbia University Press, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, announced yesterday that the Press would publish in the Fall "The Columbia Biographical Dictionary of Americans," containing 100,0000 concise entries in one volume.

NEW regulations have just been issued by the Canadian Government to protect the walrus, that huge marine mammal of the North, from extinction. Walruses are among the largest game caught in Canadian waters, where the range is from sardines to whales.

The Whistler, a sixty-one-foot auxiliary schooner, manned by six young college men, is lying off the New York Yacht Club station at Twenty-sixth Street, East River, ready to start on a two-year cruise around the world. The schooner arrived here Thursday from New Bedford, Mass., and is provisioned for one year in the tropical seas.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 22. -- Division staff officers of the New York National Guard started today the biggest week-end movement this year of guardsmen in and out of camps. About 2,650 officers and enlisted men, a total of 7,000 to be shifted before tomorrow evening, were involved in the movements.

AUTEUIL, France, July 22 (AP). -- While the fighting doubles team of George M. Lott and John Van Ryn put the United States back into the thick of the Davis Cup tennis battle today by winning a straight set match from the English pair in only an hour and ten minutes, the development of Ellsworth Vines's poor physical condition minimizes the chances of saving the series tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- A sharp increase in imports of raw materials during June as a result of expanded industrial operations increased the purchases by the United States from abroad by more than $15,000,000 over May and gave the country its first excess of imports since August, 1931.

DESPITE fast liners, long-range weapons and a worldwide system of telegraphic and radio communication, the pirate still plies his trade, as witnessed by the recent case of the five Germans who seized a Chinese ship and were later captured in Dairen, Manchuria.
HACKENSACK, N.J., July 22. -- Sergeant Patrick Quinn of the Interstate Park Police Department died in the Englewood Hospital today.

BAIREUTH, Germany, July 22. -- In a radio address from this town late tonight Chancellor Hitler upheld the Nazi German Christians "as a movement imbued by the will to rise equal to the great tasks of the present -- one that unequivocally espoused the national popular movement at a time when just as within the Catholic church, many Protestant clerics even fanatically opposed the national resurgence."

ST. LOUIS, July 22 (AP). -- The Braves pounded Bill Hallahan out of the box in the second inning today and won from the Cardinals, 9 to 5, thereby advancing to fourth place, while the Cards dropped to fifth.

OTTAWA, July 20. -- On June 1, 1,500,000 Canadians were on the relief lists, supported wholly or in part from the public funds. By July 1, the number had been reduced by 200,000, and the present month has seen so sharp a reduction that it is estimated that by Aug. 1 the figure will not greatly exceed 1,000,000.

TRENTON, N.J., July 22. -- On the turning over to the American Tobacco Company of 27,500 shares of Class B common stock by George W. Hill, president, and other directors, Vice Chancellor John J. Fallon today directed dismissal of two suits against them for an accounting of the stock allotment.
LONDON, July 22. -- The Daily Telegraph says the Prince of Wales has decided to give up his 120-acre farm at Lenton, Nottinghamshire, and his pedigreed stock will be sold in the Autumn.
To the Editor Of The New York Times: I enjoy your "Topics" but "The Farm Mystery" is too much. I can see you are not deeply versed in farm knowledge.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- Real estate subdividers and their bankers who indulged in land speculation during the pre-depression period are held largely responsible for the tax delinquencies, tax strikes and the alarming increases in public debts.

PARIS, July 22. -- There have been few more striking illustrations of the general puzzlement of professional politicians about where the world is going politically than was provided by the French Socialist conference held in Paris last weekend.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- At the end of the first two full weeks under the new Securities Act stock offerings approximating $117,000,000 had been registered with the Federal Trade Commission, according to information made public today.
A rather battered target on the practice range of the Duggan estate at Greenwich, Conn., is mute testimony to the prowess of the archers in the family.

PLANDOME, L.I., July 22. -- Miss Helen Hicks of the Rockaway Hunting Club won the women's New York State championship for the third time today by defeating Mrs. Leo G. Federman, former Long Island champion, 7 and 5, in the thirty-six hole final at the Plandome Golf Club course.

With the time drawing appreciably nearer when the steep advances in wholesale prices must be passed on to consumers in the form of much higher retail prices, the attention of merchants during the week was focused on the rapid series of developments aimed at increasing purchasing power.

SOUTHAMPTON. -- Two important events of the season will take place during the corning week, events that claim the interest not only of prominent members of the Summer colony here but also that of many in the surrounding resorts.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Big Bill Miller of the Penn Athletic Club Philadelphia, won the opening half-mile event in the Southern Rowing Association regatta today, defeating Paul L. Brower of the Potomao Boat Club in the senior single sculls race by a length and a half.

CHICAGO, July 22. -- By way of "putting teeth into" the manifesto issued yesterday at the close of its formal sessions, the International Congress of Women today adopted a ten-point program for future activities of its member groups.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP). -- The Washington Senators again took top place in the American League by defeating Detroit, 4 to 3, in a hard-fought game that was not decided until the last of the ninth.

THE robot, or automatic pilot, which has aroused so much interest in connection with the second flight of Wiley Post around the world, is really two instruments. One, mounted in the centre of the instrument board, comprises delicate gyroscopic devices which are so sensitive that they feel at once the slightest deviation of the plane from stable flight, either laterally or horizontally.

As a relief measure for the army of Wall Street brokerage clerks, the New York Stock Exchange ordered yesterday that, beginning at noon tomorrow, trading hours should be shortened from five to three. This action, taken before the market opened at 10 o'clock, was followed by an orderly two-hour market.

DALLAS, July 20. -- For the first time in years genuine optimism is felt in the demoralized oil industry in Texas and Oklahoma. It comes directly as a result of the President's big-stick order against "hot" oil; that is, oil produced in violation of the Railroad Commission's order.
PENDINE, Wales, July 22. -- Carrying a lipstick for Amy and no baggage at all for Jim, the flying Mollisons took to the air today to make their long-delayed flight to New York.

WHILE Larry Bleasdale is driving Mr. Watson to the castle of J. Gilson Hibbs in the California hills we have ample opportunity to learn something about the castle itself and the people in it. The castle, which is perfectly authentic, was transported from England after Hibbs bought it from Larry's uncle, Sir John Bleasdale.

OTTAWA, July 20. -- Energetic steps are being taken by Canadian Provinces and municipalities, and more particularly Ontario and Quebec, to eliminate objectionable advertising signs from the highways and rigidly to control the erection of signs in the future.

MANCHESTER, Mass., July 22. -- Miss Alice Marble, 19-year-old marvel who learned her tennis on the San Francisco playgrounds, today rounded out the second week of her Eastern court tour by humbling Miss Carolin Babcock of Los Angeles, who ranks third nationally, 7-5, 6-3, in the final round of the Essex County Club's invitation, tournament.

CHICAGO, July 22 (AP). -- Heavy hitting by Kiki Cuyler and Babe Herman, plus effective pitching by Charley Root when there were enemy runners on the paths, gave the second-place Cubs a 4-to-1 victory over Philadelphia today. The defeat sent the Phillies tumbling back into the cellar.

CHICAGO. WHEAT is up again and the wheat pit roaring. For the first time in years the traders have dug their way up through the load of surplus grain and caught a glimpse of that sight so dear to traders -- a short crop and a high price.

DETROIT. AUTOMOBILE manufacturing is in the midst of a severe car shortage. For the present there appears to be no relief in sight, because orders from many parts of the country are being received in such heavy volume that plant operation schedules have fallen behind.

NARROWSBURG, N.Y., July 22. -- The increase in prices of food-stuffs hit the five encampments of Boy Scouts on the thirteen-mile reservation of the Bov Scout Foundation of Greater New York across the river from here last week. Potatoes had jumped from $1 to $2 a barrel over the cost three weeks ago.

HOWEVER one may disagree with the Nazis in their effort to "aryanize" the German people, they are at least grimly consistent. Not content with eliminating "non-Aryans," they are now bent on purifying the "Aryans."

Bill Knickerbocker, Cleveland shortstop, got a single hit yesterday at the Stadium, one of five yielded by Charley (Red) Ruffing, but the blow was important enough to give the Indians their second victory over the Yankees. The score was 2 to 1.

THE new law requiring pedestrians to walk on the left of the highway is not being generally observed. That may be stated as fact on the evidence of a 400-mile drive last Sunday along the Albany Post Road (U.S. Route 9) and State Routes 5 and 12 to the northern part of New York State.

How the atmosphere in New York may be saturated with water vapor without giving the city the benefit of rain was explained yesterday by Dr. James H. Kimball of the Weather Bureau. A humidity of 100 per cent ushered in an uncomfortable day in the metropolitan area on Friday, and although showers had been promised, no rain fell.

OMAHA, July 20. -- Farmers of the Corn Belt are beginning to wonder when something is going to be done about hogs. They are looking somewhat hopefully for an answer to the corn-hog conferences held in Des Moines and Chicago this week. For hogs are the Corn Belt's specialty and up to date they have made but a sorry showing in the midst of markets that are advancing all about them.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Several hundred leading geologists, coming from about thirty countries to attend the Sixteenth International Geological Congress, which opened here today, listened to the most recent geological evidence that the world has been having a period of cool Summers for the past 4,500 years.

BAR HARBOR. -- Dogs and gardens, often considered incompatible, will unite this week to entertain Bar Harbor and its neighboring harbors. The tenth annual flower show of the Garden Club of Mount Desert will be held on Thursday afternoon at the neighborhood house in Seal Harbor.

PARIS, July 22. -- George M. Lott and John Van Ryn did what they could today to re-establish American tennis fame after yesterday's crushing singles defeats at the hands of H.W. (Bunny) Austin and Frederick Perry of England.

NEWARK, N.J., July 22. -- Belle Lu, bay filly, owned and driven by Jim Hay of South Orange, won the most spectacular event of the seventh matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP). -- Farm administrators have decided to take decisive steps to stop wild fluctuations in the nation's commodity markets, including those involving transfers of both grain and cotton.

LONDON, July 7. THE theatre is indefatigable and is said by some to be on the whole more prosperous than it was. Whether it is prosperous or not depends on your point of view. I doubt whether it is earning more money, but the money it does earn is being differently distributed.

THE semi-annual Wagner Festival Cycle at Baireuth, Bavaria, where stands the Festspielhaus built under Wagner's supervision in 1876, began last Friday with, a performance of "Die Meistersinger" under Karl Elmendorf.

Robert Phillips, a lawyer, who has spent half of his forty-five years fishing throughout the world, is one who believes that it is possible to get a thrill out of angling without going to the usual amount of trouble.

To practical men of affairs last week's sudden break in prices, both on the Stock Exchange and in the commodity markets, caused no surprise. It was only in political circles that it caused amazement and consternation. It had been recognized by every one of ordinary experience that at some point, in view of the scope and violence of the preceding rise and the highly speculative character of the buying, severe reaction would become inevitable.

TO give stinging reality to a twice-told tale is possibly the most difficult feat that any novelist can compass. Hans Fallada accomplished it recently in "Little Man, What Now?" and Elizabeth Cambridge has done as much for a theme equally old-almost, in fact, as old as time.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 22. -- Mr. and Mrs. Edward Purcell Mellon gave a reception this afternoon at Villa Maria for Mrs. Mellon's sister-in-law, Mrs. Churchill Humphrey of Louisville, Ky., who is visiting them.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 22. -- The names of 564 Princeton University students appear on the honor roll for the second half of the last academic year, made public here today by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar.

It remains as true as it was when JOHN QUINCY ADAMS protested against the rapid expansion of the Union, that one small State has as much influence in constitutional changes as the largest or oldest Commonwealth. Equally true it is that, in the Senate, Nevada or New Mexico casts as many votes as New York or California.

HERE and there in the United States the steamroller of change and standardization has left considerable areas only partially flattened out or not flattened out at all. The Southern hill folk, the "Cajans" of Louisiana, the Negro communities on certain islands off the Carolina coast, perhaps a few isolated settlements in Pennsylvania and interior New England have thus escaped or been neglected -- the fact may be phrased according to the point of view.

The 150th anniversary of the birth of General Simon Bolivar, famous Latin-American liberator, will be commemorated tomorrow at the Bolivar statue in Central Park. The Pan American Society and the Consuls General in New York of the six Bolivarian republics will sponsor the ceremonies in honor of the soldier, statesman and patriot, who was born July 2, 1783, in Caracas, Venezuela.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 22. -- The Maidstone Club's annual doubles tournament started today with thirty-two players, and at the close of play four teams had advanced to the semi-final rounds, which will be played tomorrow.

THIS volume, while in no way dependent upon it, supplements the author's "Outline History of Painting," published in 1930 by William Farquhar Payson. The earlier book concerned itself with painting in Europe to the end of the nineteenth century.

THE wealthy and aristocratic Bolivar family of Venezuela hailed the arrival of a son on July 24, 1783. The parents wanted to name the boy Santiago, after the patron saint of Spain and Venezuela. But the priest who christened him intervened.

ALBANY, July 22. -- A total of $1,759,242.26, which was the counties' share of the first collection of beer revenues taken in by the State for the period ending June 30, was distributed today by Controller Morris S. Tremaine. Figures furnished ay Mark Graves, president of the State Tax Commission, formed the basis for the distribution.

KANSAS CITY, July 22. -- Secretary Wallace was rstrained by a three-judge Federal court today from putting into effect the new commission rates he has promulgated for the Kansas City Stock Yards. The temporary order is effective for sixty days and a later hearing will be held to pass upon the merits of the rates.

WITH the news that Vines and Allison had been defeated in two singles matches by Austin and Perry at Auteuil on Friday, our Davia Cup prospects went down faster than the stock market quotations of the same day. Our tennis tourists will have to win a double-header in the Stade Roland Garros today or retreat, bag and baggage, from a scene of disaster.
"WHY do they fly like that? How do they do it?"

DENVER, July 20. -- If, as Washington dispatches indicate, production of domestic beet sugar is to be limited to 1,265,000 long tons, a heart-breaking moan will rise from Colorado. Already the clans are gathering. The reason that they did not get into action when the conference on the sugar industry opened is explainable only on the ground that they were asleep.

Sixty-odd nations met at London and found they were not ready to make common concessions necessary to working out a plan of world economic cooperation. And so the World Economic Conference will recess next Thursday. It may meet again; it may not.
NEW YORK. Count James de Martino, who has been staying at the Pierre, is the week-end guest of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence H. Mackay in Roslyn, L.I.
LONDON, July 22. -- The text of the agreement on monetary silver, signed tonight by eight nations attending the World Economic Conference, is as follows:

ROBERT MONTGOMERY, one of Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer's brightest young men, stopped off in town last week to pay his disrespects to Hollywood and the producers therein. Mr. Montgomery had this and that to say about the picture makers, but he prefaced it all with the explanation that he really was not mad at MGM and, in fact, had no complaint.

GENERAL ITALO BALBO and his air armada, guided by magnetic compass and radio compass, across 6,100 miles of land and sea, talked back and forth with the Old and New Worlds throughout the historic flight that spanned the hemispheres.

Those in charge of the National Sweepstakes, the Gold Cup event to be held on the Shrewsbury River at Red Bank, N.J., on Aug. 12, are figuring on twelve entries. It will be the fourth race for the Sweepstakes trophy.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- Although output in most productive lines was higher in the week ended on July 15 than in the preceding week, there were indications of a tendency for operations to level off, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

A frequent complaint or government is that it is too remote from the people. Except when the average citizen pays his taxes or gets a traffic ticket from a policeman he rarely comes in contact with the establishment his votes set up for the administration of his public affairs.

LONDON, July 22. -- The delegates of eight countries chiefly interested in silver signed an agreement late tonight, designed to raise and stabilize the price of the white metal for the next four years.

THE three million theatregoers who have passed through the foyer of the Radio City Music Hall since its opening are only dimly aware of the unseen organization that makes the wheels turn. Behind the scenes is an amazing town within a town, peopled by hundreds of artisans and technicians whose activities begin soon after sun-up and continue until a new dawn is graying the city spires outside.

Consistent buying of Fall styles featured the wholesale markets here during the week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. It was noteworthy, this buying office reports, that purchases of higher-price, better-type merchandise were extensively made, reflecting the plans of retailers to promote trade in quality goods.

PARIS. WITH a currency still stable and a relatively small number of unemployed, the French nation counts itself comparatively fortunate among the great powers. The crisis has, nevertheless, already bitten deep into the economic life of the country and the latest and most significant of its effects is that wheat-growing no longer pays.

The crisis has, nevertheless, already bitten deep into the economic life of the country and the latest and most significant of its effects is that wheat-growing no longer pays.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent report of President Robinson of the College of the City of New York that those who choose he teaching profession present a psychological "inferiority" is a most appropriate example of the viciousness of playing number fames with Freudian slang.

BRIAN AHERNE, now making his American motion-picture debut as Marlene Dietrich's leading man in "The Song of Songs," at the Criterion, was born Brian de Lacey Aherne in King's Norton, Worcestershire, England, on May 2, 1902.

A CASUAL, glance through the lists of openings of new plays scheduled in the different Summer theatres throughout the country indicate that the centre of theatrical activity during the months of June, July and August is no longer Broadway, but the more rural parts of these United States.

After one of the most nervous two-hour trading periods in many years, with fluctuations over a range of $3 a bale, prices on the Cotton Exchange closed yesterday with net gains of 3 to 14 points, or 15 to 70 cents a bale. Absence of rain in dry sections of the cotton belt, less weakness in outside markets and heavy buying for trade account steadied the market as he session progressed.

Seventy-five thousand spectators waiting for the arrival of Wiley Post at Floyd Bennett Field last night were taken by surprise when the round-the-world flier swooped out of the sky at midnight and taxied up the concrete runway.

BOULDER DAM. A NETWORK of mountain roads leads sharply downward for half a dozen miles of wild loops and hairpin turns, through a region where ancient volcanic disturbances have thrown up savage hillocks of red and black lava-stone, gnarled now by millenniums of weathering into a devil's refuse heap of sterile grotesques.

HERE is a neat parcel of optimistic modernism from England. D.L. Murray casts some amusing aspersions on society and incidentally conveys the glad tidings that with certain authors regaining their sense of humor they no longer consider it bad form to bring light-hearted comedy back to the pages of fiction when depicting the present depressing era.

LONDON, July 21. -- The World Economic Conference will adjourn Thursday after dragging on for nearly a month since President Roosevelt's message made it clear that no progress could be made on the basic problems of currency, credit or tariffs.

Plentiful supplies of commodities resulted in a depressed wholesale vegetable market during the latter part of the last week, and demand was slowed by hot weather, George G. Royee, director of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 22. -- President Roosevelt departed this afternoon for a twenty-four-hour cruise aboard the cutter Sequoia in the hope of getting some respite from the heat wave that enveloped Washington.

GODTHAAB, West Greenland, July 22. -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh completed safely one of the most perilous stages of their Atlantic flight tonight when their seaplane floated gently down to the water at Godthaab Harbor at 7:30 o'clock tonight Greenland time.

The broadest definitions ever ascribed to the word "income" are probably contained in revenue measures in connection with the determination of what constitutes "net taxable income." These definitions are inclusive of almost every conceivable kind of gains, profits, realized increment and accretions, as well as earnings and income resulting from the employment of capital and labor.

EVERY collector who develops an interest in the technical niceties of first editions ("points," is the currently abused term) is in danger of compiling a bibliography of some favorite author. It does not seem to matter that the subject has been treated before.

It took MAGELLAN'S expedition one month more than three years to circumnavigate the globe and WILEY POST a little more than a week. POST tells us the familiar story of wind and fog, of sleet which formed on wings and which had to be melted off by a descent. Yet his flight was something more than an athletic feat on the part of a man of steady nerves and great courage.

The unbroken rise in steel operations since the last week of March, when the industry was at 14 per cent, was checked last week when the rate barely held at 57 per cent, according to the magazine Steel. A combination of circumstances, none of them bearish in itself, leveled off production, the publication explains.
WASHINGTON, July 23. -- A $90,000,000 bonus for wheat farmers, to be paid for curtailment of production, will be ready for distribution this Fall, Secretary Wallace announced today.

Two outstanding heroes of the air who have just completed epoch-making flights met for the first time yesterday when General Italo Balbo called on Wiley Post at the Hotel Roosevelt to congratulate him on his round-the-world flight. The two are as unlike in temperament, background and physical appearance as men can well be.

Boxing bouts will be one of many features of the three-day seashore fete to be held this week at the Brightwaters Casino, Bay Shore, L.I., for the benefit of the Southside Hospital. Leading amateur boxers of the metropolitan district will compete, but instead of the usual purses, gold watches will be the awards.

The current week's schedule in the Summer theatres is an ambitious one. At least fifteen plays of more or less consequence are being shown for the first time in houses all along the Atlantic seaboard. Those theatres that cannot, this week, boast of premieres, are contenting themselves with reviving drama of recent seasons.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP). -- Coordination of all local efforts in an anti-crime campaign was urged tonight by Joseph B. Keenan, director of the Federal Government's anti-racketeering campaign, in an address over the National Broadcasting System.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 23. -- This citadel of the non-union bituminous coal industry was stormed today by 2,579 delegates said to represent 160,000 members of the United Mine Workers of America in four Southern States, who pledged their support to the National Industrial Recovery Act, to the union's efforts for the 30-hour week and the movement for union recognition.

If the Recovery Administration, through the National Legitimate Theatre Committee, can get general compliance with the code just formulated for producers and workers in the "spoken drama," the public will gain some long-sought advantages that no previous committee has ever been able to obtain.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP). -- Compromises among dissenting factions of various industries were sought today by the Recovery Administration as it made ready for the opening of the campaign to reemploy 6,000,000 men and women.
PHILADELPHIA, July 23. -- A kidnapper's bullet proved fatal at 7 o'clock this evening to Frank A. McClatchy, real estate broker of suburban Cynwyd.

LONDON, July 22. -- This week's early relapse in the dollar when it actually but momentarily stood at a discount on sterling naturally attracted widespread attention. To those closely in touch with events, however, the movement caused no surprise.
LONDON, July 23. -- The Board of Jewish Deputies, representing 300,000 Jews in Great Britain, voted today 110 to 27 not to proclaim an official boycott of German goods and services at present.

GODTHAAB, West Greenland, July 23. -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh told the correspondent today that by the time he had finished the exploratory flights which he and Mrs. Lindbergh are to make over Greenland, he feared it would be too late in the season to go on to Europe via Reykjavik, Iceland, to Stockholm, as he had hoped.

"The modern Communists' dream is only a secular version of the common religious hope," said the Right Rev. John Newton McCormick, Bishop of Western Michigan, in a sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

CINCINNATI, July 23 (AP). -- A power-house attack headed by Chick Hafey, who hit five doubles in six times at bat, gave Cincinnati a double victory over the Pirates today, 6 to 1 and 6 to 4. The Reds gained sixth place in the National League race.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- Beginning tomorrow, values of grains are to rebuild themselves on a new foundation. After trebling within four months and reaching the highest level since 1930 in the wildest speculation known in years, they plunged downward with such force as to close the futures markets.

A lull in buying activity was evidenced in the wholesale markets here last week due primarily to the increase in wholesale prices and to the reduction in the number of buyers here. New showings were made of fur trimmed dresses and suits, which were well received.
Mrs. Ada Allerton, 84 years old, an invalid, committed suicide yesterday by inhaling gas in a furnished room at 405 West Nineteenth Street. She had lived there for five years.
Four men were arrested yesterday in Brooklyn charged with blackmail, attempted extortion and felonious assault. They will be arraigned today in Coney Island Court.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 23. -- A last-period goal scored by Terence Preece, after young Billy Reynolds had nursed the ball cleverly up to the mouth of the goal from midfield, carried Stephen Sanford's Hurricanes into the semifinal round of the national junior polo championship at the Sands Point Club today.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 23. -- "The only good reason I can think of for our cracking up was that I was jolly well worn out," Captain James A. Mollison remarked wanly to doctors as he lay on an operating table of the emergency ward of Bridgeport Hospital tonight.
Marc W. Haas and James Weiskopf are with Emanuel Co.

Many of the chronic illnesses which affect one in every ten persons may be charged directly to the attitude of physicians and the public, resulting from misinformation or lack of information as to this group of diseases, according to a report made public yesterday by the Welfare Council of New York City.

BOSTON, July 23. -- At 4:15 A.M. today. Engineer Harry Brown of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad lolled at the throttle of his engine on the slow freight unromantically named "The OB4," engaged in the dull and ordinary business of hauling a load of Connecticut onions to the Boston produce market.
"Biography," the Theatre Guild's version of S.N. Behrman's comedy, will close its run at the Avon on Saturday night. Thomas Chalmers has replaced Jay Fassett for the final week.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 23. -- Another world's record and another championship went to Miss Lenore Kight today as the women's national A.A.U. swimming championships were concluded on the sun-flooded waters of Zach's Bay. A tremendous crowd of 40,000 saw the Homestead (Pa.) girl complete her sweep of the four free-style events with a runaway triumph in the 880-yard race and set her second mark of the meeting.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Geology, aided by astronomy, physics, chemistry and mathematics, is slowly filling in the gaps in science's book of Genesis, in which a "day" is of the order of several hundred million years, according to geologists attending the sixteenth International Geological Congress, which opened here yesterday.

A duplex penthouse of fourteen rooms atop the Columbia Broadcasting Building, 485 Madison Avenue, has been rented to Yves S. De Villers. The penthouse was built by John H. Carpenter for his own occupancy. Among its features are large terraces, growing grass plot, a fifty-foot drawing room and a large billiard room.

TOKYO, July 22. -- With the discovery of nine pistols in the possession of a rural group of patriots who had planned to participate in terrorism, the "prayer-meeting conspiracy" against high officials today assumed a more sinister complexion.

NEWPORT, July 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. Paulding Fosdick entertained with a buffet dinner at Sea Beach this evening, having more than thirty guests. Among others who gave dinner parties were Mr. and Mrs. William F. Whitehouse and Miss Julia A. Berwind.

Although the nations taking a part in the Economic Conference could not agree about anything important, they begged to differ amid expressions of most charming deference and courtesy. In particular did they insist upon explaining that not one of them had the slightest thought of interfering with the plans and projects of the other.

Delay of at least a fortnight in picking a fusion candidate for Mayor, so a program might be adopted and fusion with independent Democrats accomplished more satisfactorily, was urged yesterday by eight anti-Tammany Democrats, among them James E. Finegan, fusion candidate for Controller in 1925.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- The Chicago Board of Trade and other leading grain markets throughout the country will reopen for trading in futures tomorrow morning under the most stringent set of restrictions ever imposed upon the grain markets in the United States.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 23. -- Frank Shields of New York succeeded Clifford Sutter of New Orleans as the bolder of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club challenge trophy today when he won his second successive turf court tennis tournament of the season.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Fortyfive per cent of the member bank deposits of the United States are made up of those of $50,000 and over, despite the fact that they comprise less than 1 per cent of the total number of deposits, it was revealed by the board.

For the first time in ten years the famous reach of Fire Island Inlet has provided bluefish at this time of the Summer. For as long as any old-timer around Great South Bay can recall, that area has been, at this season, the happy hunting grounds of the fluke fishermen.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- Eighty-two guests and eleven employes, surprised as a dance was concluding early today at the Olympic Golf and Country Club, surrendered $14,000 and jewelry valued at $30,000 to five masked robbers who held possession of the club for forty minutes.

PARIS, July 22. -- The Bourse was calm this week and not unduly influenced by the Wall Street agitation, nevertheless, financial spheres follow with greatest interest the development of the situation in America, repercussion from which cannot fail ultimately to be felt the world over.

Moralizing on last week's severe break in the speculative markets is not perhaps likely to be of great use. So far as regards participants in any such speculation, most of them are convinced before the break that reaction can never come: after it, they tell every one why it was a certainty.

The increased number of patients seeking free care has resulted in "serious if not dangerous" overcrowding in New York City's municipal hospitals and in serious financial problems for the voluntary hospitals, the United Hospital Fund announced yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Two miles south of the George Washington Bridge, in the woods between Fort Lee and Palisade, can be found men sitting on running-boards of trucks, all engaged in the unstrenuous task of bird-trapping. Armed with written permission from game wardens to catch legally unprotected birds, and freely confessing their ignorance about recognizing one bird from another, they bitterly resent intrusion.

Reiterating its view that there is urgent need for "a domestic barometer of the purchasing power of our dollar," the committee for establishment of a free gold market in the United States has made public its conclusions based on a special analysis prepared for the committee by the National Industrial Conference Board.

With alight prospects that the various groups in the shipping industry can agree on the drafting of a code of ethics to suit shipowners and labor, it was indicated yesterday that the United States Shipping Board might be asked to take charge.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 23. -- Arrangements have been made by the family of Charles F. Urschel, millionaire oil man, snatched from his home late last night by two machine gunners, to pay ransom as soon as contact with the kidnappers is established, it was learned authoritatively today.

The flying Mollisons -- Captain James A. Mollison and his wife, Amy Johnson -- have been dogged with misfortune in their first joint attempt to set a new long-distance record, but each has a long record of individual accomplishment in previous adventures.

JERUSALEM, July 23. -- More than twenty leaders of the extreme wing of the Zionist Revisionist party were arrested today in various parts of the country, including Jerusalem, Tel Aviv and two Jewish villages, Kfarsaba and Kalmania, when the police simultaneously raided houses in connection with the murder of Dr. Chaim Arlosoroff, member of the Jewish Agency Executive of Palestine.

The Yankees closed their home stand against Western invaders yesterday at the Stadium with a twin victory over the Cleveland Indiana before 35,000 fans. They advanced to first place, half a game ahead of the Senators, in the race for the American League pennant.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Sweatshop conditions in the shirt industry, with plants working overtime and half the employes earning less than $7.40 in a busy week, were revealed in a report made public today by Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor.

HAVANA, July 22. -- Fifteen women public school teachers who were arrested in the editorial offices of El Pais, a Spanish newspaper, this morning after presenting a protest against nonpayment of salaries, were released from Principe Fortress this afternoon fey order of General Alberto Herrera, Secretary of War and Navy.

Premiums received by the sixtyfive companies writing workmen's compensation insurance in New York State totaled $42,000,000 in 1932, according to a report made public yesterday at the office of State Superintendent of Insurance George S. Van Schaick.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- A price of 5 cents a pound for hogs at midweek, although the highest in several months, failed last week to increase the shipments from farms to leading packing centres, the receipts being 30,000 smaller than in the previous week and the smallest since June 3.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 23. -- A new golf champion was crowned today as Walter Scheiber of the Hillcrest Golf Club of Jamaica won the Metropolitan P.G.A. title after a hard-fought duel with Walter Kozak of Pomonok, scoring by 1 up over thirty-six holes at the Rockwood Hall Country Club course.

ALBANY, July 23 (AP). -- Albany hit Jersey City pitchers freely today and won both games of the double-header by scores of 9 to 3 and 8 to 2. Shealy, in the first game, and Filley, in the second, pitched steadily for the Senators. The hitting of Thompson featured.

The first Minimum Wage Board created under the State's Minimum Wage Law for women and children will meet this afternoon in the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street. The first industry to be considered for the fixing of minimum rates of pay will be the laundry industry, employing some 20,000 women in this State.

Immediate action to counteract the failure of the London economic conference to agree upon a program of currency stabilization and tariff reforms is necessary to avert world-wide disaster. Viscount Snowden of Ickornshaw, former British Chancellor of the Exchequer, declared yesterday in a radio address from London.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your letters from readers column has recently contained several communications concerning the present administration's methods of distributing patronafe. One idea seems rather common to all -- the statement of the Postmaster General that qualifications come first is taken with a grain of salt.

CALCUTTA, July 23. -- J.M. Sen Gupta, leader of the All-India National Congress party in Bengal and five times Mayor of Calcutta, died as a result of a stroke early today at Ranchi in Bihar, where he was being detained as a State prisoner.

A new dawn is certainly coming up on a world filled with refreshed vigor, but the question must be asked, "Will it shine upon a moral and ethical revival or will it see merely an intensification of the old materialistic civilization?" said the Rev. Dr. Franklin F. Fry, secretary of the Board of American Missions of the United Lutheran Church in America, yesterday.
Bathing beaches in and near the city were thronged yesterday with the largest crowds of the season, the oppressive heat driving thousands of the city's millions to the seashore in search of relief.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP). -- A program for overhauling the nation's system of marketing grain, sharply curtailing public participation in trading, was under consideration tonight by farm administrators who have agreed on one premise in a plan of action-that "reform must come."

If the Soviet Government falls, the chances are that "there will break over the wearied land a continual tempest of paltry wars after the Chinese model, destroying all that is European or national in Russia and probably ending in the permanent Balkanization of a sixth part of the globe."

The American Rolling Mills Company is asking the holders of its 4 1/2 per cent gold notes outstanding in the amount of $13,992,000 and due on Nov. 1 next, to exchange them for new 5 per cent notes maturing on Nov. 1, 1938.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP). -- A home run with the bases full in the tenth inning by Harvey Hendrick, a pinch hitter, gave the Cubs a 9-to-5 victory over the Phillies in the first game of their double-header today and Bill Jurges provided the punch that gave the National League champions a 3-to-1 decision in the nightcap.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- New York and Utah will be the first States to begin actual work on public road schedules with money obtained from the Public Works Administration, eleven plans for New York and six for Utah having been approved today by Secretary Ickes.

HOLLYWOOD, July 23 (AP). -- The "Help Wanted" sign was posted in front of eleven motion-picture studios today as producers decided to throw down the gauntlet to striking sound technicians, whose walkout at midnight Saturday stopped all production and threatens to throw the 27,000 workers in the industry here out of employment.
BOSTON, July 23 (AP). -- The Red Sox took their fourth and fifth straight games to sweep the series with the White Sox today, 6 -- 2 and 7 -- 2, behind able pitching by H. Johnson and Pipgras.

ELMIRA, July 23. -- August C. Haller of Pittsburgh, glider manufacturer and pilot, was forced to take a parachute leap from his glider 500 feet over the edge of the city late this afternoon. He landed, sustaining only superficial injuries, while his plane crashed 500 feet away.
MADRID, July 23. -- At dawn today, many so-called Fascisti, the right-wing leaders, who were charged with passing out handbills inciting to rebellion, were arrested in Madrid and in the provinces.

Dean Frank H. Sommer of the New York University Law School announced yesterday that forty-one students of that division had received scholarships or honorary recognition for high scholastic standing for the school year 19321933.
General Italo Balbo decided last night to take off with the Italian air squadron on its return trip to Italy at 8 o'clock this morning.

THE warfare among the professional masters of the midiron over the P.G.A. championship, and how and when it should be played, must be giving the United, States Golf Association officials a hearty laugh.

NEW ORLEANS. July 23. -- There was more excitement and activity in the cotton contract market here last week than had been experienced in years. Early in the week prices advanced to new high levels for the season, when the October option went to 11.98 cents and all the months back of October advanced well above the 12-cent line.

PENN YAN, N.Y., July 23 (AP). -- Three yachtsmen were missing tonight as an aftermath of a furious storm which broke over Keuka Lake today, overturning and dismasting many boats in the colorful Keuka Yacht Club regatta.

ALBANY, July 23. -- Governor Lehman today appointed forty-one men and women interested in education, including four members of the Legislature, to act as a committee to study the cost of public education. The group will determine whether further economy cuts can be made without lowering the standards of education.

The Century of Progress in Chicago presents an impressive view of the advances that man has made in the last hundred years. The "I will" spirit has been powerful in lifting a new glory out of the lake.

The Electric Bond and Share Company reports cash in banks amounting to $42,413,200 on June 30, against $30,692,805 a year before, and total current assets of $50,445,128, against $39,088,438, including for both periods more than $5,000,000 in United States Government securities and acceptances and nearly $2,000,000 of municipal and other short-term securities.

Humanism was condemned by the Rev. Dr. Adam W. Burnet, pastor of the Westbourne Presbyterian Church, Glasgow, Scotland, in a sermon heard by more than 900 persons yesterday morning in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

The Chrystie-Forsyth Street tract, which the city has decided to lease for a model housing development, should be left open for playgrounds and tennis courts, Miss Lillian Wald, president of the Henry Street Settlement, declared yesterday.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 23. -- Outdoor sports were the major interest here this week-end. A large gallery watched the second day of the men's annual invitation doubles at the Maidstone Club, when Edward W. Burns and his partner, Manuel Alonso, defeated two members of the Oxford-Cambridge tennis team, Douglas Freshwater and Grady C. Frank; while Watson Washburn and Arthur McPherson defeated Lindsey Tiers and Edward McKnight of Princeton, N.J.

OCEAN CITY, N.J., July 23. -- A sneak thief here made good his escape this afternoon from an impromptu posse of sixty Summer residents when he plunged into the ocean. He is now believed to have drowned.

Charles L. Eidlitz, chairman of the board of the Credit Association of the Building Trades of New York and a former electrical contractor, will administer the code for the electrical industry in this city and vicinity when it is adopted and approved, according Co the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

Thousands of spectators, waiting at Floyd Bennett Field yesterday evening for the arrival of James and Amy Mollison, saw a small white biplane containing two men plunge 300 feet into the waters of Jamaica Bay. The occupants of the plane, neither of whom was seriously hurt, were rescued by Coast Guards.

BASLE, Switzerland, July 23. -- Interest in the conversations started hero today by world bankers assembling for tomorrow's meeting of the board of the Bank for International Settlements centred on how they would affect the future of the gold standard.
The 107th Infantry Regiment of the New York National Guard -- the old Seventh -- departed yesterday for its annual two weeks of intensive field training at Camp Smith, Peekskill.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Cease and desist orders directed against the practice of selling made-over hats as if they were new have been issued to nine companies in New York by the Federal Trade Commission.
BERLIN, July 22. -- The break in Wall Street securities and the fall in wheat and other commodity prices slightly depressed the Berlin Boerse, but there was no material effect on business sentiment.

Lovers of legend will be cheered by the experience of an elderly gentleman with a long white beard like CHARLEMAGNE'S who was sleeping peacefully on a shady bench in the Berlin Tiergarten the other day. A buzzing sound which may at first have lulled him to slumber grew strong enough to wake him.

After pushing to new high levels for the movement and in many cases for the last two or three years, commodity futures traded on local exchanges experienced one of the most precipitous declines on record on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday. Trading in nearly all cases was the heaviest for any week on record.

Expenditures for unemployment relief in New York State for June in local, State and Federal funds totaled $12,686,534, according to the monthly report made public yesterday by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration. The number of families helped was 380,771, or approximately 1,660,000 individuals out of a total population of 12,588,066.

If the people of the country would stop gambling in the stock market and turn their adventurous spirit toward the improvement of society, many of the evils now confronting us would be remedied, Bishop William P. Remington of Eastern Oregon said yesterday in a sermon as guest preacher at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fiftythird Street and Fifth Avenue.
