AUTEUIL, France, July 23. -- Wilmer Allison was up against a better tennis player today in the Davis Cup interzone finals, between England and the United States. Bunny Austin played a very safe game, retrieving balls from the back of the court, waiting for his chances and making quick use of them to give many needed points.

BERLIN, July 23. -- Today the German revolution has reached the stage dreaded by many Germans and foreseen by foreign observers in Germany during the past few weeks. The Hitler regime is menaced not by any external enemy, either in the country or outside, but by the danger of an internal explosion.

LONDON, July 23. -- The pulse of the World Economic Conference began to beat a little faster late tonight as important delegates who had been absent for the past fortnight began to return for the closing days of this session, which will be decisive for its future.

Theirs a Single World A person has had to look twice at the map in the paper these last few weeks to decide whether it is the Regional Planning Commission or MATTERN and POST. That rough circle of heavy black and broken lines at first sight is one more scheme of arterial highways and bridges and by-passes by the regional experts for going all around New York City.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP). -- The Detroit Tigers went on a slugging rampage in the eighth inning today and scored nine runs, more than enough to drop the Washington Senators into second place in the American League.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- Steady gains are being made in this district in almost all lines of business under readjustment plans of the government. The output of factories has been increased, employment has been spread and wages have been raised.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Negotiations between the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the employing groups in the coat and suit industry for an agreement to be incorporated in the trade's recovery code were broken off today through differences on wage scales and on the week-work system of production.

An appeal for contributions to a campaign fund, which it is hoped will reach $100,000, has been sent out by Walter S. Mack Jr., treasurer of the Organization of Regular Republicans for Change in the New York County Leadership. The organization is conducting a fight to oust Samuel S. Koenig as county chairman.

AUTEUIL, France, July 23 (AP). -- England, on the basis of its splendid showing against Australia in the European zone finals and against the United States, probably will enter the Davis Cup challenge round a slight favorite over France, the cup-holder.

The Union News Company has leased a large space in the basement of the Vanderbilt Avenue Building, at 51 East Forty-second Street, where it will establish a restaurant, lunchroom and bar. The deal involves about 6,500 square feet of floor, which will be altered for occupancy by about Aug. 20.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 23. -- Jubilee, owned by H. Boyd Atkin, came home first in the special star class race of the Sunday series, held by the New Rochelle Yacht Club today.
BERLIN, July 23. -- Admiral von Schroeder organized and commanded the marine corps occupation of Flanders during the World War.

Conferences of Treasury officials and representatives of the Reserve Banks have been considering in Washington questions of Federal financing which must soon be taken up. Apart from the new funds needed to launch the Government's public works program and to cover routine expenditures until current revenues pick up, there are outstanding obligations which must be paid as they fall due.
CHICAGO, July 23. -- The pulse of the nation's real estate market is quickening for the first time in four years.

Starting the ninth inning yesterday at Ebbets Field with the Dodgers leading, 5 to 1, Walter Beck found both himself and his successor, Joe Shaute, out and seven Giant runs in before the ordeal was over. The Dodgers finished on the losing end, 8 to 5.

RYE, N.Y., July 23. -- The untiring among the Long Island Sound racing skippers and crews came out thirty-seven yachts strong today for the special regatta of the American Yacht Club. The week at Larchmont had not subdued them.
Nearly $476,400,000 is invested in land, buildings and euipment of New York City's public school system, according to the annual financial and statistical report of the Board of Education.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The other day a curious excerpt from a letter appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES. The writer ingenuously advocated the return of the bearded male in America -- on grounds civic and esthetic. Let us hope the suggestion was as innocent as it looked.
WASHINGTON, July 23. -- President Roosevelt will fire the opening gun tomorrow night in the bold frontal attack which he has ordered on the nation's unemployment problem.

TRUCKEE, Cal., July 23 (AP). -- A grove of tall pine trees on the shores of Lake Tahoe was dedicated today to the Governors attending their twenty-fifth annual convention which opens tomorrow at Sacramento.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. C. Tiffany Richardson gave a luncheon today at the Crossways for Mrs. Frank Browne Keech, who is visiting them.

Crowds waited for hours at Floyd Bennett airport early last night, drawn there by the prospect of seeing Captain James A. Mollison and Amy Johnson land and by a three-ring air circus. They inspected the Italian air armada ready for its return flight to Italy, stared at the Winnie Mae, which carried Post twice around the world and gaped in admiration at Alford J. Williams's hair-raisins stunts above their heads.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 23. -- Winifred Monro, a nurse in the family of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Franklin of Pound Hollow, died early today in the North Country Community Hospital of injuries she received in an attempt to save the 2-year-old daughter of the Franklins, a grandchild of P.A.S. Franklin, from injury.

LONDON, July 22. -- Perhaps the most fitting description, published here of the British Government's offer to convert its American dollar loan is The Financial Times's characterization of the plan as ingenious but immoral. There is no doubt about its ingenuity and there is no doubt that it is actually a breach of contract.

LONDON, July 23. -- The silver agreement reached at the economic conference is not, in the opinion of The London Times, the kind of agreement "ardently desired by those who hold that one of the most helpful contributions to world recovery would be to restore the purchasing power of China and other sliver-using countries by giving silver an international monetary value."

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $3,306,760,600. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.
Investors bought numerous flats and small houses in New Jersey in deals reported over the week-end.

VIENNA, July 23. -- Baron Werner von Alversleben, who was arrested for participation in the attempt to murder Dr. Richard Steidle, Security Director for Tyrol, and confessed he had also planned to assassinate the Police Minister, Major Emil Fey, is a young Prussian Junker of a distinguished family.
The new vestry of St. Mark's-inthe-Bouwerie has at last been declared legal, according to a formal announcement made yesterday by Boyd L. Bailey, clerk of the church.

ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., July 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Napoleon Bonaparte entertained at the Atlantic Beach Club this evening. A collection of comic verses about prominent members of the club was read. Among the guests were:

Urging immediate cooperation between the building industry and the Federal Government to prevent the diversion of funds into other forms of investment, George H. Gray, director of the New England Division of the American Institute of Architects, declares that violent price rises of building materials threaten to arrest recovery in that business and to thwart the plans of home builders.
Alarmed at the steady decrease in wages resulting from improved equipment and faster schedules, pilots of the Eastern Air Transport delivered an ultimatum to company officials last Saturday.

MOSCOW, July 23. -- Considerable interest is shown here in the report from Washington that a semigovernmental corporation with capital of $400,000,000 to $500,000,000 was contemplated to finance trade with the Soviet Union.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 23. -- Mrs. E. Parmalee Prentice of Mount Hope Farm, Williamstown, was hostess to a company of 125 friends at a musicale yesterday afternoon. The artists were Miss Astrid Fjelde, soprano, and Archer Gibson, organist.

Langston Hughes, author of "Not Without Laughter," has just arrived in Japan after a year's trip through Soviet Russia and Siberia. He will leave Tokyo soon for Shanghai and will sail from there for San Francisco, bringing material for a new book which Alfred A. Knopf expects to publish next year.

BERLIN, July 22. -- Trade improvement continues. Railroad car loadings are 6 per cent above those of the same period in 1932. Of German tonnage on July 1, 20.4 per cent was laid up, against 27.2 per cent on June 1 and 35 per cent on April 1, 1932.

LONDON, July 22. -- Newfoundland will temporarily lose her status as a self-governing colony if the British Government approves the report of Lord Amulree's commission, which was recently sent to investigate the island's financial plight.

BERLIN, July 23. -- Complaints of undue pressure, threats and actual interference by the Nazi partisans with voters of the other side in today's Protestant Church elections reached the non-Nazi election board from various quarters.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- Pledges of support for the President's blanket work-spreading and wage-raising code continued to arrive today in a steady stream of telegrams to the President and General Johnson. They came from a wide range of business enterprises, including a shipbuilding concern, printing establishment, a furniture factory, motion picture producers, a brewery, paper factories, a beauty parlor, drug stores and a pottery.

With admirable consistency Senator THOMAS of Oklahoma maintains that what the financial situation calls for now is "physical inflation." So far we have had only "mind inflation," and how broken a reed that is the markets for stocks and commodities last week clearly demonstrated.
Chicago Board of Trade suspended business in future contracts in the grains and provisions, July 21, 22.

WASHINGTON, July 23. -- A sharp protest against the oil code submitted by the American Petroleum Institute was filed today with General Hugh S. Johnson, Administrator of the National Recovery Act, by the Eastern Independent Oil Marketers Association.

A draft for a proposed bill to permit judges to grant stays not exceeding one year in mortgage foreclosure proceedings against homes and farms was submitted yesterday to Lucius R. Eastman, chairman of the Governor's home and farm mortgage advisory committee, by the Consolidated Home Owners Mortgage Committee, New York Division.

LONDON, July 23. -- Charles W. Berry, Controller of New York City, held a dinner conference today with Samuel Untermyer, the city's special counsel in transit matters and related financial problems. The meeting was held on the eve of Mr. Berry's departure for Paris to continue his study of municipal financing in European cities.

NEW YORK. Lady Chilton, wife of the British Ambassador to Chile, and her brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Howard O'Brien of Grand Rapids, Mich., will arrive at the Ambassador on Wednesday to remain for a few days before sailing for Chile.

PITTSBURGH, July 23. -- The point at which production of steel would level off is now thought to have been reached. No decrease is expected within the next three or four weeks, but a lull thereafter is foreseen because forces that would give the trade a fresh impetus could hardly begin to exert their influence so soon.

ROME, July 23 (AP). -- In a report wired to Premier Mussolini today, General Italo Balbo said that the existence of anti-Fascist sentiment abroad was a myth which was exploded by the enthusiastic welcome his air squadron has received in America.

NEW HAVEN, July 23. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 70.4, which compares with 68.8 a week ago, 66.6 two weeks ago, 65.1 three weeks ago and 64 four weeks ago.

Fagged out after thirty-nine hours spent fighting the elements, Captain James A. Mollison and his wife, Amy Johnson, wrecked their airplane, the Seafarer, at Stratford, Conn., last night with the lights of New York almost in sight.
General Italo Balbo made public last night the following message received from Colonel and Mrs. Charles Lindbergh. It was sent from Cartwright, Labrador.
BERLIN, July 23. -- Wiley Post's round-the-world flight has fired the German aviation world with enthusiasm.

PARIS, July 23. -- As had been expected since Friday, when Ellsworth Vines and Wilmer Allison were beaten in straight sets, much to every one's surprise, by the English singles players, H.W. (Bunny) Austin and Frederick Perry, the United States today lost the Davis Cup interzone finals.

PARIS, July 23. -- As had been expected since Friday, when Ellsworth Vines and Wilmer Allison were beaten in straight sets, much to every one's surprise, by the English singles players, H.W. (Bunny) Austin and Frederick Perry, the United States today lost the Davis Cup interzone finals.

The sesquicentennial of the birth of General Simon Bolivar, South American liberator, at Caracas, Venezuela, was celebrated here yesterday with exercises at his statue in Central Park near West Eighty-third Street. South American consular officers and many Latin-American residents of the city attended.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A remote spot in East Africa, somewhere in the vicinity of the Riff valleys, is the most likely site of the original Garden of Eden, birthplace of the human race, the sixteenth International Geological Congress was told here today by Sir Arthur Smith Woodward, eminent British anthropologist.
VIENNA, July 24 -- An account of the situation in the German concentration camps was published today in the Catholic newspaper Reichspost.

National socialism will last in Germany, in the opinion of Hamilton Fish Armstrong, editor of Foreign Affairs, who made a visit to Central Europe recently. His book, "Hitler's Reich," will be published today by the Macmillan Company.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 24 (AP) -- A warning that the administration will seek to prevent extreme high as well as extreme low prices for agricultural products was sounded here tonight by Secretary Wallace in an address before the American Institute of Cooperation.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- A break in the prices of lard had an unfavorable influence today on the market for live hogs, quotations for these toeing unchanged to 25 cents a hundredweight lower than on last Friday. Top prices were $4.80, against $4.85 a week ago. The average at $4.40 was down 15 cents.
LONDON, July 24 -- The London Times will publish the following tomorrow:
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Public hearings on the code of fair practices to govern the rayon weaving industry will open tomorrow.

To the Editor of The Nets York Times: Why go to Europe, or even to the Maine coast, for a vacation when there is so much vacation-exploring worth doing within the limits of New York City? We turned our attention today to Jamaica Bay, which has received much publicity recently as the alighting point of General Ealbo's fleet -- the climax of the great aviator's magnificent progression across the world.

Happy and animated despite the sweltering heat that enveloped them as soon as they set foot on shore, the members of the English Wightman Cup tennis team arrived in this city yesterday aboard the Britannic of the White Star Line.

Mrs. Mary Adams Love of 468 Riverside Drive has announced the marriage on Friday of her daughter, Miss Martha Randolph Love, to Louis Butler McCagg of this city, son of Mrs. Louis Butler McCagg of 18 East Eighty-fourth Street and Newport, R.I., and the late Mr. McCagg.

ALBANY, July 24 -- The Milk Control Board received a formal threat today that at least 40,000 dairy farmers would go on strike Aug. 1 if the board did not abolish the present price classification plan and guarantee farmers 45 per cent of the retail price for their product.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Three protests from interest in Detroit, San Francisco and Denver against terms of the blanket voluntary wage-raising and hour-limiting agreement were received today by Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator.

PARIS, July 24 -- Mlle. Suzanne Lenglen, in a copyrighted article published in L'Intransigeant today, criticized the training methods of the United States Davis Cup team, declaring that "while the British are trained reasonably, the Americans have been submitted to training which is so severe one may describe it as senseless.

The Council of Real Estate Associations adopted resolutions at a meeting in the Hotel Astor last night to ask Governor Lehman to send an emergency message recommending mortgage relief to the special session of the Legislature. About thirty delegates of property owners' organizations throughout the city attended.

BERLIN, July 24 -- The Boerse opened with a downward tendency today. Stocks lost between 2 and 3 per cent and bonds declined as much as 2 per ccent. Trading, however, was exceedingly slow and the dullness was held mainly responsible for the market's weakness.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- President Roosevelt's radio address to the nation, appealing for support of the National Recovery program, was, in full:...

DETROIT, Mich., July 24 -- With the approval of the Controller of the Currency, directors and two officers of the new Manufacturers National Bank were named today. John Ballantyne, formerly chairman of the First National Bank and president of the Detroit Bankers Company, will be president of the new institution, and Henry H. Sanger, former president of the National Bank of Commerce, will be vice president and cashier.

Plans have been completed for the marriage of Miss Katharine Elizabeth Collin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Welch Collin Jr. of Sewickley, Pa., to Robert R. Forrester Jr., son of Mrs. Harry A. Wilson of 515 Fifth Avenue, this city, and Robert R. Forrester, also of New York.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 24 -- The bulk of the estate of William L. Ward, leader of the Westchester Republicans, who died a week ago, goes to his four children, "share-and-share alike," according to the terms of his will, filed for probate today in the Surrogate's Court here.

Eighteen Roman Catholic organizations received more than $275,000 under the will of Rose C. Newman, the appraisal of her estate showed yesterday. Miss Newman died March 24, 1932, leaving $512,946 gross and $402,571 net, of which $445,760 was in real estate, including 1387-93 St. Nicholas Avenue, worth $343,000.
Dwellings and tenement properties formed the bulk of the realty trading in near-by New Jersey territory as recorded yesterday. Transfers were reported as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Cabinet Advisory Board allocated an additional $19,851,648 today for Federal public works and four other phases of construction, including $4,828,000 for completion of the annex of the postoffice building at Eighth Avenue and West Thirtythird Street, New York City.

MANILA, July 24 -- A demand for equal treatment for Philippine sugar by the United States as long as the Philippines were under the Stars and Stripes was made in a resolution passed today by the Legislature.

The Council of the Actors Equity Association yesterday protested against "the action of the Nazi Government in barring Jews from the German stage." Its protest was made in a resolution sent by Frank Gillmore, Equity's president, to the International Union of Persons Connected With the Stage, with headquarters at Vienna.

Former Mayor John F. Hylan announced yesterday that he was a candidate for the fusion nomination for Mayor, although he apparently has abandoned hope of obtaining the recommendation of the fusion group headed by former Governor Charles S. Whitman, which has been trying to pick a candidate.

New York City saved $872,067.86 on its police protection during the second quarter of 1933, ended June 30, as compared with the same quarter last year, according to Police Commissioner Bolan's report to Mayor O'Brien, made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Continuation of the emergency restrictions on grain trading already in effect until the submission and approval of codes of fair competition for grain exchanges was agreed upon today at a conference of representatives of the grain trades with the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 24 -- The Chaco peace parley is expected here to be removed from the jurisdiction of the commission appointed by the League of Nations and to be placed again in the hands of Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru because of the League Commission's inability to get Paraguay and Bolivia to agree to a plan of procedure.
"East River Romance," by Edwin Gilbert, will be shown at East Hampton, L.I., on Thursday evening. Betty Bronson is the star and Leon Errol is directing.

PARIS, July 24 -- I had lunch with Ellsworth Vines and checked over the events of yesterday in the Davis Cup play. It must be understood that Vines was in shape to play very hard tennis against Fred Perry.

In a report to the American Chemical Society Dr. LEWIS RADCLIFFE of the United States Bureau of Fisheries calls attention to the fact that the treaty of the League of Nations designed to save the whaling industry has not yet been sanctioned by a sufficient number of countries to make it effective.

SANTA ROSA, Cal., July 24 -- James L. Case, 70 years old, Forestville rancher and former preacher, today won the first round of his battle with the Analy Savings Bank of Sebastopol in the now famous Sonoma County "mortgage fight."

Wiley Post does not intend to give up flying now that he has flown twice around the world in record time, and he is longing for money enough to do some work in the further development of flying with the aid of modern instruments.
TOKYO, July 24 -- The public court-martial of ten young naval officers for alleged implication in the murder of Premier Inukai and other acts of terrorism on May 15, 1932, began at Yokosuka today.

Pending action on an application for a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the Ann Arbor Railroad's receivers have deferred the payment of interest on its 7,000,000 of 4 per cent firstmortgage bonds, A.K. Atkinson, treasurer for the receivers, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- John Scheck, a 20-year-old criminal, armed with a pistol which had been smuggled in to him, escaped from a pen at the criminal court today, dashed into the court room of Judge Charles K. Molthrop and shot and fatally wounded John Sevick, a policeman.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 24 -- A deadlock, with Governor Lehman and the Republicans ranged against Tammany, loomed tonight as legislators began to gather for the special session of the Legislature to open on Wednesday.

A group of police officials and crime experts, on their way to Chicago to attend committee meetings looking toward forming the proposed International World Police, arrived here yesterday. Nine, from European countries, came aboard the steamship Franconia, and others from American and Canadian cities were here to greet them.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- This week the wings of the "blue hawk" will begin to spread over the United States. That is General Hugh S. Johnson's name for the eagle on the N.R.A. shield that will be posted by all employers -- except farmers -- of more than two persons enlisted under the code of the National Industry Recovery Act.

The flying Mollisons came to New York yesterday, not as they had hoped to come, but they flew. Lying back wearily on white hospital pillows, with, a nurse and two physicians beside them, Captain James A. Mollison and his wife, Amy, made the flight from Bridgeport, Conn., where they had crashed the night before, as passengers in a roomy amphibian plane.

Net working capital of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. amounted to $113,926,123 on June 30, comparing with $98,505,953 on Dec. 31, 1932, according to the report for the first six months of 1933 issued yesterday. Current assets were $18,075,354 higher at $125,401,107, and current liabilities rose $2,655,184 to $11,474,984.

Governor LEHMAN'S appointment of a committee to make a thorough survey of the cost of public education in the State of New York does not imply that he is opposed to continuing State aid for schools on whatever scale may be necessary. He has thus far shown a willingness to follow, so far as concerns this matter, in the footsteps of his two predecessors, Governor SMITH and Governor ROOSEVELT.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 24 -- The Art Association was the scene this evening of the annual concert for the benefit of the coal fund. A large audience was present. A number of dinners preceded the event. The asisting artists were Maxim Karolik, tenor; Miss Aniceta Shea, soprano; Miksa Merson and Mrs. Lewis A. Armistead, pianists, and H. Wood Thompson as accompanist.

Large-scale operation of taxicabs at rates below the prevailing level is being planned by several groups in the industry, it was reported yesterday. The Hack Bureau of the Police Department now has under consideration the approval of two meters calibrated for a rate of 10 cents for the first one-third of a mile and 5 cents for each additional third.

For the first time in history, the Federal Government Intervened directly yesterday in a labor dispute in the ladies' garment industry of this city and succeeded in having postponed the threatened strike of 30,000 cloakmakers. The strike was to have been called this week as a result of the breaking off of negotiations in Washington between the union and employers over approval of a code for the industry.

Midsummer heat, intensified by high humidity, caused two deaths and five prostrations in the city yesterday. The day's maximum, 92, reached at 2 P.M., was four degrees under the high mark of June 9, the hottest day so far this Summer, and two degrees under the hottest July 24 in the Weather Bureau's history, which was in 1910.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Liquidation of many millions of bushels of grain futures was effected today on the Board of Trade here, but in a most orderly manner, and the largest part of the trading in wheat, oats and rye was above the minimum-price levels established by the officials of the Exchange.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 24 -- Making his first appearance in the metropolitan district in some time, George Von Elm paired with Don Grant, Lido president, to gain a tie in the pro-amateur tournament held at the Lido Country Club today as a prelude to the Long Island open.

Long shots had their innings at Empire City yesterday, and Filter, an 8 to 1 shot, got home first in the Equality Purse, which had the place of honor on the program. The victor, a gelded son of Sweep and Aqua Pura, carried the Howe Stable colors.

MALVERN, England, July 24 -- Bernard Shaw is still the patron saint of Sir Barry Jackson's annual Malvern festival of the drama which opened tonight. Although none of his plays, new or old, is included in this year's cycle of 400 years of British drama, Shaw himself is again one of the chief attraction.

BASLE, July 24 -- Governors of European central banks, after a meeting of the board of the Bank for International Settlements here today, returned to their countries to prepare to entrench themselves in the status quo until after the United States monetary experiment has been completed.

Fall Buying Activa Despite Break. With, more buyers In the market here than a week ago, the effect of last week's slump in stock and commodity prices wag not particularly evident in the wholesale markets here yesterday. Orders for Fall style merchandise, particularly dresses and furs, continued to be placed in good volume.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 24 -- With Miss Helen Jacobs, the national women's champion; John Hope Doeg, men's titleholder in 1930, and Frankie Parker of Milwaukee, the national clay-court champion, all making their first appearance of the year on American turf, the forty-sixth annual invitation tournament of the Sea-bright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club got under way today.

RUMSON, N.J., July 24 -- By establishing a two-stroke margin, Mrs. Leo Federman of Glen Oaks, runner-up to Miss Helen Hicks in the New York York State championship last week, led the field today in the initial eighteen-hole round of the women's New Jersey shore golf championship with a round of 83.
LONDON, July 24 -- The World Economic Conference's monetary and financial commission adopted its report in a brief public session this afternoon and adjourned.
Operators enlivened real estate trading in the metropolitan district yesterday by purchases of four apartment houses, three in the Bronx and one in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Movements of vessels follow, an dates are July 24 unless otherwise specified:

BUENOS AIRES, July 24 -- There is considerable political unrest in the Brazilian State of Sao Paulo, according to advices received here, but reports of a revolt reaching New York appear to be premature. President Getulio Vargas, however, is said to have decided to remove Waldomiro Lima as Federal Interventor in the State for political reasons and the people of Sao Paulo object to his removal.

The first twelve railroads to report not only tripled their net operating income in June, compared with June, 1932, but they showed a substantial increase, compared with June, 1931. This was the first time that an increase on a two year basis has been shown since 1929.

CHICAGO, July 24 -- Edward A. Crawford was suspended today from all privileges of the Chicago Board of Trade for "inability to meet obligations." He was registered for the firm of E.A. Crawford Co. of New York.

For the second consecutive month American foreign trade showed marked improvement in June-- a season of the year when there is usually a decline. Exports increased in value by $5,000,000, compared with a loss in the same month last year of $17,000,000. Imports made a still more favorable showing.
LONDON, July 24 -- The divergent policies of the British dominions and the mother country are developing into an open quarrel as the World Economic Conference draws to a close.

Mrs. Cornelius V. Whitney now holds the distinction of making one of the finest catches of the swordfishing season off Montauk. Her prize -- a 143 1/2-pound fighter -- was landed on Saturday about twenty miles southwest of Montauk Point.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- Slamming the offerings of the Athletics' ace hurlers, Bob Grove and George Earnshaw, to all corners of Shibe Park, the Senators today twice conquered Philadelphia to regain the lead in the American League race with a half-game advantage over the idle Yankees.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The hearing on the code of fair competition for the oil industry, practically every provision of which is a matter of controversy between the major producers, the independent producers and labor, began today with General Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, directing the proceedings.

MADRID, Tuesday, July 25 -- Arrests on a wholesale scale have been made throughout Spain during the night and are continuing early this morning. Leaders of both the extreme Right and Left parties have been gathered in by hundreds in a movement to repress what the government asserts was a plot for a conservative coup d'etat.The Syndicalist leaders also were rounded up, however.

LOS ANGELES, July 24 -- Retailating against employment of non-union sound technicians to replace strikers, 6,000 union workers were called out today from Hollywood motion-picture studios on a sympathetic strike.

Courses and lectures designed to teach volunteer women's groups in Queens the philosophy of modern social service as well as actual methods of dealing with difficult family situations are being given by Mrs. Kathleen Wehrbein, executlve director of the Family Welfare Society of Queens.

In a letter to President ROOSEVELT, published this morning, the chairman of the executive committee of the National Civil Service Reform League asks him to amend his recent Executive Order with regard to Presidential postmasters by restoring President WILSON'S requirement that the Postmaster General certify to the President the name of the highest qualified person on the eligible list.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., July 24 (AP) -- State Executives attending the annual conference of Governors here today unanimously pledged President Roosevelt "whole-hearted and active support" of the national recovery program.

GODTHAAB, Greenland, July 24 -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh intends to stay six weeks in Greenland on the aerial mapping tour he is making with Mrs. Lindbergh in the north country, but he does not intend to go to either Iceland, the Faroe Islands or Denmark, he told The Associated Press tonight.

In failing to make the first quarterly payment of $5,994.86 due yesterday to the Actors Equity Association, the Managers Protective Association, which has long been considered moribund in theatrical circles, has voided its ten-year "basic agreement" with Equity.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 24 -- Mrs. Thomas Hucknall, former Connecticut State champion, and Mrs. J.J. O'Reilly of Knollwood led the field of ninety-one players that teed off at the Woodway Country Club today in the annual women's Fairfield and Westchester open championship for the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy.

Monday, July 24, 1933. Money market was quiet., Business was light, and quotations for all classes unchanged from last week. Call loans on the Stock Exchange and in the counter trading were done at 1 per cent, Federal funds, 1/8 1/4. The money post on the Exchange opened at the usual hour of 10:40 A.M, notwithstanding the later opening for trading in stocks. Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were all steady.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- President Roosevelt opened his national re-employment drive tonight in a frank, vigorous appeal to his countrymen to subscribe to the emergency industrial code and thereby put millions back to work by Autumn.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on July 19 shows increases for the week of $22,000,000 in loans and investments, $26,000,000 in time deposits and $12,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks, and a decrease of $47,000,000 in net demand deposits.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 24 -- The annual New Jersey Centre Junior and Boys' tennis championships got under way today on the courts of the Montclair Athletic Club. Two rounds were completed.

MANCHESTER, England, July 24 (Canadian Press) -- With four wickets in hand, England was 112 runs behind the West Indies as the second test cricket match of the season continued today. Scores at close of the second day's play were 375 for the British West Indies and 263 for six for England.
HELSINGFORS, July 24 -- The hunger strike of 376 men and 113 women Coumunist prisoners in the Ekenas and Hameenlina prisons ended today with the unconditional surrender of the strikers.
LEBANON, Va., July 24 -- (AP) Former Governor Henry C. Stuart died today at his home at Elk Garden, Russell County. He had been ill for two weeks. His age was 78.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24 (AP) -- Stating he was in possession of a good clue to the identity of two men who fatally wounded Frank A. McClatchy in attempting to kidnap him, Lieutenant Clarence Duke of the Lower Merion Township police said tonight he planned to go to Newark in search of the slayers.

Only coffee futures, among the various commodities traded on local exchanges, failed to gain in yesterday's markets. Gains in some of the staples were wide in fairly heavy trading. Most cash prices were higher.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Receivers for the Wabash Railway today were asked by the Interstate Commerce Commission what, if anything, they were doing to get back "extraordinary" payments made by the railroad during 1930 and 1931 to the late William H. Williams, then president and chairman of the board of the company.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- While a steady stream of telegrams continued to pour into the offices of the National Recovery Administration pledging cooperation in the voluntary "blanket" code program, the Labor Advisory Committee of the administration met to outline possible steps to end the rising tide of discrimination against union organizational activities all over the country.

COLD SPRING, N.Y, July 24 -- An attempt to kidnap Miss Edia Neumoegen, 25 years old, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manfred L. Neumoegen of Lake Mahopac, became known today when Frank Early, 25, of this village, an ex-convict, was arraigned before Justice of the Peace Roy Christian and held without bail.

Francis Kester, ship news reporter of The Oakland (Cal.) Tribune, won first prize of $250 in a national contest sponsored by the United Artists Corporation, it was announced yesterday. The contest was restricted to newspaper men who "cover the waterfront" and was for the best true stories of maritime incidents.

CHICAGO had the all-star ball game. Chicago is going to have the East-West polo matches. Louis E. Stoddard, chairman of the executive committee of the United States Polo Association, was talking of that yesterday in the new offices of the association.

To the Editor of The New York Times: About a week ago I noted an interview with Senator Wagner in THE NEW YORK TIMES, in which the Senator had much praise to bestow upon the new Federal Home Loan Act.

Supreme Court Justice Lydon banded down an opinion yesterday giving authorities for his rulings during the trial of the suit against stockholders of the Bank of United States. The suit was brought by Joseph A. BrodericK, State Superintendent of Banks, to collect an assessment of $25 a share.

The Drive on Crime. The intensified drive by Federal agents, police and other peace officers against kidnappers and gangsters in general brought telling results yesterday. Outstanding achievements in the campaign for law and order were:

GENEVA, N.Y., July 24 (AP) -- Seventy-eight members of the Boys Crusader Band of Newark, N.J., which started out with high hopes two weeks ago 153 strong for the Chicago World's Fair, were homeward bound tonight.

Twenty-eight operators of trolley cars and buses of the Jamaica Central Railways, Inc., will receive annual "no-accident" bonuses at ceremonies tomorrow afternoon at 3:30 at the company's transportation office, New York and 114th Avenues, Jamaica, according to an announcement yesterday.

The report of the General Foods Corporation for the second quarter of 1933 shows net profits of $3,104,394 after charges and taxes, equal to 59 cents a share earned on 5,251,468 shares of no-par common stock outstanding on June 30, comparing with $3,455,325, or 66 cents a share, for the same period in 1932.

NEWARK, N.J., July 24 (AP ) -- Baltimore made it three in a row over Newark today, launching a twelve-hit attack that gained a 6-5 victory, after spotting the Bears a 4-1 advantage until the sixth inning.
General Italo Balbo and his ninety-six officers and men said their farewells to the United States yesterday and prepared to complete their historic exploit by flying back to Italy.

The chorus of the Metropolitan Opera House and Paul Althouse, tenor, sang with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, directed by Hans Lange, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. The all-Wagner program comprised the overture, grand march and Pilgrim's Chorus from "Tannhauser";

Second - guessing - the ill - fated American Davis Cup tennis expeditions during the past half dozen years has become a popular midsummer sport, but the consequences of the latest and by far the most painful setback to the United States team in Paris seem likely to have more far-reaching effect than ever before.

Samuel Walter, the government witness who first asserted and then denied that his name had been forged to an affidavit supporting a motion for a new trial for Sidney Paris, convicted bucket shop operator, changed his story again yesterday.
LATONIA, Ky., July 24 -- The Greentree Stable of Mrs. Payne Whitney completed a double at Latonia today when two juvenile fillies, Cherokee Sal and Courland, accounted for the second and third races.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- President Roosevelt will soon put in operation the Corporation of Foreign Security Holders, authorized in the Securities Act for the relief of American owners of foreign bonds.

Charles Pilatsky, Assistant District Attorney, spent yesterday reading to a trial jury in General Sessions the unpublished book that Mrs. Frances W. King is accused of submitting to Bruce Barton with an offer to "take $50,000." He expects to conclude it today.

Lord SNOWDEN'S radio address on Sunday shows again that he is one of the miserable tribe of "orthodox economists." The wretches still persist in making their opinions known, despite the way in which they have been booed off the stage by up-and-coming exponents of the new school-- the Principle of Uncertainty -- of political economy.

The Citizens Savings Bank took a mortgage from the 622 West 137th Street Corp. for $20,500. due Nov. 15, 1938. at 3 per cent for the next year and 4 per cent thereafter, on 620-622 W. 137th St., 85 feet of frontage, and this is consolidated with another mortgage for $130,000 simultaneously to the banK to form one first lien of $150,500.

A code establishing minimum wages, hours of work and trade practices was made public yesterday by the American National Retail Jewelers Association after being filed with the National Recovery Administration. The association claims to embrace in its membership more than 3,000 retail jewelry stores whose sales constitute the greater part of the total retail jewelry business in the country.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Chambers of Rock Hill, Bedford Hills, N.Y., have joined Mrs. Daniel M. Brady at the Plaza.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a refreshing and a tonic thing to read some one -- James A. Summers in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES -- who has not boiled our world dilemma down to its essence of "capitalism flowering into socialism," or "capitalism collapsing under communism."

Mayor O'Brien said last night in Warrensburg, N.Y., where he spent the week-end, that there would be no change in the city's program for new revenues, consisting of a 1 per cent increase in both the State sales tax and stock transfer tax.

The State's first Minimum Wage Board was officially and ceremoniously set in motion yesterday at the State Office Building. After industrial and legislative representatives had praised the board its members began considering mininum rates of pay for the laundry industry.

Railroad bonds led rallies in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange in yesterday's abbreviated trading, numerous other domestic and foreign bonds also rising. United Spates Government issues were steady.

MARSEILLES, July 24 -- Leon Trotsky again disappointed friends and enemies who were on the docks here to meet him today, just as he had done last year, by slipping secretly ashore before the ship that brought him from Turkey had docked.

PARIS, July 24 (AP) -- Because of the widespread criticism of Captain Bernon S. Prentice of the American Davis Cup team and the published charge that he was responsible for prolonging the Ellswrorth Vines Davis Cup match with the Britisher, Fred Perry, yesterday, until the American champion collapsed, Vines gave a signed statement to The Associated Press today, exonerating Prentice.

PARIS, July 24 (AP) -- The burden of retaining the Davis Cup, emblem of international tennis supremacy, for France was placed squarely on the sturdy shoulders of Henri Cochet today as Jean Borotra definitely declined a singles assignment.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A code of fair competition for the wool textile industry was taken up in two hearings today before A.D. Whiteside, Deputy Administrator, who, at nightfall, promised to end the inquiry tomorrow.
BERLIN, July 24 -- Chancellor Hitler's Nazis today were accused of illegal registration for yesterday's election in the Protestant churches.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Sharp opposition to the proposed amendments to the lumber industry's code of fair practice, giving the code authority the power to regulate production and fix minimum prices, developed today at the fourth session of the healings on the code before Dudley Gates, Deputy Recovery Administrator.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 24 (AP) -- Prompted by a desire to assure the safe return of Charles F. Urschel, oil millionaire, held for ransom by two machine gunners who kidnapped him from his home Saturday night. Federal authorities were called off the case tonight for twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- In a statement regarding the arrest of Roger Touhy, Edward McFadden, Willie Sharkey and Gustave Schaefer, the Departtnent of Justice said that McFadden was a well-known Chicago gangster and labor agitator and that Sharkey and Schaefer wera underworld characters.

Opposition reminiscent in bitterness of that which greeted the proposal for a city bridge-and-auto tax levy began to take form yesterday against Mayor O'Brien's later plan for an increased retail sales tax.

All speculative markets were in some confusion yesterday, but the trend was in the direction of higher prices. The Stock Exchange resumed operations on a three-hour basis in order to relieve the bookkeeping work that has been pressed upon the clerical staffs of commission houses; Chicago Board of Trade reopened after having been entirely closed on the last two business days of last week.

VIENNA, July 24 -- Police investigation of the case of Baron Werner von Alversleben, who was arrested on charges of attempting to murder Dr. Richard Steidle, Security Director of Tyrol, and plotting to assassinate Major Emil Fey, Security Minister, has revealed that official German quarters are furnishing considerable assistance to Nazi terrorists, the government charges.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- American shipbuilders today acceded reluctantly to the demands of Administrator Hugh S. Johnson of the National Recovery Act and agreed to maintain a 32-hour week in shipyards where government construction is undertaken.

PARIS, July 24 -- Four thousand motion-picture theatre owners in France, who want to import an unrestricted number of Hollywood and other foreign films, are busily mobilizing a counter-offensive to the effort of French film producers to stifle foreign competition through governmental embargoes.

The arrests in the Hamm kidnapping case again draw attention to the rapidly increasing list of abductions which have been solved. Especially since the Federal Goveminent has taken an active part in running down kidnappers, the percentage of such criminals brought to justice hag mounted rapidly.

A reply to critics of tax exemption for low-cost model housing in New York is contained in the 1933 report of the State Board of Housing, prepared for Governor Lehman and the State Legislature and now in the hands of the printer.

DEXTER, Iowa, July 24 (AP) -- Clyde Barrow,,notorious Texas outlaw, fought a machine-gun battle with police in a wooded hideaway today, and tonight was dodging over Western Iowa with airplanes, armored cars, motorcycles and automobiles -- all connected by wireless -- in hot pursuit.

For Rapid Students. WILEY POST will not be surprised if three or four years from now somebody goes around the earth in forty-eight hours in a plane equipped for blind flying. This is a prospect which cannot but delight every serious student of world affairs.
ST. LOUIS, July 24 -- Frankie Frisch, captain and second baseman of the St. Louis Cardinals since 1927, was appointed manager of the team today, succeeding Charles E. (Gabby) Street.
Falling in love is not at all the stupidest thing that mankind does and gravitation cannot be held responsible for Cupid's actions, if Professor Albert Einstein's theory of love is correct.

Arthur Stringer, whose "Marriage by Capture" was published recently by Bobbs-Merrill, has left for Labrador to gather material for his next novel, which will be serialized before publication in book form.
ST. LOUIS, July 24 -- Frankie Frisch, captain and second baseman of the St. Louis Cardinals since 1927, was appointed manager of the team today, succeeding Charles E. (Gabby) Street.
Falling in love is not at all the stupidest thing that mankind does and gravitation cannot be held responsible for Cupid's actions, if Professor Albert Einstein's theory of love is correct.

Arthur Stringer, whose "Marriage by Capture" was published recently by Bobbs-Merrill, has left for Labrador to gather material for his next novel, which will be serialized before publication in book form.

Dangers that might develop in President Roosevelt's recovery plans were outlined yesterday by Dr. A. Grenfell Price, head of St. Mark's College, University of Adelaide, South Australia. Dr. Price, who was chairman of the Emergency Committee of South Australia during the economic crisis there, lectured on Australian recovery at Columbia University in connection with the Summer session.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Mumsie, a 2-year-old daughter of Bubbling Over, racing in the colors of C. Koerner, a former jockey, got up in the last few strides to win the fifth race, a claiming affair, today at Arlington Park.
Two judges of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals decided yesterday that Jack Pleva and Harry Schwartz, election inspectors, had been convicted unfairly of fraud at the polls.

FITCHBURG, Mass., July 25 -- Miss Helen Coolidge, daughter of United States Senator Marcus A. Coolidge and Mrs. Coolidge, and Harry Hines Woodring, First Assistant Secretary of War and former Governor of Kansas, were married this noon at the home of the bride's parents in the presence of 500 guests.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 25 -- Joseph Klitch, owner of the building in which an explosion occurred in North Arlington on June 9, killing ten persons and injuring seventy-five others, and Alex Scheinzeit, president of the Atlantic Pyroxylin Company, which stored cellulose in the building, were indicted by the Bergen County grand jury today on a charge of manslaughter.

Although new dance steps are being introduced constantly by various dancing organizations, the fox trot still remains the predominant dance of America. This was conceded yesterday by officials of the Dancing Masters of America, Inc., on the second day of their golden jubilee convention and normal school at the Hotel New Yorker, where new steps are being taught.

President Roosevelt's appeal to employers to subscribe to the emergency code has created a problem, leading bankers said yesterday. A large proportion of bank employes, being in executive or managerial positions, do not come within the scope of the blanket code recently announced, and many other employes, by the nature of their work, are difficult to fit into such a code, it is pointed out.
Irving Ben Cooper, who is being considered as a possible Fusion candidate for District Attorney, described last night how he thought the office should be administered. He spoke from Station WEVD.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 25 -- Mrs. Catharine Singer Eastman of Wykagyl took the lead in the second round of the annual Women's Westchester-Fairfield open golf championship at the Woodway Country Club today. The Elizabeth Wheeler trophy, which goes to the winner, was held by Mrs. Eastman in 1931.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 25 -- With a. brilliant record of success behind her on clay courts. Baroness Maud Levi gained her most signal tennis victory of the season when she defeated Miss Carolin Babcock today.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The National Recovery Administration today concluded hearings on the wool textile and rayon weaving codes, and confronted the task of digesting the record and adjusting differences.

Alameda County, Cal. Bids have been invited for an issue of $1,000,000 Alameda County (Cal.) relief bonds dated Jan. 1, 1933, and due from 1944 to 1949. The bonds, which are part of an authorized issue of $3,000,000, are to carry interest of not more than 5 per cent, the rate to be named by the bidder in multiples of one-quarter of 1 per cent.

The European police officials who are visiting here on their way to a world crime conference in Chicago spent all yesterday morning at Police Headquarters and the Police Academy and the afternoon in individual sight-seeing. In the evening they attended a dinner at the Waldorf arranged by Mayor O'Brien.
PITTSBURGH, July 25 -- The Pirates defeated the second-place Cubs in both ends of a double-header today, 4 to 3 and 4 to 1, and got back into the thick of the National League race.

BERLIN, July 25 -- A nation-wide raid on "Communists and other enemies of the State" was staged in Germany today by order of the secret State police on the ground that, despite repression and concentration camps, the Communist menace was still acute.

Protests against city relief methods were voiced yesterday in Union Square at a meeting held as a sendoff to a group of delegates of three unemployed organizations who will present their demands to Governor Lehman today. The delegates left by automobile for Albany after the meeting, which was attended by about 100 persons.

A decrease during the last calendar year in the per capita cost of instruction in the city's public schools is shown in figures made public yesterday at the Board of Education. The figures, taken from the board's annual financial and statistical report, prepared under the direction of Frederick D. Chambers, auditor of the board, were released by Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 25 -- Mrs. Jose M. Ferrer gave a luncheon today at Barcarolle for her sister, Miss Teresa R. O'Donohue, who is visiting her.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Rodman Drake de Kay and family left yesterday to visit her parents, Rear Admiral and Mrs. Thomas T. Craven, at Annapolis, Md. She will return after the marriage of her sister, Miss Olga von Klinkofstrom Craven, to Lionel Glenn Anderson on Aug. 5.

Several leases on Park Avenue were included in the list of apartment rentals reported by brokers yesterday. Mrs. Julian Gray rented her apartment in the cooperative building at 1,105 Park Avenue to Joseph L. Ray, vice president of the Singer Sewing Machine Company, through Stafford Port.
BERLIN, July 25 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement of July 22 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

BUENOS AIRES, July 25 -- Withdrawal of the Chaco negotiations from the League of Nations and resubmission to the ABCP powers -- Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru -- is the outcome of Bolivian diplomatic initiative at Rio de Janeiro de signed to repudiate the League's action in sending an investigating commission to Chaco without Bolivia's consent, according to well-informed sources in the Latin-American diplomatic corps.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 25 -- Roger Touhy, head of a gang that has operated for several years in the northwest part of Cook County, Ill., and three of his associates, charged with kidnapping William Hamm Jr., in St. Paul, Minn., last month, were arraigned here today before United States Commissioner Floyd E. Jenkins.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 (AP) -- Executives attending the annual conference of Governors here were lavish today in their praise of the address of President Roosevelt to the people on the national recovery program. Here are comments of several Governors:

A substantial increase in earnings was reported by the Procter Gamble Company for the fiscal year ended on June 30. The net profit after depreciation, interest, Federal taxes, advertising and special introductory work, was $10,811,325.
MANILA, July 25 -- The entire Hawes Independence Law controversy was plunged into a welter of personalities today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 25 -- The final "garden pops" concert by unemployed musicians at the Westchester County Centre will be held tomorrow night. Mrs. Marion Downes, sponsor of the concerts, which began June 28, explained last night, when she announced the closing, that the orchestra would have been able to play to increasing audiences through August "if Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians had not interfered."

SEWANEE, Tenn., July 25 -- Solemn and impressive ceremonies were held here today on the fortieth anniversary of the elevation of the Right Rev. Thomas F. Gailor as a Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church and his twenty-fifth year as chancellor of the University of the South.
ST. LOUIS, July 25 -- The Cardinals made Frankie Frisch's debut as manager a success today by defeating the Reds, 3 to 1.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with interest the letter of Benno Lewinson, suggesting possible relief to mortgagors in the entry of tremendous deficiency judgments. The inequitable situation of the mortgagee in his foreclosure action obtaining both the land and the huge deficiency judgment, at times equaling the amount of his mortgage, is apparent.

Leasing of retail space in various parts of Manhattan and manufacturing quarters in the midtown west side garment district formed an important part of the realty trading reported by brokers yesterday.

The improvement in the steel industry during the second quarter of the year enabled the United States Steel Corporation to show from operations in the quarter an income of $4,881,554 before depreciation, interest charges and overhead expenses of its ore properties, it was announced yesterday.
Eleven properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were bought in at foreclosure sales yesterday, all the parcels going to the plaintiffs. The results follow:

Commonwealth and Southern Corporation-Year ended June 30: Net income after depreciation, charges and taxes, $9,271,404, equal after preferred dividends to slightly less than 1 cent a share on the common stock, compared with $18,611,719, or 28 cents a common share, in preceding year.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Berenice Urschel named a group of intermediaries today and also offered to deal directly herself with the kidnappers of her husband, Charles F. Urschel, wealthy oil man.

Abraham Lincoln was the most sincerely thoughtful man the United States has produced and probably he wisest in sympathy and understanding, according to Herbert Agar, whose book, "The People's Choice," will be published today by Houghton Mifflin Company.

Fishing offshore in recent days has provided some of the best sport of the season as was indicated yesterday by the report of White Cap, a veteran salt water fisherman. He reports that on Monday the Sachem, Captain Jack Martin, out of Sheepshead Bay, fished off Manasquam and the Klondike banks and wrecks and got an unusual catch of porgies, bluefish and sea bass.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Nothing will hamper the President's program of industrial recovery and impede his aim to take half of the nation out of "four years of economic hell," National Recovery Administrator Hugh S. Johnson declared tonight over a National Broadcasting Company network.

Sales of "Anthony Adverse" by Hervey Allen totaled 8,414 copies yesterday. Farrar Rinehart, publishers, believed the total approached a record for a single day's re-orders. The total sale of the book to date is approximately 90,000 and the printing of the second hundred thousand has been ordered.

GOODWOOD, England, July 25 -- Taking the lead at the start and never relinquishing it. Captain A. S. Wills's 4-year-old Pharacre today captured the historic Steward's Cup Handicap. The victor is by Pharos out of Sweet Acre.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Due to circumstances, the daily life of the Roosevelt administration thus far has been expedient. It has had to live from day to day without much advance planning. Many of the plans which it has made, or to which if has subscribed -- the London conference, for example -- have had to be altered during the very process of execution.

REGINA, Sask., July 25 (Canadian Press) -- Lieut. Commander Frank Hawks arrived here at 8:10 P.M., Mountain Standard Time (11:10 New York Daylight Saving Time), completing a non-stop flight from New York. He covered the 1,620 miles in 10 hours, 42 minutes.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Mountains tremble and produce emeralds, sapphires and rubies, rare gases and precious elements such as radium, the sixteenth international geological congress was told here today.

A plan of reorganization of the National Gas and Electric Corporation dated July 1 has been addressed to holders of the company's securities by the reorganization committee headed by Arthur H. Gilbert of Spencer Trask Co. It provides for the ownership of 61 1/2 per cent of the common stock of a new corporation by the first mortgage bondholders of the company, formerly controlled by the American Commonwealths Power Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A series of conferences between the representatives of the union and the employers in the coat and suit industry here today failed to break the deadlock on the points that blocked accord on Sunday, when negotiations ended and all factions returned to New York.

Chinese civil government is being reestablished in the demilitarized zone set up by the truce with Japan last Spring. In another few weeks Chinese authority will run clear back to the Great Wall, but not, of course, beyond it into Jehol. That province is now under control by Japan for as long as are the three original Manchurian provinces.

The superior mud runner Condescend, owned and trained by J. F. Richardson, was a decisive victor in the featured Dexterous Purse at Empire City yesterday. Through going as thick and wet as pea soup, the 5-year-old son of Snob II won easily.

Net income of the General Motors Corporation for the quarter ended June 30 was eight times as great as in the same quarter last year. Yesterday's preliminary report was viewed in Wall Street as a major reflection of the manner in which increased public buying has improved the position of a leading industry.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 (AP) -- Assurances of complete cooperation in his "war against the enemy of fear, despondency and depression" were given to President Roosevelt tonight by Governors James Rolph Jr. of California and John Garland Pollard of Virginia in responding to the President's message.

A new company will be formed to take over the assets and liabilities of the United Cigar Stores Company of America and its subsidiaries, under a reorganization plan announced last night. A committee has been working on the plan since the company went into bankruptcy on Aug. 29, 1932.

Unemployment insurance for New York State for which the State, the employer and the employe, respectively, would provide a fund, was predicted yesterday by Mrs. Herbert E. Miter, treasurer of the Republican Housing Conference and a director of United Neighborhood Houses of Greater New York.

Slight increases in the number of failures in the retail, manufacturing and other commercial groups featured business defaults for the week ended July 20, in comparison with the previous week, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., July 25 (AP) -- Conflicting claims on the effects of a strike called among sound technicians in the movie industry were made today, producers insisting that their schedules were proceeding under somewhat reduced programs and one union executive contending that all but two of 794 cameramen had walked out.

The production of "Murder at the Vanities" struck a snag yesterday when difficulties arose between Earl Carroll and the union of scenic artists. The latter declined to allow the building of sets until debts owed by the producer to some of its members had been paid.

With his hands and feet tied together behind his back and his mouth gagged by a strip of bedsheeting that had caused his death by strangulation, the body of Dr. E. Warren Sylla, 65 years old, a well-to-do dentist, was found yesterday morning on his bedroom floor in his apartment at 21 East Ninetieth Street.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Roosevelt tonight greeted by radio his "old associates and new friends" assembled at the Governors' conference in San Francisco. He took occasion in his brief address to praise the Governors for their cooperation "in the business of lifting this country from economic chaos" and to outline briefly some of the problems to be solved by mutual State-Federal action.

A recreation, haven for children, far above the dangers of congested east-side districts, was demonstrated yesterday by New York's first roof playground at Public School 31, Monroe and Gouverneur Streets. Operation of the centre was made possible this Summer by a gift from Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger in memory of the late George W. Ochs Oakes.

BERLIN, July 25 -- The Boerse recovered today from its sinking spell of yesterday. Both stocks and bonds displayed an improved tone. The turnover, however, remained small. In one case a sale amounting to only 3,000 marks caused a drop of 7 per cent in that particular stock.

Gross daily average crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,673,350 barrels, compared with 2,633,150 barrels in the previous week, an increase of 40,200 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A gain of 33,800 barrels in the average daily output in Oklahoma was the most important change.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mayor O'Brien has stated with brutal frankness the issue before the extra session of the Legislature. In a sentence it is, "We bosses must stand together." He wants to evade responsibility for levying the new taxes which New York City must have to meet its bills, to pay its employes, to provide funds for the unemployed and to take care of the interest on its obligations.

STOCKHOLM, July 25 -- America's touring track and field stars annexed five events and lost two against Swedish athletes today at Vasteras. The American setbacks occurred in the 400-meter relay and the discus throw.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 25 -- Eagerness of Brazil to enter into a new trade agreement with the United States was expressed today by Oswaldo Aranha, the Minister of Finance.
Joe Judge, veteran first baseman, who started the season as a Dodger regular, yesterday received his unconditional release from the Brooklyn club.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., July 25 -- Two boys, 12 and 11 years old, were killed and a third, 7, was critically injured here today when they were struck by an express train while they were walking along the tracks on their way home from a beach.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A year's extension in the time within which options may be exercised on the 2,000,000 bales of government-owned cotton by farmers contracting for acreage reduction this year was granted today by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.
OCEANSIDE, Cal., July 25 -- Seven bodies were taken from the wreckage of an army bombing plane, which dropped a wing and crashed when 1,000 feet above the southeastern city limits today at noon.

Buyers Here Show Increase. Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a considerable increase over the number reported in the previous week and for the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

Candy manufacturers and dispensers, motion picture operators and wardrobe concessionaires will pay new taxes to the city, under the terms of three ordinances passed yesterday by the Board of Aldermen.

Prince Bishnu of Nepal, accompanied by Colonel the Rajah Bahadur Singh; Mayor James M. Curley of Boston, Mrs. Paul G. Curley and Miss Mary Curley are among those arriving today from Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 25 -- Mrs. Frederick Kellogg Hollister held a meeting at her Drew Lane home today to plan for the annual fashion show and bridge at the Maidstone Club for the benefit of the East Hampton Settlement House.

TOKYO, July 25 -- The terrorism in Tokyo on May 15, 1932, was intended to create a military government under Lieut. Gen. Sadao Araki, the War Minister, according to a statement today at the court-martial of eleven naval cadets accused of implication.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- The National Corn and Hog Producers Committea tonight adopted an emergency program calling for the removal of 500,000,000 pounds of pork and pork products from the American market by Jan. 1 to increase prices under the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, notified the representatives of American and foreign flag ship lines yesterday that he was prepared to formulate a code of working conditions for pier workers throughout the country without the assistance of the lines, if they refused to cooperate.

WASHINGTON, D.C., July 25 -- Russian trade possibilities were the subject of a conference late this afternoon between Raymond Moley, Assistant Secretary of State, and Smith W. Brookhart, former Senator and now special foreign trade adviser to the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 25 -- "All change probably arose in the first place because of women," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said in an address before 7,000 persons in the amphitheatre here tonight, calling for a united fight by women for the recovery program.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP) -- The Senators recorded a 5-to-1 victory over the Athletics today, in a contest that was shortened to five innings by rain, and increased their lead over the idle Yankees to a full game.

PARIS, July 25 -- After seeing the "taxation extremes" to which Parisians submit docilely, Controller Charles W. Berry of New York has concluded that New Yorkers really do not appreciate how well off they are.

Early gains in some of the commodity markets failed yesterday to hold against light profit-taking, and most of the staples traded on local exchanges closed irregularly lower for the day. The trading volume also decreased. Most cash prices were higher.

ALBANY, July 25 -- Threats of a strike by 40,000 dairy farmers drew from the Milk Control Board today the statement that "now appears to be the time to learn whether these matters are to be controlled by reason and the forms of law or by threats of violence and lawlessness."

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 25 -- Miss Mary McElroy, daughter of City Manager H.F. McElroy, took the stand in Circuit Court here today and pointed out Walter H. McGee, former Oregon convict, as the leader of a band of kidnappers who seized her last May and held her a prisoner until a $30,000 ransom was paid.

The amnesty bill providing that all Cubans charged with or convicted of revolutionary or anti-administration activities since Jan. 1, 1927, shall be pardoned promises to clear the political atmosphere and contribute to the success of the mediation of Ambassador WELLES.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Employment of between 5,000,000 and 6,000,000 new workers before Labor Day was predicted tonight by Hugh S. Johnson, Industrial Administrator, on the basis of responses received to President Roosevelt's appeal for immediate adoption of the national industrial code.

ST. LOUIS, July 25 -- Michael Musiala, a farmer living near Madison, Ill., made a complete confession today of his part in the kidnapping of August Luer of Alton, Ill., according to Joseph Gerk, Chief of Police.
DACHAU, Bavaria, July 25 -- The name of this idyllic little town, situated about a half-hour's automobile ride from Munich, has become a word of dread throughout Bavaria.

LOS ANGELES, July 25 -- One hundred men, women and children, including many school teachers and students from New York and vicinity, are stranded in Lincoln Park auto camp here, wondering how they will get back home, while the Rev. Enos Jansen, their leader and president of the Coast-to-Coast Collegiate Camp Tours inc., is being investigated by Deputy District Attorney Woodhead.

HAVANA, July 25 (AP) -- The House of Representatives, with only three negative votes, tonight passed a government amnesty bill covering all political crimes committed, since Jan. 1, 1927. The Senate passed the measure yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Three New York concerns offering securities with a total market value of $2,750,000 were among ten companies submitting prospectuses to the Federal Trade Commission today in compliance with the Securities Act.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

Another chapter in the campaign against racketeers in the Bronx was written yesterday in the Bronx Court of Special Sessions, where Joseph Weiner, reputed boss racketeer of the poultry business was found guilty of conspiracy to coerce.

Mr. and Mrs. H. Murray Jacoby gave a reception yesterday afternoon in the roof garden of the St. Moritz for His Highness, Ras Desta Demtu, son-in-law of Emperor Haile Selassie I of Abyssinia. Mr. Jacoby was special Ambassador to Ethiopia for the coronation of the Emperor.

BERLIN, July 25 -- Wilhelm Furtwaengler, conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, Germany's most celebrated one, has been making persistent efforts to obtain the appearance in the next musical season of the usual representative "foreign artists," but without success.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 25 -- Another consistent round of golf enabled Mrs. Leo G. Federman of Glen Oaks to maintain the lead in the women's New Jersey shore championship at the end of thirty-six holes of medal play today.

Man's First Home. East Africa is brought forward as the cradle of the human race, in a speech at the international congress of geologists in Washington. The proposition will be stigmatized at Berlin as another piece of anti-Nazi propaganda, designed to suggest that Nordic-Aryans are only bleached Negroes; unless it should turn out that the exact spot in East Africa where mankind was born is the former German East Africa.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Roosevelt is determined to throw the full force of the government behind the war on armed crime.

Speculative activity on the Stock Exchange was curtailed again yesterday and the turnover ran at the rate of only a little more than 1,000,000 shares an hour. That would, of course, have been enormous business a year or so ago, but by comparison with the volume of the recent past it shows up poorly.

With trading still on a limited scale, railroad bonds continued yesterday to be the feature in bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. Most issues in this group continued to advance. Foreign obligations were steady at higher levels, while domestic corporation bonds were irregular.

After advancing slightly, prices on the Cotton Exchange were set back nearly $2 a bale yesterday and ended with losses of 6 to 13 points, or 30 to 65 cents a bale. With the exception of the last half-hour, when there was professional liquidation, the market was quiet.

When F. El Khedidi, a well-to-do merchant of Tunis, who arrived yesterday on the French liner Ile de France wearing his picturesque Arab costume with a red fez with a long black tassel and the gold diamond studded Order of "Officier of Tunisie" on his breast, was informed that he must go to Ellis Island, he burst into tears.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 25 -- Fred Davis, 18-year-old assistant caddie master at the Rye Country Club, shot par golf in an extra nine-hole playoff with Peter Pennucci, Fenimore, to annex the annual Westchester caddie masters' title today at Green Meadow.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A demand for drastic regulation of the major oil companies in the "lease and agency" practice, which it was declared threatens to destroy thousands of independent gasoline and oil dealers, featured today's hearing on the code of fair competition for the oil industry.

LONDON, July 25 -- Eight early love letters that Napoleon wrote to Josephine, from the late Lord Rosebery's library, were sold at Sotheby's today for L4,400 to Ben Maggs, a London bookseller, after stern competition from Gabriel Wells, a New Yorker, and a number of eager French bidders.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, July 25 -- The largest dry dock in the world, built for the 73,000-ton Cunard liner that is now lying unfinished on her stocks at Clydeside, will be opened by the King tomorrow.

The plan of rearrangement of capitalization of the Associated Gas and Electric Company, dated May 15, has been modified in order to give debenture holders of the company who temporarily prefer option No. 1 the additional right at any time after Dec. 31, 1938.

Italy's air armada, under the command of General Italo Balbo, left New York yesterday almost as dra- matically as it arrived. Group by group the wide-winged planes took off from Jamaica Bay, beginning at 10 o'clock, and sixteen minutes later were circling overhead.

Plans for the canoe sailing races for the International Challenge Cup were completed yesterday, and the way is now clear to restore to competition one of the most historic trophies in international marine sport.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The organization upon which will fall the responsibility for carrying out the provisions of the $3,300,000,000 Federal aid features of the National Recovery Act was practically completed late today when Secretary Ickes announced the names of the ten regional advisers.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 25 -- Four gunmen late today overtook an automobile in which two Kanawha County deputy sheriffs were taking a convicted armed robber to the State penitentiary at Moundsville, killed one of the deputies, wounded the other and escaped with the prisoner, who also was shot in the rain of bullets.

The Citizens' Budget Commission offered to Mayor O'Brien yesterday its solution of the deadlock between the city and the State over methods of raising relief funds. It suggested issues of State relief bonds amounting to $200,000,000.

LONDON, July 25 -- The bureau, or steering committee, of the World Economic Conference decided this afternoon to recommend it be entrusted with the direction of work during an indefinite recess and the decision as to a date when the conference shall reassemble.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The flood of messages pledging support for his blanket, minimum wages, maximum working hours program which began pouring in on the President last night after his radio speech was continuing tonight. Already numbering more than 10,000, they have convinced him that his program will become operative throughout the country.

Opposition to Mayor O'Brien's plan for an increased sales tax, designed to lift his administration from its financial difficulties, continued to grow yesterday. It was announced that not only New York City merchants but also organized labor and up-State business men would mass their forces against the proposal.

The city convention of the Socialist party will reconvene tonight at 8 o'clock in the People's House, 7 East Fifteenth Street, to name a candidate for Mayor and other city offices. Norman Thomas, it was said, continues reluctant to accept the nomination again and belief was expressed that some other candidate would be picked, possibly former Assemblyman Charles Solomon of Brooklyn.
The Mollisons are not through with long-distance flying, they said yesterday afternoon in their suite at the Plaza Hotel after nearly eighteen hours of refreshing sleep.
