MANCHESTER, England, July 25 (Canadian Press) -- The second test cricket match between England and the touring British West Indies ended today in a draw. Scores were: West Indies 375 and 225, England 374. The time limit did not permit England to take a second innings.

Charles J. Lubin, assistant postmaster here, announced yesterday that beginning tomorrow all letter carriers would begin the delivery of blank certificates of compliance with the National Recovery Act codes to establishments having three or more employes.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 25 -- Thomas Hitchcock Jr. rearranged the line-ups for the Eastern team polo test match at Bostwick Field today and the result was a tie score. The game was one of the best the season has yet produced.

John De Witt Sterry, who died at South Poland, Me., on June 13, bequeathed $25,000 to the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, 201 East Sixty-first Street, for the establishment of the "George E. Sterry Dole," the income to be used to supply free eyeglasses and spectacles to persons too poor to buy them.

DETROIT, July 25 (AP) -- The Tigers opened their home stand today with a 9-to-3 victory over the Browns. The home team batters fattened their averages with fifteen hits from the offerings of Hadley and Gray. McDonald worked the closing inning, but yielded no hits.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- On the eve of opening of bids for the largest individual naval building program in the country's history, the National Recovery Administration still held the shipbuilders' code in abeyance tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Characterizing the "market racket" as second only to the "kidnapping racket," Senator Thomas of Oklahoma this afternoon urged government publication of "the reasonable value" of stocks listed on the New York and other great security exchanges.

Helen Broderick, comedienne, will be co-starred in "As Thousands Cheer," the Irving Berlin-Moss Hart revue which is coming to the Music Box in September. Others who will be starred in the show are Marilyn Miller and Clifton Webb.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 25 -- Even without help from the wind, he Lido course managed to do more than hold its own against the 120 golfers who teed off in the Long Island Open championship today. Only one contestant managed to break the par figures of 72.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 25 -- The executive committee of the Westchester County Republican Committee and the party leaders of the county's cities and towns met here today and elected a temporary committee of three to direct the party's affairs in Westchester.

George G. Berry, son of Controller Charles W. Berry, was promoted yesterday to the position of city bond salesman at a salary of $15 a day. His father is in Europe studying municipal finance on an expense allowance from the city.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 25 -- John R. Wing of St. Andrews carded 77 -- 8 -- 69 at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club today to win the low net prize in Class A of the Metropolitan Golf Association one-day handicap golf tournament. He also was the only one of the eighty-five starters to play the eighteen holes in less than 80.

The first move by a leading motor car manufacturer to coordinate the shipments of its products between the highways and the railways is under consideration by the Ford Motor Company, it was disclosed in industrial circles yesterday.

ROME, July 25 -- Premier Goemboes of Hungary arrived in Rome this evening for a stay of three days, during which he will have a number of important conferences with Premier Mussolini and other leading Italian statesmen. He is accompanied by Foreign Minister Kanya and four political and economic experts.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 25 -- Zell Eaton of Oklahoma City, a 19-year-old youngster, romped off with the Western amateur golf championship's qualifying test today with a thirty-six hole total of 72 -- 69 -- 141.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- A slowing up of employment gains in July was reported tonight by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, on the basis of preliminary trade union figures.

General Italo Balbo, radioing from his flagship I-Balb, sent farewell messages of thanks to Federal and municipal officials for the entertainment and consideration he and the personnel of his flying fleet had received while in the United States.

ALBANY, July 25 -- Only the firm hand of Governor Lehman can prevent the extraordinary session of the Legislature convening at 2 P.M. tomorrow from losing its way and the program to provide New York City with funds for relief from going on the rocks.

The fusion nomination for Mayor last night apparently lay between former Representative F.H. La Guardia, Republican, and former Assemblyman Langdon W. Post, Democrat. Former Governor Charles S. Whitman, chairman of the Republican Mayoralty Committee, was said to favor Mr. Post.

STILL up there and not a bit dizzy on account of the attitude, the Giants will swing into action on their own Harlem lawn this afternoon with the jolly Dodgers as their guests. This is a great race in the National League -- and not a bad race in the American League, either -- but the Giants still have those four pitchers, haven't they? That makes the outlook bright for Terry's terriers.

Jersey City's tax sale, scheduled for Aug. 16, affecting 12,000 parcels of property, was postponed indefinitely yesterday. This action followed a conference of the city commission called by Mayor Frank Hague within a few hours of his return from a vacation abroad.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Industrial activity increased rapidly in June, as in the two preceding months, and in the first half of July there was a further advance, despite the usual seasonal tendency toward a slump, the Federal Reserve Board announced today in its monthly review of business developments.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 25 -- The defeat of John Dietz of Summit, top-seeded player, by Seymour Galina of Newark featured play in the junior division of the New Jersey centre tennis championship today at the Montclair Athletic Club.

Wiley Post was the guest of honor yesterday at a luncheon given by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce at the Hotel Roosevelt. In a speech that was long for him -- ten minutes -- he made known his plans to attain new record speeds and suggested that at high altitudes his plane might reach "several hundred miles an hour -- perhaps 500."
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

LONDON, July 25 -- In an editorial in The London Times tonight there was sent to President Roosevelt a message of hope and support as earnest and friendly as any he could receive from his most loyal followers.

BERLIN, July 25 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency) -- The Jewish Telegraphic Agency was informed through the United States Consulate General here today that the German Government had lifted its prohibition and granted permission to the organization to resume its foreign news service, permitting its correspondents here to resume sending out news of events in Germany.

CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- Warren Wright's Some Pomp, somewhat overlooked in the wagering, won the Winona Purse at Arlington Park today. The 3-to-5 favorite, Wise Daughter, from the stables of Fred Burton, ran out of the money.

After extending its advance in the first few hours of trading, the share market turned weak yesterday afternoon and closed with average losses of more than a point. The wheat market, which operated under rigid restrictions, showed substantial net gains as did corn and other grains.

The President asked in his radio address on Monday night that no one "cavil" at his announcement of plans and hopes. Nobody will wish to. If he desires a return of prosperity by any or all means that may be devised, the country desires it even more ardently. Mr. ROOSEVELT does not need to preach to those who are already converted.

SHEDIAC, N.B., July 25 -- Lusty cries of "Welcome Balbo," mingled with the "Bienvenue" and the "Vive" of the French as the commander of the Italian air armada led his fleet down to a resting place on the waters of Shediac Bay this afternoon, on their homeward flight after their good-will expedition to America.

President Roosevelt received pledges of support in response to his appeal to industry to speed national recovery by increase in wages and reduction in employes' hours from concerns in industrial centres throughout the country yesterday, according to dispatches to The Associated Press.

The Affiliated Dress Manufacturers, Inc., employing some 4,500 workers, presented a code to the National Recovery Administration yesterday. This is the third code to be presented for the dress industry, others having been submitted by the Association of Dress Manufacturers and the National Dress Manufacturers Association.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Grain exchange representatives today agreed upon important changes toward stabilizing prices of their commodities and the elimination of wild speculation.

ALBANY, July 25 -- Stirred by the spread of kidnapping, which culminated in this area in the seizure of John J. O'Connell Jr., Governor Lehman has decided to present to the extraordinary session of the Legislature, opening tomorrow, a program of legislation designed to strike at the crime.

Although the stock market's activity yesterday continued to run it a level far less than the average luring last week, the New York Stock Exchange, which reduced its trading hours from five to three on Monday, took other measures yesterday to diminish the strain on hard-pressed brokers and their employes.
Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, released yesterday the following information pertaining to the taxes imposed under the Agricultural Adjustment Act with respect to cotton:

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Employers who are under contract to unions will be expected to reduce the number of hours for industrial workers to thirty-five a week, if they accept the voluntary blanket agreement proposed by President Roosevelt as an emergency measure to stimulate employment until specific codes are adopted, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, said today.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- President Roosevelt said today he had not decided on the proposal that the Treasury issue long-term bonds in connection with the Aug. 15 financing, when $469.089,000 in 4 per cent certificates will be retired.

In the eager and hopeful drive to make the Recovery Act a success it is inevitable that exaggerated statements and predictions should be made. One of them is that it is make or break for this country within the next sixty days. It has been said, in effect, that the Industrial Recovery Act must save us, or nothing else can.

ALBANY, July 26. -- The opening moments of the special session of the Legislature today were marked by a sharp debate over a resolution in the Senate placing New York on record as favoring the expenditure of $27,500,000 of Federal funds for improving the barge canal.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The administrative organization to direct expenditure of the remainder of the $3,300,000,000 public works fund was completed today with the appointment of three citizens as advisers for all the States excepting Texas which obtained four.

KANSAS CITY, July 26 (AP). -- The case of Walter H. McGee, former Oregon convict, who is charged with kidnapping Miss Mary McElroy, 25, daughter of the City Manager, was given to a Circuit Court jury late today. The State demanded a death penalty verdict.

Four organizations of business men, including virtually all the shippers and consignees of goods in New York, joined yesterday in a letter demanding that the transportation companies doing business in the Port of New York put an end to the alleged loaders' racket on the piers.

ALBANY, July 26. -- A definite parting of the ways between Governor Lehman and the Tammany-controlled administration of New York City, marked the opening today of the extraordinary session of the Legislature to enact measures to ease the city's financial straits.

ST. LOOTS, July 26. -- Rogers Hornsby, erstwhile firebrand of the National League, today signed a contract to pilot the St. Louis Browns. He immediately announced plans to create a fighting ball club and to be a playing manager.

The fusion group headed by former Governor Charles S. Whitman stood ready last night to name Robert Moses, former Secretary of State and intimate friend of Alfred E. Smith, for the fusion nomination for Mayor. Unless blocked by protests from the outside or by the refusal of the prospective candidate, this action will be taken at a meeting at the Lawyers Club today.

The North American Continent might be one country today had it not been for the persecution after the American Revolution of those loyal to the British crown, Lewis Einstein asserts in his book, "Divided Loyalties," just published by Houghton Mifflin Company.

BERLIN, July 26. -- The Boerse suffered a reaction today, which was interpreted in the light of preparations for month-end settlements. It was noted that the public is still out of the market despite optimistic reports from the economic front.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The issue of a closed or open shop in the men's clothing industry was brought forcibly to the fore as today's hearing ended on rival codes submitted by opposing factions in the industry.
Charles Solomon, a Brooklyn lawyer and former Socialist Assemblyman, received the Socialist party nomination for Mayor last night at the party's city convention in the Rand School.

Encouraged by the Industrial progress shown in the reports of important companies, the share market moved confidently upward yesterday but in trading that fell far short of the daily average of the last few weeks.
Several houses and two "taxpayers" changed hands in New Jersey yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 26 (AP). -- Facing light competition from a group of Swedish athletes, the touring track and field stars from the United States made a clean sweep of six events in a meet at Surahammar tonight.

LONDON, July 26. -- The whole of the business of the House of Commons was suddenly swept aside tonight while for hours, in a sweltering heat, members of all parties roared protests against three Scotland Yard detectives.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The next important feature of the National Recovery Act, the section getting aside $25,000,000 to create "subsistence homesteads" for par- tially employed heads of families, will be set in motion as quickly as Secretary Ickes can complete a definite working plan for the experiment.

Wall Street, even the brokerage houses, welcomed the slower rate of speculative operations yesterday. The 2,000,000-share day on the Stock Exchange, although it came about because of the three-hour market, gave confidence to the trading community and encouraged the belief that the storm had blown itself out.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The Agricultural Adjustment Administration has decided that the rules of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange provide adequate restrictions and will not seek further tions, and will not seek further curbs on speculative transactions in that market.

The epilogue of a thrilling waterfront drama was written yesterday when Coast Guard boats and an army lifting barge salvaged the destroyed rum boat Oblay in Sheepshead Bay. The Oblay, a fast launch, low-lying in the water and colored gray, had occupied the attention of Coast Guards since 2 o'clock last Monday morning and the crew of the Patrol 2292, in command of Lieutenant Brooks, breathed sighs of relief when the job was finished.

For the second successive week production of steel ingots has declined and demand for finished steel has continued to taper, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age. The publication reports, however, that the market for steel scrap, always considered a sensitive barometer, has risen to a new high level for the year, prices having been raised in virtually all market centres except Chicago and St. Louis.

Yesterday's news included distinctly favorable reports from two major industries in the field of transportation. The first twenty railways to file returns for June showed a gross income 16 per cent above that for the same month last year. But because of large economies which have been made in operating costs, the comparison of net income is still more favorable.

Real estate trading in this city yesterday was dominated again by contracts for space in commercial buildings. Brokers' reports for the past few days indicate that business rentals constitute the major part of their new business, with an apparently increasing demand for retail scores.

The prosperity drive of the Federal Government under the National Recovery Act will be launched officially in the metropolitan area today under the direction of the New York office of the Department of Commerce.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 26. -- The Lenox Horse Show will open Friday at 9:30 A.M., at the Hanna Farm, and will continue for two days. John Matthews, secretary and treasurer, has received 142 entries in forty-seven classes. Flowing Gold, for three years American champion saddle mare, owned by Mrs. Florence Dibble of Old Town Farm, Newburyport, Mass., will be exhibited.

A request that the city apply at once for Federal funds under the National Industrial Recovery Act to develop more than 3,000 acres of unused park lands was sent yesterday to Mayor O'Brien by Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Secretary Swanson's policy of "a navy second to none under the terms of the London Naval Treaty" was launched today when bids for construction of twenty-one fighting craft were opened. It was the largest number of vessels ever sought in American naval history in a single mass bidding.

DETROIT, July 26 (AP). -- The Tigers won a free-hitting contest from the Browns today, 9 to 7. Although Tommy Bridges yielded thirteen hits, he won the game just before he grave way to Elon Hogsett by hitting a three-bagger with the bases full in the seventh.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 26. -- Stricken with acute appendicitis, former Senator David Baird Jr. of New Jersey underwent an emergency operation here at the Cooper Hospital this afternoon. For about two weeks he had been complaining of pains in his side.

BARCELONA, July 26. -- United States Consul General Claude Dawson has made energetic representations to the civil authorities concerning alleged mistreatment by Barcelona policemen of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Peterzell of Philadelphia, who have come to tour Spain by automobile.
New York's rival National League baseball clubs sent each other along In different directions yesterday on the pennant trail.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Wholesale prices increased about 1.2 per cent during the week ended July 22, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. This compares with an advance of 2.50 per cent in the previous week. The index number for the week ended July 22 was 69.7, as compared with 68.9 for the week ended July 15.

BALTIMORE, July 26. -- In a copyrighted dispatch from its Washington correspondent The Baltimore Sun says today that word has reached Washington and that overtures have been made by the Pennsylvania Railroad to the Baltimore Ohio for a merger of the two properties in the interest of economy and efficiency.
SEABRIGHT, N. J., July 26. -- After two days of lull, the storm broke about the heads of the mighty today in the invitation turf court tournament of the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- With the greatest peace-time "prosperity mobilization" the United States has known beginning tomorrow, President Roosevelt indicated today that the 17,000 responses to his appeal for the adoption of the blanket code assured the success of the Industrial Recovery program and re-employment of thousands of men within a very few weeks.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 26. -- The will of Benjamin Baker, editor of The Annalist, on file in Surrogate's Court here today, leaves the residue of his estate in equal shares to his three children. Mrs. Lydia C. Lamb of Concord, Mass., and Miss Frances Palfrey Baker and David Baker, both of Hartsdale.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The reactions in the stock and commodities markets last week will have served a good purpose should the result on the public be such as to cause them to reflect. The present is a good time to consider carefully just where the influences generated by NRA are likely to lead us.
ALBANY, N.Y., July 26 (AP). Jersey City won both games of today double-header from Albany by scores of 5 to 2 and 4 to 2.

LOS ANGELES, July 26. -- Collapse of the strike of movie technicians, which has partially paralyzed the motion-picture industry, was indicated tonight when union leaders dispatched word to Pat Casey, labor contact man for the producers, asking immediate arbitration.
MANAGUA, July 26. -- Pedro Altamirano, Augosto C. Sandino's chief General, and his two sons were assassinated by unidentified enemies a few days ago near Bocay in the Department of Jinotega.

Formation of the New York Buying Office Association and the development of a program under the National Industrial Recovery Act were decided upon yesterday at a meeting of a tentative executive committee representing leading group and resident buying offices here.

LONDON, July 26. -- The United States will stoutly champion in the closing meeting of the World Economic Conference tomorrow the wisdom of continuing resolutely to try to solve the world's ills by conferences of nations. At a time when Premier Mussolini, David Lloyd George and others are demanding a ban on conferences, Cordell Hull and James M. Cox will defend this method and counter-attack sharply against isolationism.

LONDON, July 26. -- Professor Albert Einstein listened from the distinguished strangers' gallery in the House of Commons today when a bill was introduced extending the opportunities for Jews living in other countries to become citizens of the British Empire.

DACHAU, Bavaria, July 26. -- The educational concentration camps of Nazi Germany apparently are destined to become permanent institutions, designed to crush in the bud any opposition and teach the misguided the only true national religion.

The little town of Chalon-sur-Saone has settled down to normal life after having paraded around the statue of JOSEPH NICEPHORE NIEPCE in its public square and crowded into the unpretentious museum where a few relics of his inventive activity are preserved. For NIEPCE, who shares with DAGUERRE the honor of having discovered photography, died a hundred years ago in near-by Gras.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Pressing for a united front, General Johnson went before a large group of manufacturers today to appeal for full cooperation. The group included the board of directors and the steering committee of the National Association of Manufacturers and representatives of thirtyeight affiliated State organizations.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 26. -- The Aknusti polo team advanced into the final round of the national junior championship by registering an 11-to-5 victory over the United States Army quartet today at Meadow Brook. The Army won the title last year.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP). -- Confronted with the apparent impossibly task of reconciling widely divergent views of factions of the oil industry over controlling production and refining, Hugh S. Johnson, Industrial Administrator, decided today that Federal officials should write their own program for the oil business.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 26. -- Mrs. Charles Eastman, of Wykagyl, the former Miss Catharine Singer, shot another 83 over the Wood-way course today to win the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy for the second time.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 26 (AP). -- Unexplained motor trips and telephone calls conflicted today with the constant reiterations of family spokesmen that no contact has been made with the men who kidnapped Charles F. Urschel, oil operator, from his home here Saturday night.

Alfonso Palladino's love for animals brought recognition for him as a hero yesterday. He is a taxicab driver. While in the vicinity of Pier 28, East River, on July 15, he plunged into the water and saved a dog from drowning.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 26. -- After wavering on the first nine holes at the Lido course today, Walter Kozak, the defending champion, rallied on the last nine to widen his lead in the Long Island open championship to four strokes, When he took 39 to go out in the 1 second round of the seventy-two-hole battle for the title, two of his rivals caught up with him.

Suprime Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler heard argument yesterday and will hand down today a decision on applications by three insurance companies to transfer reinsurance placed with the Globe Rutgers Fire Insurance Company to other companies.
NEW YORK. Former Senator Peter Goelet Gerry of Rhode Island is at the Pierre, where he has been joined by Mrs. Gerry, who returned on the Bremen. They will go to Newport later.

An armed hold-up man climbed into Maurice Carrilot's roadster late yesterday afternoon while Carrilot, a surgical instrument salesman, was waiting at the Manhattan approach of the Washington Bridge across the Harlem River, 181st Street and Amsterdam Avenue, for the traffic lights to change.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 26. -- Rear Admiral Luke McNamee, United States Navy, president of the Naval War College; officers of his staff and students were guests of honor at a reception and smoker given tonight by the citizens of the city at Oakland Farm through the courtesy of State Senator William H. Vanderbilt.

A program by many composers, including a large number of new works, will be presented by Paul Whiteman in his debut as a guest conductor with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, augmented by his own band of players, at the Lewisohn Stadium on Friday night, Aug. 4.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 26. -- Three Pleasantville neighbors of Wilbur K. Hitchcock, Justice of the Peace of Mount Pleasant and a member of its Town Board, sought today in Supreme Court here to restrain Justice Hitchcock and his wife from maintaining a dog kennel on their estate.
The New York Curb Exchange has admitted to its list the 1,177,604 shares of capital stock of $1 par value of the Fidelio Brewery, Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- The necessitv for sweeping changes in the code of fair practice submitted to the National Recovery Administrator by the lumber industry faced the Code Authority today at the close of a six-day hearing.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP). -- Pledges of cooperation in the administration's shorter hours-wage raising campaign continued today to pile up at the White House and Industrial Recovery headquarters.

TRENTON, N.J., July 26. -- John C. Reed of Atlantic City was named by William A. Stevens, Attorney General, today as a special assistant and assigned to take charge of the Atlantic County Prosecutor's office. He will replace Joseph Lanigan, an Assistant Attorney General, and is to serve until the vacancy is filled by Gubernatorial appointment.

Wiley Post will make his stage debut today at the Radio City Musio Hall, where he will begin a week's engagement. His act will include the showing on the screen of newsreel pictures of his latest world flight, followed by his description of the trip.

WHITE PLAINS, July 26. -- Joseph Urban, scenic decorator, architect, designer and painter, who died in New York on July 10, made his widow, Mary Urban, his sole heir, according to the terms of his filed for probate in Surrogate's Court here today.

The President has again invited the "House of Governors" to meet with him at Washington. When ha was New York's Chief Executive he was a loyal member of that organization, attended its meetings regularly and sought earnestly to find a function for what, on paper, seems to be one of the most powerful groups in the United States.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The complaint la often made that Insurance is high because so many fake claims are made against the companies. My own recent experience "would lead me to believe that perhaps the business methods of some companies are responsible for part of the high cost of Insurance.
NEWARK, N.J., July 26 (AP). -- Newark and Baltimore divided a double-header today, the Orioles taking the opener, 11-5, and the Bears winning the nightcap, 5-1.

Money market was quiet, outside money on call loans going at 3/4 to 1 per cent, while the exchange rate remained at 1. Time money market ranged from 1 to 2 per cent for the near and distant dates, and commercial paper and acceptances were unchanged in discount.

A letter offering to "take $50,000" from Bruce Barton was Identified yesterday in General Sessions by Albert D. Osborne, handwriting expert, as in the handwriting of Mrs, Frances W. King. She is now on trial before Judge Joseph E. Corrigan on charges of blackmail and attempting to extort that amount from the publicist and advertising executive by threatening to publish a book she had written about him.

PARIS, July 26 (AP). -- Limping slightly but apparently in the best of spirits, Ellsworth Vines Jr. today left with other members of the United States Davis Cup team for Cherbourg to board the Olympic, homeward bound.

As a result of strength in the stock and grain markets and the first mention, of weevil in the weekly weather summary so far this season, prices of cotton advanced yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and closed 15 to 17 points, or 75 to 85 cents a bale, higher than on Tuesday.
The bluefish have reached the region of the Rockaways and veteran fishermen now feel assured that the sport of catching this species is on a sound basis for the season.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- Wiley Post was acclaimed as an outstanding courageous aviator by President Roosevelt today, who received him and Mrs. Post at the White House. The reception to the "round-the-world flier" was held just about the time a group of the Citizens Military Training Corps arrived from Fort Myer.

A firm tone prevailed yesterday in the local commodity markets, as early losses were either converted into gains or substantially reduced. Trading was much lighter than it had been recently. Cash prices continued to advance.

EVEN the bewildered tennis fans are now beginning to admit that this country may survive the calamity that befell our Davis Cup squad at Auteuil. It was a stunning shock, to be sure, but nobody was killed and the world still rotates on its axis.
Musicians Boycott Germany. TOSCANINI and KREISLER are only the two most eminent on a steadily growing list of artists who feel that they cannot practice their art in a Nazi-coordinated Germany.

LONDON, July 26. -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain chilled the hopes of President Roosevelt's admirers in the House of Commons today by making clear that the British Government is not ready to follow American policy on currency or public works.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 (AP). -- Governors attending the annual conference of State executives asked the Federal Government today "to pursue to the utmost" its vigorous prosecution of racketeers to the end that kidnapping and kindred crimes be suppressed.
The Rev. Charles J. Deane, dean of Fordham College, announced yesterday that 148 undergraduates had won places on the 1932-33 honor roll.

DETROIT, July 26. -- In cooperation with President Roosevelt's recovery program 200,000 automobile workers in plants connected with the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce will receive a wage Increase Aug. 1, it was announced today following adoption of a resolution by directors of the chamber which called for an adjustment of wage rates.

A rise in payroll levels of about 40 per cent and an immediate direct increase in employment of at least 20,000 persons is expected under the code of fair competition of the pulp and paper industry, which will be submitted to the Recovery Administration in Washington today.

BOSTON, July 26. -- The expected drive of the Yankees at the expense of the Red Sox failed to materialize today. Calculated to put them on even terms with the Senators again, it ran into something of a traffic jam out of which the world's champions emerged with nothing more than an even break.

WARSAW, July 26. -- The Polish Legation in Moscow and the Soviet diplomatic mission here will soon be raised to the rank of embassies as a consequence of recent developments in Polish-Soviet relations.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- With the technique of its administration and some aspects of its application not yet entirely clarified, the Securities Act will go into effect tomorrow. Of the fifty-seven new issues for which descriptive statements were filed on July 7.

Whatever others may think, the President is pleased with the contents and the effects of his July 3 message to the World Economic and Monetary Conference. Those who have discussed the subject with him came away with this definite understanding.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- President Roosevelt, in a conference today with Attorney General Cummings, instructed the Department of Justice to make an intensive study of recent kidnappings throughout the country and to report on the advisability of creating a super-police force to check the growth of organized crime.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- With the receipt by the Recovery Administration today of a code for the soft coal operators of Alabama came reports of trouble in the soft coal fields of Pennsylvania, where 6,000 men are on strike.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 26. -- Seymour Knox's Aurora polo team rallied to beat the Hurricanes at the Sands Point Club today and carry on to the final round of the national junior polo championship.

Members of the coordinating committee for the Eastern railroads met here informally yesterday and studied a tentative formula for reductions to be made in the salaries of higher railroad officials. The committee was formed as part of the system organized under the recent railroad law and headed by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator.

Redistribution of the income from the State gasoline tax and motor vehicle license fees so that New York City would receive a larger proportion of the income from vehicles operating exclusively within the city limits was suggested last night to the Legislature by Percy, C. Magnus, president of the New York Board of Trade.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- "Farmer-minded" State officers In New York were praised at the Century of Progress Exposition today by E. A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, in an address to a delegation of 2,000 New York farmers who are here on an excursion to the fair.

A party of forty-three Italian industrialists and professional leaders, who arrived here Tuesday on the Vulcania on their way to the Chicago Fair, went sight-seeing yesterday. One of their spokesmen, Mario Mazzucchelli, lawyer, author of books on history and social science and writer for two Italian newspapers, said that "after only a few hours here, I can understand already, from seeing this city, how your nation has achieved its position of, economic world leadership."

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 26 (AP). -- The "Western Golf Association today postponed the second round of its amateur tournament until tomorrow after Incessant rainfall had converted the Country Club course into a marsh and half the starting field had been eliminated In muddy contests over the boggy tract.

ALBANY, July 26. -- The Education Department announced today the names of 150 young men and women who will receive State scholarships to Cornell University. The scholarships entitle the holder to a reduction of $200 a year from the regular tuition fees.

Six companies, comprising 1,218 war veterans enrolled in the Civilian Conservation Corps, who have been getting into condition at Plattsburg Barracks, will leave this week for field work near Wrightsville, Vt., it was announced yesterday at the headquarters of the Second Corps Area on Governors Island.

WASHINGTON, July 26. -- A theory postulating the existence of mysterious cosmic impulses outside the earth, which accelerate its rotation in the manner of a grown-up giving a push to a child in a swing was proposed here today before the International Geological Congress.
Winthrop W. Aldrich, president of the Chase National Bank, and Mrs. Aldrich are sailing tonight for Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 26. -- Both the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and the Republic Steel Corporation placed fires today in two additional blast furnaces preparatory to their resumption. increasing iron output in this district to 60 per cent of capacity.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, July 26. -- Amid the cheers of thousands, King George turned a new page in Great Britain's maritime history today when he formally opened the world's largest dry dock. Queen Mary, emptying a goblet of empire wine into the $6,250,000 structure, christened it the King George V Graving Dock.
BERLIN, July 26. -- Stockholders of the Hamburg-American Line were told today that the boycott movement against Germany in many countries was being felt with increasing force by German shipping.

BERLIN, July 26. -- The German Statistical Office announced today that the total number of hours actually worked by German Industry in June increased 25 per cent above the low point of January this year and that in the same period the total number of employed workers increased 15 per cent.

Masses attended by thousands were said from 5:30 yesterday morning until 10 o'clock last night at the two shrines of St. Ann, mother of the Virgin Mary, in uptown and downtown Manhattan. The masses ended the annual St. Ann Novena, and bus loads of pilgrims from many Eastern States came to venerate the relics of the saint, which are said to possess miraculous power.
ALBANY, July 26. -- The text of Governor Lehman's message to the Legislature wvas as follows:

The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday that its net operating income for June was $4,384,965, against $192,052 in June, 1932, an increase of more than 2,000 per cent, which resulted in putting net operating income for the six months 60 per cent ahead of the same period last year.

Leading manufacturers of automobile tires announced yesterday an increase of 10 per cent in prices, the third mark-up since May 1. The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company took the initiative and other manufacturers, as well as Sears, Roebuck Co., who compete with retail distributers, immediately fell into line.

The cash income of the country's farmers in June was about $388,000,000, or 37 per cent more than in the same month last year, according to estimates by the State Street Research and Management Corporation in conjunction with the Corn Industries Research Foundation.

The Postoffice Department asked the steamship lines holding contacts for the transportation of mails yesterday to cooperate in reducing the cost of the service to the government. It had been rumored in shipping circles that the lines would be obliged to accept a smaller sum for the service in 1934.
Although Captain James A. Mollison and his wife were still awaiting word from physicians yesterday as to when they would be able to go about as they pleased, plans for entertaining them proceeded.

SALEM, N.H., July 26 (AP). -- After failing in her first start, Kashmary, black daughter of the famous Mr. McElwyn, made a stirring comeback today to provide the Grand Circuit's opening Rockingham Park program with its outstanding upset.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26. -- Wood alcohol stolen from a West Philadelphia garage and peddled through that section of the city during the last, three days has killed at least ten persons, according to a police investigation.
WASHINGTON, July 26. -- A fortyhour work week and a wage scale averaging about $18 are contained in the code presented today for the hosiery industry to Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator.
MOSCOW, July 26. -- The Edison electric interests are pushing business with Russia without waiting for Washington to make up its mind about recognition.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 26. -- Mrs. Henry W. Sage Jr. gave a dinner tonight at Wyllys House. Her guests included Mrs. Thomas Bealle Davis, Mrs. Charles Edward Merrill, Mrs. Duncan S. Ellsworth, Mrs. Pere Wilmer, Mrs. John W. Kiser, Mrs. James W. Ingram, Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson and Mrs. Charles Henry Mellon.
PARIS, July 26. -- France, in common with several other countries, has recently, following the law of demand and supply, considerably increased her exports of arms and ammunition.

St. CHRISTOPHER'S feast is kept by the Roman Catholics on July 25. On Tuesday at a multitude of churches motor cars were blessed. It was fitting that the patron saint of mariners and travelers should become the protector of automobilists. The continuity and adaptability of the pious legend are thus again illustrated.

BUENOS AIRES, July 26. -- Meager, strictly censored dispatches arriving here from Rio de Janeiro indicate a serious political crisis in the State of Sao Paulo, Brazil; which has not yet been settled. No direct news has been received from Sao Paulo since Saturday, while the Federal Government has not issued a statement on what is going on or permitted correspondents to tell.

In the Tyrol, where a man can stand up and be touched by natural strength and splendor, motion pictures can afford to deal with simple things. Luis Trenker, who produced "The Lost Battalion," is also responsible for "The Rebel," which reached these shores in an English version at the Rivoli yesterday.
HAVANA, July 26. -- President Machado issued a decree today restoring the constitutional guarantees and signed an amnesty bill to free all political prisoners.

The North American Company and subsidiaries report consolidated net income of $13,019,936 for the twelve months ended on June 30, equal to $1-47 a share earned on the average number of common shares outstanding in the period, comparing with $21,377,365, or $2.83 a share, in the preceding year.

SEA GIRT, N.J., July 26. -- New Jersey's famous Essex Troop, long the silk-stocking unit of the State's citizen soldiery, is facing eventual transformation into some other branch of the military service or becoming motorized cavalry. A decision as to the future status of the regiment may be reached in the near future.

Interest in the bond market yesterday centred chiefly upon discussions of the government financing on Aug. 15. Reports that a longterm issue was being considered had a moderately depressing effect upon outstanding bonds which was increased in the late trading.

The Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company has offered to holders of Cleveland, Lorain Wheeling Railway Company consolidated first mortgage 5 per cent bonds due on Oct. 1 next to refund the bonds by paying 40 per cent in cash, requiring $2,000,000, and the balance, or $3,000,000, in its own notes.

DEAL, N. J., July 26. -- Mrs. Leo G. Federman of Glen Oaks won the women's New Jersey Shore championship trophy by a margin of seven strokes at the end of the fifty-four-hole medal play golf tourney today.
Two persons were taken Ill at almost the same moment in a restaurant at Broadway and 104th Street yesterday morning. One was a man, the other a woman. They were total strangers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Soon will come in the great assize of public opinion the question of whose influence more than any one else's had to do with the turning of the tide of opinion in the matter of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, which now, happily, awaits formal adoption by the remaining States in the Union.

SHOAL HARBOR, Nfld., July 26 (AP). -- General Italo Balbo, leader of the transatlantic air armada, landed here today with, twenty-three of his Italian seaplanes, finishing the third lap of the homeward journey from Chicago.

Mayor O'Brien's chief Interest in Governor Lehman's message to the extraordinary session of the Legislature yesterday turned on the part of it urging that the Governor be authorized to appoint fiscal agents for municipalities if they default on their obligations.

Mayor James M. Curley or Boston returned from Europe yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, accompanied by his family. They left the ship at Quarantine at noon in the United States Coast Guard cutter Hudson to catch the 2 P.M. train from the Grand Central Station.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 26. -- Believed to be the victim of a "ride," Raymond Housell, 29 years old, son of Mrs. Julia Housell, president of the Highland Park Women's Democratic Club, was found early today at the rear of St. Peter's Hospital, here, with a bullet wound in his back.

Three armed bandits, who brought along their own rope and four collapsible cardboard boxes in which to pack their loot, tied up the entire working staff of Irving Feinberg, furrier, at 242 West Thirtieth Street, yesterday afternoon and escaped with fox furs valued by Feinberg at $15,000.
John C. Baxter, 55 years old, builder of the Madison Square Garden Bowl in Long Island City, was injured fatally yesterday when he was struck by a motor truck at Sixth Avenue and Thirteenth Street.

CHICAGO, July 26 (AP). -- First Minstrel, from the Greentree Stable, failed to race Impressively in the Green Bay Purse today at Arlington Park and lost much of his prestige for the $35,000 Futurity to be run here Saturday.

Walter Salvo, a Columbia University student from Northampton, Mass., identified Howard Heater, 28 years old, a soda dispenser, of 308 West Ninety-third Street, in West Side Court yesterday as one of four men who assaulted him in the Delta Kappa Epsilon fraternity house, 608 West 113th Street, early Monday morning, stabbing and beating him while he was in bed.

SARANAC LAKE, N.T., July 26 (AP). -- State police continued their search today for three men who robbed and assaulted Cassius Durkin of Vermontville, a crippled World War veteran, early yesterday after dragging him from his roadside stand. They escaped with $100.

The governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the admission to the list of 1,642,989 shares of Class A stock of $1 par value of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation in substitution for outstanding nopar common shares in accordance with a readjustment of capital approved by stockholders on April 26.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 26. -- The series of "Garden Pop" concerts held here for the last month ended tonight at the Westchester County Centre with the house crowded to the doors. More than 3,500 persons attended the closing program, which was given over entirely to German music.

CHICAGO, July 26. -- At no time today did the price of leading grains come close to selling at the minimum figures at which they are "pegged" on leading American grain exchanges. A wave of general buying swept into the markets following the announcement that minimum prices were to continue in effect and that the distressed liquidation of large lines had been completed.

Thirty-two yachts have been entered for the Bayside Yacht Club's thirteenth annual race out around Block Island and return, which, will be started off the mouth of Little Neck Bay tomorrow at noon. The list was announced yesterday.

Judged by administrative precepts, a sales tax possesses both good and evil qualities. Nevertheless, to the sovereignty it is a tempting form of taxation. The sales tax is easily calculated; the incidence is readily fixed; It is less subject to wide fluctuations of revenue than income taxes.
Wiley Post, unassuming world traveler from Oklahoma, received the acclaim of the city yesterday for his latest and greatest achievement in aviation.

Three thoroughbreds, each at odds-on, won through the heavy footing at Empire City yesterday. Fleet Flag, 1 to 4; Irene's Bob, 2 to 9, and Pending, 7 to 10, were the heavy favorites, and each won by a generous margin.
Ras Desta Demtu, son-in-law and Special Envoy of the Emperor of Abyssinia, will sail today for Havre on the French liner Ile de France, accompanied by Paulos Menameno, Ethiopian Consul in Jerusalem.

Senator James Couzens of Michigan returned from the London conference yesterday unwilling to call it a failure. Arriving on the United States liner Washington, he admitted his disappointment in the outcome, but held that fruitful seeds might have been sown and that the conclave had been productive in understanding and in education.

ELKHART, Ind., July 27 (AP) -- The British Jack and the Stars and Stripes whipped through the breeze side by side today as a famous English engineer, William Gilbertson of Carlisle, shoved the Twentieth Century Limited from Chicago into Elkhart two minutes ahead of time.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- President Roosevelt in the next few days will announce further plans to cope with kidnapping and all forms of racketeering. Having given long study to the organized crime problem, he is prepared to use the Bureau of Investigation of the Department of Justice as the nucleus of a Federal organization to run down racketeering.

HAVANA, July 27 -- The first round-table discussion of constitutional reforms, the ground on which definite peace in Cuba is expected to be built, took place late this afternoon at the United States Embassy between delegates of the Cuban Government and opposition factors.

HARBIN, Manchuria, July 27 -- Reports of secret construction by Manchukuo and Japan of a railway of tremendous strategic importance in relation to the Russian Maritime Province were confirmed for the first time today by this correspondent.

An easier outside market for call loans collateraled by government paper, which was done at 1/2, compared with 3/4, was the only feature of an otherwise quiet market in money. The Stock Exchange rate remained at 1 per cent, and Federal funds 1/8 @ 1/4.

A committee of the Transatlantic Passenger Conference, appointed several weeks ago to study the international traffic situation, will submit a proposal to the principals of the conference Monday in London designed to alter competitive factors among the various types of ships.
ALBANY, July 27 -- Governor Lehman took action today to place New York as the first State officially and by statute in line with the Federal industry recovery program.

Skippers and crews who will participate in the Bayside Yacht Club's annual race around 'Block Island and back gathered at the club last night for the dinner preceding the race. The start will be made at noon today off the mouth of Little Neck Bay.
Paul Thomaschefsky gave to Czeslaw Slupkowski a mortgage for $5,500, due July 1, 1936, at 6 per cent, on the five-story tenement at 315 W. 134th St., subject to prior mortgages of $16,500.

Morris L. Ernst, a member of the New York State Banking Board, in a speech over WEVD last night in which he discussed the nominations of fusion candidates for New York City offices, urged his listeners "to take a page out of the Roosevelt program."
DETROIT, July 27 (AP). -- Four Detroit pitchers failed to stem a St. Louis onslaught today, but it took twelve innings to decide the issue in favor of the Browns, 10 to 9.
I.A. Hirschmann, director of sales and publicity for Lord Taylor, returned from a six-week tour of Europe and England yesterday on the United States liner Washington.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The War Department issued the following orders today, dated July 26:
Carl Hubbell turned back the Dodgers single-handed before some 5,000 fans at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

HAVEN, Me., July 27 (AP) -- Summoned here by telephone, Dr. Irving Cashell, a Washington veterinarian, completed a 700-mile flight from the nation's capital tonight to treat Balkash, a prize-winning Samoyed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What may be called the fundamental economic dogma of the gospel of the New Deal is that low prices cause low wages, and that, consequently, high prices would mean high wages and a correspondingly higher purchasing power on the part of wage earners, which, in turn, would mean a revival of industry.

BUENOS AIRES, July 27 -- Confusion and misunderstanding are attending the resumption of negotiations by the powers [Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru] for peace between Bolivia and Paraguay. Five conflicting official statements have been given out at five of the seven capitals involved.

KANSAS CITY, July 27 -- The first death verdict in a kidnapping case was rendered today by a Missouri jury which convicted Walter H. McGee of the abduction for $30,000 ransom of Miss Mary McElroy, daughter of H.T. McElroy, city manager.

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP). -- With Monte Pearson, young righthander, allowing only five hits, the Indians trounced the White Sox, 9 to 1, today, sweeping the three-game series. The Chicago losing streak was extended to eight straight.
PARIS, July 27 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ending July 26, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,200,000,000, an increase of $4,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $234,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The text of Secretary Hull's speech before the World Economic Conference today at London, as given out by the State Department, follows:

In the next three or four days contractors in the dress industry may be forced to close their shops, whether there is a strike or not, S.J. Harris, general manager of the Association of Dress Manufacturers, said last night. He spoke at a mass meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated July 25:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial "The Break in the Markets" you state that "prices do not rise merely because some one's imagination has selected a higher level as more appropriate."

The history of the George Washington bicentennial celebration, sponsored by a commission of which Representative Sol Bloom was director, has been issued in a volume of 700 pages. A reproduction of a Gilbert Stuart portrait of Washington in colors precedes the story of the celebration.
ST. LOUIS, July 27 (AP). -- The Cardinals bunched four hits in the ninth inning to score two runs and defeat the Reds today, 4 to 3. St. Louis swept the three-game series.

The Drug Institute of America, representing about 20,000 druggists, issued a statement yesterday recommending that the 60,000 druggists of the country sign the individual agreements under the President's blanket code but petition the National Recovery Administration for relief where hardships in working hours are involved.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (AP). -- The Phillies batted their way out of the National League cellar today by virture of a pair of triumphs over the Braves, the first game, 4 to 3, and the nightcap, 2 to 1.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 27. -- A group of Williamstown women are forming a garden club. At a meeting held at the home of Miss Laura E. Dwight she was chosen temporary chairman and Miss Sara T. Tenney secretary and treasurer. Mrs. E. Crosby Doughty, Mrs. George Alfred Cluett and Mrs. William T. Floyd are on the organization committee.

Archie O. Dawson, president of the New York Young Republican Club, expressed the hope last night that Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, the fusion choice for Mayor, would give satisfactory assurances that he was opposed not only to Tammany Hall, but "to the corrupt leadership of our own party as well."

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- With two opposing factions of the men's clothing industry as wide apart as ever, hearings were ended late this afternoon on rival codes submitted respectively by the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A., and the Industrial Recovery Association of Clothing Manufacturers.
"Going Gay," which was scheduled to open on Monday at the Morosco, will open Wednesday night instead.

Mr. STRAUS, in advocating the development of the unused acres of park lands, has anticipated the next major problem after the conquest of unemployment. He stresses the increased need of provision for the outdoor play of multitudes, in view of increased leisure time due to the shortened work-day and work-week.

A "holy crusade" against Tammany is called for this year "because almost everything which is considered holy in American public life is at stake," James E. Finegan asserts in his book "Tammany at Bay," published today by Dodd, Mead Co.

LONDON, July 27 (AP) -- The Bank for International Settlements was upheld by James M. Cox of Ohio in a final address at the plenary session of the World Economic Conference today as providing a valuable means of dealing with the problem of international indebtedness and future extension of international credits.

The end did not crown the work in the case of the World Economic Conference. Its expiring session yesterday was marked by several funeral orations which sharply disagreed. But not even those who came to praise the Conference, not to bury it, were able to point to any definite achievement by it.

READING, Pa., July 27 -- Dr. Benjamin M. Squires, indicted by a Federal grand jury in Chicago along with twenty-three others, an- nounced tonight he planned no more meetings as mediator with manufacturers in the Reading hosiery strike and said he would leave for Chicago immediately.

The address of Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald to the United States yesterday over Columbia and National Broadcasting Company networks, as transcribed here by the National Broadcasting Company, was as follows:

Stockholders of the County Trust Company gave unanimous approval yesterday to the merger of the institution with the Lawyers Trust Company at a special meeting held in the bank's office in the Empire State Building. Similar action was taken by the Lawyers Trust Company on Tuesday.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Grain markets are regarded as having again become one-sided, and with buyers predominating today on the Board of Trade here, prices were rushed rapidly upward. December wheat at the top showed 8 cents above yesterday's finish, the maximum advance permitted for one day under the present regulations, while oats for the second successive day advanced the limit of 4 cents a bushel.

LET there be no more worry in the Bronx about the fate of the Yankees this year. A soothing soothsayer has kindly forwarded his predictions, and even Colonel Jacob Ruppert, who gets weak in the knees if the Yanks are a run behind at the end of the first inning, will be able to sit back in comfort now.

Data providing a broader view of last week's break in the commodity markets are now coming to hand. The Annalist's index of wholesale prices, published today, shows a fall of 4.6 points during the seven days from July 18 to 25. This is the sharpest decline for a single week in the records of the index and clearly reflects the collapse of a speculative movement in wheat and certain other important commodities.

LONDON, July 27 -- Secretary of State Hull and most of the United States clerical force at the World Economic Conference slipped out of London quietly tonight and sailed from Southampton a few hours later aboard the liner President Harding.

With the sharpest decline for a single week in its history, the Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices dropped 4.6 points to 102.4 on Tuesday from 107.0 (revised) the Tuesday previous. Sharp breaks in the grains and flour caused three-quarters of the week's loss.

ALBANY, July 27 -- Removal of two of the three members of the State Milk Control Board was asked of Governor Lehman today by Albert Woodhead of Rochester, head of a group of milk producers. Declaring that Dr. Thomas Parran, Commissioner of Health, was the "only friend of the farmers" on the board, Mr. Woodhead asked the Governor to oust both Director Kenneth F. Fee and Charles H. Baldwin, Commissioner of Agriculture, the other members.
Several east side penthouses were included in the list of apartment rentals announced by brokers yesterday.

In his message to the extraordinary session of the Legislature, Governor LEHMAN renews his recommendation of legislation to provide for defaults by municipalities on their funded obligations. He asks for a general authorization in the case of such defaults to set up a financial agency whose power would be restricted to "approving or "vetoing any item of appropriation "or expenditure by the municipality, or "the incurring of any debt by it."
PARIS, July 27 -- Former Premier Edouard Herriot writes in today's L'Ere Nouvelle of President Roosevelt's radio address on recovery:

New protests were voiced by business organizations here yesterday against increasing the State sales tax from 1 to 2 per cent, while Grover A. Whalen made a radio address against the increase over the National Broadcasting System last night.

Mrs. Frances W. King took the witness stand yesterday in her own defense and told a story disagreeing with that already told by Bruce Barton, publicist and advertising executive, who accuses her of blackmail and an attempt to extort $50,000 from him.

With representatives of consumers charging that the utility companies are "stalling" to prolong the hearings, the Public Service Commission's inquiry into electric rates in the city continued yesterday with an involved and technical cross-examination of expert witnesses.

CHICAGO, July 27 -- Al Capone, Dr. Benjamin Squires of the University of Chicago and Aaron Sapiro, New York attorney who once sued Henry Ford for $1,000,000 in a libel action, were indicted by the Cook County grand jury here today with twenty-one other persons, following the jury's long investigation into trade rackets.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange became more active yesterday and a series of large buying orders advanced prices, which ended 26 to 30 points, or $1.30 to $1.50 a bale, higher than on Wednesday. October rose above 11 cents a pound to the highest quotation this week.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Cabinet advisory board today allotted $6,000,000 to the War Department and $4,850,620 to the Department of Agriculture, bringing allocations under the $3,300,000,000 public works fund to almost three-quarters of a billion dollars.

Ras Desta Demtu, Prince of the Royal House of Abyssinia, would like to build an amusement park in his native land. He made this decision after a visit to this country, which, will end today when he sails on the Ile de France.

The first fifty railroads to report for June showed a total net operating income of about $50,787,000, against $14,489,000 in June, 1932, an increase of 250.5 per cent, as against $41,559,000 in June, 1931, an increase of 22.2 per cent. In May their net income was $34,271,000, against $12,299,000 in May, 1932, an increase of 178.6 per cent.

Bank clearings throughout the country again ran far ahead of last year, according to the weekly compilation by Dunn Bradstreet, Inc. The total for the week ended on Wednesday was the third largest of the year. It was the sixth time this year that the $5,000,000,000 mark has been crossed.

Jersey City and Hudson County employes, numbering about 8,000, whose salaries recently were reduced 40 per cent, will have 25 per cent of the reduction restored through the issuance of tax anticipation notes.

Salvage Work Undone. Fifteen years after the Armistice a speech in the House of Commons pillories the German Government in terms that the world gladly believed to be forgotten. We hear again of the rape of Belgium, of the spirit of Schrecklichkeit, of the "Huns."

SHOAL HARBOR, Nfld., July 27 (Canadian Press) -- Officers and men of the Italian air armada prepared to get a good night's rest in view of a possible take-off tomorrow morning on their 1,800-mile flight to Ireland, the longest jump of their journey from Italy to Chicago and return.

Declaring that he wanted more time to devote to his family and private practice, Dr. J.G. William Greeff, Hospitals Commissioner, announced his resignation yesterday in a letter to Mayor O'Brien. It becomes effective on Aug. 15.

Wall Street was in a happy frame of mind yesterday, what with the stock and commodity markets advancing confidently and further company reports testifying to the uninterrupted improvement in business. To experienced observers in the commission houses it seemed that the various markets had fully recovered their balance after the disastrous fall of last week.

Late last season Milton Aborn gave at the St. James a brief curriculum of Gilbert and Sullivan revivals. As if to herald the beginning of a new theatrical year, he moved across the street last evening and into the Majestic. There he and his opera company put forth Michael Balfe's "The Bohemian Girl," that has been shown here not at all since 1913.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- After only two hours of discussion today the code of fair competition for the rayon and synthetic yarn producing industry was ready to be written into its final form for presentation to the President by the end of the week.

Preston Burch and his brother Selby figured in three triumphs at Empire City yesterday. Scout Chief, owned and trained by Preston, won the curtain raiser, at 30 to 1, and his brother's Giggley Ann, an 8 to 1 shot, annexed the third.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total bills discounted for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William D. Guthrie left yesterday to join former Ambassador and Mrs. James R. Sheffield at their camp at Saranac Inn.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 27. -- With a much enlarged list of patrons and patronesses from the Summer colony the second of the series of chamber music was given at Wakehurst, home of Mrs. James Laurens an Alen, this evening. Mrs. Helen Cameron Lanier, wife of Reginald B. Lanier of Gravel Court, sang two groups of songs.

Odds are greater than twelve to one against the "average man" making any spectacular profits or permanent gains in stock market speculation, Professor Carl N. Shuster, head of the mathematics department of the State Teachers College, Trenton, N.J., declared yesterday in an address at the Summer session of Columbia University.

In one of the most important realty transactions of the year in the midtown Park Avenue residential district, Louis Kaiser, a senior member of the New York Stock Exchange firm bearing his name, purchased yesterday the apartment building at the northeast corner of Park Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, known as 405 Park Avenue.

CHICAGO, July 27 (UP) -- Advising Anna, racing in the colors of Mrs. Jack Howard of Louisville, Ky., triumphed in the featured Brookwood Purse at Arlington Park today after a spectacular stretch finish with John Marsh's Miss Bunting.

Evidence regarding the alleged loaders' racket on the piers will be laid before a Federal grand jury, beginning next Monday, it was revealed yesterday. It will be presented by John Harlan Amen and Albert J. Law, special assistants to the Attorney General of the United States.
SALEM, N.H., July 27 (AP) -- The crack trotter Mary Reynolds, recent winner of an $11,405 stake at North Randall, scored in impressive fashion on the Grand Circuit card today.

LONDON, July 27 -- Great Britain and her dominions tonight announced that until world currencies are again stabilized on gold they will make the empire a single monetary unit based on sterling, entirely independent of gold currencies or the dollar.

Heaviness in United States Government obligations and further strength in railroad bonds were the features yesterday of trading in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading ran above the level of Wednesday. Foreign obligations were irregular.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Faced with the necessity of shaping its domestic program within a fortnight, the administration today made a last minute effort to bring some tangible results from the conference of wheat producing nations at London prior to its adjournnent tonight until Aug. 21.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Recent letters to the editor of THE TIMES complain of the abuse of deficiency judgments following mortgage foreclosures. Our present laws expressly provide for such abuses. It is to be hoped that the manifest evils and stress of our times will result in changes in the laws, with some consideration for the rights of the man of slender means.

Residential deals reported by brokers in Westchester County yesterday reflected an unusual amount of activity in the real estate field for midsummer. An estate at Croton, an old homestead at Bronxville, and several homes in Larchmont and Scarsdale were reported in new ownership.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- In a nation-wide appeal to all Governors and State directors of emergency relief today, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal administrator, urged that attention be given without delay to the problem of the transient unemployed, which he characterized as serious and certain to become acute this Winter.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 27 -- The end of the trail came for Frankie Parker of Milwaukee today in the semi-finals of his first grass court tennis tournament of the year at the Seabright Lawn Tennis and Cricket Club.

Wiley Post, aerial globe trotter, turned actor yesterday on the stage of the Radio City Music Hall. His metropolitan debut was without benefit of rehearsal, but he was far from stage-struck when he appeared behind the footlights.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 27 -- "If any one beats me it will be Willie Klein," said Walter Kozak, Pomonok professional, as he started out to play his last round in the Long Island open championship at Lido today.

The appeal of Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association, to Mayor O'Brien for an application for Federal funds to develop all of the city's unused park lands was received with coolness yesterday by Borough President Harvey of Queens.

When the stage stars of the Gay Nineties met yesterday afternoon on the observation terrace of the Empire State Building, three of the figures present were the man who danced for Lincoln, the man who introduced the cake-walk, and the girl who first sang the "Schnitzelbank Song" at Tony Pastor's forty years ago.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 27 -- With Gerry Smith playing brilliantly at No. 3, the Ox Ridge team rode into the final round of the Wheatley Cups tournament tonight, turning back Aknusti, 11 to 4.
WASHINGTON, July 27. -- Mrs. Courtney Letts Stillwell Borden of Chicago and Washington was married, here today to Felipe A. Espil, the Argentine Ambassador.

Five death benefits of more than $1,000,000 were paid on insurance policies by companies in this country during 1932, according to a study by the National Underwriter. The largest claim was on the life of Frederick S. Ruth, New York City realty broker, for $2,425,000.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Exports of smelted gold ore and imperfectly refined ore are prohibited except under license of the Secretary of the Treasury, while gold concentrates and gold ore may be exported, according to a ruling of Attorney General Cummings, portions of which were made public today.

ALBANY, July 27 -- Spurred by a special message from Governor Lehman, the Senate passed today a bill to make immediately available a revolving fund of $10,200,000 for improvement of the Barge Canal. The project would be part of a $27,500,000 canal program which the Senate is seeking to have the Federal Government approve as part of its public works program.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 27 -- Legal heads and advisers of twenty-one leading American railroads today drafted new legislation to submit to President Roosevelt and the next Congress. It was explained that the railway executives expect a call from the administration for advice.

Official notification that the basic agreement between the Managers Protective Association and the Actors Equity Association had been canceled was given yesterday to the former group by Frank Gillmore, president of Equity.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 27 -- Max Marston of the Merion Country Club in Philadelphia shot a sub-par 70 today to win the medal in the qualifying round of the fourteenth annual men's invitation tournament of the Shenecossett Golf Club.

Except for a sharp sinking spell in the gold mining group on the Stock Exchange, the share market continued its cautious advance yesterday with little interference. Prices were substantially higher at the close in this market as well as on the various commodity exchanges where operations for the rise were carried on aggressively and successfully.

The firm of Paine, Webber Co., which has membership in the New York Stock Echange, was disclosed yesterday as the purchaser of the 20 per cent stock interest in the Kansas City Southern Railroad sold recently by the Chicago Great Western Railway.

Operations of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in August should equal the present rate, 50 per cent of capacity, which is the top of the present upturn for the company. Eugene G. Grace, president of the corporation, said yesterday in issuing its report of earnings for the quarter ended on June 30.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Severe criticism of the methods followed by Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, and his deputies in the handling of the labor aspects of various codes is contained in a letter addressed to President Roosevelt by the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, made public today.

BERLIN, July 27 -- With the public showing somewhat more interest and traders more optimistic prices at today's session of the Boerse were firmer. A number of stocks netted advances of 1 to 2 points and more, with collieries, steels and public utilities the chief gainers.

LONDON, July 27 -- Interim announcements by the London Midland Scottish and the Southern Railways for the past half-year, showing last year's distributions were repeated in both cases and substantial reductions effected in working expenses, had a heartening effect on home rails and other sections of the Stock Exchange today.

Deputy Controller John H. O'Brien, in charge of the sale of the city's tax-anticipation bonds, said yesterday that some of his salesmen would earn $6,000 a day instead of $15 if they worked on a commission of one-tenth of 1 per cent.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 27 (AP) -- Nervous and apparently on the verge of collapse, Mrs. Charles F. Urschel, wife of the kidnapped Oklahoma oil man, conferred today with newspaper men, who agreed to withdraw from the home and make possible unobserved communication with the abductors.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Mainly for the benefit of homeowners, the Federal Trade Commission today exempted from registration requirements two classes of notes and bonds secured by small plots of real estate.

Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck ordered The Chicago Tribune and its syndicate yesterday to continue their comic strip service to The Washington Post, halting their advertised intention of transferring the service to The Washington Herald.

Continued improvement in business plus a substantial loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation are essential if the rehabilitation of the National Surety Company is to be successful, it was explained yesterday to bondholders of the concern at a meeting in the State Office Building.

Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, commander of the Twenty-seventh Division during the World War and formerly a member of the Transit Commission, was named yesterday for the fusion nomination for Mayor by the group headed by former Governor Charles S. Whitman.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/2 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 1 1/2 per cent for the best names.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- From all parts of the nation today field reports poured in on the Recovery Administration that business and industry were doing their part by swinging into the national re-employment movement and signing President Roosevelt's blanket code.

Only routine changes were shown in the weekly report of the Federal Reserve System published yesterday. The system maintained its purchases of United States Government securities at the reduced rate of $10,000,000 a week and money in circulation declined $34,000,000.

The number of persons actively engaged in fresh-water fishing in the United States has shown a marked increase in recent weeks, according to an announcement made yesterday by the Department of Commerce through the Bureau of Fisheries.

An issue of $1,000,000 Metropolitan District Hartford County (Conn.) 3 1/2 per cent water bonds dated Aug. 1, 1933, and maturing $25,000 annually on Aug. 1, 1934 to 1973, was purchased yesterday by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, Roosevelt Sons and Shaw, Aldrich Co. and G.L. Austin Co. of Hartford at 100.202.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 27. -- Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the twenty-sixth annual flower show of the Garden Club of Southampton and the Southampton Horticultural Society which opened this afternoon in the auditorium of the parochial school in Hill Street.

Movements in commodity futures prices on local exchanges yesterday were irregular. Sugar, cocoa, silver and wool tops were higher, while coffee, silk and hides were lower. Trading was quiet. Cash prices were also mixed.

Captain James Mollison and his wife, Amy, will leave the Plaza Hotel this afternoon to go to Rye, where they will be the week-end guests of G.P. Putnam and his wife, Amelia Earhart. After Miss Earhart made her solo transatlantic flight last year she met the Mollisons in London and there exchanged flying experiences.
ALBANY, July 27 -- Following is the text of the Schackno-Steingut Bill, designed to place the State of New York in line with the national recovery program:

Judge SEABURY defined yesterday his personal effort in the city campaign as being to "prevent Tammany Hall from "naming the Fusion candidate for "Mayor." That purpose will have been attained if General O'RYAN, to whom the Fusion committee offered the nomination yesterday, becomes the candidate.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company reports a net loss of $2,078,424 for the second quarter of 1933, the smallest net loss for any quarter since the second quarter of 1932, when the loss was $1,881,979. Net loss in the first quarter of 1933 amounted to $3,491,572.

The salary of George B. Cortelyou, as president of the Consolidated Gas Company, was revealed yesterday at the Public Service Commission as $100,000 up to May 1. In the general salary reduction of the Consolidated system effective on that date Mr. Cortelyou's pay was cut to $91,666.57.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 27 -- Frank William Peek Jr., a pioneer in high voltage electrical engineering research and widely known as the "inventor of man-made lightning" was killed near Gaspe, Quebec, yesterday when the automobile he was driving was struck by the locomotive of a Canadian Railway train at a grade-crossing.

RYE, N.Y., July 27 -- When business ended last Friday night at the popcorn and taffy stand in Playland, the county amusement park here, Alphonzo Howe was glad to get from behind the counter where he works fairly hard for his $20 a week. He started home.

TOKYO, July 27 -- The trial of eleven naval cadets for complicity in the assassination on May 15, 1932, of Premier Inukai continues to produce soapbox orations the crudity of which is giving considerable relief to the public.
