MADRID, July 27 -- Spain today became the twentieth nation formally to recognize the Soviet Union when President Alcala Zamora in a meeting of the Cabinet held at the Presidential palace endorsed a decision made by the Cabinet last week to open diplomatic and commercial relations with Russia.

Anthony Vurchio, 13 years old, and his father, Nicholas, a truckman, of 446 East 122d Street, called on the Testaro family, their relatives, at 430 East 122d Street, yesterday afternoon. The elder Vurchio took the keys out of his automobile before he went to make the call.
Entries for the national amateur golf championship total 580, only 20 fewer than last year, according to an announcement yesterday.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 27 -- A four-oared crew which won two Canadian championships in two hours today sent Buffalo's youthful West Sides away to a flying start in their drive to retain club honors at the fifty-first Royal Canadian Henley regatta.

Three men were convicted of first-degree robbery by a jury in Judge Nott's part of General Sessions yesterday afternoon in the hold-up and theft of $49,500 in jewelry, all of which was insured, from Sava Kehaya, a one-time private banker, in his former home at 2, East Eighty-eighth Street on the evening of Oct. 6 last.

Mrs. Helen Wills Moody will lead the United States squad against Great Britain's team in the women's international tennis matches for the Wightman Cup at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills next Friday and Saturday. She was chosen yesterday to captain the American forces for the second straight year and for the second time in her tennis career.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 27 -- Mrs. J.R. Arneill of the Woodway Country Club, Stamford, won the low gross prize with an 88 in a one-day tournament of the Westchester and Fairfield Women's Golf Association today. The event was held at the Innis Arden Golf Club, Old Greenwich.

Hans Kindler, who made his first appearance as a conductor in this city last night with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium, made it clear from the Outset that his is a vigorous, assertive personality. Whether his penetration is as profound as his command is firm is a question that will be more satisfactorily determined by the end of his visit.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- All sorts of businesses throughout the country are represented in the 20,000 telegrams and letters which have rained in upon President Roosevelt and the National Recovery Administration since the President's broadcast last Monday night.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Definite progress toward agreement on limitation of contractors and on responsibility for labor standards in "outside shops" was made today at conferences between representatives of the union and the employing groups in the coat and suit industry, relative to evolving of a collective labor contract for the industry's recovery code.
Leases of stores to retailers featured business renting in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn yesterday, when brokers reported several deals for good retail selling locations.

NEWARK, N.J., July 27 (AP). -- Rochester whittled the Bears' lead in the International League to one game and a half by taking the series opener tonight, 5 to 4. The Red Wings administered a defeat to Don Brennan on his first mound assignment since his return from the Yankees.

ALBANY, July 27 -- Supporters of Mayor O'Brien's legislative program to provide the City of New York with relief funds admitted defeat today, after taking an inventory of their strength in the Legislature. They found that, not even in the Senate, where the Democrats are in control, would there be sufficient votes to pass the legislation demanded by the city administration.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Tribute to the "splendid spirit of cooperation" with which the American people are uniting in a finish fight on the depression was paid today by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, who has just returned from a three-weeks' motor trip covering 4,000 miles in her blue roadster.

DETROIT, July 27 -- General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, arrived here from Washington in an army airplane late today to confer with leaders of the automotive industry and assist them in solving the wage problems.

LONDON, July 27 -- Amid mingled reproaches, regrets and expressions of pious hope, in which two speeches of confidence and expectation from the United States delegation stood out by sheer contrast, the World Economic Conference went into the silence today.

Although there was a delay in the arrival and distribution of the papers to be signed by employers in the government's prosperity campaign under the National Recovery Act, the drive was under way yesterday, with hundreds of employers pledging their cooperation to the local office of the Department of Commerce in the Custom House.

BREMEN, July 27 -- Following yesterday's resignation in a body of the administration of the Hamburg-American Line, its sister shipping company, the North German Lloyd, at its regular general meeting today accepted the resignations of Philip Heineke, long its president, and its executive board.

A combination of influences, none of them of a striking character, produced a violent rally in the dollar in foreign exchange yesterday. The pound sterling fell 11 3/4 cents in dollar valuation to $4.50 1/2, the lowest price since July 6, and the franc dropped 12 3/4 points to 5.31 1/4 cents.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The rhythms and patterns of "dancing" mountains to the "music" of the orchestra of terrific forces which played in the interior of the earth hundreds of millions of years before man was born have been deciphered from the ancient rocks in which they had been "frozen" since the time the "dance" came to an end.
With the exception of two store buildings, real estate sales in New Jersey yesterday were confined entirely to housing properties.

WASHINGTON, July 27. -- The Yankees escaped a shut-out today. They also gained the distinction of carrying the opening struggle of a four-game series with their arch tormentors, the Senators, into an extra inning.

BOSTON, July 27 (AP). -- Connie Mack's Athletics collected fourteen hits off Dusty Rhodes, Red Sox hurler, today, but Boston beat the Philadelphians, 6 to 2. One of the Athletics' runs came on Jimmy Foxx's twenty-ninth homer of the season.

Governor Lehman's Home and Farm Mortgage Advisory Committee concluded its hearings yesterday in the offices of the Merchants Association, in the Woolworth Building. Lucius R. Eastman, chairman, said he would make a preliminary report at once by telephone to Governor Lehman, but declined to divulge the nature of the report or the relief recommendations to be made.

The Continental Oil Company reports for the quarter ended June 30 a consolidated net loss of $2,135,722 after expenses, interest, minority interest and reserves for intangible development costs, depletion, lease amortization and depreciation. In the first quarter of this year the company reported a net losss of $2,825,247 after similar charges and reserves, making the total loss for the six months $4,960,969.

PARIS, July 27 -- The challenge round for the Davis Cup will begin tomorrow between France and England. The English team will be the same one which beat the United States last week. In place of Jean Borotra as second-string player in the singles France will use Andre Merlin, a youngster renowned for his fighting qualities.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 27 -- Christian A. Luhnow, owner and editor of Trust Companies, a monthly financial magazine, who died July 19 at his home in Scarsdale, made his sons, Christian C. Luhnow and Frederick E. Luhnow, his principal heirs.
The proportion of the Bank's reserve to liability is 43.54 per cent.
Two men, picked up in Stamford, Conn., yesterday and brought here later in the day, were booked last night on charges of homicide in the murder of Dr. E. Warren Sylla, 65-year-old dentist.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Preparations are being made for an audience of 75,000 to hear a presentation of "Aida" by the Texas Grand Opera Association, the climax of "Texas Day," Aug. 23, at a Century of Progress Exposition.
Among the host of salt water fishermen in this country there is a big army of surf anglers. They look with disdain upon those who go beyond the shore to indulge in the sport.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works announced yesterday in Philadelphia that on July 21, the last day upon which deposits of 51/2 per cent notes, due March 1, 1933, were accepted under the refunding plan declared operative on July 17, there was 99.18 per cent of the notes in the hands of the committee.
ARMONK, N.Y., July 28 -- The Westchester Embassy Club here was the scene tonight of a "basque" party, to aid the social service department of the New York Cancer Institute.

STOCKHOLM, July 28 -- America's barnstorming track and field athletes scored a clean sweep against Swedish and Danish athletes in an international meet held at Malmo tonight. A large crowd attended, including the Swedish Crown Prince, who presented the prizes, and Prince Carl Johan.
The government's recovery drive was under way here yesterday on a mass scale.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A new geologic map of the United States, which sums up a hundred years of geological research in this country, was introduced today before the International Geological Congress here.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Repayment by the Pennsylvania Railroad Company of the last instalment of the $28,900,000 which it borrowed from the government in the depression today was regarded by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation as a hopeful sign that the carriers are on the eve of a complete return to private financing.

Statisticians of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company saw a reflection of improved economic conditions yesterday in an outstanding health record for industrial policy holders during the first six months of this year in the United States and Canada.

Burnt Finger Odds. The little fellow's chances of making a "killing" in Wall Street, or holding on permanently to any profits at all, have just been estimated by a Jersey professor of mathematics at 1 to 12.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Two large organizations of non-union bituminous coal operators, said to represent considerably more than 50 per cent of the national output, filed a code with the Recovery Administration today. At the same time they announced wage increases which they estimated would add $60,000,000 a year to the earnings of 350,000 miners.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- President Roosevelt today approved the expenditure of $63,000,000 for a power dam and reclamation project in the Columbia River and of $22,700,000 for the development of the Casper-Alcova flood control and reclamation project in the North Platte River, Wyoming.

Anthony Berkeley, one of the founders of the English Detection Club, is the author of the Crime Club selection for August, "Dead Mrs. Stratton," to be published next "Wednesday. This Is another story in the career of Roger Sheringham, the detective, who finds himself this time against the police, since he is accused of murdering Mrs. Stratton.

A form of agreement for arbitration of the claims of the closed Harriman National Bank and Trust Company has been submitted to member banks of the New York Clearing House Association. The agreement places the liability of the clearing house banks to be arbitrated at $8,875,000.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- With ninety days to complete their task, the first Federal boards will be set up next week to review the claims of 150,000 veterans for pension payments on ailments presumed to have originated in service.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 28 -- Frederick H. Prince's Weetamoe, with Harold S. Vanderbilt at the helm, today gained the first race of the series for the Constellation Trophy, offered by former Commodore Arthur Curtiss James. She defeated Vanitie, with her owner, Gerard B. Lambert, at the wheel, by 5 minutes 44 seconds on corrected time.
Tammany's board of strategy, ill at ease over Mayor John P. O'Brien's chance for re-election, has had experts at work since last Spring trying to determine whether he should be the party's candidate.

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (AP) -- The Phillies, nine runs behind in the fifth inning, came back today to tie the score in the ninth and add another run in the tenth to beat the Boston Braves, 13 to 12, and sweep their three-game series.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- James A. Moffett, vice president of tie Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, resigned today as the outgrowth of a sharp fight within the company over policy and a disagreement on the question whether he should accept appointment to the industrial advisory committee.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Improvement was credited in several countries today by the Department of Commerce in its weekly summary of world economic conditions based on reports from its representatives abroad. The summary, in part follows:
NEWARK, N.J., July 28 (AP) -- Rochester made it two straight over Newark today and cut the lead of the pacemakers to a half game.
VIENNA, July 28 -- Five persons, including a soldier, were injured in Graz tonight by the explosion of a large tear-gas bomb.

AUTEUIL, France, July 28 (AP) -- Fred Perry fainted from fatigue in the dressing room after winning his grueling struggle with Henri Cochet, though there was no sign of distress as the stalwart Briton trounced the great French star today in their Davis Cup match.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 28 -- The Friday night supper dance at the Muenchinger King tonight proved popular with a large number of younger members of the colony. One of the largest parties was that given by John Jacob Astor, who had about forty of his friends whom he had entertained at dinner earlier.

Mrs. Frances W. King returned to the witness stand in her own defense yesterday, apparently determined, after her nervous breakdown the previous day, to be tried for blackmail and extortion according to her own rules.
LONDON, July 28 (AP) -- The American contract bridge team led by Ely Culbertson forged rapidly ahead of its English opponents today, ending the first night's play 4,180 points to the good.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange broke yesterday and ended with losses of 42 to 48 points, or $2.10 to $2.40 a bale. Following Thursday's advance, offerings of contracts increased as demand decreased. Having made record-breaking purchases the last three months, being uncertain as to their ability to market goods freely at the materially higher level of prices, mills have bought less raw material this week.

Four New York public institutions will eventually receive $13,500 in bequests under the will of Mrs. Bertha H. Minturn, widow of Robert Shaw Minturn, New York lawyer, who died in Paris on June 29, last. This was disclosed when her will was offered for probate yesterday in Surrogates' Court. The estate was formally valued at "more than $20,000."
MOSCOW, July 28 -- Soviet coal production has fallen about 5 or 6 per cent in the last six weeks and the reasons for this alarm the Soviet press.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Why is it that some men persist in characterizing, directly or by inference, an internationalist as "a type of patriot who loves every country but his own"?

CHICAGO, July 28 -- At least six of the twenty-four alleged conspirators named in the racket indictments returned yesterday by the Cook County grand jury have apparently fled the State and are believed to be planning to fight extradition.

The century plant which has been set out in the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park, just south of the main conservatory is about to stage its "blossom of the century." Visitors are attracted to the twelve-foot stalk, which is topped by flower buds, and botanists at the park are making observations daily to determine when the flowers will be ready to open.
LONDON, July 28 -- The text of the declaration issued yesterday by British Empire delegates to the World Economic Conference follows:

DETROIT, July 28 -- Ending a flying visit to Detroit and three hastily summoned conferences with officials, General Johnson dashed back to Washington tonight in an army airplane, bearing the wage-work agreement of the nation's automobile industry.

LONDON, July 28 -- The Canadian delegation to the World Economic Conference today issued a statement challenging the correctness of statments by a Russian delegate who replied several days ago to charges of E.N. Rhodes, Canadian Minister of Finance, that Russian timber competed unfairly, on the world markets.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 28 -- Two first-round matches were played in the Wheatley Cups polo tournament at the Meadow Brook Club today, with the Meadow Larks defeating the Vipers, 9 to 6, and The Oasis combination routing Hempstead, 15 to 5.

THE news from Auteuil indicates that Great Britain must have a National Recovery Act of its own. Messrs. Austin and Perry have made a good start toward recovering the Davis Cup, a long-wandering trophy that was once a prized possession in jolly old England.

Roebling Building, Inc., Henry E. Keough, president, representing the bondholders' committee, yesterday acquired at foreclosure auction the eighteen-story Roebling Building, at 117-121 Liberty Street, on a bid of $200,000.
Robert Jacob's yawl Nimbus, a former Larchmont Class O racing sloop, and Robert Teller's yawl Playmate, took the lead in the Bayside-Block Island yacht race yesterday.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it would resume its normal five-hour sessions Monday. Three-hour sessions were placed in effect this week as a relief measure for overworked brokers and their workers.
SEATTLE, July 28 (AP) -- The Most Rev. Vladimir Alexandrof, Seattle Archbishop of the Russian Orthodox Greek Catholic Church, has been made an Archbishop-elect of the Catholic Church.

The normal midsummer recession is but faintly discernible in general trade activity this season, as reports from all sections of the country are uniform in the lack of evidence of any reversal of the business trend which has been progressively upward for nearly four months, according to the weekly business review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The bond market on the New York Stock Exchange was irregular yesterday in moderate trading, except in United States Government securities, which were firmer in the heaviest day's trading since May 11. Large blocks of Treasury 3 1/3s and 3s changed hands in the late trading at advanced levels.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Tammany Hall was ignored in New York appointments made today by President Roosevelt. All the important posts were given to men who were pre-convention Roosevelt men.

A story of adventure in the frozen wilds of Canada is told by Helge Ingstad in "The Land of Feast and Famine," just published by Alfred A. Knopf. The book has been translated from the Norwegian by Eugene Gay-Tifft.
LONDON, July 28 -- An "authorized" English translation of Adolf Hitler's first and only book, "Mein Kampf" ["My Struggle"] is about to be issued in England and the United States.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 28 (AP) -- Producing one of the greatest rallies the tournament has seen, Walter Emery, the national intercollegiate titleholder from Oklahoma City, today overcame a four-hole deficit to defeat Leland Hamman of Waco, Texas.

ALBANY, July 28 -- Recommendations that the Women's Farm Colony at Greycourt be used by more inmates is included in an approved report of the condition of the colony filed with the Commission of Correction. The report was made by James McC. Shillinglaw.

LONDON, July 20 (By Mail) -- A few billion years ago all the galaxies were together in a space no larger than is now occupied by one of them, but they at once began to separate, so starting the expansion of the universe, according to a theory presented to the Royal Astronomical Society here by Professor Willem de Sitter, noted Dutch astronomer.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The National Recovery Administration ruled today that compensation of employes now receiving more than the minimum wage specified in the President's "blanket code" must not be reduced to offset the specified reduction in hours of labor.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., July 28 -- Vesta, Mr. and Mrs. Gerard S. Smith's 7-year-old chestnut mare, today won the polo pony championship at the first charity horse show of the Blind Brook Polo Club. This was the only championship on today's program and the award was well received.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 28 -- Max Marston of Philadelphia, the medalist, and C. Tracy Barnes, last year's victor, of Locust Valley, N.Y., gained the quarter-finals of the fourteenth annual Shenecossett golf tournament today.

Captain James A. Mollison and Amy Johnson, his wife, gave a graphic account of their flight over the radio yesterday afternoon. Their story was rebroadcast by the National Broadcasting Company to the British Empire through the facilities of the British Broadcasting Company.

Aaron Sapiro, the lawyer indicted with Al Capone and others Thursday in Chicago in an alleged "racket" conspiracy, entered a general denial in the Tombs Court yesterday. He was arraigned before Magistrate Aurelio as a fugitive from Illinois, on an affidavit signed by Detective Ipschner, who took him into custody a few hours after his indictment in the lawyer's office at 521 Fifth Avenue.
"Biography," the Theatre Guild's production of the Behrman comedy, will close its run after tonight's performance at the Avon.
The State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board made public yesterday a warning to brewers and wholesalers against acquiring a proprietary interest in any retail establishment selling beer or wine.
LENOX, Mass., July 28 -- The Lenox Horse Show opened today on the Dan R. Hanna Farm with 325 entries in forty-seven classes. It was an outstanding society event, with all parking spaces sold.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A code of fair competition, described as representing "an extraordinary agreement of all legitimate theatre Interests," was filed with the National Recovery Administration today by the principal organizations of producers, actors, dramatists, musicians, chorus boys and girls, stage workers, press agents and others whose livelihood depends on the success of the theatre.
BERLIN, July 28 (AP) -- The secret police today seized all copies of the June edition of The American Redbook magazine that could be found in Prussia.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Bidden godspeed by a throng at the Union Station, President Roosevelt departed at midnight on a special train for his first visit to Hyde Park, his country home on the Hudson, since he was inaugurated.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Bituminous producers in the Appalachian field, running from Pennsylvania to Tennessee, submitted the following code to the Recovery Administration today:
Housing sales formed the bulk of realty trading in New Jersey yesterday.

DETROIT, July 28 -- Approval of a wage-work code for the automobile industry was announced today by General Hugh S. Johnson, director of the national recovery program, and the directors of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce.

The police early this morning raided a stag party on the fourth floor of the Knights of Columbus Hotel, Fiftieth Street and Eighth Avenue, taking ninety persons, including six women, into custody. The prisoners were taken to the Weat Forty-seventh Street station.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 28 -- A band of youthful oarsmen who disdain orthodox form but have the brawn and courage to win, brought the Buffalo West Sides four more national titles in the Royal Canadian Henley regatta today.
CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP) -- The Indians had practically no trouble defeating the Tigers, 7 to 2, today in the opener of their three-game series to take a firm hold on fourth place.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Recovery Administrator Johnson frill take a "firm hand" in seeking to have industry agree upon codes, but he will not write any codes, it was explained today at the offices of the administration.

Mayor O'Brien made something of a mystery last night of the reasons behind the Board of Estimate's decision to readvertise contracts for furnishing and equipping the $7,000,000 Bronx County Court House.

TO the Editor of The New York Times: I have received, reprinted in the columns of my college's alumni journal, the opinions of a graduate of long standing regarding the position of the college professor in the present administration. He thinks the influence of the "professorial advisers" baleful, and heartily deplores the fact that such "dogmatizers" now have "the whole country as their laboratory."

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that five new partnerships had been proposed. They are Clifford Co., 52 Wall Street; Richards, Hume Heffernan, 49 Wall Street; Taylor, Bates Co., 48 Wall Street; Myles Keating, 61 Broadway, at Joseph Walker Sons, and Sargeant, Malo Co., Equitable Building, Denver, Colp. Clifford Co. will go into action on Aug. 7 and the others on next Tuesday.

It seems possible that President ROOSEVELT, on his vacation for a few days at Hyde Park, will pursue a policy of what WOODROW WILSON called " watchful waiting." He has now launched the Recovery Act. His other measures of relief and recuperation are in the way of being tried out.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Beat Mata Hari and take the $48,000.
There were more men teachers in the city schools in the last year, both in numbers and in percentage of the total, than at any time in the last twenty years.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 28 -- Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston gave a dinner tonight at Old Trees, their home in First Neek Lane, for Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Cromwell and Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston Jr., who are visiting them. Among their other guests were Mr. and Mrs. C. Tiffany Richardson and Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Gifford Grace, who arrived today to visit Mr. and Mrs. Richardson.

Declaring that a super-tax on retail sales would remain a possibility until the project was definitely dropped both by the Legislature and the New York City administration, the merchants of the city continued yesterday in their fight to avoid such an impost.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The theatre industry's code, as submitted today, stated that the Dramatists Guild of the Authors League had agreed as a means of determining whether the code would encourage theatrical production and increase employment to amend the minimum basic agreement now established.

It would be foolish, to deny that the anti-Tammany movement has been hurt by the events of the past few days. For some weeks the appearance of uncertainty and fumbling on the part of the Fusion committee had not been calculated to exhilarate citizens who sincerely wished the cause well.

ALBANY, July 28 -- With a Statewide milk strike scheduled for Tuesday, Captain Emil Greenberg, representing the Community Councils of New York City, asked Governor Lehman today to remove the Milk Board and leave matters now under its jurisdiction to the special session of the Legislature.

SALEM, N.H., July 28 (AP) -- Given two faultless drives by Tom Berry, the 2-year-old brown filly Bertha C. Hanover today trotted to a double victory at Rockingham park. The performance featured the third program of the Grand Circuit's sixteen-day meeting.

BERLIN, July 28 -- The executive of the National Socialist shop cells organization has withdrawn its commissars from the Karstadt department stores, the "Epa," which is the German equivalent of the Woolworth stores, and all other enterprises, private and public, for which deputies of the Nazi labor organization had previously been appointed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the daughter of a former Republican Governor of New York and Vice President of the United States, as one reared from childhood in a Republican atmosphere, nourished on Republican doctrines, brought up to regard sound money as almost the equivalent of honesty in financial dealing's, I want to put in a word for the New Deal.
To the Editor of The New York Times : I beg to express my gratification on your editorial in this morning's issue upon the nomination of General O'Ryan by the Fusion Council.

Lee Shubert and C.P. Greneker, a member of his executive staff, left here yesterday for Pasadena, Cal., where they will attend the second tryout in this country of the Walter Hasenclever satirical fantasy, "Man of Wax."

LONDON, July 28 -- There was great excitement in the Foreign Exchange Market today following a rumor from Washington that the policy of price-raising by devaluation of the dollar had been suspended temporarily. An immediate scramble to buy dollars at New York began and from the overnight rate of $4.53 1/2 to the pound, the quotation went to $4.32.

ALBANY, July 28 -- Governor Lehman recommended to the Legislature today the enactment of temporary liquor-control measures to become effective immediately in case of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment prior to the next regular session in January.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 28 -- A nation-wide investigation of the disposal of $500,000 worth of United States Treasury bonds, stolen Nov. 29,1932, from the Continental Bank and Trust Company, 30 Broad Street, New York, centred here today.

Holdings of the Central States Electric Corporation, an investment trust, in the North American Company, huge Harrison Williams public utility system, amount to approximately 10 per cent of its stock, it was made known yesterday. Central States, also a member of the Harrison Williams group of companies, revealed the actual number of shares held in its affiliates for the first time.

The Canter colt, Precursor, owned by H.W. Maxwell, a member of the Jockey Club, who races only a small string, captured the featured Somers Purse yesterday at Empire City. It was the second victory of Precursor's career.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- One-fifth of the children in the country are "below par," as a result of the industrial depression, the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor said today.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., July 28 -- Grimy mill workers paused today in their task of putting red hot plates through a 140-inch mill at the Homestead plant of the Carnegie Steel Company to tell Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, what they thought of working conditions in the industry, and how they felt about the new wage scales and working hour provisions which are to result from an adoption of a code of fair practices.

The United Licensed Officers Association, representing the officers of the American merchant marine, requested the Postoffice Department yesterday to defer its proposed reduction in ocean mail contract payments until the officers' salaries have been adjusted under the terms of the National Industrial Recovery Act.

Why is kidnapping apparently on the way to become a thriving "racket" ? Why, to its practitioners, professional or amateur, does it look like a profitable speculative business? A writer in The Law Journal gives the answer, obvious enough but naturally unregarded by the distressed relatives of the kidnapped:
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Among those who sent pledges today to support the President's recovery program were:

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Federal investigation of the shooting of four strikers in the vicinity of the mines of the H.C. Frick Coke Company, subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, was requested by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, in a letter sent today to Secretary Perkins.

While chain-store sales in this district virtually caught up in June with last year, department stores cut their decline and wholesale firms reported a record increase over the same month last year. These facts are shown in the report of the monthly survey of credit and business conditions by the Federal Reserve agent at New York, excerpts from which follow:

ROME, July 28 (AP) -- Premier Mussolini plans to spend his fiftieth birthday tomorrow quietly at Riccione, the Adriatic resort where he went today after two days of conferences with Premier Goemboes of Hungary. With his family, he will enjoy the sea bathing.
LONDON, July 28 -- Members of Parliament started their long vacation tonight and unless something unexpected happens Parliament will not meet again until Nov. 7.
PARIS, July 28 -- England's tennis invaders scored devastating victories over France in each of the two singles matches at the Roland Garros Stadium in Auteuil today.

PEIPING, July 28 -- While the true Japanese purpose in Chahar is still obscure, it is learned from a Japanese source that a Japanese regiment has moved from Miyun and is proceeding westward toward Fengning, close to the Chahar boundary.

Business on the various markets was much, slower yesterday than usual. Transactions on the Stock Exchange amounted to only 1,390,000 shares which, even for a three-hour trading day, is considered small in this extraordinary season. Such a total compares with 2,461,000 shares on Thursday and with a daily average volume that ran well above 5,000,000 shares before the sharp reaction of last week.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- A $1,000,000 damage suit against Gustavus F. Swift Jr. a member of the packing company family, and two others was filed in Federal court here by E.W. Backus, president of the Minnesota and Ontario Paper Company of Minneapolis.

DETROIT, July 28 -- Along with the adjustments which will be necessary under the Motorcar Code, the automobile industry is about to make its annual heavy investment in machinery necessary to the production of next year's models.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 28 (AP) -- The State of Illinois undertook today the organization of a secret, highly cooperative agency to stamp out kidnapping through the united efforts of Federal, State and city authorities.

BARWICK, Ga., July 28 -- The population of Barwick, save for a few of the old folk, is traveling en masse to the Chicago fair, Niagara Falls and points north in celebration of a profitable watermelon crop.
The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

Numerous statistical charts purporting to show that the economic depression has lifted and that no reason exists for emergency rate reductions were offered by the electric companies of the city yesterday at the hearing before the Public Service Commission.

GODTHAAB, Greenland, July 28 (AP) -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, who is here on an aerial map-making expedition, telegraphed an American oil company today requesting the deposit of gasoline and oil at Stavanger, Norway.

PARIS, July 28 -- Fred Perry, the young Englishman whose sensational successive victories over Wilmer Allison, Elisworth Vines Jr. and Henri Cochet in Davis Cup play have attracted world attention, is a comparative newcomer to topflight tennis.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The National Recovery Administration will have to use a firm hand if a code for the cloak and suit industry is to be written and the differences between the union and the employing groups are to be adjusted. After four days of intensive discussion, the conferees were unable to reach an agreement and returned to New York City today.

NEWCASTLE, England, July 28 (Canadian Press) -- The British West Indies cricket team today won its match against Northumberland by an innings and 183 runs. It was the most sensational victory of the tourists' campaign in the United Kingdom.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated July 28:

PHILADELPHIA, July 28 -- About 12,000 miners are on strike in the western Pennsylvania soft coal fields and both the operators and the union apparently in a "fight to the finish" on the question of unionization, Governor Pinchot at hishome in Milford today, said he had been "realiably informed" that gunmen were being imported from New York by the coal operators.

GUILFORD, Conn., July 28 -- E.S. Stevens piloted Lively Lady to victory in the Star Class event, one of the feature races of the inaugural Eastern Connecticut Yacht Racing Association regatta at the Sachem's Head Yacht Club today.
Opposition to General John F. O'Ryan, chosen for the Fusion nomination by the group headed by former Governor Charles S. Whitman, grew yesterday.

PATERSON, N.J., July 28 -- Two electric bombs, exploding within a few minutes of each other today, wrecked the offices of two chiropractors, broke considerable window glass and injured seven persons, six of whom are in hospitals.

Representatives of labor and brewery interests met at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday and accepted the hours and wage provisions of the President's blanket code under the National Recovery Act. It is expected this action will affect some 30,000 workers in the industry.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Establishment of an interdepartmental board for adjustment of contracts between the government and private firms because of increasing costs under the National Industrial Recovery Act was urged today by Robert L. Lund, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, in a letter to Secretary Roper.

With trading still on a reduced scale, prices for commodities broke sharply yesterday on local commodity Exchanges. Not a single gain was reported. The only reason given in most markets for the decline was the early strength in the dollar in foreign exchange circles.
LONDON, July 28 -- It is only a day after the recess of the great World Economic Conference, yet already some of its results are becoming plain and they are paradoxical indeed.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Minimum prices for sales of grain futures on the Board of Trade here, which had been in effect on the first four days of this week, were abolished today and a new schedule covering maximum price changes which will be effective until further notice was announced.

BERLIN, July 28 -- Market recovery in the dollar enabled the Boerse to maintain a firm tendency today, and the usual effects of the weekend and month-end developments failed to halt the prevailing optimistic tone. Although buying by the public continues to show a certain reserve, leading specialties continued strong today.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The War Department issued the following orders today: Madden, Brig. Gen. J.F., U.S.A. to Second Corps Area, Governors Island. N.Y., about Sept. 26.

A sweet reasonableness that will surprise the people of Michigan no less than his Congressional colleagues radiated from Senator COUZENS on his return from the London conference. He was unwilling to call it a failure. He was certain that the seeds of future international compacts were sown. He had been deeply educated in international affairs, in which he was inexperienced, and hoped that was worth the small sum it had cost the Government.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The National Association of Manufacturers sent a bulletin to its members today suggesting that they not sign President Roosevelt's blanket NIRA Code until they had ascertained how the Recovery Administration interpreted the case of labor receiving higher wages but working longer hours than stipulated in the code.

CLEVELAND, July 28 (AP) -- General Hugh S. Johnson, chief of the National Recovery Administration, flew to Cleveland today and told a crowd gathered in the public square: "I went to Detroit to get the automobile code and I have it here in my pocket."

The Department of Justice announced yesterday that its agents nave been instructed to speed up their investigation of suspected hoarders of gold. There is to be " a final check " of the list, followed by publication of names and prosecutions in the courts. This is not the first warning of such action.

PARIS, July 28 -- General John. F. O'Ryan would make a first-class Mayor, in the opinion of Controller Berry, who is returning to New York aboard the liner Berengaria, which leaves Cherbourg tomorrow.
U.S. Department of Agriculture.
LONDON, July 28 -- The American yacht Dorade, sailed by Roderick and Olin J. Stephens, today again won the Fastnet Cup race, which has been described as the Grand National of ocean racing.

Gounod's "Faust," given last night at the New York Hippodrome, enlisted the services of Lawrence Power in the title role, Nino Ruisi as Mephistopheles. Lucy Monroe as Marguerite, Giuseppe Interrante as Valentine, Luigi Dalle Molle as Wagner, Bernice Schalker as Siebel and Alice Homer as Marthe.

ALBANY, July 28 -- The O'Brien administration will present a new plan to meet the city's financial problem tomorrow, when George McAneny, Sanitation Commissioner, lunches with Governor Lehman at the Executive Mansion.

The Most Rev. John J. Dunn, Auxiliary Bishop and Vicar General of the Archdiocese of New York, presented this week to Cardinal Hayes an album containing a "spiritual bouquet" from Bishops, superiors of religious orders, priests, sisters, and brothers in the missions of the Far East.

The four-story dwelling at 102 West Eighty-seventh Street has been leased for a long term by Wolfgang Wurz from the Brevar Realty Corporation. The lessee is renovating the house. A.N. Gitterman and James P. Welden acted as brokers.

HOLLYWOOD, July 28 (AP) -- A direct appeal for government action in the strike of 5,000 workers in Hollywood's major motion-picture studios was made today to President Roosevelt by leaders of the five affected unions.

NEW YORK. Dr. Victor C. Thorne will give a tea dance on Sept. 22 at Thornebrook, his home in Greenwich, Conn., to introduce to society his daughter, Miss Victoria Corse Thorne. A dance will be given for Miss Thorne and Miss Catharine A. Sturges, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Sturges of Fairfield, Conn., on Nov. 29 at the Ritz-Carlton.

Among the 247 devotees of many religions who will address the World Fellowship of Faiths at Chicago next month is an Indian Prince. This Prince has foresworn the age-old caste system because of his belief in the brotherhood of man and has made himself an outcast among his own people.

Because of the suspension of trading today on the security exchanges, business will be suspended to a large extent. The banks will be open, and some of the commodity markets, but otherwise the business will be slow. Beginning on Monday, the markets will operate on the previous five-hour basis.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 28 -- Frank Shields of New York, formerly looked upon as the heir apparent to the American, tennis throne during the ascendancy of William Tilden, today regained his stature as one of the foremost figures of the turf courts.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- An international world police to serve as a clearing house and service unit for the departments of all nations was formed here today after deliberations by police executives of the important cities of Europe, Canada and the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Administration confirmation that Ambassador Welles is attempting to mediate in Cuban politics with the complete approval of President Roosevelt was furnished today when Acting Secretary of State Phillips said:

The wife and daughter of Joseph W. Harriman took the witness stand yesterday in Federal Court. While the indicted banker acted the part pictured for him, they told of his mental decline, which began, they said, with the death of his son Alan in 1928.

Despite the augmented police detail that has guarded the streets of Chinatown since the killing of a tong man in Boston last week, Ging Wing, a member of the On Leong Tong, was slain early this morning in what appeared to be the first outbreak of tong warfare here in four years.
Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association, denied yesterday that the merchants were responsible for loading evils...

PATERSON, N.J., July 29. -- A eering throng of workers meeting at Fairlawn, N.J., this morning scinded a vote taken yesterday and decided to call off the strike that had been in progress during the week at the Textile Dyeing and printinting Company of America, Inc., Fair lawn.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Francis J. Sinnott of Brooklyn was designated today by Postmaster General Farley as Acting Postmaster of Brooklyn. He will take charge of the office at the close of business on Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Two codes designed to restore 1,100,000 persons to jobs in retail establishments and increase payrolls $750,000,000 were filed with the Recovery Administration, tonight. General Johnson was in conference with his aides this evening in an attempt to speed up the agreement on these codes and their acceptance by spokesmen for employers of 5,000,000 men and women in retail establishments by Tuesday.

BUDAPEST, July 29. -- Luis Perley, a member of the Budapest City Council and leader of a radical group of World War veterans, was arrested last night in Budapest on a charge of having plotted to murder Premier Goemboes tonight on his return from Rome.

A meeting to be held here on Aug. 10 is expected to provide a test as to whether the railroads can obtain the support of other forms of transportation for legislation which they have drafted for submission to Congress. Until now, the reaction of the interests which the railroads seek to placate has been negative or lukewarm.
LONDON, July 29 -- Something happened in the House of Commons this week that proves that fascism in Britain is still a long way off.

In an exchange of shots between three police radio cars and a sedan containing three gunmen about midnight last night, Rose Morrale, 24 years old, of 598 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, was shot and wounded in the right arm. She was treated at the Methodist Episcopal Hospital.

IT is an unhappy fact about Hollywood that when a film is exhilarating enough and fine enough and original enough to win critical benedictions and public hallelujahs, it rareiy has an important influence on the pictures that come after it.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 29. -- President Roosevelt indicated today that he was pleasad, rather than disturbed, by the resignation yesterday of J.A. Moffett as vice president and member of the board of directors of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

ATHENS, July 13. -- Explosion of the myth that Chian wine was the most delicious beverage of the ancient world and discovery of the lintel stone of a classical library not mentioned in the chronicles of its time may be considered the chief services of the American excavators who are exploring the Athenian agora for the month of May, if one exclude the Mycenean grave upon which work has been halted because of technical difficulties.

Many national advertisers are operating during the current year under advertising budgets made up for periods of one, three or six months in advance instead of the customary twelve-months' period usually employed in previous years, according to a survey of national advertising budgets released yesterday by the Association of National Advertisers, Inc.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Harris Weinstein, in his discussion of Pieron's theory in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, appears to fall into some error himself when he affirms that "mental processes are dependent upon brain tissue," for he would apparently bring this "brain tissue" into existence spontaneously, whereas it must surely have been preceded by a mental process, inasmuch as a design always implies a designer.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated July 27:
WASHINGTON, July 29. -- The Federal Government's warfare against organized crime throughout the country was getting under way here today.

ALL roads lead to Rome, but some are better marked than others. The inadequacy of highway signs is one of those chronic complaints of motorists which, through sheer repetition, no longer are listened to, like grandaunt's laments about her rheumatism.

EVERY now and then there come whispers or shouts from a Floridan, New Jerseyite or Long Islander to the effect that motion-picture production is being shifted gradually to Florida, New Jersey or Long Island, as the case may be.

THE appeal, drafted in Amsterdam on behalf of the Jews of the world, to the League of Nations to provide "Nansen passports" for those German Jews who are unable to leave Germany, or who have left without passports, recalls the troubled post-war days when those documents came to the rescue of many thousands exiled from their homes.

NEWARK, N.J., July 29 -- Humbrooke, bay mare, owned by Jim Hay of South Orange, scored a spectacular upset in winning the Morristown Trot, feature of the eighth matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Business developments in the week ended on July 22 were overshadowed by the severe break in the stock and organized commodity markets, according to the weekly review of domestic conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

MEMPHIS, July 27 -- Whatever crowing Tennessee Democrats were prepared to engage in following their success in holding the State in line for repeal has been temporarily postponed, largely at the instance of Tennessee Republicans. The Democrats put repeal over, but in doing so they got a jolting the like of which the party in Tennessee has not suffered since the Harding landslide of 1920.

Copyright, 1933, by NANA, Inc., and THE NEW YORK TIMES. The motorship Wyatt Earp, formerly the Fanefjord, which will carry the Ellsworth Transantarctic Flight Expedition, will make a 20,000-mile voyage from Norway to the Ross Sea in Antarctica.

The merchant shipping of the world totaled 67,920,185 tons, a decrease of 1,814,125 tons during the last twelve months, according to the annual tables published yesterday by Lloyd's Register of Shipping. The shipyards of the world showed little activity during the year, whereas old tonnage was destroyed.

FOUR conductors will direct the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in the course of this week at the stadium: Hans Kindler, Hans Lange, Paul Whiteman and Willem van Hoogstraten. Mr. Kindler's last two appearances will take place tonight and Wednesday.

WITHIN the last month air history has been made with a series of varied flights which have tested every phase of aeronautical science. First, in interest if not in significance, is the massed flight of the Italian air fleet, which already has included one formation transoceanic hop of 1,500 miles.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- New types of scientific divining rods, for the ferreting out of treasures buried deep beneath the surface of the earth, were described here today before the closing sessions of the Sixteenth International Geological Congress.

By H.I. BROCK THIS week they will be racing at Saratoga, as they have done since the Sixties of the last century. It was then that John Morrissey. the Tipperary-born prizefighter who defeated John C. Heenan, who made and lost vast fortunes as gambler, who was twice elected to Congress, became promoter of the first race track there.

THE greatest effort at directing public opinion toward a national objective since the war, perhaps in the history of the country, began last week with the direct appeal by General Hugh S. Johnson to more than 12,000 communities in the United states to form committees to carry on the struggle against depression.

NEWARK, N.J., July 29 -- The Bears increased their first-place lead to a game and a half today by defeating Rochester, 5 to 4, in the final game of the series. In the eighth Jack Saltzgaver's single scored Red Rolfe with the winning run.

PARIS, July 14. THE two Russian ballet companies have been and gone and it is now possible to form some estimate of their respective merits. They have both passed on to London, and one of them -- the Monte Carlo ballet -- is to be seen after the Summer in New York.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., July 29. -- National Guard troops moved into Fayette County late today to preserve order in the soft coal strike area under the authority of a proclamation issued by Governor Pinchot at Harrisburg.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Approval of a marketing agreement to stabilize prices and practices within the fluid milk industry of the Chicago metropolitan milk shed was announced today by Secretary Wallace.
WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Eleven New York City banks with billions of dollars in resources pledged their cooperation to the National Recovery Administration today.

Gauging the work-creating possibilities of the administration's plan for limiting working hours, the National Industrial Conference Board yesterday announced that the application last May of the thirty-five hour week in manufacturing industry and forty-hour week in non-manufacturing pursuits would have added 1,681,000 more workers to the number employed in that month.
Many Happy Returns. MOTHER EARTH: But why should people be interested in my birthday?

America's system of public schools may be revolutionized if President Roosevelt's New Deal works. This is the conviction which is growing in the thousands of school teachers gathered this Summer on the Columbia University campus and giving their seminars and forums an unprecedented vitality and enthusiasm.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Under the headline, "Paris Doctor Warns Against Sun Bathing." THE TIMES published correspondence from Paris drawing the attention of sun bathing enthusiasts to the dangers of immoderate exposure of the skin to sunshine.

BERLIN, July 28. -- Heary Ford's dictum, "history is bunk," does not find support among the Nazi leaders. At least, it they should privately admit there is more or less humbug about the presentation of history in the schools they would nevertheless hold, in contradistinction to Mr. Ford, that skillfully used, it can be converted into most valuable "bunk."

DETROIT. INDUSTRIAL, code regulation of automobile manufacturing is almost certain to have the effect of raising motor car prices. This conclusion can be drawn from broad hints that company executives have let drop recently in speaking of the future under NRA operation.

PAUL-JEAN TOULET was one of the hors-d'oeuvres of modern French letters. There are many of them, men with unique and fastidious talents approaching genius who are not hailed by the vast general public but are rather coterie-gods, little idols to smaller groups.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 29 -- Over a twenty-nine-mile triangular course that from the start was enshrouded in fog, Weetamoe, Frederick H. Prince's big racing sloop, again defeated Gerard B. Lambert's Vanitie off here today.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP). -- James A. Moffett of New York, who resigned yesterday as vice president of Standard Oil of New Jersey, was pointed to authoritatively today as the man who will enforce oil production control.

GOLF went democratic even before the national political tide turned in that direction at the Presidential polls in 1932. In the great boom period in this country, the simple pastime fostered by the thrifty inhabitants of the seacoast of Scotland was converted into a luxurious game garnished with gorgeous appointments and surroundings.

ONCE again the sometimes grinning, sometimes scowling giant Feng Yu-hsiang has come into the limelight in China. To the intelligentsia be is a clown, but to the peasants, coolies and a few reformers he has been at intervals the hero of China's post-Empire political melodrama.

TOKYO, July 29. -- Reorganization and reinforcement of the Japanese forces in Manchuria are being planned, according to the newspaper Nichi Nichi, which, though it does not quote any authority, is frequently well informed on army policy.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation authorized today the purchase of $995,000 worth of preferred stock in seven reorganized banks.

PARIS, July 28. -- France is following with that passionate interest which her intellectuals always give to any new movement what is described here as President Roosevelt's "experiment." Opinion, however, is divided. There are always two sides to the French mental outlook.

HERE is a very practical and useful book for all who are concerned with school affairs in their relation to local or higher government. The author, who is Professor of Education In the University of Chicago, explains that the volume has grown out of course he has been giving for several years in the legal and constitutional basis of school administration.

Instead of using a single 1,350-horse power motor in his speed boat Miss Britain. HI, Hubert Scott-Paine, challenger for the Harmsworth Trophy, has four Napier motors in his craft, according to reports received here. They are said to develop a power somewhat comparable to the 6,400 of the four motors arranged in tandem in Gar Wood's Miss America X.
BRYN MAWR, Pa., July 29. -- Dick Freeman of Princeton polo fame helped the Bryn Mawr Freebooters carry off the honors in the round-robin tournament today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While you laud the convention regulating the manufacture and distribution of arcotics, you do not mention two interesting points, both of which have been covered in dispatches to your paper -- Japan and Holland did not ratify the convention; Manchukuo has taken steps to plant enormous areas to poppies.
One hundred and twenty-five days out of Christiansand, Norway, the yawl Trade Wind, a 25-footer, sailed into New York Harbor yesterday and docked at Sixty-ninth Street, Brooklyn.

THIS is a long and emotional novel. It goes on and on playing upon all the heartstrings that come within its reach, reducing the obvious to its lowest common demoninator. Clearly intended to be realistically lifelike as opposed to the romanticism of its nineteenth century prototypes, it is actually for sentimental readers who do not care to think their reading matter through.

A PROGRAM exchange has been effected between WOR and WNYC. The municipal station receives WOR's non-commercial Sunday features between 5 and 7 P.M.; on Thursdays from 9 to 9:30 P.M., and the symphony concert beginning at 8 o'clock on Saturday nights.
With activity in the major industries at or near their high marks for the year, there were comparatively few signs of a seasonal letup in general business last week.

MADRID. NOWHERE down the kaleidoscopic parade of the centuries has the church been so intermingled with a nation's life in all its countless aspects as in Spain. The cross and the flag entered Granada side by side, after freeing Spain from the vestiges of Moorish domination.

DODGE CITY, Kan., July 27 -- The high plains area of the South-west which has been hit by two successive wheat failures and drought of unparalleled severity, sees a chance for rehabilitation in the Roosevelt administration's pubic works program.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 29. -- Danseuse, 6-year-old chestnut mare owned by Mrs. J. Vernon Bouvier 3d of East Hampton, won the hunter championship at the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club's annual show today. Mrs. Bouvier rode her entry.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Cal., July 29 (AP). -- A tall woman with a crown of gray hair, alert blue eyes and easy carriage may be seen these Summer mornings walking on the sloping lawn which surrounds her hill-top home.

NEWPORT. -- The Summer colony here this week swing into the homestretch -- the month, of August -- going at full speed. Certainly there is enough on the calendar for the present week to keep all hands busy.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 22 amounted to 648,914 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 708 cars, or 0.1 per cent, more than for the preceding week, and 147,002 cars, or 29.3 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, but 93,567 cars, or 12.6 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP). -- General Johnson, the Recovery Administrator, stated today that the open shop provision in the trade practice code submitted by the automobile industry seemed to be in accord with the recovery program. He expressed the opinion that it would be in conformity with the act guaranteeing employes the right to bargain collectively.

BUENOS AIRES, July 29. -- Banks must reduce their interest rates and be content with smaller profits was a Presidential ultimatum delivered today. President Agustin P. Justo uttered it to representatives of all national and foreign banks after he had called them to the executive offices for a conference.

EARLY launching of August sales during the week by some stores served to check the midsummer decline usually experienced in retail trade. These promotions will be featured on a much wider scale than in recent years by many stores, beginning this week.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP). -- The Federal Narcotic Commission announced today that it had conclusive evidence teat at least 200 thoroughbreds, competing in as many races on American tracks in the last eight months, had been doped.
DUBLIN, July 28 -- The Senate has thrown down a new challenge to the government this week, refusing to pass the Economies Bill.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 29 -- The Maidstone Club's eight annual women's invitation tennis tournament for the gold cups donated by Secretary of the Treasury William H. Woodin got away to a slow start today, only two matches being played.
COLOGNE, July 29. -- The twenty-fifth international Esperanto congress will open here tomorrow with more than 1,000 delegates from thirty countries.

THEODOR PLIVIER. who wrote "The Kaiser's Coolies," is the author of "The Kaiser Goes: The Generals Remain," which The Macmillan Company will publish in August. This is a novel of the last days of the World Wax and of the events preceding and following the Kaiser's night to Holland, told from the viewpoint of the common soldier and his family.
DES MOINES, Iowa, July 29. -- Young America is traveling in greater numbers than last year, despite President Roosevelt's effort through the Civilian Conservation Corps to curb the movement.

HISTORICAL houses are increasingly becoming the objectives of motor trips for antiquarians, who find in them a vivid re-creation of the past and numerous suggestions for correct backgrounds for furnishings which they may own themselves.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity declined for the first time since March 18 in the week ended July 22. Losses in four of the six series brought the combined figure to 95.8 as compared with 99.0 in the previous week and 64.6 for the corresponding week of last year.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 29 -- Stroking their way to victories in ten of the twenty-five championship events the Buffalo West Sides tonight had won the Royal Canadian Henley Regatta for the second straight year.

The wounding of a second Chinese in a Harlem restaurant shortly after 3 o'clock yesterday morning, a few hours after one had been slain by gunmen in Chinatown, led Assistant Chief Inspector Sullivan, head of the Detective Division, to call on the Federal authorities yesterday to aid in suppressing a new tong war outbreak.

CHERBOURG, July 19 -- Cherbourg's new deep-water port, which enables big ocean liners to come in and tie up at new piers instead of debarking passengers on tenders out in the roads, will be inaugurated July 30 in the presence of President Lebrun.

PARIS, July 16. -- In the future, when historians shall treat of the present era they will ask whether the miscarriage of the World Economic Conference was not an inspiration for an entente among the great European powers.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 29. -- Mrs. Henry P. Davison was hostess this afternoon at her estate at Peacock Point to more than 500 members of the Nassau County Council, Republican recruits, young men and women of voting age. They played tennis, swam on the private beach, participated in a potato race on the wide fields and cooked a barbecue supper on the sands.

FOUR new pictures, two of which are billed as "multistar vehicles," will be released next month by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. They are "Tugboat Annie," with Marie Dressier and Wallace Beery; "Turn Back the Clock," with Lee Tracy; "Show World," with Alice Brady, Frank Morgan, Jimmy Durante and several others, and "Night Flight," with Helen Hayes, John and Lionel Barrymore, Clark Gable, Robert Montgomery, Myrna Loy and William Gargan.
WASHINGTON, July 29. -- The code of fair competition for the automobile industry, submitted today to the National Recovery Administration, reads in full:

DETROIT, July 27 -- Michigan's first Democratic Governor in nearly two decades has the distinction of being the first Governor of the State against whom recall petitions have been circulated. Nor is the effort one of Republican Michigan to discredit a Democratic administration, since the leaders of both parties have expressed themselves decidedly against it.
LONDON, July 29. -- Charwomen today occupied the "seats of the mighty," cleaning up after the dispersal of the World Economic Conference.

The Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation has reported a net loss $10,695,503 after taxes, charges, depreciation of capital assets, amortization of leaseholds, loss on investments and capital assets and other deductions for 1932, but before providing for dividends in arrears on the cumulative preferred stocks of subsidiaries.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the "average citizens" referred to by Professor Fisher in his recent letter to THE TIMES, I resent being told that my sort "does not distinguish between a price and a price level." In recent years the general price level has fluctuated so widely that even the dullest must have had the difference brought home to him.

FOX Movietone City covers an area of about 110 acres in a strip of land approximately a mile long and a quarter mile wide, between Beverly Hills and Fox Hills, about five miles from the Pacific Ocean, and an equal distance from Hollywood.

Dog fanciers in the United States are much interested in receiving and analyzing the new code of ethics which the American Kennel Club has just completed and which shortly will be distributed in the form of a pamphlet.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 29. -- The old Seventh Regiment, New York National Guard, was reviewed here this afternoon by Rear Admiral frank R. Lackey, commander of the New York State Naval Militia. The review commemorated the fiftieth anniversary of the first encampment of the Seventh Regiment at Peekskill.

Harrison Grey Fiske, noted as a producer of Shakespeare, Ibsen and the seventeenth century dramatists, and as the husband of the late Mrs. Minnie Maddern Fiske, famous actress, will observe his seventy-second birthday anniversary today. He will observe it, he declared yesterday, by not reflecting bitterly on the state of the contemporary theatre.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 29. -- With five national championships and many other events on the program, the fourth annual Summer tournament of the American Bridge League will begin. Monday in the Municipal Convention Hall on the boardwalk here and will continue throughout the week.

WASHINGTON. PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S midsummer vacation at Hyde Park, brief though it may be, was made possible only through detailed arrangements for the transfer of the "nerve centre" of the administrative machinery to Poughkeepsie.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Persistent liquidation by longs was under way today on the Board of Trade here and for the second day all grains closed at the maximum declines permitted under the exchange's regulations. Wheat, rye and barley were off 5 cents a bushel, corn 4 cents and oats 3 cents at the last, with sellers at the closing figures.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Seasonal influences brought a little slower tempo in trade and industry this week. Compared with last year, however, sales of merchandise at wholesale and retail were sharply higher.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I believe that your paper wants to be fair in both your criticisms and praises. You have that reputation and in view of that I am writing you about the Bronx Terminal Market. The material contained herein was sent to John P. O'Brien, Mayor of New York, Jan. 21 of this year.

DETROIT, July 29. -- Henry Ford tomorrow will observe his seventieth birthday, but there will be no celebration of the occasion and, aside from going over the usual great number of congratulatory messages, the automobile manufacturer expects to spend the day quietly with his family at Fair Lane, his estate in Dearborn.

Generous supplies of fresh fruits and vegetables appeared in the wholesale markets throughout the week, it was said yesterday by George G. Royce, director of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets. Reasonable prices prevailed and many commission merchants found difficulty in disposing of daily consignments because of light buying.

THIS is the season for apartment hunting, honeymooning, canoeing through Long Lake and -- writing pieces about next year's theatrical prospects. In an earnest, and perhaps misguided, effort to learn what next Fall will bring to Broadway this column started asking around.

WASHINGTON, July 29. - To start quickly expenditures for Federal aid highway construction in the States, for which $400,000,000 was earmarked in the recovery act, the Cabinet Advisory Board has evolved a plan to give money in advance to States unable to pay their own way.

GUILFORD, Conn., July 29. -- Repeating the victory scored yesterday in the Eastern Connecticut Yacht Racing Association regatta, Lively Lady finished first again today in the star class. Forsaking his place on tile committee boat, Robert C. Stevens Jr., chairman of tha race committee, took the helm of his boat and won by over three minutes.

Further news of the adventures in upper Burma of Marmaduke M. Mizzle, the persisting Mincing Lane caraway seed merchant, was received yesterday from Skranji-Ypangi by his friend, the spice merchant of Water Street. Skranji-Ypangi is ten parasangs above Mejongyi, whence came Mizzle's last communique.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 29 -- Max Marston of Philadelphia today fought his way into the final of the sixth Shenecossett invitation golf tournament by defeating Henry Lanman, Providence, 1 up, in a torrid battle played in scorching heat.

Sir FREDERICK POLLOCK, eminent as a judge and law-writer, is in his eighty-eigth year. One turns eagerly to his article in the current Quarterly Review on " Talkers I Have Known." In a life so long and rich in friendships with distinguished persons he must have heard plenty of golden talk.

AN announcer is on the air! "Well, here we are at Floyd Bennett Field -- the municipal airport of the City of New York and some time between now and the wee hours we will give you a word-picture of Wiley Post's arrival -- the first man to fly solo around the world.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 29 -- The second annual midsummer dog show of the mid-Jersey Field Dog Club, staged today at Inglehurst, the estate of Charles T. Ingley, executive vice president of the American Kennel Club, proved an outstanding event of the year in the dog world.

ST. LOUIS, July 27. -- Missouri will vote in favor of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment on Aug. 19, but the drys have started court proceedings which they hope will nullify the election and carry the final decision over until the general election of November, 1934.

PARIS, July 29. -- Lyolene stresses youthful, narrow pencil-line dresses for day wear, with real or simulated two-piece effects. It corrects the figure's architecture by wide-stitched tucks, finishing seams, widening shoulders and narrowing hips without an artificial appearance.

MR. LORWIN'S scholarly and thoroughly objective study is a timely contribution to the profound revaluation of values now under way in the United States. Although completed apparently before the adoption of the National Industrial Recovery Act, the book anticipates in detail the problems that confront labor in the situation that gave birth to that legislation.

With the security exchanges closed to permit their clerical organizations to catch up with their work, Wall Street business was sharply curtailed yesterday. The banks were open and there was trading in foreign exchanges. Most of the commodity markets also were open.

Nervous fluctuations of prices over a range of a quarter cent a pound characterized trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. Following Fridays break of $2 a bale, prices declined another dollar at one time, but they recovered, and at the close of the market were 2 poins lower to 2 points higher than on Friday, or a movement of 10 cents a bale either way.

On Wednesday, July 19, the dollar reached its lowest price on foreign markets. From that day's depreciation of 31 per cent there was a fairly steady recovery last Thursday it was 26 1/8 per cent. It was not accidental that this recovery should have begun on the same day with the break in prices.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The plight of the sorely beset Yankees became more acute than ever today as their strategic retreat on the north, bank of the Potomac was turned into almost a complete rout.
The eleventh annual series for the Wightman Cup will be held on Friday and Saturday at the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills.

THE roaming Bedouin sometimes fulfills an archaeological function. He is ultimately responsible for the fact that our expedition, the largest excavating group in the Near East, is encamped in a waterless waste fifty miles northeast of Bagdad.

THE Humper, who was an itinerant oil driller with a flair for women, didn't want to go back to Trinidad because there was a girl there he was sure to make the mistake of marrying. So Maitland, his chief, confronted with a practically even decision, allowed this trifling fact to sway his judgment the necessary inch or two.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.L., July 29. Several hundred members of the Summer colonies in Southampton, East Hampton and Westhampton attended the horse show today at the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club. Various entertainments were held throughout the day at estates for week-end visitors.
James Simpson, formerly chairman of Marshall Field Co. of Chicago and now chairman of the former Insull utility group in the Chicago area, sailed yesterday on the Cunard liner Aquitania.

PARIS. TWO principal characters divide the interest of the textile style serial, soon to be presented in the Winter instalment of Paris fashion showings. They are the Rough Diamond, with a heart of gold, and the Superslick Customer, who looks too good to be true, but turns out a solid citizen in the end.

An Increase of 38 per cent In man-hours worked in manufacturing plants during June, as compared with May, substantially augmented the purchasing power of the country, the National Industrial Conference Board, Inc., announced yesterday.

Asserting that a forty-hour week "is not feasible or practicable in the restaurant industry," the National Restaurant Institute made public yesterday a letter to General Hugh S. Johnson, enclosing a code of fair competition it has drafted for the industry.

THE whole history of the World War will never be told; it could not be without the telling of many millions of individual histories. Wars are not the actions of nations, the movements of troops, the winning or losing of battles -- at least modern wars are not.

BAYHEAD, N.J., July 29 -- This quiet, conservative Summer resort on the shores of Barnegat Bay is gunning for a "Peeping Tom." The men of the bungalow colony of some 2,500 Summer residents are hunting him with clubs and shotguns. The women are locking all doors each night.

The national industrial recovery program has displaced the Russian experiment in interest among Europeans, as its success or failure will have far-reaching effects throughout the Continent, I.A. Hirschmann, publicity director of Lord Taylor, said here yesterday.

ALBANY, July 29. -- A thinly veiled threat to withhold State aid from county fairs which allow 3.2 beer to be sold was contained in a letter made public today by Charles H. Baldwin, Commissioner of Agriculture.

German citizens with extensive capital holdings in foreign countries, including the United States, have so far shown little disposition to report their holdings of foreign exchange or other assets to the Reich exchange authorities as required under the German law of June 8, despite the severe penalties for willful failure to comply with the law, according to the view prevalent in International banking circles.

Out of $7,250,000 made available a year ago by Wall Street banks for the refinancing of home mortgages in New York State, only $3,045,000 was called into use, it was disclosed last week by Charles O'Connor Hennessy, president of the Savings and Loan Bank of the State of New Tork, through which the fund was released.

OMAHA, July 27 -- Corn Belt business is pretty generally set to line up under the President's voluntary emergency code to create employment, raise wages and increase purchasing power; not in a spirit of yielding to compulsion, but with an apparently sincere feeling that the end to be attained is highly desirable and the means proposed will probably be effective.

Almost every pulpit in Manhattan will have a visiting preacher this morning. With few exceptions the pastors of the city's churches are on their vacations. Four of the leading Protestant Episcopal churches will have Bishops in their pulpits. Many churches will have college presidents or professors as their preachers.

STOCKHOLM. LIGHT on the early developments of Etruscan art comes through the recent finds of a Swedish archaeological expedition on the island of Cyprus. The 18,000 objects unearthed -- comprising terra cotta and stone sculpture, engraved metal, gold and silver jewelry -- will be shown to the public for the first time in connection with the congress of art historians that assembles in Stockholm the first week in September, as already indicated in these columns.

BERLIN, July 29. -- While the economic reconstruction of the new Germany is marking time and the corporative State is still in the making, the Teutonization of the Third Reich -- the equivalent in the view of its rulers to eliminating Jews and Jewish influence -- is proceeding with unabated vigor.

AS the New Deal goes into effect -- with control codes under way for our basic industries and with the whole fabric of American business, from farm to factory and to store, being woven into a pattern of planned economy -- one turns to the ledger of the nation's resources.

SALEM, N.H., July 29 (AP). -- The Grand Circuit's star pacers and trotters appeared back In form today, for doubles were registered In all three of the two-heat races that featured the fourth program of the sixteen-day Rockingham Park meeting.

The reorganization of the North German Lloyd and Hamburg-American steamship lines and the election of a common executive board at meetings last week in Hamburg and Bremen upset recent predictions of shipping men and caused widespread discussion of its possible effect upon international trade.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Bridge enthusiasts will have their innings in a growing round of Summer social activities on the north Jersey shore this week. The seventh, annual national championship tournament of the American Bridge League will open tomorrow at the Asbury Park Convention Hall and continue through Saturday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The "uprising of the radicals" which now disturbs so many of us is not nearly so great a menace as the "downsitting of the conservatives." Fortunately, the unthinking, misinformed and sometime cowardly leaders of nearly every class in our country are rapidly being repudiated.
