LONDON, July 29. -- After passing through a period of reproach and misrepresentation almost amounting to abuse such as has rarely been encountered by the representatives of any great country, the United States delegation to the Economic Conference is proceeding homeward, in the phrase of the old trotting ring, with its "head up and its tail over the dashboard."

ON Friday next one of the greatest of American dance events will occur when the Santo Domingo Corn Dance is performed by Indians of the South-west. Because of its distance from metropolitan centres, it will be out of the reach of many hundreds of dancers and others who might deem it a privilege to be present.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 28 -- Practically a 100 per cent response has been made to President Roosevelt's Industrial Recovery Plan in the Eighth Federal Reserve District and the reports of increased wages and shorter hours come from many concerns.

An alleged plan to embarrass George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, by asking for a Congressional investigation of his office, was revealed yesterday at the hearing before Judge Caffey into a charge that forged affidavits had been presented to the court.

THE trail is cold when Inspector Frost of Scotland Yard is sent to Crevenna Cove in Cornwall to Investigate the death of the man whose body was found on the sands near the Devil's Beacon. A week has passed since the murder, and all that is known of the man is that he called himself John Jones and that he had kept pretty much to himself during his brief stay in the neighborhood.

A SPEEDING and clamorous age, enamored of its own noise and speed, may think that it is not interested in either sacraments or simple folk -- its primitive ancestors -- but, notwithstanding all its raucous clatter and superficiality, it is still well salted with the saving grace of people who like to read thought-provoking books and enjoy the process of enlarging and illuminating both their inner and their outer horizons.

James Butler's home-bred filly, Star Fire, 5 -- 2, considered hopelessly outmatched in the Yonkers Handicap, won decisively by a length and a half to the astonishment of 6,000 spectators at Empire City yesterday. The only other starter was C.V. Whitney's Clotho, which had been made a 7-to-20 favorite.

While officials of the national administration have protested that the course of the dollar in foreign exchange markets should have no bearing on the internal price structure in this country, traders in commodities have persisted in attaching great importance to every movement of the currency.

SUFFERN, N.Y., July 29 -- Indignant at what they call "the near-nudist tendencies" of some of the members of the German-American Commercial League, which has rented a forty-acre camp site in Viola Road here, residents of the section have appealed to the police and are planning to go before the Ramapo Town Board and the Ramapo Zoning Commission to have the camp barred as a public nuisance.

ST. LOUIS, July 29 (AP) -- Back in his world series form of 1931, Pepper Martin crashed out a home run with two on base in the tenth inning to give the Cardinals a 9-to-6 triumph in the series opener with the Cubs today.

IT cannot be said that the discussion of the earth's age at the International Geological Congress last week told us more than we learned from the meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science held last June at Chicago.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., July 29. -- The role of the "forgotten man" was thrust here today upon Charles Fretz, a circus sideshow performer. Buried alive since last Monday, he passed last night six feet beneath the ground while the owner of the circus, avoiding service of legal papers and the paying of his performers, disappeared.

To The Editor of The New York Times: One of the best things I have read in your paper for many days is your editorial comment on Professor Moley's "apology" for the apparent failure of the London conference. The idea of "serene and detached" international friendships is one that should be intensively cultivated.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., July 29. -- Miss Jeanne Nehrbas'a capable brown mare, Cleopatra, captured the championship for saddle horses over 14.2 hands at the Blind Brook Polo Club's charity horse show today.

PARIS, July 27 -- Many Holiday-resort novelties are appearing. Silver masts draped with a whole string of enameled pennants form a seagoing shoulder pin on sweater or dinner frocks. They are seen at yacht clubs.
WASHINGTON. PRICES go up again on Sept. 1. This advance notice is given so that you may take advantage of the present low prices." "We reserve the right to raise prices against further notice."

LONDON, July 29. -- David Lloyd George, who has been in the limelight for the past week because of his demand for all-around tariffs including meat, declares in an exclusive interview in tomorrow's Sunday Times:

JONATHAN GREEN began life in a small Pennsylvania town as the son of a hopelessly alcoholic father and a mother who supported the family by taking in washing. Johnny was a stupid, overgrown, rather loutish youth, with no moral sense worth mentioning.

WASHINGTON, D.C., July 29 -- Statistics on the effects of the depression on American children, gathered over a period of two years from organizations in many parts of the country, have just been made public by the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- The Pennsylvania coal strike is viewed here as a major battle between the open-shop interests and the forces of organized labor in industry; and it was giving the National Recovery Administration considerable worry today.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 29. -- By breaking 50 straight targets, G.E. Mole took the high scratch cup at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today.

BOSTON, July 27 -- Not without reason do Democratic leaders both in the State and the nation contemplate with some apprehension the political situation in Boston. The city is overwhelmingly Democratic. In any bi-partisan election for Mayor the Democratic candidate would always be due to win, but the nominally non-partisan syssem under the present charter may easily result this year in the election of a Republican, as was the case eight years ago.

TORONTO, Ont., July 29 -- The estimated surplus of Teck-Hughes Gold Mines, Ltd., after allowing for taxes and depreciation, in the nine months of the fiscal year ended on May 31 was $2,628,837. This was equal to 49.6 cents a share on the company's 4,807,144 shares of $1 par value.

The Saratoga race meeting, which many admirers regard as the greatest in the country, will begin on Thursday to run for twenty-seven days. Stretching back almost to the beginning of the sport in this State, Saratoga long has been noted for the number and tradition of its stakes.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 29 -- Ally Cornwell won two races at the Nassau Driving Club matinee at the Fair Grounds today.
CHICAGO. CHICAGO'S Board of Trade, the centre of the world's buying and selling of grains, has just passed through perhaps the most dramatic period in its history.

A history of fifty years of ballroom dancing, compiled by Oscar Duryea in connection with the golden jubilee convention of the Dancing Masters of Amercia, Inc., now in session here, depicts the evolution of dances from the so-called elegant Eighties to the present day.

WASHINGTON, D.C. -- A long - cherished development of park recreational facilities is being undertaken in many parts of the country as a result of the inclusion of State parks in President Roosevelt's emergency conservation program.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Dixiana's filly Far Star showed the way to seven other of the leading 2-year-olds in training to win with surprising ease in the $47,115 Arlington Futurity before 25,000 at Arlington Park today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 27. -- The initial response of business and industry in this State to the President's blanket industrial code was a spontaneous pledge to support the recovery program. Leaders in finance, merchandising, transportation and manufacture registered immediate zeal to abide by the new regime.

The Brooklyn Museum has placed on exhibition in Asiatic Hall a varied collection of Mohammedan art dating from the tenth to the nineteenth centuries. A few articles such as an alabaster mortar from Mesopotamia, 700 B.C., go back to earlier periods.

OF late years ballets have often formed a sort of corollary to the Covent Garden opera season. This year an exceptionally brief term of opera left the field open for the successors and imitators of Diaghileff, who have made full use of their opportunity.

SLOATSBURG, N.Y., July 29 -- A camp in the woods and a graduate school of higher learning the open sky and classrooms; the glint of a lake's smooth surface and the smells of a laboratory, with a learned professor reciting formulae; psychology, philosophy, science, combined with dancing, sports and handicrafts; this may seem an Alice-in-Wonderland jumble.
ATLANTA, July 27 -- Governor Eugene Talmadge believes that the duty of a Governor is to govern, and whether wisely or not, that is precisely what he is doing these moisture-laden dog days.

George U. Harvey, Borough President of Queens, charged yesterday that Controller Berry's failure to register nearly 100 contracts for assessable public improvements in Queens, which had been let more than six months ago, would result in a 100 per cent increase or more than $1,000,000 in cost for the improvements to Queens taxpayers.

SOME one recently set forth In a charming and persuasive magazine article the conviction that the essay Is a declining and practically defunct form of literary expression. It is an interesting theory, but as long as there are writers who produce and publishers who publish such vita intriguing and delightful essays as those which compose this book it remains merely a theory and nothing more.

DR. CASE'S discriminating and richly informed study of the economic, political and social development of the early Christian church has as its central thought the conviction "that a religion so utterly lacking in social prestige at the outset should become the only respectable faith for men of culture and high position in the Roman Empire is one of the most astounding facts in ancient history."

NEWARK, N.J., July 29. -- Colonel William H. Kelly, head of the New Jersey State Department of Banking and Insurance, announced today his approval of the merger of five building and loan associations here. The group will become the New Empire Building and Loan Association, which will have resources in excess of $3,000,000.

OCEAN CITY, Md., July 29. -- Albert C. Ritchie, Governor of Maryland, guest here of State Controller William F. Gordy for the week-end, suffered a hemmorhage of the nose late last night, requiring the services of two surgeons and a trained nurse.

MR. ALDINGTON calls his latest novel "a romance" and certainly it celebrates a love story of more than usual ardor and fulfillment. But his subtitle is expressive for another and more significant reason, since the book, through its hero, Tony Clarendon, is permeated by a romantic philosophy of life.

ON display in the local offices or the Fox Film Corporation is the original manuscript of "The Power and the Glory," written by Preston Sturges, author of "Strictly Dishonorable" and "Child of Manhattan." It reveals, among other things, Mr. Sturges's refusal to be limited by the traditional canons of screen story-writers.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., July 29 -- Displaying the smooth stroke which earned her three second places in the national swimming championships at Jones Beach recently, Miss Susan Robertson of the Women's S.A. of New York successfully defended her Metropolitan A.A.U. senior 880-yard free-style title today.
WHAT'S new along fashion's Rialto? Hats, of course. In spite of the fact that they add the finishing touch to one's costume, they are the first out of the box when it comes to the season's styles.

BUFFALO, July 27.-The operation, of the new Federal laws to promote economic recovery have become, in their local effect, the major subject of community interest to a degree that has relegated to second place even a heated struggle over the selection of candidates for Mayor.

BOSTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Red Sox gave Bob (Lefty) Grove his second straight defeat today in downing the Athletics, 8 to 1. Eight hits were made off Grove in six innings. He was removed for a pinch batter and Cain allowed five hits and four runs in the last two sessions.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 -- A double victory rewarded the Dodgers today for more than five hours of battling with the Phillies in intense heat. They beat Shotton's men in the opener, 12 to 11, but had an easier time taking the nightcap, 14 to 4.

A majority of the laws under which beer may be sold legally in the various States show "encouraging indications of a new attitude toward liquor and liquor regulations," it was said yesterday by Mrs. John S. Sheppard.

BUDGETEERS hesitant about making an automobile trip to the Century of Progress Fair may be encouraged by the experience of three young New Yorkers, of whom I was one. We recently made this journey from New York, keeping a statistical record of our mileage and expenses.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 29 -- A tribute to the late William L. Ward of Port Chester for his "wise, faithful and creative leadership" as chairman of the Westchester County Republican committee was made public by members of the committee here today.

Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Merchants Tax Committee, announced yesterday that despite reports of a possible change in the city's tax program the committee was pushing the work of organizing 138,000 retail shopkeepers and their 700,000 employes, to develop cooperation with labor and the consuming groups.

With a hot southwest wind blowing over the city all day, New York sweltered yesterday in mid-Summer temperatures that reached a maximum of 91 degrees. Little or no relief was promised for today, the forecast being for fair and continued warm weather, with fresh winds from the southwest.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- J. Edgar Hoover, chief of the Justice Department's Bureau of Investigation, was appointed by Attorney General Cummings today as director of the Division of Investigation created by the President's executive order of June 10.

BERLIN, July 29 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- The political police today granted permission, to the Jewish Telegraphic Agency to reopen its Berlin, bureau for the distribution of news to the agency's subscribers in Germany. The order, effective Monday, follows several days of effort on the part of George S. Messersmith, United States Consul General, in behalf of the American-owned news service.

To the Music Editor. Regardless of whether one agrees or disagrees with the so-called Marxist approach to art, I believe that Mr. Downes's criticism of Tchemodanoff's "A History of Music in Connection with the History of Social Development," in THE TIMES of July 23, was rather unfair.

As a result of the improvement in business activity and the rise in commodity prices since the beginning of March, earnings of leading American industrial corporations in the second quarter showed a large gain, compared with the figures for the similar period of last year, and for the first quarter of this year.

BELLE HARBOR, L.I., July 29. -- William Feldhusen, Staten Island's star professional outboard driver, cut through the choppy waters of Jamaica Bay today, winning two races and registering a total of 1,600 points. As a result he gained the Mayor O'Brien trophy awarded to celebrate the revival of the Long Island speedboat championships.

There is no reason to question the sincerity of the final words of the message which President ROOSEVELT sent to Prime Minister MACDONALD as the World Economic Conference adjourned. He said: "You can count on our continued efforts toward world rehabllitation." Europeans may be excused if they now regard such assurances from Washington with a degree of skepticism.

HOLLYWOOD, July 29 (AP). -- Incipient clashes between striking film technicians and those who refused to go out in the general strike of union workers in the motion picture studios caused tensity in Hollywood tonight.

THE story of the attempts to establish the first English colony on the shores of America is one of discouragement and heartbreak. It was a critical period in the history of the British Empire, as her ablest statesmen foresaw that the battle for supremacy against Spain would have to be fought out in the New World.

Criticism of the efficacy of some phases of Christian missionary work in China was voiced yesterday in the fourth instalment of material supplementing the report recently made by the Laymen's Foreign Missions Inquiry's Commission of Appraisal.

UTICA, N.Y., July 29. -- Leaders of independent dairymen at a meeting here this afternoon decided to call a State-wide milk "holiday" to begin Tuesday morning. They declared that they would withhold their milk from the market until their demands for 45 per cent of the retail prices are met by the State Milk Control Board.

Spain is in control of a "brain trust" which is beginning to encounter opposition from the rural population, according to Professor Frank Callcott of the Spanish department of Columbia University. The wisdom of conducting the nation's affairs with "so many theorists" and with "so few practical men" is being seriously questioned, Professor Callcott said following his return from Spain, where he has been engaged in literary research.

ELIMINATION of railroad grade crossings, one of President Roosevelt's "pet" projects, is getting increased attention as the Federal aid program develops. This State, first to obtain approval for road plans under the $400,000,000 Federal highway appropriation, is to spend part of its $22,500,000 allotment for gradecrossing work.
SALZBURG, Austria, July 29. -- The Salzburg Festival opened brilliantly before an international audience tonight with Beethoven's "Fidelio," conducted by Richard Strauss.

LONDON. ONE of the most curious organizations in the world-the International Society of Collectors of Lead Soldiers -- recently held an exhibition in Paris. More than 10,000 miniature warriors were displayed.

At the incidence of income taxes in 1913, and for several years thereafter, withholding of the tax at the source of the income and payment thereof to the collector by the withholding agent or principal, was not an unusual statutory requirement. EDWARD HUTTON, or possibly Richard Bagot (or, it may well have been both), once likened pre-war Italy-the Third Italy, the Italy of the Risorgimento, the Italy of dolce far niente -- to a blind lyre-player who had lost his plectrum.

LATONIA, Ky., July 29 (AP). -- Esseff of the Dixiana Stable came up with a rush in the final sixteenth today to win the Latonia Oaks, closing day feature, and a purse of $2,030. The winner paid $6.32 for $2 to win.
To the Music Editor: Some very interesting questions are raised by Mr. Olin Downes's article "Propaganda and Music," in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 23.

BALTIMORE, July 29. -- Charles Cabot of New Haven, Conn., piloted Felix Kitten to victory today in the free-for-all outboard motor boat race, as the two-day trl-city regatta opened on the Severn River. There were fifteen entrants in the event.

What a single individual eats from day to day may seem, to be of no national consequence, but a recent address by the senior agricultural economist of the United States Department of Agriculture, Dr. O.E. BAKER, suggests the vast import of the changes in the diet of the people as a whole.
ROME, July 29 -- Premier Mussolini is 50 years old today.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Philip Murray of Pittsburgh, international vice president of the United Mine Workers of America, renewed here today his pledge that his organization would cooperate with Governor Pinchot in attempts to bring peace to the coal fields of Western Pennsylvania.
BUDAPEST, July 29 -- One of the worst injustices to Chancellor Hitler is to charge him with lacking achievements in foreign politics.

Too many political factors are Involved in this question to permit a simple answer, but some light may be thrown on the subject by observing where New York City actually has raised its governmental expenses in the past.

With 100 clerks assigned to the task, the New York headquarters of the government's blanket code campaign, set up in the Custom House, began tabulation yesterday of the early returns and prepared for an expected deluge of pledges tomorrow.

Merchants are now beginning to resist the undue increases in wholesale prices which are being quoted on many staple lines, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. "Buyers," the report states, "are once again figuring manufacturing costs and are carefully discriminating between legitimate price advances in consideration of added labor and higher material costs, as opposed to speculative advances."

NEW YORK. Mrs. Samuel Owen Edmonds accompanied by her nephew, Griswold Coles Raetze, sailed yesterday, to take a motor trip through England and Scotland. Mr. Raetze will return in September, but Mrs. Edmonds will remain abroad for several months.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Movements of Vessels follow, all dates are July 28, unless otherwise specified:

THE two painters who have attracted most attention from the public in the current Summer exhibitions are in the show at the Reinhardt Galleries, of which a partial account was given last week -- Redon, who has become much better known to the general public since the opening of the collection made by Miss Lizzie Bliss, and Raffaelli, who appears in a guise almost wholly unfamiliar to the American gallery visitor.

PITTSBURGH, July 29 (AP) -- With the injured Fred Lindstrom in the role of hero, Pittsburgh today defeated Cincinnati, 9 to 8 and 6 to 4, and vaulted over the losing Chicago Cubs into second place in the National League.

PARIS. SUMMER brings more than the doldrums to France's film industry -- it serves as the signal for a renewed assault upon foreign pictures on the part of the French producers. Each year as July 1 approaches and the existing film regulations near their expiration, the industry here, which is always in difficulty, and this year in really desperate straits, appeals to the government to save it.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S reference, in his recent radio address to the nation, to the Governors Conference, which meets every year, recalls the time when, twenty-five years ago, President Theodore Roosevelt brought this group into being. Under the earlier Roosevelt, the conference was concerned with the conservation of our natural resources; in later years its activities were confined largely to local subjects.

LOUISVILLE, July 27 -- Kentuckians, with Louisville, the metropolis, in the van, have accepted the National Recovery Act and the Roosevelt program of Industrial codes with enthusiasm. Even that most difficult of all problems, relief for the overpopulated bituminous coal-mining regions, seems to have a chance to be solved.
The New York Fire Department reduced its expenses by $956,303.44 for the first six months of this year, compared to the first half of 1932, its semiannual report showed yesterday.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 29 (AP). -- Addressing a Republican luncheon gathering today, Speaker Joseph A. McGinnis of the State Assembly declared that the Republican Assembly is set squarely against Tammany Hall's plan for levying new State-wide taxes to help New York City out of its financial difficulties.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 29. -- Greeted by his mother on the front porch, of the house where he was born, President Roosevelt came home today for a brief vacation from the rigorous work of administering the "New Deal."

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 29. As a part of the government's Aug. 15 financing the Treasury will issue About $500,000,000 of bonds, the first long-term issue since September, 1931. Secretary Woodin announced this at his home hero today.

RYE, N.Y., July 29. -- "Sky Night," a moonlight fete, will be given next Saturday night at the Westchester Country Club here, in the interest of the National Amateur Charity Air Pageant, which is scheduled for Oct. 7 and 8 at Roosevelt Field, under the auspices of the United States Amateur Air Pilots Association.

PARIS, July. 29 -- France won the doubles match at the Roland Garroa Stadium in Auteuil today but England still leads in the Davia Cup challenge round, 2-1, with all the odds in its favor. The two final singles contests will be played tomorrow.

HALIFAX, July 27 -- A group of engineers and business men, acting in close cooperation with the Provincial Department, of Mines, have organized the Nova Scotia Gold Mining Association, with the object of sustaining their theory that this Province is "a proved but long-neglected gold field."

ALBANY, July 29. -- A final proposal for legislation to enable the New York City administration to finance unemployment relief, without imposing new local taxes before election day, was submitted to Governor Lehman today by George McAneny, Sanitation Commissioner.

THERE has been an abundance of action in the cinema career of Ralph Forbes. It was amid the audible blood and thunder of "The Green Goddels" that he made his debut on the talking screen. At present, after surviving the perils of numerous cinematic adventures, he is again surrounded by considerable sound and fury in "The Phantom Broadcast," the new melodrama at the original Roxy.
Members of the all-United States women's touring field Hockey team are scheduled to sail for Europe on Aug. 25 aboard the North German Lloyd liner Europa.

FROM London comes word that England will soon be able to peer into the pages of her early history via the motion pictures, for London Film Productions, Ltd., is producing a film entitled "The Private Life of Henry VIII," with Charles Laughton in the title role.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- In response to inquiries at the Treasury Department relative to the French debt, the official records were cited today to show that actual payments of $486,075,891 have been made on the obligation. The French debt as funded was $4,025,386,686.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 29 (AP). -- Fred Moller, manager of the Bridgeport airport, announced today that Captain James and Amy Johnson Mollison would return next Friday to the scene of the crash which ended their flight from Pendine, Wales.

SALZBURG, Austria. IN Austria, on the Austro-German frontier * * * What visions that phrase must call up at this moment to newspaper readers in America! Austria and Germany are at loggerheads, so much so that, although diplomatic relations continue, the Austrian Chancellor, Dr. Dollfuss, recently had to appeal for "at least such ordinary decencies of diplomatic usage as Germany accords, say, to Soviet Russia."

HAVANA, July 29. -- One student was wounded and twelve were arrested tills afternoon during a clash, between policemen and an Opposition group which was returning from Colon Cemetery following the transfer of the body of Juan Gonzalez Rubiera to a mausoleum recently constructed by public subscription.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., July 29. -- Governor and Mrs. Lehman were the guests of honor at a dinner given at the Lake George Club this evening by residents of Lake George and vicinity. Several after-dinner speakers paid high tribute to the Governor and his wife.

DUBLIN. A WORK of genius has been published in Ireland. It is called "Fice Blian Ag Fas" (Talbot Press, Dublin), and It is the first masterpiece that has been written in modern Gaelic. "Twenty Years A Growing" is the English translation of this work, which is to be published in the United States by the Viking Press.
CHICAGO, July 29. -- Maurice B. Rissman, as a trustee of Edwin D. Krenn's share in the Edith Rockefeller McConnick Trust, filed in Probate Court today a claim for $1,261,128 against the trust.
MOSCOW, July 29. -- The most puzzling thing to all foreigners who visit Russia is money.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Rogers Hornsby's debut as an American League manager was a success today as his St. Louis Browns came from behind to defeat the Chicago White Sox, 3 to 2, in the first game of their series.

Financial interest centred yesterday in the action of the commodity markets and, to a less extent, in the movement of foreign exchange. The New York Stock Exchange and other important domestic security markets remained closed to give the overworked brokerage personnel a breathing spell.

July is invariably one of the Treasury's lean months, since it includes no quarterly payment of income taxes.

BERLIN, July 29. -- In an effort to put an end to secret Communist activities the police in Berlin and various other German cities made surprise raids today, resulting in about 250 arrests, including those of a number of women.

WITH a tenth anniversary flourish the Grand Central Art Galleries lent color to the local week in art by opening a branch -- if a venture so coordinate and so magnificently quartered can be called a branch -- in the old Union Club Building at Fifty-first Street and Fifth Avenue.

CLEVELAND, July 29 (AP) -- Clint Brown not only blanked the Tigers with seven hits today, but scampered home with the winning run in the seventh on a single by Johnny Oulliber as the Indians marked up their fifth straight victory today, 1 to 0.

BARCELONA, July 19. -- Such an innocent-appearing matter as a commercial treaty between Spain and Uruguay is causing strained relations between Catalonia and Galicia, two of Spain's most outstanding historic regions. The dispute is causing serious concern to the central government at Madrid since the quarreling regions constitute important sectors of its political support.
AUTEUIL, France, July 29 (AP). -- Despite the French triumph today. England remains confident of gaining the deciding victory in the singles tomorrow.

Governor J.C.B. Ehringhaus of North Carolina said yesterday that his State had reduced expenditures more than 32 per cent since he took office on Jan. 1, "has balanced her budget and is living well within her means." The Governor gave an interview here at the Hotel New Yorker, following what he said was a successful visit to bankers with regard to the renewal of North Carolina's outstanding obligations.

WASHINGTON, July 29. -- Treasury receipts for the first twenty-seven days of July amounted to $144,563,789, an increase of $68,550,386 as compared with the corresponding period of July, 1932, while expenditures of $249,773,255 were $211,511,233 lower.

ONE of the most crowded periods in the field of spectacular aviation draws to a close. General Italo Balbo, whose squadron of twenty-four winged sea birds thrilled New York, is homeward bound, leaving behind him an impression of extraordinary dynamic force coupled with suavity in an unusual and attractive personality.
Manager Bill Terry lifted the Giants from the danger of defeat to victory over the Boston Braves yesterday before 12,000 fans at the Polo Grounds.

NO, there was no scandal about it, and no one was cheated or deceived, even if America was "double-crossed." On the contrary, everybody concerned seems to have had a most delightful and enjoyable time and to have brought out of the double-crossing a store of happy and precious memories.

NORWAY has just lost Greenland to Denmark; but she has gained such a hold for her literature on all Englishspeaking peoples as neither Denmark nor Sweden can claim. Although their literatures have been translated piecemeal and evaluated in the same fashion, they have not been integrated, in English, as Professor Jorgenson has here done for the entire body of writings by the fellow-countrymen of Leif Ericson and Bernt Balchen.

MILAN, July 14, 1933. THE Scala management issued yesterday its financial statement for the 1933 season. It shows box-office receipts of four and two-third million lire, plus subsidies of four and three-quarter million, aggregating nearly nine and a half million ($665,000 at present exchange).
Captain James Mollison and his wife, Amy Johnson, received a bouquet of flowers yesterday from President Roosevelt and a letter addressed to Captain Mollison which read:

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., July 29. -- In a rambling old frame building on Crow Hill Road, two or three miles from Mount Kisco, William H. Bridge is setting up an educational institute for training in the technique of peace. He defines it as "a house of retreat for leaders -- a school for peace workers."
Trading in local commodity markets came almost to a standstill yesterday. The trend of prices was lower, with silver, rubber and silk losing ground. Hides, copper and wool tops were steady.

SARATOGA SPRINGS. -- A marked increase in the number of health seekers at the State-owned mineral bath houses during the present month and the throng of prominent society folk who have engaged cottages for the coming month while the racing is in progress are ample assurance that Saratoga is retaining her full popularity as one of the country's favorite recreation and watering places.

AN INTRODUCTION TO LIBRARY SCIENCE" is the formidable title given to this Interesting little book, and, as if the author thought that none but those who seek the most esoteric knowledge should dare to look beyond the title page, he gave to each essay therein these forbidding signposts: The Nature of Science, the Sociological Problem, the Psychological Problem, the Historical Problem and Practical Considerations.

SOUTHAMPTON. -- For more than forty years the annual invitation tennis tournament, which, opens tomorrow afternoon on the courts of the Meadow Club, has marked the climax of the social season in Southampton. There is every indication that the lively series of entertainments begun in connection with the annual horse show just held at the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club will continue throughout the coming week.
CHICAGO, July 29 -- A legal fight over the right of Secretary Wallace to enforce provisions of the Chicago milk agreement threatens to prevent it going into effect on Tuesday.
LONDON. July 11. -- The London Times prints the following dispatch from a special correspondent in Moscow:

WITH its 653 pages "Living-stones" could scarcely be mistaken for a light Summer novel; but, though not to be read at a sitting, it is a book which the gentle borrower will not charm from your table until you have turned the last leaf.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, who headed the delegation which failed to reach an agreement with employers' associations on an industrial code, announced last night that he had called a meeting of the executive boards of eleven locals here.
CHICAGO, July 29 -- A legal fight over the right of Secretary Wallace to enforce provisions of the Chicago milk agreement threatens to prevent it going into effect on Tuesday.
LONDON. July 11. -- The London Times prints the following dispatch from a special correspondent in Moscow:

WITH its 653 pages "Living-stones" could scarcely be mistaken for a light Summer novel; but, though not to be read at a sitting, it is a book which the gentle borrower will not charm from your table until you have turned the last leaf.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, who headed the delegation which failed to reach an agreement with employers' associations on an industrial code, announced last night that he had called a meeting of the executive boards of eleven locals here.

ANTWERP, July 18 -- Two tunnels under the Scheldt Estuary here will be opened by King Albert of Belgium on Sept. 10. The engineers in charge of the work, among whom are several Americans, have completed it fifteen months before the date specified in the contract.

This story of strange happenings near the port of Marseilles was awarded the French Prix du Roman d'Aventure of 1932. It opens peacefully enough with a customs guard spitting into the canal as he watches the early morning traffic across the bridge.

BALTIMORE, July 29 -- With a view to ascertaining the workings of and reactions to the company union plan of the Sparrows Point plant of the Bethlehem Steel Company, Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, braved the sweltering heat of the furnaces and the smoke and clamor today to talk with the grimy workers there.
MADRID, July 28 -- Spain's recognition of Russia as the second Spanish-speaking nation to accept the Soviet regime points toward Madrid's increased prestige and activity in international affairs.
LENOX, Mass., July 29. -- When the two-day Lenox Horse Show ended today, Miss Elmina Brewster of New Haven, Conn., had won six blue ribbons and three championship awards.

BALTIMORE, July 29 -- With a view to ascertaining the workings of and reactions to the company union plan of the Sparrows Point plant of the Bethlehem Steel Company, Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, braved the sweltering heat of the furnaces and the smoke and clamor today to talk with the grimy workers there.
MADRID, July 28 -- Spain's recognition of Russia as the second Spanish-speaking nation to accept the Soviet regime points toward Madrid's increased prestige and activity in international affairs.
LENOX, Mass., July 29. -- When the two-day Lenox Horse Show ended today, Miss Elmina Brewster of New Haven, Conn., had won six blue ribbons and three championship awards.

THE truth in the old proverb that a myth dies hard is being borne out by the slowness with which Europe is giving up its cherished conception of Uncle Sam -- "the rich uncle from America." How the myth came into being is easy enough to understand when we stop to realize how many millions of uncles for years sent money to their relatives in the "old country."

ST. LOUIS, July 30 -- Two modern baseball records fell today before the brilliant pitching of Jerome (Dizzy) Dean and the stellar catching of Jimmy Wilson of the St. Louis Cardinals. The Cards took both ends of a double-header from the Chicago Cubs, 8 to 2 and 6 to 5.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., July 30. -- Colonel E. Parmalee Prentice of New York celebrated his seveneth birthday yesterday. Mrs. Prentice gave a birthday dinner arty in his honor at Mount Hope Farm, Williamstown. Colonel Prentice was born in Davenport, Iowa.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 30. -- The gates ,of Krum Elbow opened in welcome today to Captain James and Amy Johnson Mollison, who were guests at luncheon of President and Mrs. Roosevelt.

Karl Werner Heye, 3d, 26 years old, a broker, of 46 Washington Square South, was accidentally shot and killed yesterday aboard the Bremen, of the North German Lloyd, now at sea bound for Europe, by his traveling companion, Charles Manger.

WASHINGTON. July 30 (AP). -- With hope renewed for an international wheat agreement, farm administrators tonight considered extending the time before they determine the acreage reduction to be required in their $135,000,000 program to limit domestic wheat production.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- A constitutional amendment empowering the Federal and State Governments to collect a tax upon about $35,000,000,000 worth of securities now exempt from levies will be urged by Senator Lonergan of Connecticut when Congress reconvenes in January.

BUENOS AIRES, July 30. -- Prices of wheat and flaxseed strengthened here last week, but corn declined the equivalent of 1/2 cent a bushel under heavy bearish pressure designed to discredit the government's recent attempt to fix the price at 4.50 pesos a quintal.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- It is estimated that the Spring wheat crop in the American and Canadian Northwest this year will be 151,000,000 bushels smaller than it was last year and that all North American wheat production will be the smallest in recent years.

LONDON, July 29. -- The stock markets, after being rather violently affected by the recent Wall Street decline, are getting firmly on their feet again. Important though the American recovery plans are and powerfully as Wall Street may continue to influence international financial sentiment, the markets appear to be shaking themselves freer of American trends.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP). -- A possibility that John D. Rockefeller Jr. might waive his customary policy of noninterference with his companies to line up the Standard of New Jersey behind the administration's oil stabilization program was reported tonight in informed circles.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- To expedite the machinery for the submission of codes of fair competition from industry to final approval of the President the National Recovery Administration made public today a list of assignments of deputy administrators.

BARCELONA, July 30. -- The feudal State of Andorra today defied France and Spain when its Council, protected by the whole armed forces and citizenry of the republic, took possession of the Capitol. Andorra has been under joint suzerainty of the head of the French State and of the Spanish Bishop of Urgel since 1278.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 30. -- The appearance of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and of Miss Betty Nuthall and her mates on the British Wightman Cup team drew one of the largest crowds on record at the Maidstone Club today.

MIAMI, Fla., July 30. -- Sweeping across the Florida Peninsula on a course more than 100 miles north of here this afternoon and tonight, a West Indian storm inflicted a loss probably exceeding more than $1,000,000, chiefly to citrus crops.

The spirit that prevailed when Jesus divided the loaves and fishes among a multitude is being manifested today by the nation's industrial leaders under the guidance of the Roosevelt administration, the Rev. Paul J. Hoh of the Parish School Board of the United Lutheran Church, said yesterday.

MAYS LANDING, N.J., July 30. -- A bursting automobile tire tonight caused the death here of one person and injury to two others. Mrs. Mildred Abrams, 30 years old, of Glenolden, a suburb of Philadelphia, was killed when the car in which she was riding on the White Horse Pike overturned after a front tire had burst.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Further delay in naming the date of the hearing on the soft coal code may endanger the possibility of arriving at an early agreement in view of the flare-up of strikes in the Pennsylvania mines, according to Ben Grey, executive director of the Central Coal Associates, in a statement made public today.
LONDON, July 30. -- A dispatch to be printed by The London Times tomorrow under a Berlin date line will say:

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The policy of the administration is to test to the full extent the Industrial Recovery Act program before even, seriously considering entrance upon any inflationary currency program, advisers of the President declare.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., July 30. -- With the tension in the Western Pennsylvania soft coal fields eased by the presence of National Guardsmen, the H.C. Frick Coke Company will attempt to resume operations in seventeen of its mines which are now closed by the strike.

SAG HARBOR, L.I., July 30. -- Two Princeton graduates of the class of 1932, both socially prominent, were killed, and four other persons slightly injured early tonight in an automobile collision at Montauk Highway and Sagg Road. William Bayard Blackwell, 23 years old, and Thomas Palmer, 23, were killed.

If the Recovery Act fails to meet the high hopes with which it has been put into effect, it will not be for lack of general good-will and the finest spirit of cooperation. In response to President ROOSEVELT'S appeal and the energetic demands of General JOHNSON, offers and pledges have poured in from all over the country and from every form of industry and business.

BERLIN, July 29. -- The uninterrupted increase in the Reichsbank's reserves since the end of June is taken to indicate that the transfer of 50 per cent of the bond interest is assured till the end of the year. The increase, however, is partly attributable to a return of "flight capital" in consequence of the new law treating violations of exchange regulations as treason.

Engineers Public Service Company -- Year ended June 30: Consolidated net income, $3,003,132, equal, after preferred dividends, to 36 cents a share earned for common stock, against $5,466,894, or $1.65 a share, in the preceding year.
LIDO BEACH, L.I., July 30. -- A "mythical cruise of the Ile deFrance" will take place here on Saturday. A number of large dinner parties have been arranged by members to precede the entertainment.

A few years ago, when GEORGE OLVANY was elected New York County Democratic leader through the influence of AL SMITH and others, much was heard of "the New Tammany." The Judge and his sponsors were to reform it utterly. The Tiger was to give up his evil ways, if not his stripes.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 30. -- With the annual invitation tennis tournament at the Maidstone Club, yacht races at the Devon Yacht Club yesterday afternoon and a golf tournament being played today between graduates of Princeton and Yale who are Maidstone Club members, this was an eventful week-end here.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- The story or man, from a million years ago down through the dim past to the dawn of history about 5000 B.C., is graphically told by comprehensive exhibits in a new hall at Field Museum of Natural History opening to the public for the first time on Tuesday.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., July 30. -- Revelations of an asserted plot by Charles (Pretty Boy) Floyd, Oklahoma gunman, to kidnap a Hollywood motion-picture actress resulted in a heavy guard being placed about the Malibu Beach movie colony while Federal officers and police searched Southern California for the outlaw.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Hard had the echoes of applause the greeted President Roosevelt's rad appeal to the nation to support the blanket code died down, early la week, when appeals began to po into the Recovery Administration for interpretation and clarification of the terms of the code.

The four-story apartment house in Brooklyn at 1,589-1,607 Ocean Ave nue, southeast corner of Avenue K has been purchased by I. D.S. Meister. The building accommodates fifty-four families and has a frontage of 170 feet on Ocean Avenue by 110 feet on Avenue K.

Anti-Koenig voters in the Thirteenth Assembly District charged yesterday that they had been Induced through misrepresentations to sign pro-Koenig petitions for Republican county committeemen. They added that they had written to Valentine J. Hahn, Commissioner of Elections and pro-Koenig leader of the district, demanding that their names be stricken from the petitions, but had received no reply.

School children display an "amazing desire" to glorify everything connected with war, according to the results of a survey by Professors Adelaide Case and Paul M. Limbert of Teachers College, Columbia University, made public yesterday.

Aroused by problems which enactment of the Banking Act of 1933 created for them, bankers in the leading centres of the country have organized themselves to study and propose fundamental reforms to take the place of the emergency measures enacted by the last session of Congress.

PITTSBURGH, July 30. -- While no decrease in steel production has become distinctly visible to the industry here, it is regarded, as certain that one will begin within two weeks as mills begin to complete, in succession, orders taken at prices below those now ruling.
ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., July 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. William Carmichael Jr. gave a dinner last evening at Atlantic Beach Club in honor of Mr. Carmichael's birthday. Guests included:

The National Industrial Recovery Act bears the same relation to the United States as the Five-Year Plan does to Soviet Russia, the Rev. C. Everett Wagner declared yesterday in his sermon at the Union Methodist Episcopal Church, Forty-eighth Street west of Broadway.

News from London was published on Saturday that Adolf Hitler had "authorized" an English translation of his first and only book and that it would be issued soon in England and this country. Houghton Mifflin Company announced it would publish the book in the Fall under the title, "My Battle."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 30. -- A youthful hold-up man entered a room on the ninth floor of the Hotel Claridge here shortly after 2 o'clock this morning pointed a revolver at Mrs. Philip Glemby of 912 Fifth Avenue, New York City, the wife of a wealthy hair net manufacturer, and forced her into a bathroom, where he tied her hands with a towel and escaped with jewelry valued at more than $75,000.

LONDON, July 30 (AP). -- Negotiations for a wheat restriction scheme took a turn for the better over the week-end and prospects were brightened for an eventual agreement adapting production of the world's principal staple to demand.

Buying activity showed some improvement in the wholesale apparel markets here last week. The number of out-of-town buyers coming in to make initial Fall purchases was large, and they were optimistic regarding prospects for active business.

Youth and Recovery. President ROOSEVELT says in a message to the national organization of Young Democratic Clubs that he counts "heavily" on the youth of America to help in the great drive for national recovery.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We wonder whether any reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES might be persuaded to take a kindly Interest in a problem of the boys of the New York State Training School at Warwick.
James Dolan, close friend and confidant of the murdered Alice Kenny Diamond, was shot and killed by gunmen at 9 o'clock last night in a beer-garden at 142 Flat-bush Avenue, Brooklyn.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $3,306,587,600. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

BUDAPEST, July 30. -- Herr Stockinger, the Austrian Minister of Commerce, arrived here this morning for a three-day conference with Premier Goemboes, Dr. Tihamer Fabinyi, Minister of Commerce; Bela Imredy, Minister of Finance, and Nicholas Kallay, Minister of Agriculture.
NEW YORK. Lady Mildred Fitz Gerald of London is at the Waldorf-Astoria.

ALBANY, July 30. -- John J. O'Connell Jr., 24, was returned at 4 o'clock this morning to the Helderberg Mountain camp of his politically powerful uncle, Daniel P. O'Connell, after payment of $40,000 ransom.

CINCINNATI, July 30 (AP). -- Ninth inning drives carried the Pirates to victory in both games of a double-header with the Reds today and placed them a game and a half closer to the league-leading Giants. The scores were 5 to 4 and 8 to 6.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- A statement that James A. Moffett, former senior vice president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, resigned from that organization against the counsel and to the regret of his associates, was issued here tonight by Walter C. Teagle, president of the company.

THE Dodgers dropped in to visit the Giants at the Polo Grounds last week and the feats of Joe (Poodles) Hutcheson in a Brooklyn uniform started an argument that still rages. It concerns two types of baseball: offensive and defensive.
Houses, two filling stations and a theatre came under new control in New Jersey deals announced over the week-end.

Indications are evident, reports Frank H. Alcott, secretary-manager of the New York Lumber Trade Association, that the increase in building construction throughout the metropolitan area will resume its upward trend just as soon as all or a majority of the building trade firms adjust their operations to the requirements of the National Recovery Act.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 30. -- Belmont Field of the Meadow Brook Club was the scene of a round robin today in which each of the three teams playing registered one victory and suffered one defeat.

Test operation of trains over two new links of the city subway system in Queens will begin today. The trial runs will extend from Eighth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, Manhattan, to Roosevelt Avenue and Broadway, Queens, and from Queens Plaza to Nassau Avenue in Long Island City.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 30. -- North Shore society occupied the boxes at the ringside of the annual Brookville horse show, which was held in the paddock of the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Davis on the Cedar Swamp Road at Glen Head today for the benefit of the society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

Rallies early last week in local commodity markets were substantially reduced and in some cases converted into losses as a result of later reactions. Silver, rubber, silk and coffee futures closed lower, while sugar, cocoa, raw hides and wool tops were higher.

In a radio talk from Berlin yesterday, broadcast in this country over a NBC network, Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, president of this Reichsbank, said Germany was convinced of the failure of the World Economic Conference at London and, in the future, would conduct her economic and political negotiations exclusively with the nations and parties directly concerned.

CHICAGO, July 30. -- Inability of producers, packers and live stock interests to arrive at a satisfactory code for curtailing production and processing of hogs and products has resulted in leaders going to Washington, where it is expected satisfactory plans will be developed.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The fortunes of the Yankees took a decided turn for the better today when they made the startling discovery that it was not necessary to shoot holes in the distant barriers of Griffith Stadium to bring down their arch-tormentors, the Senators.

NEWARK, N.J., July 30 (AP). -- The Newark Bears increased their International League lead to three and one-half games today by taking a double-header from Buffalo, 12 to 3 and 2 to 1. Meanwhile Rochester was losing twice to Baltimore.

MOUNTAINAIR, N.M., July 30 (AP). -- Mrs. A.B. Layman rode with grim possemen about the mountain fastnesses of central New Mexico for three hours today in a vain hunt for her son, Jack Layman, ex-convict sought for murder.

A letter from the Merchants Association of New York to legislative leaders of both parties at Albany, protesting strongly against any legislation permitting NewYork City to impose a sales tax, was made public yesterday by Louis K. Comstock, president of the association.
W.B. Campbell's schooner Grey Gull II was the winner of the Bayside Yacht Club's thirteenth annual handicap auxiliary race to Block Island and return which ended yesterday.

The disappearance of David M. Kahan, real estate operator and former brewer, from his home at 255 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, last Thursday, was attributed to kidnappers yesterday when the car that he drove was found abandoned at Van Cortlandt Park.

VIENNA, July 30. -- Charges that Albert Leo Schlageter, German Nazi national hero, betrayed his German associates and worked as a spy for Poland and France were published today in the Socialist Arbeiter Zeitung.

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 30. -- Max Marston, veteran Philadelphia golfer, won his sixth Shenecossett golf tournament in eight attempts by trouncing Dow Ahern, 21-year-old player of Willimantic, Conn., 9 and 8, in the thirty-sixth-hole final today.

CHERBOURG, France, July 30. -- President Lebrun today presided at the formal opening of Cherbourg's new $12,500,000 deep-water port and maritime station. M. Lebrun expressed the hope that early business recovery and a revival of transatlantic travel would justify the great expenditure which gives France one of the leading ports of Western Europe.
To the Editor of The New York times: I am taking the liberty of commenting on the various letters in today's issue relating to economic subjects.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is difficult to comprehend that any civilized community or sovereign State could permit the perpetration of such outrages upon bird life as described by Mrs. H.D. Reynolds in her letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES.
LONDON, July 30. -- There is a general realization that the German military forces today are very different from those contemplated by the makers of the Versailles treaty.

PARIS, July 29. -- Financial Paris is following the development of the Roosevelt program closely. The latest Presidential address has given a plain description of measures already taken but makes no fresh disclosures.

Speaker MCGINNIES on Saturday summoned the Republicans of this State to resist to the death the attempt of the Democrats to gain control of both branches of the Legislature. In this he was but doing his partisan duty. But he colored his picture too highly when he painted the terrible results if the Republicans were to lose their majority in the Assembly.

NEW ORLEANS, La., July 30. -- As a result of the drastic decline in prices late in the previous week, activity in the cotton market here was reduced greatly last week. Following the liquidation of the long interest there was a general disposition to await events.

James Mattern, who cracked up eighty miles from the nearest settlement in Eastern Siberia while on his way to Nome, arrived in New York yesterday. Flying a borrowed plane, he landed at Floyd Bennett Field at 4:41 P.M., having flown from Toronto in 4 hours and 11 minutes.
CHERBOURG, France, July 30 (AP). -- Cherbourg's new $2,500,000 maritime station was officially opened today by President Albert Lebrun.

ARMONK, N.Y., July 30. -- Willie Turnesa carded 69-69-138 today to win the 36-hole invitation medal play golf tournament at the Westchester Embassy Golf and Country Club. His 69s also shattered the amateur course record of 70 made by Charles Paul.
The policies toward aging workers of 800 American corporations are analyzed in a report made public today by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- The universal tariff truce to which the United States pledged adherence for the duration of the World Economic Conference has risen for the second time to plague officials of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration in working out their program.

A single national transportation organization to include companies engaged in ocean, river, harbor, canal, motor and air transportation and terminal and warehouse operations was urged yesterday by Joseph Scott, traffic executive, as the agency to bring transportation in line with the new governmental scheme of regulated business.

The above chart shows the fluctuations of dollar and sterling exchange in terms of the French franc in 1932 and the first half of 1933. The chart has been released by the Council of Foreign Relations for the information of its members.

Will Rogers, unofficia ambassador at large, appears on the screen of the Trans-Lux Theatre this week greeting delegates to the Governors' Conference at Truckee, Cal. Also on the newsreel program are glimpses of industrial leaders pledging support to the industrial recovery program; of a grasshopper plague in the West and a locust plague in Algeria; the Salinas (Cal.) rodeo and a 2-year-old golfer.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 30. -- Danseuse, the chestnut mare owned by Mrs. J.V. Bouvier 3d of East Hampton, L.I., won the hunter championship at the Brookville Charity Horse Show today. The Bouvier entry climaxed a day of fine performances by beating Golden Fruit, Mrs. Congreve Jackson's bay gelding, for the rosette.

STUTTGART, Germany, July 30 (AP). -- The "march into the third Reich" climaxed the great Turnfest [national gymnastic festival] here today as 150,000 turners paraded in a body twenty-three miles long before Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Nazi Minister of Popular Enlightenment and Propaganda.

Establishment of a playground on the recently cleared tract on Chrystie and Forsyth Streets, between Second and Third Avenues, instead of a model housing project, is recommended by the Children's Aid Society in a letter to Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, Inc., made public yesterday.

The Dodgers failed to continue the heavy cannonading that marked their double victory at Philadelphia Saturday and with their attack all but silenced were easy victims of the Phillies at Ebbets Field yesterday.

CUMBERLAND GAP, Tenn., July 30 (AP). -- By shouting so loudly that his voice was heard -- according to the judges -- a distance of eight miles and in three States at the same time, Lee Chrisman, 32 years old, a Kentucky auctioneer living near Danville, early today set what his followers claim is a world record.

Firemen strove almost four hours yesterday afternoon to conquer a smoky blaze in the cellar of a five-story building at 166 William Street. Twenty-three of them were cut by flying glass or overcome by a combination of the heat and the thick gray smoke that poured from the basement.
The winning streak of the Giants was snapped at the Polo Grounds yesterday in a shattering fire of home-run drives by the Boston Braves.

Louis H.F. Mouquin, head of Mouquin, Inc., visited the musty wine cellar beneath the old Wendel house at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street yesterday at the request of Charles G. Koss, administrator of the estate of Miss Ella V. Wendel.

NEW HAVEN, July 30. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 69.6, which compares with 70.4 a week ago, 68.8 two weeks ago, 66.6 three weeks ago and 65.1 four weeks ago. The previous week's average was the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP). -- More work ahead for long-idle bituminous coal miners was the story behind Bureau of Mines figures made public today on June stocks and industrial consumption.
BERLIN, July 29. -- Coal output in the first half of the year was 52,391,000 tons, against 50,322,000 in the corresponding period of 1932.
LONDON, July 29. -- The sharp rise in the dollar has taken the market almost completely by surprise, although it is generally accepted that the reason for the movement is simple.

ALBANY, July 30. -- Governor Lehman made it clear tonight that all the resources of the State would be employed to protect milk producers cooperating with the Milk Control Board in the event of a threatened opposition strike.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP). -- Out of the West, from the capital of moviedom into the capital of the nation, has come the bicycle craze.

LONDON, July 30 (AP). -- The American contract bridge quartet, led by Ely Culbertson, stretching its lead over a revamped British team by 3,250 points in the last fifty boards, finished a three-day match tonight with a 10,370-point lead, winning by 62,260 points to 51,890.

The intense heat yesterday, which drove the mercury to 92 degrees in the late afternoon, falling only three degrees short of the record for the date in 1917, caused four deaths and sent the year's largest crowds to the beaches.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Grafton Mortimer gave a luncheon at Dune- side for E. Victor Loew of Gray Horse Lodge, Tuxedo Park, their house guest; Colonel Henry H. Rogers and his son-in-law and , daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Arturo Peralta Ramos.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Checks aggregating about $6,000,000 will be mailed tomorrow and Tuesday to about 300,000 families to whom allotments have been made by members of the Civilian Conservation Corps.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Much is heard of the necessity of purchasing power as a means of raising prices and bringing about recovery. The inflationists have regarded money in general as purchasing power, without distinguishing between the different forms of money, such as gold, notes of banks and the government, and checks drawn on deposits.

BUENOS AIRES, July 30. -- The only fact clearly defined by the recent exchange of diplomatic notes regarding the Chaco peace negotiations is that the ABCP group, to which Bolivia and Paraguay want the negotiations returned, no longer exists.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- August 15 financing of the Treasury will take the form of the Issuance of more than $850,000,000 In long-term bonds and two-year notes, Dean Acheson, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, announced today.

Jersey City swept a double-header with Montreal at Jersey City yesterday as the two clubs opened a series. The first game went thirteen innings with the home club triumphing, 9 to 5. The second contest was won by a I-to-0 count.

The break in the prices of stocks, grains and cotton in the latter part of this month has had no important influence on the business situation in the opinion of the National City Bank. In its monthly bulletin, published today, the bank says it would be difficult to show that any but the speculators had suffered greatly.
Nineteen years ago this morning the leading editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES, under the title "Critical Days," ended with this paragraph:
WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Capital and labor will lock horns tomorrow morning at the hearing on the code of fair competition submitted by the steel industry.

DARIEN, Conn., July 30. -- William Ziegler Jr. opened his 100-acre Great Island Summer home here today to the public for a gala sports carnival for the benefit of St. Luke's Episcopal Church and St. John's Roman Catholic Church, both of this town.

Christians need a new viewpoint on the values of life, not more legislation designed to shut out the evil forces of the world, the Rev. Dr. Hugh Black, a professor at the Union Theological Seminary, said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 30. -- The iron and steel industry here will start the month of August with schedules close to 67 per cent, after completing July with an average of 65 per cent, the best production rate for July since 1929.

Captain Jacob Martin, veteran Sheepshead Bay fishing-boat pilot, contributes an interesting sidelight to the art of angling for bluefish. Fishing the waters along the Atlantic Coast for many years, he has gained a thorough knowledge of the peculiarities of almost all salt water species, but declares that he has yet to fathom the habits of the bluefish.

LONDON, July 30. -- For the first time in twenty years Canada will appear as a borrower in the London market this week with a u15,000,000 sterling loan. [At current quotations this is $67,800,000 or 63,054,000 Canadian dollars.]

COLOGNE, July 30. -- Flanked by the flags of thirty-two nations, 1,000 delegates to the twenty-fifth International Esperanto congress met in the Guerzenich, Cologne's picturesque auditorium, today to listen to welcoming addresses by international Esperantists and city officials.

OTTAWA, July 30 (Canadian Press). -- The announcement that Canada has arranged for a London loan represents the second major financial operation by the Dominion government within a week. The other was the renewal of the loan of $50,000,000 borrowed from the chartered banks of Canada.

Economy in its march has stepped hard on many soft places, but there are some traditions and antiquities which she has to spare. Last year painful rumors came from the Boston Custom House. In earlier times it took at least four officials to do what wouldn't have been too hard work for one.
The Woolworth Building was surrounded by police radio cars for an hour last night while perspiring detectives went up and down in elevators looking for a walletsnatcher.

A square deal for the workingman was advocated as a solution of many of the world's ills by the Rev. Dr. Gordon H. Baker in his sermon yesterday morning before the congregation of the Home Baptist Church, at the Pythian Temple, 135 West Seventieth Street.

DUBLIN, July 30. -- Ominous symptoms of government action regarding General Owen O'Duffy's new Irish National Guard, successor to the Army Comrades' Association, developed today. Several leading members of the guard, an organization opposed politically to President de Valera and supporting former President Cosgrave, were approached by detectives and requested to surrender their revolvers, for which they held permits.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 30. -- President Roosevelt is asked to extend the new deal to the motion picture industry "before the independents are wiped out," in a telegram from the Allied Theatre Owners of New Jersey.
For the second time within three days an apparent attempt was made early yestreday to rob the Brooklyn Museum.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The appeal to Bishop Manning by the unions of the various trades and crafts that have been engaged in building the Cathedral of St. John the Divine to start up and continue construction, on which THE TIMES commented very sympathetically on July 3, deserves greater public support than has yet been given.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., July 30. -- Several hundred members of the 114th Infantry Association, all World War veterans, closed their two-day convention here today by calling upon the government to offset Federal deficits by passing a law "eliminating all tax-exempt securities, thereby enabling the government to collect taxes on more than $50,000,000,000 worth of such securities."
"Chance and Change" was the subject of the sermon yesterday morning at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, by the Right Rev. John Newton McCormick, Bishop of Western Michigan.
LONDON, July 30. -- The London Times will print tomorrow the following dispatch from Munich:

An increase of 35,087 depositors in mutual savings banks throughout the country in the first six months of this year brought the total within 100,000 of the high record. The increase reversed the trend of the latter half of 1932, and on June 30 the number of depositors stood at 13,303,553.

Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, picked last Thursday by the fusion conference as its candidate for Mayor, returned to the city last night and said he would announce tonight whether he would accept the nomination.

ALBANY, July 30. -- Republican legislators returned to the capital tonight with a frigid attitude toward the latest proposal -- a State bond issue -- to finance New York City's relief needs, so as to avoid a new local tax before election day.

MOSCOW, July 30. -- A remarkable and significant picture of Bolshevik leaders occupies fully twothirds of the front page of Pravda today, the thirtieth anniversary of the founding of the Bolshevik party at the second congress of the Russian Social Democratic party, held in London.

The President is expected to announce this week appointment of regional boards to review claims for veterans' relief. This is a consequence of the dispute in the last session of Congress over reform of the pension system. The Senate then opposed removal from the list of veterans whose disabilities were "presumed" by law to have some connection with war service, provided such disabilities occurred within a specified period following the date of discharge.

To the numerous people who were convinced by the sudden break in prices, a week and a half ago, that "recovery" was ended for good and all, the behavior of last week's markets must have been enlightening. The three-day collapse had been spectacular, but the next week canceled about half of the loss.
PARIS, July 30. -- Great Britain gained possession of the Davis Cup today, but only by the narrowest of margins, defeating France by three matches to two.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30. -- The Metropolitan Opera Association will give fourteen Tuesday evening performances here, starting on Dec. 19 and closing on March 27. The announcement officially disposes of persistent rumors that the company would withdraw from Philadelphia next Winter.

With the return to a five-hour trading day on the Stock Exchange yesterday, speculative operations were resumed rather aggressively. But the pressure in this market, as well as in that for the agricultural staples, was toward lower quotations.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP). -- The text of the code for the furniture, hardware, mail order, clothiers and furnishers, department stores, specialty shops, shoe and dry goods retailers follows.
Immediate action by the Federal Government to assist public schools throughout the country was advocated last night by Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University.
The Walrus Foresaw. Whenever people want to convey a sense of the particularly incongruous they quote:
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 31. -- Ideal weather attracted many members of the Summer colony to the beach today. Among them were:

BERLIN, July 31. -- The Boerse was dull today, although the tone was generally firm, despite almost complete absence of speculative interest. Minings, industrials, I.G. Farben and other specialties and fixed-interest bonds remained firm in the face of no trading.

Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin declined yesterday to sign judgments ordering the sale of mortgaged real estate and announced that he intended to bring to the attention of Governor Lehman the need for relief for realty owner's.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 31. -- Governor Lehman took issue today with Charles H. Baldwin, Commissioner of Agriculture, who recently sent a circular letter to the county fair associations warning them that State aid might be withheld if they permitted the sale of 3.2 per cent beer on their grounds.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Faced with an impending court action over the constitutionality of the Chicago milk marketing agreement, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration was preparing today for a quick test of its authority under the licensing provisions of the emergency law.

ALBANY, July 31. -- Manny Strewl, intermediary in the release of John J. O'Connell Jr., who was freed by a kidnap band after twenty-three days on payment of $40,000 ransom, was in custody tonight for questioning.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 31. -- Sir Derrick J. Wernher, president of the American Bridge League, stepped on the platform of the municipal convention hall here this afternoon just long enough to welcome the competitors in the fourth annual Summer tournament of the league here.
Ethan S. Allen is with Mitchell, Hutchins Co.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The greatest event of the depression has happened: A new player entered the game, rolled up his sleeves to show that he was on the square, laid a couple of six-guns on the table to show everybody else that they had better play on the square and called for a new deal.
COWES, England, July 31. -- Dis- aster threatened King George's racing yacht today when stormy weather caused racing to be abandoned on the opening day of the Cowes regatta.

Walter L. Rice, special assistant to the United States Attorney General, filed an information yesterday charging eight alleged racketeers in the live poultry trade and three local unions with criminal contempt of court.

Manhattan lost one-third of its public school pupils in average daily attendance in elementary and junior high schools in the ten-year period ended in 1932. The attendance figures, contained in the annual financial and statistical report of the Board of Education for 1932, were announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 31. -- The Soviet aeronautic engineer Chertofsky, designer of the stratosphere balloon which is expected to make the first regular flight on Aviation Day, Aug. 18, outlines the aims of the experiment in an article in the biweekly magazine Technica.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Perhaps you will permit me to reply to the letter of Bernard Weiss captioned "Discounting a Remedy."

PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (AP). -- Back from the international golf wars, big Ed Dudley, American Ry- der Cup team member, maintained a steady pace through thirty-six holes today to lead the field in the Philadelphia open championship tournament.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 31. -- A fine marble bust of Augustus, the first Roman Emperor, made during his lifetime, is among the objects unearthed by the third campaign of archaeological excavations con- ducted by the American School of Classical Studies in Athens, accord- ing to Dr. T. Leslie Shear, director of the excavations and Professor of Classical Archaeology at Princeton University.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 31 (AP). -- A race to save the life of 5-year-old Barbara Bourne was lost today, although an aviator, an ambulance driver and a policeman on a motorcycle all did their level best.
Following are the records of kidnapping cases in the United States in the last few years in which the kidnappers have been apprehended and punished, or in which they are awaiting trial:

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 31. -- Jack Mackie Jr. and his partner, Pete Cassella, professional at the Valley Stream club, are making a good thing out of the Long Island Golf Association's amateur-pro tournaments.

MEXICO, D.F., July 31. -- Former President Plutarco Elias Calles's speech yesterday was "in harmony with the spirit of the United States, as I understand it, looking to closer cooperation among members of the Pan American Union," declared United States Ambassador Josephus Daniels today.

BOMBAY, Tuesday, Aug. 1. -- Mahatma Gandhi, his wife, his secretary and thirty followers were arrested at 1:40 this morning at the Mahatma's seminary at Ahmedabad as they were preparing to start on a march to spread the new gospel of "individual civil disobedience."

After three favorites had scored in succession, Miss Purray from the Tranquillity Farm charged through the stretch at Empire City yesterday and won at 6 to 1 in the fourth race, the Dyckman Purse. It was a close finish, only a neck dividing the first two.

The United States Treasury's first venture into the long-term bond market in nearly two years will be an unqualified success. This was evident from the enthusiastic reception accorded by Wall Street yesterday to Secretary Woodin's announcement of an offering on Aug. 15 of $500,000,000 of eight-year 3 1/4 per cent bonds.

In Roswell, N.M., Paul Horgan is celebrating simultaneously his thirtieth birthday and his winning of the Harper Prize novel competition for 1933 with his first novel to reach publication, "The Fault of Angels." The book will be issued on Aug. 24.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 31 (AP). -- The Commercial National Bank was placed under a conservatorship at its own request today subsequent to its purchase, through misunderstanding, of $500,000 in Liberty Bonds stolen from the Continental Bank and Trust Company of New York.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP). -- A tentative trade practice plan for the oil industry, calling for Federal supervision of production as a basic step toward stability, was laid before petroleum leaders tonight by Hugh S. Johnson, the Industrial Administrator.

Supreme Court Justice Selah B. Strong in Brooklyn reserved decision yesterday on the plea of an aged and destitute widow for permission to disinter her husband's body and sell the cemetery lot to relieve her distress.
Fishing continues to hold its peak along the New Jersey coast. This can be attested by many Philadel- phia, Brooklyn and Manhattan anglers.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Puonc hearings on the iron and steel industry's code of fair competition were completed today in a dramatic six-hour session at which the industry voluntarily withdrew its company union stipulation but insisted on retaining the open-shop principle.

With most United States Government issues declining in moderate transactions despite a favorable reception by the financial district of the news of the Treasury's August financing, there was general weakness yesterday in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Samuel Dwight Brewster of The Birches, Glen Cove, who had been visiting friends in Camden, Me., is now at the Marshall House, York Harbor. She will go soon to Bretton Woods for the remainder of the month.
