The United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries, excluding the Philadelphia Gas Works Company, report a consolidated net income of $33,428,924 for the twelve months ended June 30, 1933. This is equal after preferred dividends to $1.27 a share earned on the common stock outstanding at midyear, comparing with $36,624,771, or $1.41 a share, earned in the preceding twelve months.

Now that happy days are here again, the code form of government should in- vestigate the melancholy of the radio. As thing's are at present it is almost impossible for the Summer celibate to find a lively tune. As he sits shirtless, beside the open window of an evening, what does he discover?

ALBANY, N.Y., July 31. -- Governor Lehman sent another special message to the extraordinary session of the Legislature tonight urging additional measures to put the State in line with the National Recovery program.

United States. ASSISTANT DIRECTOR OF SOCIAL WORK (Warden's Assistant). -- Applications must be on file not later than Aug. 31 for an examination to fill vacancies in U.S. penal and correctional institutions. The salary $2,600 to $3,100 a year. Competitors will not be required to report for examination at any place, but will be rated on the following subjects, which will have the relative weights indicated: Education and experience.

Governor Lehman Intends to ask the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board soon to consider permitting the sale of 3.2 beer by small candy stores, Samuel Katz, president of the Triboro Tobacco, Stationery and Candy Stores Association, announced yesterday on his return to Brooklyn from Albany.

Throughout the code hearings in Washington and elsewhere, General JOHNSON seems to be devoting himself to enforcement of the principle that no special interest shall make use of the National Industry Recovery Act to gain an advantage over another. Where there has been conflict between employers and employes, the open shop and organized labor, the Administrator has kept his eye fixed on the purpose of the whole experiment.

BRENTWOOD, L.I., July 31. -- Members of the Suffolk County forest rangers and the forest fire reserves of the Long Island State Park Commission gained a respite today in their two-day fight against a forest fire. Thousands of acres of scrub oak and valuable timber land between Brentwood and Central Islip and as far south as the northern outskirts of Islip and Bay Shore have been burned.

NORWICH, N.Y., July 31. -- Three hundred farmers from adjoining counties voted unanimously at a mass meeting here today to start the milk holiday Tuesday morning. Milk will be kept at home off the road.

The Chase National Bank has asked for tenders of external thirty-year 5 per cent sinking fund gold bonds, due Feb. 1, 1957, of the State of New South Wales, before Friday, at prices not exceeding par and accrued interest, sufficient to exhaust the sum of $135,057 in the sinking fund.

New securities publicly offered here in July showed a decline in the number of issues and face values from the previous month, although a marked rise occurred in the number of new stock issues placed on the market. The total was $84,044,000, composed of twenty-seven bond issues aggregating $62,028,000 and twenty-one stock issues totaling $22,016,000.

Stating that the new Securities Act does not specifically mention mortgages, mortgage bonds or mortgage loans, the National Association of Real Estate Boards has sent a request to the Federal Trade Commission asking that a definite interpretation of the act be made whereby the exemption of real estate mortgages or trust deeds in the nature of realty mortgages will be clearly stated.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The merits and demerits of expending Federal funds for deepening and improving portions of the Erie and Oswego Canals, as part of a waterway from the Great Lakes to the Hudson River, were debated at a public hearing today before the Board of Army Engineers.

NEWARK, N.J., July 31 (AP). -- Buffalo defeated Hewark, 7 -- 0, today behind the fine pitching of Ray Lucas, who gave nine hits and three walks, but tightened with men on bases and left eleven stranded.
ROCHESTER, July 31 (AP). -- Independent dairymen, estimated to number 50,000, were pledged and ready tonight to begin tomorrow to withhold their product from the market.
MANILA, July 31. -- The final act of repudiation of the Philippine Independence Mission which sponsored and aided the passage of the Hawes Law in Washington was completed in the Legislature today.

The Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company and its affiliate, the Corn Exchange Safe Deposit Company, announced yesterday that they had signed the blanket code agreement under the National Industrial Recovery Act and sent the pledge to Washington.

Changes in and additions to the personnel of the various Jesuit colleges and high schools in the metropolitan area and several transfers of administration were announced yesterday by the Very Rev. Edward C. Phillips, Provincial of the Maryland-New York Province of the Society of Jesus.

ALBANY, July 31. -- Balked in its attempt to obtain the minutes of the last three meetings of the Niagara Hudson Corporation, the Public Service Commission retaliated today by making public the salaries paid to officials of the companies which make up the corporation.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- The ease with which habitual criminals obtain liberty is one of the first of the abuses which must be corrected in order to make more effective warfare on organized crime, according to J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Bureau of Investigation at Washington, for whom a paper on the crime situation was read today before the opening session of the International Association of Chiefs of Police.

No change occured in the call loan rates for money in July on either of the Stock Exchanges here, the same quotations having run continuously since April 13. Mounting loans to brokers and heavy withdrawals of demand deposits by interior banks failed to cause any stringency in funds used for loans against securities.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 31. -- Small home owners from New York and other cities, demanding legislation to insure a moratorium on mortgages for the period of the depression, will make a demonstration at the Capitol tomorrow to impress the Legislature with the seriousness of their situation.
Declining revenues and rates of return were shown by the electric companies yesterday in opposing the fixing of temporary emergency rate reductions by the Public Service Commission.

Giulia P. Morosini, daughter of the late Giovanni Morosini, financier and associate of the late Jay Gould, left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,877,593 gross and $1,304,025 net, of which $330,504 went to public institutions. Her gifts included one of the finest collections of arms and armor in the country.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 31. -- Hot and sultry weather that clung like a blanket over the Hudson Val- ley and sent the thermometer above the 100 degree mark at Krum Elbow today, considerably marred the vacation plans of President Roosevelt.

ALBANY, July 31. -- Death as the penalty for kidnapping where the victim has not been returned alive before the trial was urged by Governor Lehman in a special message tonight to the extraordinary session of the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Hundreds of Federal employes were assured today that they woud be kept on the payroll from fifty days to five months longer instead of being dropped ten days hence.

James Mattern, whose interrupted flight around the world ended Sunday when he flew back to Floyd Bennett Field in a borrowed airplane, received the official felicitations of the city yesterday from Mayor O'Brien at City Hall.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- Twenty-two witnesses, including stable owners, officials of two of Chicago's race tracks and trainers, went before a Federal grand jury here today as the Narcotic Bureau continued its investigation of the alleged doping of race horses.

When he considers such mysteries as the slight variations in the length of the day noted ever since HALLEY'S time, the shifting of the Poles and the great crustal movements, Dr. ARNOLD HEIM, a geologist of international reputation, finds it necessary to go out into the vast universe to account for them.

PLYMOUTH, England, July 31. -- Samuel Untermyer, president of the World Jewish Economic Federation, who sailed for New York on the liner Paris tonight, declared the organization of a world-wide movement for the defense of the 600,000 German Jews had proved successful beyond his most sanguine expectations.

Reports in circulation over Sunday that inflationary measures beyond expenditures for public works might be delayed unsettled speculative buying of cotton yesterday, and prices on the Cotton Exchange broke a half cent a pound, closing near the day's lowest level with losses of 44 to 51 points, or $2.20 to $2.55 a bale.

As a result of activities by the Atlas Corporation, through the Pacific Eastern Corporation, the number of common shares of the Shenandoah Corporation in the hands of the public has been reduced to 432,052 shares out of an issue of 5,897,432 shares.

PATERSON, N.J., July 31. -- The question of how violators of the National Industrial Recovery Act are to be punished took definite form here today when it was learned that seven silk dyeing concerns that signed a code a week ago are already charged with having violated it.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Only one who has not studied general conditions and land valuations on the lower east side can raise the issue of "mysterious fluctuations in the value of building sites in the slum areas" -- if this section is the supposed target. There is no mystery about different values along different thoroughfares.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Nine of the largest retail groups reached an agreement tonight with General Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, to begin operations immediately with shorter hours and higher wages.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Secretary Wallace and George Peek, Farm Act Adminstrator, issued a joint statement today to cultivate the farmers' attitude in favor of the work of the Farm Adjustment and Recovery Administrations. They declared that "the farmer has a tremendous stake in the Roosevelt Administration's plans not only to raise farm prices but to increase wages and employment as well."

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP). -- New interpretations to clarify the President's voluntary re-employment agreement were issued tonight by the Recovery Administration, among them one providing for business men without employes obtaining the NRA eagle insignia.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 31. -- Seven persons were killed and eighty were wounded today in the Hotel Europe in Brno, Czechoslovakia, when a guest at the hotel committed suicide by exploding a bomb that is believed to have contained ecrasite.

The magic of the Negro folksong sung with fervor and without affectation was once more to be experienced at the Lewisohn Stadium last night, when the Hall Johnson Negro Choir made the first of its annual appearances at the concert of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra.

The players in the revival of "The Pirates of Penzance," which Milton Aborn is presenting for one week at the Majestic Theatre, starting next Monday, will include Frank Moulan, William Danforth, Vera Ross, Herbert Waterous. Allan Waterous, Roy Cropper and Ruth Altman.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., July 31. -- Clarence Clark of Forest Hill, for- mer New Jersey professional champion, and Victor Ghezzi of Rumson led the New Jersey qualifiers for the National P.G.A. championship today. Each scored 141, one stroke under par, for two rounds over the Forest Hill Field Club course.

An avalanche of signed agreements under the President's recovery program descended upon the local office of the Department of Commerce in the Custom House yesterday, the first full day in the recovery campaign inaugurated by the government.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company announced yesterday that it would put into effect today the provisions of the President's re-employment agreement under the blanket code in all its 15,700 retail store, offices, warehouses and food plants throughout the country.
NEW ORLEANS, July 31. -- Governor Alien issued a proclamation for qualified martial law today on the eve of a court investigation of alleged frauds in the general election of November, 1932.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 31. -- Finals in the Maidstone Club's annual invitation singles tennis tournament were played today before a large gallery, with Miss Alice Marble playing Miss Betty Nuthall of England in tne finals for the singles gold cup.

SALEM, N.H., July 31 (AP). -- At- lantic Volo, the brown son of Peter Volo and the $50,000 Hambletonian Stake candidate of I.O. Blake of New York, became one of the first-ranking 3-year-old trotters on the Grand Circuit today. He registered a double victory over small but high-class fields at Rockingham Park.

A surprise party at which his family, friends and colleagues gathered to do him honor was tendered Richard Aldrich, music critic emeritus of THE NEW YORK TIMES, on the occasion of his seventieth birthday yesterday afternoon at his home at Barrytown-on-the-Hudson.
New York suffered yesterday the most extreme July heat ever recorded here.
UNIONTOWN, Pa., July 31. -- The strike in the soft coal fields spread suddenly and unexpectedly up the Monongahela Valley today.

In the conferences at Washington many industrial and financial leaders have taken part. It appears that incidentally and quietly they have laid before the authorities a powerful business argument against currency inflation. This was not their main errand. They were there to seek cooperation with the Government in the revival of manufactures and the extension of credit.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Declaring that "the long-discussed revolution is actually under way in the United States," Donald R. Richberg, general counsel of the National Recovery Administration, in a radio address tonight summoned Americans "to wage a war against selfishness and greed that corrupt the individual and destroy the nation."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter from Gordon MacCreagh under the caption "Helping the Farmer" expresses support of what I fear is a quite general misapprehension, namely, that the farmers have gone on blind- ly increasing acreage of major crops, and thus are responsible for depressed prices caused by overproduction.
AMITYVILLE, L.I., July 31. -- As a preliminary to the eighteenth annual race meet of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association, the Unqua Corinthian Yacht Club held an invitation regatta today.
WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Books on the Treasury's offering of $850,000,000 in bonds and notes had been open only few hours today when subscriptions far exceeded the government's financial requirements.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- Following the third consecutive business day in which grain prices plunged downward the maximum amount permitted for a day's trading, the directors of the Chicago Board of Trade tonight again imposed minimum prices on all grains and also on provisions.
ST. LOUIS, July 31 (AP). -- The Browns, bunching three hits with a donation of seven bases on balls, scored eight runs in the seventh inning to defeat the Indians today, 12 to 8.
WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Inspired by the great Babe Ruth, the Yankees concluded their siege of the capital today with a smashing victory over the Senators.

Mrs. Frances W. King finished testifying in her own defense yesterday. She is on trial in General Sessions on charges of blackmail and of attempting to extort $50,000 from Bruce Barton, publicist and advertising executive.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- With 13,000 firms in this area accepting the blanket recovery code sponsored by President Roosevelt, thousands of Chicago's army of unemployed thronged the employment offices of factories and stores today and stood in line at agencies in a quest for the jobs made available under the new program.

Mid-week diversions have been planned by several beach and country clubs near the city. The City Country Club, which was organized recently and which has its Summer headquarters at 240th Street and Van Cortlandt Park East, will hold its first entertainment tonight with a tea dance and moonlight boating party.

The program for the mass meeting tonight in Town Hall; 123 West Forty-third Street, to protest against any additional sales tax was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen. Mr. Whalen is chairman of the merchants committee which is fighting the levy, suggested by Mayor O'Brien to meet the city's financial difficulties.
Transactions in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange in July to taled $384,014,300. This was the largest amount of bonds dealt in since December, 1924.

There was a marked increase in July in the retirement of bonds before their maturity dates, the total of those called for payment last month being more than double that of June. Refundings announced for future months made the largest number of entire issues called in any month this year.

The Chrysler Corporation and subsidiary companies announced yesterday a net profit of $7,785,616, or $1.80 a share on the capital stock, for the second quarter of 1933, in contrast with a net loss of $3,038,082 in the first quarter and with a net profit of $1,186,052, or 27 cents a share, earned in the second quarter of 1932.

The city's acute financial situation and the depleted condition of the street improvement fund were cited yesterday by Acting Controller Frank J. Prial as the principal reasons why the Department of Finance could not register the 100 contracts for assessable public improvements in Queens awarded several months ago.

SUNDERLAND, England, July 31 (Canadian Press). -- The two-day cricket match between the touring West Indies eleven and Durham ended in a draw today, when rain baited play shortly after the teatime interval.

Except for silver, the price movement of all commodity futures traded on local exchanges was lower yesterday. Activity was somewhat greater than on most days last week, but continued small in comparison with the volume before that.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Compensatory taxes of 4.2 cents a pound on paper articles coming in competition with cotton products, and 8.4 cents a pound on rayon were urged today by S. Robert Glassford of New York on behalf of the Cotton Textile Institute, at a hearing before the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.
WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Movements of vessels follow. All dates are July 29, unless otherwise specified:

Improvement in June in dividend payments to stockholders was continued in July. More dividend rates were increased than in any month since December last, and more than in July, 1932. Extra payments and resumption of payments were well above the totals of last year, while reduced and omitted payments fell far below the number of a year ago.
ALBANY, July 31. -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's message to the Legislature on the kidnapping evil:
George McAneny, Sanitation Commissioner, announced yesterday that the next shake-up in his department would affect 800 men in responsible posts.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Tuesday, Aug. 1. -- Charles F. Urschel, kidnapped oil milionaire, has been returned, it was announced at the Urschel home here early today.

Money market was featureless. Rates in all sections were maintained without change, while business was small. Stock Exchange call loans remained at 1 per cent, which also ruled in the counter trading. Federal funds were 1/8 Time money, commercial paper and acceptances were steady.

BLUE POINT, L.I., July 31. -- Frustrated by a train crew on her first attempt, Miss. Ethel Ellison, 47 years old, of 1,190 Clay Avenue, the Bronx, succeeded here today in getting herself struck and mortally injured by a Long Island Railroad train.

CHICAGO, July 31. -- Princess Camelia, a 4-year-old daughter of Royal Canopy-Sunmelia, running for Mrs. John Marsch of Chicago, scored a surprise victory in the Cascades Pursa, top event of Hawthorne's opening program today.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Retirement from the diplomatic service of Robert Woods Bliss, recently Ambassador to Argentina, was announced today by the State Department. He was retired today in accordance with the law authorizing retirement after thirty years of service.

ABOARD THE S.S. BREMEN, at Sea, July 31. -- Very few of the Bremen's first class passengers were aware of the fatal accidental shooting in an A deck cabin at 3 o'clock Sunday morning of Karl Werner Heye 3d by his cabin mate, Charles Manger.

The question whether the value of freshly laundered hose, shirts and collars increases when they are disposed of to strangers was examined and ruled upon yesterday in Washington Heights Court by Magistrate Brodsky.
COLOGNE, July 31. -- The International Esperanto Congress today heard Director Kreuz of the Esperanto Central Bureau at Geneva read a report on progress during 1932.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 31. -- The forty-third annual Southampton invitation tennis tournament got under way on the turf courts of the Meadow Club today with two form reversals cutting into the ranks of the brilliant array of talent gathered here.
Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan postponed yesterday his decision on the offer of the fusion nomination for Mayor, made to him last week by the group headed by former Governor Charles S. Whitman.
Eugene Breier of the home club yesterday won the Long Island cad- die championship over the links of the Fresh Meadow Country Club at Flushing.

Large shipments of gold to France, almost all of which was released from earmarked holdings, were the principal movements of the metal here in July. Exports of $84,562,500 and no imports compared with exports of $2,700,000 and imports of $332,000 in June, and exports of $23,322,500 and imports of $7,298,600 in July, 1932.

Application in the Supreme Court for a certificate of reasonable doubt for Thomas Patrick Morris, 53-year-old house painter who tried to collect the entire Wendel fortune and received an indeterminate sentence to the penitentiary for conspiracy, will be made on Aug. 7.

HAVANA, July 31. -- Protests against the treatment of the public by the Cuban military forces, which are still maintaining control of most of the island despite the restoration of constitutional guarantees, are pouring into Havana, to be placed before the United States Ambassador, Sumner Welles, who has been accepted as mediator between the Machado government and its opponents.

Captain James A. Mollison and his wife, Amy Johnson, first couple to fly the Atlantic in a westerly direction, will receive today the official welcome of the city. The program includes the traditional Broadway parade from the Battery to City Hall, a speech of welcome by Mayor O'Brien in the Aldermanic Chamber and the presentation to each of the filers of a gold medal.

The volume of trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the third heaviest on record and would have been the largest month's business in the history of the Exchange but for the short sessions and holidays. The most active day was July 21, when 9,573,900 shares were traded, and the largest week that ended July 22, when transactions totaled 42,335,223 shares, the second largest week on record.

State Sales Tax Bureaus in Manhattan and Brooklyn were swamped yesterday with thousands of returns for the first two months of the State's emergency 1 per cent sales levy. Yesterday was the last day for filing the two-month returns.
BERLIN, July 31. -- Three more distinguished German scholars have been shelved by the authorities.

BOSTON, July 31. -- The second step in the rebuilding of the Boston Red Sox, which became the sole aim of President Tom Yawkey and General Manager Eddie Collins when they purchased the club from Bob Quinn last February, was taken today when the control of the Reading franchise in the New YorkPennsylvania League passed into their hands.

ALBANY, July 31. -- Governor Lehman is thoroughly aroused over the failure of the New York City authorities to develop any plan, acceptable to him, to enable the city to keep up its system of relief to the unemployed. The Governor's annoyance is shared by the Republicans in the Legislature.

It was the weakness in the grain markets, more than anything else, which gave Wall Street its blue Monday. All comment wis directed toward the unsettled status of the commodities. Speculators looked all day for a recovery, but it never came.

Independent motion picture producers, distributors and exhibitors met yesterday at the Hotel Astor and agreed tentatively on the basic principles of a code of fair trade practice for submission at Washington under the NIRA. The meeting was under the auspices of the Federation of the Motion Picture Industry of America, Inc. P.S. Harrison, president of the federation, said that 30 1/2 per cent of the producing and distributing organizations of America were represented.

Buyers Here Press for Deliveries. Orders for Fall merchandise, particularly coats, dresses and accessories, were again heavy in the local markets yesterday, with the number of buyers here approaching the August peak. Many of the store representatives are here to survey conditions which have developed since their initial trips.
PARIS, July 31. -- Maggy Rouff sounds a Winter style note with tiny shaped basques jutting shelf-like from the hips and flattened in front and back, giving a brand new youthful silhouette.

Dr. Barnum Brown, who hunts the prehistoric dinosaur by airplane, is leaving for the West today on a one-man expedition. Dr. Brown, who is curator of fossil reptiles at the American Museum of Natural History and an authority on the ancient monsters, is the only paleontologist, it is believed, who has introduced flying machines into the hunt for pre-historic bones.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 31. -- A British victory in the singles and a British-American triumph in the doubles at the expense of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody marked the closing round of the invitation ten- nis tournament at the Maidstone Club today.
Relief seekers clashed with police at three Home Relief Bureau stations in Brooklyn yesterday. Two policemen were hurt in one of the disturbances. There were no arrests.
WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Secretary Ferkins asserted today at the opening hearing on the steel code that the working hours proposed were too long and that wages were too low.

Conflicting influences, some operating in the direction of firmer money and some tending to produce even lower rates affected the money market here last month, says the Aug. 1 monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Joseph W. Harriman, former president of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, suffered a heart attack yesterday in Federal Court, where Judge Francis G. Caffey was conducting a hearing into his sanity.

Offices of the Home Owners Loan Corporation of the State of NewYork were opened yesterday in the Empire State Building. Officials on duty reported that several applications for help had been received under the plan for Federal aid for distressed property owners and that these applications were being classified for prompt action when the work of approving or rejecting loan pleas is started shortly.

BUENOS AIRES, July 31. -- The impression is growing in diplomatic circles here that Brazil is preparing to act alone as mediator in the Chaco war in case Argentina, Chile and Peru decide not to participate as the ABCP group under a League of Nations mandate.

The Federal Government announced yesterday the terms of its August financing. Two securities are offered to the public. One is an issue of $500,000,000 in eight-year bonds, bearing interest at 3 1/4 per cent. The other consists of $350,000,000 in two-year notes, with interest at 1 5/8 per cent.

REGINA, Sask., July 31 (Canadian Press). -- Financing of world wheat surpluses and forecasting of future prices in wheat marketing were the chief subjects discussed at today's session of the World's Grain Conference here.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting members in ninety leading cities on July 26 shows decreases for the week of $104,000,000 in loans and investments, $69,000,000 in net demand deposits, $9,000,000 in time deposits and $21,000,000 in government deposits, and increases of $25,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $6,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

VIENNA, July 31. -- Responding to inquiries by three great powers the Austrian Government has furnished them with full details concerning recent Nazi aggressions. This information was given today when inquiries were made about reports circulating abroad that Britain, France and Italy intended to make joint representations at Berlin regarding the Nazi campaign.

Starting this morning 1,670 youths from New York, New Jersey and Delaware will leave their homes and report at four army training centres in New York State for thirty days' instruction in Citizens Military Training Camps.

The National Automobile Chamber of Commerce announced yesterday from its headquarters at 366 Madison Avenue that members of the chamber, comprising most of the leading automobile, motor truck and bus producing companies and representing 98 per cent of the annual production of the chamber membership, had signed approval of the industry's code covering minimum wages and hours of work adopted in Detroit last Friday and filed with the National Recovery Administration.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP). -- Opposing factions in the boot and shoe industry remained deadlocked tonight on details of a code of competition despite the efforts of National Recovery Administrators to effect a compromise.

War or peace is the issue that will be decided by the final results of the World Economic Conference when it reconvenes, said Senator Key Pittman, a United States delegate to the conference, in a broadcast from London last night. His talk was heard in this country over National Broadcasting Company networks.

The killing of four Chinese here in the last three weeks, and the wounding of a fifth prompted George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, to have subpoenas issued yesterday calling for the appearance today before the Federal grand jury of the secretaries of the On Leong and Hip Sing Tongs.

Local commodity markets became firm yesterday after being weak at their opening. Only sugar and silver ended the day with losses, and these were smaller than on some recent days. Most cash prices were higher.

"An American Omnibus," which Doubleday, Doran Co. will publish today, may attract the attention of collectors of Sinclair Lewis's first editions, for it contains "Ring Around Rosie," a short story by Lewis, which has not appeared before in book form.
ALBANY, Aug. 1. -- Governor Lehman, in a special message to the Legislature today, urged enactment of a bill requiring the payment of interest on deposits of all public moneys.

VIENNA, Aug. 1. -- Das Neue Tagebuch, published here by the exiled editors of the former German weekly of the same name, today prints charges that Dr. Alfred Strauss, a lawyer, was recently murdered in the concentration camp at Dachau, near Munich.
SCHEDULE OF MATCHES. Friday, Aug. 4. First Match at 3 P.M. Singles -- Miss Helen Jacobs, U.S., vs. Miss Dorothy Round: Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, U.S., vs. Miss Peggy Scriven.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1. -- Archibald M. Johnson, son of Senator Hiram Johnson, committed suicide early today in the library of his suburban home.

The government's recovery drive under the President's blanket code continued with increasing momentum yesterday as another 20,000 employers in New York and vicinity signed the re-employment agreements under the code and forwarded them to the local office of the Department of Commerce in the Custom House Building.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are a number of people whose hanging -- though I would disapprove of and try to prevent it -- might not disturb my sleep. There are a very few -- rascals all -- whose demeanor suggests that they would delight to compass a similar fate for me.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1. -- Frankie Parker today found his forehand on grass and the finest tennis that Berkeley Bell has played in the East this year was unavailing against him.

Back from their unsuccessful quest of the Davis Cup, four players of the United States squad and Bernon S. Prentice, their non-playing captain, arrived yesterday aboard the White Star liner Olympic. The players were Ellsworth Vines, Wilmer Allison, John Van Ryn and George Lott.

Captain William J. Pedrick, president of the Fifth Avenue Association, issued an anti-sales-tax statement last night on behalf of a group of Fifth Avenue merchants who attended the Town Hall protest meeting.

In that shabby old news room or Mr. DANA'S Sun, reached by steep stairs in a building whose duty and tradition it was to be on fire at least once every twenty-four hours, Boss LORD, the managing editor, had his undistinguished and unprotected desk in one corner on the Park Row side.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Several of your correspondents lately have advanced the theory that if we brought back the whipping-post it would deter criminals. The vital objection to any such backward step in the treatment of criminals is not based on any tenderness for the offender, but upon its effect upon the officials who administer the punishment and upon all who know of the brutality.

Fifty-seven bathers, including three women and several children, were injured at Coney Island yesterday when a section of wooden balcony gave way beneath their weight. They were thrown seventeen feet to the platform surrounding the outdoor swimming pool at Steeplechase Park.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- Clad in gray coats, gray trousers, white hats, white crossed belts and white gloves, 1,000 members of the 107th Infantry, the old Seventh Regiment of Manhattan, led by Colonel Ralph C. Tobin, observed the fiftieth anniversary of the first encampment of this National Guard unit at Camp Smith today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- In a front page editorial headed "Let's Face the Facts." The Chicago Daily News comments on President Roosevelt's industrial recovery program as follows:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1. -- Members of the Summer colony and their guests filled Parrish Memorial Hall tonight, when the Hampton Players opened their season, under the direction and management of Henry Codman Potter and, George Haight, with the presentation of "Perhaps We Are," a new comedy by Paul Osborn.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Johnnie Neun's triple to deep left in the last half of the ninth inning scored Pete Stack and enabled the Bears to defeat Buffalo by 5 to 4 tonight. The victory gave Newark the series, three games to one, and increased its advantage over Rochester to three and one-half games.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Rejection of all bids received Wednesday by the Navy Department for construction of three cruisers was urged tonight by Chairman Trammell of the Senate Naval Committee in a letter to President Roosevelt, charging that the bidders had advance information on rival offers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The Agricultural Adjustment Administration has obtained a loan of $30,000,000 needed for taking over from the Farm Credit Administration 1,019,184 bales of spot cotton to supply options taken by farmers under the reduction program.

Charles S. Devoy, chief clerk of the Supreme Court in Brooklyn since 1920 and one of the best known Republicans in the borough, died early yesterday morning at the age of 71 in St. John's Hospital. He entered the hospital on July 19 for a gland operation and underwent a preliminary operation a few days ago.
Carl Hubbell's streak of consecutive scoreless innings was ended by the Braves at the Polo Grounds yesterday -- but not before the Giants southpaw had broken the National League record.

Public utility industries employing more than 1,000,000 are engaged in studying the National Industrial Recovery Act and the means of drawing up special codes for each of the separate industries or their major subdivisions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Organization of a nation-wide force of Federal employes to carry quickly to farmers in every county the benefits of the $2,000,000,000 farm mortgage legislation has been started by Henry Morgenthau Jr., governor of the Farm Credit Administration.
ABOARD THE MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, Aug.1 (Wireless). -- We have been almost two days at sea on our 20,000-mile journey from Norway to the Ross Sea in Antarctica.
Two anniversary memorial services were held yesterday for firemen who lost their lives in the Ritz Tower fire of Aug. 1, 1932. Relatives, friends and former comrades paid tribute at the exercises.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Advocates of Federal regulation of petroleum prices were told tonight by Hugh S. Johnson, the Industrial Administrator, that he would not recommend any price fixing to President Roosevelt until the effect of production control had been determined.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- Support of Governor Lehman's ideas for strengthening the laws against kidnapping was voiced today at the convention of the International. Association of Police Chiefs by Dr. Carleton Simon, former Deputy Police Commissioner of New York City.

Tammany Hall never has acted "in more impudent disregard of the public interest," George Trosk, associate of Samuel Seabury in the Hofstadter inquiry, declared last night in asking for public support of the move to overthrow the organization at the polls in November.

A protest against any additional retail sales tax, coupled with a request for the repeal of the present 1 per cent tax, was addressed yesterday by Joseph Gorodiz, credit adviser of the East Broadway Merchants Association, to Irwin Steingut, minority leader in the Assembly.

LONDON, Aug. 1. -- President Roosevelt's refusal to stabilize the dollar was emphatically upheld to day by the Midland Bank's monthly review in an article reflecting the inflationist views of the bank's chairman, Reginald McKenna.

Hugh Rodgers King was produced as a surprise witness for the prosecution yesterday to contradict the testimony given by his wife in her own defense during the last three days. Mrs. King is on trial in General Sessions before Judge Joseph E. Corrigan on charges of blackmail and attempting to extort $50,000 from Bruce Barton, publicist and advertising executive.

ALBANY, Aug. 1. -- A detailed story of the negotiations with the kidnappers of John J. O'Connell Jr. was presented for the first time tonight by Louis Snyder, attorney for Manny Strewl, intermediary in the payment of $40,000 ransom.

About 100 independent motionpicture theatre owners attended a meeting of the Motion Picture Theatre Industry of the Metropolitan District yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor. Virtually all Signed resolutions endorsing and approving President Roosevelt's blanket code under the NRA.They asked, however, that they be put under the temporary code applying to retailers, until the motion-picture code is completed.

Recovery of the bust of AUGUSTUS in Athens recalls his visit to Athens in the year 19 B.C. VIRGIL had gone to join him there, intending to spend some time in Greece and Asia in "perfecting" the Aeneid, but was persuaded by AUGUSTUS to return with him to Italy.
CLEVELND, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Dr. Frank Robertson Van Horn, geologist, "father of football" at Case School of Applied Science, died in Lakeside Hospital today of arthritis. He was 61 years old.

ALBANY, Aug. 1. -- Singing and waving placards, about 1,000 small home owners and landlords marched up Capitol Hill today and appealed to Governor Lehman for a moratorium on the foreclosure of mortgages on small homes and farms.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- Opening a drive to enlist further the cooperation of banking institutions in the national recovery program, the administration offered today to add $1,000,000,000 to their capital reserves to replemish the stream of commercial credit.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 1. -- A list of State and district Recovery Boards, composed of persons "drafted" by President Roosevelt to carry out the Recovery program, was made public today by the National Recovery Administration. The State boards for New York. New Jersey and Connecticut are:

MOSCOW, Aug. 1. -- Soviet leaders are still attempting to reduce the administrative staffs of collective farms which often are such a great burden that the workers in the fields do not prosper when they have excellent crops.

Former Hot Weather. Let us take a look at the thermometer and say a kind word for the Old Deal. There was a time in New York not so long ago when a heat wave meant daily prostrations by the hundreds and deaths by the score.

BOMBAY, Aug. 1. -- The Government of India has a new plan for dealing with Mahatma Gandhi. With his wife, his secretary and thirty-two of his disciples arrested with him this morning at Ahmedabad, he will be taken to Poona and there released after service of an order requiring him to abandon his new "individual civil disobedience" campaign.

ALBANY, Aug. 1. -- A settlement was reached late today in the tangled New York City relief tax situation when the New York City authorities withdrew their program for a State-wide tax to bring financial aid to the city. Governor Lehman thus won a complete victory for the principles and procedure he laid down in a special message to the Legislature on the opening day of the extraordinary session.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Darting to the front as the barrier was sprung in the Nordic Purse, the feature at Hawthorne today, Madwind, racing in the colors of A.A. Baroni of Reno, Nev., galloped to victory by a neck over Katherine E. Hitt's All Rowes.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- One of two youths picked up here on Sunday on a Sullivan Law charge admitted today, according to police, that they had killed a West Virginia deputy sheriff on July 25. The king took place, the youth was quoted as saying, when, aided by two others, he tried to rescue his brother, a convicted robber, who also was slain in the gunfight with two policemen.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Outstanding bankers of New Jersey, assembled here today for a conference with Governor Moore and the State Banking and Insurance Commissioner, Colonel William H. Kelly, laid the ground work for a concerted drive against Federal operation of the deposit insurance feature of the recently enacted Glass-Steagall Act with a view to establishing independent State deposit insurance under administration of the State Department of Banking and Insurance.

A mass meeting of citizens and taxpayers at Town Hall last night emphatically protested Mayor O'Brien's proposal for a new sales tax to meet the city's relief problem. The gathering strongly disapproved both the new plan put forward yesterday for a municipal 1 per cent sales tax within New York City and the abandoned proposition to increase the present 1 per cent State sales tax to 2 per cent.

Edward P. Mulrooney, chairman of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, was asked yesterday to modify the board's recent ruling which prohibits brewers and wholesalers from furnishing signs to retailers to be placed outside of their establishments if "any monetary consideration" is involved.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- A triangular fight over wages for skilled and semi-skilled workers in the millinery industry was staged as hearings on the code of fair competition affecting women's and children's hats began today before Deputy Recovery Administrator Earl Dean Howard.

Scoring seven runs in the second inning, the Montreal Royals went on to rout Jersey City, 11 to 1, on the latter team's home grounds yesterday. The Jerseys previously had beaten the Royals in three straight games.

The Consolidated Oil Corporation yesterday morning lowered its crude oil price schedule in the Mid-continent and Texas areas to conform to those of the subsidiaries of the Standard Oil Companies of New Jersey and Indiana, the Texas Corporation and other large purchasers there which had refused to meet the higher schedule posted by the Magnolia Petroleum Company, the Continental Oil Company and others.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 1. -- An attempt was made by a mob of 100 men to take three international labor defense attorneys, being escorted by National Guardsmen from Tuscaloosa to Birmingham tonight, from their train near here. The mob, however, confronted by the guardsmen, gave up the attempt.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1. -- More than 2,000 strikers and strike sympathizers battled police today at the Cambria Silk Hosiery Company's mill. Several persons suffered minor injuries and thirty-five were arrested.

Shipping interests will await action by the Shipping Board before demanding a clarification of the government's rights with respect to intercoastal rates, it was indicated yesterday. Milton P. Bauman, chairman of the Shippers' Conference of Greater New York, said that that organization would not act until the board does.

A committee calling itself the Citizens Committee to Investigate Conditions in the Fur Industry -- but characterized by the Fur Workers Union, affiliated with the American Federation of Labor, as an "innocents committee set up by the Communist party" -- made a report of its investigation yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 1 (AP). -- With Sam West and Carl Reynolds leading the attack, Rogers Hornsby's Browns made it two straight over the Indians today, winning, 5 to 2. The two outfielders garnered more than half the St. Louis hits, which included West's circuit drive and Reynolds's triple.

Mr. LA GUARDIA declared yesterday his intention to enter the Republican primary as a candidate for Mayor. With an abundance of caution, he added that he stood ready to withdraw in case a satisfactory nominee were agreed upon. This obviously does not mean, in his mind, General O'RYAN.

The Federal Government will not give any direct aid to education at the present time. Dr. George P. Zook, United States Commissioner of Education, said last night in an address before the Institute on Administration of Public Education at Teachers College, Columbia University.
PITTSBURGH. Aug. 1 (AP). -- The Pittsburgh Pirates drew a game nearer the league-leading New York Giants today as they defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 9 to 3, for their eighth straight victory.

The Olympic, which arrived yesterday afternoon from Southampton and Cherbourg, brought three film stars, a composer and tales of the simple life, to which the passengers reverted suddenly on Monday night as the ship approached the torrid shores af the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Shooting a brilliant two-under-par round of 69 for his last 18-holes, Ed Dudley, American Ryder Cup star, set a new tournament record of 288 to win the Philadelphia open golf championship today.
NEW YORK. Elizabeth, Lady Cheylesmore, who has been visiting her sister, Mrs. Paul Fitz Simons, is expected at the Madison tomorrow and will sail Friday night on the Olympic.

The daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,697,850 barrels, compared with 2,673,350 barrels in the preceding week, a gain of 24,500 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. An increase of 34,850 barrels in the daily output of East Texas and a decline of 20,950 barrels in that of Oklahoma were the most important changes for the week.
UHALT and Mailho. It was Babe Ruth who grew indignant about it. He looked up from the perusal of a newspaper and, pointing an accusing finger at a small item therein, said indignantly:

The Western Union Telegraph Company reports a net income of $2,644,649 for the first half of 1933, equal to $2.53 a share earned on 1,045,280 shares of stock, comparing with $346,257, or 33 cents a share, earned in the first half of 1932.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Shooting a bristling 68, four under par, Tab Boyer of Portland, Ore., today set the pace over the first eighteen holes of the thirty-six-hole qualifying round of the national public links golf tournament. Boyer posted 34. 34 -- 68.

Supreme Court Justice Strong in Brooklyn refused yesterday to grant an adjournment of an injunction hearing affecting about 3,000 bakery workers. He also cited for contempt of court the bakery workers' counsel when he attempted to submit an affidavit in support of his request for a delay.
Captain James A. Mollison and his wife Amy Johnson, the only couple that has flown west across the North Atlantic, were cheered enthusiastically yesterday at the official reception of New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We are now fast approaching the season of pressure on sterling. The net effect is going to be not only favorable for dollars but also for Continental currencies. The French franc, Swiss franc and Dutch guilder are doomed. It is only a question of time, and no nation knows it better than the British.

When the candles begin to droop on the chimney-piece look out. It is a sign of torrid weather. For when the mercury is swelling up through the 90's, the chimney-piece candles, which have held themselves erect with such pride all Winter, gradually begin to lose heart.

Francis White, recently appointed United States Minister to Czechoslovakia, will sail for his new post today on the United States liner Washington. He will be accompanied by Mrs. White. The Washington, one of the last liners leaving New York in time to land passengers in England for the grouse shooting, will have many prominent passengers from New York and other Eastern cities on their way to participate in this Summer sport.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1. -- Mrs. William H. Woodin, wife of the Secretary of the Treasury, was the guest of honor at a luncheon given today at the Devon Yacht Club by Mrs. Dudley Roberts. Among the other guests were:

The first revenue freight train to run over the New York Central Railroad's west side viaduct moved to its destination yesterday with F.E. Williamson, president of the company, in the cab. Their attention attracted by blasts from the oil-electric locomotive's whistle, onlookers cheered the train's passage.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 1. -- In another of the test polo games which are being held among players trying for places on the East team in the coming Chicago matches, the White team again defeated the opposition today, 10 to 6.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 1. -- William A. Stevens, State Attorney General, renewed his protest today to the War Department against alleged violations by New York City in the dumping of garbage at sea.
There were many expressions of regret yesterday at the death of Chester S. Lord, chancellor of the University of New York and former managing editor of The Sun.

Sportsmen who endeavor to catch the elusive swordfish off Montauk have discovered that they are confronted with a great many difficulties. One of these is fog. This is nature's shield for the big fish, and apparently it operates to give the broadbills a chance to recuperate after the many assaults by anglers.

GREENFIELD, Mass., Aug. 1. -- Because the Great and General Court of Massachusetts overlooked the possibility that three Selectmen might go to jail at once, the Wendell Town Hall today was moved bag and baggage into the Franklin County House of Correction here for the conduct of the affairs of Wendell.

The property at 735-759 Seventh Avenue and 154-166 West Fiftieth Street, southeast corner, consisting of the three-story Earl Carroll Theatre and six-story offices, and the leasehold at 161 West Forty-ninth Street were put up at foreclosure auction yesterday in an action by Jacob Shapiro, plaintiff, against the 755 Seventh Avenue Corporation, the Earl Carroll Realty Corporation and others.

President Roosevelt sent a telegram yesterday to his old friend, former Governor Alfred E. Smith, on the opening of the Lawyers County Trust Company for business at 160 Broadway. The institution represents a consolidation of the County Trust and Lawyers Trust Companies.

TOKYO, Aug. 1. -- Japanese Army and Navy chiefs today presented revised estimates for the 1934-35 defense expenditures larger than any in previous history and 45 per cent above the appropriations for the current year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- In six grants, the Public Works Administration allocated nearly $100,000,000 today, principally for river projects in Western States, and by these allotments crossed the billion dollar mark in public works grants made out of the $3,500,000,000 fund voted by Congress.

Mayor O'Brien said last night that he had given no thought to methods by which city taxes on retail sales and stock transfers might be collected if the Legislature apporved the bill submitted in the Senate at Albany yesterday.
Sales of flats and small dwellings featured trading in New Jersey yesterday.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Staging a strong closing rally, George Reith, veteran chairman of the card committee of the Knickerbocker Whist Club of New York, and B. Jay Becker of Philadelphia won the special men's contract pair event, which was concluded at the American Bridge League's tournament here this afternoon.

If the general economic situation is such as to give the NRA fair opportunity in which to prove itself, there is every reason to believe that, when its two years are up, the basic principles of the act will be written permanently into our statute books.

Jobs for 10,000 additional radio factory employes with an annual increase in the industry's payroll of $3,000,000 was the prospect held out yesterday by the Radio Manufacturers Association as a result of the code filed by the association Saturday in Washington under the National Industrial Recovery Act.

Having discovered that it could not bluff the Governor, or induce him to penalize the entire State for its wasteful conduct of the city's financial affairs, Tammany has agreed to present to the special legislative session a city tax program. Thus the responsibility for the city's financial condition will be fixed and the area levied upon to repair it will be limited to that which, year after year, permits Tammany to misgovern it.

The J.C. Penney Company reported for the first half of this year a net income of $3,138,730, after deducting for expenses, depreciation, amortization, reserve for Federal taxes and other charges, and including $107,203 profits of subsidiaries.

VALENTIA, Irish Free State, Aug. 1. -- Weather reports here tonight were all favorable for the transatlantic flight of General Italo Balbo and his fleet of seaplanes. A gentle wind was blowing from the west.

One hundred and twenty children from the lower east side tenements were stranded yesterday at a condemned camp in Sullivan County, N.Y., where they had gone for a vacation that had been paid for through the hard-earned savings of their parents.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The suggestion of Governor Lehman that a "City Affairs Commission" be appointed by the State Executive to supervise the receipts and expenditures of city governments is one that commands the thoughtful attention of every citizen of New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Though I agree whole-heartedly with Governor Lehman in his determination to make the municipal authorities responsible for the new city taxes, there is one element in the Governor's program that seems to me to be fraught with danger to the people of this State.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 1. -- Jack Mackie Jr., former New York State amateur champion, and Peter Cassella of Valley Stream today captured first honors with 67 in a metropolitan golf association amateur-pro best-ball tournament at the Garden City Country Club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- The psychological effect of pegged minimum prices for grain and provision futures on the Chicago Board of Trade was marked today, the action of the markets being just the reverse of that of yesterday. Today there were no sellers, and wheat, rye and barley advanced 5 cents a bushel, corn 4 cents and oats 3 cents, each recovering its loss of the previous day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- General Hugh S. Johnson, Industrial Recovery Administrator, expects to deal extensively with the Western Pennsylvania coal strike situation in a speech tomorrow before a gathering of the State's industrial leaders in Harrisburg.

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- Wall Street's unsteady tone yesterday had an unfavorable effect on the Berlin Boerse, which experienced another period of stagnation today. The midsummer holiday season also accounts for almost complete absence of speculative interest.

ALBANY, Aug. 1. -- Drastic changes in existing statutes to adjust these to the Federal Industrial Recovery Act and other Federal rehabilitation measures so as to enable the State more readily to avail itself of Federal aid for public-work projects were recommended by Governor Lehman today in a special message to the extraordinary session of the Legislature.
Police officials from eight European countries were present yesterday when patrolmen were assigned to their posts in the Forty-sixth Precinct station on Ryer Avenue, the Bronx.

In the belief that neither General John F. O'Ryan nor former Representative F.H. La. Guardia can be elected, members of the Republican Mayoralty Committee sought yesterday for a compromise candidate for the fusion nomination for Mayor.

The Sailors' Snug Harbor on the north shore of Staten Island yesterday reached its century mark. The event was quietly celebrated with a special dinner served to the 887 old sailors in the main dining room at noon.
U.S. Department of Agriculture Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.
Repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment "by the time the snow flies" is a possibility suggested by Alfred E. Smith in his monthly editorial in New Outlook, published today.

Buyer Registrations Drop in Week A considerable drop in the number of buyers reported in the market during the week ended yesterday was noted in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and for the same period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.
BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- Forty-six persons were seized by the police here today charged with attempting to distribute "Communist" leaflets calling for anti-war action.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 1. -- The Colorado Fuel and Iron Company, a $50,000,000 corporation, was placed in Federal receivership today following a default on bond interest. Arthur Roeder, president of the company, appointed receiver, said that its business would be "carried on as usual, under direction of the court, with strict economy methods."

The heat wave that had held most of the East in its grip since Saturday continued unabated yesterday, while the West and South were enjoying more temperate weather than is usual at this time of the year.

A Federal investigation of tong warfare in Chinatown began yesterday when the secretaries of the Hip Sing and On Leong Tongs were questioned before a grand jury. Later Koliang Yih, Chinese Consul General, assured United States Attorney Medalie that he would use his influence to end hostilities.

Unless the master code for the legitimate theatre, which was adopted by all organized theatrical groups on July 21, is modified, O. E. Wee and Jules J. Leventhal, prolific revivalists, will be forced out of business, Mr. Leventhal said yesterday.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 1 (AP). -- The best 3-year-old pacing of the year was turned in today by Logan Scott, black son of Peter Scott, owned by Allan J. Wilson of Boston. Mr. Wilson is sponsor of the current Rockingham Park Grand Circuit meeting.
The first of the index numbers giving the average of commodity prices on Aug. 1, compiled by Dun's Review, was given out yesterday. It showed a rise in the average of 4.7 per cent for the month.

PARIS, Aug. 1. -- "Statuesque mobility" is Lucien Lelong's slogan. Beautiful, rather than free movement is preferred. With movie camera and mirrors he achieves this effect in modern sartorial kinetics.

LONDON, Aug. 1 (Canadian Press). -- Essex moved up into third place behind Yorkshire and Sussex in the first-class county cricket championship following today's results. Kent, former third-place holder, went back.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Aug. 1 (AP). -- Judge Henry B. Foster today ruled that attorneys employed by the International Labor Defense had not been retained to defend Dan Pippen Jr., 18-year-old Negro, on charges of slaying Miss Vaudine Maddox, 21.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy vacated yesterday a decree dissolving the marriage of Alessandro Scuri, former assistant conductor at the Metropolitan Opera House, to Elin Louise Scuri. The court held that Scuri "deliberately perpetrated a fraud" when he testified in 1923 that he had not heard from his wife since 1915, when she was ill and that he believed her to be dead.

It was again apparent yesterday that the share market is being dominated by the course of prices on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wall Street speculators were more interested in grain than in anything else. Many commission houses which do not post grain prices were obliged to issue frequent bulletins for the information of their customers.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange recovered a half cent a pound yesterday and closed with gains of 30 to 39 points, or $1.50 to $1.95 a bale. After selling at 10.08 cents in the early trading, the October touched 10.59 cents under heavy buying from several directions.

A total of sixty feature-length pictures will be released by Warner Brothers during the 1933-34 season, thirty of that number to be produced by the Warner subsidiary company, First National. The Vitaphone Corporation, another Warner subsidiary, will produce 130 short subjects.

HAMBURG, Aug. 1. -- Four Communists sentenced to death by a special court June 6 were beheaded today in Altona, on the opposite side of the River Elbe from Hamburg. They were August Luettke, a seaman; Karl Wolff, a journeyman; Bruno Tesch and Walther Mueller, an unskilled laborer.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 1. -- The Misses Leta and Betty Morris, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis G. Morris, gave a treasure hunt at their home, Malbone, this afternoon. About sixty members of the younger set were present. There were a dozen or more clues planted about the estate.

The Delaware sportswoman, Mrs. Thomas H. Somerville, won the featured Pelham Purse at Empire City yesterday when her Light Brigade gelding, March Step, lasted to score by a neck. After leading for most of the mile and seventy yards, March Step was challenged strongly in the stretch by Modern Ace.

James F. Ryan, 35-year-old Boston lawyer, was shot and critically wounded yesterday morning in the apartment of his brother-in-law at 2,608 Creston Avenue, the Bronx. The brother-in-law, George C. McDonald, 49, was locked up in the Ryer Avenue station charged with felonious assault.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The wings of the blue eagle, insignia of acceptance by industry of the President's re-employment program, appeared in tens of thousands of stores and business establishments today, according to reports that poured into the offices of the National Recovery Administration today.

All four trade groups shared in the decline in failures noted for the week ended July 27, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The decrease was greatest in the retail division, in which 209 failures were recorded, against 225 in the previous week and 450 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP). -- Hopeful once more for an international wheat agreement, Secretary Wallace today postponed until Aug. 24 his decision on the percentage of wheat acreage reduction to be required of farmers in return for government benefit payments to be made them under the voluntary domestic allotment plan.

A ten-ton truck loaded with silk valued at $19,000 was stolen in Brooklyn early yesterday by a group of armed men, who kidnapped the driver and his helper and left them bound and gagged in a furnished room at 214 Ninth Street.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey postponed yesterday further hearings on Joseph W. Harriman's mental condition until Aug. 29 after Dr. Menas S. Gregory of Bellevue Hospital had testified that the indicted banker was too ill to come to court.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 1. -- Tax assessment schedules posted here today showing a reduction of 5 per cent, revealed that J. Pierpont Morgan and the Pratt family were the two largest taxpayers in this vicinity. Properties owned by Mr. Morgan are assessed at $1,967,210.

Several leases of large apartments in Park Avenue were included in the list of suite rentals reported by brokers yesterday. William Saxe took a penthouse, with terrace, formerly occupied by Gene Tunney, in 983 Park Avenue, through Pease Elliman, with Tishman Realty and Construction Company as co-brokers.

The June statement of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation shows loans amounting to $120,000,000. This compares with $170,000,000 in May and with $206,000,000 in April. Since February, when a peak for the year was reached at $262,000,000, the figure has fallen consistently each month.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP). -- The Cubs broke their six-game losing streak and regained third place by defeating the Reds, 3 to 1, today in the opening game of the series.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 1. -- General Sir Robert Baden-Powell, originator of the Boy Scout movement, arrived here last night on a Danubian steamet. He traveled incognito in the company of 100 American Boy Scouts who had no idea the founder of the movement was among them.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- A Turnesa seems to be continually popping up in metropolitan district` golf.

A slight recovery, led by the railroad issues, took place in the domestic corporation bond list on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Industrial and public utility issues also were higher, while United States Government and foreign government obligations were irregular.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 1. -- Mrs. Leo G. Federman of Glen Oaks shot a splendid 80 to carry away the low gross award in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's weekly tournament over the North Hempstead Country Club's links today.
BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 1. -- With the fleet divided between Bay Shore and Babylon, ninety-four craft started in the eighteenth annual regatta of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association today.

COVE NECK, L.I., Aug. 1. -- Mrs. Samuel Reading Bertron, wife of the international banker, was drowned on her estate here early tonight as she was taking her pet dog for a walk along her private lake after dinner.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- Miss Betty Pletsch of Tamarack lowered the women's competitive record for the Siwanoy Country Club course today when she returned a card of 79 in the weekly tournament of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association.

LONDON, Aug. 1. -- There will be no opposition from the Left Wing to Arthur Henderson's return to Parliament, it has been decided. His victory over the Conservative in the forthcoming by-election at Clay Cross, where a House of Commons vacancy occurred as the result of the death of a fellow-Laborite.

Recovery was the rule yesterday on all the financial and commodity markets. Securities, grain, cotton and the lesser staple products moved sharply higher but in trading that was somewhat less active than that of the day before. The gold value of the dollar was increased again.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- Kidnapping and racketeering occupied President Roosevelt's direct attention today as he discussed these problems with Raymond F. Moley, Assistant Secretary of State, in the privacy of Krum Elbow, the President's family home.
HAVANA, Aug. 1. -- Police and soldiers fired into a crowd of strikers at Neptuno and Aguila Streets at 6:30 tonight, killing one man and badly wounding twelve. Alleged leaders were arrested.
The opening of "Going Gay," the Donald Blackwell-William Miles play, which was scheduled for this evening at the Morosco Theatre, has been postponed until tomorrow evening.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Aug. 1. -- One man was killed, three more were critically wounded, and fifteen others were hurt seriously enough to require hospital treatment in a series of fights between striking miners and company deputies in the Western Pennsylvania soft coal fields today.
A second New York bank, the Pennsylvania Exchange Bank of 322 Eighth Avenue, announced yesterday that it had signed President Roosevelt's blanket code.
Quietness pervaded all sections of the money market, resulting in quotations for the different classifications remaining unchanged from the preceding day.

New tenants have been found for numerous stores in scattered sections of Manhattan, according to rentals announced yesterday by brokers. The deals indicated an especially good demand for retail selling locations on such leading thoroughfares as Fifth, Sixth, Madison and Lexington Avenues and Broadway.

BOONVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The scheduled "State-wide" milk strike of the Empire Dairymen's Association developed in only four of the State's sixty-two counties today, but with violence that sent troopers speeding to the protection of dairy plants and milk trains.

MADRID, Aug. 1. -- Efforts to rescue 300 Spanish soldiers who are believed to have been held captive by the Moors in the Sahara ever since the great disaster to the Spanish arms in Morocco in 1921 are being pushed by the government.

Gambling in stocks and commodities was condemned yesterday by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, in a monthly letter to the association's nearly 20,000 members. He also fired a broadside at "tipping services."

Twenty physicians, electrical experts, policemen and a university professor worked for more than four and a half hours yesterday in an effort to save the life of a young radio technician who received an electrical shock while experimenting on a police radio-broadcasting set.

Financial interests headed by E. L. Cord assumed control of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation at a meeting of the board of directors yesterday afternoon, when Mr. Cord was elected chairman of the board, succeeding William M. Flook. Mr. Flook was elected vice chairman of the board.

ALBANY, Aug. 2. -- The legislative leaders have abandoned the tentative plan to rush the New York City Unemployment Relief Tax Bill through under an emergency message from the Governor. They have decided to give opponents of the proposed legislation a public hearing before the Senate and Assembly Committees on Taxation and Retrenchment.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- Temporary injunction was issued today by Federal Judge William H. Kirkpatrick restraining the Pennsylvania Securities Commission and its counsel from instituting criminal proceedings or otherwise interfering with the reorganization plan proposed by the Associated Gas and Electric Company.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The wage and hour, provisions of the code to be signed by bankers in lieu of subscribing to the President's blanket code follow:

THE following report has been received and, if there are no objections, will be adopted as read: "Sir: The Cingalese Prince (Wilmar Finch, Master) cleared from New York for Yokohama with the undersigned aboard under instructions to note, observe and report on the various sports activities encountered afloat and ashore during the trip around the world.

Changes in public interest in reading matter are reflected quickly in the various departments of the New York Public Library, according to officials of that institution. Current events and business trends especially affect the economic division.

To the Editor of The New York Times: This coming November we, a million or more thinking, voting citizens, hope for a political change in our city. The machine that has the city by the throat is in no sense a political organization; it is truly a mutual benefit club, solely to take care of its own followers, with the city payroll and patronage for its objective.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The transfer of Assistant Secretary Moley from the State Department to temporary duty in the Department of Justice aroused much speculation in Washington today.
Dots or No Dots? The most vital Issue In the whole National Recov-ery program is, of course, the question whether we shall end up by speaking of it as the NRA or the N.R.A.
Housing deals formed the bulk of realty trading in New Jersey yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- About 1,000,000 employes embraced in six large industrial divisions joined the industrial recovery movement today under a modified Presidential re-employment agreement.

PARIS, Aug 2 -- "Concerted action" to prevent the recurrence of such incidents as the recent Nazi attacks on Chancellor Dollfuss of Austria by tracts dropped from airplanes is under discussion at the French Foreign Office and in various European countries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- About 1,000 men in many States will be returned to work by the Department of Commerce as a result of the allocation of $2,600,000 by the Public Works Administration to the Coast and Geodetic Survey, Secretary Roper announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- By voluntary action and in cooperation with the National Recovery Administration, the cotton textile industry today, set up national and State machinery which would reach down into every textile mill in the country and seek to guarantee a peaceful settlement of all disputes.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 (AP). -- The Indians pounded Lena Stiles hard to stage an eight-run rally in the ninth inning today and defeat the Browns, 16 to 8. The game was delayed fifty-three minutes by rain.
New York and its environs passed yesterday through the fifth successive day of abnormal heat. Twenty-four persons died in or near the city from causes directly attributable to the high temperature.
MOSCOW, Aug. 2. -- Somewhat dismal is Pravda's weekly summary today of the news from the southern grain front. It is unpleasantly reminiscent of last Summer's harvesting reports.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Public Works Administration reserved to itself today the right to deal directly with political subdivisions without State interference, and action was believed imminent, on applications for funds for a number of important non-Federal projects.

Mrs. Frances W. King was found guilty last night by a jury in General Sessions Court of blackmailing Bruce Barton, author and advertising executive. The Jury, which returned its verdict after seven hours' deliberation, "strongly recommended her to the mercy of the court."

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 2 -- Getting a string of three birdies on the last nine, Leslie Leal of Bellingham Wash., forged into a tie with Tab Boyer of Portland, Ore., for medal honors today in the 36-hole qualifying round of the national public links golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Sheriff Dave Harris, substitute outfielder, and Pitcher Alvin Crowder today put on an all-star act to help the Senators gain a 2-to-1 decision over the Red Sox.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- "Equipoise goes in the Wilson," is the word on almost every tongue here tonight on the eve of the opening of the annual race meeting of the Saratoga Association.

HARRISBURG, Aug. 2. -- A demand that bloodshed and the disruption of the nation's recovery plans in the coal strike of Western Pennsylvania cease was made here today by Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator.

Continued protests against the proposal for a new city sales tax were voiced yesterday as representatives of the retail merchants of New York City demanded a public hearing on the Buckley Bill, which would give authority to the municipal-government to impose a "super-tax" on retail sales here.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Sixty-four contract bridge enthusiasts reverted to an old, half-forgotten love this afternoon as they competed in the national mixed pair auction championship, the only auction event on the program of the American Bridge League's Summer tournament here.

The New York Stock Exchange took the most extensive and drastic action in its history yesterday to curb speculation in securities. Margin requirements were made specific and high. Full information as to pools, syndicates, joint accounts and options was demanded weekly.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Union Settlement is facing the possibility of having to close its Summer camps in Palisades Interstate Park early in August unless funds can be secured Immediately with which to continue them. "We have more than enough applications to fill the boys' and girls' camps until after Labor Day.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- A better demand developed for hogs today, based in part on the advance in grains and the early strength in provisions, although the latter had been ignored the previous day. A return of cooler weather throughout the West also induced buyers to take hold more freely, and prices advanced 5 to 10 cents a hundred-weight at the yards.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 2 -- The fourth world Boy Scout jamboree was opened this afternoon at Goedoelloe, near here, by the Hungarian Regent, Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Thirty thousand Boy Scouts from fifty-three countries were assembled when Admiral Horthy, greeted by cheers from an audience of 40,000 persons rode into the scout camp on a white horse.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Sensational golf on the part of Gene Homans and William Walker enabled the Englewood pair to tie the record for the New Jersey State amateur-professional tourney at the Forest Hill Field Club today.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. James Rockwell Sheffield are at the Plaza.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Nine Freehold volunteer firemen are in hospitals tonight and three others are suffering from minor burns received this afternoon when an eight-gallon gasoline tank exploded in the Small Woman's Coat Factory of Fred Polchek, at 39 Mechanic Street.
Dr. John F. Condon, the Jafsie of the Lindbergh kidnapping case, still believes he was dealing with the actual criminals. He said yesterday that he is sure they will be caught and punished some day.

Old and new liquor dealers and speculators, anticipating early repeal, have increased the demand for spirits at government warehouses more than 200 per cent during the last few weeks. This condition, rather than the liberalized medicinal rules, it was believed, has caused whisky prices to soar.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- A broad transportation program will be laid before Congress in January, through the activities of the Transportation Committee of the Commerce Department, which is working with Joseph B. Eastman, railroad coordinator Secretary Roper said today.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- Tired but eager for action, more than nine hundred young men, including about five hundred from New York City, have arrived here for thirty days' training in the Citizens Military Training Camp.
BERLIN, Aug. 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of July 31 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP). The Cubs chased Red Lucas from the mound in less than one inning today and went on to a 10-to-6 victory over the Reds.

Mayor O'Brien asked the Department of Hospitals yesterday for a complete investigation and a report to him as soon as, possible on charges of negligence against internes at Jamaica Hospital, a private institution in Queens.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2. -- Declaration of martial law by President Roosevelt to fight crime was advocated at the meeting here today of the International Association of Police Chiefs.
