Realty interests here are aiding in the movement for prompt formulation of a national code for their business in line with the Federal recovery program and will participate in a conference of property owners and managers to be held for that purpose in Chicago tomorrow, according to Anton L. Trunk, president of the Real Estate Board of New York.

ANDORRA, Aug. 2 -- The Andorrans are still standing firm on their virtual declaration of independence, issued Saturday, in which they denied the right of their co-princes to depose the Council General and the First Syndic elected by it, to call new elections or otherwise to interfere in their internal affairs.

Protests have been received from leading retailers throughout the country against the efforts of manufacturers' trade associations to include in their codes provisions "imposing undue regulations and restraints upon terms and discounts and methods of doing business with retailers," the National Retail Dry Goods Association announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The steady expansion of productive activity continued throughout the country in the early part of July, "but operations since have tender to level off," according to a survey of current business made public today by the Commerce Department.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 2 -- A state of war for Managua and a state of siege for the entire republic were declared today by President Juan B. Sacasa as precautionary measures after the explosion last night, which destroyed most of the government's ammunition.

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- A drastic plan for expropriation of all property of landlords who cannot or will not keep their houses habitable is among the recommendations of Lord Moynea's housing committee, which issued Its report tonight.
The New York Stock Exchange yesterday announced several changes in the partnerships of its member firms as follows:

The famous Race off New London is the latest scene of a run of bluefish, according to reports received yesterday. This will be great news to a big army of salt-water anglers who have come to know that territory as one of the finest along the Sound.

Miss Helen Hall, who has been head of the University Settlement of Philadelphia for eleven years, took up yesterday the post of head worker of the Henry Street Settlement. Miss Hall succeeds Miss Lillian D. Wald, who founded the Settlement forty years ago and had been head worker since its founding until recently when she was elected president.
Visitors at seaside resorts along our coast will know what Earl BUXTON was talking about when he said in the House of Lords recently:

With the steel demand "showing unexpected staying powers" and ingot production unchanged front the week before at 57 per cent of capacity. The Iron Age in Its midweek review remarks that "from present indications" business is less likely to be affected by "seasonal influences than by a shortage of fuel."

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 2 -- The 3 year-old Brown Berry, owned by J.K. Lyle of Plainfield, N.J. qualified as the favorite for the famous Hambletonian Stake by capturing two firsts and a second in competition with eleven others in the $5,000 American Trotting Stake today.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2. -- The Giants mixed bad baseball with good in that order today and split a double-header,with the Phillies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- A plan for adjusting the financial difficulties of foreign service officers on duty in gold exchange countries, where the dollar value of their salaries has depreciated by about 25 per cent measured in the local currencies, was announced by the State Department today.

Mrs. Thomas R. Queen's filly Grannys Trade scored by a length and a half over H. Teller Archibald's Westy Junior in the short six furlongs of the Mosholu Purse as the twenty-two-day meeting at Empire City ended yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 2. -- The continued heat wave sent most of the Summer residents to Bailey's Beach today. There were many picnic parties on the beach. One of the largest was given by Mr. and Mrs. Henry Sanford Jr., who have been visiting Mrs. Sanford's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Davis.
Alfred A. Taylor, who was Street Cleaning Commissioner under Mayor Walker, retired yesterday from his $10,840 position. Sanitation Commissioner George McAneny said the position would not be filled.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 2 (AP). -- The Newark Bears opened their series with Montreal today by taking both ends of a. double-header, 5-4 and 4-1.

General John F. O'Ryan will withdraw his name from consideration as the fusion candidate for Mayor unless the members of the Republican Mayoralty committee, meeting today, support him with "convincing unanimity."

On Monday prices on the Cotton Exchange broke a half cent a pound, and on Tuesday they advanced a half cent, while yesterday they both declined and advanced nearly a half cent in the five hours of trading. After selling at 10.62 cents early, the October touched 10.18 cents and recovered around 10.60.
BOSTON, Aug. 2. -- Playing in heat only slightly less intense than they experienced in New York, the Dodgers displayed stamina enough today to divide a double-header with the Braves.

Overconfidence was a contributing factor in the defeat of the United States Davis Cup team by Great Britain, according to Mercer Beasley, Princeton tennis coach, who assisted in coaching the American squad overseas.

It was just about the time that the commission houses had resigned themselves to less than a million-share turnover on the Stock Exchange, and when the brokers were preparing to make a break for home promptly at 3 o'clock, that the late flurry developed yesterday afternoon.

PARIS, Aug. 2. -- At the close of the first six months of the year French taxation returns show a decline of more than 673,000,000 francs (currently about $35,198,000), compared with the same period last year, with the biggest drop in indirect taxation.

TULSA, Okla., Aug. 2 (AP). -- Another brief struggle of independent oil forces to achieve first rank as crude oil price setters apparently had ended today with announcements from the Sinclair-Prairie oil marketing and Empire Pipe Line and Continental companies reducing schedules 13 cents a barrel to a 62-cent peak.

BERLIN, Aug. 2. -- With domestic buying and speculative interest continuing at tha point of stagnation and stimulative foreign Influences also lacking, the Boerse resigned itself today to another listless session. Barring immaterial variations, price levels remained unchanged.

SANDS POINT, L.I., Aug. 2. -- Mrs. Katheryn Knowles Jandorf, wife of Louis C. Jandorf, the former automobile accessory manufacturer, died today in Port Washington of burns she received on Monday afternoon when a tank of propane gas exploded in her home here and injured her, her maid and the butler.

Ten years ago the nomination of ROBERT W. BLISS as Minister to Sweden was said by THE TIMES to furnish a good illustration of what the reorganization of the foreign service should make possible -- "the promotion of experienced and technically competent "men, even if entering the consular service, to the highest diplomatic posts."

Among the commercial leases announced yesterday were several contracts for retail space in the Madison Avenue district, taken by firms dealing in gowns, millinery and other apparel for women. Renting of stores for other lines of trade also continued brisk.

In a State-wide reorganization of the title and mortgage guaranty business, George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance, took over for rehabilitation yesterday six companies in and near New York City, with liabilities of $1,336,500,000 and assets of $101,816,000.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Subscriptions for the $850,000,000 bonds and notes offered by the Treasury for its Aug. 15 financing have exceeded $4,500,000,000. The $500,000,000 bond issue was oversubscribed six times and subscriptions for the $350,000,000 worth of two-year Treasury notes totaled $1,500,000,000.
Jersey City swept a double-header with Buffalo at Jersey City yesterday, 4 to 2 and 9 to 4.

What is the reason for the extraordinary difference between Chicago and New York prices? In this town in recent weeks, as many competent surveyors and sociologists have assured us, speakeasy rates have hardened, firmed, risen, jumped. After a period of f ailing, they have climbed.

General O'RYAN stipulated that there must be substantial Republican unity behind his candidacy. Otherwise he would not accept the nomination for Mayor. As himself an independent Democrat, the General understands perfectly that a fairly united Republican vote is necessary for success in the November election.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Huey Long's supporters were routed today from the field of battle over a recount of November's election ballots by action of two criminal district judges.

An argument said to have arisen over the price of a room led to the fatal shooting yesterday morning of Patrolman John F. Finneran, 29 years old, of 974 St. Nicholas Avenue, in the Hotel St. Paul, Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

SALEM, Mass., Aug. 2 (AP). -- Wide-eyed and defiant, Jessie B. Costello, accused of slaying her husband, denied today the accusations of a reserve policeman that she had engaged in an illicit affair with him.
New York banks will not need to avail themselves of the offer of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, issued on Tuesday by its chairman, Jesse H. Jones, to buy preferred stock of banks.

August Fur Events Doing Well. Reports regarding consumer response to August fur sales are of a highly encouraging tenor. Substantial increases over a year ago are being enjoyed by many stores, the volume in some instances being 50 per cent or more ahead of the corresponding period of 1932.

After an ownership of less than a month Frederick Brown yesterday resold the eleven-story business building at 73 Fifth Avenue, north-east corner of Fifteenth Street, to the Eltee Holding Corporation. The structure is known as the Kensington Building and occupies a plot 38.6 by 125 feet, with an "L," measuring 25 by 100 feet.
PARIS, Aug. 2. -- Minister of Finance Georges Bonnet announced tonight that the subscription to the second slice of treasury bonds would be closed next Saturday.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 2. -- The body of Henry C. Gennerich, 60 years old, a grain merchant, with offices in New York City, was found this morning in the garage at his home, 201 Ciaremont Avenue, this city, shot through the head.

Shipments of $12,301,200 of gold were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank, $6,504,000 consigned to Czechoslovakia and $5,797,200 to France. Of the total $11,954,000 consisted of gold withdrawn from earmark, while $347,200 came from other sources and represented a loss to the monetary gold stocks of the country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, called a conference this evening to end the soft coal strikes in Pennsylvania, which have crippled many mines and resulted in the walk-out of 50,000 men and much bloodshed and the loss of one life.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2. -- Mr. and Mrs. Sydney S. Breese gave a large reception this afternoon at Tucker Cottage, their place on Peconic Bay. Among .their guests were:

A survey of the whole Police Department, including the supervisors of patrol -- known as the "shoo-fly" squad -- has been in progress for nearly two weeks, it was disclosed yesterday by Commissioner Bolan.

One of the proverbial duties of a British Prime Minister is to interpret or mitigate the indiscretions of members of his Cabinet. Mr. GLADSTONE was very good at this. He had a command of ambiguous language which came to be called " Gladstonese," and which often stood him in good stead.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- A possibility that the question or pricefixing or establishment of a "costrecovery formula" for the petroleum industry would be put up to President Roosevelt was seen here today, as the industry appeared to be lining up more solidly behind the proposal.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Substantial improvement in the government's financial situation was indicated in the Treasury's monthend statement for July, Issued today.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2. -- Listing a total of $2,020,024.24 in liabilities and assets of only $134,718.93, Jesse L. Lasky, pioneer motion-picture producer, today sought aid of the newly amended bankruptcy act to make a compromise with his creditors, and filed a debtor's petition with the United States District Court.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- Lucile Paray shows the tightest skirts seen here, although some are slightly mitigated by circular flounce hems. Her evening gowns sheathe the legs nearly to the ankles and then are flared or split, making dignified progress possible.

Representatives of the twenty banks which are members of the New York Clearing House Association met yesterday to consider telephonic advices from Washington that a tentative code for banks under the National Recovery Administration had been formulated.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The British, French and Italian Governments are about to take joint action to discourage German Nazi aerial demonstrations over the Austrian frontier.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 2 -- Legislation at the special session convened today should be limited to recovery measures, backing up President Roosevelt's program, Governor Robert H. Gore told the Puerto Rican Legislature in his first message since taking office a month ago.

Business on the Stock Exchange was at low ebb in the first three or four hours of trading yesterday, but fresh speculative interest was aroused in the late dealings and the market advanced sharply. Transactions amounted to 1,727,000 shares, of which almost one-half occurred in the last hour.
ALBANY, Aug. 2 -- The kidnapping of Joohn J. O'Connell Jr. will be submitted to the Albany County grand jury early next week, District Attorney John T. Delaney announced tonight.

Reports from Washington received in Wall Street yesterday that active inflationary measures would be taken soon sent the dollar tumbling in the foreign exchange market, promoted a sharp rally in the stock market and unsettled the government bond market.

DETROIT, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Senator Couzens today paid in full assessments against stock held in his wife's name in Detroit's two closed national banks. Forwarding checks totaling $30,423.39 to the bank receivers, the Senator said that, although collection of the assessments has been restrained by court action, "the moral obligation to pay is clear."

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 2 -- Shifting winds and a squall that came out of the northwest when most of the classes were on the last leg of the course marked the second day's racing of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's championship week.
RENO, Nev., Aug. 2 -- Lewis Luckenbach, ship line owner of New York City, filed suit for divorce today from Delia Louise Luckenbach, charging cruelty.

BERLIN, Aug. 2 -- George S. Messersmith, United States Consul General, has demanded and obtained a hearing for Walter Orloff of 1,982 Seventy-fourth Street, Brooklyn, who has been held in Greifswald, Pomerania, since July 1 on a charge of having participated in communistic activities there and in Stettin.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- Indignant criticism of the manner in which Philadelphia police are handling the hosiery strike situation was voiced by Mrs. Cornelia Bryce Pinchot, wife of the Governor, in a telephone conversation today with Joseph A. Lestrange, acting Superintendent of Police.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2 -- Twenty-four hours after his return with the Davis Cup team, George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago went on the courts of the Meadow Club with Sidney B. Wood Jr. today and won two matches in the Southampton invitation doubles.

With the President's approval the directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation have stated their readiness " to match capital dollars with "any sound bank that can use additional capital to good advantage." This would be done through purchase of preferred stock issued by the bank itself, paying a dividend of 5 per cent.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Aug. 2. -- Warned by yesterday's fatal fighting, National Guard troops set up machine guns at critical points in the Fayette County coal mine region today and the day passed in comparative peace.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Mr. Sponge, running in the colors of C. Leroy King of Memphis, raced to an unexpected triumph today in the Sky Harbor Handicap, top event at Hawthorne. He took the measure of the favorites, Norman Church's Gallant Sir and Indian Runner.
ALBANY, Aug. 2. -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's special message in relation to mortgage relief:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that President Roosevelt's happy days are being: translated from promise to performance, the young men of our country are giving voice to a persistent complaint that in the restoration of work there is no place for them because the women have usurped all, or nearly all, of the white-collar jobs.

ON BOARD STEAMSHIP PRESIDENT HARDING, at Sea, Aug. 2 -- "The World Economic Conference was not a failure, as only the surface of the problem of restoring human confidence in government and in economic processes was scratched," Secretary of State Cordell Hull told your correspondent today.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Texas, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Haggard and gaunt from exposure and heavily bearded, a man who first gave his name as Jack A. Davis, 33, of Kissimee, Fla., lay on a hospital bed here and related a tale of hurricane horrors experienced when the sloop he was sailing capsized in the Yucatan Channel and of drifting for more than a week without food or water.

Prices of futures continued to move higher in local commodity markets yesterday, as reports that the dollar might be devalued after all were again heard. Trading was slightly more active. Cash prices also advanced.

Oscar S. Rosner, attorney for S. W. Straus Co., Inc., was attacked yesterday by a woman about two-thirds his height in a court room on the second floor of the Federal Building immediately after a hearing before Judge Coxe on motions concerning bankruptcy proceedings against the corporation.
The most elaborate organization enlisted in a public cause Since the war was being set up yesterday in this State and city.

SOMERVIDLE, N.J., Aug. 2 -- The New York-Allentown (Pa,) bus of the Golden Arrow lane skidded near here today, sidewiped a truck and injured thirteen of its fifteen passengers. Four of the injured were taken to Somerset Hospital in a serious condition.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP). -- Peggy Hopkins Joyce was reported "very sick, but not in a serious condition" from an attack of tonsilitis today in Michael Reese Hospital. She was taken to the hospital last night. Her appearances at a theatre were canceled.

LONDON, Aug. 2. -- Ten thousand farmers, mostly located in Southern England, Have banded together to resist tithe payments -- a relic of the Middle Ages, when persons were called upon to pay one-tenth of the produce of all land and labor to the support of the church.

ALBANY, Aug. 2 -- Relief for home owners threatened with loss of their homes through foreclosure was urged by Governor Lehman in a message sent today to the Legislature. The Governor recommended enactment of a law establishing a moratorium on foreclosure proceedings for a period ending, on May 1, 1934, in cases where such proceedings were brought by reason of non-payment of principal.

Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals, who declined recently to accept the suggestion of the Supreme Court that he withdraw from the Interborough Rapid Transit Company's receivership proceedings, again resisted yesterday an attempt to bring about his removal.

For nine years Patrolman John Flynn of Traffic D has dodged taxis, trucks and touring cars in the course of his duties at Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-third Street, at the western entrance to Grand Central Terminal. He has been menaced by reckless drivers and too-cautious drivers; he has been distracted by wide-eyed tourists and bleary-eyed merrymakers.

While the police continued yesterday their search for John Stevens, operator of Kamp Kill Kare, closed by the health authorities of Sullivan County, the parents of east side children who had spent vacations there were divided in their opinions of him.
ST. THOMAS, Ont., Aug. 2. -- The Rev. Hiel Wood of Springfield, Ont., died there on Monday night in his ninety-ninth year. He was active in the ministry for nearly seventy years.

DUBLIN, Aug. 2 -- General Eoin O'Duffy, Director General of the National Guards and leader of the Irish blue shirts disclaimed tonight any intention of establishing a dictatorship as Eamon de Valera, President of the Executive Council, had charged in the Dail last night.

The Italian liner Conte di Savoia will arrive today from Mediterranean parts. On board is General Jose Luis Amezcua, Mexican military expert. According to information received by the Italian Line, General Amezcua is returning from a military mission in Italy, but at the Mexican Cousulate General it was said nothing was known there of such a mission.
LONDON, Aug. 2. -- Sir Graham Bower, who was closely associated with the famous Jameson raid into the Transvaal in 1895, died today in a London nursing home at the age of 85.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 2. -- The new naval construction plans of the Japanese navy will, according to figures available at the Navy Department here, leave Japan's navy much inferior to the United States Navy in heavy ships.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Guarded silence marked the investigation today of the kidnapping of Charles F. Urschel, oil millionaire, ransomed Monday night for an amount variously estimated at from $25,000 to $200,000.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 2. -- With hostilities flaring for the second time in two days, St. Louis conquered Pittsburgh by 4 to 3 today in a twelve-inning melee marked by a fistic exchange between Bill Walker, Card pitcher, and Arky Vaughan, Pirate shortstop, and disputes with the umpire.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 2 (AP). -- Offerings were light on Georgia's bright leaf tobacco markets today, but improved prices brought expressions of satisfaction from growers at Adel and Hahira, where farmers yesterday protested the opening day quotations to Federal and State officials.

Net assets of the Shenondoah Corporation increased, more than 121 per cent in the six months ended on June 30, while those of its major subsidiary, the Blue Ridge Corporation, gained 25 per cent. The corporation's current reports give the first reflection of the change in managements which took place last Spring, when the two companies came under the control of the Atlas Corporation.

TOKYO, Aug. 2. -- The ceaseless preoccupation of the Japanese Navy with the problems the approach of an enemy fleet from the Pacific would bring is the subject of the triennial grand manoeuvres now approaching a climax so realistic that it includes three days and nights of air raids over Tokyo.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- As the opening move in a militant campaign against kidnapping and racketeering, President Roosevelt relieved Raymond F. Moley temporarily of his duties as Assistant Secretary of State today to conduct a special survey of crime-preventive measures for the Department of Justice.

Nine institutions share with relatives in the estate of Louise Closser Hale, novelist and actress, who died on July 26, last, in Hollywood, Cal. This was disclosed yesterday when her will was offered for probate here. The estate was formally valued at "more than $10,000."

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Aug. 2 (AP). -- John J. Cunningham, San Antonio attorney, and Z.D. Bonner, who recently resigned as president of the Commercial National Bank, were charged today with receiving and concealing stolen property.

The Yankees returned to the Stadium yesterday in the hope of enjoying a few moments of relaxation. Instead, they walked right into a severe trouncing from the Athletics that consumed all of two and a half hours.

Captain R. Drace White, U.S.N., Supervisor of New York Harbor, declared yesterday that evidence to verify charges of dumping of city garbage in harbor waters inside the limits prescribed by law could not be obtained. Captain White investigated charges made by Attorney General William Stevens of New Jersey in a letter to Secretary of War Dern and said that they were apparently based on error.

Governor LEHMAN has come to the rescue of the small home and farm owner by proposals that will commend themselves to humanitarians and sound business men alike. He has asked the Legislature to declare a moratorium on mortgage principal payments until next May for the owners of homes and farms who have met their tax and interest payments but are unable to find the money to pay principal instalments.

BOONVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 2 (AP) -- New YorK State's milk strike, marked at its opening yesterday by armed clashes between troopers and angry farmers, spread to new sectors today as hundreds of cans of milk wrested from non-strikers were dumped upon roads leading to city dairy plants.
PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 2 -- There were two developments here today in the situation which has arisen from the adoption of industrial codes by branches of the silk industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP). -- The large railroads of the nation were asked today to fall in step with the administration's "back to work" campaign by "spending every available dollar" on long over-due repairs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- To remove what the Interior Department termed "an injustice allowed to stand for nearly a quarter-century," President Roosevelt restored the civil service status today to Louis R. Glavis, recently appointed chief of the Division of Investigations of that department.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Two Poland-China pigs were delivered at the War Department today in restitution by a grandnephew of General Sherman for two commandeered by Union raiders from the Jefferson Davis estate during the "March to the Sea."

PARIS, Aug. 3. -- The expected relief from prohibitive tariffs on imports from the United States through Ministerial decree still was not forthcoming today, and the French press intimated candidly that American hopes in this respect were without "reasonable foundation."

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 3. -- After many hours of anxiety, due in some measure to the silence of their radio apparatus, Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and his wife returned to Holstenborg, Greenland, tonight to tell the story of a perilous flight across Davis Strait through fog and storm, and above closely packed ice floes that would have meant instant death had their engine failed.

To the Editor of The New York Times; In this morning's TIMES, under the title "How to Beat Tammany," Mr. Ausfresser points out that "the only chance" to do so "in the coming election is for all anti-Tammany groups to unite and vote for one candidate to run against Mayor O'Brien."
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 3. -- A young woman and a man were Killed and five men injured when two automobiles collided head-on at the Mullica River Bridge on the New York road, near here today.

Nathan L. Amster, president ot the Manhattan Railway Company, said yesterday that the affidavit filed by that company last Wednesday, accusing Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals of bias and prejudice, had been forced upon the company.

Bank clearings in the week ended on Wednesday were about 5600,000,000 less than in the preceding week, although they continued to run slightly ahead of last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The drop was largely a reflection of the sharp decline in security and commodity transactions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- June exports at $119,808,917 were $5,565,519 larger than shipments for May and showed an increase of $5,660,449 over those of June, 1932, the Department of Commerce announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Officials taking stock of the progress already made by the Recovery Administration indicated a belief today that the movement to restore purchasing power had gone beyond either the expectations of the administration or the knowledge of the public.

Representatives of independent taxicab operators were advised to wait until a code for their industry was promulgated under the NIRA, when they appeared before Deputy Police Commissioner Felix A. Muldoon yesterday requesting authorization to put lower taxi rates into effect.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 3 (AP). -- Two of harness racing's crack veterans, the 4-year-old chestnut trotter Vansandt, owned by Irvin W. Gleason of Williamsport, Pa., and Dick Reynolds, 5-year-old pacing star of the W.W. Reynolds stables of Winston-Salem, N.C., today dominated the Grand Circuit's eighth program at Rockingham Park.

The regular July grand jury was about to be discharged by Judge Koenig in General Sessions yesterday, when its foreman, Robert Appleton, handed two presentments to the court. On presentment, a copy of which Judge Koenig, at the request of the grrand jurors, said he would forward to Governor Lehman, was based on testimony last month before the grand jurors by Commissioner of Accounts Higgins.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Aug. 3. -- While the Pennsylvania soft coal region awaited word from Wash- ington on the strike negotiations, the H.C. Frick Coke Company, subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, which is chiefly affected, struck back at tire miners whose aggressive picketing has forced the Frick plants to close.

WHEN sighted recently, Lucien Pierre Brouillard was wearing white shoes, gray trousers, gray suspenders and a white open-weave shirt. No tie, no hat. He is in town, as he modestly explained it, for the purpose of removing the middleweight crown from the brow of Ben Jeby, the ceremony to take place next Wednesday evening at the Polo Grounds, weather and Ben Jeby permitting.
Eight additional organizations joined the rising tide of protest against the proposed, new city sales tax yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- Telephoning from Berlin tonight, the correspondent of The London Times says that the possibility of representations in Berlin by Britain, France and Italy in connection with Nazi propaganda against Austria has strengthened the belief in Germany that Chancellor Dollfuss may have suggested foreign intervention.
BOONVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- The milk strike swept into Western and Southern New York today, bringing an additional 10,000 farmers into line.

The Annalist reports that its weekly index of wholesale commodity prices on Tuesday was 103.1, or 0.6 point higher than the 102.5 (revised) announced the week before. The advance, it says, concealed sharp fluctuations of prices under the leadership of the grains.

HANOVER, Germany, Aug. 3. -- Max Syring, German distance ace, conquered Joe McCluskey of NewYork in a great 3,000-meter run before a crowd of 7,000 in Hindenburg Stadium today. But America's touring track and field athletes won seven of the nine events in which they participated.

Money market remained at a standstill. Routine requirements running to light amount was all that engaged the attention of borrowers, and lenders were making the accommodation at rates which have prevailed without change now for weeks.

The Railroad Credit Corporation announced yesterday that it would make a repayment of 1 per cent on Aug. 15 to railroads which contributed to the loan pool that it adminstered from the proceeds of freight surcharges. This will be the second distribution.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Fourteen solid hits, including five of the extra-base variety, enabled the Washington Senators to defeat the Boston Red Sox by 8 -- 4 today and increase their league lead to three full games over the Yankees.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Although Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City deferred making any definite announcements here today, 1,000 party workers from Hudson County acclaimed Governor A. Harry Moore as the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate.
The country estate of the late Isabella M. Brown on the north side of Sycamore Avenue, Shrewsbury, N. J., has been bought by C. Frederick Neilson of Shrewsbury.

Nine individuals and three organizations, including a local of the teamsters' union, were indicted yesterday by the Federal grand jury on the charge of violating the Sherman anti-trust law by extorting $3,000,000 a year in double loading charges on fruits and vegetables.

HAVANA, Aug. 3. -- A general strike paralyzing transportation and commerce throughout Cuba became imminent tonight as unions in many industries in Havana and the interior pledged support to the striking omnibus, taxicab and truck drivers of the island.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- Captain James and Amy Johnson Mollison will be the guests of honor at "sky night," a moonlight fete to be held Saturday night at the Westchester Country Club for the benefit of the Judson Health Centre, the Emergency Exchange Association and the United States Amateur Air Pilots Association.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Every lawful means for the extermination of criminals who prey upon the public will be taken by the Roosevelt Administration, Joseph B. Keenan, Assistant Attorney General in charge of racket cases and suppression of kidnapping, declared here tonight.

BOSTON, Aug. 3. -- -Old Tom Zachary, tossing his southpaw tantalizers with extraordinary efficiency, held the Dodgers to two singles and the Braves romped away with the third game of the current series today, 3 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The greatest naval building program ever undertaken as a unit in the history of the country was ordered today when the Navy Department awarded contracts for twenty-one ships to be built by private shipyards and allocated sixteen vessels to be constructed at navy yards.

In The Wichita Sunday Beacon, "Kansas greatest newspaper," is the annual homecoming speech of Senator ARTHUR CAPPER, Kansas' greatest statesman-publisher. "After all," he declares with conviction and authority, "there is no place like home." He might have added that there's no place like Kansas.

DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Definite plans for holding the Harmsworth Trophy races here next month were going forward today following receipt of word that Hubert ScottPaine, British challenger, would sail for the United States within the next two weeks.
PARIS, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

Peter Moore Speer, for many years general counsel of the Standard Oil Company of New York and later a vice president, died last night after a short illness at St. Luke's Hospital in his seventy-first year.

ROCHESTER, Minn., Aug. 3. -- The vigilance of a nurse and a locked bedroom door in the country estate Ivywood of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Mayo, frustrated an attempted kidnapping of one or more of three Mayo children, 2 1/2 to 6 years old, early Tuesday morning, it was learned today.
A four-day Fall program of racing was announced yesterday by the American Yacht Club of Rye, N.Y., with tentative plans for a cruising event of a novel type. The dates are Sept. 7, 8, 9 and 10.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 3. -- Craig Wood, Hollywood (N.J.) professional, and Jimmy Dante, Braidburn pro, set a fast pace today in the first eighteen holes of the New Jersey State open golf championship. Each shot a 69 at the Forest Hill Field Club to share the lead.
New York's large department stores joined with the city and domestic consumer groups yesterday before the Public Service Commission in pressing for immediate reductions in electric rates.

The merchant seamen of all nations dealing with the United States profited by the failure of the London Economic Conference to act or international maritime treaties, Silas B. Axtell, counsel for the International Seamen's Union, said on his return yesterday from a month's visit in Europe.

The plan for compensating government officials abroad for the loss of income involved in the fall of the dollar to 75 per cent of its former value consists simply of paying them in gold dollars. The government has already shipped $347,000 gold to France for the purpose.

The Class 1 railroads increased their gross revenues in the first half of the year 39.5 per cent ahead of the same period last year, according to the Bureau of Railway Economics. This was the first six-month period in which an increase has been shown since 1929.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- A two-man exploring expedition that will attempt to save 200 starving persons and study for science the little-visited Tristan da Cunha island group in the South Atlantic Ocean will leave here in a month.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Fifty thousand spectators jammed a bowl built in Soldier Field tonight to witness amateur international battles between the champions of Ireland and the Chicago Golden Glove titleholders. All bouts were at three rounds.

DETROIT, Aug. 3 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- Observance of "Deutscher Tag" here was marked by a declaration in which Detroit Germans declared themselves in opposition to racial and religious bigotry. The declaration stated that they look for political guidance to Washington and not to Berlin.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3. -- Bryan M. Grant Jr. of Atlanta, Ga., the smallest player in senior tennis competition, added another notable conquest today to his record as the giant-killer of the courts.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- Running swiftly through a steady drizzle of rain, Equipose today maintained his place as the champion of the handicap division. By three lengths the famous son of Pennant and Swinging beat the good mare Tambour in the Wilson, with Mate five lengths back in third position.
A demand for tenement houses was Indicated in transactions closed yesterday in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 3. -- The Newport Country Club was the scene today of the qualifying round of the annual invitation tournament. More than a hundred entrants are taking part. The annual tournament dinner for the visiting players and club members took place this evening with about ninety present.

Details of the rehabilitation plans under which six title and mortgage companies with outstanding guarantees of $1,336,500,000 and assets of $101,816,000 will continue in business were made public yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, who named a group of well-known men to help carry out his program.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For the past month or so there has been a great hue and cry in the New York newspapers about sweatshop conditions in many of the Pennsylvania factories. Reforms, like charities, should begin at home.

DEADWOOD, S. D., Aug. 3. -- Hordes of bewhiskered strangers, pistols strapped to their belts, and women clad in the old-fashioned billowing garb of a half century ago trod the streets of Deadwood tonight with blue-uniformed cavalrymen and war-bedecked Sioux Indians.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP). -- After waiting 102 games to hit a home run, Manager Charlie Grimm delivered one in the eighth inning today to break up a pitching duel between Guy Bush and Paul Derringer and give the Cubs a 2-to-1 victory over the Reds.

ALBANY, Aug. 3. -- Chief figures in the investigation of the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr. were absent from the city tonight and it was reported that they were completing plans which they hoped would bring about the arrest of the kidnappers.

David M. Kahan, real estate operator and former brewer, who disappeared July 27 from his home at 255 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday in Hudson, N.Y., and taken to Brooklyn Police Headquarters on a charge of attempted extortion.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 3 (AP). -- The Newark Bears tonight captured their second straight double-header from the Royals, taking the first game by 4 to 3 behind the fine pitching of the ex-Yale collegian. Johnny Broaca, and the second by 9 to 3 in six innings.

Controller Charles W. Berry, who studied foreign methods of city taxation, will return today on the Cunard liner Berengaria. Henry Morgenthau and Edward Bruce, delegates at the London conference; Dr. De Torres y Echevarria, Cuban delegate to the conference, are also on the Berengaria.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- The American Legion was summoned by its own leadership today to enlist "a million strong" in an aggressive campaign for the National Recovery Administration.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Aug. 3. -- A costly misunderstanding in bidding which led to a 2,000 point set eliminated P. Hal Sims and his teammates, George Unger, Charles Lochridge And Joian Rau. in the first knockout round of the challenge contract team-of-four competition this afternoon at the American Bridge League's tournament here.

PARIS, Aug. 3. -- Although it was confirmed here this morning that concerted action by Britain, France and Italy to try to put an end to Nazi baiting of Austria was imminent, discussion of a technical point is apparently delaying a decision as to the step to be taken.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The government does not contemplate entering upon inflation of the currency at present and will issue cheaper money only as a last resort to stimulate trade, according to a close adviser of the President who discussed financial policies with him this week.

GREAT RIVER, L.I., Aug. 3. -- A rolling sea with a strong east to southeast wind today greeted the fleet competing on the third day of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association championship races. The regatta was held off the Timber Point Club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Grand opera at cinema prices will come to Chicago again this Fall. Fortune Gallo, impresario, announced today that beginning Labor Day he would open a four weeks' season of the San Carlo Grand Opera Company at the Auditorium Theatre, offering twenty operas at prices ranging from $1 to 25 cents.

Net asset value of the common stock of the Atlas Co. oration rose from S7.01 a share on Dec. 31 to approximately $12 a share on June 30, or 71 per cent, according to a letter sent yesterday to stockholders by Floyd B. Odium, president.

On the green of the Stadium yesterday, before the astonished gaze of 7,500 onlookers, lean and dour Robert Moses Grove, ace lefthander of the Athletics, shut out the Yankees as he pitched the Mackmen to a 7-0 triumph over the world's champions.

Loans on securities by members of the New York Stock Exchange increased $135,857,814 in July, making the fourth consecutive monthly advance. At the close of business on July 31, brokers' loans as reported by the New York Stock Exchange amounted to $916,243,934, compared with $780,386,120 on June 30, $528,509,438 at the end of May, and $241,599,943 at the close of July, 1932, the lowest since records have been available.

Two injunctions restraining theatre operating companies. from hiring non-union film operators were granted yesterday by Supreme Court Justice McLaughlin in favor of Harry Sherman as president of Local 306 of the Moving Picture Machine Operators Union.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Following a pitchers' duel between Harder and Wells which left the score tied, 2 and 2, after seven innings, the Indians rallied today and defeated the Browns, 7 to 2, for an even break in the series.

The Citizens Military Training Camp at Camp Dix, N. J., will open today with, 785 young men from New York, New Jersey and Delaware who are taking the work allotted to students of at least one Summer's experience.

PARIS, Aug. 3. -- The teachers of the French secondary schools in their national congress here today pledged themselves to fight against the Daladier government and announced a half-hour protest strike on the day Parliament reconvenes.

A standardized oyster and how to produce it by artificial means were among the topics discussed yesterday by the Oyster Growers and Dealers Association of North America, Inc. The association, which is meeting jointly with the National Shellfisheries Association, opened its annual two-day convention yesterday morning in the Hotel New Yorker.

Among the thousands of boys and young men riding the freight trains these last two or three years a handful have turned their experiences to account in stories for the magazines and newspapers. A few were the work of young men with experience or training in writing, and the knowledge in such cases that their hard knocks would bring a cash return must have colored their attitude.

The campaign of the President s re-employment emergency committee for the City of New York, of which Grover A. Whalen is chairman, will be launched officially on Monday with an organization that will extend into every borough and into every branch of industry and business, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Mud runners carried off the honors at Hawthorne today. In the feature race, at one mile and a sixteenth, BigRed, racing in the colors of T.H. McCaffrey of Lexington, Ky., surprised by scoring by a half-length. John E. Hughes's Silent Shot conquered Knights Gal for the place.

PARIS, Aug. 3. -- Serious rioting in which many demonstrators and several policemen were injured occurred today and tonight in Strasbourg, where the building strike declared a few days ago, is fast turning into a general strike.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- While United States efforts to promote political tranquillity in Cuba have retarded the progress of negotiations for a reciprocal trade agreement, preliminary discussions of the proposed treaty are going forward in Havana, Acting Secretary of State Phillips said today.

GENEVA, Aug. 3. -- The Council of the League of Nations agreed today at the request of Bolivia and Paraguay that it would ask their neighbors, Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru, to present to them "a formula such as would establish a just and lasting peace between them."

Continued weakness of dollar exchange resulting from the wide circulation of reports that active measures of inflation might be taken shortly by the government featured the foreign exchange market yesterday. Early in the day all foreign exchanges advanced in terms of the United States unit. Sterling was up 5 1/4 cents and the franc was 6 1/2 points higher.
HYDE PARK, Aug. 3. -- President Roosevelt today ordered all speed possible in relieving the home mortgage situation in New York State under the Federal Home Loan Act.

Virtually $2,000,000 was paid by the E.L. Cord interests for control of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, which yesterday received a contract award from the United States Government for the building of two light cruisers at $11,677,000 each and four destroyers at $3,775,000 each, a total of $38,454,000.

Pivotal problems upon which attention in matters of labor relations must be centred as this country works its way out of the depression" are cited in "Labor Relations Under the Recovery Act," published by Whittlesey House. McGraw-Hill Book Company, Inc.

SALZBURG, Aug. 3. -- Bruno Walter, whom the Nazis ousted from Germany as "non-Aryan," has become the hero of the year's Salzburg Festival in Austria. In the popular estimation he ranks with Max Reinhardt, who devised the great spectacles that originally made Salzburg famous.

ABOARD THE MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, Aug. 3 (by Wireless). -- Strong head winds and high seas have very considerably reduced the speed of the Ellsworth transantarctic flight expedition's motorship in the last two days. Otherwise the vessel is behaving well on its 20,000-mile voyage from Norway to the Ross Sea in Antarctica.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 3. -- After hearing charges that a code for the industry had been drawn and submitted at Washington over the heads of their representatives on the national planning board of the Silk Association of America, members of the Silk Manufacturers Association voted here tonight to revoke permission previously granted to the national body to formulate a code.

William H. Kelly, as Commissioner of Banking and Insurance of New Jersey and on behalf of the Steneck Trust Company, in liquidation, has transferred to the recently organized Seaboard Trust Company fifty parcels of realty located in Jersey City, Hoboken, North Bergen, Union City and Weehawken, with a taxable valuation of $1,326,750, of which $407,900 represents the value of the lands and $918,850 the value of the improvements.

TOKYO, Aug. 3 (AP). -- The negotiations between Russia and Manchukuo over the sale of the Chinese Eastern Railway in Manchuria showed their first progress today when the Russians offered to take 200,000,000 gold rubles instead of 250,000,000 (nominally $103,000,000 instead of $128,750,000).

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- The Buckley Bill to "relieve the people of the City of New York from the hardship and suffering caused by unemployment" through an authorization for the city to levy taxes on its residents for' unemployment relief purposes was extensively amended today by its introducer.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The President's re-employment drive was extended to the nation's railroads today when Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator, appealed today to the heads of all Class I roads to spend "every available dollar" to increase employment.
Unsettlement on the Stock Exchange yesterday was largely ascribed to the overnight announcement of plans looking to the curtailment of speculative excesses in the security markets.

HAVANA, Aug. 3 (AP). -- A "modified Presidential system" will be recommended to Congress by the mixed commission working out constitutional reforms under the guidance of United States Ambassador Welles, the envoy announced today.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- The racing period was opened here today in the presence of many well-known turf followers.
LONDON, Friday, Aug. 4. -- A note of warning if not of alarm is struck by The London Times today in an editorial drawing attention to "disquieting similarities" between today and 1914.

The General Electric Company announced yesterday that the minimum wage rates and maximum hour provisions in the industrial recovery code drawn up for the electrical manufacturing industry would be put into effect by that company next Monday.

BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- The Boerse continued today to reflect an uneven tendency, due to aloofness of the buying public. The general tone was slightly improved, however, as a result of gradual betterment in the Ruhr industrial situation and improvement in the iron market.

The next polo test match among players trying for the East team that will oppose the West at Chicago will be held Sunday at 4 P. M. at the Sands Point Club in Port Washington, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP). -- The first effort of the Federal Government to cut the flow of oil to market received a challenge today in a suit filed in the District of Columbia Supreme Court for a group of Texas refiners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Preventive rather than corrective action will be the policy of the administration in protecting consumers against inordinate price increases on foods and textiles incident to the recovery program, according to Dr. Frederick C. Howe, consumers' counsel for the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- Walter Orloff, 28-year-old American medical student who has been held by the police of Greifswald on a charge of having participated in communistic activities there and in Stettin, was examined by high officials at the Prussian Ministry of Justice in Berlin today.

The differences between Earl Carroll and Local 829 of the United Scenic Artists Union over doing work for the new production, "Murder at the Vanities," got into court yesterday when Supreme Court Justice McLaughlin signed an order directing the union to show cause before Justice Frankenthaler today why It should not be restrained from interfering with the production, scheduled to open next month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The first hearing on racketeering will be held by the Senate Special Committee in New York on Aug. 14, Senator Copeland, chairman, announced today. This followed a conference with Louis McHenry Howe, secretary to the President.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- More than 25,000 Italian - Americans today visited the Century of Progress Exposition for Italian Day ceremonies, which included the dedication of a bronze statue of Columbus in Grant Park and the presentation of "Aida" in the court of the Hall of Science tonight.

The following statement on the results of the World Economic Conference was sent to THE NEW YORK TIMES by Henry Morgenthau Sr., who is returning to this country from London after having headed the American delegation at the International Wheat Conference.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange fluctuated nervously over a range of more than a quarter cent a pound yesterday and ended the day with a loss of 14 to 15 points, or 70 to 75 cents a bale.

AKUTAN, Alaska, July 29 (Delayed in Transmission). -- We have just completed exploration of Akutan volcano, probably the largest crater on the Aleutian Islands. It is larger than Katmai crater and similar, to Aniakchak.

LONDON, Aug. 3. -- When Gar Wood drives his 6,400-horsepower Miss America X to the starting line for the opening Harmsworth Trophy race on Sept. 2 he will be challenged by one of the most remarkable looking craft afloat.

The end-of-the-month credit requirements made only small demands upon the Federal Reserve System last week, according to the system's report for the period ended on Wednesday, published yesterday. Money in circulation went up only $17,000,000 of which less than $1,000,000 was supplied through increased use of Federal Reserve notes and $3,621,000 through the issuance of Federal Reserve Bank notes.

Representatives of the twenty banks of the New York Clearing House Association voted unanimously yesterday to adopt the code for banks prepared by the National Recovery Administration. Following the action of the Clearing House, which is expected to set the example for thousands of other banks throughout the country, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced that it had subscribed to the code.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Reports were current in the grain trade today that a leading bakery had bought about 250,000 barrels of flour. There was free buying of wheat futures both here and in Minneapolis cred-_ ited to mills which, it was assumed, were hedging against flour sales in some position, but local flour brokers were unable to confirm the rumor.

NEW YORK. Miss Helen G. Thompson will give a supper with dancing tonight in the roof garden of the St. Regis for Miss Fay Hines of Memphis, Tenn., and her brother, Charles G. Thompson, who will be married on Sept. 26 in Memphis.

Three Governments reported yesterday a large success in floating new loans. In Paris the French Minister of Finance announced that subscriptions to an issue of 2,000,000,000 francs in 4 1/2 per cent bonds will be closed tomorrow, with indications of a larger demand than the amount offered.

At last the Government at Washing-- ton has seen the need of doing something for its officers living abroad where the dollar has depreciated. This means a cut of about 25 per cent in the real value of their pay, in addition to the general salary reduction of 15 per cent generally affecting Federal employes.

Weather Slows Furniture Sales. Extremely warm weather of the last few days has cut seriously into the volume of business done at the opening of August furniture sales throughout the city, retailers reported yesterday. The stores expected a heavy attendance at the opening of the promotions but only a few of the larger establishments found the consumer response up to expectations.
Mayor O'Brien wrote to Police Commissioner Bolan yesterday urging that the full resources of the Police Department be mobilized to end kidnapping and other crimes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ending Aug. 2, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,209,000,000, an increase of $9,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $207,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

Discovery of the proper ration and a program of intense artificial rearing have produced some remarkable results in the propagation of ruffed grouse at the Game Institute's Farm at Clinton, N.J., according to a report made yesterday by Arthur M. Bartley, director of field activities of the More Game Birds Foundation.

The Treasury Department's complete monthly report of the stock of all kinds of money in the United States as of July 1 shows the following principal changes in June. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted; gold released from earmark is added:
LONDON, Aug. 3. -- Up to a laTE hour tonight Vickers-Armstrong, Ltd., had received no information regarding A. V. Lander's deports tion from Turkey, according to F C. Yapp, one of the directors.

The story of a three-month watch on a mysterious house at 35 West Sixty-ninth Street and a raid that meant freedom and comfort for a 10-year-old boy who allegedly had been ill-treated was unfolded yesterday in the Children's court.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 3. -- The sinking fund commission today authorized a loan of $9,820 to the city on emergency notes maturing in December, 1934, covering the amount due to realty experts employed on tax appeal cases.
Leases of large space in Manhattan buildings to restaurant concerns featured business renting yesterday.

He Gets Service One form of purchasing power which should continue to prosper under the New Deal la the lone male shopper in the women's wear aisles of the department stores. Timid, dazed, hopelessly outnumbered in the swirl and stampede of women shoppers, he yet exercises a tremendous power in getting service from the saleswomen.

Price movements in local commodity markets were irregular yesterday. Opening prices were for the most part higher, but later reactions resulted in some losses on the day. Trading was relatively quiet. Cash prices also were irregular.

The word " jamboree," which has a rather boisterous sound, is conditionally admitted to the English, dictionaries as " American slang." But it np.w has a new and international definition by theBoy Scouts under the leadership of the Chief Scout, Sir ROBERT BADEN-POWELL.

ALBANY, Aug. 3. -- The State Milk Control Board threatened today to allow States outside the present milk shed to send fluid milk into New York if the activities of the strikers in up-State areas menaced the current supply.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- Settlement of the Pennsylvania coal strike as a result of new conferences which will begin tomorrow was regarded as possible in coal circles tonight.

ALBANY, Aug. 3. -- Governor Lehman today called upon the Legislature to pass a series of amendments to the Public Service Commission Law, some of which were before the Legislature in the regular session this year and failed of passage owing to pressure brought to bear by utility corporations.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 3. -- Robert Law, financier, former official of the Barnsdall Oil Corparation, and sportsman, died last night in his automobile of a heart attack on the way to his home, Lawridge, here, from the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, Greenwich, of which he was a former commodore.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Railway labor decided tonight to bring to the attention of President Roosevelt what was called the "failure of the railroads to cooperate with the President in this great drive for the restoration at prosperity."

The heat wave In New York and many other parts of the East, abated yesterday after five days of the most torrid weather the city had felt since 1918. The first cool breezes came early in the morning from the northeast, dropping the mercury to 74, the normal average for the date.

PARIS, Aug. 3. -- Miranda has a good youthful collection featuring original versions of the high, narrow shoulder-line and the narrow tube skirt, tempered by wide trimmed hems, horizontally or vertically tucked or cartridge pleated.

Led by its captain, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, the United States team will seek its third straight victory over Great Britain in the Wightman Cup team matches starting today at the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills.
LONDON, Aug. 3 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Recovery Administration officials expressed the opinion today that they had sufficiently clarified the position of newspapers in relation to the President's voluntary re-employment agreement to open the way for publishers to come in without difficulty.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We hear a lot about the troubles of the air mail transport companies with the government in Washington, but why don't they give service which the people need and will use instead of so many out-of-the-way places? New York is just as far away from Philadelphia as it is from Omaha, Neb., when It comes to mail service.

DENVER, Aug. 3. -- Five thousand persons were driven from their homes, two were drowned and $1,000,000 damage was caused by a 60-foot wall of water, which swept down on Denver today when the Castlewood Dam, thirty miles southeast of the city gave way at 2:30 A.M. Several other persons are reported missing.

Operations on the Stock Exchange were limited to a considerable extent yesterday by the artificial restrictions that had been applied, over night, in an effort to restrain speculative activity. The impression, in trading circles in Wall Street, was that operations would be sharply curtailed by the raising of margin requirements and the decision to expose details of pool operations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The hearing on the basic code of fair practice for the petroleum industry, which was written with the help of the Recovery Administration after the industry had failed to agree on its own code, was adjourned subject to recall by the administrator today.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 3 (AP). -- Peace and a swirling rainstorm, settied over Forbes Field today as Dizzy Dean, the strikeout king, muffled the Pirates' bats and led the Cardinals to a 4-to-1 six-inning conquest. The result put the Pirates three and a half games back of the idle Giants.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The cartoon in THE TIMES Sunday appealed to me greatly. It seems to me that cartoons like this, that show New York beggared by Tammany, would stir, up your people at this time. The experience that came to me as Deputy Controller of the city of Rochester a year ago occurs to my mind.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3. -- Charles A. Munn, who is visiting his son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. M. Dorland Doyle, at Swallow Ridge, gave a dinner tonight at Canoe Place Inn for Anthony J. Drexel of Philadelphia, who is passing tennis week at the Irving.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 3 (AP). -- Robert Lee Miller of Jacksonville, Fla., marched two steps nearer the successful defense of his national public links golf championship today.

BERLIN, Aug. 3. -- The Reich Institute for Business Research, publishes its latest bulletin under the renewed management of Dr. Ernst F. Wagemann, who retired after the national revolution but has just been recalled by the Nazi powers to head the institute again.

YONKERS, Aug. 3. -- Directors of the Yonkers National Bank and Trust Company, of which W.F. Bleakley is president, issued today a statement endorsing the plan for organizing the proposed First National Bank of Yonkers. The two banks are in no way connected.

NORWICH, England, Aug. 3 (Canadian Press). -- The British West Indies and the second-class Norfolk cricket teams declared their match drawn today when the time limit expired. The visitors had scored 496 for eight declared and 35 runs for the loss of two wickets to 257 for the home team in its first innings.

Trading in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange was dull again yesterday, with United States Government issues showing further weakness in all instances where activity developed. Foreign bonds were moderately stronger, while domestic issues eased despite a slight gain in the average price for industrials.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today an application by the Charleston Western Carolina Railway Company to procure authentication and delivery to it of $72,000 of first mortgage bonds, bringing a strong dissenting opinion from Commissioner Porter.

New financing approved by the voters of twenty-three communities in twelve States last month totaled $27,836,852, the largest figure for July in several years, due chiefly to large authorizations by the State of Alabama and the city of Portland, Ore., where issues of $19,000,000 refunding certificates of indebtedness and $6,000,000 sewerage bonds, respectively, were authorized.

The New York Stock Exchange has done a service to the country as well as to itself in adopting new rules for the supervision of speculative trading. Those who have opposed Federal regulation of the Exchange because it had full power to regulate itself are at least partially justified by this reform.

ALBANY, Aug. 3. -- Authorization for cities to create municipal housing agencies to obtain money under the national recovery program was urged today by Governor Lehman in a special message to the Legislature.

Former Representative F.H. La Guardia was picked early this morning for the fusion nomination for Mayor. The choice was made at a conference between the harmonizing committee headed by Charles C. Burlingham and a subcommittee of the Republican Mayoralty Committee, of which former Governor Charles S. Whitman is chairman.

Andrew Cameron Pearson, chairman of the board of directors of the United Publishers Corporation, publishers of The Dry Goods Economist, Iron Age, Hardware Age and other trade publications, who died on March 31, left most of his estate to his widow and children, it became known yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 4 (AP). -- Three persons were fatally injured and two others slightly hurt in an automobile accident on a railroad grade crossing north of Kingston early today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Unemployment relief grants aggregating $5,111,271 were approved today by Harry L. Hopkins, Federal Relief Administrator. Six States and the Territory of Hawaii were the beneficiaries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The first of the special boards who will review the case, histories of more than 453,000 "presumptive" disability cases of war veterans were named today by General Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans' Affairs.

ROSLYN, L.I., Aug. 4. -- George L. Hubbell, counsel for this village, is confronted today with a problem which, he admits, is the greatest he has ever encountered during his long career at the bar. It was "wished on me," he says, by the village fathers.

An executive committee of leading residents, business men, industrialists and financiers was set up yesterday to direct the recovery drive that is to begin in this city on Monday. Fifteen thousand additional employers signed re-employment agreements under the President's blanket code.

A bill fostered by the Joint Mortgage Moratorium Conference, calling for a mortgage foreclosure moratorium on all types of property where taxes and interest have been paid, is scheduled to be introduced in both branches of the emergency session of the Legislature on Monday, according to R.B. Stringham, chairman of the conference.

ALBANY, Aug. 4. -- Mark Graves, president of the Tax Commission, stated today that only retail merchants actually turning over tax money to the State could deduct the 1 per cent retail sales tax in making up personal income tax returns.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- There was no snap today to the buying of grains on the Board of Trade here. Bullish enthusiasm was checked by press reports from Washington intimating that inflationary action was being held up by the administration.

EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- Tonight's opening performance of the "1933 Maidstone Revels" in the Maidstone Club ballroom attracted a brilliant audience of nearly 500. The show will be repeated tomorrow night. Miss Adelaide Moffett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Moffett, made a hit singing "On the Piano" and dancing with the Misses Katharine Barker and Winifred Lee in "The Three Steppers."

KOENIGSBERG, East Prussia, Aug. 4. -- In August, 1914, Field Marshall Paul von Hindenburg won in this province, near the little town of Tannenberg, one of the classic if not decisive battles of military history, thereby giving, imperial Germany sufficient moral and material stimulus to survive the Marne and continue the war for four more bloody years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Substantial support by the railroad industry of the recovery drive was indicated today as communications from the heads of large railroad systems began arriving at the office of the transportation coordinator, Joseph B. Eastman, pledging acceptance of his appeal to put more men back to work.

Airplanes, police launches and Coast Guard cutters searched the lower bay for two hours last night after William Young, general manager of an amusement park at Midland Beach, S. I., reported he had seen an excursion steamer on fire three miles off shore.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Hearings on codes for the cotton garment and shirt industries closed today with many factions still in sharp disagreement and instructions to them from Deputy Administrator Lindsay Rogers to attempt conciliation and report back to him by Wednesday.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Scoring his second triumph of the week. Raphael Guastavino sailed his star class boat, Kinkajou II, to victory in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's fourth championship regatta today.

The Philharmonic-Symphony and Paul Whiteman's Orchestra, with Mr. Whiteman officiating, were mated at the Lewisohn Stadium last night. It was, to judge by the audience, a successful alliance. The biggest crowd of the season jammed the concrete stand and most of the field seats, and the customary indications of popular approval were decidedly not lacking.
Dr. Charles G. Pease, president of the Non-Smokers Protective League, admitted yesterday that the odds were against him in his long fight against tobacco, but he "is not entirely defeated yet."

MOSCOW, Aug. 4. -- Sweeping amnesties were announced today for political and common-law prisoners employed on the White Sea Canal, which was recently completed by the Ogpu and visited by Joseph Stalin.

The immediate effect on the closing of the Stock Exchange by the release of capsules of tear gas yesterday was to throw the whole financial district into confusion. When the pulse of Wall Street suddenly stopped beating, the other markets found themselves without a weathervane and the entire mechanism was short-circuited.
HOLSTENBORG, Greenland, Aug. 4. -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh started on the most perilous of their Greenland flights at 11:30 this morning, local time.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Tunes so old their words have been forgotten, and dance steps which were traditions when Daniel Boone cut his way over the Appalachians into Kentucky, are the stock in trade of contestants in Asheville's annual folk song and dance festival now going on.

Four young men were arrested in Boston last night on suspicion and a fifth, a Harvard graduate, was being sought by the New York and Boston police in the gas bombing of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
ALBANY, Aug. 4. -- Following is the text of the special message of Governor Lehman urging an investigation concerning the Milk Control Board:
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ogden Bacon of the Plaza have gone to White Lodge, their place in Newport, for the remainder of the Summer.

Business in the money market was quieter than usual, the closing of the Stock Exchange shortly after midday as a result of damage to the ventilating system of the Exchange building being a factor. Rates for call loans, mtaurity money and business paper were all unchanged.

The slightly more than $1,000,000 in pensions paid by the Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church last year was almost double the payments guaranteed by the rules under which the fund was organized fifteen years ago, according to a statement made yesterday by Bradford B. Locke, secretary of the fund.

BERLIN, Aug. 4. -- Having taken control of everything else in Germany, the National Socialists have now set out to capture the last strongholds of the old regime -- the Foreign Office and the diplomatic service.

LAKE RONKONKOMA, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Miss Maude Adams made her first public appearance yesterday since her retirement from the stage at a garden party on the grounds of the Catholic Order of the Cenacle, to which Miss Adams gave the large estate, eleven years ago.

BERLIN, Aug. 4. -- The Boerse closed the week today in a listless, reactionary mood which depressed stock quotations as much as 4 per cent. Professional traders who had marked up prices yesterday sold out again when the public refused to follow them. Sales obviously for foreign accounts further depressed sentiment.

A plot on the east side of Fresh Pond Road in the business section of Ridgewood, Queens, on a portion of which formerly stood the old Whitney Theatre, has been sold by Glenwood Terrace Homes Corporation to the Schirr Realty Corporation.

CARTERET, N.J., Aug. 4. -- Abraham D. Glass, representing about five hundred depositors of the First National Bank, now operating under a conservator, announced today that the stockholders had approved a plan for re-, opening the bank and that it had been forwarded to Washington for Federal approval.
With only a few voices raised in protest, the Republican Mayoralty Committee and the City party accepted former Representative F. H. La Guardia yesterday as the fusion nominee for Mayor.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 4. -- A father, son and son-in-law, members of a well-to-do family, were drowned in the ocean two miles off Longport this morning when the two younger men jumped from a speed boat in a heroic but futile effort to save the third, who had suffered a heart attack.

Two more title and mortgage guarantee companies were, taken over for rehabilitation and reorganization yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance. At the same time he announced that two insurance companies had been taken over because of frozen assets.

Andrew Mills, president of the Drydock Savings Institution, was elected yesterday president of the Savings Banks Trust Company, the recently organized central institution for the savings banks of the State. The election took place at a meeting of the stockholders in the Hotel Waldorf-Astorla.
MOSCOW, Aug. 4. -- The harvest news is decidedly better today.

In a deal which was expected to be the forerunner of other purchases by the same group, an investing syndicate yesterday announced the acquisition of the property at 28 East Seventieth Street, southeast corner of Madison Avenue, a fifteen-story apartment hotel called Hampton House and formerly known as the Mirabeau.
BERLIN, Aug. 4. -- As part of the Nazis' intensified warfare against all "Marxists," the Berlin police were instructed today to shoot, if necessary, to exterminate distributers of Communist leaflets.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Philadelphia's "Schuylkill Navy" won two of the four championships decided today in the sixty-first annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen on the choppy waters of Lake Michigan.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There can be no real and lasting recovery for any of the individual nations that comprise civilized society unless that recovery is universal. That is an outstanding fact.

What for a long time appeared to be insuperable obstacle to a successful Fusion campaign against Tammany have now been happily removed. Public thanks are due to the gentlemen who worked so hard and tenaciously to clear the way. General O'RYAN, in particular, behaved in the most handsome manner.

The twenty-second annual exhibition of the Art Association of Newport will be opened today in the organization's main building. The show will be held in conjunction with the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York, which is lending a large selection from its permanent collection.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Looking for a job and a home, Elliott Roosevelt and his second wife settled down in Southern California today.

The man who has been designated to head the fusion ticket has a reputation as a fighter. Fiorello H. La Guardia, World War aviator, former President of the Board of Aldermen and former Representative of the Twentieth Congressional District, has a habit of overcoming heavy odds.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 4. -- An intensive investigation by Federal and local authorities started here today to determine the truth of charges that carpenters and laborers working on Newark's new Federal building have been forced to rebate part of their wages to certain subcontractors or their agents.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 4 (AP). -- Robert Lee Miller of Jacksonville Fla., defending champion, and Charles Ferrera of San Francisco, the 1931 victor, won the two finalist places in the National Public Links golf tournament today.

BLUFF POINT, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- Jack Cameron, young Toronto golfer who has been winning tournaments consistently lately, took the medal in the first annual invitation tournament of the Lake Champlain Country Club today with a 74.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Raymond Moley, Assistant Secretary of State, took over today his new job as director of the Federal government's campaign against kidnapping, racketeering and gangster outlawry.

LONDON, Aug. 4. -- A memorial tablet is to be erected in the Poets' Corner of Westminster Abbey in memory of Adam Lindsay Gordon who was born in October, 1833, and became one of the greatest Australian poets.

Arthur Huttick of the West Side received the decision over Tommy Do Stefano of Hartford, Conn., In the main eight-round boxing bout at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation, Brooklyn, last night. A crowd of 1,500 attended. Huttick weighed 182 pounds and De Stefano 189.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company lost $969,398 in the fiscal year ended on June 30, comparing with $831,749 net loss the year before. This was without deducting any amount for the 5 per cent rental on Manhattan Railway modified guarantee stock, which is payable if earned.
HYDE PARK, N. Y., Aug. 4. -- President Roosevelt cleared the desk of routine tasks today in expectation of a far-reaching discussion of international affairs over the week-end with Secretary Hull.

Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, who headed the delegation of United States representatives to the London conference will return today with Mrs. Hull on the United States liner President Harding. Others on the President Harding, arriving from Hamburg, Southampton, Havre and Cobh, are:

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.T., Aug. 4. -- Mrs. T.J. Lewis's How High and Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Helianthus divided the honors at Saratoga today. The former captured the Seneca Claiming Stakes, white Helianthus dominated the thirtieth renewal of the Campfire Purse.
LONDON, Aug. 4. -- Whispers that Germany is rearming on a large scale will soon be brought into the open by the British and French Governments, it was learned today.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler reserved decision yesterday on an application by Murder at the Vanities, Inc., producer of the new Earl Carroll show of that name to restrain Local 829 of the United Scenic Artists from prohibiting its members from working for the production.
