NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 4 (AP). -- The Newark Bears scored their sixth straight victory today, defeating the Montreal Royals, 11 -- 7, in a game that saw the Bears hit three opposing pitchers for sixteen safeties.

Francis A. O'Neill, United States Commissioner, issued a warrant yesterday for the arrest of Jack Corbett, alleged confidence man, because the suspect failed to make an appearance in the Federal Building when his case was called for a hearing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Can it really be true that something of permanent value is being taught us by four dreary years of depression and disaster? Has "rugged individualism" not proved the best of medicines for the ills of the body politic? Granted millionaires have multiplied, but at the shameful cost of want and misery for those millions classed as "the masses."

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Too many errors spoiled Burleigh Grimes's first pitching start for St. Louis today, and the Pittsburgh Pirates came through with a ninthinning run to beat the Cards, 5 to 4, evening the four-game series.

During his active career Controller BERRY has often confided to the public his views and plans. But never has he dropped more wisdom, than in the interview he accorded yesterday to the ship-news reporters upon his return from an inspection, at public expense, of tax devices employed in London and Paris.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- The president of the Saratoga Racing Association, George H. Bull, saw his plans work out too perfectly. If there was one thing that Saratoga needed, it was rain for the course and the grass and the trees and the fancy flowers that adorn the historic track in this Spa. The lawn was toasted and the steeplechase course was burned to a crisp.

Under the temporary Saturday closing schedule, trading on the Stock Exchange and also on the Curb Market will be suspended today. As a result business in Wall Street will be sharply reduced. The banks will be open and dealings in foreign exchange will take place as usual.

Miss Helen Jay Garrettson, a great-granddaughter of Chief Justice John Jay, who died last Tuesday, bequeathed $5,000 to the Society of the New York Hospital, 8 West Sixteenth Street, it was disclosed yesterday when her will was offered for probate.

Behind the seven-hit pitching of Cy Slaalien, a rookie right-hander, Jersey City won the first game of a double-header, 6-3, with Buffalo at Jersey City yesterday. The second contest went to the visitors, 7 to 4, but the victory in the opener gave the Jerseys a three-to-one edge in the series.

The Radio Corporation of America reports a net loss of $1,268,212 for the first six months of this year, contrasting with a net income of $219,406 for the first half of 1932. No dividends were paid for the period, whereas $343,019 in dividends was paid on the Class A preferred stock in the corresponding period of last year.
LA PAZ. Bolivia, Aug. 4. -- Paraguayan activities in the Gondra sector during the last few days culminated in a moonlight attack last night.
Oysters henceforth will rank among the brain foods if their effect upon white rats is a criterion.

The consequences of Great Britain's abandonment of the gold standard have not yet fully appeared, in the opinion of H.F. Fraser, Professor of Economics in Swarthmore College, whose book, "Great Britain, and the Gold Standard," has been published by the Macmillan Company.
TIENTSIN, Aug. 4. -- Lieut. Gen. Nakamura told this correspondent today the Japanese forces would be completely withdrawn from the demilitarized area of North China soon.

Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange remained yesterday under the shadow of next Tuesday's government crop estimate and the final prices were 15 to 18 points, or 75 cents to 90 cents a bale, lower than on Thursday. The volume of business was small.
BRIDGEPORT, Aug. 4. -- The Mollisons were still wearing bandages when they arrived today.

Floyd L. Carlisle and Herman Russeil, chairmen, respectively, of special code committees of the Edison Electric Institute and the American Gas Association, announced here yesterday that separate codes for the electric power and gas industries were being executed and would be delivered this morning to the National Recovery Administration in Washington.
BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 4. -- With two rounds still to be played, the New Jersey State open golf championship developed into a keen race today with twelve men within eight shots of the leader.

BOSTON, Aug. 4. -- Eugene S. Daniell Jr., who is being sought by the New York and Boston police in connection with the "knockout" bombing of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, is an educated young man who seeks to further his national political ambitions by spectacular tactics.

The Real Estate Board of New York entered its plea for an immediate reduction in the electric rates affecting small commercial and large wholesale consumers at the hearing yesterday before the Public Service Commission.

ALBANY, Aug. 4. -- The investigation of the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr. turned to the Adirondacks today as it was revealed that John T. Delaney, District Attorney, and aides were pressing a search for information in the vicinity of North Creek.

SALZBURG, Aug. 4. -- The first Wagner opera ever presented in the Salzburg music festival was given here tonight. While neither the equipment nor the vast personnel of Baireuth was available, the production achieved great success.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP). -- As a suggested solution to the quarrel within the petroleum industry over price regulation, Recovery Administration officials considered today a proposal to fix a ratio between the prices of crude oil and refined products and require that as one moved up the other should advance to the same degree.

Following an appeal issued by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal coordinator, on Thursday that the railroads provide all employment possible, two railroad presidents here issued statements yesterday outlining the employment situation on their properties.

Edward Bruce, silver expert with the American delegation at the London conference, returned yesterday on the Cunard liner Berengaria with a conviction that the conference resolutions on the silver question would go far to restore normal business conditions, particularly for countries bordering the Pacific.

Because of the interruption of trading by the injection yesterday of tear gas into the Stock Exchange's ventilating system, the security markets gave an uncompleted performance. Other markets remained open the full day.

Henry Morgenthau, American delegate to the wheat conference in London and Geneva, returned yesterday to report to President Roosevelt that Europe is seething with war spirit and bristling with arms against an imminent conflict.

ALBANY. Aug. 4. -- A proposal for a referendum in November on the question of creating a State-operated system for distribution of hard liquors and wines after repeal of prohibition was advanced today by Assemblyman Saul S. Streit, Democrat, of New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP). -- A cherished hope of the administration to get the government out of the shipping business has combined with President Roosevelt's Federal reorganization plans to shorten the days left to the sixteen-year-old Merchant Fleet Corporation and Shipping Board.

Operators of the seven Eastern shipyards which obtained contracts from the Navy Department to build twenty-one new ships were notified yesterday of the government's action, and immediately advanced plans which they had started several weeks ago when it was indicated that the government would share its work with the private yards.

ST. MICHAELS, Md., Aug. 4. -- Rough water, kicked up by a strong northeast wind, cut down the speedboat fields today in the Miles River Yacht Club's annual regatta and forced abandonment of the outboard races.
HYDE PARK, N. Y., Saturday, Aug. 5. -- President Roosevelt early today announced a truce In the strike in the soft-coal fields of Pennsylvania.

For more than two months 5,000 lovers of grand opera have swarmed nightly into the Hippodrome to hear music grave or gay. On nights of record-breaking heat they have paid their half-dollars and forgotten the thermometer in laughter and tears, cheering and applause.

Prices of futures sagged yesterday in trading on local commodity Exchanges in limited activity. The let-up in trading was especially conspicuous in those markets which have been watching security prices closely. All cash prices were lower.

A demonstration of food workers yesterday brought together a crowd of more than 1,000 in front of the Hotel Commodore and the Grand Central Station and caused the arrest of twenty-seven men, women and young girls.

New State and municipal finaneing scheduled for the coming week amounts to $20,022,767, of which 75 per cent will be floated on Wednesday. This total compares with a revised total of $7,078,691 for this week and a weekly average of $13,238,423 for the year to date.
Dr. Walter P. MacGibbon, 64 years old, was found yesterday with a fractured skull, a broken jaw and severe lacerations of his face and legs in his penthouse apartment at 23 East Sixty-third Street.
CHICAGO, Saturday, Aug. 5. -- Lieut. Commander Settle decided on this morning's take-off on his stratosphere flight after examining the weather map and tersely saying: "It's O.K."

Protesting the master code adopted July 21 by organized groups of the legitimate theatre as discriminatory and not representative, stock and repertory managers throughout the country have formed the National Dramatic Stock Association to protect their interests and to represent them in their dealings with the National Recovery Administration.

The plan of John D. Rockefeller Jr. to donate a large tract in the picturesque Jackson Hole region of Wyoming to the Federal Government for enlargement of the Grand Teton National Park was defended yesterday in a statement issued by Vanderbilt Webb, president of the Snake River Land Company, on behalf of Mr. Rockefeller.

Representing more than 90 per cent of commercial aviation, the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce filed its code for the manufacturing branches of the industry yesterday afternoon. The document was presented at the office of General Hugh S. Johnson in Washington by Thomas A. Morgan, president, and Leighton Rogers, executive vice president of the chamber.

Mrs. Frances Wagner King was sentenced yesterday by Judge Joseph E. Corrigan in General Sessions to a prison term of from five to ten years for blackmailing Bruce Barton, publicist and advertising executive.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Galloping Into the lead at the stretch turn, Royal Blunder, from the Audley Farm, scored an easy victory today in the top event at Hawthorne, the Berwyn Purse.

HAVANA, Aug. 4. -- Preparations for a return of martial law were made today because of the spread of transportation and other strikes throughout Cuba. A decree declaring a state of war and the abolition of constitutional guarantees was drafted, but President Machado refused to sign it until public order had been disturbed.

In a letter to the newspapers, tempered with a note of sadness rather than bitterness, John E. Gratke, managing director of the Broadway Association, chided the city's journals yesterday. Specifically, Mr. Gratke hinted that reports of the heat in New York during the last four or five days tended to spread the impression that the city was perhaps a little warmer than other places.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Improved trade prospects in Canada and indications of generally better conditions in a number of other countries were reported by the Commerce Department today in its weekly review of foreign business conditions, based on advices from commercial attaches abroad.

PARIS, Aug. 4. -- Worth stresses 1880 or 1890 lines with back emphasis, pleats, basques and bustle effects for day and evening. Quaint basque jacket suits with the jacket buttoned up the front and short basques, flared in back on front, are notable for all hours.
CHICAGO. Aug. 4. -- Insurance against kidnapping is now being underwritten through London Lloyd's.

RUMSON, N.J., Aug. 4. -- Listen, a brown mare owned by Miss Sylvia White of Shrewsbury, N.J., and ridden by Ivor Balding, today once more carried off the H.L. Herbert Cup, one of the most important trophies offered at the annual Monmouth County Horse Show.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- An end of the strike of 50,000 Pennsylvania bituminous coal miners was agreed upon, subject to approval by President Roosevelt, at 6:30 o'clock this evening in the office of General Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, after an exciting day of negotiations.

What is being done for national recovery should not let us forget our local responsibility for those who cannot be "recovered" by employment, who are cared for by the voluntary social service agencies of the community. Mrs. ROOSEVELT, despite her many activities, has accepted the chairmanship of the Woman's Committee of the National Citizens Committee of Mobilization for Human Needs.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug 4. -- The quarter finals of the team-of-four competition at the American Bridge League's annual Summer tournament here were played this afternoon with the favorites in each of the four matches coming through to victory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- Settlement of the Pennsylvania coal strike and the creation, under the direction of General Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, of a plan to forestall future strikes and lockouts, became known here tonight simultaneously with the news that fifteen additional industries had come under the President's reemployment agreement as modified to serve their special needs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Governor proposes a short moratorium on foreclosures of home and farm mortgages, provided interest and tax payments are kept up. There is no practical need for such a measure. An a class the home owners who are able to keep up these payments are finding ready cooperation from mortgagees and are not distressed at all.

While legal beer is proving a great help to Oklahoma's finances, Governor "Alfalfa Bill" Murray, interviewed here yesterday, indicated that there would be no rush in his State to ratify repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. Arriving in New York Thursday night to address a dinner in honor of Wiley Post, the flier, he found that the flier had gone West and the dinner had been postponed.

Alfred E. Smith announced yesterday that definite assurances had been received that Surrogate James A. Foley, whose term expires this year, would be nominated by both major parties. Mr. Smith is chairman of a non-partisan committee which he formed some time ago to insure Judge Foley's renomination and re-election.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Frankie Parker, the 17-year-old Milwaukee star, held the centre of the stage today in the forty-third annual Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.

On such days of debauched meteorology as we have just had, O well for him who can refrain from words of sin and converse with friendly oldfashioned folk. A visitor in a town on the Suffolk coast -- England, not Long Island -- picked up the term "gays."

Higher Woolen Prices Due. New price lists on woolen and worsted piece goods, showing advances of 10 to 20 per cent over the quotations prevailing before mills withdrew them, are expected at the start of next week. On a number of ranges mills have already priced goods and are quoting them to buy ers, who have made inquiries on those particular cloths.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- We of the Public Works Administration are engaged in a mighty effort to restore purchasing power in the United Sttaes.

Learning to Be Hard. "BRUNO WALTER and MAX REINHARDT have been acclaimed by enthusiastic audiences at the Salzburg festival. The eminent conductor and the world-famous producer and stage director are exiles from Germany.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4. -- Several hundred members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the annual Boys Club dinner dance in aid of the William Carey Camp of the Boys Club of New York in Jamesport, L.I., which was held tonight at Canoe Place Inn.
BOSTON, Aug. 4. -- The Dodgers were nearly helpless at bat today and dropped both ends of a doubleheader to the boisterous Braves, scoring only a single run in the double disaster.
DETROIT, Aug. 4 (AP). -- Hank Greenberg got a home run in the second inning and a single in the eleventh to bat in all the runs by which Detroit defeated Chicago, 3 to 2, today.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Saturday Pa., Aug. 5. -- Word of the agreement for a truce in the coal strike was received here early this morning by William Feeney, president of District 4 of the United Mine Workers of America, by telephone from John L. Lewis, international president of the union.
Robert J. Cromie, editor and owner of The Vancouver Sun, in New York yesterday en route home from a European trip, said "there is under way in Russia one of the world's greatest booms."

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 4. -- Twenty-five thousand persons in Stratford and Bridgeport paid tribute today to the flying Mollisons when they flew here for a public reception. They thanked the people of this city for the hospitality shown after their flight across the Atlantic from Pendine, Wales, which ended with a crash at Bridgeport Airport on July 23.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor announced today that its index number of wholesale prices for the week ended July 29 stands at 69.2, as compared with 69.7 for the week ended July 22, showing a decrease of approximately three-fourths of 1 per cent.

ALBANY, Aug. 4. -- With the State milk strike extending and growing in violence, Governor Lehman sent a special message today calling on the extraordinary session of the Legislature to begin an immediate investigation to determine whether the Milk Control Board should be continued or abolished.

In the absence of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody, who was forced to remain in her hotel because of a sprained back, a 20-year-old Boston girl understudy "stole the show" as the United States swept the three opening Wightman Cup matches yesterday.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 4. -- Mrs. Henry Walters was a luncheon hostess today at Sherwood.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP). -- President Roosevelt today was called upon to rescue from jeopardy plans of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration to distribute about $200,000,000 to farmers within the next sixty days in return for agreements to curtail their output of wheat and cotton.

The Chemical Bank and Trust Company, as trustee under a tenyear 6 per cent gold debenture issue of $11,600,000, began foreclosure proceedings yesterday in United States District Court against the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation.

Replying to certain questions from Donald D. Richberg, general counsel of the National Recovery Administration, bearing on the code submitted by the steel industry. Robert P. Lamont, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, informed the administration yesterday that the steel industry had "gone the limit" in its proposals and could go no further.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4. -- For the second successive time the Giants smothered the Phillies today under a sustained exhibition of hitting that has had few parallels in baseball history. The score was 18 to 1.

The expansion in bank exchanges which was set in motion in April continued into last month, a report of the leading clearing houses in the country showing that $24,055,588,063 had been involved in the business volume for July.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP). -- With its $850,000,000 recovery security issue oversubscribed six times, the Treasury tonight finally closed its books on the offering, which had been held open to receive subscriptions in which Treasury certificates maturing in September were offered in payment.

The Department of Hospitals continued yesterday its investigation of the ambulance service of Jamaioa Hospital, a private institution in Queens. At the same time, the State Department of Social Welfare and District Attorney Charles S. Colden of Queens moved to begin separate inquiries into charges of negligence of internes on ambulance duty.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 4. -- The Reformation and the Renaissance were child's play compared to what is going to happen to the world during the next century, according to Dean Fraser Metzger of Rutgers University in his address at the annual Summer session convocation here today.

CHICAGO, Saturday, Aug. 5. -- With a crew of naval reservists hanging to the ropes, the giant balloon in which Lieut. Commander T. G. W. Settle plans to ascend into the stratosphere stood filled with hydrogen gas at Soldier Field ready for the take-off early today.
LONDON, Aug. 4. -- Miss Beatrice Gottlieb. 27-year-old golfer of Tuckahoe. N.Y., beat the Prince of Wales today in an eighteen-hole match at Coombe Hill, Surrey.

Dr. W.F. Krone, veteran angler of Newark, yesterday stepped forth to claim the honors of the season to date by taking a record-sized marlin along the New Jersey coast. Dr. Krone, fishing from the private yacht Tysoe. owned by Frank O. Runyon of Englewood, landed the fish after sixty-seven minutes of hard fighting.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- With a ratio of one automobile to every five persons and more motor vehicles than all other countries combined, the United States could transport its entire population by motor if it were necessary for all to be moved at the same time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP). -- This year's wool production in the United States, which is being marketed at prices higher than for any recent year, is estimated at 348,194,000 pounds by the Department of Agriculture.

The penal methods of Sing Sing prison were studied yesterday by the group of European police officials who came to this country as delegates to the first international police conference organized last week in Chicago.

PARIS, Aug. 4. -- France seems to be voluntarily playing a secondary role in the advancement of the project for a joint protest with Great Britain and Italy against the German National Socialist attitude and actions toward Austria.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 4. -- Governor Moore, following an all-afternoon conference with the Federal Public Works Commission of New Jersey, said that he would ask the Legislature to permit the people to vote in the November elections on a State bond issue of about $50,000,000 to finance State construction projects, toward the cost of which the Federal Government would contribute about 30 per cent.

VIENNA, Aug. 4. -- Five German journalists, including Franz Riedel, correspondent of Vice Chancellor von Papen's newspaper, Germania, were arrested today under the recent emergency decree for having written articles for German papers attacking the Austrian Government.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Valuations fixed by the State Board of Tax Appeals on main stem and second-class railroad properties in the city of Bayonne for the years 1930 and 1931 were upheld today by the State Supreme Court. Appeals were filed in eleven cases in which the requested increase ranged from $100 to $200,000, on the contention that they were fixed too low by the board.

THE progress of mechanical invention may be responsible for the depression -- but it has provided us with a number of means of making it endurable. Not least among these compensatory blessings are the modern methods of keeping cool.
AMES, Iowa, Aug. 2 (By Mail). -- Artists' crayons from agricultural waste are a possibility as the result of recent studies at Iowa State College.
ABINGDON, Va., Aug. 5. -- Virginia's mountain folk who knew her father, once a resident here, are looking forward eagerly to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's visit to their music festival.

BURLINGTON, Vt., July 27. -- Vermonters are proud of their Green Mountains. They enjoy having visitors come into the State to enjoy their scenery. But they are divided on the question or whether a skyline highway should be built over the peaks of those mountains from the Massachusetts line to the Canadian border to attract more visitors.

THOSE who remember Helen Parry Eden in her inimitable first volume of poems, "Bread and Circuses." published in 1913, and its fine successor, "Coal and Candlelight" (1917), will be overjoyed after a lapse of time to meet her again in this collection of fascinating tales interspersed with the beauty of later lyrics.

JOHN TRAVERS, returning to England from New York, falls into a strange reverie which remains with him during the entire voyage. He is a well-known architect of luxury hotels and great modern buildings in steel and concrete.

LOOKING back over the invisible yet very real barrier which separates the twentieth from the nineteenth century one sees, a little dimly now, the jovial if irreverent figure of Robert G. Ingersoll, the great agnostic, whose centennial anniversary falls on Aug. 11.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 2. -- Senator Harry F. Byrd is firmly entrenched as the political arbiter of Virginia. That is the principal fact that emerges when the returns from the Democratic primary on Tuesday are analyzed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP). -- With the aid of two Boston errors and air-tight pitching in the pinches by Monte Weaver, the Senators today defeated the Red Sox for the third successive time, 3 to 2.

BAD NAUHEIM, Germany, Aug. 5. -- Gustav Oberlaender of Reading, Pa., president and founder of the Oberlaender Trust, which has been financing "American good-will expeditions" and scientific and educational commissions to Germany, has arrived here to take the cure.
DUBLIN, Aug. 4. -- The outstanding development of the week was the surprise action of the Republican Government in collecting all the arms held under license in the country.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The first Saturday of racing saw many prominent arrivals here. Postmaster General James A. Farley and Jouett Shouse watched today's racing events and are at the Grand Union for the week-end.

About 200,000 men are employed by the shipping industry aboard ship, on harbor craft or in the offices of the lines, according to a survey by the American Steamship Owners Association. There are 500 American ships in the foreign trade, carrying products of the nation from sixteen Atlantic, nineteen Gulf and twenty-four Pacific Coast ports to markets in 125 foreign lands.

With the adoption of new regulations tightening margin requirements and bringing pool operations under closer scrutiny, the New York Stock Exchange has taken the most advanced step in its history toward the elimination of speculative abuses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- There was a further slackening of industrial operations in the week ended on July 29, but some industries established new peaks of production for the recovery period, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the United States Department of Commerce.

"Confidence in New York City real estate cannot be restored until the present burdensome assessments on real estate are adjusted and properties are assessed in a manner that is fair and equitable to all concerned," said Philip N. Arnold, president of the National Realty Valuation Corporation, which company has been engaged by several large owners of real estate to review assessments placed against their property, yesterday in discussing prospects for an upswing in realty values.

BACK in the trust-busting days, T.R., the wielder of the big stick, did not always speak softly. On one occasion he hurled the bitter words "malefactors of great wealth" at a number of men who were tying the country together with shining rails and whose interests, he contended, were harmful to the public.

STOCKHOLM. CONSTANT reminders of a "third kingdom" as a beneficent reign of peace and prosperity, practically realized already by the Hitler forces, have prompted some Swedish writers to dig out the earlier literary or other history of the term.

BLUFF POINT, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Jack Cameron of Toronto defeated Page Hufty of Chevy Chase in the feature match of the second round of the invitation golf tournament at the Lake Champlain Country Club today. Cameron, who has compiled a fine record in Canadian tournament play lately, scored a 1 up victory over the former North and South amateur champion.

MYSTIC, Conn. PERHAPS its present showing isn't the best the Mystic Art Association has ever held, but it appears to be; and according to many reputable philosophers, appearance is everything in this simulacrum we call Life.

HOLLYWOOD. WITH the technicians' strike in its second week, production activities limped along in the various studios at a little more than half of normal, with producers showing hesitancy in placing new pictures before the cameras.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 2. -- To Robert Moorefield of The Register staff belongs the credit for having discovered the forgotten town, and its name in Nira.

Buyers are being advised that many types of merchandise purchased at present prices are subject to further increases before shipment, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

Plans to organize all war veterans of the nation by Congressional districts to safeguard their interests politically were discussed yesterday by the Municipal Council of the Veterans Voters League, at its headquarters, 346 Broadway.

John F. Cudahy of Milwaukee, new Ambassador to Poland, was honored yesterday by Polish-American leaders at a luncheon given by Nowy Swiat, the Polish Morning World of New York, at the Hotel Lafayette. Mr. Cudahy, who will sail on Aug. 9 aboard the President Harding, will transfer at Antwerp to a Polish vessel landing at Gdynia.

MR. J.B. BOOTH is one of the most Irritating compilers of anecdotes and "I remembers" that ever lived. His "Pink Parade," pink because the author once labored for that slightly risque sheet The Sporting Times, also known as The Pink 'Un, Is a conglomeration of jokes, anecdotes, thumb-nail sketches, descriptions and what-nots that sound as though they were dredged from old files of clippings.

GAPING Lilliputians or Brobdingnagians could have excited no more bewilderment in a captive Gulliver than crowds of Hollywood folk aroused in the eight Eskimos brought back from the Arctic by W.S. Van Dyke to play in the adaptation of Peter Freuchen's novel, "Eskimo," some weeks ago.

THEY are putting the finishing touches to the new Ypres. The belfry has just been restored all the way to the golden dragon at the top. The market hall (no longer the famous Cloth Hall of the old Ypres) is being pushed to completion and should be finished this year.
GUAYAQUIL, July 26. -- An expectant, even anxious, concern is evident with respect to the meeting of Congress, Aug. 10. the anniversary of Ecuador's Declaration of Independence.

JANE AUSTEN once wrote to her 12-year-old niece advising her to cease writing till she was 16 because, she said, she herself had often wished she had read more and written less in the corresponding years. Whatever her reasons, we cannot agree with them.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Captain James Mollison and Amy Johnson Mollison were guests of honor tonight at Sky Night, a moonlight fete held on the terrace of the Westchester Country Club for the benefit of the Judson Health Centre, the Emergency Exchange Association and the United States Amateur Air Pilots Association.

A story of educational pioneering with sometimes a dangerous adventure and hardships, but with ultimate success, is recalled by the death the other day of Miss Jennie E. Howard, the last survivor of a group of American teachers who went in 1883 to Argentina to organize normal schools for that country.

SALZBURG, Austria. Aug. 5 -- There is gradually assembling here quite a little colony of "non-Aryan" or only "semi-Aryan" artists, both musical and dramatic, whom Naziruled Germany has ousted either for their opinions, their religion or their descent.

WASHINGTON. WITH the opening of the campaign to put 6,000,000 unemployed American wage earners back to work before Labor Day, under the sheltering wings of the National Recovery Administration's Blue Eagle, the concept of labor as a commodity and of wages as determined by the law of supply and demand is under momentous challenge.

HOT SPRINGS, Va. -- The Summer social season will rise to its height on Friday and Saturday, when the sixth annual horse show, under the auspices of the Bath County Horse Show Association, will be held. A benefit for the Community House Hospital, the show will attract a fashionable gathering from many Northern cities.

BOSTON, Aug. 5. -- The collapse of the Dodgers on the eastern front was made complete today. Huck Betts, more generous in allowing hits than Walter Beck, had much the better support and the Braves triumphed, 2 to 1, with the winning run unearned.

Courtney Robert Hall's letter concerning professors in politics, in THE TIMES of July 29, fails to take account of the fact that some of President Roosevelt's intimate advisers are professors who have had scant experience outside the campus.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Riding through the middle of the match with too much speed and hitting too well for the opposition, Ox Ridge galloped rather easil to victory in the Wheatley Cups final at the Meadow Brook Club today. The winners defeated The Oasis, 11 to 2, in the game which ended the first half of the tournament season at the club.

LISBON, Aug. 4. -- For several weeks there have been rumors of a contemplated change in the Salazar Cabinet, and, along with the rumors, the usual exaggerated sidewalk conversation about a Ministerial crisis and conflicts of ideas among the Cabinet leaders.
BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Aug. 8 (AP). -- The lower Rio Grande valley counted the cost tonight of an eighty-mile tropical hurricane at one dead, one injured and property damage estimated at $1,500,000.

BARCELONA, July 24. -- The feud between the Catalan land owners and the peasants, known as rabassaires, has broken out into open warfare in which mob violence figures and in which both sides announce their intention of defying the law if it does not suit them.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Edmund R. Cummins, in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, disagrees with my statement that mental processes are dependent upon brain tissue. He advances the rather trite argument that thought must precede brain tissue, inasmuch as the design, in this case the brain pattern, must have a designer -- thought.

More than 700 educators from all sections of the country, who are enrolled in the Summer session of Teachers College, Columbia University, attended the annual Summer session beefsteak dinner of Teachers College yesterday at the Horace Mann School in Riverdale.

HAVANA, Aug. 5. -- The success of the negotiations now under way in Cuba for a definite solution of Cuba's political turmoil hung in the balance today because of the strikes which are gaining momentum and have taken on a frankly revolutionary character.
John J. O'Connell Jr., released by kidnappers a week ago, motored here yesterday from Albany, accompanied by the District Attorney of Albany County, John T. Delaney.

A keenly competitive battle to hold the retail grocery outlets they now enjoy will develop among brewers here before Fall, a prominent brewer predicted yesterday. At the present time, according to a survey completed last week, the retail grocery store is handling up to twelve different brands of bottled beer, with an average of nine and one-half brands to a store.
VIENNA, Aug. 5. -- The Neue Freie Presse reports tonight that Chancellor Dollfuss will leave for Rome in a few days to meet Premier Mussolini at the latter's invitation.
HARBIN, Manchuria. CHILD of imperialism and parent of conflict, the Chinese Eastern Railway has fallen upon evil days.

LAKE PLACID -- On Saturday night one of the major events of the season at Lake Placid will begin when the annual midsummer ice carnival opens at the big Olympic arena. Originally planned for the nights of Aug. 18 and 19, the carnival is now to occupy an entire week, starting with an exhibition ice hockey match on the opening night between teams of the Rideau Club of Ottawa and the Lake Placid Athletic Club.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Gallant Sir, owned by Norman W. Church of Los Angeles, won the Hawthorne Handicap before 15,000 spectators at Hawthorne today. Big Brand was second and Waylayer third.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Big Bill Miller of the Penn A.C. won his fourth consecutive national singles sculling title today, a feat never before accomplished in American amateur rowing. Philadelphia oarsmen won most of the glory as the sixty-first annual regatta of the National Association of Oarsmen concluded.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Johnny Kinder, Jumping Brook professional who has headed the New Jersey pros and amateurs in the State open championship for the last two years, was unceremoniously dethroned at the Forest Hill Field Club today.

THREE books of instruction in the game of tennis by qualified experts. Miss Jacobs won the women's national singles championship of the United States last year. Mrs. Wightman is a four-times winner of that title in former years. Mercer Beasley is tennis coach at Lawrenceville School and Princeton University and was the coach of our much discomfited Davis Cup squad of the current year. Each book is plentifully illustrated with action photographs of well-known players.

Pledges by employers in the New York area under the President's blanket code passed the 100,000 mark yesterday, at the expiration of the first full week of the local NRA campaign.

As a result of the recent upheaval in the security and commodity markets, the agitation for some form of Federal control or regulation of the exchanges of the country has been revived. Threats and admonitions from Washington are heard, fresh inquiries have been demanded and the president of the New York Stock Exchange has had a visit from the counsel of the Senate committee which has been investigating Wall Street.

PRAGUE, July 19. -- Czechoslovakia is determined to suppress with a firm hand the activities of Hitlerites in her own territory. This policy is accounted for by the fact that the Northern and Western districts of Bohemia are inhabited almost entirely by Germans (Sudetendeutsche) among whom there are large numbers of Nationals and Nazis.
