THE volume of Professor Huebner and McCahan, one of a series of the social and economic aspects of life insurance, is a useful manual as far as it goes. Designed for the classroom as well as the professional underwriter, it restates in a form that is both clear and cogent the benefits and merits of life insurance as an investment for the prospective policy holder.

RUMSON, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Highest honors in the annual Monmouth County Horse Show today were awarded to the chestnut mare Winning Ways, owned by the Pennypack Valley Farm of Mrs. L.L. Rowland of Southampton, Pa.

The action taken last week by the New York Stock Exchange in changing its by-laws and rules further to curb speculation was the climax of a movement which had been proceeding steadily since a short time after the stock market crash in 1929.

FOLLOWING the severe poliomyelitis epidemic of 1916, several civic, fraternal and service organizations in New York State made a study of the handicapped child and his problems. Conditions were found to be so appalling that a State-wide survey was made by a committee appointed by the Governor, resulting in the enactment of several laws which created our present State plan in 1926.

LONDON. THE death of Sir Anthony Hope Hawkins (Anthony Hope) has reminded us of the change in literary fashions since "The Prisoner of Zenda" appeared in 1894. Indeed, the very type of State depicted therein would nowadays seem so incredible that the romance itself might be expected to lack verisimilitude.

In a letter recently sent to Secretary of the Interior Ickes by Joseph M. Brody, New York City builder, attention is called to the views expressed to Secretary Ickes by R.E.J. Summers, head of the Summers engineering firm, that under competitive building public works will be delayed for at least another six months.

ROME, Aug. 5. -- The recently built town of Littoria, which marks the victory of man's efforts after a thousand years of struggle against the miasmic Pontine marshes, is now a happy thriving community in a vast plain blossoming into new life.
BELGRADE, Aug. 5. -- Among the forces that have cause for gratitude to Chancellor Hitler's government is the Yugoslav dictatorship.

"BETTER understanding," "bonds of friendship that unite our two countries," "common interest of mankind" -- these stereotyped phrases or something like them are sure to be uttered whenever a new international radio circuit or telephone line is formally dedicated to the public service.

HENRY TRAVERS, playing in "Another Language" at the Capitol, is a veteran of the stage, although this is only his second motion-picture appearance. He played the part of the doctor's father in "Reunion in Vienna" and subsequently was given a contract with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3. -- Pennsylvania's new woman Secretary of Labor and Industry has been receiving baptism of fire. While the soft coal warfare was being waged in the Alleghanies with real bullets, causing bloodshed, the textile strikes this week produced sporadic outbreaks in the City of Brotherly Love and vicinity, where the principal ammunition consisted of eggs, bricks and ripe fruit, with only an occasional rifle bullet felling a striker.

Marked improvement in retail buying last week was reported yesterday by various lines of business, and this despite the heat early in the period. This improvement coincided with a cessation of industrial gains and moderate recessions in some instances, a condition which was interpreted as a trend toward a more even adjustment between production and consumption.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- A large, white spot, so immense that it could engulf the earth, has suddenly appeared on the equator of Saturn, the ringed planet. It was discovered by John E. Willis, astronomer of the Naval Observatory at 12:18 o'clock this morning.

LEAVING the Humphrey-Weidman dance program for comment to the dance department on another page, the programs of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra next week will offer a number of interesting items. Among these will be an evening devoted partly to music by Johann Strauss, a Beethoven-Wagner program and the performance of Mahler's First symphony, announced for Friday evening.

JEAN THOMAS is, on her father's side, a Kentucky mountain woman herself. When, therefore, she was asked by a famous criminal lawyer to become his stenographer in the hill country trials, she accepted with delight. Only 17 years old as she was, she knew the lure of such an adventure, she was possessed by a sincere desire to know more of these isolated people.

CARMEL. N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Dermat led a fast field in the Class A trot and pace today. In the first brush Janet McGregor gave Dermat a stiff battle. Waymart took the second whirl and set the pace in the third until passed on the home stretch.

Summer camps for children are at the middle of what every one anticipated would be a hard season, and although the enrolment figures remain uncertain in the many large camps to which fresh batches of youngsters are sent all through the Summer, it is possible to see how the camping movement in general is faring.

Considerably refreshed after their twenty-four-hour respite, the Yankees appeared to be riding once more on an even keel at the Stadium yesterday. Then, to the utter consternation of a crowd of 18,000, they were sunk again.

WASHINGTON. THE recent negotiations between General Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, and executives of oil companies for the purpose of drafting a code for the industry to lay before the President have brought into the limelight the cleavage between the major petroleum concerns and the so-called independents.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Dates set for hearings on twelve basic codes of competition before the National Recovery Administration were anonunced today as follows:

Standing off a dangerous rally by the British, the crippled United States Wightman Cup team won the women's international tennis trophy for the third year in a row at Forest Hills yesterday. The final score was 4 -- 3.

The Estates Collection Service, supposedly an outside agency supporting itself on commissions earned through the collection of accounts for bankrupt estates, is in reality merely a department of the Irving Trust Company, standing receiver in bankruptcy cases, Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe ruled yesterday.
The hot weather of the last week brought a demand for lighter foods, which was reflected in market reports yesterday by an upward trend in prices on lettuce, tomatoes, berries and matermelons.

PARIS, Aug. 4. -- On a wall of the Guaranty Trust Company Building at the corner of the Rue Royale and Place de la Concorde there is still to be seen one of those public notices which appeared, as if by magic, everywhere on the morning of Aug. 1, 1914, with the heading "General Mobilization."

Announcements last week of bonds to be redeemed before their dates of maturity were principally for future months, only some small parts of municipal issues being posted for August payment. Those called for payment in future months consisted of several large industrial and foreign obligations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Elaborate provisions against unfair competition are made in the tentative code for retail establishments upon which hearings before the National Recovery Administration are to begin Aug. 15.

THE Lindberghs, who have been flying over Greenland and across the icy waters of Baffin's Bay to Baffin Island, are writing another chapter in the fascinating saga of that ice-clad land, which has been the threshold of northern exploration and new trails for a thousand years.

STOCKHOLM, July 20. -- Democracy is the key word of present political discussion in Sweden, and the one cool contribution that is coming out of weeks of intensive concentration, not unmixed with flaming prejudices, on the problems of the near neighbors Germany and Russia is the discovery here that communism, on the one hand, and nazism or fascism, on the other, are one and the same thing.

Preachers in the city will point out today the part the churches can play in the national recovery program. A number of pulpits will be filled by clergymen from Great Britain and Canada. In several of the largest Protestant Episcopal churches Bishops will preach.

Paul Codes and I are about to take off on what we plan as a record-breaking flight. We hope to win back for France the non-stop distance record now held by the British airmen O.R. Gayford and G.E. Nicholetts.

Eugene S. Daniell Jr., 28-year-old Harvard graduate, was arrested here yesterday as the leader of a small group of political iconoclasts who, the police believe, arranged the gassing of the New York Stock Exchange on Friday as a party publicity measure.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 5 (AP). -- Five men were shot to death and eight wounded, one critically, in fights attributed to the primary election in Kentucky today, and another died in what was believed to be an aftermath of a row during the last November election.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 5. -- A margin of eleven runs decided the issue today in favor of the cricketers of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club in their match against the Veteran Cricketers of New York. The score was 142 to 131.
UNIONTOWN, Pa., Aug. 5. -- The coal strike truce agreed on at Washington Friday night was rejected here tonight by the leaders of the local unions of the United Mine Workers of America.

THAT Germany is suffering from acute mass-paranoia there appears to be little doubt. The symptoms are succinctly set forth by Mr. Armstrong in his "Hitler's Reich -- The First Phase." The phenomena reacted on are demonstrated with documentary evidence by Professor Kosok in his "Modern Germany."

DETROIT. MIDSUMMER is going to bring into operation the New Deal for the automobile dealer. Leaders of the distribution forces in Detroit and throughout the country have the date Aug. 15 marked on their calendars as the day soon after which unfair used-car trading should be a thing of the past.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The Eastern grass court championships got under way today at the Westchester Country Club with two matches being played in the men's division and thirteen in the women's.

TELEVISION for many years has been the jig-saw puzzle of science. Pioneer experimenters, lacking electron tube devices, deemed it impossible to emulate the human eye, so they did the next best and chopped the scene into tiny bits for broadcasting.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Caesars Ghost and Mrs. Charles M. Amory's Red Wagon divided honors today before 10,000 spectators, including Postmaster General Farley and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, wife of the Governor.

SOUTHAMPTON -- The gayety of the past week promises to con- tinue throughout the remaining weeks of the Summer. Many members of house parties at various estates in the colony who arrived for the two large dances of this week-end, the Boys Club dinner dance at Canoe Place Inn on Friday night and the Tennis Ball of last night at the Meadow Club, are continuing their visits for the events of the coming week.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 5 -- It was early in the afternoon and the races had not started. Two gray-haired, stylish, stout gentlemen were seated on the clubhouse veranda looking out across the track. One was tall, the other was short. The tall one said:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The National Association of Tobacco Distributors for the wholesale distributers and the retail tobacco dealers of America submitted a code of fair competition and mar- keting arrangement to the National Recovery and the Agricultural Ad- justment Administrators today.

LEIPZIG, Aug. 5. -- Business men ot Jewish stock were assured they would not receive discriminatory treatment at the Leipzig Fair, which will open on Aug. 27, in a statement issued today by the fair's executive office, aiming to reassure foreign customers.

THIS volume contains the major works of that pleasantly minor author of England's pre-war period -- Saki. The first item is "The Unbearable "Bassington," a brilliant tale of a young man who failed to make a good marriage and died of it. Readers of Saki have long admired the regiment of polished paragraphs that describe a certain class of mannered London where such a tragedy could be possible.

PARIS, Aug. 5. -- Schiaparelli's style collection continues the wide topped line but abandons superimposed architectural shoulders for a natural cut and rounds off all angles. Narrow pencil-line dresses and skirt-lengths are unchanged.

Representative S.D. McReynolds, chairman of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs and a delegate to the London Conference, returned on the liner President Harding of the United States Lines yesterday in the party accompanying Secretary Cordell Hull.
DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 4. -- Sustained activity in business and industry and increasing optimism have marked the trend of affairs throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District during the last week.

MOUNT VERNON, N. T., Aug. 5. -- An attempt to occupy the leisure time of adult unemployed and working persons with useful reading matter is being carried on by the city's Board of Education with funds allotted for "made work" for unemployed by the State Department of Education.

THIS is the diamond jubilee year of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, formerly the Royal Northwest Mounted Police. The famous force was established in 1873, following the acquisition of the Western prairie land in 1870 by the Dominion of Canada.

THERE have been not a few attempts to analyze the effects of music on various personalities. There has perhaps always been the idea that music of various kinds, in various ways, has definite effects; they have often been noted down.

Lions are tawny; tigers and zebras are striped; leppards are spotted; many birds, worms and insects are green; everything that crawls, swims or flies has a coloring peculiar to its species. Mimicry was DARWIN'S explanation. Animals attempt to elude their enemies by assuming the appearance of their surroundings.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The suggestion of Charles Francis Coe in his article published in THE NEW YORK TIMES in favor of a national police force to subdue all crime raises many interesting problems. Mr. Coe entirely ignores the constitutional questions involved. I was a Police Commissioner in St. Louis for four years, and I believe I have some understanding of the crime problem.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The official summary of the Interstate Commerce Commission's decision against a reduction in rail freight rates is as follows:

DELAFIELD, Wis., Aug. 5 (AP). -- The boys' double championship of the Western Tennis Tournament was won today by the East-West combination of Russell Bobbitt of Atlanta, Ga., and Bobby Harmon of Berkeley, Cal., the singles winner.

WHEN the receipts of a play fall below a certain mark these torrid days a closing notice is posted and the play, in the vernacular of Broadway, "folds up" on Saturday night. The scenery goes to the storehouse and the actors go in search of other jobs.

The New York State Division of the Consolidated Home Owners Mortgage Committee sent a telegram to President Roosevelt at Hyde Park yesterday, asking him to use his influence to stop foreclosures of mortgages on homes, at least until the Federal acts designed to assist financially distressed home owners are in operation.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Upward of 200 delegates from Virginia, Maryland, Missouri, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York and several from the Province of Ontario, Canada, arrived here this afternoon to attend the Young People's Interdenomination Conference, which began a week's session at the Stony Brook Assembly this evening.

BUDAPEST, July 24. -- In Debreezin Hospital the king of Hungararian adventurers, Ignaz Strassnoff, has just died at the age of 65. At various times during his life he disposed of large sums of money, the proceeds of his swindles. When he died, however, his whole estate consisted of his stock-in-trade-monocle and a shabby uniform of an officer in the Royal Hungarian Hussars.
An exodus of salt-water fishermen from this city and environs today is evident from the bookings which boat captains from almost every port on Long Island reported yesterday.

Should colleges as well as shops begin to display the blue eagle as an earnest that they are doing their bit toward national recovery? Crippled as many of them are with reduced incomes and reduced appropriations from Legislatures, perhaps not all could now certify that they are paying an approved minimum academic wage.

Forty years ago a copy of the old Viking ships of Leif Ericson's time came into New York Harbor, after crossing from Norway in forty-three days. A bronzed young sea captain of 35 commanded the eighty-foot craft and her crew of eleven men. They viewed the sights of New York, including the old Waldorf, which had just risen at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, then proceeded to the World's Fair at Chicago and to Washington.

NORTH BERWICK, Scotland, Aug. 5. -- Walter Hagen and Denny Shute, last of the American Ryder Cup golf team still in Great Britain, played their final exhibition match together today, beating W.D. Torrance and R.B. Denholm 3 and 2.
Three companies of the General Motors group reported yesterday increased activities, two in sales and one in production.

THE radio industry is on the threshold of a "new deal." Falling in line with President Roosevelt's national recovery program, the Radio Manufacturers Association has filed with the National Recovery Administration an application for a code for the radio manufacturing industry to begin operation immediately upon its acceptance by the government.

BOSTON, Aug. 2. -- The entire town government of Wendell, a municipality in the western part of the State with a population of 353 persons, is in jail, and conducting the town government all the same.

August will be a lively convention month for the philatelists of the United States. Three important meetings are scheduled, of which the largest will be that of the American Philatelic Society in Chicago from Aug. 22 to 26.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Offers to sign President Roosevelt's reemployment agreement, but with certain exceptions as to hours of labor for highly technical employes, were made to the Recovery Administration by the Edison Electric Institute and the American Gag Association today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to order a general reduction in freight rates. In a 7 to 3 decision, it sustained the position of the railroads as against socalled basic producers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If the authors of the code provisions of the National Recovery Act were consciously influenced by ancient common law precedents, that fact does not seem to have been disclosed, and self-regulation by industry is by many assumed to be an untried if not a revolutionary thing.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Mid-August, which frequently finds the Jersey shore social activities in a brief lull, will not have any such respite this year. This week will bring many activities, the most notable of which will be the national sweepstakes and regatta sponsored by the Red Bank Yacht Racing Association, which will be held on the north branch of the Shrewsbury River on Saturday.

Far out over the Atlantic last night a great silver monoplane, the Joseph Le Brix. bearing the Tricolor of France, moved steadily eastward, seeking a world's distance record. It left Floyd Bennett Field yesterday morning at 5:41 o'clock, Eastern Daylight Time, for some point -- nearly three days hence -- in Asia.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Overtaking ten rivals on the last leg of the course, Raphael Guastavino, the 20-year-old skipper of the Star Class boat Kinkajou II, slipped into second place in the concluding race of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association series to clinch the Corry Trophy.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Frank Shields earned the right to have his name inscribed on the historic Meadow Club bowl by defeating Frankie Parker, brilliant seventeen-year-old star, today. The rangy New York player won by 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1 as the forty-third annual Southampton invitation tennis tournament came to a close.

Retailers all over the country took steps during the week to bring their store operations within the provisions of the temporary code agreed on last Monday by six major associations in the field of distribution. At the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association it was reported yesterday that a full spirit of cooperation was evidenced in the response of merchants.
ST. MICHAELS, Md., Aug. 5. -- The colorful Chesapeake Bay log sailing canoes captured the spotlight in the final of the Miles River Yacht Club's annual regatta today.

MOSCOW, Aug. 4. -- THIS summer has witnessed an interesting evolution in the relationship of the Soviet labor unions to the proletarian State, an evolution that appears to be the final phase of the labor union movement here.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 5. -- The Jockey Club meeting, the biggest Brazilian turf and social event, will be held tomorrow. Forty horses are entered for the Brazil Prize of $25,000.

Lieutenant Maurice Rossi, who is 32 years old, has been a military pilot since 1919 and has 3,000 hours in the air to his credit. He has flown nearly 500 hours in the big Bleriot monoplane with which he and Lieutenant Paul Codes are confident they will set a world's distance record.

IN the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is the only laboratory of its kind in this country, perhaps in the world. It is a place where the effect of ocean waves on various barriers can be studied under controlled conditions. The man who presides over it is Professor Kenneth C. Reynolds, whose ambition in life just now is to design breakwaters, bulkheads and seawalls that cannot be undermined.

Attracted by the prospects which reciprocal trading relations with Latin America hold for American business men, export trade organ- izations last week began gathering information to lay before the State Department in an endeavor to help guide the administration in its announced plan of effecting closer trade agreements with South and Central American nations.

In this article, second of a daily series of personal reports by the men directing the Federal administration's recovery projects, the chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority tells of the unique plans being developed for the States in that region.

PARIS. WITH July 14 the "season" ends in Paris, and all good Parisians take themselves and their children to the seashore or the mountains, leaving the grands boulevards and street cafes, Montmartre and the lazily meandering Seine, Montparnasse and the lovely Bois de Boulogne to the Anglo-Saxon invaders.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- In a balloon christened "A Century of Progress" Lieut. Commander T. G. W. Settle of the navy took off from Soldier Field at 4:05 o'clock, Eastern Day light Saving Time, this morning bound for the stratosphere.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Pausing in his stride only long enough to announce the Recovery Administration's major achievements of the last twenty-four hours. Administrator Hugh S. Johnson conferred with his deputies today on plans for intensifying the drive to enlist all of industry under the President's reemployment program as soon as possible.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 2. -- When the Blue Eagle came down to roost on Main Street this week the corn belt received its first good look at recovery in action. Up to now it has been something mainly sensed but unseen. With farm prices moving upward by fits and starts it was evident that something was going on, but the mechanics of it were not in sight.

A new Jesuit missionary policy was formulated last week when the Very Rev. Edward C. Phillips, provincial of the Maryland-New York Province of the Society of Jesus, assigned eight young Jesuit scholastics to the Philippine Islands to complete their studies.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Wholesale business was stimulated by the arrival of the advance guard of buyers for the Interstate Merchants Council fall sessions, which began Monday, and by the opening of several gift and house wares trade exhibitions.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 5. -- Construction of units in northern California of a State-wide water program was provided for today when Governor Rolph signed enabling legislation for the issuance of $270.000,000 of revenue bonds to finance the project.

Dean Teachers College, Columbia. We have known for many years past -- indeed, it' has now become generally accepted -- that we cannot trust the education of American children to the sum of money available from the resources of a small taxing district, nor to the social ideals of a backward, illiterate community.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Covering the first half-mile in 1:04 flat, Hilana, bay filly owned by Herb Roulston of New York, set a new track record for 3-year-old pacers when she stepped a mile in 2:12 1/4 at the Weequahic Park track today.

All drydock and ship and boat repairing yards in the Greater New York district have united to administer the code governing the industry, it was announced yesterday by the New York and New Jersey Drydock Association, 24 State Street.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Undiscouraged by the spectacular anticlimax to his balloon ascension, Lieut. Commander T.G.W. Settle today declared he was "eager for another go at it."

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 2. -- The saying is that only fools and strangers will predict the weather in Texas. It is the same way with forecasting what the Legislature will do, but the indications are such that it seems safe to say that the special session of the Legislature to toe convened in September will modify or suspend the severe anti-trust laws.
To the Editor of The New York Times: There has come to my attention a letter by Kenneth Holland captioned "Conservation of Human" appearing in THE TIMES of July 6.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 2. -- Widely regarded by friend and foe as probably marking a turning point in the rule of Huey P. Long, Kingfish and Senator of Louisiana, the recounting of some of the ballots cast in the positively remarkable -- even for Louisiana -- election of November, 1932, has gotten under way.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Almost as sensational as the flight of the Blue Eagles over Chicago, thousands of which have alighted and now perch proudly on the premises of those who do their part, has been the midsummer awakening of the civic conscience, issuing in a new war on crime and racketeering.

HARTFORD, Aug. 3. -- Connecticut, faced with growing demands for new State taxes to relieve the burden of municipal levies upon real estate, is waiting for its new State Tax Study Commission to give some indication of what proposals will be placed before the next session of the General Assembly.

TODAY RADIO OPERETTA -- One of the gayest of all light operas, Gilbert and Sullivan's "Pirates of Penzance," performed under the baton of Harold Sanford. The cast of this one-hour microphone version presents Muriel Wilson, soprano, as Mabel; Fred Hufsmith, tenor, as Frederick, the first "conscientious objector"; Edward Wolter, baritone, as the Pirate King, and Walter Preston, baritone, as Major General Stanley, his mortal enemy.

Miss Amelia Earhart, transatlantic flier, will enter the airline field again, it was learned here yesterday. She and Paul Collins, former vice president in charge of operations of the Ludington Airlines, with which Miss Earhart also was connected, will operate a new service between Boston and Bangor, Me., as a subsidiary of the Boston Maine Railroad.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5. -- The Giants split a double-header with the Phillies today and rounded the century mark in the season's play with sixty victories and forty defeats. The even break reduced the margin of the league-leading Terrymen to three games over the Pirates.

MADRID, Aug. 4. -- Just as a woman powders her nose to get her man, so the revolutionary governments of Spanish-speaking countries invariably brighten up their capital cities to win the people. That is what is happening in Madrid now.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Out of a Winter of darkness, out of a Spring of confusing cross purposes, the United States has come groping, bewildered. True, there are some who appear to know what is occurring, but the great mass of people do not.

Business was almost at a standstill yesterday in the financial section of New York. The Stock Exchange and the Curb Exchange closed and such markets as remained open were able to command much less than the usual Saturday attention. Many of the Wall Street organizations operated with skeleton staffs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP). -- A readjustment of freight rates on horses and mules between points in South-western and Western trunk line territory was ordered today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

BERLIN, Aug. 5. -- Despite assurances of the German Olympic Committee at the Vienna Congress June 8 that German Jews would not be excluded from the German teams of the eleventh Olympiad, utterances since of sports leaders make safe the prediction that few, if any, will compete for the Fatherland three years hence.

ATLANTA, Aug. 5. -- Seventy-five girls and women, attired in chic clothing fashioned from sugar bags, chicken feed sacks, cotton sheeting, guano sacks and varied cotton materials, demonstrated the practical possibilities of cotton to Secretary Wallace here today.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Hal Smith, rookie right-hander, held the Cubs to five hits today and the Pirates took the opening game of the series, 6 to 2.

Railroad men foresee in the last half of the current year a continuation of a policy to provide as much employment as possible. This policy, they assert, began when, in 1930, they responded to an appeal by President Hoover by authorizing the largest expenditures of any year in their history.

BY formal action of the State Legislature the tomtit, or Carolina chickadee, recently became the official bird of North Carolina. This year has seen Indiana also adopt an official bird -- the Eastern cardinal. Only four States -- Connecticut, Iowa, New Jersey and Tennessee -- remain without feathered representatives.

An extensive and useful program of work which will result in permanent improvements has been begun by two camps of the Civilian Conservation Corps, initiated by President Roosevelt as one of his measures for the relief of unemployment, which have been established in the Harriman section of the Palisades Interstate Park in the highlands of the Hudson and the Northern Ramapo Mountains, the commissioners of the Palisades Interstate Park assert.

TOWN, with its hustle and its bustle, is beginning to loom on the horizon of vacation-filled Summer. With the thought of Autumn and its busy days comes a curiosity about clothes, an anticipation, of the thrill that means a new costume and with it a change of mental attitude.

Charles A. Alexander, president of the Red Bank Yacht Club Racing Association, yesterday received word from George Reis of Lake George, N.Y., that he would have his Gold Cup boat El Lagarto at Red Bank on Saturday to defend his laurels in the National Sweepstakes, the big motor boat event the coming week-end on the Shrewsbury River.

LIEUTENANT COMMANDER VANDERBILT commanded his own boat in a voyage around the world. That is enough to make any one break the thoushalt-not-covet commandment. The boat was Alva, a motor ship 264 feet over all, built according to specifications of luxuriousness and seaworthiness undreamed of in the average yachtsman's philosophy.

THE return of Ernest Bloch, after years spent in Europe, has been the occasion of a private hearing of his latest composition, a setting of the Jewish service, which he completed under circumstances that made possible an exceptional degree of seclusion and concentration upon his task.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Members of the Board of Trade were notified today by that organization to furnish promptly to the Grain Futures Administration a statement covering individual operations and holdings of wheat futures from June 14 to July 31, inclusive, in excess of 200,000 bushels for any individual account, and also to make separate reports of any transaction in excess of 200,000 bushels resulting from operations in daily or weekly bids or offers.

AN effort is being made to persuade the Federal Government to grubstake thousands of prospectors with the purpose of relieving unemployment and increasing the gold supply. The plan was evolved by Randolph Walker of New York, who laid it recently before President Roosevelt, and it bas been endorsed by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- A story of thrift displayed by Indians of the Navajo Reservation employed in a civilian conservation camp at Shiprock, N.M., and who, after obtaining money to eradicate grasshoppers, bought 1,100 young turkeys to eat the grasshoppers, was related today in a report to Robert Fechner.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Announcement of the creation of a National Board of Arbitration was made today in the following statement:

PROFESSOR SCHUMAN has not been content to let his book speak for itself, but in the first of two prefaces seeks, apparently, to commend it by sarcastic criticism of other works with which it may be compared, and sarcastic warnings to readers of what they may expect.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aup. 5. -- Charles Ferrera. 28-year-old San Francisco iron worker, removed the national public links golf crown from the brow of Robert Lee Miller of Jacksonville, Fla., today in winning the championship for the second time in three years.

I WAS in Belgium in the Summer of 1915 when the fieldgray German uniforms were thick in the streets of Brussels and in ruined Louvain, when the Belgian women spoke in whispers, glancing over their shoulders. I was in Russia in 1924 when underneath the surface of triumph and gay, exultant confidence in the future there was the silent terrorstricken remnant of the old nobility.

According to a recent survey by two professors in Teachers College, children between the ages of 10 and 15 reveal an "amazing desire" to glorify everything associated with war. That weakness is not peculiar to children. Many of their elders have the same blind spot on their mental retinas.

In response to requests from manufacturers and producers engaged in export trade, the National Foreign Trade Council yesterday sent letters to 4,000 exporters advising them of methods to conform to the National Industrial Recovery Act and at the same time maintain their competitive position with foreign producers.
WARSAW, Aug. 5. -- Poland and Danzig signed two important agreements this afternoon concerning the fuller use by Poland of Danzig's port and Polish citizens' special rights in the Free City.

Calling attention to the trend toward a larger volume of money being loaned on mortgages by the building loan associations throughout the country, Morton Bodfish, executive manager of the United States Building and Loan League, cites the fact that this condition is naturally reflected in an increase in building construction.

Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh landed safely at Ella Island, about 165 miles north-northwest of Scoresby Sound on the east coast of Greenland, at 5:45 o'clock Friday afternoon. Eastern Daylight Time, after a 500-mile flight over the inland ice cap, according to dispatches received by Pan American Airways yesterday.

Eight European police chiefs and crime experts sailed for their homes yesterday on the Cunard liner Berengaria, carrying away the conviction that America has first-class modern police methods, but that police work and politics cannot be mixed.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Hand to hand fighting between State troopers and strikers in a nearly State-wide milk holiday sent eight members of the State constabulary to hospitals today, one man so badly injured that he may die, and resulted in undetermined injuries to a score of strikers.

The income of Mrs. Elbert H. Gary, her two daughters and two grandchildren from the cooperative apartment house at 2 East Sixtyseventh Street and 855 and 856 Fifth Avenue will be reduced if the Supreme Court acts favorably on a petition filed by the Manufacturers Trust Company, it was revealed yesterday.

SINCE the beginnings of literary discussion, search has been prosecuted in vain for an adequate definition of poetry. Irrespective of its content, the majority would hold that poetry must, for one fundamental, distinctively differ from prose in its form.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Eight hundred young men from New York, New Jersey and Delaware were welcomed by Brig. Gen. H.L. Laubach, commandant, this afternoon, at exercises marking the formal opening of the annual citizens military training camp here.

The number of stockholders of leading American corporations turned slightly downward in the first half of this year, the movement coinciding with the revival of stock market activity and the simultaneous accumulation of large blocks of shares by important investment accounts, both private and incorporated.

HUPMOBILE dealers are showing a new standard six in a lower price than the de luxe silver anniversary six. The new model is offered in three body types -- five-passenger sedan, coupe with rumble seat and five-passenger victoria.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP). -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner today recommended suspension of previous conditions and establishment of new ones in the acquisition of certain short lines by the New York Central Railroad to unify its system.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "While the London conference was dealing with very real issues, one of the basic problems was not touched," said Dr. Louis I. Dublin on his return from London. "The problem of distribution of population in relation to resources is waiting for solution."

DETROIT, Aug. 5 (AP). -- The Ford Motor Company today announced its return to the five-day, forty-hour week, but at the same time word came from persons close to Henry Ford that he still views the National Recovery Act, to which he has not subscribed, as threatening unionization of all industry.

COLETTE always approaches the subject of love with the skill and authority of a specialist in such matters. In other departments of life she has little to say; she takes no interest in the world, in society, in man's adjustment to his environment.

With the annual bank holiday in Liverpool, the stock exchanges here closed and the first government crop estimate of the 1933 season due on Tuesday, both trading and fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday were the smallest in some time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Soon after his return here by army plane from Hyde Park, where he gave President Roosevelt the terms of the agreements ending the Pennsylvania soft-coal strike. Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, made public the texts of the two agreements.

The latest -- and leading -- "dark horse" for the famed Hambletonian trot is Brown Berry. This speedy trotter, owned by the Lytle Brothers of Plainfield, N.J., gained his new ranking through his spectacular victory in the recent American Stake No. 1 at Rockingham Park.

MARION, Va. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will attend the White Top Mountain Folk Music Festival on Friday and Saturday. The mountain people of Southwest Virginia. East Tennessee and Western North Carolina are all astir over the news.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The Federal Government has made cash advances of $2,819.136,788.92, through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation since that agency began operation on Feb. 2, 1932, according to information made available today by the Corporation.

EVERY so often it seems to happen that the lists become spotted with piano concertos, as though the form was epidemic -- which it probably is. The added comment is not intended in any way to be facetious. Dyed in the wool enthusiasts will remember when disks gave off sounds rather less resembling a piano than do Segovia's guitar records.

NEWPORT -- With the Narra gansett Bay Regatta an the visit of the New York Yacht Club fleet on its annual cruise both on the program for two days each, this is to be yachting week in every sense of the word.

WASHINGTON. WITH the progress of the campaign for national recovery depending in large part upon its directors' knowledge of economic facts, there is now an increasing interest in the many fact-finding agencies already at work in the capital.

GARDEN vases and bird baths, sun dials and sculptured figures are now found as often in backyards and on penthouse roofs as on country lawns. Antique examples bring a halo of romance to modern terraces. They are practically indestructible, and time only adds to them a soft gray patina.

With a bullet hole through the heart, and another just a few inches above it, the body of Henry F. Sanborn, General Eastern Agent of the St. Louis San Francisco Railroad, and a son of the late United States Circuit Judge Walter Henry Sanborn of St. Paul, Minn., was found yesterday in a woodland in Queens near where the Long Island Motor Parkway crosses the North Hempstead Turnpike.

LONDON. THERE new bridges over the Thames at Hampton Court, Chiswick and Twickenham were opened recently by the Prince of Wales, primarily to serve as links in the King's Highway. But besides carrying the road and its far-flung traffic across the river, these bridges pay architectural tribute to their immediate surroundings.

HIGH temperatures put an effective damper on retail trade during the early part of the week. Improvement was noticeable, however, with the arrival of cooler weather, and plans for pushing promotional events during the period directly ahead are now being vigorously developed by the stores.

AN experiment of unpredictable possibilities is now under way at the Dancers' Club, under the sponsorship of the State Education Department and the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration. Here for the first time dancing and allied theatrical subjects are being taught in the adult educational courses conducted by the University of the State of New York for the benefit of the unemployed, without the payment of tuition.

With, the Stock Exchange and other security markets closed, interest was confined yesterday to those commodities in which trading took place and to the movement of foreign exchange. Wall Street operated on about a 50 per cent basis.

Elimination of the present quantity discount system, as applied in the floor coverings industry, and substitution of a one-price sales policy for all retail dealers was urged here yesterday by Henry A. Manz, who for twelve years acted as sales manager for floor coverings manufacturers.

The offer of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York to serve as a clearing house for individual port codes which may be coordinated as a single code for the shipping industry under the National Industrial Recovery Act has been accepted by several branches of the industry and by port groups whose interests will be affected by the government's economic policy.

VOLTAIRE," the new Arliss picture, will be presented to the first-nighters of New York, London and Paris on a particular evening in the not distant future. The Warners presented it informally a fortnight ago at a dinner on board the Ile de France.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The visit of Prince (Ras) Desta Demtu, son-in-law of Emperor Haile Selassie I of Abyssinia, draws attention to that ancient and yet little known empire. Ras Desta made the long voyage from the heart of Africa to Washington for no other purpose than to return officially the visit of the Special Diplomatic Mission which President Hoover dispatched in the Fall of 1930.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- In a tiny Moth airplane, bought second hand more than three years ago, a former Royal Air Force pilot, John Grierson, took off from Brough Airdrome near Hull this morning on the first stage of a solo flight to New York by the North Atlantic route.

With the opening of the new municipal subway this month to Jackson Heights and its eventual completion to Jamaica, Frank Ray Howe, president of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce, predicts that building construction in the areas in Queens served by the new line will duplicate to a large extent, conditions which followed the opening of earlier subway routes in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.

PARIS, Aug. 3. -- The first Winter openings endorse realism. The exaggerated angelic and demoniac trends are both abandoned for more rational human lines. Waists and shoulders are nearly normal. Suits with broad but simple shoulders are in the majority.

WHERE the overland route between Asia and Europe crosses the Amber Road, which connects the South with the Baltic Sea -- there is the heart of old Poland. There the Goths and Vandals, Huns and Magyars did battle, and there the marauding Mongols of Genghis Khan descended on the West, lighting the highway of destruction with flaming peasant huts.

SO much has been written about Mrs. Pat Campbell, noted English actress, and so many legends concerning her personality have spread in the past four decades over two continents that probably she and certainly the representative of this department were somewhat puzzled a few days ago when they came face to face for an interview.

WILL ROGERS and Fred Stone, who have previously substituted for each other before the footlights and the microphone, will make their first joint appearance on Aug. 13. WJZ will be the New York outlet for this broadcast at 9 P.M.
NEW YORK. J. Lorimer Worden who had been at the Pierre, sailed yesterday on the Olympic to join Mrs. Worden in England. They are expected to return early next month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- A general response by Pennsylvania's striking coal miners to the truce announced by President Roosevelt was awaited today by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America. Mr. Lewis called the agreements "temporary," indicating he was ready to fight for union recognition throughout the nation's coal fields.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 5. -- With "The Financial Situation" as its selected theme, the third annual economic conference for engineers will open here next Saturday at the Summer engineering camp of Stevens Institute of Technology.

Governor LEHMAN has shown little interest in plans calling for an increase of the State's debt beyond the proposed $60,000,000 bond issue which is to be submitted to the electorate In November. There is no question of the excellence of the State's credit. But its indebtedness has been increasing for some years at a rate which warrants reluctance to take over responsibilities properly belonging to local governmental units.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 5. -- Henry F. Sanborn was appointed general Eastern agent of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway, with headquarters at New York, on Sept. 15, 1930. He had for several years been general agent for the road at Chicago.
CAPE TOWN, July 7. -- Sensational finds of golden ornaments and other relics of a vanished native race have just been made in the Northern Transvaal at a place called Mapungubwe the Hill of Mystery.

BOSTON, Aug. 2. -- Codes, Nothelse but. All other subjects in New England are incidental, but the codes, blanket and special, are in everybody's mind and questions about them and the possible outcome of the NIRA movement are on everybody's lips.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Aug. 5. -- Howard Schenken and Davis Burnstine made a tremendous score this afternoon in the final round of the masters pair event at the American Bridge League tournament here to repeat the victory they scored two years ago in the annual blue ribbon event for contract pairs.

PARIS, Aug. 5. -- Instructions were sent by the French Foreign Office today to Ambassador Francois-Poncet in Berlin to make verbal representations to Foreign Minister von Neurath concerning Germany's policy toward Austria and the recent Austro-German incidents.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Life imprisonment for two labor terrorists and a sentence of twenty years for the girl companion of one of them were meted out today by a jury which found the three guilty of murder in a verdict returned in Judge Harry B. Miller's court.

HYDK PARK, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- President Roosevelt joined today with leaders of industry and labor in appealing directly to the public to end strikes and lockouts as hindrances to the operation of the national recovery program.
Former Controller Charles L. Craig recommended a program of city taxes and economies, aimed at raising $72,000,000 a year in new revenue, to Governor Lehman and the Legislature yesterday.

THE inclusion of "baby bonds," of $50 denomination, in the Treasury's $500,000,000 issue of Aug. 15, already oversubscribed, marks another attempt to interest the small investor in government securities. Early this Spring New York City put out a tax-anticipation issue to tempt persons of moderate incomes, selling the bonds directly to consumers as a kind of emergency measure when municipal financing was difficult.

THE $20,000 prize offered Jointly by Frederick A. Stokes Company of New York and Hodder A. Stroughton, Ltd., of London, for the best novel in a competition open to all the world, has been won by Janet Beith with her novel entitled "No Second Spring."
ALBANY, Aug. 5. -- As the upState milk strike grew in violence today reports spread that Governor Lehman might call out the National Guard to curb the disorder.

FROM some accounts, the depression has given quite a boost to a sideline of the industry with which comparatively few motor owners are acquainted. One company which makes a business of retreading tires worn threadbare reports a large increase in trade, its operations in the last two years having grown from one to twenty-five plants.
UNITED STATES Coast Guard officials are looking back with pride upon a year's experience with the "flying lifeboat," an amphibian plane specially constructed for deep-sea rescue work.

Signor MUSSOLINI gave a rather contemptuous but characteristic, kick to the World Economic Conference as it lay dying. In an article contributed by him to The Morning Post of London he declared that the Conference was doomed to failure from the start. It was too large.

THE HAGUE, July 19. -- Holland's traditional open-door policy has been the cause of a remarkable prosperity in the Dutch East Indies, but is showing its drawback in the present extraordinary circumstances. Especially in the case of the Japanese the effects of complete freedom of trading and industrial activity are telling seriously on Dutch enterprise.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Taking advantage of the base hits and bases on balls Wild Bill Hallahan yielded liberally, the Cincinnati Reds ended a ten-game losing streak today by defeating the Cardinals 6 to 3, in the first game of a double-header. Then they got the worst of a pitching battle between Vance and Benton, losing the second, 2 to 1.

MISSOURI'S Imposition of the death penalty in a kidnapping case -- the first sentence ot its kind in this country -- serves to recall crimes other than murder that carry, or have carried in the past, a sentence of death. Only eight of the forty-eight States have abolished capital punishment, and these eight have abolished it for a given period, ranging from fifteen to eighty-three years.

MILAN. THE exhibition of architecture and decorative arts, which takes place here every three years, is being held for the fifth time this Summer. The extraordinary contrast that it presents with the dull and traditional 1930 Triennale should prove of exceptional interest to students and critics of modern architecture.

Some time between last Feb. 8, when armed guards left a branch of the postoffice in Varick Street, and Feb. 15, when the liner Leviathan, docked at Southampton, a bag containing $131,000 worth of Kingdom of Italy bonds vanished from the custody of the United States.

WITH the issuance last week of the motor manufacturers' code, submitted through the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce, a basis was provided for development of a comprehensive program affecting the nation's 24,000,000 car owners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 29 amounted to 638,396 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. The total was 10,518 cars or 1.6 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, but 127,293 cars or 24.9 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 123,422 cars or 16.2 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

SANTIAGO, Chill, Aug. 4. -- Firmly denying that the Chilean nitrate of soda industry, backed by the Chilean Government, was responsible for the recent break-up of the Paris negotiations for a European nitrate cartel, the Cosach Nitrate Corporation adds that this country has never adopted a dumping policy, as it was alleged to have done.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Mouette, the 12-meter sloop of Horace Havemeyer, slipped through the waters of Long Island Sound off Execution Light today to win one of the feature events of the annual open races of the Port Washington Yacht Club.

Horace M. Albright, retiring as Director of the National Park Service, has for twenty years had an intimate acquaintance with the wonder spots that have been set aside as national preserves. Here he describes ten of the most beautiful.

WHEN Fanny Burney's little boy Alexander was very young, it is reported of him that he called his nurse a fool. "'My dear,' said his mama, 'you must never call your nurse a fool,' 'Who may I call fool, then?' 'Nobody, my little boy.' 'Why, then, what's the word made for?' said Alex, sharp enough."

The Isthmian Steamship Company has agreed to conform to the terms of the Associated Steamship Lines Conference in the maintenance of rates, rules and practices, although remaining outside conference membership, the Shipping Board has announced.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Hollywood Bowl, noted for Its "symphonies under the stars," was the scene today of Hollywood's latest fisticuffs, with Sir Hamilton Harty, distinguished English conductor, on the receiving end.

WITH the issuance last week of the motor manufacturers' code, submitted through the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce, a basis was provided for development of a comprehensive program affecting the nation's 24,000,000 car owners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on July 29 amounted to 638,396 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. The total was 10,518 cars or 1.6 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, but 127,293 cars or 24.9 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 123,422 cars or 16.2 per cent fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

SANTIAGO, Chill, Aug. 4. -- Firmly denying that the Chilean nitrate of soda industry, backed by the Chilean Government, was responsible for the recent break-up of the Paris negotiations for a European nitrate cartel, the Cosach Nitrate Corporation adds that this country has never adopted a dumping policy, as it was alleged to have done.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 5. -- Mouette, the 12-meter sloop of Horace Havemeyer, slipped through the waters of Long Island Sound off Execution Light today to win one of the feature events of the annual open races of the Port Washington Yacht Club.

Horace M. Albright, retiring as Director of the National Park Service, has for twenty years had an intimate acquaintance with the wonder spots that have been set aside as national preserves. Here he describes ten of the most beautiful.

FOR hundreds of millions of people a general rise in the price of raw materials and agricultural products is urgent. This question affects not only agricultural countries but also great industrial nations who sell a large proportion of their manufactures to agricultural and mining communities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The National Board of Arbitration, approved today by President Roosevelt in a statement issued at his Summer home, was created today by the National Recovery Administration, after several days of conferences of the Industrial and Labor Advisory Boards.

THE discovery of rattlesnakes startled the Bronx recently, the shock giving place to a sense of gratified relief in the community when a professional "snake act" man in a local commercial museum came forward with information that the reptiles had been dead when transported to the scene of the "discovery."

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Aug. 3. -- California bogged down this week under application of a 2 1/2 per cent sales tax and an impending 1 per cent income tax. The Governor may veto the latter. Anyway, he is being importuned from all sections of the State to withhold his signature, and unofficial spokesmen agree that he is not enthusiastic over the measure.

HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 5 (AP). -- Because their work keeps them apart, Adrienne Ames, Paramount featured player, and Stephen Ames, New York stock broker, have agreed on a trial separation. They were married in New York City on Aug. 21, 1929.
GASTONTA, N.C., Aug. 5. -- Whether Clay Fogleman, put to death yesterday for murder, died an innocent man was a puzzling question that remained unanswered tonight.

Ira Rosenstock, a director of the Greater New York Taxpayers Association, has suggested to Mayor O'Brien that the Board of Estimate authorize the issuance of "rent relief certificates" to landlords of residertial properties in return for the rental of apartments to indigent tenants.

The New York Trust Company reported yesterday, after having surveyed international payments made by and to this country, it had reached the conclusion that there was an absence of international factors which might have necessitated abandonment of the gold standard by the United States, and that therefore the step had been taken because of domestic problems.

For the second consecutive week THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has declined, the sharp drop in the cotton forwardings figure being mainly responsible for a loss of almost 4 points in the combined number. For the week ended July 29 the index stood at 92.0, compared with 95.8 in the previous week and 63.9 for the corresponding week of last year.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 5. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs continued on their losing way today when Newark took both ends of a double header, 11 -- 3 and 4 -- 3. The victories ran the Bears' winning streak to eight straight games.

NO. 1 "Abenia," Lake George, New York, July 30th, 1933. Mr. Richard Aldrich, "Rokeby," Barrytown, New York. Dear Mr. Aldrich: I have just learned you are to celebrate your seventieth birthday tomorrow, the 31st.

LONDON, July 21. WHAT would otherwise have been a blank interval in theatrical activity has been given interest by a sudden swerving of fashion toward ballet and by a new play of Mr. A.A. Milne's. Soon we shall be occupied by the Malvern and Canterbury Festivals; then, settling down in London again, shall watch the new season begin.

It might have seemed madness a few years ago to propose continuance of school into the hot months. Now the Summer session in colleges and universities has become customary. New York is almost as much of an educational centre in August as in midwinter. And the student life is more like that of the medieval universities when with the greater freedom and informality there is also the greater intellectual seriousness.

Because of quota restrictions the United States has no immigration problem today, Harold Fields, executive director of the National League for American Citizenship, writes in an article in the current issue of The South Atlantic Quarterly.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 5. -- Pilgrim trains from all parts of Belgium rolled steadily all day into the town of Beauraing where miraculous appearances of the Virgin were reported to have occurred. Thousands of others arrive daily by bus and private automobiles.

LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 6.-- Coincident with the opening of Great Britain's Navy Week yesterday it was learned that the First Lord of the Admiralty, Sir Bolton EyresMonsell, intends to propose big extensions in the Royal Navy in estimates now being prepared for the next budget, according to The Sunday Dispatch.

COLLEEN MOORE is to the cinema what the aficionado is to the Spanish bull ring, she confessed at the Sherry-Netherland on one of last week's hotter afternoons. During the four years of her absence from Hollywood, she has not lost her passion for pictures.

LONDON, July 27. -- The splendid performance of General Balbo's air armada on its flight to America will have the result of speeding up the new naval policy of Great Britain. The Italian achievement shows that no time is to be lost in placing the British naval forces upon a new footing.

THE extreme length of line which Edgar Lee Masters has adopted for much of the work contained in this volume, while making quotation within the confines of a newspaper column generally impractical, lends adornment to the page selected for this limited edition.

Moscow. IN attempting to estimate the Soviet view of events in the United States one is confronted by a number of difficulties that would not arise in the case of other countries. The correctness and interest, say, of French or British judgment of American affairs would depend chiefly upon the extent and accuracy of the Frenchman's or Englishman's Knowledge of America.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 2. -- When Gen. Hugh S. Johnson remarked in "Washington last week-end that Cleveland, its Mayor and its citizens were genuinely enthusiastic over NTRA he gave the Great Lakes industrial capital some deserved advertising.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 3. -- Throughout the Tobacco Belt in Southeast Georgia this week the voice of the tobacco auctioneer has been making a very cheerful sound. The tobacco markets throughout this part of Georgia opened on Tuesday, Aug. 1, and since that day there have been daily auctions at Statesboro, Waycross, Blackshear, Douglas, Adel, Fitzgerald, Hazlehurst, Metter and other points that have tobacco warehouses.

The voluntary response or business executives to the dictates of the National Industrial Recovery Act is a stupendous exhibition of concomitant effort. While the effectiveness of the effort is largely dependent upon a concert of action in the various branches of industrial and commercial activities, there are certain collateral factors, the influence of which will signally affect the outcome of the recovery program.

To a correspondent who attributes himself to Nashville The New Republic permits liberties that must pain and anger some of our most treasured literary sandwich-men. This mischievous person is glad that communism is dying rapidly; sad because our literary gents, who have a genius for attaching themselves to moribund parties, will make a tiresome hullabaloo for months.

THE Great Wall of India is not, says Ian Hay, such a wall as that famous stone structure the Chinese built centuries ago, nor such a wall as the Romans would have bullt, "with a continuous city of soldiers and camp followers along its entire length on one side and a wide strip of carefully maintained desolation on the other.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 5. -- Although trotting much slower than in his previous starts at Rockingham. Calumet Desmond, 3-year-old brown colt owned by M.B. Dodd of Winsted, Conn., today registered a decisive triumph over eight rivals, including a few candidates for the $50,000 Hambletonian Stake, in the Rotary International $1,000 event.

The sharp rise in general business activity, and particularly in textile activity, is "totally unjustified by even the most optimistic hopes for an effective consumer demand to absorb these goods in the near period ahead." according to the current issue of the Textile Organon, published yesterday by the Tubize-Chatillon Corporation.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 5. -- The value of metallic minerals produced in British Columbia in the first half of 1933 was 13.4 per cent less than in the first half of 1932, according to a summary issued by British Columbia's Minister of Mines. It is estimated at $12,407,984, compared with $14,336,060 the year before.

While the effectiveness of the effort is largely dependent upon a concert of action in the various branches of industrial and commercial activities, there are certain collateral factors, the influence of which will signally affect the outcome of the recovery program.

This mischievous person is glad that communism is dying rapidly; sad because our literary gents, who have a genius for attaching themselves to moribund parties, will make a tiresome hullabaloo for months.

THE Great Wall of India is not, says Ian Hay, such a wall as that famous stone structure the Chinese built centuries ago, nor such a wall as the Romans would have bullt, "with a continuous city of soldiers and camp followers along its entire length on one side and a wide strip of carefully maintained desolation on the other.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 5. -- Although trotting much slower than in his previous starts at Rockingham. Calumet Desmond, 3-year-old brown colt owned by M.B. Dodd of Winsted, Conn., today registered a decisive triumph over eight rivals, including a few candidates for the $50,000 Hambletonian Stake, in the Rotary International $1,000 event.

GANANOQUE, Ont., Aug. 5 (AP). -- The arrest of Gordon Dignem, native of Wolff Island, on a charge of sending a threatening letter to Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge, wife of a New York financier, with the ostensible purpose of attempting to extort money from her, was revealed here today by Ontario provincial police.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 5. -- House parties and a large number of dinners have made this a notable week-end in the Newport Summer colony.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Yachts of all sizes, ranging from sleek sloops to large schooners, began gathering here today for the racing runs to the eastward that start tomorrow and will last two weeks. As craft after craft came to anchor for the night, there promised to be the largest assemblage of the kind in years.

Charles C. Burlingham, chairman of the harmony committee which brought about the designation of Major F.H. La Guardia as the fusion nominee for Mayor, will call another conference for Tuesday to complete the city ticket. Candidates for Controller and President of the Board of Adermen will be named then.

After three weeks operation of the cotton textile code of fair competition, the most significant development is the registration of actual complaints of violations against only seven of the 1,200 cotton mills in the country, according to opinions expressed here yesterday by leading executives.

EVERY now and again it is apparent that it is a wise idea to have the author take a hand in the filming of his story. Undoubtedly there are writers who are too exacting to be helpful, but in the majority of cases a narrative turned into a screen script by the author is endowed with far greater freshness, intelligence and smoothness than if it were entrusted to some studio experts.

NORTH SUTTON, N.H., Aug. 5. -- A Summer camp for girls, near here, was put under a strong guard of National Guardsmen, police and Sheriff's deputies today as a result of a threat to kidnap one of the camp girls.

AIDED by a transportation expert who made his report to Congressman James M. Mead, chairman of the House Committee on Postoffices and Post Roads, Congress is preparing once more to amend the Air Mail Bill and to change drastically the air mail set-up as built so expeditiously by former Postmaster General Walter F. Brown.

New plays are again being shown at a good many of the Summer -- and the country -- theatres. The current week finds about a baker's dozen of them being listed for world premieres at points along the Atlantic coast. Those theatres which do not offer the new drama are contenting themselves with revivals of the old, the subject matter being mainly the Broadway successes of the last two or three years.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- In an exciting finish, with the first and second place boats separated by a mere second, Themis II captured the Star Class race off here today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- Paul Maxin, alias J. Paul Faraday, as gentle a convict as ever walked away from a State prison, sat calmly in the Detective Bureau last night after he was arrested in the offices of the Reardon Paint Company, where he was advertising manager.
Eight persons were killed and about twenty injured in automobile accidents in or near New York yesterday.

The article in yesterday's TIMES by President ARTHUR E. MORGAN, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, tells of the human side of the enterprise. The engineering side of it is in competent hands. But the expert engineer, who is acquainted with the behavior of the crust of the earth, is no less an authority on human habits and relations.

LEWISTOWN, Pa., Aug. 6 (AP). -- The Lewistown plant of the Viscose Company has posted notices announcing that 600 more men will be added to the payroll tomorrow in compliance with the rayon code. The local plant, which now employs 4,000, added 270 during the last two weeks.

BERLIN. Aug. 6. -- Despite the handicap of a heavy cold, Glenn Cunningham, great middle distance runner from Kansas, defeated Erik Ny of Sweden and Dr. Otto Peltzer of Germany in near-record time over the 1,000-meter route today.

A proposed code for the architectural profession supplementing that drawn for the building industry in general has been adopted by the American Institute of Architects and is now before General Hugh Johnson for his approval. Details of the proposed rules of fair practice under which architects are to work are contained in the current release of the Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

BERLIN, Aug. 5. -- The Reichsbank's new policy of replenishing reserves at the cost of transfer of amortization bonds thus far has met with success. In June, the first month of the reduced transfer, reserves rose from 274,000,000 to 323,000,000 marks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A change of administration at Washington brings about a revaluation of the national position in its relations with debtor countries and in some cases a revision by those countries of their foreign and domestic policies.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Aug. 6. -- There was a decided falling off last week in trading on the Cotton Exchange here. Prices fluctuated nervously, but considering the great volume of liquidation and the frequent stop-loss orders uncovered, the market developed much sustaining power.

An expert bit of relief hurling by George Uhle aided no little yesterday in a Yankee triumph at the Stadium that was sorely needed. For while the McCarthymen were downing the Red Sox, 5 to 4, before 15,000 fans, the Athletics were taking the Senators into camp.

Integrity of leadership and freedom from that moral cynicism which is "so easy to give way to" are the only forces that can rid New York City voters of the "inept and fumbling regime of Tammany Hall," the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie, rector of Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- A rush of business interests, ranging from small retail establishments to large manufacturing corporations, to sign the code presented by the National Recovery Administration was the feature in this district last week. Some 50,000 concerns signed the agreement to increase operations, employes and wages.
Bill Terry's Giants went down to defeat in the first game at Ebbets Field yesterday by 6 to 3, but managed to conquer the Dodgers in the nightcap, 3 to 2.

KOENIGSBERG, East Prussia, Aug. 6. -- The virtual abolition of unemployment in this province, hailed by the Nazis as "the miracle of East Prussia," is accomplished by a veiled conscription of labor and capital. It is made possible only by the dictatorial powers possessed by the Nazis and propaganda like governments use to win support in times of war.

Overcoming a three-goal handicap, the Governors Island polo team triumphed over the First Division quartet by 11 to 10 on the latter's field in Brooklyn yesterday. A crowd of 3,000 witnessed the game, which was played at a fast pace.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Should not all codes which are drawn in the future stipulate that members of the NRA code groups are to deal only with each other? This seems necessary in view of the opinion of Donald Richberg, general counsel to the NRA, that inevitably there will be a 10 per cent minimum, of slackers.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 6. -- A vigorous first-half attack that piled up a total of 11 goals before half-time carried the White polo team to victory at Sands Point today, 13 to 7.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The appointment of a Presidential board of seven to mediate industrial disputes on a national basis opens the way for the next step -- establishment of a federation of industries which shall be co-extensive with a superfederation of labor.

American industry has been cooperating in setting up the National Industry Recovery Act to a degree never before known in this country save in the two years of our participation in the World War. It has united in this cooperation despite the fact that in its ranks there is a difference of opinion concerning the wisdom and the probable results of NRA.
Samuel Untermyer, leader in the Jewish boycott against Germany, returned yesterday on the French liner Paris to the accompaniment of an enthusiastic harbor welcome.

BOSTON, Aug. 6 (AP). -- In two pitchers' battles before a crowd of 28,000, the Braves and the Phillies broke even today. The visitors took the first game, 1 to 0, and Boston came back to win the second, 2 to 1, in ten innings.

PARIS, Aug. 5. -- For the time being the French Treasury's position is very favorable. Direct tax collections begun in July and the loan of 2,000,000,000 francs issued by the French Government met with complete success.

Under the rehabilitation plan o George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, the New York Title Insurance Company, formed last week to take over the assets of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, will not undertake any form of guaranteed mortgage business.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6. -- Discovery near Clovis, N.M., of authoritative evidence supporting the theory that prehistoric man hunted the mammoth, camel, musk-ox, horse and an extinct type of bison in America was reported jointly tonight by the University of Pennsylvania Museum and the Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences.

The "mobilization" of more than 5,000,000 high school and junior college students in the country into a volunteer auxiliary corps to carry the principles of President Roosevelt's recovery program into practically every home was urged in a resolution submitted yesterday to the National Committee on the Emergency in Education.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Aug. 6. -- Desperate last-minute efforts to ward off the threatened reopening of the labor war in the Western Pennsylvania soft coal mine fields, with the threat of more bloodshed, were partly successful tonight.

PARIS, Aug. 5. -- Contradictory information has been published lately about President Roosevelt's views, but financial circles believe that the United States Government will pursue the inflationary program which has been drawn up and that in consequence further decrease in the dollar is possible.

Dvorak's "Symphony From the New World" and a group of compositions by Johann Strauss, including the overture to the "Gypsy Baron"; three waltzes, "The Emperor," "Perpetual Motion" and "Tales From the Vienna Woods," and the overture to "Die Fledermaus," will be presented at tonight's concert in the Lewisohn Stadium by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra.

Agreement in the shipping industry with respect to the adoption of a code of ethics for shipowners and their employes was further delayed yesterday when leaders of maritime labor indicated that they would oppose any move to have the Shipping Board named coordinator of shipping.

Mary Van Kleeck, director of the department of industrial studies of the Russell Sage Foundation, addressed a telegram yesterday to Secretary of Labor Perkins, canceling her acceptance of membership in the Federal Advisory Council of the United States Employment Service and protesting the labor policy of the national administration.

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, in a formal statement issued yesterday, attacked the additional sales tax and stock transfer tax proposed by Tammany as additional sources of city revenue.

General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, in a letter to the Lebanon Shirt Company, made public yesterday by Ferdinand Pecora, the company's attorney, expressed himself as being fully satisfied that the concern's premature use of the NRA emblem "did not proceed from an intention to disregard the letter of the law."

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- Although now firmly in the grip of the slack holiday period, the stock markets are showing a confidence which is very encouraging. It says much for the sound technical condition of the markets that they were only temporarily and never dangerously affected by Wall Street's recent break.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 6. -- Many entertainments were given today throughout the colony for tennis week guests. Mr. and Mrs. Carll Tucker of Penwood, Mount Kisco, N.Y., gave a luncheon today on board their yacht. Migrant, which is anchored off the Sebonac Yacht Club.

One of five young men who were thrown headlong into Long Island Sound when their small sloop capsized in a gust of wind at daybreak yesterday lost his life battling a choppy sea near the Middle Ground Light.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., Aug. 6. -- The 12-meter Cantitoe, owned by Van S. Merle-Smith, defeated seventeen rival craft of the racing division as the American Yacht Club completed the first run of its annual cruise tonight.

Movements of prices in local commodity markets last week were irregular. Early in the week, most staples recovered part of their preceding losses, but later many of these gains were wiped out. Only silver and crude rubber closed higher.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May we call the attention of the readers of your paper to the Summer activities of the New York Association for the Blind?

"In civilized lands we lose all sense of the value and beauty of human life when we see it in crowds," the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Church in America, declared yesterday afternoon over WEAF in a coast-to-coast broadcast.

Rallying to win the first game and leading throughout the second, the New York Police Department baseball team captured a benefit doubleheader from the Black Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The scores were 5 to 3 and 7 to 3.

Cure by Hush. Deep rooted in the heart of man is the belief that the way to make things all right is to keep them out of the papers. The Secretary of the Broadway Association scolds the press for reporting the recent heat wave.

ANGMAGSALIK, Greenland, Aug. 6. -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh arrived here unexpectedly late this afternoon after a 700-mile flight from Clavering Island, northward on the eastern coast, where they had spent the last two days with the Danish explorer, Dr. Lauge Koch.
PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 6 -- The tennis tournament ball at the Wyantenuck Country Club in Great Barrington last night brought out a company of two hundred from the South Berkshire colonies.
