CINCINNATI, Aug. 6 (AP). -- The Reds bounced back out of the National League cellar today by handing the Cardinals a double defeat in extra-inning games, 2 to 1 and 1 to 0. They advanced to seventh place, ousting the Dodgers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Disquieting reports from the Pennsylvania soft coal districts that miners were delaying acceptance of...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP). -- The Senators lost ground in the American League race by bowing to the Athletics, 12 to 8, today while the Yankees were winning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Gatherings like the world conference of Boy Scourt leaders, which opens at Godollo, Hungary, tomorrow, were characterized today by President Roosevelt as among "the most important contributions to world peace that have ever been developed."
NEW YORK. Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas Murray Butler are expected today from Southampton at the Ritz-Carlton.

Gains in governmental revenue of more than $1,250,000,000 and the creation of 650,000 new jobs were forecast as a result of prohibition repeal in a survey made public yesterday by the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform.

The sunny walks in Bronx Park were filled yesterday with men, women and children scurrying to the Botanical Gardens. Their objective was the century plant, which, according to the best information, was due to bloom.

The special session of the Legislature gives an opportunity to the city to offer a plan for cutting the costs of municipal government, Peter Grimm, chairman of the board of trustees of the Citizens Budget Commission, declared yesterday.

Creation of an "American Scotland Yard" with a national police force for the control of racketeering and attendant crimes is proposed to the Federal Bar Association in a report submitted by its anti-racketeering committee.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- The American situation is too bewildering to admit of clear judgment, but It is obvious that international currency stability cannot be achieved until the United States is through with its program.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 6. -- The rate of steel production, having leveled off three weeks ago after a sharp rise, began last week to decrease, and the trade expects the decline to continue until some new influence arises. The American Metal Market estimated production of steel ingots last week at 58 per cent of capacity, compared with 59 per cent in the two preceding weeks, when the highest level of the movement was attained.

ALBANY, Aug. 6. -- Preparations were being completed tonight by returning legislators for the public hearing Tuesday on measures sought by the New York City administration to permit levying new taxes for unemployment relief.

BLUFF POINT, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- George J. Gillespie Jr., of the Oakland Golf Club, Bayside, L.I., won the first annual invitation tournament at the Lake Champlain Country Club today, when he defeated Jack Cameron of Toronto, the medalist, 3 and 2.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP). -- The Chicago Cubs combined a six-hit pitching performance by Pat Malone with an uprising against Steve Swetonic in the fifth inning today to shut out the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6 to 0, and even the series.
Following is the text of Samuel Untermyer's address last nigh over Station WABC after his return from Europe:

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- The C.V. Whitney stables are located among the fine old elms beyond the backstretch of the main track. Seated on the porch of his little cottage, Trainer Tom Healey can look across a narrow strip of lawn and see peering out from his stall a dark chestnut horse with a narrow white stripe down his face. That's the top horse of the turf today: Equipoise.

YELLOWSTONE PARK, Wyo., Aug. 6. -- A committee of five United States Senators, under the chairmanship of Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota, halted here today on their way to the Jackson Hole country where tomorrow they will start a park land inquiry.
George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, listed the achievements of his office in the year ended June 30 in his annual report, made public yesterday.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- President Roosevelt in conference with Secretary of State Hull today closed the first chapter of the London Economic Conference and turned the eyes of his administration's foreign policy toward South America.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 6. (AP). -- The Maple Leafs snapped the winning streak of the Bears today when Buck Marrow out-pitched Don Brennan, 1 -- 0, in the seveninning nightcap, after Newark had come from behind to take the opener, 7 to 5, for their ninth straight.
Following is the text of the compromise code for the coat and suit industry as finally approved by the National Recovery Administration:

HAVANA, Aug. 6. -- With strikes in Cuba still spreading, President Machado called a special session of Congress for 3 P.M. tomorrow to obtain authority to place the republic again under military rule.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 6. -- Garden plots of 50 by 100 feet, farmed by 965 families whose bread-winners were otherwise unemployed, each produced an average of $137.14 worth of vegetables this Summer, it was shown in a report made public today by Robert H.G. Pederson of the Nassau County Emergency Work Bureau.

DEAL, N.J., Aug. 6. -- By the slender margin of 300 points the contract bridge foursome of Howard Schenken, Richard L. Frey, Oswald Jacoby and David Burnstine won the national challenge team-of-four championship here today.

H.G. Wells has written another "outline." In his "Shape of Things to Come," to be published early in September by MacMillan, Mr. Wells outlines what he conceives as the history of the next century and a half. He forecasts that wars will be followed eventually by a world State.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 6. -- Alfred V. Leaman Jr., socially prominent New York commission merchant, and Mrs. Laurice White Page, wife of Seymour Page of 1,049 Park Avenue, New York, were instantly killed early today when a car in which they were returning from a supper party at the Montauk Island Club sidewiped another car on the Montauk Highway and overturned.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 (AP). -- After the Browns forced the first game to eleven innings before they yielded to the White Sox, 6 to 5, today, George Blaeholder held the visitors to four hits and won the nightcap, 7 -- 1.

The drive to enlist 500,000 employers in this State and city under the NRA and the President's reemployment agreement and find jobs for hundreds of thousands of workers will be launched here today from campaign headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, Aug. 6. -- The efficiency of the suction method of salvaging has been proved for the first time during the latest operations of the Italian salvage ship Artiglio in raising scattered coins and other bits of metal from the wreck of the sunken liner Egypt.

NORTH BUTTON, N.H., Aug. 6. -- Divided into three shifts of twenty-five men each, a combined force of National Guardsmen, Sheriff's deputies. State police and Federal agents continued a night and day guard at Camp Buena on Kezar Lake here.

GARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Professor Henry Fairfield Osborn philosophized on what in his opinion constitutes a useful and contented life today on his estate here as he prepared for his seventy-sixth birthday, which will be celebrated Tuesday.
Mike Zarrill conquered Ted Crabtree to gain the quarter-finals in the Staten Island men's singles tennis championship tourney at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, yesterday. The score was 6-4, 6-4.

ST. JOHNSVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 6 (AP). -- State Troopers tonight threw a guard about the home of Arthur Galusha, a farmer, who said milk pickets had threatened to lynch him because he drove a dairy truck into the village today.

An unusual batting streak by the Brooklyn Cricket Club against the Staten Island bowlers enabled the former to win their match in the annual series of the Metropolitan and New Jersey Cricket Association at Livingston, S.I., yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP). -- Howard La Brant of the Columbia Club, Chicago, today won the national single-blade championship in the opening program of the American Canoe Association annual regatta.

UTICA, Aug. 6 (AP). -- Trouble at Waterville, eight miles from Utica, sent troopers and Deputy Sheriffs there this morning to find 500 farmers assembled about a Borden Company plant. They agreed to disperse after they obtained assurance that the plant would not obtain milk during the day.

A group of 239 French veterans with 100 of their wives and woman relatives arrived here late yesterday afternoon on the Paris to return the visit which the American Legion made to France in 1927. They were welcomed at the pier and at a dinner in the Hotel Pennsylvania given last night by Louis Johnson, National Commander of the Legion.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Colonel Martin L. Crimmins, retired, of New York, one of the most noted herpetologists of the country, was struck by a poisonous cottonmouth snake here tonight just prior to a lecture he was to have given on "Snakebites and Their Treatment."

A proposed marketing agreement and code of fair competition has been filed with the Secretary of Agriculture by the cane sugar refining industry, it was announced yesterday from the office of the American Sugar Refining Company.

BERLIN, Aug. 6. -- Eighty thousand Nazi storm troopers paraded before Captain Ernst Roehm, their chief of staff, on Tempelhof Field today and heard him hurl defiance at National Socialism's critics abroad.

Watching Jack Holt being broken on the wheel of a woman's infidelity is as unpleasant a pastime as watching a Hercules weeping over a torn fingernail. In "The Wrecker" Mr. Holt starts out with that exuberant confidence and audacity which make him one of the cinema's greatest vicarious satisfactions.

They have known duller Sundays down at the county jail at 434 West Thirty-seventh Street than yesterday turned out to be. The inmates of the jail, who call themselves, unofficially, the Alimony Club, and take pride in maintaining a rather exclusive atmosphere, are only thirty-three in number.

TOKYO, Aug. 6. -- Nine million persons in and around Tokyo have been successfully innoculated with the idea that their homes are exposed to aerial attacks. Each night for the past ten days district after district has rehearsed the air defense measures which will be put in practice during the grand manoeuvres of the navy in the coming week.

Violent methods can effect no permanent cure of conditions in India, according to Dr. H.C.E. Zacharias, whose book, "Renascent India," has been published by E.P. Dutton Co., Inc. The author has spent the greater part of his life in the East, was attached to the Servants of India Society in Poona, and now is lecturing on modern Indian history at the Catholic University at Lille, France.

The executive committee of the Citizens Union issued yesterday a statement urging the political parties to join in the renomination of three judges. They are Justice Philip J. McCook of the Supreme Court, First District; Surrogate James A. Foley of New York County and Justice William Chilvera of the Ninth District Municipal Court, Manhattan.

INDIAN LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Indignant residents of the Adirondacks will renew their appeal to Governor Lehman early this week to take some action to restrain the power companies from drawing heavily on many picturesque lakes of the Adirondack State Reservation at the height of the vacation season.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6. -- With the revelation that kidnappers had demanded $15,000 from James R. Downes, Pennsylvania Railroad executive, as the price of his daughter's safety at a girl's camp at North Sutton, N.H., Department of Justice agents and Pennsylvania police today joined New England police in a search for the extortionists.

With the markets more or less subdued as a result of various restrictions, the financial community had an opportunity last week to appraise industrial and trade conditions with a greater degree of detachment than at any time previously this Summer.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- Corn specialists predict a smaller crop this year, the effect of which is somewhat modified as a market influence by the large visible supply, which is said to be the greatest on record, being 60,731,000 bushels, virtually 50,000,000 bushels more than a year ago.

The Department of Agriculture will publish tomorrow its first estimate of the condition and indicated yield per acre of the new cotton crop. It will be possible then to judge now much help the boll weevil is giving Secretary WALLACE in his effort to destroy part of this year's harvest in order to enhance the value of the remainder.

Amy Johnson Mollison will be the guest today of the women pilots of the 99 Club at a luncheon to be given at the Long Island Aviation Country Club at Hicksville, L.I. Miss Amelia Earhart, national president of the club, said last night that about thirty members from the Eastern States would be present.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- With a change in encampment of New York National Guardsmen at the various camps, 5,000 men were in motion over the week-end, with Camp Smith, here, the only large headquarters left open for training. Pine Camp was closed for the season yesterday with the departure of the 105th Field Artillery of the Bronx and Brooklyn, commanded by Colonel Clarence H. Higginson.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP). -- Special boards of review set up to pass upon cases of war veterans' presumptive service disability were directed today by Frank T. Hines, veterans' administrator, not to "allow their personal feelings to intrude."

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 6. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 70.6, which compares with 69.6 a week ago, 70.4 two weeks ago, 68.8 three Weeks ago and 66.6 four weeks ago. The present average is the highest of the year to date; the average of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: When, some time ago, I expressed my misgivings on the administration's proposal to include a large program of naval building in its public works budget, I had no idea that I would so soon read in THE NEW YORK TIMES that Japan is planning to offset our project with bigger and better battleship-building of her own.
WASHINGTON , Aug. 6. -- Hearings on two codes of fair competition will open at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning before deputy administrators of the National Recovery Administration.

The battle of the present generation to recover the spiritual life was discussed yesterday morning in the James Memorial Chapel of Union Theological Seminary, 120th Street and Broadway, by the Rev. Dr. Robert Russell Wicks, dean of the chapel of Princeton University.

Sportsmen are much interested in big game fishing because it furnishes thrills which, they claim, can not be equaled by any other sport. Likewise, the recent effort to introduce the bow and arrow as a means for taking the big broadbills has aroused much interest.
"The Pirates of Penzance" will be revived tonight, for a week's engagement at the Majestic Theatre. Another revival opening this evening as that of "Tommy," which takes place at the Forrest Theatre.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Shotguns and rifles barked today as strikers and non-strikers clashed on the fourth day of the milk war in the Rochester area, marking the most serious outbreak since the opening of hostilities. One man was wounded and two women were beaten.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- Traders in grain have experienced two weeks of price restrictions on the Board of Trade and are beginning to chafe under them, as they believe that liquidation, which required the fixing of the restrictions, is about ended and the markets would do better were they to act on the daily run of news, which in the main has been extremely bullish, with indications of a continuance.
PARIS, Monday, Aug. 7. -- Lieutenant Maurice Rossi and Paul Codos passed over Le Bourget air field at 8:30 last evening...
The American Museum of Natural History would like it to become generally known that the museum is not in the market for specimens of the Chinese mantis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Urging the country to buy now, to buy for re-employment and to buy because prices would soon go higher, Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, spoke by telephone today to a public rally held in Cleveland under the auspices of Mayor Ray Miller and his local NRA committee.

Demand for ready-to-wear in the wholesale apparel markets dropped off last week and orders were confined mainly to current fashion merchandise. At the second openings by the French couturiers, the trend to the modes of the Nineties was further confirmed.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 6. -- The re-sail of the Eastern Yacht Club's first mid-Summer race by the classes which hunted vainly for the wandering buoy yesterday, and the regular Sunday regatta were held today. In addition there were the Guy Lowell Memorial Cup races, the annual junior regatta of the Pleon Yacht Club and the annual lightship race of the Boston Yacht Club.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 6. -- Two hundred journalists are registered as attending the present Salzburg Festival. Some are critics who come every year to write about the operas, concerts or dramatic productions, all of which have European fame of long standing.
Another murder mystery confronted the police yesterday, after the discovery on Saturday of the body of Henry F. Sanborn, railway executive, buried in a wooded section of Bayside, Queens.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 6. -- President Salamanca, in a message to Congress today, declared that Bolivia must continue the Chaco war until a "reasonable peace" had been obtained and that it would be a mistake to cease hostilities now only to reinstitute them later.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Urging the country to buy now, to buy for re-employment and to buy because prices would soon go higher, Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, spoke by telephone today to a public rally held in Cleveland under the auspices of Mayor Ray Miller and his local NRA committee.

Former Governor James M. Cox, a delegate to the London conference, will return today on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Lucrezia Bori of the Metropolitan Opera, Orestes Ferrcra, Secretary of State of Cuba; J.E. Dockendorf, president of the Black Diamond Steamship Line; Cass Canfield, president of Harper's magazine, and C.T.I. Roark, polo player, are among the other passengers on the Europa.

Integrity of character is an essential of "the durable satisfactions of life," which cannot be enjoyed in their deepest sense without religious faith, said the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon yesterday at Riverside Church.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 6. -- Miss Hope Kingsley, who with her mother, Mrs. Darwin P. Kingsley, is spending the Summer at the Maidstone Inn, gave a garden party and tea there this afternoon for her sister, Mrs. Ralph H. Boots, and Dr. Boots of New York, who are visiting here for two weeks.

By what name of glory or affection shall we salute our polyonymous old friend, Governor MURRAY, a beloved guest and no stranger within the gates of Manhattan last week? Be he welcome by whatever name he will: Sage of Tishomingo, Alfalfa BILL, Cocklebur BiLL, Mussolini -- a little flattened out -- of Oklahoma.
An odd accident on the Hudson electric division of the New York Central Railroad at 225th Street yesterday afternoon added a touch of novelty to traveling for many passengers on trains from the West.

Nothing could have brought the President greater cheer than the pledgee of loyalty to him made to the National Commander of the American Legion. The "battle order" sent out to more than ten thousand posts of the Legion called upon all the members to stand by the President in his fight to bring back contentment and plenty to "millions of American homes."

Organization Republican opposition to the plan of the fusionists to name candidates for borough and county offices developed yesterday. This was particularly evident in regard to the suggestion that United States Attorney George Z. Medalie might be named as the fusion candidate for District Attorney of New York County.

An editorial in the current issue of the Witness, national weekly of the Protestant Episcopal Church, urges the churches to refrain from becoming "ballyhoo agents" for the Roosevelt administration's national recovery campaign.

Junior campers in the vicinity of Wonalancet, N.H., will hear an address by Sir Wilfred Grenfell on the afternoon of Aug. 15 at Chinook Kennels, Wonalancet, in a program arranged under the auspices of the Grenfell Association of America, Inc., and in the interests of Labrador relief work.
DETROIT, Aug. 6 (AP). -- The Tigers won a double-header from Cleveland today, 7 to 3 and 2 to 1, thereby climbing into the first division and shoving the Indians back into fifth place.
For the second day in succession Jersey City and Rochester broke even in a double-header yesterday at Jersey City. The Red Wings triumphed, 4 to 1, after which Jersey City won, 4 to 2.

There is many a good laugh in the picture, "Her Bodyguard," which is now on exhibition at the Paramount. The actual plot may be shallow and unimportant, but the variety of cheery incidents makes for a capital warm-weather entertainment.

The compromise code for the cloak and suit industry, as finally approved by the National Recovery Administration in Washington, goes into effect today. It affects 31,000 workers, 25,000 of them in New York City.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- General Johnson, in a message to the Indiana Retail Grocers Association today, said that "in several local communities, retailers are making joint agreements to shorten hours."
CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- The desirable ratio of the production of corn to that of hogs is giving farmers, packers and the United States Department of Agriculture much trouble.
Deals announced in New Jersey over the week-end included several resales of properties. Housing sales dominated the trading.

PARIS, Aug. 6. -- It was confirmed here today that the French and British Ambassadors yesterday failed to present their identical remonstrance to the German Foreign Office against Nazi hostility to Austria, but it was said the protest would be made tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Employers with government contracts should not be penalized because they have increased wages and decreased hours. President Roosevelt declared tonight in a statement. He said he would recommend that adjustments be made in view of the increased costs resulting from the subscribing of employers to codes of fair competition or to the President's agreement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Another board of economists and college professors has been set up through the Influence of the Rockefeller Fund to study the administration's farm relief policy. Apcording to officials of the Department of Agriculture, two economists formerly connected with the old Farm Board, Professors Joseph S. Davis and John D. Black, working with the Brookings Institution, are now engaged in a study of the operations of the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

One-quarter of the retail sales within New York State in 1932 were made on Long Island, according to an anlysis of commercial conditions completed by the Long Island Chamber of Commerce and made public yesterday. The analysis also shows that the area now has more than one-quarter of the spendable money available in the State.

PARIS, Aug. 6. -- Jean Patou, in his Fall and Winter fashion exhibition, creates a novel version of the 1880 movement with a plain sheath dress front, covering without concealing the figure and concentrating interest in the skirt back.
Balmy weather, cloudless skies and a warm south wind drew large crowds to the beaches in and near the city yesterday. No attendance records were endangered, but every beach was thronged.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Equipoise, the C.V. Whitney champion, which has won $297,170, will this week begin the training drive which is likely to make him the second largest money winner in the world in three more starts.

Elisha Lee, vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad and Federal Manager of the road's Eastern lines under the United States Railroad Administration during the war was stricken with apoplexy while crossing the New York Central Railroad tracks at Ninety-sixth Street and the Hudson River last night, and died almost immediately.
MOSCOW, Aug. 6. -- Representative William I. Sirovich of New York, visiting Soviet Russia again after two years, finds great improvement everywhere.

The situation among the sword fishermen of the metropolitan district has taken on a somewhat brighter aspect in the last forty-eight hours, but it cannot be said that the sportsmen are filled with great hopes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Rayak, the terminus of the longest nonstop flight, the National Geographic Society said today, is an important Syrian railroad junction situated in a highland valley between the Liban (Lebanon) and Anti-Liban Mountains.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Hearing on a basic code of fair competition for the lime industry will open tomorrow at 10 A.M. in the Garden Room of the Hotel Mayflower before Malcolm Muir, Deputy National Recovery Administrator.

PLATTSBURG, Aug. 7. -- The first week of training and spirited activity over, young men of the Citizens Military Training Camp who are quartered here for thirty days' instruction received more advanced tutelage today in close order and gun drills.

ANGMAGSALIK, Greenland, Aug. 7. -- Today Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh rested, probably because of bad weather, rain and fog. However, as soon as the weather improves, the flight to Reykjavik, Iceland, will be made.

John McArdle, local organizer and international president of the Newspaper Mailers Union, died of a heart attack on Sunday night at Mountain Lake, N.J., where he was spending the week-end with his family. He was 62 years old.

NORTH SUTTON, N.H., Aug. 7. -- Camp Bueno, from which criminals have threatened to kidnap Miss Betty Downes of Philadelphia, 15-year-old daughter of James R. Downes, freight traffic chief of the Pennsylvania Railroad, continued to enjoy security today under a heavy guard of National Guardsmen, Sheriff's deputies and State police.

To the Editor of The New York times: Let's look this ghost-writing animal straight in the face. Is he a friend or foe of the writing profession? One thing sure -- he is not a friend of the reading public, for his motive is one of deceit, and nothing built on misrepresentation is constructive.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Opening a new phase of the government's anti-crime campaign, high government official today started a series of conferences at the call of Raymond Moley to seek ways of unifying Federal and State activities.

EAST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 7. -- Two armed robbers entered the Old Bavaria, a roadhouse on Jerusalem Avenue, here, early this morning, held up the proprietor and escaped with $1,800, representing the week-end receipts.

KOENIGSBERG, Aug. 7. -- East Prussia is combating unemployment by preparing all young men and women for farm work. Youths between 16 and 25 years, boys and girls, are organized in the Land Service and placed in groups of ten to twenty on deteriorated estates now in the hands of public credit institutions.

Revealing for the first time the extent of the funds under its administration, North American Trust Shares reports that as of June 30 the combined market value of its underlying assets was $57,416,608. The report includes both the cumulative and the non-cumulative series.

Robert Van Iderstine, chairman of the board of the American Equitable Assurance Company of New York and a director of many other insurance firms, died at 9 o'clock last night at Post-Graduate Hospital. He was 60 years old and had been in good health and active in business until Saturday, when he complained of feeling ill.

Sir William Bragg, one of England's most famous scientists and a winner of the Nobel Prize in physics, has taken time from his researches to write a book for the general reader which he calls "The Universe of Light." The Macmillan Company will publish it today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The State Department had received no official information tonight of the reported agreement in Havana among the elements opposing the Machado regime. The latest reports from Ambassador Welles indicated merely that he was continuing his mediation efforts despite the growing general strike and that meetings were being held frequently with the different factions.

As the first steps in carrying out the agreement recently made for refunding the debt of the city of Miami, Fla., the municipality has paid to the committee of its bondholders certain funds which it had collected for interest on the bonds and the bondholders' committee, in turn, has withdrawn all suits which it had instituted against the city.

The non-stop distance record, now unofficially held by Lieutenant Maurice Rossi and Paul Codos of France, is, next to the speed mark, the most coveted of international airplane records. In the eyes of designers and builders of planes and engines, a non-stop distance flignt is perhaps the best test of the efficiency of flying machines and power plants.
PARIS, Aug. 6. -- With our full load of gasoline, we set out from New York in the direction of Halifax.

Police Commissioner Bolan announced yesterday that a new timing schedule for traffic signals on the east side of Manhattan, from First to Fifth Avenue inclusive, would begin at 10 o'clock this morning. About an hour will be required for the changes in the lights, so that the new system will be in full operation about 11 A.M.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governor Lehman's recommendation to the Legislature on home relief can, in my opinion, affect few home owners. The suggestion made by the Governor that foreclosure proceedings shall not be allowed for mere failure to pay principal on a mortgage, provided interest and taxes are paid, will not satisfy very many.

ROME, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Austria wants to increase her military strength and has privately asked the governments of Great Britain, France and Italy for permission to do so, it was learned in an authoritative source today.

ALBANY, Aug. 7. -- Writs of habeas corpus were served today upon Chief of Police David M. Smurl of Albany and Police Commissioner James Bolan of New York City directing them to produce Manny Strewl, intermediary in the release of John J. O'Connell Jr. by his kidnappers.

David Haas, treasurer and a director of L. Bachmann Co., Inc., woolen commission merchants at 257 Fourth Avenue, died on Sunday at his apartment in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria of heart disease after two years of illness. His age was 56.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Grain exchanges responded today to the demand of farm administrators for a code governing reforms intended to bring stabilization of prices.

A joint meeting of the executive boards of the locals affiliated with the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, at Beethoven Hall last night, adopted a resolution expressing approval of the code for the cloak and suit industry, which went into effect yesterday after approval by President Roosevelt last Saturday.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 7. -- The Westchester County Park System, serving 7,224,000 persons during the last year, an increase of 300,000 over the year before, was operated at a net cost of the taxpayers of $124,415, or $147,540 less than in 1931, according to the annual report of the Park Commission, filed today with the Board of Supervisors.

This assurance is given by the Health Commissioner, Dr. WYNNE. It is based upon possible enlargement of the "milk shed" -- the area from which milk is brought into New York City. It now comprises six States -- New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Connecticut, Vermont and Massachusetts -- besides New Tork, and Dr. WYNNE is ready to extend the area of inspection to other States if it becomes necessary to seek a further supply.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- A 50-to-1 shot jolted form players today when the Glen Riddle Farm's Man o' War filly Speed Boat scored at that price in the ninth running of the Test Stakes, a seven-furlong dash.

PARIS, Aug. 7. -- The projected fifteen per cent surtax against imports from the United States because of the depreciation of the dollar may be expected "very soon," according to this morning's edition of Les Echos, an important commercial newspaper.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 7. -- Rocked by a revolt that caused withdrawal of several Ryder Cup stars, the 1933 National Professional Golfers Association championship opens at the Blue Mound Country Club tomorrow with a field of 100 out to topple Olin Dutra off his throne.
Colonel Carlos Mendleta has been frequently mentioned as the leading Oppositionist candidate for the Presidency of Cuba if President Machado should resign or be removed from office.

Eugene S. Daniell Jr., young Boston lawyer and Harvard graduate, will be arraigned in Tombs Court today on suspicion of malicious mischief in connection with the gas bombing of the Stock Exchange on Friday. He has been held in the Tombs in default of $10,000 bail since his arrest at the Hotel St. Paul here early Saturday.

The foreign flag steamship lines serving American ports declared their willingness yesterday to cooperate with the American flag lines in bringing shipping under the term of the National Industrial Recovery Act but maintained that their personnel afloat is not subject to the act.

The spirit of service and comradeship that characterized the relationship between French and American soldiers during the World War was renewed yesterday at exercises in honor of the visiting delegation of French veterans who arrived here Sunday.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Secretary Dern told a Chamber of Commerce audience here tonight that attempts to gain selfish advantage through the NRA will not be tolerated.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 7 (AP). -- The Rochester Red Wings inaugurated night baseball this evening by dropping a 4-to-0 verdict to the Newark Bears before 15,000 fans.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens submitted yesterday a budget of $5,055,436.82, an increase of $717,087.80 over the $4,338,345.02 allowed for this year. The belief that President Roosevelt's reconstruction program calling for increased cost of materials and shorter working hours for labor would be successful was the reason behind estimates of cost that caused the increased budget, Borough President Harvey said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- With forty-six nations adhering to the tariff truce, which is considered to be still in effect during the official recess of the London conference, Secretary Hull declared today on his return to his office at the State Department that his policy of international trade expansion was still vigorous and feasible.

ALBANY, Aug. 7. -- Governor Lehman sent tonight a special message to the Legislature urging passage of a bill giving private bankers and corporations power to "do all acts which are necessary or required by law to secure full benefits" available to them under the new Federal Banking Act.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 7. -- Mr. and Mrs. T. Markoe Robertson gave a dinner tonight at Wyndecote for Anthony J. Drexel of Philadelphia, who is passing a fortnight at the Irving. Among their other guests were:

Arnold Simons of Louisville, Ky., national public parks men's singles champion, made his first start in the defense of his title yesterday at Central Park and turned in an impressive straight-set victory over Charles Lejeck of Chicago. The score was 6-2, 6-2, 7-5.

CAIRO, Aug. 7. -- The Ministry of Agriculture of the Egyptian Government issued today figures on cotton acreage in 1933. A marked increase which was shown over last year is believed to be due to the fact that the fellahin failed to find profit in cereals which they had been induced to cultivate, because of extremely low prices, and therefore resumed cotton planting.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 7. -- Lieutenant Gerald D. Vaine, in command of State police in the Rochester area, said today he had been informed of a plot to dynamite bridges and culverts on all highways leading into Rochester and stop all milk shipments.

Pressing its fight to oust Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals from jurisdiction over the Inter-borough receivership, the Manhattan Railway Company served notice yesterday that it would not recognize any order or ruling in the case made by him on or after July 27, 1933.

Advances in the higher coupon Treasury issues featured quiet trading in United States Government bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, while domestic corporation bonds eased moderately in desultory transactions and foreign issues were slightly higher as a group.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- The Aviation Corporation and its subsidiaries today reported a consolidated net profit of $321,057 for the six months ended on June 30. This was its first profit. The profit contrasts with a loss of $2,565,371 for the corresponding period of 1932.
CULVER, Ind., Aug. 7. -- Favorites advanced without exception In the early rounds of the annual national junior and boys' tennis championship tournaments which opened today.
HAVANA, Aug. 7. -- In view of the misleading and preposterous messages sent today from this city by an American correspondent, I ask you in a spirit of fairness to ponder the following facts:

JACKSON, Wyo., Aug. 7. -- The Senate Committee on Public Lands began this afternoon its long-heralded inquiry into the cash contributions of John D. Rockefeller Jr. toward the acquirement of thousands of acres of mountain lands needed to complete the Grand Teton National Park.

New public financing, excluding domestic and Canadian municipal flotation, in the United States in the first seven months of this year amounted to only $164,939,000, according to a compilation by Otto P. Schwarzschild, president of the National Statistical Service, Inc.

New York Isolated. If the Japanese bombers whom Mr. BRISBANE sees almost any day putting the U.S. out of commission wanted to cripple railway communication between New York and the West, where along the line of the New York Central would they drop their destructive missiles?

The Public Service Commission's investigation of electric rates of the Consolidated Gas system was virtually completed yesterday. A brief hearing will be held tomorrow to accommodate one other company. Briefs will be submitted Monday and the commission will rule on temporary emergency rate cuts soon afterward.

FAIRHAVEN, N. Y., Aug. 7. -- Rochester and Buffalo divided honors in the two main events as the four-day regatta sponsored by the Lake Yacht Racing Association opened today. The races followed the completion of the eighty-seven-mile contest from Cobourg, Ont., to Fairhaven.

PARIS, Aug. 7. -- The French fliers, Paul Codos and Lieutenant Maurice Rossi, beat the world's long-distance straight-line record by at least 220 miles when they landed today at Rayak, Syria. Their own estimate of their flying distance is 5,900 miles.

There was a decline of $3,586,540,000 in the aggregate market value of all listed stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in July, the loss amounting to 9.8 per cent, according to the monthly bulletin issued by the Exchange. This virtually eliminated the $3,875,687,000 gain registered in June.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- In the face of bitter Republican charges of cowardice by Governor Lehman for his handling of the milk strike, the Democratic Senate adopted tonight a resolution to create a legislative committee of twelve members to inquire into the situation.

Lacking any special incentive, the markets moved indolently yesterday. Trading on the Stock Exchange was extremely light, the day's transactions in stocks falling short of 1,000,000 shares for the first time for a full five-hour day since the middle of April.

After a day of intensive investigation, which admittedly had accomplished nothing, the police working on the mysterious murder of Henry F. Sanborn, 44-year-old railroad executive, still were hopeful last night that the case would be solved.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The text of the Executive Agreement signed today at Port au Prince by Norman Armour, Minister to Haiti, and Foreign Minister Blanchet follows:

Americans and Canadians shared honors in the four special international bouts which featured the semi-monthly amateur boxing show conducted by the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island last night. The United States and Canada each accounted for two triumphs.

Members of the bench, city officials, political leaders and a large contingent of Police Department members were among the friends who yesterday attended funeral services for Thomas F. McAvoy, Tammany Sachem, held in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Catherine of Genoa, West 153d Street near Broadway.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 7. -- Ewald Balser, Austrian actor, whom the Nazis had been boasting they had induced to break his Salzburg contract, duly appeared today to rehearse the title role in "Faust." This being the case, another Austrian failure is to be credited to the German disturbers who would like to turn over the country to the Hitlerite movement.

HALIFAX, N.S., Aug. 7 (Canadian Press). -- Dr. Archibald MacMechan, for forty years Professor of English at Dalhousie University, died at his home here tonight. He retired from the university in 1931 and had devoted most of his time since to writing and traveling.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- A plan of constitutional reform for Burma, if separated from India, has been prepared for the joint select committee on Indian constitutional reform by Sir Samuel Hoare, Secretary of State for India.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- With the approval today by the Cabinet Advisory Board of highway plans for New Jersey; Pennsylvania, Illinois and Alabama, a total of $380,344,288 of the $400,000,000 earmarked in the National Recovery Bill for the State road improvements was authorized.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Aug. 7. -- F. Stanley Kreps, former City Solicitor of Ocean City, but now in the New Jersey State Penitentiary, was divorced today by his wife, Mrs. Justine Kress Kreps.

As compared with Thursday, the last full five-hour day of the previous week, yesterday's turnover on the Stock Exchange showed a decrease of about 50 per cent. The figures for the two days were 765,000 and 1,509,000. Up until 11 o'clock yesterday the business on the Exchange amounted to only 250,000 shares.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 7 (AP). -- Dissolution of Drug, Inc., of New York City, and the segregation of its property into five new corporations, was approved today by stockholders. No stock, it was announced, was voted against the reorganization plan, which had been recommended by the directors last June.
For thirty years, except when they were getting new coats of paint, the two dark green benches had stood fast to their iron moorings in front of the Settlement House at 265 Henry Street.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Minot Amory returned on the Majestic and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7 (AP). -- In an answer to a suit for $51,000 damages for alleged breach of promise, Dr. Maurice D. Turbow, Los Angeles dentist, asserted today that the political ambitions of Miss Louise Ruth Shapiro, a Newark (N.J.) attorney, constituted a bar to their marriage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- An agreement providing for the removal of United States marines from Haiti on Oct. 1, 1934, and new financial arrangements starting from that date, with less stringent supervision of the island republic's finances, was signed at Port au Prince today, the State Department announced tonight.

Edward Kenny, a former convict, and Mrs. Florence Palmer Flynn, known to the underworld as ThreeFingered Flo, were taken into custody in the office of a Manhattan attorney yesterday and questioned at Brooklyn Police Headquarters in connection with three recent murders.

P.A. Staples, general manager of the Hershey sugar refinery, the largest in Cuba, issued a statement yesterday through the New York office of the Hershey Sugar Sales Corporation, criticizing the action of the thirteen companies who comprise the American sugar refining industry in seeking special privileges in their proposed code under the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Early announcement by President Roosevelt of an inflation program was predicted here today when It became known that three special students of the monetary question have been, summoned to a conference at the Summer White House tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7. -- A 25 per cent increase in piece work and hourly rates in the hosiery industry was announced tonight following a meeting of directors of the Full Fashioned Hosiery Manufacturers of America, Inc.
George McAneny, Sanitation Commissioner, launched a campaign yesterday to clean up the city streets. As an initial step he had 552 waste disposal cans installed at various points.
Two stirring ninth-inning rallies gave the Yankees two victories over Washington yesterday at the Stadium in a world's series setting and reduced the distance between the teams to a single game.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly member banks in ninety leading cities on Aug. 2 shows decreases for the week of $123,000,000 in net demand deposits, $90,000,000 in investments and $15,000,000 in loans.

Thomas Hitchcock Jr., captain and selector of the All-East team for the special polo matches against the West at Chicago, announced the make up of his side yesterday for the series which starts on Sunday.

TORONTO, Aug. 7 (AP). -- In one pitchers' duel and one batting bee Toronto and Jersey City today divided a double-header, the Leafs winning the first game, 2 to 1, and the Jerseys the second, 10 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The National Mediation Board of the NRA effected preliminary organization today and laid plans to prepare agenda subjects to be taken up when permanent organization is completed.

Accessories Take Buying Lead. Accessories again figured prominently in the orders for women's wear reaching this market yesterday. In coat and dress lines attention was largely concentrated on the openings abroad, which will provide the basis for the second showings of Fail garments here, and to code developments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- With the filing of seventeen new registration statements with the Federal Trade Commission, securities listed under the new Securities Act reached today a total of $150,800,000.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 7. -- The Town Board of Mamaroneck approved today a bond issue of $508,000 to be sold on Aug. 22. The issue includes $110,000 to carry town welfare work to the end of the year. The remainder will take up certificates of indebtedness issued for sewer, highway and water projects.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 7. -- Mrs. Clarence F. Alcott entertained with a tea this afternoon at her Lily Pond Lane estate, after the meeting of the Ladies Village Improvement Society. Mrs. Howard Morris, first vice president, presided at the meeting in the absence of Mrs. Frank P. Shepard, president.

In what he described as the climax of his present visit to the United States, Captain James A. Mollison was the guest yesterday of the newly formed Transoceanic Fliers of America. The organization lived up to its name. In a patio of the Cafe Bonaparte at 310 East Forty-fourth Street were assembled for luncheon more airmen who have actually flown oceans than had come together before in New York.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Aug. 7. -- Another effort to persuade the striking miners of Fayette County to return to work under the truce obtained by the National Recovery Administration will be made here tomorrow morning.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) . -- Scoring victories in three events today, the Washington (D. C.) Canoe Club retained the national championship of the American Canoe Association's annual regatta with 55 points. The Breeds Club of Roxbury, Mass., which led after the single blade events yesterday, finished second with 28 points.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Before America decides on the color for a shirt to go with its new emblem, there are one or two questions a rank non-conformist and member of the 10 per cent obstructionists would like to ask. Say I belong to the employer class -- the small employer with a moderate income; my dividends have been cut, my taxes are increasing, my profits are nil.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 7 (AP). -- A Negro lawyer's plea that four Negroes, scheduled to die today in the electric chair, had teen tortured into confessions of murder, halted the executions just before the death watches were to begin at Raiford State Prison.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- The Boerse opened the week in a listless mood. Continued apathy of the speculating and investing public again left the market in a state of stagnation. The absence of stimulating reaction from New York or London also contributed to the sluggish tone.
PHILADELPHIA. Aug. 7 (AP). -- Bucky Walters, a Philadelphia boy with the Boston Red Sox, made his debut before his home folks today and led the Red Sox to an 8-to-5 victory over the Athletics.
REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 7.-- I arrived here at 2:30 this afternoon after a trying flight from Thorshavn, during which I feared many times I was going to plunge into the sea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- responding to a nation-wide appeal by the Federal Emergency Relief Administrator, three States have submitted programs to aid homeless and transient persons whose movements in search of employment have raised a major relief problem.

BURLINGAME, Cal., Aug. 7 (AP) -- The death of Fortune Nelson, (Bunny) Burson, 33-year-old San Francisco orchestra leader, from injuries received in a fight at the home of his fiancee was termed by police today as "a matter for the coroner's jury."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Officials of the National Beet Growers Association said today that they would oppose the proposed international sugar marketing agreement at a hearing starting Thursday before farm administrators.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Twenty thousand of the 60,000 striking soft-coal miners in Pennsylvania returned to work today and the others will return soon, according to a statement made here today by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, after receiving reports from his district presidents in the Pennsylvania areas.

ROCKVTLLE CENTER, L. I., Aug. 7. -- After bumping into poor golfing weather which cut attendance considerably, the Long Island Golf Association had better luck today when forty-nine couples turned out for the pro-amateur tournament at the Rockville Country Club.

Purchase by Frederick Brown, operator, of the fifteen-story business building at 11-13 West Thirtieth Street featured the comparatively light realty trading reported yesterday in the metropolitan district.

PARIS, Aug. 7. -- Vionnet closes the Fall fashions salons with striking variations of her classic silhouette with shell chest effects and big sleeves, gathered full at both the top and the wrist. Rounded shoulders are featured on coats and dresses.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- Over the tricky Oak Park Country Club course today, Miss Bernice Wall of Oshkosh, Wis., set the pace for more than 160 golfers in the qualifying round of the Women's Western Golf Association tournament. She scored a 79 total, one over women's par.

BROWNSVILLE, Pa., Aug. 7. -- With thousands of strikers refusing to return to the mines under the Roosevelt truce, the Federal Government today opened an investigation, into alleged communistic agitation in the Western Pennsylvania soft coal fields.

The Commercial Investment Trust's semiannual report shows that a decline in the volume of bills and accounts purchased in the first three months of this year was more than offset in the second quarter, but that its net income for the six months was smaller than for the corresponding period last year.

ALBANY, Aug. 7. -- Governor Lehman said tonight that the State Government was powerless to do anything for the residents and Summer dwellers on Indian Lake who had complained that the power companies were drawing so heavily on this picturesque body of water in the Adirondacks.

Several sales in the Red Bank and Rumson sections of New Jersey have been made by the Joseph G. McCue Agency at Rumson. One of the largest deals was that of the Gerard Romaine homestead with eight acres of land in Romaine Park, Rumson, which was purchased by Robert B. Smith of New York City.

The independent fusion commit tee, formed last Winter by Joseph M. Price, met last night at the Bar Association Building and endorsed the mayoralty candidacy of F.H. La Guardia. Mr. Price, chairman of the committee, had fought Mr. La Guardia's candidacy at the fusion conferences.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Rolland (Lena) Stiles, with the aid of live double plays by his companions, shut out the White Sox today, 6 to 0, and the Browns took the four-game series from the Sox, 3 to 1.

Joseph Michaels, 37 years old, an auctioneer, of 1,775 East Twenty-fourth Street, Brooklyn, was in the criminal line-up at Police Headquarters charged with receiving stolen goods. He was arrested Sunday afternoon at his home by detectives, who waited until after his mother's funeral.
CAPE TOWN, Aug. 7. -- The South African Government is seriously perturbed by the giant strides the Nazi movement is making in the mandated territory of Southwest Africa, formerly a German colony.

With F.H. La Guardia already Darned as the fusion candidate for Mayor, another selection for the city ticket seemed assured yesterday when Bernard S. Deutsch consented to become a candidate for President of the Board of Aldermen.

Assemblyman David Paris, who is accused of having knowingly submitted forged affidavits in Federal Court, admitted yesterday on the witness stand before Judge Francis G. Caffey that he had been told in advance that some of the supposed signers would repudiate them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- The basis of allocations for subscriptions of $4,700,000,000 to the Treasury's offering of $850,000,000 in bonds and notes Aug. 15 was announced today by Acting Secretary Acheson.

Declaring that a wholesale moratorium on homes and farms is not only unnecessary but would be unjust, Frank Fox, president of the Realty Associates Securities Corporation, issued a statement yesterday in which he said:

The list of prominent passengers departing today on the North German Lloyd liner Europa includes Grand Duchesse Marie of Russia; William L. Nevin, president of John Wanamaker Co.; Victor Ridder, secretary of the StaatsHerold Corporation, and Lyman Delano, chairman of the board of the Atlanta Coast Line Railroad.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 7. -- The yearling sales are about to start. This is drama by night and society never fails to occupy the best seats. Big cars are parked for blocks around the huge shed under which E. J. Tranter, wearing a calm air and a tuxedo, conducts the annual auction sales of yearling thoroughbreds.

BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- The German Government today rebuked Great Britain and France for protesting against Nazi propaganda in Austria aimed at the overthrow of the Austrian Government and the establishment of Hitlerite rule in Vienna.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 7. -- Postmaster General James A. Farley was the guest of the Friends of Franklin Roosevelt Club of Monmouth County at a dinner at the Monterey Hotel here tonight. About 500 persons, including many prominent Democrats, attended.

Retail cleaners, dyers and tailors of the East opened a two-day convention at the Irving Plaza yesterday to draw up an NRA code for their industry. They voted to form what was said to be the first national association of retail cleaners and tailors in the United States.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 7. -- The most cosmopolitan field yet to gather for an American tennis tournament this season held forth on the courts of the Westchester Country Club today as the Eastern grass court championships got into full swing.

MADISON, Conn., Aug. 7. -- Again the Connecticut shore had the Summer breeze today instead of the Long Island sand dunes. It played a decisive part for the racing fleet on the second run of the American Yacht Club. The race was from Port Jefferson, L. I., to Duck Island Roads.
RENO, Nev., Aug. 7. -- Florence M. Lamborn, who came here to file suit for divorce against Arthur H. Lamborn, New York sugar broker, has returned to New York to complete a property settlement.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Driving her own car, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt came here today with three personal friends from her home in Hyde Park, and spent six hours touring the girls' camps on the lake shores near by. She brought a picnic lunch with her which the party ate in a secluded woodland spot.

General Gerardo Machado y Morales, fifth President of the Republic of Cuba, has been the storm centre of the Cuban situation for several years. His removal from office has been the one demand upon which all factions of the opposition have been able to agree.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP). -- Miss Tulsa, a 4-year-old daughter of Tryster-Tuscola, running in the colors of Jack Howard of Lexington, Ky., scored her sixth victory in seven starts today in the fifth event at Hawthorne.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP). -- A terrific collision between a giant meteor and the planet Saturn was advanced today by Naval Observatory astronomers as a possible cause of the huge wnite spot that has appeared on the planet.

VIENNA, Aug. 7. -- While protests were being made In Berlin today by France and Great Britain against violation of Austrian territorial rights by German airplanes, a new outrage was committed by German Nazis in the murder of an Austrian frontier guard.

By special intervention of merciful Providence, Mr. Aborn is still sweetening the urban Summer with Gilbert and Sullivan. Last evening at the Majestic he revived his revival of the "Pirates of Penzance" with enough relish of its humors to keep "this querulous column contented.
SWANSEA, Wales, Aug. 7 (Canadian Press). -- The touring West Indians today tallied 463 runs in the first innings of their cricket match against Glamorgan, first-class county eleven.

MANILA, Aug. 7. -- The sending of a new independence mission to the United States next January was definitely decided upon by the leaders of the Quezon bloc today, regardless of the action taken on the Hawes Law. These leaders say that if the law is accepted certain amendments will be vitally necessary, and if it is rejected the mission will work for a new and better independence measure.

WARSAW, Aug. 7. -- The creation of a powerful Senate and the granting of real power to the President of Poland will be urged in the Sejm this Fall Colonel Walery Slawek, former Premier and head of Marshal Pilsudski's bloc in the Parliament, announced today at the annual meeting of the Legionaires' Association.
ALBANY, Aug. 7. -- Governor Lehman demanded tonight action to insure State reapportionment in time for the elections of 1934.

Evening up of accounts in preparation for today's government crop estimate caused irregular fluctuations yesterday on the Cotton Exchange and at its close the market showed losses of 14 to 17 points, or 70 to 85 cents a bale.

ALBANY, Aug. 7. -- Final action on the New York City tax and unemployment relief aid bill in the Senate and Assembly is expected during the legislative week beginning tonight. Reports were current today that the New York City authorities were prepared to change the bases they have proposed for the revenues sought to help the city out of its financial hole.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 7. -- Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Hamilton Rice, who have as their guest at Miramar, Mrs. John Rice, sister-in-law of Dr. Rice, gave a luncheon there today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Monroe Butler, California manager for the Home Owners Loan Corporation, has advised the Home Loan Bank Board that the Bank of America had instructed its branches throughout California to accept Home Owners Loan Corporation bonds.

BAY SHORE, L. I., Aug. 7. -- The lead in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association junior championships was taken today by the Sayville Yacht Club, Winning one race and placing second in another of the series of six that will determine this district's entrants in the Sears Bowl competition, Sayville showed the way to a Babylon crew for the Commodore Frank Gulden Trophy.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Bills to create a special authority to construct a $12,500,000 causeway and vehicular tunnel across the Hudson River from Nyack to Tarrytown under the Federal public works program were introduced at the extraordinary session of the Legislature tonight.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 7. -- In connection with a warning to State department heads that there must be a continued sharp reduction of expenditures to assure a balanced budget at the end of the current fiscal year, Governor Moore urged county and municipal governing bodies today to follow the State's example in economizing.

Mary Austin, who is spending the Summer in Sante Fe, N. M., has completed arrangements for an extensive lecture tour next Fall. Mrs. Austin's often-reprinted story, "Papago Wedding," recently made another reappearance in "An American Omnibus,'' published by Doubleday Doran.

James M. Cox, former Governor of Ohio, a delegate to the London conference, at which he was president of the monetary commission, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. He said the conference had been held too soon and that in his opinion no one country could be blamed for its limited achievements.

Herman A. Doolittle, manager of the main office, at 285 Madison Avenue, of McCann-Erickson, Inc., general advertising agency, died on Sunday at North Rye Beach, N.H., of a heart attack. He had been there on a vacation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP). -- A special board of the National Recovery Administration today stepped into the controversy over a code of fair competition for the boot and shoe industry, hoping to produce a temporary agreement on minimum hours and wages.

The production of steel in the United States in July amounted to 3,203,810 tons, the largest output for any month since August, 1930, when 3,695,293 tons were produced, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This compares with an output of 2,597,517 tons in June and 806,722 tons in July, 1932, the smallest output for any month in the recent history of the steel industry.

When GOEBBELS, Nazi Minister of Propaganda, announced that the German stock was to be improved by the application of eugenic principles a shudder must have run down many spines. If HITLER dared to revive belief in a discredited and wholly mythical Aryan as a racial ideal, what might not be expected of a fanatical interpretation of GALTON'S teachings?
PHOENIX, Ariz., Aug 7 (AP). -- Arizona, prohibition leaders conceded tonight, will vote tomorrow to make this State the twenty-first to approve repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Aug. 6. -- William J. Sherry, minority leader of the Westchester Board of Supervisors, was ruled out of order at a meeting of the board here today when he sought to present a minority report on a committee investigation into the conduct of Playland at Rye.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- The grain markets are still showing effects of the break in prices on July 19 and 20. Speculative interest in all American markets today was light. Price changes in the main were largely results of minor local operations, but an undertone of uneasiness prevailed.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 7 (AP). -- Chief Abbedale, black son of Abbedale, racing under the colors of J.T. Mallory of Oakland, R.I., showed his best in sweeping to a triple victory in the 2:17 class pace, feature event of today's Grand Circuit program at Rockingham Park.

A $2,250,000 increase in pay for 15,000 employes of the Western Electric Company was announced yesterday as the company signed President Roosevelt's re-employment agreement. The increase averaged 11 per cent for all hourly rated employes having salaries up to $3,240 a year.

LONDON, Aug. 7. -- The German Government told Britain and France to mind their own business when the British Charge d' Affaires and the French Ambassador in Berlin protested against Nazi airplane propaganda raids over Ausria.

Labor will find it dangerous to renounce its right to strike without an acceptable substitute, Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, decleared yesterday. He spoke before more than 750 students and faculty members of the New York University at the Summer school assembly, School of Education auditorium, 41 West Fourth Street.

The Interstate Commerce Commismission has rejected a plea for lower freight rates filed by several national associations representing farmers, coal producers and lumber manufacturers. They did not ask specific reductions, but sought to show that existing rates are out of line with commodity prices.

The tense feeling which marked the opening of the trial of Jacob Mellon and two other laundry organizers charged with conspiracy was suddenly heightened at the close of the session yesterday when County Judge McLaughlin in Brooklyn took strong measures to prevent the intimidation of witnesses.

Various estimates have been put forth of the time necessary to show that the Recovery Act is successful or not. General JOHNSON once said that we should know within sixty days. Another Federal authority stated last week that the battle is already half won.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Loan associations, savings banks and homestead associations were urged today by President Roosevelt to aid in his program "to enable unfortunate home owners to save their homes."

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad Company and six Chicago commission merchants and concerns were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of unlawfully receiving, soliciting and granting rebates.

A situation unprecedented in recent years in the floor coverings industry, according to trade observers, confronted the several hundred buyers who came here yesterday to attend the Fall opening of rug and carpet lines. Instead of the customary guarantees against price changes buyers who made commitments were informed that mills had raised prices 5 to 15 per cent for the opening, but would not accept orders for delivery at the new levels beyond Sept. 1.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Aug. 7 unless otherwise specified.

The city committee directing the NRA campaign for more jobs, Shorter hours and higher wages swung officially into action yesterday under the chairmanship of Grover A. Whalen with the assistance of leading industrialists, business men and civic workers.

HAVANA, Aug. 7. -- Cuba's "passive revolution" flared into violent rioting this afternoon when crowds celebrated a false report that President Gerardo Machado had resigned. Twenty persons are known to have been killed by police bullets and 123 wounded, of whom 24 are not expected to live. But the toll may be higher.

DETROIT, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Although the Tigers made six errors, four in one inning, they batted out a 6-to-3 victory over Cleveland today in the final contest of a series that went to Detroit, four games to one.

Price movements in futures in local commodity markets were irregular yesterday. For the most part, opening prices were higher, but the markets sagged off and several staples closed lower. Trading was dull. Cash prices were lower.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 7 (AP). -- The airplane Joseph Lebrix, piloted by the Frenchmen, Maurice Rossi and Paul Codos, landed at the military airfield at Rayak, about thirty miles from here, at 5:10 o'clock this evening, Greenwich Mean Time (1:10 P.M. in New York), with the proud claim of having shattered the world distance record by nearly 600 miles.

BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- The Boerse was dull today. Many stocks had no turnover at all. Reports that the Reichsbank. dividend would be transferred in full produced a temporary flurry, during which the shares of the bank gained 3 per cent.

By the skin of its teeth, Cherry Street was saved yesterday from open warfare with Henry Street, its neighbor and one-time friend. But it took all the diplomacy of the Settlement House, at 265 Henry Street, to do it.

The Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore and the Hartford Electric Light Company have addressed resignations to the Edison Electric Institute due to their expressed inability to sign the code for the power industry laid before the National Recovery Administration at Washington on Saturday, it became known yesterday.

Leaders of the motion-picture industry, in which forty-seven groups have been preparing codes for submission, were assembled yesterday by Sol A. Rosenblatt, Deputy NRA Administrator, and told to prepare a unified code by next Monday.

Scoring his first victory in ten starts, Ray Benge yesterday pitched the Dodgers to an eleven-inning 1-to-0 triumph, holding the Giants to three singles at Ebbets Field. A wild throw by Johnny Vergez with the bases filled gave the Dodgers the run.

M'SIEU LUCIEN PIERRE BROUILLARD expects to win the middleweight title from Ben Jeby this evening at the Polo Grounds, weather permitting. After that, he plans to eat a few good meals and go after the owner of the light heavyweight title. He has grown from 135 pounds to 160 pounds in three years. If Camera stays around for a while, M'sieu Lucien may catch up to him.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Lansing Parmelee Reed will give a small dance on the night of Sept. 8 at Windy Hill, Shore Road, Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Julia Reed.

Upsets and brilliant performances again featured the sectional qualifying trials for the national amateur golf championship yesterday on twenty-two courses from New York to Honolulu. The tournament will be held over the Kenwood course at Cincinnati, Sept. 11 to 16.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 8. (AP). -- Discovery of some of the money paid to kidnappers of Charles K. Urschel, Oklahoma City oil man, and the arrest today of three men linked with passing the marked currency, prompted Federal operatives to hope that Twin City gang haunts might yield full answer to the mystery of the abductors' identities.
LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Any further violation of Austrian independence by the Hitler government probably will mean an appeal to the League of Nations, it was indicated here today.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Mrs. George Viebrock of Queens Valley, who was one of the qualifiers in the recent women's New York State championship, won her first major golf prize in the one-day tourney of the women's Metropolitan Golf Association at the Leewood Golf Club, today.
TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 8 (AP). -- A gigantic municipal bond forgery, which authorities believe may have been a $1,000,000 swindle, caused the closing of three State banks today and the arrest of one man.

DANZIG, Aug. 8. -- The first thing that attracts the attention of the visitor to this Free City on the Baltic as soon as he steps out of the railway station is an obelisk just unveiled to the memory of Danzig's veterans of the World War. It probably is the most militant war memorial anywhere.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Government purchases will be made only from firms entitled to display the Blue Eagle, according to General Johnson, the recovery administrator.

The spiritual aspect of the flight of Captain James A. Mollison and his wife, the former Amy Johnson, was discussed at a luncheon given in their honor yesterday at the Ritz Tower under the auspices of the Catholic Actors Guild of America.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Cuban developments were the centre of interest at the State Department today. Jefferson Caffery, Assistant Secretary of State, held a long telephone conversation with Ambassador Welles in Havana late this afternoon, but declined to make public the United States envoy's estimate of the situation.

A warrant for the arrest of John Stevens, charging that he defrauded the poor in a Summer camp scheme was issued in Essex Market Court yesterday by Magistrate Thomas A. Aurelio, who dismissed a summons against Miss Nettie Woll, 17, of 5 Ten Eyck Street, Brooklyn, a high school student who was employed by Stevens.

BLUFF POINT, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Miss Helen Silleck of Greenwich, Conn., won the medal in the first annual international invitation tournament for women over the links of the Lake Champlain Country Club today.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Schooners, with a fresh breeze favoring them, came to the fore today in the final run of the American Yacht Club cruise, which was twenty-one miles from Duck Island Roads to here.

The Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics has completed a special study of price trends during the depression. It shows how mistaken is the theory that all prices follow approximately the same general curve, whose upward or downward course is determined by some set of influences readily identified, such as changes in the amount of currency in circulation.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 8 (AP). -- A belief that kidnappers struck down and killed 27-year-old Oliver S. Baily, a leader of the younger smart set of society, was expressed by relatives and friends tonight. They thought it possible that the kidnappers found the young captive more than they could handle.

An informal meeting open to all creditors was held yesterday at the Bar Building, 36 West Forty-fourth Street, to consider the situation of Dr. Edward A. Crawford. He is the physician who became a market plunger with some small savings after the war, and whose margin holdings, mostly of grains, but also of securities, were estimated at $50,000,000 when the market broke on July 19.

PRAGUE, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Before a crowd of 8,000, America's touring track and field stars gave a brilliant display of speed and athletic prowess to win all but one of twelve events in which they were entered in a meet today against Czechoslovak stars.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 8 -- Mrs. Irving H. Taylor gave a dinner tonight for Mrs. Richard W. Woolworth, who is visiting Mrs. Paul Scheerer at her Dunemere Lane Summer home. Mr. Woolworth will arrive on Thursday to take part in the annual golf tournament for the Maidstone Bowl during the three days beginning on Saturday.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 8 -- The Richmond Garden Club met this afternoon with Mrs. Zenas Crane at Willow Brook, Dalton. Mrs. W. Rockwood Gibbs, president, conducted a questionnaire on "shrubs," and Mrs. James E. Greeg of Pittsfield read a paper on "gourds."

The Golden Rule Foundation announced yesterday that it would present cash prizes totaling more than $1,000 for economy menus, suggestions for gifts, budgets, wardrobes, ways to increase the family income and for "educational and inspirational suggestions."

Although the share market was still languid by comparison with the trading of past weeks, the course of prices yesterday ran steadily upward after an irregular and dull opening. Transactions on the Stock Exchange amounted to 1,232,000 shares, against 765,000 on the previous day.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Rochester evened the series with Newark today by defeating the league leaders in a loosely played game by the score of 8 to 6.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- II Duce never flinches, not even in a dentist's chair.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What is the matter with American athletes? Why must these excellent and, in most cases, highly skilled young men be forever excused and alibied when they don't win every contest they go in for? Are they of such puny structure that their infrequent failures must be always explained away, usually in a manner unfavorable to their foreign opponents?

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 8 -- Representing a decrease of $83,646,615 from the close of 1932, William H. Kelly, State Banking Commissioner, reported today that deposits in banks under supervision of the State Banking Department totaled $1,092,342,269 at the end of June.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Aug. 8 -- It costs an average of 20 1/4 cents to commission a Kentucky Colonel -- or an Admiral for that matter -- according to Nat B. Sewell, State inspector and examiner.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 8 -- Showers took some of the smoke out of a sou'wester blowing here today. A fair racing breeze remained, however, as a fleet of 236 boats sailed in the last of the Eastern Yacht Club's midsummer series.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- President Roosevelt spent today canvassing the economic situation in talks with three members of his "brain trust," but at the end of the conversations it was stated that no conclusions had been reached.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange was firm and slightly more active yesterday, with increasing interest displayed in convertible issues and a fairly strong demand evident for United States Treasury bonds. Liberty bonds, which, because of their high coupons, have been selling at substantial premiums, eased off on renewed gossip of early refunding operations.

Organization of the new National Association of the Legitimate Theatre, Inc., was completed with the election of officers and the adoption of a constitution and by-laws at a meeting held yesterday afternoon in the offices of the League of New York Theatres.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP). -- An exhaustive survey of the trend of wholesale commodity prices since June, 1929, furnished industrial recovery and Treasury officials by Isador Lubin, new Commissioner of Labor Statistics, was interpreted in official quarters today as showing that some products should not be increased in price under the recovery program, while actual reductions in others might be warranted.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- F.A. Burton's filly, Wise Daughter, completely upset expectations when she won the twelfth running of the Saratoga Sales Stakes today. Driving behind the daughter of Wise Counsellor and Wise Mother was the Greentree Stable's Black Buddy, heretofore considered championship timber.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP). -- A warning to criminals that kidnapping does not pay and will be followed by swift, certain capture and severe punishment was sounded tonight by Joseph B. Keenan, special assistant to Attorney General Cummings, in an address outlining the government's plan to fight gangsters.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Flora Carol Ravens, 42 years old, a nurse, was arrested in Newark yesterday and taken to the Hudson County Jail, charged uner the new Federal kidnapping statute.

Overshadowing the World Economic Conference and all European policies are fears abroad about gold and about war, according to Dr. Lionel D. Edie, president of Mayflower Consolidated and formerly Professor of Finance at the University of Chicago.

In this disturbed modern world there still exists "a little oasis of peace and happiness," according to Sir Harry Luke, whose book, "In the Margin of History," will he published today by Houghton Mifflin Company.

Sales of General Motors cars to consumers in July continued to run at a high level, although there was a slight seasonal dip from the June total. The number of cars sold was the greatest in any July since 1929.

ROME, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Pope Pius XI today received in audience Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, son of the former President of the United States. Mgr. Eugene Burke, rector of the American College, accompanied Colonel Roosevelt on his visit to the Pontiff.

GREENWOOD, Miss., Aug. 8 (AP). A death-bed statement from Dr. Preston Kennedy accusing an associate woman physician, Dr. Sara Tuth Dean, of poisoning him was disclosed here today by District Attorney Arthur Jordan.
