A protest against any further delay in providing adequate relief for the unemployed was signed here yesterday by nineteen ministers and social workers, the Rev. James Myers, industrial secretary of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, announced.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8. -- Two hundred women strikers fought with police today in new strike disorders, but were dispersed after nearly fifteen minutes.

From the architect's point of view, Rome is more appealing today than it was before the restoration program of Premier Mussolini, Cass Gilbert reported yesterday on his return from Europe on the White Star liner Majestic.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Perhaps metropolitan milk consumers would give ear to the views of a Grade B producer from up-State concerning the milk war.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- His most determined effort of the season checkmated at Southampton, Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York was well launched on another effort to find his winning form of 1931 today in the Eastern championships at the Westchester Country Club.
Eugene S. Daniell Jr., the 28-year-old Boston lawyer accused of flooding the New York Stock Exchange with tear gas last Friday, was indicted yesterday on a charge of malicious mischief, a felony.

More than 200 lawyers practicing in New York City have signed a petition endorsing the candidacy of Surrogate James A. Delehanty of New York County to succeed himself for a full term of fourteen years and urging the voters to reelect him.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York asked General Hugh S. Johnson yesterday to delegate to the Shipping Board or its successor the powers of the National Recovery Administration in administering the affairs of the shipping industry.

Bushrod H. Spencer, a handwriting expert who had been retained by Assemblyman David Paris to testify that five affivadits the latter submitted in Federal court did not bear forged signatures, testified yesterday for the government. Mr. Spencer said that in his opinion Sidney Paris, brother of the Assemblyman, had signed all five.

HARBOR GRACE, Nfld., Aug. 8. -- The Bellanca monoplane White Eagle crashed in landing here this afternoon, after flying from Floyd Bennett Field, New York. Those aboard escaped serious injury but the plane was crippled. One wing was broken and one strut of the landing gear gave way as the machine looped into rough ground at the side of the runway.

BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- The feud that the German Government declared against the Association of Foreign Correspondents in Berlin shortly after Chancellor Hitler came into power ended today with a bargain that freed an Austrian correspondent from a German jail.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Cabinet Advisory Board approved today a grant of $400,000 to the Federal Power Commission to carry forward the administration's plan to survey "comprehensively" the entire country in a national plan for the development of water power and the transmission of electricity.

ALBANY, Aug. 8. -- On the ground that there were indications that violence was decreasing in the milk-strike area, Governor Lehman said tonight that he had no intention for the present of calling out the National Guard to preserve order.

Mobilization of all business and civic organizations in the President's re-employment campaign was ordered yesterday by the local campaign committee, under the chairmanship of Grover A. Whalen. While 15,430 additional employers signed the President's re-employment agreement, the local campaign committee proceeded with plans to conduct its NRA drive on a mass scale by enlisting every organization of importance in the business and civic life of the community in support of the effort.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP). -- Louis (Doc) Stacci, a roadhouse operator also known as Stacy, was named by the Federal Government today as the man who plotted the scheme to free Frank Nash, escaped convict, at the Union Station in Kansas City on June 17.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 8 -- The "massacre" of Cubans celebrating reports that President Machado would resign was seen today by General Mario G. Menocal, former President of the island republic, as a tragic experience confirming his view that "Machado must go."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP). -- A decision within three days is expected from a committee selected today by the Cabinet Advisory Board to determine if farm administrators may make benefit payments of more than $200,000,000 to farmers this Fall without deducting debts owed the government.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 8. -- A powerful nitroglycerine bomb was found today beneath the hood of an automobile owned by Dr. William Cooper, 35-year-old chiropractor, of 84 Rosedale Avenue, East Paterson. Police believe the device was placed in the machine by the same person who, within the last few weeks, has made attempts upon the lives of three Paterson chiropractors.

An unemployed painter, visiting a friend in The Bud Shop, a haberdashery, at 57 East 125th Street last night, floored an armed holdup man with a flying tackle, wrenched his pistol away from him and shot the gunman in the back, when he dashed out into the street.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- A total of 545,800 was realized at an auction of thirty-two thoroughbreds tonight. This was the first of the sales which annually take place during the race meeting. Brood mares formed the largest division, although there were some yearlings, weanlings and one stallion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While so many tears are being shed over the sad plight of the holders of mortgage certificates, let us not fail also to emit at least a sigh for the forgotten owner of the property.

RAYAK, Syria, Aug. 8 (By Wireless). -- In a fifty-six hour flight from New York to the airport here in our monoplane, the Joseph Lebrix, we have beaten the world's long-distance record for a direct flight.
Earl Whitehill outpitched Johnny Allen yesterday at the stadium and kept the Yankees away from first place in the American League pennant race.
ALBANY, Aug. 8 -- Extension of a moratorium on mortgage foreclosures for non-payment of principal to all real estate instead of part was urged today by Senator Schackno, Democrat, of the Bronx.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Cubs, who last week assisted Dizzy Dean to a new major league record by striking out seventeen times, today avenged themselves by defeating the Cardinal ace, 4 to 2, and sending the St. Louis team into a tie for fourth place.

The various ship lines operating in the Cuban trade were kept busy yesterday replying to queries as to the situation in Cuba and its effect on their sailings. Most of the lines have kept in touch with their Cuban offices by telephone the last few days and closed their offices Monday afternoon with reassuring reports from their agents.

Immediate discontinuance of the ambulance service supported by the city at Jamaica Hospital was ordered last night by Mayor O'Brien. His order followed the suepension of ambulance certificates of two more of the hospital internes yesterday by James H. Fay, Acting Commissioner of Hospitals.

Word for Dead Nazi officials in East Prussia have a plan for the economic reorganization of East Prussia and the abolition of unemployment. In describing it the Nazi leaders exhibit a strong family resemblance to Moscow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Despite the general increase in business activity, money in circulation dropped off sharply in July, indicating a return of hoarded currency to banks and through them to the Treasury and Federal Reserve Banks.

An appraisal yesterday of the estate of Stewart Hill Jones, a pioneer in the bronze industry and founder of the Canadian Bronze Company, showed that bequests of $187,814 each will go to the Presbyterian and New York Hospitals of this city, and Grace and Receiving Hospitals of Detroit.

HORTA, Azores, Aug. 8 -- Out of the heat and haze over the mid-Atlantic came General Balbo and his Italian air squadron this afternoon, safely at the end of their 1,400-mile flight from Shoal Harbor, Nfld.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- A cotton crop of 12,314,000 bales for 1933 was forecast by the Department of Agriculture today after deducting 4,247,000 bales as the prospective yield on 10,304,000 acres taken out of cultivation under the reduction program of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.
Harriet Hoctor, premiere danseuse in the forthcoming Joe Cook show, "Hold Your Horses," arrived yesterday to begin rehearsals in that revue. Bob Alton has been engaged to direct the dances.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Three more special boards to review "presumptive" cases of disability among World War veterans were named today by General Frank T. Hines, veterans' administrator, after they had been approved by President Roosevelt at Hyde Park.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The longshot players had a chance to do some cheering today at Hawthorne when John J. Coughlin's Camp Douglas, a rank outsider, won the Park Ridge Purse after a thrilling battle with the Audley Farm's Royal Blunder, and paid the rousing price of $126.62 for $2.

ANDORRA, Aug. 8. -- The first revolutionary fervor of the Andorrans having spent itself, it begins to appear that the revolutionists will take a vacation until after Sept. 29, the Feast of St. Michael.

Outroarer of a hundred hells' Incalculable decibels! What became of our New York Anti-Noise Society? If one remembers, It was going to throttle all the steam hullabaloo on the North and East Rivers, pour silence into the horns of a million automobiles, reduce the radio to a whisper, restore peace to our days and nights.

Ben Jeby, recognized by the New York State Athletic Association as middleweight champion, will defend his title in a fifteen-round bout against Lou Brouillard of Worcester, Mass., at the Polo Grounds tonight. The battle will mark Jeby's third defense of the crown he won in an elimination bout with Frank Battaglla at Madison Square Garden last January.

ALBANY, Aug. 8 -- The Buckley bill to empower New York City to levy a 1 per cent sales tax, and a tax not to exceed 4 cents a share on the transfer of stocks, to finance unemployment relief, faces defeat in its present form. This became evident today after a hearing on the measure before the Senate and Assembly committees on taxation and retrenchment.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 8 -- Colonel Henry H. Rogers gave a large reception this afternoon at his oceanfront place for his son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Arturo Peralta Ramos, who will sail for Europe tomorrow, and for Anthony J. Drexel of Philadelphia, who will leave Southampton tomorrow for Narragansett.

President Roosevelt's recovery program, although "admirable and magnificent," cannot be of permanent benefit unless it includes an earnest attempt to solve international problems, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, asserted last night in an address before more than 2,500 Columbia Summer session students at the annual Summer convocation in the university gymnasium.

SWANSEA, Wales, Aug. 8 (Canadian Press) -- The touring British West Indian cricket team today defeated Glamorgan, county championship team, by 10 wickets, scoring 463 and 30 for the loss of no wickets to 295 and 197 for Glamorgan.
LONDON, Aug. 8. -- A dispatch to The London Times from Berlin tonight says:

YORKLYN, Del., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Breaking 143 out of 150 double targets, or 75 pairs, Frank M. Troeh, Oregon amateur State champion, today won the Yorklyn introductory, inauguration feature of the thirteenth annual T. Clarence Marshall trapshootingr classic.

Rise in Buyers' Total for Week. A sharp increase was noted in the number of out-of-town buyers reported last week in comparison with the previous week, but the number was considerably under the figure for the corresponding period last year, according to the list published in THE TIMES.

Day after day, night after night, in what from the middle of June to the middle of September is one of the most unpleasant climates in the world, General JOHNSON and his aides have been unceasingly working. Their purpose is by the end of August to make the NRA specific and blanket codes generally operative in the whole nation.

TORONTO, Aug. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Jersey City's heavy artillery was brought into play today to give the visitors two victories out of three games in the present series against Toronto. The score was 11 to 7.
Winning two matches yesterday at Central Park, Miss Helen Germaine of New York, women's national public parks singles champion, reached the quarter-final round in the eleventh annual tournament.
Minthorne T. Gordon, long a powerful figure in Staten Island politics, narrowly escaped assassination late last night in his home at 101 Douglas Road, Emerson Hill, Concord, S.I.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- An offer to operate under President Roosevelt's blanket re-employment agreement with a number of modifications was presented today to the Recovery Administration by the nation's newspaper publishers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City started the defense of her women's Western Golf Association title today by defeating Mrs. H. Austin Pardue of Minneapolis, 1 up, in the opening round of the championship flight.
Sites for new dwellings were bought in Ridgewood and River Edge, N.J., yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Ten stake races for purses totaling $40,000 have been approved by the Maryland Racing Commission for the Laurel track in Maryland, which will hold its twenty-five-day horse racing meet during October.
Langdon W. Post, the Assemblyman who was denied renomination last year by Tammany, was picked last night as the fusion nominee for President of the Borough of Manhattan.
UNIONTOWN, Pa., Aug. 8. -- President Roosevelt intervened directly in the Pennsylvania soft coal strike today and settled it.

Although kidnapping and blackmail were suggested yesterday as possible motives for the mysterious murder of Henry F. Sanborn, railroad executive, Queens authorities said that they had made little progress toward a solution.
Purchases on Riverside Drive and Gold Street and the leasing of several west side dwellings formed the major items of interest in Manhattan realty trading yesterday.

The Dancing Masters of America, Inc., representing 4,500 dancing instructors in this country, have devised a new step called the Nira, in honor of the National Recovery Act, it was announced yesterday at the organization's golden jubilee convention at the Hotel New Yorker.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Equaling par on his last round, Willie Turnesa, 19-year-old Fairview golfer, led the eighty-four players from the metropolitan district and elsewhere who competed at the Siwanoy Country Club today for the right to enter the national amateur championship next month.

VIENNA, Aug. 8 -- The Austrian Government, while pleased that the great powers have intervened in its behalf in Berlin, will not itself take up any attitude in the matter unless and until they take further action.

Responding to Mayor O'Brlen's recent order to cut budget expenses to the bone "and then scrape the bone," twenty-two city and county departments submitted estimates yesterday showing a net budget decrease of $174,761 for the lot.

BERLIN, Aug. 8 -- The auxiliary police force in Prussia, consisting of Nazi brown shirts with a sprinkling of Stahlhelm men, has been abolished by an order of Premier Goering which will become effective Aug. 15.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Management and labor in bituminous coal mining, one of the nation's basic industries, will begin the attempt to decide on a code at a hearing tomorrow before the National Recovery Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Credit for the Haitian agreement signed yesterday at Port au Prince for the removal of United States Marines and less stringent financial arrangements, effective Oct. 1, 1934, was given by Secretary of State Hull today largely to the efficient administration of that country's affairs by the government under President Stenio Vincent.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,679,200 barrels, compared with 2,697,850 barrels in the preceding week, a decline of 18,650 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 32,150 barrels in the daily output of Oklahoma and a gain of 6,100 barrels in California were the most important changes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Immediate savings from President Roosevelt's government reorganization program originally estimated by Democrats in Congress at upward of $25,000,000, were said at the Budget Bureau today to have been reduced to a rate of around $5,000,000 annually by executive orders modifying the plans.

Controller Charles W. Berry issued a formal statement yesterday complaining that he had been misquoted last Friday when he arrived home from a European trip, which, he said, was paid for entirely out of his own pocket.

East side Manhattan crosstown traffic was speeded up as much as 50 per cent yesterday when a new-timing schedule for traffic lights was put into effect. First Deputy Police Commissioner Philip D. Hoyt, in charge of traffic, made an inspection tour of the area affected and pronounced the new system "a great success."

ALBANY, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Non-striking New York dairymen fought back today against strikers and alleged terrorists who have succeeded in closing or virtually closing many up-State milk plants and causing a milk shortage in two cities.

The reports of 151 Class I steam railways to the Interstate Commerce Commission for May show an aggregate net loss of $3,101,140 after taxes and charges, compared with a net loss of $29,791,305 in May, last year. The net operating income of these roads was $40,680,527 in May, against $11,665,701 in May, 1932.

The Citizens Budget Commission and the City Club expressed their endorsement yesterday of the principle of a city tax on transportation fares to raise relief funds, while the Fifth Avenue Association renewed its opposition to the city sales tax pending at Albany.

An injunction to restrain the Associated Gas and Electric Company from rearranging its debt capitalization was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck in a suit by Mrs. Elizabeth E. Rabenold as the owner of $165,000 convertible 4 1/2 per cent gold debentures due in 1949, in behalf of herself and other debenture holders.

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- The reply of Under-Secretary von Buelow of the German Foreign Office to the French Ambassador yesterday in regard to Austria and the manner in which it was communicated to the press through the Wolff and Conti agencies are expected to do more to stiffen French national policy than any single event that has happened in recent years.

Daphne du Maurier, author of "The Loving Spirit" and "I'll Never Be Young Again," has written a new novel, "The Progress of Julius," which Doubleday, Doran Co., Inc., will publish today. The author is the 27-year-old daughter of the actor Gerald du Maurier and the granddaughter of George du Maurier, whose "Trilby" and "Peter Ibbetsen" brought him fame.
A heavy wave swept forty children off a sandbar at Edgemere, Queens, yesterday afternoon and turned an orphans' outing at the beach into one of the season's worst bathing tragedies.

HORTA, Azores, Aug. 8 -- General Aldo Pellegrini, second in command of the Italian armada, received an enthusiastic ovation from the waiting crowd as he climbed from the cockpit of his flying boat here this afternoon. He showed no sign of weariness after the 1,400- mile flight from Shoal Harbor, Nfld.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 5:
Price movements in local commodities markets were again irregular yesterday. In the case of several staples, prices moved higher after unsettled openings. Cash prices also were irregular.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Mortimer L. Shuford Jr., 12-year-old son of a New York attorney who lives at 10 Bailey Place here, was found by his father early tonight hanging from a rafter in the cellar of the home. The boy had been in good spirits all day and had been riding in the afternoon with his mother.

JACKSON, Wyo., Aug. 8. -- Investigation of the efforts of John D. Rockefeller Jr. to bring into Federal ownership and control the mountain and valley border land needed to complete the Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks entered a controversial stage this afternoon.
Completed plans for the proposed Hudson River tunnel and viaduct from Nyack to Tarrytown will permit immediate construction if the project is approved under the Federal public works program.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- The public is regarded as gradually coming back into the grain markets, outside buying increasing today in both corn and oats on the Board of Trade. Part of this was ascribed to the monetary conferences scheduled between President Roosevelt and his advisers and part to a general return of confidence.

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- Mainbocher shows, in the display of Autumn and Winter fashions here, a sensationally successful modernization of lines associated with the 1912 period. He is reviving long-sheath skirts, flaring cutaway peplums, flounced bustle or cascade back vogrues, and also basque jackets with flaring backs.
HAVANA, Aug. 8 -- The formula for a solution of Cuba's problems presented by United States Ambassador Welles to President Machado today embodied, it was revealed, the following points:

President Roosevelt's program for national recovery does not attempt to set up a super-government over business or industry but plans to give them the opportunity to govern themselves. Postmaster General James A. Farley declared last night in a radio address over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 8 -- Mrs. Moses Taylor this afternoon opened her gardens at the Glen for the benefit of the Civic League. In the evening she gave a small dinner, later taking her guests to the Casino Theatre. The Casino Players presented as their fifth production "The Command to Love." with Henry Hull and Gale Sondergaard in the leading roles.

Secretary HUGHES, when defining the relations of the United States with Haiti, said that this country had no aim but to establish peace and stability, coveted no part of Haiti, and would welcome the day " when it can " leave Haiti with the reasonable as" surance that the Haitians will be able " to maintain an independent govern"ment competent to keep order and " discharge its international obliga" tions."

One of the most elaborate codes submitted so far under the government's recovery program is that for the cane sugar refining industry filed with the Secretary of Agriculture under the Agricultural Adjustment Act. A proposed code for the beet sugar industry was filed at the same time.

The American Superpower Corporation issued yesterday a special report for the seven months ended on July 31 showing securities owned with a market value of $60,219,230 on that date against a market value of $33,517,880 on Jan. 17, 1933, for investments held on Dec. 31, 1932, and one of $27,212,814 for investments held on June 9, 1932.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr. was laid to Manny Strewl and "several others" by District Attorney Delaney here today.

While speculative elements in Wall Street would have preferred to ascribe yesterday's measured advance on the Stock Exchange to the revival of inflation talk, they had to concede that other influences were at work. The point was emphasized, in many informed quarters that, at the beginning of the second week in August -- the "dog days" -- there has been no widespread decline in business activity.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr. was laid to Manny Strewl and "several others" by District Attorney Delaney here today.
CULVER, Ind., Aug. 8 -- Two stars fell by the wayside and several others had narrow escapes in play for the national Junior and boys' tennis championships today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I see by the papers today that the President is very happy about the way things are turning out, and I wonder if ha understands how much unhappiness and want he has caused many widows and orphans.
This is the season of the year when the angler really should have the preference in news, and yet who is to deny the right of the hunter to advice and information regarding game?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

The government estimate on the cotton crop, issued today, was more than 1,000,000 bales larger than the trade had expected, and prices on the Cotton Exchange broke a half-cent as a result. Although the Crop Reporting Board subtracted 4,247,000 bales from what would otherwise have been an indicated yield of 16,561,000, the probable outturn of only about 700,000 under that of last year was a surprise.

HAVANA, Aug. 8 -- While the Cuban people waited tensely today to learn what action President Gerardo Machado would take in regard to the peace formula presented by United States Ambassador Sumner Welles, various high chiefs of the government were marshaling their forces to oppose intervention by the United States, which they believe to be imminent.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Lefty Grow was reached for fourteen hits by the Red Sox today, but managed to hold them in check while his team-mates were connecting for extra base blows from three pitchers to give the Athletics a 7-to-6 triumph.
ALBANY, Aug. 8. -- Manny Strewl charged with participating in the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr., was lodged in jail here tonight after being taken into custody in the Court House at Monticello.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 8 -- Leading a par-shelling brjgade that shattered qualifying records, Mortie Dutra of Detroit and Jimmy Hines from the Timber Point Club. New York, tied for the national professional golf championship medal today.

Rain last night caused the postponement of the dance program scheduled to be given at the Lewisohn Stadium by Doris Humphrey, Charles Weidman and their concert groups. The first appearance of these dancers in the stadium series will therefore take place tonight, weather permitting.

STONEVILLE, Miss., Aug. 8 (AP). -- In a surprise speech on war debts and tariffs, Secretary of Agriculture Wallace today told several thousand Mississippi, Louisiana and Arkansas farmers gathered in mass meeting here that adjustment of both debts and tariffs would be necessary to revive American farm exports.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Edward D. Duffield, president of the Prudential Insurance Company, issued today the following statement regarding the Home Owners Loan Corporation's bonds:

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 9. -- The negotiations for the sale of the Chinese Eastern Railway which have been in the doldrums have now entered a decisive stage. Abandoning formal procedure, the Soviet representative, Benedict Koslovsky and Manchukuo's Vice Minister for Foreign Affairs, Chuichi Ohashi, who is a Japanese, began private conversations yesterday unattended by Japanese observers or Manchurian delegates.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The following letters and code were submitted to the National Recovery Administration today by the American Newspaper Publishers Association:

As the forty-five employes of the Quintette Hat Company, Inc., on the ninth floor of the twelve-story loft building, at 48 West Thirty-eighth Street, were finishing their work, about 5 P.M. yesterday, four armed robbers entered and held up the girl bookkeeper, who was preparing the weekly pay envelopes The loot amounted to $2,600.

The Allied Owners Corporation, which has its principal office in Brooklyn and is engaged in erecting buildings and selling them on the instalment plan, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal court. The petition, signed by Francis T. Pender, president of the corporation, listed assets of $19,853,588.36 and liabilities of $13,623,675.84.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Speculation on the appointment of a successor to Dr. Paul M. Pearson as Governor of the Virgin Islands has been revived through his presence here to take up general insular affairs with the government.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 8 -- The Belgian State Railways realized $240,000 from the sale of tickets to pilgrims who visited Beauraing over the week-end, it was announced today. Forty pilgrim trains were run, one coming from Utrecht, Holland, with 900 passengers, while large contingents of Germans came from Cologne.

Charging Tammany with waste, inefficiency, corruption and graft, and condemning the organization's political methods as ruthless, greedy, intimidating and coercive, Fiorello H. La Guardia, fusion nominee for Mayor, urged the cooperation of all citizens last night in ousting the present municipal administration at the polls next November.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Concurrently with the new offensive ordered by General Johnson to blanket the country, irrespective of pending or future codes, with modified agreements with the President, it became known today that the weapon of publishing names is to be the first swung against violators of codes and agreements.

Two units of the city subway system in Queens will be opened to the public one minute after midnigut on Aug. 19, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday. One is the line from Eighth Avenue and Fiftieth Street, Manhattan, to Roosevelt Avenue and Broadway, Queens.

GARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Professor Henry Fairfield Osborn, naturalist, celebrated his seventy-sixth birthday today at his home, Castle Rock. He left his estate, 900 feet above the banks of the Hudson, once for a motor trip to Hyde Park, where he was a guest at a tea given by President and Mrs. Roosevelt.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 8 -- "Being a public service corporation whose rates for service are under State regulation by the Public Service Commission of Maryland, we cannot join other classes of industry in submitting a code of fair competition," the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company announced today through Herbert A. Wagner, president.
What Was the Joke? General HUGH JOHNSON could not possibly do more for national recovery in less time than by giving the widest publicity to the joke that made him laugh so heartily early last week.
UNIONTOWN, Pa., Aug. 9. -- The highways of the Western Pennsylvania soft coal region, which had been lined with strike pickets for two weeks, were dotted today with miners going back to work.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The agricultural adjustment administration has returned to the Federal Government for the financing of its operations at a highly favorable interest rate.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- William Ziegler Jr's. Cattail scored his second victory of the meeting when he led by a half length today at the end of the mile of the Mohawk Claiming Stakes. The race had a value of $1,845 to the winner.

Lew Hahn will sever his connection with the Hahn Department Stores, Inc., on Aug. 31, he announced yesterday. His contract with the department store chair will expire on that date and will not be renewed.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Furious hand-to-hand fighting in which forty-two soldiers were killed battling dissident tribesmen at Djebel Babou Sunday was reported in dispatches reaching Rabat today. Two officers and fifty-three soldiers were wounded.

Thus far the National Recovery Act lias not been so much enforced as voluntarily accepted. It is really an extraordinary spectacle presented by the daily record of code after code devised for separate industries and the accumulated signatures of heads of corporations.
BERLIN, Aug. 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Aug. 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 9. -- Mary Reynolds, brown filly owned by W. N. Reynolds of Winston-Salem, N.C., became the favorite for next week's $50,000 Hambletonian Trotting Stake today when she outclassed her rivals in the National Stake for 3-year-olds.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 9 (AP). -- National Guardsmen took up sentry duty in the marble halls of the Kansas Treasury today as State and Federal officials pressed an inquiry into the clever forgery of at least nine issues of municipal bonds.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- The first major program for the reorganization and simplification of Westchester government since the unsuccessful post-war charter fights was started here today with the first meeting of a special committee named by the Board of Supervisors.

The annual music memory contest held by the Goldman Band, under the direction of Edwin Franko Goldman, took place last night on the Mall in Central Park. An audience of 40,000, one of the largest of the Central Park concerts this season was present to participate in the contest and to hear the music that made up the second half of the program.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 9. -- Out of another withering bombardment of par, Olin Dutra, defending titleholder, and Gene Sarazen, outstanding favorite, emerged victorious today in their first-round matches in the Professional Golf Association championship at the Blue Mound Country club.

Indications that the Consolidated Gas Electric Light Company of Baltimore and certain Connecticut utilities were planning to withdraw from the American Gas Association because of their unwillingness to sign a code for the manufactured gas industry were seen here yesterday, following resignations of the Baltimore company and the Hartford Electric Light Company from the Edison Electric Institute for the same reason.
The Yankees are three games behind the Senators in the American League pennant race this morning, because they couldn't do a thing with the pitching of Monte Weaver at the Stadium yesterday.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 9. -- John J. Henkel, 16 years old, a ward of the Cincinnati Juvenile Court, was indicted today on charges growing out of the slaying of Oliver S. Baily, 27, a leader of the younger set of Cincinnati society.

An attempt of the Federal Government to collect additional income tax and interest amounting to $1,980,939.46 from William Fox of the motion-picture industry was revealed by a lien filed in the District Court here yesterday by John S. Shea, deputy collector of internal revenue.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Plans for a survey of kidnapping and racketeering occupied President Roosevelt early this afternoon as he conferred with his two chief lieutenants in this new Federal campaign.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- President Roosevelt appealed to Cuba tonight to submerge political differences in the interest of solving "the problems of starvation and of depression."

A few familiar landmarks are destined to disappear today in Washington. The Prohibition Bureau loses its identity. Its powers of enforcement go off one way, in the direction of a new Division of Investigation in the Department of Justice, while its licensing powers are transferred to the Bureau of Internal Revenue in the Treasury.
The Institute of Pacific Relations will assemble next Monday at Banff, Canada, for a discussion of international economic conflicts. The conference will close Aug. 28.

Three more fusion candidates, W. Arthur Cunningham of Queens for Controller, Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. for District Attorney of New York County and George U. Harvey for Borough President of Queens, were selected yesterday by the harmony committee, headed by Charles C. Burlingham.

Except for raw sugar and copper futures, commodities traded on local exchanges moved to higher price levels yesterday. The volume of trading on most exchanges also showed improvement. Most cash prices were higher.

ABOARD THE MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, Aug. 9 (by Wireless). -- Twelve of General Italo Balbo's victorious air armada swept above us at 8:30 this morning. The van of the squadron swooped low and wagged a signal with gleaming wings. Others, at various altitudes, sped on toward Lisbon.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange not only regained yesterday all the ground lost on Tuesday, but advanced above the level prevailing when the unexpectedly large estimate of the Government's Crop Reporting Bureau appeared. After having sold at 9.49 cents a pound immediately after the report was issued, October recovered a quarter cent on Tuesday, and added another quarter cent yesterday.

The grand jury returned three indictments yesterday against Eugene S. Daniell Jr., charged with gassing the Stock Exchange last Friday, under which the young Boston lawyer, if convicted, could be imprisoned for sixteen years.

ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- Striking milk producers resorted to violence in two instances today, the ninth of the State milk holiday, sending bullets through six tank trucks on the road in Oneida County and braving barrages of tear gas in Broome County to dump milk from conveyances.
IT was about high noon yesterday when Manager Joe Cronin of the Senators finished packing his trunk. Then he hauled out a large book and sat down to look at it.

Not for a long time, if ever, have the city administration and its political bosses been in a quandary equal to the one they are now facing in the matter of new city taxes. The public rose so violently against Mayor O'BRIEN'S happy-thought suggestions that they had to be abandoned.

A brief flurry of excitement over a possible violation of the amateur code by Miss Helen Jacobs, women's national tennis champion, quickly died down yesterday, while the investigation of the amateur standing of Ellsworth Vines Jr. was still under way.
ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- An appeal for further relief to home owners pressed by mortgage payments was carried to legislators today by spokesmen for many groups from New York City.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The Spanish and British Ambassadors formally protested today to Ambassador Welles concerning excesses committed against their nationals in the Cuban disorders, according to authentic advices received here today.
NEW YORK. The Spanish Ambassador, Don Juan Francisco de Cardenas, and Senora de Cardenas are at the Ambassador.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 9. -- One by one the creations of the New York Yacht Club came into the harbor here today. Tonight, when anchor lights began twinkling, the mouth of the Thames looked like an illuminated amusement park.

HORTA, Azores, Aug. 9. -- Thousands of spectators lining the waterfront at Ponta Delgada saw the flying boat I-Rani of the Italian air squadron turn over and crash to the water in taking off this morning. Lieutenant Enrico Squaglia, second pilot, died from his injuries. The remaining three members of its crew. Captain Celso Ranieri, Sergeant-Mechanic Luigi Cremaschi ind Radio Sergeant Aldo Boveri, were injured.
Following is the "Plan and Purpose of the New York State and City Committees Directing the Campaign in Support of the President's Program for National Recovery" as adopted here yesterday:

The Board of Education received a report at its meeting yesterday showing contributions by teachers and other employes to the school relief fund of $103,224 during June and July. The total contributed since the fund was started in October, 1930, is $3,518,000 and the total from all sources $3,553,555.

Sixty-one policemen were transferred yesterday by Police Commissioner Bolan from division details, including plain-clothes work, patrol supervision, clerical work and special assignments, to new posts. The transfers constituted the first large shake-up since Mr. Bolan became commissioner.

Jose Iturbi, the pianist, who will appear for the first time in America as conductor next Sunday night at the symphony concert in the Lewisohn Stadium as well as in the role of soloist, declared yesterday that he would not play a Liszt concerto, but only a Beethoven concerto, before he conducted the orchestra in the performance of the "Eroica" symphony.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 9. -- The F. Trubee Davison party has obtained five elephants to complete the Akeley group at the American Museum of Natural History.

Publication of the autobiography of Colonel A.A. ANDERSON is timely in that it recalls the creation of the Yellowstone Forest Reserve, of which he was the first superintendent. When he went to Wyoming the Government had not prohibited the free grazing of cattle on public lands.
HAVANA, Aug. 9. -- President Machado this afternoon declared a state of war throughout Cuba and ordered the army to take control as the turbulent political situation reached an impasse.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The text of the code of fair competition for grain exchanges and their members is as follows:

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 9 (AP). -- The Federal Government marshaled its court and investigating forces today for an onslaught on the kidnappers of William Hamm Jr., St. Paul brewer, and Charles F. Urschel, Oklahoma oil man.

PARIS, Aug. 9. -- Germany's reply to the Franco-British "friendly reminder" that Austria is an independent country and must remain so has aroused, as was to be feared, a somewhat polemical spirit within this country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Federal appointments in New York City are being held up until after the selection of the city ticket, it became known today. Although the Tammany leaders have strongly urged the President to fill the jobs in advance of that time, he has refused and has not even intimated that they will be recognized in the few jobs not yet filled in Manhattan.

ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- Acting swiftly and at the request of Governor Lehman today, the Legislature passed a bill empowering Sheriffs in the counties torn by the milk strike to appoint as many special deputies as they needed to maintain order.
Controller Charles W. Berry announced yesterday that he was not a candidate for renomination.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 9 (AP). -- General Mario G. Menocal. Cuban Opposition leader, predicted today that within "forty-eight to seventy-two hours" the United States Government would publicly renounce President Machado or armed revolt would break out in every province of the island republic.

Officials made little progress yesterday in establishing responsibility for the drowning of seven inmates of the Pride of Judea Home off Edgemere, Queens, or in recovering the bodies of the six boys still missing.

Captain C.T.I. Roark, field leader of Great Britain's international polo team in 1930, is scheduled to play today in the club polo at Meadow Brook. This will be his first match here this season. He arrived from England on Tuesday.

BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- The German newspapers announce under page-wide banner headlines today that according to figures of the National Insurance Institute the number of jobless in Germany decreased 358,000 more in the second half of July and now totals only 4,486,000.

BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- The Boerse was colorless but more hopeful today. Reports of a new and substantial drop in the official figures of unemployment, an increase in the Reichsbank's note coverage from 9.2 to 9.9 per cent and the decree of Premier Goering of Prussia against official interference in productive business contributed to the improvement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Nonunion bituminous coal operators today refused to withdraw the company-union provision from their proposed code and rejected the idea of government supervision of their industry.

SUFFERN, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- The village zoning commission met tonight with four or five residents to discuss the objections of the community to the German-American Commercial League, which has a camp here on a fifty-acre tract leased for a year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- President Roosevelt's board to arbitrate labor troubles in the coal fields, seeking today to put a final end to the Pennsylvania coal strike, issued after a brief hearing a ruling on how check weighmen should be elected -- one of the points of controversy between labor and operators.

HONOLULU, Aug. 9. -- Two officers and three enlisted men of the United States Navy were killed here today when a twin-motored patrol plane in which they were flying crashed on a coral reef about a mile off Fort Weaver. A fourth enlisted man, who was in the plane, escaped with slight injuries.

In a letter to Miss Mary Van Kleeck, director of industrial studies of the Russell Sage Foundation, Mrs. Gertrude Beeks Easley, who was secretary of the executive committee of the Committee on Labor of the Council of National Defense during the war, took issue yesterday with Miss Van Kleeck on "several vital points" raised by her when she resigned last Sunday from the Advisory Council of the United States Employment Service.

JACKSON, Wyo., Aug. 9. -- The alleged skyrocketing of Jackson Hole real estate values through the application of a "repurchase system" by persons, whose holdings were in the shadow of the Grand Teton, was described at today's hearing in the investigation of the acquisition of the properties to present to the nation for a park and wild game reservation.
BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- What to do about the "Marxist" small fry interned in the concentration camps has become an increasingly difficult problem for the Nazi authorities.

LONDON, Aug. 9. -- A report on the vexed question of North Atlantic passenger rates, it is understood, has been signed by members of the enlarged special committee appointed by the North Atlantic Shipping Conference and will shortly be submitted to the full conference.

Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. is a descendant of an old Dutch family, and a son of Jacob Gould Schurman, who was president of Cornell University from 1892 to 1920, Minister Plenipotentiary to China from 1921 to 1925, and Ambassador to Germany from 1925 to 1930.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Every one must sympathize with the efforts of Governor Lehman as expressed in his recent message to the Legislature advocating relief to mortgagors. In almost every instance it is to the best interest not only of the mortgagor but of the mortgagee as well to postpone foreclosures.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Further indications of improving business are found in the Federal Reserve Board's monthly report showing that department store sales in July were 4 per cent greater than a year ago. Reports came from 431 stores in 212 leading cities.

Sales and leases of residential properties featured the Manhattan realty transactions as reported by brokers yesterday. The purchases included a private home and a tenement on the west side, and the leases covered both east and west side properties.

Bancroft Mitchell, son of the former United States Attorney General, when interviewed yesterday by newspaper correspondents in Florence, Italy, expressed complete willingness to cooperate with the New York police in their investigation into the murder of Henry F. Sanborn, railroad executive.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- The Oakland Grove Hotel, a large adjoining boathouse in which there were fifteen motor boats, two bungalows and a garage were completely destroyed tonight by the most spectacular fire Lake George has witnessed in more than twenty years.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Many governmental bureaus and establishments go into the discard tomorrow under the economy reorganization program of President Roosevelt.

ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- Mayor O'Brien's New York City tax program, incorporated in the Buckley bill, upon which there was a public hearing before the Senate and Assembly committees on taxation and retrenchment yesterday, was committed today to the legislative scrap heap.

LONDON, Aug. 9. -- News from Berlin of the issuance by the Foreign Exchange Control Department of an order which, if enforced, would "compel British and other foreign shipping companies to close their offices in Germany" aroused great interest among British shipowners who have been calling for reports.

Deserving Democrats are so multitudinous, patient and largely unrewarded that it is a pleasure to come upon some of them in their hour of public testimony against the prosperity of the wicked. To the Oregon brethren have been given grapes of gall. A Republican has been appointed Federal re-employment director.

YORKLYN, Del., Aug. 9 (AP). -- Breaking 497 out of 500 targets, Joseph F. Hiestand of Hillsboro, Ohio, won the 500-target amateur championship of the world today. He scored in the feature event of the second day's card of the thirteenth annual T. Clarence Marshall trapshooting classic.

The adjusted index of electric power production suffered a fractional loss for the week ended Aug. 5, the figure dropping back to 96.7 from 97.4 in the previous week. The index stood at 83.6 in the corresponding week of last year. A drop in actual output at a period when the seasonal factor is unchanged was responsible for the loss.

Leading copper executives, who, for the last few weeks have been writing a code for that industry under the National Industrial Recovery Act, went on Tuesday night to Washington, where they expect to complete their task before the administrator of the act takes the work out of their hands.

A proposal that courts receive wide discretionary powers of relief in threatened foreclosure on farms and homes, even where taxes and interest are unpaid, was embodied in the report of Governor Lehman's State Farm and Home Mortgage Advisory Committee, made public yesterday.

An eight-hour day for policemen in third-class cities and in towns and villages of the State will be sought through legislative action, as the result of a resolution adopted yesterday at the State Police Conference in session at the Hotel Waldorf Astoria.

As the Federal Government's drive against racketeers proceeds, there are going to be some "surprising denouements," Randolph C. Shaw, a special Assistant Attorney General, specializing on beer racket cases, said yesterday. Mr. Shaw was interviewed at the Hotel New Yorker, where he arrived after completing the Union City Brewery case in Newark.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- President Roosevelt's National Labor Board of Mediation took a decisive step today in the recovery drive, summoning manufacturers and workers involved in hosiery and shirtmakers' strikes to appear in Washington.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 9 (AP). -- Rochester slipped into a tie for second place with Baltimore today by losing twice to Newark, 8 to 5 and 7 to 2. Jimmy DeShong and Jim Weaver were the victorious hurlers. The latter gained his twentieth triumph of the season, as he set back the Red Wings with four hits.

MARSEILLES, Aug. 9. -- Great preparations are being made at the Istres naval aviation station near this city for the reception of General Balbo and his air armada. They are expected to halt there on the flight to Rome. It is believed the Italian aviators will reach Marseilles Thursday.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 9. -- Karl Maria von Weber's opera "Oberon," which has almost disappeared from the world's opera stages, except for Salzburg, was given here tonight for the only time at this season's festival. It has seldom been produced elsewhere since this century began.

PARIS, Aug. 9. -- Adjustments in the general tariff rates on products from the United States, increased by the decree of July 14, will be announced in tomorrow's Journal Officiel, it was learned tonight.

LISBON, Aug. 9. -- Twenty-three flying boats of General Italo Balbo's Italian air armada settled down this afternoon, amid the cheers of a large crowd of Portuguese, on the Tagus River at Alfeite, opposite Lisbon. They had completed the final ocean flight, from the Azores, in their long voyage from Orbetello, Italy, to Chicago and back.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The President's nation-wide reforestation program is now operating at top speed in all sections of the country.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Charles P. Howard, president of the International Typographical Union, in a statement tonight, declared that the code submitted yesterday by the American Newspaper Publishers Association "does not conform to either the spirit or the letter" of the National Industrial Recovery Act.

A prisoner, fleeing from the Snyder Avenue Police Station, Brooklyn, after knocking down a detective and diving through a window, was shot by a policeman on the campus of Erasmus Hall High School yesterday. About twenty-five policemen and detectives took part in the pursuit, which attracted a crowd of about 500.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- Mrs. Gregg Lifur of Los Angeles squared an old account today when she wrecked Mrs. Opal Hill's chances for a fourth women's Western golf championship. She toppled the champion, 3 and 2, in the second round of the thirty-first annual renewal of the tournament and reached the quarter-finals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Four new statements of registration of security issues were announced today by the Federal Trade Commission, bringing the total securities registered to more than $166,479,900. The list today follows:

Acceptance of the code filed with the National Recovery Administration by the American Newspaper Publishers Association was announced yesterday by many newspapers. Among them were THE NEW YORK TIMES, the Scripps-Howard and the Hearst newspapers, The New York Evening Post, The New York Herald Tribune and The Brooklyn Daily Eagle.

ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- The fourth successive monthly advance in the State's factory employment and wage payments occurred from the middle of June to the middle of July, according to Industrial Commissioner Elmer F. Andrews. The grain in employment amounted to 4.2 per cent and in payrolls to 6 per cent.
Plaintiffs bid in fourteen properties in Manhattan and the Bronx at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The results follow:
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Piling up six runs in the first inning, the Red Sox defeated the Athletics, 8 to 4, today, to wind up the three-game series with two victories to one for Philadelphia.

Snappers have arrived at Sheepshead Bay and Rockaway Point, according to reports received yesterday. And for that matter pier and bulkhead fishing is being enjoyed in almost all the waters of Greater New York as well as down Long Island way and at favored spots along the New Jersey coast.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 9. -- Mrs. Garrow T. Geer gave a large reception this afternoon at Redbrook, her place in Noyack Road. At the tea table were Mrs. Albert F. Jaeckel and Mrs. Francis Oakey.

DUBLIN, Aug. 9. -- When the Dail Eireann met this evening for the fast sitting of the present session, President de Valera introduced three bils to amend the Constitution that would sever three more links between the British crown and the Free State charter.

The hearings before the Public Service Commission on earnings of the electric utility companies in the city and suburban areas as a basis for temporary emergency rate reductions were completed yesterday. A decision by the commission is expected next week.

About 36,000 sales tax returns, yielding total cash payments of $2,657,000, have been filed at the State tax collection offices at 80 Centre Street and 150 Court Street, Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by W.M. Dawson and H.B. Cocheu, district tax supervisors.

PEIPING, Aug. 9. -- Meager facts of the bombing by Japanese airplanes of the village of Pingtingpu, near Kuyuan, about 120 miles north of Peiping, were contained in a telegram received here today from a Belgian priest of a Catholic mission in the village.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- General Hugh S. Johnson, the Recovery Administrator, studied today the code submitted by the American Newspaper Publishers Association and a decision may soon be made on whether it is acceptable. It is known that privately he had expressed some objections to it, but aides said no final opinion has been formulated.
The State and city re-employment committees moved forward rapidly yesterday in their joint endeavor to make New York State and New York City the leaders in the national NRA campaign.

Common stock of the Beneficial Industrial Loan Corporation has been approved for listing by the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange. This is the first time that the shares of a corporation whose income is derived entirely from the granting of small personal loans have been approved for listing by the Exchange.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 9. -- It is beginning to look as if Willie Turnesa, Westchester County's 19year-old champion, is the boy that other golfers in the metropolitan district have to beat in tournaments.

With sixty-four entrants listed, the draw for the women's national singles tennis championship was made yesterday at the offices of the United States Lawn Tennis Association. The tourney will start Monday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.
The air transport division of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, Inc., presented its code yesterday at the offices of General Hugh S. Johnson and made public a copy here.

TOKYO, Aug. 9. -- Scenes and sounds of simulated warfare were loosed on Tokyo today for the "spiritual education" of the 15,000,000 inhabitants of the metropolitan area as the navy and the army started a three-day sham battle for possession of the capital.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Manufacturers in most of the clothing and textile lines have been forced to capacity operation to meet the demands of wholesalers and retailers, who have bought madly for the past few months in expectation of higher prices. Although in most cases unwarranted, higher prices have been realized.
BOSTON, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Ben Cantwell hung up his fifteenth pitching triumph today. His squeeze bunt in the fifth inning brought in the run that gave the Braves a 3-to-2 triumph over the Phillies.

All markets showed pronounced strength yesterday in more active trading. Stocks, in which transactions were twice as heavy as on the day before, closed 1 to 6 points higher, and there were wide advances in bonds and commodities.

PEIPING, China, Aug. 9. -- North China military headquarters of the Chinese Nationalist government announced today that 6,000 Japanese and Manchukuoan troops had invaded Chinese territory in Chahar Province at Dolon Nor in resumption of Chino-Japanese hostilities.

BERLIN, Aug. 9. -- Considerable confusion has arisen in the offices of foreign shipping companies about the new order received from the Foreign Exchange Control Department, which appeared to mean that intending travelers would have to apply for special permission from foreign exchange control offices before booking passage with a foreign line, though they would be at liberty to book freely with the German lines.

JACKSON, Wyo., Aug. 9. -- The Senate committee inquirying into the land purchases of John D. Rockefeller Jr. in the Jackson Hole Country was asked today by State Senator William D. Deloney to "get this thing settled for us so we may go on with our work."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The average person must wonder why the terms of the laundry industry which were rejected by the Recovery Administration were ever submitted for consideration. For the East the minimum rates did not exceed 25 cents an hour, an insignificant amount compared with the rates of other industries.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 9. -- Warren Christner, a Topeka youngster, sprang the big surprise of today's play for the boys' national tennis championship when he defeated Roy Velinder of San Antonio, Texas, in a third-round match, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

Who is this Secretary of Agriculture telling the farmers in the Mississippi Valley how to recover their export business? It is Mr. WALLACE, a member of the Cabinet which is said to have made up its mind to drop everything else and go in for "economic nationalism."

Burger Court, a six-story elevator apartment house at the northeast corner of 169th Street and the Grand Concourse, was sold yesterday by the owner, Solomon Schelemsky, to the Wingdon Realty Corporation, of which H. Lee Lurie is president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Reported criticism by members of the American Veterans' Association that American Legion members dominated the first special Investigating boards named by General Hines to review the more than 453,000 "presumptive" cases of veterans disability failed today to bring a reply from the Veterans' Administration, the American Legion, Veterans of Foreign Wars or the Disabled American Veterans.

The proposed price control provision, which many executives are seeking to have included in the oil code being drawn in Washington, does not mean the fixing of rigid prices for the ultimate consumer as in the case, for example, of public utilities, according to Henry M. Dawes, president of the Pure Oil Company.
Ben Jeby, east side yougster, whose oaken strength is his greatest recommendation, was knocked out at the Polo Grounds last night and lost his world's middleweight championship.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The grain exchanges submitted a code today which includes the emergency restrictions on speculative trading and price fluctuations under which they are now operating and increases margin requirements on a sliding scale based on the size of contracts.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 9. -- By winning first place, two seconds and a third in the series concluded today off the Bay Shore Yacht Club, the Bay Shore crew won the junior championship of Great South Bay. It earned the right to compete in the junior championship of United States and Canada at Gloucester, Mass., for the Sears Trophy.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP). -- Cleverly rated by Wayne Wright, Gay World from the stables of J.A. Nix of California galloped to victory today in the Round Lake Purse at Hawthorne.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is not too late for America to preserve her financial honor. We have a mountain of gold, could easily spare one thousand million or it for foreign creditors in the unlikely contingency that so much would be demanded of us.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- At least a billion dollars will be needed this Winter to meet unemployment relief needs, Harry L. Hopkins, Federal relief administrator, declared today.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- President Roosevelt hailed today a chart showing that between March 4 and July 31, the first five months of his administration, prices of commodities had risen to about the average levels of 1910 to 1914. It is understood that the administration's objective on prices is the average of the 1924-26 levels.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Production of crude petroleum in June amounted to 82,841,000 barrels, the Bureau of Mines announced today. This was a decrease of nearly 2,000,000 barrels from the May output, although the daily average (2.762,000 barrels) was 28,000 barrels greater than in May.

Black Leads in Early Reorders. The early reorders now being received on women's Fall coats, dresses and accessories indicate black is beginning to move well in retail channels, with marked favor also accorded the gray and brown hues.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP). -- The Cubs battered their erstwhile teammate, Burleigh Grimes, out of action in less than an inning today. They continued their assault against Sylvester Johnson and Tex Carleton to defeat the Cardinals, 10 to 7, in the final contest of a two-game series.

While Wall Street stressed yesterday the so-called "private advices" from Washington which stirred the hopes of inflationists, the best judgment was that the share market, by advancing sharply, was simply responding to favorable developments in domestic business.
Ben Jeby weighed 159 pounds and Lou Brouillard scaled 158 1/2 for their world's championship middleweight fight at the Polo Grounds last night.

A decision yesterday by City Court Justice James C. Madigan regarding the possession of a diamond disclosed that for the last three years the jewelry trade, pawnbrokers and loan associations have incurred many losses through dealing with persons representing that they had power to sell or pawn diamonds and other gems, whereas they actually had acquired them under memorandum agreements and could not convey title.

About 400 photographic studies of pet animals, mostly dogs, and their owners were displayed yesterday in the small ballroom of the Hotel Plaza under auspices of the New York State Committee Against Vivisection.

TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 10. -- Tokyo's colored lights were darkened last night when citizens cooperated with the army in the most elaborate training for an anti-air attack ever undergone by any capital in peace time.

A release of $465,400 gold from earmark and the shipment of an equal amount abroad, $347,200 to France and $118,200 to Germany, was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The gold shipped to Germany was metal that had been earmarked months ago.

The New York entry in the eleventh annual national public parks clay-court championship tourney was reduced to two players yesterday. The survivors gained the semi-final bracket in the women's division and the quarterfinal round in the men's section.

BAGDAD, Iraq, Aug. 9. -- The government of Iraq has protested to the League of Nations on the fighting between Assyrian raiders and Iraq troops. Iraq intimates that the French mandatory government in Syria is responsible for the loss of life in Iraq and for the expense to which Iraq has been put by the failure of Syria to prevent the incursion.
TORONTO, Aug. 9 (AP). -- An early attack in the first game and one big frame in the second contest today gave Toronto a double victory over Jersey City. The score of each game was 6 to 2.

Money market was quiet. No changes were reported either in quotation or volume. Stock Exchange call loans were done at 1 per cent, as usual, outside money at 3/4, and Federal funds 1/3. Time money continued easy, with nominal quotations for all maturities prevailing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that beer has returned, I wonder if the public is cognizant of the fallacy in the widespread belief that since it is mild and non-intoxicating, it is therefore perfectly innocuous. We may find it linking up with a threatening increase in the already alarming statistics of automobile accidents.

Within a few hours after he had given Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins his resignation, Immigration Commissioner Edward Corsi was requested by the Secretary to remain at his post to guide the bureau through its reorganization, he revealed last night.

The vast ramifications of the fortune owned by the Mellon family and the extent to which it affects the average American citizen are discussed by Harvey O'Connor in "Mellon's Millions -- The Biography of a Fortune," published today by the John Day Company.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- The defeat of Miss Joan Ridley of England and Keith Gledhill of Santa Barbara marked a day notable for the high quality of the women's tennis and the difficulties experienced by the elect in the men's singles today at the Westchester Country Club.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 9. -- The harbor here was virtually deserted today for nearly all of the yachts that were in port had departed to join the New York Yacht Club fleet at New London for the cruise. The Lone Star with Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Prince left yesterday.

HAVANA, Aug. 9. -- The general strike in Cuba has given "enemies of the public peace" an opportunity "to create a revolutionary state in the country," it was stated today in President Machado's decree declaring a state of war, to come into effect at 6 o'clock this evening.

Although the demand for steel is "commencing to waver in the face" of labor troubles, soaring fuel prices and "confusion growing out of the application of the NRA blanket code," operation in the industry remain at about 57 per cent of ingot capacity, which is approximately the same as a week ago, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age.

The first appearance of Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman and their dance groups at the Lewisohn Stadium was without question a great success. A wellchosen program containing several novelties, superb teamwork by the group and the distinguished dancing of the principals combined to set a new standard for Stadium performances.

ALBANY, Aug. 9. -- Indicted for the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr. with ten unidentified persons, Manny Strewl, ex-convict and intermediary in the ransom payment, pleaded not guilty when he was arraigned here today.

More testimony concerning threats and sabotage in the Brooklyn laundry trade was given in yesterday's session of the trial of Jacob Mellon, alleged laundry "czar," and two other members of the Affiliated Laundry Owners Club of Brooklyn.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 10. -- The Cold Spring Harbor Yacht Club won a second leg on the Commodore Robert Law Cup today with a total of 31 points as the series for junior yachtsmen under 18 years came to a close at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club course.

Dr. William J. Mayo, one of the founders of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., said yesterday that if he could advise all the medical students in the country with one word he would tell them to become general practitioners instead of specialists.

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation decreased 86,546 tons in July, according to official figures issued yesterday showing bookings for 2,020,125 tons on July 31, comparing with 2,106,671 on June 30. This was the first decline since March, when unfilled orders were 1,841,002 tons, the low mark for the depression.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- A dispatch to The London Times from Berlin says that misgivings of foreign shipping lines as to their future activities in Germany were intensified today when it was found the most rigid construction was being put on the order issued by the Foreign Exchange Control Department regarding passages booked on foreign ships.

A leading New Jersey deal yesterday was the sale of an eight-acre property on Egbert Hill, Morristown, by the Morris County Savings Bank. The place was owned for some years by Livingston Whitney and later by Mrs. Roy C. Cool. It has now been purchased by Charles H. Colvin through Eugene V. Welsh, broker in the deal.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Wholesale arrests were made today by State troopers and Sheriffs' deputies in their effort to break the backbone of the ten-day-old strike of milk producers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Mrs. Roosevelt expressed concern today about minimum wages for women lower than for men as embodied in several of the industrial codes, and said that she intended to discuss the matter with Secretary Perkins and General Johnson.

Magistrate Goldstein in the Tombs court yesterday found Miss Hortense Danaher, 425 West End Avenue, dismissed city employe, guilty of disorderly conduct on July 17 last. In causing a disturbance in a lawyer's office at 401 Broadway. Miss Danaher, who said she was an investigator, was ordered to give $500 bond to keep the peace for six months.
ALBANY, Aug. 10. -- The Senate Codes Committee today struck from the kidnapping bill recommended by Governor Lehman the clause making payment of ransom a felony.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 10 (AP). -- An appeal to the nation to "buy now" in stores displaying the NRA blue eagle was made tonight by General Hugh S. Johnson, the Recovery Administrator.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 10 (AP). -- Canadian field crops will range this year 16 to 57 per cent below the averages, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics forecast today. Drought and heat did heavy damage, especially in Ontario and the Prairie Provinces.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- Firing a round of crackling sub-par golf, Miss Virginia Van Wie of Chicago, the national champion, led the way into the semi-finals of the women's Western title tournament today at the Oak Park Country Club.

Increased industrial activity measured in the amount of dirt in New York's air is one meteorologist's method of reading the signs of the times. David R. Morris, meteorologist at the Central Park Weather Bureau, mentioned this condition as one of many phenomena he had recorded during the month of July.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Aug. 10. -- A spectacular fire tonight leveled a block of frame buildings, including two bathing establishments, comprising part of an amusement park, along the beach front on Raritan Bay. Flames shooting hundreds of feet into the air could be seen for miles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The plaint of the milk producers, as set forth in today's issue by Helen Willcox, certainly gives cause for thought, particularly on the part of a consumer who is paying for bottled milk Grade B 18 cents a quart, for Grade A 20 cents a quart.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 10 (AP). -- Disclosures today raised to $799,000 the amount of forged Kansas municipal bonds involved in a swindle which has brought two arrests, the closing of three banks and the placing of National Guardsmen in the State Treasury.

The sharks now reported as visiting off the ocean beaches in New York's neighborhood are not interested in bathers, but in New York's garbage disposal methods. Their presence in these waters at this season is not unusual or alarming, according to Dr. E.W. Gudger, associate in living fishes at the American Museum of Natural History.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- A decisive length victory for Slapdash in the Schuylerville Stakes caused many observers here today to place her again in the front rank among the 2-year-old fillies.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 10. -- Recovering the brilliant approach shots that made history in his national open play-off against Bobby Jones back in 1928, Johnny Farrell of New York knocked Olin Dutra off his Professional Golf Association national championship throne today.

The Queens Democratic Executive Committee named designees for local offices yesterday and adopted a resolution calling upon the Democratic leaders to nominate a Queens man to head the Board of Aldermen. The committee met in the Jefferson Democratic Club, Flushing.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- An encouraging average of $1,103 per head was realized at the Fasig-Tipton yearling sale tonight as forty-five head were sold for a total of $49,650. The sale was well attended, Harry Giddings being prominent among the buyers.
Day's NRA Developments. Number of employers signing re-employment agreement here approaches 150,000.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- Difficulty in obtaining American visas is holding up fifteen German professors Dr. Alvin Johnson intends to bring to the New School of Social Research in New York, of which, he is the director.
Leonard Hartman, former Columbia tennis captain, provided the major upset in the eleventh annual national public parks championship yesterday at Central Park.
Moving sedately behind another one of those flawless pitching exhibitions, the Giants upset the Phillies with almost ridiculous ease at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Assemblyman David Paris, an attorney, was suspended yesterday from practice in Federal Court for five years by order of Judge Francis G. Caffey, who ruled that he had been guilty of submitting three forged affidavits to the court.

TOKYO, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Testimony that fears of "American domination" were the motive for the assassination of Premier Inukai May 15, 1932, and other terroristic acts was given today by Lieutenant Horishi Yamagishi, leader of the naval officers who are being tried in a naval court on charges of responsibility for those events.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 10. -- Captain C.T.I. Roark, British internationalist, had his first workout of the campaign on American soil at the Meadow Brook Club today. He rode in his accustomed place of No. 3 with a White team which lost a well-contested match to a strong Red side, 11 to 8.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Following is a summary of the plea made by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers of America, at the hearing today on the adoption of a code for the industry:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -- The six government-owned piers in Hoboken, N.J., passed into private bands today after fifteen years of government ownership.
ALBANY, Aug. 10. -- Marked improvement in the milk strike situation was noted by Governor Lehman this afternoon.

Senator Key Pittman of Nevada, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, returned from Europe yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan and said that an "immediate decision" must be taken by the United States in the Cuban crisis.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10. -- The New York Yacht Club fleet arrived on its annual cruise this afternoon. The annual dinner was given by Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt in honor of the flag officers of the club, headed by Commodore Junius Spencer Morgan.
PARIS, Aug. 10 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

An educational dole system which would provide a guaranteed livelihood for the youths of the country "up to the age when society is prepared to offer employment" is part of an eight-point program for the reorganization of education that was adopted yesterday by the National Conference on the Financing of Education, in session at Teachers College, Columbia University.
Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday were irregular, quotations ending 18 to 22 points lower than on Wednesday.

Wall Street found it difficult yesterday to assign reasons for the conflicting market movements. The fact that grains went up while stocks went down distorted the picture. But the impression everywhere was that the share market took undue notice of the readjustment which was reflected in the unfilled, tonnage report of the United States Steel Corporation.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 10 (AP). -- George Ball of El Paso, Texas, and Russell Bobbitt, Atlanta, Ga., scored upset victories to enter the semi-final round of the National Junior and Boys' Tennis Championships today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Dissatisfaction with the proposed code of competition presented by grain exchanges was voiced today by George N. Peek, Chief Farm Administrator, who declared further steps were necessary "to clean house."
Edward Crandall will play opposite Lora Baxter in the Ivor Novello play, "A Party," which will open at the Playhouse the week after next.

Deciding after a brief tour of New York that the buildings are too high and that the London "Underground" is steadier than the subway, William Gilbertson and John Jackson, crew of the British train the Royal Scot, boarded the Broadway Limited yesterday afternoon a bit disillusioned.

The business men of the country must protect from the exploitation of "gyps and racketeers" the new purchasing power created through the NRA, H.J. Kenner, director of the complaint bureau of the New York City NRA Committee and general manager of the Better Business Bureau, said yesterday at a luncheon of the Rotary Club of New York at the Hotel Commodore.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Thousands of us learned with keen interest of the arrival of General Balbo at Lisbon, and many saw his flying boats en route or moored at the landing buoys. All have admired the skill and courage of the Italian airmen which made the flight of 6,000 miles possible.
CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The Campbell Soup Company announced today through its president, Arthur C. Dorrance, a 25 per cent increase in the purchase price of tomatoes under contract from growers.

In subtlety, as in urbanity, the German Foreign Office is worthy of the best Hitlerian tradition. England and France protest against the Nazi propaganda to upset the Austrian Government and substitute the blessed, strictly Aryan regime. The Foreign Office waves the protestants away with a public admonition.

With Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, the Bronx leader, absent, John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, and the three other Democratic county leaders reached a formal decision yesterday to renominate Mayor O'Brien.
