An effort to curtail the number of cruising taxicabs in midtown. Manhattan was begun yesterday by the Police Department. Commissioner Bolan announced that 1,008 new corner stands, at which cabs might wait for fares, would be established as soon as possible.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- For a day on which the singles play was limited to two quarter final matches, the program of competition in the Eastern turf court tennis championships at the Westchester Country Club this afternoon provided entertainment of a remarkably satisfying character.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP). -- In a final statement today as Director of the Prohibition Bureau, Major A.V. Dalrymple charged some of his associates with "duplicity, double-crossing and double-dealing," and demanded that they be let out of government service.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler denied yesterday the application by the Globe and Rutgers Fire Insurance Company to terminate the rehabilitation proceedings started on March 24 last by George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, and permit the company to resume business.

FLORENCE, S.C., Aug. 10 (AP). -- General satisfaction apparently existed among farmers of the South Carolina and border tobacco belts, which opened the season's auction sales today, as substantially higher average prices were paid than on last year's opening.

By the names now added to the city ticket, the Fusion prospects in the coming campaign are distinctly brightened. Selection of Mr. CUNNINGHAM of Queens, formerly of Brooklyn, for Controller assures a spirited fight for that important office. Never did it seem so urgent as at present for the city to have a chief fiscal officer of proved ability and political independence.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 10 (AP). -- In an appeal addressed to the American people, General Mario G. Menocal, former President of Cuba and Oppositionist leader, tonight asserted "Machado is not Cuba" and urged that the island republic be spared intervention by the United States.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 10. -- The Guaranty Trust Company of New York obtained yesterday the right to sue the Central of Georgia Railway and its receiver, H.D. Pollard, on five mortgages securing approximately $11,000,000 in bonds for which it is trustee for the bondholders.
Captain J.A. Mollison, transatlantic flier, will sail on the White Star liner Majestic tonight for England. Mrs. Mollison will sail later in the month on the Britannic.

Sava Kehaya, 43 years old, a former private banker now in the real estate business, and his wife, Mary, 31, were arrested late yesterday afternoon on an attempted grand larceny charge. The charge grew out of an alleged $49,500 jewelry hold-up in their former apartment at 2 East Eighty-eighth Street on the evening of last Oct. 6.

TOKYO, Friday. Aug. 11. -- The elaborate air manoeuvres, simulating an attack by an enemy from "the southeast," were concluded at 5 o'clock this morning. Bombers, flying low over the city, were answered by anti-aircraft guns and machine-guns guided by searchlights.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Representatives of actors, producers, the stage unions and dramatists joined today in voicing approval of the agreement at a bearing on the theatre code. Instead of the dissension heretofore manifested almost tinvariably among those connected with the legitimate theatre, there was virtually complete unanimity.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 10 (AP). -- Dr. Hugh Parshall, one of the outstanding drivers on the Grand Circuit, piloted the bay gelding J.E. Vonian, owned by J.E. Crosbie of Tulsa, Okla., to a surprising triple victory at Rockingham Park today.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 10. -- Tolley's Bunker, a seven-foot cavity guarding the eighteenth green at the Garden City Golf Club, marks the spot where Tommy Goodwin, lanky Monroe youngster, surrendered his title as New York State amateur champion today.

Acceptances of the newspaper code proposed by the American Newspaper Publishers Association continued to come in yesterday from all parts of the country. In New York it was accepted by The New York Sun.
ST. PAUL, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Three men were questioned today by Federal operatives on how they came to possess $1,500 in marked ransom money paid for the release of Charles Urschel.
The United States Army and Miss Liberty, the statue, have parted company after forty-seven years of happy union.

NEW HAMBURG, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Scores of boys who are being transformed from derelicts on city streets into practical farmers gathered around President Roosevelt's car this afternoon and cheered him as he told them of the advantages of farm life.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The Cuban deadlock continued through the day, reports to the State Department indicated. Oscar B. Cintas, the Cuban Ambassador, followed his visit to Hyde Park yesterday by a two-hour conference with Secretary Hull and Undersecretary Phillips today.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 10. -- It seems extremely unlikely that the mediation of Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru in the Chaco dispute will be renewed in accordance with the recent request of Bolivia and Paraguay to the League of Nations to transfer the diplomatic negotiations back to the neighboring republics.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- An important success in President Roosevelt's drive to bring about peace between labor and industry was recorded tonight when the National Labor Board persuaded employers and employes involved in the hosiery mill strike in Pennsylvania to sign an agreement which will end the eight-week dispute.

An increase of $18,277,000 in the gold reserves of the Federal Reserve System was the principal item of interest in the weekly report issued yesterday. This advance, reflecting the transfer of gold certificates from the Treasury to the Reserve Banks, lifted the gold reserves to a high record at $3,577,7S7,000.

The New York Curb Exchange has been notified by the National Union Radio Corporation its certificate of incorporation has taken amended so as to authorize 10,000 shares of new no par preferred stock. The company is issuing new permanent common stock certificates, bearing on the reverse side a statement of the designations and preferences of the preferred and common shares.

Angered at the fact that the law permitted only the imposition of a fine for failing to return a $10 fee to a jobless hotel clerk, more than 200 unemployed, complainants in similar actions, attempted in West Side Court yesterday to attack Harry Augustern, of 666 West End Avenue, an employment agent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The Cuban military establishment consists of about 12,000 men, according to the latest information available here today. This force is divided into the regular army of slightly fewer than 6,000 men and the Rural Guard of slightly more than 6,000 men.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Aug. 9, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,215,000,000, an increase of $6,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $161,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- A further general decline in the prospects for crops was reported by the Department of Agriculture today on the basis of Aug. 1 conditions.

Uncertainty surrounding the unfilled tonnage report of the United States Steel Corporation had an unsettling effect upon the share market yesterday after many stocks, favored by speculators, had extended their gains of the previous day.

PARIS, Aug. 10. -- Tariff relief was granted in a decree published today to more than seventy products of the United States. This result is being hailed as a triumph for Ambassador Straus on his first major diplomatic task.

Strength in almost all United States Government bonds on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday greeted the admission to dealings of about $500,000,000 Treasury 3 1/4s of 1941 on a when-issued basis. The new series opened at 100.19 on a lot of $17,000, the day's low, and closed at 100.21 after reaching 100.23.

Almost 200 house servants, char-women, storekeepers and other hard-working folk of German extraction crowded Magistrate Earl A. Smith's court room in Yorkville yesterday at the arraignment of Lorenz Strack, real estate broker.

A Brooklyn laundry owner testified yesterday that his refusal to pay $80 in "back dues" to the Affiliated Laundry Owners' Club in Brooklyn was followed by an invasion of his place by a gang of hoodlums who wrecked $2,500 worth of fixtures.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Twenty-six immigration inspectors, six naturalization officials and sixty-one minor employes, all of whom are in the New York City district except eight, who are in Buffalo, will be "separated from the service" on Aug. 19 as a result of the merger of the Bureaus of Immigration and Naturalization by the Department of Labor.
Mixed price movements developed yesterday in the various commodities traded on local exchanges as the volume of trading dried up to some extent. Cash prices were irregular, with the majority higher.

Mrs. Fred Feigl received yesterday the silver star medal with double oak leaf, a citation posthumously awarded to her son, the late Lieutenant Jefferson Feigl, for gallantry in action while on liaison duty with infantry March 10, 1918, near Beaumont, France.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 10. -- The first shot for fusion and La Guardia was fired on Long Island this afternoon in this village, where Judge Samuel Seabury makes his Summer home. A letter from Judge Seabury was read before a gathering of 150 New York women who spend their Summers here.

Alarmed by the confusion among retail stores regarding closing hours and the time stores are to be kept in operation, F.H. Massmann, president of the National Chain Stores Association and chairman of the chain grocery store committee of the chain grocery industry, issued a statement yesterday warning against violations of the code and setting a store-operating week of sixty-three hours.

The New York Central Railroad Company, including all leased lines, reports for June a net income of $1,085,922 after all charges. This compared with a net income of $105,708 in May and was in contrast with a deficit of $3,068,024 in June, 1932.
Controller Charles W. Berry announced yesterday that he would retire on Sept. 16.

BERLIN, Aug. 10. -- The Boerse continued today to exhibit a slugglish tendency, and the absence of speculative or buying interest again was responsible for further drops all along the line. Heavy industrials that were prominently affected were Harpener, Gelsenkirchen and Vereingtestahl, losing from three-fourth of 1 per cent to 1 1/2 per cent, while Ilseder dropped as much as 8 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- A basic wage of $5 a day and a thirty-hour week in the soft coal mines were urged by John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, at a hearing on the twenty-seven bituminous codes today.

Charles P. Sullivan, Chief Assistant District Attorney of Queens, announced last night that the Queens County grand jury would be asked to make a survey of beach conditions at Edgemere, Queens, where seven wards of the Pde of Judea Home of Brooklyn were drowned last Tuesday.

Katherine Howard, fifth wife of Henry VIII, is the protagonist of a new novel by Philip Lindsay which Little, Brown Co. will publish today. The author is a native of Australia, who went to England at the age of 23, after a fling at newspaper work.

The greatest bores in the world "frequently are found among the leading lights of our financial firmament," according to the anonymous author of "The Mirrors of Wall Street," published today by G.P. Putnam's Sons.

Off-shore fishing is improving rapidly, according to all reports. The full moon, most of the boat captains say, caused a slight let-up in the runs, but there now are indications that the fish will come in strong again, especially if there is a strong northeast blow.

YORKLYN, Del., Aug. 10. -- Karl Maust of Detroit, after dead-locking with Frank M. Troeh, Oregon amateur champion, at 174 broken targets out of 175 for honors in the Brandywine, today won the toss-up for the coveted trophy.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Hitting in every inning and scoring in half of them, the White Sox got to Carl Fischer and Elden Auker for thirteen safeties and a 6-to-3 victory over the Tigers in the opening game of the series today.

BOSTON, Aug. 10. -- Al Crowder, Washington right-hander, turned in his seventeenth victory of the season today with a six-hit performance as the Senators defeated the Red Sox, 5 to 3. The triumph put the winners three and one-half games ahead of the idle New York Yankees.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is registrar for $1,750,000 of first mortgage 6 per cent serial bonds of the Cosden Oil Company.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- The British Government today took the most charitable view possible of last night's broadcast from Munich by Theodor Habicht, Nazi "Inspector for Austria," attacking the Dollfuss government, although it was a clear violation of the assurance given to the Italian Ambassador in Berlin by Germany last week-end.
VENICE, Cal., Aug. 10 (AP). -- His automobile's plunge off an ocean pier killed Jean Malin today a few minutes after he had ended a "farewell appearance" at a night club.

PLATTSBURG, Aug. 10. -- About 650 pyramidal tents vacated by the Veterans and Civilian Conservation Corps were "truck" by the Citizens Military Training Camp battalion today. The work was described as an exercise in building camp.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date and total bills discounted to be at the lowest. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10. -- After a long, listless drill here from New London, Conn., the New York Yacht Club fleet straggled in tonight on the first leg of its annual cruise.

NEW YORK. Mrs. H. Montague Robertson and Miss Lily F. Robertson have left by motor for Bar Harbor, where they will be the guests of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander J. Bruen at Ambleside. Mrs. Robertson and her daughter will return to New York by way of Canada.

That the farmer at the middle of last month was in the best economic situation since October, 1930, is the conclusion reached by The Annalist from a study of figures issued by the Department of Agriculture. The publication says:

Rentals of entire floors in business buildings in Manhattan were announced yesterday. The large volume of business leases included contracts for many stores and for space in buildings on Fifth Avenue. The rentals follow:

The United Licensed Officers Association submitted to General Hugh S. Johnson yesterday a code of fair practice to govern the employment of officers of the American merchant marine, based on the provisions of the National Industrial Recovery Act.

Following is a list of postoffices in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens where employers may file certificates of compliance with re-employment agreements and obtain the NRA insignia. The postoffice is not authorized to give rulings or definitions concerning the provisions of the President's re-employment agreement. All such inquiries should be addressed to the bureau of information of the local NRA committee at the Hotel Pennsylvania:

Production of automobiles in July by members of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce was approximately three times as great as in the corresponding month last year. The chamber includes all important manufacturers except the Ford Motor Company.
Former Controller Charles L. Craig made public yesterday a letter to former Mayor John F. Hylan denying certain assertions made by Justice Hylan in a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES July 5.

JACKSON, Wyo., Aug. 10. -- A flare-up between committee members and their counsel, John P. Pickett of Cheyenne, marked one of the closing phases today of the hearings here by a sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Public Lands, investigating the proposed extension of the Grand Teton National Park.

PARIS, Aug. 10. -- The American Chamber of Commerce of France, which has seen, its membership reduced by more than 35 per cent in the last three years, is now threatened with eviction from its spacious quarters in the heart of the opera district.

HAVANA, Aug. 10. -- Further delay in clearing up the turbulent Cuban situation loomed tonight when Orestes Ferrara, Secretary of State, told your correspondent that within the next forty-eight hours President Gerardo Machado would present a counter-proposal to the formula submitted several days ago by United States Ambassador Sumner Welles.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- Traders regarded the government's report on coarse grains, issued today after the close of the Board of Trade, as sensationally bullish and look for a sharp advance in prices tomorrow. Little comment was heard regarding wheat, as the figures for the country were only 4,000,000 bushels above those of the previous month.

ALBANY, Aug. 10. -- Republican members of the Assembly from New York City, aided by a group of up-State members, revolted today against the proposal to give the city administration blanket power to impose emergency taxes for unemployment relief.

Grover A. Whalen, who led New York City merchants in their fight against a city retail sales tax, said over the radio last night that the merchants would push their fight for abolition of the State sales tax next year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Warning was issued by Secretary Ickes today that speculative attempts for private profit by land deals preceding the proposed low-cost housing projects under study by the Public Works Administration would meet with defeat.

TASTES differ. The Hindus do not like dogs. The Egyptians revered them. In ancient Ethiopia a dog was elected titular king. Alcibiades had his favorite canine. The noble Romans kept greyhounds. The Welsh miners have their favorite whippets. Shakespeare mentioned dog racing in "The Merry Wives of Windsor," to wit:

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The deadly Dutch elm disease, which was detected early last month near here and which threatens to destroy all elm trees in the entire Northeast unless eradicated, has been found on one elm in Brooklyn, according to Dr. O.N. Liming of the United States Department of Agriculture, who is in charge of the disease eradication campaign now under way in Northern New Jersey.

The Coat and Suit Code Authority set up under the code approved for the industry by the National Recovery Administration and now in operation held its first meeting yesterday at the office of the impartial chairman of the industry, 130 West Thirty-first Street.

DUBLIN, Aug. 10. -- The government has decided to issue a proclamation banning a Fascist blue shirt parade to the Griffith and Coiling cenotaph, arranged for Sunday. An Order in Council will be made by the de Valera Cabinet tomorrow and the proclamation will be issued shortly after.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 10 (AP). -- Newark obtained an even break with Rochester on the season's play when the Bears closed the present series with a victory, 3 to 2, today.

Commercial Paper. Yesterday. .1 1/2 per cent for the best names Wednesday .1 1/2 per cent for the best names The quotations are for three-four months' paper. * * * Wholesale Activity Spottier. A greater trend toward spottiness has featured wholesale market activity here this week. In staple lines, where merchandise is not to be had except at peak prices, activity has notably subsided for the moment.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 10. -- The deadly Dutch elm disease, which was detected early last month near here and which threatens to destroy all elm trees in the entire Northeast unless eradicated, has been found on one elm in Brooklyn, according to Dr. O.N. Liming of the United States Department of Agriculture, who is in charge of the disease eradication campaign now under way in Northern New Jersey.

Mules Must Unlearn. Among those who are finding difficulty in adjusting themselves to the Agricultural Adjustment Act are the mules in the cotton fields of the South. Farmers plowing under one-third of their cotton crop have trouble in making the draught mule behave.
TORONTO, Aug. 10 (AP). -- Jersey City broke even in the six-game series with Toronto by winning the final game, 8 -- 5, after ten innings today.

A further reduction in bank clearings, carrying the total for the country below last year's figures for the first time in several weeks, took place in the week ended on Wednesday, according to reports from twenty-one cities compiled by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Thursday, Aug. 10, 1933. Money market was dull. Quotations were unchanged for all classes, while business was small and chiefly of a routine character. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent, outside money at 3/4 and Federal funds 1/5.
A solemn pledge made last Fall to the American people is being redeemed through the NRA, declared Postmaster General James A. Farley last night at the Hotel Biltmore.

SAN FRANCESCO, Aug. 10. -- Television is technically ready for broadcasting, but its launching on a basis akin to radio will require quite an outlay of capital, J.B. McCargar, president of Television Laboratories, Ltd., stated upon his return from the East.

The proposal for a general monatorium on mortgage foreclosures in the State is being opposed by the Mortgage Conference of New York which is headed by Philip A. Benson, president of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn.

Merging of the Bureaus of Immigration and Naturalization as an economy measure is made possible by the smaller influx of aliens. As Mr. HAROLD FIELDS, secretary of the National League of American Citizenship, said in his article on "The Alien Problem of Today," there is now a relative immobility of migration throughout the world.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Every so often the cry is made that Times Square should be improved -- is made either by business men of the district or others who because of pleasant associations are interested and love the place. It is strange that with so many good resolutions so little has been done.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Under an Executive order issued by President Roosevelt tonight all contractors supplying the government hereafter must conform with industrial codes.

The Exchange admitted yesterday to its list the following securities: CHICAGO EASTERN ILLINOIS RAILWAY COMPANY. -- Chemical Bank and Trust Company certificates of deposit for general mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds due May 1, 1951.

EAST ROCKAWAY, L.I., Aug. 10. -- Rodney Morgan, vice president of the Helman Manufacturing Company of Brooklyn and a resident of this village for the last thirty-three years, was convicted of hit-and-run driving before Justice Edward T. Neu and a jury here last night.

ALBANY, Aug. 10. -- Announcing that he intended to present further evidence to the Albany County grand jury in the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr., District Attorney Delaney asserted today that Manny Strewl, the indicted intermediary, had been definitely linked to some of the ransom notes.

VIENNA, Aug. 10. -- The government organ Reichspost today assailed last night's radio denunciation of the Dollfuss government from Munich by Theodor Habicht, Nazi "inspector for Austria" until he was expelled from the country.
LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds, sterling:

The committee in charge of the NRA campaign in the State under the chairmanship of W. Averell Harriman extended the drive yesterday to twenty-five more counties. The State campaign now covers fifty-two counties outside of the five in New York City.

The Blue Eagle, insignia of the National Recovery Administration, will take to the air this morning when thirty army planes will fly over New York to a dozen cities with nine tons of the NRA stickers and placards.

In spite of all that has been published on the subject, many are still confused with regard to what is proposed by the Recovery Act, the President's Agreement, and the various trade codes. It is partly to clear up doubts, and to act as a sort of clearing house for information, that the separate NRA committees have been formed in the various cities and States.
BERLIN, Aug. 10. -- Shrinkages in the trade with the United States and Russia are the outstanding features of Germany's foreign commerce balance sheet for the first six months of 1933.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 10. -- Mrs. Preston Davie of Southampton, member of the New York State Republican Committee, addressed a meeting of 200 women at the home of Mrs. Clarence F. Alcott today. Her talk was devoted to the fusion movement in New York City and Republican State politics.

Joe Weber of the veteran comedy team of Weber and Fields, win celebrate his sixty-sixth birthday today. He was at his office at 1,431 Broadway yesterday for the first time since the taxicab accident on June 2 which sent him to a hospital for more than two weeks.

ALBANY, Aug. 11. -- The influence of President Roosevelt was brought to bear today in the impasse in the Legislature here over measures to enable New York City to impose local taxes to provide funds for unemployment relief.

Representatives of the American and British. Governments acted yesterday to protect the interests of steamship lines in the German trade following the announcement by the German Foreign Exchange Control Department that new restrictive policies on the booking of foreign passengers in Germany would be rigidly enforced.

An air circus and stunt-flying exhibition, enlisting many prominent aviators, will be held tomorrow afternoon at the Sands Point Bath Club, Sands Point, L.I., in the interests of the National Charity Air Pageant to take place on Oct. 7 and 8 at Roosevelt Field for the joint benefit of the Judson Health Centre and the Emergency Exchange Association.

ROME, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Thousands of persons came to Rome today to participate in the welcoming ceremonies for General Italo Balbo and his seaplane squadron, scheduled to return home tomorrow from their round-trip flight across the Atlantic to Chicago.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- The tangled situation which prevails in the 3-year-old nanks was further confused today when the Glen Riddle Farm's War Glory won the Saranac Handicap from the best that could be mustered against him.
TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Governor Alfred M. Landon indicated today that impeachment proceedings might be warranted in the Kansas municipal bond forgery scandal.
G.W. Forbes, Prime Minister, and Robert Masters, Minister of Industries and Education of New Zealand, arrived here yesterday on the Cunard liner Aquitania from the London conference.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11. -- Prices in Argentina have taken a definite upward turn, according to the monthly report of the Bureau of National Statistics, which points out that the value of exports for July was the highest for any month this year, although the July tonnage was slightly less than that of other months.

More than $208,682,000 has been paid to the depositors of nearly all of the sixty-four banks taken ever by the State Banking Department in the last three years, according to figures made public yesterday by Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banking.

Dr. Frank Parker Day, scholar, educator and soldier, has resigned from the presidency of Union College, Schenectady, N.Y., a post he has held since May 4, 1929, it was announced here yesterday. He has been in ill health since last January, and since then he has been unable to attend to his college duties.

Russel Crouse, writer, returned from a Scandinavian and Russian cruise yesterday on the Swedish liner Kungsholm. He said one of the most surprising things he observed in Russia was the sacrifices the adult population is making for the children of the country.

J. j. Slater, manufacturers and retailers of footwear for women, have leased two stores with mezzanine and basement at 575 and 577 Madison Avenue, in the American Art Association Building, between Fifty-sixth and Fifth-seventh Streets.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- State Senatorial leaders of both parties will meet at P.M., Monday, in Albany, to study the mortgage moratorium and anti-deficiency judgment bills presented to the Legislature. The plan is to consolidate their principal purposes into two bills -- one on a mortgage moratorium, and the other to amend the law governing deficiency judgments, according to a statement made here today by Senator Walter W. Westall.

BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- The Boerse had another listless session today, with sporadic improvements in the mining and smelting favorites the only indications of passing firmness. Vereinigestahl, Phoenix, Gelsepkirchen, Harpener and Rheinstahl gained three-fourths of 1 per cent to 1 per cent on the day.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The Blue Eagle has full power to spread its wings over intrastate public utilities, General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, asserted today. He made this clear in a discussion of the status of the Baltimore Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company, which has expressed willingness to accept wages and hours features of a code but not others.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Latin-American acceptance of President Roosevelt's plan for a "Pan-American commercial alliance" will depend upon United States' treatment of Cuba in its plea for an improved outlet here for sugar, Thomas L. Chadbourne today told the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- In its second major rate decision in a week, the Interstate Commerce Commission today voted, 6 to 4, against reducing charges on bituminous coal from Pennsylvania, Maryland and Northern West Virginia mines to Eastern trunk line and New England territories.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Aug. 11 -- Hubert Scott-Faine put his Harmsworth Trophy challenger, Miss Britain III, through a final trial today prior to shipment tomorrow to Detroit to meet Gar Wood for the International Motor Boating Trophy.

ALBANY, Aug. 11. -- Thirty alimony cases in the New York County jail are discussed in a report made to the State Commission of Correction by Commissioner Jesse Jacobs and Inspector James McC. Shillinglaw of a recent inspection.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP). -- A sugar stabilization plan, designed to raise and regulate prices in the American domestic market, was submitted to Secretary of Agriculture Wallace today for approval, despite the threat of Western beet sugar growers to refuse to accept it.
ALBANY, Aug. 11. -- A detailed plan for control of hard liquor which will become effective on the end of prohibition will be enacted by the special session of the Legislature.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- A 22-year-old Iowa coed, Miss Lucille Robinson or Dea Moines, will meet Miss Virginia Van Wie of Chicago, women's national champion, tomorrow in a 36-hole match for the women's Western golf championship.

BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- Dr. Wilhelm Haenecke, the son-in-law of Friedrich Ebert, the German republic's first President, was arrested at Gottingen today. Prior to the revolution in 1918, he was a Landrath and administrative head of his district.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Special privileges obtained by Terrence Druggan, Chicago beer baron, at Leavenworth Penitentiary will cost him an extra five months in prison.

CORINTH, Miss., Aug. 11 (AP). -- Three organizers of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers Union, who have been active here among employes of the Weather Pants Company, were escorted to the Tennessee line today by an undetermined number of men in two automobiles.

Captain James Mollison boarded the White Star liner Majestic at 10:15 o'clock last night to go back to England and supervise the construction of a new plane, a sister-ship of the one in which he and his wife made their recent flight.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 11 (AP). -- The State milk strike, boiling for ten days, came down to a simmer this morning. "It's just about over," was the consensus of law officers.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- All attempts today to discover the originator of the report that Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh had crashed to his death in Greenland failed. London was blaming Copenhagen, and Copenhagen was blaming New York, but no scapegoat could be found.
To the Editor of The New York Times: We want a code for "Idea" men -- a criminal code for the prosecution of those who pirate our ideas.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The New Deal means a "square deal" for women in industry, according to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

LONDON, Aug. 11. -- The difficulties in obtaining American visas that confronted a group of fifteen German professors who are to join the faculty of the New School for Social Research have now been settled with the receipt by the United States Consulate here of instructions from Washington to facilitate the professors' applications.
With the adoption of a code for barbers by the Journeymen Barbers International Union of America the NRA announced yesterday the regulations covering maximum hours for the barber and beauty shops.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics index of wholesale prices was unchanged for the week ended Aug. 5, remaining at 69.2.

General Alberto Herrera has been one of the mainstays of the Machado regime through the turbulent times of the last three years. A veteran of the Cuban insurrection which eventually led to the intervention of the United States against Spain in 1898, he has had a long career in the army.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Approval of a three-year loan of $3,862,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Chicago North Western Railway Company for enabling it to refinance a maturity of $7,724,000 of mortgage bonds on Oct. 1 was announced today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

ALBANY, Aug. 11. -- Out of 1,180 law students, many of whom were graduated in June from law schools in the State, 527 were successful in the June examinations for admission to the bar, it was announced today by John Kirkland Clark of New York, Philip J. Wickser of Buffalo and Rollin B. Sanford of Albany, comprising the State Board of Law Examiners.
The proposed airplane demonstration over New York City yesterday in behalf of the NRA campaign was postponed until today, because of bad weather.
MONTREAL, Aug. 11 (AP). -- Representatives of the standard railway unions of Canada, at a meeting here today culminating a series of negotiations, joined in a cooperative association.

Elmer Adler, head of Pynson Printers, delivered an address yesterday over station WOR on printing as an art rather than as a trade. He said that the first letters cast were frank imitations of pen-drawn symbols.

Two governmental measures for overcoming the depression are proposed by Guy W. Mallon, Cincinnati lawyer, who has been active in civic affairs, in his book, "Bankera vs. Consumers," just published by the John Day Company.

The haze which nung over general trade activities a week ago because of the confusion arising from the interpretation of the new codes and the appearance of a restricted seasonal recession in scattered industrial divisions has apparently been cleared, according to the weekly business review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

A sign painter dangled for twenty minutes yesterday at the end of a scaffold rope, eighty-five feet above the sidewalk at 508 West 156th Street, before he was rescued by a fireman who was lowered by another rope from the roof of the Broadway Storage House.
Only the Platt Amendment has prevented the Cuban people from driving President Gerardo Machado from power, according to Raymond Leslie Buell, research director of the Foreign Policy Association.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 11 -- An estate in excess of $200,000 was left by Chester S. Lord, chancellor of the University of the State of New York, and former managing editor of The New York Sun. His will was filed here today for probate with Surrogate Leone D. Howell.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Ted Lyons, veteran White Sox hurler, flashed all his old-time artistry today and shaded Fred Marberry in a fine hurlers' duel, giving the Chicagoans their second straight victory over the Tigers, 2 to 0.

The work of enforcing prohibition until the Eighteenth Amendment is repealed is to be carried on in New York with a staff of only 122 employes of the newly expanded Division of Investigation of the Department of Justice.

BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- The day that for fourteen years symbolized the birth of republican Germany to millions of Germans and all the outside world was silently dropped from the calendar today. Constitution Day, which up to this year had been the occasion for official observance throughout the Reich, has ceased to be.

A warning against "racketeers" who may attempt to charge fees to aid home owners in filing applications for Federal aid in refinancing their mortgages was issued yesterday by the New York branch of the Home Owners Loan Corporation.
CULVER, Ind., Aug. 11 -- California youngsters will fight it out tomorrow for three of the four junior and boys' tennis championships of the United States.

Mrs. Henry Morganthau has presented to the Metropolitan Museum of Art twenty icons of Byzantine and Russian workmanship which she collected in the Near East. They will be placed on exhibition this morning in the museum's room of recent accessions.

The Esperantists have in their very name a hope of a world-embracing auxiliary language. It is not thought that it or any other such artificial international language will take the place of a national or primary language. The function of the one differs from that of the other in that the auxiliary language is serviceable chiefly in merely seeking and giving information.
Organized labor in New York City, representing 750,000 workers and hundreds of organizations, was enlisted in the local NRA campaign yesterday and made an integral part of the campaign organization.
Fred Perry, England's Davis Cup singles ace, arrived yesterday aboard the Cunarder Aquitania along with three of his countrymen to make a bid for the American tennis crown.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11. -- Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the first in a series of operatic performances by artists of the Metropolitan Opera Association, under the direction of "Wilfred Pelletier, also of the Metropolitan Opera, which was held tonight at Four Fountains, the Ethel Hunt Tyng memorial.

A two-and-a-half-year search by the Department of Justice for a portable radio set that was said to have been used to communicate with rum-runners ended in Brooklyn yesterday morning with the arrest of two men and the seizure of an automobile from which the set was operated.

George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, took possession yesterday of the Lawyers Title and Guaranty Company for rehabilitation under his plan for reorganization of the mortgage guarantee business in this State. He also took over an affiliate, the Lawyers Westchester Mortgage and Title Company.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11 -- Towhaired Olin J. Stephens 2d, who won the transatlantic race two years ago in his yawl Dorade, sailed the 12-meter sloop Iris to victory today and captured the classic Astor Cup.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Movement of grain to market which showed a sharp upturn in some parts of the Southwest and in the mountain territory when prices were leaping upward, has virtually ceased since trading in futures on the grain exchanges was restricted.

Reaction overtook the commodity markets yesterday with temporarily unsettling effect upon securities. Grains and cotton were extremely weak. Stocks and bonds, as a consequence of the downturn in the agricultural staples, lost all of a modest early advance.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 11. -- The Savings Investment and Trust Company, the largest banking institution in the Oranges, absorbed today the East Orange Trust Company, which has been operated for about a year on a management contract by Savings Investment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Government estimates indicated today that this year's carry-over of United States wheat is the largest in the nation's history, 385,881,000 bushels as of July 1.

SUGAR HILL, N.H., Aug. 11. -- The fourth annual flower show of the White Mountain Garden Club opened today at Peckett's on Sugar Hill, where the displays were made in the huge barn-playhouse. A model cottage of the 1700 epoch, furnished with period antiques, on the Peckett estate was exhibited, the proceeds to be used for the fund the club is raising to defray expenses of landscaping the railway station grounds at Littleton.

Government estimates published yesterday again forecast the smallest crops of grain in many years. At 499,000,000 bushels the indicated yield of wheat is the lowest since 1893. Corn has been cut by more than 100,000,000 bushels since the July 1 estimates were published, and the harvest now indicated is the smallest with one exception sinca 1901.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Have legislators throughout the country, in their religious frenzy to arrive at a solution of our national kidnapping problem, lost sight of a momentous angle of the situation? A discussion of the methods employed by syndicates engaged in interstate kidnapping will not only show that this particular crime is highly standardized, but it will prove edifying as well.

A committee of Christian leaders, organized as a gesture of good-will to the Jews of New York City, will cooperate in sponsoring the performance of "The Romance of a People." a musical and dramatic pageant of Jewish history to be presented at the Polo Grounds on Sept. 14.
DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Saturday, Aug. 12. -- At 12:50 A.M. today the government announced that the Public Safety Act had been put into force by an order of the Executive Council.
Federal financial aid for education was advocated in a report adopted yesterday by the National Conference on the Financing of Education, now in session at Teachers College, Columbia University.

The Angel of Death hovers over the speakeasy. With prohibition staggering on its last legs, Louis and Frank and Joe are developing that far-away look which denotes impending changes. Months ago students of manners perceived that something of great moment was in the offing.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 11. -- Attorney General Cummings, explaining the effect of the executive order of President Roosevelt, which consolidated the Bureau of Investigation and Prohibition, said today that "the function of these two bureaus, abolished by the executive order, will be carried on by a newly created department known as the Division of Investigation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governor Lehman, in his special message to the Legislature, recommended municipal housing and the establishment of local municipal boards for such a purpose. in view of this, it is interesting to note that the English Government has put an end to subsidized building.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- An intimation that the government would provide for rigid control over oil production in the petroleum tradepractice plan now nearing completion came today from General Johnson, whose aides are writing it.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 (AP) -- After four scoreless frames the Cardinals began hitting today and won a heavy batting game from, the Reds, 8 to 5. The Cards got thirteen hits and the Reds twelve. Pepper Martin and Ernie Orsatti each made four hits.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Quietly and deftly an army of 35,000,000 women is being formed by a woman''commander-in-chief," Mary E. Hughes, new aide to Hugh S. Johnson, Industrial Administrator.

FRED PERRY, who clinched the Davis Cup victory for Great Britain, landed on these shores yesterday and a very good thing it is, too. He came just in time. The tennis situation in these parts has grown too serious. There should be some fun in the game. If our own players fail, Mr. Perry will provide it. He not only provides fun for the spectators, but he seems to enjoy the game himself.

An indictment charging first degree murder in the recent strangling of Dr. E. Warren Sylla, 65-year-old dentist, was returned yesterday against Lawrence J. Kelly, 26 years old, of 100 Buckingham Street, New Haven, and Edward F. Moran, 22, of 639 Greenwich Avenue, Stamford.

DETROIT, Aug. 11. -- Motor-car makers entered into the trade agreement calling for a fixed maximum work week and a minimum wage scale with certain reservations -- reservations designed to retain the "open shop" principle in the industry -- but they are counting upon the code and a combination of other circumstances further to expand the improvement in the consumer demand for automobiles which began last Spring.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- Raisers of hogs are in a quandary as to what can be done with their heavyweight hogs as a result of the government's movement in favor of lighter weights and the elimination of the heavy sows so that their lighter hogs will bring more money.

PRAGUE, Aug. 11. -- Statements by Chancellor Hitler of Germany in an interview published in the New Yorker Staats Zeitung and other newspapers to the effect that fewer than twenty persons lost their lives in the Nazi revolution and that the Reichstag building was burned by Communists are flatly denied by Otto Wels, chairman of the German Social Democratic party, in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Special investigating boards to review presumptive World War veteran disability cases in accordance with the President's economy program were named today for Connecticut, Rhode Island, Iowa and Alabama. Twelve such boards have now been designated, out of ninety to be set up.
BOSTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The league-leading Washington Senators opened a smashing attack in the ninth inning today, scoring six runs to beat the Red Sox in the second game of the series, 8 to 4.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- A total of $78,850 was realized tonight for forty-three yearlings, most of which were from the Claiborne and Ellerslie studs of Arthur B. Hancock. A few of the youngsters also were from the farm of Charlton Clay.
SALEM, N.H., Aug. 11 -- Two crack trotters from W.N. Reynolds's Winston-Salem (N.C.) light harness stable today dominated the Srand Circuit's fifteenth and next to last program at Rockingham Park.
An agile young monkey was at large in the wards of Bellevue Hospital last night, having toured the premises via drain pipes, window ledges, transoms and plumbing fixtures for more than nine hours.
LISBON, Portugal, Saturday, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Italo Balbo's squadron of Italian seaplanes began its take-off for Rome at 6:10 A.M. today 12:10 A.M., Eastern Daylight time.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 11 (Canadian Press). -- Canada had a wheat carry-over of 211,740,128 bushels on July 31, the end of the crop year, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. This was an increase of 79,895,382 bushels over corresponding figures for 1932.

Cuban Oppositionist leaders in exile in this country last night rejected General Alberto Herrera, President Machado's Secretary of War, or any other military or political figure of the Machado regime, as Provisional President. They insisted on the selection of some civilian who has had no connection with the Machado administration.

A large volume of realty deals in New Jersey yesterday included sales of small houses in scattered communities and approval by the State Municipal Finance Commission of the proposed sale of the $1,000,000 Brigantine Hotel at Brigantine, Atlantic County.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- The vogue of tennis "shorts" in the Eastern championships at the Westchester Country Club has become so pronounced among the women players that it appears inevitable that skirts will no longer be worn on the courts within another year or two.
The murderers of Henry F. Sanborn, railroad executive, probably did not carry their victim's body to the thicket in Queens where it was found, but drove there in a car, it was announced yesterday.
The following letter has "been received, "by the publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES from Louis Johnson, National Commander of the American Legion:

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 -- The Chicago Cubs climbed over the Pittsburgh Pirates into second place in the National League today, winning the belated opener of their important series, 8 to 2, behind the expert hurling of Guy Bush.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A proposal by which newspapers could join immediately in the NRA campaign under the President's Agreement through a substitution of wage and work-hours provisions was laid before publishers today by Hugh S. Johnson, the Industrial Administrator.
Anglers who go after salt water fish, from Cape May to Montauk, are likely to have some difficulties over the week-end, according to weather reports and boat captains.

The musical memory of Albert E. Koonz of 1,632 Taylor Avenue, the Bronx, served him well last Wednesday night when the Goldman Band played on The Mall in Central Park, for Edwin Franko Goldman, the conductor, announced at-last night's concert that Mr. Koonz had won first prize in the annual music memory contest with a score of 100 per cent.

YORKLYN, Del., Aug. 11 (AP) -- By breaking 175 straight targets Frank M. Troeh of Portland, Ore., today won the Auburn Heights Special, feature of the fourth day of the T. Clarence Marshall blue-ribbon trapshooting classic.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11. -- The "pegs" will be removed from the grain markets on the Board of Trade here when they close on next Tuesday, after having been in effect since July 31. This decision was reached today by the directors of the Exchange at a meeting following a trading session in which wheat lost 5 cents a bushel net.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- George M. Lott Jr. of Chicago went down in crushing defeat before Lester B. Stoefen of Los Angeles at 6 -- 4, 6 -- 0 in singles today, and then came lack to the court with Gregory Mangin to end the long-winning streak of Frank Shields and Frankie Parker in doubles.

Representatives of railroads and other transportation agencies who have been meeting here for two days, adjourned yesterday to reassemble in Chicago on Sept. 7. No resolutions were adopted, but it is hoped that between now and the time Congress convenes in January a definite legislative policy on national transportation will be evolved.

Prices of Bonds fluctuated irregularly yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange under a lower volume of business. Leading rail and utility issues were mostly higher, but speculative loans of these groups and the industrials were moderately easier.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 11 -- "So far as our commission is concerned, there will be no raising of prices to the consumer of electricity or other public utility services by reason of compliance with the recovery program, if we can help it," said Harold E. West, chairman of the Maryland Public Service Commission, today.

Things Seen Abroad. Tourists returning from foreign parts continue to bring back comfort for the optimist and the pessimist alike. Traveler A reports that conditions in Moscow are now fine; he saw more destitution in Berlin.

Completion of the Tammany city ticket was prevented yesterday by failure of John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, and John H. McCooey, Brooklyn leader, to get in touch with Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, Democratic leader of the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The struggle in the Illinois coal fields between the United Mine Workers of America and the Progressive Miners of America was injected into the hearing on the coal code before Kenneth M. Simpson, deputy administrator, this afternoon by Walter Nesbit, representative at large from Illinois.

A downward trend in prices developed yesterday in trading on local commodity exchanges, with the result that all commodities except hides and wool tops closed with at least some positions under the preceding close. Cash prices were all lower.

Among the passengers arriving on the Holland-America liner Statendam today is a group from Czechoslovakia en route to the Century of Progress Exposition at Chicago. In the group is Elisabeth Nikolska, ballerina of the National Opera at Prague, and a troupe of ballet dancers who will appear with her at the exposition.

New bond offerings this week totaled $9,992,000, consisting exclusively of State and municipal issues. This contrasted with a single issue of $5,000,000 of six-month notes last week, when there was no bond financing, apart from the United States Treasury's offering of $500,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent eight-year bonds.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Bisons reeled off a third straight triumph, tonight. They defeated the league-leading Newark Bears by 9 to 4 before 12,500 fans.

A new device to whet the curiosity of mystery-story readers will be tried soon by Houghton Mifflin Company. In "Death Behind the Door," by Victor MacClure, which will be published on Aug. 23, an important clue will be marked in invisible ink somewhere in the book.

Discussing the National Recovery Act before The New York Times Advertising Club yesterday morning, William H. Rankin, president of the William H. Rankin Advertising Company and chairman of the NRA New York Advertising Committee, asserted that his committee's job was to "convince 1,500,000 small dealers and business men that they should sign the code.

JACKSON, Wyo., Aug. 11 -- The investigation of John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s purchases of lands for the extension of the Grand Teton National Park ended today so far as the Western phase of the controversy is concerned. At the conclusion of the hearing Senator Nye, chairman of the Senate subcommittee which has conducted the investigation, asserted that none of the complaints by land owners was justified by the evidence.

The Kernan bill, now before the State Legislature, which provides that, in the event of prohibition repeal, hard liquor shall be controlled by the New York State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board until the enactment of permanent legislation, was endorsed yesterday by Mrs. Marion Booth Kelley.

HAVANA, Aug. 11. -- Artillery Battalion No. 1, stationed in Cabana fortress under the command of Captain Patricio de Cardenas, led the way in today's revolt. It demanded the resignation of the President within twenty-four hours. All other battalions were invited to join in the movement and broadcasts to this effect went out addressed to the interior.
HAVANA, Aug. 11. -- The Cuban Army, after a successful revolt, today ordered President Machado to resign by noon tomorrow.

Because of the restrictions imposed by the various exchanges, business in Wall Street today will be on a greatly reduced basis. The Stock Exchange will be closed. Banks will be open as usual and there will be dealings in foreign exchange.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11. -- It is learned from an authoritative official source that very careful steps are being quietly taken toward renewing direct diplomatic negotiations between Bolivia and Paraguay for the settlement of the Chaco question.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11. -- Miss Florence Rice, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Grantland Rice of New York and East Hampton, and Miss Whitney Bourne, daughter of Mrs. Harvey Dow Gibson and George Bourne, received an ovation at tonight's performance of "I Want Love," a new comedy by P. G. Wodehouse, at the John Drew Memorial Theatre, Guild Hall.

More is meant than meets the ear in President ROOSEVELT'S letter to Governor LEHMAN respecting relief work in cities. Mr. ROOSEVELT writes, indeed, in general terms applicable to all States and cities, but it is perfectly clear that his eye is fixed mainly upon this State and city.

No changes were apparent in any section of the money market, rates and conditions in call loans, maturity money and business paper remaining steady in quiet trading. Stock Exchange day loans commanded 1 per cent, Street trades 3/4 and Federal funds 1/8.

BERLIN, Aug. 11 (AP) -- George S. Messersmith. United States Consul General, decided today to make a report to the State Department in Washington regarding discriminations against foreign shipping companies contained in a recent order whereby they may transfer only 200 marks of passage money per passenger to the home office.

10 to 25% Rise Due on Coats. An advance of 10 to 25 per cent in wholesale prices of women's coats, over those prevailing on Aug. 5, was seen here yesterday as likely to be put into effect under the cloak code, with fabric and fur rises also factors.

Rain yesterday failed to halt the eleventh annual national public parks championship tennis tournament. Extended the courtesy by First Deputy Police Commissioner Philip D. Hoyt to play at The Court Souse, a private club at 205 East Sixty-fourth Street, the contestants went into action there instead of in Central Park.

BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- Five days ago when the Soviet Union was in the middle of harvesting one of the biggest crops in Russian history, the "White" newspaper Svoboda of Riga devoted its whole front page to the "new Russian famine" and to "the starvation and suffering comparable to the famine of 1921."
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- President Roosevelt headed back to the capital tonight tanned by outdoor recreation which he mingled with official activities during his fortnight's holiday at home here.

Dr. George Norlin, president of the University of Colorado, who has been the Roosevelt Guest Professor of American Life and Institutions at the University of Berlin, returned yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Albert Ballin. He spent more than a year in Germany.
An accidental meeting between four detectives and an ex-convict in Jersey City yesterday afternoon was believed by the police to have solved a kidnapping and robbery.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- A three-point program designed to rehabilitate the entire economic and social life of Cuba hangs in the balance as a result of the Cuban revolt.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Aug. 11 (AP). -- Receiver for the Everglades Club Company, owner of one of America's best known resorts for the wealthy, was asked today in a suit charging about $50,000 has been "fraudulently" paid out of the company's funds to members of the Toledo bond and banking firm of Spitzer-Rorick Company.

Samuel Untermyer, special financial adviser to the Board of Estimate and Mayor O'Brien, urged yesterday that the impending vacancy in the Controller's office be filled by Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial.

MADRID, Aug. 11. -- Spain, which has had a great deal of experience with dictatorships, looks on President Machado's present position in Cuba as ridiculous and untenable. With even his diplomats resigning and the whole structure of his government collapsing, it was thought today the next step would be the swift failing of his last support, army loyalty.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 11 -- Robert Sweeny, a former member of the Oxford team, and Eddie Driggs Jr., first winner of the New York State amateur golf championship, will be opponents in tomorrow's thirty-six-hole final of the Empire State event at the Garden City Golf Club.

A Summer school of Catholic Action, sponsored by the Central Office of the Sodality of Our Lady, in St. Louis, Mo., will be conducted from Monday, Aug. 28, to Saturday, Sept. 2, in the Xavier High School, 30 West Sixteenth Street. The school will be under tha auspices of Fordham University and under the general direction of the Rev.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 11 -- John Colt, Princeton banker and since last March State Director of Emergency Relief, was appointed State Finance Commissioner by Governor Moore today. He will be virtually dictator of the State's finances.

BLUFF POINT, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Miss Marjorie Harrison of Ausable Forks, N.Y., 14-year-old golfer, gained the final round of the first annual international invitation tournament for women at the Lake Champlain Country Club today. She scored a 19-hole 1 up victory over Mrs. J. Oliver Morris of Albany.

VIENNA, Aug. 11 -- An alleged plot by German and Austrian Nazis to murder Prince Ernst von Starhemberg, leader of the Austrian Heimwehr, was disclosed to the Linz police last night by Franz Wolf, a member of the Upper Austrian Nazi party.

The city of Antwerp has engaged Cornelius F. Cahalane, tunnel and bridge expert, to organize the police patrol for its new vehicular, pedestrian and bicycle tubes under the Scheldt Estuary. King Albert will open the tunnels on Sept. 10.

Prices for cotton broke nearly $2 a bale yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, canceling all the recovery that had been made after the government crop estimate was issued and establishing low records for the week. After having touched 9.49 cents a pound on Tuesday, the October broke to 9.40 cents, and all but the two distant deliveries ended below 10 cents, with a loss of 35 to 39 points on the day.

Former Magistrate Charles A. Oberwager declared yesterday that there was no ground for the fear of hundreds of house servants, charwomen, storekeepers and other hard-working folk of German extraction in Yorkville that they have lost more than $1,000,000 of lifetime savings entrusted to Lorenz Strack.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 11 -- Gene Sarazen and Johnny Farrell marched into the semi-finals of the national Professional Golf Association championship with impressive victories today, but a pair of comparative unknowns to major competition dealt upsets that stole the show.

Reductions ranging from 28 cents to $1.24 a ton on all-rail shipments of prepared anthracite coal from the Pennsylvania mines to points in New England, Long Island and Westchester were put into effect yesterday by the railroads. They followed a series of discussions starting in April between the anthracite operators and the railroads serving them.

Mayor O'BRIEN'S renomination is said to have been fully decided upon by Tammany and its associated party bosses. But there is a general feeling that this is one of the things which can be altered while you wait. There is many a slip between the designation and the nomination, as also between the nomination and the election.

Assistant District Attorney William Kleinman completed yesterday the prosecution of three men on trial in the Kings County Court on a conspiracy indictment charging racketeering in the laundry business.

HAVANA, Aug. 11. -- Short-lived though it was, the Cuban Army's bloddless coup d'etat today keyed this already tense city to fever pitch and left it bewildered at the dramatic swiftness of exciting events.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Field 3d and Vincent Astor.

PARIS, Aug. 11 -- An arrangement has been reached with the Japanese for the recognition of French rights in the Chinese Eastern Railway, according to a Harbin dispatch in today's Dernieres Nouvelles, a Russian newspaper published here.

Democrats have been known to vote occasionally for Republicans. It is of vivid record that at times they fight one another more fiercely than they do the traditional enemy. Occasionally, after they leave the rural communities in which they drink in their politics and come to great cities, they fraternize socially with Republicans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- All the chief corn and wheat areas have shared in the general crop decline predicted for this year, an analysis by the Department of Agriculture revealed today. Iowa's corn harvest was forecast at 407,740,000 bushels, compared to 539,672,000 last year, while the new Illinois crop was put at 222,778,000 bushels, as against 387,043,000 in 1932.

When a law Is not a law was a legal point troubling the District Attorney's office yesterday. The question arose from the discovery that Eugene S. Daniell Jr., 28-year-old Boston lawyer accused of gassing the Stock Exchange had been indicted last Wednesday under a non-existent law.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 11. -- Seventeen years ago Dennis P. Dowd Jr., a Sea Cliff boy, the son of Mrs. Dennis P. Dowd of Locust Avenue, died in France, the first American who sailed to enlist in the World War. Today his mother is being consulted by a committee as to a suitable memorial to be erected to his memory.

LONDON, Aug. 11 -- Following its previous proposal that the Bank of England should be "socialized," the Labor party now suggests that the "Big Five" British banks should be amalgamated into a single banking corporation under public ownership and control.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Locked doors cloaked deliberations of a special Federal grand jury today as it heard testimony about the $100,000 kidnapping of William Hamm Jr., millionaire brewer of St. Paul. Justice Department operatives dotted the corridors.

Nazim of Hyderabad -- there can't be many titles that sound more magnificent and mysterious. It was among the jobs one dreamed of in the days when one habitually shipped with Sindbad and tried to rub old lamps into intelligence officers. Even now there is magic in the name.

BUFFALO, Aug. 12. -- Newark defeated Buffalo by a score of 3 to 1 tonight before a crowd of 14,000.

FOREIGN travel in the United States has given rise to a literature so vast that it would appear to defy analysis. Yet the patience and zeal of bibliographers has succeeded. bit by bit, in unraveling this amorphous material material so that a systematic study of its separate elements is now possible.

NEW YORK CITY took another step to expedite the movement of its enormous motor travel when the Police Department last Tuesday inaugurated a new timing schedule for traffic lights in the east side area.

THE theatre, which is one of the most cosmopolitan institutions between the Poles, has, as a consequence, a host of hands which stretch either in gestures of friendliness or greed across the seas. NEWPORT. -- Tennis Week, the busiest week of the Summer season here, has arrived. The Summer colony is ready for a hectic seven days, having taken a running start with the events of the past weekend.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP). -- The Buffalo Chamber of Commerce asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to deny the petition of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad for modification of commission orders to allow it to cancel certain existing routes and channels of trade in acquiring control of the Buffalo.

As a result of the controversy over price-fixing in the petroleum industry at hearings in Washington on a code for the oil business, J. Edward Jones submitted yesterday to General Hugh S. Johnson a set of price-adjusting formulas.

The rule against smoking at professional boxing matches, so rigidly championed by the late William H. Muldoon when he was a member of the New York State Athletic Commission, is expected to be scrapped in the near future.

CENTRAL CITT, Col., Aug. 7, AGAIN this once-famous Colorado gold mining camp has stepped out of its memories to present in its old Opera House an altogether admirable production of Franz Lehar's tuneful and sparkling operetta, "The Merry Widow."

CONET ISLAND, Ohio, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Favored by his light impost and displaying a decided liking for the heavy track, C.V. Whitney's Contraband ran one of the best races of his career to account for the Sinton Hotel Handicap, feature of the Cincinnati Jockey Club's half-holiday program today.
Twenty-four additional city and county departments filed their 1934 budget estimates yesterday, showing a net increase of $68,027.51 over their current allowances.

To The Editor of The New York Times: It seems to me there might very well be established a School of Actuality, if you like, a new school of thought to deal frankly and clearly and realistically with the various circumstances and events of life. Not that there is any lack of attempting so to deal with them or any lack of success necessarily in such attempts.

The bodies of five orphans drowned in the ocean off Edgamere, Queens, last Tuesday during an outing of the Pride of Judea Home were recovered yesterday within a radius of several miles of the scene of the tragedy.

PARIS, Aug. 11. -- Most people in France, including those in the government, have apparently decided to wait to see what Nazi Germany will do next. But it is apparent that among all classes there has begun to develop a kind of fatalistic spirit regarding the future.

The Ward liner Morro Castle returned from Havana yesterday with first-hand accounts of conditions in the capital of Cuba. Most of the passengers returned without having set foot in Havana, but a few had ventured into the city amid scattered firing and had prowled around, looking into the closed shops.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12 (AP). -- The Cardinals scored two runs on a hit, a sacrifice, an error, a walk and a long fly in the eighth inning to come from behind and defeat the Reds today, 3 to 2.
LONDON, July 29. -- The Morning Post today publishes the folowing:

THE international solo dance contest, held earlier in the Summer in Warsaw under the auspices of the musical magazine Muzyka, with Polish Government backing, attracted a number of leading European dancers. This event apparently filled the vacancy in international dance events left by the omission of the German dance congress and by the second contest of the International Archives in Paris.

THE decade following the World War is memorable for many reasons. But possibly few of its developments have been less spectacular and more significant than the emergence into active practical life of a goodly number of men trained in the study of crime and its ways, in laboratory research and in the administration of criminal law, and adept in the practical working out of modern thought and experiment applied to the control of crime.

Settlement in full of all claims against former officers and directors of the Pacific Eastern Corporation in the period when it was the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation has been offered to stockholders and will be voted on at a special meeting on Aug. 28.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Cal., Aug. 11. -- Because Stanford University's income has been reduced heavily by the depression, the authorities have removed the numerical restriction on women students. Heretofore the enrolment has been limited to 500.

MUSIC should be a portion of the mental diet of every individual. Percy Grainger, Australian composer and pianist, believes. He contends music is music, and when attempts are made "to split melody into casts the result is as bad as class legislation."

BOSTON, Aug. 9. -- The Governor of this Commonwealth and the Federal Emergency Administrator of Public Works, Joseph B. Ely, and Secretary of the Interior Ickes, respectively, have been having a lively clash over the method of allocation of the share of Massachusetts in the $3,000,000,000 appropriated for public projects in the National Recovery Act.

WASHINGTON. WITH its assumption of jurisdiction over the industrial disputes affecting the hosiery industry in Reading, Pa., and the shirt industry in Pottsville, Pa., the National Labor Board set forth a few days ago on the path charted during the World War by the National War Labor Board.

PORT KENT, N.Y. -- The Lake Champlain interstate regatta, the first of what is intended as a series of annual regattas, will take place here on Saturday, with prominent owners of fast speed boats from Port Kent, Burlington and other points on both the New York and Vermont shores competing.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 9. -- Although Oregon's primaries are nine months away, political ambitions to occupy the Governor's chair are beginning to crop out into the open in such a fashion as to indicate interesting possibilities for the contest for the accolade or both the Republican and Democratic parties.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 9. -- Unless threats materialize to block the State water-conservation project by referendum petitions -- a contingency not greatly feared -- California soon will be launched in a public enterprise that in mere physical dimensions will exceed anything of the kind ever undertaken in this country.

Many benefits have resulted from lobbying, by American women in behalf of social welfare legislation, Dr. Sophonisba P. Breckinridge writes in her "Women in the Twentieth Century," a monograph published by the McGraw-Hill Book Company under the auspices of the Research Committee on Social Trends. Dr. Breckinridge, who investigated the women's movement in this country for the committee, lists such lobbying as one of the notable political activities of American women.

Jones Beach, which has been the centre of a number of important swimming competitions during the last year, including the recent women's national championships will be the scene of the national A. A.U. long distance tests next Sunday.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 12 (AP). -- As if working on a gigantic puzzle, investigators are slowly piecing together the tangled operations of Ronald Finney, bond broker and market speculator, in the Kansas bond forgery scandal.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Aug. 12 (AP). -- Governor Pollard of Virginia and his bride, on their honeymoon here, have before them a petition here, have in the case of "the Commonwealth of Virginia vs. one black and white setter dog, the property of Mrs. Marion J. Belk."

The intention of the Actors Equity Association to exercise its jurisdiction henceforth over the entertainers who appear en the stages of motion picture "presentation houses" was announced yesterday by Frank Gillmore, president of Equity, in filing a code with the National Recovery Administration.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 11, unless otherwise specified:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The question whether gold hoarders will be prosecuted will be decided by Attorney General Cummings when he returns to Washington this week after a short vacation at his home in Connecticut.

DURING the present recess of the World Economic Conference the thought is likely to escape many that the conference was after all the creature of the League of Nations, that it was but one of a number of specific methods adopted by that international body to attack the principal problem confronting all nations today, and that is the problem of economics.

LONDON. THE outstanding results of the World Economic Conference are to be seen, not in the inconclusive reports of its numerous committees, but in the events which grew out of it. Most notable of all was the drawing together of the self-governing nations of the British Empire in an agreement -- announced after the conference had finished its largely futile labors -- to pursue a common monetary policy.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Tonight's "golf widows' ball" at the Maidstone Club, for which women wore black or white evening dresses, was a gay event. Mrs. A. Wallace Chauncey, chairman of the entertainment committee, planned the ball because of the three-day golf tournament this week-end for the Maidstone Bowl, for which her husband, A. Wallace Chauncey, is committee chairman.

FIVE American composers who form the central committee of the Second Yaddo Festival for Contemporary American Music met recently at Yaddo, Saratoga Springs, N.Y., to choose programs for the coming festival. The members of this year's committee are Aaron Copland, chairman; George Antheil, Richard Donovan, Wallingford Riegger and Randall Thompson.

Interest in the Harmsworth, race at Detroit is growing as the time approaches for another challenge to Gar Wood's supremacy. The "breakdown" jinx which has hovered over every challenger since Wood won the coveted plaque back in 1920 is one of the chief obstacles which will confront Hubert Scott-Paine in the speedboat classic over Labor Day.

MANILA, July 8. -- Philippine sugar producers are protesting against the award of the contract for sugar for the United States Army In the Philippines to Japanese middlemen and Javanese producers more on principle than on the actual figures in the case.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- The West-Chester Country Club was the scene tonight of a dinner dance held In donor of the players participating In the Eastern court tennis championships on the courts of the club-house.

After making a night of it, Bellevue Hospital's incorrigible monkey (Macaca Rhesus) who upset the whole place when it escaped Friday, was back yesterday morning in its cage on the roof of the pathological building, ready to catch the mumps for science.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Eddie Driggs, former Princeton football star, won the New York State amateur golf crown for the second time at the Garden City Golf Club today when he defeated Robert Sweeny of the Sands Point Club, 8 and 7, in the thirty-six-hole final.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- A serious situation has again arisen in two of the Pennsylvania coal fields where a strike was recently adjusted through the National Recovery Administration, and Gerard Swope, chairman of the Coal Mediation Board, and Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Recovery Administrator, are bending every effort to adjust it amicably.

ALBANY, Aug. 12 (AP). -- An automobile bearing Mrs. Grace Crudeau of Hackensack, N.J., and her infant child was somewhere between that city and Lake George tonight, its occupants unaware that State police teletype wires were flashing warnings that medicine carried by the mother had been mixed too strongly and might prove fatal to the baby.

LONDON, Aug. 1. -- In this year of grace 1933 one of the ancient colleges of Oxford University causes cattle to be seized upon the land of a farmer In the ancient county of Kent. The cows later disappear mysteriously at night time from under the nose of the bailiff, put in by the college to guard them.

IF you cut from your favorite elm tree a twig the size of lead pencil and find a thin brown streak following the bark line, send for the tree doctor, or take the twig to the nearest agricultural station. The brown streak is a danger sign.
