CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP). -- The White Sox found Detroit pitching to their liking today and pounded out their third straight triumph over the Tigers, 11 to 2.

MEXICO, D.F., Aug. 11. -- The seven North and Central American countries represented in the radio conference that closed here this week agreed through their delegations to shelve for future discussion the complicated problem of channel frequencies and recommend that their governments make technical studies to pave the way for an accord.

OTTAWA, Canada, Aug. 9. -- Before the end of this year there will be elections in two, and perhaps three, of the Canadian Provinces, and in each case a Conservative government will put its existence at stake. Next year is almost certain to see a Dominion election when the administration -- also a Conservative one -- of Prime Minister R.B. Bennett will be rejected or continued in office.
ROME, Aug. 12. -- Returning today from their 12,000-mile flight to Chicago, General Italo Balbo and his armada had one of the greatest welcomes ever accorded in Rome's long history to her heroes.

DEATH from coronary thrombosis is the verdict of the Medical Examiner after his autopsy on the body of Theodosia Burr, but Inspector Skane is suspicious. He declares that "some one stuck the trombosis into her," and it is his intention to find out who did it.

PHILADELPHIA. Aug. 12. -- Old Joe Buzzard, who at 75 rates himself as the second best horse thief in the country, will leave the Eastern Sttae Penitentiary on Monday a free man. But Old Joe was anything but jovial today over the prospect.

THE London Studio, in its August issue, discusses the architecture of the Century of Progress Exposition and contains besides, among others, the following articles: "Australian Painters of Today," by Gwen Morton Spencer; "The Folk Art of Bengal (Wood Sculpture)," by G.S. Dutt; "Swedish Arts and Crafts at the Chicago Fair," by Arne Otte Skold; "British Interior Decorators: Herman Schrijver," by Derek Patmore.

Those commodity markets which remained open yesterday were subjected to fresh selling pressure, as a result of which prices were sharply reduced again. The security exchanges and the smaller commodity exchanges were closed.
PARIS, Aug. 11. -- France is somewhat belatedly giving closer study to the national industrial recovery program in the United States in an effort to find out what it is really all about.

A code of fair competition calling for a forty-hour week and a minimum wage of 37 1/2 cents an hour for men and 25 cents an hour for women workers has been submitted to the NRA authorities in Washington by the National Burlap Bag Dealers Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The wheat carry-over last year of 640,000,000 bushels in all countries was emphasized today by Secretary Wallace in "A Balanced Harvest," an official manual of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, as an argument for the administration's wheat reduction campaign.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The success of Sumner Welles in mediating the complex Cuban political situation is of the kind rarely falling to the lot of a young diplomat, in the view of administrative officials.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Aug. 12. -- The International Congress of School Teachers Associations, a world-wide organization, today voted to exclude from its session the German Nazi representatives, including the Bavarian Minister of Education and the delegates of the German Fascist Teachers Federation.
MOSCOW, Aug. 11. -- "This is a year of perelom," they are now saying in the Soviet Union, and the voices are confident, instead of merely hopeful, as three months ago.
LONDON. AT the moment Canada is sitting pretty. For the first time in her history, both the dollar and the pound have cracked; but instead of being buried in the ruins, she is making a handy profit.

HAVANA, Aug. 12. -- President Gerardo Machado, after asking Congress for a "leave of absence," fled from Cuba by airplane this afternoon. His destination was reported to be Nassau, in the Bahamas, but he had not arrived there late tonight.

Despite high tariffs and nationalism, foreign trade goes on; industry constantly demands the raw products of remote lands. Banker and planter, merchant and manufacturer, all have a hand in this far-reaching business, but none is more important than the cargo ship -- the peaceful carrier of goods and good-will.

HAVANA, Aug. 12. -- Army leaders, who yesterday seized the harbor fortress and other points of advantage without firing a shot, approved the choice of Senor Cespedes as the new President and gave permission for General Herrera to remain as Secretary of War until the scheme of legal succession to the high office could be completed.

MOUNT WILSON OBSERVATORY, Cal., Aug. 12. -- One of the greatest showers of meteors in modern times fell into the earth's atmosphere last night and early today to brighten the skies and be recorded on the photographic plates of astronomers stationed on Southern California mountains.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Miss Lucille Robinson, a comely youngster from Des Moines, Ia., dealt the national champion, Miss Virginia Van Wie or Chicago, a 6 and 5 defeat today to win the women's Western open golf title, a priza that has eluded the Chicago star for nine years.

AIDED by cool weather and increasing signs of improved purchasing power, retail trade locally showed distinct gains during the week. Estimates are that for the first half of this month an increase of 3 to 4 per cent over the corresponding period 2 year ago will be reported by leading stores here.

About 150 Communists and members of trade unions and language organizations gathered at South and Whitehall Streets yesterday morning to protest against the recent execution of Communists in Germany, and the Finnish-Fascist attacks upon thirty-nine Communists now staging a hunger strike in Finnish jails.

ROME, Aug. 12. -- In no field of activity has the new impulse given to Italian life by fascism been so obvious as in that of public works. Whatever opinions any one may hold concerning the spiritual and doctrinal content of fascism, it is almost universally conceded that from a purely material standpoint Italy has made giant strides under the present regime.

At Goshen, A.Y., tomorrow, a Grand Circuit meeting of more than ordinary interest will open. The meeting will run for five days, closing on Friday. In that time more than $100,000 in stakes and prizes will be won.

Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial was recommended to Mayor O'Brien yesterday by Herman A. Metz, former Controller, as the best man to fill the Controllership to be vacated, by the retirement of Charles W. Berry on Sept. 16.

CUBA'S political crisis, which again reached the stage of open revolt last week, is the culmination of nearly nine years of turmoil, economic depression and social distress. This period has been marked by labor unrest, student revolt, armed insurrection and governmental repression.

Ten years hence every home will make its own indoor climate. Let blizzards rage, let humid August bring the perspiration to every brow -- perpetual Spring will suffuse the livings-room. Advertisements of air-conditioners will sing of the weather-making machinery in the cellar as poets once sang of the hearth, and glorify the fan, the dehumidifier and the air-washer as magical devices for keeping the boys and girls out of automobiles o' nights.

COLOGNE, Germany, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Competing in the German national track and field championships, Hans Sievert, world's record holder in the decathlon, finished the first five events of his specialty today 90 points ahead of his total for the same events when he set the record at 8,467.62 at Hamburg, July 23.

THIS is such an unpretentious book that the reader needs to dip well into it in order to pet its full flavor and quality. But it is so wholesome with its tang of salt air and fresh earth-smell and the renovating breezes blowing through it that after a little while one begins to realize its individual charm.

Although buying orders for 50,000 bales or more of cotton, attributed to government agencies, were executed yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, prices continued downward with only temporary interruption. A rally of 15 points failed to hold and pressure from all directions closed the list at the bottom.

LONDON. WHAT does it mean? That is the question every one in the publishing world is asking about a warning just issued from Buckingham Palace. This announcement relates to the King's copyright in "letters or papers addressed to his Majesty or prepared for his Majesty's information."

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- More than 100 cowboys and cowgirls, representing fourteen Western States, Canada and Mexico, had sent in their entries today to contest in the World's Fair rodeo, termed by Will Rogers the "Olympic Games" of Western sports.

HELEN HATES as Stella Hallam in the pictorial translation of Rose Franken's play, "Another Language," which was at the Capitol, may have her troubles with her husband's family, particularly with Mom Hallam, but she is at least spared the poignant sufferings she was forced to endure in all her other screen roles.
Murk and Work. "Well, I see by the paper," said Alice, "that the air in New York City was much dirtier in July than the month before."

FRANCE has planted her flag on seven almost-forgotten islands lying between the Philippines and Indo-China. These islands, in which Japan has also shown some interest, are merely dots of coral, comprising some 225 acres. They are outside the zone of American ownership.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP). -- In the role of peacemaker, Hugh S. Johnson, the industrial chieftain, attempted tonight to settle differences between two prominent members of the NRA organization and bring to an end the first open feud in his official family.
LONDON, Aug. 11. -- Every indication points to a record grouse shooting in Scotland in the season which opens tomorrow.

WASHINGTON. IN signing the cotton textile code, the first to be agreed to under the National Industrial Recovery Act, President Roosevelt listed the prohibition of the employment of children under 16 years of age first among the "many significant circumstances" attending this result.
VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 12. -- By the close margin of four seconds, the America's, cup yacht Weetamoe today defeated the Vanitie in the 37-mile run here of the New York Yacht Club from Newport.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 12. -- Gene Sarazen rode into the final of the national Professional Golfers Association championship today with Willie Goggin, an unknown to golf renown.

The New York branch of the Home Owners Loan Corporation will begin "fulltime" operation tomorrow at 9:30 A.M., when the permanent quarters of the organization will be opened on the fourth floor of the Empire State Building.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Preliminary drag hunts are being held at the Berkshire Hunt and Country Club at Lenox in preparation for the regular season with hunt breakfasts, which will be held Sundays, starting Aug. 20, until the snow flies.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Alex Gerard Jr. of the Salisbury Club won his second-round match in the Maidstone Club's second annual Maidstone Bowl golf tournament today, defeating J.E. Lewis of Shorehaven, 1 up. Gerard will meet Richard Woolworth of Mount Kisco, last year's winner here, in the third round.

BANFF. -- On wagons and stranger conveyances, and with out-riders on cayuses, Indian tribes from the Morley and Nordegg reservations are converging on Banff for their annual festival on Friday, Saturday and Sunday when frontier history will be turned back 100 years and redskins by the hundreds will stage their native pageants, dances and tribal competitions.

CHARLES H. DAVIS of Mystic died on Aug. 5, in his seventy-eighth year. He had all but attained the venerable four-score. And yet in writing about him it is impossible to summon a vision other than that of youth.

AN encyclopedic treatise on the climates of the world has long been sorely needed, and one is now in course of publication. The nearest approach to such a work has hitherto been the well-known "Handbuch der Klimatologle" of the late Julius Hann, the third edition of which, in three volumes, appeared upward of twenty years ago, while a fourth edition of the first volume, revised by Professor K. Knoch, has appeared within the last year.

THE milk strike in up-State New York, begun on Aug. 1, and marked by the seizure and destruction of thousands of gallons of milk on the way to market, is the result of grievances long smoldering in the dairy industry and fanned to flame by the depression.

The American, merchant marine has been "put on the spot" by foreign lines and American interest that have directed their attack on government ship subsidies in the form of mail contracts and construction loans, according to P.V. G. Mitchell, vice president of the Roosevelt Steamship Company, operator of the United States Lines.
LONDON, Aug. 11. -- That blood-stained old spectre, the Irish problem, is leering at England again, but nobody here is losing much sleep over it.

A warning that a sharp rise in the dollar and a consequent reaction in commodity and security prices are not improbable in the Fall was sounded here yesterday by Paul P. Gourrich, consulting economist, who urged immediate steps to cause re-employment and fair distribution of the national income.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The Agricultural Adjustment and Grain Futures Administration spurred their investigation into recent transactions on the Chicago Board of Trade today after a further break in prices in the face of a bullish crop report.

DIAMOND POINT, Lake George, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- A new agreement to prevent unduly low or high, water levels on Lake George will be sought with the International Paper Company by the State Conservation Department, Lithgow Osborne, Conservation Commissioner, told members of the Lake George Association at their annual meeting here today.

MOSCOW. STRANGE and varied have been the ways in which Hollywood has interpreted the work of famous authors. But now the prize must go to Moscow for its extraordinary version of O. Henry's story, "Alias Jimmy Valentine"! O. Henry has been exposed to a "Marxist-Leninist interpretation" and the story of what happened to O. Henry in Moscow is typical of the attitude of the cinema industry in the Soviet Union.

WITH experts of one sort or another scrutinizing city expenditures so closely, Floyd Bennett Field, New York's municipal airport out at the end of Flatbush Avenue, has come in for some criticism. New York, it is said, is efficiently served by Newark Airport, just as for years the Pennsylvania Railroad served New York from the other side of the river.

WITH admirable timeliness Mr. James E. Finegan, described on the title page of this book as "Anti-Tammany Democrat, Organizer of No-Deal Judiciary Party in 1931, Formulator of Charges of Prodigious Waste and Inefficiency Against Mayor Walker in 1932, and Member of the New York Bar," levels a lance at the benevolent and social organization which has so much to do with governing our fair city.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 12. -- With the annual election for chairman of the Nassau County Democratic Committee only about a month away, five members of the party announced today that they were seeking the office. With the chairmansnip goes the county leadership.
YOU need have no worries about me," said President Roosevelt, prior to one of his early Presidential radio talks to the people. I am an old band at broadcasting."

OTTAWA, Aug. 3. -- The Secretary of State for Canada, C.H. Cahan, has addressed an official letter to all judicial authorities having to do with the issue of naturalization papers, instructing them to conduct careful inquiries into the character and antecedents of all applications for Canadian citizenship.

WASHINGTON, Aug, 12. -- The first of a series of meetings by the Public Works Administration's National Planning Board, created to help Secretary Ickes and the Cabinet Advisory Board develop a national plan for public works projects of every nature, will be held Monday morning at the Century Club in New York City.

Henry W. Rodney, a secret service agent, whose experience has taught him to believe that counterfeiters are a canny lot, explained yesterday in the Federal Building that there were exceptions to all rules.

To the Editor of The New York Tiems: To rock the boat of Federal reconstruction in these trying times must be construed as an act lacking in patriotism. Fully aware of this fact, and with due respect to the men who are so valiantly trying to drag our country out of the slough of despond into which it has unnecessarily fallen, I still find that I must do just that.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 12. -- After a spell of the doldrums and much hauling, a light southerly breeze finally stirred the waters and allowed a fleet of 275 boats to sail today in the Corinthian Yacht Club regatta.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 5 amounted to 613,112 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 25,284 cars, or 4 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week, but 116,486 cars, or 23.5 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 121,618 cars, or 16.6 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
ROME, Aug. 12. -- General Italo Balbo, commander of the Italian air armada, on his return to Rome was elevated to the Tank of Air Marshal by Premier Mussolini in a decree published tonight.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- The business relations between officials of the Chicago Board of Trade and Dr. E. A. Crawford, New York broker, will be aired in public as a result of the controversy over the proposed Exchange code, grain men said here today.

AN unusually significant contribution to the understanding of early American arts is the current exhibition at the Berkshire Museum. Pittsfield Mass., of stencils used for the ornamentation of walls and furniture. These are part of an extensive collection of more than a thousand pieces gathered by Miss Janet Waring a pioneer in this field of antique decoration.

The only adequate solution of Negro education in the South depends upon a complete program of Federal aid, according to Professor Mabel Carney of Teachers College, Columbia University, who has completed a survey of educational conditions in Southern States.

BLUFF POINT, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Miss Marjorie Harrison, 14-year-old golfing star from Ausable Forks, N.Y., won her first big tournament today. She scored a thrilling nineteen-hole victory in the final of the first annual invitation event for women at the Lake Champlain Country Club.

IN this book Clyde Kluckhohn tells the story of four attempts be has made to enter, explore and conquer Wild Horse Mesa, on the north shore of the Colorado River, near the junction with it of the San Juan River. In only one of these, that made in the Summer of 1928, was be successful.

Plight of Our Birds. Our song-birds and other birds are being rapidly killed off, regardless of attempts to protect them. The destruction of birds will mean added expense for the farmers and added prices for food to the consumer, quite apart from the loss, of joy and cheer that our little song-birds bestow on the world in payment for their right to live.

BERLIN, Aug. 11. -- His friends call him "the flying philosopher," but to millions of Germans Dr. Hugo Eckener remains "Germany's grand old man of the air."

DUBLIN, Aug. 11. -- Despite all the rumors of impending civil strife and political disturbance, one of the most successful of the famous Dublin horse shows was concluded this evening after a record run for four days.

Senator PITTMAN'S transmarine experiences brought him only a change of sky, not of mind. He comes back to us with undiminished hopefulness and vivacity; even with something of the impetuosity that belongs to his bright home in the settin' sun. From the Economic Conference he brings the belief that "we got half what we went to London for."
REVAL, Estonia, Aug. 12. -- The Estonian Government's decision of yesterday to proclaim military law in all provinces signifies the beginning of a serious political crisis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Shippers and receivers of freight were asked today by Joseph B. Eastman, transportation coordinator, to aid in bringing about an improved rail freight service by making known to him their particular needs and objections to existing facilities.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 5. -- Colorado and Wyoming are rapidly digging themselves out of the depression. In the case of Wyoming the resurrection is nearly complete. The advance in wool prices, following directly on the heels of the Farm Bill, is the key to the situation there.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Open hearings on a code for the bituminous coal industry were concluded today and experts of the NRA prepared to digest and collate the information furnished with the hope of bringing all sides into agreement.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 12 (AP). -- Conflicting statements on the support behind a call for a milk strike in Connecticut Thursday came today from dairy groups as Governor Cross and the State Milk Control Board sought an early solution of the issues which precipitated the crisis.

FIVE months of research and preparation were required before "Bitter Sweet," the British and Dominions picture, was ready to enter production. The story deals with four periods, 1875, 1880, 1895 and the present, and experts were employed to ascertain the proper styles of architecture, decoration, dress and coiffure for each.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- A production quota of 7,000,000 gallons of medicinal liquor for 1934 was tentatively fixed today by the Bureau of Industrial Alcohol.

PARIS, Aug. 10. -- Fashions at the final Winter showings reveal the characteristic 1934 silhouette. It consists of a long tight sheath skirt, split or full below the knees, that has a strong reminiscent flavor of the 1912 epoch. The silhouette is varied by basque peplums and decorative hem and collar treatments that jut out without hiding the basic line.

Forced out of the Wightman cup matches by an injured back, Mrs. Helen Wills Moody will make her first tournament appearance at Forest Hills in two years tomorrow, when the women's national championship will get under way at the West Side Tennis Club.

THE fine portrait of Gopal Krishna Gokhale prefixed to this candid and illuminating story of India's renascence is a fitting preface. Gokhale, who founded the Servants of India Society of which Dr. Zacharias is an associate, died in 1915 before affairs in his country had got to the revolutionary stage, and his nationalistic liberalism, which never bordered on the extreme and which is that of the Moderates, the party to which the author belongs.

A strike of 30,000 members of the painting and allied trades in New York City by union painters, paper-hangers and decorators was sanctioned yesterday if employers do not meet demands for a thirty-hour week and a uniform wage scale for all work in the industry, based on the pay of the first part of October, 1929.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Fifty men and women prominent in industrial, labor and civic circles were drafted by the Federal Employment Service today to serve on an advisory committee which will formulate policies and help solve problems relating to employment.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 12 (AP). -- The Federal Government invaded gangland today with indictments under its new kidnapping law against four members of the Touhy mob of Chicago.
Eighty-six persons were killed and 4,378 were injured in the city during July as a result of street accidents involving all types of vehicles, the Police Department reported yesterday.

SALEM, N.H., Aug. 12. -- The 3-year-old bay filly Marianna, the 550,000 Hambletonian Stake candidate of H. Stacey Smith of Newark, N.J., today gained her initial Rockingham Park victory during the closing program of the Grand Circuit's Salem meeting.
Taking up the business of baseball after a three-day vacation, the Dodgers failed to display any winning form at Ebbets Field yesterday and lost to the Braves, 5 to 3.

Several entire Issues of domestic bonds and parts of two foreign bond issues for payment in future months, together with various municipal bonds and warrants for redemption in August were the principal announcements last week of securities called for payment before their maturity dates.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 12 (AP). -- Captain Alan Winslow, author and United States World War flier, was injured seriously today when he fell from a third-story window of a hotel. Several hours later he was still unconscious in a hospital and slight hope was held for his recovery.

PARIS, Aug. 12. -- The whole question of tariff discrimination against the United. States, which was thought settled two days ago by France's yielding to the United States Embassy's vigorous protests, was reopened today when it was learned France had again placed a large group of American products on the maximum tariff list.

WHITE TOP MOUNTAIN, Va., Aug. 12 (AP). -- Two vociferous mountain, welcomes, one at Abingdon and the other on this lofty peak, greeted Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today when she arrived on her father's Old Virginia hunting grounds.

IN the arts as in athletics and aviation, we applaud the audacity of exploits which we would not presume to attempt. As Lindbergh leapt across an ocean from one world to another, so did Gibbon throw a bridge of knowledge across centuries of ignorance, and while few have read in its entirety so great a work as "The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire," the hero of history who wrote it is acclaimed forever.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10. -- In promoting the effectiveness of the NRA Wisconsin easily holds the lead over Illinois and Indiana. In Illinois there is as yet no State organization at work in cooperation with the Federal agents of the recovery program, no local effort to stimulate business response or consumer support.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10. -- Within a little more than a month of the primary election, Pittsburgh's Mayoralty campaign is still so confused that the so-called boss of the Republican organization, State Senator James J. Coyne, who is under indictment in an election fraud case, is an internal issue in both the republican and Democratic parties, and the independent Republican strength is divided by two candidates.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, Aug. 12. -- For the third year in succession, a filly proved better than the smartest juvenile colts when Wise Daughter was a decisive victor today in the Saratoga. Special, the sporting sweep in which the winner takes all.

DEACON EVERETT SCOTT has been invited to fit in and watch Lou Gehrig break the record for personal appearances in consecutive big league games. Weather permitting and no accidents intervening, this is expected to take place early this week while the Yankees are playing at Sportsman's Park in St. Louis.

With the Chicago Board of Trade preparing to remove on Tuesday the "pegs" that have supported the grain markets for the last two weeks, the whole price structure, in securities as well as commodities, is about to be subjected to the severest test since the recovery program was launched.

To The Editor of The New York Times: The answer as to the fate of migratory game very soon will be given u by President Roosevelt and Secretary Wallace, in whose hands the decision rests. The answer for all non-migratory game is that already it is down to the dregs of "game" and "sport," and little remains but half-tame English pheasants, rabbits with or without tularemia, and a very few friendly squirrels.

As an economy measure several pastors have returned from their vacations this week to relieve their assistants so that they may go on their vacations. These are churches for the most part which until this season have engaged outstanding clergymen from other cities to fill their pulpits.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP). -- The long soccer season got under way in Scotland today, two weeks ahead of the opening of the English league.
Freddy Fitzsimmons joined the select group of Memphis Bill Terry's shut-out flinders yesterday by blanking the Phillies at the Polo Grounds, 2 to 0.

That the United States cannot be permanently stabilized until "mass consumption is coordinated and correlated, with mass production to insure a carefully but practically organized balance between the two" is the opinion expressed yesterday by Arthur J. Morris, president of the Morris Plan Company of New York and founder of the Morris Plan System.
Belief that employers could be prosecuted under the mail fraud statutes for violations of NRA codes they had signed was expressed here yesterday by Postmaster General James A. Farley.

Basing their convictions on increased employment, higher wage scales, better commodity prices and the feeling of confidence generated by the Roosevelt administration, manufacturers in the various merchandise markets look forward to their most active Fall season in several years, according to a canvass of leading executives by THE TIMES during the week.

Senator Royal S. Copeland chairman of the Senate Racket Investigating Committee, which will open hearings at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York tomorrow, predicted yesterday that NRA would help destroy racketeering.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- More than 2,000,000 workers were enlisted in the NRA army today when General Hugh Johnson approved modifications of the President's Agreement under which the electric light and power, natural and manufactured gas, telephone, canning and construction industries may operate.

Practically all sectors of public opinion among the Cuban Oppositionists regard the choice of Dr. Carlos Manuel de Cespedes as Provisional President as satisfactory. The only voice that has been raised against him is that of General Mario G. Menocal, former President of Cuba, and head of the so-called "orthodox" wing of the Conservative party, which refused to cooperate with President Machado during the latter's administration.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- The United States Consulate here refused today to grant a visa to Tom Mann, 76-year-old Communist leader, who had intended to visit the United States. Mann professed to be going as head of a "British anti-war delegation" to address pacifist meetings.

The boycott against German goods, among Jews as well as non-Jews, has spread over all Europe, and thousands of Jews are still continuing to escape from Hitler and Hitlerism. Samuel A. Frommer of Indianapolis said yesterday on his return on the steamer Statendam of the Holland-America Line.

An unusually large number of deaths was caused in New York City by the recent hot weather. Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday. Mortality was high particularly among infants and in the older age groups.
MILFORD, Pa., Aug. 12 (AP). -- Swinging into the sixty-ninth year of his colorful life, Governor Gifford Pinchot has pickerel and poetry as reminders of his birthday yesterday.

MARIE DRESSLER, who is to be seen this week at the Capitol in "Tugboat Annie," was born in Coburg, Canada, the daughter of Alexander Koerber, an officer who had settled down in the Dominion after seeing service in the Crimean War.

SUMTER, S.C., Aug. 10 -- What will, or what can, be done about tobacco? And when? These are questions that have been bothering the Tobacco Belt for weeks, but they have become more pressing as auction sales get under way in the southernmost areas of the belt where the crop is made, cured and marketed earlier than it is in parts of North Carolina and in Kentucky, Tennessee and Virginia.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Sharpshooting Pittsburgh batting behind impregnable pitching today gave the Pirates a double conquest of the Chicago Cubs, 5 to 2 and 3 to 2, and boosted them back into second place in the National League.

HUNTINGTON, L.I. -- Aug. 12 -- The Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club defeated the Staten Island Cricket Club today by a margin of 120 runs in a Metropolitan and New Jersey Cricket Association match. The totals were 178 -- 58.

HAVANA, Aug. 12. -- Celebrating the downfall of President Gerardo Machado, wildly exultant mobs today and tonight rushed rioting through the streets of Havana. They looted the Presidential Palace and sacked and burned the properties of officials and sympathizers of the fallen regime.

THE recent visit of two distinguished foreigners wearing beards has led American men to take stock of their chins. Though we are a beardless nation, one prophet has had the temerity to announce that "a new bearded age is on the way."

LAKE FOREST, Ill., Aug. 12. -- Final preparations were completed tonight for the opening game of the newest event in American polo, the East-West matches. Tomorrow afternoon at 4:30, on the picturesque field of the Onwentsia Club here, picked players from the two sections of the country will ride out to start a two-out-of-three games series.

FLOGGING, one of the oldest forms of punishment, is still permitted in a few countries and in one of our Southern States. A recent dispatch from London announced that "two 20-year-old youths were ordered flogged at Old Bailey for what was said to be the first armed robbery in Great Britain with sawed-off shotguns."

DUBLIN, Aug. 12. -- "There will be no more civil war in Ireland as long as we have the power to prevent it," Eamon de Valera, President of the Free State Executive Council, emphatically stated in a special interview today explaining the policy adopted by his government in prohibiting tomorrow's proposed demonstration by the National Guard, or Blue Shirts.

BERLIN. A BOOK of great freshness and vivacity is the American adventure of young Wolf-gang Langewiesche (Verlag Engelhorn, Stuttgart). A student of economics, gone abroad in his search for increased knowledge of the factors that govern humanity and the economic world, he meets an American journalist, Mr. Marey, in London.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- An additional grant of $1,529,714 for unemployment relief was made to New York today by Harry L. Hopkins. Federal Emergency Relief Administrator.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 12. -- L.G. Moffatt captured the high scratch cup in the registered shoot at the Nassau Trapshopting Club today. He had a card of 99 targets. F.C. Chapman finished with the same score, but shot for targets only.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Assets of the defunct Illinois Life Insurance Company, which at one time were valued at $12,000,000, have a "knockdown value" today of only $4,239,000. Jacob I. Grossman. Federal master in chancery, said in a report submitted to Judge James H. Wilkerson.

THIS is the latest and by no means the least valuable of the admirable "Classics of International Law" of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. The first volume coutains a photographic reproduction of the 1612 edition of Gentili's classic, and the second a translation of the text by Professor Rolfe of the University of Pennsylvania and an illuminating and appreciative introduction by Coleman Phililpson, an English barrister.

A statement by Cardinal Hayes stressing the importance of the nineteenth meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Charities to be held Oct. 1 to 4 in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel was made public yesterday at the headquarters of the New York Catholic Charities.

EACH of the codes presented by the aircraft industry under the NRA program contains clauses of much interest. In the code of the manufacturers the provision that no design may he used or transferred by a second party without agreement on the part of the designer and due compensation to him strikes at the heart of a practice which the manufacturers have steadily opposed.

WEST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Members of the yacht racing squadron of the West Hampton Country Club resumed their weekly regattas off the Speonk Shore today. The feature of the regatta was the sail-off of one of the Great South Bay championships.

TURNING the telescope of the United States Naval Observtory to the meridian eighteen minutes after midnight on Saturday, Aug. 5, Astronomer John E. Willis saw the great white spot of Saturn, which has played so conspicuous a part in the news of science tooth here and abroad.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- A combination of factors, of which officials find the primary one to be the rapid development of hard-surfaced highways, is causing the nation's railroads to abandon trackage at a greater rate than ever before.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 12. -- Two important sporting and social events will be held in Greenwich next month.

ONCE upon a time there flourished what was known as the impressionistic school of writers, although latterly not so much has been heard of them, so many other schools having clamored for a hearing. Whether there can be "impressionism" in writing, many have questioned, while granting that in the field of painting there can be no questioning the designation.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 12. -- In the six months ended on June 30, Ontario' gold mines produced bullion to the value of $22,060,443, or $1,182,249 less than in the panic period of 1932. The premium on gold amounted, however, to $4,839,840, making the total return to producing companies $26,900,284.

THE week at the Stadium is to be one of unquestioned variety, beginning with Mr. Iturbi's debut in this country as a conductor tonight. Mr. Iturbi will not only conduct a program in cluding the "Eroica," but will appear as piano soloist in the Third Beethoven concerto in C minor.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- A reform in the law governing discharge of children from institutions, to give the committing court an opportunity to pass upon the fitness of the home before the child leaves the institution, is urged by Children's Court Judge George W. Smyth of Westchester County in his annual report, submitted this week to the Board of Supervisors.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been a reader of THE TIMES'S political news from the various States for a good many years and always considered this a good way to keep posted on conditions throughout the country. I find myself, however, in disagreement with your correspondent's article from Memphis explaining the prohibition vote in East Tennessee.

Santo Domingo will celebrate on Wednesday the sixty-eighth anniversary of the restoration of its political independence from Spain and the end of the third year of the administration of President Rafael L. Trujillo.

Last week's statement of the Federal Reserve Banks showed that their holdings of gold have again reached a new high record. The present figure is $3,577,000,000. This compares with $2,680,000,000 on the same date last year and with $2,892,000,000 immediately before the banking crisis of last March.

BOSTON. Aug. 12 (AP). -- The powerful slugging of Ossie Bluege and Buddy Myer today enabled the league-leading Senators to make a clean sweep of their three-game series with the Red Sox. Washington's 2-to-1 triumph gave Earl (Lefty) Whitehill his fifteenth victory in twenty-one starts.
Civilization has killed off more ducks and other wild waterfowl than hunters, according to a report submitted yesterday to the More Game Birds Foundation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whither does the sudden and radical change in our economic order lead? If the experiment is not successful, what then? And if it is successful, will government control reach out still further in the interests of Mr. Average Citizen?

THE situation in the United States today, economically, politically and socially, is one of the most delicate and perhaps decisive that we have ever experienced. It is possible that a determining part in it may be played by one of our strongest national traits, the love of speculation.

SHRUB OAK, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- With two blues and one yellow ribbon in three appearances over the obstacles, Gordon Wright's chestnut gelding. Sonny, outshone all other competitors today at the first Camelot Farms' Horse Show, on the estate of Harry C. Arthur Jr.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12.-- Prominent among the dinner parties here tonight was that given by Mrs. James Laurens Van Alen at Wakehurst. The thirty guests were later entertained with a musical program.

VIENNA, Aug. 11. -- Germany's brusque treatment of the Anglo-French efforts to induce her to stop bullying little Austria has been a considerable disappointment to the Dollfuss government despite the second-hand reassurances of the British Foreign Office that Berlin had promised Rome it would be better behaved in the future.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 12. -- Miss Anne, a bay mare owned by Henry Seaman and driven by Ally Cornwell, won the 2:15 trot and pace at the Fair Grounds today after three thrilling miles.

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 7. -- As Professor Irving Fisher pointed out recently, stabilization of currency is not necessarily stabilization relatively to gold. The stabilization of most interest and importance to the man in the street is stabilization of buying power of the currency which he may be carrying.

The Banking Act of 1933, which has been in effect for nearly two months, appears to have had the deflationary results that were predicted for it. Since the bill was signed by President Roosevelt on June 16 there has been a steady decline in Federal Reserve member-bank credit, wiping out the rise which had taken place in the preceding month under the influence of the Federal Reserve's credit expansion campaign.

MONTREAL, Aug. 12 (Canadian Press). -- Six of the twenty-four fliers left by General Italo Balbo in Newfoundiand when he decided that his planes would be too heavily laden for the long flight across the Atlantic are in Montreal today. They are on their way to New York City, where they will sail for Italy aboard the Rex or the Conte di Savoia.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- The fifth annual tournament of the Virginias Seniors Golf Association which will open tomorrow on the No. 1 Greenbrier course is attracting many lovers of the sport. The tournament will continue through Tuesday and Wednesday.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 12. -- Equaling three world's marks, the United States touring track and field team today continued its sweep of foreign opposition, winning eight of nine events in competition with the leading Hungarian stars.

JOINING the general upswing in production, RKO-Radio had five pictures before the cameras and microphones last week. Two of them, "Ann Vickers" and "Little Women," had entered the production lists the week before.

LIKE many another note in the papers these mad days, the week's most imposing theatrical trifle has been carried here by cable from London. Naturally enough, it would concern Mr. Coward, lately returned from tours and battleships.

BAR HARBOR -- The international tennis tournament between players of the British and United States Navies is finished and tomorrow younger members of the colony will take over the courts. Play will be in two classes of mixed doubles, one for boys and girls under 16, and one for those between 16 and 20, for the eight silver cups which the club is offering to the winners and runners-up.

SALISBURY, Md., Aug. 12 (AP). -- Four men were killed and four others hurt near here early today when the Pennsylvania Railroad fast express. The Cavalier, struck a section of track that apparently had been tamperedr with and over-turned.

A determined effort is to be made by the American Kennel Club to reduce the number of cases that are brought before the several trial boards of the organization. The first step in simplifying procedure was the adoption of a uniform code. All trial boards now operate along identical lines.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 9. -- Missouri business men are showing their willingness to sign a recovery code by hanging some 37,000 NRA blue eagles in their windows -- representing considerably more than one-third of the 100,000 employers to whom the certificates were sent for signature -- but skepticism of its ultimate end is beginning to become more emphatically expressed.

LONDON. Aug. 12 (AP). -- The following are the Board of Trade figures for the month of July: Exports of British products, L29,840,000; re-exports, foreign goods. L4,320,000; total exports, L34,160,000; imports, L53,700,000; excess of imports, L19,540,000.

With the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb closed, business in Wall Street was sharply restricted yesterday. The New York Cotton. Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade were open as usual and speculative operations were confined to these institutions.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- Three championships were won in the Eastern turf court tournament today, but outstanding on the program was the superlative tennis played by Sidney B. Wood Jr. of New York and Lester B. Stoefen of Los Angeles in the semi-final round of the men's singles.

IF you cannot draw a tiger," says the old Chinese proverb, "draw a dog." Now there has always been a certain amount of suspicion among Westerners that the Pekingese did not belong to the dog family anyway, but the revelations of Annie Coath Dixey's astonishing history are going to shock many persons who had not suspected the small beast of having jungle relatives.

Reports from the Federal Reserve centres for last week show mixed influences at work in retail trade, which on the whole appears to be slightly better than seasonal, and continued activity in wholesale and manufacturing lines in anticipation of buoyant conditions in the Fall.

GENEVA, Aug. 11. -- The test of the Four-Power Pact that Germany's radio aviation interference with Austria gave this week has been followed with professional interest by League of Nations circles. They do not regret to find the results liable to make ratification of the pact harder in Great Britain and France.

THE war that still means more than any other war to the people of this Republic -- the Civil War and the World War notwithstanding -- is still that usually styled "Revolutionary." To Europe -- even to England -- it was a very little war.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Aug. 12. -- The horse show ball was held tonight at Fassifern Farm by the Bath County Horse Show Association, with more than 300 attending. The ball, as was the horse show which ended here today was held for the benefit of the Community House Hospital.
WARSAW, Aug. 11. -- Ignace Jan Paderewski will not be able to vote for members of the Senate under the new Constitution drafted by the Pilsudski bloc for action at the Fall parliamentary session.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Business activity showed a moderate recession in the week ended on Aug. 5, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Contrary to the heretofore generally acknowledged right of the Bureau of Internal Revenue to fix valuations for tax purposes, the new capital stock tax, by provision of the National Industrial Recovery Act, permits the corporation to figuratively assess itself upon a self-imposed valuation.

FAR-REACHING recommendations, affecting the millions of bus travelers in this country, are embodied in the code submitted by the National Association of Motor Bus Operators. These recommendations -- aside from those affecting labor -- include the fixing of minimum rates between the principal towns and cities, compulsory insurance for the protection of passengers on interstate routes and licensing of bus transport lines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- President Roosevelt on his return to the White House late today awaited a detailed report from Ambassador Sumner Welles on the Cuban situation. The tension of the past two days was noticeably relaxed and the plain inference was drawn that the trend of political events in Havana has been of a nature satisfactory to this government.

In one of the feature events that made the Harlem River a racing course yesterday. Arthur L. Strang of the New York A.C. spun down the mile stretch to capture the metropolitan single sculling championship.

Is the era of rugged individualism among universities passing, in favor of coordinated academic effort? Already the States of Oklahoma and Washington have begun to eliminate duplications of function among their colleges. And now Chicago's two great privately controlled universities -- Chicago and Northwestern -- are considering similar possibilities of cooperation.

Plans for curbing expensive services to customers, appointment of a committee to hold apparently excessive wholesale price advances in check and a setback to efforts on the part of some stores radically to curtail hours of store operation under the retail code were major developments in the retail field during the week.

The trial of three men in the Kings County Court on a conspiracy indictment charging racketeering in the laundry business in Brooklyn was continued yesterday before Judge Alonzo G. McLaughlin and a jury. The men on trial are Jacob Mellon, Morris Rothenberg and Edward Lollo, said,to be officers of the Affiliated Laundry Owners Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Confidence that racing interests would far from the tracks those who "dope." horses, before drastic Federal action becomes necessary, was expressed today by Harry J. Anslinger, Commissioner of Narcotics.

DUBLIN, Aug. 12. -- Heavy patrols of police at important points in the city are the only public evidence of the tension that exists here. Tonight following the government's proscribing of the "National Guards' " parade tomorrow.

With only one series showing a rise, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity continued its downward movement for the week ended Aug. 5. The figure dropped more than 2 points to 89.8 from 92 in the previous week. A year ago the number was 63.8.

The political strife in Cuba has stimulated interest in the extent of this country's financial stake in that republic. According to the best Information available in the financial community, American individuals, institutions and corporations have invested between $1,250,000,000 and $1,500,000,000 in Cuba.

BAIREUTH, July 29, 1933. LOOKING back over the first completed lap of the current Baireuth festival two things stand out -- the mediocrity of the performance as a whole and the unmitigated attempt, through sophistry and propaganda, to identify Richard Wagner with Nazidom and all its works.

HOLLYWOOD. WITH the anticipated ending of the studio technicians' strike by the Federal Government, the town settled down this week and attempted to regain the ground lost when sound men, photographers and laboratory employes ceased work after a wage and hour dispute with Columbia studios by the sound group.

Some of the reviewers of H.M. TOM-LINSON'S "The Snows of Helicon" feel impatient at his remote and rebuking point of view. He is a practicing mystic. Mentally and spiritually he has withdrawn from the metallic clatter of the modern industrial world. Ever since he published his orchestrated log of an adventuresome voyage into the heart of the South American jungle he has been recognized as one of our most lyric writers and piercing thinkers.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 12. -- The police began today an investigation in the laboratories of the Solbosch University where an explosion last evening wrecked a gondola built for the proposed stratosphere flight by Cosyns. Experts made an examination of the gondola and instruments to determine the causes of the accident, which resulted in the death of one workman and injuries to two other persons.
ALBANY, Aug. 12. -- Governor Lehman rejected tonight the proposal for a one-week truce in the milk strike, which had been announced half an hour before by a committee of strike leaders.

CULVER, Ind., Aug. 12. -- Donald Budge, red-headed youngster from Oakland, Calif., is the new junior national tennis champion. He won the title today by defeating Gene Mako of Los Angeles, the heavy favorite, in a hard-fought five-set match.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 12 (AP). -- The Indians pulled the first of a three-game series with the Browns out of the fire in the tenth inning today. The score was 4 to 3.

AN indoor set, covering more than a square block and believed to have been one of the largest in the history of motion pictures, was built by Warner Brothers at its West Coast studios for the filming of "Captured." The set was that of the German prison camp in which most of the picture's action took place.

MR. LATIMER'S thorough and painstaking work is likely to be the last word on industrial pensions for years to come. Prepared as the result of several years' study which embraced examination of 500 pension plans in American industry, these two volumes would appear to answer nearly every question that may be asked on the subject.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- President Roosevelt returned to the capital late this afternoon, after a 180-mile automobile trip through the Shenandoah Valley, where he visited five civilian Conservation Corps camps.

THE college girl -- she who is about to pass through the portals that lead to halls of knowledge, as well as she who has already crossed the sill -- will soon be bursting into town again after her Summer at the resorts, golden brown and full of vigor and vim.

HAVANA, Aug. 12 (By Wireless). -- The still increasing roar, as I write, of public jubilation at the abrupt withdrawal of President Gerardo Machado carries a note of rising vengeance, of heady mob spirit which may be the cause of more serious excesses than those already witnessed.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- The stay-at-homes among Long Island Sound yachtsmen turned out with ninety-seven craft today for the thirty-seventh annual races of the Huguenot Yacht Club.

TOKYO, Aug. 12 (AP). -- Japan's magnificent young swimmers, who swept the Olympic Games at Los Angeles last Summer, today began their own private meet, the Japanese national championships, in record-breaking fashion, one world mark falling in preliminary heats.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP). -- In an effort to increase the returns to dairy farmers the Farm Adjustment Administration is drafting a blanket marketing agreement to apply to the nation's milk distributing industry.

THE gasoline filling station -- water trough of the machine age -- is now in a period of transition. It has developed rapidly from a simple dispensing depot to a planned service headquarters, discarding some picturesqueness and a good deal of inefficiency on the way.

LONDON, Aug. 12 (Canadian Press). -- The touring British West Indies team will go to bat in the third and last test cricket match against England on Monday, facing an English first-innings score of 312 runs. England won the first test and the second was drawn.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- Baby's bottle of milk, disarmingly innocent in its purity, will outlast as an issue the blood being shed and the platitudes being uttered in its cause by otherwise peaceful farmers whose strike possibly has brought New York State closer to martial law than at any time since the Revolutionary War.

ONE sees by the jacket that the English reviewers have already compared this first novel to the Five Towns tales of Arnold Bennett. The comparison is just and appropriate. "Original Design" is a sound and worthy performance and in nowise obviously imitative.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 12 (AP). -- A Sheriff who carries his riot gun to lawn parties chanced upon a gang murder early today in time to visit death on two men and capture a third member of the group.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- The regatta ball of the Lake George Club next Saturday night at the Diamond Point clubhouse will be the climax to the afternoon of speedboat racing for the Governor Lehman Cup. Mrs. John Elliott Parry and Miss Bertha Parry have charge of plans for the regatta dinner, and a committee headed by Miss Margaret Peters is arranging for the ball.

Stores throughout the country are now reporting an increase in trade, with sales stimulated by freer money circulation instead, of credit, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

WHILE the same cannot be said of the "pedestrians keep to the left" rule, another law also effective last July 1 is being faithfully observed by the operators of commercial vehicles which it affects. That is the measure requiring the use of two pairs of reflectors on trucks and buses, one pair of red ones at the rear and one pair of yellow at front, placed so as to indicate the width of the vehicle.

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Coasting along at a leisurely gait in the final heat after he had virtually clinched the test with two swift victories in the first two races. George Reis of Lake George. N.Y., won the national sweepstakes motor-boating trophy today.

A new attempt to link high school and junior college education more closely than ever with current problems is to be made by Fieldston School, one of the units sponsored by the Ethical Culture Society. Under a grant of funds made available just before the death last Spring of Dr. Felix Adler, founder and leader of the society, an extensive research has been undertaken for this purpose.

MIAMI, Fla., Sunday, Aug. 13 (AP). -- Dr. Orestes Ferrara, Secretary of State of the fallen Machado government, flew here late yesterday from Havana. He was fired upon when he left Cuba and was booed when he arrived here. He left during the night for New York from Hollywood, near this city.

MID - AUGUST finds the broadcasters busy completing plans that presage a crowded and varied program schedule for the Fall and Winter months. Many of the old favorites that signed off at the beginning of Summer will return to the kilocycles before the leaves begin to fall, joining the ranks of those now on the air who will carry on into the new season.

IN a tour recently made by two representatives from each of the navy's continental aircraft repair bases, three representatives from the Bureau of Aeronautics and one from the Bureau of Supplies and Accounts, these representatives made a comprehensive study of aircraft repair methods and costs at Air Corps repair depots and at the overhaul centres of the larger commercial airlines in the United States.

MR. KASTEIN'S previous studies in Messianism and mysticism have destroyed for him the old historical antinomies of subjective and objective. He frankly admits that he is writing subjective history with a bias and a thesis and ventures the validity of his interpretations on the validity of his personal preferences and hopes.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 -- "Pegged prices" checked a declining tendency today in the grain market on the Board of Trade. Little disposition to rally was shown, and the close was at the bottom, with sellers offering all deliveries of grain and provisions at the lowest levels at which they could be sold under the exchange regulations.

PARIS. THE tailored suit has always been the Parisienne's fashion pet and just now it is being specially pushed as a protest against a plethora of fuss and ruffles. Its success in the United States is more sporadic, but it is certain that this Winter the clear-cut three-piece tailleur will occupy a fair portion of the wardrobe space lately allotted to the dress-and-loose-jacket ensemble.

George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, began an investigation yesterday of complaints that racketeers were attempting to collect fees from small home-owners by offering to aid them in obtaining loans from the Home Owners Loan Corporation.

The sailing vessels Amerigo Vespucci and Cristoforo Colombo, training ships of the Italian Royal Naval Academy, are scheduled to anchor in the North River next Saturday for a twelve-day visit. The ships reached Baltimore last week and will sail late this week for New York, the final stop before they start home.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Belarion owned by former Mayor Newton B. Smalley of North Plainfield, captured premier honors in the light-harness racing card at the Borough Park track today. Belarion, a trotter, won the only extra heat event.

TEJOS CITY, at the head of the old Chisholm Trail, was a small cow town at the end of the Civil War. when Aaron Burrell opened his tiny general merchandise store in a reconditioned wagon shed. From his early boyhood in the Duchy of Baden Aaron had dreamed of the New World Later in his uncle Simon's store in St Louis. he had listened eagerly to the talk of Texas-bound travelers.

Holding that upward revision of the tariff would defeat rather than help aims of the National Recovery Act, George F. Bauer, chairman of the World Trade League, yesterday announced that his organization will begin an active campaign for tariff concessions to countries which consent to enter into reciprocal trade treaties with the United States, Mr. Bauer returned last week from London, where he attended the World Economic Conference.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- The special investigating board to review presumptive disability cases for Kansas, the thirteenth board to be named by General Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans' Affairs, is composed of three World War veterans, two of whom are American Legion members.
PEARY LODGE, Greenland, Aug. 12. -- The University of Michigan, Pan-American Airways Greenland expedition is bringing to a close its Polar Year program for 1933.

Dr. Carlos Manuel de Cesjedes, who is to succeed Gerardo Machado as President of Cuba is the son of "the George Washington of Cuba," the Carlos Manuel de Cespedes who formed a provisional government for a republic of Cuba in 1868, in one of the revolts against the Spanish colonial government which preceded the liberation of Cuba in 1898.
Shortly before 9 o'clock yesterday morning Morris Saskewitz, 55 years old, a well-to-do garage owner, was shot dead in the cellar of his home at 430 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

A new Summer policy will be inaugurated at Madison Square Garden on Thursday, when a boxing program will be offered. Patsy Perroni, rugged Cleveland heavyweight, will oppose Isidore Gastanaga, hard-hitting Spanish boxer, in the feature bout of ten rounds.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 12. -- Scores of Cuban exiles, no longer expatriates of their island republic with the downfall of the Machado regime, prepared tonight to return by airplane and steamship to their homes.

The commercial recovery of bromine from the sea, once regarded as impossible, has been accomplished by chemistry and a new industry is arising from a process by which bromine is removed from sea water and converted into commercial bromides.
LONDON, Aug. 12. -- Signs of a slight improvement in Great Britain's foreign trade were discernible in the Board of Trade returns for July, published today.

President DE VALERA said some time ago that the Irish Free State is in the way of becoming "a hair-shirt republic." It, was a vivid phrase to illustrate the demands which are made upon the Irish people in striving to carry out what they conceive to be their highest national aspirations.

SURF CITY, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Fishermen along the New Jersey coast do not entirely agree with Dr. E.W. Gudger of the American Museum of Natural History, that New York garbage dumped at sea is attracting sharks to bathing beaches. One of the heaviest concentrations of ocean-migrating fish in a generation has been reported this Summer.

HAVANA, Aug. 12. -- Wildest disorders, eclisping even those experienced when independence was granted to the Cubans in 1901, prevailed in the streets late today as the frenzied populace celebrated the downfall of the Machado regime.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Several small hotels in other centres were damaged today in the violent storm which swept for fifty miles across Eastern New York from Sacandaga Lake to the Vermont line. Amsterdam, Cambridge, Pittstown, Valley Falls and Mechanicsville were hit.

MR. CLARK CALVIN GRIFFITH, owner of the Washington Senators, who has become so proud of his white hair that he refuses to wear a hat in public places, was piping along in a high sing-song voice about baseball when up strode Al Schacht, who nudged Mr. Griffith to one side and took charge of the conversation.

Increasing pressure upon city officials to sponsor a 2-cent tax on rapid transit fares will follow if State legislation is passed giving the city blanket authority to impose new taxes in order to raise relief funds, it was indicated last night.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 13 -- Jubilee, the Star Class boat skippered by John and H.B. Atkin, defeated fourteen rivals today to win the Captain's Island trophy. She led the runner-up, S. C. Treat's Alpha II, by 11 minutes, 40 seconds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The reorganization of the prohibition enforcement division was cited tonight by Louis McHenry Howe as an example of President Roosevelt's broad plan for simplifying governmental functions.

The late weeks of Summer are a time of year in which the financial mind traditionally outlines for itself the Autumn situation. This is natural because in midsummer all the requisitions of the Spring trade are completed, Autumn requisitions have not yet begun, yet most of the underlying influences are coming into sight.

A Quart of Milk. Some day when the experts have succeeded in measuring the atom, the speed of cosmic rays and the age of the earth, they may be able to work out an approximately correct statement of how much the farmer gets for a quart of milk.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to congratulate and thank you for your editorial in today's issue entitled "An Act of National Faith." Such an interpretation of the National Recovery Act is timely, needful and most helpful. It is not enough to state the program of such an act.

ROME, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Italian mass flight to America and return was a "consecrated Fascist revolution in the skies of two continents," Premier Mussolini declared today in addressing the Balbo aviators after a triumphal procession under the historic Arch of Constantine.
PARIS, Aug. 13 -- Continued pessimism here over the possibility of success of the United States economic experiment was typically expressed today by Frederick Jenny, financial editor of Le Temps.

Jose Iturbi, the pianist, made his debut here last night as a conductor. The emphasis is on the word "conductor." For Mr. Iturbi revealed that he is distinctly more than a time-beater, that he has, in fact, marked talent for orchestral direction.

Obligations of the United States Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $3,651,396,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and noninterest-bearing discount bills.

Steel business is holding up much better than usual this Summer, with operations continuing at 54 per cent last week, according to the magazine Steel. The publication says that the industry expects new buying to be considerably larger in the last half of the month than in the first.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The bulk of an army of 30,000 workers will go into action in the wheatproducing areas tomorrow in an effort to trim the nation's average annual harvests.

Arnold P. Simons of Louisville, Ky., halted the drive of Leonard Hartman of New York, 6-3, 6-3, 6-4, and retained his national public parks tennis championship on the Central Park courts yesterday. Miss Helen Germaine, New York's entry in the women's singles and winner of the 1932 title, lost her crown to Miss Ruth Bailey of St. Louis.

The century plant in the Bronx Park Botanical Gardens is again in disgrace. The plant inconvenienced a lot of people by its failure to bloom. Sunday before last, and some of its most ardent apologists thought that the least it could do was to bloom yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A parade around the base paths marked the final appearance of the Athletics this season as the Red Sox scored a 19-to-10 victory, featured by an 11-run first inning. None of the eleven was earned.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Aug. 14 -- The danger of the Yellow River's returning to its old bed, which it abandoned in 1852, has again become acute. Honan authorities have telegraphically warned the Kiangsu provincial government of a tendency of the floodwaters to flow southeastward from Lanfeng, twenty-eight miles eastward of Kaifeng, which is on the Lunghai Railway.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 13 -- Mr. and Mrs. Carll Tucker of Pennwood, Mount Kisco, N.T., who will leave tomorrow after a fortnight's stay here, gave a large luncheon today on board their yacht Migrant, which is anchored off the Sebonac Yacht Club.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Clifford Sutler's quest of his third leg on the Eastern grass court challenge trophy came to naught today in the face of a high-voltage attack that fairly burned up the turf beneath his feet.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 13 (AP) -- Describing the mob killing of the Negroes under indictment in Tuscaloosa County as a "heinous crime," Governor B.M. Miller today sent a telegram to Judge Henry B. Foster at Tuscaloosa ordering an immediate grand jury investigation.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Aug. 13 -- The cotton market was dominated last week by the first report of the season from the Department of Agriculture on the cotton crop. Before the report was issued on Tuesday morning, the market had been influenced by a large volume of liquidation and evening-up of commitments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Permanent positions in the technical field service of the new Immigration and Naturalization Service of the Labor Department will be filled on the basis of examinations starting tomorrow. More than 2,000 employes holding temporary four months' appointments will compete in the tests before special boards.

Armstrong Cork Company -- Six months ended June 30: Gross profit from operations, $3,218,803; net after expenses, $1,458,943; total income, $1,729,973; net operating profit after depreciation, charges and estimated Federal taxes, $568,697; net operating profit of foreign subsidiaries, $64,721, making total operating profit $633,418 for the company.
LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The Economist's index number of wholesale commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on Aug. 9 at 65, against 65.3 a fortnight before and 60.4 on Sept, 18, 1931.

Net sales of the General Motors Corporation as shown in its pamphlet report for the six months ended on June 30 amounted to $311,954,474, compared with $296,798,534 for the same period of 1932. For the second quarter net sales amounted to $191,954,311 against 5147,134,818 for the second quarter last year.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Cardinals profited by six errors by the Reds to win both ends of a double-header today, 3 to 2 and 4 to 3.

Charles C. Burlingham, whose intervention brought about the substitution of Fiorella H. La Guardia for General John F. O'Ryan as the fusion candidate for Mayor, again took up the role of harmonizer yesterday in an attempt to reach an agreement with the New York and Bronx County Republican organizations on nominations for minor places on the fusion ticket.

Declaring that the city administration has ignored the vital problem of economy in next year's municipal expenditures, the Citizens Budget Commission, in a statement issued yesterday, urged action on this subject at the special session of the Legislature.

Dr. Carroll Lane Fenton's recently published "The World of Fossils" is an addition to the Appleton New World of Science Series. In 1921, while still a student, the author became associate editor of The American Midland Naturalist. Later he and Mrs. Fenton published a book on Iowa fossils.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 13 -- Three Negroes, held under indictments charging them with the murder of a white girl 21 years old, were taken from officers and two were shot to death at Woodstock, 25 miles west of here, early this morning.

A German shepherd puppy fell eight feet into a rock-covered hole yesterday and before he was pulled out most of Broadway between 180th and 190th Streets was in an uproar. Equally upset was a large part of the Police Department, the Consolidated Gas Company and Charlie, the 2-month-old dog.

A brief in which the city will ask an immediate temporary reduction in electric light and gas rates is to be filed today with the Public Service Commission by Corporation Counsel Hilly, according to an announcement from his office yesterday.
Chicago, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Allowing only three hits in the last nine innings, Vic Sorrell pitched the Tigers to a 17-inning, 6-to-5 victory over the White Sox today.

CARIBOU ISLAND, Quebec, Aug. 13 (Canadian Press) -- The small, coastwise passenger steamer North Shore was pounding itself to pieces on a reef near here tonight, while a party of Roman Catholic dignitaries, headed by Mgr. Andrea Cassulo, Papal Delegate to Canada and Newfoundland, were safe at Rimouski, after a thrilling rescue from the vessel by boats manned by fishermen and the ship's crew.

Any traveler among the multitudes now on rolling vacation could add to his enjoyment of overnight stops and improve his knowledge of country life in America by investigating the book-case. We do not mean the usual examination of the mail-order catalogues, though they contain ample material for many hours of profitable pleasure.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Senator Brookhart has made another statement anent Soviet recognition that seems to need clarification. He seems to hold that unless recognition is given within three weeks the one-hundred-million-dollar-a-year trade with Russia which we can obtain will go to Great Britain, France, Spain, Italy and Poland.

There are few places in the United States where fishing is as diversified as along the Atlantic Coast in waters adjacent to New York. Fortunate anglers who live within the confines of the metropolitan district have more chances to catch different kinds of fish than sportsmen who live elsewhere.

Although modern "colloquial" translations of the Gospel may at first seem almost blasphemous when read from the pulpit, they are frequently of value in explaining passages of earlier translations that have become obscured by changes in the meanings of words, the Rev. Dr. Louis Childs Sanford, Bishop of the San Joaquin district, California, said yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Incarnation, Madison Avenue at Thirty-fifth Street.
NASSAU, Bahamas, Aug. 13 -- A twin-motored amphibian plane bearing Gerardo Machado into political exile came down on the waters of Nassau Harbor soon after dawn today.

Federal prohibition is obviously on its last legs, but close students who have watched its behavior carefully from the beginning and have almost come to love it in spite of all its little peculiarities will notice with satisfaction that there is no change in formulas or conduct.

PARIS, Aug. 13 -- While it is admitted that the Soviet foreign policy has been much wiser and more cautious than the world had expected from a revolutionary government, Moscow is now faced by problems that would tax the most skillful statesmen.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- In the absence of Hugh S. Johnson, Recovery Administrator, President Roosevelt today moved to speed up action on codes of fair competition in the nation's basic industries.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- The steadiness of the dollar this past week is arousing comment as to its reason. The recent fluctuations have been narrower and business smaller than at any time since the United States abandoned the gold standard. If the United States authorities have desired to keep the rate stable they, have certainly experienced no difficulty in accomplishing their purpose, because business in exchange has recently shrunk to extremely small proportions.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Manager Charlie Grimm of the Cubs batted his team to a 3-to-2 victory over the second-place Pirates today and advanced Chicago to within half a game of Pittsburgh.

Wholesale apparel markets here were still in a state of confusion last week as manufacturers attempted to adjust themselves to conditions arising under the recovery program. In the coat and suit market work will be held up all this week, while producers reorganize their operations to comply with the new code.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- A warning to trade unions not to give up their right to strike under the workings of the NRA or the Labor Arbitration Commission was sounded here today at the State meeting of the Continental Congress of Workers and Farmers, attended by nearly 400 delegates.

The transfer of seventy-six keepers in various city prisons was announced yesterday by William J. Cahill. Commissioner of Correction. The shake-up, which is effective on "VVednesday, was said to be one of the most drastic of its kind in the history of the department, affecting 20 per cent of the department's guards.

Adoption of a code prepared by the Association of Stock Exchange Firms, representing most of the firms doing business on the New York Stock Exchange, will be discussed by a special committee and officials of the administration in Washington on Wednesday.

BAYONNE, N.J., Monday. Aug. 14 -- A delegation of 350 men, women and children from Passaic, who had spent the day at Coney Island was marooned off shore here last night on the excursion boat Crescent. While heading into Newark Bay from Kill von Kull at 7:30 P.M. Captain J.J. Cross missed the channel and the boat went aground in the mud flats about 200 feet from the pier of the Texas Oil Company.
ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- The strike of milk farmers of the State, beset with violence for almost two weeks, was considered here tonight to be virtually at an end.
BUFFALO, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Big Jim Weaver was aided by Buffalo errors today in turning in his twenty-first triumph of the campaign. Newark made it two out of three over the Bisons by winning, 4 to 2.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- A right-about-face regarding legislation which would permit betting on New York tracks looms as a result of an informal conference which took place among important political and racing figures in the last few days, it became known today.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 13 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 70.3, which compares with 70.6 a week ago, 69.6 two weeks ago, 70.4 three weeks ago and 68.8 four weeks ago. The average of a week ago was the highest of.the year to date; that of March 5, at 55, was the lowest.

HAVANA, Aug. 13 (By Wireless) -- Apprehension is growing here lest the new methods and surprises of this revolution in Cuba may result in yet another and more serious surprise because of the failure of the army to exert its authority and prevent mass emotion from getting out of hand.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 13 -- The national A.A.U. pentathlon championship at Warinanco Park today was captured by Eulace Peacock of the Shore A.C., a former Union (N.J.) High School star. The winner piled up 3,221.85 points in the five events.

The whole system of handling its clergy should be revolutionized by the Protestant Episcopal Church at its next triennial general convention, the Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinty Parish, declares in his first annual statement published in the Year Book for 1932, made public yesterday.

SANDTORFER BRUCH, Baden, Germany, Aug. 13 -- Seven hundred young men between the ages of 18 and 25 are at work these days at this hottest spot in Germany, half an hour's auto ride from Mannheim, to convert a water-logged moorland into fertile garden land.

PARIS, Aug. 12 -- Paris market activity is now at a low point. The holidays and the heat wave have caused decreased turnovers in all branches of business.
