At the Stock Exchange the volume of transactions has been much reduced. The few orders given by investors are quickly executed at opening rates and then the market again becomes inactive.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13 -- New evidence that big game hunters lived in North America fully 15,000 years ago was described today in a report from Edgar B. Howard, Philadelphia archaeologist, who is excavating in New Mexico.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 13 -- With John Hay (Jock) Whitney doing most of the scoring and the three Balding Brothers affording him superb support, the Reds defeated Laddie Sanford's Whites, 12 to 6, in the weekly polo match at the Sands Point Club today.

Birds in their little nests agree, but do members of the Brain Trust? Not always, if we may believe the public dispatches and the grapevine reports from Washington. One lady at the head of an important commission suffered a nervous collapse on account of differences with a "professor-member," whom she thereupon incontinently dismissed.
Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, peace advocate and woman's suffrage leader, announced yesterday the formation of the Protest Committee of Non-Jewish Women Against the Persecution of Jews in Germany.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 13 -- After the long run here from Newport yesterday the New York Yacht Club fleet remained idle today. It was a case of resting at harbor moorings in preparation for the seventy-seven-mile run tomorrow out around Cape Cod to Provincetown, Mass., the longest of the cruise.

Pride is the fountainhead of all vices, the Rev. Robert E. Woods declared yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, warning against considering it "merely a fault about which one may be facetious."

It looked like another dull Sunday at Madison Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street yesterday morning. Patrolman Richard Broderick, casting an occasional surreptitious glance at his own reflection in the plate glass windows as he strolled along, frankly yawned at the bore-some perspective of closed shops and deserted pavements that is Madison Avenue early on a Sunday morning.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- Governor Lehman announced today that he had commuted the sentences of seventeen inmates of various State penal institutions. In each instance he outlined the reasons for shortening the sentences of the convicted men.

HAVANA, Aug. 13 -- Dr. Carlos Manuel de Cespedes, suddenly elevated to the Presidency of Cuba in succession to the deposed Gerardo Machado, said today in an interview with The Associated Press correspondent that his people were grateful to the United States for its attitude toward Cuban sovereignty in the present crisis.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Because he was "unable to enjoy life any more," Julius Myers, a leading merchant of Springfield, Ill., leaped to his death today from the sixteenth floor of the Hotel Sherman.
CARMEL,, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- And How, the chestnut gelding from the stabla of Mrs. Gunnar Larsen of New Rochelle, N.Y., won the hunter championship of the first horse show of the Gipsy Trail Club today.

Reduction or the value of the dollar in international exchange has protected the American market from excessive importations of merchandise from low-currency countries, the National Foreign Trade Council announced yesterday in a report which stresses the fact that American foreign trade took a definite turn upward in the first six months of this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The destroyers Taylor and Claxton, which have been ordered to proceed to Cuba, were reported tonight by the navy to be off the southern coast of Florida, which would put them within a short run of Havana.

The problem facing all democratic countries is the reconciliation of political democracy with economic development, according to Dennis W. Brogan, teacher of American Government at the London School of Economics, whose book, "Government of the People," a study of the American political system and how it works, will be published today by Harper Brothers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- Announcement today of the special board to review presumptive war disability claims in Colorado gave a majority of nine of the fourteen boards so far named to World War veterans, according to information made available at the Veterans' Administration.

Another week of varied entertainment in the Summer theatres from Maine to Virginia will begin this evening, with some sixteen new plays listed for world premieres and any number of veterans from Broadway stages turning up in rural surroundings.

ALBANY, Aug. 13 -- With the Republicans adopting a watchful waiting attitude toward the proposed blanket tax measure for New York City, spokesmen for the O'Brien administration were prepared tonight to offer to the special session of the Legislature measures they said would save $15,000,000 in the cost of the city government.

All dressmakers, union and nonunion, are expected to register their opinion in the strike referendum to be held throughout Manhattan and Brooklyn today. The referendum is to determine whether the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the joint board of the Dress and Waistmakers Union shall call a general strike of 60,000 workers in the dress industry in New York City, New Jersey and Connecticut.

Lewis E. Lawes, warden of Sing Sing, "who has been invited to appear today before the United State Senate Subcommittee to Investigate Backeteering, said yesterday he believed all major crimes should be made Federal offenses.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 13 -- More than 200 persons witnessed the junior riding and jumping competition at the East Hampton Riding Club grounds yesterday afternoon. In the riding class for children under 10, the winners were Miss Helen Shepard and Alvin Krech.
The New York Police Department baseball team conquered the New York A.C. nine, 10-9, in a free-hitting contest at Travers Island yesterday. The victors collected sixteen safeties, the losers eleven.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- Farmers who expect to make money raising hogs are still uncertain whether they will have to feed them for shorter periods, using less corn and producing lighter animals, as the committee in Washington that is in charge of the processing plan has been unable yet to fix a ratio of corn to hogs which will give the animals a weight of 150 to 170 pounds.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The Yankees touched a new low at Griffith Stadium today when Washington swept them aside, 4 to 3.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13 -- The text of a speech made here today by General Hugh S. Johnson follows:

BERLIN, Aug. 13 -- An all Jewish theatre for Berlin has been licensed by the Prussian Government on condition that all its acting, administrative and technical personnel are Jews and that it offer no tickets at public sale.

No short-cut or miracle may be expected to bring the millennium, the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer declared yesterday at the Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West at Sixty-fifth Street. Faith in Christ, is necessary to remove the woes of the world, he asserted.

Despite the urgent need for Federal and State financial aid for education, public schools throughout the country must remain under the direct control of local communities "if the American system of education is to be safeguarded," according to a report adopted yesterday by the National Conference on the Financing of Education, in session at Teachers College, Columbia University.

YAKMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 13 -- The Casa Madrid, a fashionable Cape Cod play resort opened in June at a reported cost of $100,000, was raided early this morning by thirty-five State troopers led by Assistant Attorney General George B. Lourie.

The loss of 50,000 to 75,000 members in Christian churches in China through loyalty to an international viewpoint in the face of growing nationalism was pointed out as good religious news yesterday by the Rev. Jesse S. Dancey, preaching at the Broadway Temple Methodist Episcopal Church, at 174th Street.

NEWPORT, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- Felix Piseck, a leader of the Central New York striking dairy farmers, refused tonight to recognize Albert Woodhead's authority to end the strike, but termed tomorrow's cessation the start of a week's truce.
MONTREAL, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Montreal and Jersey City divided a double header today before 5,000 fans. The visitors won the opener, 4 to 3, and Montreal took the second, 4 to 1.
Sales of housing properties in North Bergen and Jersey City featured realty trading in New Jersey over the week-end.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- A fleet of fifty-eight craft, made up of ten classes, took part in the special regatta conducted by the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club on Long Island Sound today. The interclub class, which provided the most number of competitors with thirteen entrants, also furnished the highlight of the program with a close finish.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The city housing question is far from being settled in one way or another. Undoubtedly there is no cohesion of ideas among the different groups of persons concerned in it. Still, land is available everywhere, money is not lacking and plans for housing projects of all kinds are ready.

The report of a committee appointed by Mayor O'Brien to study the factors involved in acquiring the Fort Schuyler Military Reservation from the War Department as a city park was made public yesterday. It recommended that the Mayor make a direct appeal to President Roosevelt.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 13 -- A freak rain, hail and electrical storm, which raged with fury over this place for several hours this afternoon, did great damage. Hundreds of trees lost their branches or were blown down, crashing into roofs or crushing tops of automobiles parked alongside the sidewalks.

The grain traffic at New York, both inbound and outbound, has continued this year the decline that started in 1932 and that reduced to new low marks the volume of base cargoes available to ships operating in the foreign trade.
VIENNA, Aug. 13 -- Recent reports from Switzerland indicate that unofficial negotiations between Germany and Austria have been begun in Swiss territory to achieve a reconciliation.
There still was not a deal of heavy clouting at the Polo Grounds yesterday. But there were two smacks that contributed no little toward the annoyance of about 15,000 spectators.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- All reports of deterioration of the country's crops of grains as issued recently by private statisticians have been confirmed fully by the government's figures, indicating a shortage of around 1,000,000,000 bushels in corn, oats and barley, compared with last year.

A definite upturn in the employment demand in the New York area since the launching of the NRA movement has been noted by various agencies reporting daily to local NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Figures showing the extent of the increased demand were made public yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, New York City chairman of the President's Re-employment Committee.

JOHNSONBURG, N.J., Aug. 13. -- Sharp criticism of the NRA program was expressed here today by Professor Walter Rautenstrauch, head of the Department of Industrial Engineering of Columbia University, in an address at the Economic Conference of Engineers at the Stevens Engineering Camp.

John W. Davis, legal counsel for J.P. Morgan Co. in the banking inquiry before the Senate committee early in the Summer, returned yesterday from a brief rest in England and Scotland. He arrived on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, accompanied by Mrs. Davis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- President Roosevelt expressed deep gratification today as he heard of the progress of the re-employment drive in New York, reported during an hour's conversation with Grover A. Whalen, chairman, for New York City, and W. Averell Harriman, chairman for New York State.
LAKE FOREST, Ill., Aug. 13 -- The West polo team defeated the East on the field of the Onwentsia Club today, 15 goals to 11.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Willis S. Paine has returned to the Plaza from Nahant, Mass.

Many have been complaining that no exact statement of the city's financial situation can be got from the authorities. The bankers protested that they could not understand the figures submitted to them by Controller BERRY, which, as it happened, were not consistent with each other from week to week.

Civil employes of New York City, exclusive of those of the Board of Education, who carry on their own relief activities, contributed monetary relief amounting to $1,332,647.18 to 13,747 needy families, representing 57,793 persons, in the last fiscal year.

America should renounce her selfish nationalism for the sake of humanity, Bishop William F. Anderson declared in his sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street. Dr. Anderson, a retired Methodist Episcopal Bishop, is Professor of the History of Religion at Carleton College, Northfleld, Minn.

Net changes in prices for commodities traded in local markets last week were small on balance. Trading continued to run at restricted levels. In the middle of the week there was a rally which more than wiped out early losses. These gains, however, were evened off in later declines.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13 -- A bullish cash situation and a bearish speculative condition confronts the world's grain trade, particularly in the United States and Canada. Crops this year are unusually short, not only of wheat but of all feed grains.
TODAY'S STADIUM MATCHES. 2 P.M. -- Miss Betty Nuthall, Great Britain, vs. Miss Jane Sharp, United States.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 13 -- All grain prices declined here last week in sympathy with lower prices in the European and North American markets, which local observers describe, with considerable resentment, as a natural reaction from the excessive speculation engendered by President Roosevelt's efforts artificially to increase prices.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- The first of the new navy ship contracts under the recovery program will probably be signed this week, the Public Works Administration announced today.

SCRANTON, Pa., Aug. 13 -- President Roosevelt and the Democrats of Pennsylvania were lauded today by Postmaster General Farley in an address before an audience of 25,000 persons at the annual Irish Day celebration staged at Rocky Glen by the Ancient Order of Hibernians of Lackawanna County.

It will take years to show that mobilization of the unemployed has done for the forests and woodlands of the United States. CHARLES LATHROP PACK, President of the American Tree Association, estimates that the work of these "forest workers" will mean the annual saving of hundreds of millions of dollars.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- President Roosevelt tonight ordered three American warships to proceed to Cuban waters to protect American citizens.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 13 (AP) -- The first fellows of the Econometric Soicety, international body for advancement of economic theory in its relation to statistics and mathematics, were announced tonight by Professor Irving Fisher of Yale, president of the society.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13 -- General Hugh S. Johnson flew into the Middle West today with a plea for the President's re-employment program, and declared that its success depended upon cooperation of the "people in each town" and, in the last analysis, upon the women.

DUBLIN, Aug. 13 -- Dublin's day of dread passed in sinister quiet. No tribute was paid today to the memory of Arthur Griffith, first head of the Irish Free State. The cenotaph at Leinster Lawn, which bears three bronze medallions commemorating Griffith, Michael Collins and Kevin O'Higgins was not adorned by even a single wreath.

It was an even break for the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday. They lost the first game to the Braves, 6 to 2. The afterpiece was another story and 15,000 Flatbush fans drew from that contest the kind of thrills they have not felt in weeks.

Colonel Carlos Mendieta and Colonel Roberto Mendez Penate, heads of the Union Nacionalista in exile here, issued an appeal to the Cuban people last night to end the violence that has followed the fall of the Machado Government.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of this morning you publish some statements about Majorca made by Theodore Pratt, statements so misleading and unjust that I cannot refrain from entering a protest.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Aug. 13 (AP) -- A pretty 18-year-old girl, born amid the roar of a British barrage near the World War battle lines in Belgium, was not to be daunted today when three hold-up men confronted her.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 13 (AP) -- The Indians broke tie scores twice today to take a double-header from the Browns, 5 to 3 and 3 to 2, and gained a game and a half on the third-place Athletics.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 13 -- Storming over the fairways and greens of the Blue Mound Club with magic irons and a putter that routed par by four shots, Gene Sarazen won the national professional golf championship for the third time in his illustrious career today.
COLOGNE, Germany, Aug. 13 (AP) -- Hans Sievert failed by 32.26 points today to equal the world's decathlon record he set at 8,467.62 points in Hamburg on July 23. His total was 8,435.36.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13 -- Mr. and Mrs. John Russell Pope entertained with a large reception and tea at the Waves this afternoon as a housewarming. A program of Hungarian music was presented by a gypsy ensemble from New York. Miss Jane Pope will give a dance at the Waves tomorrow evening.
HAVANA, Aug. 13 -- Dr. Carlos Manuel de Cespedes became Cuba's new President this morning when he took the oath of office at his residence before Supreme Court Justice Juan O. Menocal.

Improved business conditions are reflected in the large volume of office, store and showroom rentals announced in Manhattan over the week-end. Renting agents were especially encouraged by the number of firms taking new space as the result of decisions to expand their facilities.

The Beekman Street Hospital records in its annual report, made public yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, president, that "the unusual times through which we are passing caused a substantial increase in the number of patients admitted and treated by the hospital during the past twelve months."

As a means of promoting recovery in Cuba, the Roosevelt Administration is considering negotiation of a reciprocal trade agreement with that country. American markets are essential to Cuban producers. Before the depression nearly four-fifths of the island's exports were sold in the United States and our purchases of Cuban goods exceeded $200,000,000 annually.

An educational charter, outlining a program "for action by the American people" essential for the financing of school systems throughout the country, was adopted yesterday by the National Conference on the Financing of Education, in session at Teachers College, Columbia University.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 14. -- Several thousand persons are believed to have been drowned by the rampant Yellow River, the flooding waters of which continued spreading today over wide areas along its 2,600-mile course.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and the Socony-Vacuum Corporation, the largest American exporting oil companies, virtually have completed arrangements for the reciprocal handling of oil products abroad. No agreement had yet been entered into, it was stated yesterday, but little, if any, difficulty was expected in ironing out the few remaining details that were delaying signatures.
TOPEKA, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Governor Landon today directed Lester Goodell, Shawnee County attorney, to begin prosecution against T.B. Boyd, State Treasurer, in the State bond forgery scandal case.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 14. -- Miss Amy Aspegren, who is passing the remainder of the season at the Irving with her mother, Mrs. John. Aspegren, gave a luncheon' there today for Miss Mary M. Livingston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Moncrieffe Livingston of Kilsyth, Huntington, L.I., and for Miss Dorothy H. McGee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh H. McGee of Toplyn, Roslyn, L.I., who have joined her for a visit.

Another solved kidnapping was added to the growing list of recent cases in which arrests have been made when an escaped Kansas convict and five others were held yesterday for the kidnapping of Charles Urschel.Some of the outstanding abduction cases and the results Federal agents and police have obtained in them follow:

Fox Film Corporation and coordinator for the producers and distributers, said last night that the producers had completed their part of the code and had it in first-draft form. The distributers were unable to draw up their first draft, he said, until the exhibitors' code was finished.

Trading in the listed bond market yesterday was a routine affair. Total transactions were slightly below the aggregate of last Friday and fluctuations in prices of the more active issues were generally confined to narrow ranges. The trend of prices for domestic corporation bonds was irregularly lower and in the foreign group irregularly higher.

The only feature in the money market was an easing of five and six months funds, where the rate was reduced to 1 1/4 and 1 1/2 per cent. Call loans continued at 1 per cent with 1/4 per cent quoted on the outside. Governments loaned at 1 per cent.

Depression and Dictators. MACHADO, it is pointed out in an Associated Press dispatch from Washington, is the latest in a long succession of Latin-American "strong men" whom the economic depression has driven from power.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 -- The polo forces of the East and West rested today, the East checking over its defeated forces and the West its injuries.

Discussing the progress of the NRA movement throughout New York State, W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Campaign Committee for the State of New York, announced that at the close of business yesterday the number of registrations for the State, outside New York City, totaled 63,186, as against 38,426 for the City of New York.

Eugene S. Daniell Jr., lawyer and Harvard graduate, pleaded not guilty in General Sessions yesterday to two indictments charging third degree felonious assault and malicious mischief in the placing of two tear-gas bombs in the New York Stock Exchange on Aug. 4.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Frederic G. Achelis of Round Hill Road, Greenwich, will give a dinner dance on Sept. 21 to introduce to society her daughter, Miss Audrey Achelis.

ROME, Aug. 14. -- Communication with ultra short waves only a foot and a half long through or around physical obstacles was reported here today before the science department of the Royal Academy by Guglielmo Marconi, noted Italian wireless inventor.

Although government purchases yesterday were estimated at 25.000 bales, prices on the Cotton Exchange continued down with a loss of about $1 a bale. Liquidation and hedges against old and new cotton kept the market under pressure and quotations ended at the bottom, with losses 19 to 23 points and the lowest closing since May 26.

MARTIN LOMASNEY, who died in Boston on Saturday, probably wasn't much known outside Massachusetts, but there is no politician like him left there. For it must be nearer fifty than forty years he was a power in Democratic politics. Though he served with distinction in the Legislature and the Constitutional Convention, he never cared much for office.

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Aug. 15. -- More than 50,000 Chinese are homeless and destitute as a result of the floods of the Yellow River in Honan and Hopei Provinces, and more than twice that number, it is believed, are destitute in Shantung Province, making the total number of homeless more than 150,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Cuba faces a period of persecution and not peace, according to Dr. Orestes Ferrara, exiled Secretary of State and confidant of General Gerardo Machado, deposed President of the island republic.

Colonel Carlos Mendieta and Colonel Roberto Mendez Penate, heads of the Union Nacionalista, arranged yesterday to sail for Cuba aboard the steamship Morro Castle on Saturday. They will be accompanied by several other Cuban exiles who spent the last years of the Machado regime in New York.

PARIS, Aug. 14. -- Difficulty has arisen in the application of France's effort at controlled economy by fixing the price of wheat. Just before its recess, Parliament decided this year's harvest would be sold at a minimum of 115 francs a quintal (about $1.72 a bushel at the current exchange), but with the harvest reaped, farmers are finding no buyers at that price and their situation is giving rise to many protests.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 14. -- With the gross municipal deb in New Jersey in excess of $1,200,000,000, the Legislature's joint committee on taxation warned today that grave consequences were inevitable if the taxing system were not revised immediately and real estate relieved of the burden.

DUBLIN, Aug. 14 (Canadian Press). -- Events were moving swiftly today toward an early dissolution of the Irish Free State Dail. Some observers predicted a general election during September. Others thought the election would be during the Winter.

The North German Lloyd liner Bremen, sailing tonight for Cherbourg, Southampton and Bremen, will have among her prominent passengers Dr. Robert Maynard Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago; Norman Armour, United States Minister to Haiti; Arturo Peralta Ramos, and Mrs. Ramos, the former Millicent Rogers.

The seven-story Hudsonia apartment building at 315-21 W. 79th St. was sold by the Seamen's Bank for Savings to the Marshall Trading Corp., James Marshall, president, for about $245,000, the bank taking back a purchase-money mortgage for $240,000, due in five years, at 3 per cent for the first year, 3 1/2 per cent for the following two years and 4 per cent for the last two years.

PASADENA, Cal., Aug. 14 (AP). -- Helen Bendowski, 28 years old, a beauty shop operator, was found shot dead yesterday on the roof of the flowenr shop and near the pent-house of Harold Wolcott, 33, her alleged sweetheart.
CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Jockey Jack Westrope, the star apprentice rider from Montana, dominated the racing at Hawthorne today when he booted home five winners.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 14. -- Slashing out a home run, triple, double and single to drive in nine runs for a new American League record, Jimmy Foxx today led the Philadelphia Athletics to a 11-to-5 victory over the Cleveland Indians. It was the Mackmen's first game of their last Western invasion.

The Cuban revolution came to New York yesterday when a crowd of frantic young exiles raided the Cuban Consulate, threatened and assaulted the Acting Consul General and hauled off to Harlem a bust and a portrait of former President Gerardo Machado.

A three-page printed set of principles and questions to be applied to public works projects was formulated here yesterday in the Century Club at the first meeting of the National Planning Board of the Federal Public Works Administration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Definite accomplishment by the London Economic Conference through the adoption of a resolution tending to stabilize the price of silver was described to President Roosevelt today by Senator Pittman, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee and delegate to the conference.

Earnings of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company for the six months ended on June 30 after charges, depreciation and preferred dividends amounted to $5,453,915, or 87 cents a share on 6,274,253 common shares, against $6,823,991 or $1.09 a share, in the first half of 1932.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- If Congress were in session, Washington would not be the one-ring circus it has recently become with General Hugh S. Johnson as ringmaster. The perplexities and major problems that daily press for solution in the National Recovery Administration would be getting an oratorical airing on Capitol Hill.

PARIS, Aug. 14. -- Adolph Hitler's accession to power gave a fresh impetus to the flagging cause of the White Russian emigres not only in Germany but in Eastern Europe generally. The younger emigres hastened to form their own Brown Shirt detachment in the Nazi army, with their old imperial white, blue and red flag and the slogan, "Down with the Jews, Marxists and Third International."

Drought conditions in New York State this Summer have retarded the planting operations of the Division of Game and Fisheries of the State Conservation Department to an alarming extent, Commissioner Lithgow Osborne announced yesterday.
TOKYO, Aug. 14. -- Two world records were broken and several Olympic marks bettered as the three-day Japanese swimming championships came to a close today with the racing of the finals.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Aug. 14. -- Undaunted by the weather, thirty-seven pairs turned out today for the sixth special pro-amateur tournament held by the Long Island Golf Association on the Wheatley Hills Golf Club course.

Figures made public yesterday by Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Commissioner of Health, indicate that the success of the Health Department's campaign against diphtheria will save the taxpayers about $113,000 this year.
MONTREAL, Aug. 14 (AP). -- With the aid of the first triple play made by the Royals since joining the International League in 1928, Montreal defeated Jersey City today, 7 to 3.

In all that really matters Mr. Aborn is an able producer. You may lust after more brilliants than Mr. Aborn and his company have at their disposal in "The Yeomen of the Guard," which was staged at the Majestic last evening; and you may dream of impossibly accomplished voices that could match Sullivan note for note and catch the full luster of the music.

Accused of obtaining $7,500 from fifteen persons on promises of employment with the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, James J. McCauley, 29 years old, of 4,343 Richardson Avenue, the Bronx, was arrested yesterday and charged with grand larceny.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 14. -- The Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's Pastime, skippered by Hugh M. Campbell, with Vincent West and Donald Browning as crew, today captured the first of a series of five Atlantic Class yacht races to decide the junior championship of Long Island Sound.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 14. -- Mrs. John Laurence Hutton Jr. has organized her group of manikins for a fashion show, which will be held on Aug. 31 at the Maidstone Club in connection with a benefit bridge for the East Hampton Settlement House.

DALLAS, Aug. 14. -- Harvey J. Bailey, alleged leader in three of the most sensational crimes in many months, and a dozen other persons were under arrest tonight here, in St. Paul and in Denver as the Department of Justice realized its first major triumph in the recently undertaken war against kidnapping and racketeering.
GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Five first-class races make up the card announced tonight for the opening day of the annual Grand Circuit meeting at Good Time Park tomorrow.

The Brooklyn laundry industry is being pushed back again into the washboard era in the opinion of Thomas F. Peterson, former Republican candidate for Congress, who testified yesterday that "all this talk about gunmen" in the laundry industry is beginning to frighten Brooklyn housewives.

Schooldays came to the west side court yesterday morning, a little ahead of season. The pedagogue was Magistrate Benjamin Greenspan, and the guilty pupils were two fruit peddlers, who had been arrested on complaint of neighborhood merchants.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14. -- Miss Jane Pope entertained with a dance this evening at The Waves, the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Russell Pope. This party was the beginning of the busy whirl of entertaining that is to mark this week and a large assemblage of the younger colony members were present.

In a decision handed down yesterday Judge Marcus B. Campbell in the United States District Court in Brooklyn dismissed a suit brought by the American Tri-Ergon Corporation against the Paramount Publix Corporation alleging infringement of patent rights of a process for the production of combined sound and picture films.

ALBANY, Aug. 14. -- The extraordinary session of the Legislature entered its fourth week tonight with the lawmakers generally in complete ignorance regarding New York City's tax program, to enact which the extra session was called.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Aug. 14. -- The America's Cup craft, Weetamoe, led the New York Yacht Club fleet here tonight, finishing the long run of seventy-seven miles out around Cape Cod from Vineyard Haven nearly seven miles ahead of the Vanitie.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 14 (AP). -- Harvey Bailey was first arrested in what officers say has been a long and criminal life as he was keeping a date with old man par.

PEIPING, Aug. 14. -- Although Feng Yu-hsiang, who arrived in Peiping at noon today, denied that the Japanese had recaptured Dolon Nor, in Chahar Province, 180 miles north of this city, it was understood that Premier Wang Ching-wei, after conferring with General Chiang Kai-shek, has confirmed the loss of the Chinese city.

A memorandum opposing the ordering of temporary emergency rates for electric service was filed yesterday with the Public Service Commission on behalf of electric companies affiliated with the Consolidated Gas Company of New York.
A meeting to draw up plans for a real estate code under the National Recovery Act will be held in Chicago next Saturday by the directors of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

The Cord Corporation has bought control of the Checker Cab Manufacturing Corporation, it was announced yesterday by L.B. Manning, executive vice president of the Cord Corporation. The Checker company, which had total assets of $4,546,000 at the end of last year, is one of the largest taxicab manufacturing concerns in the country.

New York surrendered completely to Chicago yesterday in the indecision as to which way the markets should move. Because the grain markets stood still, the share market merely dawdled. The moderate declines here reflected nothing more than occasional adjustments growing out of the suspension of animation in Chicago.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14. -- The Association of Grain Commission Merchants, composed of Board of Trade interests, adopted a resolution at a meeting late today opposing the "pegging" of grain prices. Those present were the senior heads of houses which operate as partnerships and the executive heads of corporations.

Several large deals are pending in the real estate market, but the only one closed yesterday involved the resale of 19 East Seventy-ninth Street by Frederick Brown, realty operator, to an investing client of the Leonard S. Gans Company, Inc.
DETROIT, Aug. 14 (AP). -- One big inning, the seventh, in which the Tigers batted around and got six hits and four runs, gave Detroit a 6-to-5 triumph over the Red Sox today.

BANEF, Alta., Aug. 14 (Canadian Press). -- Canada is deeply concerned in major external issues which seriously affect the United States, and, conversely, any attack made upon the Dominion which might seem likely to result in giving any non-British people a foothold here would almost certainly bring the United States into action on Canada's side.
ALBANY, Aug. 14. -- The Senate passed tonight a series of measures recommended by Governor Lehman to put New York State in line with the national recovery program.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Aug. 14. -- The day started out drearily for old Joe Buzzard, horse and chicken thief and one of the Eastern Penitentiary's most appreciative residents. Old Joe, who is 75, was to be freed, leaving behind him 84-year-old Abe Buzzard, his favorite brother and model in horse stealing.

John Irving Romer, president of Printers' Ink Publishing Company and the Romer Publishing Company, who died last Wednesday, left most of his estate, estimated at more than $1,000,000, to his widow, Mrs. Katharine Northam Romer, of 1,115 Fifth Avenue, it was disclosed when his will was filed for probate.

Samuel Untermyer, special financial adviser to the O'Brien administration, will present to Governor Lehman in Albany today a new program to obtain immediate funds for relief and early restoration of the city's credit.

KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 14 (AP). -- The family of Gerardo Machado, deposed President of Cuba, narrowly escaped a mob in a flight to the gunboat which bore them here today, Dr. Baldomero Grau, Senor Machado's son-in-law, related.

Economists used to ask: "Who will pay the bills of Socialism?" A more pressing question today relates to the class that will have to pay most of the bills presented, or to be presented, by NRA. The Government has from the first been quite frank about it. That the price of bread would be increased through the subsidies to be given the growers of wheat was admitted.

A complete change in the caste system governing the untouchables in India will be brought about within the next five years, according to K. Natarajan of Bombay, a leader in social reform, who is making his first visit to this country.

Financial results of their operations were announced yesterday by about a dozen companies, most of which are industrial. Some of the reports were for fiscal years, but most were for the six months ended with June.
While all the markets were timid yesterday, largely as the result of uncertainty surrounding the Chicago Board of Trade dilemma, there was no extensive liquidation on any of the exchanges.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP). -- A definite improvement in business conditions in September was forecast today by the Lumber Survey Committee of the Commerce Department's Timber Conservation Corps.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Modifications of the Presidential Re-employment Agreement affecting thousands of workers in eight industries and trades were approved today. They were cigar manufacturing sausage casing, office equipment manufacturing, sheet rubber and related sundries, cotton compress and warehouse, telephone manufacturing, yeast and retail confectioners.
LONDON, Aug. 14 (Canadian Press). -- The West Indies cricket team today faced an innings defeat in the third and last test match of the season against England at the Kennington Oval.

Hundreds of home owners, many of them faced with the loss of their property through foreclosures, flocked yesterday to the office of the Home Owners Loan Corporation, which opened for its first day on the fourth floor of the Empire State Building.
HAVANA, Aug. 14. -- A new Cuban government, headed by President Carlos Manuel de Cespedes, began, to function this morning as the Cabinet was sworn in at 11 o'clock at the Presidential Palace.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- A survey showing that the average price of a pound loaf of white bread in eighteen important cities was only 1.4 cents higher on Aug. 2 than on Feb. 15 was made public today by Dr. Fred C. Howe, consumers counsel of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.
BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- John O'Connor, professional of the Sagamore Golf Club, won the Northeastern New York golf championship today by carding a 73, 72 for a 145 total.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14. -- The Yankees, en route to St. Louis, stopped here long enough today to drop an exhibition game to the Pirates before a crowd of 10,000. The score was 10 to 2, and the chief victim was Walter Brown.

Export shipments of cars and trucks from plants of the General Motors Corporation in the United States and Canada last month were 196 per cent greater than in July, 1932, and for the first seven months of the year were 59 per cent larger than in the same part of last year.
The Democratic county leaders failed again yesterday to complete the Tammany city ticket at a conference at the Plaza Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- With conditions in Havana quieter today, the Navy Department announced tonight that the destroyer Claxton had been ordered to leave Havana and go to the naval base at Guantanamo. Thus, only the destroyer Taylor was left in Havana Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Charging that consumers' interests were not being adequately protected under the national recovery program, Professor William F. Ogburn of the University of Chicago resigned today from the Consumers Advisory Board.

A valuable viola, owned by Alma Gluck wife of Efrem Zimbalist, was stolen yesterday morning from the automobile of Louis Kiezman, violinst, while the machine was parked in West 121st Street near the Juilliard School of Music in Claremont Avenue.

New life insurance in July came within 3.7 per cent of the total for the same month last year -- the closest approach to a corresponding period in the preceding year in many months. This is shown in the monthly report of the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United States Department of Commerce.

Gas utilities are a "normal, even business" which is not likely to share in any immediate prosperity, it was testified yesterday at the hearing before the Public Service Commission into rates charged in the city.

Passengers who returned yesterday on the Panama Pacific liner Pennsylvania told of visiting Havana under the strangest conditions tourists ever encountered. Most of the liner's passengers had only a few hours in the Cuban port, when the ship docked there on Friday, but there were a few who had been in Havana during the worst days preceding the downfall of President Machado.
Charles Dalton, Winifred Harris, Jane Corcoran, Bernard Jukes and Mary Heberden have been added to the cast of "A Party," which will open Wednesday night of next week at the Playhouse.

Reorders Reflect Retail Gains. Reorders for coats, furs and dresses continued to reach the markets here yesterday in good volume, reflecting the improvement in retail sales. The labor stoppage in the cloak trade did not have any material effect on orders, inasmuch as the cessation of work had been discounted and also because of the expectation that the stoppage will be of short duration.

The local NRA movement faced last night its first major problem, a threatened strike of 60,000 dressmakers, after having recieved earlier in the day the support of 800 persons representing practically every field of business and civic activity here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The Federal Trade Commission was asked today to issue its first stop order under the Securities Registration Act against the sale of stock by a Texas concern represented as promising "big quick profit winnings" to "dear friends and backers."

while overcast skies and occasional flurries of rain precluded the start of the women's national tennis tournament yesterday, Miss Helen Jacobs, the champion, sat in her suite overlooking the courts of the West Side Tennis Club -- nervous as a school girl about to give a recitation.

HAVANA, Aug. 14. -- When Americans, representing all the United States immense and varied interests in Cuba, gathered at the American Club for the first time under the de Cespedes regime it was in an utter change of mood.

BERLIN, Aug. 14. -- While representatives of foreign shipping lines booking business in Germany are awaiting the outcome of representations by their respective governments respecting the restrictions imposed on their activities by the German Foreign Exchange Bureau, it is learned the restrictions are also meeting opposition from German shipping circles, despite the discrimination in their favor.

The wages and working hours of thousands of employes of subway, surface-car and bus lines in this city will be affected by a code soon to be presented to the National Recovery Administration by the American Transit Association. Details of the proposed code, which will apply to traction workers throughout the country, are being withheld pending action by Federal officials.
BOSTON, Aug. 14. -- Three men escaped today during a riot of convicts at the Suffolk County House of Correction on Deer Island, in Boston Harbor, but were quickly recaptured.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 14 (AP). -- The Buffalo Bisons outrallied the Newark Bears tonight to gain an 3-5 decision and square the series of four games. Timely hitting by Joe Brown and Fresco Thompson featured. Ollie Tucker hit his twenty-fourth homer of the year with the bases empty.

ST. LOUIS. Aug. 14 (AP). -- The spread of a strange type of "sleeping sickness" which has taken six lives since it began July 23, is challenging the resources of city, State and Federal health officials.
TODAY'S STADIUM MATCHES. 2 P.M. -- Miss Betty Nuthall, Great Britain, vs. Miss Jane Sharp, United States.

This little peninsula, thrust out from the Bronx into the Sound, has been the subject of controversy since its first occupation nearly three hundred years ago. In 1669 a committee was appointed "to view lands and to examine into, "hear, and to determine several matters and cases in difference" between the town of Westchester and one THOMAS HUNT about" his commonage "and watering place upon Throgmorton's Neck."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Religious intolerance is condemned by Donald R. Richberg, General Counsel to the National Recovery Administration, in a communication addressed to Bernard S. Deutsch, president of the American Jewish Congress.

VIENNA, Aug. 14. -- Confiscated Nazi documents which prove Germany is subsidizing the Austrian Nazi party were printed today in the Reichspost, a Vienna newspaper which is regarded as speaking for the Austrian Government.
ALBANY, Aug. 14. -- Milk farmers called off the State strike today after 500 of them had marched to the Capitol in the hope that Governor Lehman would address them.

The results of a series of studies of the influence of motion pictures and coffee on children's sleep are disclosed in a book, "Children's Sleep," published by the Macmillan Company. The authors are Samuel Renshaw, Professor of Experimental Psychology at Ohio State University; Vernon L. Miller, instructor in psychology, Bowdoin College, and Dorothy P. Marquis, N. R.C. Fellow, Yale University.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- Attorney General Cummings congratulated justice agents today on having "killed two birds with one stone" in the capture of Bailey.

BERLIN, Aug. 14. -- The Boerse continued dull and listless today. The session opened with prices weaker all along the line. There was little or no speculative or investment interest, and steel and mining stocks eased during the session.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

In an effort to stimulate public interest in a season none too successful financially, the management of the concerts by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium will experiment with the production of opera, it became known yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 14. -- The London Times will devote its leading editorial tomorrow to President Roosevelt's recovery program and its already impressive effect on Canada.

CAMP MOORE, N.J., Aug. 14. -- Ordinary building bricks and putty guns were used as military weapons here today by members of the Forty-fourth Military Police Company of Passaic, under the command of Captain Grover P. Heinzmann. The War Department had failed to provide ammunition for pistol practice.

PARIS, Aug. 14. -- After due editorial tribute has been paid to the great Italian air exploit just terminated, the French press today speculates with some misgivings on the military significance of General Balbo's feat.

An amendment to the master code of the legitimate theatre permitting stock and repertory managers to use the "throw-away" ticket system in communities supporting less than three legitimate attractions is contained in the revised copy of the code which was received here yesterday from Washington.

DUBLIN, Aug. 14. -- The anticlimax in Dublin yesterday, when the quiet was broken mainly by exchanges of jokes between passersby and police squads stationed at government buildings, indicates how little real tension there is in the Irish situation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The speed with which the Blue Eagle, symbol of the National Recovery Administration, has made its flight into every hamlet in the land was described to President Roosevelt today by General Hugh Johnson, Recovery Administrator.
JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Aug. 14. -- The funeral will be held on Wednesday afternoon for John H. Waters.
LONDON, Aug. 14. -- It is believed here that members of the North Atlantic Shipping Conference are near another serious clash.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We hear one week that all inflationary ideas have been dropped or put over for consideration in the rather distant future, and the next week we learn that a group of monetary theorists and inflationary economists are visiting the President and that some actual inflationary move such as devaluing the dollar is shortly to be announced.

Support of President Roosevelt's business recovery program through the NRA movement was voted unanimously by 800 men and women representing practically all fields of business and civic activity here yesterday.

Reduction of taxicab rates to 15 cents a mile, notwithstanding the recent refusal of the Police Department to license 15-cent meters, will be undertaken this week by a group of independent operators, it was announced yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 14. -- Judge Frank C. Phillips today gave John Mayher an opportunity to sell his new automobile in exchange for his bride's freedom, but Mayher spurned the offer and his bride of six months was sent to the workhouse for thirty days.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 14. -- The old saying that "anything can happen in golf" seemed especially appropriate today when Jack Hagen, the first player to step on the tee in the special hole-in-one tournament sponsored by The World-Telegram, holed an ace on the fly.
Following is the text of Samuel Untermyer's letter to Mayor O'Brien outlining a new financial policy for the city administration:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial correspondence from Rochester relative to the two milk strikes which have occurred this year very properly devotes considerable space to the personality of Albert Woodhead. Your correspondent describes him as a "Rochester automobile dealer and sideline farmer."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Aug. 9 shows a decrease for the week of $33,000,000 in loans and investments and increases of $20,000,000 in net demand deposits and $44,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- The mud-running Blind Bowboy, owned by G.H. Bostwick, was a decisive winner in the featured Catskill Claiming Stakes today.

A photostatic copy of the manuscript of one of the first books ever written on the American Indian has been obtained by the Bureau of American Ethnology of the Smithsonian Institution, it was announced yesterday. This work, consisting of 80 printed pages and 500 pages in manuscript, was discovered in the Vatican Library by Dr. Charles H. Clark while he was seeking manuscript material bearing on early American history for the Smithsonian.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 14 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- Rabbi Stephen S. Wise, honorary president of the American Jewish Congress and one of the moving spirits in the convocation of the Jewish World Congress, in a speech here tonight strongly supported the use of the boycott weapon by Jews against the Nazi regime in Germany.
A wide break in sugar was the feature of trading on local commodities exchanges yesterday. All markets closed with substantial losses, with trading quiet in most cases. Cash prices drifted lower.

Although the Merchants Association of New York City and the New York State Chamber of Commerce have been designated by the NRA to grant stays to worthy concerns asking relief under paragraph 17 of the President's Agreement, other representative trade organizations generally have jurisdiction to perform the same function.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Aug. 14 (AP). -- National Guardsmen were hastily mobilized here tonight as Elmore Clark, 28 years old, one of three Negroes seized by a mob early yesterday, was found alive and suffering only minor wounds.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 14. -- "Love Flies in the Window," a three-act drawing room comedy drama in six scenes, by Ann Morrison Chapin, was produced tonight for the first time on any stage by F. Cowles Strickland at the Berkshire Playhouse in Stockbridge.
A record field of 119 players will compete for the United States women's golf championship at the Exmoor Club, Chicago, Aug. 28-Sept. 2, A.M. Reid, secretary of the U. S.G.A., said yesterday.
Several properties in foreclosure actions were included in the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.
A wide variety of weapons for use in a nation-wide war on organized crime was proposed yesterday to United States Senator Royal S. Copeland's subcommittee investigating racketeering.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP). -- President of the twelve Federal Land Banks began conferences here today with Henry Morgenthau Jr., governor of the Farm Credit Administration, to devise plans for speeding up farm mortgage refinancing.

SALEM, Mass., Aug. 15 (AP). -- Mrs. Jessie B. Costello, 31-year-old widow, was acquitted today after one hour and forty-three minutes of deliberation by a jury which heard her charged with slaying her husband, Fire Captain William J. Costello of Peabody, with poison.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The government, by invoking the full power of the Farm Act, is prepared to subsidize wheat exports to the Orient unless an international crop cut agreement is reached, Secretary Wallace said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Five additional special boards to review World War veterans' presumptive disability cases regarding compensation payments, making a total of twenty of the eighty or more boards to be appointed, were named today by General Frank T. Hines, with the approval of President Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Allocations to Federal Reserve districts of the Treasury issue of 3 1/4 per cent bonds of 1941 today were as follows:

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 15 (Canadian Press) -- The Cabinet Council is expected to give early consideration to the request of gold mining companies in the United States, including Alaska, to ship their ore and concentrates into Canada for smelting and refining.

J.E. McDonald, Commissioner of Agriculture of Texas, sent a telegram "yesterday to President Roosevelt urging him to issue immediately a proclamation calling for the destruction of 20 per cent more of the present cotton crop. A copy of the message was received from Mr. McDonald by Robert M. Harriss of the cotton firm of Harriss Vose.

BERLIN, Aug. 15. -- The weakness which has characterized the stock market for the last fortnight again was in evidence today. Yesterday's weak close in New York and the absence of incentives from European markets were depressing factors at today's session here.

A direct appeal to President Paul von Hindenburg to save the 600,000 Jews of Germany from "certain extermination" was made yesterday by the American Jewish Congress here in the form of a 5,000-word open letter.

John A. Lynch, Borough President of Richmond for the last eleven years, was refused redesignation last night and William S. Hart, former Sheriff of Richmond County, was chosen Democratic candidate for the presidency of the borough.

The title of the comedy, "Poor Little Thing," in which Queenie Smith will appear late this month under the Shubert banner, has been changed to "The Blue Widow." Included in the cast will be Helen Flint, Roberta Beatty, Albert Van Dekker, Don Beddoe, Ralph Locke, Sam Wren, Claire Stratton, Eleanor King and Harold Conklin.

LONDON, Aug. 15. -- The rebellion of part of the Assyrian minority in Iraq, according to The London Times, has had a tragic sequel, about 200 persons being killed who had no connection with the revolt.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 15 -- The gallows loomed ahead tonight for Harvey Bailey, one of the chief "public enemies" of the nation, as Federal and State officials moved swiftly on many fronts to bring to justice the perpetrators of the Union Station massacre in Kansas City and the kidnapping of Charles F. Urschel, Oklahoma City oil man.

The Electric Power and Light Corporation reports a consolidated net income of $2,997,801 for the twelve months ended on March 31, after taxes, charges, depreciation, underlying dividends and minority interests, equivalent to $5.82 a share earned on 515,122 shares of $7 cumulative defererd stock, comprising with $9,265,737, equal after preferred and second preferred dividend to $1 a share on 3,339,945 common shares, in the preceding year, on the present capital basis.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- Five thousand followers of light harness racing turned out at Good Time Park today for the opening of the Grand Circuit meeting. More than three times that number are expected tomorrow when the famous Hambletonian Stake, the richest of all trotting events, is to be decided.
Proposals advanced by employers as a means of ending the strike of 4,000 upholstery workers were rejected last night by the New York local of the International Upholsterers' Union.

TOPEKA, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Tom Boyd, State Treasurer, faced an embezzlement charge tonight in the $1,000,000 Kansas bond forgery scandal, while Governor Alf M. Landon promised impeachment proceedings against him and possibly other State officials.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 15 -- A feud between the Rev. Felix G. Robinson, pastor of St. John's Lutheran Church-by-the-Sea here, and Charles W. Ackerman, a member of the board of trustees, reached a climax tonight with the report that Mr. Ackerman had ordered the pastor to vacate the church premises tomorrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: BEVERLY HILLS, Cal., Aug. 15 -- Well, I was just sitting around here late this afternoon and happened to have a day off tomorrow (Wednesday), and the West is playing the East polo in Chicago tomorrow.

American foreign trade has sunk to so low a level for so many months that even a moderate gain in volume or in value assumes large proportions when put on a percentage basis. Thus one of the leading companies manufacturing motor cars has reported an increase of 196 per cent in its export sales last month, compared with the corresponding month of 1932.

At a meeting at the Hippodrome last night attended by 4,500 left-wing dressmakers, it was voted unanimously to call a general strike in the dressmaking shops at 10 o'clock this morning. This strike, although coincident with the strike fostered by the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, has no connection with it, its sponsors said.

Jack Lambert, 21 years old, who helped a puppy to escape a rocky grave at Broadway, near 190th. Street, last Sunday, and Frank Fitzpatrick Jr., the 6-year-old , owner of the dog, received the recognition of the Humane Society yesterday.

The six-point " educational charter " drafted by the National Conference on the Financing of Education is a statement of democracy's basic code. It assumes that, unless universal education of such quality, character and extent as this document defines is supported by the public, America cannot persist as a democratic nation.

Trading in bonds on the New York Stock Exchange was slow yesterday, most prices showing minor irregularities. The turnover, which was slightly less than $8,000,000, was the smallest since March 20, when speculative interest was low after the nation-wide bank holiday.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 15 Many members of the Summer colony attended the fashion show and tea in behalf of the Southampton Fresh Air Home for Crippled Children which was held this afternoon at Lenoir, the estate of Mrs. Rufus L. Fatterson.

A steadier tone prevailed yesterday in the various commodities markets here, although prices moved irregularly. Sugar, rubber and copper futures closed higher, silver and cocoa were lower, and changes in other staples were mixed.

LONDON, Aug. 15. -- Simultaneously with the announcement of Senator Guglielmo Marconi's newest success in radio transmission with sixty-centimeter waves, there opened in London today a giant radio exhibition of which remarkable results are being achieved with short waves and low power.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 16 -- The Emperor of Japan sailed today from the principal base of his navy, Yokosuka, to assume personal command over operations of the most formidable array of warcraft ever assembled in Far Eastern waters.

NRA and Fahr. In the year 2033 the historian will write: "To realize the desperate state to which Americans were reduced in the Summer of 1933, we need only look at photographs of the time, showing government officials, military officers, bankers and professors without a coat to their back."
ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- Governor Lehman, in a special message to the Legislature, called today for warfare on racketeering in New York, State.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It would all be so easy if only Will Rogers were right! You quota him "Stay home and build a big army and navy. They can't come here to lick us and we are not going there to lick them, so how you going to have any war?"

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Another clash between Senator Robinson, Democratic leader of the Senate, and his political foe, Huey Long of Louisiana, has resulted in a victory for the Arkansas Senator.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Temporary wage and hour schedules to permit newspapers to obtain NRA's Blue Eagle at once under the President's re-employment agreement were approved tonight by Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, on submission by the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Cotton, consumed during July was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 600,143 bales of lint and 90,497 bales of linters, compared with. 696,472 and 81,468 during June this year, and 278,568 and 37,896 during July last year.
READING, Pa., Aug. 15. -- Exciting finishes marked the inauguration of the Central Circuit light harness classes over the Kutztown Fair track today.

Booth Tarkington's new novel, "Presenting Lily Mars," will be published today by Doubleday, Doran Co. In this book Mr. Tarkington turns to the theatre for his material. The heroine, Lily Mars, a small-town girl with genius for the theatre, comes to Broadway.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The league-leading Senators opened their final invasion of the West with a 5-to-1 victory over the White Sox today as Alvin Crowder, their ace right-hander, kept nine Chicago hits well spaced. It was Crowder's nineteenth victory of the season as against eight defeats.

A movement to revive the art of spinning here was begun yesterday with a demonstration conducted by the Homecrafts League, an organization sponsored by the Adult Education Department of New York State.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Slipping through a cordon of more than 300 policemen and Federal agents armed with machine guns, directed from an army airplane, two gangsters got away today with a dummy package they thought contained $50,000 in cash which had been used as bait to lure them into the ambush.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Presidential intervention in the tangled coal code situation will result in the return to this city in forty-eight hours of the nation's leading bituminous coal operators, it was reported tonight.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 15 (AP). -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh alighted in Vatnagardar Sound, two and a half miles from this town, at 7:42 P.M. local time, today [4:42 P.M. New York Daylight Time], after a flight of about 500 miles from Angmagsalik, Greenland.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- With a large increase in the public debt certain under the recovery program, officials today were discussing the feasibility of a change in the government's policy on the debt.

The Marine Midland Trust Company of New York, as successor trustee under the issue of 5 per cent sinking fund gold debentures of the Kreuger Toll Company, has notified holders of those securities that on Sept. 1 it will pay $25 on account of each $1,000 debenture and $12.50 on account of each $500 debenture outstanding.

Alice Kurkjian, soprano, and Alfredo Gandolfi, Metropolitan baritone, were the soloists last night when the Metropolitan Opera Chorus joined the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for its second group of appearances at the Lewisohn Stadium.

The Citizens Budget Commission and other civic organizations voiced approval yesterday of Samuel Untermyer's proposal that the city rehabilitate its credit standing by "cleaning house" by means of new and far-reaching economies in government costs.

Grover Whalen, chairman of the City Emergency Re-employment Committee, called upon university students yesterday to aid the National Recovery Act by "helping to arouse the irresistible force of public opinion, which will be more powerful than all law and coercion in creating a new economic America."

A series of tax reforms that will shift the emphasis from the present "high" property tax to other forms of taxation must be instituted "if the public school system is to remain intact," according to a report adopted yesterday by the National Conference on the Financing of Education, now in session at Teachers College, Columbia University.

MANILA, Aug. 15. -- Senator Manuel Quezon, after a caucus of the majority in the Philippine Senate this morning, announced they had agreed to hold a plebiscite, on the Hawes Independence Law in October, prior to the close of the present legislative session.
The animal population of the Bronx Zoo was increased by one yesterday morning with the birth of a sixty-five-pound zebra.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The United States Government turned its face toward Europe today for the first time since the adjournment of the London Economic Conference. The subsidence of excitement about the Cuban situation gave officials an opportunity to make plans for the forthcoming war debts discussion with several European governments, and to prepare for disarmament talks with Norman H. Davis, who is expected here tomorrow.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 15 -- Although the holdings of J.P. Morgan, assessed on the 1934 roll at $1,547,210, received the same 5 per cent reduction as did those of all other property owners in Glen Cove this year, the banker filed complaint early today at the annual grievance day session presided over at City Hall by John A. Neafsey, Commissioner of Assessments.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 15. -- Armando Salles Oliveira, director and part-owner of the Estado de Sao Paulo, leading Paulista daily newspaper, has been chosen as Sao Paulo Interventor, it was authoritatively stated today. Although the decree of appointment has not yet been published, it is believed that President Vargas will issue it this week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Criticism of the National Recovery Administration has come from three quarters. The first group, wholly disbelieving in the economics and the sociology of the plan, has not been very articulate, due to the unpopularity that attends expressions of this kind at present.

LONDON, Aug. 15. -- The constitution and powers proposed for the projected central reserve bank for India were defined tonight in the report of Sir Reginald Mant's committee, which marks another milestone on the road toward Indian self-government.

ORADELL, N.J., Aug. 15. -- More than half of the field of forty-three in a women's metropolitan one-day tournament at the Hackensack Golf Club today reported "no cards," with the net prize going to Miss Caroline Sprague of Leewood on matched cards, after she had tied at 79 with Mrs. L. Satz of Fenimore.

The proposed code of the Metropolitan Garage Board of Trade, Inc., made public yesterday, provides for a reduction in the work week from seventy-two to fifty-four hours, which would immediately give jobs to 2,500 additional employes, it is estimated.

The Italian liner Rex is due here early this morning with all the speed laurels of the Atlantic. By noon yesterday as the liner neared New York three world records for speed had been broken in the swiftest run any liner ever made.
ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- With the milk strike definitely over, Governor Lehman urged the Milk Control Board today to conduct a thorough inquiry to insure an early settlement of the entire milk problem.
Film Curb, a trade journal, published by Thomas Hamlln, in RKO Building. Rockefeller Center. The lessee has been in smaller quarters on W. 44th St. for eleven years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In regard to the proposed moratorium on the foreclosure of mortgages, it seems to me that both the Governor and his committee show a lack of appreciation of the realities of the situation.

Charles A. Benedict, the oldest undertaker in New York City, who has buried generation after generation in the old Ninth Ward, celebrated his ninety-fifth birthday yesterday at his home, 150 West Thirteenth Street.
Auctioneers put up fourteen Manhattan and Bronx properties at foreclosure sales yesterday. All the parcels were bid in by the plaintiffs. One sale was adjourned. The results follow:

Monroe County, N.Y. A new issue of $453,000 Monroe County (N.Y.) bonds dated Aug. 10, 1933, and due from 1936 to 1942, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate comprising Lehman Brothers, the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo and Sage, Wolcott Steele of Rochester.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The government will let the grain market take its own course for the time being, even though the Chicago Board of Trade "pulls the peg" on prices tomorrow morning Secretary of Agriculture Wallace said tonight after a three-hour meeting of the executive council in the White House.

DETROIT, Aug. 15 -- When the one-man bank grand jury hearing was resumed today before Judge Harry B. Keidan, Wilson W. Mills, former chairman of the board of the First National Bank-Detroit, asserted that refusal of Senator Couzens to sanction an R.F.C. loan of $6,200,000 to the Guardian Detroit Union group caused the crash of Detroit banks in February and the closing of every bank in Michigan.

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 15 -- Two men were missing today following an explosion that set fire to a barge unloading fuel oil on the dock of the Peoples Fuel Oil Company here.Flames spread across the waters of the Passaic River as the barge was towed out to midstream.

In accord with annual custom, several thousand Roman Catholics from all parts of the city went to Coney Island yesterday to observe Assumption Day by bathing. They believe there is a "cure" in the waters on the day and most of them were crippled, blind or ill.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 15. -- Until dusk this evening a long procession of golfers came to the tee at the third hole of the Salisbury Country Club's No. 2 course hoping to duplicate Jack Hagen's feat of yesterday of scoring a hole-in-one.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The Man o' War-colt, War Glory, followed bis Saranac Handicap victory by capturing the forty-fourth running of the Kenner Stakes, one of the oldest 3-year-old tests in the country, today at Saratoga.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 15. -- A husband is justified in slapping his wife in the mouth if she calls him bad names, Vice Chancellor Malcolm G. Buchanan ruled today.

BERLIN, Aug. 15 -- Relatives of Philip Scheidemann, former Chancellor of Germany, who were imprisoned in German concentration camps after an article by Herr Scheidemann criticizing the Hitler regime had been published in THE NEW YORK TIMES, have been released after having been held more than a month.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Secretary Wallace has at his disposal large resources to call upon to stimulate exports if he utilizes the full powers of the Farm Act.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The constitutionality of the National Industrial Recovery Act as it applies to oil control was upheld today by Justice Joseph Cox in District of Columbia Supreme Court.
GUAYAQUIL, Aug. 15. -- The resignation of President Juan de Dios Martinez Mera has been demanded by Congress by a vote of 42, to 22. The President has refused to step down.
BOSTON, Aug. 15 -- Two New York yachting parties figured in rescues today, one off the New, Hampshire coast and the other at Cape Cod.

LONDON, Aug. 15 (Canadian Press) -- England today scored a decisive victory over the British West Indies in the third and last cricket test match between the two teams, winning by an Innings and 17 runs.

Gross crude oil production in the United States last week averaged 2,789,600 barrels daily, compared with 2,679,200 in the previous week, a rise of 110,400 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Daily increases of 96,150 barrels in Oklahoma and of 13,900 in California were the most important changes.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- Samuel Untermyer, as special financial adviser to the New York City administration, spent about two hours in secluded conference on city affairs with Governor Lehman. Both were reticent about their talk.

The Copeland committee is beginning to get at some of the roots of racketeering. It heard the testimony yesterday of two expert witnesses. Mr. MEDALIE, United States Attorney, and Chief Justice KERNOCHAN of the Court of Special Sessions. Both had the courage to speak out in open meeting on the alliance between politics and the more sensational forms of organized crime.
The strike of 60,000 dressmakers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, voted in a referendum on Monday, will go into effect this morning at 10 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Four major surveys intended to effect economies and improve the transportation service of the country are being carried on by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation. The studies cover merchandise traffic, carload freight movements, passenger traffic and marketing.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Hitting timely behind Bill Hallahan's tight hurling, the St. Louis Cardinals opened a five-game series at Baker Bowl today by downing the Phillies, 5 to 1.

TOKTO, Aug. 15. -- As the court-martial of the young officers implicated, in the murder of Premier Inukai drags slowly along, it becomes clear that the revolutionary mentality is more advanced among the so-called patriots than among the Communists.

Charging that John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, is the real Mayor of the city, Representative Loring M. Black, candidate for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, issued a statement yesterday attacking Mr. Curry, Mayor O'Brien and John H. McCooey, Brooklyn Democratic leader.
BERLIN, Aug. 15. -- Germany's export surplus for July, 25,000,000 marks, represented a drop of 12 per cent in a month. In June the export surplus had shrunk 68 per cent.
Fascism will survive Mussolini, in the estimate of Paul Einzig, British economist, whose new book, "The Economic Foundations of Fascism," has been published by the Macmillan Company.

A rise in retail defaults, with declines in each of the other three classifications, featured business failures for the week ended Aug. 10, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The retail embarrassments increased 8 to 232. The largest decline was noted in the manufacturing group, which showed a drop of 6 to 13.

PEIPING, Aug. 15. -- A detailed account of the allegedly unprovoked bombing of the Catholic Mission at Pingtingpu by five Japanese airplanes on Aug. 7 was received from Bishop Leon Desmedt, Apostolic Vicar of the Kalgan district. [Pingtingpu is in Chahar Province, near Kuyuan, 110 miles northwest of Peiping.]

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- For the third straight day American grain markets closed, at the ''pegged" prices in effect on the leading exchanges, and with, the exception of a few sales of Duluth durum wheat, trading throughout the day was at the bottom levels.
PROVINCETOWN, Mass., Aug. 15. -- The entire fleet of the New York Yacht Club arrived here by the small hours this morning in contrast to the experience of two years ago.
MONTREAL, Aug. 15. -- Production of newsprint by the Canadian mills was sharply higher last month than in the same month of last year, the increase amounting to 26.6 per cent.

Edward A. Filene returned from a visit to Europe yesterday convinced that the United States should, for its own good, follow the European trend toward economic isolation and intense nationalism. The Boston merchant returned on the French liner Ile de France.

James J. McCauley, accused of netting $7,500 by swindling fifteen persons by promises of employment with the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, was committed to Bellevue Hospital yesterday for observation for ten days regarding his mental condition pending a hearing on Aug. 26 on charges of grand larceny.

DOVER, N.J., Aug. 15. -- An unidentified madman who lived in a primitive shelter in the Hickory Nut Hollow woods near Lake Hopatcong murdered Miss Anna Ulm, New York secretary, whose body was found near here Sunday night, the police here believed tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 -- With agricultural strikes spreading in California and threatening to paralyze big fruit canning and packing operations, State Highway police were rushed to the worst affected areas today to supplement sheriffs' posses.

George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, told Senator Royal S. Copeland's committee on racketeering yesterday that gangsters and racketeers would continue to flourish in cities "until politics is divorced from municipal control."

President Roosevelt in his foreign policy is aiming at "a new ideal in the relations between States" and "a Foreign Service not solely concerned with the development of our own interests," Alexander W. Weddell, newly appointed Ambassador to Argentina, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- An effort to obtain authority to remove Al Capone, gangster leader serving a Federal sentence in Atlanta prison, to Chicago for trial on State charges was made today by State's Attorney Courtney of Cook County, III.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For the sad children, already far below par because of family food shortage or because they have been hurried out of overcrowded hospital wards without due time for convalescence, whose only hops of the out-of-doors is their own tenement fire-escape, the Children's Aid Society maintains the Milbank House for Boys at Valhalla and the Elizabeth Milbank Anderson Convalescent Home for Girls at Chappaqua.

The melancholy stories that have been told in petitions to the Governor and in committee hearings at Albany have revealed the many personal tragedies behind the mortgage situation. Hard-working and self-respecting individuals who set out in the pre-depression years to establish themselves as home-owners have found, themselves not only threatened with eviction but saddled with " deficiency judgments " which may be a lifelong burden.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The following extract from a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES written by Louis Johnson, National Commander of the American Legion, is certainly unique:

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Arrangements for the return of Al Capone to stand trial with twenty-three others named in a blanket indictment charging racket control of five service industries were completed today when Judge John Prystalski signed a writ directing the warden of the Atlanta Federal prison to bring Capone into court here.

The Italian liner Rex will arrive today a day ahead of schedule. Among the liner's passengers are Prince Domenico Orsini, Princess Maria Borchesi, Bernardino Molinari, conductor, and Mrs. Molinari. Another passenger is Frank Scully, an author and the editor of a symposium for the ailing called "Fun in Bed."
