SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 15 -- Mrs. May Hansen, 38-year-old mother of two children, after a night in jail and eight hours of grilling was taken this afternoon to her country home six miles west of Rockford, where her divorced husband, Earl Hanson, 42, met his death Sunday night in his flaming automobile, a death which authorities say was a murder.

Although the new regime in Cuba is faced with a treasury believed to be well-nigh empty, Wall Street bankers in close touch with the Cuban financial situation indicated yesterday that the republic might be able to weather the storm without recourse to a general moratorium on its debts.

Before Mr. UNTERMYER was offered the position of special counsel in subway matters and general financial adviser of the city government, he had made more than one severe arraignment of the Tammany administration of municipal affairs. If the city authorities had the too clever idea of muzzling him by this appointment, they have now found out that they were far more gullible than he is.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The State Department was satisfied today that conditions throughout Cuba were gradually becoming quieter and there seemed to be prospect of a further American demonstration, of force, even for the moral effect.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15. -- Out of a welter of sixty-two matches decided during the day, Ellsworth Vines and his top-seeded cohorts came through today in the annual singles tennis tournament for the Newport Casino Cup. Vines already has two legs on the Cup and a third victory this year would give him permanent possession.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 15. -- The Larchmont Yacht Club's Frolic, skippered by Robert M. Bavier Jr., with W. Gregory Moue Jr. and Edgar B. Whiting as crew, took the lead in the five-race series for the junior Atlantic class championship of Long Island Sound by winning the third race today.

The membership of the State committee of the President's re-employment campaign for New York State was announced by W. Averell Harriman, State chairman, at NRA headquarters in the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The largest cash balance in the history of the Treasury in peace-time was established today to meet expenditures of President Roosevelt's recovery program.

BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Braves used all of their five hits off Guy Bush in scoring runs today and defeated the Cubs, 2 to 1, in the series opener. The defeat dropped Chicago a full game behind the idle Pittsburgh Pirates in their second- place duel.

The Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation reports for the year ended on June 30 consolidated net income amounting to $14,484,335 after taxes, charges, depreciation, underlying dividends and minority interest, equivalent after preferred dividends, to 70 cents a share earned on 11,610,036 no par common shares outstanding.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Lefty Grove outpitched Wes Ferrell today and the Athletics made it two in a row over the Indians. The score was 8 to 7.

A contest among the North Atlantic ports, involving freight rates on both rail and water transportation, was threatened yesterday at a hearing of the freight traffic managers' committee of the Trunk Line Association on the application of the port of Albany for new rail rates to the Middle West.

The metropolitan district has supplied one-sixth of the entries for the women's national golf championship, which will be played at the Exmoor Country Club, Highland Park, Ill., during the week of Aug. 28.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Rochester defeated Jersey City in the first game of the final series between the two clubs, 9 to 5, today. The Wings bunched five hits and four bases on balls off Joe Cascarella and Joe Bloomer for seven runs in the sixth inning.

Edouardo J. Chibas, Secretary of Public Works in the new Cuban Cabinet, who has been an exile in New York and Washington, expressed gratitude to the American people for helping the Cubans get rid of Gerardo Machado, in an interview here yesterday before leaving last night for Havana.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- A resolution urging improvement of the New York and New Jersey channels of the New York port as part of the rivers and harbors development program of the Federal Government was adopted by the State Senate today.

Mr. LLOYD GEORGE'S funeral oration in the House of Commons over free trade and Liberalism was supplemented by a newspaper interview in which he declared once more that his heart was true to the old love; but in a protectionist world one must cleave to protection.

Edouardo J. Chibas, Secretary of Public Works in the new Cuban Cabinet, who has been an exile in New York and Washington, expressed gratitude to the American people for helping the Cubans get rid of Gerardo Machado, in an interview here yesterday before leaving last night for Havana.

WASHINGTON, Aug-. 15 (AP). -- Led by the farm, textile and food products groups, the wholesale commodity price level was shown by the Labor Department today to have increased 6 per cent in July over June. This was the fifth consecutive month showing an increase.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Aug. 14 unless otherwise specified:

A total of 8,404 signed NRA agreements was received in the morning mail at the Custom House yesterday, according to an announcement by James F. Hodgson, district director of the United States Department of Commerce. This brings the total for the New York district to 183,262.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Edgerton Parsons gave a luncheon yesterday at Chatham Walk for Mrs. James T. Harahan, Mrs. Archibald B. Gwathmey and Miss Maria Chapin.

There are more mental patients, in the hospitals of the United States than all other kinds combined, according to Colonel H. Edmund Bullis, executive officer of the National Committee on Mental Hygiene.

With Mrs. Helen Wills Moody returning to the scene of her repeated triumphs for the first time in two years and Miss Helen Jacobs setting a new fashion for the tournament, the forty-sixth annual women's national championship got under way yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

Reluctantly conceding that Chicago had stolen the spotlight, Wall Street stood aside yesterday to await developments. No one disputes the fact that the course of all the markets will be governed in the next few days by what happens on the Board of Trade.
Leasehold deals involving properties on the west side of Manhattan featured realty trading yesterday. Some activity also was reported in the Bronx and Brooklyn.

Buyers' Arrivals Drop Sharply. There was a large decrease in the total number of buyers registered in the market last week as compared with the previous week and the figure was well under the number reported for the corresponding week last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Aug. 15 (AP). -- Behind the doors of the grand jury room, Elmore Clark, 28-year-old Negro, today related his experiences in the hands of a mob which wounded him and lynched two other Negroes under indictment on a charge of killing a white woman.

The deal through which the Cord Corporation obtained control of the Checker Cab Manufacturing Corporation was effected through the purchase of options on 58,837 shares of Checker Cab's stock, according to a spokesman for that company.
GENEVA, Aug. 15. -- The Permanent Central Opium Board considered today its secretary's quarterly report.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15. -- A large crowd was out for the opening of the invitation tennis tournament at the Casino today. It was a day of signal activity for the younger members of the colony. All of the debutantes and the younger girls were present.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 15 -- In their greeting to Rogers Hornsby as manager of the Browns today the Yankees took a game from the Missourians, 8 to 5. And it was well they did, for they escaped losing further ground in the American League pennant race.

Differences of opinion between Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, Bronx Democratic leader, on the one hand, and John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, and John H. McCooey, Brooklyn leader, on the other, apparently were settled yesterday and the completion of the Democratic city ticket is expected today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- In an oral opinion rejecting a plea of Texas refiners for an injunction against orders of Secretary Ickes prohibiting interstate shipment of oil produced in violation of State regulations, Justice Joseph M. Cox in the District of Columbia Supreme Court today upheld in principle the National Industrial Recovery Act.

HAVANA, Aug. 15 -- Relaxing from the strain of the last four days of turmoil, the Cuban public turned their thoughts today toward economic affairs and the rebuilding of the republic in the confident belief that the downfall of the dictator, Gerardo Machado, has brought a new era to the island.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The National Recovery Administration took official cognizance today of the threatened dressmakers' strike in New York City.
DETROIT, Aug. 15 (AP) -- In a game of heavy clouting that saw nine doubles and one home run, the Red Sox defeated Detroit, 5 to 3, today to even the series at one game each.

Patriotic, fraternal and civic organizations joined a jubilant citizenry of Hoboken last night, in a parade through the city streets to celebrate the opening scheduled for today of the newly organized Seaboard Trust Company. The bank had been formed by a reorganization committee of the closed Steneck Trust Company and had purchased the assets of the closed bank.

With the clatter of trucks and couplings reduced to a faint murmur, the city's first "noise-proof" subway car was operated over the Lexington Avenue division of the I.R.T. yesterday morning from Brooklyn Bridge station to Eighty-sixth Street and back.
Because of the dislocation on the Chicago Board of Trade traders in securities continued to mark time yesterday. The indecision and inactivity were even more pronounced than on the day before.

Dates for the hunting seasons on migratory birds in the United States have not yet been announced by the Biological Survey. As a result many sportsmen from various parts of the country are becoming a little anxious as they look at the calendar and realize that the shooting seasons cannot be far off.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The Federal Trade Commission issued today its first "stop order" against the sale of securities under the recently enacted Securities Act. It forbade further sales by the Speculative Investment Trust of Fort Worth.

WOODMERE, L.I., Aug. 15. -- Johnny Mears, young Garden City Country Club star, practically ran away with the honors in today's Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament at the Woodmere Golf Club.

GENEVA, Aug. 15 -- At the request of the United States and Argentina and two League members, Canada and Australia, Joseph Avenol, Secretary General of the League of Nations, today invited twenty-six other League members and Soviet Russia to a wheat conference in London next Monday.

Lorenz Strack, Yorkville mortgage and realty broker, who has been held in the Tombs in $100,000 bail on complaints of persons who entrusted their money to him for investment, was released in $15,000 bail yesterday after a hearing before Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP). -- John C. Mulligan, 45, a jewelry store employe, was held tonight without bail on a charge of murder while police sought clues to what they described as the slaying at a drinking party of Mrs. Ella M. Schrodt, 58.

Inquiry into the accounts of Russell T. Sherwood, who was sought unsuccessfully during the Hofstadter legislative inquiry into the financial affairs of former Mayor Walker, has been resumed by the Federal grand jury, it was learned yesterday.
TORONTO, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Hitting Pete Jablonowski freely in the first four innings, Toronto scored an 8-2 victory to start a four-game series with the Newark Bears today.

ALBANY, Aug. 15 -- The proposed improvement of the State Barge Canal with Federal funds was assailed today by a spokesman for the New York Central Railroad at a hearing before the Assembly Ways and Means Committee.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Players of both the East and West polo teams held short workouts at the Onwentsia Club in Lake Forest today. Tomorrow they will play the second game of the East-West series of three tests.

Several Jersey City properties were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday. Joseph W. Horner resold to Ignacz Pacholec the three-story, six-family brick flat at 384 Berpen Av., near Oak St., Jersey City. The seller purchased the realty from the Hudson City Savings Bank last Feb. 6 for around $14.000.

Midget Wolgast of Philadelphia, recognized in New York State as world's flyweight champion, outpointed Pete Sanstol of Norway in the ten-round feature bout at Fugazy Bowl last night. A crowd of 4,000 saw Wolgast outbox his rival in a non-title match.
LONDON, Aug. 15. -- A dispatch to The London Times from Berlin today says:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- The National Recovery Administration pressed forward today with action on modifications of the President's Agreement for various trades and industries.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Meeting to discuss the prospective steel code here today, a group of leaders of the industry left a conference with Secretary Perkins when William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, appeared in his capacity as labor adviser for the Recovery Administration.

The United States liner Manhattan will sail today for Cobh, Plymouth, Havre and Hamburg. Among her passengers will be Dr. Sao-Ke Alfred Sze, Chinese Minister to the United States; Representative Frederick R. Lehlback of New Jersey, Hiram Bingham Jr., American Consul at Warsaw. Others will be:
The closing concert by the Goldman Band on the Mall in Central Park was conducted last night by Edwin Franko Goldman, completing the sixteenth season.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Representatives of several cities which have milk marketing agreements awaiting action warned the Farm Administration today that unless they were approved quickly the programs might fall through entirely.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 16 -- Over a smooth sea and with a fair wind, Van S. Merle-Smith's 12-meter racer Cantitoe swept part Halfway Rock off here today the winner of the Navy Challenge Cup for sloops on the New York Yacht Club run from Provincetown.

One of the largest realty investment deals of the year was closed yesterday, when J.L. Reiss, president of the International Tailoring Company, bought the fifteen-story and penthouse office and showroom building at 385 Fifth Avenue from Frederick Brown.

Murder complaints against three men and a woman alleged to have been involved in two killings in Brooklyn were dismissed yesterday by Magistrate David Malbin in Brooklyn Homicide Court after police testified they had no material evidence against any of the defendants.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Rochester made it two in a row over Jersey City under the lights tonight, clubbing out a 6-to-2 triumph. The Red Wings nicked Mike Meola for ten safe blows, including triples by Selkirk and Goodman.

Savings banks and other lending institutions took over several of the sixteen parcels of defaulted real estate in Manhattan and the Bronx at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. Most of the properties were dwellings and flats. The results follow:

Hungary, whose very name amuses the schoolboy with its lean sound, is witnessing the beginnings of a new political party with the stomach for its platform. In a suburb of Budapest it is making its first appeal to the voters, but it believes in the fundamental importance of the doctrine of stomachracy, and will soon make a national appeal.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 14:
TORONTO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Sweeping to decisive victories by scores of 14 -- 0 and 6 -- 1, Toronto took a double-header from Newark today to make it three straight victories in the series.

Almost 60,000 workers in the dress manufacturing industry walked out of 2,100 shops in the metropolitan area yesterday in the first major strike New York has experienced since the National Recovery Administration was created.

The old proverb that the slow gait of the turtle gets it further in the end was placed in jeopardy last evening when an unidentified 20-pound snapping turtle, believed to be about 150 years old, narrowly escaped death in trying a crossing of Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, between State Street and the Long Island station during the rush hour.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The proposed code for the gas industry as submitted Monday by the American Gas Association and now under consideration by the Recovery Administration reads as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Two official reports covering employment and relief costs, received today by President Roosevelt, were hailed by him and other administration officials as signs of business improvement.

The weakness in outside markets, particularly in Chicago, was the dominating influence in trading yesterday on local commodity exchanges. All staples closed at lower price levels in fair volumes of trading. Cash prices were also lower in most markets.

The International Hydro-Electric System reports for the year ended on June 30 that its consolidated net income was $2,134,762 after charges, taxes, depreciation, underlying dividends and minority interests. This would be equivalent, if applied directly to Class A stock after pre- ferred dividends, to $1.92 a share on 858,197 no par Class A shares, and would compare with $3,364,479, or $3.34 a Class A share on the same basis, for the preceding year.

The American Power and Light Company reports a consolidated net income of $6,999,343 for the twelve months ended an March 31, equal to about $2.49 a share earned on 978,444 shares of $5 preferred stock after dividend requirements on 793,581 shares of $6 preferred stock.

With trading on the Chicago Board of Trade almost at a standstill in spite of the removal of the supporting "pegs" in that market, Wall Street's position yesterday was merely that of an onlooker. Although business on the Stock Exchange was twice as large as that of the previous day, the dealings were almost wholly professional and the price movements were slow.

President HADLEY of Yale used to say that the best educated man is the one who can ask the most intelligent questions. Under that definition Governor LEHMAN should qualify for high academic honors. He has a way of asking penetrating questions. His latest are addressed to the State Milk Control Board.
John P. O'Brien, the present Mayor, whom the Democratic organizations have redesignated for the same office, is a native of Worcester, Mass., where he was born on Feb. 1, 1873.

DETROIT, Aug. 16 -- An assertion that Herbert Hoover did all in his power to end the Detroit bank crisis was made today by Wilson W. Mills, former chairman of the First National Bank, Detroit, in testifying before the grand jury bank inquiry.

The appearance of low-rate taxicabs was postponed yesterday pending the outcome of a plea for an injunction restraining the police from depriving the drivers of their hackbooks and the cabs of their meters as threatened by Police Commissioner Bolan.

About 200,000 employers in the metropolitan area are now eligible to display the NRA Blue Eagle and the slogan "We Do Our Part," according to figures made public yesterday by James F. Hodgson, district manager of the Department of Commerce and official NRA head in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A revised modification of the President's Re-employment Agreement for daily newspapers was issued today by the National Recovery Administration to correct an omission in the agreement approved last night by General Johnson.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- A new type of flying boat, suitable for general patrol work is being tried out under service conditions at Anacostia, D.C., for the Navy Department.
BOSTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- An eighth-inning attack on Bud Tinning and Leroy Herrmann, recently recalled from Los Angeles, gave the Braves six runs and a 6-to-1 victory over the Cubs today.

BERLIN, Aug. 36 -- The Boerse continued dull and listless today and early gains were lost in the course of the session. Most favorites remained at yesterday's level, but I.G. Farben and Reichsbank gave way, sagging under the influence resulting from the continued absence of buyers.

Two efforts to reach an international agreement on wheat having failed, the League of Nations is about to make a third. It has invited into conference not only delegates of the four principal exporting countries -- the United States. Canada, Argentina and Australia -- but also representatives of twenty-seven other States, including the chief importing countries.

One of the first large philanthropic entertainments planned for the Autumn is a fashion show to be given in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Oct. 5 to raise funds for the social service auxiliary of the Metropolitan Hospital. The proceeds are to be shared also by the Emergency Tuberculosis Relief Committee.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 -- Contrary to an announcement made last night, the new bill to enable New York City to levy special taxes for unemployment relief was not introduced today in the Senate and Assembly. It was said to have received the approval of Samuel Untermyer, special financial aide to the New York City administration, prior to his departure from the Capitol late yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, Aug. 17 -- Hopes that the swollen Yellow River would keep to its course and not flow into its old southern channel, or cut a new one, were again dimmed tonight by reports from the flooded districts.

HAVANA, Aug. 16 (By Wireless). -- "For twelve years I have worked around a plan for a new reciprocity treaty with the United States," said President Manuel Carlos de Cespedes of Cuba in a talk I have just had with him. "We ask the United States to agree to the treaty, not only out of friendship, but because of our common economic interest.

Quiet dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday resulted in generally lower prices for domestic corporation issues and irregularly lower prices for foreign loans. United States Government bonds closed generally higher, up 4-32 point to 3-32 off.

ALBANY, Aug. 16 -- The Senate and Assembly leaders of both parties made a real effort today to bring the extraordinary session to a close before the week-end. Whether it will terminate in an adjournment sine die or with a recess for thirty days remains an open question.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- In explaining the apparent inconsistency of the government in reducing forces and expenditures, while at the same time, through the recovery program, urging that industry enlarge and increase its payrolls, Secretary Roper said that the government was organizing on a permanent basis while business had been asked to function temporarily on a passing emergency basis.

The fusion harmony committee, headed by Charles C. Burlingham, endorsed yesterday the candidacy of James A. Foley and James A. Delehanty for the Surrogates' Court. The committee's action insured the election of both, as they have also been nominated by Tammany.

Most taxpayers are unreasonable in their demands for decreased school expenditure, in the opinion of 832 Summer School students of the New York University School of Education, 90 per cent of whom represent communities whose school budgets have been sharply reduced during the last four years.
New York sneak thieves reached a new high yesterday afternoon. To utilize their loot they will have to buy General Francesco de Pinedo's airplane and fly the Atlantic.

In response to the complaint of certain shipping interests against the proposed regulation of shipping under the terms of the National Industrial Recovery Act, General Hugh S. Johnson notified the Maritime Association of New York yesterday that he has asked Attorney General Cummings to rule on the status of the industry.

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Senators kept up their swift pace today by taking another 5-to-1 decision from the White Sox and extending their winning streak to eight straight. The victory, coupled with the Yankees' defeat, increased Washington's lead over the New York club to six and a half games.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The proposal to reduce cab rates in New York has met a well-deserved negative in the courts pending the working out of a code for the business -- and well it need be done.

A general alarm was broadcast yesterday along the Atlantic Coast and in other parts of the world for sixty tuna. These sixty tuna carry license plates and have not been heard from since they disappeared at about Long. 9 degrees W., Lat. 39 degrees N. on June 22, 1932.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Information on competition between railroads and trucks in handling of freight in leas-than-carload lots and the problem of developing door-to-door service by the railroads is sought in questionnaires sent to the presidents of more than 100 of the larger railroads by Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- A slight tempering of the zeal of the Roosevelt administration for forcing the pace in European disarmament was noticeable today in connection with conversations at the White House and at the State Department with Norman Davis, Ambassador at Large.
DETROIT, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Detroit made the best possible use of seven hits today and defeated Boston, 6 to 5, to take a one-game edge in tha current series.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 -- A peaceful settlement of strikes and other labor difficulties threatening huge losses to California fruit and vegetable crops was sought today by State and Federal officials.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Aug. 16 -- A confession that he fatally poisoned four members of a family because of fear he would be implicated in the theft of papers to be used as evidence against a client was signed today by Mark H. Shank, 41-year-old lawyer of Akron, Ohio.

A suit brought in 1931 by George L.O'Hare to establish the validity of twenty-nine $1,000 bonds of the Dayton Union Railroad Company, which he bought for $25 in 1929, was dismissed yesterday by Federal Judge Patterson for lack of jurisdiction.

MOSCOW, Aug. 16 -- Having prohibited zealous Communists from driving the peasants into collectivization too speedily in the early months of 1930 by forbidding the collectivization of cows, small live stock and poultry, the Soviet Government took a new step today to fulfill Joseph Stalin's promise to the first collective peasants' congress early this year.
Sales of a Jersey City apartment house corner and a Tenafly tract featured the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Miss., Aug. 16 (AP) -- Chancellor R.E. Jackson refused today the writ of habeas corpus sought for Dr. Sara Ruth Dean, child specialist charged with killing Dr. John Preston Kennedy, Greenwood surgeon, by giving him poisoned whisky.

Mayor O'Brien was requested by the City Club yesterday to ask for an emergency message at Albany to expedite passage of six bills aimed at reform of the city's fiscal system. The request was made by letter. But the Mayor was not at City Hall yesterday, having said a few days ago he intended to return to the Adirondacks to complete his vacation.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 16 -- The Larchmont Yacht Club's Frolic, skippered by Bob Bavier Jr., with Edgar Whiting and Gregory Maue Jr. as crew, captured the junior Atlantic Class championship of Long Island Sound in a five-race series concluded today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In answer to "Inquisitor," I would say that it is quite possible to gamble in the stock market, but that all who operate therein are not gamblers. If depends on the knowledge brought to the business. If "Inquisitor" were to start a small business in a line unfamiliar to him he would be gambling.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Barn Swallow added her name to a victory roll that opened in 1872 when she captured the $15,000 Alabama Stakes today. The event, the feature offering for 3-year-old fillies at this meeting, was at a mile and a quarter.

The steel industry's rate of production has declined in the last week from 57 per cent of capacity to 53 per cent as a result of seasonal influences and difficulties arising from the establishment of codes under the National Recovery Act, according to the weekly review of The Iron Age.

PARIS, Aug. 16 -- Premier Daladier today warmly thanked Paul Codos and Maurice Rossi for bringing back to France the world's record for a non-stop distance flight. He greeted the fliers at a great reception in their honor at Le Bourget Airport this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Secretary Perkins sought today to clear up misunderstandings to which she attributed a "walk-out" of six steel executives from her office yesterday when William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, appeared as labor adviser on the steel code.

BANFF, Alta., Aug. 16 (Canadian Press). -- Grain growers of Western Canada are producing wheat through power machinery at prices with which the peasantry of Europe cannot compete without heavy tariff protection, it was stated today at a round-table conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations.
Faster than any other liner in the world, the Rex of the Italian Line steamed into port in full dress early yesterday flying the blue ribbon of the Atlantic at her mainmast.

LEIPZIG, Aug. 16 -- Official notice was taken today of reports that an international committee of lawyers intended to meet at The Hague and examine evidence bearing on the Reichstag fire of Feb. 26 as a means of offsetting the simultaneous trial of Communists now under arrest in Germany who are accused of a plot to burn the building.

Wall Street took only passing notice yesterday of the share market, the financial focus having shifted some time ago to Chicago. Even the announcement that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had declared its regular dividend gave the market no thrill.

The executive committees of the Democratic organizations in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx met simultaneously at their respective headquarters yesterday afternoon, and designated the city-wide and county tickets to be presented for the approval of the voters this Fall.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 16 -- The Women's Long Island Golf Association tried an experiment today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 16 -- Members of the Summer colony and their guests filled Parrish Memorial Hall here tonight when the Hampton Players, under the direction of Henry Codman Potter and George Haight, opened their second production this season, "Double Door," a new drama by Elizabeth McFadden.

The national code of fair competition for the building industry, now before General Johnson, has as a basis the principle of self-government in each group of the industry and self-government in localities, S.F. Voorhees, chairman of the code committee of the Construction League of the United States, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A code for traveling salesmen, calling for minimum salaries, guaranteed expense accounts and week-ends at home, was submitted to the National Recovery Administration today by the United Commercial Travelers of America, representing a membership of more than 100,000 active and retired salesmen and business men.

Italy on the Ocean. After BALBO comes the Rex. Glory these days rains down on Italy and her Duce. He said the other day in dedicating the farmland and townsites reclaimed from the Pontine Marshes: "These are the battles we prefer to win."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- A change has come upon the Department of State since the recess of the London conference. For the first time the office and anterooms of Secretary Hull have become the acknowledged headquarters of activity in the great baroque building.

GRUNDY, Va., Aug. 16 (AP) -- A charge of slaying three men whose bodies were found in an automobile on Knox Creek in Buchanan County, W. Va., was lodged tonight against Matilda Roberts, 39, of Lindsey, W. Va.
Fifteen hundred delicatessen merchants from all parts of New York City and the metropolitan area adopted a tentative code yesterday at a mass meeting at the Hotel Commodore.

Robert A.C. Smith, former Commissioner of Docks of New York City, who died aboard the liner Majestic in Southampton Harbor on May 27, left his entire estate to his immediate family and employes, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogates' Court.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- A revised NRA code for the theatre, with General Johnson's recommendation for acceptance, was ready for the President tonight, and an executive order approving it is expected soon. The code will be in effect ten days afterward.

The City of Buffalo, N.Y., announced yesterday that it would enter the market a week from today with a new issue of $9,500,000 of bonds, the largest amount scheduled by a municipality in several weeks. The issue will consist of $3,000,000 of tax sale bonds due on Sept. 1, 1938, and $6,500,000 of refunding bonds due $130,000 annually on Sept. 1, from 1934 to 1938, and $390,000 annually on Sept. 1, from 1939 to 1953.

Although prices on the Cotton Exchange continued downward yesterday and lost $2 a bale, the first partial recovery in five days followed, and a late rally left the list 12 to 21 points lower than on Tuesday. The grain situation had a disturbing effect, and not until the October delivery of cotton had broken through the 8 1/2-cent level did enough buying power develop to stem the decline.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The British Government's fears of a shipping war with Germany dwindled today with the news that the Germans were showing a friendlier attitude toward foreign shipping lines.

A fiesta will be held at International House tonight to raise funds for Cuban students exiled in New York so that they can return to Havana. The affair will be sponsored by the Directorio Estudiantil of the University of Havana, the governing body of the anti-Machado student movement organized in 1927.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Messages urging quick action by the government to "peg" the prices of grains piled up today at the Department of Agriculture, but Secretary Wallace and farm administrators indicated that they intended to disregard them and leave marketing regulations entirely to the grain exchanges for the present.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 16 -- A baseball record was equaled today while the Yankees were floundering in defeat.
NEW YORK. Albert Eugene Gallatin, who returned recently from Europe, left the Pierre yesterday for Lenox, Mass.
ROME, Aug. 16 -- The results of my latest experiments hardly deserve the name of a new invention, for they have merely confirmed what we already knew after many months of patient research.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- In the interest of economy and efficiency, President Roosevelt plans to abandon several army posts scattered throughout the country, some of which date back to the Revolution.

Flowers that vanished from American gardens and returned to the wild state 150 years ago and more; plants that have never had a place in the formal garden but blush unseen in mountain fastnesses, will be sought by an expedition of the New York Botanical Garden, it was announced there yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- The hunt for the remnants of the Touhy gang was extended today to three counties of Southeastern Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- A determination of the extent to which the Federal Government shall go in regulating prices and production in an oil code tonight rested with President Roosevelt, on whose desk differing views were understood authoritatively to have been laid by Recovery Administration aides.
BOMBAY, Aug. 16 -- Mahatma Gandhi achieved speedy victory today in his latest threat to resort to fasting to attain his ends.

While dissatisfaction with the government and antagonism toward employers as a class is widespread among unemployed professional engineers, "genuine political or economic radicalism" is not much greater among idle engineers than among those who are employed.

The Committee of Gourmets of the Society for the Advancement of Better Living held a little intimate luncheon yesterday in one of its favored haunts in West Forty-sixth Street. The name of the restaurant was shrouded in anonymity, as were the names of the members who attended.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The American banking structure is virtually back on its feet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- The crisis over the bituminous coal industry's code was intensified today as a large group of non-union operators prepared to reject the National Recovery Administration's demand that the clause qualifying collective bargaining be stricken from the proposed code.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Successive singles by Porter, Cissell and Averill in the ninth inning gave the Indians the winning run today as Cleveland gained a 5-to-4 decision over the Athletics.

VIENNA, Aug. 16 -- A meeting of the Cabinet tonight called to deal with the newspaper Reichspost's revelations of plans of the Austrian and German Nazis for the conquest of this country decided on punitive measures against Austrian citizens who work from abroad against the interests of their own nation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For some time past the writer has been pondering over the inequity of permitting owners of revenue-producing properties to avoid paying their taxes. Most of our municipalities are experiencing financial difficulties because of the large amount of tax arrears that remain unpaid.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

WILLIAM HAROLD TERRY, called Memphis Bill, was getting ready to face an invasion from the West. He was preparing to marshal his Giant forces against the advance squadron from Cincinnati, the alleged "cannon fodder" of the Western brigade. The "storm, troops" from St. Louis, Chicago and Pittsburgh will come later into the Harlem sector in three distinct waves.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Speeding up its program for a cotton crop cut, the Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today that checks to producers who have signed acreage-reduction contracts would be distributed as rapidly as the required certificates of performance were received.

Two spirited contests at Ebbets Field yesterday, highly spiced by a bitter word battle between Umpire Ted McGrew, Manager Max Carey and Senor Alfonso Lopez, resulted in an even break for the Pirates and Dodgers. A crowd of 12,000 attended.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Prime Minister MacDonald is hurrying to London from Scotland tonight to deal personally with the ugly situation resulting from the massacre of hundreds of Assyrians in Northern Iraq. He intends to spend most of tomorrow at the Foreign Office fulfilling his promise of a few weeks ago that "in cases of emergency" he would become Acting Foreign Secretary during Sir John Simon's absence.

HAVANA, Thursday, Aug. 17 -- Forty-two soldiers and two policemen were gravely wounded early today when soldiers laid siege to a building where a large group of members of La Porra, General Machado's secret police, believed to be headed by former Chief of Police Antonio Ainciart, had been cornered.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., Aug. 16 -- With a rearranged line-up the East fought its way back to even terms with the surprising Western four today, winning the second game of the first East-West polo series in history. The score was 12 to 8.

President Roosevelt's "new deal" constitutes the introduction into the economic system of a new power of organization "which can be used to counterbalance the effects of organization gone wrong and grant to every one economic security, a chance for self-fulfillment and a right to live," Professor A.A. Berle Jr. of Columbia University declared last night.
LONDON, Aug. 16 -- The London Times printed today the following dispatch from Berlin:

CHICAGO, Aug. 16 -- Prices of grains on American exchanges dropped today the maximum amounts permitted under the regulations governing one day's fluctuations when the "peg" was withdrawn at the opening of the markets.

If imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, Tammany must think well of the way in which the Fusion ticket was made up. Its own, at any rate, follows the other pretty closely -- in race, religion and locality. To Manhattan goes the Mayoralty nomination, to the Bronx the candidacy for President of the Board of Aldermen, and to Brooklyn the Controllership.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 16 (AP) -- San Francisco's eleventh, annual grand opera season, two and a half months away, has not yet had a public seat sale, but it is five-sixths sold out.

Sava Kehaya, 43 years old, a former private banker now in the real estate business, and his wife, Mary E. Kehaya, 31, were indicted yesterday on a fraud charge. Three men now in the Tombs awaiting sentences on a hold-up conviction were also indicted in the same case.
The demand for retail stores which has featured business leasing for several weeks continued yesterday, when brokers announced rentals of several shops in the midtown section of Manhattan.
REYKJAVIK, Aug. 16 -- Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh expect to remain in Iceland until at least Friday, when they may fly to England.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Direct intervention by President Roosevelt to bring about a quick codification of the steel and coal industries was believed near tonight.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16 -- Anglesea, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Beverley Bogert, was the scene tonight of a dinner dance for more than 100 guests. The event began a series of dances that will mark the remainder of the week. Tomorrow evening the scene shifts to Miramar, the home of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Hamilton Rice, where 400 persons are expected.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 16 -- Several hundred reserve officers and civilians who had gathered here today to witness a demonstration of chemical warfare were forced to run from the field when a shifting wind blew clouds of tear gas on the spectators.

These orders were issued in the Second Corps Area. The following-named Coast Artillery Corps Reserve officers, assigned to 2d Coast Artillery District, are ordered to active duty, Aug. 17, at station indicated, for training:
The stretch-drive of the Giants, designed by Manager Bill Terry to nail down the National League's pennant, got away on schedule at the Polo Grounds yesterday with highly gratifying results.

In more than one of the published letters of the late GEORGE E. WOODBERRY he appeared very like a puzzled pointer dog not knowing what to make of the strange new literary creatures that turned up under his nose. Professor WOODBERRY himself clung to the classic tradition in which he had been bred.
LAKE FOREST, Ill., Aug. 16 -- The detailed play of the intersectional polo game between the East and the West today follows:
BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- With favorites progressing easily, the metropolitan junior and boys' tennis championships continued today at Briarcliff Lodge.
Stock traders and bond traders on the New York Curb Exchange settled a long-standing question of superiority yesterday, but the stock traders proved their claim by the narrowest of margins.
An optimistic report of progress in the emergency re-employment campaign in New York State was made yesterday by W.A. Harriman, chairman of the State NRA.

State of Louisiana. A new issue of $7,500,000 highway bonds was announced yesterday by the State of Louisiana for award on Sept. 30. The bonds, to be known as Series H, carry a 5 per cent coupon and will mature $1,500,000 annually on Sept. 30, 1936 to 1940.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Dr. T.J. Conte of Winged Foot accounted for the low gross honors in the one-day tourney of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club today.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 16 -- Frank A. Tibbetts, who retired as the principal of Dickenson High School here on July 1, had been in ill health for nearly two years.

The completion yesterday of the Democratic city and county tickets marked the passing from politics, for the time, at least, of three men who were under fire by the investigating committee of which Samuel Seabury was counsel.

"The Sell Out," a satire on the radio-advertising business, will be produced by the Theatre Craftsmen, a new theatrical organization, early next month, probably at the Cort Theatre. The play is the work of Albert G. Miller and is being directed by Ashley Miller.

The United States has failed in Cuba, according to Carleton Beals, whose book, "The Crime of Cuba," will be published today by the J.B. Lippincott Company. Mr. Beals, who has made a long study of Latin America, is the author of "Mexican Maze" and other books.

PARIS, Aug. 16 (AP) -- America's touring track stars, coming down to the close of their highly successful tour of the European centres, set a clean sweep of all events as the goal of their meet with a picked team from five French clubs tomorrow night.

To carry out their reciprocal trade arrangements in the Far East, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey and the Socony-Vacuum Corporation will form a company into which will be placed the properties of both companies in that section of the world.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 (AP) -- A home run by Jimmy Collins, Cardinals' first baseman, in the twelfth inning of a hard-fought first game spoiled the Phillies' chances of taking both ends of a double-header today.

Two sets of twins, a red-headed baby and a baby only one month old were among the competitors at the best-looking baby contest held yesterday afternoon on the Central Park Mall in front of the bandstand. The contest, open to all Manhattan babies under one and a half years of age, was sponsored by the Police Department and Uncle Robert.
A discouraging report regarding brant has just been made public by the Biological Survey of the United States Department of Agriculture.
HAVANA, Aug. 16 -- Strike conditions along Havana's water front showed no signs of improving today, despite latest efforts to effect a settlement.

TIMBER POINT, L.I., Aug. 16 -- Bellport's entry in the women's championship regatta for the Commodore Henry Morgan Bowl, held under the auspices of the Timber Point Club, won the first annual competition for the trophy today.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- In the most dramatic finish in the history of the Hambletonian Stake, Mary Reynolds won the classic of the light harness turf today, taking the final heat by the decisive margin of three lengths.

DENVER, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Denver Post says a trap set by Federal agents was left unsprung and a planned kidnapping of Guy Waggoner, Fort Worth (Texas) oil operator and sportsman, was frustrated by the arrests of Albert Bates here and Harvey Bailey in Texas.
All the artillery was again on one side at Forest Hills yesterday.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 16 (AP) -- The Federal Government took the first steps today in the prosecution of Harvey Bailey and four others charged with the kidnapping of Charles F. Urschel, Oklahoma City oil man, by ordering them held on bonds totaling $300,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 -- This city became an unexpected haven today for Senora Elvira Machado and members of her household who fled Cuba when last week's army coup deposed her husband, General Gerardo Machado, from the Presidency.

Robert Andrey Jr., 18 years old, of 305 Haven Avenue, took a dare late Tuesday night. Another boy, still unidentified yesterday, dared him to climb to the top of the 600-foot tower of the George Washington Bridge at 178th Street and the Hudson River and put out the red aviation warning lights.

The statement of Colonel BULLIS, executive officer of the National Committee on Mental Hygiene, that "one per"son out of every twenty-two becomes "a patient in a mental hospital for "some time during his or her lifetime" must give a hurried people pause. More than half the patients in all hospitals, public and private, according to the last hospital census conducted by the American Medical Association, were mental patients.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 16 -- Ellsworth Vines, defending his Newport Casino singles laurels, went into the quarter-final round today with a formidable array opposing him. With Vines are seven other outstanding stars of the American tennis world, each of whom is a member of this tournament's seeded group.

A general strike of 12,000 workers in the underwear division of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union was averted temporarily last night in the Hotel Pennsylvania when a group of manufacturers, called together by a union supervisor, formed a committee of five to confer with other manufacturers in the hope of treating with the union.

Boxing will return to Madison Square Garden tonight. In the feature bout of ten rounds Promoter Jimmy Johnston will present Isidoro Gastanaga, Spanish heavyweight, and Patsy Perroni of Cleveland. A new refrigerating system has been installed in the Garden for the comfort of the fans.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 16 -- Donald J. Zinn, 19 years old, of York, Pa., a newly enlisted private in the United States Army, was shot and killed at Fort Slocum today following an argument with Corporal Truman E. Smith. The corporal, who is 44 years old, then fired two bullets into his own chest.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 16 -- Six persons were rescued this afternoon from the 38-foot cruiser Nixie II, owned by H.C. Sharp of Saxon Avenue, Bay Shore, when it caught fire and burned to the water's edge after its gasoline tanks exploded in Great South Bay near Point o' Woods.

LONDON, Aug. 16 -- Insurance brokers connected with Lloyd's whose business it is to insure people against any sort of hazard from twins to shipwrecks, reserved decision today on a new question: Odds against making a hole-in-one in golf.
The largest number of employes to leave the service of the New York postoffice at one time, 441 in all, will retire at the end of this month. This was announced yesterday by Postmaster John J. Kiely.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Contracts with the government must be filled according to their terms, regardless of increased costs due to the National Industrial Recovery Act, Controller General J.R. McCarl ruled today.

George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, said yesterday that he was willing to give the New York County grand jury the names of the four political racketeers to whom he referred anonymously before Senator Royal S. Copeland's investigating committee on Tuesday.

Tens of thousands of teachers in the United States are receiving salaries "far below the minimum wages that have been set in any of the codes announced to date for practically untrained workers," according to a report adopted yesterday by the National Conference on the Financing of Education, now in session at Teachers College, Columbia University.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 16 -- A portrait of Mrs. Pauline Van Der Voort Dresser of Southampton, whose engagement to Colonel H.H. Rogers was announced this week, will be among the paintings by Albert Herter included in an exhibition of work by East Hampton artists at the Guild Hall Galleries here beginning next Tuesday and continuing until Sept. 5.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 -- Vigilance and common sense on the part of the consumer, backed by an aroused public opinion, are better defenses against unduly increased living costs than fixed prices in industrial codes, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared at her press conference today.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. E. de Forest Simmons are guests of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Traver on their yacht, the Masquerader.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Combining Monte Weaver's four-hit pitching with sixteen hits on the attack, the Senators drove through to a 14-to-1 victory over the White Sox today.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler denied yesterday an application for a preliminary injunction restraining Noel Coward, author, dramatist and composer, and the publishing house of Doubleday, Doran Company, Inc., from continuing to sell Mr. Coward's book, "Spangled Unicorn."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Rochester today closed its season play with Jersey City by triumphing in two combats, 5 to 4 and 5 to 0. The games, pitched by Tony Kaufmann, and Bill McAfee, gave the Wings a sweep on the current series and 19 victories against 5 defeats on the twentyfour games of the campaign's series.

The prospect of a grand jury investigation of the testimony last Tuesday by George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, before the Copeland Senate committee, of collusion between racketeers and at least four political leaders in this city, remained in a state of uncertainty yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- President Roosevelt and his National Recovery Administration moved today to break the jam on important pending industrial codes and thus to remove the serious threat presented to the industrial program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Plans for the subsidized export of wheat at prices below the American level were announced today at the Agriculture Department in the same breath with the heralding of a prospect for additional processing taxes on wheat and cotton.

The report of the Pennsylvania Railroad to the Interstate Commerce Commission for the six months ended on June 30 shows net income of $3,969,427 after charges and taxes; equal to 30 cents a share on the 13,167,427 shares of capital stock.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- President Roosevelt signed the basic code of fair competition for the legitimate theatre industry today.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- After a short but bitter debate, the bill to give the Alcoholic Eeverage Board temporary control over distribution of hard liquors and wines in the event of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment passed the Senate this evening.
Milton Aborn's season of musical revivals at the Majestic Theatre will close tomorrow evening. The current offering is "The Yeoman of the Guard."

Following the vigorous recovery in grain and cotton, stocks engaged yesterday in the broadest advance in more than three weeks. Pressure against commodities was lifted suddenly after a weak opening, and thereafter all markets pointed sharply upward in an impressive reversal of form.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Hearings on codes affecting more than 5,000,000 employes were scheduled today, while codes affecting other thousands were being hastened through hearings.

MANAGER DONIE BUSH and Coach Jewel Ens of the Cincinnati Reds are absolutely neutral in the argument over the National League pennant this year. As cellar-dwellers, they have only an academic interest in the outcome. Nevertheless, they were discussing it briskly about noontime yesterday after Manager Donie had returned from a tour of the strike area in the garment-working trade.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Aug. 16, as reported by the Federal Reserve banks, was $2,230,000,000, an increase of $15,000,000 compared with the preceding week, and a decrease of $122,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Scotland Yard, with the appointment of the first women detectives in its history, is linking to the French police axiom "cherchez la femme" (seek the woman) a new one: "Set a woman to catch a woman."

Prominent members of the National Administration's financial and reconstruction groups will address the annual convention of the American Bankers Association to be held in Chicago, Sept. 4 to 7, inclusive, according to an announcement made yesterday by Francis H. Sisson, president of the association.

BENTON, Ark., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Mark H. Shank, confessed poison slayer of four persons, was arraigned before a justice of the peace today on a first-degree murder charge, pleaded not guilty and was ordered held without bond for grand jury action.
Police Commissioner James S. Bolan, speaking yesterday over WNYC, analyzed New York's traffic problem and its record as compared with other cities in motor vehicle accidents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- After seeking unsuccessfully an agreement between rival associations of shoe manufacturers on a fair competition code, National Recovery Administration officials sent the dispute back today to the manufacturers to debate among themselves.

Charles A. Levine, first transatlantic airplane passenger, was arrested yesterday in Jersey City charged with having attempted to pass a counterfeit $100 gold certificate on a ticket agent of the Pennsylvania Railroad in the Journal Square Station.

Thomas Beer's first volume of fiction in five years, called "Mrs. Egg and Other Barbarians," will be published today by Alfred A. Knopf. The volume contains six stories, two of which, according to the author, no magazine would print unless he permitted softening.
Patsy Perroni, rugged heavyweight from Cleveland, handily defeated Isidoro Gastanaga, hardhitting Spanish battler, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

There axe so many contemporary poets and schools of poetry, and so many of these poets are critics, that at first sight it is a little bewildering to learn from Mr. F.L. LUCAS'S Warton Lecture to the British Academy on "The Criticism of Poetry" that "all critical standards have broken down." Sorrowfully and rhetorically Mr. LUCAS asks himself:

The President's Re-employment Campaign Committee for the State of New York, of which W. Averell Harriman is chairman, will hold its first meeting today at noon in NRA headquarters in the Hotel Pennsylvania. Governor Lehman has been invited to attend.

The National Power and Light Company reports a consolidated net income of $7,770,465 for the twelve months ended on March 31, equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.12 a share on 5,454,801 common shares and comparing with $10,688,271, or $1.65 a share, in the preceding year.

BERLIN, Aug. 17 -- Trading continued quiet on the Boerse today, but the general tone was better. Steady improvement in the Reichsbank's gold coverage was favorably commented on. There was some call for heavy industrial specialties, but the volume trading was small.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17 -- Ellsworth Vines, defending singles champion in the fifty-second annual Newport Casino tennis tournament, gained the semi-final round today in easy fashion. He advanced with three other high-ranking stars.
PARIS, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

DETROIT, Aug. 17 -- Before a crowded court room, Senator James Couzens today related his own "inside story" of events -- ranging from the White House to the Dearborn office of Henry Ford -- that preceded the Michigan and national bank holidays, and charged that banker witnesses before an investigating jury here had not "told all they knew."

The largest gain for a month in two years in the dollar acceptance business of banks in the United States was reported yesterday for July by Robert H. Bean, executive secretary of the American Acceptance Council. In his monthly study, of bankers' bills he said in part:

Julian S. Myrick was named non-playing captain of the Eastern team and Ellsworth Vines captain of the West for the annual East-West tennis matches, it was announced yesterday. The matches will be held at the Orange (N.J.) Lawn Tennis Club on Aug. 30 and 31.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17 -- Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Hamilton Rice tonight were hosts at a ball for 400 persons at Miramar, their home. Orange, pink and blue were the predominating colors.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Indians lined offerings of four Philadelphia pitchers to all corners of the lot and routed the Athletics, 15 to 4, today.

PARIS, Aug. 17 -- The resumption of the German radio attacks on the Austrian Government will not be protested by France for the moment, it was stated at the Foreign Office today, but a definite plan for coordinated economic retaliation by France, Britain and Italy has been formulated.

In keeping with the buying enthusiasm manifested in the share and commodity markets, the bond market on the Stock Exchange moved higher yesterday, with the trading most active in several days. All sections closed at advances. United States Government bonds mounted 1-32 to 7-32 point except two issues, which eased 1-32, and one, which hold unchanged.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 17 -- Virtual abandonment of the Ellis act, by which the State of Arkansas undertook to force holders of Arkansas bonds to accept certain terms of refunding, amounting to repudiation in the opinion of many Eastern bondholders, is regarded as assured as the result of conferences held last week in Little Rock.

Tammany financial incompetence has been displaying itself at Albany also. The plans submitted by the city authorities to Governor LEHMAN and to the Legislature have simply piled one muddle upon another. Impossible taxes have been asked and rejected. The official municipal program has been changed from day to day -- one might say from hour to hour.
Two new sections of the city-owned Independent subway will be opened to the public at one minute after midnight tonight, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 17 -- Governor Moore has proposed to Governor Pinchot and the Pennsylvania Interstate Bridge Commission the building up of a reserve fund from tolls collected from users of the Philadelphia-Camden Bridge, he announced today.

Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador to the United States, will arrive today on the North German Lloyd liner Columbus. Others on the Columbus are Ragid Nureddin Bey, general education inspector of Turkey, and his family; Laurence Wolfe, singer, and the following:
NEWTON, N.J., Aug. 17 -- A gray squirrel with a flair for aeronautics and a fighting disposition is disrupting the telephone service of this community.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 17. -- The body of John Donovan, 65 years old, a retired merchant, who had been murdered with an axe by persons who afterward ransacked the house thoroughly, was discovered shortly before 10 o'clock tonight in the kitchen of his home at 69 Court Street here.

The United Restaurant Owners Association, at a meeting at the Hotel Astor yesterday afternoon, voted overwhelmingly its "whole-hearted support" of President Roosevelt's re-employment campaign. The association also resolved to do its utmost to put people back to work, to shorten work hours of their employes and to increase wages.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., reports for the three months ended on June 30 a net profit of $1,943,047, after all charges and reserves and exclusive of an exchange credit adjustment of $522,517 transferred to the contingent reserve account.

SPRINGTOWN, Ark., Aug. 17 (AP) -- Gene Johnson, a confederate of the Wilbur Underhill gang of escaped Kansas prison convicts, was fatally wounded and his wife, Jewell Johnson, was shot when a posse opened fire with machine guns and rifles at the Johnson farm home near here early today.

The booming forehand drive of Mrs. Helen Wills Moody reverberated through the Forest Hills Stadium yesterday to serve definite notice upon her rivals that it is no invalid with whom they have to reckon in their quest of the women's national tennis championship.

Compliance with the NRA provisions will increase the payroll of the gas companies of the Consolidated utility group here by $2,000,000. These and other additional expenses were cited yesterday by the utilities in opposition to temporary emergency rate reductions at the hearing before the Public Service Commission.

Doubtless on the theory that this is no time in which to indulge in unnecessary suspense, the Giants floored the Reds for the second straight in the series at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Thus they edged a little closer to that pennant.

After several weeks of hostilities, during which members of On Leong Tong and Hip Sing Tong alternately billed one another throughout the country, a treaty of peace was signed here on Wednesday in the office of Kiliang Yih, Chinese Consul General.

Heirs of the late Charles H. Ebbets, owner of the Brooklyn baseball club, obtained from Surrogate Wingate in Brooklyn yesterday a preliminary order in a proceeding to compel executors of the estate to bare the management secrets of the baseball club.

Since the enactment of the National Industrial Recovery Act and through the opportunities it has offered, rapid progress in the furtherance of public works in the New York region has been made, according to a survey made public yesterday by the Regional Plan Association.

Following early strength, the dollar weakened appreciably yesterday in the late dealings and closed sharply lower in terms of all leading foreign currencies. In most instances, the gains made by the dollar in the previous few days were erased.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Douglas Fairbanks and his son, Douglas Jr., announced joint plans today for three films to be produced in England in conjunction with Alexander Korda and to be released through United Artists.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- The Senate, at a belated and somewhat stormy session, passed today a revised New York City tax bill by a simple majority. All the Republican members recorded on the final roll-call voted in opposition.

Immediate State financial aid for local educational units was urged in a report adopted yesterday by the National Conference on the Financing of Education. The conference, which has been in session for two weeks at Teachers College, Columbia University, closed its meeting.

The will of Alexander Konta, banker, publicist and former member of the State Board of Parole, who died on April 27 at his home, 75 Central Eark West, filed in Surrogate's Court, revealed yesterday that he made no provision for his widow or relatives in this country.
Peter J. McGowan, secretary of the Board of Estimate, said yesterday that he would retire on pension on Sept. 9, ending thirty-eight years of service.

HAVANA, Aug. 17 -- With the strike of harbor workers in Havana and other Cuban ports still unbroken, Dr. Joaquin Martinez Saenz, Secretary of the Treasury and a high chief of the ABC revolutionary organization, intervened today in an effort to bring about a compromise between the Dock Workers Union and the steamship companies.

Persons in the know began hinting at great developments yesterday when the entire Forty-first Street Hotel, lock, stock and barrel, was dumped out on the sidewalk and later carted to the City Encumbrance Bureau because it obstructed traffic.

Wall Street was hopeful yesterday that the emergency conditions in the grain markets had been overcome and that normal trading practices would be restored. The share market here registered its confidence by rising anywhere from 1 to 8 or 9 points.
DETROIT, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Boston defeated Detroit, 6 to 2, today behind the five-hit pitching of Bob Weiland, who allowed no more than one safety in any inning.

LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The stock markets were quieter today with the settlement of a heavy account, but most sections continued cheerful. Industrials were active. British funds were still quiet, but the conversion loan tended to improve in the afternoon.

BANFF, Alberta, Aug. 17 (Canadian Press) -- Belief that the United States will have to inflate its currency if the Industrial Recovery Act is to function successfully has been expressed here by Professor E.T.Q. Gregory of the University of London, a member of the British group attending the biennial convention of the Institute of Pacific Relations.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The amalgamation of the Cunard and White Star lines is expected to be announced within the next few days by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer.

The last two important posts on the fusion ticket were agreed on yesterday at a conference between members of the fusion harmony committee headed by Charles C. Burlingham, and the Republican leaders of Richmond and the Bronx, Alfred L. Breor and John J. Knewitz.

Compositions by Arcady Dubensky arid Boris Levenson received their first Lewisohn Stadium performances last night by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Willem van Hobgstraten conducting. Mr. Dubensky was represented by a fugue for violins in nine parts and Mr. Levenson by a fantasy on two Hebrew folk tunes and a "A Night in Bagdad," an Oriental tone picture.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low figure.

A local cut-rate taxicab operator has discovered how long is the shadow cast by the NRA. For some time there have been rumors that New York was to be the next battle-ground in the taxicab rate war which has wrought such havoc in Baltimore, Washington and other cities.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Mr. and Mrs. C.V. Whitney won three races here today, including the feature, in the first sweep of the kind since the meeting began.
HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Leo Kaufmann, Gedney Farms star, carried off the medal in the qualifying round of the sixth annual Green Meadow Country Club invitation tournament today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 17 -- Dr. Jerome Clarke Hunsaker, vice-president of the Goodyear-Zeppelin Corporation and internationally known for his contributions to aeronautical engineering, has accepted appointment as head of the department of mechanical engineering of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, President Compton stated today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Two special reviewing boards to reclassify presumptive disability oases of World War veterans were named today by Frank T. Hines, veterans' administrator, one for the Philadelphia region and Delaware and one for Pittsburgh.

A lone seafarer with a robot helsman "that steered just as well as I could" tied his thirty-six-foot sloop at the French Line pier at the foot of West Fifteenth Street last night after making what he believed to be one of the fastest Atlantic crossings of its kind.

Evidence to show that the authorities of Jamaica Hospital had given instructions in violation of a State law forbidding institutions with ambulances supported at public expense to refuse to take patients to the hospital upon their request, was brought out yesterday at a public hearing.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- In answer to the suggestion of Neil S. McCarthy, Western spare, Eric Pedley is to come here from California to play on the West's polo team in the final and deciding game against the East on Sunday. He will take the place of the injured Rube Williams.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The index number of wholesale com- modity prices as computed by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor showed an increase from June to July. This index number, which includes 784 commodities or price series weighted according to their importance and based on the average prices for 1926, as 100, averaged 68.9 for July, compared with 65 for June, an increase of 6 per cent.

Mrs. Ogden Reid, vice president of The New York Herald Tribune, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, and Mark Eisner, chairman of the local NRA Interpretations Bureau, appealed for support of the NRA movement in addresses broadcast last night from New York City.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (AP) -- With Tex Carleton holding his opponents to eight hits, the Cardinals scored their third victory in as many days over the Phillies today, winning 9 to 5. As a result, St. Louis regained fourth place.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Jockey Jack Westrope starred again at Hawthorne today. He carried the silks of Stuyvesant Peabody, president of the Lincoln Fields Jockey Club, to victory with Martie Flynn in the second and Technocracy in the fourth.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday changes in partnerships and in listed issues.

July Store Collections Up 4.54%. Retail collections in July registered a gain of 4.54 per cent, the largest increase shown by the twenty-store index of the Credit Bureau of Greater New York, Inc., since the compilation of the figures began, in September, 1931.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Miss Lorna Whittlesey's fine sailing enabled her to sweep the opening races today in the series to decide the Long Island Sound representative for the women's national championship next month.

Russell T. Sherwood, former financial agent for James J. Walker, declined yesterday to answer questions concerning communications he might have had with the former Mayor or his representatives during his own absence of twenty months from this city, when his testimony was wanted at the Seabury inquiry.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The plea is now, as frequently, renewed that New York City, paying more than one-half, perhaps two-thirds, of the State taxes, should receive a proportionate share in the distribution of taxes.
BAGDAD, Aug. 17 -- King Feisal's proposed flight to Switzerland has been postponed for at least a week until after the arrival of Sir Francis Humphrys, the British Ambassador, who is now in London.

Unwounded, except for a negligible abrasion on the scalp, the body of James Palermo, 30 years old, was found at 7 o'clock yesterday morning, doubled up in a gray blanket in the roadway near an empty lot at Twenty-third Street and Thirty-fourth Avenue, Astoria, Queens.

The Annalist reports that its index of business activity has been revised back to the beginning of 1920 and shows a further substantial increase to 90.4 (preliminary) for July from 83.2 for June. The depression low record for the revised index was 58.5 for March, whence it rose to 64.1 for April and 72.5 for May.

While the Western world has been worrying over its troubles, SVEN HEDIN'S Sino-Swedish Expedition has teen for six years, and over a "front" of 2,600 miles, studying a part of the earth that has reverted to the desert. In small units these signalmen of science have carried on their researches and reported tack to the main army of science their discoveries.

A trust fund of life insurance aggregating many thousands of dollars was created by Joseph W. Harriman, indicted banker, for the benefit of his wife and family on Oct. 24, 1931. This was disclosed in the Supreme Court yesterday when the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company applied for the appointment of a substitute trustee to replace it on the ground that it had resigned at the request of persons interested in the trust.
LONDON, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the recital by Willard Fry, American baritone, which took place this afternoon at Gissa-bu, the home of Mr. and Mrs. La Motte T. Cohu, in the Shinnecock Hills.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The following Coast Guard changes for the week ending Aug. 16, were announced today:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Dr. Manuel Marquez Sterling y Lore de Mola received confirmation here today of his appointment as Cuban Ambassador to the United States. He has been living in Washington since last February at the home of his son, Dr. Carlos Marquez Sterling.

ON BOARD THE SCHOONER MORRISSEY, North of Hudson Bay, Aug. 17. -- All are well on the ship. We are having marvellous weather, but ice conditions are bad in Foxe Channel, because the wind hasn't sent the ice out.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Proposals to issue securities of an indicated amount of $3,244,100 were included in four more registration statements which have been filed under the Securities Act with the Federal Trade Commission. This brings the total so far proposed in such statements to $174,031,400.

Jacob Mellon and three of his associates in the Affiliated Laundry Owners Club of Brooklyn pleaded guilty before County Judge McLaughlin in Brooklyn yesterday to a charge of conspiracy in operating a laundry racket in Brooklyn.

Opening sluggishly, but quickly catching the turn in general sentiment which occurred shortly before noon, commodity futures on local exchanges raced to higher levels yesterday. Trading was somewhat more active. The majority of cash prices also gained.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17 -- Unsuccessful in their search for members of the Touhy kidnapping gang in the Chicago area, the police today turned to the theory that the gang had fled by private airplanes from its accustomed haunts to seek sanctuary in the Southwest.

After several weeks of declines, the total of bank clearings turned upward against last week and, with the aid of New York City, went well ahead of those of a year ago, according to the weekly compilation of reports from twenty-one leading cities by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Abandonment of superfluous army posts, as urged upon President ROOSEVELT, has often engaged the attention of Secretaries of War, and as often it has been opposed. When army officers did not know the three hundred and more posts and how to reach them, it was tune to publish "The Baedeker of the Army," which Captain CHARLES J. SULLIVAN did in 1926.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Governments everywhere have always conceded the valuable contribution of the voluntary hospitals to the communities that they serve. The philanthropic contribution of these institutions, which comes as a free gift to the governments their progressiveness, the humane and scientific standards which they have elaborated, have been their outstanding characteristics and, in a measure, have enabled them to survive difficult periods of financial stress.

ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- A series of important measures recommended by Governor Lehman were passed by the Senate tonight after the Democratic-controlled Public Service Committee had killed the Governor's program for public utility regulation this morning.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- Trotting in the blue and gold colors of the Arden Homestead Stable of Goshen, N.Y., the bay horse Calumet Crusader, 2:01 1/2, equaled the world's trotting record for three heats today.

A further increase of $4,380,000 in the gold reserves of the Federal Reserve System, bringing the total to the high record of $3,582,167,000, was one feature of the weekly statement issued yesterday. The monetary gold stocks of the country gained $1,000,000 in the week.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- The largest and most successful sale of yearlings so far this year was held tonight, with a total of $87,050 being realized for fortyfour head.

TORONTO, Aug. 17 -- Producing the fighting qualities of a real champion, Harry Cooper of Chicago began the defense of his Canadian open golf championship today by shooting a brilliant 70. Thus he led the field of 138 in the first round of the 72-hole title test.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Upon the interpretation given by the NRA, and perhaps the courts, to one brief section of the Recovery Act depends in considerable degree the future relations between capital and labor.

VIENNA, Aug. 17 -- The Austrian Government is perfectly willing to let Germany bring her differences with this country before the League of Nations if the statement broadcast by Theodor Habicht last night over the Munich radio really repre- sented the intentions of the Wilhelmstrasse.

Fifty-five additional brick dwellings are planned for Flushing by the Paramount Homes Corporation, which last week sold the last of fifty houses built in 1932.
