Purchase of the new dwelling sites and erection of the homes involve more than $400,000, according to the Halleran Agency, the broker, which reports that the financing has been arranged directly with an estate.

Thomas Carroll, a private chauffeur, killed himself and seriously wounded his wife, Mrs. Helen Carroll, yesterday in the Hotel Empire, Broadway and Sixty-third Street. The couple, parents of eleven children, ranging in age from 4 to 20, had been married twenty-two years but were separated.

Contrary to a seasonal trend which almost invariably dips in July, the Labor Department's index of factory employment rose last month by 7.2 per cent. Payrolls increased by 7.9. These gains largely antedated the effort to increase both jobs and wages by means of the NRA.

The background of the Nineties will be invoked for the weekly gala entertainment of the Atlantic Beach Club tonight. Members and guests will appear in the costumes of "the ladies and gentlemen of the ensemble."

Yesterday's four-cent recovery in wheat may or may not have ended an episode characterized chiefly by absurdity. Not often has legitimate business on an important market been so completely upset by futile efforts at controlling prices. On July 18 wheat had been put up 32 cents a bushel in three weeks; the most active influence, as every one now knows, having been a crude and reckless speculation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Merger of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company and eleven subsidiary corporations was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission on condition that the Rock Island accept the commission's rulings on the consideration paid in each case.
BOLTON LANDING-ON-LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 17 -- There were several upsets on the second day of the annual Sagamore tennis tournament today.

Houghton Mifflin Company, which has announced for Fall publication an English translation of Hitler's book, "My Battle," is denounced in the current issue of the American Hebrew and Jewish Tribune, an Anglo-Jewish weekly published at 212 Fifth Avenue.
WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 17 -- Two practice polo matches were played at the Meadow Brook Club today after a week's lay-off due to rain and wet fields.

Discovery of a group of chemicals, of known composition, which duplicate the action of certain mysterious agents produced by virulent bacteria for breaking down the body's resistance, is reported today in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
BERLIN, Aug. 17 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Aug. 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- Following is the text of the city administration bill to confer new taxing powers on the city government:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Co-ordinator of Transportation, said today that the section on car pooling of his administration was undertaking a detailed study of the problem with all interests which may be affected by plans which eventually will be considered for a general or limited freight-car pool.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- Answering various innuendoes aimed at him for the past week, Mayor Kelly told today about a $105,000 income tax settlement he made with the Federal Government in May, 1932.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- New pressure was put on the President today to adopt inflationary measures to help farm prices and there was evidence that more appeals would be made to him by the champions of the inflation policy.

The adjusted index of lumber production was practically unchanged for the week ended Aug. 12, the figure being 65.8, as compared with 65.9 in the preceding period and 35.8 in the corresponding week of last year. The increase in production barely missed reaching the rise seasonal at this time of the year.
PARIS, Aug. 17 -- The American track and field team concluded its triumphant tour of Europe today by defeating the leading stars of Paris clubs.

Representatives of the Merchants Association of New York and of chambers of commerce in New York City met yesterday with Mark Eisner, chairman of the NRA Committee on Interpretations, to discuss means of handling exceptions to the President's Agreement under Paragraph 14.
ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- The exchange of correspondence between Governor Lehman and Samuel Untermyer follows:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Union versus non-union labor was the issue at a hearing today on the code for the hat, hat supplies and cap industry before Dr. Lindsay Rogers, Deputy Recovery Administrator.
ALBANY, Aug. 17 -- The revised Mortgage Moratorium Bill as passed by the Legislature today reads as follows:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- Employment is back to the level of October, 1931, and payrolls in July were about $29,000,000 above the weekly wages in March, Secretary Perkins said today in summarizing figures reported to the Department of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- After weeks of wrangling, a code of fair competition was handed to the oil industry this afternoon by General Johnson, who bluntly stated that the code was going to the President at 4 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.

BERLIN, Aug. 17. -- Representatives of foreign shipping lines in Germany have been asked to attend a conference at the Ministry of Economics tomorrow, at which the question of regulating the transfer of passage money abroad will be discussed.

Although the operations of American Agricultural Chemical Company of Delaware and subsidiaries resulted in a net loss for the fiscal year ended on June 30, last, Horace Bowker, president and general manager, expressed an optimistic view for the future of the company.

Nature Earns Her NRA. First and biggest of the Blue Eagles should have gone to Mother Nature; she is certainly doing her part. She gave the United States the smallest wheat crop in apparently half a century.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

SHANGHAI, Friday, Aug. 18 -- More than 1,500,000 Chinese have been driven from their homes by the flooded Yallow River in the northern part of Honan Province and the southwestern part of Shantung Province, according to estimates made by foreign engineers who have just returned from the affected areas.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 15:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Cabinet Advisory Board of the Public Works Administration today approved plans for Federal and private projects, involving an expenditure of $65,347,499.
TORONTO, Aug. 17 (AP) -- Darkness ended a twilight game tonight between Newark and Toronto with the score 2-all at the end of the ninth.
BUZZARDS BAY, Mass., Aug. 17 -- Through a haze followed by a drizzle of rain, the New York Yacht Club fleet made the run today from Marblehead, Mass., to the Cape Cod Canal.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Racing in the Tor Bay regatta today, the yacht Shamrock V was caught in a squall and dismasted. The cook, Joe Haste, was thrown overboard, but was rescued unhurt.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- Racing in the Tor Bay regatta today, the yacht Shamrock V was caught in a squall and dismasted. The cook, Joe Haste, was thrown overboard, but was rescued unhurt.
LONDON, Aug. 17 -- The London Times received the following dispatch today from Berlin:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- President Roosevelt sent for a representative group of non-union bituminous coal operators today and served on them an ultimatum demanding that they agree on a basic "universal" code by Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 15:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 -- The Cabinet Advisory Board of the Public Works Administration today approved plans for Federal and private projects, involving an expenditure of $65,347,499.

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 17. -- Reports received here today indicate that Dr. Lauge Koch, concluding his East Greenland expedition, has accomplished aviation feats involving significant geographic and geologic results. The flights were performed with Danish naval airplanes.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York entered the fight yesterday to abolish the free storage of freight on steamship piers, notifying the Port of New York Authority of its willingness to cooperate in an investigation recently undertaken.
A partial and tentative settlement of the strike of 60,000 dressmakers, which has paralyzed the garment industry of the metropolitan area since Wednesday's walkout, was reached early this morning.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 18 (AP). -- Buffalo picked on Joe Bartulis, an old team-mate, to stage an extra-base hitting orgy tonight and as a result Jersey City went down to defeat in the series opener, 8 to 4.

Reports that the New York Stock Exchange would soon establish rules segregating members into four classes, within which each would have to confine its operations, were described as unauthorized yesterday by Richard Whitney, president of the Exchange.

The true meaning of the German revolution was that it stemmed the "frightening advance" of communism upon the entire world, Dr. Hans Luther, German Ambassador to the United States, declared yesterday on his return on the North German Lloyd liner Columbus after a visit to his home.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18 -- Lugging full sail through a dense fog, Gerard B. Lambert's America's Cup sloop Vanitie today scored easily in the last run of the New York Yacht Club cruise. The race of thirty-six and one-half miles brought the fleet here from Wings Neck on Buzzard's Bay.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Traders here who had been on the bull side of wheat for several days were largely responsible for a quick decline in that grain today on the Board of Trade. Prices were up as much as 1 3/8 cents from Thursday's finish early, with many professional operators buying aggressively, expecting a further advance as a result of yesterday's upturn and of inflation talk from Washington.
The Board of Education was urged at a public hearing on the 1934 school budget yesterday to adopt the spirit of the NRA, by increasing, rather than cutting, appropriations.

DETROIT, Aug. 18 -- An "orgy of consolidations, the building of fictitious values and the creation of one holding company upon another," were blamed by Senator Couzens today for Detroit's bank collapse.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.
LAKE FOREST, Ill., Aug. 18. -- The West's crippled polo team was joined today by Eric Pedley, who landed in Chicago just before noon after a swift flight from Los Angeles.

Business will be a standstill on the security exchanges today, but trading will be conducted as usual on the more important commodity markets. The Chicago Board of Trade, which holds the centre of the stage at the moment, will be open for its usual Saturday trading.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 18 -- With about 600 yards to go, the booming of the 7 o'clock gun, tonight announced no race in the first of the series for the Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup, which Live Yankee of the Stamford Club is defending.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor announced today that its index number of the general level of wholesale prices for last week, the week ending Aug. 12, showed a strengthening of prices following the decline of prices for the week of July 29.

Just before its adjournment till October the Joint Select Committee on Indian Constitutional Reform heard representatives of the All-India Varnashram Swarajya Sangha. According to its witnesses, this organization, formed in 1929, stands for 95 per cent of the Hindu community.

MOSCOW, Aug. 18 -- The dropping of a small caterpillar tank attached to a huge parachute from a bombing plane and the jumping of fortysix airmen with parachutes simultaneously were outstanding features of the first All-Union Aviation Festival held here today.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- The announcement printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES today that the long-discussed amalgamation of the Cunard and White Star lines was on the eve of conclusion caused a flutter in British shipping circles.

Several cases of infantile paralysis have been reported in this city and parts of the metropolitan area. Health officials said that the outbreak was a mild one, although it caused one death yesterday at Long Branch, N.J., and has cost four lives in Westchester County.

The spirit in which the whole State of New York is joining in the President's Re-employment Cam- paign was acclaimed by Governor Lehman yesterday. A telegram from the Governor was read at the first meeting of the State commit- tee of the NRA movement by W. Averell Harriman, its chairman.

The Radio Manufacturers Asso- ciation was advised yesterday by General Hugh S. Johnson, NRA Administrator, that he had rejected the code proposed by their indus- try. He instructed the radio manu- facturers to go under the code of the National Electrical Manufac- turers Association, which already has been approved.

Plans for the opening of the "University in Exile," with a faculty of German professors driven from their country by the anti-Jewish and anti-liberal stand of the Nazi government, were announced here yesterday by Dr. Alvin Johnson, director of the New School for Social Research.
Call money renewed at 1 per cent, with a small supply of outside funds quoted at 3/4 per cent. Time loans, commercial paper and acceptance rates continued unchanged in a quiet market.

Two subsidiaries of the New York Title and Mortgage Company -- Land Estates, Inc., and the Liberdar Holding Corporation, which were said to own real estate valued at $80,000,000 in all, were petitioned into an equity receivership yesterday.

The Triborough Bridge project has been before the public for so long that it is thoroughly familiar. Joining the boroughs of Bronx, Queens and Manhattan, it will serve as the only direct highway connection between Long Island and the mainland. At the same time it will relieve the pressure on the Queensboro Bridge and serve as a useful by-pass for traffic which would otherwise congest the upper east side.

ALBANY, Aug. 18 -- The State and nation were represented here today in the dual ceremony of dedicating the new Parker F. Dunn Memorial Bridge, which connects Albany and Rensselaer, and the laying of the cornerstone of the new $3,000,000 postoffice.

Drastic changes in interscholastic athletics, including the suppression of interschool competition in favor of intra-school activities are recommended in a survey prepared under the direction of Charles M. Stebbins of Erasmus High School, Brooklyn, and made public yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 18 -- The Yankees today scored a farewell victory over the Browns, 8 to 3, then headed for Chicago with two of their stars as casualties.

BERLIN, Aug. 18 -- The annual German radio show, being held at the Kaiserdamm Fairgrounds, was opened today by Dr. Paul Joseph Goebbels, Minister of Propaganda, who asserted in his speech that radio had been totally neglected by the men who ruled Germany before the Nazis came into power.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just ready THE TIMES editorial "The Same Old Paymaster."

PARIS, Aug. 18. -- France's unfavorable trade balance for the first seven months of this year totals 6,879,500,000 francs [currently about $365,989,400 with the franc worth 5.32 cents], compared with 6,110,500,000 francs [about $325,078,600] for the same period in 1932.

A map of the Arctic published by the American Geographical Society of New York in 1930 showed an open space between Northeast Foreland, Greenland, and Franz Josef Land in the same latitude but north of Kara Sea. Between Northeast Foreland and Svalbard (Spitsbergen) there was also a blank.

Passengers departing today on the French liner Ile de France include Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Seabury, Martin Beck, theatrical producer, with his wife; Sylvia Sidney, screen star; Benita Hume, English actress; Leon Gordon, portrait painter; Max Hymans, member of the French Chamber of Deputies, and E.W. Fairchild, publisher.
WASHINGTON, Saturday, Aug. 19. -- Hugh S. Johnson, the NRA Ad- ministrator, early today announced that an agreement had been reached upon a code of fair competition for the steel industry.

BOLTON LANDING-ON-LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- T. Gilford Smith defeated J. Garfield King in the second round of the Sagamore tennis tournament today. Smith, winner of the men's singles last year, was given a hard battle before he triumphed at 6 -- 1, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 4.

"The Greater New York Recreadion Authority," under the terms of the bill introduced in Albany, would consist of fifteen members, the park commissioners of each five boroughs and ten persons to be named by the Mayor. Vacancies other than by expiration of term would be filled by the Mayor for the unexpired term, and the chairman of the board would be chosen by the Mayor.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- Tambour, considered by many the best race mare in training, was an easy winner today in the thirty-first running of the Delaware handicap, a mile test for older horses.
HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- After a day of upsets, two Long Island and two Westchester stars survive for the semi-final round in the sixth annual Green Meadow Country Club invitation tournament.

HAVANA, Aug. 18 -- Members of the ABC revolutionary organization, searching for a comrade who had been seized during the Machado regime, today found four bodies buried in the stock corral of the Castillo de Atares, formerly under command of Captain Manuel Crespo, chief of the Presidential guard.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 18 -- Miss Lorna Whittelsey again proved to be the leading woman skipper of Long Island Sound when she piloted the Indian Harbor Yacht Club entry to two more victories today for four in a row in the series that started yesterday.

NICE, Aug. 18. -- Fifteen interna- tional society leaders, including Lady Mendl, the former Elsie de Wolfe of New York, were forced to jump into the Mediterranean and swim for their lives when the lux- urious power yacht Petit Nicols caught fire and sank off Ile St. Honorat, near Antibes, today.

DETROIT, Aug. 18 -- It's highspeed water -- that sheltered course in the St. Clair River above Algonac and extending beyond Marine City, where Gar Wood and Hubert Scott-Paine will match skill and boats in the Harmsworth trophy race a fortnight hence.

It is fortunate that at this moment of codifying there is in session a group of men especially conversant with educational finance who are ready to "speak up" for the teachers. The large share that amounts granted for education had in local and State budgets has led many communities and States to make their first reductions in appropriations for public schools.
NEW YORK. The Italian Ambassador, Augusto Rosso, is at the Ritz-Carlton.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 18. -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles Suydam Cutting gave a dinner tonight at Mocomanto for Mr. and Mrs. Evander B. Schley, who are passing several days with them. Among their other guests were:
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18 -- Ellsworth Vines, national tennis champion, was upset by Frank Shields in the semi-finals of the Newport Casino Cup singles today.

Although prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced in the early trading yesterday, the rise of more than $5 a bale in twenty-four hours started nervous oscillations in a range of 40 points, resulting in a finish 6 to 13 points lower on the day.

The best hope for lasting peace in the soft-coal fields of Pennsylvania, where only a few days ago company deputies and striking miners were fighting with pistols, tear gas, clubs and stones, is in the fact that Presi- dent Roosevelt is taking a personal hand in the struggle to formulate a coal code, and quite obviously is thoroughly informed of the dangers in the situation.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 18 (AP). -- A hunch led to the seizure by the Coast Guard today of the whitehulled Felicia, a $200,000 yacht once owned by Senator Metcalf of Rhode Island, as a rum-runner.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The full force of the National Recovery Ad-

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The first fruit of labor's new deal, now being formulated by the President's national labor board, were made apparent today in a brief statement issued by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

Two new links in the city subway system were placed in operation at 12:01 o'clock this morning after extensive celebrations by business and civic groups which held they were forerunners of returning prosperity and expansion for the areas served.

VIENNA, Aug. 18 -- The fact that Stephen Tauschitz, the Austrian Minister to Germany, is in Vienna and that Dr. Kurt Rieth, the German Minister in Vienna, will leave tomorrow for Berlin has given rise to speculation whether either will return permanently to his post.

DIAMOND POINT, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- On the eve of the first race for the Governor Lehman Cup over the Lake George Club course tomorrow afternoon, W.F. Crook's hydroplanes Betty III and Betty IV and Colonel Jonathan Moore's FalconIV appear to be the strongest contenders.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The automobile industry's hearing on a code began and ended today with employers and organized labor so far apart on wages, union recognition and hours of work that it appeared tonight that General Johnson had a major operation on his hands if these contending elements were to be brought to speedy agree- ment.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- A major offensive against Republican up-State rule and traditional control of the Assembly will be started here tomorrow at one of the largest Democratic rallies ever held in this State.

ALBANY, Aug. 18 -- A bill to create a "Greater New York Recreadion Authority" to develop unused park lands in New York City for recreation sports and health purposes with Federal funds, was introduced in the Senate today.

TOPEKA, Aug. 18 (AP). -- A disclosure that Ronald Finney, Emporia bond broker, paid currency into the office of Tom B. Boyd, State Treasurer, to redeem spurious bonds or interest coupons which had been presented to the Treasury for payment was made today by Fred M. Harris, special counsel for Governor Landon in the million-dollar Kansas bond forgery investigation.
A group of anti-Machado Cubans who have been exiles in New York for some months will sail for Havana on the steamship Morro Castle this afternoon. They will arrive in Havana Tuesday.

The Japanese Empire has no apologies to offer the world for what critics abroad have consid- ered the drastic and abrupt action her armies have taken in Man- churia and more recently in North China. Such criticism clearly indicates either ignorance of or unwill- ingness to understand the history of the past generation, especially with reference to Japan's relations with China and with the rest of the world.

The Shepard and Calmar steamship lines, which alone operate in the intercoastal freight trade outside the membership of the United States Intercoastal Conference, will be supported by the Shippers' Conference of Greater New York in a contest challenging the powers of the Shipping Board to designate minimum rates for intercoastal water-borne traffic.

The Triborough Bridge Authority took steps yesterday to determine how promptly it could get and put to use the $44,200,000 loan and subsidy, tentatively approved on Thursday by the Federal Public Works Administration.

Early gains in most of the commodities markets were reduced yesterday to losses as a result of the general turnabout in sentiment in outside markets. Trading was in good volume throughout the day. Most cash prices closed lower.

The Houghton Mifflin Company estimates that from 1880 to last July 1 it has sold 1,333,176 volumes of the works of John Burroughs, in addition to about 16,000 sets. The most popular titles are "Wake Robin," "The Summit of the Years," "Field and Study," "Winter Sunshine" and "Riverby."

Missouri votes today on the Eighteenth Amendment and will in all probability become the twenty-second State to ratify repeal. Then the approval of only fourteen more States will be required to amend the Constitution. Since seventeen now seem certain to vote before the end of the year, there is an excellent chance that the work will be completed early in December.

There is very little likelihood that the old controversy regarding man-eating sharks ever will be completely settled. The news columns of the newspapers, in recent days, have contained items regarding shark scares along the Jersey and Long Island Sound shores.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 18 -- Tonight's dinner dance at the Devon Yacht Club was a notable affair, opening as it did East Hampton's horse show week-end. Scores of house parties are being given at Summer homes here. Tomorrow's ninth annual horse show at the Riding Club on Pantigo Lane will bring hundreds of spectators.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Spokes- men for railroad labor asked President Roosevelt today to put the railroads under the NRA through establishment of a code as a means of protecting transportation employes.

NUREMBERG, Aug. 18. -- The medieval methods of punishment that the Nuremberg Nazis have applied to the victims of their racial and political prejudices are to be extended to lawbreakers, it would seem.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 18 (Canadian Press) -- Regulations governing the importation of gold concentrates from the United States to be refined in Canada probably will be announced tomorrow, it was stated today at the Finance Department.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Nego- tiations toward writing a code for the bituminous coal industry struck a snag today when a method of operation proposed by the Recovery Administration and accepted by all factors resulted in slowing up the work.

As the midsummer season has been passed without any appreciable modification in the progressive movement which has characterized general business since the early part of April, the possibility of any sizable recession becomes more remote with each passing week, according to the weekly business review of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

ALBANY, Aug. 18 -- After all-day conferences of Republican members of the Assembly had failed to break the deadlock over the New York City Tax Bill, the leaders of the Legislature gave up tonight their attempts to bring the extraordinary session to a close, and ordered a recess until Monday night.

AMES, Iowa, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Corporations, banks, insurance companies and investment companies, which once took mortgages on Iowa farms as security for loans, today own land equal in area to about seven of the State's ninety-nine counties, according to W.G. Murray and R.C. Bentley, agricultural economists of Iowa State College.

The strike settlement plan for the dress industry, including col- lective bargaining and the elimina- tion of the sweatshop, was adopted with cheers yesterday by the mem- bership of the National Dress Manufacturers Association.

Executives of the leading depart- ment stores of New York City sub- mitted yesterday to Grover A. Whalen, city chairman of the Pres- ident's Re-employment Campaign, their plans for instituting a 40-hour week with two shifts of employes.

In his letter to the Governor, Mr. UNTERMYER declared it to be "unfortunate" that an "impending local election" is interfering with efforts to restore the city's credit. He now acknowledges that this circumstance has a "greater weight than I had ascribed to it."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The Civilian Conservation Corps will be continued at full strength through next Winter and Spring under a decision by President Roosevelt announced today at the White House.

LONDON, Aug. 18 -- A new British operatic enterprise, to be called the Metropolitan Opera Company of London, was launched today at a luncheon attended by members of the company, which includes Florence Easton, the Canadian soprano, and other leading English operatic stars.

Not from the Northeast but from the South has come the first strong note of concern over what may happen to Negro labor under certain operations of the National Recovery Administration. The Norfolk Virginia-Pilot and its colleague The Ledger-Dispatch of that city have pointed out a real danger to "low-skilled or unskilled" Negroes in reports of labor displacements in the South under the minimum wage and hours sections of the President's Agreement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- A merger of the New York and Philadelphia inspection districts of the Air Regulation Service of the Department of Commerce, with headquarters at Floyd Bennett Field, was announced today as a part of the aeronautics branch reorganization program.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- Ten race-horse owners, managers, trainers and track employes were indicted by a Federal grand jury today in connection with the "doping" of horses at Arlington Park and other tracks. The indictments charge violation of the Harrison Anti-Narcotic Act.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 18 -- Favorable conditions in Canada, Italy and South Africa were reported by the Commerce Department today in its weekly survey of foreign business conditions, based on advices from commercial attaches abroad.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- A total of $47,900 was realized tonight at the sale of yearlings of Major T.C. McDowell and Philip T. Chinn. In all, forty-two head were sold for an average of about $1,140.

Retail Gains Marked in Week. While weather conditions yesterday and Thursday proved a handicap, the first three days of the week brought the heaviest retail gains for many months, local retail executives reported yesterday. Brisk buying was noted of fur, furniture, fur-trimmed cloth coat and rug items.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The belief that currency actually in use by the public has increased substantially since March was expressed today by Eugene R. Black, Governor of the Federal Reserve Board, in explaining its monetary policies.

MANCHESTER, Vt., Aug. 18. -- H. Law Weatherwax and John E. Parker Jr., who played on Yale's golf team this year, entered the final round of the Robert Todd Lincoln Memorial Cup golf tourney by victories today at the Ekwanok Country Club.

Bonds on the Stock Exchange moved irregularly yesterday, with the average prices of leading domestic railroad, utility and industrial issues showing small declines, while those of foreign loans pointed higher. Trading was active, exceeding $12,000,000 for the first time in several days.
Two revivals will end their Broadway engagements tonight. They are "John Ferguson," at the Belmont Theatre, and "The Yeomen of the Guard," at the Majestic.

Tamiris and a group of Bahama Negro dancers opened last night the third and last series of dance performances to be given this Summer in the Lewisohn Stadium. The uncertain weather did considerable damage to the size of the audience, but those who were present spared no effort to demonstrate their pleasure in the performance.

The municipal bond market will be more active next week than it has been this week. New issues scheduled for award total $15,441,389, representing the requirements of thirty-eight communities. This amount compares with $4,902,615 this week and with the weekly average of $13,260,015 for the year to date.

Walter Orloff, Brooklyn medical student who was deported from Germany because of alleged political activity in the university he was attending, arrived yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg. He appeared frightened and nervous.

CHERBOURG, Aug. 18 -- When Ralph Metcalfe boarded the boat train at Gare Saint Lazare this morning to embark on the North German Lloyd liner Europa for the United States, he discovered he had left his passport in a Paris hotel. The train pulled out before he had time to send for it.

Jesus deserves a chief place within any circle of wits, however exclusive it be, in the opinion of Dudley Zuver, whose book, "Salvation by Laughter -- A Study of Religion and the Sense of Humor," is about to be published by Harper Brothers.

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, who has just returned from a fishing trip, began acting yesterday as a mediator in the latest dispute in the fusion ranks, which originated in the make-up of the county ticket in Queens.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- Arthur I. Reese, 38 years old, an alleged member of the Touhy gang, wanted for questioning in the kidnapping of William Hamm Jr., St. Paul brewer, for which Roger Touhy, gang leader and three of his men are held, was arrested today in LaSalle, Ill., by Sheriff E.J. Welter of LaSalle County.

The annual sessions of the Summer school for ministers and students of religion under the auspices of Union Theological Seminary were concluded yesterday. The six-week course was attended by more than 100 registrants.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of Kate M. Sheridan endorsing Mr. Mulrooney's propaganda for the old-time whipping-post and severer sentences as a remedy for the habitual criminal inspires me to write and present another angle of the criminal problem.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Lynn Nelson, young Chicago right-hander, pitched fine relief ball in the last seven frames today to give the Cubs a 4-to-3 victory over the Braves in the last game of the series.

Frank J. Prial, First Deputy Con- troller, announced yesterday that he would retire on Sept. 17. At the same time he disclosed that he might run for Controller in opposi- tion to John N. Harman of Brook- lyn, Tammany's candidate.

BANFF, Alta., Aug. 18 (Canadian Press). -- An assertion that Japan's population problem could not be solved by decreases in the birth rate or by birth control was made before the Institute of Pacific Relations today in a paper by Professor Teijiro Uyeda of the Tokyo University of Commerce.

Business conditions, as reflected by measures of production and shipments, showed further improvement in July, according to the report yesterday of the conference of statisticians in industry of the National Industrial Conference Board.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company yesterday bought in for $1,000,000 the Casino Theatre, formerly the Earl Carroll, at the southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Fiftieth Street. The sale was held by Joseph P. Day at 18 Vesey Street as the result of an action brought by the insurance company against the 755 Seventh Avenue Corporation and others on a mortgage and interest amounting to $1,616,343.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Inter- nal revenue collections for the government in July rose $69,429,228 over the collections for the same month in 1932, figures issued at the Treasury Department revealed today. The increase figured in percentage is 112 per cent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on the railway rate decision was very much to the point, and particularly interesting to me was your suggestion that the National Recovery Administration might do much to ameliorate the unhealthy competitive conditions that now obtain in the transportation industry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Sumner Welles, United States Ambassador to Cuba, will return to the State Department as Assistant Secretary of State, it is generally understood here, although an official announcement has not been made.

TORONTO, Aug. 18 -- A young Ottawa professional, Bobby Alston, showed the way today to a band of pros from the United States, headed by Gene Sarazen, as the half-way mark in the annual Canadian open golf championship was reached.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 18 -- All villages immediately southward and westward of Hotse, in Western Shantung Province, have been swept away by the flood of the Yellow River, General Han Fu-chu, Governor of the province, has telegraphed to the Nanking Government.

The five-story residence at 24 E. 81st St. was sold by the trustees of the will of J. Stevens Ulman to the Shahpuhr Corp., Hagop Kevorkian president, for $95,000, the buyer giving back a purchase money mortgage for $80,000, payable Sept. 1, 1938, at 2 1/2 per cent until Jan. 15, 1934, and at 5 per cent thereafter.

MONTREAL, Aug. 18 (Canadian Press.) -- Johnny Broaca, bespectacled righthander and former Yale star, established a season's record for strike-outs in the International League tonight while pitching Newark to a 4-2 victory over Montreal.

PARIS, Aug. 18. -- Under the heading "The Naval Armaments Race" Le Temps presents to its readers a very melancholy outlook for the cause of disarmament as a result of the decision of the United States to build up its quota under the London naval agreement coupled with the desire of Japan to seek revision of the 5-5-3 ratio in 1935.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18 -- Miss Adelaide Whitehouse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F.H. Whitehouse, who made her debut last season, was guest of honor at two parties tonight. Early in the evening a dinner for about seventy guests was given for her by her parents at their home, Stone Villa and later she was honor guest at a reception and dance given by Mrs. John H. Prentice at Belmead.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- The Senate today passed unanimously the Byron Bill making possession of a submachine gun a felony. It is one of a series of measures sought by Governor Lehman in the warfare against gangsters and racketeers.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Aug. 18 (AP) -- Thirteen convicts of the Federal Penitentiary Annex were in solitary confinement tonight as the outgrowth of rioting incident to tightening of discipline since the Terry Druggan scandal.

The company being formed by Socony-Vacuum and Standard Oil of New Jersey interests for the joint handling of their operations in the Far East will be headed by George W. Walden and W.B. Walker, it is understood. The directorate will be equally divided between representatives of the two companies.

DETROIT, Aug. 18 -- New-car registration figures this month hold more than ordinary interest for the sales executives of the motor car industry. From the statistics they hope to be able to determine the extent of the delayed beying wave that swept into the automobile market last Spring and has shown only intermittent signs of spending itself.

Close to 85 per cent of the 7 per cent income bonds of the American Railways Company has been deposited under the reorganization plan, which requires deposits of at least 85 per cent of these securities and of equal amounts of first and refunding mortgage 5 per cent bonds of the Scranton Railway Company and consolidated mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds of the Altoona Logan Valley Electric Railway Company, both in Pennsylvania.

The appointment of individual chairmen in the local NRA Commit- tee for the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island was announced last night by Grover A. Whalen at a mass meeting of the civic group of the NRA at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The meeting was attended by nearly 1,000 representatives of various or- ganizations, trades and occupations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What can the banks do to aid the government in its plans to bring about the economic rehabilitation of the nation? This question is foremost in the minds of many bankers and government officials anxious about the success of the NRA and its purposes.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Hunters, jumpers and polo mounts predominated in the opening session of the two-day Monmouth County Country Club charity horse show being held for the benefit of the Fitkin Memorial Hospital, Neptune, and other Monmouth County charities.

ALBANY, Aug. 18 -- Spurred by a special message from Governor Lehman, the Senate today passed a bill appropriating $75,000 for the Milk Control Board. The measure, sponsored by Senator William T. Byrne, specifically allocated $25,000 of this for an investigation of the spread between the price paid to the milk farmer and that charged to the retail consumer.

The rain came down at Forest Hills yesterday and with it a stream of errors that washed out the lead of 7 -- 6 and 40 -- 0 which Miss Sarah Palfrey held over Miss Dorothy Round of England in the second set of their match in the women's national tennis championship.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- Movements of vessels follow (all dates are Aug. 17, unless otherwise specified):

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 18 -- Brig. Gen. Lucius R. Holbrook, commander of the Second Corps Area in the absence of Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, who is on leave, made a surprise visit here today. He inspected the Summer activities of 500 reserve officers now in training and visited the citizens military training camp, where 800 youths from New York, New Jersey and Delaware are receiving instruction.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP). -- A single to centre by Ossie Bluege with the bases filled in the tenth inning scored two runs and gave the Senators a 6-to-4 victory over the White Sox today and a new record for winning streaks in the American League this season.

An unexpected setback yesterday in wheat and some of the other commodities halted suddenly the Stock Exchange advance that had started on Thursday. The share market rose rather confidently at the opening, but it began to retrace its steps around noon after the grain and cotton markets had turned reactionary.

Grocers, 84-Hour Code. When it came to framing their NRA code, a group of grocers in the poorer sections of Conshohocken, Pa., apparently took the 48 hours stipulated in the national retail code, reversed the figures to make it 84, and submitted the result to General JOHNSON of Washington.

Miss Beatrice Gottlieb, the only woman to beat the Prince of Wales at golf, returned yesterday on the United States liner President Roosevelt very proud of the autographed score card and the box of golf balls given to her by the vanquished.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Band Wagon and his stablemate, Hope to Do, racing in the colors of Admiral Cary T. Grayson of Washington, ran one-two in the feature at Hawthorne toay.

BERLIN, Aug. 18 -- At Wannsee, near Potsdam -- Berlin's and Germany's Coney Island -- new signs displayed along the approaches and on the municipal bathhouses taken over from the Liberalist-Marxist administration informed the wayfarer today that "Jews are forbidden admittance to the beach."

THERE is nothing specific about the amateur golf championship and the Havemeyer Trophy in the NRA program, but some gallant citizen might win himself a personal Blue Eagle by recovering the championship title and the handsome Havemeyer Trophy. They were carried off to Canada, last September by C. Ross Somerville, called Sandy.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 18 (AP). -- Sniped at continually by desperate Berber tribesmen, 25,000 French native troops and Foreign Legionaires methodically mopped up today around Djebel Badou, the last stronghold of the wild Berbers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. (AP) -- President Roosevelt, pondering a decision upon how far Federal price-fixing in the oil industry should extend, decided suddenly to- day to name himself head of an organization to administer petro- leum industry affairs under an NRA code.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 -- The government's corn-hog plan was explained in a speech by Secretary Wallace today as involving the slaughter of 5,000,000 hogs, with the meat to go for relief, the addition of $55,000,000 to the income of farmers and an increase in the price of hogs in general.

DETROIT, Aug. 18 (AP). -- The Tigers won an uphill battle from the Athletics, 7-6, in a series opener today, batting around in the sixth to score four runs and lead, 6-5. Then they put over what proved to be the winning run in the seventh without the benefit of a single hit.
Several Jersey City housing parcels were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

Two Italian submarines, the first foreign undersea craft to enter this port since the war, will arrive today from Northern waters where they were a part of the patrol for the Balbo flight. The submarines, the Balilla and the Millelire, will be accompanied by two drifters, the Mateucci and Biglieri.
A wide variety of properties in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn came under new control in sales and leases announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The Cabinet Advisory Board today allocated $2,272,051 for permanent additions to the Marine Hospital at Stapleton, Staten Island. The improvements will replace the temporary structures, which, it is said, have been rapidly deteriorating, and will provide modern operating facilities and 400 beds.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- "The Milton Point Frolics of 1933" will be presented on Friday night at the Milton Point Casino, for the benefit of the unemployed of Westchester County.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Chester T. Birch, captain-elect of the Dartmouth golf team, won the annual Green Meadow Country Club invitation tourney today when he defeated C. Ward Birch of Woodway, 2 and 1, in the final round.

MADRID, Aug. 18. -- A tall, pleasant young man traveling around Europe as an ordinary tourist has done as much to create good feeling for the United States as any ambassador. He is Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., who, by his unaffectedness, innate tact and dignity, has done much to counteract impressions created by other kinds of tourists in Europe.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Business continued to recede in the week ended on Aug. 12, the Department of Commerce indicated today in its weekly survey of domestic conditions.

George G. Royce reported yesterday in his consumers' weekly review of local wholesale markets that fresh vegetables from near-by States and from the West were fairly plentiful here last week. Mr. Royce is director of the local office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

THERE may be some rivalry in two picture books recalling the follies and the furores of not too recent decades that appear on the October horizon. "The American Procession," to be issued by Harper's, with explanatory captions by Frederick Lewis ("Only Yesterday") Allen, will have the cream of Brady's Civil War Pictures in its progression from 1860 to the present.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Women owners swept the three feature races before 15,000 persons today. Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Inlander captured the Travers, Mrs. John D. Hertz's Contessa was a surprise winner in the Spinaway and Mrs. Morton L. Schwartz's Lord Johnson got home first in the Shillelah Steeplechase Handicap.

TWO murders, each linked by some mysterious bond to the third tragedy, presage the assassination of the British Prime Minister death striking him instantaneously, without leaving a trace of its source, in his room at the House of Commons.
The final handicap list for the year has been mailed by the Metropolitan Golf Association to its member clubs throughout the district, and numerous changes appear.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 19 From across the vast spaces separating this planet from the Milky Way there flashed from the southern skies this week the visual record of a cataclysm which transformed the obscure star Nova Ophiuchus No. 3 from the sun of the eleventh to the sixth and a half magnitude 10,000 years or more ago.

HOUGHTON LAKE, Mich. IN a day when automobiles by thousands tour across America, a team and wagon on a longdistance journey constitute a curiosity. With a team, a wagon and a dog, Leon D. Maydole passed through here late in July on his way from North Dakota to Gloversville, N.Y., driving back to his old home town in the way of the Fortyniners and the other pioneers who opened the West.

SELDOM has such a tale of greed, misery, bloodshed and futility been placed between the covers of book as is told in this new volume by Mr. Beals. Seldom has a country appeared so utterly without hope for the future as the Cuba which is painted for us here.

What part are schools and colleges to have in the National Recovery program? Should there be a code for teachers that would help increase the employment and purchasing power of the million or more persons in educational work? Leaders of teacher groups throughout the country are discussing these questions.

WHILE Ben Bernie began his career as a violin prodigy, It was as "the old maestro," a dispenser of jazz and jests, that he became known to the nation via the air waves. He began life as Bernard Ancel, one of eleven little Ancels, in Bayonne, N.J.
POINT O' WOODS, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Langdon Thorne sailed his Fleet Star II over the finish line first today in the Star class event of the invitation regatta of the Point o' Woods Yacht Club.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Breaking 48 out of 50 targets, Frank C. Chapman captured the high scratch cup at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. The high handicap prize went to F. Wise.

A race against time, with the blue ribbon of the Atlantic as the stake, takes a heavy toll from officers and crew, according to Captain Francesco Tarabotto of the Italian liner Rex. As he rested from the recent record-breaking trip, he told of the strain, the manoeuvring for favorable weather and the thrill that are part of a transatlantic crossing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The New York Long Branch Railroad Company has been directed by the War Department to alter its bridge over the south channel of Shark River in New Jersey.

RETAIL trade forged ahead during the week, with volume during the first three days registering the largest gains since the early part of the Spring. Leading local stores are credited with a 5 per cent increase in volume over the first half of the month.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Aug. 19. -- Four important units of the Democratic party pledged themselves at a meeting in Grotto Park here today to a campaign for "reorganization and modernization" of local and county governments.

THE Art Students League opened last Wednesday its thirty-third annual Summer exhibition, containing work by more than 100 students, from a score of States. It contains art produced in the Summer classes of George Grosz, Jules Gotlieb, George B. Bridgman, Richard Lahey, Kimon Nicolaides and George Picken; also the Studio Class.
PARIS, Aug. 12. -- Paris, with the approach of mid-August, touches the nadir of mundane activity. In the code of the Parisians, it does not do to be seen in town during August.

Centripetal and centrifugal forces vie with each other in the modern metropolis. Urbanization gives way to suburbanization. The city draws from afar, sucks men and women into the whirlpool of its life, and then casts them up on near-by beaches. At the very centre of the vortex, as in nature, a low pressure area may develop, as on the east side of New York.
ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The text of the report and resolution unanimously adopted by the meeting of Democrats here today is as follows:

Mrs. Minnie Johnson Fallen, 21 years old, a former physical director of church activities in Waco, Texas, who had recently suffered a complete nervous breakdown, was being sought yesterday by detectives of the Missing Persons Bureau after her disappearance here on Thursday.
TULSA, Okla., Aug. 19 (AP). -- Evidence that babies born out of wedlock have been sold here for adoption was revealed today by Mrs. Mabel Bassett, State Commissioner of Charities and Corrections.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 19. -- The nation's best marksmen converged on this little hamlet today anxious to get in a few more practice shots before the opening of the thirty-fourth annual Grand American Handicap Tournament on Monday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19. -- Three dances that drew guests from all quarters of the Summer colony were held tonight to mark the close of tennis week. Many dinner parties were given before the dances, at which floral and electrical displays were features.

The anglers of this district are now getting more action than at any other time this season, according to reports compiled yesterday. While the best fishing in recent weeks has been along the New Jersey coast, and far down Long Island's shore, the fisherman now can direct his angling around Sandy Hook, Ambrose Channel and Gedney Channel.

ALMOST every American who has traveled across the Atlantic has wished that we might have in America that delightful European institution, the sidewalk cafe. Now, this Summer, all of a sudden, here it is in New York. We come upon it in many a street.

The week found the dress, coat and suit markets practically at a standstill, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. In the coat and suit industry factories were completely closed pending the final satisfactory adjustment of the labor situation in conjunction with the NRA code.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 19. -- The Rev. Felix G. Robinson, pastor of St. John's Lutheran Church-by-the-Sea, announced today his resignation from the pastorate of the church and from the ministerium of the United Lutheran Synod of New York to take effect tomorrow morning, when his farewell sermon will be delivered.

SPENCER TRACY, currently appearing in "The Power and the Glory," was born in Milwaukee, Wis., just three months and five days after the beginning of the twentieth century. He went in for dramatics and debating, the latter particularly, at Marquette University -- then Ripon College -- in Milwaukee, and was so good an orator that he got a job campaigning for the soldiers' bonus one Summer after the war.

THOMAS BEER'S readers -- and that classification must include a good many persons -- will rejoice that he has resolved to present these stories in book form. Mrs. Egg, that mountainous and worldly wise matriarch with her eleven grandchildren and her Gargantuan passion for good living.

THE idea that only by direct physical contact, by so-called living, can one learn about life, is pure nonsense. The thing can be done more effectively through reading and thinking. Nobody one meets is as interesting as the characters found in books and no experience as important or exalting as absorbing the thought of a great mind or imbibing the prose or verse of a master of style.

HAVE you ever seen a great city after an earthquake? The scene is terrifying: demolished buildings, fires, the ground in furrows, from which vapors are still escaping: the dead still half-buried under the ruins. But already the people have regained courage and begun to rebuild their city.

The questions of Japanese migration and naval ratios have been the outstanding obstacles to perfect accord between Japan and the United States. The California land and school legislation aimed against Japanese and the 1924 Exclusion Act had most unpleasant effects on the sentiments of the Japanese people, but in the main the relations between our two countries have been friendly since the United States opened Japan to world intercourse.

The controversy over what steamship was the first to cross the Atlantic was revived yesterday as the result of the observance of the centenary of the sailing of the Canadian steamship Royal William. A special stamp was issued in Canada on Thursday, the anniversary of the sailing, and throughout Canada meetings were held at which the Royal William was hailed as the first ship to cross the ocean with steam propulsion.

ONLY the most indulgent definition could describe Mr. Bromfield's new book as a novel. It has many of the qualities and ingredients of fiction, but that its place is properly in the field of autobiography he would readily acknowledge.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- James Roosevelt, father of the President, owned the first motor yacht registered by the Department of Commerce.

Revealing that they have resources at their command hitherto unsuspected, the Giants conquered the Cubs at the Polo Grounds yesterday with a withering blast that confounded the Chicagoans and even bewildered the crowd of 20,000 onlookers.

THE task of social and economic readjustment upon which this nation has embarked under the National Industrial Recovery Act finds expression in these two studies of important specific aspects of the problem.

The important part that the schools are to play in national recovery is now being significantly Stated by many of our leading thinkers. Yet the National Conference on the Financing of Education, just ended at Teachers College, Columbia Univeisily, startled some conservatives when it stated the principle:

ANOTHER theatrical season now steps forward to take its chances with Broadway, the movies, the NRA, the critics and Life in the abstract. A casual glance suggests that those steps will be halting ones, at least for the time being.

PARIS. COMPRESSING the modern girl into the ladylike Victorian mold must be done with tact or the result is likely to suggest the answer to the question of what would happen if an irresistible force should meet an immovable body -- "inconceivable violence."

Harold Stirling Vanderbilt, yachting and bridge enthusiast, and Miss Gertrude L. Conaway were quietly married yesterday morning in his apartment at the Hotel Barclay by the Rev. Paul Stevens Olver of St. Thomas Parish.

LONDON. THE problem of the reviewing of detective novels has brought a lively correspondence to the editor of The Crime Book Society Magazine. The complaint is made that too many reviewers are wont to spoil a book for prospective readers by letting the author's cat out of the bag.

RIO DE JANEIRO. THE literary activity of Brazil in these days is characterized by a very interesting phenomenon: there are many talented writers and few, very few books of real merit. Within the last five years there were published, in prose, only three books that will survive the process of formation of the Brazilian literature: "A Viagem Maravilhosa," by Graca Aranha; "Bagaceira," by Jose Americo, and "Minino de Engenho," by Lina do Rego.

WOODSTOCK. IT isn't so easy to keep track of the exhibitions at Woodstock. The opening affair this Summer, a thirty-year retrospective, was commented upon in these columns June 18. Since then there have been, I believe, several shows, but the current one is called the "first annual."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, who returned recently from Europe, gave a dinner tonight at Bayberry Land, their place in the Shinnecock Hills, for Mr. and Mrs. John W. Cross and Charles C. Auchincloss, their house guests.

BUFFALO, Aug. 17. -- With the NRA campaign in full stride, the general acceptance of the plan by business houses in this community is beyond question, even though the responses to the publicity efforts appear to have grown less rather than more enthusiastic as decisions on practical questions have brought home a clearer understanding of what is expected.

NOWHERE is the spirit ofEngland more clearly expressed than in the little poem which tells us that in whatever foreign land an Englishman lies buried his grave becomes a little spot of England. Against such impassioned loyalty to one's native country internationalism must stand but a poor chance in its effort to achieve its fullest significance.

PALISADES, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- A petition asking Postmaster General Farley to investigate why a contract award for carrying the United States mail here, was given to Miss Frances Weschler, 21 years old, and later rescinded, is being circulated in Palisades.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Danseuse, a chestnut mare owned by Mrs. J.V. Bouvier 3d of East Hampton, won the hunter championship at the East Hamp- ton Riding Club's ninth annual horse show today.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 16. -- Almost lost in the agitation over beer and relief bonds is the proposed constitutional amendment for county home rule, also to be voted on in the Aug. 26 election. Beer has its advocates and adversaries tearing at each other's throats and so has the $20,000 State relief bond issue.

Three hold-up suspects, wanted in connection with a series of early morning robberies, were arrested in a stolen taxicab at Ninth Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street yesterday, largely because they gave an unemployed man a dollar.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Mr. and Mrs. Fred Wettach's big chestnut gelding, By Request, out- jumped his rivals to take the blue ribbon in the knock-down-and-out jumping class at the second session of the fourth annual Lake Placid Horse Show today.

HAVANA, Aug. 19. -- Sumner Welles, United States Ambassador, in a statement to the Cuban press this afternoon warned the nation that order must be maintained and the public must leave the punishment of delinquent officials of the deposed Machado regime to constituted government if a record of progress was to be made by the new regime.

APPEALING for help in St. Louis recently in forwarding the NRA campaign, General Hugh S. Johnson said: "The first thing in this great program is to get Blue Eagles in every window. The time for dealing with the 'unimportant chiseling fringe' will come as soon as that is done."

BERLIN, Aug. 19. -- A formal apology by the commander of the Nazi storm troops in Berlin will be made to United States Ambassador William E. Dodd next week for the attack by a storm trooper last Tuesday night on Dr. Daniel Mulvihill of the Long Island Medical College Hospital, it was announced by the Bureau of the Secret Political Police today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19. -- Ch. Heather Reveller of Sporran, Scottish terrier, was awarded the title of best in show at the twenty-ninth, annual dog show of the Rhode Is- land Kennel Club, held today at Glen Farm, the estate of Mrs. Moses, in the neighboring town of Portsmouth.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 19. -- The 14-year-old trotting gelding, Christie Mac, owned and driven by Robert Elderkin of St. James, L.I., won the 2:15 Class Trot and Pace today. The event, featured the Nassau Driving Club matinee at the Fair Grounds.

IN August the beauty of the flower garden has become mature, matronly and a bit florid, not to say loud -- so loud that the higher critics of horticulture might justifiably look down their aristocratic noses at the garden and accuse it of overdressing.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19 (AP). -- AlCrowder scored his twentieth victory of the season in defeating the Browns, 5 to 3, today to give the Senators their eleventh consecutive triumph, but it was not Jack Burns's fault.

Dean E. Raymond Bossange of the New York University College of Fine Arts announced yesterday that Winold Reiss, noted painter and designer, had been appointed Assistant Professor of Mural Painting of the university.

Foreign trade figures of the United States for June, and of Great Britain for July, indicate that world trade has been slowly overcoming the international barriers since the United States suspended gold exports in March.

A MOUNTAIN TOWNSHIP" is a collection of stories, character sketches -- a true Yankee commentary on village gossip. The verses, hardly verses at all and yet not prose, seem a mere setting down of words as they have been spoken.

HARVEY W. SCOTT, who had a chief part in raising monuments on the Pacific Coast to others, is himself to stand in bronze of BORGLUM'S fashioning, in the Oregon country. Thirty years ago he offered "the implement of the ceremony" to President THEODORE ROOSEVELT, when he laid the cornerstone of the monument in Portland to the explorers LEWIS and CLARK.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -- The oil industry, after weeks of conflict over price control, was brought fully into the recovery campaign in a trade code approved by President Roosevelt tonight just before he departed for Hyde Park, N.Y.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 18. -- Bruno Walter sat at his desk in the Mozarteum today in the loose brown suit and easy shoes the Salzburg Festival crowd knows so well an seemed to find the world good. The hard month of rehearsal of concerts and opera lay behind him and it had been worth while.

Final settlement of the strike of 60,000 dressmakers, which has paralyzed 2,100 shops in the metropolitan area since Wednesday, is expected tomorrow afternoon, when the strikers, in mass meeting at the 71st Regiment Armory, will vote on the agreements reached with employers' associations yesterday.

NARROWSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- More than 2500 Boy Scouts from New York City are dressing up their five encampments on the reservation of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York across the river, in preparation for their welcome to President Roosevelt when he arrives Wednesday.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 19. -- Live Yankee, representing the Stamford Yacht Club, won the first race of the series for the Manhasset Bay Challenge Cup today with Robin finishing second and Astrild third.

PERHAPS it is still sweltering in some parts of the country. As the article is being written the thermometer is playing around in the 80s and locusts are announcing that more hot weather is to come. But in spite of all this thoughts turn to Autumn togs, walks down country lanes amid aisles of flaming trees and along fairways across which sweep cool October breezes.

ROME, Aug. 18. -- On his return to Rome Air Minister Italo Balbo declared the whole credit for the Italian armada's successful flight was due to Premier Mussolini. He described himself as a soldier who merely carried out his superior's orders.

THE apparently resistless urge of many lovers of belles-lettres to translate Dante into English, we had occasion to observe nearly two years ago in these columns when reviewing the work of Professors Fletcher and Lockert, was "possibly the most amazing literary paradox of the age."
WEST POINT, Aug. 19. -- The Corps of Cadets will leave here tomorrow morning on its annual "hike" into the country west of the reservation, the march extending as far as Monroe, Orange County.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- The written word in some cases, to be easily understood, is best accompanied by a map. This certainly is true in the case of Ireland when the British interest in the problem needs to be explained. In fact, that interest cannot be fully understood, if the geographical relationship between the two islands is not taken into consideration.

TORONTO, Aug. 19. -- Joe Kirkwood, the Australian trick-shot star, ripped through the last two rounds of the Canadian open in sub-par golf today. As a result he scored one of the most decisive triumphs in the history of the competition.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. THANKS to the World's Fair, Chicago is recapturing its former reputation as a Summer show city. The legitimate stage in the Loop now presents a catalogue of five playbills; at times the total has gone as high as eight.
WEST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Light winds and fog hampered the fleet in the weekly regatta of the Yacht Racing Squadron of the West Hampton Country Club on Moriches Bay today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19. -- Miss Gertrude L. Conaway, who was married today to Harold S. Vanderbilt, is the daughter of the late Mrs. W. Barklie Henry and the late John L. Conaway, a prominent horseman and clubman of this city. Her father died more than twenty years ago and her mother, whose second husband was a wealthy yachtsman and retired banker, died in 1930.

ALBANY, Aug. 19 (AP). -- The Public Service Commission today ordered five railroad companies to show cause at public hearings in Albany Aug. 30 and 31 why they should not comply with orders of the commission directing the elimination of certain grade crossings.
Despite Mayor O'Brien's injunctions for strict economy in the 1934 budget, eighteen additional city departments filed estimates yesterday which in most instances requested increased amounts.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 19. -- Gold mines of Ontario produced bullion to the value of $3,636,754 in July, a decline of $11,938 from the total for June. Ore milled in July amounted to 462,635 tons, against 457,886 tons in June, indicating lower average grade for July.
LONDON, Aug. 18. -- The massacre of hundreds of Assyrians in the mountain fastnesses of Iraq has muddied diplomatic waters far beyond the boundaries of the Arab kingdom.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 19. -- In a meadow beside the quiet Hoosac River, between North Adams and Williamstown, there was dedicated this afternoon a replica of Fort Massachusetts, erected in 1745 by the colony of Massachusetts Bay to protect its western frontier.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Proposed codes of fair competition for cocoa and chocolate manufacturers and biscuit and cracker makers were made public today by the Farm Adjustment Administration.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- Concentrated buying of wheat on the Board of Trade by a local commission house on orders said to have originated in New York caused a revival today of reports that a pool had been formed to operate in wheat. Leading interests here disclaimed knowledge of such a pool.

Students and instructors from New College, a new unit at Teachers College, Columbia University, are learning together what rural life is like just now by joining hands in running a farm in the Blue Ridge Mountains of North Carolina. The project is an attempt to carry on community life with an educational objective, and is an integral part of the New Col- lege program.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 19. -- Among those giving luncheons at tables set under the apple trees at the picturesque old Riding Club today during the ninth annual Horse Show were:

Several score members of the United Depositors of the Bank of United States assembled at the State Building yesterday seeking an interview with Joseph A. Broderick, State Banking Superintendent. They carried banners demanding "our money in full."

OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Target practice has been taken up by Charles F. Urschel and his close associates. The possibility of an attempt at reprisal by friends of men they have helped to arrest and charge with the kidnapping of the Oklahoma oil man has brought about this attention to marksmanship.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 19. -- Mrs. Richard Evans Sperry will give a dinner for her daughter, Miss Georgia Buck, before the dance at the Greenwich Country Club on Sept. 22, when Mr. and Mrs. John A. Topping of Belle Haven, Greenwich, will present their granddaughter, Miss Mary A. Topping, who was graduated in June at the Westover School.

PROFESSOR LASKI praises Mr. Brogan's book, which, by the way is the work of one of his colleagues in the London School of Economics, as "the most illuminating treatise on American government since the late Lord Bryce's famous volumes of fifty years ago," as "distinguished by a wealth of knowledge to which, probably, no living Englishman can pretend," and as exhibiting "the capacity to grasp the living dynamic which animates an institutional framework."

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES article on "Big Bells of the World" appears to be in error in giving to Great Paul the title as the largest articulate bell. SacreCoeur in Paris, with its Savoyarde, would seem to take precedence over St. Paul's in London, in this respect.

IN the past twelve years $15,000,000,000 have been spent on the roads of the country, and a large part of it has gone toward constructing substantial highway surfaces. Yet only about 10 per cent of the total of all roads are surfaced, while some 3,000,000 miles of earth roads are yet to be improved.

BOB CLAIRMONT is a tradition in Greenwich Village. To those who knew him he was a reality, sure enough. He inherited a fortune on one of the strangest flukes imaginable and he lived in New York during the years of the boom era with a prodigality and a physical exuberance, guided by something like a genuine personal philosophy, that were stimulating and in some aspects even admirable.

Calls of bonds for redemption this month before maturities which were issued last week affected only a few small and unimportant municipal issues. The total for August is now $22,355,000, compared with $12,509,000 in the preceding month and $56,143,000 in August a year ago.
BERLIN, Aug. 19. -- Supplementary orders tightening the restrictions against Jewish physicians have been issued by Dr. Wagner, Nazi Commissar for the medical profession.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Attorney General Cummings made known today that he would postpone any statement on prosecution of gold hoarders until Thursday. Returning from a holiday in Connecticut, he received new reports on the situation.

BOXING may be in a slump in these parts, but over in Europe there is much activity, one way and another, as witness these interesting items culled from the official bulletin of the International Boxing Union, published monthly and sent out from 24 Boulevard Poissonniere, Paris:

Aetna Brewing Company -- Fifteen weeks ended July 31: Net income after all charges except Federal and State taxes, $72,884, equal to 34 cents a share on 213,000 shares. American Encaustic Tiling Company, Ltd., and Subsidiaries -- Six months ended June 30:

Revival of the plans and policies of Joseph V. McKee, formerly President of the Board of Aldermen, particularly those for the reduction of the city's expenses, were promised yesterday by James T. Lyons, Democratic candidate for Borough President of the Bronx, in accepting the designation of the executive committee of his party.

NEWPORT. -- After the busy whirl of social activities that marked the past week incident to the invitation tennis tournament at the Casino, the present week win appear rather quiet despite the fact that there was varied events scheduled and cards are out for numerous purely social affairs.

Special services for deaf-mutes will be conducted in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier today, which is Ephpheta Sunday in the ecclesiastical calendar. The Rev. Alien Clay Lambert, pastor of St. Thomas's Lutheran Church, who has just returned from the Century of Progress Exposition in Chicago, will occupy his own pulpit this morning.

IN an effort to complete the summary on the right, this column asked its London branch to track down Gilbert Miller and to learn his plans. Mr. Miller, discovered directing a picture at Elstree, said he has none beyond the "two undecided" plays for Herbert Marshall and Edna Best and for Helen Hayes.

Forty-two pioneers in American chemistry who attended the Columbian Exposition in Chicago in 1893 will be guests of honor at a dinner Sept. 14 of the American Chemical Society at the Century of Progress Exposition in Chicago. The eighty-sixth meeting of the society, with more than 3,000 scientists participating, will be held Sept. 10 to 15.

The completion of final arrangements for the New York University football squad to do its preseason training at its new camp at Lake Sebago, near Sloatsburg, N.Y., was announced yesterday by Albert B. Nixon, graduate manager of athletics at N.Y.U.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 19. -- A new department of economics and government will be in operation with the opening of the scholastic year at the Naval Academy on Sept. 29.

The problem that is uppermost in the minds of public utility men is the rate question, which in many States is occupying the centre of the stage so far as the various service industries are concerned. It is destined to remain in the limelight as a matter of immediate importance for a considerable period, in the opinion of leaders in the field.

RADIO announcers associated with the Columbia Broadcasting System have been handed a new list of "dont's" which eliminates familiar and recurrent phrases up to now overworked on the air. The announcer who tells the audience what it has been thinking, through the use of such a phrase as "You have just been enjoying" is singled out for rebuke.

DETROIT. EXECUTIVES of automobile manufacturing companies are still loath to comment on future code regulation of usedcar trade-in allowances under the NRA. However, they favor it as a constructive measure and one long needed to give the retail branch of the automobile business some semblance of stability.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Norman Thomas, former Socialist candidate for President, praised the "New Deal" today as a tribute to the capacity of the American people and to the leadership of President Roosevelt. Simultaneously he criticized the recovery program as not going far enough in the direction of socialism.
To the Editor of THE New York Times Grover Whalen's appeal to a group of New York University students for their support of the NRA suggests a problem which the Recovery Act does not attempt to solve.

THE "Mellon Millions," of which Mr. O'Connor writes in this scathing biography of the former Secretary of the Treasury and Ambassador to the Court of St. James, had their beginning in June, 1839, when, "being then of the ripe age of 25, Thomas Mellon Esq., swung his shingle in front of his modest office on Fifth Avenue, Pittsburgh, some distance from the court house."

SOUTHAMPTON. -- There is every indication that the unusually crowded program of social and artistic events will continue throughout the remainder of the season. Already preparations are being made by many younger members of the colony as well as their elders for the entertainment of house parties, which will feature the last two important week-ends of the Summer.

PHILIP LINDSAY'S realistic portrait of Morgan the freebooter showed his ability to reproduce a brutal age with a stark truthfulness that precluded offense. This later historically accurate and finely imaginative attempt to re-create the tragic story of Henry VIII's final bid for personal and domestic happiness with his fifth Queen, Katherine Howard, is not so much a step as a leap forward in the same direction.

The new supply of crude oil in the United States during June was 84,984,000 barrels, the largest for that month since 1929 and an increase of 16.9 per cent from the 72,704,000 barrels in June last year, according to a compilation by William J. Kemnitzer, petroleum technologist, from data of the United States Bureau of Mines.

Protesting any curtailment of the air-mail service, as indicated in dispatches from Washington, the Merchants Association of New York has sent a letter and resolutions to Postmaster General Parley urging reduction in air-mail rates. Proposals to restrict the facilities for air mail were called "short-sighted economy."

WASHINGTON. AT 40 Sumner Welles finds himself the most-talked-of diplomat in the service of the United States Government. Largely through his efforts as mediator between the factions of Cuba, order is gradually being brought out of the chaos of that sorely beset country without the necessity of an intervention by the United States that might have been misconstrued by other nations of Latin America.

PARIS. IT is now three hundred years since Sebastien le Prestre Vauban was born, but the frontier which he engraved upon French soil still determines France's destiny. At Ypres and many another place the forts that Vauban built stood valiantly against German cannon fire, once again protecting French lives and French territory from the invading enemy.
FAR-REACHING, fundamental changes are likely in the political, economic and social structure of Cuba, and in her relations with the United States, as a result of the fall of Machado.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- The annual drive for the Memorial Hospital at North Conway terminates today, and all hotels at Jackson, Intervale, Kearsarge, Chocorua and the Con-ways have given entertainments to raise money for the fund.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 19. -- Nassau Hall, the original building of Princeton University, will be illuminated next Saturday night to mark the 150th anniversary of the bestowal upon George Washington of the thanks of the Continental Congress for his conduct of the Revolutionary War.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -- President Roosevelt intervened today in the labor dispute of the Kansas City Southern Railway after his special mediation board reported that the employes would not accept the proposed new wage scale.

TO Venezuela went Jonathan Norton Leonard, apparently in search of something different in civilization, something he would like better than the variety he was acquainted with in the United States. He found it. And he has written this book to tell others what it is like and how much he enjoyed it and that they'd better go there, too.
