TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 19. -- A four-track highway between Boston and Washington, avoiding all big cities and providing a forty-mile-an-hour rate of speed with safety has been approved by high-way officials of every one of the eight States involved, it was revealed here today.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The Summer exhibit of the Cooperstown Art Association opened here today in its temporary gallery at the Village Club for a showing of one week. One hundred and seventy-six items from the hands of fifty-six participants were viewed by large and enthusiastic groups of art lovers.
BOSTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -- The Braves took the opening game of a series from the Pirates today by a score of 5 to 2, making 12 hits off three pitchers, Meine, Hoyt and Chagnon.

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 19. -- Public utilities in New Hampshire under regulation of the State public service commission have been advised by the commission not to sign any NRA code until the commission has given its approval.

DETROIT, Aug. 19. -- Hubert ScottPaine, a smiling, jovial red-haired English boat builder, who hopes to beat Gar Wood in a Harmsworth Trophy race, arrived today to prepare for the contest that will be held on the St. Clair River about thirty-five miles north of here a fortnight hence.

VIENNA, Aug. 18. -- Amid much that was illuminating and even amusing the most important feature of the confiscated Nazi documents published this week by the Reichspost was their confirmation of reports that Hitlerite Germany was encouraging the formation of the Austrian legion.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 19. -- Dr. L.E. Estler of Arlington drove his pacing mare, Janet Dillon, to a straight-heat victory in the Wa- verly Pace, which featured the Weequahic Park matinee today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- Tony Lazzeri missed a desperate clutch for a blazing drive just over his head and to his right at Comiskey Park today, and the White Sox downed the Yankees, 8 to 7, in twelve innings. As a result, the McCarthymen now trail the Senators by eight and one-half games.

LONDON, Aug. 19. -- A group of British trade union leaders left for Amsterdam tonight to attend a meeting of an international committee which is arranging to defend the prisoners in the German Reichstag fire trial.

CHENGTU, China, July 11. -- Szechuan Province, buried deep in China, has its exponents of progress. Not the least of these is General Yang Sen, until ten years ago Governor of the province -- until the two Lius, uncle and nephew, united armies to shrink his political stature.

If the evolution of industry is to be toward greater consolidation, the partnership with the government should be strong enough to protect the consumer. The full answer on price adjustments will probably not be written for many years to come, but the issue is fundamental.

DETROIT, Aug. 19. -- Persons close to Henry Ford today advanced the prediction -- although admitting it was largely conjecture-that the Detroit manufacturer would not sign the code of the automobile industry, but would wait until its final terms were made known and then would "go it one better."

President Roosevelt will open with an address the 1933 Mobilization for Human Needs on Sept. 8 at the White House, according to an announcement made by Newton D. Baker, mobilization chairman, through the organization's office here.

The committees of the motionpicture industry at work since a week ago Tuesday to draft an NRA code, closed their sessions at the Bar Association Building at noon yesterday and left the work in the hands of skeleton continuing committees.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The highest minimum rates of pay yet proposed to the National Recovery Administration were provided for today in a code for the aviation industry, on which General Johnson set hearings for Thursday.

LONDON, Aug. 19. -- Asserting that for President Roosevelt the recovery campaign spells death or glory, The Sunday Times in its leading editorial says it is already clear that in certain initial particulars the American experiment is proving a disapointment.
The New York Times weekly index of business activity declined slightly for the week ended Aug. 12. The figure dropped to 89.2 from 89.8 in the previous week. A year ago the number was 64.2.

BROADCASTERS on vacation in regions west of the Hudson in River often return to the microphone with new ideas pertaining to radio showmanship. They are likely to learn more in two weeks on a trip across the countryside than from the mail received for a month.
An effort to break the speed boat record around Manhattan Island will be made today when a fleet of nearly twenty competes in a race that will start and finish, off Duffy's Yacht Landing.

PARIS, Aug. 19. -- France's wheat problem is beginning to assume political and social importance of great consequence. So far governmental action has not brought any solution and indeed it has seemed only to complicate the situation. Basically the problem is one of overproduction.

ALBANY, Aug. 19. -- The value of an investigation of the spread between the price paid to the farmer for his milk and that charged to the retail consumer was stressed in a letter from the Milk Control Board to Governor Lehman made public today.

The first day's operation of the new Queens links of the city subway system proceeded on exact schedule and without interruption of any kind, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday. The new lines, linking Manhattan to the Jackson Heights section of Queens, and Long Island City to the Greenpoint area in Brooklyn, were opened to the public at 12:01 A.M. yesterday.

THE author of this volume has collected and selected her material with excellent judgment and has put it together with imagination and an understanding of children's interests. The book contains a wealth of information about the customs and traditions, in English-speaking countries, connected with well-known holidays and others not so wellknown.

POCONO PINES, Pa., Aug. 19 (AP). -- America's "public enemy No. 1" was nominated today by Professor Walter A. Maier of the Concordia Lutheran Seminary, St. Louis, as the college professor who "takes the pay of Christian endowments" and then "poisons the brain and the heart and the soul of his students."

PARIS, Aug. 17. -- Louiseboulanger is dealing successfully with the nineteen-hundred fashion formula by making fitted, classic jacket tailleurs of stiff lacquered brocade. They are accompanied by ascots of satin, patterned with tiny flowers, or of lame and short-sleeved, striped net blouses made with a surplice decollete back and front.

DUBLIN, Aug. 18. -- Talk of a general election and speculation concerning the future of General Owen O'Duffy's National Guard are the dominant topics here after an anxious week in which the Blue Shirt leader canceled the church parades scheduled for Sunday in commemoration of Michael Collins, Arthur Griffith and Kevin O'Higgins, the founders of the Free State.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19. -- A mounting wave of wet votes from rural sections and cities tonight added Missouri to the twenty-one States voting to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment. In the generally light balloting the majority for repeal was running about 4 to 1.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19. -- Three more deaths from sleeping sickness, making a total of eleven since July 30 in the epidemic here, prompted fresh efforts by authorities today to find a means to check the malady.

Ferdinand Pecora, counsel to the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, is considering a recommendation that the government establish an agency to keep stock market investors posted on the actual value of their securities.

The sixty-eight Ellis Island employes who were retired from the service yesterday under the economy program of the immigration and naturalization bureau closed their desks and sadly bade goodbye to fellow-workers of many years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The publication of the "Diplomatic Dictionary" has just been made the occasion for an international meeting here under the auspices of the International Diplomatic Academy. Premier Edouard Daladier and members of the diplomatic corps were present.

DUBLIN, Aug. 17. -- In Ireland, as elsewhere, what people find puzzling about fascism is that the same word describes such different programs, as varied as are the colors of the suits worn by its adherents.

Thus far the National Recovery Act has been borne along on a sort of wave of popular enthusiasm. Emotional appeals to the patriotic spirit of America have been multiplied in a thousand ways, and have met with a response reaching Washington like the sound of many waters.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Aug. 19. -- Under the direction of Wilfred Pelletier of the Metropolitan Opera Association, the one-act opera "The Secret of Suzanne," as well as scenes from Massenet's "Manon." were presented in the auditorium last evening.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Selection of 450 new camp sites needed to continue through the Winter the work of the Civilian Conservation Corps, as authorized by President Roosevelt, will be soon made, Robert Fechner, director, announced today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 16. -- The lawyer whose own witness testifies unexpectedly against him in court is in a position not half so unhappy as that in which Alabama finds itself this week as a result of the lynching by a group of masked men last Sunday morning of two Negroes accused of the rape and murder of a white girl near Tuscaloosa.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 19. -- Death rode the highways in Northern Indiana early today, claiming ten lives in accidents near South Bend and Fort Wayne. Fourteen other persons were injured, most of them seriously.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 19. -- The Brooklyn Cricket Club lost to the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton eleven at Warinanco Park today. It was the first defeat of the season for the losers in the annual championship series of the Metropolitan and New Jersey Cricket Association.

Grain and cotton markets made a partial recovery yesterday after their unsettlement of Friday and there were other fresh indications of returning financial confidence. These markets had a clear field and a monopoly upon such speculative interest as could be aroused on a sultry Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Fair competition codes for the steel, oil and lumber industries were signed by President Roosevelt a short while before he left tonight for a few days' rest at his mother's estate at Hyde Park on the Hudson River.

BAR HARBOR -- Summer is never more lovely than, in these late days of August on Mount Desert, but beneath its warmth there are occasional whiffs of Autumn chill, and crimson flecks appearing on the hillsides remind the Summer guests that it is not long before the social season of 1933 is ended.

Next month approximately $136,000,000 of German dollar bonds marketed here since the war will go into default under the German Government's decree of June 9 halting payments on foreign bonded debt in terms of foreign currencies. The interest due on these bonds in September amounts to less than $4,500,000 and the amortization to less than $2,250,000.

IN approaching contemporary Chinese literature the literary critic is most struck by the short story. There are poems, plays, essays, criticisms, novels and biographies being published in China but all are exceedingly experimental and bewildered, so that one can doubt their enduring vitality with the exception perhaps of a few Something in the form of the short story has made it more successful.

HAVANA, Aug. 19. -- President De Cespedes at 10:15 o'clock tonight [11:15 New York time] broadcast a message to the American people over an international radio hookup of the Columbia broadcasting system. John T. Wilford, publisher and editor of The Havana American News, introduced Cuba's Chief Executive.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- President Roosevelt left for Hyde Park at 11 o'clock tonight, hopeful of finding some time for relaxation at his mother's estate, Hyde Park House, on the bluffs overlooking the Hudson River.

THE automobile, which with allied industries is largely represented at the Chicago World's Fair, is to have a week of its own, Sept. 2-9. A parade of motor cars will inaugurate the celebration, in which exhibitors of automobiles and automotive accessories will participate.

To the Editor of The NEW YORK TIMES: "The only way to prevent war in this modern complicated world of ours is to organize the principal nations by treaty, disarmament and close association in a league of nations such that it will be impossible for one or more nations suddenly to face the world with an ultimatum or imperialistic program that will lead to war."

LAKE PLACID. -- Notable among the Adirondack sports events of this week will be the first annual Saranac Inn Country Club invitation golf championship, opening on the Saranac Inn course on Tuesday for the Connable Trophy, presented by Frank Lee Connable of New York City, president of the club.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- Man o' War sent one of his grandsons out to- day to gallop to a surprising victory in the $5,000 added Hawthorne Juvenile Handicap.

DIAMOND POINT, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- F.W. Kavanaugh's brownhulled Dodge runabout, Chief II, gained the first leg on the Governor Lehman Cup today in the feature event of the Lake George Club's motor boat regatta.

A NEW and dramatic chapter in the history of the sea will begin in a few days, when operations to salvage the treasure of the British frigate Lutine, sunk off the coast of Holland in 1799, will begin. In the hold of the vessel there is, it is estimated, more than $10,000,000 in gold and silver.

In the following comparisons the index numbers of employment and payrolls for July complied by the Labor Bureau of the Department of Commerce are based on returns from eighty-nine industries since the end of 1930 and on fifty-four for earlier dates.

BERLIN, Aug. 18. -- The Zionist Congress opening Monday in Prague is probably of more lively interest to the new Germany than was the World Economic Conference. It is apprehended that the Zionist meeting may eventuate in some action. It may stir up more animosities abroad, and it may restimulate boycott tendencies here.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The skippers in the sixteenth championship race of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound had to contend with a number of weather changes for their races off Travers Island today.

Peace and prosperity cannot come to Europe until territorial claims have been abandoned, declares Albert Guerard in an article in September Current History entitled, "Redraw the Map of Europe?" in which he discusses revisionist aspirations in the light of history and present realities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The National Recovery Administration, through Hugh S. Johnson, administrator, informed today the proponents of twenty-nine separate codes for the bituminous coal industry that the administration wished to have one broad, simple code.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (AP). -- The Indians took a firmer grip on third place today by defeating the Red Sox, 6 to 5.

PARIS, Aug. 19. -- The bargemen on the rivers and canals of Northern France went on strike today. By tying their boats together and jamming them across the waterways they have stopped all traffic on the Aisne and Oise rivers and they are now threatening to set up a big blockade across the lower Seine.

It is evident from the grim contest that has been going on in Washington that the steel industry is concerned over the safety of its sacred open-shop principle. There is to be a ninety-day test of a makeshift code approved tentatively by the NRA.

GENEVA, Aug. 19. -- Efforts are being made on a new basis behind the scenes both in Washington and Paris to improve Franco-American relations, according to private information reaching Geneva. The Franco-American "peacemakers" are represented as being encouraged to continue their long job by progress they feel they are making.

Daniel Frohman, dean of the American theatre, whose managerial experiences cover more than half a century, will celebrate his eighty-second birthday on Tuesday. Who's Who says that Mr. Frohman was born in 1853, which would make him two years younger, but the producer does not seem to mind revealing his real age.

MONTREAL, Aug. 19. -- Frank Hawks was the first arrival this afternoon on the good-will flight of planes from Roosevelt Field, N.Y., to the Canadian Air Pageant at St. Hubert. Hazy atmospheric conditions and low ceiling in the vicinity of New York hampered the flight.

A code of fair practice establishing a 32-hour week and a minimum wage at the rate of $1.40 an hour for glaziers and setters, and 37 1/2 cents to 75 cents for apprentices was forwarded to Washington yesterday by the Consolidated Flat Glass Setters' Association through the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce which directed the preparation of the code.

Marked let-downs in manufacturing and wholesale trade reflected in last week's reports from Federal Reserve centres were accompanied by further improvement in retail trade and in the financial situation generally, indicating that adjustment between production and consumption is well under way.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 16. -- All along the bends and reaches of the big river from Cairo to New Orleans the swing of the shovel will, in a few days, herald the resumption of flood control work and with it, the temporary adjustment of the differences in departmental Washington that have halted the Mississippi River project since Aug. 1 and thrown thousands out of employment.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Administration efforts to work out an agreement to raise prices in the American sugar market approached a successful conclusion today when domestic beet growers finally agreed to accept a quota of 1,750,000 tons.
VIENNA, Aug. 19. -- A striking appeal for Russian famine victims, who he declared were likely to be numbered once more by the million, was made today by Cardinal Innitzer, Archbishop of Vienna.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Aug. 12 amounted to 622,759 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 9,647 cars, or 1.6 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 110,794 cars, or 21.6 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, but 120,867 cars, or 16.3 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

Colonel Carlos Mendieta sailed for Havana aboard the steamship Morro Castle yesterday afternoon at the head of a group of anti-Machado Cubans who were exiles in New York during the last months of the Machado regime.
The Star Class international championship series of races will be contested at Long Beach, Calif., starting on Friday and extending until Sept. 30.

BOSTON, Aug. 16. -- For the assistance of owners who are in peril of losing their homes there are now available in all New England two Federal relief agencies, and in Massachusetts they may obtain assistance also from the State. The Federal Home Loan Bank for the New England District is now getting well under way.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (AP). -- The body of James E. Gray, 49, a widely traveled mechanical engineer, was found beside a lonely road in suburban Euclid today, the victim of a corrosive poison.

A mediation board to settle labor and other controversies brought befor the city committee of the President's Emergency Re-employment Campaign was appointed yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, chairman. The mediation board is composed of three representatives each of the public, labor and employer groups.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A legalized massacre of prong-horned antelope occurred in Wyoming in 1929. Tame through long protection, these rare animals were mowed down en masse like sheep and within a few days after the season opened the automobiles of so-called hunters were literally glutted with antelope carcasses.
MOSCOW, Aug. 18. -- There are interesting contrasts and parallels between the three great European "dictatorships" -- that is, single-party authorities which brook no rival or opposition.

ASBURY PARK. -- Summer colonists of the North Jersey shore are looking forward to the testimonial dinner to be given to Postmaster General James A. Farley tomorrow night at the Ross Fenton Farm when, for the first time this season, members of the social set will mingle with political leaders of the State and nation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The steel industry code, signed by President Roosevelt tonight, contains several important changes in provisions governing maximum hours of work and the administration and duration of the code. An official summary gives these changes as follows:

STARTING today, 6,000 motionpicture theatres will display specially prepared NRA film as the motion-picture industry's initial contribution to a program helpful to the President's emergency re-employment campaign. The film will be in the form of trailers, featuring outstanding screen personalities.

Parliamentary oratory has changed in Great Britain as everywhere else. The old grand style of GLADSTONE with its rolling periods and classic quotations is heard no more in the House of Commons. The tendency is in the direction of shorter and more direct speeches, largely in the manner of an animated conversation.

EVERY pleasant Sunday morning from May 30 until Labor Day or later, thousands of hikers leave the city by ferry, train or subway and thousands more in automobiles -- not necessarily to take long walks, but many of them to stroll or picnic in the woods.

IN the increased speeds of the air mail and the consequent increased realization of the values of these same speeds, two weaknesses stand out. Both apply locally and perhaps generally. One weakness lies in the handling of the mail between airport and postoffice and the other in the fact that the airplane, for all its speed, fails to serve the two greatest cities in the east as between each other, New York and Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Adoption of "a sound business-like annual naval building program, continuous in its planning, to reduce demands on the taxpayer was advocated in a radio speech tonight by Admiral William H. Standley, Chief of Naval Operations.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Chuck Klein's mighty bat, the bludgeon which is leading the National League in batting and home runs, poled out three four-baggers today to contribute largely toward the Phillies' twin triumph over the Reds.

DUBLIN, Irish Free State, Aug. 19 (AP). -- The Free State entered another week-end of political anxiety with hundreds of Blue Shirt National Guard parades scheduled for tomorrow throughout the country.

A field of eight boats, four challengers and four defenders, will compete for the classic Gold Cup in the three thirty-mile heats which will be held at Detroit on Sept. 1, it was announced yesterday by Charles F. Chapman, secretary of the Gold Cup Contest Board.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 18. -- Am- bassador Daniels and former President Calles have met for the first time since the former's appointment as the envoy of the United States to Mexico.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The birth controllers are "beginning to show their hands. In THE NEW YORK TIMES Aug. 6, Guy Irving Burch argues for control of population by contraception. He is probably aware that the masses will not control population by artificial means.
The establishment of the five-day working week under the NRA is making possible the observance of the Jewish Sabbath, according to the Jewish Education Association of New York.

After a loss of about $1 a bale in the early trading yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved nearly $2 and ended 10 to 15 points higher than on Friday. A better tone in the wheat market and the menace of three tropical disturances moving toward cotton-growing States created more support, while week-end covering helped the advance.

GENEVA, Aug. 18. -- Efforts are being made on a new basis, behind the scenes both in Washington and Paris, to improve Franco-American relations, according to private information reaching here. The "peacemakers" at work are represented as being encouraged to continue their long job by the progress they feel they are making.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Aug. 16. -- North and South California have buried the hatchet so far as political differences are concerned, and for a couple of years there has been less talk than usual over a divided State, but now the war dogs are loose again.
ALBANY, Aug. 19. -- Senator John J. Dunnigan charged today that Republican legislators were blocking the New York City Tax Bill to aid the fusion campaign against Mayor O'Brien.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 16. -- Rated until recently as one of the two driest States in the Union, and now seen by the prohibitionists as virtually their last hope, North Carolina seems headed straight for repeal. The drys are making a determined campaign, and they will begin beating the tom-toms in earnest at rallies scheduled in every county on Sunday, Sept. 3.
MONTREAL, Aug. 19 (AP). -- The Newark Bears won their second straight game of the series from Montreal tonight, 5 -- 4, but only by just surviving a Royal rally in the ninth.
NEW YORK. Sydney J. Smith has returned to the Pierre from Saratoga Springs.

PARIS, Aug. 4. APART from the Comedie Francaise and the Odeon, and without counting the Opera or the four theatres giving musical plays, there are only three leading theatres open in Paris. Two of these have holiday programs and holiday companies, and only one, the Palais-Royal, boasts a play that was produced during the full season -- and this is now being performed by the understudies.

THERE can be composers in words. There have been. Their forms are sometimes patterned after elaborate musical structures. How many today know De Quincey's "DreamFugue"? It has its prelude, its subjects and counter-subjects, episodes and stretto, and a magnificent organ point and coda.

Mrs. William Walker Rockwell, a member of the national board of the Y.W.C.A. and prominent as a welfare organizer, was killed yesterday when the automobile in which she was riding with her husband and daughter swerved from the road, plowed through a fence and turned over north of Farmington, Conn.

PASADENA, Cal. WPARKER LYON went out to buy a stamp and came home with a stage coach. In that way did this retired capitalist of Pasadena start what has become the largest collection of California gold-rush relics ever assembled in one place.

A FEW months ago when the future of the Metropolitan Opera seemed in doubt and a campaign was under way to raise a guarantee fund of $300,000 there were many ready to pronounce the last words over the corpse that was opera.

VIENNA, Aug. 19. -- Johann Kern, a workman, who was arrested in Salzburg after an illicit trip to Berlin, is stated to have confessed he had returned with the intention of assassinating Chancellor Dollfuss, War Minister Vaugoin and Security Minister Fey.

TOKYO. RECENT acts of the Japanese and American Governments raise the question whether the nations may not have been wrong when they thought that the Washington conference of 1921-22 and the London conference of 1930 had found the way to keep naval rivalries within safe limits.

THIS book presents the results of a thorough study of the cotton growing and marketing situation in its relation to the establishment and growth of cotton cooperatives in the Southeastern States. Of Its two authors, Mr. Gee is Professor of Rural Economics in the University of Virginia and director of that institution's Institute for Research in the Social Sciences, while Mr. Terry is research associate in the University.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Buffalo captured both ends of a double-header from Jersey City tonight winning by 5 to 1 in a seven-inning twilight affair and 8 to 5 under the lights.

LAKELAND, Fla., Aug. 15. -- While shots fired in the Cuban revolution last week were heard more or less distinctly around the world, some of the loudest of the repercussions were heard in Florida, where economic interests are involved with the insular commerce in no small way.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 17:

BOLTON LANDING - ON - LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Nearly 500 spectators watched William Aydelotte, former national indoor champion, defeat two opponents, Selden Crary and Robert Stevens, in the Sagamore tennis tournament today.

WHEN Wall Street is deserted by its milling crowds by day and lower Broadway looks forlorn, one knows that another week-end has come. It is then that the highways throb with motor cars and the beaches are alive with a solid mass of humanity: the metropolis floods the countryside.

THE development of the porphyry copper mines, which include that group of the coppers characterized by uniformity and huge size of ore body, with low average per ton metal value, deserves more consideration from the student of American life than a brief mention under mining history.

Just before leaving yesterday for Europe on the Ile de France, Samuel Seabury issued a statement assailing Tammany as "a quasi-criminal organization" and urging the election of the fusion ticket to rehabilitate the credit of the city.

ROME, Aug. 19. -- A large expedition of Italian scientists, headed by Bruno Rossi, Professor of Physics at the University of Padua, is about to leave for Asmara in the Italian colony of Eritrea. East Africa, to conduct experiments aiming to establish the true nature of the cosmic rays.

The company that is being formed by the Socony-Vacuum Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey to conduct their operations in the Far East will include the marketing outlets of Socony-Vacuum in India. These outlets are being supplied now by the Soviet under a contract which runs until 1937 and which, it is understood, will be carried out by the new jointly owned company.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- Final prep- arations were completed today for tomorrow's deciding match in the first East-West polo series of history.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Another President -- another Roosevelt -- has taken in hand that problem child of American business, the bituminous coal industry.

HOLLYWOOD. THE town stirred a little this week and a degree of interest entered the midsummer monotony of the cinema. Anna Sten was presented by Samuel Goldwyn, and Greta Garbo, emerging from a year of obscurity, created a moment of excitement with the announcement of John Gilbert's return to the screen.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The members of the Wichita "Omnibus College" have done well to call attention, as mentioned in THE NEW YORK TIMES, to the fact that the French spoken in Quebec was found by them to be lacking in purity.

LONDON, Aug. 19. -- The Zionist Congress, opening Monday at Prague, will voice the greatest Jewish grievance in centuries, and will, therefore, be of greater importance than almost any of its seventeen predecessors. The congress meets in the shadow of the greatest calamity which has befallen the Jews in modern times -- the anti-Jewish crusade in Germany.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The War Department issued the following orders today: Davids, Col. H.G., Inf., about Sept. 27 to Fort Sam Houston, Texas.
LONDON, Aug. 19. -- Germany today defeated Great Britain, 76 to 59, in a track and field meet at White City.

THOSE who think of ancient Rome as a city of togas, of eloquent speeches and glorious wars would do well to read this book in order to bring the city closer to their understanding and to realize that, when all is said and done, the Romans were a people very much like ourselves.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Postmaster General James A. Farley will return to his native county tomorrow for the seventh annual clambake of the Rockland County Democratic Club at the German Masonic Home grounds at Tappan. Mr. Farley will come from the Elmira convention with the Rockland County delegation.

HONOLULU, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Honolulu police said today they believed they had broken up an organization of gun-runners that had surreptitiously imported firearms into Hawaii and distributed them to aliens and Filipino plantation laborers.

Governor Lehman and former Governor Alfred E. Smith will lecture at Columbia University this Fall during the twenty-first season of the Columbia University Institute of Arts and Sciences, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Russell Potter, director.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 19. -- Several years ago when a State boxing commission was created Dr. Drury was named a member because of his interest in and knowledge of the sport.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Cecil Smith, the Western polo player, was arrested today on a criminal attack charge made by Miss Eugenie Rose, 23, a nurse.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Orme Wilson of New York, assistant chief of the division of Latin-American affairs in the State Department, has been designated as first secretary of the embassy in Berlin.

Figures of the Treasury Department published last week measure the progress toward restoring normal banking conditions since the panic of last March. They show that 13,951 institutions are now operating without restrictions, while 2,870 are still closed or are functioning on a restricted basis.

DETROIT, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Fred Marberry of the Tigers was robbed of a perfect game against the Athletics today when Foxx and McNair singled in the eighth inning, but he did give the Tigers a 6-to-0 victory.

THERE is no remedy for the acute embarrassment which assails one when a novelist of Booth Tarkington's attainments produces so inept and tedious a book as "Presenting Lily Mars." Were it the work of a new writer one could shrug it aside with the cavalier gesture which it deserves.

Indications that the controversial points which so far have held up completion of the master code for the grocery trade will be ironed out this week and the finished code submitted for governmental approval were seen here yesterday, as the executive committee entrusted with forming the code made plans for meeting with administration representatives in Washington.
LONDON, Aug. 19. -- Douglas Fairbanks's announcement that he was forsaking Hollywood for England was taken by the British press today to spell the doom of the California centre of the film world.

TOKYO, Aug. 19. -- The little fingers of nine persons, preserved in a bottle of alcohol, were produced today at the court martial of army cadets who are accused of complicity in the assassination of Premier Ki Inukai in May, 1932.

THE Columbia Company continues to give us surprises. Though for one month it omitted to Issue an album set, the company continues regularly to supply extraordinarily sound and varied fare, within the scope of what three years ago would have been regarded as a short list.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The daily newspapers published by Westchester Newspapers, Inc., of which J. Noel Macy is president and Hugh W. Robertson editorial vice president, hailed today the thirty-seventh anniversary of the present management of THE NEW YORK TIMES in an editorial entitled "A Great Newspaper Achievement."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- James A. Farley, as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, today addressed a telegraphic appeal to the voters of the State of Washington for a favorable vote on prohibition repeal in their special election Aug. 29.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 19 (AP). -- Dr. Samuel Fortier, University of California professor and former chief of the irrigation investigation bureau of the United States Department of Agriculture, died here last night at the age of 78.
The women's crew from the Indi- an Harbor Yacht Club of Greenwich, Conn., will set out for the championship tests off Cohasset, Mass., next month with a very definite purpose.

WASHINGTON. THE importance of the public domain of the United States is being emphasized by officials of the Roosevelt administration in carrying forward the new deal. The latest indication of such recognition was given when Secretary of the Interior Ickes, reversing the action of his Republican predecessors, ordered all private fences removed from the public domain in the West so that the land might be open to every one for grazing purposes on equal terms.

A letter declaring that the demand for unemployment relief is still heavy and that it will probably continue so during the Winter was made public yesterday by the Welfare Council of New York City, after copies had been sent to relief officials.

THIS newest addition to the excellent series of small monographs whose purpose is to present in book form rapid resumes of the advances that have been made in important branches of scientific endeavor, has anthroplogy for its theme.
OUT of the fog loomed a moving shadow -- a colossues of a man descending on me with his right hand upraised and his left carrying what might have been a Brobdingnagian bludgeon grasped in the middle.
LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes and Mrs. Hughes, who are at the Sagamore, have been guests of honor at several social gatherings along the Bolton Road.

PARIS, Aug. 19. -- President Roosevelt's firm tone with the oil, steel, coal and automobile industries and General Johnson's determination for quick action have roused new interest here in the giant undertaking which the President and administration have in hand.

PARIS, July 29, 1933. THANKS to the appearance of the Monte Carlo Ballet, the Paris season ended with some excellent performances. This troupe, which continues the tradition of Diaghileff's Russian Ballet, gave interesting ballets last year, but this season, enriched by many new talented artists, disciplined and unified, it impressed one as by far the best troupe we have seen since the death of Diaghileff.

IN his "Contract Bridge Omnibus," Harold Thorne has set forth, in as condensed a form as is practicable, the difference between the various systems of contract bridge which are now in vogue. This book is intended for the use of bridge enthusiasts who, skilled and experienced though they may be, have found themselves at a loss when paired off with partners using different and unfamiliar conventions.

PUBLIC opinion in New York City is aroused as it has not been in a generation. Public opinion here grew incredibly complacent in the decade of the Twenties, for one reason because large numbers of middle-class home owners had been attracted, or had fled, to the suburbs, leaving behind them an unusually high proportion of the very rich and the very-poor, both of which groups are by nature preoccupied.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Five additional registration statements covering proposed issues of $1,315,000 were filed with the Federal Trade Commission today under the Securities Act. The total amount of securities proposed in such statements to date is $175,346,400.

NOW that the Federal Government has announced its determination to wage active combat against crimes of violence coupled with extortion, perpetrated by organized gangsters and instigated by those who plan their work, it is of primary importance for the law-abiding citizen to understand the problem fully.

IF there is one fact which seems to have been established by the events of recent years it is that Solomon was wrong when he wrote. "The thing that hath been, it is that which shall be; and that which is done is that which shall be done; and there is no new thing under the sun."

To the Editor of The NEW YORK TIMES: "Classic statue found on Maine coast. Do you want it?" seemed the perfect telegram to send to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But the impulse was checked by realization that the new wing which that institution would have to erect to accommodate the treasure must be at least eight miles in height.
One of the most remarkable rallies in the history of the women's national tennis championship was witnessed yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19, -- Had the full 1933 cotton crop been per- mitted to mature, the South would be "face to face with the dire consequences of four or five cent cotton," C.A. Cobb, Chief of the Cotton Production Section of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, said today.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Aug. 19. -- Edward V. Quinn's brilliant jump- ers, Lord Erin and Your Way, from the Claredda Farm at Shrewsbury, today were named champion hunter and reserve, respectively, at the closing session of the two-day Mon- mouth County Country Club Horse Show.

PTTTSFIELD, Mass. -- Sheffield, a typical Southern Berkshire town with a wide, elm-shaded Main Street lined with ancient houses reminiscent of old Deerfield, is to celebrate its 200th anniversary on Friday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19. -- Frank Shields, following his victory yesterday over the national champion, Ellsworth Vines, won the singles final of the fifty-second annual Newport Casino tennis tournament today by blasting his way through the formidable Wilmer Allison, 1 -- 6, 11 -- 9, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Charles Diel of the Mount Vernon Y.M.C.A. Aquatic Club and Miss Syralda Carrabine of the Orienta Beach Club shared the honors in the second annual Northern Westchester County swimming meet in the Pleasantville pool today.

IRAQ, the land of the Garden of Eden, is in difficulties. Released from Britain's mandate last October as a country capable of self-government and admitted into the League, she has recently witnessed sanguinary battle between factions of her own people.

To the Editor of The New York Times : S. Boyd Darling's letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES leaves the reader with the impression that the legislative, the executive or administrative, and the judicial functions of government can be in truth, and indeed are, separated.

ROME, Aug. 19. -- Chancellor Dollfuss of Austria arrived unexpectedly at Rimini by airplane late this afternoon for a series of conferences with Premier Mussolini, who is spending a few days' vacation with his family at Riccione, a seaside resort near by. Dr. Dollfuss is expected to fly back to Vienna early next week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Decision on the controversial issue of price-fixing and production control in the oil industry was left with President Roosevelt in the code for that group which he signed tonight.
BOGOTA, Aug. 19. -- Liberal Representatives have presented in the Colombian House an Agrian Land Expropriation and Distribution Bill which EI Tiempo asks all Liberals to support.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 18, unless otherwise specified.

The next big golf event on the local program will be the John G. Anderson memorial tournament at Winged Foot on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. This event, inaugurated a few years ago by the late Mr. Anderson, is one of the most enjoyable tournaments of the year.

"ROCKABYE baby on the housetop." That is the way the old rhyme will now have to go, for in its ascent skyward New York has not forgotten its children. For them it has rediscovered the roofs of which it once was conscious only when they leaked.

PHOTOGRAPHIC murals, though wholly modern, may yet be used with admirable results to assist in creating period effects. Not only are complete photographic wall coverings and wall panelings possible, but friezes, dadoes, ornamental borders and over-door decorations can be successfully executed in this new medium.

NEW YORK CITY is today floundering in an extraordinary financial morass. The municipal government cannot meet the demands made upon it for the remaining months of the year for work and home relief amounting to less than $25,000,000; it cannot borrow for this purpose because its credit is impaired; it cannot give adequate tax relief to the distressed real estate owners because successive years of extravagant administration have saddled the city with ever-increasing debts.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 19. -- Alpha Sigma Rho climbed from fifth place to lead the twenty-one Rutgers fraternities in scholarship during the past year, it was announced today by Luther H. Martin, registrar. Lambda Chi Alpha, ninth last year, rose to second place, and Omicron Alpha Tau and Theta Chi retained their third and fourth place listings.

BANFF, Alta., Aug. 19 (Canadian Press). -- Danger threatened if application of the National Industrial Recovery Act in the United States, leading to higher wages and higher costs, resulted in competition of foreign products, declared Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institute, Washington, and Assistant Secretary of State in the Wilson administration, addressing the Institute of Pacific Relations.

Life insurance companies throughout the country are beginning to get their share of the business improvement which has resulted jointly from the rehabilitation of public sentiment and the increase in buying power since the end of March. Gross volumes of underwriting are still running somewhat behind last year, but the long period of increasing declines is believed to have been terminated.

BUFFOONERY and subtlety, foolishness and wisdom, madness and sanity, are linked in the picturization, of Gertrude Tonkonogy's play, "Three-Cornered Moon," which evoked such constant mirth from Paramount audiences that It has been held over at that theatre for a second week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Recovery Administrator Johnson took steps today to block the possible evasion of the President's Re-employment Agreement by certain restaurant owners, who had sought to retrieve the extra labor costs imposed by the Blue Eagle by charging waiters for their meals.

The Japanese swimmers came to their first Olympic Games at Antwerp in 1920 using the antiquated sidestroke as a means of propulsion through the water. They came to their fourth Olympic Games at Los Angeles in 1932 using the fastest crawl stroke that man has ever seen.

Jack Crawford of Australia, the most celebrated tennis player of the year with the exception of Frederick Perry of England, will make his first American appearance of the season in the national doubles championship starting tomorrow at the Longwood Cricket Club, Brookline, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -- The code for the lumber and timber products industry, including production control and minimum price provisions, establishes a forty-hour maximum work week but allows for forty-eight hours at seasonal peaks. Minimum wages range from 23 cents to 42 1/2 cents an hour, representing in some instances a 100 per cent increase.
PARIS, Aug. 19. -- France's wheat problem is beginning to assume great political and social importance.

THE recent appearance of Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman and their groups at the Lewisohn Stadium constituted a novelty in that they marked the debut of this admirable ensemble in the outdoors series. The more important news involved in the engagement, however, is to be found in the fact that it was the first public appearance of Miss Humphrey in nearly a year and a half.
LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Aug. 19. -- With a field of fifty drivers, the first heats of the New Jersey State outboard championship races were held today. The finals will be run tomorrow afternoon.

PROVIDENCE. AN entirely novel form of airship structure, tested with favorable results by the Guggenheim School of Aeronautics, New York University, has been designed by Roland B. Respess of Wickford and Cranston, R.I., and is to be laid before government officials for approval.

HAVANA, Aug. 19. -- Stories of torture were unfolded in detail at historic Atares Fortress today as high army authorities launched an investigation into the finding of four bodies buried in a horse stable there. The bodies, which had lain in the shallow graves from three to eighteen months, were those of men who had opposed the Machado administration.

The failure of trade association members to use widely the cost accounting systems prepared for them by their groups is revealed in a survey which was released to THE TIMES yesterday by the National Association of Cost Accountants. Of seventy-two associations in the manufacturing field replying to the accountants' questionnaire, only forty-seven had at some time or other devised and recommended a uniform cost accounting system.

GUGLIELMO MARCONI startled television experimenters, who are planning for ultra-short wave image broadcast, during the past week by announcing that the micro-waves in his latest tests carry beyond the horizon. Heretofore, the tiny waves have been termed quasi-optical because they travel in straight lines and fly over the earth's curvature like sparks off a grinding wheel.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19. -- Despite her nineteen years, Gerard B. Lambert's America's Cup yacht Vanitie won the King's Cup race off here today.

Following the receipt of advices from Washington that mobilization of the whole nation for signing up consumers under the NRA would begin on Aug. 28, W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Committee for the State, yesterday asked State, country and community chairmen who may have begun their campaigns to defer completing them until the end of the month.

The London Economist, recognizing the failure of the London conference to grapple with deadlocked international trade, considers dispassionately such efforts as are being made for purely nationalist recuperation. Its discussion of the "industrial recovery campaign" in the United States is sympathetic, but in the matter of prediction non-committal.

Because of the closing of the security exchanges, business in Wall Street yesterday was of much less than the usual Saturday proportions. Most of the brokerage personnel and all the professional traders took a holiday. The banks were open as usual, and perfunctory dealings in foreign exchange took place.
Tales for Children. Alice looked up from the morning paper and stared off into the distance.

THE thirty-two letters contained in this little book are copied from the Harry Elkins Widener collection in the Harvard College Library and are here published, with the permission of Sir Henry F. Dickens, for the first time.

THE subject of the frequent inadequacy of road signs, on which some comment has been made in these columns, is one which periodically agitates highway designers and safety connoisseurs. They disagree on a number of particulars, save on the point that in too many instances the markers fail as guides for the motorist.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP). -- President Roosevelt reached into the writing profession today to fill two diplomatic posts, appointing Meredith Nicholson, Indiana author, to be Minister to Paraguay, and Leo R. Sack, Washington newspaper man, as Minister to Costa Rica.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- The Chicago Board of Trade, founded in 1848, a leading factor in the upbuilding of this city and the Central West, has been in an inactive condition since Aug. 1. Between four and five hundred grain traders have done little more than sit about for the past two weeks, smoking and swapping stories.

Winthrop Rockefeller, 21-year-old son of John D. Rockefeller Jr., landed at the Newark Airport shortly before 3 P. M. yesterday after a flight from Fort Worth, Texas, and laughed at reports that he was being guarded against kidnappers.

TOPEKA, Aug. 16. -- The people Of Kansas, amazed at one of the biggest bond forgery scandals the Middle West ever has known, and realizing that trusted State officials as well as prominent citizens have perpetrated frauds that may exceed more than a million dollars, face serious contemplation of their theories and practices of government.

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, who has been acting as mediator in the dispute between the Republican organization and the fusionists over the make-up of the Queens ticket, expressed the belief yesterday that a satisfactory settlement would be reached by tomorrow.

Without fanfare or ceremony two Italian submarines and their tenders, called drifters, arrived in New York harbor yesterday with about 200 officers and seamen. The submarines were the Balilla and the Millelire, and the drifters were the Mateucci and Biglieri.

SCANT attention was paid to Professor Walter B. Cannon of Harvard when he first presented, before the alumni of Massachusetts Institute of Technology last February, a program for economic stabilization, based on his knowledge of the functioning of the human body.

MOSCOW, Aug. 19 (AP). -- Denying the charge by Cardinal Innitzer of Austria that millions have died of starvation in Soviet Russia in the past few months, a Foreign Office official tonight said: "There is no cannibalism and, I may say, there are no Cardinals in Soviet Russia."

SUMTER, S.C., Aug. 19 (AP). -- Sometime cotton acreage reduction figures may have to be revised, for G.C. Rowland, a Sumter banker, has developed five-lock-boll cotton to take the place of the usual four-lock-boll.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 (AP). -- Missouri today stood as the twentysecond State to have voted the Twenty-first (repeal) Amendment. In an election which aroused little interest and gave the expected overwhelming majority in favor of prohibition repeal, in excess of 600,000 voters yesterday supported the repeal cause by more than 3 to 1.
Government that will mature within the next twelve months amount to $2,950,820,200. They consist of Treasury certificates of indebtedness, notes and non-interest-bearing discount bills.

DUBLIN, Aug. 20 -- Despite the government's warnings, the Blue Shirts held meetings in almost every town of the Free State today and observed two minutes of silence in memory of Arthur Griffith, Michael Collins and Kevin O'Higgins.
Eck Calder's brown-hulled run-about, Let's Go, won the around Manhattan Island motor-boat race yesterday, gaining a disputed victory over Don Ferraro and the latter's Jackie B.

LAKE HOPATCONG, N.J., Aug. 20 -- Fred Jacoby Jr. of North Bergen today captured the William C. Schantz Memorial Trophy race, which brought to a close the two-day New Jersey outboard championship regatta.
NUREMBERG, Aug. 20 -- The eyes of German Nazidom are turned these days to Nuremberg, where, on Aug. 30, the first national congress of the only legal party in Germany is to open.

BOLTON LANDING-ON-LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Before the largest gallery ever to witness a tennis match here. William Aydelotte of Schenectady won the men's singles final of the Sagamore tennis tournament today. The former national indoor champion beat a clubmate, Rufus Burbridge, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 20 -- Mr. and Mrs. Paul Pryibil of Bogheid, Glen Cove, who have leased the Gables for the rest of the season, gave a luncheon today at the Meadow Club for Count and Countess Giuseppe Cippico of Rome, who are visiting them. Among their other guests were:

Raymond L. Ditmars, curator of reptiles and mammals at the Bronx Zoo, plans to sail on Thursday for Panama for an excursion into the thick jungles of the Madden Dam area. He will he a passenger on the United Fruit Company's liner Veragua.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Hugh S. Johnson has tentatively set mid-November, or the end of the year at the latest, for his retirement from the epochal task of setting industry back on its feet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Reflecting the condition of the national banks of the United States for the first time since the March holiday, a report today by Controller of the Currency J. F. T. O'Connor showed that resources of the 4,902 licensed institutions amounted June 30 to $20,860,491,000.

TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 21 -- Emperor Hirohito led into Tokyo Bay this morning the greatest armada ever commanded by any Japanese ruler. Since Friday night the fleet has been steaming homeward at 15 knots from out at sea thousands of miles to the south where, in a mimic clash of capital ships, it concluded its grand ennial manoeuvres.

The rules of fair competition in the building industry are expected to be adopted in code form by the middle of September, according to the current Dow Service Dally Building Reports. The codification of building practices was prepared by the Construction League of the United States and submitted to General Hugh Johnson on Aug. 7.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Without their pilot and with their greatest box-office magnet an early casualty, the Yankees took two games from the White Sox today at Comiskey Park. Forty-three thousand fans, the second largest crowd of the season here, saw the contests.

It is still too early to forecast the effect of the operation of the National Recovery Act on the North American Company and its subsidiaries, says Frank L. Dame, president of the company, in his quarterly letter to stockholders.

RICCIONE, Italy, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Independence of Austria is the principal basis of her international policy. Chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss told Premier Mussolini here today, according to a communique issued after the conference.
ALBANY, Aug. 20 -- Major crimes in New York State in the first half of 1933 decreased 15.8 per cent, according to data made public today by Dr. Walter N. Thayer, State Commissioner of Correction.

In the first public demonstration of an air-conditioned automobile, a group of persons rode about the city yesterday and did not inhale any of the fumes of heavy traffic. A cool and equable temperature was maintained inside the car.

Charles H. Tuttle, former United States Atorney, who was named recently as chairman of the Republican city-wide campaign committee, announced yesterday the appointment of Colonel Henry Rogers Winthrop as chairman of its finance committee.

There was some thunderous cannonading on the west bank of the Harlem yesterday. The Giants, used to winning on a couple of runs a day, again surprised some 30,000 fans with their show of batting power.

HADDONFIELD, N.J., Aug. 20 Joseph F. Wallworth, a real estate and insurance broker and former President of the State Senate, ended his life by shooting himself in the head today at his home here. Friends said he had suffered from a heart ailment.

An elaborate entertainment called the "Sands Point Charity Revue" will be staged at the Sands Point Bath Club, Sands Point, L.I. on Saturday night in the interests of the National Charity Air Pageant, which is to be held at Roosevelt Field on Oct. 7 and 8.
LAKE FOREST, Ill., Aug. 20 -- The detailed play of the intersectional polo game between the East and West today follows:

The Indian, according to all fishing history in this country, caught only the number of fish he needed for his day's food. He also was very careful to see that he altered no natural condition while fishing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Indicated expenditures for building operations in July in 776 cities having a population of 10,000 or over were $38,006,669, as compared with $42,855,209 in June, a decrease of 11.3 per cent, according to building report permits received by the Department of Labor.

In a number of American communities there has been something of a return to barter. Goods and services have been exchanged for other services and goods. In the dearth of money and employment, barter exchanges have been established. Of them lawyers have become members.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- To keep pace with the fast-moving recovery drive, the Farm Administration today began an intensive search for solution of the perplexing problem presented by over-production of milk, from which the American farmer gets his largest income.

The Governors Island polo team vanquished the First Division of Fort Hamilton, 10 -- 5, yesterday at Governors Island in the opening contest of their annual five-game series for the Colyer Trophy. A crowd of 3,500 spectators, one of the largest of the season, watched the match.

The national committee of the "Pay Your Taxes Campaign," under the auspices of the National Municipal League, has, after many weeks of preparation, launched its drive to awaken nation-wide interest in the payment of taxes in order to check tax delinquency and the consequent threat to municipal credit.

LONDON, Aug. 20 -- The wheat conference will resume its work tomorrow in an atmosphere only slightly less pessimistic than that when the economic conference assembled two months ago. The impression in London tonight is that nationalistic policies still rule the delegates of the sixteen nations who are expected to attend.

A freakish northeaster of almost hurricane violence descended late yesterday upon the Long Island and New Jersey coasts, kicking Up mountainous seas that capsized fishing craft and took a toll of at least six lives.

Returning to his former position in the State Department, Ambassador WELLES has to his credit a notable achievement in Cuba. He himself would be the first to protest against too high praise for it. He did not create the situation out of which he helped to find a way of escape.
PARIS, Aug. 19. -- Fluctuations in the dollar are much talked of here and French financial circles are following very closely the execution of President Roosevelt's recovery program.

Among the delights set aside by the Long Island State Park Commission for the enjoyment of the people of this city and its environs and the "down-easters" of Nassau and Suffolk is Bethpage Park, a 1,400-acre tract on the county line, ideally suited for picnicking, golf and other recreational facilities.

Transportation interests on the inland waterways, including rivers and lakes, have launched a campaign against the Eastern railroads, charging that the railroads are trying to win away their traffic by wrecking through rates. They have appealed to shippers to aid them in a protest to the Interstate Commerce Commission and the response of shippers in the metropolitan district thus far indicates that they will aid the water lines.
Hindustan Art Co., Dr. Ella Leidheuser, president, shop for sale of Oriental art objects in Sunken Plaza of Rockefeller Center through Guy E. Giroux, broker.

MOSCOW, Aug. 20 -- Foreign correspondents here were warned individually today by the press section of the Foreign Office not to attempt to travel in the provinces or elsewhere in the Soviet Union without first submitting an itinerary and outlining the purpose of the trip and obtaining formal permission.

Wages for unskilled labor in the manufacturing industries of the United States rose to an average of $15.83 a week in June, against 514.42 in May, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday in an analysis of earnings levels.

MANNHEIM, Aug. 20 -- This city, at the confluence of the Rhine and Neckar, was once the cultural centre of the Palatinate and now is the industrial centre of Southwestern Germany. It boasts of the biggest palace and one of the biggest inland harbors in Germany, and its products go world-wide.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 20. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 70.3, which compares with 70.3 a week ago, 70.6 two weeks ago, 69.6 three weeks ago and 70.4 four weeks ago. The average of two weeks ago was the highest of the year to date; that of March 5. at 55. was the lowest.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- The Seventy-first Infantry Regiment of Manhattan, under the command of Colonel Walter A. De Lamater, marched into Camp Smith near here today for the fiftieth session of Summer training at the camp.
NEW YORK. Mrs. S. DeLancey Townsend will arrive tomorrow on the Olympic and will be at the Carlyle.

Because Franklin D. Roosevelt combines "the preacher's gift" with "a remarkable genius for administration," he ranks among the nation's great Presidents, the Rev. Dr. Jesse S. Dancey, director of the Wesley Foundation at Iowa State College, said in his sermon yesterday morning at the Broadway Temple Methodist Episcopal Church, Broadway and 174th Street.

Final settlement of the dress strike was announced early yesterday morning, after employers' and labor's representatives had signed agreements, which, it was estimated, will provide jobs for at least 10,000 additional workers in the industry.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 20 -- Two goals in the fourth period gave John Hay (Jock) Whitney's Greentree four a 6-5 triumph over the Hurricanes today on the Sands Point Club polo field.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20 -- A luncheon was given today at the Clambake Club by Mr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Thomas. A Hungarian gypsy ensemble played for their guests.

Vigor and foresight, exercised by an unfettered clergy, are absolutely essential to a useful and going church, the Rev. Dr. A. W. Beaven declared yesterday morning. Dr. Beaven, who is president of the Colgate-Rochester Divinity School, is guest preacher this month at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Fortyeighth Street.

A move to have the serving of free beer or other beverages with meals, or of free food with beverages, listed among unfair practices in the restaurant industry will be made by the Society of Restaurateurs tomorrow afternoon.

MUNICH, Aug. 20 (London Times dispatch) -- Still another speech on Austria, was broadcast by the Munich wireless station tonight by Theodor Habicht, Nazi "inspector for Austria," who made repeated allusions to "the war waged by the Dollfuss government against its own people."

MONTREAL, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Montreal and Newark wound up their season's play against each other by splitting a double-header today. The Bears won the opener, 4 to 2, and the Royals took the second game, 3 to 2.

Labor difficulties affected buying activity in the wholesale apparel markets here last week. The strikes, which were settled toward the close of the week, added fresh difficulties to the already complicated delivery situation. On the heels of the labor settlement came word that producers in the dress field will be forced to advance prices.
BERLIN, Aug. 20 (London Times Dispatch) -- The conflict between Nazi promises and practices is again revealed by several recent incidents.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- A Federal crime fighting unit, the powerful division of investigation of the Department of Justice, has become a new cause for fear among the gangsters, the kidnappers and the gunmen of Chicago and the mid-West.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 20 -- Confusion and contradiction continue to characterize the official statements of the Foreign Ministers engaged in the negotiations looking toward the resumption of mediation by Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru in the Chaco war between Bolivia and Paraguay.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The league-leading Senators flouted an old superstition when they won their thirteenth consecutive game today, defeating the Browns 4 to 3 in the nightcap of a double-header, after winning the first game 2 to 1.

O. Henry and Subways. On the same page with the story of the opening of the two new subway links was the story of the probable reopening of a Times Square restaurant which was a favorite with O. HENRY. The connection is obvious.
LAKE FOREST, Ill., Aug. 20 -- The West came through to victory today in the climax of what has been one of the most exciting polo series of modern history.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20 -- Buying of steel has continued at a low rate. As opportunity to purchase or specify at old prices expired in some products on July 1 and on some others on Aug. 1, a dull was expected, but a revival was looked for by the middle of August.
Densmore Shute, Philadelphia golfer who won the British open championship at St. Andrews, returned yesterday on the Cunard liner Samaria, accompanied by his wife.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20 -- Bright spots in business and financial circles in this district largely outnumbered the dark ones last week, there being an increasing disposition to keep the output of factories at a good level. All interests which have not adopted codes are preparing them for submission to Washington.

"An old Asiatic idea, which has nothing to do with abstract Marxism, the immemorial idea of a compulsory paradise in which every one is forced to be happy, is today being championed by the Bolsheviks with a fanatical zeal that has never been equaled," according to Essad-Bey, whose new book, "Ogpu -- The Plot Against the World" will be published today by the Viking Press.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Do American workers want independent trade unions or do they want company unions? Are the independent unions forcing workers to join or is pressure being brought to bear on them to affiliate with the company unions?

Steel operations were reduced 3 points last week to 51 per cent of capacity, according to the magazine Steel. The clarification of the industrial code situation, which has been confusing to iron and steel producers, is -- expected by the publication to supply a strong impetus for terminating the present intermission in buying.
New York Athletic Club's baseball team overwhelmed the Holy Name Club, 12 -- 1, at Travers Island yesterday. The victors gathered sixteen hits to six for the opposition.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 20 (By Wireless) -- John Grierson, British airman attempting a solo fight to American, crashed on taking off for Greenland and wrecked his Moth seaplane so badly that he had to give up his attempt.
CHICAGO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Burglaries and business rackets present the most vexing problems to law enforcement officials and criminologists in a majority of the States, a survey showed today.

LONDON, Aug. 19. -- The recent fall in the price of wheat is attracting widespread attention. Starting from a low point of 4s. 2d. per 100 pounds last February, the British price of wheat reached 6s. 2 3/8d. on July 19, an advance of 48 per cent.
APROPOS of the Hambletonian and some comment in this corner on the general subject of harness racing, there came the following letter with a Massachusetts tang:

The high cost of dealing with crime is gradually turning the American people to a policy of crime prevention, the Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Prince, a director of the Canadian Prisoners Welfare Association and a member of the Nova Scotia Royal Commission on Jail Reform, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Memories of World War protests over the use of cruel and inhuman implements of warfare were revived today by State Department publication, of secret messages between the United States and othes powers.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- President Roosevelt, arriving here today for another fortnight at the beautiful amily estate on the Hudson River, looked for completion of the basic industrial codes through promulgation of a coal agreement within the next forty-eight or seventy-two hours.

COALDALE, Pa., Aug. 20. -- The anthracite strike, latest of Pennsylvania's coal miner uprisings, was ended this afternoon when more than 15,000 men agreed to return to work pending Federal hearings on the hard coal code.
More than 7,000 men and women in up-State communities will be actively engaged in the National Recovery campaign by the end of the week. Next week 100,000 may be enlisted.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Fresh from their third straight Newport Casino victory, Ellsworth Vines and Keith Gledhill, California holders of the national doubles tennis championship, will start defending their title against an international field tomorrow at Longwood.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20 (AP) -- Two men, one a Summer cottager and the other one of the men nominated as intermediary in the recent O'Connell kidnapping case, were shot about midnight last night when State police engaged in a running gun battle with robbers who stole a safe containing diamonds valued at $2,000.

Weakness in most of the commodities at the close of last week was attributed to the further softening of grain and cotton prices, which observers were inclined to attribute to technical conditions, and all the principal staples ended below the close of the preceding week, excepting silk, which was virtually unchanged.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- The subsistence homestead plan, a little known feature of the National Recovery Act, will revolutionize manufacturing industry in this country in the next twenty years, Louis McHenry Howe, secretary to President Roosevelt, said tonight in a radio address over the National Broadcasting Company's circuit.

The principles of religion are about to be applied in America in the partnership of business and politics under the National Industrial Recovery Act, the Rev. Dr. Elliott Darlington said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 20 (AP) The Indians took both games of a double-header from the Red Sox, 14 to 6 and 9 to 4, for their third and fourth consecutive triumphs over the visitors today. In maintaining their grip on third place they stretched their winning streak to six games.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Miller's letter on the collection of back taxes and his suggested remedy of the situation do not consider the causes of such delinquencies, which are just as obvious as the results thereof. Our municipalities are in most cases the direct victims of the greed of the various administrations.

BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- A strong but non-imperialistic Germany rising to the heights of prosperity through the proper application of technocracy was pictured to the German masses in the usual week-end barrage of speeches by Nazi leaders today.

BARCELONA, -- Aug. 20 -- Citizens of the tiny State of Andorra were stunned today as they contemplated the occupation of their land by fifty French gendarmes, who had come to enforce the orders of the co-princes of Andorra, the Spanish Bishop of Urgel and the President of France.

ALBANY, Aug. 20 -- Legislators returning for the fifth week of the extraordinary session eagerly awaited tonight the results of week-end conferences on the New York City Tax Bill. They hope that a compromise has been achieved that will bring the special session to an end early this week.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- The major portion of the $250 championship jumping stake at the concluding session of the fourth annual Lake Placid horse show today was won by By Request, 7-year-old chestnut gelding. The victor, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Fred Wettach Jr. of Shrewsbury, N.J., was ridden by Mr. Wettach.

BUFFALO, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Despite a badly crippled line-up the Bisons gained a split of today's twin bill with Jersey City. The visitors won the opener, 9 to 5, and Milstead's fine pitching gave the Bisons a 3-to-2 verdict in the nightcap.

Dan Flynn was in a mellow mood early yesterday morning -- mellow but wistful. Here he was, 32 years old, getting along in life, but not making much of a splash anywhere, not even in quiet Woodside, Queens, where he lives and where a splash can be heard quite a distance.

Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national chairman of the campaign to raise $2,000,000 for relief work in Germany, announced yesterday that figures submitted to his organization show that 100,000 Jews in Germany have already lost all opportunities to earn a living.

"Voltaire," the new Warner Brothers picture featuring George Arliss, will be presented beginning tomorrow morning at the Hollywood Theatre. In the supporting cast are Doris Kenyon, Margaret Lindsay, Theodore Newton, Reginald Owen and Ivan Simpson.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Glenn Frank, president of the University of Wisconsin, in an address over the National Broadcasting Company's network tonight said that the National Recovery Act was fraught with tremendous possibilities, both for good and evil, but that it was the duty of all Americans to stand firmly back of President Roosevelt, to whom had been given a mandate to restore prosperity to the country.
PARIS, Aug. 20. -- Liquid funds are still plentiful in the money market and rates have remained at about 1 1/2 per cent for open market discounts and 1 1/8 per cent for dayto-day funds.

HAVANA, Aug. 20 -- Tito Sampol, former sergeant of the secret police and known as one of former President Machado's most efficient killers, committed suicide this morning outside a cafe on the corner of Carlos III and Infanta Streets.

An attack upon Tammany's sincerity in professing allegiance to the five-cent fare on rapid transit lines will be part of the fusion strategy in the coming Mayoralty campaign, it was indicated yesterday.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 20 -- Professor Albert Sprague Coolidge of Harvard, viola player, was the assisting artist this afternoon at the chamber music concert in Mrs. Frederick S. Coolidge's Temple of Music at Pittsfield. The program included compositions by Brahms, Jarnach and Rubin Goldmark.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 20 -- Grain crops here are faced with disaster unless abundant rains materialize in the immediate future, according to a report by the Bureau of Rural Statistics. The report describes as "poor" the condition of growing wheat, flaxseed, oats, barley and rye.

Frances Winmar, who won the $5,000 Atlantic non-fiction prize with her "Poor Splendid Wings: The Rosettis and Their Circle," expects to return to this country shortly before the publication of her book on Sept. 22. On being informed that her book had won the prize, she sailed for London to resume her study of the young rebels who turned Victorian ideas and conventions topsy-turvy.
DETROIT, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The Tigers today won a double-header from the Athletics, 5 to 4 and 4 to 1, and tightened their hold on fourth place.

In the State campaign which the Democrats formally opened on Saturday their objective is not hidden. Their aim is to win control of the Assembly at Albany, and so of the Legislature. To do this they must make gains up-State. Years age the rural counties used to send enough Democrats to the Assembly to make a majority with the aid of those elected from this city.
"The Blue Widow," with Queenie Smith heading the cast, which is scheduled for presentation next week, will open at the Morosco Theatre instead of at the Bijou, as formerly announced.
BERLIN, Aug. 20. -- Trade generally continues to improve, according to official reports, but a seasonal slackening is noted in automobiles and someother branches of industry.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Aug. 20. -- Wide price fluctuations and alternate periods of quiet and activity featured the cotton market here last week. After a slight opening advance, the market turned downward, and by Wednesday it had lost about 100 points, making prices the lowest of the season and representing a decline of approximately 360 points, or $18 a bale, from the year's highest level.

BERLIN, Aug. 19.-- Bankers see in Germany's recent foreign trade development no reason to apprehend a new suspension or reduction of bond transfers. The currency reserves have continued to improve; since the end of June, when the partial moratorium came into force, they have increased 25 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The administration's efforts for industrial codification, which yesterday brought the steel, oil and lumber industries under the sign of the NRA Blue Eagle, are to be continued unabated this week and until the bulk of American business has been enlisted in the recovery program.

LONDON, Aug. 19. -- The trend of commodity prices has been distinctly unsatisfactory in the last month. Nearly all leading products have reacted sharply, although they still retain a fair part of their earlier rise.

JONES BEACH, L.I., Aug. 20 -- Miss Susan Robertson, star of the Women's Swimming Association, repeated her triumph of 1932 wh she won the women's senior national A.A.U. long-distance championship today.
