The National Executive Committee of the American Jewish Congress, in an all-day emergency session yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker, unanimously adopted a resolution to support the world boycott against German goods and to work for its extension among the non-Jewish population of the United States through an appeal to the sense of fair play and justice of the American people.

MOSCOW, Aug. 20 -- Reports from abroad that the Vatican wants to relieve "millions of victims of the Russian famine" are greeted here with the same scorn and indignation that met earlier news that German Nazis were collecting funds for "starving German Volga colonists" and the appeals of emigre Russian newspapers in the Baltic States for "relief of a worse famine in Russia than that of 1921."

After losing a lot of its fans by failing to bloom on three successive Sundays, the century plant in the Bronx Park Botanical Gardens has suddenly waked up to the situation. Loyal supporters, who felt pretty dashed about it Sunday before last, came away with a new spring in their step yesterday.

Employment of 23,209 additional men and women by forty-six New York concerns in as many different lines since Aug. 1 as a direct result of enrolment under the Blue Eagle was reported as the result of a survey yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, city chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Campaign.

About 23,000 cloakmakers, who stopped work a week ago, following difficulties in putting into effect some of the provisions of the recently approved code for the coat and suit industry, are expected to resume work early this week.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 20 -- Mr. and Mrs. Stanley W. Burke, who have the Dominy cottage on Lily Pond Lane this season, gave a luncheon for thirty-six guests there today.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.T., Aug. 20 -- Jubilee, owned and sailed by H.B. Atkin, captured first place in the Star Class race at the weekly regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today.

Although John F. Curry, leader of Tammany, and John H. McCooey, Brooklyn Democratic leader, are reported to have expressed confidence that Mayor John P. O'Brien will be re-elected by a minimum plurality of 300,000, other influential members of the party are not so certain and have advised the creation of a new Tammany war board to direct the campaign.

PRAGUE, Aug. 20 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency) -- A program for dealing with the German-Jewish situation was worked out by a special committee today for presentation at the eighteenth World Zionist Congress which will open in Lucerno Hall tomorrow night.

The state of mind in financial and political circles being what it is, the fact that last week's alternating decline and recovery in wheat should have held the centre of the stage was natural enough. It was not that the reaction had been alarming or astonishing; on the contrary, it followed the invariable rule of markets in which an utterly abnormal rise, accompanied in its later stages by reckless speculation, had culminated.
TOPEKA, Aug. 20 -- Federal intervention to assist in prosecution of Kansas officials in the $2,000,000 bond forgery scandal appeared today to be a possibility.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Four persons were killed and three critically injured here today when an automobile got out of control on a curve at the top of the steep slope on East Main Street and crashed into a tree.

BOSTON, Aug. 20 (AP) -- The fast-traveling Braves took a double-header from the Pirates today, 5 to 4 in eleven innings, and 8 to 1, and thereby advanced with the Cardinals to virtually even terms with Pittsburgh for the runner-up position in the National League.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The quick-step repeal votes by twentytwo States in unbroken succession, topped by Missouri's 3-to-1 ballot, today showed the possibility that the Eighteenth Amendment could be voted out of the Constitution within the next seventy-eight days.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- Trade will precede the flag in this country's relations with Rus , it appeared today. Diplomatic recognition is taken for granted here as a development of the relatively near future, but many Americans evince a willingness to sell their goods to Russia in advance of that formal step.
BERLIN, Aug. 20 (AP) -- Thousands of Catholic youths of the Berlin Bishopric gathered today at Neukoelln stadium and pledged allegiance to Chancellor Adolf Hitler.
Frankie Frisch and his Cardinals brushed by the Dodgers twice yesterday and moved into a virtual tie with the Pirates and Braves for second place.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 20 -- Equipoise, bright star of the American turf, will leave here tomorrow in a special car which will be hooked onto the Twentieth Century Limited at Albany.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP). -- Approval of modified Presidential Reemployment Agreements for seventeen industries, bringing their thousands of workers under the shorter-hour, higher-wage program of the NRA, was announced tonight by General Johnson.

ALBANY, Aug. 20 -- Expenses for operating public school systems in all cities in New York State have increased 70 per cent in ten years, according to a survey made public today by the New York State conference of Mayors. The number of teachers meanwhile increased 35 per cent, while the population of the cities was increasing 21 per cent and the average daily attendance of students 23 per cent.

THURLES, Irish Free State, Aug. 20 -- President de Valera, who spoke at an open-air meeting here tonight, received a rousing reception and was cheered when he referred to General O'Dulfy's organization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- While some progress toward formulation of a coal code was reported today by spokesmen for the bituminous coal industry, the Recovery Administration began writing the basis of a code.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 20 -- New principles of acoustical control and visibility of the stage have been introduced in the reconstruction here of Murray Hall, the Princeton University auditorium, where theatrical productions of the Theatre Intime, undergraduate dramatic organization, are presented.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Aug. 21 -- The belief that the Yellow River would not change its channel this year, but would certainly do so three or four years hence, was expressed by Ho Chin-wu, managing director of the Peiping-Hankow Railway.

HAVANA, Aug. 20 -- General Mario G. Menocal, former President of Cuba and chief of the abortive rebellion of August, 1931, who returned unheralded this morning by plane from Miami, in a statement to the press tonight indicated his displeasure with the present government and emphasized the need for carrying out the revolutionary program for the reconstruction of the republic.

DUBLIN, Aug. 20 -- General O'Duffy, leader of the Blue Shirt National Guard, declared tonight that if in spite of the legal and constitutional character of his organization the government declared it unlawful, "the government shall he guilty of a positive act of tyranny."
All bills for electric energy consumed in New York City will be reduced 6 per cent beginning Sept. 1 for a year, by order of the Public Service Commission.

The four-story Mannes Music School at 155-59 E. 74th St. was sold by the 157 East Seventy-fourth Street Corp., Alfred T. Karmer, president, to David Mannes, who gave to Martha H.P. Strong a mortgage on the parcel for $25,000, payable three years hence, at 5 1/2 per cent.

At the request of Samuel Untermyer, acting as financial adviser to the Mayor, a committee of six has been formed to aid in the plan put forward by Mr. Untermyer for re-establishing the credit of the city, Peter Grimm, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, announced yesterday.

With sails furled and ropes neatly coiled on her decks, the Amerigo Vespucci, flagship of the Royal Italian Naval Training Squadron, was berthed yesterday morning at the Italian Line pier, foot of West Fifty-sixth Street. While the vast hull, painted in longitudinal stripes of black and white, to symbolize her readiness for battle, was slowly warped into position, her sister ship, the Cristoforo Colombo, lay to in the North River awaiting her turn to dock.
LONDON, Aug. 19. -- Activity in the stock market remains considerably above the August average. The public has been on holiday, but has been keeping a close eye on the security markets.

Some of the worst weather of a bad crop year has centred in the Corn Belt. The yield now forecast by the Department of Agriculture is the smallest with one exception since 1901. Corn prices have risen so rapidly that even despite the recent break they are nearly 100 per cent above the low mark for the year.

Under the patronage of the Grand Duchess Marie and the Princesses Nina and Xenia of Russia, a "Russian fete" will be given at the Atlantic Beach Club on Sept. 9 to augment a fund for the assistance of unemployed Russians in this country.

Fifteen Broadway ticket agencies over a period of two and a half years have voluntarily wiped out a debt of $25,000 which the League of New York Theatres owed the National City Bank on a note endorsed by Lawrence Langner, Arthur Hopkins, L. Lawrence Weber, Marcus Heiman and Arthur Hammerstein.
BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- What progress has Germany made under her Nazi rulers in the last three months toward insuring the stability, peace and power that are their avowed aims?

HAVANA, Aug. 20 -- A frenzied mob late today disinterred the body of Antonio B. Ainciart, former head of the national police, from the grave in Marianao Cemetery where it had been buried a short time be- fore, took it to the entrance of Havana University and there mutilated and burned it before an ambulance crew scattered the demonstrators.

Fifteen Broadway ticket agencies over a period of two and a half years have voluntarily wiped out a debt of $25,000 which the League of New York Theatres owed the National City Bank on a note endorsed by Lawrence Langner, Arthur Hopkins, L. Lawrence Weber, Marcus Heiman and Arthur Hammerstein.
BERLIN, Aug. 20 -- What progress has Germany made under her Nazi rulers in the last three months toward insuring the stability, peace and power that are their avowed aims?

HAVANA, Aug. 20 -- A frenzied mob late today disinterred the body of Antonio B. Ainciart, former head of the national police, from the grave in Marianao Cemetery where it had been buried a short time be- fore, took it to the entrance of Havana University and there mutilated and burned it before an ambulance crew scattered the demonstrators.

America is in a now era in which we may be compelled by economic necessity to establish peace, the Rev. Dr. Paul Scharer, pastor of Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Sixty-fifth Street and Central Park West, said in a radio sermon over WEAF yesterday afternoon.
TODAY'S MATCHES. 3:30 P.M. -- Miss Dorothy Round. England, vs. Miss Helen Jacobs, Berkeley, Calif.
Conveyance of a Teaneck development parcel by a bank featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported over the week-end.

When JOHN W. DAVIS returned from Europe the other day he was asked what he thought of the forty-hour week. "I have always believed, and "still do, that no man should work less "than eight hours," he is reported to have said to the ship-news couriers. "What are we going to do with all "these extra hours?

OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 21 (AP). -- The government has enough evidence, District Attorney Herbert K. Hyde asserted today, to put the kidnappers of Charles F. Urschel behind prison bars for life without calling the oil millionaire as a witness.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- The extraordinary session of the Legislature entered its fifth week tonight, with the fate of the legislation to empower the New York City administration to raise funds for unemployment relief through local taxation still in the balance.

Twenty years ago, remembering how many famous literary names have adorned the American diplomatic service, Mr. WILSON tried to bring Mr. MEREDITH NICHOLSON into it. The post offered him was that of Minister to Portugal, if memory holds her seat. She has lost it, if The Indianapolis News is right and it was the Spanish mission.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 21. -- President Justo today appointed Federico Pinedo Minister of Finance to succeed Alberto Hueyo, who resigned, and Luis Duhau Minister of Agriculture, to succeed the late Antonio de Tomaso. Both are members of the Chamber of Deputies.

PRAGUE, Aug. 21. -- In his speech opening the Zionist Congress tonight Dr. Nahum Sokolow, referring to what he called "the lie in our midst," described assimilation of the Jews as attempting "to put blinkers on our public opinion" that it might not see "the handwriting on the wall, the danger threatening a spiritual epidemic of anti-Semitism."

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Aug. 21 -- Plans for an aerial funeral for Lieutenant Harold E. McMahon of the Army Air Reserves, whose body lies in a marsh near Leipsec, Del., where his plane crashed Saturday, were announced here today by Herbert McCory, newspaper photographer, who had flown with Lieutenant McMahon during the last four years.

The 6 per cent cut in electric rates ordered by the Public Service Commission for Sept. 1 in New York City will be opposed by the companies affected, George B. Cortelyou, president of the Consolidated Gas Company, revealed yesterday.
Mayor John P. O'Brien pledged his personal cooperation and that of all municipal departments yesterday to the NRA movement.
TOKYO, Aug. 21. -- The French Government has been informed in a long note that Japan objects to its occupation of nine coral islets in the China Sea.

LONDON, Aug. 21 -- Official circles here profess they are well satisfied with the way Premier Mussolini is handling the Austro-German situation. What is more, the British are quite willing to let him handle it alone awhile without diplomatic help from London.

HAVANA, Aug. 21. -- The A B C secret society, police and soldiers continued rounding up former Machado adherents. Among them was Rafael Castro, a policeman who was alleged to have participated in several crimes of violence.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- For eighteen innings the Yankees and White Sox struggled through four hours and eleven minutes of tense baseball today. Then Umpire Harry Geisel, in charge of the field, called the game because of darkness with the score knotted at 3 -- all when Simmons's fly fell into the waiting hands of Lazzeri.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Aug. 21 (AP). -- The death penalty will be demanded in the trial of David A. Lamson, accused of the murder of his 28-year-old wife, Allene Thorpe Lamson, the prosecution announced today after indicating the State's case would continue to be of a circumstantial nature.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety leading cities on Aug. 16 shows increases for the week of $45,000,000 in loans. $149,000,000 in holdings of United States Government securities and $323,000,000 in government deposits, and a decrease of $132,000,000 in net demand deposits.
WASHINGTON, AUG. 21 -- Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Aug. 21, unless otherwise specified:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The National Labor Board acted at a closed hearing today to settle the Hollywood film strike before it spreads over all the country and darkens all motion-picture theatres. The board heard the side of the National Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and Moving Picture Operators, backing the strike of the sound technicians in the studios on the Coast.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 18:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Every right-minded and loyal citizen should and, I think to the extent of his ability to discern the right, does support the President and General Johnson in their effort to get idle men back to work, at wages and under conditions fair to the laborer and the employer.

David Binney Putnam, who has been more places than most men see in a lifetime, returned yesterday from an exploration trip in British Guiana and Northern Brazil to seek the source of diamonds washed down from South American mountains.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 21 (AP) -- The little brown jug, long the prize of victory between Michigan and Minnesota football teams and which has been missing since the Wolverine-Gopher game of 1931, has been found.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 21 (AP). -- Buffalo continued fighting briskly toward a league playoff berth today as it humbled Jersey City, 11 to 6.

Joining the other theatre chains in listing their programs for the new season, the RKO theatres in Greater New York announced yesterday they would show fifty-two pictures produced by RKO Radio and a selected number of fox, Columbia, Paramount and Universal productions.

All bond groups showed irregularity in quiet dealings on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The turnover was less than $8,500,000. As a rule, the better-rated issues showed the smallest price variations. United States Government bonds were fairly well traded, the active issues closing 3-32 point higher to 2-32 lower on the day.

ALBANY, Aug. 21 -- The Assembly tonight followed the lead of the Senate in passing a bill recommended by Governor Lehman to appropriate $75,000 for the milk control board, with $25,000 specifically allocated for an investigation of the spread in price between what the farmer receives for his milk and what the consumer is compelled to pay.
NEW YORK. Mrs. W. DeForest Manice, who had been visiting in Memphis, Term., is at the Plaza.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- The largest batch of yearlings of the season to date, fifty-four head, brought the annual sales to a close at this place tonight. The money total realized, however, was not the largest, the sum of $45,575 being bid, or an average of almost $844.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 21 -- Two youngsters dominated a large field of experienced shooters today in the opening program of the thirty-fourth annual Grand American handicap tournament. They walked away with three out of four championships while their elders looked on in amazement.
BREMEN, Germany, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Dr. Heinrich Albert, chairman of the board of the North German Lloyd Line, resigned today, effective Sept. 30. He was appointed May 12, 1932.

The speedy settlement of the dress strike, with Grover A. Whalen, city chairman of the NRA, as mediator, had led dozens of dissatisfied labor groups to dump their troubles into the lap of the NRA here, Henry F. Wolff, chief of the committee's bureau of complaints, said last night.

It was in keeping with the historic relations of Andorra and France that, if there must be intervention in the name of reform, it should be made by a peace force of gendarmes. It was CHARLEMAGNE who drove the Moors from the valleys. It was NAPOLEON who, as First Consul, signed a decree reinstating the inhabitants of Andorra in their former relations with France and restoring the ancient protectorate.

SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 31 -- Mrs. Henry White of Eim Court, Lenox, Mass., who is passing the remainder of the Summer at the Meadow Club; gave a luncheon there today. Among her guests were Mrs. Arthur B. Claflin, Mrs. Rufus L. Patterson, Mrs. George G. De Witt, Mrs. Amory G. Hodges, Mrs. William Appleton Burnham and Mrs. Charles Tracy Barney.

AUSTIN, Texas, Aug. 21 UP) -- Texas will decide Saturday at a State-wide election whether it shall join the unbroken line of twenty-two States voting for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment or head a revolt in the other direction.
Frankie Frisch looked as grim as the weather, which was bad and getting rapidly worse. Perhaps it was a mistake to have brought the subject up in the first place.

CANNES, Aug. 21 -- Former Mayor James J. Walker's promised statement as to whether he would be willing to return and testify at the inquiry regarding his income now being conducted in New York was handed to American newspaper correspondents faere today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Increases in the prices of bread have been checked "at least temporarily," Dr. Frederic C. Howe, consumers' counsel of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration, stated today on the basis of reports from twenty-two field offices.

Difficulty in preparing a code for the burlesque branch of the entertainment field was apparent yesterday. Burlesque managers and officials of the group working to frame the code refused to make any public statements following a meeting in the morning in the Hotel Forrest or following a conference of managers in the afternoon in the office of L.H. Herk of the Empire Burlesque Association in the Strand Theatre building.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 21 (AP). -- Four straight defeats have made Ellsworth Vines, national tennis champion, puzzled but not worried.

Money market continued quiet, the only change appearing in time loans, where the rate for three and four months' funds was quoted at 1 per cent flat, against 1@1 1/4 previously. Call loans renewed at 1 per cent, with outside money posted at 3/4 per cent. Commercial paper and acceptances rates remained unchanged.

Independent Austria is finding friends outside the League of Nations. Though herself not a signatory to the Four-Power Treaty, she has obtained help under it as against the threatened meddling of German Nazis in her internal affairs. In protest against the latter, the Italian Government was the first and firmest to make representations at Berlin.

The first American performance of Tchaikovsky's opera, "Iolanthe," the composer's last work for the lyric stage, will be presented in the Garden Theatre of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, Scarborough, N. Y., on Sunday evening, Sept. 10, under the auspices of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

BOLTON LANDING - ON - LAKE GEORGE. N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Miss Dorothy Hoyt of Schenectady triumphed over Miss Gretchen Stevenson of Bolton Landing in the final of the women's Sagamore singles tennis tournament today. The score was 6 -- 1, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 1.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21 -- Parties for the younger members of the Summer colony continue to be prominent among the social affairs, and starting the week the chief event tonight was a young people's dance given by Mr. and Mrs. S. Griswold Flagg of Philadelphia at Seaweed, the Dolan villa at the end of Bellevue Avenue, which they are occupying this Summer.

The week opened with substantial gains in most of the principal commodities, with transactions in good volume. Sentiment was firm in most instances. Cash prices were about evenly divided between losses and gains.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) -- President Roosevelt is expected in administration circles to announce early this week the membership of the committee of fifteen to govern the oil industry, with a Federal agency authorized by the petroleum code signed Saturday.

Supreme Court Justice Carew signed an order yesterday approving the consolidation of the Association of Dress Manufacturers, Inc., and the Metropolitan Dress Contractors Association as the United Association of Dress Manufacturers, Inc.
VIENNA, Aug. 21 -- Chancellor Dollfuss returned to Vienna at 2 P.M. today from his week-end with Premier Mussolini at Riccione, Italy, and left two hours later for Salzburg.

As evidence of the progress of the NRA movement up-State, W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Committee for the State of New York, announced yesterday that he had received a report that every employer in Pawling had pledged his support of the NRA program.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 21 -- A northeaster with heavy rains drenched the fighting forces and almost brought defeat to the American army today, in its opening drive on Red invaders, in the war game which for a week will keep three reserve divisions and a cavalry regiment here in a tactical defense of New York and Philadelphia.
DETROIT, Aug. 21 (AP). -- After four games of good hurling, for as many victories, Detroit's pitching staff collapsed today and Philadelphia wound up the series with a 12-to-7 victory.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- While wheat on the Board of Trade here today had a maximum range of 3 1/4 cents a bushel and corn one of 3 cents. the fluctuations were regarded by most traders as meaningless and in large measure reflecting in-and-out operations by commission houses and professional operators.
Reorganization of the capital structure of the Fox Film Corporation was completed yesterday by the burning of $29,614,845 of its bonds and coupons.

John A. Lynch. Borough President of Richmond, denied designation for renomination by the Democratic organization headed by David S. Rendt, announced yesterday that he would run for re-election as an independent against former Sheriff William S. Hart, the organization designee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Brig. Gen. Harold B. Fiske has been selected by President Roosevelt, on recommendation of Secretary Dern, for advancement to the grade of Major General, to replace Major Gen. Campbell King, retired, and was assigned today to command of the Panama Canal Department, to succeed Major Gen. Preston Brown.

MOSCOW, Aug. 21. -- The Communist party cleansing, now in progress throughout the Soviet Union, appears less drastic than the expected expulsion of 30 per cent of the members. The results so far published cover less than a quarter of the total membership but give a cross section of the whole country with expulsions ranging from 15 to 25 per cent.

More than 900,000 traveling salesmen of the United States will appeal directly to President Roosevelt within the next ten days for permission to adopt a separate code of their own, according to Joseph H. Dryer, president of the National Council of Traveling Salesmen's Association of America.
Residential properties comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

After successfully eluding annoying postponements on four successive afternoons of threatening weather, rain finally caught up with the Giants yesterday and washed out the third game of the series with the Cubs at the Polo Grounds.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 21 -- F. Cowles Strickland, director of the Berkshire Playhouse at Stockbridge, opened the final week of the dramatic season there tonight with a presentation of Lawton Campbell's comedy, "Solid South." Besides Vera Alien and Charles Coburn, others who had leading parts in the cast were Margaret Love, Gertrude Clements, Gage Clark, John Beal and Charles Francis.

Willem van Hoogstraten made his last appearance of the esason in the Stadium series of concerts by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in the Great Hall of the City College of New York last night. The miserable weather that has dogged the concerts this Summer caused the postponement of "Madama Butterfly" which was scheduled for last night and which will be presented tonight regardless of the weather, outdoors if it is clear or indoors if it rains.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 -- Mounting acclaim for Cecil Smith, the big Texan who led a band of hardriding Westerners to victory over the East, today promised to send him to the top of the polo world as a shareholder of the cherished ten-goal rating with Tommy Hitchcock.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP). -- In preparation for a contemplated nation-wide milk production control plan, representatives of dairymen's organizations today talked with Farm Administration officials about competing imports and what should be done about them.

EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- A tea with music was given this afternoon at the Thomas Moran Grallery, Guild Hall, by Mr. and Mrs. Adolf Fedde. Mrs. Henry T. Wills of Southampton and Mrs. E. Rodney Burnett poured. The assisting artist was Mario Cozzi, young baritone who recently arrived from La Scala, of Milan. Miguel Sandoval was the accompanist.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 21 -- The National Recovery Administration swung toward further objectives with the opening of the new week, determined to make good on the promise to President Roosevelt to fashion a code for the coal industry, should operators longer fail to agree.
The White Star liner Olympic will arrive today from Southampton and Cherbourg. On board are:
TODAY'S MATCHES. 3:30 P.M. -- Miss Dorothy Round. England, vs. Miss Helen Jacobs, Berkeley, Cal.

MOSCOW, Aug. 21 -- About 100,000 children are being organized in "light cavalry detachments" to guard against grain thefts "and retrieve stray kernels dropped by harvesters in the North Caucasus fields.

VIENNA, Aug. 21 -- That Adolf Hitler as a youth in Vienna had Jewish friends, did his small business mostly with Jews and condemned Russian pogroms because "one can hate In the mass but not in the Individual" was asserted today in a newspaper article of reminiscences by Reinhold Hanisch, a Viennese engraver, who lived and worked with him then.
BRISTOL, England, Aug. 21 (AP). -- The touring West Indies cricket team trailed Gloucestershire by 299 runs today at the close of the first innings and the second day of play The match ends tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP). -- The Recovery Administration announced tonight a modified re-employment agreement for the office building industry, which is expected to add 8,000 employes to the 100,000 already employed in that business:

A tunnel was found yesterday running between a rickety old frame dwelling in West Twenty-ninth Street and 250 West Thirtieth Street, which houses a stock of broadtail and Persian lamb pelts worth nearly $500,000.

The chance that a new type of economic system may evolve out of the present embryonic form of German national socialism is discussed by Calvin B. Hoover in his "German Enters the Third Reich," published today by Macmillan.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Monte Pearson, recruit right-handed pitcher who joined Cleveland only six weeks ago, today hurled his sixth victory as the Indians swamped the Red Sox, 10 to 1, to sweep the five-game series.
DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 21 -- Former President Herbert Hoover will be requested to testify at the inquiry into the Detroit banking situation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP). -- An obstacle which caused a temporary breakdown in negotiations for a sugar-marketing pact was cleared away today through presentation to Secretary Wallace of a written agreement by which domestic beet interests consented to participate in a production quota plan.

CHICAGO. Aug. 21 -- The Federal Government's wholesale purchase of surplus hogs and small pigs, in the plan of Secretary of Agriculture Wallace to relieve the present glut and advance farm prices, is to start in Chicago and five other markets on Wednesday.

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 21 -- James Turnesa, assistant caddie master at the Briar Hills course in Westchester, won the caddie masters' championship of the metropolitan district today in an all-day rain by playing the south and north courses of the Canoe Brook Country Club in 75, 81 -- 156.

CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Earl Pool, one of America's veteran riders, rode Cathop to victory in the top race at Hawthorne today in a driving finish over Karl Eitel. Lemon Hills finished third in the six-furlong sprint.

The northeast gale that descended unexpectedly upon the New Jersey coast last Sunday afternoon, scattering more than a hundred fishing craft and capsizing at least nine, was blowing with undiminished force last night. With a tropical hurricane headed in this direction, Coast Guard vessels intensified their search for disabled boats and survivors.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Aug. 21 -- The Rev. Felix G. Robinson, whose resignation was accepted yesterday morning by the congregation of St. John's Lutheran Church by-the-Sea, was recalled tonight at a joint meeting of the congregation and its council.

The Union Tank Car Company reports for the six months ended June 30 a net income of $469.764 after expenses, depreciation, interest and estimated Federal income taxes, equal to 38 cents a share on the 1,200,000 capital shares outstanding.

Samuel S. Koenig, chairman of the New York County Republican Committee, yesterday characterized the Tammany city ticket, headed by Mayor O'Brien. "as the weakest ticket ever nominated by Tammany Hall in all my experience." Mr. Koenig, who spoke at a luncheon at the National Republican Club for the members of the Republican Executive Committee and the candidates for county and borough offices, said he would take the stump in the campaign, and predicted fusion victory.

A branch of the Federal Home Owners Loans Corporation was opened officially yesterday at 391 East 149th Street, the Bronx. It soon was thronged by small home owners seeking relief against foreclosures and loans for taxes and repairs.

BERLIN, Aug. 21 -- The Boerse opened today with a pronounced sinking spell which depressed quotations 3 to 6 per cent. Heavy industrials, headed by Gelsenkirchen, started the downward procession which soon included electric, chemical, lignite and potash shares and then spread to the entire list.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The retail code on which hearings will be held tomorrow was submitted by a group of trade associations, including the National Retail Furniture Association, the National Retail Hardware Association, the Mail Order Association of America, the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers, the National Shoe Retailers Association and the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Mrs. Minnie Johnson Fullen, 21 years old, sportswoman and physical instructor of Waco, Texas, who vanished last Thursday from the home of her sister, Mrs. Lucile Oxberry, at 63 East Ninth Street, wandered into a Sheepshead Bay drug store yesterday.

Free to Agree. DIEGO RIVERA has received a commission from the University of Mexico to paint a series of murals depicting the history of medicine. The Mexican artist, according to the account in The Herald Tribune, was greatly elated by the invitation.

MALMO, Sweden, Aug. 21 (London Times dispatch). -- With Malmo as a centre the Swedish Nazi party is now concentrating its propaganda on the province of Skane. Skane is the most populous of the Swedish provinces and though by no means worse off than other parts of Sweden its problems are so largely agricultural that the Nazis perhaps regard it as good ground for agitation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The Cabinet advisory board of the Recovery Administration decided today as a step to protect the public health against profiteering, to request all industries now operating under codes to submit information on recent price increases.

"The Untried Case: The SaccoVanzetti Case and the Moreili Gang," is an attempt to show who committed the murders for which Sacco and Vanzetti were found guilty and executed. The author is Herbert B. Ehrmann, who was junior counsel for Sacco and Vanzetti in 1926-27, and who investigated the Madeiros confession of guilt which was intended to clear Sacco and Vanzetti.

OTTAWA, Ont., Aug. 21 (Canadian Press) -- Several requests for further details to facilitate the shipment of gold ore and concentrates to Canada from the United States have been received at the Finance Department since the official announcement on Saturday that such importations would be permitted.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Jacksonville, Fla., led the nation during 1932 in murders per capita, according to a survey just completed by Frederick Rex, librarian for the city of Chicago.

PRAGUE, Aug. 21. -- Dr. Nahum Sokolow, president of the World Zionist Organization, asserted in opening the eighteenth world Zionist congress here tonight that as a result of the persecutions in Germany the Jewish question must be brought before the international forum and fugitives must find a refuge in Palestine.
WARSAW, Aug. 21 -- The seventh International Conference on Historical Science opened today in the Polytechnic Institute in Warsaw with more than 1,000 delegates from forty countries.

The almond-eyed Asiatic who remained a fugitive from justice for more than twenty-four hours in the East Fifty-first Street police station returned yesterday, but surrender came only after detectives and patrolmen had gone through another workout.

As early as June, before the first code under the NRA received the Government's approval, a difference of opinion appeared in the oil industry on the moot question of price-fixing. Advocates of it carried the day at a round-table meeting in Chicago and wrote into their proposed code a sectior urging the Government to fix both minimum and maximum price for motor fuel and other petroleum products.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 21. -- Formation of a policing unit to seek out violations of the National Recovery Act will feature discussions of the State Federation of Labor which will open tomorrow its four-day annual convention.

Enzymes, those mysterious miracle workers in the chemical laboratory of the living body, have been found to play an important role in the development of cancer, according to a preliminary report on research work carried on during the last year at the Cancer Research Laboratory, Graduate School of Medicine, University of Pennsylvania.

PARIS. Aug. 21 -- Instead of helping to clarify the situation to permit the forming of a united policy in regard to the maintenance of Austrian independence, the interview between Premier Mussolini of Italy and Chancellor Dollfuss of Austria has seemed to serve only to stir up new complications.

The final negotiations in the settlement of the dress strike struck unexpected snags last night which are expected to delay full accord, and which may keep many thousands of the workers out on strike for several more days.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- President Roosevelt took a holiday today, one of very few he has had since he was inaugurated.
The text of the agreement to end the dress strike, which became effective yesterday and is valid until Jan. 31, 1936, follows:

THE cowboys from Texas and the caballeros from California took the East-West polo series in Chicago. This is just another case of the breaking up of old territorial rights in this country. Years ago it wasn't polo unless it was played on Long Island and by Long Islanders. Now the riders of the range and the gallopers of the Golden Slope are on top of the polo field.

A survey of all city jobs, whether under civil service or exempt classifications, to determine which ones are "useless" and should be abolished, will be one of the first tasks of the civic committee of six cooperating with Samuel Untermyer to map a program of municipal economy.
To the Editor of The New York Times: When the Emergency Tuberculosis Relief Committee was founded in 1917 we rarely had appeals for relief from the so-called white-collar class.

The Triborough Bridge Authority has no power to employ men on the span under the terms of the Federal loan granted to the city last week to finance its completion, George Gordon Battle, chairman of the Authority, said yesterday.

Taking matters into their own hands, the members of the August county grand jury yesterday invited United States Attorney George Z. Medalie and Chief Justice Frederic Kernochan of Special Sessions to appear and enlarge upon their recent charges of alliances between politicians and racketeers.
ALBANY, Aug. 21 -- The bill strengthening the State laws governing kidnapping was passed in the Assembly tonight and will be before Governor Lehman tomorrow for approval.

SANTA FE, N.M., Aug. 21 (AP). -- Seriously injured in an automobile accident which cost the life of William Hunter, 28 years old, of Buffalo, Jane McLean, Santa Fe dancer, made a gruelling climb today from the bottom of a 1,000-foot canyon and obtained aid from a motorist.

Formal charges have been filed with Governor Lehman asking the removal from office of Controller Charles W. Berry, it was announced yesterday by James E. Finegan, independent Democrat of Brooklyn. Five other taxpayers joined him in signing the document, which was forwarded to Albany.

New York City's financial problem is fourfold. It must somehow make both ends meet in the conduct of its day-by-day affairs, lay its hands on enough money to take care of victims of the depression, get ahead with its public improvement program and meet its outstanding obligations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is now pending in our State certain mortgage moratorium legislation. One bill provides for a moratorium on mortgage principal to July 1, 1934, provided interest and taxes are paid and there is no other default or breach by the owner of the terms and provisions of the mortgage.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Airplanes on American-operated lines flew 76,642,393 passenger miles with only two passenger fatalities in the first half of 1933, according to figures issued today by Ewing Y. Mitchell, Assistant Secretary of Commerce.

TORONTO, Aug. 21 (AP). -- Toronto lost half a game in the torrid race for a play-off post in the International League by dividing a doubleheader today with Albany, while Buffalo was defeating Jersey City.

MANNHEIM, Germany, Aug. 21. -- The question which the American traveler in Germany is beginning to hear more and more frequently and with an increasingly anxious undertone is, "What does America think about the new Germany?"

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 21 -- A prediction that President Roosevelt would be re-elected in 1936 "by even a greater majority than in 1932" was made here tonight by Postmaster General Farley in an address to the members of six Democratic clubs at Ross Fenton Farms.

Fishermen along the south New Jersey coast have been enjoying wonderful sport, the returns over the week-end showing that nearly every kind of fish the sportsman could care for is on hand in abundance. In a trip off Barnegat Fred Clinton of Peekskill, N.Y., took thirty-three blues, one bonita and one dolphin and R.W. Buddsall and a party of friends from Westfield, N.J., hooked thirty blues.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange failed yesterday to maintain advances and closed with losses of 2 to 7 points, but the market displayed considerable resistance in view of the recovery of $5 a bale previously made from the low records of last week.
While continuance of activity by realty operators and others was reported yesterday, few closings of deals were reported.

Apparel Activity Revives Quickly. With the labor stoppages in the cloak and dress trades no longer a factor, activity registered a quick pick-up yesterday in the wholesale markets here. Mail orders received by the resident offices were quite heavy and retailers took action to spur deliveries on orders which have been notably delayed.

BANFF, Alta., Aug. 21 (Canadian Press) -- The entire capitalistic system of the world must be readjusted before the ills now affecting it can be cured and before the problem of unemployment can be solved, according to Newton D. Baker, head of the United States delegation, declared before the Institute of Pacific Relations here today.

Charges of fradulent practices and unworthiness to act as real estate brokers brought against the McAteer Realty Company, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, have resulted in the revocation of the company's license, it was disclosed yesterday by A.S. Wechsler, deputy chief of the Division of Licenses.

Frank J. Denniston announced yesterday that he had submitted his resignation as director of the North Atlantic district of the Merchant Fleet Corporation, operating department of the Shipping Board, to become executive head of the North Atlantic Terminals Service, Inc., lessees of the government piers in Hoboken.

ALBANY, Aug. 21 -- Three representatives of the Community Councils of New York City appeared before the State Milk Control Board this afternoon at a hearing called to obtain the viewpoint of consumers. They were Captain Eil Greenberg, chairman of the special milk committee; Frank P. Beal and Atwood Russell.

After the derangement of last week in the commodity markets, Wall Street moved carefully yesterday. There was a pervasive optimism, but the spirit of caution was abroad. Everywhere the disposition was to await the turn of the seasons at Labor Day.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The National Recovery Administration hopes to complete writing a code for the bituminous coal industry tomorrow, according to reports tonight from General Johnson's office.

Adjustment of the difficulties surrounding the codification of the major industries under the National Industrial Recovery Act gave impetus to all the markets yesterday. Stocks closed substantially higher on the day and commodities retraced most of the ground lost in an early reaction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP). -- The Pennsylvania and Grand Trunk Western Railroads applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to acquire control of the Grand Trunk-Pennsylvania Transportation Company with the intention of buying four car ferries on Lake Michigan owned by the Grand Trunk-Milwaukee Car Ferry Company.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 21 -- Through its chairman, Senator A. Crozer Reeves of Mercer County, the Legislature's Joint Committee on Taxation issued a final statement today defending its proposals for imposition of new taxes to relieve real estate and making sharp reply to criticism Voiced by Emerson L. Richards, Senate President.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- A tea was given this afternoon on the terrace overlooking the Sagamore Beach Club by Mrs. James L. Hand, donor of the permanent cup for the third annual amateur Sagamore tennis tournament, in honor of the players and sponsors.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- Joseph B. Eastman. Federal Coordinator of Transportation, has received from the railroads regional coordinating committees communications indicating cooperation with his desire that they assume charge of a survey being taken collectively in each region by the railroads to ascertain possible economies through unification or joint use of facilities and the consolidation or pooling of traffie services.
MANILA, Aug. 21 -- Despite strong objections from the Osmena-Roxas faction, Senator Quezon's majority moved forward smoothly today toward approval of the independence plebiscite bill.

The resignations of Joseph Stanley-Brown and Hayward Cleveland as president of the board of directors and superintendent, respectively, of Jamaica Hospital were accepted by the executive committee of the institution's board of directors after a protracted meeting yesterday, it became known last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP).-- A contention that a forty-hour week in the leather industry would "make no contribution to the recovery campaign" was advanced before the NRA today by labor leaders of the trade in appealing for shorter hours and higher pay than the industry proposed under its code.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 -- Densmore Shute said today he probably would meet Johnny Goodman of Omaha, the United States open golf titleholder, in a match for the "world's championship" at the Miami-Biltmore Country Club, Miami, in February.
LONDON, Aug. 21. -- The draft of a proposed wheat agreement that would bind consuming nations to increase their purchases was submitted today at the International Wheat Conference. The text follows:

BOSTON, Aug. 21 -- Eighteen men were captured with the sixty-foot power yacht Pueblos, loaded with $60,000 worth of liquor, and two seven-ton refrigerator trucks by customs agents after a chase in Scituate Harbor early this morning.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21-- An ordinance permitting the city of San Francisco to borrow in the open market a maximum of $5,135,000 to take care of municipal obligations during the so-called "dry period" from now until taxes become due in December was adopted by the Board of Supervisors today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- The drive of the United States for Latin-American business will open officially tomorrow when discussions with Colombia will begin here. Dr. Fabio Lozano, the Colombian Minister, will hold his first meeting at that time with William Phillips, Acting Secretary of State, and Jefferson Caffery, Assistant Secretary.

One hundred and twelve classes make up the prize list of the National Horse Show for 1933, which was announced yesterday by President J. Spencer Weed. Premium lists will be sent to exhibitors all over the United States and Canada. Entries will close on Oct. 17.

Authority to take control of the Westchester Title and Trust Company of White Plains, for rehabiliitation and for the protection of creditors and investors, was granted to George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, in a Supreme Court decision yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -- All corporations not otherwise specifically exempted will be subject to the capital stock tax for the entire year if they have been "doing business" after June 15, 1933, for any part of a taxable year, the Internal Revenue Bureau ruled today.
NARROWSBURG, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Details of the program for the visit of President Roosevelt at the reservation of the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York on Wednesday were being worked out today.

HAVANA, Aug. 21. -- The strike of 3,000 dock workers and stevedores, which has paralyzed shipping at Cuban ports or the past seventeen days, was settled tonight when the steamship companies and labor unions reached an agreement for the resumption of work tomorrow morning.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Driving rain and a rough sea resulted in the Midget sailing championship of Long Island Sound being postponed today. It was to have been started under the auspices of the Larchmont Yacht Club.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 2 (AP). -- Dr. Mack, a 2-year-old pace today won the feature event of th Grand Circuit's inaugural at th 1933 Illinois State Fair. With $60 added the race, the Illinois Breeders Futurity, was worth $811.75.

OUT of the elevator stepped Karl August Grimm, portrait painter, cabinet-worker, banjo soloist in Grimm's Family Orchestra (rates for all festive occasions) and manager of the Chicago Cubs. He was wearing a gray suit, a gray felt hat and his customary coating of deep tan on his smiling countenance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Presi dent Roosevelt is expected to set up within the next week the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation which, beginning Jan. 1, is to guarantee the security of bank deposits up to $2,500 on an individual account.

Jane R. Hopkins and Lyman Mason left Oklahoma City a week ago Thursday to be married in Tulsa. They quarreled on the way and were afraid to return. Yesterday they were held in West Side Court here as vagrants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- A basis for a soft coal coda has been prepared by the Recovery Administration but the Important provisions of wages and hours are still blank, it was reported today at General Johnson's office.

Controller Charles W. Berry, charged with neglecting his official duties after he had applied for retirement, asked the Board of Estimate yesterday to withhold action on his retirement until the charges had been disposed of by Governor Lehman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The Federal Emergency Administration of Public Works entered today on what Secretary of the Interior Ickes, as administrator, described as the "second phase" of its operations, namely, the starting of the new decentralized State organization.

BANFF, Alta., Aug. 22 (Canadian Press). -- An indication that Japan would modify her regulations denying privileges of coastwise trade to foreign ships if other nations would do the same was heard today at the conference of the Institute of Pacific Relations.

The fusion harmony committee held another conference yesterday without making any progress in its efforts to get Warren B. Ashmead, Queens County Republican chairman, to put a Democrat on the Queens Republican county ticket.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Vice Commodore Henry Cross, chairman of the Seaside Park Yacht Club Regatta Committee, announced tonight the entries already received for the fifth annual Bamberger Trophy series for International Star Class yachts to be held on Barnegat Bay on Sept. 2, 3 and 4.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Organized labor expects the National Recovery Act to settle once for all the right of employes to organize and bargain collectively, free from coercion by employers.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa will arrive today from Bremen and Channel ports. On board are Thomas W. Lamont, banker; John N. Willys, former Ambassador to Poland and chairman of the Willys-Overland Company; Joseph E. Wldener of Philadelphia and Fritz von Opal, son of the motor car manufacturer.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,766,500 barrels, compared with 2,789,600 in the previous week, a decline of 23,100 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decrease of 44,000 barrels daily in Oklahoma and an increase of 18,100 in East Texas were among the most important changes.

PRAGUE, Aug. 22. -- A demand that within the next ten years land and employment must be provided in Palestine for hundreds of thousands of Jews and in the next two generations for millions was the feature of the political report presented in today's session of the Eighteenth World Zionist Congress by Professor Selig Brodetzky of Leeds, England.

The Association for the Aid of Crippled Children, 105 East Twenty-second Street, will receive eventually the residuary estate of Milo M. Belding, one of the founders of Belding Brothers, silk thread manufacturers and distributers, valued at $3,112,817.57, according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday.
Although most of yesterday's real estate trading was done on the east side, One of the largest deals of the day was the purchase by Frederick Brown of a large apartment house on the upper west side.

Difficulties of apartment house owners and managers in operating under the National Recovery Act Code system were explained to nearly 1,000 members of the Real Estate Board of New York yesterday afternoon at a meeting in the Hotel Commodore ballroom by Lawrence A. Cummings, vice president of the board.

Following charges here that President von Hindenburg of Germany is being held incomunicado in his own land, the German Embassy in Washington confirmed a report last night that it had refused to forward to President von Hindenburg a memorial prepared last week by the American Jewish Congress about conditions in Germany.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Frank Grabem, champion, of the Plandome Golf Club, scored an impressive 38, 34 -- 72 on the rainsoaked Westchester Hills Country Club links today to win in the first flight of the New York Athletic Club one-day golf tournament.

Despite the failure of the World Economic Conference to make headway in reducing tariffs, Secretary HULL retains his faith that it will be possible to remove some of the barriers which cripple trade. Washington dispatches state that he believes the revised plan presented by him at London offers a practicable method of procedure.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Aug. 22. -- A field of nearly forty intrepid linkswomen braved the threatening weather today to participate in the one-day tournament held on the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club course under the auspices of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

A code for owners and operators of ships was adopted yesterday by the executive committee of the American Steamship Owners Association. A special committee headed by J. Caldwell Jenkins, vice president of the Black Diamond Steamship Company, which had worked on the matter for six weeks, submitted the proposal to the meeting of about fifty shipping executives.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 22. -- An explosion in one of the machine rooms of the Celluloid Corporation plant at 76 Westcott Street here this morning cost the lives of three employes and resulted in injuries to five other persons, one of whom is in a critical condition.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- Norman W. Church's 3-year-old colt Northgalis triumphed by a neck over Jake Lowenstein's Aladdin's Dream in the mile and a sixteenth race which held the feature position on the card at Hawthorne today. Her Elegance, from the stable of Otto W. Lehmann, ran third after having been backed into favoritism.

In "King Edward VII," E. F. Benson, himself the son of an Archbishop of Canterbury, reports on the old Edwardian sport of tobogganning down staircases on teatrays without neglecting King Edward's influence on British foreign policy and his services to the cause of international amity.

The Agricultural Mortgage Bank of Colombia, controlled by the Colombian Government, has arranged to take over the portfolio of the Mortgage Bank of Colombia, according to word received here yesterday. The Agricultural Bank has approximately $24,000,000 of bonds outstanding here and the Mortgage Bank, about $11,000,000.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 22. -- An automobile salesman from Clinton, Ind., was crowned trapshooting's champion of champions in today's feature event of the Grand American Handicap tournament -- the battle between holders of State titles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- An administration promise to clarify its position on the labor provisions of the Recovery Act tonight brought closer the prospects for an agreement on a code of fair practices for the automobile industry.

State of Colorado. Further diminution of the normal volume of State and municipal borrowing in the open market is in prospect as the result of the enactment of legislation this week by the State of Colorado authorizing the borrowing of $20,000,000 for highway construction from the Federal Government.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 22. -- The national doubles tennis tournament today advanced into the second round of play with the twelve seeded teams surviving at the Longwood Cricket Club Courts, Chestnut Hill.

Edward J. Ahearn, Democratic leader in the Fourth Assembly District and former State Senator, issued a statement early this morning in which he said that his name had been published in an evening newspaper yesterday as one of the Democratic leaders accused by the Federal District Attorney and he demanded, "inasmuch as the charge is utterly false in every respect," that Mr. Medalie either substantiate his accusation or retract it immediately.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 22. -- After hearing charges by Senate President Emerson L. Richards, chairman, that brewery interests had sought to block permanent beer legislation by payment of a bribe, the State Beverage Commission formally approved tonight the draft of a bill creating a State excise commission of four members.

BERLIN, Aug. 22. -- Alfred Ernst, division commander of the Berlin storm troops, the Hitlerite army, called today at the United States Embassy and made a formal apology to Ambassador Dodd for the assault by one of his troopers upon Dr. Daniel Mulvihill of New York a week ago.
PALO ALTO, Aug. 22. -- The text of former President Hoover's telegram to Prosecutor Toy follows:
LONDON, Aug. 22. -- News of Europe's unprecedented wheat crop and North America's huge additional surplus threw the world wheat situation into uncertainty and anxiety today.

With active preparations under way at State NRA headquarters at the Hotel Pennsylvania for the Blue Eagle drive starting next Monday, W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Committee for the State of New York, announced yesterday that great emphasis was being placed on the undertaking as one of cooperation.

Stockholders of the Fox Film Corporation which was reorganized recently, elected yesterday a new board of directors, which included only three members of the old board. The new board consists of Sidney R. Kent, W.C. Michel, John D. Clark, Harley L. Clarke, H. Donald Campbell, Richard F. Hoyt, Daniel O. Hastings, Arthur W. Loasby, Ernest W. Niver, Herman G. Place, Seton Porter and Sydney Towell.

Internal dissension in the ranks of both the Democratic and Republican parties, with the trouble centring in Manhattan, was reflected in the designations for the primary elections, filed up to midnight last night. The time for filing expired at midnight.
Conveyance of several industrial parcels in Jersey City featured the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

A warning that abuse of Paragraph 14 of the President's Agreement, intentional or otherwise, "may seriously prejudice the success of the re-employment program," was sounded yesterday by Mark Eisner, chairman of the local NRA Bureau of Interpretations.

LANDAU, the Palatinate, Germany, Aug. 22. -- It is usually assumed that the Jews in the small towns and villages of Germany suffer more at the hands of the antiSemitic Nazis than the Jews in the larger cities, on the theory that small-town animosities and neighborhood control of the buying public are likely to find more violent and more effective expression in the rural regions than amid the great anonymity of metropolitan populations.

CLOVIS, N.M., Aug. 22. -- Aroused by the ruthless depredations of gunmen and the slaying of six wellknown Southwestern peace officers, a posse of 200 men-every one ready to shoot-has declared war to the death on bands of desperate criminals infesting the one-time stamping grounds of Billy the Kid.

Nikolas Parfomchuk was shaking all over as he stood in Fulton Fish Market yesterday, waiting for the red-faced man to give him the daily ration of free seconds that has kept the five other Parfomchuks alive these last few months. Fish, fish, fish, every day, and sometimes fish soup.
DETROIT, Aug. 22. -- Former President Hoover declined an invitation today to come here to give testimony before the grand jury inquiry into the closing of two national banks last Winter.

Major league baseball, still strug gling to climb "out of the red," must adopt the proposal for a mid Summer series of inter-league games or do something equally drastic in order to revive interest in 1934, in the belief of William L. (Bill) Veeck, president of the Chicago Cubs.

Sword fishing off Montauk has not been of high quality in recent days, due, say the boat captains, to the prevailing east wind that has whipped up the waters, keeping all kinds of game fish far at sea.
FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Aug. 22. -- A legal exchange of wives was revealed here today with the news that two army officers had remarried, each wedding the former wife of the other.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Both galleries of Guild Hall in East Hampton are devoted to an exhibition of new and characteristic work by six artists of New York and East Hampton. The exhibition opened today and will continue until Sept. 5.

Leases of apartments for the coming Fall season were reported in large volume yesterday. The Upper east side led in the number of rentals. though the west side was not far behind. Among the leases were the following:

The Lyceum Theatre in West Forty-fifth Street is among those ancient houses listed by smart, new stage magazines under the general heading of "dark." Its wide doube doors are locked against a public which, in fact, no longer cares to intrude, and dust has gathered among its heavily carved panels.

DUBLIN, Aug. 22. -- The Free State Government outlawed tonight the National Guard, formerly the Army Comrades' Association, and re-established the military tribunal of five army officers to hear charges under the resurrected Public Safety Act.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Aug. 22. -- Without giving any indication of their intentions, Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh slipped away quietly this morning and were followed soon by their mother ship, the Jelling. The Lindberghs' seaplane turned inland and at 6:30 P.M., Greenwich Time, landed at Eskefjord near Seydisfjord on the eastern coast.

ALBANY, Aug. 22. -- Despite strong pressure from Governor Lehman and in the face of his special message, members of his own party again killed in committee today all the major items in his public utility program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Importers cited the poetry of the Stein Song of Old Heidelberg and the pathos of the man who wants English ale for his stomach's sake in pleas before the Tariff Commission today for a 50 per cent cut in the duty on foreign brew.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Plans were being formulated by General Johnson today for mobilizing Federal credit behind those industries and trades that have enlisted in the work-spreading and wage-raising program of the NRA.

Except for the demonstration of strength in the shares of automobile companies the stock market fell short of its usual entertainment standards yesterday. But Wall Street found it illuminating as an index to sentiment. From the action of the market it was concluded that the forces of optimism were still in control.

After pottering around in the outskirts of the great city "Love and Babies" became last evening a recognized inhabitant at the Cort where Mr. Truex and three other actors tried to assemble their senses of humor. Mr. Truex is a jaunty comedian when the circumstances of the play are favorable.
President Machado from the Bahamas for trial here on charges ranging from murder to malfeasance will be passed upon Friday by the criminal section of the Cuban Supreme Court.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 22 (AP) -- Purchase of 40,000,000 pounds of dark fired tobacco, or the entire holdings of the Eastern and Western Dark Fired Tobacco Growers Associations of Tennessee and Kentucky, was announced here tonight by Rogers Caldwell, investment banker.

A 14-year-old boy saved two young children from drowning yesterday in Sheepshead Bay. They were struggling helplessly in the choppy water when he saw their plight and plunged in. While some 200 persons looked on, the boy brought the two to safety; then he vanished, saying he did not want "to answer questions about it."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The text of a proposed code for Public Schools and Public School Teachers, as submitted to the NRA by the executive council of the American Federation of Teachers but which the NRA has declined to consider since teachers do not come under the NRA is as follows:

RED BANK, N.J., Aug. 22. -- An explosion, believed to have been caused by bomb, damaged today the home here of S.S. Thompson, general contractor. Although the concussion broke windows in nearby houses and roused the neighborhood, Mr. Thompson, his wife, two daughters, a son and a niece were uninjured.

An opera, Puccini's "Madame Butterfly," was presented last night at Lewisohn Stadium, but not in full dress. Until an hour before starting time the management believed that it would be necessary to take the performance indoors, and when it was decided to brave the threatening rain it was too late to hang the sets.

Nathan Lamport, philanthropist, retired merchant and realty owner, who left half his net estate to aid fellow-Jews when he died on Aug. 13, 1928, left an estate appraised yesterday at $1,261.188 gross and $928.307 net. The chief beneficiary was the Ansl Charity Foundation, for which he chose a title made up of the initials of his Hebraic name.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The statement of General Johnson at the hearing on the retail code today was as follows:

BERLIN, Aug. 22. -- The inhabitants of Berlin are watching with much interest, tinctured with some uneasiness, preparations of extraordinary thoroughness that are being made to counter any future danger from the air.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is always a pleasure to find that THE TIMES readers are lovers of nature and especially of birds. Spuyten Duyvil is eight minutes from Broadway, but because of the trees and gardens we have many feathered friends, both permanent and transient.

An enthusiastic county grand jury yesterday heard United States Attorney George Z. Medalie tell what he knew of an alliance between racketeers and politicians, and afterward, with a burst of applause, voted to continue the investigation into rackets.

Too Well Prepared? NEWTON D. BAKER told the Institute of Pacific Relations at Banff that one Paramount need for solving the problems of mankind is a new type of education. Youth must not be trained along classical lines, but with an eye on the actual conditions of life outside of college.
Irregularity developed yesterday in the principal commodities, with shading of prices in several instances. Sugar, however, was strong and moderately active. Cash markets were generally stronger.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Life terms for every one of the eleven suspects in the Charles F. Urschel kidnapping, whether principals or accomplices, will be demanded by the government, Joseph B. Keenan, Special Assistant United States Attorney General, said tonight.

ALBANY, Aug. 22. -- After signing the bill appropriating $75,000 for the Milk Control Board today, Governor Lehman called upon the board to begin an immediate investigation of the cost of distributing milk.

To the Editor of The New York Times Why the Blue Eagle as an emblem? Why not the Little Brown Hen? That has always done its part, while the screaming eagle, with its predatory instincts, wars on every defenseless living creature, tame or wild.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22 (AP). -- Philadelphia batters collected three home runs today while West was the only St. Louis representative to duplicate the feat, and the Athletics won, 7 to 6. It was the fifth straight defeat for Rogers Hornsby's last place Browns.

NEW YORK. Lionel Marks of London gave a dinner last night at the Pierre. His guests included Captain and Mrs. Lawson Johnstone, Mr. and Mrs. John H.F. Haskell, Miss Genevieve Kenny, Miss Violet Hughes, the Earl of Gosford and Andre de Saint Phale.

Texas is to vote next Saturday on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. The campaign has shown Democratic ranks divided. Vice President GARNER has urged the State to add its vote to that of the twenty-two others which have already voted for repeal. Representative JOE BAILEY and ex-Governor JIM FERGUSON have been speaking on the same side of the question.

The Society of Restaurateurs met yesterday afternoon at the Aldine Club, 200 Fifth Avenue, to formulate the views it will present at the hearing on the restaurant industry's proposed basic code in Washington next Monday.

PARIS, Aug. 22. -- The conference of the Second International today completed its second day with procedure still in the speech-making stage, and without the Americans having yet had a chance to speak.

HAVANA, Aug. 22. -- Colonels Carlos Mendieta and Roberto Mendez Penate, leaders of the Union Nationalists and leaders of the August (1931) rebellion, returning from exile in the United States, were welcomed this morning with the greatest demonstration seen in Havana since the beginning of the late Machado regime.

Pronounced strength in United States Government bonds was the feature of an otherwise irregular bond market yesterday on the Stock Exchange. The long-term Treasury issues mounted 1-32 to 9-32 point with the exception of the Liberty 3 1/2 s, which eased 232, and the 3 1/8 s, which held unchanged.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- The grain markets moved steadily forward today after faltering at the opening. At the top wheat on the Board of Trade here was up 2 7/8 cents a bushel from the early low, while rye was as much as 5 cents higher from yesterday's finish, that being the maximum rise permitted under the market's regulations.

Both the death rate and the birth rate dropped In New York City last week, it was announced by Dr. Shlrley W. Wynne, Health Commissioner. The death rate, 7.48 for each 1,000 of population, was the lowest for any week so far this year.

The National Legitimate Theatre Committee, the tribunal which will govern the theatrical industry under the provisions of the NRA, will start to function on Monday, when the first meeting will be held in the offices of the League of New York Theatres in the Paramount Building.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- The stock markets were less active today, profit-taking causing most sections to become irregular. A sharp advance in British funds followed a strong investment demand, partly as a result of quietness elsewhere.

All of us admire Postmaster General FARLEY'S energy and success in applied politics. He never wearies of well-saying and well-doing. Even at his Summer capital in the New Jersey Deal he doesn't cease from his labors with tongue and pen. Already his far gaze is directed to 1936; and he re-elects Mr. ROOSEVELT as easily as he elected him.
To the Editor of The New YorK Times: You omit certain interesting and, I believe, vital facts in your comments concerning women's fashions and their role in the recovery.
Plaintiffs bought in eleven properties at auction sales yesterday. One property was withdrawn from sale and one scheduled sale was adjourned. The results follow:
BRISTOL, England, Aug. 22 (Canadian Press). -- Gloucestershire defeated the touring British West Indies cricket eleven by 7 wickets today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The reestablishment of order in Cuba, which is taken for granted here, has turned the attention of the administration to the financial plight of the island. State Department officials today were engaged in a study of the indebtedness which the de Cespedes government will have to face.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The War Deparment issued the following orders today dated Aug. 19:

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- The rafters of the gymnasium of Armour Co. in the Union Stock Yard's rang with protests of minority stockholders today as T. George Lee, president, forced through the assemblage a motion adjourning until Sept. 1 the special meeting called to ratify the management's plan for reorganization of the company's capital.

The Lewisohn Stadium season will be extended to permit the production of two post-season performmances of opera, Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheim, chairman of Stadium Concerts, Inc., announced yesterday. The unexpected demand for tickets for the performance of "Madame Butterfly" last night was given as the reason.

BERLIN, Aug. 22. -- Weakness on the Boerse continued today despite the official announcement of another big drop in unemployment figures. With a few exceptions, the stock list sagged, the losses ranging up to 5 per cent. Some finan- cial commentators are expressing alarm at the continued decline, which is endangering many accounts.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 22. -- Mrs. Cornelia Bryce Pinchot, who has appeared in the picket lines and encouraged strikers in several parts of Pennsylvania, received a union card here today from the American Federation of Full Fashioned Hosiery Workers.

H.C. Abell, who has served with the Electric Bond and Share group of utilities since 1921, has resigned all offices and directorates in that company and its affiliates and is retiring from active business. His home is in New Orleans. The directors of the Memphis Street Railway Company, a subsidiary of the National Power and Light Company, yesterday accepted his resignation as a director, but other units have not yet taken action.
Daniel C. Mulloncy, Boston banker, was arrested here yesterday as he left the Federal grand jury, where he had been a witness in an investigation into the income of former Mayor Walker.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 22. -- The Yankees encountered a gale and the Indians in the Municipal Stadium today and downed the clan of Walter Johnson, 4 to 3, in the opening game of the series.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- Hector C. Bywater, The Daily Telegraph's well-informed naval correspondent announces tonight that as a result of the United States and Japanese programs new plans are expected from the Admiralty for restoring Great Britain's sea power.

BERLIN, Aug. 22. -- Circumstances, which sometimes favor diplomats as well as sailors and other persons whom a kind providence protects, have come to the rescue of the diplomatic corps in Germany in a somewhat difficult situation. It is in the matter of the rally of Nazi storm troopers in Nuremberg, which is to begin Aug. 30 and be a notable celebration.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Mrs. Harvey Nathaniel Davis, wife of the president of Stevens Institute of Technology, was struck and killed by a hit and run driver as she rode a bicycle on the Montauk Highway near here at 8 o'clock tonight.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- A heavy track and rain contributed to the rough treatment accorded favorites today at Saratoga, all six favorites meeting defeat. Tambour administered the worst shock to form when she was defeated at 3 to 5 in the Champlain Handicap.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had ordered the New York Telephone Company to submit separate bills for advertising and classified directory listings. The inclusion of charges for such items in bills for telephone service is forbidden.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (Canadian Press). -- Sussex scored the most decisive victory in the series of first-class county cricket matches concluding today, trouncing Worcester by an innings and 73 runs at Eastbourne.

Although the New York Public Library experienced a marked Increase in attendance as the depression developed, it has noticed no corresponding decrease this Summer despite the drop in unemployment, it was revealed yesterday at the main building at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

The only development in the money market was a reduction of 1/8 in the yield for bills maturing in four, five and six months, the previous rates having been in effect since July 7. Call loans renewed at 1 per cent, with outside funds quoted at 3/4 per cent.

The accomplishment of the National Recovery Administration thus far in increasing wages and employment alone "entitles the plan to further trial and full cooperation," former Governor Alfred E. Smith declared last night in inaugurating a series of addresses by prominent men on the NIRA.

The action taken by the Navy Department in placing civil workers in the yards on a five-day week, with a corresponding reduction in pay, is considered by President Roosevelt as a "temporary measure," according to information received yesterday by Thomas Mahoney, secretary of the Metal Trades Council of the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

There were forty-three passengers from Havana on the Ward liner Orlente, which docked yesterday from Mexico after a call at the Cuban port. Approximately half of these were Cuban refugees, according to officers of the vessel.

Buyer Registrations Off Sharply The number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a marked decrease under the total listed for the corresponding week a year ago and also in comparison with the previous week's registrations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The White Sox routed their Boston jinx today and swept both ends of a double-header with the Red Sox, 8 to 1 and 4 to 0. The White Sox previously had taken only two out of eleven games from the Boston club this season.

Trading on the Cotton Exchange reflected yesterday an undertone of resistance to selling pressure, and after prices had held within a narrow range early they moved upward $1 a bale and at the end of the session showed gains of 10 to 17 points.
The promised tropical hurricane did not arrive here as scheduled yesterday, but high northeast winds and violent rain squalls swept the metropolitan area during the early morning hours.

A committee to study and report on the proper use of the leisure accruing to millions as a result of shorter working hours under the NRA program was appointed yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, City Chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Campaign.
CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 22. -- The old army game of "cussing at the mules" became one of "cussing" about the lack of mules here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Representatives of 1,000,000 retail stores were told by General Johnson today that the Recovery Administration would not stand for the reaping of "an expedient profit by a sort of speculative pricing of goods."
