WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- A proposed national marketing agreement for fluid milk is being drafted by Agricultural Adjustment Administration officials and dairymen. It would fix minimum and maximum prices for milk and place definite limits on price spreads.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 19:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- An application by the Western Pacific Railroad for a loan of $1,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to pay interest due on Sept. 1 has failed of approval by the finance division of the Interstate Commerce Commission on the ground that it would not be adequately secured.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The United States is authoritatively pronounced ready to accept supervision and control of armament manufacturers by a joint international authority as part of a hoped for world disarmament agreement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a citizen of the State of New York I wish to support with all possible heartiness the report and resolutions relative to county and local government in this State which were unanimously adopted at a meeting of Democrats held at Elmira on Saturday last.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- A plan of the Federal Emergency Relief Administration to aid needy, unemployed teachers by authorizing expenditure of relief funds to furnish them employment in certain j cases, was announced today. It will provide for the reopening of schools in many States, especially in rural sections, which have been closed for lack of public funds.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 22. -- The State Federation of Labor at the opening session of its annual convention today moved to get behind the National Recovery program.
The battle of Forest Hills continued to remain a washout yesterday.

All markets were firm yesterday, but they failed to arouse any great amount of speculative enthusiasm. Transactions on the Stock Exchange made up a total of 1,963,000 shares which, at this season, is considered a sub-normal volume by comparison with the earlier Summer average.
Rain for the second successive day kept the Giants in idleness yesterday, when it washed out the double-header with the Cubs. This time Manager Bill Terry Was something more than Just mildly put out.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I call the attention of employers to the functions of the New York State Employment Service? It maintains a complete employment service suitable for every industry and last year served more than 36,000 employers.

NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Aug. 22. -- With a fine 72 this afternoon, coupled with a 75 this morning, Johnny Golden of Wee Burn retained the Connecticut open golf championship at the Shuttle Meadow Country Club. His 72-hole total was 291.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- Two men arrested in Kansas City as suspects in a $131,000 registered mall band theft on the steamer Leviathan were brought to Chicago by airplane today and locked up in an outlying police station.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 22 (AP). -- Driven by Doc Parshall, Lee Storm won the free-for-all pace in today's feature event on the Grand Circuit program.

ALBANY, Aug. 22. -- The Republican-controlled Assembly was preparing tonight for a show-down tomorrow over the Buckley bill empowering the City of New York to raise funds for unemployment relief through local taxation. The bill has already passed the Democratic Senate by a straight party vote.

Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, declared yesterday that the entire future of rate reductions in the State was being endangered by the opposition of public service corporations to Governor Lehman's utilities program.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 22. -- Argentine public opinion appears irrevocably convinced that Bolivia's intransigence and the consequent failure of the ABCP negotiations are due directly to Bolivia's enjoying the political support of the United States Government, the financial support of big American interests and the moral support of the American people.

Huey Long, the Louisiana Senator, Bible student and mathematician, held forth before a group of interviewers at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday, quoted Scripture texts to urge inflation and stumped the audience with algebra problems to demonstrate the need of Sabbatical years for reviewing what one learned in school.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP). -- An investigation by Attorney General Cummings into what he termed a campaign to drive down the price of cotton through short selling was asked today by Senator Thomas of Oklahoma.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- There was a total of about 960,000,000 bushels of wheat in the world on Aug. 1, and the United States had about 36 per cent of the amount, or 345,000,000.

The first five railroads to report earnings for July showed a total net operating income of $7,697,000 in that month, against $2,841,000 in July, 1932, an increase of 170.9 per cent and against $4,594,000 in July, 1931, a rise of 67.5 per cent. The total for July was 1.35 per cent ahead of that for June, which in turn was 224 per cent greater than in June 1932.

The 1934 city budget will show an increase of at least $50,640,000 over the current budget before any economies can be made, it was said yesterday by Samuel Untermyer, special financial counsel to the Board of Estimate and the Mayor.

VIENNA, Aug. 22. -- An anti-Austrian speech of even more ferocious tenor than its predecessors was broadcast from Munich tonight by an anonymous "exiled leader of the Austrian Nazis." which was taken to indicate that the toning down of Nazi propaganda against Austria after the Franco-British demand was intended to be only temporary.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 22 (AP). -- A plea for the support of governmental efforts to restore "normal and reasonable living conditions for those willing to work," and a demand for economy in places "where it is worse needed" than "at the expense of the veterans," was voiced today by Louis A. Johnson, National Commander of the American Legion, at the convention of the Michigan Department.

The five steps that must be taken to comply with the President's Reemployment Agreement and to obtain the Blue Eagle are outlined by General Hugh S. Johnson, National Recovery Administrator, in an official explanation of the President's Agreement, made public in every part of the country yesterday.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 22 (AP). -- The Summit County grand jury indicted six former officers of the First-Central Trust Company today on charges of misapplication of funds. The First-Central was Akron's largest bank at the time it failed to receive a license to reopen after the national banking holiday in March.

Rumblings of discontent were still evident in the dress industry last night as its leaders moved to Washington for the code hearing today, after ratification yesterday by the contractors of the terms of the strike settlement.

BARCELONA, Aug. 22. -- The rebellious citizens or Andorra today issued a new defiance of their eoprinces, the President of France and the Spanish Bishop of Urgel, who are attempting to enforce thetr authority by an invasion of French gendarmes.

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- The Reich Institute for Labor Placement and Unemployment Insurance announces that the number of registered unemployed in Germany decreased 130,000 more during the first half of August, bringing the total down to 4,334,158.
The drive of the local NRA already is showing a marked and favorable effect on local industry, Edward C. Rybicki, director of the City Free Employment Agency, said yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 23 -- President Roosevelt's instructions to Norman H. Davis to support the principle of the French proposal for setting up a system of armaments control throughout the world has been warmly welcomed here. It comes at a moment when the European situation seems to many to be getting into an almost inextricable tangle.

LANDAU, Germany, Aug. 23 -- The Palatinate is a land of winedrinking Bavarians as distinguished from the beer-drinking Bavarians of Munich and the adjacent territory. Just as the Bavarian breweries are eager to develop trade to the United States, so the Palatinate wine growers look forward to the repeal of American prohibition as the possible salvation of their chronic distress.

A harvest dance and carnival will be held on the night of Sept. 9 at Brookside Farm, the country residence of Colonel and Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler in Rye, for the benefit of the Child Study Association of America and its Summer play schools committee.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 23 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury quickly indicted fourteen persons today in the kidnapping of Charles F. Urschel, oil man, completing a secret hearing in only five hours.

Developments in the money market were centred in time loans, where the rates for five and six months' funds were reduced to 1@ 1 1/4 per cent, against 1 1/4@ 1 1/2 previously, and in bankers' acceptances, where a reduction of 1/8 of 1 per cent in the yields for sixty and ninety days' bills was made.

ALBANY, Aug. 23 -- New York City retailers and big dealers joined today in the plea for a rise in price to the consumer within the territory they serve. The Milk Control Board was told that the 1 cent a quart rise was needed to keep the retailers from "going out of business," while representatives of large distributing concerns urged "immediate rises" to head off "bankruptcies right and left."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Carlos Pujol in his letter to THE TIMES has misconstrued the reference to Tomas Estrada Palma in my article "Cuba's Struggle: What Led to the Crisis." Nothing could have been further from my mind than to liken the character of Estrada Palma to that of Machado, or to impute personal corruption or tyranny to the former.
Reports from the Eastern States which permit quail shooting indicate that there will be an abundance of that fine game bird this Autumn.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 23 (AP). -- C. V. Whitney's Contraband scored his fourth successive victory and retained an unsullied record at Coney Island when he led home a small but select field of handicappers in the Wilmington, today's principal attraction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Secretary Ickes served notice today as the Public Works Administrator that allotments from the $3,300,000,000 Public Works Fund must be applied immediately to the opening up of new jobs, so that men now idle may be "moved swiftly from relief to payrolls."
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Cleat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade flattened out today after showing strength early. Wheat at the top was as much as 2% cents a bushel higher than yesterday and corn was up a cent. Late weakness in Winnipeg led to increased pressure on wheat, however, while scattered liquidation developed in September corn, and both grains eased quickly.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Five American teams, two from Australia and one from England gained the quarter-final round of the national doubles tennis championship on the slippery grass courts of the Longwood Cricket Club today.

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- The news reaching Germany today that President Roosevelt was sending Norman H. Davis back to the disarmament conference in September with Instructions to support a certain measure of armament control to be incorporated in the MacDonald plan, and to be ready to discuss a consultative pact to which the United States might adhere in order to appease the French susceptibilities, is featured in tonight's newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Cotton of this year's crop, ginned prior to Aug. 16 was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 459,911 running bales, counting 9,725 round bales as half bales. To that date last year, ginnings totaled 251,451 running bales, including 3,619 round bales, counted as half bales.

SILVER BAY ON LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- An assertion that President Roosevelt had made "the most significant contribution" to American history in the century by moving a nation to think was made by Henry H. Heimann, representing Secretary Roper, before the annual conference on industrial relations here tonight.

With all due respect to Jose Iturbi's musicianship and his power to attract the public, the hero of last night's Philharmonic-Symphony concert in the Great Hall of the City College was the audience. To have ventured out into the driving rainstorm and to have sat in an oppressively close hall to hear a program of music, no matter what the compositions or who the attraction, constituted courage and hardihood of rare quality.
WITH the Polo Grounds still under water, some of the Pirates engaged in a sedentary game of indoor baseball in the lobby of their hostelry. The line-up of one gossiping group was as follows:

Now that August is almost done, an attempt has been made to treat the theatre as a mature profession. Mrs. Pat Campbell and Cissie Loftus are appearing in Ivor Novello's "A Party," which was put on amidst a roar of rain at The Playhouse last evening.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- The Audley Farm's Royal Blunder led a select field of five 3-year-olds in the Fox Valley Purse, feature at Hawthorne, today. The Blue Ridge Farm's Dusky Devil was beaten a length to finish second, with Thomas H. McCaffrey's Big Red third.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- William G. Barrett, 55 years old, of Easton Avenue, one of this city's most prominent citizens and a member of an old Bedford family, shot and killed himself this morning after writing three notes, according to County Medical Examiner Amos O. Squire.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The legislative representatives of the Citizens Budget Commission issued the following statement regarding the New York City Central Purchase Bill passed today unanimously by both houses or the Legislature.

John F. Hylan, Children's Court justice, was nominated for Mayor last night by the New Deal party at a convention in the Amphion Theatre, at 437 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn. About 100 persons attended the convention, of which John F. Finn of Flushing acted as chairman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The text of his statement by General Johnson in his name and that of Donald R. Richberg, general counsel of the NRA, in the course of a radio speech tonight, wherein the Recovery Administrator sought to clarify the collective bargaining provision of the Recovery Act, is as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent letter to THE TIMES Paul Miersch complains that "the air on the lower floors of stores, motion-picture houses and the like is chilled often to a degree dangerous to one who enters from the broiling hot streets, while on the upper floors or galleries the temperature remains stifling."

A rehearing on the order reducing electric rates 6 per cent on Sept. 1 was requested of the Public Service Commission in a petition filed last night by former Judge William L. Ransom, counsel for the electric companies of the Consolidated Gas Company's system.

Fire Lieutenant Richard Burke of 196 East Thirty-second Street, Brooklyn, heads the civil service list for fire captairi with a percentage of 86.30 obtained in the examination last November, the Municipal Civil Service Commission announced yesterday.
ALBANY, Aug. 23 -- The bill investing the Attorney General with broad powers to open war on racketeering was passed unanimously in the Senate tonight. Approval in the Assembly is expected tomorrow.

CAMP DIX, N.J., Aug. 23 -- With streets flooded, the parade ground a lake and all military activities temporarily suspended in the worst storm in the history of this post, Camp Dix faces tonight the menace of a water famine. The electric power lines which supply current for the camp water works were broken when falling trees hit the wires.
Three bandoneon players and as many ordinary musicians, all of whom had been brought here from Argentina to play in a night club, were admitted conditionally to the United States yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Federal Government joined the State today in investigating the collapse last Spring of two of Cleveland's three largest banks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Demands that maximum working hours bear a fixed relation to hours that stores are kept open were voiced today at a long hearing on the retail trade stores code, which does not include food and drugs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been asked many times what it costs to produce a quart of milk on the farm. It costs today at least 4.5 cents to produce a quart (of milk on a well-managed dairy farm. Unfortunately, the average farmer knows little about figuring costs, and all his attempts have been more or less fruitless.

SPRINGFIELD, ILL., Aug. 23 -- (AP) -- Ben White, veteran driver, was spilled from his sulky during the Grand Circuit program at the Illinois State Fair today. He was treated at the Emergency Hospital for scratches and bruises about the face.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- General Johnson, supported by Donald R. Richberg, counsel for the NRA, moved tonight to settle the "open shop" controversy revolving around the government's program of industrial codification.

More than $6,000,000 of gold that had been earmarked for hoarding purposes was restored yesterday to the monetary gold stocks of the country after a ruling by the Treasury Department against giving an export license to the owner of the gold.

Ten charitable institutions will receive eventually $87,000 and the residue from the estate of Michael Gernsheim of 630 West 141st Street, who died on Aug. 4, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed in Surrogate's Court. The bequests are payable after the death of his daughter, Miss Alice J.N. Gernsheim of the same address, who receives a life income from the residuary estate.

More than 150 employes of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., credit rating firm at 290 Broadway, became violently ill of food poisoning late yesterday afternoon following luncheon in the employes' cooperative restaurant. Pending an analysis of the various items on the menu, the police were inclined to attribute the illness to egg-salad sandwiches that were served.

Statements by the National Recovery Administrator indicating that further credit expansion was in prospect as part of the NRA program stimulated the markets for a time yesterday, but the early gains were canceled when commodity prices turned downward in the afternoon.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 23 -- In some of the closest contests the Grand American Handicap trapshooting tournament has experienced for many years, class championships were settled today with more than 400 marksmen taking part.
A sale in the downtown shopping district of Jersey City was included in the New Jersey realty trading reported yesterday.

Wall Street was prepared yesterday for an active resumption of the advance and was disappointed when the early buying movement petered out. The expansion in trading activity pleased the brokers, who had been feeling the effects of the recent let-down.
From the storm centre off the Virginia Capes there came by radio yesterday a meager and often interrupted story of a stout old ship's winning fight against a gale and heavy seas.
WASHINGTON. Aug. 23 -- The War Department issued the following orders today: Fiske. Brig. Gen. H.B., appointed Major General. Aug. 1. 1933.

Supreme Court Justice Alfred Krankenthaler was designated yesterday by the Appellate Division of that court to hold an additional special term to hear and dispose of 11 matters relating to the rehabilitation of title and mortgage guarantee companies by George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 23 -- President Roosevelt desires peace between labor and the employer while the country is beating back to prosperity, according to views expressed by the President in a letter to Charles E. Johnston, president of the Kansas City Southern Railroad.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 23 -- Governor Cross today telegraphed General Johnson asking an "immediate public retraction" of a statement reported from his organization that Connecticut was not co-operating sufficiently in the NRA program.

Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, in keeping with a promise made a week ago at a dinner, revealed yesterday a list of boxing attractions that could very well be held in Madison Square Garden -- if the fighters would agree to fight.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 -- In a courtroom jammed to the doors, the Rev. Fr. Charles E. Coughlin today denounced the economic philosophy of Herbert Hoover during his administration, condemned Detroit banking methods, and charged two closed national banks here were "wrecked by the philosophy that money in the hands of the masses was a menace."

After three days of postponements, officials of the United States Lawn Tennis Association and the West Side Tennis Club were discouraged last night about bringing the women's championship to a conclusion at Forest Hills.

Retail Price Rise Broadening. The variety of merchandise now carrying higher retail prices because of increased replacement costs is steadily broadening, and indications are that the average rise for August will substantially exceed that reported for July, it was said here yesterday.

The Shippers' Conference of Greater New York acted yesterday to maintain the status of inland water lines as participants in the official classification governing through rates of the Eastern railroads and river and lake carriers. In a petition to the Interstate Commerce Commission the conference asked for suspension of the action of A.H. Greenly, agent of the classification committee of the railroads, barring the Seaboard-Great Lakes Corporation as a participant in the classification.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 -- Police guarded millinery shops today as the Cloth Hat, Cap and Millinery Workers Union called out all workers not already on strike. A few plants were still operating tonight, despite the general strike order, but more than 1,400 workers walked out.

CANTERBURY, England. Aug. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Kent, one of the leading first-class county cricket sides, opened its three-day match with the touring British West Indies team today by scoring 331 runs in the first innings.

From the beginning an air of unreality hung over the proceedings of the New York Legislature in special session. Never was there a clearer case of things not being what they seem. Tammany Senators sought to block the utility bills recommended by Governor LEHMAN.

Four members of the American team of track and field invaders returned from Europe yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa with considerably more baggage than they took over. Extra suitcases, won on the Continent, were loaded with cups, medals, cameras and other assorted prizes.
COPENHAGEN, Aug. 23 -- It is expected Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh will now fly here, ppssibly directly after refueling in the Faeroes or via Stavanger, Norway, where there is a large gasoline depot.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Washington caught the fag end of the hurricane that raged along the coast last night and today.

The grand jury, which had begun an investigation of rackets from which the office of District Attorney Grain was excluded, had its plans for secrecy upset yesterday when a transcript of the proceedings was laid before Assistant District Attorney Harold Hastings by the official stenographer.

PARIS, Aug. 23. -- President Roosevelt said in reply to a question that the United States would never agree to military sanctions proposed by the League of Nations, but that it was ready to approve economic sanctions against an aggressor nation, according to an article written by Mme. Kraemer-Bach for the newspaper Petit Parisien.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The new three-cent NRA postage stamps are being criticized as "too Russian" in design, also as below the normal standard of achievement of the engravers responsible for other Federal postage stamps.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Rumors that the administration might adopt some policy of inflation were again in circulation today. They followed the statement made yesterday by Hugh S. Johnson, NRA Administrator, that he had a plan to discuss with the Federal Reserve Board and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for an expansion of credit facilities which would speed up the NRA program.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- Miss Eugenie Rose, the Evanston nurse who caused the arrest on Saturday of Cecil Smith, Texas polo player, in the East-West match here, on a charge of criminal assault, announced today she would not prosecute the case.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- A completed program for issuance of bonds by the Home-Owners Loan Corporation for refinancing mortgages on small homes threatened with foreclosure will be announced within a few days by the Home Loan Bank Board.

Although prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced about 15 points once yesterday, a reaction occurred when the wheat and stock markets reacted. A break of $1.50 a bale left the list 11 to 17 points net lower. Resistance was shown for four hours, despite the favorable weekly weather summaries and reports of increasing curtailment in mill centres.

LONDON, Aug. 23. -- It is believed that Prime Minister Bennett of Canada has urgently appealed to the British Government for a drastic cut in the quantity of timber that Russia shall be allowed to send to Britain in the future.
Important increases in employment figures as a result of the State driye of the NRA were reported at the headquarters of W. Averell Harriman, State chairman yesterday.
TEN MILE RIVER CAMP, N. Y., Aug. 23 -- The text of President Roosevelt's speech to the Boy Scouts of New York City today was as follows:

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- The Boerse opened today with an attempt to steady itself following yesterday's declines, but renewed sales produced new weakness and caused additional losses up to 4 per cent. The decline started with the government valorization loan and soon spread to the stock list.

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- Yielding to National Socialist pressure, the Junkers of East Prussia adopted a resolution at a meeting in Konigsberg today offering to divide their big estates, in part at least, to provide land for the establishment of peasant homesteads.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Let Walter N. Thayer 3d take heed of facts so far not cited in letters to THE NEW YORK TIMES. The real fault, as I see it, lies in three places -- with the lawyers, the prison parole boards and the prison wardens.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Maitland Connfelt of Farley, Brookville, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Enid Connfelt, to Ogden Goelet, oldest Son of Robert Goelet of 2 East Sixty-first Street and Chester, N.Y., by his first wife, the former Miss Elsie Whelen of Philadelphia, now Mrs. Henry Clews of France.

Jews and Germans. The problem of the Jews in HITLER'S Germany is not exhausted by asking what will happen to approximately 600,000 Jews exposed to Nazi malice and fury. There is the bigger question of what will happen to the souls of 65,000,000 Germans who have been swept off their feet by Nazi agitation or compelled to be the reluctant witnesses of Nazi violence.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- Consideration was given to the abolition of the Westchester County Park Commission at a meeting today of the special committee of the Board of Supervisors. The comimittee now is studying means of effecting further economies in county and municipal government in Westchester County.

Although mill bookings "continue to lag and production has receded further," The Iron Age, in its midweek review, reports that a better feeling exists in the industry as a result of the final adoption of the steel code. This action, it asserts, "has cleared the atmosphere of many of the doubts and fears that had been accumulating in recent weeks."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The National Labor Board of the Recovery Administration ordered a settlement today of the strike of motion picture technicians at Hollwood.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Some small retailers, whose investment is not more than $500, were called sources of unfair competition today by A. Lincoln Wisler, president of the United Business Men's Association of Chicago, at the hearings on the retail code.

Yesterday's Washington dispatches gave the Agricultural Department's estimate of the world's "wheat carryover" on Aug. 1 as 960,000,000 bushels; the increase over last August being stated at 180,000,000 bushels. Although an increase had been expected, the figure given was somewhat startling.

ALBANY, Aug. 23 -- The Buckley bill, giving the Municipal Assembly in New York City blanket authority to impose local taxes for unemployment relief, was passed this evening in the Senate and Assembly, with amendments to protect non-residents against the special taxes.

A terrific northeast storm and in some places the tailend of a tropical hurricane battered the seaboard States from the Carolinas northward yesterday, menacing coastwise shipping and causing at least ten deaths and millions of dollars of property damage.

With output showing a greater-than-seasonal rise, the adjusted index of electric power production scored an advance of 1 point for the week ended Aug. 19. The figure rose to 96.3 from 95.3 in the previous week and compares with 83.4 for the corresponding period of last year.

Unless race track betting is legalized in New York State, the sport will be doomed after this year, declared Joseph E. Widener, who returned from Europe yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Mr. Widener is president of the Westchester Racing Association, which operates Belmont Park, and also is vice chairman of the Jockey Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- General Johnson's clarification tonight of Section 7 (a), the collective bargaining clause of the Recovery Act, which he ruled "cannot be changed by the interpretation of any one," was accepted here as an effort to allay the turmoil in the soft-coal fields which followed a report he was planning an interpretation that would diminish the rights of organized labor.

The Board of Education unanimously approved a $131,604,266.47 budget estimate for 1934 at a special meeting yesterday afternoon. The new budget, if approved by the Board of Estimate, will represent a net increase of $2,051,399.31 over the money actually appropriated for 1933, which totaled $129,552,867.16.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been called to the fact that in your issue of Aug. 2 you reprinted a portion of an editorial from The New Outlook by Editor Alfred Emmanuel Smith. In the reprint occurs the statement: "Nothing could go further to show the rout of the dry forces in the recent convention campaign than the use by them of old, discredited hacks like Bishop Cannon."

BERLIN, Aug. 23 -- Preparations for the trial of the five men accused of burning the Reichstag Building last February are getting along with all the bitterness and controversy that such a trial would naturally engender.

Paul Blanshard, executive director of the City Affairs Committee, returned on the French liner Champlain yesterday from a trip to Europe to demonstrate that he could make a study of foreign municipal affairs at a total cost of less than $500.
WASHINGTON, Aug 23 -- American exports increased in value 21 per cent in July over June to $145,000,000 and the value of imports rose 17 per cent to $143,000,000.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23 -- An exhibition of dolls, old and new, was staged today under the direction of a committee headed by Mrs. William B. Bristow for the benefit of the Wall Baby Clinic of the Civic League of this city. The exhibition was a decided novelty, with more than 200 dolls shown.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 23 -- Virginia's coast bore the brunt of the worst storm in a quarter of a century today. A northeaster piled up against a gale from the Caribbean to severely damage beach resorts, flood the streets of tidewater cities, tie up shipping in the Hampton Roads area, threaten the lives of hundreds of cottagers and then tear inland with terrific force to uproot trees and unroof houses.

OTTAWA, Aug. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Resuming play after the luncheon period, Sir Julien Cahn's touring cricket team retired the remainder of the all-star aggregation of the Ottawa Valley Cricket Council in short order for a total of 107 runs for the local team today.

What REGINALD HERBER wrote of "vile man" in Ceylon is recalled by Sir JOHN HARRIS'S account in The Manchester Guardian of inhuman practices on the island where "every prospect pleases." The world has just been celebrating the centenary of WILBERFORCE, but slavery of a "truly terrible type" is still existent in certain corners of the earth, though under other names.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- President Roosevelt asserted in a speech today that all the 130,000,000 inhabitants of the United States would soon belong to the NRA drive aimed at restoring prosperity.

TOKYO, Aug. 23 -- Japanese officials denied today that their representations to Paris regarding the nine islands France recently anaexed in the China Sea amounted to an actual claim to Japanese sovereignty.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The juvenile situation became more complicated today when Mrs. Payne Whitney's entry of First Minstrel and Soon Over ran one, three through the mud of a heavy track at Saratoga in the twenty-first running of the Sanford Stakes.

LONDON, Aug. 23 -- Important agreements were reached at the international wheat conference this afternoon under the presidency of Prime Minister R.B. Bennett of Canada on the presentation of the reports of the two committees on proposals to alleviate world wheat problems.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 -- The 1933 football season will push off unofficially tomorrow night at Soldier Field with a battle between a great collection of Far Western stars and a squad of talent selected from the Middle West and East.

The Chesapeake Corporation announced yesterday that it had further reduced its holdings of Chesapeake Ohio Railway stock in order to liquidate bank loans. The corporation, which is an intermediary through which the Alleghany Corporation controls the line, now holds 3,726,508 C. O. common shares, against a maximum, of 4,094,008 at the end of 1931.

The first five railways to report earnings for July show the best record for that month in any year since 1930. Net operating income is 170 per cent above the figure for July last year and 67 per cent better than that for the same month of 1931. Both sides of the ledger have contributed to this encouraging performance.

In accordance with the agreement with the fusion leaders, John J. Knewitz, Republican leader of the Bronx, withdrew yesterday four of the candidates whose petitions were filed with the Board of Elections before Tuesday midnight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Industrial production which increased from June to July, contrary to seasonal tendency, has continued at a relatively high level in recent weeks, the Federal Reserve Board said today in its summary of general business and financial conditions.

The Handicap Golfers' Association of America has announced its list of qualifiers for the 36-hole play-off for the national handicap championship. It also has requested that the two rounds be played before Aug. 27 and score cards attested and mailed to its offices, 425 Fifth Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 21:
PRAGUE, Aug. 23 -- Despite the stormy protests of the Revisionist faction, the World Zionist Congress elected Professor Leo Motzkin of Paris president of the eighteenth annual meeting today.

Controller Charles W. Berry in a letter yesterday to Governor Lehman sought to vindicate his administration in the face of charges of official misconduct made by a group of Brooklyn Democrats led by James E. Finegan.

Several corporations issued yesterday reports of the financial results of their operations. Most of them showed losses, but the General American Transportation Corporation announced net profits equal to $1.15 a share for the first half of this year.

Further improvement in prices of United States Government bonds and mild rallies in leading foreign loans contrasted with irregularly lower quotations on domestic corporation bonds yesterday on the Stock Exchange. Trading, however, was considerably more active than in several days, the turnover topping $10,000,000.

More than 200 representatives of the twenty-seven trades employed at the navy yard in Brooklyn met at the yard last night to endorse a resolution protesting what was termed the "abortive order" of the Secretary of the Navy, which on Aug. 6 placed civil workers in navy yards on a five-day week, with a corresponding cut in pay.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Construction of a ship canal across New Jersey at a coat of $173.000,000, which would give employment, to thousands of men, was advanced here today by New Jersey members of Congress for a place in the administration's public works program.

Sharp criticism from Clark Griffith, president of the Washington Senators, added to the impression yesterday that American League club owners, as a whole, do not favor the proposal for inaugurating midseason inter-league competition between the two major baseball circuits next year.
NEW YORK. Mrs. John T. Pratt gave a luncheon for her daughter, Mrs. Paul H. Nitze, yesterday in the roof garden of the Pierre.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The hearing on the dress trade code before the NRA today was devoted almost entirely to the presentation of arguments for and against contractors.
The dollar cheapened sharply yesterday in foreign exchange, although there was no news to account for the fresh weakness, and the volume of business transacted was light.

A charming acknowledgment of the old accusation -- that father bought sonny an electric train for his own amusement, or took him to the circus so that he himself could see the animals -- is made by the parents of children in the Lincoln School and Horace Mann School.

The performances of opera at the Lewisohn Stadium scheduled for tonight and tomorrow night will be postponed to next Monday and Tuesday evenings, it was announced last night. The continued rain and the Weather Bureau forecast of little or no let-up in the unfavorable atmospheric conditions prompted this decision, according to the announcement of Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, chairman of Stadium Concerts, Inc.

The NRA city committee, which has come to be looked upon, since Grover A. Whalen's settlement of the dress strike, as the official mediator between labor and capital, will concentrate its attention today on five industries in which strikes affecting nearly 70,000 workers are threatened.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- The Japanese Embassy said today the note delivered in Paris by the Japanese Charge d'Affaires was in the nature of a protest against the occupation of the nine small islands and was not a claim to sovereignty.

C.G. Jung tries to explain creativeness in art in his new book, "Modern Man in Search of a Soul," published today by Harcourt, Brace. He seeks at the same time to explain some of the eccentricities of artists.

HAVANA, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Soldiers and police were ordered to patrol the streets and parks of this city tonight after authorities received a report demonstrations were planned by Communists. A permit had been denied to parade in observance of the execution of Nicola Sacco and Bartholomeo Vanzetti in the United States six years ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- Following is a summary of the code of air competition for the motionpicture industry as submitted today to Deputy Administrator Rosenblatt by the pro lucers and distributers' committees, which met in New York with the exhibitors' committee pursuant to Mr. Rosenblatt's request that the industry compose its differences:

The State Department of Labor made public yesterday a report by the Laundry Minimum Wage Board which will be accepted as a basis for public hearings. The report was drawn up under the new State Minimum Wage Law, and under it, it was estimated, the wages of 80 per cent of the laundry employes would be increased.

Everybody drinks milk, or eats it in some form. A pint a day is the ordinary city-dweller's ration. If there is one subject in which it might be supposed consumers would be interested, it is milk supply, control and distribution. Yet when the State Milk Board held a hearing on the subject early this week, and invited consumers to attend, only three put in an appearance.
Mild real estate activity in this city yesterday was featured by the sale of a large apartment house near Bronx Park.

At Tuesday's election of members of the Nova Scotia General Assembly the Liberals, who have been the outs since 1925, beat the Conservatives by more than 2 to 1. Political meetings of both sides were crowded. The contest was supposed to be so close that bets were as scarce as hen's teeth.

The American Water Works and Electric Company reports for July gross revenues of $3,758,264, comparing with $3.507,991 in the same month last year, an improvement which was larger than the ordinary seasonal increase. Grots revenues were $3,644,173, against $3,564,051 a year ago.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 23 -- Mrs. Hugh Smiley was hostess at a tea and reception this afternoon at Fenton Brook Farms, South Egremont. Among the guests were Professor Edward Vermilye Huntington of Harvard University, Mrs. Huntington and Mrs. Lewis J. Johnson of Cambridge, Mrs. James P. Robinson, Mrs. John Marvin Wright, Mrs. Margaret S. Zimmele, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander B. Trowbridge and Mr. and Mrs. Tracy Lay of Washington.

DETROIT, Aug. 23 (AP) -- After outstanding work by Tommy Bridges on the mound and at bat had won the opening engagement of a double-header, 2 to 1, the Tigers today suffered a return of their pitching weakness and the Senators took the closing game, 9 to 5.

The coordinating committee for the railroads in the East appointed yesterday three committees to assume the duties hitherto carried out by the general committee for the Eastern railroads, whereupon it was announced that the general committee would be dissolved.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There has appeared in the newspapers the report of an accusation which is to be brought by a certain lawyer before the Cuban courts against me and involving also President Machado and some other members of his Cabinet.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 -- The Yankees tried unsuccessfully at Municipal Stadium today to overcome high winds and the enemy two days running. Their bats stilled by the superb pitching of Clint Brown, the McCarthymen bowed to the Indians, 2 to 1.

With a view to easing the tasks of employes of New York Stock Exchange firms in periods active trading, the Exchange has prepared a plan on which its governing committee will take action next Wednesday. The plan provides for deliveries a day later than at present of stocks and bonds sold on the Exchange.

WEST HAMPTON BEACH, L.I., Aug. 23 -- Raymond M. Lynch, 26 years old, a grocery clerk of this place, was arraigned before Justice of the Peace Stewart Howell here today on charges of manslaughter and leaving the scene of an accident.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- The Red Sox losing streak was extended to nine straight games today when they were held to seven hits in a double-header. The White Sox swept the twin bill, 3 to 1 and 12 to 1.

ALBANY, Aug. 23 -- The Senate tonight passed unanimously a bill embodying one minor item in Governor Lehman's public utility program, but the major bills were still held in the Democratic-controlled Public Service Committee, in defiance of the demand of the Governor that they be brought to the floor.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 23 -- The New York State Federation of Labor prepared today to throw its full support behind a drive for unemployment insurance.

BANFF, Alberta, Aug. 23 (Canadian Press) -- A warning that a world war could not be avoided unless problems now worrying the nations in the Pacific area were solved was uttered today by Sir Andrew MaeFayden of London at the first plenary session of the Institute of Pacific Relations.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP) -- Some 30,000 hogs today led the procession of 5,000,000 plus which will troop to slaughter houses in the next forty days to rescue the American hog-raiser from his economic doldrums.

A petition asking that the Pennsylvania Railroad be required to absorb its subsidiary, the Long Island Railroad, and operate it as a division rather than as a separate corporate entity, was filed yesterday with the Federal Coordinator of Transportation by Ernie Adamson, 111 John Street, who states that he is a commuter living in Rockville Centre, L.I.

Mixed tendencies continued yesterday in the various commodity markets, reflecting uncertainty in the grain and cotton markets, and prices for futures at the close showed moderate advances or losses, with silver a strong feature in more active trading.

BOSTON, Aug. 23 -- With Wally Berger's big bat blasting out the winning runs for the second successive day, the Boston Braves today strengthened their hold on second place, defeating the St. Louis Cardinals 4 to 3 in the first game of a three-game series.

PARIS, Aug. 23 -- The conference of the Socialist and Labor International heard today an attack on the American National Recovery Administration by Professor Maynard Krueger of the University of Chicago, speaking on behalf of the American delegation.

MOSCOW, Aug. 23. -- The excellent arvest about to be gathered shows that any report of a famine in Russia is today an exaggeration or malignant propaganda. The food shortage which has affected almost the whole population in the last year, and particularly the grain-producing provinces -- that is, the Ukraine, North Caucasus, the Lower Volga region -- has, however, caused heavy loss of life.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 -- A promise and a warning to the country that the National Recovery Administration would soon embark on a campaign to "mop up" the abuses of Blue Eagle agreements was made by Hugh S. Johnson, the Recovery Administrator, over a nation-wide radio broadcast tonight.

Apparently with his sword still buckled on and a smoking revolver in his hand, Major Gen. Smedley D. Butler, retired, dictated the record of his adventures through thirty-three years in the Marines to Lowell Thomas, and the book, "Old Gimlet Eye," crowded with them, is published by Farrar Rinehart today.

Surveys made of ducks in the North American Continent have not come up to the anticipated standard, the United States Biological Survey announced yesterday. As a result the seasons for the wild waterfowl shooting for this year have not yet been made known to the public.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- In one of the greatest performances of his spectacular career Harry Newman of Michigan led the East to a thrilling 13-7 triumph over the West in their all-star football battle before 45,000 spectators at Soldier Field tonight.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The Browns divided a double bill with the Athletics today, dropping the second game, 4 to 3, after winning the first, 7 to 6, in eleven innings. The nightcap was a pitchers' battle between Cain and Hadley. Philadelphia won in the eighth by scbring two runs on a walk, a two-base hit by Higgins and a single by Williams.

Eight persons were injured yesterday when an automobile owned by Justice John F. Hylan, former Mayor, was in a head-on collision on the Queensboro Bridge with an ambulance bringing a patient from East Hampton, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve bank credit outstanding during the week ended Aug. 23, as reported by the Federal Reserve banks, was $2,243,000,000, an increase of $13,000,000 compared with the preceding week and a decrease of $33,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

A code fixing a forty-five-hour week, and minimum wages of 40 cents an hour for men and 30 cents for women, was proposed for the laundry industry of New York City by the Queens Power Laundry Association which promulgated and adopted it.

Several firms in the garment trade figured in deals for manufacturing, office and showroom space yesterday. These transactions formed the bulk of the day's activity in Manhattan and kept brokers busy over a wide area, although most of the new tenants were firms taking space in the west side garment area.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 24. -- The Stockbridge exhibition committee, of which John C. Johansen is chairman and Miss Olive Beaver Curtis, secretary, has sent out invitations to the twenty-fifth annual "Varnishing Day" reception at the Berkshire Playhouse on Sept. 2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The approval of Secretary Wallace and President Roosevelt was virtually all that was necessary today to put before the growers for acceptance a new cotton plan to limit acreage to 25,000,000 next year.

The Federal grand jury in Brooklyn handed to Judge Mortimer W. Byers in United States court yesterday an indictment charging C. Bertram Mahler, former president and director of the Richmond National Bank of New York in Richmond Hill, with making a false entry in a report to the Controller of the Currency.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24. -- A number of new entertainments have been added to the program in honor of the officers and midshipmen aboard the U.S.S. Wyoming and the officers of H.M.S. Norfolk when they visit here next month.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Aug. 24 (AP). -- In a Federal court room guarded with machine guns, R.G. Shannon, one of fourteen persons indicted for the kidnapping of Charles F. Urschel, testified today that Albert Bates, under arrest at Denver, and George Kelly, a fugitive brought the Oklahoma City oil man to his home for safekeeping.

The largest entertainment yet planned for this season at the Sands Point Bath Club, Sands Point, L.I., will take place there tomorrow night when a charity revue entitled "Yes, We Have No Capannas" will be given in the interests of the National Charity Amateur Air Pageant, which will be held Oct. 7 and 8 at Roosevelt Field.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- A revised code for the retail trade stores industry, submitted by the code sponsors tonight, tightened up the fair trade practices over which Percy S. Straus, president of R.H. Macy Co., and the majority of the rest of the industry, including Macy's fourteen largest New York competitors, locked horns at a hearing on the code during the day.

The Carter Oil Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, announced yesterday that at 7 o'clock this morning it would advance all grades of Oklahoma and Kansas crude oil 10 cents a barrel. The Humble Oil and Refining Company, another subsidiary of the New Jersey company, almost immediately announced that it would make a similar advance throughout Texas and New Mexico.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 24. -- Maryland National Guard observers in airplanes flew over Chesapeake Bay, the many rivers flowing into it and the tidewater counties of both the Eastern and Western Shores, surveying the storm damage today.

Disbursements by the companies of the Standard Oil group for the current quarter of the year are estimated at $19,546,576, the smallest amount for a quarter since the close of 1915, according to a compilation by Carl H. Pforzheimer Co.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Aug. 23, unless otherwise specified:

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 24. -- The story of 18-year-old Dietze von Tyle who told how she had been smuggled into this country from France with four other persons and her dog last April was under Investigation here today.

The total bank clearings of twenty-one leading cities of the country during the week ended on Wednesday were $4,134,378,000, compared with $4,477,628,000 in the previous week and $3,666,607,000 in the corresponding week last year, according to a compilation by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

A suit to restrain the approval of a proposed settlement of litigation against the directors of the former Goldman Sacbs Trading Corporation (now the Pacific Eastern Corporation) for an accounting of alleged losses of $200,000,000 on the ground of mismanagement was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by Abraham N. Levy and Hose W. Levy, as stockholders of the Pacific Eastern.

Dr. James E. West, Chief Scout Executive of the Boy Scouts of America, will return today from Godello, Hungary, where he attended the international Scout conference and jamboree. Others arriving on the Cunarder Berengaria, from Southampton via Cherbourg, include:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The circumstances in which approximately $6,249,000 in gold was returned yesterday to the country's monetary gold stocks, as shown by the daily pold report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, became known today.

A dinner was given last night in the starlight roof garden of the Waldorf-Astoria by the Italy America Society for Admiral Romeo Bernotti, commander of the Italian Naval Division training ships, and Commander Count Valerio Della Campana, who was in charge of the Italian submarines that accompanied General Italo Balbo and his flying squadron on their recent trip to this country.

Keen competition featured the award yesterday by the city of Buffalo, N.Y., of a new issue of $9,500,000 of bonds, which went to a banking group headed by the City Company of New York, Inc. The issue, consisting of $3,000,000 tax sale bonds due on Sept. 1, 1938, and $6,500,000 of refunding bonds due on Sept. 1, 1934 to 1953, fetched a price of 100.20999, with the interest rate stipulated as 4.20 per cent.

No basis for charges that Ellsworth Vines Jr., national tennis champion, had violated the amateur rule was found by the amateur rule committee of the United States Lawn Tennis Association, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 24. -- The stock markets remained quiet today and the volume of business was small. British funds were unchanged, holding recent gains. Japanese bonds strengthened.

Chase Mellen Jr., Harvard graduate, World War veteran and member of an old American family, was picked last night as the candidate of the Organization Of Regular Republicans for Change in the New York County Leadership to oppose Samuel S. Koenig for election as county chairman.

PRAGUE, Aug. 24. -- The Zionist Congress after a stormy discussion tonight refused to accept two proposals by the Revisionist and Democratic Revisionist factions for a boycott of Germany and, instead, adopted by 265 votes a milder resolution invoking unspecified League help for German Jews.

Final instructions to all State NRA leaders for conducting the State consumer canvass or Blue Eagle campaign beginning Monday were sent out yesterday by W. Averell Harriman, chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Committee for the State of New York.

ALBANY, Aug. 24. -- Although the relief legislation asked for by the City of New York had been passed by the Legislature and put in the hands of the Governor, the affairs of the city were well in the foreground today, at the final meetings of the extraordinary session.

Morris Berg, 32 years old, who conducts a stationery store at 32-03 Broadway, Astoria was found guilty yesterday of renting out through a circulating library an obscene book. His sentence in the Queens Court of Special Sessions was deferred until Sept. 7.

BANFF, Alberta, Aug. 24 (Canadian Press). -- A picture of a world marking time until the United States recovery scheme has been further advanced was painted today by members of the Institute of Pacific Relations, in conference here.

HAVANA, Aug. 24. -- The de Cespedes Cabinet's decision tonight to dissolve Congress and call new elections put a check to increasing uneasiness over its failure to announce a definite policy and satisfied the demand for the immediate dissolution of Congress voiced by the Directorio Estudiantil, composed of students and alumni of the University of Havana.

Money market continued quiet. Stock Exchange call loans renewed at 1 per cent, with outside money posted at three-quarters of 1 per cent. Governments at one-half of 1 per cent and Federal funds at one-eighth of 1 per cent. Commercial paper and acceptances, rates unchanged.

BAGHDAD, Iraq., Aug. 24. -- King Feisal's departure has again been postponed for a week. The newspaper Alam Al Arabi politely suggests that the "presence of his Majesty at the heart of the kingdom amid his people continuously has become necessary for the reinforcement of agencies making for peace and the continued maintenance of calm and tranquillity."

A new plan to help artists and enable residents of the city to have fine paintings in their homes at small cost is being worked out by the College Art Association, 137 East Fifty-seventh Street, through a "rent-a-picture library," to begin operation in the early Fall.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date, while total bills discounted reached a new low figure. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low point.

Presiding Justice Frederic Kernochan of Special Sessions Court went before the county grand jury inquiring into rackets yesterday and reiterated his charges of a collusive league between politicians and gangsters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The man who keeps his waistline small when he reaches middle age is the most likely to win the race for health, is the conclusion drawn from a new study of the relation of weight to physical defects just published by the Public Health Service.
CANNES, France, Aug. 24. -- Mystery surrounds a fighting affray involving the pugilist Georges Carpentier and several others, which occurred recently outside the Palm Beach Casino.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- One hundred thousand pigs weighing 25 to 100 pounds each have been bought at the six leading live stock markets for the government in the last two days in its processing movement. There were about 70,000 little pigs in today.

ALBANY, Aug. 24. -- The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad has been authorized by the Public Service Commission to discontinue the operation of one train in each direction between Pine Plains and Beacon in Dutchess County, and one train in each direction between Poughkeepsie, Dutchess County, and Copake in Columbia County.

Plans to celebrate "President's NRA Day" soon after Labor Day with the largest parade ever held In New York City were announced yesterday afternoon by Grover A. Whalen, city chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Committee.

Against a trend which normally dips at this season of the year, American foreign trade showed an improvement in July for the third month in succession. Exports rose to $145,000,000, compared with $120,000,000 in June. The July figure is 36 per cent above the low record of the same month of 1932.

PLATTSBURG, Aug. 24. -- There is little doubt about the anticipation of the 800 candidates of the Citizens Military Training Camp to be off for home on Tuesday, when their four-week training period will be over. But there likewise is a reluctance to leave the cool breezes and military life to which they have become inured.
BERLIN, Aug. 24. -- Call money was quoted today at 4 3/8 per cent. The dollar dropped to 3.035 marks.

SILVER BAY ON LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- The logical outcome of the measures taken to meet the present economic emergency would be permanent long-range economic planning, Howard E. Coffin told the annual conference on industrial relations here today.

Said Colonel John Kilpatrich as his polished desk he smote: "We've changed the boxing program; it's no longer table d'hote. "Beneath the bold Blue Eagle we are set to do our part, "And here we offer boxing which is strictly a la carte. "We spread this handsome menu with a touch of proper pride.

Paris, Aug. 24. -- The tendency on the Bourse today was irregular, while dullness continued to prevail. Sharp drops in the dollar and the pound sterling led to strengthening of international stocks within narrow limits. French stocks, on the other hand, weakened slightly.

When it became apparent yesterday at Kings County Hospital that Patrolman Joseph McGuire of Brooklyn might die as a result of a bite on his hand, Joseph Zagleus, 42 years old, of 749 William Avenue, and Pete Prutko, who had no home, were rearrested on charges of felonious assault.

The plan of German Government and Reichsbank authorities for servicing German dollar bond issues, except the Dawes Plan 7s and the Young Plan 5 1/2s, as announced in mid-July, whereby half of the interest for at least six months will be paid in cash and the other half in scrip payable in blocked reichsmark, still finds American bankers and bondholders undecided as to what course to pursue.
An advance of 0.2 point carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices up to 102.7 on Tuesday, from 102.5 (revised) the week previous.

Two detectives lurking near by closed in last night when James McHale, 29 years old, a bartender, drew a knife and attempted to stab two brothers, insurance men, who had defied the bartender's efforts to extort $30 from them, at Broadway and Halsey Street, Brooklyn.

BOSTON, Aug. 24. -- Boston's dizzy rush toward the National League peak continued today as the Braves, aided by Bill Hallahan's wildness and an error by Pepper Martin, turned back the Cardinals for the second straight day. It was Boston's sixth successive victory and the nineteenth out of the last twenty-three games.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- Prime Minister Bennett of Canada intends to invoke the Ottawa pacts, it was learned tonight, in an attempt to make Great Britain reduce her imports of Russian timber by at least half.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Secretary and Mrs. Woodin arrived this evening to be overnight guests of President Roosevelt at Hyde Park House, and Lewis W. Douglas will come here for luncheon tomorrow.

The naval correspondent, HECTOR C. BYWATER, who has been lamenting the decline of British sea power through punctilious carrying out of the London Treaty, regards the building plans of the United States and Japan as "a death blow to naval limitation by agreement." He declares that "the sole effect [of the treaties] has been to "emasculate the British Navy and re"juvenate all the other fleets."

BOLTON LANDING - ON - LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Garbed in oilskins, rubber caps, boots and slickers, sixty-eight golfers braved wind, rain and fog to play the qualifying round of the third annual Sagamore tournament today.

A decline of $41,000,000 in brokers' loans was reported yesterday in the condition statement of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City. This brought the total as of Wednesday down to $853,000,000 compared with $355,000,000 on the corresponding date a year ago.
ATLANTA, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Louis Hasselmans, a conductor of the Metropolitan Opera Association of New York, and Miss Frances Stephens of Atlanta were married here today at the home of the bride.

PARIS, Aug. 24. -- The split in the American delegation to the Socialist and Labor International here became definite today when Jacob Panken, in an interview with the press, expressed views divergent from those upheld by the majority of the delegation.

In a recent issue of The Forum, JOSEPH WOOD KRUTCH and EDMUND WILSON may be discovered debating the question "Is Politics Ruining Art?" Like well-bred gentlemen of the pen, each declares that he has no quarrel with the other. Yet the impression grows page by page that a difference of opinion does exist, and that Mr. KRUTCH is on one side and Mr. WILSON on the other.
SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Aug. 24. -- I came to Spain with high expectations for a country whose history is so close to that of the United States, especially Florida, California and the border States.
After four successive days of rain, officials of the United States Lawn Tennis Association hope to start the wheels turning again today in the women's national championship at Forest Hills.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Reorganization of the prohibition field forces by the consolidation of 132 offices into 23 was announced today by Attorney General Cummings.

Net operating income in July of the first thirteen roads to report for that month was $13,535,000, against $4,037,000 in July, 1932, an increase of 235.3 per cent, and against $7,993,000 in July, 1931, an increase of 69.3 per cent. Their net in June was 513,297,000, up 225.3 per cent from June, 1932.
NEW YORK. Mrs. H. Hobart Porter is returning on the Berengaria and will join her family at Lauderdale, Lawrence, L.I., where they will be for the Autumn.

The All-America women's field hockey team of 1932, together with four substitutes, sailed on the North German Lloyd liner Europa last night for a competitive invasion of Europe. Their first objective is the international tournament at Copenhagen, where teams from eight nations will participate.
LONDON, Aug. 24. -- The World Wheat Conference almost went on the rocks today while the so-called Importing countries struggled to keep their present towering tariffs against foreign grains.

ALGONAC, Mich., Aug. 24 (AP) -- The small white speed boat, Miss Britain III, with which Hubert Scott-Paine hopes to beat Gar Wood's Miss America X in the Harmsworth Trophy races, had its first trial run in American waters today and performed beautifully under a partially opened throttle.

MOUNT TREMPER, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Father James Healy, an assistant at Holy Trinity Church in West Eighty-second Street, New York, lost his life here this morning while attempting to rescue a group of tourists marooned on a tiny island by the flooded waters of Esopus Creek.

Year in and year out, on Aug. 26, the children at Camp Heckscher, near Peekskill, N.Y., give a birthday celebration in honor of August Heckscher, veteran philanthropist and founder of the camp, whether Mr. Heckscher can arrange to get there himself or not.

NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 24. -- A tale of sterling seamanship on the part of captain and crew and superb courage shown by passengers was brought to port here today with the storm-battered Eastern Steamship liner Madison.

BERLIN, Aug. 24. -- The persistent weakness that has characterized the German stock exchanges for months and that is in glaring contrast with the daily official announcements that business is improving and unemployment decreasing, is beginning to alarm German financial circles.

I appear on behalf of the New York merchants as listed in the brief already filed in support of the (b) and (e) "unfair competition" clauses; and also from a national background gained as a member of many committees of the National Retail Dry Goods Assocation and, as its past president, somewhat familiar with the as yet uncorrected abuses which bedevil the industry and all dependent on it.
All utility reports are consolidated returns, including subsidiaries, unless otherwise specified. Alabama Power Comnany (Commonwealth and Southern System) July and twelve months:

SAN SALVADOR, Aug. 24. -- A resolution declaring the Central American peace treaties of 1923 null and void was approved by Congress last night on motion of Representatives, Morales, Guzman and Trigueros.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The generation and distribution of electric power at Muscle Shoals were declared today to be a public business in which the interest of the public was superior to any private business. This statement of policy was made by David E. Liliethal for the Tennessee Valley Authority.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Equipoise, the big train of the American turf, rolled on to his sixth straight victory of the 1933 season today, winning the $25,000 added Hawthorne Gold Cup and thrilling 20,000 spectators.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Washington found three Detroit pitchers easy today and pounded out seventeen hits for a 13 to 6 victory, evening the series at two games apiece. The Senators' attack was featured by Goose Goslin, who poled out two home runs.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- Scientists can at last reconcile the classical concepts of electricity with the ultramodern view of matter and electricity, Professor Max Born, theoretical physicist of the University of Goettingen, Germany, has just announced in a communication to the British scientific journal Nature.

PARIS, Aug. 24. -- Through Mile. Marthe Oulie, who publishes in L'lntransigeant today an account of a conversation with President Roosevelt, he gave an unofficial reminder to France that settlement of the debt question could not be postponed forever without doing lasting harm to French interests.

ELMONT, L.I., Aug. 24. -- An intruder early this morning beat Mrs. Hanne Dorf, 80 years old, who lives alone here. Mrs. Dorf, the mother of the Rev. Henry Dorf, a Brooklyn minister, was taken to the Nassau Hospital possibly suffering from a fracture of the skull.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 24. -- "Any new developments in China's political situation that may occur subsequent to the return of T.V. Soong (the Finance Minister), from his world-wide tour deserve the utmost attention on Japan's part," declared Akira Ariyoshi, the Japanese Minister to China, in an exlusive interview with THE NEW YORK TIMES today.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- A pair of captains of rival college golf teams paired today to tie for the medal in the qualifying round of the John G. Anderson Memorial Tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- Raymond Massey added another achievement to his already long and varied list of characterizations tonight in "The Ace," a play based on the famous airman, Richtofen, and adapted to English by Miles Malleson, who is also the director.

The feature on the Cotton Exchange yesterday was the purchase of 25,000 bales attributed to the government in obtaining title to cotton held as collateral for seed loans. The market supplied the necessary contracts quite easily and after an advance of more than a dollar a bale the list closed 2 to 5 points higher than on Wednesday.

Tied more closely to wheat than it would like to be, the share market wandered around in a more or less foot-loose fashion yesterday. Each nervous turn in wheat was a signal for a slow-motion response on the Stock Exchange. But it happened that frequently the Chicago market had made a complete about-face before the share market had orientated itself.

CHERBOURG, France, Augr. 24. -- This port's Chamber of Commerce has been forced to consider a reduction in dock duties in view of the fact that not a single transatlantic liner has tied up in the new $12,500,000 deep-water harbor here since it was completed last May 1.

BERLIN, Aug. 24. -- The food scarcity in Russia is beginning to attract general attenion in Germany. The papers are printing news about the terrible conditions known to exist in Russian agricultural sections, where food should be plentiful, but is not, even yet, owing to last year's collections by the government of all available grain.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) -- Completion of another vast navigation artery to serve the agricultural belt of the Middle West was made possible today by the allotment of $14,153,108 of Public Works Administration funds for development of the channel project on the upper Missouri River.
The closing of "Love and Babies," the comedy at the Cort Theatre, which was announced for tomorrow evening, has been postponed for a week.

ROME, Aug. 24. -- The results of Premier Mussolini's conversations at Riccione with Chancellor Dollfuss of Austria, revealed today, are of such importance that, coupled with the understanding reached with Hungary, they may prove a decisive factor in determining the future of Central Europe.

Protest Johnson Statement. In a telegram to General Johnson yesterday, Flint Garrison, director general of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, declared that wholesale prices are on the average lower than manufacturers' quotations. "Instead of unduly advancing prices, wholesalers are holding back from advances now being made by manufacturers and thus are protecting retailers and the public from the full impact of advancing prices," he said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The Crescent Limited, bound from New York to New Orleans, plunged from a collapsing bridge over the storm-flooded eastern branch of the Anacostia River, near Cheverly, Md., at 3:45 this morning, killing the engineer and fireman and injuring thirteen others.
Hoover's Wicked "Philosophy." HERBERT HOOVER was denounced in Detroit yesterday for upholding "the philosophy that money in the hands of the masses is a menace."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Discussion of the east side housing problem goes on and a model tenement house rises on a slum site once in a while and here and there. But no wholesale rebuilding of old tenement blocks is forthcoming.

MANILA, Aug. 24. -- The Nacionalista (majority) party at a caucus tonight made important changes In the independence plebiscite proposals, dropping out the woman's suffrage clause and applying the regular election laws in framing the questions to be asked.

Prices of bonds on the Stock Exchange drifted irregularly lower yesterday in quiet dealings. All groups of domestic corporation bonds finished slightly lower on the average, while leading foreign loans gained slightly. United States Government bonds were exceedingly dull, with closing prices 3-32 points higher to the same fraction lower.

SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Voters of New Jersey may be asked at a referendum election in November to make a further diversion to other purposes of highway money for which the State issued bonds two years ago. This possibility was disclosed here tonight following a conference at the Executive Mansion between Senate President Emerson L. Richards of Atlantic City, and Governor Moore.

Declines were registered yesterday in most commodity futures under the influence of September liquidation, while cash markets were dull and reflected few changes for the day. Silk, silver, tin and wool tops were stronger in the futures markets, however.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP). -- Luke Appling's triple after Al Simmons had walked with one out in the tenth gave the White Sox a 7-to-6 overtime decision over Boston in the second game of their doubleheader today after the Red Sox had taken the opener, 6 to 1, on Johnny Welch's good pitching.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 24. -- The Yankees frustrated Oral Hildebrand's fifth attempt of the season to set them down today when they swamped the Indians, 10 to 1, at Municipal Stadium.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 24. -- Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru are considering new peace formula to Bolivia and Paraguay providing for simultaneous agreement on an armistice and setting terms of arbitration designed to overcome Bolivia's refusal to accept an armistice without an arbitration agreement by Paraguay.

On April 18, the day after the closing of the fiftieth annual Spring salon in the art gallery of Montreal, the newspapers of that city told of the disappearance of sixteen canvases. They had been cut from their frames by some very sharp instrument. All were the work of Canadian artists.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- The plan for financial reorganization of Armour Co. developed today into a battle for proxies. A second meeting of stockholders to pass upon the plan will be held here on Sept. 1.

Heavy engineering construction is showing signs of revival after two months of lethargy, The Engineering News-Record reports. The revival is attributed to beginning of the Federal public works program.
PARIS, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

In a move designed apparently to assist the National Recovery drive and at the same time to placate the rising clamor of the inflationist bloc, the Federal Reserve System suddenly has trebled the pace of its credit expansion program by purchasing $35,000,000 of United States Government securities in the open market this week.

VANDADIA, Ohio, Aug. 24. -- Firing into a stiff breeze from the 20yard line, H.S. Shellito of Ames, Iowa, shattered 121 out of a possible 125 targets today to win trapshooting's second highest prize, the preliminary handicap of the Grand American Trapshoot.
Max Carey has been re-engaged to manage the Brooklyn Dodgers for the 1934 season, an official announcement from the Ebbets Field offices said yesterday.

Wesley Williams has been the city's only Negro fire lieutenant since 1927 and, incidentally, the first in the department's history. Two days ago his name was listed among the thirty lieutenants who have passed the examination for promotion to Captain.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 24. -- Sixteen teams have been drawn for play in the national mixed doubles tennis which gets under way tomorrow at the Longwood Cricket Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The text of the proposed code submitted today for Stock Exchange concerns was as follows:

The international load line agreement which regulates the loading of the merchant ships of all leading maritime nations of the world will be extended to the intercoastal and coastwise ships of the American merchant marine if conversations between American shipping men and the National Recovery Administration are effective.

The rise in living costs to wage earners which began in May gained momentum in July according to the index of the National Industrial Conference Board. The increase over June amounted to 2.3 per cent as compared with 1 per cent in June over May and 8 per cent in May over April.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Again using the force of his high office to push along his recovery program, President Roosevelt from his Hyde Park home today initiated an important conference here of nonunion operators and labor leaders in the bituminous coal industry.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 24. -- A sharp attack on the bankers of the country as "ace racketeers," marked the closing session of the annual convention of the State Federation of Labor today.

ABOARD MOTORSHIP WYATT EARP, Aug. 24 (By Wireless). -- The Wyatt Earp, carrying Lincoln Ellsworth's transantarctic expedition, has rounded the northwest curve of Africa and is nearing the "Line," yet nothing could seem less equater-like than our surroundings.
U.S. Department of Agriculture. Meat trade conditions and wholesale prices at New York.
The battle for the National League cellar, waged yesterday on the muddy terrain of Ebbets Field, ended with the situation unchanged, the Dodgers and Reds dividing a double-header.

Charges that the cloakmakers' union is demanding the payment of back dues and initiation fees from needy unemployed workers before permitting them to take jobs created by the recently approved cloakmakers' code have been laid before the Bureau of Complaints of the local NRA, it was learned yesterday.

BERLIN, Aug. 25 (London Times Dispatch). -- The Ministry of Economic Affairs has now issued to foreign exchange control offices new instructions for the treatment of foreign shipping companies represented in Germany.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 24 (AP). -- Dick Reynolds paced the fastest mile on the Grand Circuit this year to annex the 2:11 American Pacing Classic at the Illinois State Fair today. Winner in straight heats of the $1,500 added event, the son of Single G. was timed in l:59 1/2 for the second whirl.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Aug. 22:

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- The first stake victory for the Fair Fields Stable of Mrs. Wills Sharpe Kilmen was scored today when her Sun Celtic performed unusually well over a sloppy track to take the thirty-first running of the Adirondack Handicap.
