To the Editor of The New York Times: There recently appeared at The Hague a brochure entitled "Holland Calls," which contains much information that should be highly suggestive to the great nations of the world, now struggling in the tightening coils of self-restrictive legislation.

ALBANY, Aug. 24. -- Amid scenes of turbulence and charges of partisanship, the extraordinary session of the Legislature came to a close this evening after both houses had passed a series of important measures. These included:

HAVANA, Aug. 24. -- The Cuban Cabinet tonight in an extraordinary meeting decided to dissolve Congress immediately, return to the 1901 Constitution, nullifying the reforms of 1928, and call general elections on Feb. 24, 1934.

The estate of Lisle R. Beardslee in Prospect Street, Cranford, N.J., has been sold to Dr. Frederick M. Alien of Convent, N.J., former director of the Physiatric Institute there, and who is to continue his work at the Cranford estate. The property was developed more than twenty years ago by Thomas A. Sperry at a reported cost of more than $400,000.

The hopes of the Public Service Commission and consumers' organizations that the electric light companies serving New York City would consent to a 6 per cent reduction in their rates, as ordered by the commission, were shattered yesterday.

The fusion harmony committee headed by Charles C. Burlingham, W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, and Fiorello LaGuardia, fusion candidate for Mayor, all labored yesterday in an unsuccessful attempt to get the Queens County Republican Executive Committee to withdraw Jenkin R. Hockert, a Republican, as the Republican candidate for County Clerk and substitute Thomas F. Malone, a Democrat.

The promise of the trustees of Jamaica Hospital that there will be a thorough reorganization and a correction of practices brought out in connection with its ambulance service probably will be accepted by the committee of the State Board of Social Welfare, which investigated the Institution.

A recapture clause will be inserted in every housing loan made by the Public Works Administration to permit acquisition of the property involved by the Federal Government or by the city in which it is situated. Joseph Platzker, secretary of the East Side Chamber of Commerce, made this statement in an address yesterday at the luncheon of the Rotary Club of New York in the Hotel Commodore.

CANTERBURY, England, Aug. 24 (Candian Press). -- Kent, one of the leading first-class county elevens, trounced the touring British West Indies cricket eleven today by an innings and 93 runs, needing only two of the scheduled three days of play.

The large building at 216th Street and the Harlem River, which was used by the Edison Company as a power house until a few months ago, is now serving as a mammoth studio for George Grey Barnard, the sculptor, for the erection, of the plaster model of his peace memorial, an arch 100 feet high and 60 feet wide, which he will give to the nation.
ALBANY, Aug. 24. -- The State Education Department today announced the names of high school pupils in the State who are eligible for university scholarships.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The Cubs took both ends of a twin bill today, beating the Phillies, 5 to 0, behind Guy Bush's three-hit pitching, and winning, 9 to 6, in the long-drawn-out second game. The double victory enabled Chicago to take undisputed possession of third place, the Pirates, with whom the Cubs had been tied, being idle in New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Men of science the world over will be deeply offended at the continued imprisonment in Germany of Professor Friedrich Josef Hubertus Dessauer, one of the world's leading scientists and a pioneer in the field of X-ray and radium therapy in its application to cancer and to X-ray photography.

Tammany ought to be happy. It is now monarch of all it surveys, with no one to dispute its right to tax the dwellers in this city in any way and to whatever extent it pleases. The Legislature has given it blanket authority to levy additional taxes. A Chinese war lord has no more freedom than Tammany now has to exact payments from taxpayer victims of all kinds.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 24. -- Lucien Hamilton Tyng gave a large reception this afternoon at Four Fountains, his studio in Halsey Neck Lane, for Mrs. John P. Upham of St. Paul, who is here for a visit, and for Mrs. Erastus T. Tefft of Star Ridge Farm, Brewster, N.Y., who arrived today to pass several days with Miss Janet Beecher and her sister, Miss Olive Wyndham.

Weakness in the grain markets interrupted a promising advance on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Share prices pursued an erratic course, but always influenced by the movements of commodities. The late setback on the Chicago Board of Trade was followed by a slow liquidation of stocks, so that final prices on the Stock Exchange here were well below the best prices of the day.

DETROIT, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The Rev. Father Charles E. Coughlin, appearing before the city's one-man bank jury today, named three former bank officials as "doubtful of escaping Federal indictment" and charged The Detroit Free Press with publishing faked records concerning him.

New York City weathered the hurricane with no loss of life and only minor damage. An Associated Press survey, which placed the dead at forty-two and the property damage in the millions yesterday, showed that other cities along the Middle Atlantic Coast had not been so fortunate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Talk of consolidation of the Western Pacific, Denver and Rio Grande Western and Missouri Pacific Railroads, or at least a joining of the Western Pacific and Rio Grande Western, was revived today when it became known that sumo sort of unification agreement was contemplated at the time the Reconstruction Finance Corporation granted to the Rio Grande Western a loan of $950,000 on June 29.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Revisions made in the code of fair competition for the retail stores industry, as submitted tonight, are as follows:
LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- "Real progress" in the discussion of hours and wages in the bituminous coal code was reported tonight after leaders of the United Mine Workers of America and spokesmen of non-union operators in the great Appalachian area sat down in conference.

Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York returned from Europe yesterday on the Washington of the United States Lines with his son, Robert F. Wagner Jr., after curtailing his trip to take up his duties as chairman of the Board of Operations of the NRA.
WASHINGTON. Aug. 24. -- Discussion of wage and overtime differentials prolonged the hearing on the dress-trade code before Deputy Administrator Howard today.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday several changes in partnerships and in listings of stocks and bonds.

The final steps are now being made by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd in preparation for his departure on his second expedition to the Antarctic. In an interview during a hurried visit to this city yesterday, the explorer said he was not ready to divulge the exact date of the departure of the expedition, but it became known that it would be within two months.

The most serious industrial dispute hindering the progress of the local NRA drive, the one between the neighborhood cleaners and dyers and the chain stores, was settled late last night after Henry F. Wolff, chief of the Bureau of Complaints, had spent seventy-two hours almost continually in conferences.
David S. Rendt, Commissioner of Public Works of the Borough of Richmond for the last eleven years, was summarily removed from office yesterday by Borough President John A. Lynch.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- More than 100 artists of Radio City Music Hall, New York, participated in an open-air pageant presented tonight on a specially erected stage on the hilltop terrace of the Westchester Country Club, overlooking Long Island Sound.

At the throwing open of a large area reclaimed from the Campagna, the head of the Italian Government remarked the other day: "This is the kind of warfare which we prefer." There has been, in truth, a marfeed departure in recent years from the attitude which MUSSOLINI assumed in the early years of his dictatorship.

THE score of the East-West football game at Soldier Field in Chicago was 13 -- 7 in favor of the East. Sound the loud timbrel. That will teach those chesty Westerners a fine football lesson. They thought they had a corner on all the strength and skill in the jolly old gridiron game. Now they know better, and high time, too.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Ernest W. Marland, who made and lost an oil fortune estimated at $65,000,000 and then entered politics, wants to be Governor of Oklahoma.

In sympathy with advances in other speculative markets following weakness of the dollar in foreign exchange, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved yesterday a quarter cent a pound and ended at gains of 24 to 28 points.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 25. -- Albert L. Wynne, 75-year-old Negro of Port Jefferson, L.I., will receive $500 and the income for life of a residuary estate estimated at about $40,000 under the will of Miss Lizzie J. Smith of Port Jefferson, who died there July 28 at the age of 79.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- An ultimatum to bituminous coal operators to frame an acceptable fair competition code by Tuesday or have one imposed upon the industry by President Roosevelt was delivered today by General Johnson.

Admiral Romeo Bernotti, superintendent of the Italian Royal Naval Academy, and about 270 cadets will attend low mass at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The cadets are on a training cruise aboard the Amerigo Vespucci, flagship of the Royal Italian Naval Training Squadron, and the Cristoforo Colombo, anchored here since Aug. 20.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- Receipts of pigs here for the first three days under the government's processing movement have exceeded all expectations, aggregating 291,000 head. Although this is below the average slaughter necessary to reach the 4,000,000 goal before October, pigs have piled up so rapidly that numerous market and stock yards points find it impossible to kill them until the middle of next week.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The text of the wheat agreement signed here today follows:

First steps toward bringing the New York milkshed under a code, based on the national Agricultural Adjustment Act and designed to regulate the dealings among producers, dealers, State control boards and consumers were taken yesterday at a meeting in the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- The dollar today continued its sharp decline, falling even more than it did yesterday. Opening at 18.42 francs, the rate dropped to 18.06 to close slightly stronger, owing to short covering, at 18.10. The dollar was accompanied in its decline by the pound sterling, which dropped from 83.77 francs to 83, although, in agreement with the British stabilization fund, the Bank of France had pegged the pound yesterday at 83.70.

Now that Mayor O'BRIEN has his magic wand, what is he going to do with it? Returning from the north woods to find the city in the possession of substantially the taxing powers for which he asked, he must feel a little like the fairy godmother. But perhaps more like Cinderella.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Joseph B. Eastman, Federal Coordinator of Transportation, said today that, with a single exception, the railroad executives of the country had agreed to $60,000 a year as their maximum salary.

None of the security markets will be open today, but trading will take place as usual on the principal commodity exchanges. The banks will be open, and transactions in foreign exchange will be arranged where business offers. But operations generally in Wall Street will be sharply reduced.
The Atlantic seaboard States from New England to North Carolina began efforts yesterday to restore order out of the chaos created by one of the most disastrous storms in recent years.

The failure of the New York State Legislature to include in the Mortgage Moratorium Bill all real estate, even if it were in arrears in taxes and interest, was denounced by delegates of home owners' organizations at a conference on future plans held yesterday at the office of Major F.H. LaGuardia, 1,450 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Should the Eighteenth Amendment be repealed by Dec. 1, as wet forces here predict, at least nineteen States would be in position to permit the sale of liquor as soon as the thirty-sixth State has completed ratification, unofficial surveys here today indicated.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 (AP). -- Claudette Colbert, stage and screen star, underwent an operation for appendicitis today. Her physician reported her condition satisfactory. Miss Colbert became ill yesterday as she was preparing to leave for Hawaii to make a motion picture.

Hack Wilson made his debut as a second baseman at Ebbets Field yesterday, accepted eleven chances, made two errors and helped give the 6,000 fans one of the most entertaining afternoons they've had in weeks.

LERWICK, Shetland Islands, Aug. 25 -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, who, with Mrs. Lindbergh, will remain here at least another day, took advantage of the bad weather today to study meteorological conditions in the Shetland Islands.
BERLIN, Aug. 25 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Aug. 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

Consumer councils are to be organized throughout the country to protect consumers against profiteering in connection with the NRA campaign, according to Mrs. Charles Cary Rumsey, chairman of the National Consumers Advisory Board.
The Board of Estimate voted an appropriation of $2,500,000 yesterday to finance the city's relief program for August.
LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The British Government is still awaiting official information on what Premier Mussolini and Chancellor Dollfuss of Austria decided at Riccione, Italy, last week-end.

ALBANY, Aug. 25 -- Manny Strewl, under indictment for the kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr., lost his fight today for release on bail. Justice Russell in Supreme Court rejected the plea made by his counsel, Daniel H. Prior.

TUXEDO, N.Y., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Frand D. Thompson, vice president of Foltis-Fisher, Inc., operators of a chain of restaurants in New York City, was killed today when the car he was driving and another, driven by John A. Rogel of 460 Herdle Street, Brooklyn, crashed on the highway near here.

While Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Ulrich were celebrating their golden wedding anniversary last night at the home of Carl C. Ulrich, their son, at 39 Fifth Avenue, the talk turned to the bad men of Ulrich's youth and the gunmen of today.

Aaron Sapiro, the New York lawyer under indictment in Chicago charged with having participated in a laundry racket conspiracy which linked him with Al Capone, was freed on the original indictment yesterday and immediately rearrested on a new one.

NEW YORK. Miss Phebe Andrews gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Curtis B. Dall, the Misses Katherine and Jane Halle of Cleveland, who are staying at that hotel, and Miss Giggiotta Braggiotti.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 (AP). -- The policy of the Federal Government following the national bank holiday, which, was called one of "insistence on liquidity instead of solvency," was criticized today before the one-man Detroit bank jury by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg as one that "spelled the doom of thousands of banks,"

VANDALIA. Ohio, Aug. 25 -- Walter Beaver, 36, an electrician from Benvyn, Pa., stood on the 25-yard line and fired with amaznig accuracy today to win the blue ribbon event of trapshooting, the thirty-fourth annual Grand American Handicap.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- On the basis that the prevention of a Nazi State in Austria allied to Germany and the economic restoration of the Danube valley are jointly essential, the French Government is inclined to approve Premier Mussolini's proposals to aid Chancellor Dollfuss politically and economically.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- A probability that all merchants engaged in selling goods at retail may be asked by NRA officials to operate under one master code, with exceptions covering the peculiar needs of each branch of the trades, developed today when hearings on the retail drug trade opened before A.D. Whiteside, deputy administrator.
BOLTON LANDING-ON-LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- With better weather prevailing, golfers taking part in the third annual Sagamore golf tournament turned in far better scores today than yesterday.

VIENNA, Aug. 25 -- Anti-Austrian propaganda from German wireless stations continues daily but the Dollfuss government is in less fear of an armed attack since Premier Mussolini made it clear in conferences with the Chancellor that he would aid in preserving Austria's independence.

BERLIN, Aug. 25. -- The Boerse staged something of a rally today. Prices advanced above the low levels of yesterday, but all the losses were not wiped out. Heavy industrials gained 1 to 2 per cent. Potash stocks were weak and electricals were virtually neglected.
TORONTO, Aug. 25 -- Setting the pace all the way, Mrs. Kuth TowerCorsan, Titian-haired marathoner from Toronto, captured the Canadian National Exhibition professional ten-mile swim today.
DENVER, Aug. 25 -- Police and government authorities believed tonight that Bernard Bitterman, 28 years old, a member of a prominent Denver family, has been kidnapped.

Miss Nellie Louise Condon, director of the Reptile Study Society of America, faced a problem yesterday. A garter snake, captured at Montauk on June 25, recently became the indifferent mother of sixteen wriggling little snakes. Miss Condon, who has been collecting snakes for many years, found that the care of the baby reptiles was too much for one person.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Production of motor vehicles in the United States in July totaled 233,088, a decline of 20,234 under June, but 123,945 more than in July of last year and 14,598 over July, 1931, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Salt-water fishermen may expect vastly improved conditions this week-end, according to reports gathered along the coast of Long Island from Montauk to Sheepshead Bay and along the New Jersey coast from Sandy Hook to Cape May.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- News of the agreement reached by the delegates to the World Wheat Conference at London was received with undisguised satisfaction today by officials of the State and Agricultural Departments as a step of great importance in the efforts under the New Deal to bring back prosperity.

COPENHAGEN, Aug. 25. -- Mrs. Ruth Bryan Owen, the United States Minister to Denmark, at midnight made a radio speech across the Atlantic appealing to American women to support President Roosevelt in the national recovery campaign.

A five-ton truck containing 277 bars of pig tin, each weighing 100 pounds and valued at $40 a bar, was hijacked yesterday afternoon at the intersection of Canal and West Streets, according to a story told the police.
STONY BROOK, L. I., Aug. 25 -- Mrs. John V. Bouvier 3d of East Hampton, L. I., carried away the John R. Townsend Memorial Challenge Cup today at the annual North Shore horse show got under way.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Principles governing the purchasing or selling of securities by the new open market committee of the Federal Reserve System were published today by the Federal Reserve Board.

Christopher Columbus, the Central Park squirrel that explores Madison Avenue and bites policemen on the thumb and gets away with it, returned to the park yesterday after ten days in the animal equivalent of the Bellevue observation ward.

A strange tale from the Hollywood hills Is now to be seen on the Paramount's screen. It bears the title of "This Day and Age" and was directed by Cecil B. DeMille from a story written by Bartlett Cormack. The technical work on the production is beyond reproach, but the story is excessively melodramatic.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Mr. and Mrs. David Dows gave a dinner tonight at their home in Halsey Neck Lane for Countess Fal de Saint Phalle, who arrived today to pass several days with them. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. T. Markkoe Robertson, Anthony J. Drexel of Philadelphia and Paris, Mr. and Mrs. M. Dorland Doyle, Mrs. James P. Donahue and George H. Pendleton, who is also visiting Mr. and Mrs. Dows.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- The defeat of Walter and Rudy Rothenberg, winners in last year's tourney, featured the first day's play in the John G. Anderson memorial tournament at the Winged Foot Golf Club today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Aug. 12 appears a letter on British housing by Edward P. Doyle, which would hardly seem worth while correcting if bills to create public housing authorities were not being considered by the New York Legislature, where Mr. Doyle's statements might be given some weight.

DETROIT, Augr. 25 (AP) -- A rally that netted three runs after two were out in the fourth inning and Kuhel's home run ,in the fifth today gave the Senators the final encounter of their series with Detroit, 5 to 4.

PRAGUE, Aug. 25 -- The agreement with the Nazi Government of Germany for the exportation to Palestine of seized Jewish capital in the form of German machinery was denounced today in the Eighteenth World Zionist Congress by Meer Grossman, leader of the Democratic Revisionists, a faction of the right wing extremists.

A general strike of 11,300 workers in two needle trades was threatened yesterday. Coincidently Grover A. Whalen, city chairman of the President's Re-employment Campaign, announced that all the 60,000 dressmakers whose strike he settled last Saturday were expected to return to work by Monday.

A decision restraining a meeting here of the stockholders of the Pacific Eastern Corporation, formerly the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation, on Monday to consider an offer of Goldman Sachs Co. to settle for $325,000 claims of stockholders against the former directors of the company was handed down last night by Supreme Court Justice Hofstadter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- An additional special review board for New York City to review presumptive disability cases of World War veterans was named today by Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, administrator of veterans' affairs. Two of the three regular members are World War veterans.

In The American Mercury an English, newspaper man who has served on American and Canadian journals laments "The Awful English of England." This awfulness consists in a degraded and barbarous pronunciation. The standard English in question is a dialect misbegotten of London East End Cockney.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 25 -- Residents of the Smithtown, Islip and St. James Summer colonies and many from Oyster Bay, the Westburys and Glen Cove attended the opening session today of the North Shore Horse Show at the Old Field Club and crowded the ringside, which overlooks the water.
Leon Praser, president of the Bank for International Settlements at Basle, returned yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland to spend two weeks at home.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- J.P. Morgan has taken exception to statements, published in a book on the Nazi regime, that his firm contributed to Nazi funds. The book, "Hitler as Frankenstein," by Johannes Steel, a German who fled from his country when Adolf Hitler came into power, was published recently by a British firm.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Bob Johnson, left fielder of the Athletics, personally engineered his teammates to an 11-to-3 triumph over the Brojyns today.

Cool days at the Equator, inoffensive sharks and moderate temperatures off the Horn, make tales for Captain Charles C. Dixon, an iconoclast, who sailed in windjammers for fifty years. Captain Dixon told his stories to John Herries McCulloch.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- Twenty-five men were proclaimed public enemies today by Chief of Detectives Schoemaker, who prepared to invoke two new laws to prosecute them as vagabonds. Under these statutes they may be tried upon their reputations and if convicted may be imprisoned for six months.

Three assistants of District Attorney Crain spent yesterday poring over the minutes of the grand jury inquiry into rackets from which they had been excluded, in an effort to find out what, if any, indictments could be based on the testimony so far adduced.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- Progress toward business recovery and reduction of unemployment was told by the Federal Reserve Board in its August bulletin, made public today.
Walter Busch of the City Island Yacht Club yesterday won the first of a series of canoe sailing races to select two American defenders of the international decked-canoe trophy.

A plan of reorganization of the Altonna Logan Valley Electric Railway Company, formerly an Insull property, has been announced by a bondholders' protective committee headed by J.C. Neff. It provides for the organization of a new company which is to issue $1,920,000 of first lien and collateral trust 4 per cent bonds and 12,800 no par common shares. The property is in Ppnnsylvania.

Senator Frantisek Soukup of Czechoslovakia, who came here to install his country's exhibit at the Chicago Fair, is returning to Europe today on the Cunarder Berengaria. Others sailing for Southampton and Cherbourg on the ship are:

RANTOUL, Ill., Aug. 25 (AP).Fire of unexplained origin swept through the photographic and radio equipment buildings on Chanute Field today, causing damage which Major P. E. Von Nonstrand, as Assistant Commandant, estimated at $600,000.

Mr. and Mrs. Wyllys Rosseter Betts gave a dinner last night at Beaupre, their Summer place in Syosset L.I., to celebrate the twenty-first birthday of Mr. Betts's sister, Miss Edith Godfrey Betts, who has been pasing several weeks with them.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25 -- Members of the Summer colony and many others assembled this afternoon on the front lawn of the Newport Casino for the fashion show and tea which was given in aid of the Family Welfare Society of the city.

LEIPZIG, Aug. 25 -- Complaints about two American lawyers, Arthur Garfield Hays of New York and David Levinson of Philadelphia, have been voiced by Dr. Paul Teichert, one of the three lawyers officially appointed by the Reich Supreme Court as counsel for the defendants in the Reichstag fire case.

TULSA, Okla., Aug. 25 (AP) -- Conflicting scales of crude oil prices -- alike only in that they pointed toward increased income for petroleum producers -- were in effect tonight in the Mid-Continent area. The advances surprised most producers.

An application by Irving Cooperberg as a taxpayer for permission to examine the records of the Public Welfare Department for details of the payroll of the city's emergency relief fund was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler on the ground that it would be against public policy to disclose the identities of persons accepting relief.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 25 -- More than 200 Summer colonists dined and danced at the Devon Yacht Club tonight. One of the largest parties was given by Mr. and Mrs. Warren A. Whitney of Worcester, Mass., for Miss Emily Eldredge Grainger, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. William Grainger of East Hampton, whose marriage to their son, George Clarkson Whitney.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 -- A strange kidnapping, in which the victim was forced at gun point to pay his own ransom, came to a climax in a downtown market here today. In a double gun duel the kidnapper was killed, a policeman was seriously wounded, a woman was shot and the victim of the abduction escaped from his captor.
BANFF, Alta., Aug. 25 (Canadian Press).-- Missionaries and movies came in for sharp criticism from members of the Institute of Pacific Relations in a round-table conference today.

To the Editor of The NEW York Times: I note your comment on John W.' Davis's statement that people ought to work eight hours a day. Good King Alfred, whose haunts about Winchester, England, I have just been exploring, believed eight hours should be devoted to work, eight to play and eight to sleep.

Departing yesterday from bis conference with the President at Hyde Park, Secretary WOODIN told the correspondents that he was "not resigning or inflating." Mr. ROOSEVELT himself so far confirmed this as to say that among the subjects discussed by him with Mr. WOODIN inflation was not mentioned.
CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- Macdonald Smith, veteran Scot stylist, shot a record-tying 68 on the No. 4 course at Olympia Fields today to take the lead in the Western open golf championship.

The prospect of a lively primary campaign against Tammany was indicated yesterday when Representative Loring M. Black Jr. and Assemblyman Jerome G. Ambro, candidates for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, opened head-quarters in the midtown section of Manhattan and Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial, candidate for controller, announced that he would open headquarters on Monday.

HAVANA, Aug. 25 -- Havana is celebrating tonight the dissolution of Congress and the re-establishment of the Constitution of 1901. Thousands thronged the Prado and congregated before Cuba's $20,000,000 Capitol, which was brilliantly lighted.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The ultimatum delivered to bituminous coal operators and miners by General Johnson to agree upon an NRA code by Tuesday or have the administration impose one on the industry was precipitated by a danger that the conferences now proceeding between the miners and operators may become "interminable."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Aug. 24, unless otherwise specified.

Mayor O'Brien moved yesterday to speed up the annual budget-making process of the city by ordering that all estimates affected by debt service, deficiencies and mandatory salary requirements be published early next week.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25. -- The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals today sustained a $40,000 award to Mrs. Kathleen I. Glose of Norristown against the Curtiss-Wright Flying Service, Inc., for the death of ner husband, C. William Glose, in an airplane crash near Tampa three years ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Following complaints to the Recovery Administration today by three employer groups in the coat and suit industry against tactics by union officials in New York "obstructing" the resumption of production, General Johnson.

General advances occurred yesterday in the commodity futures markets here, following the trend in the cotton and grain markets and the declining value of the dollar in the world exchange markets Cash prices were also firmer as a rule, with flour and hides alone showing declines.

SILVER BAY ON LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- A sincere effort is being made in the President's recovery program to pull America out of the economic slough of despondence and the future is bright, in the opinion of Henry I. Harriman, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, whose paper on "Toward Economic Recovery" was a feature of today's session of the sixteenth annual conference on industrial relations.

BERLIN, Aug. 25 -- Silence covers the negotiations between Premier Mussolini of Italy and Chancellor Dollfuss of Austria, as far as the German press is concerned. So the German public is still unaware that Austria has a chance of escaping the Nazi clutches.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- After four months of patient effort an agreement was signed by twenty-one countries tonight to restrict the production of wheat, lift its price in the international markets and improve the living conditions of hundreds of millions of farmers and their families throughout the world.

After announcing that the Communists, in "absolute defiance of the government" were making "war on the Blue Eagle," Grover A. Whalen, city chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Committee, disclosed yesterday his plans to meet the Communist challenge.

A working agreement has been effected by the United Fruit Company and the Pan American Airways System whereby their ships and airplanes will handle jointly the transportation of passengers and freight between the United States and thirty-one countries of the Caribbean area, including the West Indies, Central and South America, according to announcement yesterday by W.M. Penick, passenger traffic manager of the fruit company.

Former President Machado of Cuba is resting under guard in Nassau and dreaming of the time when Cubans will realize that his regime was a just one, according to Jose Izquierdo, former Mayor of Havana, who arrived yesterday on the Munson liner Munargo.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 -- The Federal Government today released a suppressed indictment against Samuel and Martin Insull and nine others, charging violation of the Federal Bankruptcy Act by transferring securities. The charge is extraditable in Greece, it is asserted, and the government has already applied under it for the arrest and extradition of Samuel Insull in Athens, his refuge.

Trade Good Despite Storms. Despite the unfavorable weather conditions during much of the week, several leading stores here managed to maintain the recent pace of retail gains, reports here yesterday indicated. Increases of about 5 per cent in dollar volume for the week against a year ago were noted in some instances.

To the Editor of The New York Time: Your editorial on wheat dumping points to a real difficulty which besets those wishing to help American agricu lture by "subsidized exporting." At east, the difficulty mentioned by you is real so long as the accepted definition of dumping "as selling for exportation for less than for consumption at home" remains valid, and so long as this explanatory phrase is interpreted in the customary manner.

TOKYO, Aug. 25 -- While Emperor Hirohito reviewed in Tokyo Bay today the strongest naval fleet ever saluted by a Japanese ruler, the newspaper Nichi Nichi made it clear that the aim of this formidable fleet was to maintain supremacy in the Western Pacific.

George M. Cohan, whose name is virtually a synonym for Broadway, is to appear as an actor in a play by Eugene O'Neill. For the Theatre Guild announced yesterday that the song writer, producer and playwright would have the leading role in "Ah, Wilderness."

The American Gas and Electric Company and subsidiaries report better than seasonal trends in earnings for July, when gross revenues were $4,601,171, compared with $4,350,934 a year before. In June gross revenues were about $4,519,000, compared with 54,423,000 in the corresponding month of 1932.

A total of $10,436,811 of new municipal bonds will come up for award next week, representing the requirements of fifty-six communities in various sections of the country. The total for this week, according to revised figures, was $16,291,389.

If Cuba receives a fair quota for her sugar in the United States, she will again become a big customer for American goods; if limited to too low a quota, she cannot regain her former prosperity and will never again be in the market for American goods, according to Carlos G. Garcia, president of the Cuban Chamber of Commerce in the United States.

ALBANY, Aug. 25 -- Failure of the Legislature, at its extraordinary session which ended last night to meet the requirements of the homerule amendment in passing the Buckley bill giving New York City power to levy special taxes may make it necessary for Governor Lehman to call another extra session soon.

News of the Federal Reserve's intensified credit-expansion campaign brought a heavy fall in the dollar yesterday in the foreign exchange market. In terms of the gold franc the dollar dropped to 68.8 cents, against better than 72 cents on Thursday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some attention ought to be given to the peculiar situation existing in respect to some of these investment trusts. I believe that the following situation is more or less typical:

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- The international wheat agreement which we have just reached here in London gives to the American farmer, and, indeed, to the world's farmer, the boon of "dollar wheat" which has always spelled prosperity.

With two members of the victorious Western team in the East-West series moving into action tomorrow on Long Island, polo interest centres on the final tournaments of the year. These are the open championship and the Monty Waterbury Memorial Cup play.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 25 -- The Yankees' farewell game of the year in Cleveland provided a crushing blow to their pennant hopes today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Gordon Rhodes's good work at bat and on the mound enabled the Red Sox to gain an easy 8-to-1 victory over the White Sox in the seventh and final game of their long series today. It was the second Boston triumph in the set.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug 25 The foreign threat in the national doubles tennis tournament received a serious setback when American combinations emerged victorious in the two international quarter-final matches at the Longwood Cricket Club today.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25. -- Two new deaths from sleeping sickness today brought to thirty the total fatalities in the outbreak which began July 30. The day's report told of twenty-five new cases, making a total of 243, of which 183 are in the county and sixty in the city.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders, dated Aug. 23:

LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 25 -- Eddie Fink of Long Beach made an impressive showing as he started his defense of the International Star class title today, winning the initial race of the championship series from fifteen challengers.
August Heckscher, philanthropist, who celebrates his eighty-fifth birthday today, received the following telegram yesterday from President Roosevelt at Hyde Park:

The money market reflected a further easing of funds when the rates for 60 and 90 days, as well as 4 months, time loans were reduced to 3/4 @ 1 per cent, against a flat 1 per cent on Thursday. Stock Exchange call loans renewed at 1 per cent, with the usual 3/4 per cent quoted on the outside.

The consolidation plans outlined by the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation call for the merger of that line with the Western Pacific Railroad into a corporation of which a substantial interest will be offered to the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, it was disclosed yesterday.

All markets welcomed the news yesterday that the Federal Reserve System was intensifying its credit-expansion campaign. The overnight developments, particularly as they related to this newest phase of the administration's recovery program, met an enthusiastic reception in Wall Street, where aggressive operations for the advance were resumed on all exchanges.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 (AP) -- Sixteen hits behind Lon Warneke's capable hurling gave the Chicago Cubs a 7-to-4 victory over the Phillies today in the second game of a double-header. This enabled them to even the day after the Phils had taken the opener, 8 to 7.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The Navy Department paved the way today for beginning construction of the $238,000,000 warship building program when contracts were signed for two 20,000-ton aircraft carriers and two 10,000-ton light cruisers.

Well Behaved Spain. FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT Jr. has kind things to say about Spain and its people. At the conclusion of what was evidently a successful vacation trip he tells The Associated Press that he is leaving Spain with real regret:

ALBANY, Aug. 25 -- Sixty-four bills were passed by the extraordinary session of the Legislature. Of these Governor Lehman has as yet approved less than half a dozen. He said today that some sixty bills were awaiting his action.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- The congress of the Socialist and Labor International closed tonight, voting a general resolution for combating fascism, Hitlerism and war by vigorous measures, but not by the violent measures suggested by the most radical members.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP). -- Modified Presidential re-employment agreements were approved today by General Johnson for the trucking, fiber and metal buttons, scrap iron and steel, handkerchief, wool felt, cocoa and chocolate, printing ink and funeral supply industries.

Alfred J. Hofmann, Republican designee for City Court justice in Queens, withdrew late yesterday afternoon. Mr. Hofmann thereby paved the way for a compromise to settle the quarrel caused by the demand of the fusionists that a Democrat be placed on the Queens County Republican ticket and the refusal of the Republican organization to withdraw any of its designees.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 -- The long struggle of the Nassau County Village Officials Association to obtain through passenger train route and joint passenger fares between points on the Long Island Railroad and points in New England was lost today when the Interstate Commerce Commission ruled that this step was not "necessary or desirable in the public interest."
The looked-for final in the women's national tennis championship between Mrs. Helen Wills Moody and the player to whom she lost her first set in six years at Wimbledon has failed to materialize.

BERLIN, Aug. 25 -- Adolf Hitler, who only a year ago became a German citizen by appointment of one of the States whose sovereignty he has since wiped out, issued today, through Dr. Wilhelm Frick, his Minister of the Interior, a decree proscribing thirty-three German citizens prominent under the republic, including its first Chancellor, annulling their citizenship and confiscating their possessions.

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- Talk of inflation of the currency was paramount today in shaping the trend of the grain markets, and, with stocks and cotton strong, it took relatively little buying on the Board of Trade to start wheat as much as 4 1/2 cents a bushel higher than yesterday's closing price, or within 1/2cent of the extreme fluctuation permitted for one day on the Exchange.

An agreement on the division of the crosstown bus routes in Manhattan between the Fifth Avenue Coach interests and the bus com- panies owned by Samuel Rosoff was indicated at a hearing yesterday before the Board of Estimate.

We suggested some time ago that if Federal funds were allotted to the State for the schools, they should be spent not for buildings but for the maintenance of teaching. It is gratifying to note that Mr. HOPKINS in his instructions to the Governors as to the application of Federal emergency relief funds has restricted their expenditure to the "minimum needs of the teachers."

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- While railroads will not be brought under the industrial code schedule, President Roosevelt is anxious that railroad workers receive the benefits accruing to employes in other industries.

The city acted promptly yesterday to assure an early start of the $42,000,000 Triborough Bridge project. At the request of George Gordon Battle, chairman of the Triborough Bridge Authority. Mayor O'Brien rushed through the Board of Estimate seven resolutions dealing with the acquisition of land for the bridge and its approaches.

Rising commodity prices are not exclusively an American phenomenon. Markets have also been improving elsewhere. The character and extent of recent gains in six important countries are summarized in the current number of The Annalist. Official index numbers for these countries in May and July are shown in the following table, together with the percentage of change during these two months:

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 25 (AP) -- As another season of Grand Circuit racing at the Illinois State Fair was concluded today. Col. Tom, son of the mighty Colonel Armstrong, won all three heats of the 2:15 pace. In the final mile he stepped the distance in 2:O1.

A lapse of four days apparently has interfered in no way with the winning touch of the pennant-inspired Giants. At least, nothing of the sort could be detected by 35,000 fans who spent a long after-noon Of almost continuous uproar at the Polo Grounds yesterday as Memphis Bill Terry's men upset the Pirates in both ends of a doubleheader.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H., Aug., 25. -- The annual minstrel show, "A Night at the Music Box," given by the staff of the Mount Washington for the benefit of the employes' emergency sick fund was held in the ballroom of the hotel tonight before a large audience.
NYACK, N.T., Aug. 25 -- Ed Don George, one of the several claimants to the world's heavyweight wrestling championship, defeated Charlie Strack of Spring Valley in a savage struggle tonight.

For two days without time out even for sleeping John Strachan, 14-year-old wanderer from 270 Carlton Street, Toronto, Canada, has been riding the city's subways trying to get to Coney Island, but without even enough success to write home about.
Open price competition is required and "loss leader" sales are prohibited by the code of fair competition filed in Washington by the National Wholesale Grocers Association of the United States.

ROME, Aug. 25 -- Negotiations for the conclusion of a pact of non-aggression and neutrality between Italy and Russia have just been concluded. The treaty will be signed at Rome before the end of the month.

A special meeting of preferred stockholders of the American Metals Company has been called for Sept. 20 to act upon proposals for the retirement or refunding of the company's four-year 5 1/2 per cent notes outstanding in the amount of $15,935,000. which will mature on April 1, 1934.

The report of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and subsidiaries for the second quarter of 1933 shows net income of $843,934, equal to 9.66 cents a share on 8,736,429 common shares, comparing with $1,847,281, or 21 cents a share, in the first quarter, and with $2,325,146, or 26.61 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1932.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25 -- A net loss of 41,087 communicant members by the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America for the fiscal year ended March 31 was reported today by the Rev. Dr. Lewis S. Mudge, stated clerk of the General Assembly.

Prices of bonds were higher on the Stock Exchange yesterday in the most active day's trading this month. Transactions totaled S12,857,000, virtually all sections of the list sharing in the increased business. With the further weakness in the dollar, leading foreign loans showed strength.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- The government's fiscal program occupied President Roosevelt's attention today as he canvassed the subject with Secretary Woodin and Budget Director Douglas.

Of the $17,000,000 in bank loans of the Northern Natural Gas Company due on Sept. 1 $16,750,000 has been renewed for six months, with options for extensions beyond that date. The difference represents $250,000 lent by a bank in Detroit, since closed, which the company arranged to pay.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25 -- Microphone, from the Sage Stable, became the first double winner of the American Legion Handicap when he scored by three lengths over a heavy track today. The son of the mud-running Fly-ing Ebony was clocked in 1:27 1-5 when he won last year over much the same kind of a deep track.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The War Department issued the following orders today: Dengler. Col F.L., C.A.C., to Presidio of San Francisco, Calif.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Governor Herbert H. Lehman and Mrs. Lehman attended the races here this afternoon with Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Stuart Green of Albany to witness the running of the Whitney Memorial Race. In memory of Payne Whitney.

PANAMA CITY, Aug. 19. -- A strict censorship on outgoing news makes It difficult to forecast what may be the final outcome of the controversy between President Martinez Mera of Ecuador and the Congress, which has already demanded his resignation.

The emergency funds of the Salvation Army will be exhausted by Sept. 30. At that time an additional and more drastic curtailment of the organization's relief program will be necessary unless additional funds can be obtained, it was announced yesterday.

Air-Conditioning for Cars. THE air-conditioned automobile made its debut here last week. Those who rode in it felt cool and comfortable in the midst of traffic heavy with fumes, and heard only faint echoes of roaring elevated trains and clattering trolley cars.

SOUTHAMPTON. -- Judging by the full calendar'of activities it would seem that members of society here are attempting to crowd as much gayety as possible into this, the last important week of the season.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just been reading with interest and pleasure the Julia New berry diary. I am myself an old timer and had my boyhood just a few years later than the times she writes of. The pleasure I got from her writings is just that they take me back into the old delightful days. Julia.

It appears likely that the dollar, in spite of its own difficulties, is about to be replaced by the pound sterling as the sick man of the foreign exchange market. It has been evident for some time that the official control has not been operating satisfactorily in support of the pound against the franc.

France would eagerly welcome a Franco-American conference for the purpose of trade reciprocity and the ultimate establishment of a new commercial treaty, in the opinion of Robert Dubard, editor-in-chief of the Parisian daily L'lntransigeant who was in New York last week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An editorial in your paper on Aug. 7 entitled "The Last Stand of Individuality" is concluded with the following words: "If the plans of the successor to Horace Mann are realized, every valley in tbat valley of valleys will, in the true Isaian sense, 'be exalted." "

WHAT Arnold Bennett and Edward Knoblock did in depicting the English scene in "Milestones," their 1921 drama of three generations, Larry Barretto has now, in different degree and with purposely narrower implication, effected for America.
Cadet James Schermerhorn, West Point, '89, was in a reminiscent mood last week. On Friday he happened upon two of his old classmates at the University Club.

The Intensified credit-Inflation campaign which the Federal Reserve System began last week has been undertaken in circumstances which are more favorable to its success than were those of previous campaigns.

When he left his home in Toronto, Canada, early on the morning of Aug. 16, John Strachan, 14 years old, didn't know where he was going and didn't care much, either. Certainly he never dreamed that he would end up as a lost child, in the headquarters of the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, at 2 East 105th Street.

THE appearance of Tamiris and the Bahama Negro Dancers as the last of the season's dance attractions at the ' Lewisohn Stadium proved to be in performance just the reverse of what it was generally expected to be.

The gay pennant dash of the Giants was slowed a trifle at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Pirates, after being properly subdued by Carl Hubbell, 2 to 1, in the opener of a double-header, suddenly got completely out of hand in the second engagement.
With 7,000 fans cheering impartially for both good and bad plays, the Reds and Dodgers closed their series at Ebbets Field yesterday by bowing to each other.
ATHENS, Aug. 26 -- Samuel Insull was detained by the police at 11 o'clock this morning as a result of a new request by the United States Government for his extradition.

LAKE PLACID. -- Miss Mary E. Woolley, president of Mt. Holyoke College, who yesterday addressed the Essex County Branch of the American Association of University Women at an open forum luncheon meeting at Westport Inn on "A New Responsibility," will today be the speaker in the series of union religious services sponsored by prominent members of the Westport colony.

TOKYO, Aug. 7. -- The active idea behind the patriotic revolutionary movement in Japan is national socialism. There is therefore an essential difference between the assassinations of last year and previous events of the same kind. Hitherto the guiding principle of the right-wing extremists of Japan has been patriotism and loyalty without ulterior purposes.
MADRID, Aug. 26. -- Democracy appears to be rapidly strengthening its grip on Spain, which has tried every kind of rule from a monarchical plutocracy to a one-man dictatorship.

WITH decorators placing emphasis on classical modes, Italian eighteenth-century pieces are in increased demand. Italy was of course, the source of the classical movement in decoration: hence it is natural that Italian chairs, settees, sofas and small tables should associate harmoniously with English and Colonial pieces designed under the same influence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- Growing concern over the financial position of Cuba has led to a decision to attach an expert of the United States Treasury Department to the American Embassy in Havana. He will make a thorough study of the Cuban financial structure, with especial attention to the public and private debt load under which the new Cuban Government is staggering.
WASHINGTON. Aug. 26. Movements of vessels follow, all dales are Aug. 25, unless otherwise specified:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- An outline of the scope and purposes of the President's emergency re-employment campaign was Issued today by General Johnson in response to many requests from newspapers for such a statement.
SEAL HARBOR, Me., Aug. 26. -- Following is the text of the radio address made by John D. Rockefeller Jr. tonight:

QUEBEC, Que., Aug. 26 -- Canadian air history was made today when Frank Hawks, United States airman, hurtled his Silver Bullet through fog and storm from Vancouver to Quebec, and covered about 2,800 miles in 17 hours and 10 minutes elapsed time.

NEW YORK. Captain Ferdinando Casardi, Naval Attache of the Italian Embassy, will "give a luncheon today in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Admiral Romeo Bernotti, Commander of the Royal Italian Naval Academy.

BEGINNING with a motor accident caused by Henry Moyle's effort to avoid running over a small gray cat, this story rapidly develops into a mystery adventure yarn involving two men and two girls in a series of terrifying experiences and transforming an elderly business man and an apparently brainless fop into heroes of romance performing such deeds of derring-do as neither of them had ever dreamed to be within his power.

WHEN still a young man, Dean Rusby was commissioned by the firm of manufacturing chemists for whom he then worked to go to South America to study the then scarcely known drug coca, or erythroxylon, the alkaloid of which is cocaine.

Big game in the United States, while showing few increases, nevertheless is about holding its own, according to a report issued yesterday by the United States Department of Agriculture. It is based upon a census taken in the 148 national forests of the country.

DETROIT. ATOMOBILE manufacturing is going to bridge the gap between Summer and Fallordinarily a period of low operation -- with little if any recession of plant activity. Uncertainly regarding the effect of NRA regulation soon to be in force has been replaced by assurance that business is to continue its accelerated pace.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 24. -- The fights for cheaper textbooks which were being waged before a number of Legislatures a few months ago have resulted in a movement throughout the South to bring about lower costs in school books. The Governors and the members of the boards of education of nine States In this tier have been invited by Governor Blackwood of South Carolina to meet in Atlanta.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Production ot wild game as an extra "crop" for Wisconsin farmers will be undertaken in all seriousness during the next live years. The University of Wisconsin will direct the plan through a Department of Game Management.

MOTORISTS of the nation, beginning next Friday, will be on their best behavior, with caution the watch word. For September, proclaimed as Highway Safety Month, will inaugurate perhaps the greatest concerted movement in this country to check the toll of motor accidents.

OUT in the United Air Lines hangar at Oakland, Calif., stands a flying wing, all metal monoplane designed, built and tested by the late Claire Vance, mail pilot. There is gasoline in the great tanks, enough for a long flight and Vance had completed his tests for such a flight before he was killed while flying the mail through the Rockies one stormy night.

Speeding up a program which was to have extended over a period of years, Pan-American Airways yesterday authorized immediate construction of new flying equipment and terminal facilities at a total cost of $3,250,000. This is in addition to the $1,750,000 recently authorized for construction of four transoceanic flying boats, now being built to specifications laid down by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, head of the technical committee of the airline.

QUEBEC, Aug. 26 (Canadian Press) -- W.A. Gordon, Minister of Immigration, was asked to prevent the immigration to Canada of German Jews forced out of Germany, in a resolution passed by the Quebee City Council.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- The text of President Roosevelts speech here today was as follows:

BEHIND securely locked doors, over which secret agents disguised as theatre watchmen keep their solemn vigil, there has been going forward in West Forty-fifth Street and its environs these past few weeks a job of carpentry comparable to the construction of the Grecian horse outside the walls of Troy.

Edison Hedges of Atlantic City will be the defending title-holder in the second annual national championship for 125-cubio inch piston displacement motor boats, which will be held at Ocean City, N. J., on Labor Day. He again will drive his boat Flying Eagle.

Serious doubts regarding the widom of granting the recent governmental $2,000,000 and $3,000,000 loans for medium-priced housing projects in Brooklyn and Queens, respectively, are expressed Frank Fox, president of Realty Associates.

IT is not for pleasure that one becomes an expatriate. One loves the regions one knew as a youngster. One is attached even to the places where one has paid taxes. And then, it is difficult to express one's self in a foreign tongue.
Speedy return of the dress and cloakmaking industry to normal was predicted yesterday by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

NEWPORT. -- With the approach of September this city and the members of the Summer colony are looking forward to two busy weeks. The visit that the U.S.S. Wyoming, with 360 midshipmen aboard, is to make for nine days and the coming of the British cruiser Norfolk for a similar stay before the Wyoming leaves will give considerable zest to the late season entertaining.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The strife-laden topic of price fixing for the oil industry, which for weeks prevented an agreement on a petroleum code, was suddenly revived today as a major issue between the NRA and advocates of rigid price control while President Roosevelt neared a final decision on the question.

LONDON. TOMORROW is the centenary of the birth of Burne-Jones. As a painter, he has passed from favor much as Tennyson has from poetry. As a master of the decorative arts, he and his leonine friend William Morris are responsible between them for a considerable part of the whole brief story of English design.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having left Bagdad a little over a month ago when Assyrian matters were beginning to look disquieting, may I be permitted to supply some of the facts which would give your readers enough of a background to enable them to read between the lines of the news?

SHANGHAI, Sunday, Aug. 27. -- It appears that only a miracle can save Tsinan, Shantung Province's capital and a city of 600,000 population from inundation, for the Yellow River is only two inches below the top of the dikes at Lokow, seven miles above the city.

The ability of the Alleghany Corporation, a $200,000,000 unit in the Van Sweringen railway - holding structure, to meet interest charges due on Oct. 1 will be affected by the action which the Chesapeake Ohio Railway's directors take at their dividend meeting scheduled for Tuesday.

THE Blue Eagle will be perched high on the microphone tonight for a coast-to-coast flight when the NRA gala broadcast goes on the air with speeches and entertainment fed into a national wire web from New York, Boston, Washington, Los Angeles and Toledo.

With the completion last week of the reorganization of the Fox Film Corporation through the retirement of $29,614,845 of debentures, the company has been freed of virtually all debts incurred as a result of Its ambitious program of expansion in 1928, 1929 and 1930.

UNLESS the Giants and Senators go into reverse with astonishing speed, it can be taken for granted that the pennant races are fairly well settled for the season of 1933. In the lull before the world's series storm there is time to look over the general batting order and see how the hitters have been getting along with the less lively ball.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26. -- An investigation of Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines's conduct of office as veterans' administrator was demanded today in a resolution adopted unanimously by the American Legion, Department of Pennsylvania, in annual convention.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- A contract bridge benefit will be held on Tuesday for Wiawaka House. Mme. Marcella Sembrich's proteges will appear In a concert on Friday to assist the Tri-County Association for the Blind. The Sagamore Hotel costume ball on Saturday completes the list of major events of the week.

SEAL HARBOR, Me., Aug. 26 -- John D. Rockefeller Jr. pleaded tonight for nation-wide cooperation to assure success of the "great adventure in reconstruction, the National Recovery Act," and declared that "to turn back is unthinkable."

WHENEVER an independent broadcasting station announces plans for a reorganization or issues a pledge of improved programs, comment is usually heard that a new network is in the process of evolution. Station WMCA's announcement that it had been acquired by a group of young men, including John Hay Whitney and Clendenin J. Ryan Jr., revived rumors that it would be groomed as the nucleus of a new network.

"SUMMER WHITE HOUSES" have of late years tended to drift about the Big Lot that is our share of this continent. The Roosevelts, being a patriarchal tribe, have preferred the family estate as a customary place of refuge when Washington gets too hot (by the purely thermometric test) to hold them.

PARIS. I HAVE often quoted Carlyle's remark: "A well-written life is just as rare as one well lived." Many biographies are disappointing because the author has not made the effort to understand his subject, to go beneath the conventional figure created by literary or political history in order to discover the man under the great man.
TORONTO, Aug. 26. -- Invading singles sculling stars from the United States and Germany captured major honors in the Canadian national exhibition's international regatta today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- A busy, not to say exciting, week in the public affairs of the country came to a close tonight with one of the most persistent questions before the National Administration literally crying out for an answer. It is:

BERLIN, Aug. 12, 1933 ALLEGATIONS of "conscientious objection" kept both Sigrid Onegin and Hans Pfitzner afar from Salzburg this Summer. The decision in each case took shape rather suddenly. Mme. Onegin was to have sung Orfeo in Gluck's opera-a part in which she has appeared several times in Salzburg -- under the direction of Bruno Walter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A far-reaching plan to guarantee retail sales near factory-fixed prices was presented to the Recovery Administration today by the nation's druggists at the conclusion of their hearing on an NRA code.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- With the death of William L. Ward, who built up the present Westchester Republican organlzation, and a series of other uncontrollable factors, the organization, faces a stiff fight at the polls this Fall to keep control of the county.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 23. -- In view of Missouri's recent 3 to 1 vote in favor of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, it may sound fantastic for the drys to entertain serious thought of challenging the legality of the election, hut some of them are going ahead with that veiy program.

AMOS 'N' ANDY, who have just begun the fifth year as aerial ambassadors for their present sponsor, have established several enviable records since they first faced WJZ's microphone in 1929. They were the first pair to create and portray a host of ethereal characters (more than sixty have been heard on their programs) without using voices other than their own.

LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The staid London stock market, so often disturbed by the gyrations of Wall Street, would welcome a calmer market in New York. Agitation in America for control of the New York Stock Exchange has therefore attracted much attention in Throgmorton Street, but with traditional British dread of government interference in finance, brokers here view definite proposals to that end dubiously.

OUT in Chicago recently women of many nations called for a new deal in women's clubs. The feminine inferiority complex is passing, they said in effect, and for the first time in history women's organizations are ready to make "a frontal attack on world problems."

STOCKHOLM, Aug. 15 -- The commercial war between Great Britain and Soviet Russia, following the Moscow trial of the British engineers, has spurred, industry here. Freighters long laid up are being recommissioned. Increases have been noted in exports of wood pulp, pit props, deals, iron ore and butter.

Speaking for the Tennessee Valley Authority, Commissioner LILIENTHAL promises that the Muscle Shoals enterprise will be so conducted as to " permil of comparison of operations with privately owned plants, to supply a yardstick and an incentive to both private and public managers."

Losing control of her automobile after it had struck a small child, a Brooklyn woman saw the car swerve yesterday into a parked automobile in which a second child was sitting. Injuries to the first child were fatal and the other is believed to have sustained a fractured spine.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 26 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency) -- The executive of the World Zionist organization had nothing to do with the negotiations which led to an agreement with the German Government for the export to Palestine, in the form of German goods, of 3,000,000 marks of capital of Jewish emigrants, Berl Locker of New York, member of the executive, told the Zionist congress here tonight.

ATHENS, Aug. 26 -- Samuel Insull, former head of the vast Insull utilities interests, was detained in a nursing home today as the United States began a second fight to extradite him. This time he is charged with violation of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Tammany Hall and the city administration, lacking a program for raising new city revenues, are relying on Samuel Untermyer, and the Grimm Committee to put forward a suitable tax program between now and election.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26. -- A new experiment in the effort to solve the secret of the cosmic ray is under way on the round-the-world liner President Garfield. Dr. Robert A. Millikan, the Pasadena physicist, is author and directing genius of the test and the Dollar Steamship Company, through its president, R. Stanley Dollar, is cooperating.

A NEW motion picture producing organization appeared last week on the eastern horizon. To be exact, it has unfurled its banner over the Eastern Service Studios, Paramount's old headquarters in Astoria. There, Eddie Cowling, who is known on Broadway and elsewhere as an actor, author, producer and even as a singer, sits serenely at a large desk as president of the concern.

WITH allowance made for decidedly unfavorable weather conditions, local retail trade made a good showing during the week. Increases over a year ago were reported for several stores, while the recession noted by others was not enough to offset substantial gains made earlier in the month.

THE truant Philip Goodman returned home a week or so ago after ten months in Munich, Vienna. Moscow -- and where you will. It seems that he has written two plays. One is called "Birth of a Hero" and its locale is post-war Austria.

HARTFORD, Aug. 24. -- The new deal in Washington is proving to be a fine thing for the New Guard faction of the Connecticut Democrats, but it is a total loss for those members of the party, including United States Senator Augustine Lonergan, who are not tried and true members of the favored faction.

Despite the National Recovery Administration's rejection last week of a code for public schools and public school teachers submitted by the American Federation of Teachers, the framing of some sort of code is under serious consideration by national educational authorities.

A BIOGRAPHY of King Edward VII -- readable, accurate and well-rounded -- would fill a place in the library that is now vacant. For the writing of such a biography, popular yet authoritative. Mr. Benson has the qualifications. The son of an Archbishop of Canterbury, he has breathed the air of Lambeth Palace and Windsor Castle.

The American Hotel Association, points out Horwath Horwath, hotel accountants, is working with the NRA on a temporary code and, while no agreement has yet been reached as to minimum wage rates and maximum working hours, it is apparent that any agreement acceptable to NRA would necessitate an increase of at least 10 to 15 per cent in apartment rates in order to cover the readjusted payroll.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 24 -- Liquor legislation is playing a large part in the special session of the Kentucky Legislature at Frankfort. The wets won a sweeping victory in both houses this week, when committees returned favorable reports on bills providing for an election of delegates to a repeal convention.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Miss Rosalie Crosby, daughter of Mrs. Henry Ashton Crosby of Mount Klsco, will make her debut at a supper dance to be given by her mother at the Lawrence Farms Golf Club here on Sept. 19. Miss Crosby attended Rosemary Hall, Greenwich, Conn., and later studied in Paris and Switzerland.

Arthur Garfield Hays announced yesterday that his request to be allowed to aid in the defense of three of the five men accused of having set fire to the Reichstag, building in Berlin last February had been denied by the German Supreme Court in Leipzig.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The Athletics rose up in the seventh inning today and put together five solid hits for as many runs to wipe out an early White Sox lead and spoil an otherwise successful Ted Lyons Day celebration by defeating the veteran hurler, 10 to 5.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Discussion of the National Recovery Act as it affects labor will be a feature of the convention of the American Federation of Labor, which will be held in this city beginning Oct. 2, it was announced today.

An early advance in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday established the highest quotations since October sold below 8 1/2 cents a pound following the last government crop estimate. Strength in Liverpool and execution of foreign buying orders started October around 9 3/4 cents, where the market met liberal week-end hedging by spot interests.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor announced today that its index number of the general level of wholesale prices for last week -- the week ended Aug. 19 -- stood at 69.3. When compared with the week ended Aug. 12 with an index of 69.4 wholesale prices showed a decrease of one-tenth of 1 per cent.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 26 -- The long impending Paterson silk strike will start Thursday morning, it was announced today following a meeting of the Associated Silk Workers. Paterson unit of the American Federation of Silk Workers.

THE Stadium season proper is over, but it has been extended to include two extra performances of opera. "Carmen" will be presented tomorrow evening and "II Trovatore" on Tuesday. These productions were planned for last week, but New York's rainy season necessitated postponing them.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 26. -- Business activity continued to show a slight recession in the week ended on Aug. 19, the Department of Commerce reported today in its weekly survey of domestic business conditions.
PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Dances for three nights, combined with many dinner and luncheon parties and golf and tennis tournaments, will make next week the liveliest of the Summer in Berkshire.

BERLIN, Aug. 26 -- Gottfried Feder, creator of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's economic program and now Under-Secretary in the Reich Ministry of Economics, outlined before the Congress of Cooperatives today the basic idea behind the National Socialist labor-creation program, which is designed to restore Germany's economic strength and do away with unemployment as the first condition for the survival of Nazidom itself.

MOSCOW, Aug. 25. -- The huge State farms -- "Soviet grain factories," as they are termed here -- have not justified the expectations and prophecies that accompanied their inauguration four or five years ago.

Except for a hesitant advance in wheat and two or three other grains, there was no movement of consequence yesterday in the few markets that remained open. Business was suspended on the security exchanges so that there were no quotations for stocks and bonds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Out of one of the most confusing phases of the soft coal code negotiations, one proposal emerged today. That was the definite suggestion by Recovery Administrator Johnson that the bituminous coal industry agree to a forty-hour week of five eight-hour days.

LONDON, Sunday, Aug. 27. -- The Sunday Times In an editorial praises the completion of the final stage of the Llndberghs' northern air route survey as a sensational example of the rapidity of progress In world communications.
Mrs. Helen Wills Moody no longer rules the courts.

CHICAGO'S "Century of Progress" has naturally given birth not only to an exposition but to a number of histories of the city. One might almost say biographies, for a strong sense of personality runs through them all. In the present volume the combination of the personality of Chicago and the personality of the author of "The Spoon River Anthology" is interesting.

BRETTON WOODS, N.H. -- This week-end marks the high point in the White Mountains season, with many social and sports events planned for visitors. Tonight Mrs. George Dent Crabbs of Franconia is giving a reading of the play "Green Pastures" at the Unitarian Church, Littleton.

The loss of a pocketbook containing $10,400 in cash and three rings valued at $750 was reported last night to the Ryer Avenue police station in the Bronx by Mrs. Dora Garfinkel of 2,757 Claflin Avenue.

The largest attendance of the sea-son taxed the facilities and capacity of the Sands Point Bath Club, Sands Point, L.I., last night for the Sands Point Charity Revue, a diversified, entertainment of public subscription given in the interests of the National Charity Air Pageant which is to be held at Roosevelt Field on Oct. 7 and 8 under the auspices of the United States Amateur Air Pilots Association, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- An agreement for coordination of the work of the Foreign. Service officers of the State Department and the commercial attaches and trade commissioners of the Department of Commerce has been announced. The new arrangement goes into effect at once.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga. ASMALL-SCALE exemplification of President Roosevelt's policy of large-scale planning is his 2,000-acre farm here surrounding his part-time home, "The Little White House."

HOLLYWOOD. PRODUCTION took a turn for the better this week with MGM reporting an all-time peak of fifteen features scheduled to be before the cameras by tomorrow and with Warner Brothers second with eight, the highest number in two years.

Everybody has taken "judicial knowledge" of the fact that modern diplomatic practice has been greatly altered from that of a century or so ago. It is a commonplace that the telegraph and telephone have today made an Ambassador something like a direct and daily correspondent of his State Department or Foreign Office.

HAVANA, Aug. 26 -- General Mario G. Menocal, former President of Cuba and Conservative leader, announced today that he would immediately begin the formation of a new party in preparation for the general elections Feb. 24, 1934.

WASHINGTON. A the nation-wide Blue Eagle campaign gets under way the NRA leaves its honeymoon period behind and enters upon the most critical and, as its spokesmen believe, the most constructive stage of its far-flung adventure in national planning.

ONCE again that hardy perennial -- the shark scare -- has blossomed forth. The Summer's crop of reports from the metropolitan area's watering places has already yielded a richer harvest of terrifying episodes than any season in recent years.

THROUGH the tropic wastes of Queensland this month a scientific expedition from Europe is traveling toward an almost inaccessible mountain range to gaze upon what is said to be the tallest orchid on earth, a giant forty-five feet high, bearing wondrous flower clusters.

Questionnaires are regarded by perhaps too many of us as unnecessary evils or positive plagues. Yet sometimes comfort comes from them, or at least the answers to them. In The Spectator is an instance of pertinent and fruitful inquiry. Commander KINGHALL, who broadcasts weekly to children, was invited by the Historical Association to speak on current history as taught in the schools.

BUILDING of a system of at least six transcontinental national highways is one of the planks in the program of the United States Good Roads Association, which is to hold its twenty-first annual convention at Beaumont, Texas, Oct. 11, 12 and 13. According to J.A. Roundtree, director general, among other measures to be taken up will be:

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23. -- Public enthusiasm for President Roosevelt has been made the chief issue in a Mayoralty contest warming up here, in which Mayor Ray T. Miller, the first Democratic Mayor since Newton D. Baker, and Congressman Martin L. Sweeney, another Democrat but a fiery rival of Miller, are battling for the "Roosevelt vote."

DUBLIN, Aug. 25 -- The struggle between President de Valera and General Owen O'Duffy overshadows all else in current Free State politics, and the outlawing of the Blue Shirts -- the National Guard -- is generally regarded as only one phase of the Irish political re ignment.

The recent rain has caused wide fluctuations in garden and truck produce, according to a statement yesterday by George G. Royce. director of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets.

The decision of the Federal Relief Administration last week to aid rural schools by manning them with unemployed teachers at work-relief wages calls attention anew to the fact that education in the United States is still mainly a country and village problem.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 -- The action of the grain markets on the Board of Trade today was somewhat confused, with wheat, oats, rye and barley averaging higher and corn lower, although the last named was up as much as 5/8 cent a bushel at the start.
