NEW HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 26 (AP). -- Twenty-two persons were injured, none seriously, late today as a section of a docking pier collapsed at Lighthouse Point, a bathing resort, and threw about 75 persons into the water of the harbor. The crash occurred at the finish of a cross-harbor swimming race.

MANILA. A FUTURE independent Philippine State is faced with the difficult and important problem of the treatment of the non-Christian population of the islands. This problem has been presented, from time to time, as if it were a question of civilizing barbaric and savage peoples; and in this form its very suggestion is resented by the Christian Filipino.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 26. -- The East projected itself boldly into the international star class yacht championship today as Adrien Iselin 2d skippered the light weather sloop Ace of Port Washington, L.I., to victory in the second race of the series off the Pacific Coast.

Because of the labor situation, wholesale stocks of dress coats, sport coats and suits and dresses of all grades are practically nil, with ten days to three weeks required for deliveries, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 26. -- The possibility of an international final in the 1933 national doubles tennis championship took on a brighter outlook today.

PARIS, Aug. 19. -- Socially speaking, Paris, which always empties in August, became for the Assumption holidays like a squeezed orange. Assumption Day itself, Aug. 15, is the biggest religious holiday of the year, and in this case falling on Tuesday, just after the week-end, stretched the holiday to four days.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 23 -- With the fervor of crusaders, the South is backing President Roosevelt in his efforts to achieve a steady and substantial movement in the direction of economic recovery. This spirit of peace patriotism is shared by men, women and children and has proved both an inspiration and a spur to the various businesses of this district.

PARIS, Aug. 26. -- The newspaper L'Ere Nouvelle, which reflects the views of the Radical-Socialist party of France, to which Premier Daladier and Edouard Herriot belong, prints today the following editorial:

MANILA, July 23. -- The rise and fall of Manuel Roxas, consummated today when his successor, Quintin Parades, was elected to the Speakership of the House of Representatives, furnished the first dramatic sidelight of the Hawes Law campaign in the Philippines.

THE noon sun of Aug. 2 flooded with white heat the desert stretch near Clovis, N.M. Under its glare a little group stood keenly watching a man working with his hands to uncover something a few feet down in a sand bank.

The continued operation of German shipping services is urged by the managing board of the Hamburg-American Line as essential to the maintenance of Germany's position in the world of shipping, despite their inability to show a favorable balance at the end of the season.

BANFF, Alta., Aug. 26 (AP). -- Dr. Inazo Nitobe, chairman of the Japanese delegation at the Institute of Pacific Relations Conference, now in session here, declared today there was "every prospect of an early settlement between Russia and Japan of the important question of purchase of the Northern Manchurian (Chinese Eastern) Railway."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation fixed at 5 per cent today the interest rate on processing tax loans which may be made by the corporation under authority granted in the Agricultural Adjustment Act.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey announces in its publication The Lamp that it believes the oil code as submitted by the National Recovery Administration, considering the wide divergence of the views to be reconciled, offers a generally acceptable initial working program with the exception of the price-fixing provision.

Several pastors are expected this morning to urge the cooperation of church members in promoting the success of the NRA program. Today has been suggested in a letter from the local NRA headquarters for concerted effort by clergymen in support of the plan.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Crime is costing the nation $13,000,000,000 a year, the National Council of '76 estimated today.

NEAR the source of the Khabur River in Northern Mesopotamia stands a great mound known as Tell Halaf. Here, in the concluding years of the past century, some tribesmen, starting to dig a grave, were terrified by the discovery of great stone images such as they had never seen before.

A call to Democratic, Republican and Socialist leaders to mobilize their party machinery in New York City for the NRA consumer drive that will be launched on Sept. 5 and continued for ten days, was issued yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, city chairman of the President's Emergency Re-employment Committee.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 26. -- Joseph Andrews's Sundance, 6-year-old bay gelding, won the feature event of the Nassau Driving Club matinee at the Fair Grounds ten day in straight heats. The gelding took the first beat by a length from Direct Strathmore in 2:13 1/4.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- President Roosevelt told his neighbors of Dutchess County today that the recovery drive, backed by a unanimity unequaled since the World War days, was bringing the country back to better times.

THE writer of these lines, several Sundays ago, was gently taken to task by sympathizers with the Russian musical Left, when he said that the present regime in Russia was too insistent upon musical polemics, and that the attempt to express the ideas of the Russian revolution in music had somehow failed -- as, he might have added, other such attempts, made under similar circumstances, have failed in previous critical periods of history.

EAST HAMPTON. L.I., Aug. 26. -- The marriage of Miss Emily Grainger, daughter of the Rev. William Grainger, rector of St. Luke's Episcopal Church here, and Mrs. Grainger, to George Clarkson Whitney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren A. Whitney of Worcester, Mass., took place this afternoon at St. Luke's and was followed by a reception for about 300 guests in the gardens of St. Luke's Rectory.

SOFIA, Aug. 10. -- First a wedding and then a birth has occurred upon the summit of Moussala, a peak of the Rila Mountains in Southern Bulgaria which rises to 9.594 feet and is the highest in the Balkans.
The grand jury investigation into rackets marked time yesterday. On the resumption of the jury sessions tomorrow the future of the inquiry will come up for consideration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP). -- A revised draft of the proposed sugar marketing agreement filed today with Secretary Wallace showed the interests involved still were moving with accord on how much of the commodity each will supply to the domestic market.

WHILE the administrators of the Agricultural Adjustment Act have been grappling with the problem of checking a too exuberant output from American farms, nature has given us an illustration of the way she performs the same task.

Detroit, long motor-minded, is to switch from the land to the water this week with a motorboat regatta far surpassing in size any ever held. It will include the Harmsworth Trophy international contest, the Gold Cup Race, the Dodge Memorial Trophy competition and a number of events between outboards.
Ray Ruddy of the New York A. C. successfully defended his metropolitan one-mile senior A. A. U. swimming championship in the seventy-five-foot pool of the Jerome Cascades yesterday.

The names of 202 honor students for the academic year 1932-33 were announced yesterday by Professor William R. Bryans, chairman of the Scholarship Committee of the New York University Evening Engineering Division.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 (AP) -- A State suit charging insolvency of the Missouri State Life Insurance Company was filed in circuit court here today preliminary to efforts to reorganize or sell the concern.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 26 -- President Justo sent to Congress today the 1934 budget providing for expenditures of 837,865,929 pesos ($301,631,734 at the present exchange). It lacks $5,500,000 of being balanced, but the message to Congress says the government will submit legislation to overcome this estimated decline in the general revenues.

THE work of building the Triborough Bridge will be resumed within a few weeks. The completion of the great structure before the end of 1935 seems assured. The Federal Public Works Administration has tentatively approved a loan of $37,000,000 for the purpose.

Among the honorary degrees conferred by the University of Cambridge last June was one given to MARCONI. In his case, the Public Orator strained the capacities of the Latin language to express praise of the wonders of wireless and radio. He began by citing a saying of an old friend of his: "My " house was filled with song and I did " not know it."

A YOUNG woman, happening into a large drug store recently, noticed that a bottle of perfume, for which she had paid a good round sum at another store, was being sold for one-third less than she had been charged.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 -- Mid-West impatience over the delay in getting the public works program of the Federal Emergency Administration under way is causing inquiry to be made as to who is to blame for the situation. Lika a rising storm, questions are pouring in one the various State advisory boards and re-employment directors: "When do we start?" "When do we get the money?" "Why the delay?"

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- The National Recovery Administration today authorized modified Presidential Re-employment Agreements for the wholesale lobster, crepe paper, steel plates, milk sugar and dried milk manufacturing industries.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The Newark Bears strengthened their International League lead by taking both games of a double-header today from the Jersey City club.
LONDON, Aug. 26. -- Great Britain, which long boasted itself as the world's workshop and the world's banker, has been forced by the world-wide economic storm to adopt a policy of "digging in."

THE first unmistakable appearance of the "idea of progress" occurred, as J.B. Bury pointed out. In eighteenth-century France, at the precise moment when Descartes and Newton were laying down the foundations of modern scientific method.

IF France accedes to the recent suggestion of her Council of Ministers to'hold a national lottery, she will use a method of balancing the budget which many countries have adopted. In such Latin-American lands as Spain, Cuba and the Argentine, lotteries have long: been a national institution.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial of Aug. 14 points out the danger of the Cuban Army becoming a Pretorian Guard. Unfortunately, this danger frequently occurs south of the Rio Grande. Latin-American armies are often designed for internal use only.
SIANFU, SHENSI, Aug. 2. -- Chinese dwelling in the valley surrounding the lonely city of Nancheng, in the mountains of Southern Shensi Province, are now ready to believe the miraculous.

OWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 26 -- Attacking Tammany as a greedy, voracious and corrupt political machine. W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, today urged the election of a Republican Assembly to prevent Tammany from levying tribute on every county and village of the State.
PARIS, Aug. 17. -- If the dollar stays down long enough American residents here will at last come to know something of France.

Forty-two young Cubans who had been exiles in New York during the Machado regime sailed for Havana yesterday afternoon on the steamship Morro Castle, at the expense of the new Cuban Government. They included students, members of the A.B.C. secret society, and others who had been active in the anti-Machado movement.

THE epidemic of sleeping sickness of the temperate zone, known as encephalitis lethargica, prevalent in St. Louis and its suburbs, is of keen interest to the United States Public Health authorities. Thus fat the official record shows 129 cases and 12 deaths, while in former outbreak elsewhere not more than twenty or thirty cases have been reported in one place.

With three series moving higher, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity rose one-tenth of a point for the week ended Aug. 19, bringing to a halt the four weeks' downward movement, in which almost 10 points were lost. The figure advanced to 89.3 from 89.2 in the previous week.
DENVER, Aug. 26 -- Using tear gas and revolvers, three bandits this morning blinded three bank messengers in the heart of the wholesale district and escaped with $36,000 in currency.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 26 (AP). -- The unprecedented peace-time powers vested in President Roosevelt by the last Congress will be the principal subject of discussion at the American Bar Association's convention opening here Wednesday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Pennsylvania can report another triumph of wild life conservation in the appearance of a pair of beavers in a stream near Pittsburgh. They are building a dam in Little Sewickley Creek, back of Sewickley Heights, a suburb, and every night scores of people gather to watch the progress of the work.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Fair Dreams, owned by E. Roland rriman, and driven by Will Dickerson, won the free-for-all trot, feature event on the final program at the Orange County fair today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- George Alpxander Armstrong of New York City, Second Secretary of Embassy at Warsaw, has been designated Second Secretary of Embassy at Berlin.

GRANTED that the so-called "narratage" treatment of the film "The Power and Glory," which is now on exhibition at the Gaiety, is interesting as a novelty and eminently well suited to this particular story, it is a question whether it will prove as successful with other productions, except possibly, as one studio official pointed out, in the picturing of biographical stories.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Aug. Aug 6. -- A New Jersey beer control plan preserving the home rule principle but giving supervisory power to a State commission was outlined yesterday in a statement by Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City. The Mayor, who controls politics in Hudson County and is leader of the Democratic party in the State, will have his plan presented when the Legislature meets Tuesday in Trenton.

WASHINGTON, PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S reforestation program, now going forward with a heartening rush, includes red men as well as white. Today in addition to the 300,000 men of the Civilian Conservation Corps, 12,200 needy Indians are being aided by the Emergency Conservation Work Act, which authorized the President to employ numbers of the unemployed in protecting and improving the forests, preventing soil erosion and in some instances engaging in flood-control work.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- The United States must export or otherwise dispose of 161,000,000 bushels of wheat during the 1333-34 marketing season, to reduce the carryover to normal size, according to estimates today by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics.

THAT a climate can be made to order, industry proved long ago. A prime reason for Great Britain's old supremacy as a spinner and weaver of cotton was her weather -- weather damp enough to prevent fibers from attracting one another electrically.

PARIS, Aug. 24 -- Cobweb, by stockings made without clocks, and plain glove-fitting shoes will complement skirts that have decorative hems or are split. Recently popular perforations and tucks are being outmoded by plain treatments.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 26. -- Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel's fine chestnut gelding. His Elegance, carried off the major honors in the North Shore Horse Show today by capturing the hunter championship, feature event of the two-day exhibition.

GREENWOOD LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 26 -- Paul Hyatt of Brooklyn, driving his Miss Shuffle, set a new Class F amateur outboard competition speed of 50.336 miles an hour to feature the first day's program of the Greenwood Lake Boat and Country Club's annual regatta on Greenwood Lake today.
PARIS. AGENERAL, objection to the new Winter fashions made by women who have merely heard about them is: "They'll make us look old." If this were true, it would damn them from the start.
LONDON, Aug. 26. -- An increase in the price of bread was anticipated generally by British Isles consumers today as one of the first important reactions to the new international wheat agreement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The pottery and earthenware industries today served notice on the Recovery Administration they could not increase wages until given more tariff protection against foreign manufacturers.

A 48-hour week for truck drivers, Helpers and dispatchers, with 40 hours for clerical workers, and a minimum wage at the rate of 40 cents an hour, are established by the code of fair competition submitted to the Recovery Administration by the Federated Truck Association of America.
MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 26. -- G. B. Watts took the high scratch cup in the skeet shoot at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. He broke 49 out of 50 targets.
GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 26. -- More Greenwich debutantes are expected to be presented to society this Autumn than ever before. The social calendar for such September parties already is crowded.

LAST Spring was published "Our Movie-Made Children." in which Henry James Forman made an analysis of an exhaustive investigation, undertaken at the instance of the Motion Picture Research Council and under the auspices of the Payne Fund, of the Influence exerted by motion pictures on children.

SOUTHAMPTON. L.I., Aug. 26. -- Mr. and Mrs. Newell W. Tllton gave a largo dinner tonight at Wyandauk. Lone lines of colored lights and lanterns illuminated the gardens of the estate that fronts Lake Agawam and bright-colored floodlights played over the grounds and the wide verandas overlooking the lake.

MARCONI'S report on his shortwave experiments conducted along the Italian coast, in which he refers to "micro-waves," has caused American laymen to ponder the distinction between ordinary short wave-lengths and the electrical vibrations to which the inventor called attention.

CHICAGO will be the Mecca this week for both heavier-than-air and lighter-than-air enthusiasts when the International Air Races, sanctioned by the American Aeronautic Association, get under way on Friday to last through Labor Day in connection with the Century of Progress Exposition.

FORTUNATE is the man who can look back, as his years grow many, over a life so full of activities, adventures, thrilling experiences, dangers, achievements as this recorded here of General Butler. Such men are not many and so our most famous Marine should consider himself, after all a favorite of fortune, even if the fickle jade has dealt him in his latter years some nasty and treacherous whacks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The observance of Peace Pact Day, sponsored by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom in commemoration of the fifth anniversary of the signature of the Briand-Kellogg Treaty, began here tonight with a radio broadcast of messages, including one from Cordell Hull, Secretary of State, and another from Andre Lefebvre de Laboulaye, the French Ambassador.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 26. -- America has had too much confidence in the leadership ability of its great masses of humanity, the Right. Rev. William Mercer Green, Bishop Coadjutor of the Diocese of Southern Mississippi, told the 228 graduates of George Peabody College for Teachers at commencement exercises today.

ATLANTA, Aug. 24 -- An appeal has been filed in the Georgia Supreme Court to the conviction of Angelo Herndon, 19-year-old Cincinnati Negro, under sentence of from 18 to 20 years' imprisonment on a charge of attempting to incite insurrection.

Existing uncertainty as to how the "codes" will work, together with the fact that reaction on the market for stocks and various commodities began when the "drive" for industrial agreements started, has naturally raised the question how business recovery will be affected.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The sharp upsets which have marked the running of stake events at this course continued today. Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Caesars Ghost was first, in the Whitney Stakes and C.V. Whitney's Roust-about was victorious in the Grand Union Hotel Stakes.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 26. -- Shooters from Houston, Texas, monopolized the North American open trapshooting championship today, the final event of the Thirty-fourth Annual Grand American Tournament.

Dollar quotations of foreign exchanges were irregular yesterday, and the gold-standard currencies continued to advance against the pound sterling. In Paris, the pound was quoted at 81 3/4 francs, which was within 1 1/4 francs of the lowest quotation ever reached, 80 1/2 francs, established on Nov. 29, last, when sterling went to $3.14 1/2 in this market.

OUTLAWED by the Irish Free State Government because it paraded in uniform despite warnings, General Owen O'Duffy's Blue Shirts have lost the right to be a uniformed organization. To those whose familiarity with Irish history does not run far into the past, he appears to have deserved suppression just for his choice of color.

ROME, Aug. 25 -- Although it is realized that no country can hope for complete economy without the recovery of others, nevertheless signs of recovery making their appearance in Italy justify the belief that the bottom of the depression has been reached as far as this country is concerned.

BOSTON, Aug. 23. -- New Hampshire is interested this Summer in the new deal at the Rockingham race track, in that other new deal known to the nation as NRA, in the political intentions of Governor Winant, and in the revenues derived from the recreation industry.

The total cost of operating Camp Tera, the experimental camp for unemployed and homeless women, at the Palisades Interstate Park has been only $4,376.25 since it was opened in June at the request of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Miss Frances Perkins, United States Secretary of Labor.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Chicago came from behind to defeat the Phillies, 6 to 4, in the first game of a double-header today.

Marked gains in retail trade, when comparison is made with the business done a year ago, continued last week despite the retarding influence of the storm in the Atlantic Seaboard area. Business generally was reported to be considerably better than seasonable.

PARIS, Aug. 25 -- France and Japan are engaged just now in one of the most delicate diplomatic debates which has arisen over the Pacific since that ocean's affairs were believed to have been settled at the Washington naval conference.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Aug. 26 (AP). -- Old Fort Holmes, historic fortification that never surrendered and never was taken since it was built by the British in 1812, fell in flames tonight after 121 years of undisputed glory.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26. -- Detectives asserted today that the kidnapping of William F. Wood, cousin of former President Taft, would have ended in his murder had not the abductor been slain.

With all candidates for the more important offices definitely fixed by the expiration of the period for filing declinations, the leaders of the fusion movement will select campaign headquarters tomorrow and name a campaign manager for their city ticket, Fiorello LaGuardia for Mayor, W. Arthur Cnnningham for Controller and Bernard S. Deutsch for President of the Board of Aldermen.
One hundred and forty-five young New Yorkers -- seamen, for a Summer -- will return this week, when the State merchant marine training ship, Empire State, steams in from the sea next Friday.
Wild Hopes Deferred. Mondays. Wednesdays and Fridays the pro-inflationists call on the President, and the rumor boys announce that inflation is at hand.
BERLIN, Aug. 26 -- The German committee in charge of the preparations for the Olympic Games, scheduled to take place in Berlin in 1936, already is intensively at work.

While most of the city's art galleries were still enjoying their Summer siesta yesterday, some 400 artists unofficially opened the Fall season with the fourth Washington Square outdoor art exhibition.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (AP) -- The pace-making Senators lost an eleven-inning struggle with the Indians today, 5 to 4, as Wesley Ferrell outlasted five Washington hurlers to turn in his 101st major league pitching conquest.

The Blue Eagle drive to complete the NRA enrollment of employers and to begin the canvass of consumers pledging their cooperation with the NRA will start tomorrow in every community of New York State, except New York City, simultaneously with the Blue Eagle drive throughout the rest of the country.

Recognition of Soviet Russia this Fall was forecast by Samuel C. Lamport, cotton exporter, who sailed for Europe yesterday on the Berengaria as the personal representative of Senator Smith W. Brookhart. Mr. Lamport will visit Europe and survey the Russian market as an outlet for the manufactured and products produced in this country under the national recovery program.

ALL who are at one with Yeats in admiring those "Who have lived in joy and laughed Into the face of Death" should like this book. In it the fiery particles of Nelson's and Trafalgar's story burn bright. It was written for no other reason than to tell again the story of one of England's great occasions.
BAR HARBOR. -- The Bar Harbor Summer colony is energetically making hay while the August sun still shines -- financial hay, destined for local relief needs during the Winter ahead.

OCEAN BEACH on Fire Island recently saw enacted in the August air an immemorial idyll and reported it as "an aerial raid of flying ants." Millions of these insects got between the Summer village and the sun and after giddy gyrations settled upon its sands and promenades in two-point landings, lost their glinting wings and mysteriously disappeared.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 26 -- Meeting for the first time since the New York Yacht Club cruise, the 12-meter sloops raced today at the Long Island Sound championship regatta of the Riverside Yacht Club Only the Cantitoe and Iris were on hand.

ALTHOUGH the Fall season of opera planned for the Hippodrome is not scheduled to open until Monday, Sept. 11, the management announces four preliminary performances: "Alda," on Sept. 7 and 9, and "Carmen," on Sept. 8 and 10.

GLOUCESTER. IT seems to be quite the thing just now to run down "modern art." But the impartial observer may reasonably feel that not all of this running is in the best of form. These "I-told-you-so" glibsters are ever so quick on the hurdles, though in the long run, quoth Zarathustra, they may prove short of breath.

LONDON, Aug. 25 -- Economic nationalism hag ruled Europe so completely in recent years that no one in London can quite believe it has suffered its first defeat. Yet this is what the wheat agreement of twenty-one nations appears to mean tonight, a few hours after its signature.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 26. -- Peace seems finally to be approaching in the Gran Chaco, where for fourteen months fierca fighting1 has been waged. This outlook is based upon the proposed action of the A B C P nations (Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Peru) for a settlement of the conflict between Paraguay and Bolivia.

Harold Dicker, 23 years old, who escaped from Auburn Prison about a year ago and from the Bronx County Jail on Aug. 18, was captured early yesterday morning and three new charges were lodged against him. The police said they had found evidence indicating that Dicker had gone back to safe-cracking during his week of freedom.

Mrs. Henry T. Fleitmann and Miss Isabel Townsend Pell, socially prominent New Yorkers, were rescued after drifting several hours in a disabled seaplane on the Cattegat, an arm of the North Sea, according to a message received here yesterday.

Adam Wahl of the Island Canoe and Yacht Club, at the tiller of his Centaur, captured the second race of the elimination series for the two-man American decked-canoe sailing challenge cup in Little Neck Bay off Bayside yesterday.

BERLIN, Aug. 26. -- The lecture announcements for the Winter term at the University of Berlin, just published, are noteworthy -- apart from their omission of a number of "Non-Aryan" former faculty members -- for the extraordinary multiplication of lectures on race and kindred subjects.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 26 -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, accompanied by his wife, completed his second transatlantic flight when he brought his seaplane down, perfectly on the waters'at the entrance of Copenhagen Harbor at 5:15 P.M. today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- An appeal to organized labor to support wholeheartedly the industrial recovery program was voiced tonight by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, in a speech over a National Broadcasting Company network.

DETROIT, Aug. 26. -- The Yankees laid down an old-time hitting barrage on Navin Field today while George Uhle tamed his former mates, the Tigers, for his second conquest in as many starts for the McCarthymen.

HAVANA, Aug. 26 -- The announcement by General Mario G. Menocal, President of Cuba from 1912 to 1920 and outstanding opponent of the recently overthrown Machado administration, that he was re-entering the political arena, is generally taken to indicate that he will again be a candidate for the Presidency.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 25. -- A significant commentary upon how the Commonwealth has fared in recent weeks is provided by the evolution of plane to celebrate the centenary of the foundation of Melbourne. Now a city with a population of more than 3,000,000, Melbourne will have been established 100 years next year.

ON the American reader having no more than general Information about Dr. Marie Slopes -- and that means the large majority of readers on this side the Atlantic -- this biography of her will make its most startling impression by its account of the great quantity, variety and value of her scientific work and its revelation of the quality of her intellect.

ONE of the most appealing of folktales is that in which the hero, either as Johnny-Cake or the Gingerbread Boy, leaps from the oven and runs away, outdistancing all his pursuers, to be at last outwitted by the superior cleverness of the fox.

THE wholesome reaction against a profusion of small ornaments in the so-called decoration of a room became so pronounced after the Paris Exposition of 1925 that the rooms of progressive modernists were as bare as the hygiene stables of a fashionable stock farm.

Calls were Issued last week for the payment of several municipal bonds and warrants this month in advance of their dates of maturity and also for the redemption of a public utility, a foreign and an industrial issue in later months. The total for August is now $22,593.000, compared with $12,509.000 in July and $56,243,000 in August, 1932, in corresponding weeks.

LONDON. THE Indian constitutional controversy has entered upon a new and dramatic phase and future political developments, both in this country and in India, will have far-reaching effects upon the daily lives of the 352,000,000 people who constitute the combined populations of British India and the Indian Native States.

When the government of the United State changes its mind it must in some cases obtain the permission of the Federal court to do so. So yesterday the government went into that court and obtained an order restraining itself from carrying out an advertised sale of smuggled Swiss watch movements.

Borough President John A. Lynch, who on Friday removed David S. Rendt, chairman of the Richmond County Democratic organization, as Commissioner of Public Works of Richmond, denied in a statement yesterday that the Seabury investigation had anything to do with the Democratic organization's refusal to renominate him for another term.

Thousands of learned professional men in Germany are temporarily and perhaps permanently lost to the world through Nazi activities against the Jewish race, according to Dr. Francis D. Donoghue, medical adviser of the Massachusetts Industrial Accident Board, who returned last week on the Veendam of the Holland-America Line.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 -- The fair-competition code for the automobile manufacturing industry was sent to President Roosevelt at Hyde Park House late today by Recovery Administrator Hugh S. Johnson.

PLATTSBURG, Aug. 26. -- Mimeographed "newspapers," bearing the legend "The Plattsburg Voice," were received through the mails by many candidates at the Citizens Military Training Camp here today. The pamphlets attacked the NRA and "militarism."

CUBA lying athwart the map like a prehistoric monster rising up out of the sea to block the passage between Florida and Yucatan; Cuba loorning on the afternoon horizon; Cuba vanishing beyond the midnight white and black of a ship's wake.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An article in THE TIMES entitled "Children Found to Glorify War," has evidently caused consternation among the professors who were investigating the views of children on the question of war. The scholars questioned ranged in age from 10 to 15 years.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 26. -- Hundreds of persons were at the Maidstone Club today to watch the water sports meet in the swimming pool. Mrs. Clarence F. Alcott was chairman.

An 18-year-old waitress was shot and killed about 6 o'clock yesterday morning while struggling with two men who were attempting to force an entry into a second-floor room she and two other young women occupied at 163 West Forty-eighth Street.

Discussions of the code of ethics for shipping will be renewed this week by representatives of companies operating the various types of harbor craft and by spokesmen of the labor groups interested in working conditions at sea and along the waterfront.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Perhaps some of your readers will recall the case of my sick uncle. You remember, he is the one who bad been ailing since 1929 and then, after a family conference last November, was operated upon in March by a new doctor who took charge of the case about that time.

PARIS. Aug. 26. -- Despite the statements of President Roosevelt and Secretary Woodin that no inflation is planned at present, the dollar today again made a sharp drop in the unofficial market, closing at 17.50 francs, against 18.10 yesterday.

The so-called undistributed surplus tax is probably one of the most perplexing, controversial and difficult of application of all internal revenue statutes enacted under the present income tax system. It provides, by Section 104 of the Revenue Act of 1932, that if any corporation is formed or availed of for the purpose of preventing the imposition of the surtax by permitting its surplus to accumulate beyond;

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 26. -- A black cocker spaniel carried off the highest honors today -- at the first exhibition of the Long Snore Kennel Club. Victor over the great Scottish terrier, Heather Reveller of Sporran, Windsweep Ladysman won a great triumph for Miss Alice A. Dodsworth of Sharon, Conn.

NEWPORT, R.I.. Aug. 26. -- Mrs. E. Morris de Peyster of New York, opened her home. Cross-ways, the former Stuyvesant Fish estate on Ocean Avenue this evening for an entertainment in the interest of the Family Welfare Society of this city. A varied program began with a two-piano recital by Jacques Fray and Mario Braggiotti.

GREENVILLE, S. C. IN upland fields and black earth bottoms, from the Carolinas to Texas, King Cotton has witnessed this season a revolution in the efforts to bolster up his reign and revenues by destroying part of the crop. The plow has been an agent of destruction, not of cultivation, in the fields.

TOKYO, Aug. 26. -- Japan's policy with regard to China, as outlined to this correspondent today by the Foreign Office spokesman, is to welcome moves for rapprochement from any source, but a wait tangible evidences before taking any steps herself.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Ultimate stabilization of currencies and world economic planning must come, James M. Cox, one of the United States delegates to the World Economic Conference, told The Cleveland News today.

ELGIN, Ill., Aug. 26 -- In the revival of the historic Elgin National Road Race today, Phil Shafer, Des Moines, Iowa, won the event in a thrilling finish. Freddie Frame of Los Angeles was second and Maurice Rose of South Bend, Ind., third.

A formal ruling by the National Recovery Administration on the status of price increases in the form of surcharges on merchandise manufactured prior to the effective data of the codes in the respective industries is expected shortly, it was announced yesterday by J.E. Pridday, president of Lord Taylor and chairman of the special committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association dealing with these surcharges.

THOUGHTFUL students of current social and economic problems will welcome a new series of "Social Action Books" announced by W.W. Norton Co. The series is being edited by Dr. Alvin Johnson, director of the New School for Social Research, who says: "The plan for these books assumes that the social-economic structure will have to be rebuilt while the tenants are living in it, therefore without the application of explosives."

CRILLON LAKE, Alaska, Aug. 25 -- The geologic and climbing parties of our Alaskan expedition are reunited for the first time in a month after three of us succeeded in climbing Mount Dagelet and three beautiful unnamed peaks, all of which were more than 9,000 feet high.

LITTLE things count for a lot when it comes to looking really well turned out. From the tip of the feather on the hat to the toe of the shoe one should be perfectly equipped. If clothes make the man hats, gloves, shoes and all the other et ceteras of the wardrobe make the woman.

THE world of art eludes the writer, and especially the American writer, with fatal persistence. It is apt to be peopled, in fiction, with wayward, incredible children. addicted to threadbare poses. The temperament" with which they are credited, the ideals which they are presumed to serve, have a hollow air of falsity.

TOKYO, Aug. 26. -- Japan's policy with regard to China, as outlined to this correspondent today by the Foreign Office spokesman, is to welcome moves for rapprochement from any source, but a wait tangible evidences before taking any steps herself.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Ultimate stabilization of currencies and world economic planning must come, James M. Cox, one of the United States delegates to the World Economic Conference, told The Cleveland News today.

ELGIN, Ill., Aug. 26 -- In the revival of the historic Elgin National Road Race today, Phil Shafer, Des Moines, Iowa, won the event in a thrilling finish. Freddie Frame of Los Angeles was second and Maurice Rose of South Bend, Ind., third.

A formal ruling by the National Recovery Administration on the status of price increases in the form of surcharges on merchandise manufactured prior to the effective data of the codes in the respective industries is expected shortly, it was announced yesterday by J.E. Pridday, president of Lord Taylor and chairman of the special committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association dealing with these surcharges.

THOUGHTFUL students of current social and economic problems will welcome a new series of "Social Action Books" announced by W.W. Norton Co. The series is being edited by Dr. Alvin Johnson, director of the New School for Social Research, who says: "The plan for these books assumes that the social-economic structure will have to be rebuilt while the tenants are living in it, therefore without the application of explosives."
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 26 (AP). -- Lloyd Brown of the Red Sox pitched and batted his team to an 8-to-1 victory over the Browns in their series opener today.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 26. -- When the Dutch steamer Hercules sailed this afternoon it left behind the forty-six passengers and members of the crew rescued from the American schooner Augusta G. Hilton in midocean on Aug. 18, after the schooner has been abandoned and set on fire to attract assistance.

VERONA, Aug. 2, 1933. MUSSOLINI was, as usual, right again when, in a recent pronouncement on the ills of the Italian theatre, lyric and dramatic, ha prescribed as remedy first-class performances in huge auditoriums.

Six hundred and seventy-nine workers in Manhattan parks have been notified that they will be placed on the equivalent of a four-and-one-half-day week, with a pay cut equal to 10 per cent, it was learned yesterday.

GENEVA, Aug. 26. -- The Permanent Central Opium Board, in its quarterly report to the League of Nations Council, adopted today, concludes that the situation has steadily improved during the last five years.

THE annual hurricane watch maintained around the Caribbean by Pan American Airways has been busier than usual this season. Already the combination meteorologists and radio operators at their isolated stations in the West Indies, Central and South America have obtained and pasred along to the Weather Bureau advance not ire of seven storms of hurricane magnitude.

Two Queens patrolmen were suspended from the Police Department and arrested on technical charges of homicide yesterday, after a collision between their automobile and another car at Sixty-fourth Road and Woodhaven Boulevard, Elmhurst, in which Emerson Davis, 42 years old, of 145 Maple Avenue, East Orange, N.J., was fatally injured.

THERE is an unexpected amount of substance to the plainly written, humble and highly deceptive autobiography of William Scott Vare, the boss of Philadelphia's Republican organization who was barred from the seat in the United States Senate to which he was elected because he spent just under $2,000,000 in the notorious primary of 1926.

The Pierce-Arrow Motor Car Company has been re-established as an independent industry and has been completely separated from the Studebakcr Corporation, which had controlled it since 1928, Arthur J. Chanter, president of the former company, announced here yesterday. The price paid was $1,000,000 in cash.

THE two main themes hi this volume of lyrics are the sub-mergence of the self in a mystic unity best symbolized by Nature, and the bravery of the human spirit in adversity. The mood of the poet is usually a kind of contemplative delight.

Back in 1923, when field hockey was still in its infancy in the United States, an American team was sent abroad for a series of matches with European teams. The trip was hardly a success. Victory was far from the hopes of these pioneer tourists.
PARIS, Aug. 19 (AP) (By Mail) -- Coats fastened with huge hidden snaps instead of being buttoned or clutched in place are a new note in Winter styles.

WASHINGTON. THE New Deal is by no means confined to the continental United States. Despite the preoccupation of President Roosevelt and his advisers with the paramount question of domestic recovery, time has been found to reassure the people of our Territories and possessions, as well as the closely related Caribbean countries of Cuba and Haiti, that they are not forgotten.

Net operating income of the first twenty-nine railroads to report their earnings for July amounted to $29,261,000, against $5,968,000 in July, 1932, an increase of 390.3 per cent, against $22,074,000 in July, 1931, an increase of 32.6 per cent, and $36,909,000 in July, 1930, a decrease of 20.7 per cent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with a great deal of Interest a letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES, in which the Rev. Ignatius W. Cox suggests that I am probably aware that the masses will not control population by contraception.

WASHINGTON. ONE of the most delicate tasks connected with the New Deal is that of the Federal Coordinator of Transportation While he has more authority over railroad operations than any one man since the Director General of the roads in war days, his duty is not to manage the lines.

LONDON. OBJECTIONS are sometimes raised to works of composite authorship, but such publications seem inevitable whenever a general subject presents phases so distinct that they cannot all be adequately treated by a single author.

PAPERS which have come into the possession of the Business Historical Society of Boston throw new sidelights on the once honorable institution of lotteries, through which money was raised in America for commercial projects, trade and settlement enterprises, national and patriotic causes and even educational purposes.

THIS absorbing book which Mrs. Beard has made leaves upon the mind of its reader a variety of vivid impressions. Not the least salient of these the forceful reminder which it furnishes of the old truth that no generalizations are more treacherous than those which are made as to the nature of woman.

BRETTON WOODS. N.H., Aug. 26. -- Members of the Summer colony at Franeonia and Sugar Hill thronged Peckett's big barn tonight at the annual barn dance given there. Farmers' costumes were worn, and the barn was decorated with shocks of corn, sheaves of wheat and golden glow.

LONDON. AN odd revival of medieval English life is to be found in the return of the Gray Friars. Men in gray habits with the knotted ropes round their waists sued as St. Francis adopted after he came out of prison, before he found his life's vocation, are once more walking through the streets of London.

DR. TANNENBAUM'S graphologic investigations of the more sinister side of the history of Elizabethan documents have a value for scholars that will have to be determined by scholars themselves. They are also interesting to the common reader as a kind of detective work of obvious ingenuity and appeal.
CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- Macdonald Smith, the former Scottish star, increased his hold on the Western open golf championship today with another par-breaking score.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 26 (AP). -- Dr. Virginia Wilson, 36 years old, widely known here in the field of psychology and psychiatry and formerly of Utica and Rome, N.Y., in an insane frenzy last night killed one woman and seriously injured another with a butcher knife.

RUTLAND, Vt., Aug. 26 (AP) -- Postmaster General James A. Farley tonight described repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment as a "vital and inseparable" part of the President's national recovery program and urged voters, without respect to party, to help strike the amendment from the Federal Constitution at this State's special election Sept. 5.
HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., Aug. 28. -- The time has arrived when Miss Virginia Van Wie, Chicago golf star, has to defend her title as women's champion of the United States.

SILVER BAY ON LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Our economic machine, like a caterpillar tractor, must lay its own track back, to prosperity by restoring the nation's purchasing power, Sidney W. Wilcox, representative of the Department of Labor, told the Silver Bay Conference on Industrial Relations at its final session today.

DESPITE its unfortunate title and an awkward beginning, this English novel. both as story and as social document, moves along its appointed course with increasing convincingness and power. It is by way of loose analogy.
SANTANDKR, Spain. Young Spain and New Spain are hosts for students from all parts of the world here this Summer in a recaptured royal palace turned into a university.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 26. -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Aug. 19 amounted to 634,845 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 12,086 cars, or 1.9 per cent, more than in the preceding week, 116,405 cars, or 22.5 per cent, more than in the corresponding week last year, and 113,755 cars, or 15.2 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.
RENO; Nev., Aug. 26. -- Suit for divorce was filed here today by Mrs. Oroville Wooster Richard against Walter L. Richard of New York on grounds of "cruelty."

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 26 -- Texas, long a pillar in the dry "Solid South," appeared tonight to have lined up as the twenty-third State to approve repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. While the Drys showed some gains in the late count, anti-prohibitionists said their victory was certain.

VISITORS at Chicago's Century of Progress Exposition have an opportunity to see a remarkable collection of antediluvian airplanes. By contrast, they have been put on exhibition beside the latest examples of the plane constructor's art.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va. -- In honor of the 126th anniversary of the birth of General Robert E. Lee, a week of special activities will begin here tomorrow. This memorial week, inaugurated with such success last year, when a new portrait of General Lee by Natalie Eynon Grauer was unveiled by Mis. Woodrow Wilson, will be an annual occurrence here, to perpetuate the memory of a famous American.

WHEN man moves in mysterious ways his wonders to perform. It Is curious what diverse interpretations will be placed upon his labors. In the realm of bibliographical investigation there are innumerable problems posed by makers of books to which the query, why did he do this? finds many answers.

LEO CARRILLO, currently appearing as Nick, the gambler, in "Moonlight and Pretzels" at the Rialto", is not a native of Greece. Neither is he Italian, Mexican or Spanish, despite the fact that most of his stage and screen portrayals have been of persons of those nationalities.

BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP). -- The pennant-striving Braves, behind the four-hit pitching of Ben Cantwell, today shut out the Cardinals, 3 to 0, to sweep the three-game series and extend their winning rush to seven straight.
